title: Bank Atlantic 7, Tigers 5, Mets 4
description: So, the Mets lost 5-4 to Detroit in todays Grapefruit League opener. The highlights: Alay Solers two scoreless innings. Julio Francos two-run single. Ben Johnsons two hits, including the hustle shown in running out a pop-up that fell between three players down the right-field line; he chugged into second with a double. For those of you watching on SNY, you would have seen all this. Now, here are two things that you didnt see:

title: (Mis)adventures in Cyberspace
description: The John McCain and John Edwards campaigns both experienced the down side of Web 2.0 recently.

title: McCain Announces Hell Announce
description: Taking the platform of a late-night talk show, Senator John S. McCain of Arizona said today that he would formally announce his campaign for the presidency in early April, erasing whatever doubt may have existed about his Mr. McCains presidential ambitions.

title: Blackberry's Magic
description: David Pogue takes another look at the Blackberry Pearl.

title: Whose Bed Is It Anyway?
description: Four years after the National Institute of Child Health and Human Development published a survey in which 12 percent of respondents reported sleeping with their babies, those babies have grown into children, and those children are still in their parents bed. Many parents are reluctant co-sleepers, too tired to disrupt a practice that may irritate one or both adults, but, in the end, seems to promise the most amount of sleep for the most people in the house.

title: Officer Is Cleared in Mass Arrests at 2004 G.O.P. Convention
description: The Manhattan district attorneys office has found that there is no basis to prosecute a city police inspector for perjury or any other offense related to arrests at protest rallies during the 2004 Republican National Convention.

title: Bush Vows to Speed Up Aid for Gulf Coast
description: BILOXI, Miss., March 1  President Bush traveled today to the Gulf Coast, still trying to recover from the winds and floods of 2005, and vowed to do everything he could to speed up federal assistance.

title: The Jose Padilla Trial
description: There were so many reasons to be appalled by President Bushs decision to detain people illegally and subject them to mental and physical abuse. The unfolding case of Jose Padilla reminds us of one of the most important: mistreating a prisoner makes it hard, if not impossible, for a real court to judge whether he has committed real crimes.

title: U.S. Markets Recover with Small Gain
description: The stock market began climbing out of the deep trough it slid into on Tuesday, rising modestly today as investor fears about a cooling economy seemed to ease somewhat.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the increase in the number of California office holders who are Asian-Americans misstated the number of Asian-Americans on the five-member Board of Equalization. There are four, not three.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: A Hedge of Green and Red

title: Coaxing More Bars Out of That Cellphone
description: Garbled conversations and dropped calls are the bane of cellphone users  not to mention the dead zones where calls cannot go through to begin with. But some recent products are designed to overcome these annoyances, improve cellular reception, and, in some cases, even extend coverage.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday about discussions between Britain and the United States over the possible stationing of an American antiballistic missile defense system on British soil misidentified the rank of an American military officer who was quoted discussing the subject. Henry Obering III is a lieutenant general, a three-star position  not a general, a four-star position.

title: Thanks to the Internet, Well Always Have Paris
description: WHILE Im certainly not the first person to come back from Paris suffering from an attack of post-traumatic shopping syndrome, I think my recent case was worse than that of the average traveler.

title: Steelers Deny Players Received Doctors Drugs
description: There is no proof that a doctor for the Pittsburgh Steelers, who has been questioned by federal agents about his purchase of growth hormone drugs, ever provided or prescribed hormones to any Steelers players, Art Rooney II, the teams president, said yesterday.

title: Illinois: Barge Spills Toxic Liquid
description: A tank barge traveling on the Ohio River has spilled up to 8,000 gallons of a toxic liquid after hitting a submerged concrete lock wall, the United States Coast Guard said. The barge, owned by Kirby Inland Marine of Houston, was carrying 960,000 gallons of a petroleum-based substance called cumene, said Lt. J. Wayne Chapman of the Coast Guards Marine Safety Unit in Paducah, Ky. The accident occurred around 10:30 p.m. Tuesday near Brookport, Ill., but the authorities did not learn of the spill until Wednesday morning, Lieutenant Chapman said.

title: A Critique of Pure Reason
description: All the presidential candidates this year will talk about education. The conventional ones will talk about improving the schools. The creative ones will talk about improving the lives of students.

title: Lights! Darks! Action! Cut! Maestro of Mise-en-Scne
description: MADRID, Feb. 26  I have sometimes seen Tintoretto as equal to Titian, the artist Annibale Carracci wrote, and at other times as inferior to Tintoretto.

title: A Hall of Fame for Great Stories
description: It is not clear how the face of the former Dodgers owner Walter OMalley came to appear on a flour tortilla in Los Angeles. When on display, it is usually accompanied by a card noting that the provenance of the tortilla is sketchy. However, the card continues, Radio carbon dating indicates that the tortilla is approximately forty years old.

title: Steroid Inquiry Raises Doubts About Matthews
description: Before Tuesday, Gary Matthews Jr. was mostly known for parlaying a career-best season with the Texas Rangers into a five-year, $50 million contract with the Los Angeles Angels, and for being his fathers son.

title: In Newly Usual Way, McCain Says Hell Run
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Senator John McCain of Arizona took the platform of a late-night talk show Wednesday and said he would formally announce his campaign for the presidency in early April. His remarks erased entirely whatever doubt could have existed about his ambitions for the Republican nomination.

title: Authors Find Their Voice, and Audience, in Podcasts
description: Scott Sigler writes science-fiction horror novels, the kind one fan called steel-tipped boot on your throat, speed-metal fiction. Mr. Sigler has written four such books, though not many people have actually read them.

title: Residential Homes
description: Manhattan

title: Sirius Chief Talks of Ways to Get XM Deal Approved
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Facing skeptical lawmakers, Mel Karmazin, the architect of a proposed merger of the nations two satellite radio companies, announced at a hearing in Congress on Wednesday that the companies would agree to government-imposed price controls and other unspecified measures to gain regulatory approval for the deal.

title: Citing Abuses, Texas Governor Ousts Leader of Youth Agency
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 28  Gov. Rick Perry removed the chairman of the Texas Youth Commission on Wednesday over charges that the agency covered up the sexual abuse of incarcerated juveniles.

title: Sometimes the Newcomers Sound a Lot Like the Old-Timers
description: It has become accepted wisdom that building a great orchestra is a long-term process. Maybe so. But as the thrilling all-Shostakovich concert by the New World Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night made clear, the slow-and-steady approach is not the only route to orchestral greatness.

title: Bruno Adds to Intrigue by Elevating a Democrat
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28  New Yorks top Democrats have spoken for weeks about trying to wrest control of the Republican-led State Senate by persuading a few Republican senators to switch parties or retire. The Senates minority leader, Malcolm A. Smith of Queens, even introduced a new acronym to Albany when he announced that several Republicans were in the ZOPA, or zone of possible agreement.

title: With Cameras, Compromising Can Pay Off
description: Most people buy their digital cameras in one of two broad categories: compact (tiny, pretty, with snapshot-quality photos) or digital S.L.R. (black, bulky, with magazine-quality photos). Choosing between them is an agonizing task. Youre far more likely to have the compact camera with you when a photo op pops up  and yet in a battle of photo quality, as an Internet commentator once put it, an S.L.R. takes better pictures with its lens cap on.

title: Freshman Helps Texas Avenge Loss to A&M
description: AUSTIN, Tex., Feb. 28  Ever since Texas lost to Texas A&M earlier this month, talk raged whether the Aggies had supplanted the Longhorns as the states top college basketball program.

title: Commack: 7 Hurt When Deck Collapses
description: The deck of a house collapsed during a reception after a funeral yesterday afternoon, injuring seven people, the Suffolk County police said. The second-story deck at 12 Dana Lane in Commack, where about 20 people had gathered after a family funeral, collapsed around 3:44 p.m., the police said. The injured, three women and four men, suffered neck, back, hip, rib and leg injuries, the police said. Five of them were taken to Stony Brook University Medical Center and St. Catherine of Siena Medical Center in Smithtown, where they were reported in stable condition, the police said.

title: After the Sell-Off
description: In a way, the stock markets rebound yesterday was as troubling as Tuesdays rout.

title: Mai Ghoussoub, 54, Writer and Provocative Publisher, Dies
description: Mai Ghoussoub, who weaved together elements of her Arab heritage and an avant-garde sensibility to make bold, provocative statements as a publisher, author, sculptor, journalist and playwright, died on Feb. 17 in London. She was 54.

title: Iran to Join Iraq Talks in Highest Contact With U.S. in 2 Years
description: BAGHDAD, Feb. 28  The top Iranian national security official, Ali Larijani, indicated Wednesday that Iranian officials would take part in a regional security conference on Iraq, setting the stage for the highest-level contact between American and Iranian officials in more than two years.

title: Stag Party at the Hunting Lodge
description: AS any dapper man o action will attest, the only masculine pursuits worth mastering are huntin, fishin and shoppin.

title: Italy: U.S. Will Not Hand Over C.I.A. Suspects
description: The United States would refuse any demand to give up 26 Central Intelligence Agency operatives ordered to stand trial in Italy on charges of kidnapping a radical Egyptian cleric there in 2003. Weve not got an extradition request from Italy, John B. Bellinger III, the legal adviser to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, told reporters in Brussels. If we got an extradition request from Italy, we would not extradite U.S. officials to Italy. The case is contentious in Italy, reportedly part of the American program called extraordinary rendition, in which terrorism suspects have been seized outside local laws and taken to third countries for interrogation. The cleric, Hassan Mustafa Osama Nasr, was recently released from prison in Egypt. He said that American agents took him to Egypt and that he was tortured there.

title: Amid Claims of Police Profiling, Study Will Review Stop and Frisks
description: The New York City Police Department has commissioned a six-month independent review of the way it stops people on the streets, sometimes searching them for illegal weapons, after the release of statistics that showed the department stopped 508,540 people in the five boroughs last year, officials said yesterday.

title: How to Fix Whats Wrong in School (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Power Companies in Northeast to Merge in $2.5 Billion Deal
description: Two privately held companies that own power plants in the Northeast said yesterday that they were merging in a deal worth $2.5 billion, creating a company that serves both New York City and the Boston area.

title: A Boot Camp for Men With a Shy Side
description: AFTER hibernating in front of the television for four months, Matt Goodrich felt flabby. He wanted a rigorous regimen to rouse his body from its winter slumber. But there was just one problem: Mr. Goodrich, a 33-year-old married father of two, did not want women to see him in all his sweat-stained glory.

title: Stephen Hawking Plans Prelude to the Ride of His Life
description: Stephen Hawking, the British cosmologist, Cambridge professor and best-selling author who has spent his career pondering the nature of gravity from a wheelchair, says he intends to get away from it all for a little while.

title: In U.S. Overtures to Foes, Signs of New Pragmatism
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  In the span of just two weeks, the United States has agreed to hold high-level contacts with Iran and Syria, and to start down the path toward formal diplomatic recognition of North Korea.

title: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about a recommendation by a federal appeals court in Manhattan for a review of all immigration cases still on appeal involving a judge who has been criticized as being hostile to people seeking asylum referred imprecisely to a new rule announced by the court on Friday. The courts plan expands the types of claims that will fall under an earlier rule, dating to October 2005, that dispensed with oral arguments in most immigration cases involving asylum claims. It does not dispense with such arguments for the first time.

title: Car Bomb Kills 7 in Wedding Party in Falluja
description: BAGHDAD, March 1  A car bomb exploded at a wedding party in the troubled city of Falluja today, killing seven guests and injuring six, the local police reported. The incident appeared to be part of a mounting battle between insurgents and locals in western Iraq, according to residents.

title: Group Reaches Settlement With F.E.C. Over 2004 Campaign Advertising
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  A major conservative group agreed to pay a $750,000 penalty as part of a settlement with the Federal Election Commission, which found that the group violated campaign finance laws by spending more than $30 million on advertisements and mailings supporting President Bushs re-election.

title: Acquisitions Help Sprints Profit Rise 32%
description: The Sprint Nextel Corporation said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit increased 32 percent after acquisitions increased revenue.

title: Is the S.E.C. Changing Course?
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  In his first year as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Christopher Cox confounded both supporters and detractors by taking a more moderate and nuanced position than they had predicted on a variety of regulatory issues, based on his record as a conservative Republican lawmaker.

title: Yankees Proctor Has a Fan in Gossage
description: TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 28  When Goose Gossage watched the Yankees on television last year, he found himself rooting for Scott Proctor. This was a common occurrence, because Proctor worked in more than half the Yankees games.

title: Low-Cost Antimalaria Pill Available
description: A new, cheap, easy-to-take pill to treat malaria is being introduced today, the first product of an innovative partnership between an international drug company and a medical charity.

title: That Tune in Your Head Could Be Your Toothbrush
description: Put a rock band in your mouth, along with a dab of toothpaste, with Tooth Tunes, a $10 musical toothbrush from Tiger Electronics, a division of Hasbro. The theory is that two minutes of brushing is needed to give teeth a proper cleaning. So the brush is really a kind of timer.

title: Unexpected Brand Name for Books: Bellevue
description: Up in a tiny office on the sixth floor of Bellevue Hospital Center sits the most unlikely tenant in this 271-year-old public institution: a fledgling publishing imprint.

title: Whats on Thursday
description: 10 P.M. (USA) NASHVILLE STAR It may be billed as countrys answer to American Idol, but so far this series hasnt catapulted any of its contestants to the kind of country stardom Carrie Underwood, the Season 4 Idol winner, has enjoyed. Tonight, this years finalists  David St. Roman and the brother-and-sister competitors Angela and Zac Hacker  perform at the Gaylord Opryland for the title and a record deal with Warner Brothers Nashville. But first, Jewel will serenade the audience, and then all 10 of this seasons contestants sing along with Randy Owen.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about an interview Vice President Dick Cheney gave aboard his military transport on Tuesday, for which he asked to be identified only as a senior administration official but then spoke in the first person about his discussions with the Pakistani and Afghan presidents, truncated the final passage in some copies. It should have read: On Iran, the administrations highest-ranking and best-known hawk challenged a questioner who suggested that oil prices might drop 10 or 15 percent if the United States took off the table the option of a military strike against Irans nuclear facilities. I dont buy it, the senior administration official said, before retreating to his cabin.

title: Not October, but Mets Play Tigers
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., Feb. 28  This was the game the Mets wished they had played last October, on a chilly Saturday night in Detroit. Instead, they had to settle for a breezy 83-degree afternoon along the Treasure Coast of Florida, where Lets Go Tigers chants at Tradition Field outnumbered those for the home team.

title: U.S. Judge Finds Padilla Competent to Face Trial
description: MIAMI, Feb. 28  A federal judge found Jose Padilla competent to stand trial on terrorism conspiracy charges Wednesday, granting a significant victory to the government in the high-profile criminal case of a United States citizen who was initially designated an enemy combatant and held without charges.

title: Gaultiers Highland Prairie Fling
description: PARIS, Feb. 28  Jean Paul Gaultier opened his Scottish Highlands-cum-cowboy-Western-theme collection with the model Coco Rocha pounding down the runway doing a Celtic dance. She wore a double-breasted red coat, but that was beside the point. Mr. Gaultier was working a theme.

title: Investment Bill Moves
description: The House of Representatives voted yesterday to revise rules for foreign investments in the United States, seeking to make them clearer for businesses while preserving national security.

title: South Africa Considers Culling Elephants as Last Resort
description: JOHANNESBURG, Feb. 28  South Africas environment minister offered a new plan on Wednesday to control the nations booming elephant population that contemplates resuming the much-criticized killing of excess animals, but only after thorough scientific study and as a last resort.

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption with a sports article on Monday about the Accenture Match Play Championship in Arizona carried incorrect information from The Associated Press about a shot by Henrik Stenson on the 28th hole on Sunday. Stenson was shown hitting from a natural sandy area, not from a bunker.

title: Sleeping by the Book
description: CHILD-sleep specialists and their progeny  their books and DVDs  are now as common as Ambien on an Eos flight. Here are a few.

title: A Little Bit Country, a Little Bit Broadway
description: The Broadway-country-gospel singer Lari White pulled a fast one in the opening moments of her New York cabaret debut in the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel on Tuesday evening. Bouncing onto the stage Ms. White delivered a jingly ode to country sunshine that augured an evening of forced cheer and perky homilies. When she suddenly broke it off to announce how exhausting it was to do the down-home Southern hospitality thing, you could almost hear the audiences collective whew!

title: Duke Prosecutor Denies Ethics Violations
description: The district attorney who brought sexual assault charges against three Duke lacrosse players did not intentionally violate ethics rules, his lawyers said yesterday in their first response to charges by the state bar.

title: New Options (and Risks) in Home Care for Elderly
description: Dr. Diane E. Meier, a geriatrician at Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, is an expert on end-of-life care. So when her elderly parents needed long-term help at home with bathing, dressing and cooking after her fathers stroke, she knew where to find assistance.

title: Millers Clout Goes Unrewarded by Veteran Voters
description: Youll excuse Marvin Miller, please, if he is more concerned right now about his left shoulder than he is about his vote count.

title: Columbine Evacuated After Threat
description: LITTLETON, Colo., March 1  Columbine High School, the site of a 1999 shooting spree, was evacuated today after officials received at least one call about a bomb threat, authorities said.

title: New Home Sales Plunge in January
description: Builders faced a growing glut of unsold homes in January as the pace of new-home sales slowed 16.6 percent from the month before  the most in 13 years.

title: Study Tracks Exposure to Diesel Fumes
description: Commuters on average spend 6 percent of their day getting back and forth to work, but their time spent in buses, trains and cars accounts for more than half their daily exposure to harmful diesel fumes that can shorten lives and cause disease, according to a new study by the environmental group Clean Air Task Force. The study, released yesterday in Washington, found that pollution levels in four cities, including New York, were four to eight times higher inside cars, buses and trains than in the outdoor air. Very fine particles, like those in diesel exhaust, are believed to shorten the lives of 70,000 Americans a year. The group said using ultra-low-sulfur diesel fuel and installing easily available filters can reduce pollution from diesel engines by 90 percent.

title: House Votes to Ease Rules on Union Organizing
description: Defying a veto threat from the White House, the House of Representatives voted today to approve legislation that would make it easier for unions to organize workers.

title: U.S. Discusses Releasing North Korean Funds
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  China and the United States are close to an accord to let North Korea regain some of the $25 million in its funds frozen in a bank in Macao now that it has agreed to start dismantling its nuclear arms program, American officials said Wednesday.

title: Court Hears Arguments Linking Right to Sue and Spending on Religion
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The question for the Supreme Court on Wednesday was a jurisdictional one: whether taxpayers who object to the way the White House Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives spends its money can get into federal court to make their case.

title: Whose Bed Is It Anyway?
description: THIS is what 3 a.m. looks like at the Costello house, a diminutive red brick three-story in the West Village: On the second floor, Harrison, age 5, is splayed, sideways and snoring, across his parents king-size, Anglo-Indian four-poster, having muscled his mother out completely and pushed his father, Paul, a 35-year-old photographer, to the extreme edge of the bed. Sara Ruffin Costello, the style director of Domino magazine, is upstairs in her 3-year-old daughter Carolinas bed, which is a hammered-metal four-poster queen dressed in pink paisley sheets with a ruffle. It is the bed I would have if I were single, Ms. Costello, 38, said. It is my dream bed, which is a good thing because I spend a lot of time in it. Harrisons bed, his fourth, a trundle model from Ikea, is empty and pristine, the least-used space in the house.

title: Dubliners Gone Noir in Those Shame-Based 1950s
description: The swirling, elegant noir Christine Falls is the first book by Benjamin Black. Under ordinary circumstances, he might be admired for the cool precision and contemplative allure of his impressive debut. But this is no tyro: Mr. Black is the Irish author John Banville, winner of the Man Booker Prize in 2005 for The Sea and a man much admired for the hauteur and inventiveness of his fiction. His use of a pen name for Christine Falls reflects the way he has spoken about this genre novel in terms of craftsmanship rather than art.

title: Arts Education Money (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Asian Markets Decline but Show Signs of Stabilizing
description: SINGAPORE, March 1  Asias stock markets closed down today amid concerns that a slowing United States economy could hurt the regions export-dependent economies, and European shares were off in the afternoon. But there were signs that the rout that began in China Tuesday and swept through global markets was abating, following reassuring comments by the chairman of the U.S. Federal Reserve.

title: Watches and the Man (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Singular Pain: When Death Cuts the Bond of Twins
description: AFTER her identical twin, Cara, died last year of a drug overdose, life stopped for her, too, Christa Parravani said. She stopped eating. Work served as a bitter, inadequate refuge. For the first time in her life, Ms. Parravani, a photographer, was alone.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,150 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: Europe to Reduce Force in Bosnia by Two-Thirds
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, Feb. 28  The European Union announced plans on Wednesday to cut the number of peacekeeping troops in Bosnia and Herzegovina by almost two-thirds, citing an improved security situation.

title: Corrections: Currents Slide Show
description: A brief item in the Currents column last Thursday about childrens furniture referred incorrectly to the name of a Hasbro toy. It is Lite-Brite, not Brite Lite.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page news analysis article yesterday about a suicide bomb attack on an American base in Afghanistan during Vice President Dick Cheneys visit, in which he expressed support for the fight against Taliban insurgents, misattributed a quotation about security threats from a Washington hearing held by the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday. It was Senator Carl Levin of Michigan, the Democratic chairman of the committee  not Mike McConnell, the new director of national intelligence, the person testifying, who said, Long-term prospects for eliminating the Taliban threat appear dim, so long as the sanctuary remains in Pakistan, and there are no encouraging signs that Pakistan is eliminating it. (Go to Article)

title: Queens: Hate-Crime Plea
description: A Flushing man pleaded guilty yesterday to drawing swastikas and writing anti-Semitic slurs at spots around a synagogue in Fresh Meadows, prosecutors said. The man, James Connolly, 21, of 170th Street, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court to fourth-degree criminal mischief as a hate crime, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Connolly was arrested in May 2005 and charged with scrawling swastikas on cars, bus shelters and a mailbox near the Electchester Jewish Center, Mr. Brown said. Mr. Connolly was expected to be sentenced to five years of probation, as well as community service and sensitivity training, Mr. Browns office said.

title: Arthur Schlesinger, Historian of Power, Dies at 89
description: Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian whose more than 20 books shaped discussions for two generations about Americas past, and who himself was a provocative, unabashedly liberal partisan, most notably while serving in the Kennedy White House, died Wednesday night in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Defacer With Mystery Agenda Is Attacking Street Art
description: Someone out there has a problem with art. Or at least a certain kind of art and artist.

title: Citi Acquisition in Prepaid Cards
description: Citigroup has agreed to buy Ecount, a privately held provider of prepaid cards, expanding its presence in the fastest-growing part of the payment industry, according to bank officials.

title: Two Possible Trump Suits: The Math Can Be Tricky
description: You have a 5-3 spade fit and a 4-4 heart fit. Which would you usually select as your trump suit? Suppose you have a 5-4 spade fit and 4-4 heart fit. Would that change your answer?

title: Suffolk Plans a Crackdown on Laborers There Illegally
description: HAUPPAUGE, N.Y., Feb. 28  Warning that the proliferation of illegal immigrants is threatening the basic harmony and quality of life in the suburbs of Long Island, the Suffolk County executive, Steve Levy, outlined a list of initiatives on Wednesday to limit the influx, including a crackdown on day laborers and contractors and the assignment of federal immigration officials to the county jail.

title: Dibs on That: Antiques Without the Antiquing
description: EVERY Wednesday, seconds before 11 a.m. Eastern time, furniture fans are stationed at their computers, poised to point and click. Its the countdown to the weekly posting of new items at 1stdibs.com, an online decorative arts marketplace with dealers from the United States and Paris.

title: Bush Aides Pledge Work for Immigration Bill
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Two senior Bush administration officials vowed on Wednesday to work with Congress to ensure passage of immigration legislation this year but publicly distanced themselves from proposals that would place most illegal immigrants on a path to citizenship.

title: Asian Markets Continue to Fall Thursday
description: SINGAPORE, March 1  Asias stock markets continued to tumble today on concerns that a slowing U.S. economy could spell trouble for Asias export-dependent economies. The losses extended the rout that began in China Tuesday and swept through global markets.

title: U.S. Knew of Threats as Cheney Visited Base
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, Feb. 28  NATO and American forces knew that a suicide bomber was at large in the Bagram area before the suicide bomb attack on Tuesday that killed 23 people at the main gate of the United States air base where Vice President Dick Cheney was staying, a NATO spokesman said Wednesday. But despite the vice presidents presence, the Afghan police chief in the area said he had not been informed of the possible threat.

title: Corrections: Top of the Heap: A Business Built on Salvage
description: An article last Thursday about stores selling salvaged architectural objects referred incorrectly to the location of the summer home of Alvan T. Fuller, the governor of Massachussetts from 1925 to 1929. It was in the Village District of Little Boars Head, North Hampton, N.H.  not in Rye Beach, N.H.

title: Real Support for the Troops (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Laptop With Vista That Seems Just Like a Fully Upgraded PC
description: The upgraded computer components needed to run Microsofts new operating system, Windows Vista, can come at a high price. Acers TravelMate 2480-2779 laptop, however, costs about $550 and runs Vista without complaint.

title: Putin Picks Security Chief to Lead Chechnya
description: MOSCOW, March 1  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia today appointed Ramzan A. Kadyrov, a widely feared young official whose security forces have been accused of kidnappings, torture and other abuses, to be the new president of the battered southern republic of Chechnya.

title: Pair That Turned in Raccoon Were Not Exposed to Rabies
description: Health officials said that the man and woman who dropped off a sick raccoon that later tested positive for rabies came forward today and indicated that they had not been exposed to rabies.

title: Transsexual Official Faces Firing in Florida
description: MIAMI, Feb. 28  Steven B. Stanton has been the city manager of Largo, about 25 miles west of Tampa, for 14 years. But he is now facing dismissal after his plans to have sex-change surgery became public.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Harry Potter Passes a Test

title: Spitzer Counterpunches With Ad Defending Health Care Overhaul
description: Responding to attacks by health care interests on cuts in his proposed budget, Gov. Eliot Spitzer defended his position yesterday in a television advertisement that portrayed him as someone battling the high cost of medical care in the state.

title: Top Taliban Leader Is Arrested in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 1  The Talibans former defense minister, Mullah Obeidullah, who has remained one of the most senior leaders in the insurgent movement, was arrested in Pakistan on Monday, the day of Vice President Dick Cheneys visit, two government officials said Thursday.

title: Girl Scout Cookies in Bulk
description: In an annual rite that is still going strong, Girl Scouts across the country have kicked off their 90th season of cookie sales but with some modern entrepreneurial twists.

title: With Anchors Still Settling In, NBC Feels Pressure at the Top
description: NBCs dominance in televisions evening news race is undergoing its most serious challenge in a decade as World News on ABC scored its second ratings victory in the last three weeks. The figures highlight the slow but steady ascent of the veteran ABC newsman Charles Gibson toward the top position among news anchors.

title: A Comeback in 3-D, but Without Those Flimsy Glasses
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28  A little past the two-minute mark, the music video for Gwen Stefanis recent single, Wind It Up, finds her chained to a fence while a flurry of bubbles and snowflakes float by. Viewed from a certain perspective  that is, through 3-D glasses  it is a dreamlike moment in which the flurry seems close enough to touch.

title: Tennessee: Tentative Pact With University Workers
description: Vanderbilt University and a union representing about 600 campus workers announced a tentative agreement after two days of meetings with a federal mediator. The three-year contract between Vanderbilt and the Laborers International Union of North America would raise the minimum wage of union workers to $10 an hour by late 2008 and would establish other annual increases. Union members will vote on the proposal tomorrow.

title: Nascars Car of Tomorrow May Be Todays Car Even Sooner
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., Feb. 28  Nascar spent years developing a racecar for its premier series, the Nextel Cup. The so-called Car of Tomorrow was designed to improve safety and competition while limiting costs.

title: In Arab Hub, the Poor Are Left to Their Fate
description: CAIRO, Feb. 23  Ali Mezar has spent his life fishing a narrow, muddy patch of the Nile in this, one of the most crowded cities in the world. But Mr. Mezar has little contact with urban civilization. He sleeps in his boat, makes tea from the dirty Nile water and on good days earns a few dollars.

title: Judge Is Urged to Back Deal on Hurricane Damage Claims
description: GULFPORT, Miss., Feb. 28  Addressing a skeptical federal judge, Mike Moore, a lawyer who helped engineer a settlement with State Farm, argued Wednesday that the deal should be approved partly because it could put hundreds of millions of dollars into the hands of victims of Hurricane Katrina by the end of the year.

title: The Senates Forgotten Iraq Choice
description: Providence, R.I.

title: Chinese Shrug Off Losses as Market Swings Back
description: SHANGHAI, Feb. 28  Seated before a row of computer terminals flickering with stock charts in a large brokerage house in this bustling city, Li Ruichang insisted he was not too worried about Tuesdays huge stock sell-off.

title: Illinois: Charges in Anthrax Hoax
description: The graduate student who forced a temporary shutdown of the University of Missouri, Rolla, on Tuesday by making false threats of anthrax and explosives was charged with making terrorist threats. The student, identified as Sujithkumar Venkatramolla, left, 22, of Nizambad, India, was also charged with first-degree assault of a law enforcement officer, armed criminal action and resisting arrest, said Courtney M. George, the Phelps County prosecuting attorney.

title: Is Looking Your Age Now Taboo?
description: BACK when she was in her early 40s and her skin was still smooth and unlined, Susan Burke used to joke that she was going to have a face-lift the minute she turned 45. The deadline came and went.

title: Dressing Up the Domestic With Something Less Routine
description: The Bird and the Bee is a small-bore pop group built around two people, the singer Inara George and the multi-instrumentalist Greg Kurstin. But it performs its gigs, as it did at Joes Pub on Monday, with a rhythm section and the kitsch detail of two backup singers wearing hair bows and pale yellow dresses.

title: Thomas C. Burke, 82, Lawyer and Trustee, Dies
description: Thomas C. Burke, a lawyer who was a member of the New York City Board of Education in the 1960s and a trustee of the Altman Foundation, which owned the Fifth Avenue department store B. Altman & Company, died Friday in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 82 and lived in Watch Hill, R.I.

title: Driver Given 18 Years to Life for Crash That Killed 2
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., Feb. 28  A man whose conviction last year on two counts of murder was a rare exception to the rule in drunken driving cases was sentenced here today to a prison term of 18 years to life.

title: A Divorce the Church Should Smile Upon
description: Los Angeles

title: Corzine Office Is Subpoenaed in an Inquiry Into Spending
description: TRENTON, Feb. 28  Subpoenas were served on the offices of Gov. Jon S. Corzine and his chief counsel on Wednesday seeking documents about last-minute appropriations that have been added to state budgets since 2004.

title: Nothing but a Title Will Satisfy Dukes Womens Team
description: DURHAM, N.C., Feb. 27  Who wants to attend a roast when they feel they have been burned on the spit? Duke Coach Gail Goestenkors was hardly in a laughing mood last April after her team suffered the most excruciating of defeats, losing a double-digit lead before falling in overtime to conference rival Maryland in the womens national championship basketball game.

title: A Grand Time for Opera
description: For the past few years, the New York City Opera has been looking beyond Lincoln Center, wondering where it will make its home. Now it knows. The City Opera has named a new general manager and artistic director, Gerard Mortier  currently director of the Paris National Opera  who has convinced the board that the opera should stay put.

title: Deliberations Continue in Libby Case
description: A question sent to the judge by the jury that is deciding the perjury case of I. Lewis Libby Jr. created a stir but did not provide any clarity about the status of the deliberations. The message was received late Tuesday, after the jury had deliberated for more than four days, and was confusing enough for Judge Reggie B. Walton to respond Wednesday morning that he did not fully understand the question. When he asked for clarification, the jurors sent back a second message: Never mind. We are clear on what we need to do, the second message read. No further clarification needed. We apologize. After the exchange, the jurors continued discussing the case through the day, departing without a verdict.

title: Bernanke Not Worried About Market Drop
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 27  Ben S. Bernanke, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, said on Wednesday that he saw little cause for alarm in either the previous days stock market plunge or new evidence of slowing economic growth.

title: At Roads End, a Birds-Eye Guide to What Lies Ahead
description: Off-road, where territory is not yet mapped, most hand-held G.P.S. systems show current map coordinates and major landmarks like streams and mountains, and keep track of the paths you have followed. They do not tell you what the terrain is like, or what is beyond the next hill or bend.

title: Iranian President to Visit Saudi Arabia
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, March 1 Irans President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad will make his first official visit to Saudi Arabia on Saturday for a summit with King Abdullah intended to tackle the burgeoning sectarian and political battles throughout the Middle East, Saudi and Iranian officials said today.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q.Are compact fluorescent light bulbs the only energy-saving option?

title: Rapid Weight Gain (but Dont Worry)
description: UNTIL recently, most weight vests were bulky 50-pound training tools designed for firefighters and football players. So a lot of walkers looking to increase their calorie burn carted around hand weights instead.

title: Hoping to Quiet Critics, Bloomberg Picks a Parent in Chief for the Citys Schools
description: Faced with mounting criticism from parents over recent changes in school bus routes and plans to reorganize the city school system, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg named a veteran education advocate yesterday to represent them at the Department of Education.

title: The Anti-Doping Fight Is About More Than Celebrities
description: Dont apologize. Thats the advice to authorities who raided what could be a major sports drug connection on Tuesday. Dont let glazed looks and polite little yawns from the public or the press deter you.

title: Deal Reached on Sex Offenders Bill
description: ALBANY, March 1  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and leaders of the Legislature said today that they had reached a deal on setting up procedures to confine sex offenders after they finish their prison sentences, joining more than a dozen other states that have similar laws.

title: A Disconnect on Hooking Up
description: WHEN Laura Sessions Stepp warned of the potentially damaging effects of hooking up in a new book, some people scoffed  particularly those who believe they were unscathed by their own unfettered years of casual sex.

title: The Knicks Miss Crawford, but They Play Just Like Him
description: BOSTON, Feb. 28  The Knicks lost Jamal Crawford, but did not lose his personality Wednesday night. They were every bit as streaky, unpredictable and maddeningly erratic as their injured starting guard.

title: Habitat in New Orleans (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Plans by Airbus to Eliminate Jobs and Shed Plants Set Off Labor Protests
description: PARIS, Feb. 28  Nearly 14,000 blue- and white-collar employees at four Airbus production sites in France stopped work as long as two hours on Wednesday afternoon to protest the companys decision to eliminate 10,000 jobs and sell as many as six factories over the next three to four years, union officials said.

title: For Some Aging Actors, Self-Mockery Sells
description: MADISON AVENUE is taking a cue from the adage that history repeats itself first as tragedy and then as farce.

title: Charles Forte, Who Founded a Hotel Empire, Dies at 98
description: LONDON, Feb. 28  Charles Forte, the owner of a hotel and restaurant empire that ranged from the Waldorf Hotel in London to the budget chain Travelodge, died on Wednesday at his home in London. He was 98.

title: For the Record
description: An article and headline yesterday about the indictment of a New Jersey state trooper whose patrol car slammed into a minivan in September, killing two sisters, misstated the charges against him. The trooper, Robert Higbee, is charged with two counts of vehicular homicide  not vehicular manslaughter or manslaughter. (There is no charge of vehicular manslaughter in New Jersey.)

title: Queens: 3 Testify on Shooting by Police
description: Three friends of Sean Bell, an unarmed man fatally shot by the police on his wedding day in November, yesterday told a Queens grand jury considering whether to indict the officers that they did not hear the officers identify themselves as the police before opening fire on Mr. Bells car, their lawyer said. The lawyer, Charlie King, confirmed the identity of one of the witnesses, Jean Nelson, but declined to identify the other two. The three were standing 20 to 40 feet from the car at the time of the shooting, Mr. King said yesterday. Mr. Bell was shot by the police on Nov. 25 after leaving his bachelor party at a strip club in Jamaica.

title: Easing of License Requirements Is Possible
description: Facing a possible revolt by state officials and a Senate effort to modify the law, Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff said the federal government would not penalize states that could not meet a May 2008 deadline to start issuing new standardized and tamper-proof drivers licenses. Mr. Chertoff said the department would be prepared to grant waivers, as current law allows. Without the waivers, drivers from states that did not comply with the law risked being told that their licenses would not be valid identification at airport checkpoints or federal buildings. On Wednesday, Congressional and Homeland Security Department officials were discussing the possibility of extending the deadline for selected states until December 2009.

title: N.F.L. Doctor Quits Amid Research Doubt
description: Dr. Elliot Pellman, whose qualifications as the longtime chairman of the N.F.L.s research committee on concussions have been a subject of widespread debate, resigned as chairman of the committee on Monday.

title: General Is Fired Over Conditions at Walter Reed
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  The two-star general in charge of Walter Reed Army Medical Center was relieved of command on Thursday, following disclosures that wounded soldiers being treated as outpatients were living in dilapidated quarters and enduring long waits for treatment.

title: The Daily Fight Against Spam
description: Q. I made the mistake of filling out a survey online, and ever since I have spent 10 to 15 minutes a day adding addresses to my block senders list. Is there any way I can block all of these at once and report them to some entity?

title: Passenger Power (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page news analysis article yesterday about a suicide bomb attack on an American base in Afghanistan during Vice President Dick Cheneys visit, in which he expressed support for the fight against Taliban insurgents, misattributed a quotation about security threats from a Washington hearing held by the Senate Armed Services Committee on Tuesday. It was Senator Carl Levin of Michigan, the Democratic chairman of the committee  not Mike McConnell, the new director of national intelligence, the person testifying, who said, Long-term prospects for eliminating the Taliban threat appear dim, so long as the sanctuary remains in Pakistan, and there are no encouraging signs that Pakistan is eliminating it.

title: Calendar
description: Artists Inspired by Writers Inspired by Nature

title: An Enthusiastic Welcome to a Haunt of Jazz Giants
description: The pianist Marilyn Crispell ended her first set at the Village Vanguard on Tuesday night according to custom, reintroducing the members of her band. What happened next was less typical. Lorraine Gordon, the Vanguards owner, hurried onstage to announce that Ms. Crispell had just played the club for the first time. And it was so beautiful, Ms. Gordon said, before requesting an encore.

title: A New Video Device That Is Not Quite a TiVo for the iPod, but Its Close
description: Converting video for use on an iPod or PlayStation Portable is often time-consuming and complex. The iLuv i182 is meant to change that.

title: Pedicabs, Under New Rules, Will No Longer Roam So Freely
description: The City Council passed a comprehensive bill yesterday to regulate New York Citys freewheeling pedicab industry for the first time, bringing to it a level of oversight similar to that imposed on taxis and tour buses.

title: Couple Sought After Leaving a Rabid Raccoon at a Shelter
description: City health officials said yesterday that they were urgently looking for a man and a woman who dropped off a sick raccoon, which later tested positive for rabies, at an East Harlem animal shelter.

title: Foiled Again by the Elusive Leek
description: I ASK you, gardeners: is there some vegetable out there that eludes you, that you cannot grow no matter how hard you try?

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about problems between Quiznos restaurant and some of its franchises referred imprecisely to the timing of an initial offering by another fast-food chain, Burger King, and the role of its chief executive, Gregory D. Brenneman. Although Mr. Brenneman helped prepare Burger King for its initial offering last year, he did not take it public on May 17; he left the company in April.

title: I.R.S. Finds Tax Errors in Reports of Nonprofits
description: Some 600 charities and foundations have had to file amended tax forms after an Internal Revenue Service study found flaws in the way they reported payments to executives and other employees.

title: Accord on Bill to Detain Sex Offenders
description: ALBANY, March 1  New York is poised to join more than a dozen states that continue to detain sex offenders after they have finished serving their prison sentences, under an agreement reached this week by Gov. Eliot Spitzer and the State Legislature.

title: Council Acts to Make Clubs Safer
description: Responding to several highly publicized cases in which young people met harm or death, the City Council passed three measures yesterday intended to make nightclubs safer and to crack down on negligent club owners.

title: Arthur Schlesinger, Historian of Power, Dies at 89
description: Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian whose more than 20 books shaped discussions for two generations about Americas past and who himself was a provocative, unabashedly liberal partisan, most notably in serving in the Kennedy White House, died last night in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: Bringing Verve to Vivaldi With Hints of Spontaneity
description: There was a moment in the concert by the German soprano Simone Kermes and members of the Venice Baroque Orchestra on Tuesday night at Weill Recital Hall when you might have thought youd mistakenly wandered into an after-hours jam session at a jazz club. It came after intermission, when the musicians ambled out and began playing seemingly spontaneously. Ms. Kermes, behind the harpsichord, offered a bit of conversational recitative. Strolling to the front of the stage she proceeded to raise the roof with a stormy solo: Siam navi allonde algenti, an aria from Vivaldis opera LOlimpiade.

title: Oracle Deal for Hyperion Is Expected
description: Oracle is near a deal to acquire Hyperion Solutions, which makes software that allows corporations to analyze and track their performance, for more than $3.1 billion, according to people briefed on the deal.

title: Emmett Williams, 81, Fluxus-Movement Poet, Dies
description: Emmett Williams, an American poet whose transposition of words into visual art and performances made him one of the founding artists of Fluxus, a performance-oriented avant-garde art movement of the 1960s, died on Feb. 14 in Berlin. He was 81 and had lived in Berlin for many years.

title: Folk Wear for the World
description: PARIS

title: Poll Shows Majority Back Health Care for All
description: A majority of Americans say the federal government should guarantee health insurance to every American, especially children, and are willing to pay higher taxes to do it, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Cuomo Voids Health Benefits for Two Boards
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28 Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo said in a legal opinion on Wednesday that the boards of two state housing authorities illegally granted themselves lifetime health insurance benefits at state expense.

title: Cutbacks May Delay Flights, NASA Leader Says
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The craft that is to replace the space shuttle could be delayed because of recent budget reductions, pushing its first missions into 2015 instead of 2014, the NASA administrator, Michael D. Griffin, told a Senate committee on Wednesday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Trips to Nowhere and Everywhere, With Irans Poet of the Cinema
description: The films of Abbas Kiarostami are at once simple and enigmatic, guileless in their formal and visual strategies and puzzling in their effects. A central figure in the blossoming of Iranian cinema in the 1990s, and a winner of the top prize at Cannes for A Taste of Cherry in 1997, Mr. Kiarostami, who is 66, has now settled into the pantheon of international master filmmakers, a status confirmed by the retrospective of his work that begins at the Museum of Modern Art today. The program, covering more than three decades and including shorts and features, documentaries and instructional films, provides plenty of opportunities to appreciate his plainness and to ponder his mysteries.

title: Slim Vote of Confidence for Italys Leader
description: ROME, Feb. 28  Italys political crisis ended, for the moment, on Wednesday night after the Senate narrowly passed a vote of confidence in Prime Minister Romano Prodis fragile government.

title: Sarkozy Outlines Foreign Policy for France
description: PARIS, Feb. 28  The center-right presidential candidate Nicolas Sarkozy wants to toughen sanctions against Iran, keep Turkey out of the European Union, create an independent European defense strategy and have a friendly but not a submissive relationship with the United States.

title: Iran: Gunmen in Southeast Attack Police
description: Gunmen killed four policemen in southeastern Sistan-Baluchestan Province and kidnapped one and took him to Pakistan, Interior Minister Mostafa Pourmohammadi told the ISNA news agency. In February, unidentified attackers in the province used a car bomb to kill 11 members of the Revolutionary Guard. Officials blame bandits and drug smugglers for the attacks and say they are using Pakistan as a base.

title: Gallic Cool in a Quartets New York Debut
description: The Amedeo Modigliani Quartet, a young Parisian ensemble, has won both the European and American versions of the annual Young Concert Artists Audition. That may seem like overkill, but each version comes with its own prizes. Among those on the American side is a New York debut concert, which the quartet played Tuesday evening at Zankel Hall.

title: Slavery Is Not Dead. Its Not Even Past.
description: The Rev. Al Sharpton seemed subdued, quiet, reflective  which was unusual.

title: Correction: Can Polyester Save the World?
description: A headline and article on Jan. 25 about the environmental impact of consumers clothing-buying habits referred incorrectly to a test by Cambridge University researchers that compared the energy required to make and clean an organic cotton T-shirt to that required for a synthetic blouse. (The error also appeared in an accompanying chart.) The blouse was made of rayon, which is derived from plants; it was not polyester, which is made from polymers. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message received on Jan. 26. This correction was delayed because editors did not follow through on the complaint.

title: PTA Moms Dedication (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Taking Work Home From the Office as Electronic Documents, Without That Nagging Sense of Insecurity
description: The line between computing at work and computing at home has been blurred. Taking work home on a U.S.B. drive is often a useful option since there is no laptop to lug.

title: A Dominatrix Ran a Brothel Amid Wealth, the Police Say
description: The police called it a high-priced brothel offering a dominatrixs services.

title: Jay Harnick, 78, Advocate of Theater for Children, Dies
description: Jay Harnick, the founder of Theaterworks/USA, the nations largest touring childrens theater company, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. He was 78.

title: Pain Relief, Step by Step
description: Much attention has been focused on the cardiovascular risks posed by Vioxx and other so-called cox-2 inhibitors in recent years, so the American Heart Association provided an important service this week by reminding us that many other painkillers have risks associated with them. The association spelled out gradations of cardiovascular risk and recommended a step-by-step approach  starting with nonmedicinal remedies  that doctors should follow when treating joint and ligament pain.

title: Romney Focuses on Conservative Straw Poll
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  The straw poll at the annual Conservative Political Action Conference beginning here Thursday has never played a pivotal role in a Republican presidential primary. But the Mitt Romney campaign nonetheless is paying for three vans, scores of registration fees and at least a half-dozen hotel rooms to pack collegiate supporters into the event.

title: A Moscow of the Mind
description: THE banquet of lobster bisque, duck salad, lamb chops and Grey Goose was lost on Gaby Mitnik. After all those vodkas, I dont remember what I ate, confided Ms. Mitnik, who celebrated her 30th birthday at Rasputin in February. She is one in a crush of Russian-Americans who make the Brooklyn restaurant and cabaret their weekend haunt.

title: For the Super-Rich, Too Much Is Never Enough
description: For voyeurs of billionaires, a brief period from mid-February to mid-March serves up two of the juiciest glimpses they will get all year. In February, the Slate 60 list of the years biggest philanthropic gifts comes out, followed in March by the Forbes magazine list of the worlds richest people.

title: For the Record
description: A sports article on Saturday about Nick OHerns victory over Tiger Woods at the Accenture Match Play Championship in Arizona referred imprecisely in some copies to a shot on the second extra hole of the head-to-head competition. Before Woods missed a 15-foot putt for par, he hit a shot out of the rough  not out of a bunker.

title: Arrests Reflect a New Focus on Fighting Steroid Sales
description: ALBANY, Feb. 28  The arrests of four people in Florida on Tuesday and the indictments of at least six doctors around the country linked to a pharmacy in Orlando, Fla., present striking evidence that authorities in several states have opened a new front in the war against illegal online sales of steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Russia: Bribe-Taking Inquiry of Traffic Police
description: The prosecutor generals office announced a nationwide investigation of the countrys notoriously, often brazenly, corrupt traffic police. In a statement, the office cited complaints by motorists that instances of bribe-taking and other abuses were on the rise despite previously announced campaigns against corruption.

title: Commerce Department Says U.S. Economy Is Weaker Than Expected
description: Analysts have been stumped by the apparent resilience of the American economy, which seemed to be bounding ahead at a 3.5 percent pace in the final quarter of last year even as the housing market fell and the Federal Reserve raised interest rates.

title: Ex-Prosecutor Says Politics Was Motive for Dismissal
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  David C. Iglesias, who was dismissed as the United States attorney in New Mexico, has said he believes that he was ousted because he resisted pressure before the 2006 elections to bring corruption charges against a Democrat in his state, a Democratic senator said on Wednesday.

title: Manhattan: Business Grants Awarded
description: The citys Department of Small Business Services said yesterday that it had awarded about one-third of the $1.5 million it can grant this year to companies for training workers. The department granted a combined $466,324 to five employers, including two manufacturers, Felix Storch Inc. in the Bronx and G.T. Machine and Tool Company in Queens, and two health care operations, Montefiore Medical Center and the Community Premier Plus health plan. The fifth recipient, Soundwriters Inc. of Long Island City, plans to hire 18 workers to create closed captions and subtitles for films and television shows. The grants can be used to cover half of the training costs, to a maximum of $300,000.

title: Project Curbs Malaria in Ugandan Group
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28  A simple, inexpensive and surprisingly powerful combination of treatments all but wiped out malaria in a group of H.I.V.-positive children in a study in Uganda, scientists are reporting.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article yesterday, about expanding visas for skilled workers, at one point misidentified the relevant legislation that the Senate is taking up this week. It is a revamped immigration bill, not an education bill.

title: 2 Paintings by Picasso Are Stolen in Paris
description: PARIS, Feb. 28  Two important paintings by Picasso estimated by the police to be worth a total of about $66 million have been stolen from the Left Bank home of his granddaughter Diana Widmaier-Picasso, the authorities announced Wednesday.

title: A Sandwich or Two, With a Row Over Gay Marriage on the Side
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 28  Dozens of colorful photos and drawings depicting families led by gay couples were rehung on the tan walls of a sandwich shop here on Wednesday, ending a three-day dust-up over art, commerce and politics.

title: Ratner Wants the Nets to Keep Carter and Kidd
description: Bruce C. Ratner, the principal owner of the Nets, said he wouldnt be a happy camper if the team were to lose Jason Kidd or Vince Carter, its star players.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Tuesday about the Vanity Fair party after the Academy Awards ceremony carried an erroneous dateline and misidentified the site of Mortons restaurant, where the party was held. The article was reported from West Hollywood, where Mortons is located  not from Beverly Hills.

title: Israeli Forces Kill 3 Islamic Militants in West Bank and Re-enter Nablus
description: JERUSALEM, Feb. 28  Israeli undercover forces fatally shot three Islamic Jihad militants in Jenin in the West Bank on Wednesday, and nearby a large contingent of Israeli soldiers re-entered Nablus just a day after withdrawing.

title: Jackets, in a Loose Sense
description: WAS it just a year ago that retailers despaired of selling a tentlike silhouette as buoyant on top as it is below? Well, the eye adjusts, as they say in the trade. Now shoppers are embracing this voluminous shape, and in particular its keystone: a short, unstructured jacket that just grazes the top of the hips.

title: Friendships No LOL Matter for Girls Becoming Adults :(
description: Waxing philosophical about the passage of time seems altogether too grandmotherly for a critic in the prime of her life. Yet on several occasions in recent weeks, works of art have made me feel I was just too old to care about 20-somethings who needlessly complicate their lives and relationships. One of those works was Anna Zieglers play BFF (thats best friends forever, for anyone too old to recognize the acronym), at the DR2 Theater.

title: Bosnia: Serbs Apologize to War Victims
description: The Serbian entity of the government of Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Republika Srpska, officially apologized to victims of the 1992-1995 civil war, two days after international judges in The Hague ruled that Bosnian Serb forces had committed genocide in the killing of nearly 8,000 Muslims in Srebrenica in 1995. The government of the Republika Srpska expresses its deepest regret for the crimes committed against non-Serbs and condemns all persons who took part in these crimes, the statement said.

title: Writing Her Own Sequel
description: BOULDER, Colo.

title: U.S. Had Doubts on North Korean Uranium Drive
description: WASHINGTON, Feb. 28  Last October, the North Koreans tested their first nuclear device, the fruition of decades of work to make a weapon out of plutonium.

title: 6 Get Grants From U.S. to Support Bio-Refineries
description: Seeking to encourage motor fuel production from materials that are cheaper and more abundant than corn, the Energy Department said yesterday that it would provide up to $385 million in six bio-refinery projects that would produce cellulosic ethanol, a type of ethanol that can be made from nonfood crops and agricultural waste.

title: Tornadoes Kill 19 in 2 States
description: ATLANTA, March 1  Deadly tornadoes swept through the Southeast and parts of the Midwest today, killing 19 people in two states, including 15 at a high school in Enterprise, Ala.

title: I, Um, Loved Your Book (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Soothing Words and a Stock Market Rebound
description: Calm returned to Wall Street yesterday.

title: With Witnesses at Risk, Murder Suspects Go Free
description: NEWARK, Feb. 27  When Yusef Johnson, a 15-year-old honors student, was killed outside an apartment complex here so gang-infested it is known as Crazyville, a witness came forward within days and told the police she knew the man she had seen fire the fatal shots.

title: For the Record
description: A dance review on Monday about the Bolshoi Ballet's performance of "Cinderella" at the Kennedy Center in Washington misidentified the author of the libretto. He is Yuri Borisov  not Nikolai Volkov, who wrote the ballet scenario.

title: The Dip Felt Around the World
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: St. Thomas Luxe
description: Situated 1,110 miles and a world away from Miami, the island of St. Thomas offers a paradisaical natural setting and an array of high-end second-home options.

title: Scenes of Old San Juan
description: Tour the cobbled streets of Puerto Ricos historic core and see a typical three-bedroom home on the market for $999,000.

title: On the Market | St. John
description: The island of St. John is a pristine and lush playground, with real estate offerings that make the other United States Virgin Islands seem like the cheap seats.

title: McCain Announces Campaign
description: March 1 - Arizona Republican Senator John McCain announced on the 'Late Show With David Letterman' that he would run for president.

title: Comic Abstraction
description: Images from the Museum of Modern Art's exhibit of works by 13 artists who borrow from comic strips, cartoons and animation.

title: The Anti-Model
description: Lara Stone isnt your typical runway android. I asked the photographer Greg Kessler to keep a record of Stone: one girl, one season. Here she is in every show since New York.

title: Po Monkeys Juke Joint
description: Willie Seaberry, 65 and a farmworker by day, also runs the Po Monkeys juke joint, where strippers  and Mr. Seaberrys suits  are the star attraction.

title: The Anti-Model
description: Lara Stone isnt your typical runway android. I asked the photographer Greg Kessler to keep a record of Stone: one girl, one season. Here she is in every show since New York.

title: Umm  Is This Thing On?
description: Hello? Yes  Ladies and gentlemen, as youre finding your seats, we have a couple of announcements to make. First, the part of The Blogger, normally played by Tom Zeller Jr., will be performed today by Patrick J. Lyons  Hey! Listen, take it easy now! Patrick, is a pro, and throwing things will get you marched right outta here!

title: Oracle to Buy Hyperion for $3.3 Billion
description: Oracle said Thursday it would buy Hyperion Solutions, which makes software that allows corporations to analyze and track their performance, for $3.3 billion in cash. The deal would be the latest trophy in a lengthy string of acquisitions for the database software giant, which has been struggling to grow from within.

title: Is the S.E.C. Changing Course?
description: In his first year as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Christopher Cox confounded both supporters and detractors by taking a more moderate and nuanced position than they had predicted on a variety of regulatory issues, based on his record as a conservative Republican lawmaker.

title: For the Super-Rich, Too Much Is Never Enough
description: For voyeurs of billionaires, a brief period from mid-February to mid-March serves up two of the juiciest snapshots they will get all year. In February, the Slate 60 list of the years biggest philanthropic gifts comes out, followed in March by the Forbes magazine list of the worlds richest people.

title: Sirius Chief Talks of Ways to Get XM Deal Approved
description: Facing skeptical lawmakers, Mel Karmazin, the architect of a proposed merger of the nations two satellite radio companies, announced at a hearing in Congress on Wednesday that the companies would agree to government-imposed price controls and other unspecified measures to gain regulatory approval for the deal.

title: Citi Acquisition in Prepaid Cards
description: Citigroup has agreed to buy Ecount, a privately held provider of prepaid cards, expanding its presence in the fastest-growing part of the payment industry, according to The New York Times. Terms of the deal, which The Times said is expected to be announced today, were not disclosed.

title: Lawyer Charged in $10 Million Securities Fraud
description: Federal prosecutors charged an ex-partner of the law firm McGuireWoods with fraud Wednesday, claiming that he illegally obtained and sold shares of various companies for a profit of millions of dollars. The lawyer, Louis W. Zehil, 41, was arrested, and a federal magistrate later set bail at $250,000. Separately, the Securities and Exchange Commission filed a civil complaint against Mr. Zehil in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Addiction, Magnified
description: "You always miss it: that world and that escape, that kind of sex," observes Peter Staley in Jay Corcoran's riveting, X-ray-acute documentary "Rock Bottom." Mr. Staley, an articulate, gay, H.I.V.-positive recovering methamphetamine user, has gained notice in recent years for showering the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan with posters bluntly connecting the popularity of crystal meth with rising rates of H.I.V. infection.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Reports 2006 Profit Increase
description: The Royal Bank of Scotland Group said its profit rose 14 percent last year and raised its dividend by 25 percent. The bank said 2006 operating profit reached 9.41 billion pounds ($18.4 billion), up from 8.25 billion in 2005 and narrowly ahead of an average forecast of 9.34 billion from a Reuters Estimates poll.

title: Helicos BioSciences Plans $100 Million I.P.O.
description: Helicos BioSciences, a venture-backed biotechnology company, filed late Wednesday to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering. Helicoss current shareholders include Flagship Ventures and Highland Capital Partners.

title: Will Electronic Arts New Chief Ramp Up M&A?
description: The appointment of John Riccitiello to the post of chief executive of Electronic Arts, the independent game maker, is a sign for at least one analyst that the company is gearing up for some dealmaking. Game Daily notes that P.J. McNealy of American Technology Research thinks the announcement sends a clear signal to the Street that ERTS will become more aggressive in the mergers and acquisition space as the new-generation console install base begins ramping.

title: Subprime Mortgages May Still Haunt the Street
description: As calm returned to Wall Street on Wednesday, one important concern  that Wall Streets bet on home loans to people with weak, or subprime, credit is souring quickly as defaults rise and home prices weaken  remained. Wall Street executives and analysts acknowledged that the subprime segment of the mortgage business had faltered because of the performance of loans issued in 2006, but many contend that the problems are well contained and do not yet pose a significant threat to investment banks or the broader global financial system.

title: Cuban and the Cubs: A Pair or a Pipe Dream?
description: Does Mark Cuban really want the Chicago Cubs so bad? Apparently not. Radar Online reported Wednesday that the tech entrepreneur was set to offer $625 million to buy the Chicago team from the Tribune Company. Radar quoted a source familiar with matter as saying Mark is desperate to buy the Cubs. He wants this so bad.

title: Icahn to Buy $2 Billion of Motorola Shares
description: Motorola  said Carl C. Icahn filed documents seeking government permission to acquire $2 billion worth of the telecoms stock. Motorola said Icahn and his Icahn Partners hedge fund are each asking the government for permission, under whats known as the Hart-Scott-Rodino securities law, to buy at least $119.7 million and up to $500 million of Motorola shares. Two other funds, Icahn Partners Master Fund and Icahn Partners Master Fund II, are each asking for permission to acquire in excess of $500 million worth, but less than 25 percent of all of Motorolas outstanding shares.

title: G.E. to Sell $2.9 Billion Swiss Re Stake
description: Swiss Re said General Electric would divest its stake, worth about 3.5 billion Swiss francs ($2.9 billion), selling half to Swiss Re and placing the other half in the market. Swiss Re had waived a lock-up period on the shares, which General Electric had received as part of the payment for its reinsurance units, which it sold for $7.4 billion to the Swiss reinsurer last year.

title: Painting Through the Pain
description: The title may suggest a wildlife documentary, but "The Cats of Mirikitani" is entirely, vibrantly human. When, early in 2001, the New York filmmaker Linda Hattendorf befriends the homeless artist who works beneath the awning of a grocery store near her SoHo apartment, she has no way of knowing where the friendship will lead  nor how their shared experience of one national tragedy will sharpen the legacy of another more than half a century earlier.

title: A Balancing Act
description: Photos from the Tintoretto exhibition at the Prado Museum in Madrid.

title: Private Equity Teams Up for Home Depot Auction, Report Says
description: Competition for Home Depots wholesale supply business is already heating up, even though the company has yet to formally announce an auction. And the roster of interested bidders reads like a private equity hall of fame. According to The Financial Times, three teams of private equity firms have formed to consider bids for the business, which could go for about $11 billion.

title: Amazon Funds Internet Site for Bookworms
description: Amazon.com was the lead investor in a funding round for Shelfari, a social-networking site for people interested in books. The amount was not disclosed but published reports estimated the total at about $1 million. Seattle-based Shelfari was founded in October. Company officials say theyll use the money for site development, sales and marketing initiatives, and general administrative costs.

title: Taking on the Myths of Private Equity
description: Private equity is getting plenty of attention these days. Headlines routinely mention firms such as the Blackstone Group, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, the Texas Pacific Group, the Carlyle Group and Providence Equity Partners as they recount the latest record-breaking buyout or takeover of a well-known company.

title: In the Erin Brockovich Town, A Real-Life Sequel Looms
description: Suppose you want to build an industrial facility that is sure to be unpopular with its neighbors, something that uses or produces or handles noxious, unpleasant stuff like, oh, say, dried sewage sludge. Naturally you have the best intentions about running it cleanly and safely, but even so, its probably wisest to put it somewhere out of the way, where not too many people are likely to be affected or annoyed by it.

title: Clubbing a Baby Penguin to Death
description: Nikke Finke opens up a can of bile on the Oscar show and then filets and serves up her own spleen. Heres one of the kinder passages:

title: This Just In
description: The Reeler, tipped by Screen Grab, points up to a the right fielders live-blogging for Libertas. (Is that meta-webby enough for you?) An excerpt:

title: Petri Dish
description: Was there a toxin loose in L.A. that had nothing to do with corrosive ego and insatiable ambition?

title: Dishtar
description: Jessica Coen of Little Golden Men  we knew there was something different about her at the VF party points us to EWs remembrance of Ishtar past.

title: Wrapping Up the Wrap-Ups
description: The Bagger is a bit autistic when it comes to feelings about film awards, but it is a given of Oscar Ninnyism that many of the best sources have an emotional connection to the awards. Daniel Kenealy of OscarWatch, for example, throws his bit into a thicket of post-hoc Oscar deconstructions and manages to generate some heat and light. And he lays off the psycho rants from last year, so all the better.

title: A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Insolence
description: In amidst all the clutter, you might have missed the Baggers Lincoln Log post-Oscar story, a little number that Movie City News billed thusly:

title: Missing Links II
description: The Bagger posted a post-Oscar wish list of lovely things gone missing in the nominations and the commentators checked in with quite a few more. On their collective nominees wish list: Clive Owen in Children of Men, Children of Men in general, Shareeka Epps, for her incandescent performance in Half Nelson (which won her a Spirit Award).

title: The True Meaning of Slow Bleed
Global Desegregation?
description: With the rainbow of backgrounds in the acting categories, youd think that the historic resistance to actors of color in worldwide markets had evaporated, but the box office is lagging behind the hardware bestowals. Michael Cieply writes in The New York Times that its a much-discussed topic in Hollywood, although usually behind closed doors.

title: The Monarchs Butterflies
description: There have been reports that Helen Mirren and Steven Frears will be heading to Buckingham Palace for tea. MT, one of the Baggers loyal readers, noted Ms. Mirrens antimonarchist upbringing and the fact that The Queen wasnt exactly an endorsement of royalty as a governing institution. When I saw The Queen, I thought that I was watching a skeptical directors brilliant dissection of a dying and desiccated institution, MT writes.

title: Headed Toward the Barn
description: The Bagger headed out to Times Square to make another one of his largely ignored breathlessly awaited videos, the last of the season. Once that sucker is in the can, we will start rolling up the carpet and striking the bleachers. But in the meantime, there are still entrails aplenty to be gone through, and much deconstruction still under construction.

title: The Grand Prix Saboteurs
description: For years Joe Saward, a fellow Formula One journalist, has regaled me with stories about World War II, the French resistance and the history of the pre-war Grand Prix drivers who played a role in all of those things.
