Whether it be while talking in Paris near his home around the corner from the Nazi security police headquarters where they interrogated spies and resistance fighters, or on the highways near old French battlefields, or at the German Grand Prix tracks, Joes stories about the past always gave a welcome perspective to our usual discussion of todays F1 circus.

title: March, That Special Time of Year
description: The defining calendar days in March are the 17th and the 21st, St. Patricks Day and the first day of spring. But the real reason many of us treat this as the greatest month of the year isnt either day in particular, but how the eternal hope of spring and the revelry of St. Pattys Day reverberate through the build up to, and playing out of, the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament.

title: 2008: Straw Polls
description: Two Republican straw polls are going down over the next few days, starting with one in Spartanburg, S.C. tonight. News reports suggest Senator Sam Brownback has been especially aggressive in campaigning for that contest by visiting the area, by calling voters and sending out direct mail, but almost all of the campaigns have paid extra attention to the conservative area in upstate South Carolina over the past week.

title: Power Lunch, Citigroup Style
description: Lunch at the Four Seasons in New York is not so much a meal as it is a performance. The restaurant is typically packed with power brokers and their admirers, assuring that any tete-a-tete gets widely noticed. So it was interesting to see Charles Prince, the chief executive of Citigroup, sharing a table there Wednesday with Sanford Weill, his predecessor at the banking giant.

title: Candidates: Just Explain Why You Voted for War
description: Channeling my fathers once-frequent dictate to me, National Interest editor Nikolas K. Gvosdev tells presidential candidates who voted for the Iraq war, Sorry isnt good enough. O.K., Gvosdev actually writes, I am tired of hearing the excuse, If I had known then what I know now in relation to ones position on the Iraq war. Gvosdev explains:

title: Telling Your Computer What to Do
description: You know what I'm really into these days? Speech recognition in Windows Vista.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Journey's End," "BFF" and "The Oresteia."

title: On the Hill: Disunion Over Bills
description: Disputes over organized labor are tying up both sides of the Capitol. Senate Democratic leaders decided to shift away from trying to debate Iraq to work on an anti-terrorism bill, but their bill isnt going so well.

title: Pavanos Bullpen Session
description: When you cover the Yankees, you write a lot about Carl Pavanos bullpen sessions. He hasnt thrown any games for the Yankees since June 27, 2005, so thats often all we can go on.

title: Let The Games Begin
description: Chien-Ming Wang takes the mound against the Minnesota Twins today at 1:15 p.m. in the teams first spring game against an actual opponent. Here is the Yankees lineup:

title: Telling Your Computer What to Do
description: You know what Im really into these days? Speech recognition in Windows Vista.

title: Market Forecast For Today: Much Talk of Cat Mortality
description: Ah, the stock market. Tuesday: Precipitous plunge. Wednesday: Modest recovery. Thursday: Well, for the first little while at least, it was precipitous plunge time again.

title: Allied Capital Barely Knows Its Subsidiary
description: Allied Capital is out with its 10K today, and my favorite part is the disembodied way it discusses its 95 percent-owned subsidiary, Business Loan Express, where there are suspicions of fraud (and a federal indictment against a former executive):

title: Sami al-Haj on Hunger Strike
description: Our prison at Guantanamo is a national disgrace, arguably doing more to hurt national security (by harming the U.S. image before the world) than to help it. And so many reports have emerged of beatings and other punishments (including, as Ive written, the brutal beating of an American soldier who was playing the role of a foreigner) that it increasingly looks as if Guantanamo represents precisely the kind of arbitrary extra-judicial treatment that we properly denounce when it happens in countries like Sudan.

title: Peacekeepers for Darfur
description: One of the biggest problems in Darfur has been getting countries to donate troops for peacekeepers, either to an African force or to a U.N. force. Rwanda has been great about sending troops, but other countries have been reluctant. And the peacekeepers dont speak Arabic, so they need interpreters. And they arent Muslim, which creates risks of cultural clashes.

title: Bird-Dogging in N.H. and Iowa
description: Getting presidential candidates to give specific answers can be hard. To help voters in Iowa and New Hampshire, hosts of the countrys first nominating contests, several left-leaning groups have stepped in to teach the fine art of bird-dogging.

title: Pedicabs: Menace or Threat?
description: Or non-polluting, convenient alternative?

title: Bristol May Be a Bargain, Analyst Says
description: Let the bottom-fishing begin. Tuesdays stock market plunge may have rattled investors, but it also cut the prices of some companies that are widely considered to be in play. One of these, the pharmaceuticals giant Bristol-Myers Squibb, received an upgrade Thursday from analysts at UBS, who wrote that the recent pullback in the companys shares reinforces takeout prospects. Speculation about a takeover of Bristol-Myers has been swirling ever since the drug maker named an interim chief executive last fall.

title: Hoax! Hoax! Hoax! Hoax!
description: Yeah, we know. That Valentines Day breakup video  a classic for every college guy who has ever despised a cheating girlfriend and dreamed of going onto Facebook and getting 2,000 people to witness him ambush her with an a cappella singing group  has gotten 747,000 whole looks on YouTube.

title: Loose Lips and a British Bid That Wasnt
description: There seems to be confusion in the aisles at Marks & Spencer. Stuart Rose, the British clothiers chief executive, created a buzz Wednesday when he said a combination with supermarket chain J Sainsbury is an interesting idea and that your shareholders would think you were an idiot if you didnt consider it. Watch this space. Hours later, the Marks & Spencer board issued a statement confirming that it had considered some kind of deal but adding that it does not intend to make an offer for Sainsbury at this time.

title: Poll: Giuliani Leaps Ahead of McCain
description: Time Magazine has released a new poll with good news for former New York Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. Mr. Giuliani is now ahead of John McCain for the Republican nomination, preferred by 38 percent of voters who said they were Republicans or leaned Republican.

title: Somaliland: Go for the Sun, Stay for the Camels
description: A couple of weeks ago, I posted an item on this blog encouraging American students to dip their toes into Africa by visiting Ethiopia as tourists. So if you want to go in as far as your ankle, come here to Somaliland  where you can buy a lovely camel like this one for about $700. The capital, Hargeisa, has a great camel market  the kind of thing you dont find in, say, London or Rome.

title: Gingrich Calls Current Debates Lunacy
description: Newt Gingrich made some caustic remarks about the current state of political debating last night during his own debate with Mario M. Cuomo at Cooper Union in New York City, calling the currently used formats childish acts of lunacy.

title: Wall Street Insiders Charged in Stock-Tipping Cases
description: An executive at UBS and a former lawyer at Morgan Stanley were charged with conspiracy and securities fraud Thursday for allegedly passing information about pending stock-rating changes and merger announcements to hedge funds and other accomplices, who then traded on the tips. In all, the insider-trading schemes involved 13 defendants who made more than $8 million in illegal profits, the U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York said in a news release describing the indictments.

title: A Norseman Not to Be Trifled With
description: Leif Ericson the Viking left little in the way of a lasting mark on the North American landscape when he and his followers reached what he called Vinland a thousand-odd years ago, the first Europeans known to have gotten here. Traces of a tiny settlement at the northern tip of Newfoundland, maybe a coin in Maine or an intriguing artifact or two elsewhere  beyond that, time seems to have erased it all.

title: Family Matters in Education
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 1 column, A Critique of Pure Reason.

title: A Flying Start for the Yankees
description: If you believe in omens, youll be happy to hear how the 2007 Yankees started off. The first swing of their first spring training game just produced a home run.

title: Has Sirius Changed Its Tune?
description: Mel Karmazin, the chief executive of Sirius Satellite Radio, told a congressional committee Wednesday that its bizarre to call Sirius and XM Satellite Radio a duopoly. In pitching a merger of the two companies, which regulators need to approve, he suggested the firms cannot raise prices because of competition from (free) terrestrial radio.

title: When the Bough Breaks, History Will Fall
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Mar. 1 column, Slavery Is Not Dead. Its Not Even Past..

title: Mets-Cards Rematch
description: Whoever created these spring-training schedules shows no mercy. First, the A.L. Champion Tigers. Today and tomorrow, its the World Champion Cardinals. Whos next: the Colts?

title: Finding Love on the Sideline
description: If Winthrop advances to the N.C.A.A. tournament and manages to win its first round game, the historic occasion may not be Coach Gregg Marshalls favorite postseason basketball moment.

title: To Seed or Not a 2 Seed?
description: Heres a rhetorical question to gnaw on while calculating your brackets the next two weeks. How will the committee deal with teams that cant schedule games because no one wants to play them?

title: Here We Go Again
description: Oscar. Oscar, everyone murmured last night after watching Marion Cotillards performance as Edith Piaf in La Vie en Rose, which opened the Film Society of Lincoln Centers annual Rendez-Vous With French Cinema series at Alice Tully Hall.

title: Snoop Dogg Dogs Damon
description: Johnny Damon was the underdog  the big underdog  to Snoop Dogg when he played the rapstar in Xbox 360 football for charity during Super Bowl week.

title: Rat Patrol Closes 3 More Restaurants
description: After a round of reinspections, the city Health Department has shut down three Pizza Hut restaurants operated by the same franchisee that owned the KFC/Taco Bell in Greenwich Village where cavorting rats became YouTube stars last week. Ten others were also shut down pending the new inspections.

title: Gingrich Predicts: Rudy vs. Hillary
description: Former House Speaker Newt Gingrich made that prediction last night during his joint appearance at Cooper Union with former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo. (See The Caucus for some other things he had to say.)

title: How I Learned to Love the Wrong Notes
description: Im a composer. Im overworked, under pressure, and I need a vacation, but I love my job and I wouldnt trade it for the world. Ive been a composer-in-residence, a visiting professor, and Ive spent time being spoiled at artists residence programs, but I do my best work at home in my cluttered apartment, chipping away daily at the tangle of notes and rhythms that I have devoted my life to.

title: Chinese Kickers
description: In a plan to penetrate the fertile and untapped market of China, the N.F.L. is training Chinese athletes to kick at a professional level.

title: Ned Lamont Rides Again
description: The election is over, but there is still plenty of anger in Connecticut directed at Joe Lieberman and his stance on the war. The senator has received plenty of criticism on the local and national blogs, plus the occasional protester at his events back at home.

title: In Other Varmint News
description: City health officials say that the man and woman who dropped off a sick raccoon that later tested positive for rabies came forward today and indicated that they had not been exposed to rabies.

title: Just Spotted: Joe Bruno at City Hall
description: Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, just left City Hall after a meeting with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Cuomo: Newt for President
description: Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who retired from public life in 1995 after losing his bid for a fourth term as governor, was decidedly partisan in his remarks last night at the Cooper Union confab, though no less civil and cordial as Newt Gingrich, the former House Speaker. The liberal New York crowd ate it up.

title: Reading the Housing-Market Tea Leaves
description: So is housing slumping in this country, or aint it?

title: Start Spreading the News
description: The Yankees finished off the Twins, 6-1, at Legends Field today. They got five runs in the first two innings and then cruised. Jason Giambi had his favorite kind of day: two walks and a two-run homer. Midseason form, as they say, surgically repaired wrist and all.

title: Chuck the Dangerous
description: Also at last nights Cooper Union event, Newt Gingrich praised Senator Charles E. Schumers new book, Positively American.

title: China Is Near
description: Sometimes you only need to see the parody; you can infer the source. Thisthing here is almost perfect, and it so cleanly busts the anti-Asianxenophobic hysteria at the center of all gee-whiz globalizationpropaganda that you really, really dont need to see the propaganda.

title: Dysfunction Junction No More?
description: For the second time this week, Gov. Eliot Spitzer and leaders of the Legislature reached a compromise that broke a deadlock on a contentious issue that had divided lawmakers for years: setting up procedures to confine sex offenders after they finish their prison sentences, joining more than a dozen other states that have similar laws.

title: Majority Back Health Care for All
description: Robin Toner reports on a New York Times/CBS News Poll showing support for guaranteeing health insurance for every American.

title: The Anti-Model
description: Lara Stone isnt your typical runway android. She walks like Lurch and you cant tell from her stunned expression if shes going to burst into tears or belt you in the chops. But we love her. Shes 23, Dutch, and she has a little gap between her front teeth.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Into Great Silence'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Into Great Silence," a documentary about one of the world's most ascetic monasteries.

title: Story of a Pie
description: Harold Holzer, a vice president at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, introduced Mario Cuomo and Newt Gingrich at their Cooper Union appearance last night.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Black Snake Moan'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews 'Black Snake Moan,' starring Christina Ricci and Samuel Jackson.

title: 2008 P.M. Update: Ratings and Appearances
description: National Journal is set to release its ideology ratings based on votes in Congress for current lawmakers, and its findings for some of the presidential contenders are somewhat surprising given their reputations.

title: New Bush, Iraq Poll Numbers
description: In the months since the Congressional elections, President Bush has lost substantial support among members of his own party, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: The E.S.P. Gap
description: If youre a patriotic American who believes in extrasensory perception, I have some bad news for you  assuming you havent already gotten it from my brain on your personal wireless network.

title: The Bagger Awards
description: David Carr (a k a The Carpetbagger) wraps up the awards season by handing out some of his own 'hardware.'

title: Second Thoughts
description: Did I write last weeks column simply to provoke you?

title: Most Support U.S. Guarantee of Health Plans
description: A majority of Americans say the federal government should guarantee health insurance to every American, especially children, and are willing to pay higher taxes to do it, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll. In the poll, Americans showed a striking willingness to make tradeoffs for a better health care system, including paying as much as $500 more in taxes a year and forgoing future tax cuts.

title: In the Colonial Athletic Association, Four Into Two Wont Go
description: George Masons surprising run through the N.C.A.A. Tournament last season attracted much attention to mid-majors and to the Colonial Athletic Association. Plenty of people will be looking at the C.A.A. tournament in Richmond, Va., this weekend, wondering if this seasons George Mason will emerge. I dont think so. And dont expect more than two teams to come out of the conference this season.

title: A Cry to Limit Chinese Imports Rings at Paper Mill
description: LUKE, Md.  For years the residents of this economically distressed hollow in the Appalachians have watched textile mills, glass factories and tire makers close down one after the other. Now its lone remaining big factory  the last man standing, as the production manager at the paper mill here put it  is threatened by imports of cheaper paper made in China.

title: Stocks Cut Losses After Sharp Sell-Off
description: Wall Street could not pull itself out of a slump today that began with a 200-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. While stocks rebounded from their morning lows, the trading day ended with prices stalled in negative territory.

title: Blogosphere Ethics (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Leisurely Pleasures of a Pedicab
description: You feel every jolt and bump of the potholed streets. You feel a communion with the pigeons that swoop down and dart just overhead. A yellow parade of taxicabs rushes by close enough to touch. A double-decker bus looms suddenly alongside, seeming, in contrast to your puny status, like a skyscraper on wheels. Look up, and the real skyscrapers soar above you.

title: The Cold Show in Fairbanks, Alaska
description: IT was nearly midnight. The air temperature was below zero. But a few tourists and I were outside, soaking in soothing natural hot springs  close to 115 degrees. Our skin was a comfortably warm bubblegum pink, even as our damp hair was frozen to our heads.

title: An Art Infusion for Lincoln Center
description: As Lincoln Center embarks on a $750 million redevelopment, it is rethinking its identity. Since it was built on the Upper West Side in the 1960s, it has been a magnet for the performing arts. Now officials are studying ways to make visual art as much of a reason to visit as music, ballet or theater.

title: End Our Pain: Hold Primary Right Now
description: Efforts are astir in Albany to have New York join the herd of states swept up in the Feb. 5 stampede.

title: Capella Telluride and Campeche Playa Golf, Marina & Spa Resort
description: Capella Telluride

title: Monticello: Environmental Police Officer Arrested
description: A police officer for the New York City Department of Environmental Protection has been charged with paying another man to burn his own truck to collect insurance money, the New York City Department of Investigation announced yesterday. The officer, Edward Kowalik, 32, of Grahamsville, was charged with third-degree arson, said Stephen F. Lungen, the Sullivan County district attorney. He pleaded not guilty. Officer Kowalik is charged with paying William Kloss of Neversink to set fire to his truck on Oct. 14. Mr. Kloss, who was also charged with arson, has pleaded not guilty, Mr. Lungen said.

title: The Big Meltdown
India: Suspected Maoist Land Mine Kills 8
description: Eight people, including six policemen, died in a land mine blast in the Dantewada district of central Chhattisgarh State, stronghold of Maoist rebels. Four of the policemen belong to a special force with expertise in jungle warfare, brought from Indias northeast.

title: Pro Football Grooms 3 Legs, With the Goal of a Billion Eyes
description: EUGENE, Ore.  The Chinese athletes Gao Wei, Ding Long and Shen Yalei are being Americanized. For the past five weeks they have lived here in western Oregon. They have combed the malls, learned to love diner food, studied English and adopted the Westernized names William, Rambo and Sean  all in an effort to become the first Chinese to play in the United States most popular sports league, the N.F.L.

title: Pressed by U.S., Pakistan Seizes a Taliban Chief
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 1  The former Taliban defense minister was arrested in Pakistan on Monday, the day of Vice President Dick Cheneys visit, two government officials said Thursday. He is the most important Taliban member to be captured since the American-led invasion of Afghanistan in 2001.

title: Buffett Seeks New (and Younger) Candidate for Top Investing Position
description: Wanted: a promising junior executive to take over the investment portfolio of one of the worlds most successful investors.

title: Art in Review
description: WORKS ON PAPER Seventh Regiment Armory  643 Park Avenue, at 67th Street  Through Monday

title: Former Student Testifies of Affair With His Principal
description: His romance with the principal of his East Side private school began in the eighth grade, with a kiss, a police officer testified yesterday.

title: Widespread Storms Cause Deaths in 3 States
description: ATLANTA, March 1  A storm system that stretched nearly 1,000 miles from the Midwest to the Southeast on Thursday killed at least 11 people in three states, including five who died when what appeared to be a tornado caused the roof to collapse at a high school in Enterprise, Ala., state emergency management officials said.

title: G.M. Reports Unexpected Increase in Feb. Sales
description: DETROIT, March 1  General Motors reported an unexpected increase in February vehicle sales today, while Detroits other automakers experienced significant declines.

title: The Silence That Kills
description: On Feb. 20, The A.P. reported from Afghanistan that a suicide attacker disguised as a health worker blew himself up near a crowd of about 150 people who had gathered for a ribbon-cutting ceremony to open an emergency ward at the main government hospital in the city of Khost. A few days later, at a Baghdad college, a female Sunni suicide bomber blew herself up amid students who were ready to sit for exams, killing 40 people.

title: Most Support U.S. Guarantee of Health Care
description: A majority of Americans say the federal government should guarantee health insurance to every American, especially children, and are willing to pay higher taxes to do it, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Regulators in Europe Will Review Sony-BMG
description: PARIS, March 1  Antitrust regulators in Europe said Thursday that they would take a second look at the merger of the music units of Sony and BMG, a union that created the second-largest record company and provoked stiff opposition from independent music publishers.

title: Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., a Partisan Historian of Power, Is Dead at 89
description: Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., the historian whose more than 20 books shaped discussions for two generations about Americas past and who himself was a provocative, unabashedly liberal partisan, most notably while serving in the Kennedy White House, died Wednesday night in Manhattan. He was 89.

title: At Night, Farmer Trades His Tractor for the Blues
description: MERIGOLD, Miss.  Thursday is known as family night at Po Monkeys juke joint here, but that doesnt mean you should bring your kids to this patched-up sharecropper shack that has swayed with rhythms and blues for nearly 50 years.

title: Washington: Impeachment Resolution Urged
description: Mayor Rocky Anderson of Salt Lake City appeared before a committee of the State Senate in Olympia in support of a resolution asking Congress to begin impeachment proceedings against President Bush. Mr. Anderson, a Democrat, said the case for impeachment was not partisan. He said the president should face impeachment for heinous human rights violations, breaches of trust, abuses of power injurious to the nation, war crimes, misleading Congress and the American people, among other reasons. Mr. Anderson also submitted a 22-page, heavily footnoted statement to legislators.

title: Keeping a Natural Silence on Snowshoes in Vermont
description: About 4,000 B.C., historians believe, people in Central Asia grew tired of sinking thigh-high in the snow. It was around then, roughly the same era the wheel was invented, that humans first strapped some kind of flat extenders to the bottoms of their feet and traversed the winter landscape by floating atop the snow.

title: Off-Season Analysis: N.F.C.
description: N.F.C. East

title: A Suddenly Convenient Truth
description: We would like to believe that the Bush administration has finally figured out how dangerous and counterproductive it is to hype intelligence  and that thats why officials are admitting theyre not sure North Korea ever got very far with a secret uranium-based nuclear program. But we doubt it.

title: 7 at a Baghdad Wedding Are Killed by a Car Bomb
description: BAGHDAD, March 1  A car bomb that was apparently aimed at a policemans wedding party in Falluja, west of Baghdad, killed seven guests on Thursday and wounded six, the local police said.

title: Bronx Election Workers Under Investigation
description: Investigators are pursuing a criminal inquiry into possible wrongdoing by employees of the New York City Board of Elections, board officials said yesterday.

title: Its Opening Day for Damons Bat
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 1  The record will show that the first Yankees swing in the first game of spring training produced a home run. Johnny Damon, the man who hit it, knew what that meant. Its only downhill from there, he said.

title: Dodger History Will Be Left on Base
description: Vero Beach, Fla.

title: Viacom Profit Up 271%, Helped by Studio Acquisition and Strong DVD Sales
description: Viacom said yesterday that fourth-quarter profit rose 271 percent, buoyed by the purchase of DreamWorks SKG and DVD sales of Over the Hedge.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Clem Labine, All-Star Reliever for Brooklyn Dodgers, Is Dead at 80
description: Clem Labine, an All-Star relief pitcher of the 1950s who helped bring the Brooklyn Dodgers four pennants and their only World Series championship, died today in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 80.

title: Proposed Increases in Fees for U.S. Residency and Citizenship Stir Protest in Newark
description: NEWARK, March 1  Chanting Stop the fee increase now in Spanish and carrying signs that read, Dont exclude us by raising prices, about 100 people rallied next to the United States Citizenship and Immigration Services office on Thursday to protest proposed fee increases for visa and citizenship applications.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Feb. 19 about the political aspirations of Muhammad Yunus, a Bangladesh banker who won the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize for his work in lending to the poor, misstated the date the photograph was taken. It was Feb. 12  not Feb. 18, the date he announced he was starting a new political party. In some copies, the caption misstated the site of Mr. Yunuss announcement. It was in Dhaka, Bangladesh  not Kolkata, India. (Kolkata is an alternate spelling of Calcutta).

title: House Panel Subpoenas 4 Prosecutors of 8 Ousted
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  A House Judiciary subcommittee voted Thursday to issue subpoenas requiring testimony from four of the eight United States attorneys recently dismissed by the Justice Department.

title: West Virginia: Ney Begins Prison Term
description: Former Representative Bob Ney, Republican of Ohio, the only lawmaker to plead guilty in the corruption investigation involving the lobbyist Jack Abramoff, has reported to a federal prison in Morgantown to begin a two-and-a-half-year term, the Justice Department said. The prison is a minimum-security institution that houses 1,300 inmates.

title: Caribbean to Screen Passports Using Interpol Global Database
description: All travelers to the Caribbean for the Cricket World Cup in March and April will have their passports checked against an international database of lost or stolen travel documents, making the islands the first region in the world to put such a system in operation.

title: Kerry Getting Some Payback for Swift Boat Campaign of 04
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  After having his name sullied during the 2004 presidential campaign by the opposition group Swift Boat Veterans for Truth, Senator John Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat, got the chance on Tuesday to sharply question Sam Fox, a major Republican donor who was recently nominated to be ambassador to Belgium, about his $50,000 contribution to the group.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Romney and Giuliani Make Pitch to Conservatives
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  They are both Republican presidential candidates who have been elected to office by largely Democratic electorates  Mitt Romney in Massachusetts and Rudolph W. Giuliani in New York City. They both have a history of taking liberal positions on social issues. And both are viewed warily by conservative Republicans who are integral to the partys nominating process.

title: Pension Fund as Tollkeeper: A Way Around the Skeptics
description: At first glance, directors of pension funds may seem ill equipped to run toll roads, particularly those as vast as the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway. After all, what do investment managers know about collecting tolls, plowing snow and paving highways?

title: Dells Profit Falls on Computer Sales
description: Dell said today that its fourth-quarter net profit fell 33.4 percent because computer sales flagged as it struggled with operational and accounting issues.

title: A Steadier Day for Stock Markets, but a Sense of Unease Lingers
description: What is bothering investors? No one thing in particular and yet everything.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: AN UNEXPECTED MINERAL BATH

title: How Quality of Intelligence Is Defined
description: High confidence generally indicates our judgments are based on high-quality information and/or the nature of the issue makes it possible to render a solid judgment.

title: Manhattan: No Rabies in Two Who Dropped Off Raccoon
description: A man and a woman urgently sought by city health officials on Wednesday came forward yesterday and indicated that they had not been exposed to rabies, which is invariably fatal if left untreated, city officials said. The two, who told city officials that they did not want to be identified, dropped off a sick raccoon at an animal shelter in East Harlem on Friday. They did not identify themselves then, and the animal later tested positive for rabies, city officials have said. Someone who knew the pair, who both work in the veterinary field, contacted city officials and identified them. The man wore gloves while handling the raccoon and the woman did not come into contact with the animal, according to a city doctor who interviewed them.

title: Whats on Friday
description: 8 P.M. (Fox) THE 38TH N.A.A.C.P. IMAGE AWARDS LL Cool J is host of this annual ceremony honoring people and projects that promote diversity in the arts, from television and film to music and literature. Soledad O'Brien will be honored with the President's Award, Bono will receive the N.A.A.C.P. Chairman's Award, and Bill Cosby will be inducted into the Image Awards Hall of Fame. Individual nominees range from America Ferrera of "Ugly Betty" and Isaiah Washington of "Grey's Anatomy" to the Academy Award-winning Forest Whitaker for "The Last King of Scotland" and Beyonc, Jennifer Hudson, Jamie Foxx and Eddie Murphy for "Dreamgirls." Nominated television films include "Tsunami: The Aftermath," "Life Is Not a Fairytale: The Fantasia Barrino Story" and Spike Lee's "When the Levees Broke: A Requiem in Four Acts." And "The Audacity of Hope: Thoughts on Reclaiming the American Dream" by Senator Barack Obama and Tavis Smiley's "Covenant With Black America" compete for best non-fiction read.

title: The Tangled Web of the Truth Machine
description: Its inventor called it the cardio-pneumo-psychograph. To a clutch of coeds in Berkeley, Calif., in 1921, it was a newfangled magic box that was somehow going to look into their minds and find out who was pilfering cash and jewelry at their college boardinghouse. To the newspaper-reading public and future generations, it was the lie detector, a contraption with dubious scientific credentials, a shady ethical aura and, as it turned out, amazing longevity.

title: Stargazing and Saguaros in the Sonoran Desert
description: AMONG sun-seeking families in Tucson, the state's second-largest city, holds a special fascination. The opportunity to play, dine and even view art outdoors appeals to families elsewhere cooped up by the cold. And its distinctly mild but rich style of Mexican food from the neighboring Sonora state across the border tempts tame young diners away from mac 'n' cheese.

title: The Path to Citizenship
description: On Wednesday, Congress took its first crack at immigration reform since the great nothing of 2006. The Senate Judiciary Committee invited Homeland Security Secretary Michael Chertoff and Commerce Secretary Carlos Gutierrez to testify on the issue. With a new Congress and a new comprehensive immigration bill expected to be introduced in the Senate within days, the hearing could have been the first spark of a rejuvenated campaign by an alliance of Congressional Democrats, moderate Republicans and the Bush administration to finally solve a problem that has festered for too long.

title: F.C.C. Rules That Rural Carriers Must Connect Internet Calls
description: WASHINGTON, March 1 (Dow Jones)  Rural telephone carriers must connect calls made by voice-over-Internet Protocol customers, the Federal Communications Commission ruled Thursday in a decision that marks the breaking down of one of the last barriers to allowing VoIP to fully compete with traditional phone carriers.

title: Canada: Inuit Say U.S. Emissions Violate Rights
description: Inuit from Canadas far north told the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights that greenhouse gases from the United States were ruining their way of life and that the consequent warming had led to having to install air- conditioners. The delegation also told the commission, based in Washington, that the American contribution to emissions, the most in the world, should be considered a human rights violation.

title: Can Lenders Suddenly Tighten Reins?
description: When a financing technique is abused, the government has a way of riding in with rules to stop the practice. Unfortunately, it often arrives far too late to prevent the damage, and just in time for its intervention to make things worse.

title: Bush Notes Frustration in Gulf Coast Recovery
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 1  President Bush acknowledged on Thursday that many Gulf Coast residents remained frustrated with the slowness of rebuilding after Hurricanes Katrina and Rita, but said, Times are changing for the better.

title: The Rats Will Not Win, Chief Varmint Hunter Vows
description: EVEN before the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene was mortified by the uninhibited late-night rat fiesta caught on videotape at a Greenwich Village KFC/Taco Bell last week and broadcast worldwide, Elliott Marcus, the bearish guy who runs the departments rodent patrol, harbored a special feeling for rats.

title: Poll Shows Bush Is Losing Support of Republicans
description: In the months since the Congressional elections, President Bush has lost substantial support among members of his own party, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Rhode Island: Shifting From Furloughs to Pay Cuts
description: Gov. Donald L. Carcieri has abandoned plans to keep state workers home for four days to help close the states budget gap. Instead, Mr. Carcieri, a Republican, says he wants to cut the salary of every state worker by 1 percent this fiscal year. He said he scrapped the plan for furlough days because directors of agencies he does not have direct authority over said their employees would not participate. Mr. Carcieri said the salary cuts would save the state $9.6 million this fiscal year and $7.7 million in the next, when state salaries will be trimmed by 0.75 percent. The plan would need a vote in the General Assembly. Rhode Island faces a two-year budget deficit of $350 million.

title: Latest Reports on Iran and North Korea Show a Newfound Caution Among Analysts
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  For more than three years, American intelligence officials have insisted that they learned from their mistakes in the months leading to the Iraq war, when murky information about Saddam Husseins weapons programs was presented as fact and inconclusive judgments were hardened into statements of near certainty.

title: U.S. Reviewing Safety of Childrens Cough Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Federal drug regulators have started a broad review of the safety of popular cough and cold remedies meant for children, a top official said Thursday.

title: Orchestral Movements: 99 Cents
description: When the New York Philharmonic announced last year that it was going to begin offering concerts as downloads, it was hard to tell how significant a move this would be. The Philharmonics initial, three-year contract with Deutsche Grammophon calls for four concerts to be recorded and released as downloads each season, as well as a fifth to be released both as a download and a conventional CD. A year later Zarin Mehta, the orchestras president and executive director, is blithely dissing that lone CD release.

title: Beyond Harry Potter and Happily Ever After
description: Eric Beckman does not own a restaurant, but if he did, his childrens menu would probably include some unusual choices: bouillabaisse, for instance. Or sashimi.

title: At Least Six Dead in Atlanta Bus Crash
description: ATLANTA, Mar. 2  A bus carrying a college baseball team plunged nearly 30 feet off an overpass in Atlanta early Friday morning, killing at least six people and injuring three more critically, emergency officials said.

title: Letter by Letter, Sacred Documents Are Reborn
description: Rabbi Zacharia Eisenbach dips his quill into a jar of black ink, then painstakingly restores each faded calligraphic letter. The quill makes a soft scratching sound as it travels slowly across the parchment. The work, intensely physical, straining the eyes and nerves, is precise and time-consuming.

title: Everything Crumbles Toward Eternities
description: Slow songs are anything but relaxed for Sparklehorse, which performed at Webster Hall on Wednesday night. Theyre tense dirges, burdened with sorrows and thoughts of mortality. Mark Linkous, Sparklehorses songwriter and singer, treats death as inevitable, while love is rare and tenuous. When Sparklehorse occasionally revs itself up to punk-rock speed, its less a release than an argument Mr. Linkous may be having with himself: Its not so hard, he sang, to trap the dead dogs of summer assaulting your slumber.

title: State Plan to Monitor Sex Offenders Goes Beyond Detention
description: ALBANY, March 1  New guidelines and procedures announced by Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders on Thursday for confining sex offenders who have completed prison sentences go well beyond detaining the most violent predators. The law, which would be one of the most far-reaching of its kind in the country, would also provide mental health treatment to inmates while they are jailed or confined and impose supervision and treatment after their release.

title: Off-Season Analysis: A.F.C.
description: A.F.C. East

title: The Other Iraq War Resolution (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly
description: McCartney Mum After Divorce Hearing

title: ABC News Wins in Sweeps Month
description: ABC News officially declared victory yesterday in the February sweeps competition among evening news shows, winning in the category of total viewers as well as the primary sales category for news programs: viewers between the ages of 25 and 54.

title: Musing on the Barenboim X-Factor
description: When the Philadelphia Orchestra announced its new artistic leadership scheme last week, at least one New Yorkers thoughts turned, paradoxically, to Daniel Barenboim and the New York Philharmonic. Charles Dutoit is to become the Philadelphia ensembles chief conductor, in typical European terminology, rather than music director, the typical American term, though it is not entirely clear how those distinctions will translate.

title: Vivendi Raises Stakes in Fight With Deutsche Telekom
description: Vivendi, the French media and entertainment company, says it has new ammunition in its long-running dispute with Deutsche Telekom over control of a Polish cellular company, escalating its effort to bring the case under American jurisdiction.

title: A Historians Valedictory
description: Arthur Schlesinger Jr. could be blunt. The worst he would say about George W. Bush in the early going was that he was an amiable mediocrity. But it did not take long for President Bush to fall close to the very bottom of Mr. Schlesingers not inconsiderable list of bad presidents  in large part because he had committed the one mistake that a great historian could not abide, which was to wantonly ignore the experience of history.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: Theater Listings
description: THICKER THAN WATER In Curt Dempsters 36 years at the helm of the Ensemble Studio Theater, he nurtured dozens of playwrights, started many careers and helped develop thousands of new plays. In January Mr. Dempster, the theaters artistic director, died at 71.

title: Deconstructing the Costs, and Emotions, of Warfare
description: William Forsythes new Three Atmospheric Studies hurtles headlong into violence, war and political doublespeak, territories seldom visited by dance in recent years. Thats probably just as well. The subjects are so huge and unruly, so difficult to process even when attended to from a safe distance, that their appropriation as dance themes seems foolhardy. Do you fill the stage with ketchup-smeared bodies? Or dispatch a looming, medal-covered general to swagger about?

title: Trying to Make Care Part of the Image of Hedge Funds
description: Standing in the brightly colored examination room on the Upper West Side of Manhattan last month, amid walls adorned with frolicking cartoon fish, Rob Davis was a far way from the fast-trading world of hedge funds.

title: Ertegun Service Today
description: A memorial service for Ahmet Ertegun, the co-founder of Atlantic Records, will take place today at 1 p.m. at the John L. Tishman Auditorium at the New School, 66 West 12th Street, between Fifth Avenue and Avenue of the Americas, Greenwich Village. Mr. Ertegun died on Dec. 14 at the age of 83.

title: Francis, Still Hobbled, Will Give It Another Try
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 1  Steve Francis said Monday that he was uncertain whether he would play again this season because of a right knee injury. But he practiced Thursday and said he expected to play against the Golden State Warriors on Friday.

title: Now, a CD Called Plagiarism in B Flat (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Shootout, Two Stars, One Goal
description: When Jaromir Jagr of the Rangers took the ice for the shootout last night at Madison Square Garden, the crowd turned its howling up a notch as it greeted its shootout-shy star.

title: 2 Iraqi Soccer Players Killed in Front of Crowd
description: BAGHDAD, Mar. 2  Two soccer players were murdered in front of their teammates in Ramadi, witnesses said, and a group of Interior Ministry employees were abducted in Diyala province as brutal sectarian violence continued to rage across much of Iraq.

title: Once Again, Nortel Says It Must Restate Its Financial Results
description: OTTAWA, March 1  Nortel Networks said Thursday that it would have to restate its results for the fourth time in four years, a move that will delay the filing of its 2006 annual report.

title: From Romantic to Folkloric, With Heart
description: A familiar traffic pattern in the concert world begins with music managers in New York sending out bright performers in all directions to play in smaller, less dense musical centers. Sometimes those centers return the favor. Lydia Artymiw, who played at Weill Recital Hall on Wednesday night, teaches piano at the University of Minnesota School of Music in Minneapolis. After a career of nearly 30 years, Ms. Artymiw has a reputation, but New York does not have that many opportunities to match name to face.

title: More Than Just Two Ex-Cowboys
description: DALLAS, March 1 (AP)  Ron Springs and Everson Walls will always share a bond forged over their years as teammates on the Dallas Cowboys. Thats nothing compared to their newest link  the kidney Walls donated to Springs.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about home health care aides misstated the amount of long-term care insurance benefits paid in 2006 and misstated the name of the organization that provided the figure. The benefits totaled $3.3 billion, not $63.3 billion. The organization was the Association for  not of  Long-Term Care Insurance.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Feb. 23 through Feb. 27 with 1,281 adults throughout the United States.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Federal Requirement for Tamper-Proof Licenses Will Raise Fees for Drivers by 2013
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Nearly 240 million Americans and legal residents will have to spend an estimated $20 more for a standardized and tamper-proof drivers license by 2013 to comply with a proposed new federal rule issued Thursday.

title: A Kvetch de Coeur From the Abyss of Middle Age
description: An acute moment of self-diagnosis occurs toward the end of the otherwise insight-starved Howard Katz, the comedy of unhappiness by Patrick Marber that opened last night at the Laura Pels Theater. The title character, a dispossessed talent agent played with a baleful mien by Alfred Molina, is seated on a park bench with a do-it-yourself death kit: a giant bottle of pills, whiskey, a razor.

title: Victor in City Council Race Dismisses Residency Issue
description: With the smell of simmering fish stew coming from the kitchen, Mathieu Eugene stood in the living room of his new two-bedroom apartment in the heart of the 40th Council District, insisting that he had signed a lease, moved in and made the place his home long before his election to the City Council.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Weekend last Friday with an article about the films that won Oscar nominations for best documentary feature carried an incomplete credit. The photograph, showing a scene from one of the films, Iraq in Fragments, was also from HBO Documentary, not just from Typecast Releasing.

title: Google Courts Small YouTube Deals, and Very Soon, a Larger One
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1  Google has been frustrated in its efforts to reach comprehensive deals with major studios and networks to put their video on YouTube. But in the meantime, it is forming partnerships with hundreds of smaller media companies that see value  or at least a valuable experiment  in contributing to the site.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: A Great Weekend Needs More Than Snow at Okemo
description: OUR caravan to the mountains moved together, but inside the passengers were very different. In one car there were a snowboarder, a novice skier and an intermediate skier. On the rack atop the other car there were three sets of expert racing skis and one pair of freestyle skiboards. One car had children of like age, the other car had children ranging from age 8 to 15. One family had been to the destination many times, the other had never seen the place.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Yonkers: Woman Charged in Crash That Killed Her Mother
description: A Yonkers woman was charged yesterday in connection with a crash on the New York Thruway last October in which her mother died, prosecutors said. The woman, Mercedes Cha, 42, of Vernon Avenue, was charged with vehicular manslaughter and driving while intoxicated, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Ms. DiFiore said Ms. Cha was driving home from her birthday party about 2:40 a.m. on Oct. 5 when she smashed into a barrier dividing an exit ramp from the Thruway near Exit 2. The crash killed her mother, Dilsa Brown, 61, who was her sole passenger, Ms. DiFiore said.

title: Missouri: More Charges in Kidnapping Case
description: Michael Devlin, who is accused of kidnapping two boys and holding one of them hostage for nearly four years, has been indicted in federal court on four counts of producing child pornography and two counts of transporting a minor for a criminal sex act, officials said. Mr. Devlin, 41, has already pleaded not guilty to charges in three Missouri counties in the abduction of William Ownby, 13, on Jan. 8, and Shawn Hornbeck, 15, in 2002, when he was 11.

title: Tax Policy Decreed by Merry Men in Tights
description: Trying to define the politics of Robin Hood, reformer of Sherwood Forest, in terms of contemporary classifications seems a bit like trying to figure out whether Aristophanes was funny like Woody Allen or funny like Carol Burnett. It is a rather pointless exercise, but potentially quite fun nevertheless. What makes Robin Hood, a new series on BBC America beginning tomorrow night, amount to such a good time is that it effortlessly prompts you to try.

title: Navy Chaplain Is Discharged
description: Lt. Gordon J. Klingenschmitt, a Navy chaplain, has lost a three-year battle to stay in the chaplain corps after superiors warned him about delivering sectarian Christian prayers and sermons at a sailors memorial service and other events attended by religiously diverse audiences. Lieutenant Klingenschmitt, who spent 16 years in the military, became a hero to religious conservatives, but was court-martialed last year for wearing his uniform at a political protest in front of the White House. He received an honorable discharge.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the challenges of creating small-scale desktop fusion devices misstated the year that a large reactor in southern France, known as ITER, might begin operating. ITER could be ready by 2016; it is not expected to take until around 2025. The article also misstated one source of financing for Eric J. Lerner, the president of Lawrenceville Plasma Physics, an alternative fusion company. While he has indeed received financing from NASA, he has not received any from the Air Force.

title: Visions That Flaunt Cartoon Pedigrees
description: The trouble with too many museum theme shows is that they begin with a viable idea and, through lack of institutional commitment, curatorial imagination or old-fashioned connoisseurship, fail to fulfill their promise.

title: A House With History
description: WHO Cliff Williams, 53, a musician from Williamsburg, Va.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Feb. 19 about the political aspirations of Muhammad Yunus, a Bangladesh banker who won the 2006 Nobel Peace Prize for his work in lending to the poor, misstated the date the photograph was taken. It was Feb. 12  not Feb. 18, the date he announced he was starting a new political party. In some copies, the caption misstated the site of Mr. Yunuss announcement. It was in Dhaka, Bangladesh  not Kolkata, India. (Kolkata is an alternate spelling of Calcutta). (Go to Article)

title: Dell Posts Sharp Declines in Earnings and Revenue
description: Dells inability to capture sales in the booming notebook computer market was reflected yesterday in its fourth-quarter financial results, which showed a sharp decline in income as well as an unusual drop in revenue.

title: Housing Official Says Door Is Closed on Starrett City Deal
description: The federal housing secretary has rejected the proposed $1.3 billion sale of Starrett City, a working-class enclave of 46 apartment buildings in Brooklyn, because the prospective buyer has failed to supply adequate financial information or a plan for how the complex would remain a viable community for New Yorkers of modest means.

title: Putin Picks Premier Tied to Abuse as Chechen Leader
description: MOSCOW, March 1  President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Thursday appointed Ramzan A. Kadyrov, a widely feared young official whose security forces have been accused of kidnappings, torture and other abuses, to be president of Chechnya, the battered southern republic.

title: House Passes Bill That Helps Unions Organize
description: Defying a veto threat from the White House, the House of Representatives yesterday approved legislation that would make it far easier for unions to organize workers.

title: Related Venues
description: Jamestown Settlement, operated by the Jamestown-Yorktown Foundation, includes outdoor living history demonstrations, an exhibition hall and a new visitors center. It is open daily 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. (until 6 p.m. June 15 through Aug. 15) and is closed Christmas and New Years Day. Admission is $13.50; $6.25 for 6- to 12-year-olds; free for those under 6; historyisfun.org.

title: Columbine High Is Evacuated After Threats
description: LITTLETON, Colo., March 1  Nearly eight years after it was the scene of the deadliest school shooting in United States history, the police evacuated Columbine High School on Thursday morning near here after someone called in bomb threats.

title: Broadway Tries to Turn Singles Into Two on the Aisle
description: On Wednesday evening the League of American Theaters and Producers presented the first Singles Night on Broadway. Not everyone immediately got the point.

title: Ground Zero Victims
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg has finally joined the urgent campaign to get Washington to care for the responders who helped New Yorkers after the Sept. 11 attacks. Many responders  and people who studied, lived or worked around the World Trade Center  are seriously ill, and Mr. Bloomberg can play an important role in making the federal government take responsibility for them.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,153 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Greenspan Is Still Able to Move Markets
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  They are marketed as intimate conversations with Alan Greenspan, and groups pay about $150,000 to hear his economic outlook.

title: 13 More Fast Food Restaurants Are Shut Down After Rat Video
description: After a round of inspections, the citys health department has shut down three Pizza Hut restaurants operated by the same franchisee that owns the KFC/Taco Bell in Greenwich Village that became infamous when television cameras captured a swarm of rats scampering inside.

title: New Jersey Clinic Is Closed, a Month After a Woman Who Had an Abortion There Fell Ill
description: NEWARK, March 1  A New Jersey abortion clinic was shut down last weekend, nearly a month after a woman who had an abortion there became ill and fell unconscious, the woman and the authorities said yesterday.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: How Will Selig Sell the Extra Innings Deal to Fans?
description: Earlier this week, it looked as if Major League Baseballs ever-pending deal that would move the Extra Innings package of out-of-market games exclusively to DirecTV might be announced today. That is no longer likely. It may happen Monday, next month or by the All-Star Game break.

title: Russia: Labor Agreement at Ford
description: Ford Motor Company signed a collective bargaining agreement with the union representing its Russian employees, averting a strike in a country that has been a bright spot for the automaker. Sales in Russia are booming; Ford made 60,000 Focus cars in Russia last year and plans to produce 75,000 this year. The company agreed to raise wages 14 percent to 20 percent and to guarantee that jobs will not be lost in outsourcing to subcontractors, according to Aleksei V. Etmanov, the union president.

title: HUD Blocks Proposed Sale of Starrett City
description: The federal housing secretary has rejected the proposed $1.3 billion sale of Starrett City, a working-class enclave of 46 apartment buildings in Brooklyn, because the prospective buyer has failed to supply adequate financial information or a plan for how the complex would remain a viable community for New Yorkers of modest means.

title: Japan: Inflation Slowed as Spending Climbed
description: The minister of economic and fiscal policy, Hiroko Ota, said there had been little change in price trends in January, after a report showed inflation slowed to zero percent for the first time since May. Prices continue to be flat, Ms. Ota said. Core consumer prices, which exclude fresh food, were unchanged from a year earlier, matching the median estimate of economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. Household spending climbed 0.6 percent in January, the statistics bureau said, the first increase since December 2005. Economists expected a 0.3 percent drop. The jobless rate was 4 percent, unchanged after the previous months figure was revised from 4.1 percent, the agency said.

title: New York Law Firms Struggle With New Restrictions on Advertising
description: New New York State rules that restrict advertising for lawyers have created headaches for a number of big corporate law firms that are based or have offices in the state.

title: Libya Gingerly Begins Seeking Economic but Not Political Reform
description: TRIPOLI, Libya, March 1  For more than three decades, Libya has been an experiment in one mans ideology. The result is a country with few functioning institutions, an unreliable legal system, inadequate schools and hospitals, and a population isolated and unprepared for modernity.

title: Even in a Song Contest, Controversy Over the Israeli Entry
description: JERUSALEM, March 2 - The Eurovision Song Contest, an annual event that proves that European popular culture can take itself just as seriously as the American variety, has created a semi-scandal of its own, with the suggestion on Thursday that the contest might ban this years Israeli entry, Push the Button, because of a supposedly inappropriate political message.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Friday about a game called Catch the Illegal Immigrant, staged by a student Republican group at New York University, that drew more protesters than players misspelled the surname of one protester. She is Dalia Yedidia, not Yedida.

title: Mendelssohn, Sibelius, Tchaikovsky at the Party
description: Composers have worked out ways to stretch the celebrations of their milestone birthdays over two seasons, and now it seems that conductors are taking modest steps in that direction too. Kurt Masur turns 80 in July, but since he is here to conduct the New York Philharmonic, the orchestra celebrated his birthday with a party after his concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday evening. The party was also a fund-raiser for the International Mendelssohn Foundation, in Leipzig, Germany, of which Mr. Masur is the president.

title: Marleys Ghost to Welcome Fans for Cricket World Cup
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica  At Bob Marleys old home in Trench Town, a rough part of this capital city that is far off the tourist route, Benjamin Cole sits in the shade and waits.

title: Imagine More Hope, All Ye Who Enter Here
description: Particularly in the Heartland, a new ensemble piece showing at Performance Space 122, is a rambling mess of feeling  about the divided American soul, the reverie of theocrats, the lost heart of real liberalism  and a play that desperately wants its audience to go home chewing, even as it fails to offer any meat.

title: Google Courts Small YouTube Deals
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 1  Google has been frustrated in its efforts to reach comprehensive deals with major studios and networks to put their video on YouTube. Meanwhile, it is forming partnerships with hundreds of smaller media companies that see value  or at least a valuable experiment  in contributing to the site.

title: Police Officers Badge Deflected a Knife Thrust, the Authorities Say
description: An intoxicated man lunged at a rookie police officer with a kitchen knife yesterday afternoon, only to have the knife shatter into five pieces as it struck the officers badge, the police said. The officer, Stuart Ingram, 22, was uninjured, and the shield, worn on the left side of his chest, was undamaged.

title: Deloitte Nominates New Chief Executive
description: Deloitte Touche Tohmatsus board nominated James. H. Quigley, head of its United States businesses, yesterday to succeed its chief executive, William G. Parrett, who will step down in May.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: 13 Charged  in Insider Trading Ring
description: Thirteen people were accused today of taking part in a major insider trading ring, including a Morgan Stanley compliance official, a UBS research executive and traders for hedge funds and brokerage firms.

title: Sony to Pay in Patent Dispute
description: The Sony Corporation, the consumer-electronics maker, agreed to pay the Immersion Corporation, a software developer, $150.3 million to end a patent dispute over technology used in the Sony PlayStation video-game console.

title: Away From Home, TV Ads Are Inescapable
description: AS if Americans do not already watch enough television, there are digital TV networks popping up on screens in groceries, office buildings, retail stores, on gas pumps, and just about every place imaginable.

title: Hunting a Killer as the Age of Aquarius Dies
description: David Finchers magnificently obsessive new film, Zodiac, tracks the story of the serial killer who left dead bodies up and down California in the 1960s and possibly the 70s, and that of the men who tried to stop him. Set when the Age of Aquarius disappeared into the black hole of the Manson family murders, the film is at once sprawling and tightly constructed, opaque and meticulously detailed. Its part police procedural, part monster movie, a funereal entertainment that is an unexpected repudiation of Mr. Finchers most famous movie, the serial-killer fiction Seven, as well as a testament to this cinematic savants gifts.

title: Manhattan: Pharmacist Charged With Defrauding Medicaid
description: A Manhattan pharmacist was charged yesterday with defrauding Medicaid of at least $1.2 million by collecting reimbursement for prescriptions that he never filled, prosecutors said. The pharmacist, Dinesh Dayabhai Shah, the owner of MLK Pharmacy in Manhattanville, was charged in Federal District Court with health care fraud, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Over the past four years, Mr. Shah and two employees bought prescriptions from Medicaid recipients for amounts less than the value of the drugs, Mr. Garcia said. He said they submitted the prescriptions to Medicaid for reimbursement and pocketed the difference.

title: Texas: Scandal Shakes Up Youth Agency
description: Battered by charges that it covered up the sexual abuse of incarcerated juveniles, the Texas Youth Commission named a new acting executive director to replace the official who retired abruptly last week, Dwight Harris, and an initial acting director, Neil Nichols. The new acting director, Edward Glenn Owens, deputy executive director of the Texas Department of Criminal Justice, was selected at the recommendation of Gov. Rick Perry at an emergency meeting by teleconference. The commissions chairman, Pete C. Alfaro, who was removed by the governor in favor of the vice chairman, announced that he would leave the board altogether. Charges that two supervisors at the West Texas State School had sexual contact with youths there and were allowed to resign without charges are under new investigation.

title: People
description: People

title: Herman Brix, 100, Athlete and a Cultured Tarzan, Dies
description: Herman Brix, who played football in the Rose Bowl, set world shot-put records and portrayed Tarzan in the movies before becoming a dapper Hollywood leading man, died on Saturday in Los Angeles.

title: Losing Their Buzz
description: Urbana, Ill.

title: Its Not Only About Price at Wal-Mart
description: For 44 years, Wal-Marts message was Low prices, always.

title: A Mix of the Old and New West in the Rugged Rockies
description: RIDGWAY, which sits hard up against the San Juans, the most rugged of Colorados mountain ranges, used to be a place you just passed through on your way to the ski slopes of Telluride, a 45-minute drive away. Ridgway still serves as a portal to Colorados southwest corner, but it has recently had a serious growth spurt, attracting young families priced out of Telluride as well as urban refugees and second-home buyers seduced by the gorgeous scenery, rural setting and smorgasbord of recreational options.

title: German Phone Company Reports a Loss
description: FRANKFURT, March 1  Deutsche Telekom posted a fourth-quarter loss of nearly 900 million euros ($1.18 billion) on Thursday as it lost customers in its home market, prompting the company to look abroad for growth.

title: Three Kings Named Louis, Born With Gilded Spoons
description: Who knew Georgians were such Francophiles?

title: Exploring Identity as a Problematic Condition
description: Lorna Simpson, whose refined and impassioned work is the subject of a 20-year retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art, began her career with an intense interest in socially engaged street photography in the Roy DeCarava mode. Then she did something unexpected to that genre. And then she did something else to it.

title: Secretary of Army Resigns in Controversy
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  The Secretary of the Army, Francis J. Harvey, resigned today amid the fallout over revelations of shabby conditions at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center, once considered the very symbol of fine medical care for military men and women.

title: Masur Approaching 80: Raising the Baton for a New Movement of Life
description: HARRISON, N.Y., Feb. 26  In 1997 the New York Philharmonic gave an elaborate surprise party at Avery Fisher Hall for Kurt Masur, then its music director, celebrating what he called a birthday I tried so hard to ignore, his 70th. As Mr. Masur, who commands the Philharmonic podium as conductor emeritus this weekend, approaches his 80th birthday in July, it seems clear that his trepidation was warranted. His 70s were not entirely kind.

title: A Remote Heart Monitor Fails to Impress an F.D.A. Panel
description: Medicines march toward remote monitoring of patients hit at least a temporary roadblock yesterday.

title: With Top-Selling Silverado, G.M. Sales Defied Trend and Rose for Month
description: DETROIT, March 1  General Motors surprised the auto industry Thursday by posting strong sales in February, when its new Chevrolet Silverado pickup unseated the Ford F-series for the title of best-selling vehicle.

title: 13 Are Accused of Trading as Insiders
description: It started in 2001 with two old friends meeting at the Oyster Bar in the basement of Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan, discussing a $25,000 debt.

title: With Salary Cap Higher, Free Agents Could Cash In
description: When the National Football Leagues free-agent signing period begins, Todd France has a basic rule. Never stray far from a cellphone.

title: Trial Opens in Case of Convicted Sex Offender Accused in Murder of 9-Year-Old Florida Girl
description: MIAMI, March 1  The drifter charged with raping and burying alive a 9-year-old girl on Floridas west coast in 2005 went to trial here Thursday, after intense publicity forced the case to be moved 300 miles from where the child, Jessica Lunsford, was murdered.

title: California Enjoys Electoral Muscle
description: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 28  In the last few weeks, Rudolph W. Giuliani surveyed tractors in rural California, Senator Barack Obama delivered his hope speech to enthusiastic Angelenos and Senator John McCain made earnest remarks about global warming while standing at the side of Californias governor.

title: Smyth Makes Debut, but Cant Rescue Isles
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 1  Ryan Smyth stood alone on the blue line, separated from his new teammates, looking every bit the part of the new kid at school. The Nassau Coliseum lights dimmed but for a spotlight that shined on Smyth, and an energized crowd rose and offered a pregame welcome.

title: Iran and Saudis Plan Summit Talks on Crises
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, March 1  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran will visit Saudi Arabia on Saturday for a summit meeting with King Abdullah intended to tackle the Middle Easts growing sectarian and political crises, Iranian officials said Thursday.

title: South Koreas Main Chinatown Lacks Only the Chinese
description: INCHON, South Korea  All was quiet in South Koreas nonbustling Chinatown on a recent weekday. The lunchtime trickle was over, leaving the streets as deserted as they had been in the morning. The shiny arches, red lanterns and towering Welcome to Chinatown sign, meant to impress visitors, seemed instead to magnify the neighborhoods inactivity.

title: White Plains: Charges in Fatal Westchester Crash
description: A Bronx woman has been charged in connection with a collision that killed a man on the Sprain Brook Parkway last October, prosecutors said. The woman, Lisa Shipp, 45, was charged with second-degree manslaughter and driving while intoxicated, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Ms. DiFiore said Ms. Shipp was northbound on the parkway about 5:50 p.m. on Oct. 12 when her car bumped into a vehicle driven by Reggie Beckford. Mr. Beckford lost control, and went down an embankment and into a tree. He was killed on impact. Ms. Shipp continued driving, and when she was stopped by the police in Greenburgh, an open bottle of vodka was found in the car, Ms. DiFiore said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An art review yesterday about a Tintoretto exhibition at the Prado in Madrid misstated the number of paintings in it. There are more than four dozen, not around three dozen. The review also referred incorrectly to a necklace of pearls scattered in a painting depicting Lucretia struggling against Tarquin. It symbolizes Lucretias lost chastity, not virginity.

title: Europeans Threaten More Fines for Microsoft
description: LONDON, March 1  The European Commission on Thursday threatened Microsoft with millions of euros in new fines in a long-running antitrust dispute, saying the company was demanding unreasonable royalties from rivals seeking to link their software to the Windows operating system.

title: Hindsight, the Knicks and Nelsons Foresight
description: Close your eyes. Take a deep breath. Let your mind wander back to March 8, 1996, the day the Knicks cast Don Nelson out as an eccentric coach and a burnout case.

title: Wendys Acts to Bypass City Order on Calories
description: Wendys International pulled nutrition posters with calorie information from its New York City locations yesterday in an effort to free itself from a city regulation requiring some restaurants to provide calorie data on menus and menu boards.

title: OHara Agrees to Stay With Giants
description: Just hours before he could have become an unrestricted free agent, Giants center Shaun OHara agreed to a multi-year contract with the team, a Giants official said Thursday night.

title: A Date With Destiny
description: CHRISTMAS. New Years Eve. Spring break. There are certain dates on the calendar when travelers know that hotel rooms in prime vacation spots will be nearly impossible to come by, even if they try to book months in advance.

title: They Say Pitchers Cant Hit, but Ankiel Is No Longer a Pitcher
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 1  He looked and dressed the part of a professional hitter, tall and lanky with sunglasses perched atop the bill of his red St. Louis Cardinals cap. The only sign of Rick Ankiels previous baseball incarnation as a pitcher came when he shagged flies in right field Thursday morning and whistled the ball into second base.

title: Captain Smith, the Tides Are Shifting on the James
description: JAMESTOWN, Va.  At the banks of the James River here, not far from where an archaeological dig has found pottery shards and remains of settlers from 400 years ago, a proud Capt. John Smith faces the waters and the setting sun. A wooden stockade extends near the shoreline  the water has moved inland over the centuries  showing where his frail fort once stood. But Smith stands heroically tall, his bronze cape seeming to ripple in the brisk winter winds. Even the inscription proclaims his importance: Governor of Virginia, 1608.

title: Bobby Rosengarden, 82, Dick Cavett Show Bandleader, Dies
description: Bobby Rosengarden, a jazz drummer who worked with musicians from Igor Stravinsky to Jimi Hendrix but became best known for making musical wisecracks as the bandleader on The Dick Cavett Show, died Tuesday in Sarasota, Fla. He was 82.

title: Veteran Care to Be Reviewed After Firing of General
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  President Bush has ordered a top-to-bottom investigation into the medical care available to returning veterans, the White House said today, a day after the firing of the two-star general in charge of Walter Reed Army Medical Center over shabby conditions there.

title: Percival Leach, 80, Savior of a Crumbling Village, Dies
description: Percival Leach, who helped turn a ramshackle collection of pre-Revolutionary and mid-19th-century buildings along an old industrial canal in northern New Jersey into Waterloo Village, a version of Colonial Williamsburg, died on Monday in Hackettstown, N.J. He was 80 and lived in a restored home just outside Waterloo Village, in Stanhope.

title: Hitting the Road for Some Hot Man-on-Bike Action
description: The Four Little Piggies  Wild Hogs, the real title, doesnt work as well  is a comedy about male midlife anxiety. Some of us may not find the subject so funny, but never mind. Somebody needed to revive the City Slickers formula, and this time the job has gone to Brad Copeland, who wrote the screenplay, and Walt Becker, who directed.

title: Senegals President Elected to 2nd Term by Wide Edge
description: DAKAR, Senegal, March 1  President Abdoulaye Wade easily won a second term, electoral officials in Senegal announced Thursday, beating his 14 opponents in the first round of voting with nearly 56 percent of the 3.4 million votes cast in Sundays election.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the eviction at DePauw University of members of the Delta Zeta sorority by the national organization referred incorrectly to a woman identified only as a black member of the sorority. Although the woman, Leah Souder, was not in fact one of 35 sorority members interviewed by the national organization, nor was she among the 23 of those 35 who received eviction letters, she says she has not heard from the national office since its reorganization of the DePauw chapter and assumes she is no longer a member.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Senators Regret Remarks on Troops
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  They come from different parties and have opposite views on what should be done in Iraq. But both Senator John McCain and Senator Barack Obama have now had to express regret for saying that American lives have been wasted in battle.

title: Beyond College Brands (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Boomlet for Al Gore (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Smile and Say Peanut Butter, Mona Lisa
description: Artists are generally not subjected to the focus groups and market research imposed on films and advertising. Yet if they were, one who would score high in the demographics category is the Brazilian-born, New York-based artist Vik Muniz.

title: After Swoon, Thrashers Make Push for Playoffs
description: ATLANTA, March 1  Some fans sat slumped in their seats and others shook their heads in disgust. Some offered final boos as the Atlanta Thrashers trudged down a tunnel to the locker room after another loss.

title: Lessons in Surviving a Mothers Dying Days
description: In the deathbed drama Two Weeks, Sally Field creates an agonizing portrait of Anita Bergman, a middle-aged American everywoman in the final stages of ovarian cancer. As her four children and their families descend on the home in North Carolina that she shares with her second husband, Jim (James Murtaugh), the movie squarely confronts the physical realities of dying.

title: Widespread Storms Cause Deaths in 3 States
description: ATLANTA, March 2  A violent storm system that stretched nearly 1,000 miles from the Midwest to the Southeast has killed at least 20 people in three states, including 8 who died when what appeared to be a tornado caused the roof to collapse at a high school in Enterprise, Ala. on Thursday, state emergency management officials said.

title: Killing Highlights Risk of Selling Marijuana, Even Legally
description: DENVER, March 1  Ken Gorman, an aging missionary of marijuana, was found murdered in his home here two weeks ago. The unsolved crime is exposing the tangled threads at the borderland of the legal and illegal drug worlds he inhabited.

title: Libby Verdict Said to Be Unlikely This Week
description: Jurors in the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. seem unlikely to reach a verdict this week and will be allowed to end deliberations at 2 p.m. today to attend to personal matters, Judge Reggie B. Walton said. The judge said he realized that there would be no verdict yesterday, the seventh day of deliberations, because jurors did not dress for such an occasion. Six of the 11 jurors wore blue jeans.

title: Miami Sound Machines
description: FOR serious club-music fans, a night on the town can sometimes feel like a job. Assignment: Scout out the top venues and D.J.'s in the city and be sure to hit them all before sunrise.

title: Oracle Acquires Hyperion Solutions
description: Oracle announced a deal today to acquire Hyperion Solutions, which makes software that allows corporations to analyze and track their performance, for about $3.3 billion.

title: McCain and Obama in Deal on Public Financing
