description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Senator John McCain joined Senator Barack Obama on Thursday in promising to accept a novel fund-raising truce if each man wins his partys presidential nomination.

title: Florida Panel Urges Steps for Painless Executions
description: A commission appointed after a botched execution in Florida recommended yesterday that the state take steps to ensure that condemned inmates have been completely sedated before injecting them with two potentially painful lethal chemicals.

title: Man Is Convicted of Attempted Murder as Hate Crime in Village Rampage
description: An unemployed barber who went on a shooting rampage in an East Village wine bar more than four years ago, screaming, White people are going to burn tonight, was convicted yesterday of attempted murder as a hate crime.

title: China: Growth Creates Migrant Underclass
description: Although the estimated 200 million urban migrant workers in China have fueled the countrys rapid economic growth, they continue to suffer abuse and discrimination, and the authorities should do more to ensure that they were properly paid and provided with essential services, Amnesty International said in a report. Terming the migrants a growing urban underclass, the report said they were routinely exploited, lived in dire conditions and were denied health care and other services because they were ineligible for residence permits in the cities where they worked.

title: Senate Democrats Vow to Confront Bush on Iraq but Are Still Working Out the Details
description: WASHINGTON, March 1  Senate Democrats tried Thursday to bridge their political differences over how to confront President Bush on Iraq even as they acknowledged that agreement on an approach remained out of reach.

title: Threat of Congress Shadows Mitchells Steroids Inquiry
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.

title: Abe Rejects Japans Files on War Sex
description: TOKYO, March 1  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe denied Thursday that Japans military had forced foreign women into sexual slavery during World War II, contradicting the Japanese governments longtime official position.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Aric Ackerman joined the L.A. Studios, Hollywood, Calif., as chief executive. He succeeds Jesse Meli, who becomes president emeritus, the company said, consulting on business development opportunities. Mr. Ackerman had been chief operating officer at @radical Media, New York.

title: The Apologetic Pop Star, Still Trying to Claim the Blues
description: At Madison Square Garden on Wednesday night John Mayer never mentioned his girlfriend, Jessica Simpson. But he did talk about dating. He said his least favorite blind dates were the ones on which he had to listen to a woman explain how nice she was. So he introduced the next song as a corrective. Its message, he said, was, Im the kind of person that would do you wrong. This did not, you can imagine, quiet the screaming crowd.

title: Genteel Enclave Puzzles Over Reports of a Dominatrix
description: BEDFORD, N.Y., March 1  Apart from the phalanx of reporters and photographers, the only hint that something was a little odd about the charming old clapboard farmhouse on Haines Road was the black cloth hanging across the second-floor windows, blotting out the sun filtering down through lofty pines.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about an effort to grant honorary American citizenship to Anne Frank referred incorrectly to the Long Island community of Sayville, the home of Christopher Bodkin, the man spearheading the campaign. Sayville does in fact have a synagogue; it is at the Sayville Jewish Community Center.

title: August Raid Drove Inquiry Into Web Sale of Steroids
description: ALBANY, March 1  A federal raid on an Alabama pharmacy company last summer was the opening salvo in a multistate investigation now being conducted by New York authorities into possible illegal Internet sales of steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the 400th anniversary of the premiere of Monteverdi's opera "L'Orfeo" and the origins and future of opera referred incorrectly to a new ticket plan at the Metropolitan Opera introduced by Peter Gelb, the general manager, who attended a recent conference in Paris on opera's place in the 21st century. The plan offers reduced-price tickets to the general public on Mondays through Thursdays, not on weekends. (The Met continues to offer reduced-price tickets to students for all performances, when available.)

title: Americas Idols
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Rudy Giuliani's Children
description: As he embarks on a campaign for the presidency, Rudolph W. Giuliani is going forward without two people who once played important roles in his political life: his children, Andrew and Caroline.

title: Pulse
description: This spring, the sleeves have it.

title: New York Law Firms Struggle With New Restrictions on Advertising
description: Recent New York State rules that restrict advertising for lawyers have created headaches for a number of big corporate law firms that are based or have offices in the state. The rule change, which took effect on Feb. 1, comes from a committee of judges in New Yorks appellate division who are charged with writing the ethical rules governing the states lawyers.

title: As Regulators Look Deeper into Sony BMG, Warner and EMI Watch from the Sidelines
description: Antitrust regulators in Europe said Thursday that they would take a deeper look into the merger of the music units of Sony and BMG, as part of a second review of a union that created the second-largest record company and provoked stiff opposition from independent music publishers.

title: HUD Blocks Proposed Sale of Starrett City
description: The federal housing secretary has rejected the proposed $1.3 billion sale of Starrett City, a working-class enclave of 46 apartment buildings in Brooklyn, because the prospective buyer has failed to supply adequate financial information or a plan for how the complex would remain a viable community for New Yorkers of modest means.

title: Once Again, Nortel Says It Must Restate Its Financial Results
description: Nortel Networks said Thursday that it would have to restate its results for the fourth time in four years, a move that will delay the filing of its 2006 annual report. The latest restatement involves results from 2004, 2005 and the first nine months of 2006. The company said that the restatements were necessary to correct mistakes in recording income and because errors by an outside actuary firm caused pension liabilities to be misstated by $104 million over several years.

title: Australian Banks See 2007 Through Rose Colored Glasses
description: Two Australian banks on Friday expressed optimism about market conditions in the country, and forecast strong revenue and profit growth for 2007. Australias Macquarie Bank said it expects profit for the fiscal year through March to rise at least 50 percent. The investment bank, which less than a month ago predicted second-half profits would decline from the first-half, now expects second-half earnings to be better than the 638 million Australian dollars ($502 million) it earned in the first-half

title: Europeans Threaten More Fines for Microsoft
description: The European Commission on Thursday threatened Microsoft with millions of euros in new fines in a long-running antitrust dispute, saying the company was demanding unreasonable royalties from rivals seeking to link their software to the Windows operating system. The commission issued a statement of objections, asking Microsoft to respond to a complaint that it was still not complying with a decision three years ago that the company had abused its dominant market position.

title: Treasury Official to Resign
description: Emil W. Henry Jr., a former senior partner of Gleacher Partners, said Thursday he would resign as Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for Financial Institutions. He has held the position since October 2005. In a letter announcing his resignation, he said he was seeking to spend more time with his family in New York. While at Gleacher Partners, Mr. Henry oversaw the firms investment activities which included private equity and hedge-fund pools.

title: S.E.C. Takes Issue With Google Tax Accounting
description: Google disclosed in its 2006 annual report on Thursday that the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission nearly a year ago had called into question how it accounted for income taxes. In the annual filing, Google said it received a letter from the S.E.C. in March 2006 on various issues and subsequently corresponded with the agency as recently as January 2007. The tax dispute remains unresolved.

title: Banker to Form Venture With Leucadia
description: Frederic M. Seegal, who was president of investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein and its predecessors from 1994 to 2001, said he has left investment bank Stephens, where he was an executive vice president. In a note to colleagues, he said he will be forming Seegal Benson Leucadia Partners, a merchant banking firm that will affiliated with Leucadia National.

title: Citigroups C.F.O. Could Collect $10 Million for 2007
description: Citigroups new chief financial officer, Gary Crittenden, may be paid close to $10 million this year, including as much as $9.5 million in incentive awards, the company said on Thursday. Mr. Crittenden will receive a $500,000 annual salary, and is eligible for up to $9.5 million of pre-tax incentive awards a year for 2007 and 2008, the bank said in a filing with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Vivendi Ramps Up Battle Against Deutsche Telekom
description: Vivendi, the French media and entertainment company, says it has new ammunition in its long-running dispute with Deutsche Telekom over control of Polands leading wireless operator, escalating its effort to bring the case under American jurisdiction. Vivendi asserts that Deutsche Telekom, the parent of T-Mobile USA, colluded with a Polish investor to steal its shares in Polska Telefonia Cyfrowa, wiping out a $2.5 billion investment.

title: Blodget Thinks Web 2.0 Should Go While The Going Is Good
description: Henry Blodget sees possible storm clouds ahead for Web 2.0 start-ups. Writing in Forbes, the former star tech analyst that should the stock market tank due to housing, flattening corporate profits, recession, China recession, etc., the Internet stocks will go with it.

title: The Softer Side of Hedge Funds
description: As private equity bigwigs talks about the need to change the public perception of the industry as a greedy boys club, some in the hedge fund business have for some time been quietly working to do the same, says The New York Times.

title: Banks Debt Gets Near-Junk Treatment
description: Goldman Sachs Group, Merrill Lynch and Morgan Stanley, which earned a record $24.5 billion in 2006, suddenly have become so speculative that their own traders are valuing the three biggest securities firms as barely more creditworthy than junk bonds, Bloomberg News reports.

title: Deloitte Nominates New Chief Executive
description: Deloitte Touche Tohmatsus board nominated James. H. Quigley, head of its United States businesses, on Thursday to succeed its chief executive, William G. Parrett, who will step down in May. Mr. Quigleys nomination is subject to a vote by member firm partners worldwide, the company, which is based in New York, said. The company also announced that John P. Connolly, chief of the British unit, would be the new chairman, succeeding Piet Hoogendoorn.

title: Rugged Ridgway
description: View scenes from Ridgway, Colo., a portal to the state's southwest corner that has recently had a serious growth spurt.

title: A Newcomer to Art Collecting
description: These days, the frenzied pitch of the art market means the new collector needs more than just money.

title: C.V.R.D. Reportedly Eyeing Alcan
description: Shares of Alcan, the worlds second-biggest aluminum producer, rose the most in two weeks on speculation Brazils Compahnia Vale do Rio Doce may make a takeover bid. Alcan, based in Montreal, climbed C$2.05, or 3.4 percent, to C$62.87 ($53.62) a share after a Brazilian newspaper, reported that C.V.R.D., the worlds largest iron-ore producer, may bid. Alcan and Alcoa, the worlds largest aluminum producer, repeatedly have been the subjects of takeover speculation amid consolidation in the mining industry.

title: Hong Kong Developer Plans China REIT Offering, Report Says
description: Gateway Group, a Hong Kong-based developer, is reviving a plan to offer the first publicly traded real estate investment trust made up solely of mainland China office buildings, Bloomberg News reported. Bloomberg said that the trust may raise as much as $500 million in a Hong Kong sale as early as the first half. The REIT would allow Gateway to cash in on rising demand for top- grade office space as foreign companies expand and upgrade their Beijing offices after China opened its domestic banking market wider to foreign competition in December.

title: Food for Thought: an Apple V.C. Fund
description: Apple is sitting on $12 billion in cash, and the pile is growing by more than $1 billion every quarter. How should the high-flying maker of iPods and Macs spend that money? According to BusinessWeeks Arik Hesseldahl, the company should launch a $1 billion venture-capital fund. Big acquisitions, especially of tech companies, havent always fared well, Mr. Hesseldahl writes. Apple also has a tendency to pick up small companies whose projects can easily be integrated with its own.

title: More Analysis of a Microsoft-Yahoo Deal
description: Microsoft could jumpstart its online business through a purchase of Web giant Yahoo , but such a deal could also open the door to potentially unmanageable risks, analysts at UBS said in a report Thursday. The analysts are just the latest to consider whether Microsoft should buy Yahoo. Speculation about such a deal has only increased with Googles recent moves deeper into the software business.

title: The Sounds of Son Volt
description: The lead singer of Son Volt talks about the band's new album, "The Search."

title: Whos Next: Business-Intellegence Software
description: Oracles deal to buy Hyperion Solutions may spark more deals for business-intelligence software companies, analysts said. The Red Herring pointed to Cognos, which it said might be a good fit for IBM. The Tech Trader Daily Blog mentions Business Objects and Informatica as possible acquisition targets.

title: Bucking Biotech Trend, Sitris Goes for I.P.O.
description: Sirtris Pharmaceuticals, whose research into the red-wine extract reservatrol brought the company to rock-star status, said Thursday it hopes to raise up to $60 million in an initial public offering. By going public at so early a stage (the company was founded in 2004), Sirtris is bucking a recent trend in biotech companies, the Boston Globe said. Biotech companies now prefer remaining private or going public through alternate routes like reverse mergers, as I.P.O.s have proven less lucrative.

title: Insider-Trading Charges Reach Far Into Wall Street
description: It started in 2001 with two old friends meeting at the Oyster Bar in the basement of Grand Central Terminal in Manhattan, discussing a $25,000 debt. It ended on Thursday with federal authorities saying that they had exposed one of the most far-reaching insider trading schemes on Wall Street in decades, drawing comparisons to the scandals of the 1980s and involving four investment banks and a web of hedge funds, day traders, lawyers and even a few supervisors, who upon discovering evidence of insider trading, blackmailed the traders to keep quiet about it.

title: Conservatives Greet Cheney
description: Just a day after returning from an eventful overseas trip, Vice President Dick Cheney spent time with one of his most receptive audiences on Thursday night  conservatives attending the 34th Annual Conservative Political Action Conference.

title: The Hardware
description: Well, the Oscars are over. But that doesnt mean all the awards have been given out. The Bagger has a few left and makes one last visit to Times Square to announce the winners.

title: Warren Buffetts Wish List
description: Here are a few of things that Warren E. Buffet, the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway, has on his to-do list:

title: Roll Credits
description: Well, that was special, wasnt it?

title: 2008: Dissatisfied Conservatives
description: Conservative Political Action Conference attendees complained about big-government, free-spending coddlers of illegal immigrants, reports Susan Milligan of The Boston Globe. They were referring to Republicans, by the way. Conservatives, so far, have been inconsolable about their presidential choices, though most of those choices (minus, conspicuously, Senator John McCain) are appearing during the weekend conference.

title: A Record Colorado Climb
description: Chris Davenport skied from the top of all 54 of Colorado's mountains above 14,000 feet in less than a year.

title: Homophoner
description: This ones just four fun, but its a LOT of fun. Its called Homophoner.

title: Those Inconvenient (Ex-) U.S. Attorneys
Military Hospital Scandal May Be Just the Beginning
description: Iraq veteran Philip Carter, writing in Slate, says the troubles at Walter Reed Army Medical Center are caused by an Army bureaucracy that discourages people from telling their leaders the truth. Its fast becoming clear that the entire military bureaucracy is rotten to the coreincapable of managing problems at Walter Reed, let alone fighting and winning a war, Carter writes. He adds:

title: More Doubts Emerge About Gap Buyout
description: Could private equity try the Gap on for size? Dont count on it, an analyst at Prudential Equity Group said in a report Friday. The report from Prudentials Stacy Pak is just the latest piece of pessimism surrounding the notion that buyout firms could take the troubled retailer under their wing and perform the kind of transformation that brought J. Crew Group back to life. We would also note that attempts to sell clothing companies havent worked out well lately.

title: What Co-op Records Can an Owner See?
description: Q I am concerned about the lack of reporting of revenues on the annual financials in my co-op. According to the bylaws, I am entitled to inspect the books, documents and accounts of the corporation.

title: Winter Pleasures
description: Japanese visitors crowd the Chena Hot Springs Resort, near Fairbanks, Alaska, a place where the dogs start to bark when the northern lights shimmer.

title: Dissecting the Game's Most Feared Swing
Want to Be a Superstar Athlete? Build More Myelin
Greenwich Village P.J.s
description: Stella McCartneys long johns and adult version of a Dr. Dentons sleeper (in an adorable wilderness-camp motif) have I Cant Be Bothered written all over them. Fashion is such a bitch-goddess nowadays  the bag, the shoes, the sheer performance of everything  that its nice to know that somebody still has a sincere answer to a hard night.

title: EMI Sings Familiar Refrain: No Deal
description: Few deals have been proposed and rejected as many times as the one between music labels EMI Group and Warner Music Group. The latest installment in the saga came Friday when EMI of Britain said it rejected a proposal from Warner Music, of New York, under which Warner would offer to acquire it for 260 pence per share, or about $4.1 billion. The offer came with too many regulatory risks and was too low anyway, EMI said in a statement on its Web site.

title: Im No CryBaby
description: 1199, the health care union, has launched another ad attack at Eliot Spitzer, in response to his earlier salvo suggesting they were a bunch of crybabies.

title: As Rumors Fly, NYSE Chief Seeks to Reassure
description: John Thain wants Wall Street to know he is not going anywhere. The chief of NYSE Group, which operates New York Stock Exchange, said during a conference call Thursday that, contrary to rumors making the rounds, he is not planning to leave the company. He also reiterated that, a recent report notwithstanding, the Securities and Exchange Commission is not investigating the trading glitches that occurred on the New York Stock Exchange on Tuesday as the Dow Jones Industrial Average was plunging more than 500 points.

title: Comment Zone: More Pie  Updated
description: Sewell Chan posted an anecdote yesterday about a younger Mario Cuomo tackling someone who threw a cream pie at Mayor Abraham Beame.

title: We Need to Put Dirt on Our Dirt
description: When I was 7 or 8, my favorite thing to do when I got my allowance was to run down to the corner store and buy a tiny package of sponges that were cut into odd shapes not quite visible behind their cellophane wrapper.

title: Jordan Leads Marists March in Metro Atlantic
description: The Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament is scheduled to begin tonight, but really, it doesnt start until Jared Jordan and the top-seeded Marist Red Foxes play tomorrow against the winner of tonights Canisius-St. Peters game.

title: Dispatch From the Ground War
description: The air war over Gov. Eliot Spitzers proposed health care cuts has been waged for days now. The Greater New York Hospital Association and 1199, the behemoth health care union, ran ads blasting the cuts, and the governor ran ads likening them to crybabies.

title: Looking for MySpace on Wall Street
description: In a tantalizing story that raises more questions than it answers, The Guardian is reporting that Reuters plans to launch what chief executive Tom Glocer calls a version of MySpace for the financial community.

title: Mo Throws in Tampa, Yanks Play in St. Pete
description: The joke is that Mariano Rivera doesnt even have a pair of gray pants in his spring training locker. He does, actually, but the point is that Rivera has reached such a lofty status that the Yankees never ask him to leave Legends Field to pitch on the road. When the team boarded buses for St. Petersburg this morning, Rivera, as usual, stayed behind.

title: Starrett City Deal: Door Is Closed
description: As Charles V. Bagli reported on the front page this morning, HUD has blocked the $1.3 billion Starrett City sale.

title: Sad News
description: Very sad news today about the death of the great Brooklyn Dodger Clem Labine.

title: Hedge Funds Loom Large in Stock-Tipping Cases
description: It was the top-tier investment banks that got a lot of the press (the New York Daily News went with the headline Morgan Scamley), but three obscure hedge funds were tightly woven into the byzantine insider-trading schemes that authorities described Thursday. High up in a statement announcing the filing of charges against 14 people in the alleged schemes, Christopher Cox, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that hedge funds were the biggest beneficiaries of the fraud and stated that his agency is targeting hedge-fund insider trading as a top priority.

title: From Crashing Gates to Hugging Trees?
description: In buying TXU, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Texas Pacific, are betting that the increasingly sensitive question of how to produce energy in an environmentally acceptable way is better handled by a privately owned firm than by one exposed to the public markets, The Economist writes. Many media outlets indeed played up the agreement the buyout firms reached with environmentalists to scale back TXUs plans to build 11 coal-fired plant in Texas. But the British magazine brings some skepticism to the deal.

title: Tardy Regulators
description: My column today warns of the risks involved in tightening subprime credit now, as home prices are falling. In tomorrows Times, I will discuss how home prices are falling in many regions, (The International Herald Tribune version of that article is now available.

title: At CPAC, Giuliani Promotes Ties to Reagan
description: Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani invoked Ronald Reagan at least a dozen times in his speech this afternoon before a fairly young audience at the Conservative Political Action Conference in Washington.

title: Serving Up a Side Dish to a Scandal
description: Wall Street is still trying to digest the news that 13 people, including current and former employees at top investment banks, were arrested in connection with what prosecutors are calling one of the biggest insider-trading schemes in decades. But the Grand Central Oyster Bar, the 94-year-old eatery where the stock-tipping schemes were allegedly hatched, seems to see a delicious bit of humor in the whole thing.

title: The Frustration of Steakhouses
description: Were in a steakhouse moment. For the past year, new steakhouses have opened at a rate, seemingly, of at least one a month. And yet Im not sure weve inched any closer to finding an ideal, all-virtues-in-one, definitive steakhouse.

title: The Duel for Big 12 Honors
description: No. 15 Texas thrilling 98-96 double-overtime victory over No. 6 Texas A&M on Wednesday night further intensified debate about the Big 12s player of the year award.

title: Pettitte Sharp in Yanks Win
description: Andy Pettitte retired all six hitters he faced today in the Yankees 3-1 victory over the Devil Rays in St. Petersburg. Chris Basak, a non-roster infielder, hit a three-run homer off Ruddy Lugo in the eighth to win it.

title: Glorifying Death
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Mar. 2 column, The Silence That Kills.

title: Blogtalk: Weekender
description: Pardon the self-linking, but a controversy has erupted over the tale of Mario Cuomo tackling a pie-thrower in 1977: Did he really? And was it apple or cream or both? (Update: We checked with The Times reporter who was there  he says Mr. Cuomo tried to grab the pie thrower, but the police got there first). [The Empire Zone]

title: S.E.C. Files Insider Trading Suit in TXU Buyout
description: In the second major insider-trading case in as many days, federal regulators have charged several unnamed individuals with profiting illegally from advance knowledge of the $45 billion buyout of TXU, the largest L.B.O. ever. The Securities and Exchange Commission filed suit in Chicago, saying that several individuals used foreign brokerage firms in the transactions to cover their tracks. The agency said that the unnamed defendants are in a position to earn more than $5.3 million in profits.

title: Girl Meets Puck, Puck Takes Girl
description: Writer Daniel Coyle describes how he lost his wife to the ice hockey rink.

title: The Brains Behind Talent
description: Neuroscientist Doug Fields's myelin research explains how these neural membranes function in developing athletic skills.

title: Praise Dancing Hits Manhattan
description: Dance is becoming a regular part of many Pentecostal church services.

title: Candidates Subtly Criticize Rivals
description: Ronald Reagans famous 11th Amendment, Thou shalt not speak ill of another Republican, rarely survives a primary season. And though no candidates at todays Conservative Political Action Conferences criticized another overtly, veiled references were not uncommon.

title: Dancing With the Candidates
description: Senator Sam Brownback, a Kansas Republican, repeated his signature line today, Im following the yellow brick road to the White House. And while there were no lions or tin men at the Conservative Political Action Conference, there was a dolphin, a walking Hershey Kiss, plenty of elephant pins and even a few straw-man arguments.

title: Its A Thin Line
description: While more Americans may be gripped today by the news that Switzerland accidentally invaded Liechtenstein Thursday morning (when a company of Swiss soldiers, carrying assault rifles but no ammunition, got lost in the dark and marched across the frontier), Carlotta Gall reports from a more heavily armed part of the world that Pakistani authorities took a small step toward securing their disputed border with Afghanistan by arresting a senior Taliban leader in the Pakistani city of Quetta.

title: Obama, Not Surprisingly, Goes Left
description: I checked in with the Brown Coach Craig Robinson a few weeks back to see how his first season is going at the Ivy League school. We also chatted a little bit about his famous brother-in-law  Democratic presidential candidate Senator Barack Obama.

title: Red Moon Rising
description: Ecliptophiles, get out your binoculars. The moon could be turning red again.

title: Free for All: Paris Fashion
description: The arrival of Andr Leon Talley, in a highwaymans cloak by Martin Grant and an Indian blue shirt, stirred the photographers last night at Yves Saint Laurent. There have been no stars at the Paris shows, only clothes and some very good, very serious ones at that. Stefano Pilati took to heart the criticism of his last YSL show, when the models traipsed on a bed of violets, the clothes of a piece with the theatrical presentation. This time he focused on line, fabric textures instead of adornment (cloqu, a blend of silk, mohair and wool) and volume, especially in raglan-sleeve coats.

title: Scratching the Surface
description: Oil companies are using new technology to extend the lives of old oil fields.

title: Growing Calls in Australia for Terror Suspects Return
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, March 3  The decision by the United States military to charge an Australian citizen, David Hicks, with one terrorism-related offense comes as Prime Minister John Howard is under mounting pressure, even from conservatives in his own party, to have Mr. Hicks charged, tried and brought home.

title: Evangelicals Focus on Climate Draws Fire of Christian Right
description: Leaders of several conservative Christian groups have sent a letter urging the National Association of Evangelicals to force its policy director in Washington to stop speaking out on global warming.

title: Marist Still Has Work to Do After Record-Setting Season
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 2  Jared Jordan is proud of what Marist has accomplished this season. Jordan, an N.B.A. prospect, has led the Red Foxes to 23 victories  the most in the colleges history  and their first Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference regular-season championship. Jordan, though, sees a potential problem in those achievements: By Sunday, none of them may matter.

title: Elmont Honors Its Late Coach by Resuming Its Season
description: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., March 2  The scoreboard read, 24-21, but the teams were only warming up. The clock showed 1 minute 30 seconds left in the first half. The possession arrow pointed to Elmont Memorial High School.

title: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about a juke joint in a sharecropper shack in Merigold, Miss., misidentified the nearby town whose casinos have drawn patrons away from the nightspot. It is Greenville, not Clarksdale.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Dismissal of Abuse Suit
description: A German citizen who says he was kidnapped and abused by the Central Intelligence Agency cannot seek redress in court because his lawsuit would expose state secrets, a United States Court of Appeals ruled yesterday in Richmond, Va.

title: Overkill
description: A famous hunter and outdoorsman recently voiced misgivings about people who use assault rifles to kill prairie dogs.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the removal of Maj. Gen. George W. Weightman from command of Walter Reed Army Medical Center erroneously ascribed his academic and professional achievements to another officer. It is General Weightman who was educated at West Point and the University of Vermont and was land component command surgeon during the 2003 invasion of Iraq  not Lt. Gen. Kevin Kiley, the Armys top medical officer.

title: Down End to a Very Down Week
description: This week, investors heard that the economy was more vulnerable than they thought. A result was Wall Streets worst week in four years.

title: An Ordered World Defined With Soothing Spareness
description: The soberly detailed work of Sally Gross, who began making dances in the 1960s, has a calming effect on the nervous system. Her dancers, connected like invisible links in a chain, forge units by the intensity of their silent, concentrated breath. But while Ms. Grosss dances convey peaceful states, they exist in a realm as severe as it is serene. Her choreography, demonstrated on Thursday at the Joyce SoHo in a selection of solos and group works, remains blessedly hard-core. There are no cute antics or silly props  only vigorous attention to rigor.

title: Warm Winters Upset Rhythms of Maple Sugar
description: MONTPELIER, Vt.  One might expect Burr Morse to have maple sugaring down to a science.

title: Better Schools Begin at Home (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Health Care Lobby Is Served Bagels and a Scolding From the Governor
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer had two of his leading critics for breakfast yesterday.

title: Social Networkings Next Phase
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 2  Next week Cisco Systems, a Silicon Valley heavyweight, plans to announce one of its most unusual deals: it is buying the technology assets of Tribe.net, a mostly forgotten social networking site, according to people close to the companies discussions.

title: Judge Warns City Over Arrests of Panhandlers
description: Saying the New York City Police Department has been outrageous in failing to follow repeated court orders barring it from ticketing peaceful panhandlers, a federal judge in Manhattan said yesterday that she would consider a proposal to hold the city in contempt of court.

title: Environmental Agency Proposes Strict Standard for Some Diesel Engines
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  The Environmental Protection Agency, which for a decade has been ratcheting up its controls on off-road diesel equipment, diesel trucks and diesel fuel, proposed stringent new pollution standards Friday on diesel locomotives and marine vessels operating in the United States.

title: Neon, Crystals and Antennae in Battery-Operated Paris
description: PARIS, March 2  There is a fad among young people on the Paris club scene of wearing T-shirts with L.E.D. displays across the chest, which blare messages like Hot Lips. You might as well say: Look at me. Im lame. In a city that is becoming increasingly neon, pitch-dark little boutiques with names like Boutique HO! and Uranium Jeans have popped up, selling battery-operated novelty belts, hats and underwear, all of which seems an incredibly wasteful affront to the environment.

title: Short History, Long View
description: INGOLSTADT, Germany, Feb. 26  Visitors to the Audi automobile museum here could be forgiven for puzzling over the first few exhibits in this striking circular glass building. There are splendid antique motor cars with names like Horch, Wanderer and DKW, but no Audis.

title: Myer Feldman, 92, Adviser to President Kennedy, Dies
description: Myer Feldman, an aide to President John F. Kennedy who remained virtually unknown to the public while playing an integral role in planning his presidential campaign, White House press conferences and governmental policies, died Thursday in Bethesda, Md. He was 92.

title: New Design for Warhead Is Awarded to Livermore
description: The Bush administration announced yesterday the winner of a competition to design the nations first new nuclear weapon in nearly two decades and immediately set out to reassure Russia and China that the weapon, if built, would pose no new threat to either nation.

title: Using the Web to Get the Boss to Pay More
description: If information is power, then most employees who enter salary negotiations are holding pea shooters while the boss is encased in a Kevlar vest.

title: An Iraqi Tribal Chief Opposes the Jihadists, and Prays
description: BAGHDAD, March 2  The sheik stared at the cake that the hotel workers had brought up to his room as a gift. Across the red gelatinlike surface was written, God protect you from the enemies and keep you for the Iraqi people.

title: Chamber Group as Rock Band, Playing Fusion of Another Sort
description: Bang on a Can has always been the most unabashedly populist of new-music organizations. Its name suggests that anyone can make music on anything, and its boundary-crossing programs have been built on the notion that contemporary music can embrace elements of rock, jazz and world music. In recent seasons, its grass-roots approach has extended to commissioning too, by inviting its audiences to contribute to the Peoples Commissioning Fund. The proceeds are put toward commissioning new works, which are performed at an annual Peoples Commissioning Fund concert by the Bang on a Can All-Stars.

title: Mystery, Partnership and Beethoven Too
description: There are performers who give polite interviews, write blogs and chat to audiences during performances. Then there are old-school musicians with such an aura of mystery and intrigue that they create excitement before even playing a note.

title: Gold Is Awaiting Its Day
description: A STOPPED clock is right twice a day. The proverbial blind squirrel probably does find the occasional acorn. And all those people who have been arguing for years, frequently on infomercials and in advertisements on talk radio, that the price of gold is going to increase drastically may finally be correct, Bloomberg Markets writes.

title: Locking Up the Ghost of Congress Past
description: Congresss quid-pro-quo corruption scandal continues to haunt the Capitol as Bob Ney, the once-unbeatable lawmaker, slips off to his prison sentence of two and a half years for peddling influence to Jack Abramoff, the bribe-dishing lobbyist already doing six years in a Florida case.

title: Again, Boeing Is Scrutinized on a Contract
description: When the Boeing Company won a $15 billion contract last November to provide the Air Force with the next generation of search-and-rescue helicopters, Boeing officials were not the only ones surprised.

title: Argentina May See Shared Custody of Its Top Job
description: BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 28  In political circles here, a single question is being asked incessantly these days: him or her? Will President Nstor Kirchner run for a second term or will he, as seems increasingly likely, step aside and let his wife, Senator Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner, become the Peronist candidate?

title: Oil Company Revives Suit on Avoidance of Royalties
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  One of the nations biggest oil producers in the Gulf of Mexico is pressing ahead with a lawsuit that could, if successful, allow energy companies to avoid as much as $60 billion in royalties to the government over the next two decades.

title: A Pattern of Normal Drought
description: It has taken humans awhile to realize that our idea of normal changes as our understanding of history deepens. Climate is a case in point. Over the past couple of decades, climatology has become a deeply historical science. In the American Southwest, climatologists have found a surprisingly detailed record of weather patterns  especially patterns of moisture  in tree rings that show that prolonged periods of drought there are normal.

title: A Radiant Voice, Presented Matter-of-Factly
description: Joyce DiDonato is the kind of singer doomed to be described with adjectives like perky or feisty. She is blond, attractive, American and cute. This is perhaps unfortunate, since none of these things have much to do with her best qualities as an artist  qualities that were displayed, intermittently but abundantly, at her Carnegie Hall recital debut at Weill Hall on Thursday night.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about whether duct tape can remove warts referred imprecisely to the publication of a study on the subject. While the study did appear last month in The Journal of Family Practice, it was originally published in November in the Archives of Pediatrics & Adolescent Medicine.

title: Big Profits, Big Worries in Oil Fields
description: Oil companies have made super profits the last few years thanks to record high oil prices. Chevron, the second-largest American oil company, earned $17 billion in 2006. But oil is harder to find and more expensive to produce. David J. OReilly, 60, Chevrons chairman and chief executive, spoke recently about the challenges big oil companies face in meeting growing oil demand, how technology has advanced the search for oil, the message behind Chevrons recent ads and the lack of an energy policy in the United States. Following are excerpts:

title: Bus Carrying College Baseball Team Crashes, Killing 6
description: ATLANTA, March 2  A bus that had been traveling all night, taking an Ohio college baseball team to Florida for a series of games, plunged nearly 30 feet off an overpass early Friday morning, killing six people and critically injuring three more, emergency officials said.

title: Dodgers White Sitting on a Fortune
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., March 2  Sharing a clubhouse with luminaries like Jeff Kent, Nomar Garciaparra and Jason Schmidt is Matt White, the Dodgers reluctant rock star.

title: Putting to a Vote the Question Who Is Cherokee?
description: TAHLEQUAH, Okla., March 1  The casinos here are crowded by midmorning; busloads of tourists stroll the streets, and construction crews are everywhere. But peace of mind eludes the prospering Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma.

title: Reporting for Duty
description: Boston

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Feb. 3 about polar bears floating on chunks of glacial ice, illustrating an article on a global warming report, carried incorrect information from the Canadian Ice Service about when and where the photograph was taken, and about who took it. The picture was taken in August 2006 in the Chukchi Sea, not in 2004 in the Bering Sea, farther south. The photographer was Amanda Byrd, not Dan Crosbie.

title: In a Comeback in Amsterdam, the Club Ten Proves Its Value
description: The fourth White House International Bridge Teams Top 16 event took place in Amsterdam from Feb. 23 to 25, with one of the home teams surging from behind in the semifinals and ultimately taking the title.

title: Smoke-Free Gambling Site Thrives Amid Debate on Ban
description: YONKERS, Feb. 28  In a vast, dimly lit room with a low ceiling and frosted glass chandeliers  but without the scent or sight of a smoky haze  video lottery terminals are arrayed in ranks like soldiers.

title: Timely Lessons From a Rebel, Who Often Created by Destroying
description: The Gordon Matta-Clark retrospective at the Whitney Museum of American Art should be required viewing for any architect born in the age of the computer screen. Few artists could match his ability to extract raw beauty from the dark, decrepit corners of a crumbling city. Fewer still haunt the architectural imagination with such force.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Feb. 3 about polar bears floating on chunks of glacial ice, illustrating an article on a global warming report, carried incorrect information from the Canadian Ice Service about when and where the photograph was taken, and about who took it. The picture was taken in August 2006 in the Chukchi Sea, not in 2004 in the Bering Sea, farther south. The photographer was Amanda Byrd, not Dan Crosbie. (Go to Article)

title: Bush Surveys Tornado Damage and Promises Aid
description: AMERICUS, Ga., March 3  President Bush provided a sympathetic shoulder today to residents of Georgia and Alabama as he surveyed damage left in the wake of deadly tornadoes on Thursday.

title: Will Freedom Bloom in the Desert?
description: Rome

title: U.S. and Europe in Accord on Air Routes
description: PARIS, March 2  Negotiators for the European Union and the United States reached a preliminary agreement on Friday to all but eliminate restrictions on trans-Atlantic air routes, a breakthrough in talks aimed at increasing the number of flights and lowering fares.

title: Tentative Deal Struck With City Would Raise Pay for Firefighters
description: The Bloomberg administration and the citys largest fire union have reached a tentative two-year contract that gives union members raises totaling 8.16 percent and increases pay for starting firefighters by nearly $10,000.

title: When It Comes to House Prices, the Bloom Is Off the Cactus
description: IN the fall of 2005, the greatest boom in home prices in America was going on in Phoenix. People stood in line just to get on lists to buy new homes. It was possible to make lots of money selling a place on a list well before the house was actually built.

title: 8 Sentenced in Morocco for Plotting Terror Attacks
description: PARIS, March 2  A Moroccan court on Friday sentenced eight Islamists to prison terms of up to 15 years for plotting terrorist attacks in France, Italy and Morocco, the government news agency in Morocco reported.

title: Ohio: Record Penalty in Illegal Labor Case
description: Maximino Garcia, the president of two temporary labor contracting companies, was sentenced late Thursday in federal court in Cincinnati to 15 months in prison for providing hundreds of illegal immigrants as workers to an air cargo company. Mr. Garcia, who pleaded guilty on Oct. 3 to conspiring to aid illegal immigrants, was also fined $25,000 and ordered to forfeit $12 million  the largest forfeiture ever ordered in an illegal labor case, immigration officials said.

title: For the Record
description: The Critics Choice column on Feb. 20, about new DVDs, including a set from First Run Features called The Cuban Masterworks Collection, referred incorrectly to unrest in Cuba in the 1830s, the time in which the film Cecilia is set. There were slave revolts then, not an independence movement. The column also omitted the co-author of the Russian novel The Twelve Chairs, the basis of a Cuban film of that name by the director Toms Gutirrez Alea. It was written by Ilya Ilf and Yevgeny Petrov, not just by Mr. Ilf.

title: Memories of a Colder Iceland
description: Reykjavik, Iceland

title: Rebellious Diplomat Finds Work as Envoy of the Voiceless
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo

title: Looking for the Bright Side of a Brutish Few Centuries
description: In A.D. 410 an army from northern Germany stormed the walled city of Rome and set in motion the fall of its empire, suspending advancements in culture, technology and political thought for the remainder of the first millennium. To remark that the ensuing 600 years were a grim time for Western civilization is like saying that the tundra is a comfortable place with the warmth of a good cardigan. The Dark Ages, making its debut tomorrow night, is the History Channels chronicle of the period, a bit of camp gore that cant seem to help presenting the European continent as a big, bleeding lesion even as it aims to offer a countervailing narrative: the pluses of plague and torture, the upside of famine, backwardness and early-infant death.

title: U.P.S. Walks Away From A380 Order
description: PARIS, March 2  United Parcel Service, the last remaining customer for the cargo version of the Airbus A380 superjumbo jet, said on Friday that it was walking away from its order for 10 planes, citing concerns that Airbus would not be able to meet a revised delivery schedule.

title: Buffalo. 1994. It Writes Itself.
description: Why why why? Why would Seth MacFarlane make a sitcom with a quacklike laugh track? That never ceases? That flares up so regularly that actors cant even begin jokes in time for them to be stepped on?

title: Leaning on Theory, Colliding With Faith
description: Creationists reject the theory of evolution. Religious pilgrims still line up for the Shroud of Turin. So it is unlikely that many Christians will lose sleep  let alone faith  because of The Lost Tomb of Jesus on the Discovery Channel tomorrow.

title: For the Record
description: A brief art review in Weekend yesterday about Limelight, an exhibition at the Triple Candie gallery in Harlem based on a 1959 show at the Limelight coffeehouse and gallery in the West Village, misidentified the content of the original show. It included reprints of photographs by major artists lent by the George Eastman House in Rochester, not originals.

title: Montana: Ranch Predator Identified
description: The animal that killed more than 120 sheep in the northeastern part of the state last year was a domesticated wolf, DNA testing has shown. The results mean that ranchers whose sheep were killed will not be eligible for reimbursement from a fund for livestock losses. Theres no possible way for the wolf to have been bred in the wild, said Suzanne Stone of Defenders of Wildlife, the environmental group that pays the reimbursement. And the fund doesnt cover domestic wolves or hybrids or dogs. The 106-pound wolf was killed by federal trappers on Nov. 2 after it killed and injured sheep over seven months.

title: U.S. Is Investigating Trades Made Just Before TXU Deal
description: Federal regulators froze more than $5.3 million that they suspect may be profits from insider trading of TXU stock options that occurred just days before a $45 billion buyout of the Texas energy company.

title: Mets Hope Park Will Be Pitcher the Fans Will Come Out to See
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 2  The only thing right about the scene was the uniform he wore. Chan Ho Park took the mound for the Mets on Friday morning 33 miles from where he expected to be, throwing to a catcher who doubled as the umpire, facing hitters he would not recognize even if he had a roster in his hand.

title: From Poetry and Song to Musical Chairs
description: A trip off the beaten dance path can be refreshing, especially when the work is as enjoyably unassuming as the program presented by Amy Pivar and a duo called ann and alexx make dances on Thursday night at Dance New Amsterdam.

title: A Mendelssohn Thats Not for the Romantics
description: Like many composers, Mendelssohn has fallen in and out of favor over the years, but his chamber music has experienced a renaissance. At the 92nd Street Y on Wednesday, the Mendelssohn Quartet seemed determined to rebuff accusations of sentimentality that have sometimes been directed toward their namesake by offering aggressive and no-nonsense interpretations of his music.

title: For the Record
description: An article and headline in Business Day on Wednesday about Toyotas plans to put a new plant near Tupelo, Miss., referred incorrectly to Tupelo honey. While Van Morrison sang about it and Peter Fonda starred in Ulees Gold, a movie about it, the city of Tupelo is not known for producing it. That distinction belongs to a region in Northwest Florida filled with tupelo gum trees, which is considered to be the worlds leading commercial producer of Tupelo honey. (Tupelo can still lay claim to being the birthplace of Elvis Presley.)

title: Red Bulls Headlong Frozen Dash Is a Crash Course in Marketing
description: QUEBEC, March 2  Maybe the gusts swirling snow through the alleys of the historic district here Friday were not actual winds of change. But in an old city famous for preserving the past, a new sport has become a showcase for changing relationships between fans and the way brands market to them.

title: An Afghan Policy Built on Pipe Dreams
description: The international communitys policy in Afghanistan is based on the claim that Afghans are willing partners in the creation of a liberal democratic state. Senator John McCain finished a recent speech on Afghanistan by saying, Billions of people around the world now embrace the ideals of political, economic and social liberty, conceived in the West, as their own.

title: A Plunge, Mixed Data and Some Mixed Messages
description: WORRIES about the global economy rattled stock markets around the world this week, paring billions and billions of dollars from the value of investors holdings. The drops, while significant, were still modest by historical standards.

title: Venezuela and Iran Strengthen Ties With Caracas-to-Tehran Flight
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 2  Iran is already Venezuelas closest ally outside Latin America, with ventures to produce oil and build cars and tractors together. Now, travelers between the countries can also take a weekly flight between Caracas and Tehran.

title: U.S. and Brazil Seek to Promote Ethanol in West
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  President Bush, hoping to reduce demand for oil in the Western Hemisphere, is preparing to finish an agreement with Brazil next week to promote the production and use of ethanol throughout Latin America and the Caribbean, according to administration officials.

title: The Lure of New York (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Libby Jury Leaves a Clue as It Heads Into Recess
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  The jury deliberating the perjury and obstruction of justice case against I. Lewis Libby Jr. recessed for the weekend on Friday without reaching a verdict, but not before leaving an intriguing clue as to the state of deliberations.

title: The Good, the Bad, the Dip
description: If your children like their Manichean battles served up Mexican-style, the new animated series El Tigre: The Adventures of Manny Rivera should be to their tastes. El Tigre, which features a three-generation superpowered family, is good versus evil with a side of guacamole  literally.

title: In the New Warfare, Women Are Targets (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Who Perfected Jersey Boys? A Fight Over Who Did What
description: Victory has a thousand fathers, which can mean one heck of a custody battle when it comes to taking credit.

title: New Orleans Files Claim Against Corps for Billions
description: The City of New Orleans filed a $77 billion damage claim against the federal government on Thursday, joining thousands of residents who have flocked to the Army Corps of Engineers seeking compensation for their losses after Hurricane Katrina in 2005.

title: Florida Revises Serious Charge Against Astronaut
description: Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, the astronaut who was accused of attacking a romantic rival with pepper spray last month, was formally charged yesterday with trying to kidnap her. But prosecutors did not charge Captain Nowak with attempted murder, as the police had recommended.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Smart and Wearable, From Different Angles
description: PARIS, March 2  The fall collection that Stefano Pilati sent out last night for Yves Saint Laurent was very concrete, in color as well as expression. He had eliminated all the abstractions of last season, like aprons, and focused on clothes that were contemporary, yet classic enough to satisfy a purist. All the way down the escalators of the Pompidou Center, the site of the show, and into the street, you could hear editors saying, At last, something to wear!

title: Britain: Diana Case Must Be Heard by Jurors
description: The inquest into the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, is to be heard by a regular jury of 12 members of the public, Britains High Court ruled. The three-judge panel said that the long-delayed inquest  which is scheduled to begin in May and is to determine the exact cause of death of Diana and her boyfriend, Emad Mohamed al-Fayed, known as Dodi  should be heard by a jury because, among other things, it might have to consider how to deal with the continuing problem of the paparazzi on wheels pursuing celebrities. An exhaustive inquiry led by Lord Stevens, the former commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, concluded last year that the car crash that killed Diana and Dodi al-Fayed 10 years ago as they fled from members of the news media in Paris was an accident. Mr. Fayeds father, Mohammed al-Fayed, above, who owns Harrods, said he welcomed the ruling and repeated his accusation that the couple had been murdered by the British establishment, led by Prince Philip.

title: Israeli Bands Antiwar Song Pushes Pop Contests Buttons
description: JERUSALEM, March 2  The Eurovision Song Contest, an annual event that proves European popular culture can take itself just as seriously as the American variety, has created a mini-scandal of its own, with the suggestion on Thursday that contest organizers might ban this years Israeli entry, Push the Button, because of what they call an inappropriate political message.

title: After Tornado, an Alabama School Tallies the Grief
description: ENTERPRISE, Ala., March 2  After the sudden pitch-black darkness, there was chaos, then screaming. And when that subsided, the students of Enterprise High School recalled on Friday, some young men and women they had grown up with were nowhere to be found, while others climbed shakily to their feet.

title: City Opera Prepares for New Life in Old Home
description: The New York City Operas announcement this week that it had landed Gerard Mortier, director of the Paris National Opera, as its new leader was hailed as the beginning of a new era for the company. But it was also the end of a saga of operatic proportions, as Mr. Mortier declared that after nearly a decade of searching for its own home, City Opera would stay put at Lincoln Center and make the best of the New York State Theater, which it shares with the New York City Ballet.

title: Markets End a Down Week on a Down Note
description: Stocks extended their slump today, finishing their worst week since January 2003.

title: A Word Too Far
description: Recently, the law firm of Fulbright & Jaworski had to grovel after one of its recruiters used a racist epithet in an interview exercise at Duke University Law School.

title: Marbury Comes Through at the End
description: When the Knicks sized up the Golden State Warriors before last nights game at Madison Square Garden, they saw a Western Conference version of themselves. The teams had the same record and they were each two and a half games from the final playoff spot in their respective conferences.

title: DirecTV Promises to Improve Baseball Package, but Others Wonder How
description: The head of DirecTV yesterday defended the satellite programmers seven-year, $700-million deal with Major League Baseball for exclusive control of the Extra Innings package of out-of-market games. He said that it was pro consumer and that cable subscribers could switch to DirecTV without upfront fees.

title: In Apology for Storm, a Preview of Spring
description: First came the rains  sheets and sheets that sloshed into subway stations, coursed over parkways, filled backyards and engorged streams, making the morning commute a circuitous, maddening mess. Then came the sun, so suddenly and brilliantly that the sky seemed to shift in mere minutes from leaden gray to china-cup blue.

title: In Citys World of Real Estate, Outsider Gets Cold Shoulder
description: For more than a month, politicians and housing officials from Albany to Washington have tried to outdo one another in vilifying David Bistricer, the developer who bid $1.3 billion for the complex of low- and moderate-income apartments in Brooklyn known as Starrett City. They suggested he would raise rents, slash services and throw longtime tenants into the streets.

title: No More Denials, Please
description: It is time for the Justice Department to stop issuing rote denials that are becoming increasingly hard to believe about the suspicious firing of eight United States attorneys. Attorney General Alberto Gonzales should appoint an impartial investigator to get to the bottom of this unfolding scandal.

title: A Thrilling Downhill Dash Caps a Record Colorado Climb
description: By most measurements, there are 54 mountains in Colorado surpassing 14,000 feet in elevation. More than a thousand people are believed to have climbed them all, and thousands more are working through the list. Peak bagging, as it is known, sometimes seems to be Colorados unofficial state sport.

title: Wheres His Right Hook?
description: WASHINGTON

title: EMIs Board Rejects Warners $4.1 Billion Bid as Inadequate
description: The EMI Group of Britain, which releases music by the Beatles and Bob Seger, rejected a $4.1 billion takeover proposal yesterday from the Warner Music Group, signaling the latest turn in a long merger dance.

title: U.S. Urges Lenders to Revise Standards on Granting Credit
description: Banks that make adjustable-rate mortgages to people with weak, or subprime, credit should consider the ability of the borrowers to pay back the loan in full, and not just whether they can make initial low payments, according to a proposal issued by federal regulators yesterday.

title: Books on Atheism Are Raising Hackles in Unlikely Places
description: Hey, guys, cant you give atheism a chance?

title: Colombia: Ex-Ministers Father Ordered Arrested
description: Prosecutors ordered the arrest of lvaro Arajo Noguera, the father of Colombias former foreign minister and an influential regional political leader, amid a widening scandal revealing ties between supporters of President lvaro Uribe and paramilitary death squads. Mr. Noguera, 74, was implicated in the kidnapping of Vctor Ochoa Daza, a member of a rival political family. Mr. Arajos daughter, Mara Consuelo Arajo, resigned as foreign minister last month; investigators have also jailed her brother on kidnapping charges. The scandal has also resulted in the arrest of Mr. Uribes former domestic intelligence chief, accused of handing over to paramilitary leaders the names of union officials and academics who became targets for assassination.

title: MoMA Directors Pay (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Koreas Agree to Resume Reunions
description: South Korea and North Korea wrapped up high-level talks, agreeing to resume reunions of families separated by the Korean War and to test-run a cross-border train in the first half of this year. But the South said it would make a final decision on resuming humanitarian aid to the North only after Pyongyang began complying with the nuclear accord reached in the six-party talks last month and shutting down its main nuclear reactor. The North had pressed for an immediate resumption of aid during the ministerial talks, which resumed after a seven-month hiatus.

title: Sell and Tell (the I.R.S.)
description: EVERYONE knows  or should know  that income earned from online auctions is taxable. But should auction sites like eBay be responsible for policing their users? Some people in government think so; eBay does not.

title: Give Me a Double Shot of Starbucks Nostalgia
description: Is it possible that there are actually two Howard Schultzes lurking around Starbucks headquarters in Seattle? I think it is.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 19 about conclusions by American intelligence and counterterrorism officials that leaders of Al Qaeda operating from Pakistan have re-established significant control over their worldwide network omitted a credit. Margot Williams reported from New York about terrorism networks.

title: Nobiz Like Shobiz, Trained by Tagg, Is Creating a Stir as a Favorite for the Derby
description: After the trainer Barclay Tagg won the Kentucky Derby in 2003 with an overlooked gelding named Funny Cide, there was every reason to believe that Tagg would turn out to be a one-hit wonder. His career began in 1971, and it had taken him 32 years to so much as make it to the Derby. He rarely had the chance to train the type of elite 3-year-old talent needed to win the Derby.

title: Whats on Monday
description: 9 P.M. (National Geographic) INSIDE NORTH KOREA Lisa Ling posed as a medical coordinator to venture inside the isolated nation and get a glimpse of society as it really is. That included a rare peek into a North Korean home  a one-bedroom apartment shared by six family members and decorated only with images of Kim Jong-il, the countrys leader. Still, Ms. Ling rarely found herself alone. Upon her arrival, she was assigned six government escorts who watched her every move and even stayed in her hotel. And forget phoning home: in a country that forbids cell phones, Ms. Ling had to relinquish hers.

title: Once Notorious, Now Just Trying Not to Be Invisible
description: Mercy now plays a major part in the religion of fame. Thats not good. Disgraced superstars  Bill Clinton, Martha Stewart, all the prostitute-frequenters and sex-tape-makers  regularly receive such automatic forgiveness from the public that were beginning to surrender the last of our meager power over them. Today, in fact, if you so much as claim annoyance at patently annoying figures like John Travolta or Rush Limbaugh, theres a deacon standing by to scold you and tell you that, no matter what, that guy was great in X and changed Y forever. I guess so. All of fames children now deserve a permanent place in the heavens.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about a plan by the New York Fire Department to add 10 weeks to its 13-week training program for probationary firefighters referred imprecisely to new requirements for recruits. Besides a high school diploma, they need only one of the following: 15 college credits, six months work experience or an honorable discharge from full-time military service. College credits are not mandatory.

title: Acquittal in Club Deaths
description: CHICAGO, March 2  Three men were acquitted Friday of involuntary manslaughter charges arising from a stampede at a Chicago nightclub that killed 21 people and injured dozens more in February 2003.

title: To Woolfs Lighthouse, Where Things Are Better Left Unsaid
description: BERKELEY, Calif., Feb. 28  Adding music to Virginia Woolfs novel To the Lighthouse would seem to be a classic case of taking coals to Newcastle. The book is already music in prose, a symphony in three movements that evokes in words rather than notes the rich flux of thought and feeling that shapes human experience, indeed that constitutes much of it.

title: On Charging Batteries, Trusting Children and Washing Fruit
description: In the journalism business we call it gathering string: collecting information on issues that seem interesting in hopes they will one day turn into full-fledged articles.

title: Newark: Shooting Leaves Man Dead, Two Others Hurt
description: A man was fatally shot and two others were wounded yesterday in a shooting in Newark, the police said. The circumstances that led to the shooting were still unclear last night, but the police said it took place between Forest Place and Lehigh Avenue shortly after 5 p.m. Two of the victims, all of whom were men, were taken to Beth Israel Medical Center, where one was pronounced dead, the police said. As of last night, his name had not been released. The other hospitalized man and the third victim, who walked to the hospital, were expected to survive, the police said.

title: Romney and Giuliani Make Pitch to Conservatives
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  Mitt Romney of Massachusetts and Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York are both Republican presidential candidates who have been voted into office by largely Democratic electorates. They both have a history of taking liberal positions on social issues. And both are viewed warily by conservative Republicans who are integral to the partys presidential nominating process.

title: Recapturing Sprawling Chaos, With Attention to Detail
description: Technical difficulties gave the perfect caption to Old Knit, the concert on Thursday at Town Hall. During attempts to connect a video input for DJ Spooky, the screen kept flashing, Not Applicable! That phrase would apply to everything standard, from musical genres to profit-making strategies, at the original Knitting Factory, which opened in February 1987.

title: Obama Had Slaveowning Kin
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  Genealogists have uncovered a new ingredient in the melting pot identity of Senator Barack Obama, the Illinois Democrat who hopes to become the first black president. His white maternal ancestors once owned slaves.

title: Novice Art Collectors Find Access Is Priceless
description: Susan Hancock came through the doors of the Pier 94 exhibition hall on the West Side of Manhattan recently with no time to waste. In half an hour, the booths of the 2007 Armory Show, the largest contemporary art fair in the country, would open: five days, 149 blue-chip galleries from all over the world, and nearly 2,000 artists with work for sale.

title: World View Podcast
description: CALVIN SIMS. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe.

title: Noticeably Absent From the Giuliani Campaign: His Children
description: As he embarks on a campaign for the presidency, former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani is going forward without two people who once played supporting roles in his political life: his children, Andrew, 21, and Caroline, 17.

title: Authorities Investigate Big Lender
description: Federal prosecutors and securities regulators are investigating stock sales and accounting errors at the New Century Financial Corporation, the biggest mortgage company that specializes in lending to people with weak, or subprime, credit, the company disclosed in a corporate filing yesterday.

title: Iraqi Soccer Players Killed; 16 Policemen Found Dead
description: BAGHDAD, March 2  Two soccer players in their 20s were killed Thursday night in front of their teammates in Ramadi by gunmen who claimed that the players had collaborated with a Sunni group that opposes insurgents and is believed to have ties to the Americans, according to witnesses and the police.

title: City School Admissions (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Rebuilding and Rehiring at Lincoln Center

title: Support Brooklyns Future (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Probing the Charged Intersection of Action and Analysis
description: Anxiety about his choices as an artist  whether making dances matters; whether any of it matters  runs through a lot of Miguel Gutierrezs choreography. If he cant see the answer from where hes standing, he should hire a substitute one night and sit in the audience. From there it is clear that his work matters a very great deal.

title: Mixed Verdicts for Merck in Vioxx Cases
description: A New Jersey state jury ruled that Merck had failed to provide adequate warning about the risks of its Vioxx painkiller in one of two cases decided yesterday.

title: Ex-Student Describes Seduction by Principal
description: He had never told anyone but his mother that he loved her  until his former Montessori principal pressed him to say it to her, a police officer testified yesterday.

title: Keeping Kids Healthy (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Qaddafi Heralds a Changing Libya, but Within Limits
description: SEBHA, Libya, March 2  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi had just spent two hours on Friday arguing that Libyas form of government was the truest democracy, when the call went out to a small group of foreign correspondents for questions.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about possible regulatory hurdles for the acquisition of the TXU Corporation by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company and the Texas Pacific Group misspelled the surname of an analyst at Innovest Strategic Value Advisors who discussed the effect of the deal on TXU rivals. He is Eric Kane, not Cane.

title: Whats on Sunday
description: 8 P.M. (ABC Family) THE DUKES OF HAZZARD: THE BEGINNING (2007). April Scott, who hails from Poplar Bluff, Mo., the so-called gateway to the Ozarks, plays Daisy Duke in this made-for-television prequel based on the series about a couple of rabble-rousing Southern cousins. Jonathan Bennett plays Bo Hazzard, Randy Wayne is his cousin Luke, and Christopher McDonald gets gussied up in white as Boss Hogg. Willie Nelson, who played Uncle Jesse in the 2005 Jessica Simpson-Johnny Knoxville big-screen version, reprises the role here.

title: In Victory for Hispanics, Judge Halts Port Chester Elections
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 2  A federal judge on Friday stopped March elections for two seats on the Port Chester Board of Trustees, finding there was sufficient evidence to make the case that the villages at-large system for voting discriminates against Hispanic residents.

title: Once Again, the Playoffs Are Proving Elusive for the Rangers
description: The last time John Davidson watched a Rangers game at Madison Square Garden, the team was playing in its first playoff series in nine years. Davidson was the longtime broadcaster who had chronicled every step of the Rangers struggle to return to the playoffs.

title: Clem Labine, 80, Brooklyn Dodgers Relief Ace, Dies
description: Clem Labine, the All-Star relief pitcher of the 1950s who helped bring the Brooklyn Dodgers four pennants and their only World Series championship, died yesterday in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 80.

title: More Than Symbol: Police Badge Saves Lives
description: For a thin wafer of metal alloy, a police officers shield carries remarkable heft. It is the emblem of honor and a pledge to serve, as cherished as a soldiers dog tags.

title: A Humane Warhorse From Wagner
description: Peter Gelb, the new general manager of the Metropolitan Opera, is determined to recruit innovative directors from the theater and film worlds and make the Met a go-to place for theatrically bold productions. More power to him.

title: Army Secretary Is Ousted in Furor Over Hospital Care
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  Army Secretary Francis J. Harvey was forced to resign Friday over the handling of revelations that wounded soldiers were receiving shabby and slow treatment at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.

title: Finding Safe Picks in a Downturn
description: ALL good things must end, and if the bull market has run its course, which seems distinctly possible after this weeks trading, the descent will be steeper for some types of stocks than others. If a protracted decline has begun, one investment adviser is warning his clients, the sharpest reversals of fortune could be experienced in what have been some of the hottest sectors.

title: Saudi Filmmaker Lacks Visa for Festival
description: A rare Saudi Arabian feature film will make its American debut at a film festival in Manhattan tomorrow night, but its director, unable to secure a visa in time, will remain in Riyadh, left to ponder the realities of artistic exchange in an era fraught with suspicion.

title: More Polished Pettitte Is Off to a Quick Start
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2  If you searched too long for a parking space or lingered in line for a hot dog, you might have missed Andy Pettittes return Friday. He was back on the mound in a game for the Yankees, but not for very long.

title: Village Voice Fires Editor After Six Months
description: David Blum, the editor in chief of The Village Voice, was fired last night after a six-month tenure.

title: Two Who Were Wounded Testify About Police Killing
description: Grand jurors investigating the fatal shooting of Sean Bell heard yesterday from two prime witnesses in the case, the two men in a car with Mr. Bell and who were wounded in a hail of 50 police bullets.

title: Showing Off Fleet Fingers and Flying Feet
description: After taking the stage at Zankel Hall on Wednesday night, the pianist Geri Allen read a statement from a scrap of paper, claiming to be too nervous to extemporize. But her message was concise and clear: in celebration of Black History Month, the concert would begin with a traditional spiritual and end with an original composition dedicated to Rosa Parks.

title: Whats on Saturday
description: 8 P.M. (Oxygen) THE ROBBER BRIDE (2007). Mary-Louise Parker temporarily puts down the weed to star in this adaptation of the Margaret Atwood novel about a femme fatale who disappears after stealing from her three best friends. She didnt just take their money.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about the opening of a new front in the war against illegal online sales of steroids and other performance-enhancing drugs referred incorrectly to anabolic steroids. They may be legally prescribed by doctors for some disorders; they are not illegal for any human use.

title: Manhattan: Judge Refuses to Set Aside Ruling in 93 Bombing Case
description: A judge yesterday refused a request by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to set aside a jurys decision in the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center that found the Port Authority responsible for 68 percent of the bombing and the bombers 32 percent liable. Justice Nicholas Figueroa of State Supreme Court in Manhattan rejected the authoritys argument that the October 2005 ruling should be set aside because the bombing was an unforeseeable event and because the jury instructions were improper. The decision clears the way for plaintiffs in the case to ask for trials to set damages, but the authority may also choose to appeal further. The 1993 truck bombing of the trade center by Islamic militants killed 6 people and injured 1,000.

title: After 20 Years, College 3-Point Line Gets Failing Grade
description: This season marks the 20th anniversary of the 3-point shots debut in college basketball. Virtually a layup today, in 1986-87 the 3-point attempt was the shot heard round the college basketball world.

title: Clements Signs With 49ers for 8 years and $80 Million
description: Nate Clements was not a free agent for long, but he made it pay off.

title: U.S. Predicting Steady Increase for Emissions
description: The Bush administration estimates that emissions by the United States of gases that contribute to global warming will grow nearly as fast through the next decade as they did the previous decade, according to a long-delayed report being completed for the United Nations.

title: Mental Hospital in Somaliland
description: Scenes from a mental hospital in Somaliland.

title: A Soldier Leaving Home
description: A group called the Bullhead Patriots sees Pvt. Resha Kane off to the airport.

title: ONeal, Soon to Turn 35, Scores 31 in Flash of Former Self
description: MIAMI, March 2  Superman sprinted up the court, not quite faster than a speeding bullet but faster, for sure, than Shaquille ONeal has run in a while.

title: Full Transcript: Bobby Valentine Interview
description: Here is the full transcript of Tyler Kepner's interview with Bobby Valentine. An abridged version of the interview that ran in the PLAY magazine can be found here.

title: Memories of a Colder Iceland
description: Reykjavik, Iceland

title: Long Days, Late Nights
description: Photographer Lauren Lancaster has been photographing various places and faces of Wall Street.

title: Universal Cinema
description: Images from the 2007 New York Arab & South Asian Film Festival.

title: An Interview With Marv Albert
description: Marv Albert takes a time-out with Bryan Curtis to talk about bad games, bad calls and great Marv Albert impersonations.

title: The Son Hits, the Father Paints
description: Nice to see Vernon Wells Sr. in the Yankees clubhouse this morning. Fans know his son, Vernon Jr., as the multitalented Toronto Blue Jays center fielder. Players know Vernon Sr. as their artist of choice.

title: Fallout Over Coulters Antigay Remark
