description: Theres some big fallout from the meeting in Washington of the Conservative Political Action Conference, three days of conferencing, caucusing, presidential addressing and book-hawking. These conferences have historically been known for displaying what its own organizers would describe as over-the-top behavior, and one of the regular speakers  Ann Coulter  offered an example of it when she used an anti-gay epithet on Friday to describe John Edwards, the former senator from North Carolina and Democratic presidential contender.

title: Can a Megastar Revive a Dormant United Artists?
Cargo Worker Lands in Trouble for Posting Photos Online of Prototype Corvette
description: DETROIT

title: Smart Kids, but Not a Smart Pick
description: The Bracket Blog sends off its congratulations to the Penn Quakers, which became the first team to qualify for the N.C.A.A. Tournament with an easy home victory over Yale last night. (In basketball, as in life, those Ivy guys are always getting invited to The Dance first.) This marks the seventh bid for the Quakers in nine seasons, their third consecutive bid and first under their new coach, Glenn Miller.

title: Vows: Kate and Jed
description: Kate Dawson met the love of her life, Jed Cohen, in a musical theater class.

title: Another Peak for The Valley?
description: Southern Illinois, which used to fret about receiving even an at-large bid for N.C.A.A. tournament, is playing for an N.C.A.A. seeding this weekend in the Missouri Valley Conference tournament.

title: Your Comments on Aid Workers With Guns
description: My Sunday column, from the U.S. military base in Djibouti, emphasizes that we can play a much larger role in assuring security in poor countries, and that this is a way of fighting terrorism as well as battling poverty. Its a point that Ive laid out in greater depth in an article in the NY Review of Books. Your comments on the column are welcome below (or you can submit them as letters to the editor at letters@nytimes.com). As always, I particularly welcome specific comments based on personal experience. By the way, this is the last of my columns from the Horn of Africa trip. I expect my Tuesday column to be about Senator Obama, and then next Sundays will be aboutah, well, thats a secret to be unveiled.

title: The Craft of Coach Proctor
description: When Scott Proctor retires, he says he wants to be the head coach of a college baseball program. Proctor has given himself a head start. In previous off-seasons, he gave one-on-one lessons to youngsters for $50 a session (although in the past few months he rested his right arm, which pitched in 83 games last season).

title: Fitting With Azzedine Alaa
description: The influential designer Azzedine Alaa, in his Paris studio, does the entire fitting process himself.

title: Four Bids, Send Them In
description: Today is what we here at The Bracket call a Four Bid Day. No, were not handing out pins to Delta Tau Chi pledges. Were bracing for an afternoon basketball buffet in which four teams will earn coveted automatic bids to the N.C.A.A. Tournament. Theyll be dancing with the Quakers come March 15.

title: A Scary English Ghost
description: The wonderful English actor Roy Dotrice was probably happier bombing the German Army (yes kids, there was a thing called World War II) than he was being shot down and placed in a Konzentrazionslager for the rest of the war, hosted by his former targets.

title: Numbers Dont Lie, but Sometimes They Dont Add Up
description: Some things in life look easy but arent. Shooting pool. Day trading. Filling out an N.C.A.A. tournament bracket. Well, OK, they ARE easy. But doing them well? Not so easy.

title: Hitting a High Note
description: The Belmont Bruins are dancing in the N.C.A.A. Tournament for the second straight year with Saturdays impressive 94-67 upset victory over top-seeded East Tennessee State in the championship game of the Atlantic Sun tournament.

title: Up Front
description: Today, Buzz Bissinger is best known as the author of Friday Night Lights, his 1990 best seller about high school football in Odessa, Tex., which inspired the 2004 film and current television series and has sold 1.5 million copies. His 2005 book, Three Nights in August, about baseball, was also a best seller. Less well known is that Bissinger is a longtime Philadelphian who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1987 for his beat reporting at The Philadelphia Inquirer. In the 1980s, Bissinger encountered urban blight at its worst. Some of these blocks looked like Dresden after the bombing in World War II, Bissinger recalled in a recent conversation. It was very disturbing to think any American city could get like this. He wrote about Mayor Edward Rendells efforts to rebuild Philadelphia in A Prayer for the City (1998). (Rendell is now the governor of Pennsylvania.)

title: Unclogging the City
description: It may take Mayor Michael Bloomberg a while to sell New Yorkers on his plan to keep New York as a desirable place to live, work and visit throughout the rest of this century. But right at hand lies a great opportunity to take bold action on a vexing quality of life and health issue: traffic congestion.

title: Nam and Pop
description: At the beginning of this fine book, Tom Bissell asks the obvious question: More than 30,000 books on Vietnam are currently in print. Why another? Hes certainly facing a challenge. Ive read a great many books about that godforsaken war and written one (no longer in print, sadly), and the literature of Vietnam, both fiction and non, is flat-out excellent. So why another? I bring ... only this, Bissell writes: I have spent most of my life thinking about it  and, more to the point, living with it, because his father, John, was a Marine Corps lieutenant who saw combat in Vietnam and, like so many others, brought the war home. What I could not know about my father because of his experience has always fascinated and troubled me, Bissell writes. Happily, for father, son and us, Harpers Magazine agreed to send both Bissells back to Vietnam for a visit, in which much, but not everything, is learned and John Bissell comes to terms with his service, if not entirely with his son. This, then, is a book that combines the virtues of distance and immediacy  the cool perspective that comes from investigating a war that was pretty much over before the author was born and the searing immediacy of being raised by a troubled veteran of that lost war.

title: Where Indian Cuisine Reaches for the Stars
description: DID the Indian restaurant, with its flock wallpaper and piped sitars and tablas, its biryanis and vindaloos, save British cuisine? It was in the '60s that Indian restaurants began to proliferate, and four decades later, in 2001, Robin Cook, the foreign minister, hailed chicken tikka masala as a true national dish of Britain. Previously, there was only fancy French food out of the reach of most, and the bland boiled nursery yuck that generations of Britons had had little choice but to swill, and tell themselves they liked.

title: One Very, Very Indie Band
description: Damn, this church is getting hectic, what with Rgine in the organists alcove coaxing the backup singers to let loose  Sing like really hungry wolves! Like youre sending a desperate alarm to the other wolves!  and Win down in the sanctuary trying to keep the upright double bass and tenor sax from veering toward smooth jazz, and Jeremy picking through dozens of black-metal shipping crates to make sure the equipments all there  Wins dobro, Rgines hurdy-gurdy, the glockenspiel, the accordions, the giant Asian cymbals and the neon Jesus sign  everything packed up tight and ready to be shipped off to London for the start of the bands yearlong world tour. Its a snowy January night just outside Montreal, and each time the front door opens, gusts of frigid air blow through the nave: Hey, close the. . . . Oh, its Liza! Hey everybody, Lizas here! Earlier, the church got so crowded that Sarah had to record her violin part (Rgine: Make it weird, like a ghost violin, a sci-fi violin, a violin from outer space!) squished into the sound booth while Richie took his guitar into the stairwell because someone was playing a Mexican reveille on the trumpet and there was a French horn warming up in the kitchen.

title: Tackling Usual Camden Practices, Like Payroll Kept in Pencil
description: CAMDEN, N.J., March 1  There was little left to surprise those who have followed the plight of Camden, New Jerseys poorest city and one that has been riddled with mismanagement.

title: Vote for Gilbert
description: I have 45 seconds to deliberate with Gilbert Arenas.

title: A Scary Tuesday Was No Black Monday
Pileup on the Tappan Zee
description: The hasty planners who threw up the Tappan Zee Bridge in the 1950s gave the region a lousy bridge and a chronic transportation headache. That headache is now the political equivalent of a full-blown migraine. The pockmarked bridge is nearing the end of its natural life, and regional policymakers and residents are confronting a blindingly complicated tangle of questions over what to do about that, how to do it, and where to get the money.

title: Hospitals Urge Screening in Lung Cancer Detection
description: ALTHOUGH the debate over the benefits of routine lung-cancer screening remains unresolved, some local hospitals are taking the lead and encouraging smokers and other high-risk patients to obtain low-dose CT scans in the belief that early detection will save lives.

title: Gentlemen of the Road
description: Chapter 6: On Some Peculiarities in the Trading Practices of Northmen

title: Jennifer Saunders Goes Absolutely Bucolic
description: Pasadena, Calif.

title: Anne Frank, U.S. Citizen? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Police and Protesters Clash in St. Petersburg
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia, March 3  An unusually large and unruly protest against the government of President Vladimir V. Putin ended here Saturday in clashes with the police and the arrest of opposition leaders. Rally organizers and the police said more than 100 people were arrested after a midafternoon scuffle between marchers and riot police on the main street, Nevsky Prospekt, in the heart of the citys tourist district. St. Petersburg, Russias second-largest city, is Mr. Putins hometown.

title: Its God vs. Satan. But What About the Nudity?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Candace Parker, Fly Girl
description: If you know only one thing about Candace Parker, its this: she dunks. And not infrequently. Over the past year, Parker, the University of Tennessees 6-foot-4 guard/forward/center, has single-handedly eclipsed the total number of dunks in the history of womens N.C.A.A. basketball. (Thats six jams to three, if youre scoring at home.) Parker pulled off her first dunk at age 15. At 17, she whupped five male contestants  including the future Denver Nuggets starter J. R. Smith  in the slam dunk contest at the McDonalds All-American High School Game. And last year, Parker became the first woman to throw down in an N.C.A.A. tournament game, dunking twice during a win over Army.

title: The Peoples Republic of Sex Kittens and Metrosexuals
Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: Rare Monteverdi, Tragicomic Rossini and a Sample Stew
description: MONTEVERDI: COMBATTIMENTO

title: Varieties in the Spices of Life
description: Varietys the very spice of life/That gives it all its flavor, the English poet William Cowper wrote three centuries ago. And judging by the depth and breadth of its spice collection, Penzeys Spices seems to have taken that message to heart.

title: Correction: Tiny State, Big Ambitions
description: An article last Sunday about Connecticut politicians who have run for president referred incorrectly to the presidential campaigns of Lamar Alexander of Tennessee. Mr. Alexander ran for president in 1996 and 2000 before being elected to the United States Senate in 2002; he did not follow in Al Gores footsteps by serving as a senator from Tennessee before seeking the White House.

title: Letters
description: Preparing for the Bar Exam

title: Alle Montagne con Papa (To the Mountains, With the Old Man)
description: 1. If were not careful, my brother, Toby, said as we loaded our bags into a taxi at Milans Malpensa airport, this could end up being a story about emergency medical facilities in northern Italy.

title: Town Shows Its Face, if Not Its Reputation
description: VIDOR, Tex.

title:
A Tragedy During Childbirth; Immigration Laws and Enforcement; A Phone Number for the Homeless; Safe Surfing on the Web; A Couples Devotion
 to Sick Animals; Preparing for College by Enjoying Oneself (9 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Dorm Plan: Students Smile, Neighbors Fret
description: Though Queens College is officially a commuter school, the institution offers several things that many branches of the City University system lack, among them grass, trees and a quadrangle bordered by buildings roofed in terra cotta that create a feeling of tranquil scholarship. But like most other branches of the City University of New York, the 18,000-student college, in Flushing, has lacked one familiar element of college life: a dormitory.

title: Sit Down for a Chat With Hedge Fund Movers
description: JOHN MAYNARD KEYNES was a day trader. Besides his own fortune, he invested the money of his employer, Kings College of Cambridge University. From 1928 to 1945, when British equities shrank 0.5 percent a year on average, Keynes earned the college an annualized return of 13.2 percent, wagering on stocks and bonds, but also currencies and commodities, using insight into global events.

title: Sita Sonty and Ross Taggart
description: Sreelakshmi Sita Sonty was married to Ross Gordon Taggart on Friday. Gerald E. Williams, a civil magistrate, officiated in his office in Arlington, Va. On Feb. 21, a Hindu priest performed a religious ceremony at the Taj Exotica, a hotel in Benaulim, India.

title: Big Brother, Armed With a Spotlight
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Want a Little Budget Ornament? Put Your Name on It
description: TRENTON

title: Darwins God
description: God has always been a puzzle for Scott Atran. When he was 10 years old, he scrawled a plaintive message on the wall of his bedroom in Baltimore. God exists, he wrote in black and orange paint, or if he doesnt, were in trouble. Atran has been struggling with questions about religion ever since  why he himself no longer believes in God and why so many other people, everywhere in the world, apparently do.

title: The Silver-Tongued Devil
description: Long drawn to silence, the Irish novelist Patrick McCabe is generally content to let the spaces between his words speak louder than the words themselves. Anybody who has read The Butcher Boy  or seen Neil Jordans faithfully warped film adaptation  knows that he loves to withhold information; as a storyteller, his preferred mode is a kind of aggressive coyness. Among other advantages, this creates an atmosphere of brooding suspense and lets McCabe delve into subjects that in heavier hands might seem garish or puerile: his portraits of a young killer in The Butcher Boy and of a transvestite prostitute in Breakfast on Pluto both were finalists for the Booker Prize.

title: Campus Exposure
description: Aaron Foster, a junior majoring in history at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, was browsing Craigslist one day in 2005 when he saw an ad for nude models. It had been posted by Boink, a glossy new sex magazine by and about college students founded by Alecia Oleyourryk, then a senior at nearby Boston University, and Christopher Anderson, a software consultant in his 30s moonlighting as a photographer. Youre going to pay me $200, and all I have to do is pretend to be with a chick  youre going to pay me to do that? was how Foster, now 24, a slim, dark-haired former marine with pierced nipples and tattoos of raking animal claws on his back, described his reaction.

title: A European Tour in Three Bottles
description: Three wines typify Moore Brothers, specialists in small French, Italian and German producers, at 33 East 20th Street (Broadway).

title: The Lot of the Consultant: Explaining What You Do
description: FOR the growing number of independent consultants, going solo can offer greater flexibility, better compensation and more family time than would generally be possible in corporate America.

title: Reading With Kundera
description: Milan Kundera (who writes these days in French) is perhaps the best, certainly the best-known, Czech fiction writer since Kafka (who was arguably more German than Czech anyway). This is his third book-length meditation on the novel, all three translated with precision and grace by Linda Asher. And while there is a fair amount of overlap and repetition in The Curtain, The Art of the Novel (1988) and Testaments Betrayed (1995), its due more to the consistency of Kunderas approach to reading and writing fiction and the persistence of certain literary preferences and prejudices  his literary values  than to an inability to move on. Its also due to his belief that reading and writing novels, from Cervantes to Rushdie, is a way of thinking that is essential for a coherent moral understanding of human nature and circumstance.

title: The Doctors Dilemma
description: Norman Bethune made his name, such as it is, as a battlefield surgeon. Drawn to the war against fascism in Spain, the Canadian physician pioneered the use of mobile medical units  the forerunners of MASH hospitals  and figured out how to preserve and transport blood to the front lines. The driving consideration was to get as close to the fighting as possible, since faster treatment of wounds meant fewer infections. I ask only to know in advance when your troops will next attack, the fictional Bethune who narrates Dennis Bocks new novel tells an uncomprehending military officer. To what end, the officer asks. Beyond saving lives? Bethune brusquely responds. Is there more?

title: Fashions Latest Crush
description: PARIS

title: The Spirit of 50s and 60s Rocks in a Song Revue
description: The older gentleman sitting behind me read down the list of songs made famous by the likes of Elvis Presley, Ben E. King, the Drifters and the Coasters, and said to his wife, Im not familiar with the titles. And I expect that the younger spectators in the family crowd at the splendid and cozy Thomaston Opera House were equally in the dark about the beehive-era hits listed in the program. But it didnt take long for the whole audience  newbies of all ages and baby boomers remembering hours spent listening to their radios  to start clapping along to the irresistible tunes of Smokey Joes Cafe.

title: Early Admissions
description: This week private preschools will send out their coveted acceptance letters to anxious parents. Once again, the number of available spots is shrinking as the city continues to experience a baby boom.

title: Long Island: Home Prices No Longer Appreciating Sharply
description: After many years of double-digit appreciation in the value of single-family homes on Long Island, the median price for homes dropped 6.25 percent in Nassau County in January and increased only slightly in Suffolk County, compared with the same month last year, according to real estate market analysts.

title: A Plane Full of Dollars (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Dcor That Sizzles, and So Do the Steaks
description: AS a restaurant critic, Ive never put much stock in ambience. Good food is good food, to my way of thinking, whether the setting is a mountaintop or a strip mall, whether the diners are wearing silk or denim. This time I was wrong.

title: Slaverys Legacy, Neverending (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Talk About a Working Vacation
description: The sun is brilliant, the sky is deep blue, the temperature hovers near 100 degrees  and I am, almost literally, freezing. Six of us have just finished our first day at the Core Performance camp at Athletes Performance, an intensive one-week indoctrination into the health and fitness philosophy of the trainer-to-the-stars Mark Verstegen, and we are quickly  and painfully  learning about regeneration, one of the key elements of the program. After a day of warm-ups, prehab exercises (designed to prevent injuries), strength screening and cardiovascular testing, Joe Gomes, our coach, has us alternating between a hot tub and a 55-degree cold plunge, a process that helps facilitate muscle recovery. At the moment, we are submerged to our necks in the frigid water. Gomes, a 28-year-old Brit who heads up Athletes Performances education programs (and has helped train Navy Seal units and consulted for the Wimbledon tennis championships), stands on the edge of the cold plunge, stopwatch in hand. We curse, whimper and complain until, finally, one of my fellow campers, Lynn Forrest, a fit, tanned and retired 40-something from Connecticut, asks the question on all of our minds: How much longer?

title: Patagonia in a New Light
description: THE end of the world is wet and cold and covered in mud. Not the kind of mud in which children like to play or the kind that signals a renewal of the earth after a rainfall. This is mud that sucks you into a mire, drags you into the ground, threatening to devour your body while forcing you to slog onward, foot over foot, simply to escape.

title: Correction: 	All _______ on the Western Front (You Decide)
description: An article on Feb. 11 about the World War I stage drama Journeys End, set on the eve of Germanys Spring Offensive, misidentified the rank of Erich Ludendorff, who led the campaign. It was deputy chief of the general staff, not field marshal.

title: A Portland Community Forges a New Identity
description: PORTLAND, Me.

title: Xbox Cinema
description: WHEN the dust finally settled on the 2006 holiday buying season, American consumers  who braved long lines, cold weather and possibly a few kicks to the shins  had spent $3.7 billion on new video-game consoles and software. And while the more than two million youngsters (and not-so-youngsters) who discovered a next-generation gaming system under the Christmas tree  a Microsoft Xbox 360, a Sony PlayStation 3 or a Nintendo Wii  represent a substantial user base for these platforms, they mean even more to the entertainment industry as a whole. To the makers of these video-game systems and to a growing number of film and television studios, they represent a significant new audience for full-length movies and television shows that can be downloaded directly to gaming consoles.

title: Tragic Mountain
description: Natural disasters follow a script in America, a maddening, though some might argue reassuring, drama that taps into our puritanical righteousness, our legacy of entitlement and our compulsion to right wrongs with regulatory legislation. Whether a hurricane is to blame or a blizzard, as in The White Cascade: The Great Northern Railway Disaster and Americas Deadliest Avalanche, by Gary Krist, our outrage in retrospect seems matched only by our lack of foresight at the time. Set in 1910 on elegant Pullmans and drab boxcars held hostage by snow in the Cascade mountains, Krists account of an avalanche  which struck early on the morning of March 1 and killed 96 men, women and children  resonates because the particulars of such national tragedies have not, in fact, changed much.

title: Scanning the Pandas
description: Ive recently learned about something called negative and positive scanning. If youre a positive scanner, it means you always see the bright side of things, even when maybe you shouldnt. Negative scanning is when everything seems to be going just fine, but you still manage to find something wrong. Its not being able to wear your favorite shirt, the one that makes you feel like a different person, because theres a pen dot on the sleeve. Its not being able to enjoy your wedding day because youre pretty sure the guy at the deli doesnt like you.

title: A High-Fashion Lane in Shanghai
description: TAIKANG ROAD, at the southern end of the French Concession area in Shanghai, does not look like a portal to the cutting edge of high fashion. A dark alleyway leads to Lane 248, a narrow street filled with, among other things, old bicycles, yam carts and clotheslines dripping with laundry.

title: Judge to Decide Validity of Case on Marijuana
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 3  A federal judge has asked the United States attorney here to submit all trial preparation memorandums in the case against a leading advocate of medical marijuana so that the court can determine if the government has been pursuing a vindictive prosecution.

title: Immigration: A Tale of Three Cities
description: Connecticut does not speak with one voice on immigration. Far from it. Cities send their own messages, some welcoming, some divisive. No municipality can make up for the lack of a consistent federal policy on immigration, or change the tendency of the United States government to look the other way, which has allowed 11 million to move to this country illegally, most to find work. Breaking the law is not to be condoned, yet many illegal immigrants will probably wind up staying here. That is why the reactions of municipal governments to this issue are important. They will shape their communities for years to come.

title: Bring Back the Politics of Personal Destruction
description: IF you had to put a date on when the Iraq war did in the Bush administration, it would be late summer 2005. Thats when the bungled federal response to Hurricane Katrina re-enacted the White House bungling of the war, this time with Americans as the principal victims. The stuff happening on Brownies watch in New Orleans was recognizably the same stuff that had happened on Donald Rumsfelds watch in Baghdad. Television viewers connected the dots and the presidents poll numbers fell into the 30s. There they have largely remained  at least until Friday, when the latest New York Times-CBS News Poll put him at 29.

title: A Torah in Warsaw Just Asking to Be Adopted
description: HARTSDALE

title: With a Little Extra Cash
description: What to do with a bonus? The right thing, of course, is to pay off debts or save it for a time when there are not any bonuses. But in Albany, extra cash in the state larder has always been a dangerous thing. Any financial windfall has legislators hungrily looking at ways to spend it. This has already started to happen, with lawmakers eyeballing a projected budgetary surplus of just under $1 billion  not all that grand when you consider that the total state budget is in the neighborhood of $120 billion, but a healthy number nonetheless.

title: Senator Says He Urged Removal of Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, said today that he had urged the Justice Department to dismiss the states top federal prosecutor, who in December was one of eight United States attorneys ousted from their jobs.

title: The Interrupted Opera, and a Message From Bowie
description: I GREW up surrounded by public media. My grandfather was involved in the founding of WBJC, the classical music public radio station in Baltimore. He was an electronics professor and helped create the station to give his students a real-life application of what they were learning.

title: Supersizing The Masters
description: If you are looking for an explanation for the seemingly relentless changes made in recent years at the Augusta National Golf Club, an excerpt from a book writtenby the club chairman is well worth reading.

title: Correction: Back at the Brink, Chrysler Finds Fewer Friends
description: An article last Sunday about the problems facing the Chrysler Group misidentified a celebrity who performed at a company party during the Detroit auto show in January. It was Emmitt Smith, the Dancing With the Stars winner and former football star  not the pop singer Seal, who performed at a different event.

title: A Tremor in Shanghai Is Felt Around the World
description: Stock markets declined around the world last week after the Shanghai market dropped steeply on Tuesday. On Wall Street, stocks had their worst weekly performance since January 2003.

title: Typecasting
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Reunion
description: Like many writers with grand ambitions, Yasmina Reza has often strained to be what shes not. She is a born satirist, a gifted and wry observer of the absurdities and feints of social life (three old friends feud over an all-white painting in her hit play Art) and of the small self-deceptions that help us all survive. Yet in her slender dramas and fictions she has also set herself up as a mini-Proust, grasping at immense themes that elude her: the slipstream of time, the isolation of individuals and especially of artists.

title: Talking About Books (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Out of India, Dances and Crafts Drawn From Inspiration
description: SATYA PRADEEP can express nine different emotions in about 45 seconds without saying a word. She squares her shoulders and elevates her chin, or lowers her eyelids and creases her brow. Her hands are as expressive as her face, twisting and curling in fluid motions around her head and shoulders.

title: Nursery School Starts, and a Novelist Is Born
description: Sands Point

title: Interview the Vampire
description: On the acknowledgments page that concludes his new novel, John Marks writes, Finally, a special debt of thanks to the folks at Don Hewitts 60 Minutes, or as I like to think of it, the CBS News Writer in Residence Program. Since Markss novel deals with a bloodsucking Eastern European monster who has slithered up from the bowels of hell with a plan to seize control of an American television program that sounds an awful lot like 60 Minutes (where Marks used to work as a producer), and since the stars of the show are portrayed as being only slightly less self-involved  and decrepit  than the vampire himself, its hard to tell how grateful Hewitt will be for this decorous nod.

title: As Political Unrest Eases, Travel Picks Up
description: WITH political stability returning to Nepal, so too are adventure-oriented travel companies, many of which had discontinued their trips to the country over the last few years.

title: Correction: Essay on Saul Bellow
description: An essay on Feb. 4 about the career of Saul Bellow referred incorrectly to his travel experiences. Though he had not visited Africa when he wrote his 1959 novel Henderson the Rain King, which was set there, he did in fact eventually take a trip to the continent, in 1970.

title: Palestinian Leaders Discuss Unity Government
description: JERUSALEM, March 4  Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president and head of Fatah, arrived in Gaza today to meet with Ismail Haniya, the caretaker prime minister from Hamas, in another effort to iron out differences over a possible Palestinian unity government.

title: Downhill From Here
description: When I moved to Colorado a few years ago in my late 50s, I was divorced and involuntarily retired  from my work in TV and from my duties as a parent. After 24 years, the jobs dried up, and my two kids were away in college. Whenever I called them, they were I.M.-ing their friends, doing homework or watching a movie. They seemed irritated by whatever I did or said, including Good morning. When I had dinner with my son, a computer-science major who is on the snowboard team and flies a plane, he would arrive late and leave quickly. Teaching a college class one day a week, I was at loose ends the rest of the time. Should I volunteer? Read the classics? Call up friends of friends?

title: Female Bonding on Bond Street
description: FOR the moment, the cobblestone block of Bond Street between Lafayette Street and the Bowery represents nothing so much as a boisterous construction zone. Workers haul materials to and fro, through sooty remnants of snow, for three large properties under construction.

title: Veterans Affairs
description: For decades, the literary genre known as the baseball memoir  think Jose Cansecos Juiced or Pete Roses My Prison Without Bars  was a chance for a retired jock to put pencil to paper and let the stories rip. (I remember this road trip in Milwaukee. . . . ) The only matter requiring much reflection was which stories, for pharmacological reasons or otherwise, to leave out. Lately, though, a new and more intriguing form of baseball literature has begun to appear. Aging ballplayers have been bringing forth not vanity memoirs but angry polemics. They have beefs with baseball and want them heard. Mike Schmidt took some whacks last year in his book Clearing the Bases, and now Dave Winfield has issued his own call to arms. In his new book, Dropping the Ball (co-written with Michael Levin), Winfield argues that baseball is subtly declining in importance to Americans, especially African-Americans.

title: The Hanging Tower of Jersey City
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Away From the City, a Studio That Rocks
description: MAMARONECK

title: Webber, Back in Michigan, Forever One of the Fab Five
description: MIAMI, March 3  On Thursday afternoon, the day of his 34th birthday, Chris Webber wore his Detroit Tigers hat, Detroit Pistons sweats and a grin so bright he looked as if he were a child unwrapping a present.

title: Facing N.C.A.A., the Best Defense Is a Legal Team
description: The black binders contained more than 700 pages and documented the misdeeds of the University of Kansas mens and womens basketball and football programs. Among the findings were payments to athletes and academic fraud. The report suggested remedies like self-imposed probation and a reduction in scholarships.

title: That Ship Will Come in, Right?
description: WAVE SYSTEMS has never had a profitable quarter. Ever. In nearly 20 years.

title: Corrections
description: Editors Note

title: Doubts Rise as States Hold Sex Offenders After Prison
description: The decision by New York to confine sex offenders beyond their prison terms places the state at the forefront of a growing national movement that is popular with politicians and voters. But such programs have almost never met a stated purpose of treating the worst criminals until they no longer pose a threat.

title: Has Real Estate Lost Its Sizzle? Not on the Farm
description: SOARING crop prices, strong export markets and growing demand for biofuels are adding up to good times for many American farmers. So its not surprising that farmland, particularly in the upper Midwest, has begun to reflect that good fortune with rapidly rising prices.

title: Do the Math
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Way Out but Feeling O.K.
description: Whats one year and 335 days between brothers?

title: Correction: Fruit of the Lemon Review
description: A review on Feb. 11 about Fruit of the Lemon, by Andrea Levy, referred incorrectly to the books publishing history. It was published in Britain in 1999; it is not a new novel (although a United States edition appeared for the first time in February), and it was written before another of Levys novels, Small Island, not after.

title: Crimes Mr. Untouchable Emerges From Shadows
description: The 74-year-old man who used to be Leroy Nicholas Barnes, owner of 60 pairs of custom-made shoes, 27 full-length leather coats and more than one Mercedes-Benz, wears baggy Lee dungarees these days and drives to work in a used car he bought five years ago.

title: The Week in Westchester
description: Mayan Temple Owners Lose in Zoning Dispute

title: Horsing Around Is Helping Kidd and the Nets
description: Jason Kidd is enjoying some of the best shooting days of his 13-year N.B.A. career, thanks in part to a game that allows him to act as if he were on the playground  and to make (or lose) some pocket change.

title: Medieval Modern: Design Strikes a Defensive Posture
description: Not so long ago, architects were obsessed with the notion that globalism, the Internet and sophisticated new building technologies were opening the way for a more fluid, transparent landscape in which walls would simply begin to melt away.

title: The Year of Hoping for Stage Magic
description: I AM making these first notes on Monday, Jan. 29, 2007.

title: Gayle Greenberg, Matthew Slonim
description: Gayle Susan Greenberg and Matthew Lance Slonim were married last evening at the Ritz-Carlton New York, Battery Park. Rabbi Peter Rubinstein officiated.

title: Behind Ivy-Covered Walls, Where Life Begins and Ends
description: Its not a good sign when arguably the most intriguing character in a play with a cast of seven is a veritable no-show.

title: Shanghai What-If: How a Shock Can Become a Shock Wave
description: COULD this be the global financial meltdown? Less than a week ago, it might have seemed preposterous to suggest that a 9 percent fall in the Shanghai stock exchange could jolt markets across the world, triggering declines in everything from European stocks to American corporate bonds.

title: Bobby Valentine, the American Tsunami
description: Bobby Valentine is so popular in Japan that a beer and a hamburger have been named for him there. But Valentine, the former New York Mets manager who once put on a fake mustache and returned to the dugout after being ejected, would prefer to be known for nudging Major League Baseball out of its global myopia. More than two dozen stars have left Japan for the United States since Hideo Nomo arrived in 1995. Valentine was managing in Japan that year and is back there now, beginning the fourth season of his second stint with the Chiba Lotte Marines, whom he led to a league title in 2005. He is pushing for the international growth of baseball, and the startling $51.1 million fee the Boston Red Sox paid for the right to negotiate with pitcher Daisuke Matsuzaka is not what he has in mind.

title: Correction: At Yale, She's Telling the American Indian Story to an Eager Audience
description: An article and a caption last Sunday about a Yale professor, Alyssa Mt. Pleasant, misstated her title and background. She is an assistant professor in the American Studies Program and History Department, not a full professor in American Indian studies (a program that does not exist at Yale). Her training at Cornell was in history and American Indian studies, not history and American studies.

title: Correction: The Awakening of Hanoi
description: An article on Feb. 18 about Hanois growing art scene misspelled the name of a historical figure used to describe the revered status of a gallery owner, Nguyen Manh Duc, by artists in Hanoi. He is considered Gandhi-like, not Ghandi-like.

title: Teaching Movie Moguls to Wipe Drool
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Buy Low. Sell High. Work Long. Party Hearty.
description: IT was a queasy week on Wall Street. And sweating through every plunge, rebound and fluctuation were bleary-eyed young workers sitting for long hours in front of computer screens in the financial district.

title: Learning a Language: A Childs Edge
description: Any adult who sets out to learn a foreign language knows how frustrating it can be to make sense of the simplest rules of semantics and syntax. Words are hard to remember; phrases, hard to come by. The mere task of pronunciation can be a battle for control: your brain tells your tongue to vibrate against the roof of your mouth, but your tongue rolls on itself instead.

title: Comings and Goings
description: If you are flying on Air France this spring, dont be surprised if fellow passengers start spouting broken Hindi or Danish at their seatback television screens. Starting in April, foreign language lessons  available in 23 tongues  will be available on Air Frances fleet of Boeing 777-300s. The interactive audiovisual language program, which is free, includes pronunciation exercises, tests and games, and was developed in partnership with Berlitz World Traveler (www.airfrance.com/us). ...This weekend, a new water park  billed as the largest in the Caribbean  opened in Atlantis, Paradise Island in the Bahamas. Aquaventure features waterfalls, a mile-long river ride and water escalators that are built around the 120-foot tall Power Tower (below), which, in turn, has four water slides. One slide  the Abyss  involves a 50-foot near-vertical drop into darkness, a plunge through a waterfall and then a splash into a cenote, where alligator gars lurk behind glass panels. The park is free for Atlantis guests (www.atlantis.com). ...New Yorkers who like to play the slots will soon be able to hop an express train to Atlantic City from Penn Station. The Atlantic City Express Service, which is being financed by the Borgata, Caesars and Harrahs hotel casinos in Atlantic City along with the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, is scheduled to begin in late 2007 or early 2008. Prices are expected to be competitive with Amtraks Acela service between New York and Philadelphia, which costs between $76 and $129 each way. ... For New Yorkers who prefer to get their adrenaline rush via food and wine, theres the Adirondack Festival of Food and Wine. The festival, from March 22 to 25 at the Mirror Lake Inn Resort and Spa in Lake Placid (www.mirrorlakeinn.com), includes guests like Curtiss Hemm, chef instructor at the New England Culinary Institute, and Dale Miller, executive chef at Jacks Oyster House in Albany. There will be seminars and competitions and three dinners with wine pairings, many of which come from New York State vineyards. ...Several high-end hotels in Montreal, including Le Place dArmes Hotel and Suites, are offering a Sweet Deal package through May 31, which invites guests to stay a second, consecutive night for half the price of the first. Also included in the package is a gift, two casino coupons, and shopping discounts (www.montrealsweetdeals.com).

title: Returning, Safe, After a Years Service in Afghanistan
description: FORT DIX, N.J., March 2  In person, Specialist Lourdes Siverio looked remarkably like the picture her mother painted of her while she was away.

title: Molecular Theory
description: DUSHAN ZARIC has a theory. Actually, Mr. Zaric, an owner of the West Village cocktailery Employees Only, has lots of theories. Some of them, on the subject of human mating rituals as they pertain to drinking, are collected in a recent book, You Didnt Hear It From Us, that Mr. Zaric wrote with his fellow Employees Only owner Jason Kosmas.

description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 3  Jason Kidds words were thick with disappointment Saturday afternoon as he dissected the Nets stunning collapse against the Boston Celtics, one of the N.B.A.s worst teams.

title: A Home as Art Project
description: BARKHAMSTED

title: Kiss Kiss Talk Talk
description: In everyday talk, storytelling is ubiquitous: Youll never believe what happened to me today.  Ill never forget the time when. ... Did you hear the one about ...? When in doubt  or at loose ends or in need of attention  we narrate. I have only anecdotal evidence to support this hunch, but it seems to me that this conversational propensity to share stories is somewhat neglected by novelists. More often than not, characters in fiction are inclined to get right to the point, to speak their minds, to engage in verbal exposition. Their authors, perhaps reluctant to share the prerogatives of plot-making with imaginary beings, tend not to indulge the digressive impulses that, in the world beyond the page, consume so much time and breath.

title: Calendar of Events
description: FILM

title: Mascots in Court, Not on the Court
description: Chief Illiniwek performed his last dance as the University of Illinoiss mascot on Feb. 21 , but he has not gone quietly.

title: 40 Years Between Records: A Shangri-La Returns
description: BABYLON, N.Y.

title: A Wildlife Lover Gets His Dream Job at Last
description: TRENTON

title: Anand and Carlsen Tie for Lead in First Half of Morelia/Linares
description: For years, Linares, Spain, has been the unlikely location for the most prestigious tournament on the chess calendar.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: A Brush With Death, and an Album Is Born
description: WHEN Marc Black got the call saying that his friend Dan Mountain had suffered a stroke, his first thought was, Yeah, but itll be O.K.

title: Critic of the K.G.B. Is Shot and Wounded Outside His Home
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  A few hours after meeting a former K.G.B. general outside a spy museum here, an outspoken critic of the Kremlin became engulfed in the kind of intrigue he studies when he was shot Thursday outside his suburban Maryland home.

title: Fears for a Dams Safety Put Tourist Area on Edge
description: BURKESVILLE, Ky.  Below the Wolf Creek Dam, which holds back the biggest manmade lake east of the Mississippi, residents joke that they are not worried about a breach but sleep in life jackets, just in case.

title: Lundqvist Gets Rest, and Backup Saves Rangers
description: When goaltender Stephen Valiquette batted the final shot of the shootout into the air yesterday afternoon, he threw his glove hand skyward and reveled in the most unlikely victory of the Rangers season as his teammates enveloped him in a joyful mob.

title: Sounds From Out of Africa, Melding Old and New
description: THEY are best known back home as the blind couple of Mali. Here they are known by their first names. Amadou Bagayoko, 52, and Mariam Doumbia, 48, met in 1974 in the orchestra of Malis Institute for the Young Blind. They began touring in 1978 with their band, Eclipse, and in 1980 they were married. Ten albums later, as Amadou & Mariam, they are renowned in world music circles. Amadou, who plays electric guitar and is a fan of Led Zeppelin, calls their music Afro-rock. On 2005s Dimanche  Bamako (Nonesuch), they teamed with the Franco-Spanish producer Manu Chao, the patron saint of found sounds, and the result won them a Victoire, the French equivalent of a Grammy. They sing in French and Bambara, Malis national language, and write their songs together, after a fashion: Hes an early bird, shes a night owl. Via translator, Amadou spoke recently by phone from Bamako, the capital of Mali, with Winter Miller about the predominantly African music hes listening to now.

title: Super Agents, Super Teams
description: THE young couple are seated together awaiting another real estate agents appraisal in what is called the English pub room of their 1730 antique home in Westport, Conn. Theirs is the kind of property that ads typically limn as historic charmer with state-of-the-art amenities. This means the imposing stone hearth is hung with a tasteful dark plasma screen instead of a fox-hunting print.

title: Emotional N.C. State Surprises No. 1 Duke
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 3  As the clock ticked to zero and the victory was secure, the North Carolina State womens basketball teams bench emptied and the players poured onto the court at Greensboro Coliseum screaming and jumping and wiping tears from their eyes.

title: Gordon Parks Lived Here. Dont Touch, Town Asks.
description: Greenburgh

title: Correction: DJ Drama
description: An article on Feb. 18 about DJ Drama, who is famous for making so-called mixtapes, which combine music samples from different artists often without permission, misspelled the surname of the creative director of an organization that works with copyrights for artists and producers. He is Eric Steuer, not Steur.

title: The Phone Ranger
description: Each day people are more brazen and rude with their cellphones. My husband bought a device that can block the signals of cellphone users who annoy him, although he knows such gizmos are illegal. Isnt his vigilante behavior worse than that of the rudest cell user?  Name Withheld, Connecticut

title: When Volvo Took a Bit Off the Top
description: WHAT WAS IT? The 1978-81 262C, which came to be known simply as the Volvo Coupe, was Volvos bid to compete in the growing class of personal coupes.

title: Scat Daddy Is Back in Derby Discussion
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla., March 3  These colts had looked each other in the eye twice before, and Scat Daddy and Nobiz Like Shobiz had split those decisions in a couple of important stakes races.

title: Alou Will Be 11 Miles From Two Murders That He Cant Forget
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 2  The phone rang in Moises Alous apartment in Montreal. It was late, creeping toward midnight, and his wife, Austria, six months pregnant with their second child, was sitting beside him, watching a movie.

title: Are Home Builders Out of the Basement Yet?
description: PRICE cuts. Amenity upgrades. Vacations. Free gas for the minivan. As the spring home-selling season looms, home builders eager to trim mounting inventories of unsold houses amid an industrywide slump are dangling these and other incentives before buyers.

title: Lo Duca Says Pelfrey Has What It Takes
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 3  Mets Manager Willie Randolph refuses to read much into the first spring starts of any of his pitchers, young or old. Given the backup-heavy lineup the Los Angeles Dodgers brought to Tradition Field on Saturday, Randolph felt even less inclined to gush over the right-hander Mike Pelfreys two scoreless innings.

title: Turning Green, Schools Lead in Solar Energy
description: IF Dan Sabia had not noticed a rebate offer on his own LIPA bill almost five years ago, the Carle Place School District might never have become a local pioneer in solar energy.

title: Learning English (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Special Olympics, the Opportunity of a Lifetime
description: WESTBROOK

title: A New Mystery to Prosecutors: Their Lost Jobs
description: This article is by David Johnston, Eric Lipton and William Yardley.

title: A Composer Forgotten to All but Mozart
description: A FEW brush strokes have come to define the otherwise obscure 18th-century composer later known as Il Divino Boemo, or the Divine Bohemian: Josef Myslivecek.

title: The 25-Year Itch
description: IN many ways, Jack Tuttle has spent the past quarter-century hunting for a new home. In the beginning, he felt no great urgency to move, though increasingly he had reason to.

title: Congestion in the Clubhouse at Spring Training
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: Good Old Days Sara Fanelli
description: Is there an art of aging? Or is there merely aging, a condition over which one hasnt all that much control and in which one is hostage to ones genetic inheritance and financial resources, and dependent on friends and family members to help ease the way into old age and thence as gently as possible into that blasted good night?

title: Feed a Pigeon, Breed a Spat
description: Feed a Pigeon, Breed a Spat

title: Falling From Grace
description: The very old word charisma, which was brought back into popular use by the German sociologist Max Weber early last century, is hard to define. Today it means a certain mysterious drawing-power common to hack politicians, Hollywood bombshells and leaders of cults. But according to Philip Rieff, the University of Pennsylvania sociologist who died last year, the term has such a variety of applications only because Weber revised as well as revived it. Rieff is best known as a sympathetic critic of Freuds work and a not-so-sympathetic historian of its cultural importance. His bleak and influential book, The Triumph of the Therapeutic (1966), described modern mans search, vain in most cases, for creeds to replace the ones that psychoanalysis undermines. Charisma, his dense and difficult new book, performs a similar task, with sociology rather than psychoanalysis as its backdrop. Forgetting the humility associated with charisma in the New Testament, Rieff warns, has led us into our most dangerous scientific experiment  with moral disorder.

title: Correction: Stephen Marley in Tallahassee, M.I.A. in India and Klaxons on Fire
description: A picture last Sunday with a review of Stephen Marleys single The Traffic Jam in the Playlist column was published in error. Instead of Mr. Marley, it showed his brother Ky-Mani.

title: Aid Workers With Guns
description: CAMP LEMONIER, Djibouti

title: Merchant Memories
description: Mall of America T-Shirt

title: Mixed Budget Messages
description: It was as if Gov. Jon Corzine had two budget messages for New Jersey, and the first was filled with good news. Not only would there be no tax increases this year, but Trenton would come up with $2 billion in relief for high property taxes and a 3 percent increase for school districts.

title: Bucking a Trend in Coffee Shops
description: Its not easy to be a locally owned coffee shop these days. Its even harder if there is a Starbucks right across the street. Yet not only is Landmark Coffee in business, but it also is often busier on weekday mornings than its globally marketed competitor.

title: Politics Means Sometimes Having to Say Youre Sorry
description: O.K., so Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wont accede to demands from some Democrats to apologize for her 2002 vote authorizing military action in Iraq.

title: N.F.L. Talks With Albany Prosecutors
description: Representatives from the National Football League and Major League Baseball have contacted the Albany district attorneys office to review some of the findings of its steroids investigation, a law enforcement official who is knowledgeable about the case said yesterday.

title: The Eighth Deadly Sin
description: YOURE wheeling a shopping cart past the fresh mozzarella, your wife and teenage daughter in the lead, at the Fairway on Broadway and West 74th Street. The three of you troll the mazelike aisles, near collisions at every turn, for goodies to keep you all well fed for the next week or three.

title: Shelving the Snow Globes in Favor of an Inward Look
description: GOOD evening, says the choreographer and stage magician extraordinaire Philippe Decoufl early in his Solo: Le Doute MHabite. I present my solo to you. It is an unexpectedly straightforward introduction from a man famous in his native France for bedazzling the senses with a brilliantly illogical mix of dance, circus, music hall, film and theater.

title: Moved by the Spirit to Dance With the Lord
description: WHILE teenage ballerinas and midriff-baring hip- hoppers cluster in the halls of the New Dance Group building on West 38th Street in Midtown Manhattan, inside one studio a very different type of dance class is starting. Twenty-five women are bowed on their knees in a circle, eyes closed, their foreheads resting on the floor.

title: Its Loud, Teenagers Love It and Its Alcohol Free
description: Netcong

title: For Obscure DVDs, a Precarious Future
description: AMONG the glories of the rising tide of DVD sales was the wave of discs that revived lost or overlooked works by filmmakers like David Lynch, Werner Herzog, Dario Argento, Jess Franco and Takashi Miike. Now some of the companies that brought those movies into homes are getting pulled under and may take future releases down with them.

title: Cloudy, With a Chance of Climate Change
description: When the Al Gore documentary An Inconvenient Truth received an Academy Award last week, it seemed a pretty sure sign that Hollywood believes that global climate change is taking place. But what about the rest of the world? Prompted by a New York winter that went from disturbing warmth to bone-chilling cold practically overnight, the Op-Ed page asked four writers from different corners of the globe to report on the erratic weather theyve been experiencing. Here are their dispatches.

title: Losing Bangladesh, by Degrees
description: Dhaka, Bangladesh

title: The Loss of a Sibling (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Tavern-Style Fare, but With Few Highlights
description: TUCKED into the woods and trimmed with white lights like a giant gingerbread house, DeerPark Tavern winks at cars as they flow by on Route 35. On a cold night, a small log fire snaps in an outdoor kiln. In the foyer, the H.Y.O.C. (hang your own coat) policy signals a relaxed mood and a certain trust. Inside, the hostess is welcoming, the wait short. Its a great-looking room, with a soaring red-lacquered ceiling and dark coffered walls. The curb appeal is real, which may explain why tables fill up early on weekends.

title: Bush Consoles Victims of Tornadoes in the South
description: AMERICUS, Ga., March 3  President Bush picked his way through the rubble of the tornado-stricken South on Saturday, promising federal aid for some Alabamians and turning up unexpectedly in a largely African-American neighborhood here in Georgia, where startled residents rushed out of their damaged houses, cell phone cameras in hand, to greet him.

title: Cajun Sound, Rock n Roll Energy
description: LAFAYETTE, La.

title: Keeping Borrowers Afloat
description: AS foreclosure rates rise, lenders are redoubling their efforts to keep borrowers afloat. Mortgage executives say that because foreclosures hurt them, too, they are trying to help curb the trend.

title: Winter Warmers
description: A visit to Sunnyside, Queens, sounds especially appealing this time of year, and while the trip will certainly not reward you with better weather, your day could turn brighter at these restaurants, a mix of the new and the established.

title: My Triplets Were Inseparable, Whatever the Risks
description: SIX weeks pregnant, I arrived at the fertility clinic in Miami to check the babys heartbeat and to determine how many.

title: Neither Clinton, Nor Obama
description: So there I was, sitting in my office, quietly contemplating suicide. I was watching a cattle call of Democratic presidential candidates on C-Span. In their five-minute speeches, they were laying it on thick with poll-tested, consultant-driven clichs of the Our Children Are Our Future variety. The thought of having to spend the next two years listening to this drivel set me wondering if it was literally possible to be bored to death.

title: For a Brownstone Lot, Tall Dreams and Troubled Neighbors
description: EVERYONE seemed to have come out ahead. In 1999, shaking off its last few crumbs of foreclosed real estate, the city sold a decrepit, century-old brownstone at 330 West 86th Street, flanked by 15-story towers.

title: Songs of Myself
description: One day in January 1931, Jimmie Rodgers  a yodeling country singer known as the Singing Brakeman  placed himself before a microphone in a San Antonio recording studio and sang, Ill tell you the story of Jimmie the Kid  hes a brakeman you all know. This fellow, he continued, yodels a yodel that everybody knows is the yodeling brakemans song.

title: Diamonds as a Bentleys Best Friend
description: MODESTY is not considered a virtue in the vehicle-adornment industry: no one buys bejeweled wheel rims or a platinum steering wheel because he wants to keep a low profile.

title: The Family Vacation (Climate-Change Lessons Included)
description: WHEN it was winter vacation time for their son, Taylor, in December, Carol and Charlie Donovan didnt plan a skiing trip or a visit to out-of-town relatives.

title: Making Childbirth Safe, Everywhere (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Marbury and Francis Give Knicks What They Need
description: ATLANTA, March 3  Seven days ago, Steve Francis had one foot in the off-season, determined to rest a sore knee and reconsider his future. But Saturday night, Francis played (a lot), dunked (once) and scored more points (26) than he ever had in a Knicks uniform.

title: Praise for Foie Gras Fortifies Its Critics
description: SHOPPING at the Fairway Market on the Upper West Side can be nearly as overwhelming a literary experience as a gustatory one. In every corner of the store, which sits under a blue awning on Broadway and 74th Street, hang signs, densely worded and brimming with enthusiasm, extolling fresh herbs  our little secret  or olive oil, or clam chowder so good, as one sign implies, that you will want to consume it intravenously.

title: Trying to Crack the Hot 100
description: LOS ANGELES

title: In This Corner, a Leftist, Riling the Right Again
description: IN Ken Loachs 1975 mini-series Days of Hope, drunken British soldiers billeted at an Irish farmhouse in 1916 harass a young woman into singing for them. She renders a republican song so plaintively that they fall silent. They have a sense of shame that is stronger than the drink, Mr. Loach later commented. And in a way she reminds them of who they are and where they come from and their own families. It was important there to break the stereotypes of soldiers as brutes.

title: Will It Be Win, Win for Joakim Noah?
description: Its a traditional bit of sports-world kabuki, acted out every time an underclassman leads his team to a championship. The celebratory pep rally. The students chanting, One more year! The marquee player aw-shucksing his way through a carefully worded speech about Getting a Degree and Loving College Life. Then the throng explodes and the star grins, knowing full well hes leaving for the pros as soon as his new agent files the paperwork.

title: Closing the Door on Open Houses
description: OPEN houses are an institution in New York City. Buyers scour the Internet and circle ads in the newspaper for the places they want to see before they fan out across the city, part of the process of becoming informed shoppers.

title: In Hot Pursuit of Leashless Dogs
description: THE Juniper Park Civic Association, a 69-year-old community group that represents the Queens neighborhoods of Maspeth and Middle Village, has never been shy about speaking out on local issues. In the last two decades, the group has made its voice heard on drag racing, collectors of recyclable cans, poor drainage on local ball fields, Wal-Mart, 7-Eleven, inaccurate local ZIP codes and a proposed truck tunnel to New Jersey, not to mention drive-by robberies, illegal basement apartments, and hours at the local library.

title: As Some Teams at Rutgers Vanish, So Will the Athletes
description: PISCATAWAY

title: British Officials Support Barring BBC Report
description: LONDON, March 4  Senior government officials rallied today to support a High Court ruling forbidding the BBC, Britains public service broadcaster, from reporting news about a campaign finance scandal under investigation by the police.

title: The Forecast for the Forecasters Is Dismal
description: LAST week, Alan Greenspan proved that a retired maestro can still seem to conduct the worlds financial orchestra, even if he no longer occupies the podium.

title: Simply Marvelous
description: Cheesy graphics, injury timeouts, late starts in Portland  welcome to the icy wilderness known as the N.B.A. regular season. On a night not long ago, the TNT network was featuring a Thursday showdown between the Los Angeles Lakers and the Sacramento Kings  a good time to seek out Seinfeld reruns, except that the announcing duties were being handled by Marv Albert and Charles Barkley. Albert is a savvy professional, a 40-year veteran of the booth. Barkley (subbing for Alberts usual TNT partner, Steve Kerr) has used his relatively short time in the business to, let us say, expand the definition of sports broadcasting: he dishes out schoolyard taunts the same way he did as a player. The encounter between play-by-play man and color analyst was fiercer than anything happening on the court.

title: Erich Windisch, 89, Is Dead; Revolutionized Ski Jumping
description: Erich Windisch, whose adjustment to an injured shoulder reshaped the sport of ski jumping, bringing competitors arms to their sides, died Feb. 14 near his home in Vail, Colo. He was 89.

title: Less Can Be More: A Tale of 2 Cylinders
description: BISHOP, Calif.

title: Turkish Documents
description: To the Editor:

title: Putting Up a Fight for Teddy Roosevelt
description: Oyster Bay

title: Kevin Durant, Shooting Star
description: Hell be gone soon, so people in Austin know they had better see him while they can. Of course, many dont even know what he looks like, since he has been in Austin little more than one semester. All they know when they push through the doors at the Frank Erwin Center is to be on the lookout for quite possibly the best basketball player ever to put on a University of Texas jersey, a tall, baby-faced freshman who plays like a mash-up of Tracy McGrady and Kevin Garnett. They spot him right away: the willowy 6-foot-10 player wearing No. 35 and bringing the ball up the court like a point guard, passing to his teammates, nailing jumpers from 15, 20, 25 feet away. They see him slash inside, dunk, get fouled and go to the free-throw line. They watch him smile and laugh and cut up with teammates, as happy as a child at play. And then they remember that Kevin Durant is only 18.

title: Iris Lifshitz, Adam Lindenbaum
description: Iris Tzipporah Lifshitz, a daughter of Cheryl and Moshe Lifshitz of Roslyn Heights, N.Y., was married last evening to Adam Jason Lindenbaum, the son of Jackie and Peter Lindenbaum of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Raphael Adler performed the ceremony at the Woodbury Jewish Center in Woodbury, N.Y.

title: Fish and Free Enterprise: A Cautionary Tale
description: As recently as late January, the stainless steel display case in Barzinis market on Broadway at 91st Street was stocked with fresh fish, creatures with shiny firm flesh and clear eyes that recall open water. The case is now empty, as is the gleaming lobster tank, once filled with clambering crustaceans.

title: Ken Lustbader and Jay Kidd
description: Ken Lustbader and Jay Kidd were married at the Montreal Courthouse on Friday. Ly Ngor Tir, a court officiant, performed the ceremony.

title: Homey, if You Dont Mind a Building Boom
description: STRADDLING Interstate 95, the Baychester section of the Bronx has long suffered from a split personality.

title: Park City, Utah:  The Cottages, Hotel Park City
description: THE BASICS

title: A Mountain of Tranquility Near Tokyos Frenzy
description: TOKYO'S reputation as an endless urban jungle is well earned. The concrete buildings, the chaotic narrow streets and scarcity of parks can tire even the most citified. Which is why visitors in the central city are often surprised to learn that an hour to the west by train, Tokyo is filled with mountains, streams and vistas that evoke Portland, Ore., or Boulder, Colo.

title: Havana in the 50s
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors Note
description: A front-page article on Jan. 21 reported on a soccer program for refugee boys in Clarkston, Ga., and how it has come to symbolize the passions that run high in the area over the issue of immigration. The article included a statement that Clarkstons mayor, Lee Swaney, had forced the resignation of the towns longtime police chief, in part because of complaints from refugees that police officers were harassing them.

title: Recalling Struggle for Civil Rights, Democrats Battle for Black Votes
Meddling in Foreign Policy
description: Its exactly what Israel and the Palestinians do not need at this volatile time. We are talking about the attempt at a New Jersey synagogue to interest American Jews in putting up money for new or existing homes in Israeli settlements on the West Bank and perhaps moving there themselves.

title: State Facilities Use of Force Is Scrutinized After a Death
description: In one of Darryl Thompsons last photos, he is wearing a blue cap and gown and gripping a rolled-up diploma from Public School 360 in the Bronx. A proud smile dents his cheeks and big fake diamonds glint from his ears.

title: Newark Officer Is Killed in Crash While Chasing a Suspect
description: NEWARK, March 3  A Newark police sergeant was killed early Saturday morning when his car flipped over as he chased a handcuffed suspect who had managed to drive away in another squad car, the authorities said.

title: Mr. Creswells Muse
description: LOOKING dapper in a blue-and-white checked shirt and a dark blue moleskin jacket, the British watercolorist Alexander Creswell stepped gingerly onto the Roosevelt Island tram and waded through a clutch of strollers and shopping bags to stake out a position by the southside window. With sketchbook and pencil in hand, the artist was ready for takeoff.

title: 16 Civilians Die as U.S. Troops Open Fire in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 4  American troops opened fire on a highway filled with civilian cars and bystanders today, American and Afghan officials said, in an incident that the Americans said left 16 civilians dead and 24 wounded as they fled the scene of a suicide car bombing in eastern Afghanistan. One American was also wounded.

title: Obama and Clinton Mark Civil Rights Struggle
description: SELMA, Ala., March 4  Evoking the passions and rivalries of the civil rights era, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton made deeply personal appeals to voters in the sanctuaries of black churches here today and then joined former President Bill Clinton for a march across a bridge where white police beat black Alabamans nearly 42 years ago.

title: The Week in New Jersey
description: Plan Allots Little New Aid to Abbott Districts

title: Confessions of a Book Abuser
description: I have to admit I was flattered when, returning to my hotel room on the shores of Lake Como, a beautiful Italian chambermaid took my hand. I knew that the hotel was noted for the attentiveness of its staff. Surely, though, such boldness elevated room service to a new level. Escorting me to the edge of the crisply made bed, the chambermaid pointed to a book on my bedside table. Does this belong to you? she asked. I looked down to see a dog-eared copy of Evelyn Waughs Vile Bodies open spread-eagle, its cracked spine facing out. Yes, I replied. Sir, that is no way to treat a book! she declared, stalking out of the room.

title: China Plans Big Increase in Military Budget
description: BEIJING, March 4  China announced its biggest increase in military spending in five years on Sunday, an increase that quickly prompted the United States to renew its calls for more transparency from the Chinese military about the scope and intent of its rapid arms buildup.

title: Correction: Airline Baggage, by the Piece or by the Pound
description: The Q&A column on Feb. 18 about airline baggage allowances misstated the number of bags permitted on British Airways' flights between Britain and the United States, Canada, the Caribbean, Nigeria, Brazil and Mexico. In economy, the limit is two bags, not one bag; in business class it is three bags, not two bags. The column also misstated the maximum size allowed for each bag. Measuring the bag in inches, its height plus its width plus its length cannot exceed a total of 62 inches. The maximum dimensions are not 98 inches in height, 39 inches in width and 31 inches in length (for a total of 168 inches).

title: Housemates
description: IN A. S. Byatts masterly Possession, a pair of literary scholars untangle old documents to rewrite the biographies of two Victorian poets. Emma Darwin (great-great-granddaughter of Charles) adopts a similar device in her first novel, The Mathematics of Love, combining the letters and memoirs of a veteran of the Napoleonic wars with the first-person narrative of a teenager who moves into the soldiers former home in the mid-1970s.

title: Local Warming
description: The deep, fur-hemmed cloth coat and long, colorful gloves that accommodate short-sleeve coats and capes have been revived by women who want to exhibit their adventuresome taste and flair. A memorable example, far right, is the skirt of the coat, all in fox. Equally dramatic is the trapeze-shape coat with a fur hem. For many women, long, above-the-elbow leather gloves add a dash of color and a new vitality to a classic black coat as winter turns the corner into March.

title: The Bumps of Winter
description: ITS a frigid afternoon in February, and Neville Ducasse, the proprietor of a 24-hour tire repair shop called Flat Fix northeast of Prospect Park, hasnt slept for four days. Got to eat, he explains in a thick Jamaican accent as he hunches over a large, red machine, realigning a tire on a BMW rim. Put food on the table, man.

title: Ryan Howard, No Asterisk
description: What would it feel like to inhabit the role that so many have auditioned for across the decades, on ballfields in all 50 states and beyond? Back foot dug into the batters box, the grip on the bat firm but relaxed. The baseball approaches as if in slow motion, and you start your swing with a short stride, a subtle shift of weight and a powerful forward thrust of the hips. Your hands follow and then, finally, the barrel of the bat comes whipping through the hitting zone and  crack!  connects with the ball, sending it on a majestic arc into the upper deck.

title: Philadelphia Stories
description: In the early 1980s, when I was a reporter at The Philadelphia Inquirer trying to act fearless covering the mean streets of a city with more mean ones than perhaps any in America, I had a brief encounter with Pete Dexter.

title: MyTheater, Seeking Friends
description: LIKE a lot of MySpace pages, this one has a slide show (various indoor scenes), music (folk-rock by Mary Lees Corvette) and a profile of its creator: male; from North Adams, Mass.; single; Taurus; and a body type best described as more to love. His interests include contemporary art, and he has nearly 3,000 friends. Also, he says hes 100 years old.

title: Colanis Concepts Make Concept Cars Look Tame
description: I AM at the moment building the most sensational Corvette ever, Luigi Colani said. Not that Chevrolet had asked him to design a Corvette, any more than BMW, Ferrari, Mazda, Volvo or other automakers had asked him to design the many models he has created over the last half-century. His artistry does not require an invitation.

title: She, the Jury
description: For five grueling college basketball seasons, the most important things in Judy Roses life were the two satellite dishes outside her home in Denver, N.C., a 55-inch big-screen television inside the den and the piles of injury reports, power rankings and statistics stacked up on the floor. She watched as many as five games a night.

title: Letters
description: From 0 to 60 to World Domination

title: Inside the List
description: BEAUTY BY MISTAKE:  Milan Kundera, whose new book of essays is reviewed on this weeks cover, has placed two novels on the Times best-seller list. One was Immortality, which had an eight-week hardcover run in 1991. The other was The Unbearable Lightness of Being, which spent one week here in hardcover in 1984, and then five more weeks in paperback four years later, after Philip Kaufmans film version was released.

title: From Natures Geometry, Healing Art
description: WHEN Barbara Evans is working on a painting, she stands in the center of a circular crystal grid on the floor surrounding the round table that holds her canvas. Watercolors in rainbow hues and gold and silver acrylics fill her palette. She pauses periodically to play a tone on one of her seven crystal singing bowls, and sometimes beats on a handmade Native American drum. Toby, a 4-year-old Hungarian vizsla, sprawls nearby and observes.

title: Midsize Bumpers Take Their Lumps
description: THE bumpers of most midsize cars are doing a poor job, says the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, an advocacy group financed by insurers.

title: Tinkering Never Stops for Top Pitchers
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 3  It can spin or cut or dip or tail. It does not rise, but it seems to sometimes. It can sink or fade or tumble or  gasp  hang. It can go faster or slower, this way or that. Marketing experts could not invent a more captivating plaything.

title: Consummate Survivor
description: If the Victorians can be said to have invented the concept of childhood  and an appreciable literature to go with it  we, the voyeuristic trauma gluttons of post-post-modernity, can perhaps be said to have invented the rubberneckers childhood. Yet we have less literature to show for it. We have the memoir instead, which, if we could apply the L word to it at all, we might call the literature of woefest.

title: Its Also Spring Training for Some Autograph Collectors
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla.  Thousands of fans attend the Mets early spring training workouts each year, before the exhibition games begin, when only a chain-link fence separates them from the stars shaking off winters rust.

title: The Legislature You Dont Know
description: Albany

title: Get Well, but Not Too Quickly
description: MANY investors will be looking for a quick recovery in the stock market this week, but such a rebound might do more harm than good over the long run, one analyst warns.

title: New Jersey: Analysts Say Home Prices Rose Little, if at All
description: After many years of double-digit appreciation in residential real estate around New Jersey, home values did not rise significantly last year and may have slipped, according to real estate market analysts.

title: Again, Kosovar Albanians Demonstrate Against U.N.
description: PRISTINA, Kosovo, March 3  For the second time in less than a month, thousands of ethnic Albanians took to the streets of this city on Saturday to protest a United Nations proposal for Kosovos future  a plan that they say falls far short of their desire for an independent state.

title: A Whole Wi-Fi Island: How Trendy Would That Be?
description: STEVE LEVY, the Suffolk County executive, wants to bring a wireless network to every developed square mile of Long Island, a project that would create one of the worlds largest wireless hot spots.

title: Puckolded
description: It probably sounds foolish to say this now, more than a year after the affair began, but I never thought it would happen to us. I assumed that after 14 happy years of marriage and four kids, Jen and I were strong enough to resist any temptation. But we werent  or, lets be honest, Jen wasnt. Its the old story: girl meets puck, puck takes girl. Then comes scoring. Lots of scoring.

title: Laugh Lines: David Letterman, Conan OBrien and Jay Leno
description: JAY LENO

title: Correction: A Night Out With James Ellroy
description: The Night Out column on Sept. 10, about the novelist James Ellroy, misstated the surname of a Los Angeles police detective who helped Mr. Ellroy investigate the unsolved case of his mothers murder. He was Rick Jackson, not Jacobson. A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message Nov. 22. This correction was delayed because editors did not follow through on the complaint.

title: For the Poorest Children, a Doctor With Wheels and a Mission
description: Hempstead

title: Is the State Selling Its Fuel Cell Businesses Short?
description: WHILE Connecticut may have the largest concentration of fuel cell-related companies in the nation, sentiment is growing that it could be in danger of losing its edge to other states that now consider fuel cells a lucrative endeavor in alternative energy.

title: A Tragedy During Childbirth (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Our Water Supply: The Next 170 Years; Priced Out, Leaving Town; Artists Enduring in Lower Manhattan (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Dealing With Deadbeats
description: Q I am the president of a 29-unit condo near Pennsylvania Station. The owners of one apartment have not paid their common charges for five years. They refuse to respond to any correspondence we send.

title: Instantly Exposed
