description: IN a back room at the SoHo Grand Hotel on West Broadway, the walls are covered with giant Polaroids of New York night-life moments that you wont see when trolling the meatpacking district with your platinum Amex: a young woman who looks as if she was dipped in gold; a man in briefs lounging with anticipation on a zebra-print rug; and two dewy-skinned women who seem ready to exchange a delighted kiss. These shots werent as provocative as some that did not appear, apparently.

title: Religious Surge in Once-Atheist China Surprises Leaders
description: SHANGHAI, March 3  Qin Fangyis religious moment came after a walk in the pouring rain two years ago to a nunnery for a ceremony that her mother had urged her to attend.

title: How to Grow a Super-Athlete
description: This story could begin in many places  it's about beginnings, after all  but I'd like to start with the recent evening when my 4-year-old daughter, Zoe, appeared before me wielding a yellow baseball bat and an important announcement: batting tees were for babies. From now on, she would hit real pitches, like the big kids.

title: This American TV Show
description: Q: Your new television show, This American Life, is basically the picture version of your longtime public-radio show, which is devoted to the art of oral storytelling. Are you abandoning that to become a documentary filmmaker? We dont say documentary because documentary sounds boring. We try to avoid that word.

title: Correction: Check In, Check Out: Tokyo: B Akasaka
description: The Check In/Check Out column on Feb. 11 about the B Akasaka hotel in Tokyo misstated the number of hotels recently introduced by the Ishin Hotels Group. It is one of six hotels  not four  in the companys b brand hotel group.

title: U.S. Makes Largest Move Into Shiite District Since 2004
description: BAGHDAD, March 4  More than 1,100 American and Iraqi soldiers in Humvees and armored personnel carriers moved Sunday into the volatile Shiite neighborhood of Sadr City, a stronghold of Iraqs largest Shiite militia, as part of the latest American-led security crackdown in the capital.

title: All Prosecution Is Local
description: Hamden

title: Ex-Astronaut Will Be Among First on the Grand Canyon Walkway
description: On March 20, the second man on the Moon, Buzz Aldrin, will lead the first walk across Skywalk, the cantilevered glass semicircular walkway that juts out 70 feet over the Grand Canyon and 4,000 feet above the Colorado River in Arizona.

title: Correction: Same Stooges. Different World. Finer Wine.
description: An article last Sunday about a new album by the Stooges misstated the release date. It is Tuesday, not March 20.

title: Sleek Dcor, Homey Food and an Accent on Pastas
description: NAMING a restaurant Nonnina  an affectionate diminutive term for grandmother in Italian  makes a statement. The word is wrapped in warmth and nostalgia, with many of those fond memories revolving around food.

title: Whistle Signals Early End for Jaspers
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 3  The season is over for Manhattan, not because the Jaspers were outplayed or outhustled but, perhaps, because of a single call.

title: Living the Good Life, Off the Leash
description: DOG parks  those outdoor play spaces that are usually enclosed  are thriving in the close-in suburbs of New Jersey, New York and Connecticut.

title: For Luxury Travelers, Indias Past Isnt Past
description: AMONG the activities offered to guests at Wildflower Hall, where once stood an English soldier's summer villa in the lap of the Himalayas, are guided walking tours that invite a visitor to savour the nostalgia of the Raj Era. As if to drive home the point, horseback riding, lawn croquet and archery are also on offer  all without a trace of irony.

title: Varieties in the Spices of Life
description: Varietys the very spice of life/That gives it all its flavor, the English poet William Cowper wrote three centuries ago. And judging by the depth and breadth of its spice collection, Penzeys Spices seems to have taken that message to heart.

title: With Anquan Boldin
description: Arizona Cardinals wide receiver Anquan Boldin was seventh in the league in receiving last season with 1,203 yards and was selected to his second Pro Bowl. It was his third 1,000-yard season in his four-year career. MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

title: A Teenage Soldiers Goodbyes on the Road to Over There
description: MOHAVE VALLEY, Ariz.

title: The Week in Connecticut
description: Firefighters Aid Patient in Need of Bone Marrow

title: Thomas Eagleton, Vice Presidential Nominee, Dies
description: Thomas F. Eagleton, a former United States senator whose legislative accomplishments were overshadowed by his removal as Democratic vice presidential candidate in 1972 after revelations of mental illness and electroshock therapy, died today in Richmond Heights, Mo. He was 77 and lived outside St. Louis in Clayton, Mo.

title: New Winds at an Island Outpost
description: STANDING behind the cramped counter of Los Guarinos, his bodega in Washington Heights, Joel Olivo deals not in big money but in small change. Jolly Ranchers candies, at a nickel apiece, are among his biggest sellers. Los Guarinos also sells cold beer and cigarettes, but on most days it is sweetness that prevails there. Neighborhood children ask for chocolate bars, and an arcade game in the corner fills the bodega with an electronic lullaby.

title: The Dissidents Son
description: What can a child know about totalitarianism? In Hisham Matars exceptional first novel, this question transcends the psychological to yield something rare in contemporary fiction: a sophisticated storybook inhabited by archetypes, told with a 9-year-olds logic, written with the emphatic and memorable lyricism of verse.

title: Three Pedestrians Are Killed Within Hours in New York City
description: In the span of four hours yesterday, three people were fatally struck by motorists in the city, the police said. In one instance, they said, a driver fled the scene.

title: Jessica Jacobson, James Reisman
description: Jessica Lee Jacobson and James Gerald Reisman are to be married this afternoon. Judge Thomas G. Armstrong of the 10th Judicial District Court, in Stillwater, Minn., is to officiate at the University Club of St. Paul.

title: The Toxic Offender
description: State law requires counties to give emergency shelter to homeless people, even those considered dangerous and detestable. Convicted sex offenders practically own this category, as the single class of criminal  more than murderers, muggers, drunken drivers, arsonists, embezzlers, treasonous spies, cannibals  most capable of getting communities into an uproar just by moving in.

title: How to Enjoy a Nordic Ritual at Any Age
description: IT was well below freezing on the Finnish coast, but there my children were, frolicking outdoors in a pool whose warmed waters were giving off enchanting tufts of steam. Soon it began to snow, and they flipped onto their backs and strained to catch the chubby flakes in their mouths like so much candy.

title: Eat, Drink and Enjoy Local Arts
description: The Asta Wine Cafe and Art Gallery, which opened in September in Huntington Village, is Long Island-proud. The co-owners, Leslie Yovino and her daughter, Stephanie, are Long Island natives intent on supporting and celebrating the community.

title: While Australia Burns
description: Canberra, Australia

title: Beekeepers Confronted by Demise of Colonies
description: THE honeybee, whose regimented hives and thick swarms resemble miniature military forces, is battling for survival against two enemies in New Jersey: a mysterious disorder that has killed millions of bees in 20 states, and the consequences of an unusually warm fall and early winter.

title: When This Camera Flashes, Nobody Says Cheese
description: There are few sights less welcome in a rear-view mirror than the distinctive double flash of a red-light camera, which photographs the license plates of cars that run the light.

title: Ben Howland Is on the Verge
description: The night before the biggest basketball game of his Weber State career, Ben Howland called his close friend Jay Hillock, a former junior-college assistant coach. Howland had a reputation for nervous excitability  he typically vomited 10 minutes before every game  so Hillock wasnt surprised when the phone rang at 2 a.m., just hours before Weber was to play a powerhouse University of Arkansas team in the second round of the 1979 N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Simulated Racing Provides Real Edge
description: The first time Regan Smith raced around Autdromo Hermanos Rodrguez, the Mexico City road course for Nascars second-tier Busch Series race today, he knew every bump and turn on the 2.5-mile circuit. He had the line he wanted to drive and knew where to shift and when to push it even before his first practice lap.

title: Revising the Limits on Personal Use
description: LAST month, an appeals court in Manhattan ruled that there was no limit on the number of apartments a building owner can remove from rent stabilization for personal use. The decision reverses a State Supreme Court ruling that an owner who was trying to take over all apartments in a stabilized building must first get permission from the states Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

title: The Must-Do List
description: The Bush administrations assault on some of the founding principles of American democracy marches onward despite the Democratic victory in the 2006 elections. The new Democratic majorities in Congress can block the sort of noxious measures that the Republican majority rubber-stamped. But preventing new assaults on civil liberties is not nearly enough.

title: 2 + 20, and Other Hedge Fund Math
description: MANY people would jump at the chance to invest in hedge funds, which have mainly been available to only the very wealthy. But a new study finds that the funds high fees make it unlikely that investors will improve their long-term performance by putting money into hedge funds.

title: The Karmazin Way: Build It, Sell It, Run It, Repeat
description: MEL KARMAZIN could sell microwavable ice to Eskimos. He started his career in ad sales at WCBS radio in New York four decades ago, quickly proved himself to be a master closer, and has been peddling his wares ever since.

title: Seeking to Preserve Eccentricity
description: SHINNECOCK HILLS

title: The Game of Kings, and a Side of Fries
description: LIKE most teammates, the chess players who like to gather at Dr. Ronald E. McNair Park in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, share a familial camaraderie. They refer to one another by nicknames like Indiana George and One a Day (the number of times the player won), and offer casual slaps on the back after a particularly good game. They graciously boast about one anothers playing.

title: Why They Fight
description: George W. Bush, reviled by the left ever since he became president, has recently accomplished the feat of acquiring a new and unlikely set of detractors. The longer he flounders in domestic and foreign policy, the more a vocal contingent of intellectuals and columnists allied to the Republican Party is attacking him. Unlike that of most Bush critics, however, their complaint isnt that the president has veered too far to the right. Its that he isnt conservative enough.

title: The Pulaski Skyway Without Traffic; Affordable Housing and Compassion (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: History, Written in the Present Tense
description: With the death last week of Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., at 89, America lost its last great public historian. The notion may sound strange, given the appetite, as voracious as at any time in recent memory, for serious works of history, and in particular the vogue for lengthy, often massively detailed biographies of the founders and of presidents.

title: Political Money and the Oscar Aisle
description: Hollywood has long been a cash register for politicians, particularly Democrats.

title: The Beach Is the Road, and the Commute Is an Adventure
description: WHEN Andy Miller and Gail Shields-Miller became empty nesters a few years ago, they planned to shake up their lives by moving from the Upper East Side to TriBeCa. We found a 6,000-square-foot loft that we could buy from a developer, and I planned to work and live there, said Ms. Shields-Miller, an interior designer.

title: A National Disgrace (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Airstrikes Hit Qaeda Post in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, March 3  The United States military said Saturday that an airstrike north of Baghdad had killed several insurgents with Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia who were using heavy artillery and machine guns to fire at American helicopters.

title: Correction: Sharing the Pain in Different Ways
description: A report in the Suits column last Sunday about a lawsuit against Salary.com referred incorrectly to stock options the company gave the plaintiff, David Nunes, a former director. It gave him 33,600, not 300,000, and they would have been worth $352,800, not at least $2.4 million, at the time of the companys initial public offering. The report also included an outdated reference to the I.P.O. It had already occurred  on Feb. 15, at $10.50 a share, higher than the target range of $8 to $10.

title: A New Legislative Push for Safer Power Windows
description: RALPH NADER, never one to mince words, wrote a letter to the National Highway Safety Bureau in 1968, demanding a public warning about the dangers of power windows, calling them upward bound glass guillotines that have strangled and injured thousands of children and infants.

title: Laundry Instructions, With Life Lessons Attached
description: IT was a laundry list. Not a metaphorical laundry list, an actual one. On the eve of my departure for college, my mother had practically filled a small spiral notebook with instructions on washing clothes, making abundant use of capitals and underlines.

title: At Home Before and Behind the Curtain
description: THE letters WYSIWYG may have helped immeasurably in closing the gap between the computer and the real world, letting you know that when you look at a properly formatted document on screen, what you see is what you get.

title: Stricter Law Fails to Diminish the Demand for Child Laborers in India
description: CALCUTTA, India  Seven days a week, 8-year-old Jasmina K. rises before dawn to fetch water for the household where she works as a maid. She washes, sweeps and hauls until about 11 at night, when she lies down to sleep on the floor by the bathroom door.

title: Poolside
description: The real pleasure of reading a memoir lies not in the consumption of confessions, but in watching a writer grapple with the reality that shaped him. War, love, addiction: no matter the subject, a good memoirist positions himself as a lens through which we can discern a universal experience. Casanovas memoirs would be nothing more than a pre-Viagra Supermans litany of conquests if his adventures did not telescope the larger tragedy of committing slow suicide in the guise of love.

title: Investigations Multiplying in Juvenile Abuse Scandal
description: HOUSTON, March 3  A sexual abuse scandal in the Texas juvenile justice system has state politics in an uproar, with accusations that damning reports were doctored and shelved and sexual predators in high positions were allowed to resign without facing charges.

title: Rajni Singh and Rajiv Shah
description: Rajni Singh, an optometrist, and Dr. Rajiv R. Shah, a nephrologist, were married on Friday by Judge Pamela G. Alexander of the Hennepin County District Court in Minneapolis. Pandit Mahinder Kumar Sharma, a Hindu priest, led a religious ceremony on Feb. 11 at the Hotel Silver Oaks in Kalimpong, India.

title: With Inquiry of Police Chief, Plainfield Is on Edge
description: PLAINFIELD, Conn., March 1  Life is routine here in Plainfield, a faded industrial town in eastern Connecticut. People work with their hands and make conversation easily. By 4 p.m. on most days, the bar at the Central Hotel is littered with drained shot glasses, and the parking lot is spotted with pickup trucks.

title: A Place at the Table
description: When the Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art opens at the Brooklyn Museum later this month, Judy Chicagos Dinner Party, a multimedia installation celebrating the role of women in Western civilization, will have a permanent home. Conceived by Chicago and executed by hundreds of women working under her direction between 1974 and 1979, The Dinner Party was seen by more than a million people in the years following its completion. But since 1988 it has spent much of the time in storage.

title: Parents and the Schools (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mad Hot Chessboard
description: Approximately one million years ago, when I was in my early teens, I briefly dipped a toe into the world of competitive chess. Much of the action in those days (the mid-1960s) took place in the old Henry Hudson Hotel on West 57th Street: I sharply remember the deep hush in the second-floor ballroom on tournament Sundays, the long tables lined with green-and-cream-squared oilcloth boards, the soft ticking of a hundred chess clocks amid the miasma of deep thought. On the walls of the Manhattan Chess Club, also in the hotel, hung black-and-white glossies of visiting greats: Reshevsky. Denker. And, of course, with his plaid shirt buttoned to the neck, his long haughty nose and basilisk stare, the boy genius Bobby Fischer.

title: Inmates Will Replace Migrants in Colorado Fields
description: DENVER, March 3  As migrant laborers flee Colorado because of tough new immigration restrictions, worried farmers are looking to prisoners to fill their places in the fields.

title: So Many Ways to Say Watch Out
description: THE new S80 is a showcase for Volvos latest safety systems, including a heartbeat sensor, an impending-crash warning and cameras that monitor blind spots alongside the car.

title: Westchester: Decline in Home Prices May Spur Sales
description: Signs of renewed optimism in Westchesters housing market are being spotted in real estate offices throughout the county these days, even though  or perhaps because  median home prices have fallen and are likely to decline even more in the months to come.

title: Antiwar Caucus Wants to Be Heard Now
description: WASHINGTON, March 2  About a dozen members of the Out of Iraq Congressional Caucus gathered on a sunny day last summer on the terrace outside the Capitol for a news conference. The only problem: no reporters showed up.

title: The Risk Is All Yours in Office E-Mail
description: Q. Your company recently announced a new policy to monitor all outgoing e-mail, including personal correspondence. How concerned should you be?

title: In Wartime, Who Has the Power?
description: WASHINGTON

title: 36 Hours in Barcelona
description: CONVENTIONAL thinking holds that Barcelona is Spain's gateway to European culture. Insofar as culture means innovative architecture and modern art, smart urban planning that prizes pedestrian-friendly boulevards and an arm's-length attitude toward deep Spanish traditions like bullfighting, such thinking is right on the money. It was in Barcelona in the 1890s that Picasso found the artistic vanguard that propelled him to Paris and world renown. And this is where Gaud spun Art Nouveau into his own quirky architectural idiom. Today the term avant-garde still applies: to Barcelona's fusion cuisine, design-accented boutique hotels, fun-loving fashion houses and even a delicious assortment of innovative chocolatiers, all of whom cut their teeth in the Catalan capital before taking on the rest of Spain.

title: Vintage Volvos Earn Their Stripes (Ask the General Who Owns One)
description: PHIL SINGHER became passionate about old Volvos in a rather roundabout way.

title: To Be Is to Undo
description: In 1953, the young Robert Rauschenberg deliberately erased a drawing by the Abstract Expressionist painter Willem de Kooning. Mr. Rauschenberg, who was accused of vandalism, defended his action by explaining that he was exploring a new kind of creative act  making a work of art through the unmaking of another. This classic of anti-art is now in the collection of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

title: The Larynxes That Invaded Broadway
description: CHRISTINE PEDI is describing Debbie, the 15-year-old she plays in the revival of Eric Bogosians Talk Radio. Shes kind of scrawny, wears tank tops and too much eye makeup, and thinks shes grown up, Ms. Pedi explains in an interview. She is too fond of Doritos. Shes calling from her pink bedroom, where she has stashed all her teen stuff  her cigarettes and birth control.

title: Predators Are Trying to Elude Escape Clause
description: In Nashville, success for the Predators may be defined less by winning the Stanley Cup than by simply finding enough fans to watch them play.

title: Helping Children to Navigate 2 Worlds
description: TOMS RIVER, N.J.

title: Stacey Harris, Daniel Maman
description: Stacey Robin Harris, the daughter of Ann Harris and Dr. Robert J. Harris of Haworth, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Daniel Yaron Maman, the son of Jenny Maman and Dr. Arie Maman of East Brunswick, N.J. Cantor Harvey Waldman officiated at the Pleasantdale Chateau, an events space in West Orange, N.J.

title: Other Voices: Iran, Spin and Unnamed Sources; Female and Spouseless
description: Re Approaching Iran Intelligence With Intelligent Skepticism (Feb. 25):

title: Brandon Crones Last Hurrah
description: One of the most memorable images of last years tournament was that of Gonzagas Adam Morrison weeping as his college career came to an abrupt and unhappy end, the then 20-year-old poleaxed by the finality of it all. But Morrison was one of the lucky ones. He had already decided to turn pro and at least had the N.B.A. to cushion the blow. Most seniors will lose their final games and never again take the floor competitively at an elite level. These are among the events most compelling figures, straining to extend their playing days just a few . . . moments . . . longer.

title: Choosing a Sect
description: As the Sunni-Shiite conflict in Iraq polarizes Muslims across the globe, the United States finds itself in the odd position of seeming to favor a Shiite government in Iraq and Sunni leaders everywhere else. As a result, there has been a lot of loose talk in policy circles recently about how the United States should finally choose sides. After all, the rift between the two denominations is almost as old as Islam itself  and so is unlikely to close soon. What began more than 1,300 years ago as an argument over whether the Prophet Muhammad should be succeeded by his cousin Ali or by an unrelated companion became a bloody civil war, then hardened over time into a theological split. As another civil war worsens in Iraq, the argument goes, America should pick a winner and back it to the hilt.

title: Mission Improbable: Tom Cruise as Mogul
description: Los Angeles

title: Letters
description: Its No Secret

title: Playwrights Diary
description: Tennessee Williams kept notes for much of his adult life, although he appears to have stopped abruptly in 1958, as he descended further into his addiction to alcohol and drugs. The really fascinating years, and the centerpiece of this absorbing volume of Williamss notebooks, edited and annotated by the independent scholar Margaret Bradham Thornton, are those that preceded and accompanied his first two triumphs in the theater, The Glass Menagerie (1945) and A Streetcar Named Desire (1947). In the late 1930s and early 40s, we see Williams drifting from New Orleans to Laguna Beach to Florida, and always back to his family in St. Louis. He had one brief affair with a woman in college but didnt have sex with a man until he was 28, and he reeled away from the experience with a feeling of revulsion. He writes on June 11, 1939: Rather horrible night with a picked up acquaintance Doug whose amorous advance made me sick at the stomach  Purity!  Oh God  It is dangerous to have ideals.

title: Home From France, With Seven Pets in Tow
description: My wife and I are planning to return to the United States after several years in France. What concerns us most about the move is the safety and well-being of our pets. We have three dogs, about 33 pounds each, and four cats, and plan to fly from Paris to Atlanta on Air France. However, we wonder whether chartering a corporate jet would be possible, and not prohibitively expensive.

title: For a Change This March 17, Try Wearing the Green in Dublin
description: Chicago dyes its river green, New York and Boston pubs go wild, but now, with even a St. Patrick's Day parade in Tokyo, isn't it time for the real thing?

title: Iran President Meets Saudi to Discuss Mideast Issues
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Sunday, March 4  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran met with King Abdullah here in the Saudi capital on Saturday to address the Middle Easts growing sectarian and political crises.

title: Correction: The Mysteries of Kabul
description: An article on Jan. 21 about Kabul and its attraction for a new generation of travelers misstated the history of the buzkashi, Afghanistans national sport. The game, a variation of polo usually played with a goat carcass, was a thriving sport in the capital well before the late 1970s. It was not brought to the capital by President Muhammad Daoud in 1978.

title: Homeless Man Is Arrested in Queens Fire
description: Fire marshals have arrested a homeless man on charges of setting a fire that ravaged an apartment building in Queens last month, displacing 120 families.

title: The Week on Long Island
description: Nassau Taking Steps Against Feral Cats

title: Bridesmaids War Stories; The Cads Companion
description: BAD BRIDESMAID

title: Living Large on a Tiny Lot
description: Flanders, N.Y.

title: Bill Looks at School-Entry Age
description: Should kindergartners be 5 when they begin school? A state representative from Canton thinks so and has introduced legislation to move the cutoff date to September, from Dec. 31.

title: Too Cold for Sailboat Racing? Dont Be Silly
description: Larchmont

title: A Cozy Book Club, in a Virtual Reading Room
description: WHEN many people think of online social networking, they picture Web sites where the young and the restless discuss their love lives and their favorite bands. But Kathryn Havemann, 60, of Dayton, Ohio, has joined a different sort of Web-based network  one where people are linked by a more sedate interest: their book collections.

title: Kate Dawson and Jedidiah Cohen
description: AS Lili in Carnival and Lydia Languish in The Rivals, Kate Dawson has taken her time finding her true love onstage. Her own romantic life required less persuasion and none of the triangulations in those Broadway shows, but it hasnt been without its theatrical moments.

title: Brackets Gone Wild!
description: Few of us considered our N.C.A.A. basketball office pool a path to personal discovery. Then came Mark Reiter and Richard Sandomir (a sportswriter for The New York Times), editors of The Enlightened Bracketologist: The Final Four of Everything.

title: An Array of Afghan Kebabs, and a Tilt Toward India
description: GIVEN that Afghanistan lies at the crossroads of India, China and the Middle East, we might well expect the food to reflect all of those influences. But, aside from the kebabs, what a meal at Shish Kebab House most brings to mind is a quieter version of Indian cuisine.

title: In Alaska, Everyones Afraid of the Water
description: Kotzebue, Alaska

title: Rubber Bullet
description: Of all the hard things moving at high speed in sports, few are as fear-inspiring as a disk of vulcanized rubber propelled toward the goalie at 100 miles per hour, generally from a distance of about 60 feet. Not many are better at the slap shot than Sheldon Souray, the All-Star defenseman for the Montreal Canadiens. Tall and strong at 6-foot-4 and 227 pounds, Souray has ranked at or near the top of the goal-scoring list for rear guards all season long  in part thanks to his slap shot, which has been measured at more than 102 miles per hour.

title: In Baghdad, Sectarian Lines Too Deadly to Cross
description: BAGHDAD, March 3  After centuries full of vibrant interaction, of marrying, sharing and selling across sects and classes, Baghdad has become a capital of corrosive and violent borderlines. Streets never crossed. Conversations never started. Doors never entered.

title: Why Match Play Doesnt Work in Golf
description: Last September, Tiger Woods watched Roger Federer win the United States Open and declared that no one was as dominant in a sport. Woodss modesty notwithstanding, the record indicates otherwise. In golfs major championships and regular 72-hole PGA Tour events, Woods, a recent winner of seven straight tournaments, dominates golf the way Federer, who well could win the Grand Slam this year, dominates tennis.

title: Mortgages May Be Messier Than You Think
description: WHAT investors dont know about why the home mortgage securities market is in distress could fill volumes. As is often the case, only after fiery markets burn out do we see the risks that buyers ignore and sellers play down.

title: Spring Theater Special; New World Symphony; The Police
description: SPRING THEATER SPECIALDefining the Terms

title: The Hospitals Bill of Rights
description: Jersey City

title: Elisabeth Weed and Matthew Mitchell
description: Elisabeth Bardsley Weed and Matthew Alan Mitchell were married last evening by the Rev. Gideon L. K. Pollach, an Episcopal priest, at St. Bartholomews Church in New York.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: Fear in Las Vegas

title: For the Gamblers, 1+2=5
description: In March 2001, a couple of Yale professors, Edward Kaplan and Stanley Garstka, published a paper called March Madness and the Office Pool, a serious, academic look at whether the code of the N.C.A.A. tournament brackets could be cracked. This treatise ran 14 pages and contained the work of two dozen statistical minds focused on a singular, noble goal: how to win the office pool. The wonks ran algorithms derived from past tournaments. They ran computer simulations. They even studied the National Invitation Tournament, a masochistic endeavor if there ever was one.

title: The Motherhood Experiment
description: To the dismay of pundits and politicians alike, women in industrialized countries and elsewhere have been bearing fewer and fewer children. More than 90 states have fertility rates below the replacement level of 2.1 children per woman, and the trend, which began in the early 1960s, is already leading to fewer workers, graying populations and dire predictions about vanishing peoples. While scholars blame several phenomena, including greater access to birth control, later marriage and a drop in what one researcher calls hopefulness about the future, many researchers agree that at least part of the problem is due to the particular burdens women face in the work force. If becoming a mother requires a woman to take a huge financial and professional hit, the thinking goes, she will be far less likely do it.

title: Posh Spice
description: Seasoning with salt and pepper has taken on new meaning in recent years  for professional and home cooks alike. For this we might have a former accountant in California to thank. Traveling the world with a suitcase filled with spices and gadgets, Jing Tio is something of a spice whisperer, introducing chefs, and diners, to new flavors. He turned Wylie Dufresne at New Yorks WD-50 on to wild hops, which recently made their debut in a savory pudding, and the pastry chef at Jol Robuchon at the Mansion in Las Vegas now makes ice cream with the herbal coffee substitute teeccino. Hops and teeccino: coming soon to a spice rack near you.

title: The Untaxed Rich, Found and Then Lost
description: FALSE advertising is part of the problem, and its right there in the name: alternative minimum tax.

title: Kimberly ODonnel, Russell Walker
description: Kimberly Ann ODonnel and Russell Hughes Walker Jr. were married Friday evening at Evamer, a vacation rental property in Vieques, P.R. The Rev. Nancy Carr, a nondenominational minister, officiated.

title: Bucs Add Plummer and Garcia
description: One day after they were spurned by Jake Plummer, the Tampa Bay Buccaneers finally got their veteran quarterback when Jeff Garcia signed a two-year contract yesterday that will put him in competition with Chris Simms for the starting job. Then Tampa Bay got Plummer, too.

title: Coffee Puts Laid-Back Town on Edge
description: New Paltz, N.Y.

title: Youth Killed in Brooklyn; 2 Men Hurt in Shooting
description: A 16-year-old was fatally stabbed about 2 a.m. yesterday during a party at a Masonic temple in Brooklyn, the police said, and moments later two men who had been involved in a dispute there were shot two blocks away.

title: Vandals Hit Cottages Included in Park Plans
description: VANDALS have damaged the five remaining cottages on West Meadow Beach in Old Stony Brook that are included in plans for a new Brookhaven town park.

title: How to Build a Village in the Middle of a City
description: PORTLAND, Me.

title: Point and Shoot for Bonus Points
description: ONE reason people visit New York is to catch a glimpse of things they'd never see in the average American city. Some such sights are mystifying, some charming, some jaw-dropping  and some are even legal.

title: Hello, Sucker
description: I would suggest moving back, said President Bush, from the cab of a yellow Caterpillar tractor at the companys East Peoria, Ill., plant. Im about to crank this sucker up. He started the engine, watched a puff of smoke belch from the stack, steered the machine around the assembly line and announced, That was fun, as he got off.

title: Dale Nosel Is THE Fan
description: If Dale Nosel is not the biggest fan of the University of Connecticut womens basketball team, he is at least its most visible. Basically, Nosel says, I shave my head before every game, and I paint the left side of my head white and the right side blue, and I also paint my arms blue and white. Thus arrayed like the stepson of the Blue Man Group, he positions himself in the sightline of opposing players and spends the better part of two hours popping up and down, chanting, shrieking and generally making a nuisance of himself. Such devotion has won him fame  hes known variously as Superfan and Blue-and-White Guy  but not without cost. Ive gotten slight rashes a couple times from the poster paint, says Nosel, who needs at least an hour to make himself up. His grades, too, have suffered. He thinks he could bump his 2.7 G.P.A. up to a 3.2 if he didnt spend so many nights watching sports. (My parents wouldnt want to see this, he says, but I picked UConn because of the sports.) There are also the nightmares. I wouldnt want to show up at a game without paint on, says Nosel, whose slumber is troubled by such visions several times a week.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Criticize Slur by Conservative Author
description: WASHINGTON, March 3  Three of the leading Republican presidential candidates on Saturday denounced one of their partys best-known conservative commentators for using an antigay epithet when discussing a Democratic presidential contender at a gathering of conservatives here.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: OTHER MIAMI BEACH CHOICES

title: Its One Building, but It Looks Like Six
description: GRACIE SQUARE has that sterling-silver ring evocative of other East River residential enclaves like Sutton Place, East End Avenue and Beekman Place.

title: A Deal for Skiers: Get Free Lift Tickets With a Job at a Resort
description: Are you still considered a ski bum if you work for your lift ticket? Anyone who loves skiing but hates the mountain of fresh debt at the end of winter (a one-day adult lift ticket at Killington can cost $72) can ski free next year with a bit of preseason planning.

title: Give Us This Day Our Daily Supplements
description: Its no surprise that athletes like their dietary supplements. By conservative estimates, they spend nearly $4 billion annually on pills, powders and other sports-nutrition products in the hope that theyll improve health and increase performance. New Orleans Saints center Jeff Faine recently told a reporter that he takes about 65 pills a day; for the sake of time management, he has taught himself to swallow as many as 17 at a time. This daily gorging pales next to that of Bill Romanowski, the former linebacker. In his 2005 autobiography, Romo: My Life on the Edge, Romanowski writes that he kept a tackle box filled with some 500 pills and would take handfuls a day, all washed down with protein shakes. He also famously admits to taking vials of THG, an anabolic steroid, but most of what he consumed were legal supplements available at any Walgreens or GNC store.

title: What Starbucks Can Learn From the Movie Palace
description: WI-FI service is quickly becoming the air-conditioning of the Internet age, enticing customers into restaurants and other public spaces in the same way that cold advertising air deliberately blasted out the open doors of air-conditioned theaters in the early 20th century to help sell tickets.

title: The Hands: Azzedine Alaa
description: Few designers know a womans body as well as Alaa. Thats his reference point, his beginning and his end. His genius comes out in the pattern-making, cutting, fitting and pressing, all of which he does himself. No designer is more influential at the moment: Witness the number of young designers paying homage to his style as well as his integrity.

title: Baghdad Borderlines
description: In an effort to stay safe, some Baghdad residents have drawn a line at their front door. They use their imaginations to escape.

title: A Walk in the Park in Patagonia
description: Trekking through a land of legend, rugged beauty and, now, upscale lodges.

title: The Curtain: An Essay in Seven Parts
description: The Consciousness of Continuity

title: Leviathan on the Right
description: Consider the following policy proposals that have been floating around Washington in the months leading up to the 2006 election: (a) creating a new cabinet-level federal Department of Families; (b) giving every child $2,000 at birth; (c) having the federal government fund 70,000 new math and science teachers; and (d) requiring every American to purchase health insurance. One might expect that those proposals were made by liberal Democrats, perhaps Ted Kennedy or Hillary Clinton preparing for their Senate majority. In fact, every one of them was made by conservative Republicans.

title: The Communists Daughter
description: It is my hope that your understanding will win out against any mistrust or anger you may harbour against me when you finally read this. It is so easy to feel anger, and Lord knows I deserve a good dose of it. But I am trying, and you will see I have been trying for quite some time. I also hope that you will read this many years from now, when you are grown, at a time when this story will be long past. With an adult's eyes it is more likely that you will see this letter for what it is, and know the regret and tenderness I feel as I compose this history for you. Of course, I know I have no control over any of this, yet still I hope. The dead must relinquish so much.

title: Winterwood
description: It was the autumn of 1981 and I'd been asked by my paper the Leinster News to do an article on folklore and changing ways in Ireland, a chance I jumped at, availing myself of the opportunity to return home to Slievenageeha, which I hadn't been to visit in years.

title: Paper Trails
description: The man spent a week trying to get rid of the cat on the front porch, then he gave up. For that week, he hissed every time he walked out the front door. He lobbed firewood over her head, let his dogs chase her up trees. He told his wife to leave the cat food across the road in the woods.

title: Charisma
description: Is it not likely that since all action is now decided from the outside in that a spray-on charisma can will soon be invented? We shall have the recognition factors sorted out, and so by purchase smartly in the economy size, spray ourselves into something extraordinary. This is simply to say what Soren Kierkegaard said more than a century ago, that all inwardness is lost. In this book, I have tried to work through, critically, toward an understanding of how my inwardness was lost for me, and to recognize those chiefly responsible for the loss-our charismatics. The writing has not been therapeutic; on the contrary, that is the point. From the extraordinary way in which Max Weber, among others, canned charisma for us, I have learned that I am opposed to all therapies. The therapeutic is that terrible beast who has been slouching toward Bethlehem. The pity of our lives is that there are no charismatics to save us from him. We can hope for the spray-on charisma can, which will realize the ancient dream of making even the least of us extraordinarily attractive on the outside. The world is fuller than ever before of people who look like charismatics and try to act the part; like the early medieval sect of Waldenses, they insist on wearing sandals, some even in winter. If not to be like the founder, which was the original reason for wearing sandals, then to be recognizable, a little extraordinary, in lieu of the spray-on charisma can. I doubt that the Western world has ever been so full of innovators all hawking their changes, or so full of deviants, all asserting their rights. Where are the charismatics? The question is, more precisely, who are the charismatics? Who deviates decisively from the beaten path? Who opens a new road, a different way of life and revelation for men to go, even remain, for such openers of new roads are all but lost. Is he a guru, like Timothy Leary, for the guru, in its original meaning, meant, I understand, heavy, weighty, venerable. A modern guru, a figure like Timothy Leary or Norman O. Brown, carries the reverse meaning. He is deliberately weightless and preaches weightlessness to us. The modern guru represents the ephemeral, the fugitive, the contingent. It is in this sense that he is an exemplar, someone to follow.

title: In the Country of Men
description: I am recalling now that last summer before I was sent away. It was 1979, and the sun was everywhere. Tripoli lay brilliant and still beneath it. Every person, animal and ant went in desperate search for shade, those occasional gray patches of mercy carved into the white of everything. But true mercy only arrived at night, a breeze chilled by the vacant desert, moistened by the humming sea, a reluctant guest silently passing through the empty streets, vague about how far it was allowed to roam in this realm of the absolute star. And it was rising now, this star, as faithful as ever, chasing away the blessed breeze. It was almost morning.

title: Adam Haberberg
description: One day the writer Adam Haberberg sits down in front of the ostriches on a bench at the Jardin des Plantes menagerie in Paris and thinks, this is it, I've found the poorhouse position. A spontaneous position, he thinks, you can find it only when you're not trying. One fine day you sit down and there you are, you're hunched in the poorhouse position. He feels at ease in this position; I feel at ease in it, he thinks, because I'm young and there's no onus on me to stay like this. In normal times Adam Haberberg soon bounces back, but these are not normal times for him, a man who's paid six euros to walk a few yards parallel with the Quai Saint-Bernard, then come back again and collapse onto the very first bench, opposite the ostriches in what is undoubtedly the ugliest and least attractive part of the garden.

title: The Mathematics of Love
description: Lancashire, 1819

title: Infidel
description: One November morning in 2004, Theo van Gogh got up to go to work at his film production company in Amsterdam. He took out his old black bicycle and headed down a main road. Waiting in a doorway was a Moroccan man with a handgun and two butcher knives.

title: Against Submission
description: In the fall of 2002, Ayaan Hirsi Ali, then a junior researcher for the social democratic party in the Netherlands, was invited to stand for election by the rival conservative party. She thought about it, and decided that if she were to enter politics, she would embark on a holy mission to have the statistics of female victims of so-called honor killings around the world officially registered. Honor killings are common in (but not unique to) Muslim societies, where the shame of adultery, or even rape, is such that for some men it can be wiped out only by murdering the women involved.

title: Taking Mount Takao
description: Take a day trip to the Tama region in Japan, an hour west of Tokyo, and discover hiking paths, lofty views and fresh air.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE COLONY, by John Tayman. (Lisa Drew/ Scribner, $16. ) This is a fascinating chronicle of the forced exile, from 1866 to 1969, of more than 8,000 leprosy patients to the remote Kalawao colony on Hawaiis Molokai island. Tayman, a former deputy editor of Outside magazine, bases his account on news reports, archival material and his own interviews with three of the colonys last living exiles. The story of Kalawao is the story of an injustice as deep and complete as any in human history, Mary Roach wrote in the Book Review. Taymans noble account makes you want to stand and applaud.

title: Editors Choice
description: REMAINDER, by Tom McCarthy. (Vintage, paper, $13.95.) In this debut novel, a Londoner emerges from a coma and seeks to reassure himself of the genuineness of his existence.

title: Style and Substance in Barcelona
description: A weekend tour of a capital of fashion, design and culture.

title: Somaliland, Stability Amid Chaos
description: In contrast to the violent mess in the rest of Somalia, Somaliland is relatively peaceful and functional.

title: The Week Ahead: March 4 - 10
description: THEATER

title: Obama and Clinton in Selma
description: SELMA, Ala.  The center of the political universe  the clichd locale that often pivots between Iowa and New Hampshire during a presidential race  can be found here today along a three-block stretch of Martin Luther King Jr. Street.

title: Why We Travel
description: "We saw several cactuses with snow on them. And, you know, you just dont ever see cactuses and snow in the same picture."

title: Stamm Leads After Second Leg of Sailing Race
description: After 49 days at sea, the Swiss yachtsman Bernard Stamm arrived in Norfolk first in the Velux 5 Oceans Race late Saturday, winning the second of three legs in this solo around-the-world race. An exhausted Stamm was able to take more than a half-hour nap knowing he had finished nearly 3,000 nautical miles ahead of Kojihiro Shiraishi of Japan, the next-closest competitor.

title: In Selma: Obamas First Visit
description: SELMA, Ala.  Over the years, Barack Obama had visited Montgomery, Ala., to celebrate the legacy of the bus boycott, and Birmingham to see its civil rights museum and bear witness to the struggle for racial equality there.

title: Clinton: The March Is Not Over Yet
description: SELMA, Ala.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton did not try to imitate her cadence-blessed husbands speaking style at the predominantly black First Baptist Church here this afternoon, but she was a hit nonetheless with her remarks that the civil rights march is not over yet.

title: Pavano Pitches In, at Last
description: A full 615 days have passed since the last time Carl Pavano took the mound in the regular season for the Yankees.

title: Laudatio: Steve Lacy
description: ROME  For anyone who has not played the Dixieland standards  say, Muskrat Ramble, Fidgety Feet, Sister Kate, Black and Blue, Rampart Street and Moldy Fig Stomp (that one I made up)  theres no postmodern theory that can beat it. Derrida, a great jazz buff, as George Lewis assures me, knows where Les Orleans Nouveaux are, but Baudrillard, a sometime Americanophile, probably doesnt know the changes.

title: Laudatio: Steve Lacy
description: ROME - For anyone who has not played the Dixieland standards - say, Muskrat Ramble, Fidgety Feet, Sister Kate, Black and Blue, Rampart Street and Moldy Fig Stomp (that one I made up) - there's no postmodern theory that can beat it. Derrida, a great jazz buff, as George Lewis assures me, knows where Les Orleans Nouveaux are, but Baudrillard, a sometime Americanophile, probably doesn't know the changes.

title: Is It Good for the Jews?
description: When I was growing up in the 40s and 50s, a single question was asked in my neighborhood of every piece of news, large or small, local or national: Is it good for the Jews? We have now learned to identify this question in all of its versions  Is it good for the Catholics? Is it good for the Latinos? Is it good for the gays? and on and on  as the paradigmatic question of identity politics, the politics that is derived not from some general, even universal, assertion of what is good, but from a particularized concern with insular interests. Is it good for us, for those of our kind, for our tribe?

title: We Eat Horses, Dont We?
description: London

title: Proud Marine Tries on a Different Uniform as Padres Prospect
description: PEORIA, Ariz., March 4  Cooper Brannan, a San Diego Padres pitching prospect, arrived at the teams spring training complex for his first formal workout Sunday in a quest to ultimately become a major leaguer.

title: Girl Scout Cookies (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan: Scrutiny of Drug Sales Sought
description: Responding to a recent investigation by the Albany County district attorney into the sale of prescription steroids over the Internet, Senator Charles E. Schumer said yesterday that he will propose legislation to make bad-faith transactions of that sort a federal crime. The senator said he would also propose greater regulation of the sale of human growth hormone, including criminal penalties for the illegal sale of the substance.

title: A Record of Failure at Center for Sex Offenders
description: ARCADIA, Fla.  Inside a privately run treatment center here for pedophiles and rapists who have completed their prison sentences, where they are supposed to reflect on their crimes and learn to control their sexual urges, bikini posters were pinned to walls.

title: Patent Fights Are a Legacy of MP3s Tangled Origins
description: AMSTERDAM, March 4  Microsoft says it was doing the right thing: paying a German rights holder $16 million to license the MP3 audio format, the foundation of the digital music boom. Then an American jury ruled that Microsoft had failed to pay another MP3 patent holder, and slapped it with a $1.52 billion judgment.

title: Buddhists Take Part in Firewalking Ritual in Japan
description: Hundreds of people followed priests in the practice, which is done near the beginning of spring in order to purify mind and body. Those assembled also prayed for health and safety.

title: Where Artists and Inventors Plot to Save the World
description: Its starting to feel like Christmas and the family is coming in, Chris Anderson said, in his almost whispering voice.

title: Quinn to March for St. Patrick, but in Dublin
description: The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, who boycotted the St. Patricks Day Parade down Fifth Avenue last year because gay and lesbian groups have not been allowed to participate, said yesterday that she would observe the holiday this year by marching in a Dublin celebration.

title: New Haven Welcomes a Booming Population of Immigrants, Legal or Not
description: NEW HAVEN, March 1  The people have been arriving here for years from Mexico, Guatemala, Jamaica and Ecuador, some staying just a few months, but more settling in for years.

title: Palestinian Leaders Try to Resolve Split Over Key Posts
description: JERUSALEM, March 4  Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president and the leader of the Fatah faction, arrived in Gaza on Sunday to meet with Ismail Haniya, the caretaker prime minister from Hamas, in another effort to iron out differences over a possible Palestinian unity government.

title: Policy Shift on Death Penalty Overwhelms Arizona Court
description: PHOENIX, March 2  Maricopa County, one of the nations fastest growing counties, now has an additional distinction: It is also a leader in seeking the death penalty.

title: Knick Embraces Chance to Make New Impression
description: In nine months as a pro, Mardy Collins has gone from obscure rookie to notorious brawl starter, then back to obscurity. But as the Knicks enter the final quarter of the season, Collins is casting for a new identity  as a steady-handed role player.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Tar Heel Women Win A.C.C. Tournament
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 4  After her team lost the Atlantic Coast Conference tournament championship game when she was a freshman in 2004, Ivory Latta made a promise to North Carolina Coach Sylvia Hatchell as they watched Duke celebrate on the court in front of them.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A subheading with the continuation of a sports article on Thursday about the highly regarded Duke womens basketball program misstated the number of games the team lost last season. It was four, not one.

title: Queens: Criticism for Con Ed
description: An assemblyman criticized Consolidated Edison yesterday, saying it mounted a $581,000 advertising campaign in his Queens district in the four months after last years nine-day blackout there while local businesses and residents suffered. The assemblyman, Michael Gianaris, a Democrat, said the ads, in local newspapers and at bus stops, were a waste of money. Martha Liipfert, a Con Ed spokeswoman, said the company had spent $90 million on the response to the blackout and in repairs.

title: ...Whos the Youngest of Them All? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Suicide Bombing Kills 20 in Baghdad Book Market
description: BAGHDAD, March 5  The book market along Mutanabi Street was a throwback to the Baghdad of old, the days of students browsing for texts, turbaned clerics hunting down religious tomes and cafe intellectuals debating politics over backgammon.

title: U.N.L.V. Forward Does Not Lack Family Support
description: LAS VEGAS, March 4  When the cheering section for Joe Darger is at full strength, it includes his father, his mother, his 18 siblings and his fathers other wife.

title: Mortgage Crisis Spirals, and Casualties Mount
description: Even in affluent Orange County, Calif., the growing wealth of executives and brokers in the booming mortgage industry was hard to miss.

title: That Films Real Message? It Could Be: Buy a Ticket
description: LOS ANGELES, March 4  Three weeks ago a handful of reporters at an international press junket here for the Warner Brothers movie 300, about the battle of Thermopylae some 2,500 years ago, cornered the director Zack Snyder with an unanticipated question.

title: On the Way to a Small Slam and a Title, Trick 2 Is Decisive
description: The final of the White House Teams in Amsterdam on Feb. 25 was between the host nation and Ireland. It proved to be an easy victory for the Dutch team of Ton Bakkeren, Huub Bertens, Sjoert Brink and Bas Drijver. They defeated John Carroll, Nick FitzGibbon, Tommy Garvey and Adam Mesbur 111 international match points to 41 over 28 boards.

title: In Las Vegas, the Drink Makes the Mayor
description: LAS VEGAS, Feb. 28  For the record, the mayor of Las Vegas, Oscar B. Goodman, likes his martinis made with a big cup of gin, on the rocks and a couple of garlic-stuffed olives. Vermouth need not apply, and dont even talk to him about vodka.

title: A Scuffle Over Pay Television in Britain Spills Into the Living Room
description: LONDON, March 3  For 3.3 million cable television viewers in Britain, Lost has disappeared. So have several other popular American series, including 24 and The Simpsons.

title: Cities Mesh Across Blurry Border, Despite Physical Barrier
description: TIJUANA, Mexico, Feb. 27  Mexican authorities complained recently that American construction workers putting up a barrier on the border between Mexico and the United States had trespassed into Mexico a full 33 feet.

title: Up Next: A Real Tally of Couch Potatoes
description: On May 31, for the first time, Nielsen Media Research will release long-awaited ratings that tell ad buyers exactly how many people are watching their commercials.

title: The Walking Wounded Who Never Saw a Battlefield
description: If youre planning to see Dying City, the crafty and unsettling new play by Christopher Shinn  and you should  you need to know one thing, lest you start to question your sanity. The stage moves.

title: On Air and in Church, Mayor Takes a Tone of Reassurance on Schools
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg stepped up his efforts yesterday to reassure parents about his management of the New York public schools, using his weekly radio address and visits to two Queens churches to defend his record and to remind parents that improving the nations largest school system was an enormous and complex task.

title: DAmato Never Folds
description: For years, Alfonse M. DAmato, the former Republican senator from New York, was the host at a Thursday evening poker game at his Capitol Hill office, playing with other lawmakers, staff members and lobbyists late into the night over pots that ranged from a few dollars to a few hundred.

title: Infernal Shades, Apparitions at Dusk, Spirits Who Tango
description: Sustaining a dance company is a tricky thing. Sustaining it for more than 50 years, as Paul Taylor has done, is an artistic feat of strength, though not without its costs.

title: Firing Off Another Round Over Health Care Budget Cuts
description: ALBANY  The Rev. Al Sharpton assails Gov. Eliot Spitzers proposed health care budget cuts in a new radio advertisement and mailings this week that will be aimed at New York City residents.

title: The Miserablist, All Grown Up and Hard at Work
description: About halfway through his concert at the Bowery Ballroom on Friday night Conor Oberst proclaimed it good. Sometimes I feel in opposition to the audience, somehow, and I dont want to, he said. He considered other, less good nights. Sometimes it goes south, and theres nothing you can do.

title: Rats to Riches: Buddies on a Theatrical Journey
description: A decade ago, when Philip Seymour Hoffman and John Ortiz first shared the stage under the auspices of the Labyrinth Theater Company, the production  from casting to staging to programs  cost about $400. Rehearsals were held in apartments or, when the performers were lucky, in a rat-infested, semiabandoned theater on the far West Side. Part of the set  a bar  was on loan from the brother of one of the actors, and the rest was built or cobbled together by the actors themselves, who hung lights and wielded handsaws alongside their scripts.

title: Citizen Bono Brings Africa to Idle Rich
description: If you are a rock star with a touch of the messiah complex, saving the world one song at a time has its limits. Even John Lennon didnt make much progress on world peace before he died.

title: Senator Sought Dismissal of New Mexico Prosecutor
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, said Sunday that he had urged the Justice Department to dismiss the states top federal prosecutor, who in December was one of eight United States attorneys ousted from their jobs.

title: Nets Add to Their Insecurity Before Long Trip
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 4  The Nets are embracing a dangerous identity that could send them to an early summer vacation if they do not find a more desirable persona once and for all.

title: Albany: Uncollected Cigarette Taxes
description: New York State loses $270 million annually in uncollected cigarette tax revenues from businesses on Indian reservations, according to a report released yesterday by State Senator Jeffrey D. Klein, a Democrat who represents parts of the Bronx and Westchester County. Gov. Eliot Spitzer has vowed to take steps to collect taxes from tobacco retailers on reservations that sell to non-Indian purchasers. In January, a state judge blocked efforts to collect such taxes under a 2005 law, ruling that the state had failed to distribute coupons allowing Indians to continue buying the products tax-free for their personal consumption. Mr. Klein has proposed splitting tax revenue with Indian tribes to encourage them to support collection of the tax.

title: Roving a Restless World, With Lots of Famous Friends
description: Like many a handsome and meticulously produced volume, Kurt Andersens Heyday ends with a grace note explaining the history and particulars of its typeface. Usually this kind of coda stands apart from the books substance. In this case its entirely consistent with what has come before. Although Heyday is a historical novel conceived on a grand scale, it is also a walking, talking almanac. Classifications, notations, translations, amplifications, derivations and formulations are not tangential to Mr. Andersens story. In a very real way they constitute the books main event.

title: In Guatemala, Officers Killings Echo Dirty War
description: GUATEMALA CITY, March 3  After three Salvadoran congressmen were waylaid and killed on a road in Guatemala last month, it did not take the authorities long to find the culprits: they were Guatemalan police officers, and their unmarked police car had a tracking device that proved they were at the scene.

title: 16 Civilians Die as U.S. Troops Fire on Afghan Road
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 4  American troops opened fire on a highway filled with civilian cars and bystanders on Sunday, American and Afghan officials said, in an incident that the Americans said left 16 civilians dead and 24 wounded after a suicide car bombing in eastern Afghanistan. One American was also wounded.

title: Exploring the Difficult to Define
description: You might think that by now New York audiences would know the composer Joji Yuasa  those, at least, whose memories reach back to the 1980s, when his work was often played here. Yet short memories are not the only reason Mr. Yuasas work isnt better defined in the collective musical consciousness; it is also because his music is hard to define at all. Twelve tone? Illustrative? Impressionistic? Romantic? Traditional? Computer music?

title: Crackdown on Pedicabs (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Cant Tell Your Cokes Apart? Sue Someone
description: REMEMBER the Three Stooges routine about the law firm called Dewey, Cheatem & Howe? Although the Coca-Cola Company is not using that particular fictional firm, it is updating the make-fun-of-lawyers shtick for new generations in a nontraditional campaign for Coke Zero.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: China Limits Idol Worship

title: Basra Raid Finds Dozens Detained by Iraq Spy Unit
description: BAGHDAD, Monday, March 5  Iraqi special forces and British troops stormed the offices of an Iraqi government intelligence agency in the southern city of Basra on Sunday, and British officials said they discovered about 30 prisoners, some showing signs of torture.

title: For Senator Schumer, a Chance to Relive a 1960s Quiz Show Triumph
description: He remembers that he helped his team win the New York City finals by identifying the pigment in white paint (titanium dioxide), but forgets what question cost his team the regional championship.

title: Manhattan: Call for More Family Court Judges
description: Betsy Gotbaum, the New York City public advocate, called yesterday for hiring more Family Court judges and extending a program that allows State Supreme Court justices to be temporarily assigned to Family Court. Since 1991, the number of judges has been fixed in state law at 47. The workload at Family Court has surged because of the increase in reports of abuse and neglect since Nixzmary Brown, 7, died after a beating in her home in Brooklyn on Jan. 11, 2006.

title: Tests Reveal Blood Clot in Cheneys Leg
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  Vice President Dick Cheney was treated today for a blood clot in his left leg that independent experts said was probably not related to his history of heart disease, but rather the result of his recent around-the-world trip, which included 65 hours of plane travel over 9 days.

title: U.S. to Offer North Korea Face-Saving Nuclear Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  In an effort to make the best of newly murky intelligence about North Korea, Bush administration officials say they plan to tell the Norths nuclear negotiators on Monday that Washingtons doubts about how much progress the country has made in enriching uranium gives North Korea a face-saving way to surrender its nuclear equipment.

title: Georgia Tornado Strips Area of Medical Services
description: AMERICUS, Ga., March 2  The tornado that ripped through this southwest Georgia town Thursday not only left a trail of death and devastation, it also stripped bare the only major medical facilities for thousands of people in a sprawling rural community.

title: Manhattan: Woman Escapes Arsonists Attack
description: An 82-year-old woman escaped her burning apartment on the Lower East Side yesterday after a neighbor struck her over the head and set her home afire, the police said. Detectives were questioning the victims neighbor, a 60-year-old woman, yesterday. The police and the victims niece, who identified the victim as Rosa Rodriguez, said the neighbor knocked on Mrs. Rodriguezs door in a building on East Sixth Street shortly before 11 a.m. and asked for change for a $10 bill. When Mrs. Rodriguez opened the door, the neighbor said, Lady, I am going to kill you, before striking her with a pipe and throwing a burning pillow into the apartment, said the niece, Margarita DeLeon, 50. Mrs. Rodriguez suffered cuts and bruises and was in stable condition at Bellevue Hospital Center yesterday, the police said. The authorities did not release the name of the woman being questioned. Mrs. DeLeon said of her aunt: Shes very sweet with everybody. She has a lot of friends.

title: An Oiler at Heart, an Islander for Now
description: Among the childhood memorabilia that Dixie and Jim Smyth keep for their three sons is a favorite photograph. Ryan Smyth, future hockey star, is 6 or 7, asleep in his bed in Banff, Alberta. New skates are on his feet, a new helmet on his head. At bedtime, he would not take them off.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Observatory column in Science Times on Tuesday, about efforts to extract silver from ore at La Isabela, Christopher Columbuss first settlement in the New World, misspelled the name of the ore. It is galena, not gallena.

title: Beijing Accelerates Its Military Spending
description: BEIJING, March 4  China announced its biggest increase in defense spending in five years on Sunday, a development that quickly prompted the United States to renew its calls for more transparency from the Chinese military about the scope and intent of its continuing, rapid arms buildup.

title: Despite Ranking, Memphis Remains a Mystery for N.C.A.A. Tournament
description: Memphis earned its first No. 1 seeding in the N.C.A.A. tournament and fell a game short of the Final Four last season. But the Tigers were hardly expected to achieve similar success this season after losing two top players from that team to the N.B.A.

title: U.S. Airstrike Kills 9 in Afghan Family
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 5  Nine members of a family were killed in an American airstrike in central Afghanistan, including five women and three children during a battle with militants, Afghan officials said today.

title: Terror Case Prosecutor Assails Defense Lawyer
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 4  The chief prosecutor for the American military commissions that will try suspected terrorists being held at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, has lashed out at the military lawyer for one of the detainees, a newspaper here reported in its weekend edition.

title: Underworld, and Theyre Dancing in the Dark
description: Chantal Yzermans, the Belgian director of the group Radical Low, began her new work, ONR-I, allegory of night, at the Danspace Project on Friday with the sort of alluring preshow that makes the rest suffer. Topless and wearing sunglasses and white cropped hipster pants embellished with clear plastic on her torso and calves, Ms. Yzermans traversed the stage, rising on her toes until her wobbly hip rocked off balance. Joining her was Ashley Chen, a smoldering dancer whose arching backbends and wild, whipping legs lent an odd symmetry to Ms. Yzermanss unhurried, finite details.

title: On Third Try, Siena Surprises Marist
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 4  Sienas 86-78 victory over Marist in a Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference tournament semifinal Sunday night was fashioned in part by 26 points from guard Kenny Hasbrouck, 17 from forward Edwin Ubiles and 15 from center Michael Haddix.

title: New CDs
description: ARCADE FIRE Neon Bible  (Merge)

title: Its Pork. Its a Pet Project. Its a Christmas Tree.
description: TRENTON, March 2  In New Jersey and New Mexico they are called Christmas tree items. New York calls them pet projects. Other states call the items WAMs, for walking around money. And in Alabama, in a rare fit of candor, it is called pass-through pork.

title: Bronx River Beavers (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ancient Times, the Sequel - Israel Celebrates Purim
description: Purim commemorates the thwarting of a plot to destroy the Jews of ancient Persia 2,400 years ago, as recounted in the Book of Esther.

title: Focus on Veterans Chief as Inquiries on Care Begin
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  As President Bush ordered an investigation of the militarys care of wounded soldiers and veterans last week, Jim Nicholson, secretary of veterans affairs, darted between events, seeking to put a positive public face on his beleaguered agency.

title: Welfare-to-Work Program to Draw Fire in Report
description: An ambitious city program to help welfare recipients who have physical or mental problems that prevent them from working has floundered during its first two years because it is poorly administered, according to a report that a community group intends to release today.

title: Taking Genocide to Court
description: Genocide moves swiftly, kills promiscuously and keeps finding new perpetrators, despite the worlds repeated vows of never again.

title: Governor Gunslinger
description: A sleepy breakfast with New York City business and civic leaders last week turned into another lively battleground for Gov. Eliot Spitzer. As he defended his efforts to rein in Medicaid spending, representatives of the hospitals and health workers fumed in the front row, especially when he contradicted their mawkish television ads. When a reporter later mentioned how Mr. Spitzer had come out guns blazing at the health establishment, he smiled and warned, that wasnt guns going.

title: NBC Anchor to Baghdad, the First Trip Since ABCs
description: The NBC News anchor Brian Williams arrived in Baghdad yesterday, the first network news anchor to travel to Baghdad since Bob Woodruff, who was then the co-anchor of ABC News, was severely injured by a roadside bomb in January 2006. Mr. Williams will start what is planned to be a week of reporting and anchoring NBCs evening newscast from Iraq.

title: Thomas F. Eagleton, 77, a Running Mate for 18 Days, Dies
description: Thomas F. Eagleton, a former United States senator whose legislative accomplishments were overshadowed by his removal as the Democratic vice presidential candidate in 1972 after revelations of mental illness and electroshock therapy, died yesterday in Richmond Heights, Mo. He was 77 and lived outside St. Louis in Clayton, Mo.

title: A Richer Trip to the Mall, Guided by Text Messages
description: SEARCH engines made it easy to find items at online stores. Now the Internet is poised to solve a more vexing problem: finding items while you are at the mall.

title: Chinese Premier Focuses on Pollution and the Poor
description: BEIJING, Monday, March 5  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao conceded Monday that China was failing on important energy and pollution goals and declared that the country must become more energy-efficient and quickly improve environmental protection to safeguard the long-term health of its booming economy.

title: BBC Provides More Detail on a Report It Didnt Show
description: LONDON, March 4  Senior government officials rallied Sunday to support a High Court ruling forbidding the BBC, Britains public service broadcaster, from transmitting news about accusations of campaign finance improprieties that are under investigation by the police.

title: On Road to Kentucky Derby, Early Contenders Emerge
description: HALLANDALE BEACH, Fla., March 4  The first Saturday in November and the Breeders Cup Juvenile are long past, and the first Saturday in May and the Kentucky Derby remain two months away. Both dates, however, were on the minds of the trainers Todd Pletcher and Doug ONeill, who each have several 3-year-olds capable of winning at Churchill Downs.

title: Blog the Debt Away
description: Public humiliation in the stocks long ago fell out of fashion. A virtual version is making a comeback. This time its a self-imposed punishment for debtors trying to abase their way back into the black.

title: Looking Ahead
description: PAULSON IN ASIA Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., below, will head to Asia this week, stopping in Japan on Monday, South Korea on Tuesday, Beijing on Wednesday and Shanghai on Thursday. The trip will include meetings with the Japanese finance minister and the governor of the Bank of Japan, and discussions about the weakness of the yen. Discussions in China will also include currency issues; Mr. Paulson has urged Chinese officials to move toward a more flexible exchange rate on the yuan. In Shanghai, Mr. Paulson is scheduled to deliver a speech on reform in Chinese financial markets.

title: Clinton and Obama Unite in Pleas to Blacks
description: SELMA, Ala., March 4  Evoking the passions and rivalries of the civil rights era, Senators Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton made deeply personal appeals to voters in the sanctuaries of black churches here on Sunday, and then joined former President Bill Clinton for a march across a bridge where white police officers beat protesters, most of them black, nearly 42 years ago.

title: Accounts
description: Accounts

title: Florida Puts Kentucky and Smith on Notice
description: GAINESVILLE, Fla., March 4  There was no formal passing of the baton Sunday, just a warm handshake at midcourt between Billy Donovan and Tubby Smith before Donovans Florida Gators played host to Smiths Kentucky Wildcats.

title: Tailor Pain Relief to the Patient (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Dolls Clad in Feminism, and Hardly Anything Else
description: LOS ANGELES, March 4  Parents looking for role models for teenage daughters: Finally there is a show for you.

title: Manhattan: Woman Escapes Arsonists Attack
description: An 82-year-old woman escaped her burning apartment on the Lower East Side yesterday after a neighbor struck her over the head and set her home afire, the police said. The neighbor, Martha Lugo, 66, was arrested and charged with attempted murder, assault and arson.

title: Alternatives to the Nursing Home (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: Malaria Pills Without Profit
description: The big pharmaceutical companies are rightly criticized for concentrating on the development and marketing of drugs that sell for high prices in the industrialized world while neglecting to produce medications that could save millions of lives in the poorest countries. So it came as especially welcome news last week that Paris-based Sanofi-Aventis, the worlds fourth-largest drug company, working in collaboration with a nonprofit drug-development organization pioneered by Doctors Without Borders, will soon introduce a cheap and easy-to-use pill to combat malaria in sub-Saharan Africa.

title: Treasury Bill Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week included todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Composers Add Tastes to Fusion
description: Bang on a Can has always been the most unabashedly populist of new-music organizations. Its name suggests that anyone can make music on anything, and its boundary-crossing programs have been built on the notion that contemporary music can embrace elements of rock, jazz and world music. In recent seasons its grass-roots approach has extended to commissioning too, by inviting its audiences to contribute to the Peoples Commissioning Fund. The proceeds are put toward commissioning new works, which are performed at an annual Peoples Commissioning Fund concert by the Bang on a Can All-Stars.

title: Ivory Coast Leader Signs Accord With Rebels
description: DAKAR, Senegal, March 4  The president of Ivory Coast and the leader of a rebel group that controls its northern half signed a new agreement on Sunday to end a political impasse and reunite the country, which has been divided by war.

title: Hamiltons Injury Will Not Alter St. Johns Plans
description: When Lamont Hamilton crumpled to the floor yesterday against Providence after a first-half collision with his teammate Anthony Mason Jr., the Big East tournament started to take on an entirely different look for St. Johns.

title: Prodigy Points the Way for Connecticut Women
description: HARTFORD, March 4  His shirt was lilac but his mood was dark. Hands on hips, Coach Geno Auriemma shouted harshly at Connecticuts freshman center, Tina Charles.

title: Mamaroneck: Womans Torso Found After Flood
description: A womans torso was found in a suitcase on a beach on Harbor Island, the police said yesterday. The suitcase was found about 2:10 p.m. on Saturday by a resident walking along the beach a day after heavy rains flooded the village. The victim, who had a tattoo of two cherries above her right breast, was described as 35 to 50 years old and 180 to 200 pounds, the authorities said. Detective Sgt. Robert Holland of the Mamaroneck Village police said that the torso had been in the suitcase about a week.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption and accompanying credit in Weekend on Friday with an article about the New York International Childrens Film Festival misstated the title of a short that will be shown. It is Electric Sleep, not Electric Sheep.

title: An Undertow of Melancholy in a Sea of Ever-Churning Humanity
description: Paul Taylor went after thorny avant-gardism at the start of his career, enjoyably irritating at least one major dance writer and by most accounts sending his audiences out scratching their heads. He has since had a go or three at spare ultramodern illogic  usually, it has seemed, with a small sly shrug. But more to the point no other choreographer has Mr. Taylors dizzyingly wide range of themes and styles.
