And no one else is quite so adept at drawing audiences into what feels like a look into all our lives, an effect enhanced by his choice of endearingly human-looking dancers capable of seemingly superhuman feats of skill and physicality.

title: Education, Education, Education
description: Its an article of faith that the key to success in real estate is location, location, location.

title: Time Change a Mini-Y2K in Tech Terms
description: Two years ago, when Congress passed a law to extend daylight saving time by a month, the move seemed a harmless step that would let the nation burn a little less fossil fuel and enjoy a bit more sunshine.

title: Japan Resists Call to Apologize for War Practice
description: TOKYO, March 5  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said today that if the United States Congress demands that Japan apologize for his nations use of foreign women as sexual slaves during World War II, his government will refuse to comply.

title: Newark: Funeral for Officer Killed in Crash
description: City officials said yesterday that a funeral mass for a police sergeant killed in a car crash while pursuing a suspect was scheduled for Wednesday morning at the Cathedral Basilica of the Sacred Heart in Newark. The sergeant, Tommaso Popolizio, 33, of Roseland, died while pursuing William Rodriguez, 22, who escaped in a stolen squad car shortly before 4 a.m. on Saturday, the police said. Mr. Rodriguez, above, whose hands had been cuffed behind his back when he was placed in the back seat of a patrol car, was able to work the handcuffs to the front of his body and crawl to the front seat through an opening in a partition, according to a city official with knowledge of the investigation. Mr. Rodriguez was arrested several minutes after the crash and was charged with aggravated manslaughter, the police said.

title: In Wine Country, Pruning Isnt Just a Part of the Job
description: FORESTVILLE, Calif., March 4  It may be the worlds most boggling spectator sport.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday, about the effects of serotonin syndrome, misstated the affiliation of Dr. Edward W. Boyer, an emergency medicine specialist, who has written about the risks of the syndrome. His primary work is with the University of Massachusetts Medical School, not with Childrens Hospital Boston.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the political fallout in Australia over the case of David Hicks, an Australian who is the first detainee from the American base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, to be charged under the Military Commissions Act of 2006, misstated the surname of the executive director of Get Up!, a group that is campaigning to bring Mr. Hicks home. He is Brett Solomon, not Simpson.

title: Oil Innovations Pump New Life Into Old Wells
description: BAKERSFIELD, Calif.  The Kern River oil field, discovered in 1899, was revived when Chevron engineers here started injecting high-pressured steam to pump out more oil. The field, whose production had slumped to 10,000 barrels a day in the 1960s, now has a daily output of 85,000 barrels.

title: A New Look at Nina Ricci and a Puzzle at Chlo
description: PARIS, March 4  In the constant to and fro of the French collections, Olivier Theyskens established a new look at Nina Ricci, while Paulo Melim Andersson turned the feminine Chlo into a puzzling abstraction.

title: President Is Leaving N.A.A.C.P.
description: WASHINGTON, March 4  The president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said on Sunday that he was stepping down after only 19 months on the job, signaling divisions within the organization, the nations oldest and largest civil rights group.

title: If You Need Your News on the Run, Read the Summary
description: Dont have time to read all of the newspaper? The Philadelphia Inquirer and its sister paper, The Daily News, are trying to address that problem by giving readers a prominent color digest of the newspapers, right in the newspapers themselves.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on NYTimes.com on Feb. 21 about the perjury trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff for Vice President Dick Cheney, incorrectly described the testimony of Ari Fleischer, the former White House spokesman. Mr. Fleischer testified that he discussed a former Central Intelligence Agency operative, Valerie Wilson, with two reporters in 2003; he did not say that Walter Pincus of The Washington Post was one of those reporters. (Mr. Pincus testified that Mr. Fleischer did discuss Ms. Wilson with him.) (Go to Article)

title: A Tinkerers Art Transforms the World, and the Getty
description: ALTADENA, Calif.  Because greater Los Angeles is the land of cars and of plenty of places to park them, it is also home to untold numbers of garage tinkerers, who practically live in the lairs next to their houses, dreaming, puttering, fixing and fiddling.

title: Without Health Benefits, a Good Life Turns Fragile
description: SALISBURY, N.C.  Vicki H. Readling vividly remembers the start of 2006.

title: A Contributor to Wikipedia Has His Fictional Side
description: In a blink, the wisdom of the crowd became the fury of the crowd. In the last few days, contributors to Wikipedia, the popular online encyclopedia, have turned against one of their own who was found to have created an elaborate false identity.

title: Congress Hears of Neglect in Veterans Care
description: Reports of bureaucratic entanglement and indifference on the part of the militarys medical care system, rather than the condition of buildings in the Walter Reed Army Medical Center, dominated a Congressional hearing today on how wounded veterans are treated.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,158 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans over the weekend:

title: From a Singer With Style, a Voice in Service of Music
description: Joyce DiDonato is the kind of singer doomed to be described with adjectives like perky or feisty. She is blond, attractive, American and cute. This is perhaps unfortunate, since none of these things have much to do with her best qualities as an artist, qualities that were displayed, intermittently but abundantly, at her Carnegie Hall recital debut at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday night.

title: A Buckeye Wears a Bulls-Eye, and Takes It All in Stride
description: Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Healthy Pavano Can Focus on Pitching for Yankees
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 4  Carl Pavano made a spring training start Sunday, and sure enough, the Yankees trainer was on the field after one batter. He was there to check on the left fielder, Jos Tbata, who had fallen to the ground in pursuit of a fly ball. He did not bother to ask how Pavano was doing.

title: Wireless Technology Speeds Health Services in Rwanda
description: To Rwandas top H.I.V./AIDS official, communication within the national health care system can be slow enough to present a threat to health.

title: Risking Testy Justices and Faulty Justice
description: What the Supreme Court says, goes. Usually.

title: English, Irish, Scots: Theyre All One, Genes Suggest
description: Britain and Ireland are so thoroughly divided in their histories that there is no single word to refer to the inhabitants of both islands. Historians teach that they are mostly descended from different peoples: the Irish from the Celts, and the English from the Anglo-Saxons who invaded from northern Europe and drove the Celts to the countrys western and northern fringes.

title: In Europe, Private Equity Firms Strive to Buff Image
description: LONDON, March 4  European private equity firms are trying to rescue their reputation.

title: New Justice, No Peace
description: Washington

title: From Ferrying Thousands Daily to Rusting Away by the Turnpike
description: EAST BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 4  In this age of online auctions, rapid-fire sheriffs sales and everything-must-go closeouts, who has not made an exorbitant purchase only to tuck it away in a closet or garage once at home, its usefulness a sudden mystery?

title: Hamas Gets Training in Iran, Israeli Official Says
description: TEL AVIV, March 5  The chief of Israels Shin Bet internal security service said today that the Islamic movement Hamas has sent dozens of men from Gaza to Iran for weapons and military training.

title: Back Story That Wasnt Heard Round the World
description: Bobby Thomsons home run against Ralph Branca is always the primary story line for the New York Giants conquest of the Brooklyn Dodgers in the 1951 National League pennant playoff. But a mostly forgotten and fractious subplot involved the Dodgers right-hander Clem Labine, who died Friday at 80, and his manipulative manager, Chuck Dressen.

title: Saudi-Iran Meeting Yields Little Substance
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 4  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran and King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia concluded an extraordinary meeting early Sunday promising a thaw in relations between the two regional powers. But they stopped short of agreeing on any concrete plans to tackle the escalating sectarian and political crises throughout the Middle East.

title: Contrasting Auditions for Spot in Mets Rotation
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., March 4  About 15 feet separated John Maine and Philip Humber in the cramped visitors clubhouse at Fort Lauderdale Stadium. They were the last of the candidates for the Mets starting rotation to make their first appearances of the spring, and their moods Sunday could hardly have diverged more.

title: Valor and Squalor
description: When Salon, the online magazine, reported on mistreatment of veterans at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center two years ago, officials simply denied that there were any problems. And they initially tried to brush off last months expos in The Washington Post.

title: Microsoft Prize of $10,000 to Promote Xbox Games
description: Reaching out to millions of aspiring game developers around the world, Microsoft plans today to announce a contest that will award $10,000 and the opportunity to entice millions of eyeballs to the next great digital diversion for the companys Xbox 360.

title: Euthanasia for Unadoptable Dogs and Cats (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Questioned About Son, Giuliani Pleads for Privacy
description: MONTEREY PARK, Calif., March 5  Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former New York City mayor seeking the Republican nomination for president, said today that the estranged relationship he has with his college-age son reflected the challenges of blended families created by divorce and remarriage, and he issued a plea for privacy to resolve the difficulties.

title: Threadbare to Quite Posh, in Just 12 Hours
description: In 1923, John W. Campbell, a millionaire American financier, built a big corner office resembling a 13th-century Florentine palazzo, a whim not unusual in the age of Gatsby, save for the whims location.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: How to Grow a Super-Athlete
description: While favorable genetics and a well-conditioned body are essential, some scientists believe that physiological changes in the brain that take place during repetitive practice may make the difference between a world-class athlete and the rest of us.

title: N.Y.C. Scavenger Hunt
description: A recent Weekend in New York column challenged you to go on a photo scavenger hunt in the city. Did you find the most expensive pizza slice? A bad parallel parking job? Here are some of the submissions we've received so far.

title: Washington Takes a Chance on Tehran
description: Good news from the war zone: Syria and Iran -- both countries that have shown little interest so far in relieving tensions in Iraq -- will take part in a conference in Baghdad this weekend in a development that has taken many by surprise. The mood in Washington is astonishingly upbeat after this radical shift in strategy.

title: Everyday Peculiarities
description: Images from the Henry Wessel retrospective at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

title: Hedge Funds Descend Ahead of Landesbank Sale
description: Hedge funds are positioned to profit from the forthcoming sale of Landesbank Berlin regardless of who buys the bank, The Financial Times reported. As the closely watched auction of Landesbank Berlin continues, hedge funds have snapped up much of the 7 percent stake in the bank that is listed on the Berlin stock exchange in a move to take advantage of German takeover rules, the report said.

title: A Warren Buffet for Washington
description: The federal government oversees a colorful array of businesses  restaurants, car dealerships, casinos, strip clubs and now even hedge funds  as their owners sit on trial for various crimes. Forbes takes a look at Len Briskman, deputy chief of business management for the U.S. Marshals Service and the man who oversees this diverse portfolio.

title: Mortgage Crisis Spirals, and Casualties Mount
description: Just as the technology boom of the late 1990s turned twenty-something programmers into dot-com billionaires, and leveraged buyouts a decade earlier turned Wall Street bankers into Masters of the Universe, the explosive growth in subprime lending turned mortgage bankers and brokers into multimillionaires seemingly overnight.

title: A Cozy Book Club, in a Virtual Reading Room
description: When many people think of online social networking, they picture Web sites where the young and the restless discuss their love lives and their favorite bands. But a more sedate sort of Web-based network  that of the bookworm  is on the rise. The New York Times notes that social networks that tap the interests and buying power of traditionally reserved groups like the bookish are a small but growing force on the Web. While the focus of many of the sites is cataloging users collections, the social element has also become an important element of their success.

title: Sit Down for a Chat With Hedge Fund Movers
description: A new book on hedge funds pulls back the curtain slightly on an industry that is gaining increasing attention from lawmakers, regulators and the media. The New York Times says that Inside the House of Money by Steven Drobny is less a book of sustained narration or explanation than a notebook of interviews developed from exclusive confabs sponsored by the authors consulting firm, Drobny Global Advisors. Still, it says, the ruminations of supposedly hush-hush hedge fund operators are richly illuminating and cost much less expensive than the fees they charge.

title: 2 + 20, and Other Hedge Fund Math
description: Many people would jump at the chance to invest in hedge funds, which have mainly been available to only the very wealthy. But a new study finds that the funds high fees make it unlikely that investors will improve their long-term performance by putting money into hedge funds, Mark Hulbert writes in The New York Times.

title: For Some, a Bacchanalian Bonus
description: Its not uncommon for companies to offer product discounts to executives and directors. But there arent many companies whose perks include a fixed amount of money specifically for buying wine. In a recent regulatory filing, UST, which makes wine in Washington State and California, said it provided its chairman and chief executive, Vincent A. Gierer Jr., with a $5,000 wine allowance.

title: Blackstone to Buy Tussauds for $1.9 Billion
description: Will we be seeing a wax likeness of Stephen Schwarzman sometime soon?

title: That Ship Will Come in, Right?
description: Wave Systems has never had a profitable quarter. Ever. In nearly 20 years.

title: Apollo Takes Countrywide, but a Rival Is Circling
description: Countrywide, Britains largest estate agency, on Friday night said it had agreed to be bought by Apollo, the private equity company, in a deal worth 1.01 billion pounds ($1.94 billion). But rumors of a counterbid have raised questions of whether a bidding war may be in the offing.

title: In Claires Auction, Apax Is Last Man Standing, Report Says
description: Private equity firm Apax is believed to be the front-runner to acquire the jewelry and accessories retailer Claires Stores in a $3 billion deal, according to The Sunday Telegraph. But it may be that the buyout shop is less of a front-runner and more like the only runner in the auction for Claires, which said in December that it was exploring strategic alternatives for its business, including a possible sale.

title: Biotech Helicos Plans I.P.O.
description: Helicos BioSciences, a 71-person firm trying to develop a faster way to analyze genes, is planning to go public in a $100 million stock offering. The company, based in Cambridge, Mass., is the latest entry in the race to build a faster and cheaper genetic sequencer, a machine that can read the letters that compose the genetic code. Once the domain of long-term biology research projects, gene sequencing has sped up in recent years and is becoming an important tool for studying diseases.

title: After the Green Tech Party, a Hangover?
description: It seems one cant go anywhere these days without being confronted with the craze over green technology. Talk of climate change has been the hottest topic of conversation at events ranging from the World Economic Forum to the Oscars.

title: Blockbuster Is Said to Seek Movielink
description: Blockbuster, the No. 1 U.S. movie rental company, is in talks to acquire Movielink, an online movie-downloading company owned by major Hollywood studios, according to news reports. Blockbuster is reportedly proposing to pay about $50 million in cash and stock to grow a third leg of its business, joining its in-store and online DVD rental operations.

title: Motorola Wont Back Icahn Nomination
description: Motorolas board would not endorse a nomination of billionaire financier Carl C. Icahn to join the board, the company said in a document filed with regulators on Friday. The mobile phone maker said it received a notice from Icahn entities for the nomination of the activist investor to its board at the companys annual meeting, scheduled for May 7. But Motorola said it does not know if Mr. Icahns entities would in fact solicit proxies or nominate Mr. Icahn at the meeting.

title: Jury Selection Begins in Black Trial
description: Conrad Blacks lawyers will be in a Chicago courtroom Monday to begin the lengthy process of selecting 12 people who will make up the jury that will decide the former media barons fate. More than 100 potential jurors have already filled out long questionnaires seeking details about their background, political views and thoughts on the corporate world in general, The Globe and Mail reported.

title: In Europe, Private Equity Strives to Buff Its Image
description: European private equity firms are anteing up to burnish their image. Under attack by politicians who called them asset strippers and locusts and by trade union leaders accusing them of cutting too many jobs, private equity firms are offering to hold meetings with their fiercest critics and have contributed 5 million pounds ($9.8 million) to set up a foundation to share part of their wealth.

title: Alltel Hopes to Dial Up a Deal, Report Says
description: Alltel, the wireless telecommunications company, has stepped up efforts to sell itself to carriers such as AT&T, Verizon Communications and Sprint Nextel, The Wall Street Journal reported. According to The Journal, the wireless operator approached AT&T recently about the possibility of selling itself to the telecoms giant. AT&T is reportedly willing to entertain the possibility, but remains skeptical about a combination because of potential antitrust problems, technology-integration issues and Alltels stock-market capitalization, which Friday stood at nearly $22 billion.

title: Palm Stock Surges Amid Deal Chatter
description: Shares of Palm jumped 11 percent Friday amid speculation that the company, which makes the Treo smart phone, could attract a takeover offer. Palm has been working with Morgan Stanley to consider its strategic options, people close to the company told DealBook. Separately, analysts at J.P. Morgan on Monday cut their rating on Palms stock to underweight from neutral, writing that the companys product line appears stale.

title: Buyout Firms Said to Circle Chrysler
description: With a slew of car makers taking a pass on a possible bid for Chrysler, the United States division of DaimlerChrysler, private equity players appear to be leading the pack of interested bidders. The Detroit News reported on Friday that the Blackstone Group has emerged as a leading contender to buy Chrysler. The paper said that Blackstone is moving forward with a detailed analysis of Chryslers finances and operations with an eye toward making a formal bid.

title: Clinton and Obama Unite in Selma
description: As they gathered to commemorate the civil rights movement, the two presidential candidates competed for black voters.

title: Cablevision at a Crossroads
description: Time Warner Cable or Comcast could theoretically pay more for Cablevision than the latest offer from its controlling family, but Cablevisions governance structure means that investors may never see that optimal payday, Breakingviews writes.

title: Racing Team Could Take Aston Martin This Week, Report Says
description: Ford Motor could announce the sale of its Aston Martin luxury performance cars unit for more than 450 million pounds ($865 million) as early as this week, Reuters reported citing an unidentified source who acknowledged that the timing of a deal may slip. According to Reuters, the Prodrive Formula One team, together with the Egyptian investment bank Naeem, is in the pole position to win Aston Martin, but others like the British buyout shop Doughty Hanson are close behind.

title: Olivier Theyskens
description: Olivier Theyskens presents his first collection for Nina Ricci in Paris.

title: Sharpton vs. Spitzer
description: In a new radio advertisement and mailings this week in New York City, the Rev. Al Sharpton will assail Gov. Eliot Spitzers proposed health-care budget cuts.

title: Colonel Allensworth's Utopia
description: Nearly a century ago, Allen Allensworth, an escaped slave from Kentucky, forged an idealistic community dedicated to Booker T. Washingtons principles of self-help and self-determination in Allensworth, Calif.

title: HSBC Says Lending Woes Arent Spreading
description: HSBC Holdings, Europes biggest banking company, said Monday that profits in 2006 were $22.1 billion, up 5 percent from $21 billion in the previous year. The company also said there had been no further deterioration in its troubled United States mortgage lending business since it warned a month ago about the deepening problems there.

title: R.I.M. Restates Profits by $250 Million after Options Inquiry
description: Research In Motion, the maker of the ubiquitous BlackBerry phones, will restate earnings by about $250 million and said its chairman will resign that position after a review of backdated stock options. While the company, based in Waterloo, Ontario, said that it did not find intentional misconduct by its executives, it will carry out a management shuffle that will include James Balsillie giving up his chairman post. He will remain co-chief executive.

title: G.O.P. Straw Poll Results
description: Last week previewed some upcoming G.O.P. straw polls, and we just wanted to update you on the results. First, we should clarify that they better reflect a candidates ability to organize supporters than the actual strength of support. Representative Duncan Hunter, for example, rallied his supporters in the days before the Spartanburg County, South Carolina straw poll, convincing them to show up despite the terrible weather Thursday and contribute to his very, very close third.

title: As Afghanistan Wobbles, No Pictures, Please
description: Swirling amid the fallout from the deaths of a number of civilians on a crowded Afghan highway yesterday is what appears to have been an attempt by some American soldiers at the scene to prevent any images of the carnage from getting out to the wider world.

title: 2008: Marching Onward
description: In case you missed the Obama-Clinton march in Selma, Ala. on Sunday, Jeff Zeleny and Patrick Healy wrap it up here.

title: Congress: Subpoenas Spotlight Fired Prosecutors
description: Democrats promised intense oversight of the Bush administration if they took the majority in Congress, accusing Republicans of totally abandoning such scrutiny. Once Democrats won, the expectation was that subpoenas would be flying over Iraq contracting, pre-war intelligence and the like.

title: Pronouncing On Public Financing
description: The Wall Street Journal editorial page doesnt like the pact between John McCain and Barack Obama to preserve spending limits and the public financing system for the 2008 general election if the two men receive the presidential nominations of their parties: [C]ampaign limits on individual contributions have instead made candidates even more reliant on organized special interests, and they reduce political competition by favoring the rich and famous. [$]

title: Subprime Mortgage Woes May Haunt Cerberus
description: As the market reels from the implosion of the subprime mortgage market, taking down profits at banking giants like HSBC, another notable company could face trouble. The New York Post reports that Cerberus Capital Managements 51 percent stake in GMAC could pose problems for the investment firm, along with its partners Citigroup and Aozora Bank.

title: Draw Your Own House Plans
description: Now that Paul and I had found John Agnelli, our builder, all we needed to do was figure out what to build.

title: Lord of the Rings
description: So if you had 10 World Series rings to choose from when you woke up in the morning, which would you wear? Theres only one person on the planet who can answer that question, and hes wearing a Yankees uniform this spring.

title: Giulianis Investment Bank Is Sold
description: Giuliani Capital Advisors, the investment banking arm of former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giulianis consulting business, will be acquired by Macquarie Group of Australia, Macquarie said early Monday. The sale, which was expected, comes as Mr. Giuliani embarks on a run for the presidency, raising questions about the fate of his various business endeavors.

title: High-tech haven
description: High-tech kitchen

title: Gwyneths goldmine
description: Its not enough that these celebrities have found fame and fortune. They also seem to be pretty good at sucking money from property markets. Two years after the actress Gwyneth Paltrow and her British rocker husband Chris Martin shelled out $7.95 million for a six-bedroom condo in New York Citys swanky TriBeCa neighborhood they have put it back on the market for a cool $14 million. With an elevator and even a rooftop swimming pool, it shouldnt be hard to find a buyer.

title: Call of the wild
description: The romance of country living is alive and well in Britain with a growing number of people swapping a PC for a plow.

title: Calling all foreigners  to Malaysia
description: Few Southeast Asian countries do self-promotion as well as Malaysia. Besides promoting itself as a top tourism destination, the government today is pushing a Malaysia My Second Home program  with the spiffy acronym MM2H  that hopes to attract foreign retirees with a renewable 10-year social visit pass and a streamlined way to buy property.

title: In Texas, the Strange Case of the Toking Toddlers
description: The videotape says it all  and it is the chief bit of evidence against two Texas teenagers who were arrested for turning two brothers, a 5-year-old and a 2-year-old, into pot-heads.

title: How to Avoid Genocide in Iraq
description: Samantha Power, author of A Problem From Hell: America and the Age of Genocide, argues on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times that fear of genocidal ethnic cleansing is no reason to maintain the American military presence in Iraq. In fact, just the opposite is the case, she suggests: What is needed to stave off even greater carnage than we see today is neither assuming massacres wont happen nor suspending thought until the surge has demonstrably failed in six months  at which point other options may no longer be viable. Rather, we must announce our intention to depart and use the intervening months to prioritize civilian protection by pursuing a bold set of measures combining political pressure, humanitarian relocation and judicial deterrence.

title: Complacency Bred Market Panic
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Mar. 2 column, The Big Meltdown.

title: Paris Fashion Week Wrap-Up
description: Photos from the last of the Paris shows including Lanvin, Louis Vuitton and Azzedine Alaa.

title: A&P, Pathmark Announce Merger Pact
description: The Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Company, operator of A&P supermarkets, announced Monday that it plans to acquire Pathmark Stores, a grocery chain concentrated in the northeastern United States, for about $679 million in cash and stock. There has been an uptick in deal activity among supermarkets in recent weeks, with Whole Foods Market agreeing to buy Wild Oats Markets last month.

title: Only 59 More
description: The first flurry of games from Championship Week has ended, and we awake Monday morning with six teams whove been formally asked to the Big Dance.

title: Giulianis Investment Bank Is Sold
description: Dealbook is reporting  that Giuliani Capital Partners, the investment banking arm of former New York City mayor Rudolph W. Giulianis consulting business, will be acquired by Macquarie Group of Australia, Macquarie said early Monday. The sale, which was expected, would eliminate some business ties that might have complicated Mr. Giulianis run for the presidency.Read more

title: Boston Private Acquires Bank Holding Company in Washington
description: A bank holding company, Boston Private Financial Holdings, said on Monday it had agreed to acquire Charter Financial for about $70.8 million in cash and stock to expand in the Pacific Northwest.

title: For those with money to burn
description: Exterior of chateau

title: An Eccentric Exploration
description: A look at the work of Tim Hawksinson, an artist whose work explores the natural world and modern life.

title: Moon Over Baghdad
description: As promised, the moon turned red over the weekend. Heres a view from Baghdad of the moon, plus some nearby stars that were visible when it was in Earths shadow.

title: Mutual Fund Managers: Lost in the Hedges?
description: You might think that someone who decides where to invest billions of dollars could bend an equity analysts ear with no problem. But as Bloomberg News tells it, some mutual fund managers are getting snubbed by stock researchers at investment banks because securities firms now order analysts to ignore everyone but the customers who pay the biggest fees. Who are these big-spending customers? Those would be hedge funds, lightly regulated investment pools that use an array of trading strategies to earn profits for their customers.

title: The Right and the Power
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Ailing  or Wailing  Baby Boomers
description: Are baby boomers really in bad physical shape? Or are we just providing more evidence that were the Whiniest Generation?

title: The Bill Clinton Factor
description: Bill Clintons appearance on the campaign trail was a special event: In a radio interview with an Iowa station, Mrs. Clinton says that her husbands appearances on her behalf will be rare, although she added, But itll happen when it can because, you know, I love seeing him. I love having him with me.

title: The Odd Couple of Social Networking
description: The peculiar deal between the router giant Cisco and the seven-employee Utah Street Networks, the owner of the also-ran social networking site Tribe.net, was formally announced Monday after having been revealed by The New York Times on Saturday. The price was not disclosed, but it was surely less than a rounding error for a company the size of Cisco. Still, the sale got noticed, if only because of the snarky commentary it elicited from Netscape cofounder Marc Andreessen.

title: P.S. Autre
description: Not that it should go to your head, but everybody here has been wondering who you are. I say, Loose lips.

title: What You Will Be
description: Leaving the Herms show the other day, wondering whether it was better to own a floor-length crocodile coat or a small apartment, I saw that I was next to Anna Wintour and her bodyguards. The doors of the Thtre du Chtelet swung open to brilliant sunshine  the daffodils are blooming here  and waiting on the sidewalk was the ever-present throng of Japanese street photographers. Though by no means as large as what one encounters outside the fashion tent in the Tuileries.

title: Private Equity I.P.O.s: The Geography Factor
description: Investors and academics have long debated how private-equity-backed companies fare in their initial public offerings. One camp argues that these companies do worse then their conventional peers because they are often loaded up with debt by their financial sponsors, who are eager for a quick exit. The other camp says they perform just as well, or better, than other I.P.O.s in the aftermarket. Data from Financial News suggest an interesting wrinkle: It may depend on which continent you are on.

title: The Politics of Apology for Japans Comfort Women
description: Debate continues to brew in Japan this week, following the Prime Minister Shinzo Abes unequivocal denial at the end of last week that the country had forced foreign women  mostly Chinese and Koreans  into sexual slavery during World War II.

title: Giulianis Blended Family
description: Former New York City Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said Monday that the estranged relationship he has with his college-age son reflected the challenges of blended families created by divorce and remarriage and he issued a plea for privacy to resolve the difficulties.

title: Murcer Plans to Return
description: Just had a chance to speak with Bobby Murcer during a conference call, and he sounds terrific. Murcer, the YES broadcaster and former Yankees center fielder, has completed radiation and chemotherapy treatments to treat a brain tumor and plans to return to the broadcast booth this season.

title: A Story of Astronomical Importance
description: This is an incredible time to be an astronomer. Actually, its an incredible time for anybodywho is interested in our place in the universe. The last few decades have seen the advent of technologies that have allowed us to see further into space than ever before.

title: With Last-Minute Bid, Citadel Takes ResMae Mortgage
description: Coming in under the wire, Citadel Investment Group snatched ResMae Mortgage from Credit Suisse, paying about $180 million for the bankrupt subprime mortgage lender. Citadel, the $13.4 billion Chicago-based hedge fund, will pay about $20 million for ResMaes lending business and 98.5 cents on the dollar for its $160 million loan portfolio. Credit Suisse, whom we reported had sewn up the bidding last month, offered $19.1 million for the lending operation and 98 cents on the dollar for the portfolio  but added several conditions, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Law Firms Question Raises, But Cant Resist Them
description: The American Lawyer offers a contrarian view of the recent rise in pay for associates at big law firms. More money, the magazines sources contend, is not necessarily the best way to keep the lawyers on board.

title: A Battle for Medical Care
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Mar. 5 column, Valor and Squalor.

title: Learning for a Lifetime
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Mar. 5 column, Education, Education, Education.

title: A Dark Horse on the Rise
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 4 column, Neither Clinton, Nor Obama.

title: Data for March 5 Column, Valor and Squalor
description: A few follow-up pieces of information on veterans and health care.

title: For Shame
description: Online video and photography have been a boon to the American sport of public shaming, which is at least as old as the pillory and the stockade.

title: Obama on the Issues (and his Grandfathers Wives)
description: In Tuesdays column, I write about Barack Obama and argue that its a canard that he is too inexperienced to be a good president. I quote briefly in the column from an interview I did with him in his Senate office on Feb. 27, but here are highlights from the transcript as a whole.

title: More from Spitzer, 1199
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer did not take the bait and attack the Rev. Al Sharpton for joining the battle against his budget.

title: The Yankees Cant Lose
description: Two outs, bases empty, Yankees down by a run in the ninth inning today. Felix Heredia on the mound for the Tigers. Josh Phelps swings on 3-0 and rips a single to left. Then Bronson Sardinha smokes a two-run, walk-off home run to right.

title: Google C.E.O. Plays Down Deal Talk
description: Just because Google spent $1.65 billion to acquire YouTube and is swimming in cash doesnt mean that Google will seek a major deal again anytime soon, according to its chief executive. Reuters said that at Morgan Stanleys technology conference, Eric Schmidt, responding to a question by analyst Mary Meeker, said that its highly unlikely the company will change course on how it uses cash.

title: Blogtalk: The No. 7, Babies Named Hillary, And Donald Trumps Dentist
description: Bloomberg in 2008? Lets ban everything. A Libertarian critique. [Reason Hit and Run]

title: Blogtalk: Seething Over Vets Care
description: The blogosphere is in uniform agreement that the conditions at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, as reported in a series of Washington Post exposs, are unacceptable. Of course, they split again when it comes to assigning blame.

title: Waiting for a Facelift
description: The trip to Fort Lauderdale Stadium, where the Mets lost a spring training game to the Orioles on Sunday, is one of my least favorites on the Grapefruit League circuit. And its not just because you take your life in your hands on the 75-to-90 minute drive from Port St. Lucie along Interstate 95. Frequently you have to drive 80 miles an hour just to keep pace with traffic, and even then youre going too slow for the occasional maniac lane-changer. (Had a guy on a motorcycle pass me on the way back going at least 110.)

title: End Game: Paris
description: After Paulo Melim Anderssons somewhat disappointing debut at Chlo (give him time, perhaps), Olivier Theyskens first show for Nina Ricci felt absolutely right and new. Not everyone thought so. And here, I suppose, might be a good place to respond to the person on the blog who asked if I wasnt contradicting myself on the Balenciaga review. A snake biting its tail, if I recall the expression. (Actually, at this stage, Miss Horyn feels more like Toby, her big blond Lab, chasing his tail. Weak.) Anyway: how do I judge the new?

title: What Kind of Music Is This Anyway?
description: The wonderful guitarist, Mark Stewart, who is a member of the Bang ona Can All-Stars, but who also plays in Paul Simons band and on the film scores of Elliot Goldenthal, says I play three kinds of music: popular, semi-popular, and unpopular. Mark calls my music and the music of Bang on a Can semi-popular.

title: Comments on the Barack Obama Column
description: I welcome your comments on my Tuesday column on Barack Obama, in which I argue that hes got plenty of experience  the grass-roots kind  for the presidency. To comment, just hit the button below.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article in some copies on Sunday about Kansas victory over Texas in a basketball game on Saturday carried incorrect information from The Associated Press about a 24-7 run by Kansas to take the lead at one point. The run occurred before the Texas star Kevin Durant injured his ankle, not after.

title: Price of a Good Name? For Louvre: $520 Million
description: PARIS, March 6  Whats the price of a good name?

title: G.O.P. Shift Is Seen on Trade
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  When the Democrats swept to victory last fall, after a campaign fueled partly by attacks on President Bushs trade policies, trade deals promoted by the administration seemed doomed in the new Congress. But that was then.

title: Walter Reed, Our National Shame (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Secrets in the Neurons
A Diagnosis for One, but an Impact Shared
description: It was the first time my daughters sixth-grade teacher had ever called, and clearly the news was not good. Breathless and upset, she phoned me at work to say that 11-year-old Lulu had been out of control for several hours that morning, yelling, crumpling papers, saying rude things and, eventually, running out of the building.

title: China Says Japanese Leaders Comments Wont Affect Ties
description: BEIJING, March 6  Chinas foreign minister urged Japan today to accept responsibility for its use of sex slaves, called comfort women, during World War II. But the minister, Li Zhoxing, made clear that the issue would not dampen Chinas desire for stronger ties between the two countries.

title: Lees Return and Light Schedule Are Healthy Signs for the Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 5  The Knicks received some good news Monday, and this time it had nothing to do with the Nets. David Lee, who has missed the past five games, was listed as probable for Tuesday nights home game against the Seattle SuperSonics.

title: More Power(ball) to You
description: It is said that Everett McKinley Dirksen, a longtime Republican senator from Illinois, once mocked the spending habits of the federal government by declaring, A billion here, a billion there, and pretty soon youre talking about real money. An innovative campaign from a state lottery is taking a different tack in an effort to convince consumers that a jackpot is always real money, however small it may be.

title: Iranian Women Are Arrested After Protests Outside Court
description: TEHRAN, March 5  Iranian authorities arrested 33 women on Sunday after protests outside a court where five of them were being tried for leading a campaign to gain more legal rights for women, newspapers reported Monday.

title: A Toast to Evolvability and Its Promise of Surprise
description: Late last month, the day after my birthday, I was feeling punch drunk on my favorite glogg of sullenness, self-pity and panic. My life was passing by at relativistic speed, not one of my rotten siblings had called to wish me a happy birthday, my husband hadnt bothered to arrange so much as a waiter-serenaded slice of cake at the restaurant the night before, and did he really think that his gift to me of an amazing squirrel-proof bird feeder would excite anybody but the squirrels?

title: Casino Dismisses Worker Seeking Smoking Ban
description: TRENTON, March 5  When the Tropicana opened its doors in Atlantic City 25 years ago, Vincent Rennich was a 24-year-old overseeing bets and payouts at the craps tables.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the tendency of Shiites and Sunnis to interact less and less with one another because of the violence in Iraq referred incorrectly to birds kept on the roof of a Shiite restaurateur and former government worker who said that he is a virtual shut-in because his neighborhood is so dangerous. While the birds are pigeons, they are not passenger pigeons, which are extinct.

title: Chief Says Chrysler Unit May Be Sold
description: The financing arm of the Chrysler Group, the American division of DaimlerChrysler, could be sold as its parent company considers options, DaimlerChryslers chief executive said yesterday.

title: State Investigates Auditors Approval of Payments
description: ALBANY, March 6  The money was supposed to be used to find sites for residential facilities for people with mental illness. And since 1998, investigators found, an auditor at the state Office of Mental Health approved more than $1.2 million in payments for site studies to a company called Very Important Property, or V.I.P.

title: Study Raises Doubts About Lung Cancer Screening
description: Lung cancer screening with CT scans does not appear to save lives, and it exposes people to serious risks of injury and even death from needless surgery, researchers are reporting.

title: Alaskan Bridge Projects Resist Earmarks Purge
description: Long after Congress removed about $450 million in budget earmarks for two bridges in the Alaskan exurbs, the fight over whether to build them is not dead.

title: Cheney Is Treated for a Blood Clot After Trip
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  Vice President Dick Cheney was treated Monday for a blood clot in his left leg that independent experts said was probably not related to his history of heart disease but rather the result of his recent around-the-world trip, which included 65 hours of plane travel over 9 days.

title: Tough Question to Answer, Tough Answer to Hear
description: Upon receiving a diagnosis of a fatal illness like metastatic cancer, Alzheimers disease or congestive heart failure, many patients ask, Doc, how much time have I got? Its a reasonable question, given that there is often much to plan for and accomplish before a progressive illness robs patients of their physical or mental abilities.

title: A Contest Where the Competitors Flex Their Lexicons
description: Billy Dorminy was perspicuous, talking about poecilonyms on television, and there was nothing pusillanimous about the way he did it.

title: Albany Expected to Join Rush to Move 08 Primary to February
description: ALBANY, March 5  New York is on the verge of joining the rush of states moving their primaries to the first Tuesday in February next year.

title: Critics of Lending Practices Adopt a Harder Edge
description: A BITTER fight over lending tactics that critics decry as predatory is heating up as the two sides introduce ambitious marketing efforts intended to woo consumer support in the struggle.

title: Delgado Says That Green Can Be All He Once Was
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 5  Their friendship goes back to their eight seasons with the Toronto Blue Jays organization, and it extends beyond baseball. After the players who did not make the trip to Fort Lauderdale for Sundays game had finished working out at the Mets complex, Carlos Delgado stopped by Shawn Greens spring home to see Greens two daughters, who are 4 and a 1 1/2 .

title: Hartford: State Official Backs Boiler Study
description: Richard Blumenthal, the Connecticut attorney general, warned a Minnesota manufacturer of outdoor wood-fired boilers yesterday not to continue with its threat of legal action against a Connecticut scientist who has published a study linking the furnaces to health problems. Mr. Blumenthal said the company, Central Boiler, threatened in January to sue the scientist, David Brown, unless he retracted or changed the study, which he performed while working for a health consulting company. Dr. Brown, a former scientist with the State Public Health Department, refused to retract the study, and in a letter yesterday, Mr. Blumenthal warned Central Boiler that should it file a lawsuit, he would intervene and encourage other attorneys general to join me. Philip Gitlen, a lawyer for Central Boiler, acknowledged yesterday that the company had raised the possibility of legal action in a letter to Dr. Brown, but said it never intended to sue him.

title: Subprime Lender Under Inquiry Puts Some Workers on Leave
description: The Fremont General Corporation, the financial services holding company, put some of its residential loan staff on paid leave yesterday pending further information and said that it would stop offering subprime mortgages.

title: Manufacturing Misdemeanors
description: The New York Police Department has been going fishing. Not content to nab criminals when they break the law on their own, the department has been planting unattended bags in subway stations to see who might take them, at which point waiting officers pounce.

title: Newark: Computer Consultant Charged With Mail Fraud
description: A consultant who worked for the city has been charged with stealing $10 million worth of equipment from the computer company Cisco Systems, federal agents said yesterday. The consultant, Michael Kyereme, 40, was arrested on Friday and has been charged with mail fraud, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said. Mr. Kyereme, who assisted city employees with computer problems, is charged with ordering unneeded replacement parts under a service contract with Cisco and selling them to computer resellers, the agents said. According to documents filed in Federal District Court, agents recovered computer parts worth $3 million at Mr. Kyeremes home.

title: Rethinking the Banquet Menu
description: Dont look for grass-fed tenderloin of beef, locally grown spring vegetables and a salad of microgreens for lunch or dinner at business conventions. Those gatherings got the name rubber chicken circuit for a reason.

title: Big Corporate Gift Expected for Los Angeles County Museum of Art
description: LOS ANGELES, March 5  The Los Angeles County Museum of Art is expected to announce a corporate gift of more than $10 million on Tuesday that it will use to finance a building project, a person close to the museum said yesterday.

title: Henri Troyat, 95, a Force in French Literature, Dies
description: PARIS, March 5  Henri Troyat, the Russian-born French writer whose novels and biographies earned him an immense following in France and considerable recognition abroad, died here on Sunday. He was 95.

title: Equity Firm Attracted to Attractions
description: LONDON, March 5  The Blackstone Group agreed on Monday to buy the Tussauds Group, owner of the Madame Tussauds wax museums, for 1 billion ($1.9 billion) in cash.

title: The Claim: Restrooms Are the Dirtiest Public Areas
description: THE FACTS They are widely considered the most bacteria-laden places around. But how much truth does the conventional wisdom about public restrooms really hold? Over the years, various studies have found that they are not quite so bad, at least compared with other public areas.

title: Messenger in Prosecutors Firings Quits
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  The Justice Department official who told seven United States attorneys in December that they were being dismissed said Monday that he was resigning.

title: Persistent Foods
description: Q. Why do the smells of some foods, like garlic, and the heat of others, like chili pepper, linger on the skin even after washing?

title: Rangers Shoot Their Way to Victory
description: At one point midway through the third period, when a referees whistle finally interrupted a barrage of shots the Rangers were unleashing last night at Madison Square Garden, Islanders goalie Rick DiPietro lay on the ice while everyone else skated off for a timeout.

title: Bush Appoints Walter Reed Commission
description: Bush administration officials pledged today to move swiftly to correct the problems uncovered at Walter Reed Medical Center and in the overall system of providing treatment and assistance for military people wounded in the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Two Officers Speak to Grand Jury on Killing of Unarmed Black Man
description: Two of the five police officers involved in the killing of Sean Bell, an unarmed black man who died in a hail of 50 police bullets, testified yesterday before a grand jury in Queens that is weighing evidence in the case.

title: Restaurant Owner Fights for Koi, and Wins
description: FREEPORT, Me., March 4  A lunch buffet filled with spareribs and sweet-and-sour chicken beckoned, but customers at the China Rose restaurant here seemed to be more interested in the 10 brightly colored koi carp in a large tank by the entrance.

title: AT&T Investors Will Have Their Say
description: The No. 1 topic among shareholders this proxy season is executive pay, and many annual shareholder meetings will feature proposals that aim to give investors more say on how compensation is structured. Some companies have embraced these so-called say-on-pay proposals as a way to start a constructive dialog with shareholders on an issue that inflames investors.

title: Senate Passes Bill to Detain Sex Offenders After Prison
description: ALBANY, March 5  The State Senate voted on Monday to make New York the 20th state in the nation to detain convicted sex offenders in psychiatric hospitals after they have served their prison sentences, and the Assembly said it would do so on Tuesday.

title: Soldiers Testify to Lawmakers Over Poor Care at Walter Reed
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  Members of Congress heard wrenching testimony on Monday from wounded soldiers treated at Walter Reed Army Medical Center and contrite promises from top Army officials to correct the conditions there.

title: Manhattan: Teenager Stabbed During Fight
description: A 16-year-old boy was stabbed repeatedly yesterday in an altercation just east of Union Square, the police said. The teenager, whose identity was not disclosed because of his age, was taken to Bellevue Hospital Center, where he was reported in stable condition with wounds to his back and side. The police said the attack occurred about 9 a.m. outside a pizzeria at 104 East 14th Street. They said they were questioning a 13-year-old boy in the case, but it was unclear what role he may have played in the assault, and no charges had been filed last evening. Ariz Anwari, an employee of the pizzeria, said he saw a teenager being chased by two young men before the assault. One of them grabbed a screwdriver or a nail or something and started hitting him, Mr. Anwari said. He said the youth who was stabbed was running for his life, and he tried to defend himself, but he couldnt.

title: Asian Markets Rebound; Europe Gets a Boost
description: NEW DELHI, March 6  The five-day slide in Asian stock markets halted today, as investors took advantage of low prices and started buying again, sparking relief in the region.

title: Broadcasters Agree to Fine Over Payoffs
description: Radio broadcasters have long been accused of corrupting the public airwaves by accepting bribes from corporate music giants.

title: Louisville Turns Adversity Into an Asset
description: It was not long ago that Louisville had lost two in a row, was in fifth place in the Big East and, with road games at Marquette and Pittsburgh looming, seemed sure to drop further in the conference standings. Less than a month later, Louisville has the longest winning streak in the conference and just may be the team to beat in the Big East tournament, which begins tomorrow at Madison Square Garden.

title: Empowered? Try Nauseated
description: If the main thing you know about the Pussycat Dolls is that the founder is the sister of Jonathan Antin, the ludicrously vain Beverly Hills hairstylist at the center of Blow Out on Bravo, then youve been watching too much reality television. But its too late to stop now.

title: Disinvitation by Obama Is Criticized
description: CHICAGO, March 5  The Rev. Jeremiah A. Wright Jr., senior pastor of the popular Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago and spiritual mentor to Senator Barack Obama, thought he knew what he would be doing on Feb. 10, the day of Senator Obamas presidential announcement.

title: V.C.U. Could Be This Year's George Mason
description: RICHMOND, Va., March 5  For those unfamiliar with Virginia Commonwealths playing style, a billboard along Interstate 95 here provides a pithy explanation. Next to a large picture of the Rams first-year coach, Anthony Grant, the sign reads: 94 feet, both ways.

title: Man Wounds 3 Co-Workers, Then Takes His Own Life
description: SIGNAL HILL, Calif., March 5  A disgruntled employee carrying a semiautomatic handgun walked into a menu printing plant here Monday, told co-workers to shut up, wounded three of them and then shot himself to death, the police said.

title: Obama: Man of the World
description: WASHINGTON

title: Bluster and Confidence Among Phillies Off-Season Acquisitions
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.

title: Breathing Easier as the Battle for Blue Skies Pays Off
description: BANGKOK  Black smoke billowing from tailpipes into the humid, tropical air was once a Bangkok trademark. But a decade and a half after Thailand began a battle for better air quality, this erstwhile icon of smog has emerged as a role model for pollution-choked capitals in Asia, with considerably cleaner air than Beijing, Jakarta, New Delhi and Shanghai.

title: Russia: Inquiry Into Death of Reporter
description: Prosecutors in Moscow said they had begun a criminal investigation into the death last week of a reporter for Kommersant, Ivan Safranov, who covered military affairs for the Moscow newspaper. He was found on the ground beneath the fifth-floor window in his apartment building on Friday evening. Investigators initially said his death was a suicide. His newspaper, in an article yesterday, said suicide was extremely unlikely, raising the possibility that he had been killed. A motive was not clear.

title: G.O.P. Unites to Defend Tax Loopholes
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and some Republican leaders in the State Senate are joining forces to oppose Gov. Eliot Spitzers proposal to raise money by closing tax loopholes, which Mr. Bloomberg believes would harm New York City businesses.

title: Exercise: Workouts May Offset One Effect of Smoking
description: Smokers who cannot give up the habit can still help themselves through exercise.

title: Village Voice Picks Editor, Its 5th in About a Year
description: The Village Voice named its fifth editor in chief in a little over a year yesterday after abruptly firing David Blum from the position on Friday afternoon.

title: 9 From One Family Die in U.S. Strike Near Kabul
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 5  Nine members of a family, including five women and three children, were killed in an American airstrike in central Afghanistan late Sunday during a battle with militants, Afghan officials said Monday.

title: Venture Capitalists Move From Web to Algae
description: NILAND, Calif.  The idea of replacing crude oil with algae may seem like a harebrained way to clean up the planet and bolster national security.

title: Florham Park: Virus Strikes Students
description: An outbreak of stomach virus hospitalized 20 students at Fairleigh Dickinson University over the past week, although health officials said the outbreak appeared to be over by yesterday. Since the first student fell ill with norovirus last Tuesday, 124 students have contracted the illness, and most were treated for dehydration at Morristown Memorial Hospital, said Art Petrosemolo, a university spokesman. The virus causes flulike symptoms, including nausea, diarrhea and headache. Over the weekend, health workers disinfected the cafeteria, bathrooms and other common areas.

title: Rings Where Friendly Punches Flew Lose to Rising Rents
description: For Pat Russo, the corner of the Sunset Park Recreation Center where he founded a free boxing program two decades ago is haunted by the sounds of youthful ambition: the shuffle of fast-moving feet, the grunts of landed punches, the shouts of Jab, jab! by hawk-eyed coaches.

title: At Mosque, Doctors Ways Get an Update
description: As the citys population continues to change, pretty much everyone must come to grips sooner or later with new realities. Exceptions are few. They most definitely do not include doctors.

title: New York Officials Urge Renewal of Federal Terrorism Insurance
description: New York officials urged Congress yesterday to renew a terrorism insurance program set to expire at the end of this year that they said allowed the citys economy to recover and grow in the years after the Sept. 11 terror attack.

title: Jazz Pianists Muse: His Jailed Brother
description: Growing up in the Bronx, Antoine Dowdell and his younger brother, Tarik, were jazz lovers who spent their allowance on Dinah Washington and Cannonball Adderley records, to the approval of their jazz-buff parents.

title: Clintons Judgment (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: White Plains: Plumber Sentenced in Fatal Crash
description: A plumber from Carmel has been sentenced to five years of probation, including four months of weekends in the Westchester County Jail, as a result of his guilty plea to vehicular manslaughter for running over a pedestrian in Port Chester, prosecutors said yesterday. The plumber, Drew Zottola, 58, was driving his van on Westchester Avenue on May 24 when he ran over Milton Vizhco, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Mr. Zottola continued driving and was stopped by the police after other drivers called 911 and described his vehicle, Ms. DiFiore said.

title: This Air Sickness Bag Is Brought to You by ...
description: ADVERTISING and eyeballs were two nouns linked in my mind well before Internet marketers started spouting them. I always associate them with the reference in The Great Gatsby to the dilapidated billboard with the all-seeing eyes of Dr. T. J. Eckleburg  an image that literature professors swoon over, but which I tend to ascribe to F. Scott Fitzgeralds probably sipping immoderately from a flask of whiskey while spotting an actual abandoned billboard on a drive to Long Island Sound.

title: Network Insiders Sign Deal to Supply Programs to NBC
description: Two former network heads of entertainment programming, Gail Berman and Lloyd Braun, signed a deal yesterday for their new company to provide programs for NBC Universal across all the companys television channels.

title: N.C.A.A. Names Schools That Miss Its Standards
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 5  The N.C.A.A. announced Monday that it would no longer accept transcripts from two schools that had sent dozens of talented athletes to high-profile college athletics programs.

title: For Sex Offenders, a Dispute Over Therapys Benefits
description: ATASCADERO, Calif.  During five years of psychotherapy at a treatment center here for sex offenders who have finished their prison terms, Bill Price, a pedophile who admits to 21 victims as young as 3, has constructed a painstaking plan for staying straight.

title: Preserving Land and Wildlife, to Restore the Afghan Identity
description: Since June, Alex Dehgan has spent most of his time in Afghanistan, working to protect the countrys wildlife and develop its first official system of protected lands.

title: Snowstorm Slams China
description: The strongest March snowstorm to hit northeast and northern China in more than a half-century caused chaos in road and rail traffic and flight cancellations in many cities.

title: Council Assails Mayors Plan to Give Principals More Autonomy
description: City lawmakers yesterday harshly criticized the Bloomberg administrations plans to give many more public school principals wider autonomy in September, telling a top city schools official that there was not enough evidence of success among 322 principals who received additional authority this academic year to justify expanding the program.

title: Memo Pad
description: A380 ARRIVING An A380 airliner with about 500 passengers aboard will arrive at Kennedy International Airport from Frankfurt around noon on March 19 in a test flight to demonstrate what its operator, Lufthansa, and its manufacturer, Airbus, call the A380s operational maturity. It will mark the first time the so-called super-jumbo airliner has been flown overseas with a full passenger load and meal service. Most of the passengers will be Airbus and Lufthansa employees, though some reporters and photographers will also be aboard. Lufthansa has ordered 15 A380s and expects its first delivery in summer 2009. Meanwhile, another Airbus A380  this one without passengers and operated by a crew from the Australian airline Qantas  is expected to arrive on the same day and at about the same time at Los Angeles International Airport, according to a joint statement by Airbus, the airport, the Los Angeles mayors office and Qantas. That flight will depart from Airbus headquarters in Toulouse, France, where the A380 program has had unexpected manufacturing delays. Los Angeles International has long lagged in making the extensive renovations to terminal gates and taxiways to accommodate the double-decker airliner, and is still some time away from doing so. The A380 will park on a ramp at Los Angeles for publicity and ground-based tests. Airbus and some airlines with A380 orders have criticized Los Angeles International for falling behind on the renovations. The airport, which is competing with San Francisco as a major Pacific overseas gateway, recently began a $723.5 million modernization of its international terminal that will include at least two gates that can accommodate the A380. Qantas has ordered 20 A380s and expects its first delivery in summer 2008.

title: Record Opium Crop Possible in Afghanistan, U.N. Study Predicts
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 5  Afghanistans opium harvest could be bigger than last years record crop, with nearly half of the provinces showing an increase in planting this year, the director of the United Nations Office for Drugs and Crime said here Monday.

title: William Anderson, Navy Hero, Dies at 85
description: William R. Anderson, who commanded the nuclear-powered submarine Nautilus on its historic cruise beneath the North Pole in August 1958 and who later served three terms in Congress, died Feb. 25 near his home in Leesburg, Va. He was 85.

title: Jets Acquire Bears Jones to Fill Hole Left by Martin
description: The Jets finally found Curtis Martins replacement last night, reaching an agreement to acquire Chicago Bears running back Thomas Jones in exchange for a second-round draft pick, said a Jets official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

title: Handicapping the Bubble Is a License to Babble
description: If Bill Maher were to devote his excellent HBO show, Real Time, to March Madness, I wonder if his closing segment would sound something like this, only much funnier:

title: Wal-Mart Says Worker Taped Reporters Calls
description: Federal investigators are looking into the actions of a computer systems technician at Wal-Mart Stores who, over a period of several months, intercepted pager and text messages and also secretly taped telephone conversations between Wal-Mart employees and a reporter for The New York Times, the company said yesterday.

title: British Court Lifts Restrictions on BBC Report
description: LONDON, March 6  British news organizations appeared to win a pitched battle of wills with the government here today when the High Court lifted restrictions on the British Broadcasting Company that blocked it from broadcasting a report on a political scandal here.

title: No Apology for Sex Slavery, Japans Prime Minister Says
description: TOKYO, March 5  Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said Monday that Japan would refuse to comply if the United States Congress demanded an apology for his nations use of foreign women as sexual slaves during World War II.

title: Fighting for Iraqs Culture
description: WITH the situation in Iraq growing seemingly graver by the day, Americans are increasingly reluctant to risk American blood to save Iraqi lives. So its a pretty tough sell to ask people to care about a bunch of old rocks with funny writing.

title: Stocks Rise in Asia, Europe and U.S.
description: NEW DELHI, March 6  The five-day slide in Asian stock markets halted today, as investors took advantage of low prices and started buying again, sparking relief in the region.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Bush to Set Out Shift in Agenda on Latin Trip
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, March 5  President Bush arrives here on Thursday with an energy partnership plan to create jobs and decrease poverty and inequality, a marked shift in Washingtons priorities for Latin America aimed at countering the challenge posed by President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela.

title: A Choice Between Facts and Emotion
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  The jury that convicted I. Lewis Libby Jr. had a difficult task: to decide whether the well-documented misstatements by Mr. Libby meant he was a calculated serial liar, or merely an innocently forgetful man.

title: For Karl and His Son, a Time for Healing
description: George Karl did not know. Coby Karl did not understand. The father and the son would get in the car and drive to a basketball game. And the part that George Karl, the N.B.A. coach, thought was special for his son was being a ball boy, wearing the team sweats and shagging balls in an electrifying arena.

title: With Help From Friend, Niagara Star Gets Dream
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 5  One night before the Metro Atlantic Athletic Conference championship game, the freshman guard Tyrone Lewis of Niagara said he had envisioned what the scene would be like after a victory to put his team in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Insurgents Shell Somali Airport as Peacekeeps Arrive
description: KINDU, Congo, March 6  When the first batch of African Union peacekeepers arrived today in Mogadishu, the capital of Somalia, they received a patently Mogadishu welcome.

title: South Africa: Man Fights Off Crocodile
description: A 37-year-old man, Michael Sithole, fought off a crocodile with a switchblade after it seized his leg as he relaxed on a river bank. He said he had taken a dip in the Letaba River, in Limpopo Province, after a day of fishing and was sitting on a rock when I suddenly felt a bite on my thigh. He said that he grabbed a knife he had used to slice bread for his lunch but that by the time he opened the blade, the crocodile had dragged him to the middle of the river. He stabbed it in the stomach, forcing it to flee. Thank goodness the knife was still new, so it was sharp enough, said Mr. Sithole, who was treated for injuries to his right leg and hands, according to the South African Press Association.

title: Former Prosecutor Says Departure Was Pressured
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  The former federal prosecutor in Maryland said Monday that he was forced out in early 2005 because of political pressure stemming from public corruption investigations involving associates of the states governor, a Republican.

title: When a Leader Missteps, a World Can Go Astray
description: In the months before the American invasion of Iraq, Zbigniew Brzezinski, former national security adviser to President Jimmy Carter, was one of the few members of the foreign policy establishment (along with Brent Scowcroft, former national security adviser to President George H. W. Bush) to speak out strongly about the dangers of going to war unilaterally against Saddam Hussein, and to warn, presciently it turns out, of the possibly dire consequences of doing so without a larger strategic plan.

title: From Where He Sits, Sheffield Sees Big Year for Rodriguez
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 5  Gary Sheffield sauntered through the corridor toward the visitors locker room at Legends Field on Monday morning. He wore sunglasses, and a thin beard framed his chin. A dozen reporters were waiting for him, and he said, I should have known.

title: For Frazzled Families on Suburban Saturdays: Not Soccer. Meditation.
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J., March 4  Here is a question worthy of contemplation: Can several suburban mothers sit quietly for an hour and clear their minds of sippy-cup lids that do not fit sippy-cup cups, of toddlers who play drums in full cereal bowls, of soccer shorts gone missing?

title: Dollars to Spare in Chinas Trove
description: HONG KONG, March 3  In the insular world of Chinas central bank they are known as the Three Xiaos, three women with similar names who oversee the greatest fortune ever assembled: Chinas more than $1 trillion in foreign exchange reserves.

title: A Clear Line on Aid (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Celebrating the Views That Others Looked Past
description: SAN FRANCISCO  In its quiet way, the Henry Wessel show here at the Museum of Modern Art is a revelation, one of the seasons sleepers.

title: Giuliani Is Selling Investment Firm; Spokeswoman Calls Step Part of Focusing on Campaign
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday the planned sale of his boutique investment bank to an Australian company, a transaction that a company official said was part of Mr. Giulianis increasing focus on his presidential campaign.

title: Undoing the Wrongs of an Administration (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Massachusetts: Man Kills Himself and Children
description: A Springfield man killed himself and his two children by setting his car on fire in the parking lot of the office where the childrens mother worked, the police said. The man, Hipolito Ortiz, 37, drove the mother of his children, Genesis, 6, and Adrian, 2, to work around 7 a.m., the police said. Mr. Ortiz then parked his car, doused it with an accelerant and lighted it, killing himself and the children, the police said. Capt. Robert Cheetham said Mr. Ortiz and the childrens mother had been estranged for about a month.

title: The Line Between Torture and Cruelty
description: The United Nations and the United States government make a distinction between torture on the one hand and cruel, degrading and inhumane treatment on the other. But a study published yesterday uses data obtained from survivors to suggest that the distinction does not exist in practice, and may inadvertently provide justification for torture.

title: Clinton Plans Major Appeal to Women
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton will begin an ambitious effort on Tuesday to enlist thousands of women to play roles in her presidential campaign, hoping to build on the enthusiasm her candidacy has stirred among female voters at early campaign events.

title: Earthquakes Kill Scores, Indonesian Officials Say
description: JAKARTA, March 6  Two powerful inland earthquakes rattled the Indonesian island of Sumatra today, leveling hundreds of buildings and killing at least 70 people, according to government officials in Jakarta.

title: Motorola May Fight to Keep Icahn Off Board
description: Motorola may be preparing for a fight to keep the billionaire activist Carl C. Icahn off its board.

title: Physicists Remember When Superconductors Were Hot
description: Like the musical Woodstock, the legend of the Woodstock of Physics grows year after year.

title: Murcer Aims to Return to Broadcasting
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 5  Bobby Murcer, the broadcaster for the YES network and former Yankees center fielder who had surgery in December to remove a malignant brain tumor, said Monday that he hoped to call games this season.

title: Asian and European Stocks Continue Decline
description: NEW DELHI, Mar. 5  Asian stock markets continued to fall today as nervous investors shunned the region despite strong economic signals from some Asian countries. The trend spread to Europe, where stocks also slid in morning trading. But on Wall Street the damage was limited, and share prices climbed after a brief fall in early trading.

title: U.S. Moves to Soothe Growing Russian Resentment
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  The Bush administration has decided to reach out more often and more intensively to Russia at a time when the leadership in Moscow is harshly criticizing American policy and some scholars say the United States has not sufficiently tended to an important relationship.

title: Stone Towers Are Decoded as Earliest Solar Observatory in the Americas
description: Early people in Peru, like others in antiquity, went to great lengths to track the rising and setting of the sun through the seasons as a guide for agriculture, an object of worship and a mystical demonstration of a rulers power.

title: A Biological Hot Spot in Africa, With New Species Still to Discover
description: The Eastern Arc Mountains of Tanzania may not be terribly tall  only half the height of their famous neighbor, Mount Kilimanjaro. But to scientists who tally the planets biodiversity, they tower over the rest of the world. The forests that cover their flanks contain the highest density of endangered animals anywhere on earth.

title: Attacks in Iraq Kill More Than 100 Shiite Pilgrims
description: BAGHDAD, March 6  Two suicide bombers killed at least 77 Shiite pilgrims in the southern city of Hilla today, the deadliest of more than a dozen attacks that killed more than 100 Shiites marching to the holy city of Karbala on the eve of one of the most important Shiite holidays, Iraqi security authorities said.

title: Baghdad Car Bomb Kills 20 on Booksellers Row
description: BAGHDAD, March 5  The book market along Mutanabi Street was a throwback to the Baghdad of old, the days of students browsing for texts, turbaned clerics hunting down religious tomes and cafe intellectuals debating politics over backgammon.

title: A Vital Discussion, Clouded
description: When a disease is described as sexually transmitted, its tempting to assume that the people who catch it must be promiscuous. Just what that means is a matter of opinion, but its a label that most parents would be pained to hear applied to their daughters.

title: A Chamber Ensemble Giving an Orchestra Concert in Disguise
description: James Levine always has more ideas than time, and perhaps the number of works he wanted to explore in the Met Orchestras series at Carnegie Hall this season exceeded the available program space. In any case, the concert he gave at Zankel Hall with the Met Chamber Ensemble on Sunday afternoon was to some extent an orchestra concert in disguise.

title: BlackBerry Makers Chairman Resigns but Will Remain as Co-C.E.O.
description: OTTAWA, March 5  The chairman of Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry handheld device, resigned on Monday after the company said it would restate about $250 million in results after reviewing its stock option grants. James L. Balsillie will remain as co-chief executive and will join with the other co-chief executive, Mike Lazaridis, to pay 10 million Canadian dollars toward some of the restatement costs.

title: Libbys Jurors Inquire About One Charge
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  The jury considering the perjury case against I. Lewis Libby Jr. suggested on Monday that some of its members were deeply uncertain about one of the five felony charges.

title: Azerbaijan: Press Complaint Over Ex-Ministers Trial
description: A press-freedom organization in Azerbaijan called on the government to allow video transmissions of the trial of Ali Insanov, the former health minister, who is accused of trying to overthrow the state. The Institute for Reporter Freedom and Safety, based in Baku, the Azerbaijani capital, accused the government of allowing only journalists it deems loyal into the courtroom after officials said there were not enough seats.

title: For Jurors, Libby Might Be Fall Guy, but He Was Guilty
