description: WASHINGTON, March 6  The jurors believed that I. Lewis Libby Jr. was a decent man, worthy of their sympathy. They believed what his chief lawyer, Theodore V. Wells Jr., told them at the outset: that Mr. Libby was at least partly a fall guy for others in the Bush administration.

title: Israeli Says Iran Is Training Hamas Men
description: TEL AVIV, March 5  The chief of Shin Bet, the Israeli internal security service, said Monday that the Islamic movement Hamas had sent dozens of men from Gaza to Iran for military training.

title: Accuser Vague on Key Details in Principals Seduction Case
description: A mans case against the principal of his East Side private school, whom he accuses of raping him when he was a student, is all about dates  the date when she first kissed him; the date she first performed oral sex on him; the date they first had intercourse.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about Thomas F. Eagleton, the former United States senator from Missouri who was removed as George McGoverns running mate in 1972 after revelations of mental illness, misstated the year he voted against the War Powers Act, a measure to limit the presidents ability to make war. It was in 1973, not 1974. (Mr. Eagleton initially sponsored the legislation but voted against it because, he said, it had been too watered down.)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on Jan. 30 about Deborah Orin-Eilbeck, the Washington bureau chief of The New York Post, misstated the year she graduated from journalism school and the name of an earlier employer. The year was 1973, not 1969, and the employer was The Chicago Daily News, not The Chicago Press. A reader pointed out the errors in an e-mail message on Feb. 23, and this correction was delayed for research.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: National Gallery Gets Jasper Johns Collection

title: Christian Right Illusion (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Prosecutors Tell of Pressures From Lawmakers
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  Six ousted United States attorneys told Congressional panels today new details about lawmakers intrusions in sensitive investigations and possible efforts by the Justice Department to squelch their public protests over their firings.

title: Letters
description: Hubris or Insightful Vision?

title: Libby Guilty of Lying in C.I.A. Leak Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, was convicted today of lying to a grand jury and to F.B.I. agents investigating the leak of the identity of a C.I.A. operative in the summer of 2003 amid a fierce public dispute over the war in Iraq.

title: Free to Vote in Florida
description: Florida is notorious for running elections badly, but its new governor is trying to fix one of the states most unjust and undemocratic practices. He has called for tearing down the barriers that prevent as many as 950,000 ex-offenders from voting.

title: Shares Continue to Sink, From Hong Kong to New York
description: The fallout from last weeks global stock dive showed few signs of letting up yesterday, as markets from Hong Kong to New York deepened their losses.

title: BlackBerry Maker to Restate Results; Officer Gives Up a Title
description: OTTAWA, March 5  Research in Motion, the maker of the BlackBerry hand-held device, said on Monday that a top executive stepped down from one of his posts after the company said it would restate about $250 million in earnings after reviewing its stock option grants.

title: A Band of Scientists Who Really Are a Band
description: The house lights went up and the blue light from a projector went off as the Amygdaloids prepared to take the stage. They plugged in their instruments, fiddled with knobs and pedals and moved a drum set forward as the previous act, a lecturer on schizophrenia, took his seat.

title: Clinton Shapes Her Image for 08 Race
description: BERLIN, N.H.  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton signs autographs meticulously, drawing out each line and curve of H-i-l-l-a-r-y, R-o-d-h-a-m and C-l-i-n-t-o-n. She leaves no stray lines or wayward marks.

title: U.N. Development Agency Suspends Its Work in North Korea
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 5  The United Nations Development Program announced Monday that it was suspending work in North Korea because the country had failed to meet conditions set up in response to American complaints that United Nations money was being diverted to the government of Kim Jong-il.

title: U.S. Seeks Account of North Korean Nuclear Effort
description: The United States said today that North Korea must fully disclose its efforts to produce highly enriched uranium as part of negotiations now under way in New York that are aimed at ending North Koreas nuclear weapons program and normalizing relations between the two countries.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about technology advances that made it possible to unlock more oil from old fields misstated Saudi Arabias total reserves, which are about a quarter of the worlds proven total. It is 260 billion barrels, not million.

title: Viennese Boys Club, in for the Weekend
description: Daniel Barenboim brought the Vienna Philharmonic to Carnegie Hall for three concerts over the weekend. Fridays Schubert and Bruckner offered private and public Vienna at its most sublime. On Saturday the orchestra played against type in a weird but instructive all-Bartok program. Sunday afternoon it was Schumanns Fourth Symphony and a collection of Wagners greatest hits.

title: The Difficult Patient, a Problem Old as History (or Older)
description: The sick man was a misery to himself and to everyone around him. For one thing, his personal hygiene was horrific. He stank. And he was constantly in pain, moaning and groaning until you began to wonder if he was doing it just for effect. Worst of all, he was a mean old cuss, angry and embittered after years of illness. All he did was complain.

title: A United Kingdom? Maybe
description: Britain and Ireland are so thoroughly divided in their histories that there is no single word to refer to the inhabitants of both islands. Historians teach that they are mostly descended from different peoples: the Irish from the Celts and the English from the Anglo-Saxons who invaded from northern Europe and drove the Celts to the countrys western and northern fringes.

title: Bob Hattoy, 56, Clinton Aide and Powerful Voice on Gay Issues, Dies
description: Bob Hattoy, who drew wide attention with a nationally televised speech about AIDS at the 1992 Democratic National Convention and then became a forceful advocate for gay and lesbian issues in the Clinton White House, died on Sunday in Sacramento. He was 56.

title: UConns Houston Tries to Steady Herself in a New Role
description: HARTFORD, March 5  Having broken Cheryl Millers California scoring record in high school, Charde Houston arrived at Connecticut from San Diego three seasons ago with the expectation of steady ascent.

title: Disparities: Singling Out Minorities for Alcohol Counseling
description: At last researchers can point to an area of medicine in which African-American and Hispanic patients get more attention than white ones do.

title: An Anguished Eyewitness to the Worlds Unraveling
description: What exactly does a hypnotized chicken have to do with Osama bin Laden? A more freakish juxtaposition of images you could hardly invent. But in My Trip to Al-Qaeda, his engaging theatrical seminar on the rise of Islamic terrorism, Lawrence Wright draws a connection between the fanciful symbol and the frightful man with persuasive simplicity.

title: Ethiopia: Cars Used by Kidnapped Travelers Found
description: A team searching for five British citizens kidnapped in Ethiopia found three of their vehicles near the disputed border with Eritrea. One bore eight shrapnel holes in the drivers door and a small explosion appears to have occurred in the passengers seat of a Land Rover, the BBC reported. A third car was more badly damaged, it said. The vehicles were found abandoned near Berhale, in the northeast Afar region that borders Eritrea, according to The Associated Press. The Britons, embassy staff members and their relatives, were sightseeing when they were seized by gunmen on Thursday along with local guides. Eritrea has denied claims that its forces seized them, and no group has claimed responsibility. This is a matter of serious concern, said the British foreign secretary, Margaret Beckett. A group of French tourists also missing since Thursday arrived in the Afar city of Mekele on Sunday and said they had not been kidnapped, as was believed.

title: Obsessive About Service, the Good and the Bad
description: I spend more time on the road than the average hotel concierge. I founded the American chapter of Les Clefs dOr, a professional association of concierges, which takes me to meetings all over the world. And when Im off work, I travel, too. Its my hobby.

title: As Teenager Sleeps, 2 Are Slain in New Jersey Condo
description: VINELAND, N.J., March 5  First there was a scuffle so violent that neighbors next door could hear it. Then there were the gunshots that took the life of a mother and her companion of two months. Finally there was one last shot, when the womans former partner, who the authorities said was behind the carnage, took his own life.

title: 11 Are Arraigned in Albany in Widening Investigation of Illegal Sales of Steroids
description: ALBANY, March 5  Eleven people accused of playing a role in a nationwide illegal prescription drug ring were arraigned here on Monday, part of what prosecutors said was a broadening investigation into the recreational use of steroids and human growth hormone.

title: Canada: Partnership Buys Pipeline
description: The Inter Pipeline Fund agreed to buy the Corridor pipeline system in Alberta from Kinder Morgan for 275 million Canadian dollars ($233 million) to become the largest shipper of bitumen from the provinces oil sands. The Corridor system transports diluted bitumen, a heavy oil, from the Athabasca oil sands project near Fort McMurray to a processing plant near Edmonton, the partnership said. Inter Pipeline will also assume 485 million Canadian dollars of Corridor debt. Inter Pipeline already operates and holds an 85 percent stake in the Cold Lake pipeline, which transports 330,000 barrels of blended bitumen a day in east-central Alberta. After the Corridor acquisition, the partnership said its lines would carry about half of the production of bitumen from Albertas tarlike oil sands.

title: New Leader Is Appointed at McAfee
description: McAfee, the large maker of security software, appointed David DeWalt of the EMC Corporation as its chief executive yesterday.

title: The Right to Organize
description: There are many reasons for the long decline in the membership rolls for private sector unions, including powerful changes in the economy and the unions past corruption scandals. And there is little doubt that federal rules and regulations for union organizing have also become increasingly hostile to labor, helping to drive unions share of the work force down from a peak of 35 percent in the 1950s to a mere 7.4 percent today.

title: Performance: Test of Pilots Shows Age May Be Advantageous
description: Airline passengers who feel reassured when they glimpse a shock of white hair in the cockpit may be on to something.

title: Voice of the Many, but Rarely Herself
description: The role of Mrs. Higgins, the mother of Prof. Henry Higgins in My Fair Lady, requires an actress capable of expressing hauteur, exasperation and motherly concern, sometimes all at once. What it does not require is a singing voice, as it is among that classic musicals few roles without a song.

title: Layoffs Follow Scandal at Colorado Megachurch
description: DENVER, March 5  In the wake of a scandal involving its founding pastor, the Rev. Ted Haggard, the New Life Church in Colorado Springs has been forced to lay off 44 of its 350 workers to offset a sharp drop in donations.

title: Failure in New Computer Diverts Air Traffic
description: WASHINGTON, March 5  A failure in one of the Federal Aviation Administrations newest air traffic computers early Monday morning forced controllers to hold airliners on the ground, send others on detours over hundreds of miles and put two into holding patterns over the ocean near Bermuda, an unusual procedure for intercontinental flights.

title: Is It Antique or Merely the Mock? Ask the Jester
description: On Sunday afternoon at City Center, Paul Taylor resurrected a period piece, or more accurately, a Piece Period, but however one wishes to read the title, the dance is a vintage delight. The work for 10, not seen in New York since 1979, was originally created for 6 performers, including Mr. Taylor, at Hunter Playhouse in 1962. That the comic spoof of national dance styles followed the creation of Aureole, one of Mr. Taylors most pure dance works, is indeed a clear indication of his restless mind.

title: Drug Maker Stops Work on Lung Disease Medicine
description: Desperate patients with a potentially fatal lung condition have spent hundreds of millions of dollars over the last few years on a drug that was not approved for their disease but was promoted for that use by its manufacturer.

title: Insufferable Clinginess, or Healthy Dependence?
description: The domestic scenes that would slowly suffocate the marriage were not scenes at all, in the usual sense, but silences, imagined slights, private fears that went unspoken. She would ask him to do the dishes after dinner and feel a shudder when he put off the chore, as if it were a rejection.

title: No Comfort
description: What part of Japanese Army sex slaves does Japans prime minister, Shinzo Abe, have so much trouble understanding and apologizing for?

title: Dollars and Dreams Chase $370 Million Jackpot
description: They lined up steadily all day, some of them clutching the long white papers with their lucky numbers already scratched out, others holding only their dreams and their hopes, for a chance at winning a record $370 million jackpot in the 12-state Mega Millions lottery.

title: In Florida, a Company Finds a New Way to Sell Hurricane Insurance
description: Most insurance executives look at the lavish houses and condominiums along the Florida coasts and cannot help thinking: hurricanes, wreckage, financial ruin.

title: For a Band Singing of Faith and Fatalism, Brevity Is the Essence of Rock
description: One hour. Nearly two dozen songs. Four members  two more than they had a year ago. On Sunday night the Thermals played a sold-out show at Bowery Ballroom. They scrambled through a set that included cryptic prayers, mutated political slogans and unfinished love stories, but they never strayed far from their bare-bones formula: a few chords, a few minutes and the song was done.

title: Mixed Ruling on Genocide Still Puts Pressure on Serbia
description: THE HAGUE, March 2  The recent ruling by the United Nations highest court that found fault with Serbia under the Genocide Convention complicates Serbias diplomatic rehabilitation, several legal experts said.

title: Casualties of the Budget Wars
description: Fox Island, Wash.

title: NBC Names New Chief for News Program
description: Less than a week after NBC Nightly News With Brian Williams lost the monthly ratings race to ABC for the first time, NBC announced yesterday that it was replacing Mr. Williamss executive producer with Alexandra Wallace, a vice president of the news division who has had broad oversight for the program since January of last year.

title: Corzine Admits He Gave More Gifts to Union Leader
description: TRENTON, March 5  In a disclosure that has increased the tension surrounding New Jerseys contract negotiations with its workers, Gov. Jon S. Corzine acknowledged that he gave more gifts to a former companion  who leads the states largest public employees union  than he previously admitted.

title: Rename Street for Jerry Orbach? Not So Fast
description: It is a tribute that has been paid to Peter Jennings, Humphrey Bogart, Joey Ramone, even Seor Wences. But getting a Manhattan street corner named for Jerry Orbach, former star of stage and screen and consummate New Yorker, will be no open-and-shut case.

title: On the Scales: Pounds Add Up on Summer Break, Study Says
description: Summer. The perfect time for children to play outside, swim  and get fatter?

title: Citizens and Kings in a Time of Turbulence
description: LONDON, March 4  Exhibitions of pre-20th-century art invariably focus on the art, which seems logical enough. The paintings might once have had political, religious or allegorical significance, but generations later it is the talent and technique of the artists themselves that matter most.

title: Editors Note
description: An article by Kurt Eichenwald on Dec. 19, 2005, reported on a teenage boys sexual exploitation on the Internet, and an accompanying Reporters Essay by Mr. Eichenwald published on nytimes.com explained the details of his initial contact with the subject.

title: A.M.D. Says Pricing Battle May Affect Its Revenue Goal
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 5  Advanced Micro Devices said Monday that it was unlikely the company would meet its target of $1.6 billion to $1.7 billion in revenue for the first quarter, providing evidence that the price war with Intel was continuing to take its toll.

title: U.S. Issues Annual Human Rights Report
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  The State Department declared today that the genocide in Darfur is the worlds gravest human rights abuse. It also issued tough critiques of Iran and North Korea, despite recent diplomatic openings to both nations.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,163 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Lanvin Shines, and Miu Miu Stumbles
description: PARIS, March 5  Marc Jacobs looked knackered. Alber Elbaz took to his bed. Editors asked to give their opinions to television cameras had to rev up like a small plane before diving off an Andean cliff. Such were the last brutal days of the fall 2007 collections.

title: Agency Halts Sale of a Modified Rice
description: WASHINGTON, March 5 (Reuters)  The Agriculture Department ordered seed dealers on Monday not to sell a long-grain rice seed that may contain a genetic modification not approved for planting.

title: Manhattan: Lawsuit Over Lost Embryos
description: Two women have sued a reproductive bank in Manhattan for $3 million, claiming that six embryos they stored there were lost. The women, Cathy L. Berger and Adriana Pacheco of Hoboken, N.J., said in papers filed on Friday in State Supreme Court that they had arranged to have the embryos stored at Repro Lab Inc. in September 2003. But in May 2006, according to the suit, they were told that the embryos were missing, could not be found and had been lost. No one at Repro Lab responded to calls for comment yesterday.

title: Asian and European Stocks Continue Decline
description: Wall Street was unable to pull itself out of the deep slump that began last week, and stocks closed lower today after a session of up-and-down trading.

title: Bronx: 75 Workers to Receive Back Wages
description: Two carwashes and an oil-change garage have agreed to pay $208,000 in back wages to 75 workers because of minimum wage, overtime and other violations, the United States Department of Labor announced yesterday. Department officials said that the companies  Pelham Bay Car Wash, Boston Road Car Wash and MCA Oil Change Corporation  had the same owner, and that the violations included paying less than the minimum wage; having employees share their tips with employees who did not work for tips; paying straight time for all overtime hours worked, even though some people worked 72 hours a week; and improperly recording hours worked.

title: Trade Deficit Narrowed in January
description: The countrys trade deficit narrowed in January as coal and manufacturing exports rose, signaling that growth may pick up in the Asia-Pacific regions fifth-largest economy. The trade shortfall narrowed to 876 million Australian dollars ($677 million) from 1.38 billion Australian dollars in December, the Bureau of Statistics reported. Exports rose 2 percent and imports dropped 1 percent. Total exports climbed to 18.12 billion Australian dollars in January. Farm exports like meat, sugar, wheat and wool declined 1 percent. Shipments of nonrural goods, which include minerals, increased 3 percent. Total imports fell to 18.99 billion Australian dollars from December. Imports of intermediate goods, which include fuel, decreased 1 percent.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Saturday about Crashed Ice, a competition created by the drink company Red Bull that is a blend of hockey and snowboardcross, misstated the number of racers who compete at a time. It is four, not three.

title: Corrections
description: Editors Note

title: California: Indictments in Beating
description: The district attorney in San Francisco announced charges in a highly publicized New Years Day assault in which several members of visiting Yale choral group were beaten. Two men, Richard Aicardi and Brian Dwyer, were charged with assaulting two members of the group, said the district attorney, Kamala Harris. The beatings occurred after the group, the Bakers Dozen, performed at a private New Years Eve party and were confronted by a group of other young men. Several singers were injured; the jaw of one was broken.

title: New DVDs: The Prisoner(s) of Zenda
description: THE PRISONER(S) OF ZENDA

title: Inmate Plotted to Kill Police Leader and Plant a Bomb, Officials Say
description: A man in jail on Rikers Island has been accused of trying to hire someone to behead Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and to bomb Police Headquarters.

title: The Vaccination Question
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: For Sex Offenders, a Dispute Over Therapy
description: About 2,700 sexual offenders in 19 states are being held indefinitely, mostly in special treatment centers, under so-called civil commitment programs.

title: Libby Juror Answers Questions
description: The following is the transcript of a press availability with Denis Collins,a Libby trial juror, as provided by Federal News Service.

title: Statement by Libby's Attorney
description: The following is a transcript of the statement by Ted Wells, defense attorney for I. Lewis Libby.

title: What's On Tonight
description: 9 P.M. (11) PUSSYCAT DOLLS PRESENT: THE SEARCH FOR THE NEXT DOLL -- Meow. In this competition series, 18 nubile contestants audition for the chance to become a member of the Pussycat Dolls, the all-woman music and dance group that started out as a burlesque ensemble in 1995. The winner, chosen from among nine finalists, must demonstrate her competence as both a singer and a dancer (toe shoes, anyone?), not to mention an excessive amount of sex appeal and the ability to both design and wear provocative attire. Judges include Robin Antin, the group's founder and choreographer; Ron Fair, chairman of Geffen Records; and the scantily clad, Grammy-winning, time-serving Lil' Kim. Jonathan Antin, the star of the Bravo series ''Blowout'' and Ms. Antin's brother, will provide hairstyle makeovers. The claws are out already.

title: Citigroup Bids $10.8 Billion for Japanese Brokerage
description: In what would be its largest takeover in Asia, the banking giant Citigroup bid $10.75 billion for Nikko Cordial, a Japanese brokerage that has been struggling with an accounting scandal. The cash offer is part of a broader effort at Citigroup to reengineer its business in Japan, which is the worlds second-largest economy but accounts for a relatively small part of Citis business. Citi has suffered some setbacks in Japan in recent years, including the shutdown of its private bank there, which regulators ordered to close in 2004.

title: BP to Buy Chevron Assets
description: BP said it had agreed to buy Chevrons manufacturing company in the Netherlands, Texaco Raffinaderij Pernis, for about $900 million, excluding working capital and hydrocarbon inventory. BP will acquire Chevrons 31 percent minority shareholding in the Netherlands Refining Company as well as Chevrons stake in the jointly owned wind farm located at the refinery; shareholdings in the nearby crude oil terminal and storage facility; and a number of associated pipelines.

title: Partnership Buys Pipeline
description: The Inter Pipeline Fund agreed to buy the Corridor pipeline system in Alberta from Kinder Morgan for 275 million Canadian dollars ($233 million) to become the largest shipper of bitumen from the provinces oil sands. The Corridor system transports diluted bitumen, a heavy oil, from the Athabasca oil sands project near Fort McMurray to a processing plant near Edmonton, the partnership said.

title: Subprime Lender Lays Off Workers Pending Sale
description: Fremont General, the financial services holding company, put some of its residential loan staff on paid leave Monday pending further information and said that it would stop offering subprime mortgages. Fremont General said in an e-mail statement that many workers had been sent home. Managers and operations people are continuing to work today and are making certain that our business data is secure and our customers are taken care of, the company said.

title: Treating a Heart Attack
Qantas Chairman Defends Buyout Deal
description: Qantass chairman, Margaret Jackson, defended her companys decision to support an $8.5 billion buyout offer from a group led by the Macquarie Bank and thje Texas Pacific Group, claiming the Australian airlines board had rewritten the rule book on private equity takeovers.

title: Aeroflex in $1 Billion Buyout Deal
description: General Atlantic and Francisco Partners agreed to buy Aeroflex, a microelectronics maker, in a $1 billion deal. Aeroflexs president, Len Borow, told Newsday that quarterly earnings pressure and new accounting requirements had made it every C.E.O.s dream to be private.

title: TicketsNow Takes $34 Million in Funding
description: TicketsNow, an online ticket reseller, said Monday it closed its first round of venture funding, drawing $34 million from a group led by Adams Street Partners. The announcement came just a few weeks after eBay, the giant Web auctioneer, agreed to buy ticket reseller StubHub for $310 million.

title: New Leader Is Appointed at McAfee
description: McAfee, the large maker of security software, appointed David DeWalt of EMC as its chief executive Monday. McAfees former chief executive, George Samenuk, stepped down in October over the backdating of stock options. Mr. DeWalt, 42, was head of EMCs customer operations.

title: NBC Production Deal Creates Uneasy Alliance
description: NBC Universal has agreed to back a production company started by two former heads of network entertainment programming, Gail Berman and Lloyd Braun. The company signed a deal Monday with NBCs chief executive, Jeffrey Zucker, at Fresco by Scotto in midtown Manhattan. Under the terms of the deal, NBC will hand over cash, about $6 million, according to Variety, in return for the first crack at programming produced by the new shingle, BermanBraun, which the two executives described to The New York Times as a ministudio.

title: Beacon Capital Unloads a Bean Town Dud
description: Not everyone is making a bundle selling commercial real estate these days.

title: Supreme Court Denies Appeal by Ebbers
description: The Supreme Court rejected Monday an appeal by Bernard J. Ebbers, the former chief executive of the telephone company WorldCom, who was convicted of orchestrating an $11 billion accounting fraud that led to the largest bankruptcy ever in the United States. Mr. Ebbers was convicted in 2005 by a federal jury in New York on nine counts of conspiracy, securities fraud and other crimes that led to Enrons bankruptcy in July 2002. He was sentenced to 25 years in prison.

title: A Historical Look: Age of U.S. Presidents
description: John McCain, if elected in 2008, would be, at 72, the oldest president to be inaugurated. And if Senator Barack Obama is elected, at 47, he would be one of the youngest. A look at the oldest and the youngest presidents to assume office.

title: Google Fundraiser Dazzles Silicon Valley
description: Silicon Valley and its attendant news media were apparently left breathless by Googles Radical Benefit for Humanity fundraiser for the X Prize Foundation, the nonprofit group that already has awarded $10 million to designers of a private spacecraft. The San Jose Mercury News raved that while Silicon valley fundraisers tend to be understated affairs, Google, ever the Silicon Valley iconoclast, has come up with its latest innovation for local philanthropists: Glamour.

title: TXU Buyers Visit With Skeptics
description: The Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts made the rounds Monday with some remaining skeptics of their proposed $45 billion buyout of TXU. The firms met with Dallas Mayor Laura Miller and some Texas business leaders who had opposed the companys original plans to build 11 coal-fired power plants.

title: Starr Foundation Defends Greenberg Deals
description: The former chief executive of the American International Group, Maurice R. Greenberg, acted in good faith in selling assets of the Starr Foundation to the companies he controls, according to a report from the foundation. The report, released Monday by the multibillion-dollar nonprofit organization, addresses accusations made more than a year ago by Eliot Spitzer, who was then the attorney general of New York and is now the states governor.

title: Ravelston to Pay $7 Million in Fraud Plea
description: Ravelston, the Toronto-based holding company once controlled by the fallen newspaper baron Conrad Black, pleaded guilty Monday to one count of fraud and agreed to pay a $7 million fine. Mr. Black, a Canadian-born media mogul and a British lord, had sought to block the company from agreeing to a plea, arguing it would ruin his chances of a fair trial. A Canadian judge disagreed.

title: Toronto Exchange Joins U.S. Partner in Joint Futures Market
description: As exchanges around the world consolidated in recent months, shareholders of the TSX Group have apparently had one big question: How would their company get into the lucrative and fast-growing derivatives business?

title: Chryslers Finance Arm Could Be Sold, C.E.O. Says
description: The financing arm of the Chrysler Group, the American division of DaimlerChrysler, could be sold as its parent company considers options, DaimlerChryslers chief executive said Monday. On Feb. 14, DaimlerChrysler said it was keeping all options open regarding the future of the Chrysler Group, leading to speculation about the prospects of a sale or a spinoff. Speaking during the Merrill Lynch Global Automotive Conference in Geneva, the chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, Dieter Zetsche, said the same held true for the financing arm.

title: Siemens Still Sees Spinoff, Not Sale, of Auto Unit
description: Siemens said Tuesday it was sticking to its plan for an initial public offering of up to half of its automotive engineering unit despite interest from potential buyers. The comments came as The Financial Times reported that TRW Automotive is considering a bid for the Siemens division, which makes products including driver assistance devices and safety systems.

title: In Grasso Fight, Cuomo Assumes Spitzers Mantle
description: The New York attorney general, Andrew M. Cuomo, will continue pursuing the states lawsuit against Richard Grasso, the former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, taking up a case opened by his predecessor, Eliot Spitzer. Were going to aggressively pursue our case, John Milgrim, a spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, told Reuters on Monday.

title: Breaux Contemplates Run
description: Friends of former Senator John B. Breaux of Louisiana say he is contemplating a run for governor there in the fall, but will not get in unless Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco, a fellow Democrat, gets out.

title: Waxing Lyrical
description: The last time Merle Haggard, the country singer, voted in a presidential election was 1984, for Ronald Reagan, a man who gave Mr. Haggard a good feeling, simple as that, he said.

title: Why Wall Street Is Rushing to Schmooze
description: After the record earnings they took home last year, Wall Street firms appear to be actively courting more prospects for mergers and initial public offerings. But why are so many gatherings taking place at the same time?

title: J.P. Morgan Crowned Top Hedge Fund Manager
description: J.P. Morgan Chase overtook Goldman Sachs to become the largest hedge-fund manager in the United States, according to a new survey, as its flagship fund gained almost 25 percent while Goldmans fell for the first time in seven years.

title: N.Y.S.E. Has Its First Day Under New Rules
description: The New York Stock Exchange on Monday said that trading at the Big Board and NYSE Arca went smoothly but that it lacked a connection with two markets. The main subsidiary of NYSE Group reported that trading went smoothly during the first day under new regulations on how orders are handled between markets. But The N.Y.S.E. said it did not have connection with the NASD ADF and ISE Stock Exchange, a unit of International Securities Exchange Holdings.

title: Former Disney Chief Adds Topps to His Collection
description: Tornante, an investment firm run by the entertainment mogul Michael Eisner, and Madison Dearborn Partners, a private equity firm, have agreed to pay $385 million for Topps, the iconic but struggling maker of baseball cards and Bazooka gum. The deal is the latest  and perhaps the largest  for Mr. Eisners firm, which he created after leaving Disney in 2005.

title: Hows Your Principal Doing?
description: City lawmakers have harshly criticized the Bloomberg administrations plans to give many more public school principals wider autonomy in September, telling a top city schools official, Eric Nadelstern, that there was not enough evidence of success among 322 principals who received additional authority this academic year to justify expanding the program.

title: The Green Kitchen
Three More In, Three TBD
description: Three more mens basketball teams earned automatic berths in the N.C.A.A. tournament last night, but George Mason lost its chance to be this years George Mason.

title: When Technology Is Worthwhile
description: Today I want to call your attention to two recent pieces about technology and winemaking by Alan Goldfarb, a correspondent for Appellation America. The first is about the process of micro-oxygenation, the unwieldy term for a process of pumping small amounts of oxygen into fermenting wine.

title: 2008: Identity Politics
description: Mark Leibovich takes a sweeping look at Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons approaches to being a female candidate, from Listener and Sister Act to Tough Hostess. She juxtaposes herself with President Bush, who she portrays as an exasperating husband who is beyond marriage counseling. The Timess Patrick Healy has more on her campaigns plan to involve more women.

title: What Congress Cant Do About the Iraq War
description: Congress can end the war, but it cant cap the number of troops on the battlefield: Writing in Slate, New York University law professors Noah Feldman and Samuel Issacharoff suggest that part of Barack Obamas proposal to limit the scope of the Iraq war is unconstitutional. They write:

title: An Education in Jokes
description: Last week, I spoke at an educational conference in Illinois. I love these tech-in-ed conferencesjust about every state has one each yearbecause theres something inspiring about seeing 3,000 teachers devote three days to keeping their minds sharp about the new technologies. And also because I always learn something myself.

title: Into the Mouths of Babes: Childhood Obesity
description: The metrics used to measure our national girth are legion, but heres another: New research suggests that the number of American children having obesity surgery has tripled in recent years  and that as many as 1,000 such operations this year may be performed on people between 12 and 19.

title: Off the News, the Show Goes On
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware, spent yesterday in Orangeburg, S.C., bounding from breakfast at the Chestnut Grill to lunch at Joe Foxs Restaurant.

title: How McCain Can Woo the Right
The Get
description: The must-haves: ultrabright windbreakers, braided belts, sailor tops, princely browns and perforated shoes.

title: Dole, Shalala to Investigate Walter Reed
description: President Bush acknowledged today the substandard conditions at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, uncovered by Washington Post reporters. Its unacceptable to me, its unacceptable to you, its unacceptable to our country and its not going to continue, he said during a speech to the American Legion.

title: Niagara to Hit the Road
description: One of the eight sites for the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament next week is Buffalo, close to the campus of the Niagara Purple Eagles. But Niagara, one of the official host schools, cannot play there.

title:
Talk to the Newsroom: Director
of Copy Desks Merrill Perlman
description: Merrill Perlman, who manages copy desks across the newsroom, is answering reader questions this week. Please submit your questions to asktheeditors@nytimes.com.

title: Proving the Obvious
description: Here's a mathematical statement that can readily understood. Take a really small number (say, 0.000000001) and a really big number (say, one hundred billion billion). Add enough copies of the really small number together, and you'll get a total that is bigger than the really big number. (Or in other words, pile up enough sand grains and you'll get a something bigger than Mount Everest.)

title: Hinson Cooks Up Bubble Trouble
description: Each year, I receive a Christmas card from the Missouri State Coach Barry Hinson. This years version had a shot of the Bears in their new arena with some type of cheesy joke that the Bears must have been very good this year because Santa got them a new arena. Big fun.

title: Ah, But Theres No Shame In Shaming
description: I see sleek opportunism in John Edwardss campaigns appropriation of the Ann Coulter CPAC video.

title: Showdown of the Conscious
description: At Room Eight, Ben Smith has posted an e-mail message, passed along by a reader, suggesting that Una Clarke is rallying her troops for a showdown to seat Dr. Mathieu Eugene on the City Council, despite questions about his residency:

title: Jay-Z Cashes in With Rocawear Deal
description: A few months after returning from rap-star retirement with a chart-topping album, Jay-Z has scored big on his other line of business: clothing. Jay-Z is selling the rights to the brand Rocawear, the urban-style apparel line he cofounded, for $204 million in cash to the Iconix Brand Group, Iconix said Tuesday. Under the licensing deal, Jay-Z, whose real name is Shawn Carter, will keep his stake in the Rocawear operating company, which manufactures Rocawears clothing for men. He will also be in charge of product development, marketing and licensing for Rocawear.

title: Putting a Stake in the Bagger
description: The results are in and have been examined, teasted apart and deconstructed. Thanks to everyone who took the time to not only read the Bagger, but comment as well. The awards season will be back before you know it, but no futher comments are being accepted for this past year.

title: Health Care for the Rest of Us (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Super Mario vs. the Pieman
description: An Empire Zone reader was so intrigued by our coverage of the 1977 pie-throwing incident  and Mario M. Cuomos role in it  that he wrote to the former governor. He shares this exchange:

title: Russian Travel Checklist: Tickets, Passport, Antidotes
description: More poison intrigue in Russia, it seems. Two American women, Marina Kovalevskaya, 49, and her daughter, Yana Kovalevskaya, 26, were hospitalized Feb. 24 in Moscow with a serious illness. Medical examiners have now confirmed that the women are suffering from exposure to thallium, which in high-enough doses can be fatal.

title: Friend of Nature? Lets See Those Shoes.
description: WHEN thinking about their contribution to global warming, concerned citizens might consider the cars they drive, the air miles they log and the energy they burn in their homes. But few would look at the shoes they wear or the food they eat.

title: Making Hay While the Market Swoons
description: On Wall Street, someones loss is usually someone elses gain. So who stands to benefit from the stomach-churning volatility that has moved the worlds equities markets in the past week or so? Christopher J. Allen, an analyst at Banc of America Securities, singles out the International Securities Exchange for special mention in a research note he published Tuesday.

title: The Week Ahead
description: Alison Smale of The International Herald Tribune assesses the top stories of the coming week.

title: Wild Horses
description: Photos from the London production of Equus, starring Daniel Radcliffe.

title: Libby Guilty of Lying in C.I.A. Leak Case
description: I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, was convicted today of lying to F.B.I. agents and grand jurors investigating the unmasking of a C.I.A. operative amid a burning dispute over the war in Iraq.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a group of service members who have sent an appeal to their Congressional representatives calling for withdrawal from Iraq referred incorrectly to an Air Force member, Jeff Slocum, who signed the appeal. He is a chief master sergeant  not chief master sergeant of the Air Force, a title now held by Rodney J. McKinley, the highest-ranking enlisted member of the Air Force.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A chart with the continuation of a front-page article on Sunday about civil commitment, the practice in some states of confining sex offenders beyond their prison terms, misstated the average annual cost per person under the system in Florida. It is $41,845, not $421,845.

title: A Long Tale About Short Selling
description: The story of Fairfax Financial Holdings has more twists and turns than The Departed, writes Bethany McLean in Fortune. It also seems to have something to inspire every kind of financial conspiracy theorist, whose ranks seem to be growing. Ms. McLean, whose famous article Is Enron Overpriced? foreshadowed that companys dramatic downfall, describes the drama at Fairfax as reaching from the trading floors of some of the worlds most powerful hedge funds to the offices of the F.B.I. to havens of corporate secrecy like Bermuda, Luxembourg and Hungary.

title: Who Will Dial Up a Deal for Palm?
description: As Palm works with Morgan Stanley to weigh its options for the future, analysts continue to speculate over who would pick up the struggling maker of Treo cellphones. Yet analysts quoted by MarketWatch on Tuesday tried to douse rumors that Nokia, Palms largest competitor, would sweep up the company.

title: With the Mets in Central Florida
description: Greetings from Osceola County Stadium in beautiful Kissimmee, where, as of 1:28 p.m., there have been no Roger Clemens sightings. No more forums to say whether he is 80 percent retired, 81 percent retired or perhaps 82 percent. Thats one thing I never understood about athletes, or anyone for that matter: if youre not 100 percent or 0 percent sure of something (or 99.9999 percent), how can you quantify the likelihood you will or will not do something?

title: Gannetts Country Clubbers to Pay Their Own Way
description: Executive perks are getting lots of attention this spring proxy season. Coincidentally, or perhaps not, Gannett, the largest newspaper publisher in the United States, has taken some small steps to limit the extras doled out to its top executives. The changes were noted by Michelle Leder of footnoted.org, who flagged a passage in Gannetts preliminary proxy statement indicating that the company will no longer provide its senior executives with any allowance for home security systems or club membership fees.

title: Tribune Sells Two Newspapers in Connecticut
description: Tribune Company said Tuesday it would sell two Connecticut newspapers to Gannett, the countrys biggest newspaper publisher. The sale of the two papers, The Advocate, based in Norwalk, and the Greenwich Time, carried a price of $73 million, putting Tribune above its previously stated goal to divest $500 million worth of assets.

title: Japanese Food for Thought
description: Overall, yesterdays sold-out symposium on food culture at the Japan Society, part of New York Citys Japanese Restaurant Week, was entertaining if not wildly instructive.

title: A Legends Field in Winter Haven
description: The Yankees are playing the Cleveland Indians now in Winter Havens Chain O Lakes Park, one of those creaky spring training sites with obstructed-view seats and a tin roof over the batting cage.

title: Gov Writes Dear Trustee Letter
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has released a copy of a letter he sent to more than 1,000 trustees of hospitals in the state in which he defends his budget and has some pointed questions for the Greater New York Hospital Association and 1199 S.E.I.U. United Healthcare Workers East, two powerful groups opposing his budget.

title: Monetizing Free Parking
description: Streetsblog points out a new fee-based service, SpotScout, that promises to connect people who are about to leave a free street parking space with subscribers who are looking for one, and comments:

title: Tom Glavine and the Inside Corner
description: The title may sound like a Sherlock Holmes mystery (it isnt, right?), but it is a tell-tale sign of Tom Glavines spring training progression. He allowed four hits and a walk in three scoreless innings this afternoon. Even for a veteran like Glavine, in his 24th spring training, getting in and out of the jams he faced can be beneficial. He can get comfortable pitching out of the stretch and resist the temptation to do too much.

title: McCain Apologizes for Walter Reed
description: Senator John McCain, the ranking Republican on the Armed Services Committee personally apologized today for what he called unacceptable conditions at Walter Reed Army Medical Center, currently the subject of hearings on the Hill.

title: For Activist Investors, Topps Sale Is Not Sweet Deal
description: For the two activist hedge funds who had long called for a sale of Topps, Tuesdays announcement that the baseball card maker would sell itself was hardly cause for celebration. Topps director Arnaud Ajdler of Crescendo Partners  one of the two funds that eventually won representation on the Topps board  quickly came out against the proposed $385 million sale to Tornante, Michael D. Eisners investment firm, and Madison Dearborn Partners, a Chicago-based buyout firm.

title: Back Door Opens for V.C.U.
description: After Virginia Commonwealths 65-59 victory against George Mason in Monday nights Colonial Athletic Association final, a few Rams bounded around the court wearing huge chain-link gold-colored necklaces. They were not trying to bring back the 80s. Rather, each link signified a team member.Its one of those all-for-one, one-for-all deals, and it was started by the teams first-year coach, Anthony Grant. The Rams bring those chains to practices and games, and will undoubtedly pack a few for next weeks N.C.A.A. tournament.The sophomore point guard Eric Maynor was not wearing one of the necklaces, but he was carrying the trophy as the tournament M.V.P. Maynor scored 9 points over the final 1 minute 55 seconds to help the Rams overcome a 5-point deficit. But his biggest contribution may have been a late rebound.The Rams led, 59-57, with 30 seconds left, and George Mason had the ball after a timeout. During the timeout, V.C.U.s director of basketball operations, Brett Nelson, who was a guard on Floridas 2000 Final Four team, pulled the 6-foot-2 Maynor aside.He told me the rebound was mine, Maynor said. He knew they were going to miss and it was coming to me.Sure enough, George Masons Dre Smith erred on a 3-pointer, Maynor cuffed the rebound and was fouled.This game was a sellout, but since many of those tickets went to teams that had been eliminated from the tournament, there were a lot of empty seats during the first half. Strangely, by halftime the place was filled with V.C.U fans. (Their campus is a few blocks from Richmond Coliseum). It was as if someone opened a back door and they all streamed in. Regardless, it was a great atmosphere. One fan was dressed in a chicken suit and another came as a banana.A colleague of mine asked the banana boy to explain his duds. His response, surprisingly, made sense:Because Im going bananas!So are the Rams.

title: J.P. Morgan Shuns Dealmaking for Growth, for Now
description: As J.P. Morgan Chase has finally digested its merger with Chicagos Bank One and beaten Goldman Sachs as the top hedge fund manager last year, whats next? According to its chief executive, James Dimon, while the countrys third-largest bank is acquisition capable, its future involves investing $1 billion in its investment banking business.

title: A View From the Libby Jury Box
description: Theres nothing like a juror talking to help peel back the secret nature of a jury panels deliberations, and in the Libby case, one of the jurors candidly took questions today in front of television cameras.

title: Good News  or Bad?  for the Curling Lobby
description: This highly educational video report from News 10 in Albany shows David Grandeau, the head of the commission, and other employees at a curling match in the middle of the workday.A commission employee says  she was fired under suspicion that she had tipped off the news station about the match.

title: Looming Presence at the Libby Trial
description: Sheryl Gay Stolberg reports on the role of Vice President Dick Cheney throughout the trial and conviction of his former chief of staff, I Lewis Libby.

title: 1199s Rivera: Dear Gov
description: That didnt take long.

title: Mysterious Misadventures of Russias Critics
description: While were on the topic of accidents befalling visitors to Russia, we might just as well take note of what seems an endless trail of untimely departures and serious injuries for a number of individuals living dangerously close to a John le Carr novel.

title: When Irish Genes Are Smiling
description: Tis a good day for the Irish - and a really bad one for Basil Fawlty  thanks to my colleague Nicholas Wades article tracing the genetic heritage of the British Isles. I grew up listening to my Irish-American relatives bristle at the social pretensions of the Anglo-Saxons in England: We were preserving civilization while they were painting themselves blue! Blue, I tell you! Now we can point to research suggesting the Celts started civilization in those isles by introducing agriculture 6,000 years ago.

title: Thats Where the Money Is
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomos public integrity unit has opened a new front: the contracting operations of a state government with an annual budget nearing $120 billion a year. Thats where the money is, said a senior official in the attorney generals office.

title: 10 Answers for Spitzer
description: The Greater New York Hospitals Association has responded to Gov. Eliot Spitzers letter today, with answers to his 10 questions for hospital CEOs:

title: A Street Corner Named Jerry?
description: Getting a Manhattan street corner named for Jerry Orbach, former star of stage and screen and consummate New Yorker, will be no open-and-shut case, his widow fears.

title: Winter Squash Soup
description: Dining columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, prepares a Thai-inspired dessert soup of winter squash in coconut milk.

title: Blogtalk: The Verdict
description: A line of intrigue that began with an op-ed in 2003 came to an end today when I. Lewis Scooter Libby was found guilty on four of five charges brought against him in what became known as the Valerie Plame Affair. The blogs saw the trial as more about Vice President Dick Cheney than about Mr. Libby, Mr. Cheneys former chief of staff.

title: One Thing Leads to Another
From Closet to the Penthouse
description: NEW YORK  In front of a swarm of television cameras and about 100 media members at the Hyatt in Midtown tonight, Commissioner Mike Tranghese handed out the Big Easts annual hardware.

title: And Theyre Off
description: Handicapping the Race for the Big East

title: Think Naughty, Think Small, Think Not
description: Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Read the rest of Warners Op-Ed, then post a comment about it below.  The Editors

title: The In Search of the Lost Chords Contest
description: Yes, this is a contest.

title: The Joys of Spring
description: Every Sunday morning for a good portion of my childhood, I would confiscate the sports section of the Philadelphia Inquirer and turn right to Jayson Starks Baseball Week in Review, a full-page collection of quirky and off-beat baseball news and anecdotes. My favorite was the annual Tom Lawless Memorial Last Guy to Get a Hit contest. With that foundation, Ive found myself drawn to searching for similar quirky and off-beat stuff. Case in point: On 6/6/06, the Dodgers scored six runs on six hits in the sixth inning against the Mets, and in his only at-bat that inning, #6 Kenny Lofton singled. Of course.

title: The Other Somalia: An Island of Stability in a Sea of Armed Chaos
description: HARGEYSA, Somalia, March 1  When the sun rises over the craggy hills of Hargeysa, it sheds light on a different kind of Somalia.

title: In the Mood for Festivals at Jazz at Lincoln Center
description: A theme of romance threads through the 2007-8 season for Jazz at Lincoln Center, Wynton Marsalis, its artistic director, said in an interview yesterday.

title: A Libby Verdict
description: There will be a great deal written and said in coming days about the frustrations of the Scooter Libby verdict  that it did not tell us whether someone deliberately blew Valerie Plame Wilsons cover or erase serious concerns about the prosecutors abuse of the First Amendment. Lets focus first on what the verdict does say.

title: Walter Reed Panel Leaders See Need for Overhaul
description: The military medical system must be redirected to meet the needs of the large numbers of seriously wounded soldiers now returning from the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, rather than mainly serving the aging veterans of earlier conflicts, the leaders of a new presidential panel said today.

title: Prosecution by Logic Defeats a Defense in Shades of Gray
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  The trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. played out as a left-brain, right-brain contest, posing the prosecutions just-the-facts appeal to logic against the defenses far more emotional argument about human frailty.

title: Attention Shoppers: Carbon Offsets in Aisle 6
description: ARE you willing to spend more so that electricity will be generated from animal manure instead of coal? If you live in Vermont, the public utility there will use your money to buy cow power made on local farms.

title: Japans Noodle of the Moment, From a Master
description: For the past few years, Sanuki udon, the long, thick, white noodle that is a specialty of the Kagawa region, has become the noodle of choice in Japan. Its appeal is its silkiness and toothsome quality, with a springy texture achieved when the wheat dough is kneaded underfoot.

title: In Arizona Desert, Indian Trackers vs. Smugglers
description: TOHONO OODHAM NATION, Ariz.  A fresh footprint in the dirt, fibers in the mesquite. Harold Thompson reads the signs like a map.

title: Atlantic City: Investigation Into Dismissal
description: Assemblyman James Whelan of Atlantic City has asked the states attorney general, labor commissioner and Casino Control Commission to investigate the firing over the weekend of a longtime Tropicana casino employee who is suing the casino, contending that he developed lung cancer from exposure to secondhand smoke on the job. The employee, Vincent Rennich, 48, a nonsmoker who in 25 years at the casino had risen to floor supervisor, had become a figure in the statewide antismoking movement before his firing. Mr. Whelan wants the state officials to determine whether his firing was an intimidation tactic and a corporate strategy to push out senior employees. The casino had no comment yesterday.

title: Martin Trow, 80, Sociologist and Higher Education Expert, Is Dead
description: Martin A. Trow, a sociologist whose research on higher education reverberated through North America and Europe, particularly his description of the transition of a college education from elite privilege to mass product, died on Feb. 24 at his home in Kensington, Calif. He was 80.

title: South Africas Trove of an Elusive Grape
description: IF you love wines made from the chenin blanc grape as I do, you are grimly aware that your source for good bottles has been more or less restricted to one: the Loire Valley of France.

title: A Piquant Appetizer That Brings Out the Best in a Wine
description: LIGHTLY, gracefully, almost teasingly, the chenin blancs from South Africa captivated my palate as I discovered hints of melon, herbs, citrus, minerals and occasionally honey. The best ones displayed admirable consistency. Many were wines that I would gladly open with an array of dishes.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: For Cheney, Political Toll May Follow Libby Verdict
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  In legal terms, the jury has spoken in the Libby case. In political terms, Dick Cheney is still awaiting a judgment.

title: Brooklyn: New Science Curriculum
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city would spend $30 million to improve science instruction in kindergarten through eighth grade during the next school year. At a news conference at Brooklyn Technical High School, Mr. Bloomberg said that the citys Education Department was developing a new citywide science curriculum that schools would be required to follow and annual science exams for grades not already tested in science by the state. The curriculum will begin in September in the third, fourth and sixth grades, city education officials said, adding that they could not provide a list of the new books or materials because they were still in negotiations with publishers and other vendors.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about an antigovernment protest in Russia referred incorrectly to Garry Kasparov, a former world chess champion, who is also a member of Russias liberal political opposition and who spoke to the crowd. He is a grandmaster under the designation of the World Chess Federation, a title awarded for life  not a former grandmaster.

title: New York Attorney General Says Auditor Defrauded State
description: ALBANY, March 6  The money was supposed to be used to find sites for group homes for people with mental illness. And since 1998, investigators found, an auditor at the states Office of Mental Health has approved more than $1.2 million in payments for site studies to a company called Very Important Property, or V.I.P.

title: U.S. Presses North Korea Over Uranium
description: The United States said yesterday that North Korea must fully disclose its efforts to produce highly enriched uranium as part of the negotiations now under way that are aimed at ending North Koreas nuclear weapons program and normalizing relations between the two countries.

title: U.S. Doctor and Daughter Sickened by Poison in Russia
description: MOSCOW, March 6  An American doctor and her daughter were being treated in a Moscow hospital on Tuesday after showing signs of thallium poisoning. Thallium is a highly toxic element with a history of use in pesticides and in murder.

title: Politics, Politics (and Its Only 07) (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Jay D. Haley, 83, Early Advocate of Involving Family in Therapy, Dies
description: Jay D. Haley, an early theorist of family therapy who in the 1960s advocated hypnosis and deeper social involvement for patients to cure emotional problems more rapidly, died on Feb. 13 at his home in San Diego. He was 83.

title: Historical Society Loses Round in Fight to Renovate a Landmark
description: In a stormy two-hour meeting before 200 neighborhood residents last night, the New-York Historical Society was rebuffed by Community Board 7 in Manhattan, which resoundingly opposed the groups proposal to renovate the exterior of its landmark building at 170 Central Park West.

title: Built for Speed, but Looking for Love
description: WATCHING a three-and-a-half-pound chicken roast in 14 minutes, time loses all meaning. The skin turns gold and crisp, juices immediately rise to the surface, and the flesh firms before your eyes. Its dizzying and seductive, like the home makeovers on TV that compress a six-month renovation into a single afternoon.

title: Through Tulle and Tears, Perfecting That Special Day
description: Her wedding is supposed to be a womans happiest moment, yet no event is more apt to make her look ridiculous.

title: Dont Ask, Dont Know, Dont Help
description: I havent kept count, but it seems to me that the number of times Ive seen President Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney give speeches about the Iraq war using smiling soldiers as their backdrops have been, well, countless. Youd think that an administration that has been so quick to exploit soldiers as props  whether it was to declare Mission Accomplished on a naval vessel or to silence critics by saying their words might endanger soldiers in battle  would have been equally quick to spare no expense in caring for those injured in the fight.

title: Searching for Michael Jordan? Microsoft Wants a Better Way
description: REDMOND, Wash., March 6  Internet searching was at the forefront of the technologies that Microsoft displayed on Tuesday at an event intended to showcase the companys research prowess.

title: Bridgeport Man Stabbed Wife and Urged Child to Aid in Attack, Police Say
description: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., March 6  Tucked in the files at Bridgeport Superior Court, it reads like a macabre laundry list: an eight-inch kitchen knife with a small spot of blood on its edge, a blood-spattered nightgown and a pair of pink Sesame Street pants with bloodstains visible.

title: Jean Baudrillard, 77, Critic and Theorist of Hyperreality, Dies
description: The French critic and provocateur Jean Baudrillard, whose theories about consumer culture and the manufactured nature of reality were intensely discussed both in rarefied philosophical circles and in blockbuster movies like The Matrix, died yesterday in Paris. He was 77.

title: F.C.C. Chief Questioning Radio Deal
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  Kevin J. Martin, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, has privately questioned recent Congressional testimony by the architect of a proposed merger of the nations two satellite radio companies that subscribers would both pay the same monthly rate and receive significantly more programming.

title: Peace Force Is Attacked on Arrival in Somalia
description: KINDU, Congo, March 6  The first group of African Union peacekeepers arrived Tuesday in Mogadishu, Somalias capital, and received a patently Mogadishu reception.

title: The Towns Biggest Event Since the Banana Fever Ended
description: ARACATACA, Colombia, March 6  Long gone are the expatriate managers of the United Fruit Company, which made Aracataca into a thriving company town in Colombias banana-growing region in the early 20th century. Gone, too, are the Gypsies who would pitch their tents on the edge of town to sell contraptions like telescopes and false teeth.

title: Artest Again Puts Himself, and N.B.A., in a Tough Spot
description: Whenever Ron Artest gets in trouble, he threatens himself, his team and the N.B.A.s image.

title: The Big Apple May Never Be Known as the Big Sparerib, but Its Smokin
description: AMOR was what she called me. Not honey, not sugar, not sir. Amor  as in Spanish for love  was what the counter woman tacked onto thank you when I paid my tab at the Ranger Texas Barbecue, which operates out of the back of a locals bar called Legends in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Report Links Two Players to Pharmacy
description: Kevin Hallinan, Major League Baseballs senior vice president for security, and several other baseball security officials are scheduled to meet in Albany today with the district attorney who is examining the online sales of illegal prescription drugs.

title: Different Challenges Face Dallas and Nets
description: DALLAS, March 6  Before the start of the season, the Nets and the Dallas Mavericks were considered contenders for their conference titles and perhaps the N.B.A. championship. Less than two weeks into the season, the Nets appeared to be the more serious contender after the Mavericks lost their first four games.

title: Intel Competition Is Where Science Rules and Research Is the Key
description: They were once the powerhouses, finishing among the top performers as predictably as the Yankees make the playoffs. But for the third year in a row both the Bronx High School of Science and Stuyvesant High School in New York City have been shut out of the circle of 40 finalists in the Intel Science Talent Search.

title: Chief Sees Difficulties in Splitting Off Chrysler Brands
description: GENEVA, March 6  The chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, Dieter Zetsche, said on Tuesday that it would be difficult to break up Chrysler, as analysts and other experts have speculated recently, because of an integrated production system that binds together its various brands.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Saturday about a draft accord on trans-Atlantic air routes misidentified one of only two United States carriers that are allowed to fly into Londons Heathrow Airport, a right that will be expanded to other airlines under the new agreement. Along with American Airlines, United Airlines currently flies into Heathrow; Delta Air Lines does not.

title: Researchers Dispute Benefits of CT Scans for Lung Cancer
description: Lung cancer screening with CT scans does not appear to save lives and exposes people to serious risks of injury and even death from needless surgery, researchers are reporting today.

title: Recipe: Winter Squash in Coconut Milk
description: Time: 30 minutes, plus cooling

title: Bush Appoints Dole and Shalala to Head Inquiry on Military Health Care
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  President Bush on Tuesday named the onetime Senate majority leader Bob Dole and Donna E. Shalala, former secretary of health and human services, to lead a bipartisan commission that will be charged with investigating problems at Walter Reed Army Medical Center and throughout the militarys health care system.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 9 P.M. (Fox) THE WEDDING BELLS Happily ever after? In this latest series from David E. Kelley, the Bell sisters  Annie (KaDee Strickland), Sammy (Sarah Jones) and Jane (Teri Polo)  inherit a wedding-planning business after their parents divorce and find themselves navigating details from nuts to bolts of tulle, while trying to manage the logistics of their own love lives.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,165 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Eighth Place Will Wait as Knicks Fall to Sonics
description: Stephon Marbury missed a free throw with nine-tenths of a second left on the clock last night  a moment painful enough to make him pull his jersey over his head. The Knicks would learn an hour later how costly it was.

title: Italian Case May Open Up Crossborder Gambling
description: LONDON, March 6  The top European court on Tuesday prohibited Italy from prosecuting bookmakers based in other European countries, a ruling that private companies hailed as a milestone in efforts to pry European betting markets from government-run monopolies.

title: U.S. Releases Rights Report, With an Acknowledgment
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  The Bush administration acknowledged Tuesday that its treatment of terrorism suspects was being questioned, even as it used an annual report to criticize the human rights records of Iraq, Afghanistan and a long list of other countries.

title: The Louvres Art: Priceless. The Louvres Name: Expensive.
description: PARIS, March 6  Whats the price of a good name?

title: Serving You Tonight Will Be Our Lawyer
description: THE review, published last month in The Philadelphia Inquirer, was three sentences long. It praised the crab cake at Chops restaurant in Bala Cynwyd, Pa., but said the meal there over all was expensive and disappointing, from the soggy and sour chopped salad to a miserably tough and fatty strip steak.

title: A Piece of History Lands in a Contemporary Fight
description: ALLENSWORTH, Calif.  It is an unlikely place for a utopia: this cracked-earth landscape of two-lane roads in the Central Valley, so remote that the lilting staccato of freight trains can be heard from miles away.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about the unusual breadth of a proposed New York law to confine sex offenders who have completed their prison sentences referred imprecisely to the trials that would be held to determine whether an offender required further supervision. They could occur either in the county where the inmate was originally convicted, or the one where he was incarcerated; they would not automatically occur in the county of conviction.

title: Manhattan: Church Treasurer Indicted
description: The volunteer treasurer of the First Reformed Episcopal Church at 317 East 50th Street was indicted on charges of stealing $409,000 from the church from 1999 to 2004, prosecutors said yesterday. Thelma Daniels Perkins, 59, of Rahway, N.J., who was the volunteer treasurer for 20 years, stole most of the money by writing checks to herself and relatives, the Manhattan district attorneys office said. Some of the checks were written to pay bills. She was also accused of stealing $16,000 from weekly collections and then writing an invalid check for the same amount that was deposited to a church account, prosecutors said. The theft was discovered when a new rector arrived at the church, prosecutors said. Ms. Perkins pleaded not guilty to grand larceny yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan and was held on $75,000 bail.

title: Vietnams Divide Endures for Native Dance Troupe
description: From a marketing perspective, Le Vu Long is a slam dunk.

title: Jerry Orbach Was a Marquee Name, but a Street Signs Another Story
description: It is a tribute that has been paid to Peter Jennings, Humphrey Bogart, Joey Ramone, even Seor Wences. But getting a Manhattan street corner named for Jerry Orbach, former star of stage and screen and consummate New Yorker, will be no open-and-shut case.

title: The New Bioplastics, More Than Just Forks
description: MEG SOBKOWICZ was on a fast career track in the oil industry. A bachelors degree in chemical engineering from Columbia landed her a job at Schlumberger running wireline logs on oil wells in New Mexico. Next stop was to be Casper, Wyo., the heart of the interior Wests oil and gas boom. But she jumped off the track.

title: The Value of Their Values
description: I began my career as a Foreign Service officer in Indonesia. There, journalists, diplomats and aid workers emphasized that local government was incompetent, inefficient and corrupt. I heard the same when working in the Balkans, Afghanistan and Iraq. My colleagues often seemed contemptuous of the nations where they served. They overlooked the cultures virtues and strengths, which are the keys to rebuilding nations, particularly after insurgency and civil war.

title: Food Calendar
description: Yum, Stinky

title: Crash in Indonesia Exposes Deep Safety Problems
description: HONG KONG, March 7  Indonesia has had yet another airline accident, yet another tragic roll call of dead travelers. This time the aircraft belonged to the national carrier, Garuda Indonesia, and not one of the many budget carriers that have sprung up in recent years.

title: A Coal Executive With a Cleanup Mission
description: ON a frigid February morning in Washington, when snow had delayed the opening of government offices, James E. Rogers was up early, already campaigning, making the case for a national policy to curb global warming.

title: Recipe: Fried Fish With Vodka and Beer Batter
description: Time: About 45 minutes

title: Whats So Bad About Big?
description: SMALL is beautiful, wrote the economist E. F. Schumacher almost 35 years ago. In most areas of the economy, he reasoned, production had become too big and too centralized.

title: After Years of Sharing Load, Jones Yearns to Carry It for Jets
description: Few running backs have their most productive seasons after age 29, but the Jets say that Thomas Jones can do just that.

title: Jury Describes Decision as Hard but Inevitable
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  One juror, Rosemary Russo, a government lawyer, described it as an emotional decision that left some jurors in tears.

title: Health Care for the Rest of Us (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Whats a Great Way to Get a Fish Fried? Give It a Shot of Vodka
description: FRYING fish is not exactly a new idea, but people do come up with new ways to do it. Some are more practical than others. At last years Madrid Fusin, the annual gathering of the worlds restaurant avant-garde, the Spanish chef Dani Garca demonstrated a method that couldnt have been simpler:

title: Another Building by a Noted Modernist Comes Under Threat, This Time in Boston
description: BOSTON, March 1  A plan to demolish a 1960 office tower by the influential architect Paul Rudolph threatens to pit a prominent developer backed by Mayor Thomas M. Menino against preservationists who see the building as a seminal example of midcentury Modernism.

title: Not All Sources Are Equal
description: Boston

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about Audi, which has become the worlds fastest-growing maker of luxury cars, referred incorrectly to its origins. The modern company was created in the 1930s by the merger of four  not three  German car-makers, including Audi itself, which had existed since 1910. The article also misspelled the name of Porsches counterpart to Audis R8 two-seat sports car. It is the Carrera, not Carerra.

title: At Least 22 Die in Indonesian Plane Crash
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 7  In the latest of a series of transportation disasters in Indonesia, a passenger airliner slammed into the ground on landing at the city of Yogyakarta today and burst into flames, killing at least 22 people and leaving many people badly injured.

title: 1,000 Journalists Killed in 10 Years While Reporting
description: PARIS, March 6 More than 1,000 journalists have been killed while reporting the news over the past 10 years as homicide has emerged as an increasingly popular tool for silencing them, a new survey has found.

title: Across the Atlantic, Slowing Breezes
description: IF a heavy reliance on fossil fuels makes a country a climate ogre, then Denmark  with its thousands of wind turbines sprinkled on the coastlines and at sea  is living a happier fairy tale.

title: Thanks to Mr. Chvez
description: Venezuela and its demagogic president, Hugo Chvez, wont get a visit from President Bush. But Mr. Chvezs appeal will be very much on Mr. Bushs mind when he visits Latin America over the next week.

title: Touch of Thai in a Squash Dessert
description: JUST before the first spring vegetables begin to appear, and almost at the last possible time to exploit last falls harvest, a friend dropped this gift in my lap: a recipe for a dessert soup of winter squash poached in coconut milk.

title: An 8th-Grade Test, 180 Degrees From Easy
description: With butterflies in their stomachs, New York States schoolchildren sit down this week and next for their annual mathematics tests, given in grades three through eight.

title: Rustic With a Dash of Sophistication
description: WE dont do right by lunch. We dont even come close. We dont pause long enough, relax fully enough, allow ourselves a real meal and allow that meal to renew us to the extent that its meant to.

title: As the Climate Heats Up, Lawyers Sharpen Their Wits
description: LAWYERS are looking at climate change and seeing visions of new business. They are showing up at meetings to discuss the legal implications of global warming, and a growing number of law firms are advertising expertise in climate change issues. The subject seems well on its way to becoming the next big thing in environmental law.

title: Woods Can Give Tour What It Wants
description: Every PGA Tour tournament director lives with the reality that Tiger Woodss presence blesses an event and that his absence hurts it.

title: Rescuers Search for Victims of Indonesian Quake
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 7  Rescue teams continued searching collapsed buildings in western Sumatra on Wednesday for victims of two large earthquakes that struck Tuesday.

title: Israel: Lebanon War Report Delayed
description: The state comptroller, Micha Lindenstrauss, delayed presenting his interim findings on the governments performance in protecting the home front during the Lebanon war. His findings, the first of several investigations into the militarys and governments handling of the 34-day war, were to be presented to a parliamentary committee, but under government pressure and claims that those under scrutiny had not been given time to respond, Mr. Lindenstrauss instead limited his comments to the progress of his investigation. He accused Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of stalling on questions from his office. Mr. Lindenstrauss said his final report would be ready in about four months. A broader report on government and army failures in the war by a commission led by Eliyahu Winograd, a retired judge, is expected within weeks.

title: Olympic Booster Tied to Clinic in Drug Inquiry
description: JUPITER, Fla., March 6  A businessman and wrestling booster who has sponsored Olympic and school-age athletes is under investigation by state and federal authorities examining the distribution of steroids and human growth hormone, according to a law enforcement official familiar with the case.

title: BP Cuts Bonus in Half for Outgoing Executive
