description: LONDON, March 6  The energy company BP cut the 2006 bonus of John Browne, its departing chief executive, almost in half for a year when the company reported record earnings but faced accusations that cost-cutting led to safety lapses at a plant in Texas.

title: South Africa: Patients Flee TB Patients
description: Some 100 patients walked out of a hospital in southeast city of East London after paramedics wearing head-to-toe protection brought in eight people suffering from the virulent strain of tuberculosis known as XDR-TB, for extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis. The strain, which leaves patients virtually untreatable, is now found throughout the country. We have nothing against them, one of the fleeing patients told the Internet news service Dispatch, but we cannot share living quarters with them. The patients left despite assurances that the newcomers would be kept in isolation.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about an antigovernment protest in Russia referred incorrectly to Garry Kasparov, a former world chess champion, who is also a member of Russias liberal political opposition and who spoke to the crowd. He is a grandmaster under the designation of the World Chess Federation, a title awarded for life  not a former grandmaster. (Go to Article)

title: Women of the Waves Seek Equal Pay
description: In surfing, the participation and performance of women have been surging, boosting industry profits. But going on 50 years since Gidget earned grudging respect from the guys  and two weeks after Wimbledon pledged to pay equal prize money to women  gender equity for the sport remains a point of contention.

title: California: Tussle Over Teaching Hospital
description: A medical school created to serve minorities, the Charles R. Drew University of Medicine and Science, announced that it would file a $125 million breach-of-contract suit against Los Angeles County after a restructuring of its teaching hospital by the county Board of Supervisors. Last fall, after failing a federal inspection, the 537-bed hospital, then known as the Martin Luther King Jr./Drew Medical Center, lost its Medicare and Medicaid contracts and $200 million in federal support. In response, the supervisors ended the hospitals residency programs, closed its trauma center and reduced the number of beds to 42. The university said the supervisors had created a catastrophe for 248 medical residents and threatened the quality of care for the 1.7 million residents in the Watts area of Los Angeles by failing to maintain King/Drews accreditation. Supervisor Yvonne B. Burke, whose district includes the hospital, called the threat of the suit unfortunate and said the supervisors were reviewing the announcement.

title: Venezuela Disavows 1980s-Era Bonds
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 6  The plot would seem to come right out of a novel in which the reader does not know whom to believe.

title: What You Get for ... $1,000,000
description: Savannah, Ga.

title: State Warns L.I. District About Deficit
description: Five years after the state tightened its oversight of the financially troubled Roosevelt school system on Long Island, the 2,800-student district has run up a budget deficit of as much as $12.3 million, the state comptroller said yesterday.

title: Radio System for Subways Gets a Rebuff
description: First, the Police Department refused to use a $140 million system built by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to carry its radio signals underground in the subway. Now, the Fire Department has also given the system a failing grade, saying it is permeated with dead spots where radio signals do not reach.

title: Citigroup Makes $10.8 Billion Bid for Japanese Brokerage Firm
description: TOKYO, March 6  Citigroup announced a $10.8 billion takeover bid Tuesday for Japans third-largest brokerage firm as it tries to make a comeback in one of the worlds richest financial markets.

title: The Wider Shame of Walter Reed
description: It is impossible not to feel fury at the shameful neglect of wounded soldiers at Walter Reeds outpatient facilities, just a few miles from an oblivious and neglectful White House. Many have been housed in rooms coated with mold and infested with cockroaches and mice. They have been swamped with confusing paperwork and forced to take responsibility for managing their own medical care. And when they or their family members have complained, their pleas for help have been callously ignored.

title: Avoiding the Cookie-Cutter Look
description: For all the appeal that a gated community holds for a second-home owner  recreational amenities, a sense of security  a planned development can sometimes put a home buyer in the architectural equivalent of a straitjacket.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Monday about the Labyrinth Theater Company misstated the number of Oscar winners who belong to the group. Besides Philip Seymour Hoffman, John Patrick Shanley has also won an Oscar, along with a Pulitzer Prize.

title: Libby Guilty of Lying in C.I.A. Leak Case
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, was convicted on Tuesday of lying to a grand jury and to F.B.I. agents investigating the leak of the identity of a C.I.A. operative in the summer of 2003 amid a fierce public dispute over the war in Iraq.

title: Conference on Fate of Central Asian Water Basin Ends in Stalemate
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, March 7  A conference convened here this week to address the fate of an ecologically threatened Central Asian water basin the size of California has ended in stalemate between the two countries that rely on it the most.

title: Medication Errors Are Studied
description: Young children are the most likely victims of surgery-related medication mistakes, a new study has found, and poor communication as the patient moves from the operating room to recovery is the most likely culprit.

title: Queens: Man Charged in Fatal Stabbing
description: A Flushing man has been arrested in connection with the fatal stabbing of a man walking home from a Chinese New Year celebration last month, prosecutors said yesterday. The suspect, Kendall Walker, 21, of Colden Street, was arrested on Monday and charged with second-degree murder, said Richard A. Brown, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Walker began arguing with Hung Chi Zhang, 40, about 4 a.m. on Feb. 18 near Colden Street and Elder Avenue. He said Mr. Walker stabbed Mr. Zhang repeatedly with a four-inch knife. Mr. Brown said Mr. Zhang immigrated to the United States five years ago and was working as a food deliveryman.

title: A Master of Monologues, Living on in His Words
description: Five minutes into Spalding Gray: Stories Left to Tell, the disarming show that opened last night at the Minetta Lane Theater, I stopped gritting my teeth and decided that a show about Spalding Gray without Spalding Gray might just work after all. As would surely be the case with most fans of Mr. Gray, the compellingly self-centered monologuist who died at 62 in 2004, I needed convincing.

title: The Data Tell a Different Story on Heart Patients
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Green License Plates Proposed to Identify Ohio Sex Offenders
description: CINCINNATI, March 6  A bipartisan effort in Ohios legislature could make the state the first to require convicted violent sex offenders and child predators to place fluorescent green license plates on their cars.

title: The Expanding Empire of an Adventurous Baker
description: IVE long suspected that there are two Iacopo Falais. One is the Euro-serious tattooed chef who snagged two stars from Frank Bruni at the increasingly adventurous Italian restaurant on Clinton Street that bears his last name.

title: The Tale of Harry Potter and the Naked Role
description: LONDON, March 6  It was a little weird at first, Erin Tobin said, seeing Harry Potter right there on the stage without his pants, or indeed any of his clothes.

title: For Internet Barons, Uncharted Investment Territory
description: ROBERT M. METCALFE, Silicon Valley legend, creator of the Ethernet standard, founder of 3Com and now a venture capitalist, makes a bold prediction about technology investors next conquest.

title: Inquiry Looks at Accusations That Wines Had False Labels
description: Federal investigators in New York are looking into allegations of counterfeiting in high-end wine sales, issuing subpoenas to auction houses that handled what were billed as rare bottles with distinguished provenances, according to people in the wine trade.

title: Think Naughty, Think Small, Think Not
description: Ann Coulters use of the epithet faggot to slur the Democratic presidential candidate John Edwards last week took me back to the schoolyards of the 1970s, when Coulter and I were both young.

title: Europeans New Mantra: Go West
description: Emboldened by the strength of the pound and the euro, Europeans are eyeing real estate across the Atlantic, while the weak dollar is forcing Americans to think twice about property in Europe, analysts say.

title: At 88, a Hall of Famer Is Still in There Pitching
description: WINTER HAVEN, Fla., March 6  The drivers door of the white Buick LaCrosse opened, and one of the senior members of the Baseball Hall of Fame stepped out briskly Tuesday morning. He was wearing the official Cleveland Indians uniform, buttoned to the top, with red-and-white-striped stirrups tucked into cleats that had his No. 19 inked in black on the side. He was ready for another day of starring as himself.

title: Inside the Immigration Maze, With No Answers
description: FARMINGVILLE, N.Y.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A television review on Saturday about The Winner, a new sitcom on Fox that has Seth MacFarlane as an executive producer, misidentified the cable channel that showed reruns of his show Family Guy, after Fox canceled it at one point. It was Cartoon Network, not Comedy Central.

title: Special Visas for Victims Remain Elusive Despite a Law
description: The law was hailed as a tool to crack down on violent crimes against immigrant women and children when President Clinton signed it. It authorized up to 10,000 special temporary visas a year to eligible victims in the United States who helped the police and prosecutors, despite fear of deportation. And it let those with the visas eventually apply for permanent residency on humanitarian grounds.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Hollywood Increases Online Marketing

title: U.S. to Owe Billions for Delays in Nuclear Dump, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  The federal government will owe $7 billion in damages for delays in opening a nuclear waste dump if the repository opens in 2017  the earliest date now possible  and any further delay will raise the price half a billion dollars a year, the head of the radioactive waste program said Tuesday.

title: Call of the Truck Stop: Gentlemen, Stop Your Engines
description: THOUGH Robert Jordan clocked three million miles in nearly 30 years hauling Wisconsin cheese around the United States, he never considered himself a typical trucker. On the road he listened to educational books on tape. He drove slower than almost everyone else, and he never saw the point of running the engine when the truck wasnt moving.

title: Ernest Gallo, 97, Founder of Winery, Dies
description: Ernest Gallo, who with his brother Julio started a winery seven decades ago that now sells one of every four bottles of wine that Americans drink, died yesterday at his home on Modesto, Calif. He was 97.

title: China Stresses Ties With Japan Despite Sex Slavery Issue
description: BEIJING, March 6  Chinas foreign minister on Tuesday urged Japan to accept responsibility for its use of comfort women sex slaves in World War II but made clear that the issue would not dampen Chinas desire to strengthen ties between the countries.

title: Obama Offers Explanation of Stock Purchases
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  Senator Barack Obama said today he did not believe it was a conflict to seek investment advice and use the brokerage services recommended by a friend and political contributor. He said he was not aware he had invested money into two of the same companies supported by some of his top donors.

title: Shades of Youth: Can You See Me Now?
description: IMAGINE Gillette running ads that declare, Stop shaving. Or Ivory soap offering advice against bathing. Or Fruit of the Loom urging consumers to Go naked in the world.

title: Arab Silence on Attacks (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Title for Rutgers Whisks UConn Back to Earth
description: HARTFORD, March 6  By early Tuesday, 7 of the top 10 womens basketball teams had lost in their conference tournaments. And then there was Connecticut, which appeared immune to parity, as if by vaccination.

title: Attacks Across Iraq Kill at Least 109 Shiite Pilgrims
description: BAGHDAD, Wednesday, March 7  Suicide bombers who lured unsuspecting pilgrims with cakes, and gunmen firing out of passing cars, turned preparations for a Shiite Muslim religious celebration into a day of carnage on Tuesday. At least 109 Shiite pilgrims were killed and more than 200 wounded with the death toll continuing to rise.

title: Makers of Sodas Try a New Pitch: Theyre Healthy
description: Healthy soda?

title: Ahead of 2008, Pataki Joins New York Law Firm
description: ALBANY, March 7Former Gov. George E. Pataki has joined the law firm of Chadbourne & Parke, the New York-based firm announced today.

title: Jordans King Urges U.S. to Pursue Peace in Mideast
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  King Abdullah II of Jordan, in a rare appearance before a joint meeting of Congress, made an impassioned plea today for the United States to lead in an active pursuit of Israeli-Palestinian peace, saying that without it none of Middle Easts other problems would be solved.

title: A Waterfront That Has Left Its Wasteland Days Behind
description: BURLINGTON, Vt.  From the rooftop terrace of the soon-to-open Courtyard by Marriott  the first new hotel built downtown here in three decades  a visitor can see the expansive waterfront, which is now a thriving arts and cultural center. A beautifully landscaped park and a promenade buffer the eastern shore of Lake Champlain. A smattering of handsome brick-and-stone buildings abut the shoreline.

title: Paul Secon, Who Helped Found Pottery Barn, Dies at 91
description: Paul Secon, who in 1949 loaded the family station wagon with discontinued and slightly damaged ceramics from an upstate New York factory, drove to Manhattan and opened the first Pottery Barn store, died Feb. 24 at his home in Rochester. He was 91.

title: Prosecutors Describe Contacts From Higher Up
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  Six ousted United States attorneys told Congressional panels Tuesday new details about lawmakers intrusions in sensitive investigations and possible efforts by the Justice Department to squelch their public protests over their firings.

title: City Faces Trial for Blocking Protests on Central Park Lawn
description: A battle over whether the Great Lawn in Central Park is open to political protesters as well as opera is headed to a jury trial.

title: An Art Gallery in the Lobby
description: Placing art in commercial buildings to enliven a lobby or courtyard is hardly a new concept. But more often than not, the art seems to be an afterthought, especially as permanent installations fade into the background with the ficus trees.

title: Scores of Shiites Killed in Iraq in 2nd Day of Strife
description: BAGHDAD, March 7  For the second straight day, insurgents struck at Shiite pilgrims and other civilians across central Iraq on Wednesday, apparently seeking to reignite a cycle of sectarian retribution as hundreds of thousands of Shiites made their pilgrimage to Karbala to commemorate the martyrdom of Imam Hussein.

title: Corporate Hippies Seek Their Bliss in a New Environmental Economy
description: CHANGE once came slowly to the job market for people seeking careers focused on the environment. No more.

title: States Aim for Green Power
description: MOST states see a value in being green these days, but some want to be greener than others.

title: Revised Figures Show Sharper Slowdown in Productivity in the Fourth Quarter of 2006
description: In business cycles, productivity slowdowns can be a difficult time for workers because employers typically respond by letting employees go. New labor statistics released yesterday showed that productivity is indeed slowing faster than first thought, raising the question of whether layoffs are soon to follow.

title: Shrimp Scampi, a Classic Open to Interpretation
description: SHRIMP scampi is a dish so entrenched in the Italian-American vernacular that until the day I decided to make it, I did not realize that I didnt know what it was.

title: Responses From Hospitals
description: The graphic that accompanied my column this week listed hospitals in a number of cities that were doing a poor job of treating heart attack patients, according to Medicare data. I asked all eight of them if they wanted to respond, and some of those replies are included below.

title: As to the Direction of the Roberts Court: The Jury Is Still Out
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  Over the Presidents Day weekend, Douglas W. Kmiec went to a popular legal Web site, Findlaw.com, to post his thoughts on the Supreme Court at midterm.

title: U.S. Owners See Link From Goals to Profits
description: The passel of American businessmen who have bought some of the top clubs in England, initially purely as investments, will inevitably become emotionally involved in their teams and the game of soccer, according to Dan Jones, a partner in the sports business group at Deloitte in London.

title: British Court Lifts Ban Over BBC Report on Campaign Scandal
description: LONDON, March 6  In a fierce battle between British authorities and news organizations, the High Court on Tuesday lifted restrictions on the BBC that had prevented it from publicizing developments in a scandal over allegations that honors had been traded for campaign contributions.

title: Airbus Workers in France Protest Planned Job Cuts
description: PARIS, March 6  Thousands of Airbus employees took to the streets Tuesday to protest a radical company revamping that has drawn fire from French politicians amid a heated presidential campaign.

title: Saudi Arabia: Suspects Held in Killings of French
description: Saudi Arabia has arrested several suspects in the shooting attack on a group of French citizens last week that killed four, security officials said, and the police were looking for two other suspects who have been warned to turn themselves in. An Interior Ministry spokesman declined to say how many people were in custody or whether any belonged to militant Islamic groups. Security officials have declined to term the attack an act of Islamist terrorism.

title: Paul Secon, Entrepreneur Who Helped Found Pottery Barn, Dies at 91
description: Paul Secon, who in 1949 loaded the family station wagon with discontinued and slightly damaged ceramics from an upstate New York factory, drove to Manhattan and opened the first Pottery Barn store, died Feb. 24 at his home in Rochester. He was 91.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening this Week

title: Pardon Libby? Left and Right Erupt in a Fight
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  If some people imagined a verdict in the criminal trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr. would calm the political passions surrounding his fate, they may have forgotten two words with a combustible history: presidential pardon.

title: Newark: One Killed and Two Beaten in Home Invasion
description: One man was killed and two were beaten after three masked gunmen invaded a studio apartment above a restaurant early yesterday, said Lupe Todd, a spokeswoman for the city. The police received a report of an armed robbery about 6:35 a.m. on Summer Avenue in which gunmen forced their way into the home, she said. One man died, a man was treated for his injuries at the apartment and another was taken to University Hospital, where he was in stable condition yesterday. The police did not identify the victims, but neighbors said the apartment was occupied by an elderly man who had lived in the area for decades. Wanda Bolquez, 40, said the man moved into the apartment a month ago and often let homeless people stay the night. Compiled by John Sullivan

title: Buying a Second Home on St. Barts
description: The road that winds around St. Barthlemy offers some of the most spectacular vistas in the Caribbean as it curves up and down steep hills, snakes along windswept beaches and crosses coconut groves and salt marshes.

title: White House Already on the Defensive Takes Another Hit With Guilty Verdict
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  At midday on Tuesday, President Bush ushered two top aides into the Oval Office to watch an unhappy moment for his administration play out on live television: the first felony conviction of a member of his inner circle.

title: Israel Arrests 18 in Crackdown
description: JERUSALEM, March 7  Israeli forces arrested 18 suspected militants in a raid on the Palestinian Authoritys military intelligence headquarters near Ramallah early today, in what appears to be a growing security crackdown in the West Bank.

title: Spitzers Budget Plan Called Hurtful to City
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs budget director mounted a blistering attack on Gov. Eliot Spitzers proposed state budget yesterday, asserting that it would create an $862 million shortfall in the New York City budget for the fiscal year that starts on July 1.

title: Cost to Operate S.I. Ferries Soared Over the Last 5 Years
description: New York Citys operating costs for the Staten Island ferry system have more than doubled in five years, largely because of reforms instituted after a deadly October 2003 crash, according to a report released yesterday.

title: Vermont Wants You to Fill Its Open Spaces
description: NORTH FERRISBURG, Vt.

title: Nets Cant Stop Dallas From 16th Straight Win
description: DALLAS, March 6  At this point in the season, the Nets tolerance for consolation prizes is as low as their margin for error.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about an investigation into stock sales and accounting errors at the New Century Financial Corporation misspelled the name of the company that had collected data on the sale of stock by New Century executives. It is Thomson Financial, not Thompson.

title: Mets Rookie Uses All the Angles to Disguise Pitches
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., March 6  On one of the first nights of the rest of his baseball life, Joe Smith returned home from practice at Wright State and practiced some more. Sitting in front of his television, Smith popped in a baseball video game and for the next few hours studied Chad Bradfords submarine-style delivery.

title: Bills on Workers Aid and Civil Confinement Pass
description: ALBANY, March 6  The New York State Legislature passed a bill on Tuesday that would bring about a sweeping overhaul of the states workers compensation system. The State Assembly also passed a measure that would establish procedures to confine sex offenders civilly after their prison sentences, following the Senates passage of the same bill on Monday.

title: Manhattan: Call for More City Housing Lawyers
description: The New York City public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum, testified yesterday that the citys housing agency was overwhelmed by its responsibility to enforce housing maintenance code violations and protect tenants from irresponsible landlords and needed to be able to hire more lawyers to take building owners to court. Speaking at a City Council committee hearing on the budget for the Department of Housing Preservation and Development, Ms. Gotbaum said the agency had fewer than 40 lawyers to handle 12,662 court cases the agency initiated in the 2005 fiscal year. While few tenants can afford lawyers, most landlords can, she said. The result is that the deck is stacked against tenants, she said. A spokesman for Ms. Gotbaum said she was calling for a doubling of the current number of housing litigation lawyers, with the cost covered by the additional revenue collected as a result of taking owners to court.

title: Powerful Governor Stands His Ground, Again, on Food Tax
description: JACKSON, Miss., March 1  The shoppers at the no-frills Brookshires supermarket  plate lunches $4.49, food stamps gladly accepted  have no doubt: swapping the nations highest state grocery tax for one of its lowest cigarette taxes is an excellent idea, and fie on the governor who opposes it.

title: Born of Post-9/11 Hopes, Restaurant Struggles to Fill Tables
description: In the aftermath of 9/11, it was a venture born of tragedy and idealism. Former workers at Windows on the World, the restaurant atop the World Trade Center where 73 employees were killed, decided to start their own restaurant.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A grouping of pictures on Sunday with an article about fears for the safety of the Wolf Creek Dam on Lake Cumberland in South Central Kentucky carried an erroneous credit for the photograph of Willis McClure, who lives near the dam. The photographer was Alan Poizner for The New York Times, not Josh Anderson of The Times.

title: Trans Fat Fight Claims Butter as a Victim
description: MATTHEW REICH is a baker dedicated to natural ingredients. He prefers butter in the cookies and brioche he turns out at Tom Cat Bakery in Long Island City, Queens, and like many professional cooks he applauds the public health effort to get artificial trans fat out of food.

title: Sony to Add Online Bells and Whistles for PlayStation 3
description: Moving to enhance its PlayStation 3 game console, Sony today plans to announce new online capabilities for it, meant to draw gamers into Sonys cyberspace community and allow them to share entertainment content they have created,  la YouTube.

title: It Takes More Than Veggies to Make a Kitchen Green
description: PETER HOFFMAN runs Savoy, a restaurant in Manhattan that specializes in seasonal food from local farms. But for as much attention as he pays to organic food and the politics of sustainable agriculture, another aspect of environmentalism eludes him. He has not found a way to keep the kitchen both clean and green.

title: Britain: Parts Maker Acquired
description: Meggitt, a British engineering and manufacturing company, agreed to buy K&F Industries Holdings of White Plains, N.Y., for $1.1 billion. Meggitt, which specializes in aerospace, military and electronics products, will pay $27 a share of K&F, or 10 percent above the stocks closing price on Monday. K&F makes aircraft wheels, brake systems and other parts.

title: The Power of Governors (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article by Reuters in Business Day yesterday about a report that concluded that Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, acted in good faith in selling assets of the Starr Foundation, a nonprofit organization started by the founder of A.I.G., misstated the source of the report. It was by an independent committee appointed by the foundation, not by the foundation itself.

title: Massachusetts: Arrests Over Workers
description: The owner of a New Bedford leather company that won more than $90 million in Defense Department contracts was arrested on charges of hiring illegal immigrants. The owner, Francesco Insolia, 50, and three employees of the company, Michael Bianco Inc., about 60 miles south of Boston, were arrested after federal agents raided the company. The owner of a nearby record shop was arrested on charges that he had provided fraudulent Social Security numbers and other documents to the workers. Calls for comment to the leather company and the record shop went unanswered.

title: Hearings Set on Status of Detainees
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  The Pentagon said on Tuesday that it planned to begin hearings this week on the status of 14 prisoners who were transferred from secret prisons to the military prison at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Queens: Wind Damage Causes Delays on No. 7 Line
description: A portion of the roof overhang that sheltered a platform of the elevated subway station at 82nd Street in Jackson Heights, Queens, blew onto the tracks yesterday, fouling service on the No. 7 line. The roof section, made of metal and wood, blew onto the Manhattan-bound tracks at 9:47 a.m., according to New York City Transit. It caused delays in service, and for much of the day Manhattan-bound trains ran on the express track from Main Street-Flushing to 61st Street-Woodside. Regular service resumed about 3:30 p.m., but last night the Manhattan-bound platform at 82nd Street was still closed for repairs, officials said. New York City Transit said no one was hurt when the roof section blew down. Much of the No. 7 line has been shut down on weekends for track and signal work.

title: NATO Mounts Largest Attack on Taliban in the South
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 6  In its largest offensive since taking command of southern Afghanistan last year, NATO mounted an attack against hundreds of Taliban and foreign insurgents in Helmand Province on Tuesday, military officials said.

title: What About ... Dating? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: To Settle Suit, Maker Agrees to Withdraw Growth Drug
description: A drug to spur growth in extremely short children will be removed from the market to settle patent infringement charges, the companies involved in the dispute announced last night.

title: Earthquakes Shake Sumatra, Killing at Least 70
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 6  Two powerful inland earthquakes rattled the Indonesian island of Sumatra on Tuesday, leveling hundreds of buildings and killing at least 70 people, according to government officials in Jakarta.

title: Leaders Try to Get House Democrats Together on Measures to End Iraq War
description: WASHINGTON, March 6  House Democratic leaders on Tuesday implored their rank and file to stick together as the debate intensified over the financing and direction of the Iraq war, saying a fractured party would impede the overarching goal of bringing the conflict to a close.

title: In 05 Investing, Obama Took Same Path as Donors
description: Less than two months after ascending to the United States Senate, Barack Obama bought more than $50,000 worth of stock in two speculative companies whose major investors included some of his biggest political donors.

title: Suspect Arraigned in Connection With Newark Officers Death
description: NEWARK, March 6  Shaking and at once scared and frustrated, the man charged in connection with the death of a Newark police officer on Saturday appeared in court on Tuesday morning.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about new ventures in online social networking for the workplace misstated the number of employees of Cisco Systems, which is reportedly acquiring technology to provide such services. It is 55,000, not 38,000. The article also misspelled the surname of the founder of a company called Crowd Factory, which designs social networks for large companies. He is Alex Mouldovan, not Muldoven.

title: From Ivy Cellar, Princeton Coach Calls for Time
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 6  For the longest time, a Penn-Princeton game meant Ivy League basketball at its best. Fierce rivals, the two have dominated the league for the better part of four decades, and their on-court battles have usually decided which team would go to the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Buyout Bid Becomes Proxy Fight
description: Whats the phrase that pays? Elvis Duran, a disc jockey on Z100, has been asking listeners for years on his radio show in New York before offering them $10,000 for the right answer.

title: Venture Capitalists Want to Put Some Algae in Your Tank
description: NILAND, Calif.  The idea of replacing crude oil with algae may seem like a harebrained way to clean up the planet and bolster national security.

title: Immigrants and the Law (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Some Like It Hot (He Likes It Steaming)
description: Its the heat and the humidity. Alexander Frater settles that question early on in Tales From the Torrid Zone as he wanders, in seven-league boots, across the earths fat, sweaty midsection, swatting flies and mosquitoes all the way. Thats not even the half of it. Along with the palm trees and the beaches and the relentless heat, the tropics also feature extreme weather, geological instability and a whole host of ghastly afflictions, Mr. Frater writes.

title: Productivity Is Less Than Estimated, and Pay Is Higher
description: Businesses spent more compensating their workers in the final three months of the year but got less productivity out of them, revised government data showed today.

title: Spreading Their Gospel on the Web
description: CO-OP AMERICA, a nonprofit group in Washington that promotes environmental sustainability, publishes the National Green Pages, a directory of environmentally conscious businesses. It has a print circulation of 100,000.

title: Friend of Nature? Lets See Those Shoes.
description: WHEN thinking about their contribution to global warming, concerned citizens might consider the cars they drive, the air miles they log and the energy they burn in their homes. But few would look at the shoes they wear or the food they eat.

title: A Doctors Surprise Case: His Lieutenants Wife
description: Set in 1987, in the waning years of Communist Yugoslavia, Rajko Grlics Border Post is a profane and playful military drama about boredom, duty and the consequences of reckless lust.

title: Put Me Out There, Coach. Im Ready to Sing.
description: After missing two concerts in his Carnegie Hall Perspectives series because of illness, Thomas Quasthoff is back in town and, judging from his expansive master class in German art song at Zankel Hall on Monday, he is energetic and robust. He didnt do any singing, beyond illustrating points he made as he coached six of his students from the Hanns Eisler School of Music in Berlin. For that, you have to turn up at his program of jazz standards tonight at Carnegie Hall.

title: Correction: Food Stuff
description: A report in the Food Stuff column last Wednesday, about young chefs who received the top rating of three stars in the current Michelin guide to restaurants in France, referred imprecisely to Anne-Sophie Pic, the chef at Pic in Valence. Although she is the only female chef in France who now has three stars, she is not the only female chef in Europe with three stars. Five three-star restaurants in Italy and Spain are run by women.

title: On the Fence
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Pickup Pix
description: Great lines at even greater prices.

title: Makers of Sodas Try a New Pitch: Theyre Healthy
description: Coca-Colas chief executive insisted at a recent conference that his diet products should be included in the health and wellness category because, with few or no calories, they are a logical answer to expanding waistlines.

title: Deep Powder
description: In one day, the Ski Utah Interconnect Adventure Tour will take you to six resorts in the deep powder of the Wasatch Range in Utah.

title: Personal Best
description: Set the bar high in classic 30s-inspired sportswear. And let the games begin.

title: Club Med
description: Membership has its privileges, as well as a look.

title: Slim Suits
description: The contemporary mans suit.

title: A Deadly Blaze
description: A house fire in the Bronx left a community in mourning.

title: Downhill in a Front Row Seat
description: Gear test with Hugh Johnson of Smugglers' Notch Resort.

title: Spring Movie Preview
description: A look at select movies coming to theaters this spring.

title: A Story of Survival of the Fittest
description: If you have been to restaurants on the affluent west side of Los Angeles, where the bar is made of slate and the lighting is low, and you have observed, with a vague sense of pity, pretty ciphers in charmeuse dresses, then Los Angeles will tell you nothing you do not already know about the atrocities that Hollywood inflicts on young women. And it will leave you feeling as distraught as you might if you had missed an especially good sale.

title: An End Tale, Through the Eyes of Saramago
description: Joe Tantalo, the artistic director of Godlight Theater Company, has a knack for dystopian allegory. His adaptations of A Clockwork Orange in 2003 and Fahrenheit 451 in 2006 were surprisingly sharp-edged, breathing vivid theatrical life into sprawling material on tiny stages. Now he has turned his talents to Blindness, the best-selling 1998 novel by the Nobel Prize-winning Portuguese writer, Jos Saramago, and the results are more mixed.

title: Swindlers With a Sense of Style
description: According to the legendary swindler Black Pearl (Ella Bole), criminals have two effective options: the counterfeit game and the mayhem game. The first requires precision and subtlety, while the second, an often bloodier brand of scam, relies on manufacturing a certain kind of havoc. Or as she describes it: total vulnerability followed by utter discombobulation.

title: Rite of Passage
description: Cecelia Nealon-Shapiro, who was adopted from a Chinese orphanage 13 years ago, is one of the first of those adopted girls to complete the rite of passage into Jewish womanhood.

title: Brecht, and Gender, at Play
description: Any production of Baal, Bertolt Brechts first play, is an act of courage. Written in 1918 before Brecht became Brecht  the sometimes reluctant proxy of a party line  it is a great play that has offended many people. Among the offended was the author, who, after his turn to Marxism years later, was disgusted by the works supposedly irresponsible romanticism and rewrote it as a tedious allegory about asocial behavior.

title: Answering the Evils of Genocide
description: Goodness, Michael Redhills gripping and important play about genocide, brings to mind Bertolt Brecht, who stripped away theatrical illusion so that the viewer could empathize with human suffering but also observe the cruelty of the historical and social forces that drive our interactions. Brechts plays were often epic extravaganzas, but Goodness, with its bare stage and few props, has the intimacy and discordant reach of a late Beethoven string quartet.

title: Glu Mobile Sets I.P.O. Price Range
description: Glu Mobile, the publisher of mobile phone games such as Deer Hunter and Diner Dash, set a price range of $10 to $12 a share on Tuesday for its proposed initial public offering and said it plans to offer 7.3 million shares. The companys backers include the Silicon Valley venture firm New Enterprise Associates.

title: Worrying About Wall Street
description: The top five Wall Street investment banks have lost a combined $40 billion in market value in the past few weeks as shareholders have fretted about subprime mortgages. That seems like an extreme overreaction, but it might not be if the troubles spill into the broader market, Breakingviews writes.

title: For Citigroups Prince, a Big Bet on Japan
description: Citigroups $10.8 billion takeover bid for Japans third-largest brokerage firm, Nikko Cordial, is an important step for Citigroups chairman and chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, who is under intense pressure from investors to deliver on his strategy of internal and international growth. Yet the deal still faces hurdles: Nikkos largest shareholder rejected Citis bid as too low.

title: Chief Sees Difficulties in Splitting Off Chrysler Brands
description: The chief executive of DaimlerChrysler, Dieter Zetsche, said on Tuesday that it would be difficult to break up Chrysler, as analysts and other experts have speculated recently, because of an integrated production system that binds together its various brands. Chrysler Group is very integrated, Mr. Zetsche told The New York Times at the Geneva Motor Show. The technical lines, like platforms, do not go along the same lines as the brands. The less they are aligned with the brands, the more difficult it would be to think of any separation.

title: Venezuela Disavows 1980s-Era Bonds
description: The plot would seem to come right out of a novel in which the reader does not know whom to believe.

title: F.C.C. Chief Questions Satellite Radio Deal
description: Mel Karmazin, whom The New York Times Richard Siklos described as a man who could sell microwavable ice to Eskimos, has apparently not sold Kevin J. Martin, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, on his plan to merge the nations two satellite radio companies.

title: BP Cuts Bonus in Half for Outgoing Executive
description: The energy company BP cut the 2006 bonus of John Browne, its departing chief executive, almost in half for a year when the company reported record earnings but faced accusations that cost-cutting led to safety lapses at a plant in Texas.

title: DayJet Lands $50 Million in Funding
description: DayJet, one of a handful of companies planning air taxi service using low-cost jets, announced a $50 million round of financing on Tuesday earmarked for getting its service off the ground. The company, which has now raised $68 million in equity financing, did not disclose terms of the funding or list participants, other than to say the group included eight institutions, private equity funds and angel investors.

title: Qantas Buyout Clears Significant Hurdle
description: The consortium behind the 11.2 billion Australian dollars ($8.7 billion) buyout proposal for Qantas Airwaysmoved closer to closing the deal Tuesday when the Australian government said it would not oppose the transaction. The government was under immense pressure from unions, politicians and members of the public to veto the takeover under its foreign investment laws, as it had done in 2001 when Royal Dutch Shell bid 10 billion Australian dollars for Woodside Petroleum.

title: Texas Pacific and Cerberus Jockey for VHS Inventor
description: The Texas Pacific Group and Cerberus Capital Management have emerged as front-runners in the race to take over the struggling Japanese consumer electronics maker JVC, formally known as the Victor Company of Japan, and are expected to submit formal bids this week, The Deal.com reported.

title: Chinese Video Site Downloads $23 Million from U.S. Investors
description: A group of venture capital firms in the United States, including the investment arm of the Walt Disney Company, was set to announce Wednesday that it had invested $23.5 million in UUSee, a major Chinese site for Web video, The Associated Press reported. The report said that Draper Fisher Jurvetson and Highland Capital Partners led the round, which also included Steamboat Ventures, Disneys venture-capital vehicle.

title: V.C.s Ante Up for a Mature Social Networking Site
description: Eons, the media company and social networking Web site designed for the 50-plus demographic and launched by Monster Worldwide founder Jeff Taylor, has received $22 million in its second round of funding to accelerate growth, the company said on Tuesday. The latest round was led by Charles River Ventures, with participation from new investors Intel Capital and Humana, as well as existing investors General Catalyst Partners and Sequoia Capital.

title: Will Citadel Be Next to Storm the Market?
description: After the solid opening of the Fortress Investment Group, the first hedge-fund manager in the United States to test the public markets, industry watchers have been wondering: Whos next? A report in The Chicago Tribune suggests that some analysts and industry players are betting that the Citadel Investment Group, which has about $13 billion in assets, will take the leap.

title: Comerica Leaves Detroit for Dallas
description: Comerica, a financial services company with assets of $58 billion, said on Tuesday that it would move its headquarters to Dallas from Detroit, dealing another blow to a city already reeling from the loss of thousands of auto jobs. Comerica said it generated much of its business in the large, fast-growing Southern states. Moving our corporate headquarters will give us greater proximity to all of our markets, and the additional resources in these markets will lead to accelerated growth, said the chief executive, Ralph W. Babb Jr.

title: Movie Gallery Buys Video-On-Demand Service
description: Movie Gallery said Wednesday it would acquire MovieBeam, an on-demand movie service backed by Disney, Intel and Cisco Systems. Financial terms were not disclosed, but Movie Gallery said in a press release that it expected the total related expense, including the initial acquisition cost and any ongoing development expenses, to be less than $10 million in 2007.

title: Lawyers Make Hay Out of Hedge Fund Activism
description: Activist and dissident shareholders, particularly hedge funds, are increasing corporate legal work as boards of directors cope with demands from sophisticated investors and proxy contests when those investors seek a board seat, according to The National Law Journal. The report notes that as directors are increasingly confronted by sophisticated activist shareholders with their own legal advisers, they are relying on advice from the companys outside lawyers.

title: Private Equity Firms Face Deadline for J Sainsbury
description: The consortium of private equity groups stalking the British supermarket chain J Sainsbury has six weeks to come up with a bid or walk away. The ultimatum, known in Britain as a put-up-or-shut-up deadline, was imposed by Britains Takeover Panel after the supermarket group appealed for a ruling.

title: More Banks Entangled In Subprime Loans, Report Says
description: The Swiss bank UBS said it had exposure to the troubled United States subprime lender New Century Financial, becoming the latest European bank to become embroiled in the mortgage market in the United States, Reuters reported. A spokesman for the Swiss bank confirmed to Reuters the existence of a loan, but declined to quantify it. I can only say the facility is secured, the spokesman said.

title: Goldman May Bid for Canadian Movie Fund, Analyst Says
description: Goldman Sachs is expected to bid for the Movie Distribution Income Fund of Canada after the close of a proposed takeover of Alliance Atlantis Communications worth 2.3 billion Canadian dollars ($2 billion), an analyst said Tuesday. The offer for the trusts units is likely to be in the $9 to $10 range, the analyst, Andy Nasr of Raymond James, told The Globe and Mail. The income fund owns a 49 percent stake in Canadas largest movie distributor, Motion Picture Distribution, and Alliance owns the rest.

title: Copyfight: Microsoft Takes Shot at Google
description: Lobbing the equivalent of a Molotov cocktail into the copyfight over intellectual property in the digital age, an associate general counsel at Microsoft, Thomas Rubin, issued a scathing attack on Google in remarks prepared for a conference of the Association of American Publishers.

title: Zells Tribune Bid Gains Traction, Report Says
description: Samuel Zell, the Chicago real estate magnate who made a fortune by turning around distressed properties, has emerged as a strong contender to buy Tribune, according to a report in The Los Angeles Times. Mr. Zells bid for Tribune, which also owns The Los Angeles Times and the Chicago Cubs baseball team, is getting serious consideration because it could buy out the disgruntled Chandler family of California and take the company private, the newspaper said. That scenario is attractive to Tribune management because it would remove the company from the pressure of Wall Street investors.

title: Taking Old Memories Digital
description: The Sony DVDirect turns your old home video tapes into DVDs.

title: Carrefours Chair Resigns, Rekindling Buyout Chatter
description: Talk that Europes largest retailer is a takeover target has intensified on news that Carrefours chairman resigned at a board meeting on Wednesday and that the French billionaire Bernard Arnault and the buyout firm Colony Capital have taken a 9.8 percent stake, valued at about 4 billion euro ($5.2 billion). in the company.

title: Texas State Senator Seeks to Rein In TXU
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and its investor group are overpaying in their proposed buyout of TXU, the Texas energy giant, based on what TXU made by overcharging customers, Texas state senator Troy Fraser told The Deal in an interivew. Mr. Fraser cowrote the law that deregulated the Texas utility industry in 1999.

title: Looking for Globalization? Follow the Money
description: Is the world round after all? Writing on Foreign Policy magazines Web site, Pankaj Ghemawat of Harvard Business School takes issue with the prevailing wisdom that our technological age is making national borders and geography irrelevant. He feels that such arguments are simply the latest in a series of exaggerated visions that also include the end of history and the convergence of tastes  that arent backed up by the data.One favorite mantra from globalization champions is how investment knows no boundaries. But how much of all the capital being invested around the world is conducted by companies outside of their home countries? The fact is, the total amount of the worlds capital formation that is generated from foreign direct investment (FDI) has been less than 10 percent for the last three years for which data are available (200305). In other words, more than 90 percent of the fixed investment around the world is still domestic. And though merger waves can push the ratio higher, it has never reached 20 percent. In a thoroughly globalized environment, one would expect this number to be much higherabout 90 percent, by my calculation. And FDI isnt an odd or unrepresentative example.

title: Around the neighborhood
description: Links to a roundup of real estate news:

title: Currents
description: Coming to Boca Raton, futurism at the beach, wallpaper by working gerbils and other artists, jewelry, furnishings and more.

title: New York Makes Barbecue Its Own
description: A few years ago, I went to see Robb Walsh when he came through town on a book tour. Robb is the restaurant critic for The Houston Press. Hes the author of The Tex Mex Cookbook. Hes the founder and head judge of a hot sauce competition in Austin. The guy knows Texas food.

title: Guessing games on a Formula One champion to be
description: In this short period between the last days of winter testing and the first race of the season next week at the Australian Grand Prix in Melbourne on March 18, the race is on to predict who the next world champion will be. Actually, there are discussions of a few more angles than just that, and from every quarter.

title: Yes, Those Were the Days
description: Three years ago I said some pessimistic things on TV about the war in Iraq. Scooter Libby called the next day. Methodically, though with a touch of wryness in his voice, he ran down a list of the hopeful developments he thought I was ignoring. Then as we were signing off, he interrupted himself and said: Anyway, thats the positive spin. I can do the negative spin just as well.

title: White House Gloom
description: No matter which way you turn this week, the White House does seem as though it has fallen under a cloud, or rather, shadowed by a darkly overcast sky. And were not talking about the lionesque March weather this week, what with its wild winds one day and light snow falling from a gray canopy today.

title: Personal Shopper
description: Whimsy and environmental awareness jockey for attention in a benefit's place settings.

title: 2008: Primary Maneuvers
description: Californias effort to move its primary from June to February moved one step closer to the goal on Tuesday when the State Assembly approved the bill. Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger is expected to sign it. The Washington Times is reporting that Senator John McCains campaign is mounting a stealth effort to change Republican presidential nomination rules in California to allow independents to vote in the Feb. 5 primary. The move could hurt Mitt Romney, who is running as a traditional conservative, and help Mr. McCain and Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Playing Hardball at Take Two Interactive
description: An investor group that includes several high-powered hedge funds wants to take the wheel at Take Two Interactive Software, the video-game publisher best known for its graphic Grand Theft Auto series.

title: YouTube Banned in Turkey After Insults to Ataturk
description: Elsewhere on the tech front this morning, it seems a Turkish court has ordered that access to the video sharing site YouTube be blocked for citizens in that country, owing to some videos available on the site that are insulting to the nations modern founder, Mustafa Kemal Ataturk.

title: Dancin in Denton
description: A quick review of last night before we dive headfirst into the Big East Tournament here.

title: Clear Channel Feud May Signal Buyout Booms Future
description: The $18.7 billion buyout of Clear Channel Communications, the nations largest radio broadcaster, has become a test of wills between some of the nations largest investors, like the mutual fund giant Fidelity Investments, which plans to vote against the deal, contending it severely undervalues its shares, and the two private equity bidders, Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital, The New York Times writes.

title: Telefnica Is Said to Pass on Telecom Italia Stake
description: Telefnicahas abandoned the idea of buying a minority stake in Telecom Italia and forming a strategic alliance, The Financial Times reported Wednesday. Telefnica, which is based in Madrid, said last week that talks with Telecom Italia were on hold, but unidentified sources told the Financial Times that Telefnica was dropping the idea of buying a stake or establishing an alliance. Prospects for a future bid have been abandoned for the foreseeable future, the sources said.

title: After Libby Trial, Provocative Punditry
description: Even if the four guilty verdicts of the Scooter Libby trial came as a surprise, most of the reactions in the blogosphere were disappointingly predictable. Still, as always on the Web, if you poke around hard enough, you can find a brave few willing to give the conventional wisdom a poke in the eye.

title: Countdown to a Garden Party
description: A biting winter wind last night has given way to some type of wintry mix for Day 1 of the Big East tournament. Its downright frigid in New York, the only kind of weather that one can expect for this tournament.

title: Thousands of House Plans
description: After quickly coming to the conclusion that we couldnt design our own house, Paul and I needed a Plan B.

title: Sting Uncovers Illegal Military Equipment Sales  to Museums
description: A 17-month investigation into the possible sale of jet-fighter parts to Iran has uncovered startling evidence that four whole F-14 Tomcat fighter jets  you know, the kind featured in the film Top Gun  changed hands on the black market in the late 1990s for less that $4,000 apiece.

title: Clearwires I.P.O. Finally Goes Live
description: Clearwire, the wireless Internet company founded by cellphone pioneer Craig McCaw, is hoping to raise $500 million in its initial public offering Wednesday, one of the biggest of the year. The company, based in Kirkland, Wash., plans to sell 20 million shares at $23 to $25 each, with an additional 3 million shares in reserve should demand prove heavy.

title: Bobo in Paradise
description: Observe the species at play, dressed for his unnatural habitat in rich, neo-peacenik threads.

title: $1,000,000 Homes
description: Tour a condo in Savannah, Ga., and houses in Santa Fe, N.M., and Sonoma, Calif.

title: Curating Cool
description: Nina Garduno makes L.A. men more fashionable - in spite of themselves.

title: Are Some Stock Analysts Rewriting History?
description: We thought it was dead, but the controversy over a widely used database of Wall Street research has popped up again. The debate began last fall when a group of researchers questioned the integrity of Thomson Financials I/B/E/S service, a clearinghouse of analysts stock picks. The researchers appeared to backtrack after Thomson disputed their methodology, but last month they published the paper and are standing by its conclusions.

title: The New Collectibles
description: To have and to hold on to.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Wednesday about an appearance by Mario M. Cuomo and Newt Gingrich at Cooper Union's Great Hall in which they encouraged politicians to engage in serious discussions along the lines of Abraham Lincoln's notable speech at Cooper Union misspelled the given name of a photographer known for his famous portrait of Lincoln. He was Mathew Brady, not Matthew.

title: Red Sox vs. Mets 2.0
description: I pulled up to City of Palms park around 9:45 this morning and, aside from the throngs of red-clad Boston fans clamoring for a glimpse of Dice-K, one of the first things I noticed was vending machines selling copies of the Boston Globeand Boston Herald. Anyone looking for the latest Dustin Pedroia or Manny Delcarmen injury news (or Manny or Schilling or Ortiz or J.D. Drew) need not look far, thats for sure.

title: Spam Before the Upper West Side Storm
description: The report in the print edition this morning on the stormy hearing  before Community Board 7  did not have room to capture the full flavor and drama of the event, or the days leading up to it.

title: And the Band Played On
description: The afternoon crowd is beginning to trickle into the Garden as Villanova and DePaul are underway. Were live from court side, sitting directly across from a scowling Gary DeCesare, the Blue Demon associate head coach.

title: Signals of Distress in Europe Seen in Banks Hiring Trend
description: Are the big investment banks seeing distress signals in Europe? They could be, according to Financial News, which sees a larger trend in Morgan Stanleys recent hiring of a top European restructuring banker. The article describes a renewed scramble by investment banks and hedge funds to hire high-yield and distressed-debt traders before a downturn in the credit market, which, if it were to happen, is likely to trigger a wave of defaults and bankruptcies. Activity on that front has been low lately.

title: Britain to Put Private Equity in the Hotseat
description: Even as a collection of private equity firms are circling the United Kingdoms largest supermarket chain  and perhaps partly because they are circling it  Britains Parliament is preparing to conduct an inquiry into the private equity business. At issue: asset-stripping, short-termism and complaints that there is a general lack of accountability for private equity funds, which usually buy public companies in debt-financed deals in hopes of selling them or taking them public later at a profit.

title: Pataki to Join Chadbourne
description: New Yorks former governor, George E. Pataki and his chief of staff, John P. Cahill, will join Chadbourne & Parke as counsel in its energy, environmental and corporate practices, the New York law firm said Wednesday. In a statement, Chadbourne emphasized the interest by Mr. Pataki, Mr. Cahill and the firm in the renewable energy sector.

title: Forgoing Pork, Pig-Style
description: There were some pigs on the Hill today. Were not being snarky or nastywere being literal.

title: All Aboard the McCain Express
description: The Straight Talk Express is coming back.

title: Big East Action  Physical, a Bit Ugly, Hotly Contested
description: The DePaul Coach Jerry Wainwright slammed his right palm against the scorers table with just under two minutes to go. A few seconds later, he buried his head in his hands as if he had a searing migraine headache. He paced the sideline. He shook his head in disgust.

title: Document: Judges Great Lawn Ruling
description: The dispute over the mayors decision to refuse to allow a political protest on the Great Lawn in Central Park during the Republican National Convention is headed to a jury trial, as we reported this morning. For the document wonks, heres the judges ruling. [pdf]

title: A Job for Pataki
description: No, its not in Washington.

title: Villanova Injury Update
description: With Syracuse and Connecticut about to start what seems like their annual Big East tournament game, heres a few quick postgame notes from Villanova-DePaul:

title: Syracuses New Duds
description: Two quick observations from the start of Syracuse-UConn: The talk of the Garden is Syracuses new uniforms, which have a lycra look to them. Also, the Syracuse center Darryl Watkins had two giant blocks of the Connecticut center Hasheem Thabeet in the first three minutes. That bodes well for Syracuse when Watkins comes to play. UConn leads 8-5. More at halftime.

title: An Immodest Proposal for Barnes & Noble
description: Barnes & Noble has been bandied about as a potentially tempting takeover candidate, with private equity firms considered the likeliest acquirers. But George Gutowski, a financial writer posting on SeekingAlpha, has an outlandish idea for a hypothetical deal: He is suggesting that Amazon.com, the online retailing giant, scrape together a few billion dollars to buy the bookseller for itself.

title: Consol Energy
description: An ad for Consol Energy.

title: Obama on Those Stocks
description: Senator Barack Obama faced a barrage of questions today following the article by our Chris Drew and Mike McIntire this morning.

title: Troubled Astronaut Fired From NASA
description: In a statement posted to its Web site, NASA effectively terminated astronaut Lisa Nowak, whose widely publicized, lovelorn road-trip across three southern states culminated last month with her arrest on charges of attempted kidnapping and attempted murder.

title: Rite of Passage
description: Cece Nealon-Shapiro is one of many girls adopted from China who are now turning 13 and celebrating a bat mitzvah.

title: The Real Cost of War
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Mar. 7 column, Dont Ask, Dont Know, Dont Help.

title: SU-UConn at the Half
description: The Garden is starting to fill up with a little energy after a back-and-forth first half between Syracuse and Connecticut. The Huskies lead the Orange 38-36, as theyve played fairly sharp. The freshman guard Jerome Dyson is leading the Huskies with 12 points. A.J. Price has nine for UConn and six assists, including the defining play of the first half  an alleyoop pass to Marcus Johnson for a dunk on the fastbreak.

title: Ex-Yankee Alert
description: The last game at Legends Field brought us a typically entertaining visit from the former Yankee Gary Sheffield, now with the Detroit Tigers. For tonights game, the Cincinnati Reds are bringing several important former Yankees, too.

title: Curling, the New Golf?
description: David Grandeau, the head of the state lobbying commission, called a while ago to say he thought this post yesterday was unfair.

title: Autopsy: Crash Killed the Music, Not Gunshot
description: One of the enduring bits of lore surrounding what Don McLean famously dubbed the day the music died  that is, the plane crash that claimed the lives of J.P. Big Bopper Richardson (think: Chantilly Lace), Buddy Holly and Richie Valens, as well as the pilot on Feb. 3, 1959  has involved a gun.

title: Hagel Drops Hints for Monday
description: For months, Senator Chuck Hagel has been flirting with the idea of seeking the 2008 Republican presidential nomination. While other Republican candidates have crisscrossed the country  from Iowa to New Hampshire and back again  Mr. Hagel has largely stayed in Washington.

title: Positive First Step for Syracuse
description: No. 5 seeded Syracuse dusted No. 12 Connecticut, 78-65, in the first round of the Big East Tournament, extending their tournament win streak to eight games. A victory over No. 4 seed Notre Dame on Thursday would tie Connecticuts Big East record for consecutive tournament wins. In doing so, the Orange (22-9) showcased maturation thats allowed them to win six of their past seven games.

title: Music Video: Kaki King
description: A video of "Playing With Pink Noise" by Kaki King.

title: Blogtalk
description: Trial balloon: Senator Martin Golden  for mayor? [Capitol Confidential]

title: Homecoming
description: Todays game between Villanova and DePaul featured five players from New York City. Curtis Sumpter, who scored 25 points, is from Brooklyn and attended Bishop Loughlin High school. Sammy Mejia, who led DePaul with 20 points, is from the Bronx and attended Roosevelt High School.

title: Coda: The Blog Remains the Same
description: Gentle readers, could you have a seat? Some housekeeping.

title: Document: City Fights Police Ruling
description: Lawyers for the city have asked a federal judge to reconsider a sweeping ruling last month that ordered the New York Police Department to stop routine videotaping of public gatherings, saying he lacked the power to make the ruling and suggesting that it would hurt efforts to deter terrorism.

title: $49 Million Left on the Table
description: New York may look like geniuses, Representative Jos Serrano said today, because the state did not buy electronic voting machines before the 2006 midterm elections. After problems in Maryland and Florida, a renewed push for a paper trail is prompting states that did invest in those systems to look for new options.While avoiding buyers remorse might seem smart, losing about $49 million in federal funds might not seem so. New York missed the deadline [$-TimesSelect] to replace its lever and punch card voting systems by the September 2006 primary. So the Election Assistance Commission is set to reclaim the funds, given to states under the Help America Vote Act of 2002.

title: Nevada, Netroots and Fox
description: The lib-blogs are stirring up a little trouble for Democrats in Nevada, a new early powerhouse with its Democratic caucus sandwiched alongside Iowa and New Hampshire (at least for now).

title: Country Road to the Dance?
description: After trailing by as many as seven points in the first half, West Virginia finished by hitting three 3-pointers in the final three minutes to go ahead of Providence 40-32. Of all the teams searching for N.C.A.A. bids here in New York this week, there may not be a pairing featuring two more desperate teams.

title: 36 Hours in Nairobi
description: Nairobi's colonial history, as well as its abundance of wildlife, cuisine and shopping, make it a great place for a weekend adventure.

title: High School Girls' Weightlifting
description: Girls' weightlifting, a high school sport sanctioned only in Florida, is embraced, improbably, by girls of all shapes, sizes and athletic abilities.

title: Wikipedia Celebrates 750 Years of American Independence
description: Here at Screens, were happy to promote the video adventures of almost anyone  pervs, monks, blasphemers, close family friends. (As loathers of buffering breaks, though, were having a hard time with onBeing.)

title: Clemens Meets Steinbrenner
description: It was probably an innocent meeting. But you never know. The media gets to see a lot here in spring training, but we couldnt witness the most interesting development at Legends Field tonight.

title: Captain America Is Dead; National Hero Since 1941
description: Captain America, a Marvel Entertainment superhero, is fatally shot by a sniper in the 25th issue of the comic, which arrived in stores yesterday. The assassination ends the sentinel of libertys fight for right, which began in 1941.

title: A Neutral Home Court?
description: For the past three seasons, the entire St. Johns program has been pushing toward tonight. The program has endured the N.C.A.A. sanctions, thin roster and embarrassing off-court shenanigans that defined the end of the Mike Jarvis era. But for all thats been written and talked about St. Johns returning to any type of college basketball postseason, there surely wasnt much buzz around the Johnnies in Madison Square Garden tonight.

title: Pac-10 Breakdown
description: The Pacific 10 conference tournament starts tonight at Staples Center in Los Angeles, with California taking on Oregon State and Washington facing Arizona State.

title: From Long Distance
description: No match-up in the first-round of the Big East tournament better epitomized the desperate nature of championship week more than No. 7 seed West Virginias game against No. 10 Providence.

title: Park Has Second Outing, This One With an Umpire
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., March 7  There was nothing simulated about Wednesdays game, nothing minor league about the opposing batters. The Boston Red Sox started David Ortiz, Manny Ramrez and J. D. Drew as part of a representative lineup to greet Chan Ho Park in his first exhibition start since his work visa arrived Tuesday, and  no surprise  he noticed a slight difference.

title: Super-Sized Tuesday
description: The jockeying among states to have early presidential primaries next year has the nations legislatures acting like schoolyard rowdies elbowing one another to get to the front of the line.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. I once saw a crib that converted to a bed with a desk, but cant find it. Can you help?

title: Jay Haley, 83, Pioneer in Family Therapy, Dies
description: Jay Haley, an early theorist of family therapy who in the 1960s advocated hypnosis and deeper social involvement for patients to cure emotional problems more rapidly, died on Feb. 13 at his home in San Diego. He was 83.

title: Nebraska Senator to Announce Monday Whether He Will Run for President
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, who has been one of the fiercest Republican critics of the Iraq war, intends to make clear on Monday whether he will seek his partys 2008 presidential nomination, a spokesman said Wednesday.

title: Bombay Stock Exchange Sells Stake to Singapore Market
description: NEW DELHI, March 7  Inflation fears and volatility are not dampening the expansion plans of stock exchanges in India.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The On Baseball column on Tuesday, about confidence among the Philadelphia Phillies as they prepare for a new season, misstated the circumstances under which they acquired pitcher Freddy Garca during the off-season. It was through a trade with the Chicago White Sox, not by signing him as a free agent.

title: Israelis Arrest 18 Suspects in Raid on Palestinian Site
description: JERUSALEM, March 7  Israeli forces arrested 18 men suspected of being militants in a raid on the Palestinian Authoritys military intelligence headquarters near Ramallah early Wednesday, in what appears to be a growing security clampdown in the West Bank.

title: Dorothy Brown, Who Is Being Evicted
description: A retired school aide, Ms. Brown, 63, told the mayor at the October office-hours session that the police ransacked her apartment after they arrested her grandson in front of her, at her building, on suspicion of selling crack cocaine. She said an officer flew into a rage, breaking a computer, after she asked him to return $6 that she claims he took from the apartment and put in his pocket. The police said they found the drugs in Ms. Browns kitchen, prompting an eviction notice. But Ms. Brown insisted that the police had planted the drugs.

title: Environmental Group Behind the TXU Deal Hires a Banker
description: The environmental movement is about to take a page from Wall Streets deal-making playbook that may give green mail a good name.

title: NASA Fires Arrested Astronaut
description: MIAMI, March 7  Capt. Lisa M. Nowak, accused last month of attacking a romantic rival for the affections of a fellow astronaut, was fired from NASA on Wednesday, agency officials said.

title: 2 Big Issuers to Ease Some Card Penalties
description: WASHINGTON, March 7 (Bloomberg News)  JPMorgan Chase & Company and Citigroup, two of the nations largest credit-card issuers, told Congressional lawmakers on Wednesday that they were changing some cardholder rates and fees that lawmakers say unfairly hurt consumers.

title: S.E.C. and Big Business (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Commons Moves to Erode Nobles Power in Britain
description: LONDON, March 7  After centuries of pageantry and power struggles between the elite and the commoners, the House of Commons voted overwhelmingly on Wednesday to introduce elections to the House of Lords. The move could finally end the tenure of appointed and hereditary peers on the red leather benches of the upper chamber and replace them with elected legislators.

title: Darrin Ruth, Who Needed Help With Collecting Back Pay
description: Mr. Ruth, a former payroll supervisor for the citys office of employment training, attended the office-hours session in November with his 8-year-old son to ask the mayor for a job and the $1,700 in back pay he said never showed up in his final paycheck. A temporary employee who worked in the job for eight months, Mr. Ruth, 46, was let go in November. He told the mayor that the agencys director had advised him to forget about the $1,700, saying, Its lost in a black hole.

title: SUNY Chancellor Will Resign in May
description: John R. Ryan, chancellor of the State University of New York, announced yesterday that he would step down at the end of May to lead a small nonprofit organization.

title: A Graduation Held in Church Leads to a Suit
description: NEWARK, March 7  A Muslim student sued the Newark public schools on Wednesday, claiming that he was unable to attend his high school graduation last June because it was held in a church. The student, Bilal Shareef, 18, said it was against his beliefs to set foot in any building with symbols involving God.

title: Producer for Katie Couric Out at CBS News
description: The shake-ups at the evening newscasts continued last night.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the conviction of I. Lewis Libby Jr. on charges of lying to a grand jury and to F.B.I. agents investigating the leak of the identity of a C.I.A. operative in 2003 misstated the middle initial of the presiding judge in some copies. He is Judge Reggie B. Walton, not Judge Reggie M.

title: Scent Activates Memory During Sleep, Study Says
description: Scientists studying how sleep affects memory have found that the whiff of a familiar scent can help a slumbering brain better remember things that it learned the evening before. A rose bouquet  delivered to peoples nostrils as they studied and, later, as they slept  improved their performance on a memory test by almost 15 percent.

title: In Policy Shift, C-Span Clears Some Clips for Web Use
description: The public affairs cable network C-Span announced yesterday that it was changing its copyright policy to allow noncommercial copying, sharing and posting on the Internet of its coverage of events sponsored by Congress or any federal agency, a decision that covers about 50 percent of its material.

title: In a Global Marketplace, Claiming a Name Becomes an Art in Itself
description: WHEN a snazzy new product goes on sale in many countries, its name must be one of a kind.

title: Japan: Nikko Shareholder Says Bid Is Too Low
description: The largest shareholder in the Nikko Cordial Corporation has rejected a $10.8 billion takeover offer from Citigroup, saying that the price is too low. The shareholder, Harris Associates of Chicago, which manages money for individual and institutional investors, believes that Nikko is worth more than 2,000 yen a share, the chief investment officer, David G. Herro, said. The offer made by Citigroup was for 1,350 yen. The share price of Nikko, which is based in Tokyo, advanced 14 percent before the Citigroup offer was announced on Tuesday and it rose another 1.3 percent yesterday, closing at 1,357 yen a share. Harris owns about 7.5 percent of Nikko.

title: 50 Years Later, Another Look at Saroyans Theater as Haven and Fortress
description: When The Cave Dwellers made its debut, in New York in 1957, it marked the writer William Saroyans return to Broadway after a self-imposed 14-year exile, and the play that resulted from that absence has felt like a pointed re-affirmation of his belief in the power and authenticity of theatrical expression. The rise of the culture of television may have caused Saroyan to see artifice everywhere; in The Cave Dwellers, he seeks above all to revere theater itself, to convince us that it remains the fortress of all the great moral truths.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,171 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Obama Says His Investments Presented No Conflicts of Interest
description: WASHINGTON, March 7  Senator Barack Obama said Wednesday that he did not believe it was a conflict of interest to seek investment advice and use the brokerage services recommended by a friend and political contributor. He said he had not been aware that his broker had invested up to $100,000 in two companies backed by some of his top donors.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Feb. 10 about a site in Brooklyn believed to be the countrys oldest standing piece of a major league ballpark, and an article on Feb. 25 about a new batting statistic to evaluate players misstated the name of a prominent baseball research organization. It is the Society for American Baseball Research; it is neither the Society of American Baseball Research nor the Society of American Baseball Researchers.

title: A Romantic Poets Words Sung in Many Contrasting Moods
description: The poems of Joseph von Eichendorff won the heart of more than one musical Romantic, and the tenor Michael Schade has collected some of the songs set to them. His program at Zankel Hall on a bitterly cold Tuesday night offered Schumann, Mendelssohn, Brahms and Hugo Wolf.

title: Memos Tell Officials How to Discuss Climate
description: Internal memorandums circulated in the Alaskan division of the Federal Fish and Wildlife Service appear to require government biologists or other employees traveling in countries around the Arctic not to discuss climate change, polar bears or sea ice if they are not designated to do so.

title: Attacks on Shiite Pilgrims Continue
description: BAGHDAD, March 7  For the second straight day, insurgents struck at Shiite pilgrims and other civilians across central Iraq on Wednesday, apparently seeking to reignite a cycle of sectarian retribution as hundreds of thousands of Shiites made their pilgrimage to Karbala to commemorate the martyrdom of Imam Hussein.

title: A Rarely Seen Side of a Rauschenberg Shift
description: The transfer drawings that Robert Rauschenberg made in the 1960s are less like works of art than a series of refined filtering systems.
