description: Violent crime rose by double-digit percentages in cities across the country over the last two years, reversing the declines of the mid- to late 1990s, according to a new report by a prominent national law enforcement association.

title: The Suns Mysterious Family
description: I began regular television broadcasting half a century ago, when we knew much less about the universe than we do now. One of my early programs was devoted to Venus, which I described as the planet of mystery. We knew that there was a dense atmosphere, rich in carbon dioxide, but our ignorance of the surface conditions was to all intents and purposes complete. Opinions differed wildly: Venus might be a raging, scorching-hot dust desert; it might be mainly oceanic; the great Cambridge astronomer Fred Hoyle even believed that it had oil wells far richer than those of Iraq or anywhere else on Earth. It was thought that as a potential colony Venus might be much more promising than Mars, a planet that for many years was thought to have canals.

title: Strike a Pose
description: We here at The Bracket will never be mistaken for fashion divas, especially after our new tie was drizzled upon by a mysterious brown liquid from the press room ceiling last night. But it is our job to point out March trends. One of The Brackets scouts texted from Atlanta during the Syracuse game to ask why the Orange assistant coach Rob Murphy was wearing a lavender bow tie. Was it Jim Phelan appreciation night? According to Mike Waters, the long-time Syracuse beat writer, this was the first time that Murphy wore the bow tie this season.

title: Bubble, Meet Air Force. Air Force, Bubble.
description: A year ago, a late-season surge put Air Force on the N.C.A.A. tournament bubble, and a first-round loss to Wyoming in the conference tournament made them one of the more hotly debated teams on Selection Sunday. The committee let them in.

title: Bad Days for El Duque and Sanchez
description: The Mets are not paying Orlando Hernandez $12 million over the next two years to pitch like he did today  5 runs on 6 hits against an Orioles team starting Ruddy Yan, Jon Knott, Adam Donachie, Eider Torres, Brandon Fahey and Chris Gomez  but thats not reason enough to sweat his performance. It was El Duques first spring start and first time pitching against another team since Sept. 28 in Atlanta, and it takes a crafty pitcher like him a little longer to regain the feel of his pitches. The time he lost after being diagnosed with arthritis two weeks ago can be made up over the next three weeks.

title: Factory Girl
description: A few years ago I was awarded a residency in the factories of Germany. Just imagine, every girls dream: a six week all-expense paid trip to Nuremberg, free access to heavy machinery, and the opportunity to observe, experience, and smell the factories of one of Germanys leading industrial cities! For me, it was a thrill. I was fascinated by machine sounds and factory environments, but I never had the chance to witness them first hand. This program, designed to combine art and industry, helped me realize my dream and get my hands and my ears dirty in an industrial environment.

title: Factory Girl
description: A few years ago I was awarded a residency in the factories of Germany. Just imagine, every girl's dream: a six week all-expense paid trip to Nuremberg, free access to heavy machinery, and the opportunity to observe, experience, and smell the factories of one of Germany's leading industrial cities! For me, it was a thrill. I was fascinated by machine sounds and factory environments, but I never had the chance to witness them first hand. This program, designed to "combine art and industry," helped me realize my dream and get my hands and my ears dirty in an industrial environment.

title: Basketball as a Second Language
description: With conference tournaments in full swing and the N.C.A.A. tournament fast approaching, I think this is a good time to offer a remedial B.S.L class: Basketball as a Second Language.

title: U.C.L.A. Out, Tixx for Sale
description: The first full day of the Pac-10 tournament is half over, and tickets can already be had for cheap.

title: Palm Readings
description: With a string of upsets bursting bubbles bursting around the country tonight, The Brackets bracket needs some clarity. And when The Bracket is unsure of how things will shape up in the N.C.A.A. Tournament (or in the numerical quagmire of the BCS in college football), theres only one person he turns to. And coincidentally, that person just happened to be at the Garden tonight.

title: Runnin Utes and Runnin Rebels Runnin Down a Dream
description: It feels like a home game for U.N.L.V., which, of course, it is. The Mountain West held this tournament in Denver for a few years, but brought it back to Las Vegas this year to pump up attendance and give the tournament a boost of Vegas-style pizzazz. The building is not full, but it is loud, as U.N.L.V. point guard Kevin Kruger, the mop-topped son of the head coach Lon Kruger, is leading the Rebels toward victory.

title: Output Falling in Oil-Rich Mexico, and Politics Gets the Blame
description: MEXICO CITY, March 8  The KU-S oil production platform off the coast of Ciudad del Carmen, with its 10,000-ton tangle of yellow and red tanks and pipes, would seem the natural product of three years of soaring energy prices. The newly installed platform certainly is the face that Mexicos state oil monopoly, Pemex, would like to show off.

title: Appeals Court Says Gun Ban Violates 2nd Amendment
description: A federal appeals court in Washington today struck down on Second Amendment grounds a gun control law in the District of Columbia that bars residents from keeping handguns in their homes.

title: Murdered Reporters Family Settles Lawsuit
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The family of a retired reporter for The New York Times who was fatally beaten near his home here in January 2006 and the District of Columbia have settled a lawsuit arising from his death, Mayor Adrian M. Fenty announced on Thursday.

title: Texas Ranger Tells of Prosecutors Lack of Interest
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 8  The Texas Ranger who investigated sexual abuse at a West Texas youth detention facility in 2005 testified Thursday that he had been unable to persuade a local prosecutor to take up the case.

title: Ex-Aide Says KeySpan Fired Him for Pointing to Irregularities
description: The former top spokesman of KeySpan Corporation, one of the biggest utilities in the Northeast, claims in a federal lawsuit that he was improperly fired four years ago as punishment for alerting executives to allegations of accounting irregularities involving hundreds of millions of dollars.

VALERIE AND HER WEEK OF WONDERS Reviewing this Czech New Wave oddity in The New York Times in 1974, Howard Thompson wrote that it evoked a pictorial music of its own. This weekend at Anthology Film Archives, it will gain another kind of music: a live score performed, under the name the Valerie Project, by an ensemble of Philadelphia folkies that includes Greg Weeks, Brooke Sietinsons and Helena Espvall of the band Espers. The new soundtrack will replace one of the films better features, its score by Lubos Fiser and Jan Klusak; the band members have said that their challenge is to equal that original music, with which we all have fallen madly in love. The film that will be screening behind them (directed in 1970 by Jaromil Jires and starring the alarmingly sexy Jaroslava Schallerova, then 14) is a true period piece, a nudie fairy-tale head trip about a girl hitting puberty and having to deal with lecherous priests and her nubile vampire grandmother  an Aquarian stew of Freud, Murnau, Hefner and the Brothers Grimm. Hit the concession stand early. (Tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 9 p.m., 32 Second Avenue, at Second Street, East Village, 212-505-5181, anthologyfilmarchives.org; $12.) MIKE HALE

title: Mountaineers Bid for the N.C.A.A. Now Looks Shaky
description: Edgar Sosa, Louisvilles freshman guard from the Bronx and Rice High School in Harlem, fouled out before his Cardinals finished off West Virginia, 82-71, in a terrific double overtime show last night in the quarterfinals of the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden.

title: Shiver Me Tenors, Mateys, and Sing to the Mizzen Mast!
description: The real opening of the New York City Operas spring season was its attention-grabbing announcement that the provocative director Gerard Mortier would take over the companys artistic leadership in 2009. And now that the City Opera of the future has everyones attention, the City Opera of the present raised its curtain on The Pirates of Penzance, its first production of the spring, on Wednesday evening.

title: For the Record
description: A sports article on Wednesday about Princetons struggling mens basketball team misattributed a quotation by a player who supports Coach Joe Scott. It was Justin Conway  not his teammate Luke Owings  who said during a postgame news conference on Tuesday: I respect Coach Scott a lot. He is the most passionate guy I have ever met, and his passion is directed toward making Princeton basketball as great as it possibly can be. I want to be with a guy who is doing everything he can and is pouring everything into what his goal is. Coach Scott definitely does that. Although both players spoke during the news conference, Owings made no comments about the coaching.

title: U.N. Hopes Ex-Rebels Will Buy Into Kosovo Peace Deal
description: VITINA, Kosovo, March 8  Hajriz Jakupi is not happy. Over the past few weeks Mr. Jakupi, a former guerrilla fighter, has been learning the details of a settlement that most of the ethnic Albanians who dominate Kosovo say should lead to an independent state. That is a dream that he and the other Albanians have long been awaiting.

title: Three Bands on Trips That Lead to the 60s
description: In a smoke-free club filled with studious indie-rock fans, the music alone created a psychedelic haze when Grizzly Bear, Beach House and the Papercuts performed at the Bowery Ballroom on Wednesday night. Harking back to the 1960s, with some technological upgrades, all three bands prize songs as reveries: havens of slow-motion drone and drift.

title: Court Orders Vonage to Pay $58 Million in Patent Case
description: A federal court yesterday ordered the Vonage Holdings Corporation, the Internet phone provider, to pay $58 million for infringing Verizons patents, dealing a blow to a company already showing signs of stress.

title: Of Coyotes, Men and Tribal Memory
description: OMAHA, March 8  An extraordinary trial took place in Omaha in 1879, one that had lasting repercussions on the fate of the nation. Years earlier the Ponca tribe had been relocated from its lands near here to Indian Territory, now Oklahoma. When land provided by the United States government proved unsuitable for their way of life, the Poncas returned to Nebraska, where they were arrested. In the first instance of American Indians standing trial in a United States courtroom, Chief Standing Bear and his people were declared persons within the meaning of the law and allowed to reclaim their ancestral home.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Sigourney Weaver as Gypsy Rose Lee

title: Mining Lifes Complexities for the Playful and Pensive
description: Jorge Drexler is the kind of songwriter who cheerfully explained, near the end of his concert at Town Hall on Tuesday, that he had based a song on the laws of conservation of matter and energy: Toda Se Transforma (Everything Transforms). In that song the heat of a kiss has repercussions reaching distant galaxies.

title: Basic Oversights Linked to Bronx Fire
description: The fire broke out around 11 p.m. in a bustling Bronx neighborhood, where anyone could have called for help in an instant. Its victims were not trapped dozens of stories up. New York City firefighters had successfully fought blazes just like it in similar buildings hundreds of times before.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Brief Awakening From a Coma
description: DENVER, March 8  A woman who has been in a coma-like state for more than six years awoke for three days this week to talk with family members and eat her favorite foods before relapsing.

title: Grandpas Legacy, Beyond Cash
description: Reeking of self-righteousness and moral reprimand, Michael O. Sajbels Ultimate Gift is a hairball of good-for-you filmmaking coughed up by 20th Century Foxs new faith-based label, Fox Faith. If the goal is to attract Christian dollars to the multiplex, perhaps insulting the artistic sensibilities of their owners is not the best way to go.

title: Nine Dead, a Community in Mourning
description: The narrow brick house on Woodycrest Avenue in the Bronx was full of childrens voices and the scent of peanut stew. In the mornings, the children would strap on their backpacks and gather on the front steps for the walk to P.S. 73; their mothers would venture out later, babies tucked in brilliantly colored slings across their backs. Friends used to tease Manthia Magassa, one of the residents, about her growing family, but she didnt mind. She would smile and say, No, its God giving.

title: California Upends U.C.L.A.s Postseason Plans
description: LOS ANGELES, March 8  When college basketballs conference tournaments tipped off this week, there seemed to be only one team in the country whose standing was set.

title: Finding Peace, and Looking for a Job
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 7  For Josh Hamilton, a recovering cocaine addict who is trying to revive his baseball career with the Cincinnati Reds, the challenges come from all angles.

title: Study Uncovers Memory Aid: A Scent During Sleep
description: Scientists studying how sleep affects memory have found that the whiff of a familiar scent can help a slumbering brain better remember things that it learned the evening before. The smell of roses  delivered to peoples nostrils as they studied and, later, as they slept  improved their performance on a memory test by about 13 percent.

title: Microsoft in First Technology License Deal
description: Microsoft said it had signed its first agreement to license its technology, almost three years after European Union antitrust regulators ordered the software company to share data to increase competition. Microsoft said the deal, with Quest Software of California, was meant to comply with an antitrust order issued in March 2004 that demanded licensing of software that helps desktop computers communicate with servers. But the deal was met with skepticism from adversaries, who questioned how a company with a longstanding relationship with Microsoft could be considered a rival. The European Commission threatened Microsoft last week with fines as high as 3 million euros ($3.9 million) a day for failing to comply with the order.

title: Frasier Is Tutor to Eliza for One Loverly Evening
description: Watch your purse if youre heading to Lincoln Center this weekend. A boisterous clan of street toughs, braying away in incomprehensible Cockney, has taken up residence in Avery Fisher Hall.

title: Bushs South America Tour Incites Fight for Attention
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, March 9  President Bush began a weeklong trip to Latin America here on Friday promising job-creating aid but ended up competing for attention with President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela, who called the American visit an act of imperialism, adding, Gringo, go home!

title: Tough Tests With Softer Footing
description: JUMP-STARTING a running regimen is a springtime rite for recreational joggers across the country. But instead of pounding pavement, millions now sprint into the woods, where the growing sport of trail running is bringing exercisers back to nature. About 6.7 million Americans now run on dirt or grass trails once a week or more, according to a 2006 report from the Outdoor Industry Foundation in Boulder, Colo.

title: End Health Perks for Public Trustees, Cuomo Says
description: ALBANY, March 8  Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo sent letters to about 100 public authorities on Thursday warning them that their trustees should not be receiving free health insurance because they are supposed to serve without compensation.

title: New U.S. Commander in Iraq Wont Rule Out Need for Added Troops
description: BAGHDAD, March 8  The new American commander in Iraq, Gen. David H. Petraeus, warned Thursday that American troops here faced a long road ahead and left open the possibility of calling in even more soldiers as he described the difficult task of calming the country.

title: Room for Everyone
description: WHO Ann Gleason, 59, and her husband, Rich Gleason, 57, both architects

title: Where Piety Meets Creativity, in Longhand
description: MARY GORDON, who does her writing longhand with a vintage Waterman pen, is staring at her office computer at Barnard Hall the way Snow Whites stepmother stared into her mirror: She does not like what she sees.

title: Serving Humanity and a Beer at a Red Hook Bar
description: IF opening a door can literally change the course of your life, that door appeared to me in late winter 1994.

title: Brazilian Politician Indicted in New York in Kickback Scheme
description: In a somewhat bizarre entry into foreign affairs by the Manhattan district attorneys office, prosecutors in New York City announced yesterday the indictment of Paulo Maluf, a major political figure in Brazil, in a construction kickback scheme at the expense of Brazilian taxpayers.

title: Trenton: Assembly Passes Veterans Bill
description: The State Assembly unanimously passed a package of 13 bills yesterday that are intended to help New Jersey veterans and current members of the armed services. The bills, which require approval by the State Senate, would extend capital gains tax exemptions on sales of primary residences, provide free hunting and fishing licenses and certain state documents, broaden civil service preferences for veterans and provide greater job protections for reservists and National Guard members called to active duty.

title: Violent Crime in Cities Shows Sharp Surge
description: Violent crime rose by double-digit percentages in cities across the country over the last two years, reversing the declines of the mid-to-late 1990s, according to a new report by a prominent national law enforcement association.

title: Hi, His Name Is Bill, and Hes an Alcoholic. Heres the Story.
description: In the spring of 1935 Bill Wilson, a self-proclaimed rum hound from New York, found himself on a business trip in Akron, Ohio, trying to annihilate his craving for a drink. He had bottomed out in a hospital some months earlier. While he was there, he was awakened by a flash of light and experienced a spiritual conversion. It impelled him to forsake the compulsion that had taken the inevitable toll on his marriage and effectively ended his career on Wall Street.

title: Look Whos No. 8! Rangers Win Again
description: UNIONDALE, March 8  Three days after the Rangers dramatic shootout victory over an Islanders team that had become their nemesis this season, the Rangers took Thursdays rematch at Nassau Coliseum, 2-1, putting themselves in a tie for the eighth and last playoff spot in the Eastern Conference.

title: Liquid American Song, Filtered Through German Pipes
description: If Americans go to Europe and sing Mahler, there is no reason Thomas Quasthoff cant come here and sing Stevie Wonder. And so he did at Carnegie Hall on Wednesday, along with Gershwin and a raft of American popular standards. This German bass-baritone, known for his fine voice and musicality in the concert repertory, is in New York overseeing the latest in his Carnegie Perspectives series. This concert was subtitled An American Songbook.

title: Sailor Started E-Mail on Terror, U.S. Says
description: HARTFORD, March 8  When Hassan Abujihaad was a sailor on a United States Navy destroyer in 2001, federal prosecutors said, he began exchanging e-mail messages with a man who ran an Internet site seeking to raise money for terrorist causes.

title: Healthy Cattle and Healthy Humans
description: Medical experts have long worried that the indiscriminate use of antibiotics in animal feed is yielding resistant strains of bacteria that may be ingested by humans and cause diseases that cant be cured. The main concern has been large-scale dosing of big herds or flocks. But an application now before the Food and Drug Administration raises the issue of whether injecting even individual animals may interfere with human medical treatments.

title: Palm Responds to the iPhone
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 8  Palm Inc., the maker of hand-held computers, has hired a top Silicon Valley software designer as it seeks to respond to the challenge posed by Apples new iPhone.

title: Japan: Key Indicator Improved in January
description: Japans machinery orders rose in January, the most in five months, signaling that capital spending will keep fueling the economy. Nongovernment machinery orders, excluding shipping and utilities, rose a seasonally adjusted 3.9 percent, to 1.09 trillion yen ($9.4 billion), from December, when they fell 0.7 percent, according to a Cabinet Office report.

title: Al Gores Outsourcing Solution
description: Washington

title: Village People: Jennifer Saunders Takes on the Pastoral
description: In Absolutely Fabulous, the brilliant series about two aging London publicity hounds, the British writer and comedian Jennifer Saunders skewered fin de sicle trendiness and decadence. In her new sitcom, Clatterford, beginning on BBC America tonight, Ms. Saunders goes after a centuries-old ideal: the English village. She doesnt so much mock the pastoral as bring it, complete with hymnal covers and harvest festivals, into the 21st century.

title: Giuliani Courts Former Partner and Antagonist
description: They made for successful but jealous partners, a pair of outsize talents and egos whose relationship crumbled more than a decade ago in a series of public spats.

title: Mets Fasten Seat Belts After a Day of Turbulence
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 8  So far, the Mets have enjoyed a peaceful, easy spring, smiling at the Yankees occasional soap operas and brushing aside the Phillies claims that they are going to win the division this season. Their first serious turbulence arrived Thursday, when they were jolted not once but twice.

title: Rangel Tells States Delegation That Spitzer Is Too Combative
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel used a meeting yesterday between the states Congressional and legislative leaders in Washington to criticize Gov. Eliot Spitzers conduct, citing the governors hostile relationship with labor and hospital groups.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 25 about an escalation in Venezuelas arms spending referred incorrectly to a statistic cited by the Defense Intelligence Agency of the United States as evidence of a rapid arms buildup. It was a 12.5 percent increase in Venezuelas 2006 defense budget, not an increase in the value of arms purchased by Venezuela last year.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about a letter urging the National Association of Evangelicals to force its vice president for government affairs to stop speaking out on global warming included incorrect information from the letter about two of the signers. Gary L. Bauer is chairman of American Values, not president of Coalitions for America. Paul Weyrich is national chairman of Coalitions for America, not chairman of American Values.

title: A Town Thats Still Down to Earth in a Highflying Ski Region
description: A DIVOT in the Green Mountains at the crossroads of Routes 11 and 100 in south-central Vermont, Londonderry could be mistaken for just another white-steepled eye blink on the way to better-known destinations like the Stratton Mountain Resort or Manchester.

title: Sirius-XM Merger (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Moves Against Spam That Pushes Hot Stocks
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has taken a step toward combating stock spam, the unsolicited bulk e-mail message that promotes cheap stocks for quick profits, which usually prove illusory.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Henri Troyat, the Russian-born French writer, misspelled the surname of a fellow member of the Acadmie Franaise who paid tribute to him. He is Maurice Druon, not Droun.

title: Veterans Face Vast Inequities Over Disability
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Staff Sgt. Gregory L. Wilson, from the Texas National Guard, waited nearly two years for his veterans disability check after he was injured in Iraq. If he had been an active-duty soldier, he would have gotten more help in cutting through the red tape.

title: Where Is the Clarion Call to Arms? (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Schoolhouse in Rwanda, Wrenching Lessons About Genocide
description: Beyond the Gates, a harrowing recounting of the 1994 Rwandan genocide, ends with an epigraph by Elie Wiesel that is worth pondering: The opposite of faith is not heresy but indifference.

title: Who Should Apologize? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Democrats Rally Behind a Pullout From Iraq in 08
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Democratic leaders in the House and Senate began a new legislative push on Thursday for the withdrawal of combat troops from Iraq in 2008, coalescing behind a fixed timetable to end the war.

title: Visit by Bush Fires Up Latins Debate Over Socialism
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, March 8  President Bush has portrayed his trip to Latin America this week as a We Care tour aimed at dispelling perceptions that he has neglected his southern neighbors.

title: U.S. Report to Fault F.B.I. on Subpoenas
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The Justice Departments inspector general has prepared a scathing report criticizing how the F.B.I. uses a form of administrative subpoena to obtain thousands of telephone, business and financial records without prior judicial approval.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a 19-year-olds account of a sexual assault on him while he was in the custody of the Texas Youth Commission gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the person he said committed the assault. It was a fellow inmate, not identified in the article, with whom he had been placed in a cell  not a guard he identified as Mr. Henry, who he said forced him into the cell. (Go to Article)

title: Mentally Ill Inmates at Risk in Isolation, Lawsuit Says
description: BOSTON, March 8  Placed in solitary confinement in a Massachusetts prison, Mark Cunningham tried to kill himself last year, advocates for inmates say.

title: Giants Get Running Back Rueben Droughns in Trade
description: The Giants, needing to fill the hole left by the retired Tiki Barber, added running back Reuben Droughns on Friday by trading wide receiver Tim Carter to the Cleveland Browns.

title: For the Record
description: The TV Watch column yesterday, about reports from Iraq by the NBC anchor Brian Williams, and the competition among NBC, ABC and CBS to draw viewers to their evening news programs, referred incorrectly to coverage of President Bushs State of the Union address in January by Charles Gibson, the ABC anchor. He covered it from Washington, not from his desk in New York.

title: I Do. But Who Invited the Old Guy?
description: For better or for worse, one of those pretty phrases that glide by in the misty-eyed blur of a traditional marriage ceremony, takes on peculiar, urgent meaning in Craig Lucass blue-hued romantic fantasy, Prelude to a Kiss, which has returned to haunt Broadway in a moody, touching revival that opened last night at the American Airlines Theater.

title: Rangers Take a Big Hit, Then Deliver a Bigger Blow
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 8  Ryan Hollweg, the Rangers agitator, stood in the locker room sporting the most visible mark of his teams hard-fought 2-1 victory over the Islanders on Thursday night  a bloody gash on his chin that soaked part of his scruffy beard.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: CBS Producer Goes Around, Comes Around
description: Rick Kaplan described his new position as the executive producer of the CBS Evening News yesterday as coming home. He worked on the broadcast in the 1970s when Walter Cronkite was the anchor. But then, he could have said the same thing at almost any television news organization this week.

title: How a Solitary Poet of the Past Speaks to 10 Artists of Today
description: Emily Dickinson (1830-86) fits, almost too perfectly, the model of the eccentric, romantic 19th-century artist. Apart from a homesick year at Mount Holyoke Female Seminary and visits to relatives or the eye doctor in Boston, she rarely left her home in Amherst, Mass. She wrote death-obsessed, heartsick, nature-absorbed, achingly precise poems: nearly 1,800 of them, though only seven were published during her lifetime, and without her full consent.

title: Europe Divided on How to Fight Global Warming
description: BRUSSELS, March 8  Divisions over how to fight global warming threatened Thursday to overshadow a summit meeting aimed at making the European Union the world leader in the battle against climate change.

title: $90 Million Gift to Orchestra Goes Public
description: An anonymous donor has promised $90 million for the Frank Gehry-designed future home of the New World Symphony in Miami Beach, Fla., one of the largest gifts to a classical music institution.

title: Rufina Amaya, 64, Dies; Salvador Survivor
description: Rufina Amaya, who in 1981 saw Salvadoran troops slaughter her family and many others in her village, then, as the only witness, dedicated her life to telling about it, died Tuesday in San Miguel, El Salvador. She was 64.

title: I.R.S. Letting Tax Lawyers Write Rules
description: The Internal Revenue Service is asking tax lawyers and accountants who create tax shelters and exploit loopholes to take the lead in writing some of its new tax rules.

title: European Bank Raises Key Rate and Hints at More Increases
description: FRANKFURT, March 8  The European Central Bank raised its benchmark interest rate by one-quarter of a percentage point on Thursday, to 3.75 percent, and made clear that it was willing to tighten credit further, possibly by the summer, in a humming European economy that could generate inflation.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: A Youth Ministry Some Call Antigay Tests Tolerance
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 8  It is the type of event that cities usually salivate over: more than 20,000 teenagers, all with a keen interest in pop culture, plenty of chaperones, and, of course, pockets full of disposable income.

title: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about troubles plaguing the coming presidential election in Nigeria incorrectly described the career of Atiku Abubakar, the current vice president, who wants to run for president but so far has been blocked by legal maneuvers to disqualify him. Although he spent much of his career as a customs officer during military rule, he was not in the military.

title: A Summit Technology Cant Reach
description: Port Townsend, Wash.

title: Winner in City Council Race Requests Another Election
description: Facing growing questions about his residency, Mathieu Eugene said yesterday that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg should call for another special election for the Brooklyn City Council seat to which Dr. Eugene was elected two weeks ago. He pledged that he would again be a candidate.

title: Nils Wessell, 92, Leader Who Transformed Tufts, Is Dead
description: Nils Y. Wessell, who as president of Tufts University from 1953 to 1966 guided its transformation from a small college to a respected university, died Sunday near his home in Naples, Fla. He was 92.

title: France: Survey Shows Tight Three-Way Contest
description: Franois Bayrou, the centrist former education minister running for president, continued to advance in the polls, with one telephone survey of 917 registered voters placing him just one point behind the Socialist Party candidate in the April 22 election, Sgolne Royal, with 24 percent to her 25 percent. It is the closest Mr. Bayrou has been to edging her out and making it to the second round of voting on May 6. In the survey, by the CSA Institute, the candidate of the right, Nicolas Sarkozy, had 26 percent. The survey, like most in France, could not calculate a margin of sampling error.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the 20th anniversary of a conference on superconductors misstated the progress of research in the field. A high-temperature superconductor was indeed used in testing a magnetically levitated train in Japan in 2005.

title: John McCabe, 78, Newspaper Executive, Dies
description: John J. McCabe, who held top executive positions at five newspapers, including The New York Times, and also served in the administration of Mayor Edward I. Koch, died on Wednesday at his home in Medford, Mass. He was 78.

title: Wearing the Green, and the Pink
description: Everyone loves a parade. Sadly, the reverse is not always true. Consider the St. Patricks Day Parade that makes its way along Fifth Avenue in Manhattan every year, a salute to all things and all people Irish  except those who wish to wear any symbol declaring they are gay or lesbian.

title: Russia: Passenger Flights to Chechnya Start Again
description: A Russian passenger jet made the first regularly scheduled landing in six years at the airport in Grozny, the capital of Chechnya. It was hailed by the regions pro-Kremlin leadership as a further sign of victory over the remaining separatists. It was timed two years to the day that Russia announced that it had killed Aslan Maskhadov, the separatist president who became a rebel commander, and after more than a year of reconstruction to restore the city.

title: China: Report Hits Back on Rights
description: China issued a response to the annual State Department report on human rights conditions globally and criticized the United States, saying it had violated the sovereignty of several nations, caused the deaths of civilians in Iraq, and violated the Geneva Conventions in its treatment of foreign prisoners. The Chinese report also listed a litany of domestic woes, from crime to racial tension. The American report said China had tightened restrictions on speech, the press and the Internet and had continued to detain political activists.

title: 2 Key Lebanese Leaders Meet
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, March 8  Saad Hariri, the Sunni Muslim leader of Lebanons March 14 coalition, the largest bloc in Congress, and the Shiite Parliament speaker, Nabih Berri, a major opposition leader, met late on Thursday night to discuss ways of ending the countrys political crisis, news agencies reported from Beirut.

title: Former Student Tells Jury Teacher Wanted to Name a Baby for Him
description: His teacher told him that if they ever had a baby girl, she would like to name the baby for him, the second young man to testify in the statutory rape trial of an East Side private school teacher told a Manhattan jury yesterday.

title: A Lawyer Finds He Can Go Home Again
description: Its not about the money, says Harvey R. Miller, with a Zen-like calm.

title: CVS Again Increases Its Offer for Caremark
description: CVS delivered what it hoped would be a knockout punch yesterday in the fight to acquire Caremark Rx, raising its offer for the drug benefits manager to $26 billion, less than a day after a rival suitor sweetened its own proposal.

title: An Anatomy of Grief: Spiny, Knotty and Convulsive
description: William Forsythe has been thinking about human disconnectedness lately, addressing it most recently in You made me a monster, a 50-minute dance installation piece performed on Wednesday night as part of Toni Morrisons Art Is Otherwise festival at the Baryshnikov Arts Center. In Three Atmospheric Studies, at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last week, Mr. Forsythe explored the kind of disconnectedness that comes with distorted verbal communication and the failure to see foreigners as anything but alien.

title: 2 Men Sentenced in Fictitious Terror Plot
description: ALBANY, March 8  Two Muslim immigrants were given 15-year sentences in federal prison on Thursday for their convictions in a fictitious terrorist plot involving money-laundering in which an F.B.I. informer pretended to deal in illegal arms.

title: In War Over Teaching Reading, a U.S.-Local Clash
description: MADISON, Wis.  Surrounded by five first graders learning to read at Hawthorne Elementary here, Stacey Hodiewicz listened as one boy struggled over a word.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a picture yesterday with an article about the funeral of Sgt. Tommaso Popolizio of the Newark Police Department, who died on Saturday in a car chase, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of police officers mourning was by Todd Heisler of The New York Times, not by Richard Perry of The Times. (Mr. Perry took the picture of Officer Johnny Banks holding Sergeant Popolizios hat.)

title: Japan: G.E. Lending Unit Scaling Back
description: The General Electric Companys Japanese consumer lending unit said it would close 60 percent of its branches and cut 15 percent of its employees as part of a restructuring plan. The GE Consumer Finance Company, a Tokyo-based lender, will shut 73 of its 115 branches and 200 of its 1,342 unmanned outlets, the firm said. The company said it would also cut as many as 400 employees out of 2,600 by the end of June.

title: Arkansas Coachs Job May Be on the Line
description: ATLANTA, March 8  Stan Heath was the got-to-have-him midmajor coach of the season in 2002, when he led 10th-seeded Kent State to the regional finals of the N.C.A.A. tournament. Several days after the Golden Flashes lost to Indiana, Heath was hired by Arkansas, which was considered a national power. He succeeded Nolan Richardson, the programs leader in victories.

title: Art in Review
description: MOTHER OF PEARL A Tradition in Asian Lacquer Metropolitan Museum of Art Through April 1

title: A Seedy Stretch, Sure, but Worth Saving, Denizens Say
description: In the salivary glands of every true New Yorker is a taste for the salacious, what the French in their love of slumming like to call nostalgia for the mud.

title: Justice Department Says F.B.I. Misused Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  The F.B.I. has improperly used provisions of the USA Patriot Act to obtain thousands of telephone, business and financial records without prior judicial approval, the Justice Departments inspector general said today in a report that embarrassed the F.B.I. and ignited outrage on Capitol Hill.

title: Rifle-Toting Mountaineer Breezes Through Security
description: Security at sports arenas has been tightened in recent years, but it is still possible for an oddly dressed bearded man to walk into a major event at Madison Square Garden with a long rifle and not be questioned or searched.

title: Debris Seen as Threat to Military Satellites
description: Debris from Chinas destruction of an obsolete weather satellite poses a threat to American military reconnaissance satellites, said Adm. Timothy J. Keating, who leads the Northern Command. On Jan. 11, China used a missile to destroy a satellite. Hundreds of tiny shards of metal are now circling the globe in low orbit, Admiral Keating said. Initial assessments indicate no immediate danger to any of our space systems, he said, but there is potential for damage.

title: For Black Women, Education Is the Key (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Backup Has Perspective and Teammates Support
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., March 8  Andy Phillips is among the more popular Yankees, an easygoing Alabaman who has climbed through the farm system with a ready smile and deep spiritual beliefs. He is also a sympathetic figure, enduring a harrowing run of family hardship.

title: No Community Board Approval for a Jerry Orbach Corner
description: In a twist worthy of a Law & Order script, the decision on whether to name a Midtown street corner for the late actor Jerry Orbach effectively ended in a hung jury last night. Not even a cameo appearance by his longtime colleague Sam Waterston could change the outcome.

title: Battle Lines Are Drawn in Hewlett Proxy Issue
description: With less than a week until Hewlett-Packards annual shareholder meeting, the first at which the contentious issue of investor elections of directors comes to a vote, battle lines have been clearly drawn. A filing made by the company yesterday and a big shareholders position are previews of the fireworks that may occur when investors gather at the Hyatt Regency in Santa Clara, Calif., on Wednesday.

title: Faith-Based Initiative (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bloomberg Meets With Relatives of Fire Victims
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who faced criticism for going ahead with a scheduled trip to Miami on Thursday in the aftermath of a fire that killed eight children and one adult in the Bronx, returned early to meet with the relatives of the victims and 150 members and representatives of the tight-knit Malian community.

title: Promoter Exits Stage, So Norfolk Tries the Role of Producer
description: The City of Norfolk, Va., held a news conference yesterday to announce that it is getting into the Broadway touring business.

title: It Came From the River, Hungry for Humans (Burp)
description: The plug-ugly monster that jumps out of a city river in The Host to scoop up and chomp down on those unlucky enough to cross its path  men, women, a whip-smart 13-year-old girl named Hyun-seo  looks like something you might find lurking at the bottom of a Hieronymus Bosch painting or trolling the depths of a murky restaurant aquarium in the middle of a toxic dump. Blink and it looks like something that slimed out of the sea in a creationist nightmare.

title: Our Squalid Government (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard-Liners Win in Northern Ireland Election
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 9  The Democratic Unionists, the hard-line Protestant party led by the Rev. Ian Paisley, and Sinn Fein, the mainly Catholic republican party, emerged today as the main winners in elections held on Wednesday for a new provincial government in Northern Ireland. More moderate groups on both sides of the sectarian divide lost seats.

title: Going to Extremes on Midwestern Slopes
description: IT took two long minutes of scouting a line before Mike Murphy was ready to jump. O.K., coming through! he yelled, as a group of skiers gathered below.

title: A Brooklyn Mother Counts Her Blessings After a Fire With a Different Outcome
description: The apartment was destroyed.

title: U.S. and South Korea Restart Talks on Free-Trade Pact
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 8  United States and South Korean trade negotiators began a hurried round of talks today as Seoul agreed to resume American beef imports in a concession aimed at smoothing the path toward what would be Washingtons most ambitious free-trade agreement in 15 years.

title: Lender Stops Accepting Mortgage Applications
description: New Century Financial, the troubled mortgage company, said yesterday it had stopped accepting new loan applications as it tried to negotiate terms with banks that had cut off its access to billions of dollars in funds.

title: Sardi Memorial Set
description: A memorial service for Vincent Sardi Jr., the restaurateur known as the unofficial mayor of Broadway, will be held at noon Tuesday at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater, 236 West 45th Street in Manhattan.

title: Arizona Falls to Oregon, Frustrating Olson More
description: LOS ANGELES, March 8  When the Arizona Wildcats arrived at Staples Center on Thursday, they found that they had been assigned to the locker room usually occupied by the Los Angeles Clippers.

title: Queens: Man Sentenced for Bias Attack
description: A Queens man was sentenced yesterday to three and a half years in prison for beating two Asian men with a cars antitheft steering lock in Douglaston last August, prosecutors said. The man, Kevin M. Brown, 19, of Auburndale, pleaded guilty in State Supreme Court on Jan. 17 to second-degree assault as a hate crime. One of the men suffered lacerations and loosened teeth, and the other a possible skull fracture.

title: Theater Listings
description: BE Anyone who has seen Stomp or Drumstruck may wonder if Mayumanas BE, the latest rhythm-dance-performance art extravaganza to claim its percussive place Off Broadway, is more of the same.

title: F.D.A. Orders Warnings on Anemia Drugs
description: The Food and Drug Administration issued strict new warnings today about overuse of drugs for anemia, following a flurry of recent studies suggesting that the medications might cause heart attacks or make cancer worse in some patients.

title: With Housing in a Slump, Mortgages Rose Anyway
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  Americans continued to load up on mortgage debt last year, even though the housing market was stalling, according to data released on Thursday by the Federal Reserve.

title: Newark: Inspector Faces New Charges
description: A former Newark housing inspector who was charged in January with raping a woman in her Chadwick Avenue apartment on Dec. 14 was arrested again yesterday and charged in additional attacks, the authorities said. After news reports of the charges against the former inspector, Albert Foster, 44, of Somerset, four other women contacted investigators and said Mr. Foster had attacked them. Mr. Foster faces numerous assault, rape and official misconduct charges in connection with those attacks, which occurred from May 2004 to November 2005, said Paul M. Loriquet, a spokesman for the Essex County prosecutors office. Mr. Foster is being held at the Essex County Jail in $250,000 bail.

title: Australian Muslims Go for Surf, Lifesaving and Burqinis
description: CRONULLA, Australia, March 3  As a teenager growing up in a Sydney suburb, Mecca Laalaa never felt anything but Australian, even though she was for the most part unable to engage in the most quintessential of Australian pastimes: swimming at the beach. Restricted by my clothing, Ms. Laalaa explained.

title: Highland Park: Guardian Named for Woman
description: A Middlesex County judge has appointed a permanent legal guardian for a wealthy Highland Park woman who is ailing and whose son and daughter have each claimed jurisdiction over her. The woman, Lillian Glasser, 86, was caught between differing state probate laws when her daughter sought guardianship under Texas law during a visit Mrs. Glasser made to San Antonio in 2005. That request was challenged by Mrs. Glassers son, and the matter moved to New Jersey after a New Jersey judge claimed jurisdiction. In a decision released yesterday, Judge Alexander P. Waugh Jr. of the Chancery Division of State Superior Court appointed Joseph J. Catanese, Mrs. Glassers court-appointed lawyer, as her guardian, and the firm Neuberger Berman to be guardian of her $25 million estate.

title: Good of the Team Cant Beat Out Love of the Dollar
description: In the days before Super Bowl XLI, Bears outside linebacker Lance Briggs was all about team, all about a lot of guys, as he said in Miami, that are willing to set aside their egos for the good of the team.

title: A Club Where a Paltry Billion Barely Covers the Entry Fee
description: With $14.46 in our pockets and noses pressed against the glass, we managed yesterday to catch a glimpse of the richest people on the planet and, quite possibly, in the galaxy.

title: Four Quartets, Written by One Man Over Half a Century
description: After the premiere of his String Quartet No. 1, played in New York by the Juilliard Quartet in 1950, the composer Leon Kirchner, then 31, was approached backstage by a mysterious man.

title: An Image Consultant to a Spinmeister Czar
description: It might seem like a television-era phenomenon, the business of politicians hiring public relations people to turn their political agendas into a recognizable brand, but its a centuries-old concept. Nicholas I, emperor of all Russia from 1825 to 1855, had his own image consultant, the artist Fedor Solntsev, whose watercolors and prints are now on view at the New York Public Library.

title: Big Wishes, Easy Credit, Tough Times
description: Them thats got shall get/Them thats not shall lose. That observation from Billie Holidays God Bless the Child sums up the cynical view of Maxed Out, James D. Scurlocks documentary investigation of debt in America. This scattershot expos of usurious banking practices examines why the most vulnerable segment of society is victimized by the lending industry and finds a simple answer: Its obscenely profitable.

title: Screams. Flames. Breaking Glass. Tumbling Bodies. And Then, Nothing but Emptiness.
description: There was a banging at the door late Wednesday night and someone called out: Fire! Two old friends, Edward Soto and David Todd, rushed outside, leaving their video game behind.

title: Hairston Says He Never Used Any Performance Enhancers
description: For the past seven years, Jerry Hairston Jr., a veteran utility infielder, has belonged to an Arizona-based training center whose members pledge not to use performance-enhancing substances.

title: National Book Critics Circle Winners
description: Kiran Desai, Daniel Mendelsohn and Simon Schama are among the winners of the National Book Critics Circle awards. For fiction, Ms. Desai won for The Inheritance of Loss (Atlantic Monthly Press), which was also the recipient of the Man Booker Prize in 2006. Mr. Schama received the nonfiction prize for Rough Crossing (Ecco). The criticism award went to Lawrence Weschler for Everything that Rises (McSweeneys); for biography, Julie Phillips won for James Tiptree, Jr. (St. Martins Press); Mr. Mendelsohn took the autobiography prize for The Lost (HarperCollins). Troy Jollimore won the poetry prize for Tom Thomson in Purgatory (Margie/IntuiT House).

title: Winners Amid Gloom and Doom
description: Chaos spells opportunity on Wall Street.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Ann Beriault, senior vice president at Young & Laramore, Indianapolis, was made a partner in the agency and promoted to principal and account services director.

title: China to Open Fund to Invest Currency Reserves
description: BEIJING, March 9  China will create a new agency to invest the countrys immense reserves of foreign currency, now totaling more than $1 trillion, the countrys finance minister announced today.

title: Ford to Give Bonuses to All
description: DEARBORN, Mich., March 8 The Ford Motor Company, which had been criticized by union leaders over the prospect of bonuses for management, said on Thursday that all of its employees would receive a modest bonus.

title: Ethics Panel Rules on Judges in Pay Dispute
description: A state ethics panel has ruled that judges should not decline to hear cases in which the lawyers are legislators just because the Legislature has declined to raise their salaries.

title: People
description: People

title: Award Honorees Describe How They Hope to Improve the World
description: MONTEREY, Calif., March 8  Some 1,200 rich and influential people were encouraged Thursday night to help build medical clinics in Rwanda, identify millions of unnamed species and support efforts to report on a still-secret story.

title: China Nears Passage of Landmark Property Law
description: BEIJING, March 8  Chinas national legislature began deliberating Thursday on a landmark law that would provide legal protections for private property as well as a law that would gradually equalize corporate taxes on foreign and domestic corporations.

title: Fifth Baseball Player Dies Days After Bus Crash
description: A fifth baseball player from Bluffton University died today in Atlanta a result of a March 2 highway accident in which a team bus plunged from an overpass onto an interstate highway below.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,179 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: U.S. and Iran May Steal the Show at Iraqs Security Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  On Saturday, Iraq will convene its neighbors meeting in Baghdad, which is supposed to be about Iraqi security.

title: Baseball Bends on TV Plan, but Doubts Linger
description: Major League Baseball does not like the terminology, but it appears to have buckled to pressure from devoted fans irate that the Extra Innings package of out-of-market games would be the exclusive property of DirecTV.

title: Angels Owner Wants Matthews to Talk
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.

title: C.E.O. Sees His Bonus Cut at Boston Scientific
description: According to federal regulators who slapped Boston Scientific with a rare company-wide warning letter early last year, quality problems with its medical devices were wide-ranging and persistent. The companys audacious $27 billion acquisition of Guidant in a bidding war with Johnson & Johnson was viewed on Wall Street as too expensive at best. And sales of its biggest product, the Taxus drug-coated stent, sagged on safety fears and concerns among doctors such stents are being used too aggressively.

title: Collective Grief After a Blaze Claims Eight of a Bronx Neighborhoods Many Children
description: High Bridge is usually a place of have-nots. In this gritty neighborhood in the Bronx and in nearby Morrisania, 41 percent of the population lives below the federal poverty level and residents have fewer years of school than those in other parts of the borough.

title: Saturn Goes Back to Warm and Fuzzy
description: GENERAL MOTORS is borrowing a tradition from an unlikely source  the National Hockey League  to help recreate the warm and fuzzy feelings consumers had for its Saturn division more than a decade ago.

title: Editors Note
description: A letter in most editions yesterday, by Syed Waris Shere, writing from Brooklyn, discussed Vice President Dick Cheney and the verdict in the trial of I. Lewis Libby Jr.

title: Detective Who Fired 31 Shots Appears Before Grand Jury
description: HED: Grand Jury Hears Testimony From Detective Who Fired 31 Times in Fatal Shooting

title: Having Your Beefcake and Talking About It, Too
description: Evidently the average man wants to watch sports, politics, strippers, car chases and crashes, have sex and go to sleep. ABC has figured out that women prefer to watch shows about sex: couples who talk about sex, then have sex, lots of it, and then talk about sex some more to each other and to their best friends.

title: The Art of Feminism as It First Took Shape
description: LOS ANGELES, March 4  If youve held your breath for 40 years waiting for something to happen, your feelings cant help being mixed when it finally does: At last! but also Not enough. Thats bound to be one reaction to Wack! Art and the Feminist Revolution at the Museum of Contemporary Art here, the first major museum show of early feminist work.

title: With Air Force on Map, Seniors Look to the Globe
description: LAS VEGAS, March 8  A little more than a week ago, the four senior starters on the Air Force basketball team learned where they would be assigned after graduating this spring. It was the latest reminder that basketball is not their primary role, that it is simply a diversion on their way to serving a five-year military commitment.

title: Department of Injustice
description: For those of us living in the Garden State, the growing scandal over the firing of federal prosecutors immediately brought to mind the subpoenas that Chris Christie, the former Bush Pioneer who is now the U.S. attorney for New Jersey, issued two months before the 2006 election  and the way news of the subpoenas was quickly leaked to local news media.

title: Ladies Choice: Snooker or Security?
description: The idea of an alternate life  the road not taken  has captivated artists for years, giving us such disparate tales as Henry Jamess Jolly Corner, in which the hero glimpses the man he might have been had he not moved to Europe, and the movie Sliding Doors, in which Gwyneth Paltrows character finds her life taking two different paths, depending on whether she catches a certain underground train. Its partly a matter of chance: whom we meet, what opportunities turn up, which random events transpire. And its partly a matter of choice: whom we get involved with, what careers we pursue, which talents we develop.

title: Unprepared for Disaster (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Choosing Israel, Not the Hamptons
description: AS an associate professor of clinical surgery and chief of high risk programs at New York-Presbyterian Hospital, Dr. Freya Schnabel is an unlikely international real estate pioneer. But as one of the first buyers in Eden Hills  a planned community 15 minutes southwest of Jerusalem  Dr. Schnabel, who is 49, is emblematic of a new breed of visitor to Israel: the foreign vacation-home buyer.

title: The Rational Mr. Buffett
description: Warren Buffett is famous worldwide for his investing acumen and lately also for his philanthropy. But his nickname, the Oracle of Omaha, does him something of a disservice. Rather than interpreting messages from the heavens, Mr. Buffetts greatest asset may be his real-world sense, which too many others in the nations executive suites seem to lack.

title: Slipping Slowly Into South Floridas Grassy Water
description: IF you heed just one bit of advice on a trip to the Everglades, let it be this: Slow down. The stunning beauty of the place can be elusive unless you're willing to move as gently and languidly as the River of Grass itself.

title: Pennsylvania: Boys Death Ruled a Suicide
description: A county coroner has ruled that a 14-year-old suburban Pittsburgh boy committed suicide using a handgun belonging to his neighbor, a state senator. The boy, Louis Farrell, was found dead last July in the woods behind his home. The inquest hearing officer also released a final report, which said the state senator, Bob Regola, had tried to cover up the fact that he had allowed his teenage son to keep the handgun in his bedroom. Mr. Regola testified that he removed the gun from his sons room three months before Louiss death. Mr. Regolas son declined to answer questions at the inquest, citing his Fifth Amendment right against compelled self-incrimination. The district attorney said he would decide whether to file charges in the next few weeks.

title: L.S.U.s Chatman Wont Coach in N.C.A.A.
description: Pokey Chatman, who coached the Louisiana State University womens basketball team to the Final Four the past three years, resigned over suspected inappropriate conduct involving her and a former player, an L.S.U. official said last night.

title: California Coasting
description: UNDER a full moon, Jalama Beach was stunning. Bathed in the pale lunar glow, the heaving black Pacific washed onto a light, sandy beach. To the north, a curve of coastline was backed by imposing mountains, massive dark hulks in the dim light. Rolling ranchland, dotted with oaks just visible against the night sky, spread out to the east and south.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Islanders Simon Indefinitely
description: The N.H.L. suspended Islanders forward Chris Simon indefinitely for a violent hit against Rangers forward Ryan Hollweg in Thursday nights game at Nassau Coliseum. A hearing will be held next week to decide the length of Simons suspension.

title: Shutting Out Terrorisms Victims
description: Terrorists terrorize people. Thats no surprise. What is shocking, and scandalous, is that American law currently bars the entry to the United States of some of terrorisms most abused victims: refugees who have been forced, often at gunpoint, to provide so-called material assistance.

title: Dealer Ready to Part With Four Czannes
description: Although Giuseppe Eskenazi is one of the worlds leading dealers in Asian art, he has a private passion for primarily European works on paper. For more than 30 years he has been quietly collecting prime examples of drawings, sketches and watercolors by modern masters like Czanne, Matisse, Picasso and Mondrian.

title: A Seaport Abuzz With Cultural Ferment
description: In Barcelona there is no need to prepare the revolution, simply because it is always ready. It leans out of the window on the street every day.

title: Start-Up Aims for Database to Automate Web Searching
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 8  A new company founded by a longtime technologist is setting out to create a vast public database intended to be read by computers rather than people, paving the way for a more automated Internet in which machines will routinely share information.

title: Manhattan: Court Allows Park Renovation
description: A state appeals court said yesterday that the Bloomberg administration could go ahead with a long-planned renovation of Washington Square Park. The decision lifts an injunction imposed last summer by a State Supreme Court judge, who said that plans by the citys Parks and Recreation Department to trim the fountain plaza area and to install a 45-foot jet spray were never adequately disclosed to the local community board, the Landmarks Commission or the Arts Commission. The five-member panel of the First Judicial Department of the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court said the Parks Department was sufficiently forthcoming with all three bodies. Arlene F. Boop, the lawyer representing the group who sued to stop the plan, said she had not decided whether to make further appeals. Two other lawsuits are pending demanding further environmental review on the $16 million project, which was first announced in 2003.

title: Make Medicare for All (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mayor Defends Trip After Fire
description: MIAMI, March 8  Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg defended his decision to go ahead with a scheduled trip to Florida on Thursday, hours after one of the deadliest fires in New York Citys recent history.

title: Iraqis Seek Role in Rebuilding Their Nation
description: BAGHDAD, March 8  When Rahim al-Daraji looks at the dusty lots just east of Sadr City where scores of bodies have been dumped in the past year, he sees a Ferris wheel, a roller coaster, coffee shops and restaurants.

title: Good Karma and Good Results for Notre Dame
description: Listening to Mike Brey after Notre Dames quarterfinal victory against Syracuse yesterday in the Big East tournament, it was difficult to tell if he was a basketball coach or hippie commune leader.

title: The Man Who May Become the Richest Rothschild
description: Happy or unhappy, each family generation often resembles another, and that is especially true when it comes to the Rothschilds.

title: Dealers and Collectors Make the Pilgrimage to Maastricht
description: The European Fine Art Fair, which opens today for a 10-day run in Maastricht, the Netherlands, is among the few independent barometers of the art market outside the auction houses.

title: Film Review: Modernity and Tradition at a Cultural Crossroads
description: Color is the stuff of life in the movies of Mira Nair, the Indian-born director whose newest film, The Namesake, follows two generations of a Bengali family from late-1970s Calcutta to New York City. Her lush palette lends her films a throbbing physicality that invites you to step into the screen and embrace the sensuous here and now.

title: Protocol Is Cited in Limiting Scientists Talks on Climate
description: WASHINGTON, March 8  The director of the Fish and Wildlife Service defended the agency requirement that two employees going to international meetings on the Arctic not discuss climate change, saying diplomatic protocol limited employees to an agreed-on agenda.

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday with an article about the patent fights involving the MP3 audio format misidentified three of the eight people shown. The man seated is Heinz Gerhuser, not Karlheinz Brandenburg. Second from right is Mr. Brandenburg, not Ernst Eberlein. And third from right is Mr. Eberlein, not Mr. Gerhuser. A corrected caption can be found at www.nytimes.com/2007/03/05 /technology/05music.html.

title: Knight of the News Conference Table
description: In an unusually chipper mood after his teams 81-71 victory over Colorado in the first round of the Big 12 tournament Thursday, Texas Tech Coach Bob Knight was in rare form during his postgame news conference.

title: A Pair of Guards Cowboy Up
description: Neither Brandon Ewing nor Brad Jones made the first-team all-Mountain West Conference team. But the Wyoming guards had the best one-two performance of any tandem Ive seen in a long time.

title: Pitts Stop
description: With about two minutes remaining in Pitts quarterfinal victory against Marquette in the Big East tournament, the Pitt band began chanting a common belief in these part. This is our house, they said, with five rhythmic claps stuck in between. If the Panthers can beat Louisville on Friday night in the Big East semifinals that will advance them to their sixth Big East final in the past seven years. Its been a stunning run of dominance in this tournament that could grow even more. Part of the reason for Pitts rugged play in New York is that they have a lot of kids from the New York area. Six players on Pitts roster are from New York or New Jersey.

title: Heading Home
description: Six years ago, when the Pac-10 first thought about reviving its conference tournament, Stanford and Arizona were the two schools that lobbied against it.

title: On the Market
Projected Storm Surge Over New York
Projected Storm Surge Over Northeastern Seaboard
Social Ties
description: A cast of haute-couture beauties, bound for the ball.

title: Carriages and Cobblestones
description: A weekend itinerary taking in the old and new in Charleston, S.C.

title: How I Became Me:
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Phillip Alder at the North American Bridge Championships
description: 03.09 | 3:50 P.M.  Maryland Pair Takes First Event at Bridge Championships

title: An Invitation to My 'Win a Trip' Contest
description: If your dream trip doesnt involve five-star luxury in Tahiti, but a bedbug-infested mattress in a malarial jungle as hungry jackals yelp outside (or if you have an ex- whom you would like to send on such a trip) then read on.

title: Pulse
description: What I'm wearing now, read my wrist and more.

title: Baryshnikov Will Star in Beckett Plays
description: Mikhail Baryshnikov will star in an evening of four one-act plays by Samuel Beckett in the 2007-8 season of the New York Theater Workshop.

title: What Will H-P Buy Next?
description: Hewlett-Packard has been acquiring its way into the big leagues of enterprise software. The 451 Group considers which companies might be next on H-Ps shopping list as it tries to fill gaps in its information-management offerings. Among the possible targets are Vignette, which the report describes as being in transition, and Interwoven, which is conducting a voluntary review of its stock option grants.

title: S.E.C. Begins Operation Spamalot
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has taken a step toward combating stock spam, the unsolicited bulk e-mail message that promotes cheap stocks for quick profits, which usually prove illusory. Starting an enforcement effort that (no doubt in a Monty-Python-esque moment of inspiration) it has named Operation Spamalot, the S.E.C. suspended trading in 35 stocks that had been promoted in recent spam campaigns. The suspensions will last for 10 days. The S.E.C. said that further investigation could lead to arrests.

title: Banks Cut Off New Centurys Credit
description: New Century Financial, the troubled mortgage company, said Thursday that it had stopped accepting new loan applications as it tried to negotiate terms with banks that had cut off its access to billions of dollars in funds. But in an indication that at least one of its lenders continues to have confidence in the company, New Century said it had received $265 million to finance loans and cover other obligations and $710 million to replace a credit line. The company did not identify the lender, but The New York Times reported that it was Morgan Stanley who provided the loan.

title: Start-Up Aims to Automate Web Searching
description: A new company founded by a longtime technologist is setting out to create a vast public database intended to be read by computers rather than people, paving the way for a more automated Internet in which machines will routinely share information. The company, Metaweb Technologies, is led by Danny Hillis, whose background includes a stint at Walt Disney Imagineering and who has long championed the idea of intelligent machines.

title: Top Bankruptcy Lawyer Leaves Greenhill
description: At least one investment bank plans on storing nuts ahead of a possible economic winter. After the announcement yesterday that Greenhill & Company lost its vice chairman, Harvey R. Miller, to his old law firm, the boutique investment bank is apparently planning to ramp up its restructuring advisory arm. Mr. Miller, the most prominent bankruptcy lawyer in the nation, has left the investment bank, where he performed advisory work, to return to Weil, Gotshal & Manges restructuring practice.

title: Real Estate Promoter Is Indicted in Ponzi Scheme
description: A real estate promoter was charged in a federal indictment unsealed Thursday with stealing tens of millions of dollars from investors in a Ponzi scheme and using the money to pay for jewelry, luxury automobiles, and credit card and tax bills. The promoter, Gene A. ONeal, 36, of Atlanta, entered a not guilty plea at a hearing in federal court in Atlanta, said Patrick Crosby, a spokesman for the United States attorneys office. Bond was set at $50,000, but ONeal was expected to post that and be released, Mr. Crosby said.

title: Ex-Gateway Officers Found Liable in Trial
description: Two former executives at the computer maker Gateway were found liable on civil claims that they manipulated financial results to meet Wall Street expectations in 2000, the Securities and Exchange Commission said on Thursday. The verdicts against Gateways former chief financial officer, John J. Todd, and the former controller, Robert D. Manza, were announced by a federal jury in San Diego after a three-week trial, the S.E.C. said.

title: Have Foxes Gotten into the I.R.S. Henhouse?
description: The Internal Revenue Service is asking tax lawyers and accountants who create tax shelters and exploit loopholes to take the lead in writing some of its new tax rules. The pilot project represents a further expansion of the increasingly common federal government practice of asking outsiders to do more of its work, prompting academics and other critics to complain that the government is going too far. They worry that having private lawyers and accountants draft tax rules could allow them to subtly skew them in favor of their clients.

title: Hedge Fund Goes Public and Finds the Water Lukewarm
description: The latest hedge fund to hit the public markets found the reception not quite as warm as it had hoped. Brevan Howard Asset Management raised 770 million euros ($1 billion) in an initial public offering of hedge fund BH Macro Limited, about half of the maximum amount originally sought. London-based Brevan Howard had said it planned to raise as much as 1.5 billion euros. The middling performance may be due, in part, to investor wariness after the stock-market swings during the past two weeks and declines in the shares of rivals.

title: CVS Raises Caremark Offer Again
description: CVS appeared to have the advantage in the fight to acquire Caremark Rx after it raised its offer for the drug benefits manager to $26 billion, The New York Times reported. The bidding battle may be enriching several hedge funds, such as Glenview Capital and D.E. Shaw, that took early stakes in Caremark, according to The New York Post.

title: Manulife and Socit Gnrale Feud over Failed Fund
description: Manulife Securities International is proceeding with a class-action lawsuit against Frances Socit Gnrale for its role in the collapse of Canadian hedge fund Portus Alternative Asset Management. Portus collapsed in 2005 after the Ontario Securities Commission began a probe of questionable transactions. Shortly after, Manulife took over claims of 6,600 of its clients who had invested 245 million dollars in Portus.

title: Nasdaq May Give NEC the Boot
description: Japanese electronics conglomerate NEC, dogged by accounting troubles, said its shares may be delisted from the Nasdaq stock market because it would likely miss a deadline for filing an earnings report. NEC, which unsettled investors by restating earnings three times last year, said it was still recalculating figures for the past business year and would probably fail to file the report by April 2, a deadline that has been twice extended by Nasdaq.

title: Drinker Biddle Reports 10% Rise in Revenue
description: Drinker Biddle & Reath reported a 10.3 percent increase in gross revenue for 2006, following its merger with rival law firm Gardner Carton & Douglas. Calling it a substantial growth year, the firm said revenue rose from $223 million in 2005 to $246 million in 2006. That number includes one months revenue from Gardner Carton, because Drinker Biddles fiscal year ended Jan. 31, 2007, and the merger was consummated on Jan. 1.

title: Sparks Fly at Congressional Hearing on Executive Pay
description: Lawmakers clashed Thursday over the idea of giving shareholders a voice in approving executive pay, while a top regulator scolded companies for failing to deliver the clear-cut pay disclosures now expected by the Securities and Exchange Commission. After a House hearing, Rep. Barney Frank (D-Mass.), chairman of the Financial Services Committee, said his panel would vote this month on a bill that would require all companies to allow shareholders to vote annually on pay deals approved by directors, as well as on golden parachutes for departing executives.

title: Clearwires I.P.O. Gets Mixed Signals
description: Shares of Clearwire, a wireless Internet service provider founded by cellular phone pioneer Craig McCaw, fell in their first day of trading Thursday after the company raised $600 million in an initial public stock offering. The company sold 24 million shares priced at $25 each on Wednesday night. The stock was priced at the upper end of its expected range of $23 to $25 and the total number of shares was increased from 20 million at the last moment.

title: Investment Banks Take Stake in Indian Exchange
description: Citigroup and Morgan Stanley agreed to invest in the National Stock Exchange of India, the nations largest, after volumes doubled in four years. Morgan Stanley will take a 3 percent stake, Citigroup will take 2 percent and Actis Capital will buy 1 percent, the exchange said in a statement. The NYSE Group and Goldman Sachs in January bought 5 percent stakes in a transaction that valued the Mumbai-based bourse at $2.3 billion.

title: Goldman Backs Gemini Mobile
description: Wireless messaging and entertainment software developer Gemini Mobile Technologies has received $20 million in new funding, intended to support continued global expansion and product development. The internationally focused company, which splits its operations among the U.S., Japan and China, added Goldman Sachs of New York to its roster of investors in the new round. Follow-on funding came from three Japanese backers: Mitsubishi-UFJ Financial Group, Mizuho Bank and Tokyo Marine.

title: Irish Ferry Operator Is Target of Management Buyout
description: Senior management at ferry operator Irish Continental Group have made a board-backed 471 million euro ($619 million) buyout offer, the company said Thursday. But with shares trading higher than the offer price, investors might be holding out for better terms, The Deal noted. The buyout proposes paying Irish Continental stockholders 18.50 euros per share, which would represent an 18.6 percent premium to the closing share price on Wednesday, the last day before an approach was announced. Irish Continental shareholders will have the option of cash or a redeemable preference share alternative.

title: The Man Who May Become the Richest Rothschild
description: How hedge fund money is changing the financial landscape  not to mention that of art, fashion and cinema  is oft-told tale of late. But in a new twist on the theme, The New York Times examines how bold bets in this eras new-money investment vehicles have reinvigorated the still glittering, if somewhat faded, prestige and wealth of Europes most storied banking family: the Rothschilds.

title: Ford to Sell Aston Martin to Prodrive Founder, Report Says
description: Signaling an end to the months of letting suitors kick Aston Martins tires, Ford Motor will sell the luxury car unit for almost 450 million pounds ($867.8 million) to an investor consortium, the Financial Times reported. Among the lead investors is David Richards, the founder of Britains Prodrive auto parts maker. An earlier report said that Naeem, the Egyptian investment bank, was also part of that group.

title: In Deal Data, Analyst Sees Bullish Sign for Stocks
description: Much of Wall Street is feverishly asking whether the recent stock-market selloffs were a blip or the start of a trend. The mergers and acquisitions market might offer some important clues, according to a report from Tobias Levkovich, chief United States equity strategist at Citigroup Investment Research.

title: Tax Rules for Buyout Funds Under Scrutiny
description: A committee of the United States Senate is evaluating possible changes to tax rules that would more than double the tax rate for some private equity fund managers, The Financial Times reported, citing a senior aide it did not identify. An initial focus will be the practice of converting management fees into carried interest to get a better tax rate, the article said.

title: Sourcefire I.P.O. Prices Above Expectations
description: Shares in Sourcefire, a network security company, priced at $15 a share Thursday evening, exceeding its pricing range and raising more than $70 million for the company, the Baltimore Sun reported Friday. That price now values the company at $346.7 million. John E. Fitzgibbon Jr., an analyst at IPOScoop.com, said that the offering was oversubscribed and that the I.P.O. should enjoy a healthy debut Friday.

title: Repairing a Broken Window
description: A decade after Rudy Giuliani and his former police commissioner, William J.
