Bratton, had a falling out after a series of spats, the two met privately in Los Angeles recently, Richard Perez-Pena reports this morning.Mr. Bratton had left the top police job under Mr. Giuliani amid seething by the mayors aides over the public perception that he was owed more credit for the citys reductions in crime than his boss. The two men hadnt spoken since 1996.

title: Breeden Turned Down 2 Board Seats, Applebees Says
description: Applebees International said that the activist hedge fund run by a former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman that has hounded it for months has rejected an offer of two board seats. Breeden Capital Management, run by Richard Breeden, declined an offer of one seat on March 2 and a second on Thursday, the casual-dining chain said in a statement Friday. The hedge fund, which is Applebees third-largest shareholder with a 5.3 percent stake, proposed a slate of four directors, including a former United States ambassador to Britain after criticizing the chain for failing to improve its performance.

title: The Gingrich Affair: Now He Tells Us
description: Newt Gingrich, whos toying with the idea of entering the Republican presidential race, yesterday acknowledged he was having an extramarital affair even as he led the charge against President Clinton over the Monica Lewinsky affair. Ed Morrissey of the Captains Quarters blog thinks that Politically, Gingrich made the right move.His peccadilloes already have had wide exposure, but not in the context of a national race. He wants to ask forgiveness up front for his mistakes, and evangelical Christians will feel compelled to grant it. Its the NCAA football strategy; take a loss up early in the season and one can still win the national championship, but the same loss late will almost certainly spell the end of any hopes of winning the big prize.

title: Dun-Dun? Doink-Doink? Dyong-Dyong?
description: In the street-naming system, the people are represented by two separate yet equally important groups: local community boards and the City Council.

title: Hedge Fund Winners and Losers in the Mortgage Meltdown
description: Chaos spells opportunity on Wall Street. So it is no surprise that the meltdown of the subprime mortgage market is producing a whos who of winners and losers among hedge funds. In a report in The New York Times, Jenny Anderson gives a run down of some the funds that hit the peaks and valleys.

title: Lobbing a Tomato Into a Food Fight
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel said yesterday that the conduct of his fellow Democrat, Eliot Spitzer, was too combative, citing the governors ongoing battle with labor and hospital groups, Danny Hakim and Raymond Hernandez report this morning.

title: Fox on the Debates
description: Roger Ailes, chairman of Fox News, had something to say about some bloggers efforts to pressure Democrats to drop Fox as a sponsor of some of the presidential debates, like the one it has scheduled for August in Nevada.

title: Gambias President Claims to Cure AIDS
description: A report on the English-language Web site of Spiegel Online draws our attention to Yahya Jammeh, the president of Gambia, who claims that he has the power to cure H.I.V. and AIDS, but can do so only on Thursdays.

title: Where Have All the V.P.s Gone?
description: Vice presidents are apparently getting a lot of attention on Wall Street  and we arent talking about Dick Cheney. Heidi Moore of Financial News reports that many investment banks are looking to hire people at the vice-president level but are finding them to be in short supply. Hedge funds (which seem to get the blame for almost anything these days) are pegged as one cause of the shortage: Ms. Moore reports that they are dangling compensation of up to $1 million to bankers just two or three years out of school.

title: Obama Puts Some Quarters in the Meter
description: Seriously, were now writing articles about Barack Obama not paying parking tickets when he was a student at Harvard? asks Washington Monthlys Political Animal, Kevin Drum. And its a good question, given the Boston Globes big scoop on how the Illinois senator paid his long overdue violations in Cambridge, Mass., shortly before announcing his presidential bid.

title: War at Home: Withdrawal Plan and Veto Threat
description: Senate Democrats are moving forward with new Iraq legislation that would aim to have troops home by March 31, 2008, while the House is looking to tie a more complicated withdrawal timetable to an Iraq spending bill. Passage will face major obstacles in the Senate, and President Bush threatened to veto the spending bill on Thursday. Republican leaders have criticized the Democratic plan for micromanaging the war.

title: Cuckoo! Cuckoo! Its Daylight Saving Time!
description: The vernal equinox is a couple weeks away, but for me spring begins with Daylight Saving Time. Its arrival always arouses two seasonal questions in my heart:

title: McCain Backs Dont Ask, Dont Tell
description: At a forum in New York on Thursday, Senator John McCain was asked a number of questions on myriad issues. While his position on the troop buildup is well known, he talked about a few other issues related to conservatives concerns about his candidacy.

title: No Sign of Duaner, Day 2
description: Duaner Sanchez remained at home for a second consecutive day as the Mets told him not to come to practice today. He remains in Port St. Lucie waiting for permission to return. Sanchez was punished yesterday for repeated tardiness, although Willie Randolph said it was only a one-day thing. The Mets have not yet disclosed a reason for banishing him again.

title: Document: Detectives for Jerry
description: Heres the letter the Detectives Endowment Association submitted last night to Community Board 5 in favor of renaming 53rd and 8th Avenue for the actor Jerry Orbach. It was read aloud by Sam Waterston, who plays a prosecutor on Law & Order. (The proposal failed to win a majority.)

title: Buyers Swarm to Tap Swedens Vin & Sprit
description: The Swedish government confirmed on Friday that it has heard from a bevy of potential suitors interested in buying Vin & Sprit, the maker of Absolut vodkda. Among them are beverage giants Pernod-Ricard, Bacardi, Diageo and Fortune Brands and several unnamed private equity firms, an unnamed source told Reuters. A sale could fetch $5 billion to $6 billion.

title: Fortress Mints Billionaires, Just in Time for Forbes
description: Hedge fund managers are known for making well-timed trades. The managers at Fortress Investment Group, the first United States hedge fund firm to go public, seem to have a knack for well-timed I.P.O.s as well. Fortress held its initial public offering the morning on February 9  which just happens to have been the cutoff date for inclusion in Forbes annual list of the worlds billionaires. As a result, five Fortress executives have made the latest list, which Forbes rolled out on Friday, with just a few hours to spare.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "My Trip to Al-Qaeda" and "Howard Katz."

title: Wikipedia To Check IDs
description: In an interview with Reuters TV in Tokyo, Jimmy Wales, the founder of Wikipedia, the user-edited online encyclopedia, said last night that contributors who identify themselves as experts will be asked to furnish some proof  of their qualifications.

title: Notes On Update 0.1.0.6
description: Like all previous posts, the items listed below are a list of major changes that weve implemented for the Beta Release Build 0.1.0.6 of Times Reader. Also like always, a lot of the changes are results of comments and feedback weve received from you guys.

title: Bloomberg: Its Another Day
description: This morning on his weekly radio program, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was asked about criticism that he should have canceled his trip to Miami because of the fatal fire in the Bronx (after the show, he met with relatives of the victims).

title: Plans, Plans Everywhere. (But Will Any of Them Work?)
description: Alison was more than willing to look at thousands of potential floor plans by herself, as part of our quest to design our dream home. But that didnt strike me as fair. So I offered to help.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a 19-year-old's account of a sexual assault on him while he was in the custody of the Texas Youth Commission gave an incorrect identification in some copies for the person he said committed the assault. It was a fellow inmate, not identified in the article, with whom he had been placed in a cell  not a guard he identified as "Mr. Henry," who he said forced him into the cell.

title: Tied Up
description: The Bracket channeled its inner-red carpet late last night, venturing deep into the bowels of Madison Square Garden to get to the bottom of the bow tie trend.

title: Who Should Pay for a Heating Unit?
description: Q Two engineers sent by my co-op board determined that I need a second heating unit. Am I responsible for installing and paying for this, or is the co-op? Also, the building manager told me that New York City's Oct. 1 to May 31 heating guidelines do not apply to co-ops. Is this true?

title: Truth Trumps Power
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Mar. 9 column, Department of Injustice.

title: Can Silicon Valley Find the Exit?
description: Chris Taylor is Business 2.0 magazines Future Boy blogger. On Friday, he looked into the financial future of Internet startups and came up with a provocative thesis. Silicon Valley no longer needs Wall Street, he declared. Entrepreneurs and their venture-capitalist financiers have a better option than an initial public offering: being acquired by the Webs cash-rich superpowers. Think Google, Yahoo, eBay and Amazon.com.

title: Houston: We have a pizza!
description: In writing Wednesdays post on New York barbecue, I may have accidentally maligned Texas pizza. Given the  possible consequences of such off-the-cuff remarks, I think its a good idea to give Texas its due.

title: F.T.C. Delays Approval of Express Scripts Bid for Caremark
description: Surprising no one, the Federal Trade Commission said Friday it was issuing a second request for information on Express Scripts $26.3 billion offer for Caremark Rx, potentially delaying approval for months. The announcement may solidify a lead held by CVS, whose $26 billion bid has already received the F.T.C.s approval.

title: President Bushs Pen Pal in Sudan
description: The Washington Post reports that President Bashir of Sudan wrote President Bush recently (a whiny defense of Sudans behavior in Darfur). Initially, the White House wasnt going to respond, just as it didnt respond to Ahmadinejads letter last year, on the theory that it didnt merit a response.

title: Jayhawks Seeking to Fly Higher
description: With U.C.L.A. having lost two consecutive games, Kansas quest to position itself for the N.C.A.A. tournaments coveted No. 1 overall seed is underway against ninth-seeded Oklahoma in the quarterfinals of the Big 12 tournament.

title: Airbag Maker Gets New Private-Equity Owner
description: Crestview Partners, a private equity firm founded by former partners from Goldman Sachs, has acquired Key Safety Systems, the company that introduced the automotive airbag in the 1960s. The seller was also a private equity shop: Ewing Management Group, a firm specializing in troubled companies that split from private equity giant Carlyle Group in 2004.

title: Defending Googles YouTube Deal
description: A flurry of articles raising questions about Googles $1.65 billion acquisition of YouTube  a flurry that included an item on DealBook  totally misses the point. That is the view of Henry Blodget, the author and former Internet analyst, who wrote about this recent negativity on his Internet Outsider blog. Last weeks revelation that YouTube booked just $15 million in revenue last year, meaning that Google paid more than 100 times revenue for the video-sharing Web site, is basically irrelevant, Mr. Blodget wrote.

title: Executive Pursuits
description: Harry Hurt III attempts a specially choreographed 15-second routine with a ballerina from the New York City Ballet.

title: War Tourists or Refugees?
description: On August 15, 2006, the day after a ceasefire ended the combat betweeen Israel and Hezbollah in Lebanon, Spencer Platt took this photograph of five young Beirutis driving in a convertible in the badly damaged southern suburbs of Beirut. Last month, the image was named the World Press Photo of the Year by an international jury of photographers and photo editors, whose chairwoman was Michele McNally, an assistant managing editor of The New York Times. On the Web site of World Press Photo, Ms. McNally described the image this way:

title: Perellas New Hire on Leaving Ivy Behind
description: Asked about his move from being manager of the University of Texass endowment fund to an asset-management job at investment bank Perella Weinberg Partners, Robert Boldt told Dan Primack of PEHub that yes, money was a factor in his switch to the private sector  but not the main factor. He also said the University of Texas gig paid pretty well, relatively speaking. But we all know that anybody whos good can make a lot more money in the private sector, he said, except maybe if youre at Harvard.

title: Vice President Giuliani?
description: Thats the betting in this post on the Globalist. I dont think it will unfold that way, but I sure wish it would. Im appalled that Cheney doesnt try to clear the air and explain himself after the Libby trial.

title: Friends of The Bracket
description: We here at The Bracket are more than happy to identify our flaws. And were grateful for the Webs boundless space that allows us to fit them all here. One misstep this week is a lack of a fearless Bracket correspondent at the A.C.C. tournament in Tampa.

title: An Unlikely Pac-10 Contender
description: The California Golden Bears went 6-12 in the Pac-10 this season, entered the conference tournament with the No. 8 seed, and are suddenly talking about winning the championship.

title: Vows: Jody and Brian
description: They met in the third grade but didn't fall in love until 25 years later.

title: Ethanol Pact: A Sweet Deal?
description: As Larry Rohter and Jim Rutenberg reported today in The Times, President Bush met President Luiz Incio Lula da Silva of Brazil in So Paulo to announce a deal aimed at encouraging the production and use of ethanol. While Mr. Bush stressed the need for the United States to wean itself off foreign sources of energy, Mr. da Silva spoke directly about how ethanol could help reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

title: The Aches and Pains of the Big 12 Tournament
description: As if watching basketball games and reporting on them was too strenuous, a masseuse is in the media workroom of the Big 12 tournament today.

title: Gawker Still Wont Make Me a Hottie of the Times.
description: I started up a Myspace.com page to help publicize my second annual Win-a-Trip contest, but nobody was supposed to notice until Sunday, when my column will address it. Alas, Gawker.com noticed.

title: Holbrooke on Iraq
description: Richard Holbrooke, who is one of the smartest people around on foreign policy, testified recently on the Hill and said some interesting things. Excerpts:

title: Carlos, Carlos, Carlos, Carlos, Carlos, Carlos and, yes, Carlos
description: Carlos Delgado took batting practice today and afterward said his stiff neck felt much better  not well enough to play against Detroit, but certainly an improvement. He told me later that his wife, Betzaida, who is scheduled to give birth on April 1, the Mets opener in St. Louis, is doing well back in Puerto Rico. He said they have planned out exactly how he will return for the birth at a moments notice. If he is playing in a game, for instance, Delgados family knows to call Mets trainer Ray Ramirez.

title: Need a Lift?
description: Air Force coach Jeff Bzdelik was standing outside the South Point Hotel and Casino, headquarters of the Mountain West Conference tournament this week, waiting for a ride around lunchtime on Friday.

title: Blogtalk: Weekender
description: Charlie Rangel: I have not been trained in psychiatry. [The Politicker]

title: The Rocker Speaks
description: Party musician Andrew W. K. takes on the comedy world and discusses joy and paradox.

title: Homeland Panel Closer Than Ever
description: Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Independent-Democrat, is taking non-partisanship to new heights, according to a press release, by making Democrats and Republicans sit next to each other instead of on opposite sides of the Homeland Security Committees dais.

title: AT&T "Experience" Demonstration
description: A video from AT&T demonstrates the features in its new "Experience" stores.

title: Thallium Poisoning Update
description: To update you on a story that Tom Zeller blogged about earlier this week, The Los Angeles Times reports today that the two American women, Marina Kovalevskaya, 49, and her daughter, Yana Kovalevskaya, 26, who came down with mysterious cases of thallium poisoning in Moscow, improved greatly after Marina Kovalevskys brother, Leon Peck, flew to Moscow with an antidote.

title: Blogtalk: Gingrichs Confession; Obeys Rant
description: Nothing sets the blogospheres fingers flying like the combination of adultery and possible presidential candidates. Newt Ginrichs radio discussion with James Dobson of Focus on the Family of his conducting an extramarital affair while calling for impeachment proceedings against President Bill Clinton got everyones attention. While many left-leaning blogs linked to the news story, most of the commentary settled on the conservative blogs.

title: The New Sarasota
description: See why Sarasota is a top vacation destination on Florida's west coast.

title: A Second Home in South Beach
description: Ten years ago, the Catalanos bought a vacation home in South Beach, Fla., and it was one of the best decisions they ever made.

title: The Exercise of Bob Knight
description: After a 66-45 loss Friday to fourth-seeded Kansas State in the Big 12 tournaments quarterfinals, Texas Tech Coach Bob Knight admitted that his team struggled with fatigue.

title: Nevada Democrats Cancel Debate With Fox
description: Well, its truly official now. The top Nevada Democrats shipped a letter off tonight to Marty Ryan, executive producer of political programs for Fox News.

title: Standing Out in the Mountain West
description: The Mountain West Conference is going through a bit of separation anxiety, as Brigham Young and Nevada-Las Vegas have separated themselves from the rest of what had been the best mid-major conference in the country, at least beyond the Missouri Valley.

title: Classic Tussle
description: Big East Commissioner Mike Tranghese cut through a few reporters and put his arm around Notre Dame Coach Mike Brey.

title: Glass Slippers? Old Hat
description: Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below.  The Editors

title: Texas A&M Slips and Likely Slides
description: Texas A&Ms 57-56 loss to seventh-seeded Oklahoma State in Fridays quarterfinals of the Big 12 tournament could have been a costly one for the seventh-ranked Aggies.

title: TXU Announces Plans for 2 Coal Plants Designed to Be Cleaner-Burning
description: HOUSTON, March 9  The TXU Corporation announced on Friday that it was making plans to build two power plants in Texas that would use advanced technology intended to capture carbon dioxide before it escapes into the atmosphere.

title: In Tragedy, Glimpsing Oft-Overlooked Newcomers Lives
description: They began alighting in New York in the late 1970s, these Malian traders riding the currents of the global economy. After a decade, maybe two, of intense work, they sent for their wives who would bear many children and settle in Harlem apartments and cacophonous old town houses on hilly streets in the Bronx.

title: Obamas Qualifications (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Soldiers Accused of Shooting Civilians in Sadr City
description: BAGHDAD, March 9  American soldiers were accused Friday of opening fire on a car carrying a family in the Baghdad district of Sadr City, killing a man and his two young daughters and wounding his son.

title: Teaching Even the Pickiest Toddlers How to Eat Their Vegetables and Love It
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 7  The picky little eaters at the Nutritional Sciences Preschool are told to play with their food and are allowed, sometimes even encouraged, to leave a little on their plates.

title: California: Nurses Union Joins A.F.L.-C.I.O.
description: The California Nurses Association said it was joining the A.F.L.-C.I.O., helping the nations main labor federation to grow after seven prominent unions left it in the past two months. The California group, which represents 75,000 registered nurses, is one of the nations most assertive small unions, having held dozens of rallies to protest Gov. Arnold Schwarzeneggers efforts to roll back a law on nurse-to-patient ratios. Rose Ann DeMoro, the unions executive director, said she hoped that joining the A.F.L.-C.I.O. would help the federations push for single-payer, universal health coverage in the United States. The California union has set up a national arm, the National Nurses Organizing Committee, seeking to unionize nurses outside the state.

title: Getting Out of a 2-Year Cellphone Contract Alive
description: The two-year contract. It is the bane of a cellphone owners existence, especially one who must have the latest hot phone at a discounted price.

title: Where Those Reactors and Centrifuges Came From
description: Aspen, Colo.

title: Walker, Fiscal Ranger
description: THE federal governments fiscal crisis is so great that it threatens the future of the republic, David M. Walker, the comptroller general of the United States, warned on 60 Minutes on Sunday (cbsnews.com).

title: Court Rejects Strict Gun Law as Unconstitutional
description: Interpreting the Second Amendment broadly, a federal appeals court in Washington yesterday struck down a gun control law in the District of Columbia that bars residents from keeping handguns in their homes.

title: Disturbing Memoir Outsells Literary Comfort Food at Starbucks
description: Starbucks prompted plenty of eye-rolling among publishing types last year when it announced that it would inaugurate its program to sell one book at a time from its coffee shops with an already certain best seller, the reliably inoffensive Mitch Albom novel For One More Day.

title: Bloomberg, Criticized Again for Response to a Crisis, Tries to Strike a Balance
description: The appeal of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has always been the notion that he is no ordinary politician, but an independent decision maker and level-headed manager willing to buck conventional wisdom in pursuing what he thinks is right.

title: Senate Moves to Vote on 9/11 Recommendations
description: The Senate cleared the way for a final vote on legislation to carry out security recommendations from the Sept. 11 commission. By a vote of 69 to 26, the Senate limited debate on proposed amendments to the Democratic-backed legislation, making it likely that the Senate would vote on the measure next week. White House officials have said President Bush will probably veto the measure because it grants union rights to 43,700 airport screeners.

title: Glass Slippers? Old Hat
description: We were laid out on the couch the other weekend, stopped in our tracks by an unforeseen afternoon broadcast of Maid in Manhattan, when an important moment of sociological revelation arose.

title: A Week of Partial Recovery
description: An unexpected drop in unemployment helped stocks post their first back-to-back gains in almost a month yesterday.

title: Knit Tops Are the Next Challenge
description: When the greeter calls "Have a Great Day!" as you leave  his smile glinting with silver braces  you know you're in yet another chain catering to the under 30 crowd.

title: Zimbabwe: Newspaper Shuts Down
description: A newspaper widely said to have been taken over by the nations secret service in 2005, The Daily Mirror, has suspended publication because of a lack of newsprint, the papers chairman, Ibbo Mandaza, said. The German news agency Deutsche Presse Agentur reported that some journalists at the newspaper have not been paid since the start of the year. Zimbabwe struggles with rampant inflation and shortages of foreign currency, fuel, food and many other commodities.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about Rufina Amaya, witness to a massacre in the village of El Mozote in El Salvador, referred incorrectly to the Salvadoran Armys exemption from human rights prosecutions. The possibility of prosecutions ended in 1993 when El Salvador passed a general amnesty law covering anyone implicated in a United Nations investigation, which stemmed from a peace accord in 1992. Impunity was not mandated in that 1992 accord, which ended the countrys 12-year civil war.

title: Basketball Skills Come Slowly to a 7-Foot-9 Center From China
description: POTOMAC, Md., March 8  Gheorghe Muresan, the 7-foot-7 former N.B.A. center, gives basketball lessons in suburban Maryland.

title: More Finding Work in U.S.
description: If the economy is really slowing as much as some recent statistics suggest, working Americans have so far managed to dodge the bullet.

title: Priest, Now Accused of Theft, Fought Audit
description: MIAMI, March 9  One of two Roman Catholic priests accused of stealing and misappropriating as much as $8.6 million donated by parishioners in South Florida sought to end an audit of church finances, complaining to diocesan officials that the financial scrutiny was undignified and a waste of money, according to documents released by prosecutors.

title: Stung by Remarks, Nevada Democrats Cancel Debate on Fox
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  Citing comments made by the chairman of Fox News about Senator Barack Obama, and under pressure from liberal groups and blogs, Nevada Democrats announced on Friday night that they had decided to cancel a debate in August on Fox News.

title: Supporting Cast Supplies Needed Boost for Pittsburgh
description: The Pittsburgh Panthers played much of last nights Big East semifinal without Aaron Gray, their biggest and best player, because he was in foul trouble. But Gray was on the floor in the final minute and sank two free throws that helped the Panthers secure a 65-59 victory over Louisville in Madison Square Garden.

title: Googles Buses Help Its Workers Beat the Rush
description: MOUNTAIN VIEW, Calif.  The perks of working at Google are the envy of Silicon Valley. Unlimited amounts of free chef-prepared food at all times of day. A climbing wall, a volleyball court and two lap pools. On-site car washes, oil changes and haircuts, not to mention free doctor checkups.

title: A Bill on Horses (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Edwards Seeks Momentum in Iowa
description: SIOUX CITY, Iowa, March 9  Outside the blinding glare of Hillarobama, John Edwards has been quietly building his campaign organization in the early primary and caucus states and amassing a bankroll to remain competitive in the crush of contests early next year.

title: First Loss Ever at Airbus, and Profit Drops at EADS
description: PARIS, March 9  Profit at European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, or EADS, plunged 94 percent last year after its main unit, the aircraft maker Airbus, reported its worst year ever, the consequence of major production troubles that have plagued its flagship superjumbo jet, the A380.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Charity Drive on American Idol

title: France: Doctors Petition for Euthanasia
description: More than 2,000 French doctors and nurses have signed a petition admitting that they had helped terminally ill patients die and calling on the government to legalize euthanasia. The petition, which was published Thursday in the newsmagazine Le Nouvel Observateur, comes days before the trial of a doctor and a nurse charged with administering a fatal dose of potassium to a woman suffering from terminal pancreatic cancer in 2003. Actively ending a patients life is illegal in France, though withholding treatment with a patients consent is allowed under some circumstances.

title: Coming to Madison Square Park: Relief at a Quarter a Flush
description: Generations of New Yorkers have mastered the act of nonchalantly slinking through restaurants and hotel lobbies where they have no business in search of a toilet. But the furtive quest for relief in public may become a fading art starting this summer, now that the city has settled on a site for the first of 20 long-awaited pay toilets.

title: Brad Delp, 55, Lead Singer for Boston, Dies
description: Brad Delp, the lead singer for the rock band Boston, was found dead on Friday in his home in Atkinson, N.H. The Associated Press reported that a police spokesman said Mr. Delp apparently died alone and that there was no indication of foul play. The cause of death is under investigation and a report is to be released Monday, The A.P. reported. Mr. Delp was 55.

title: Washington: A Setback for Foster Parents
description: An effort by foster parents to form a union was dealt a blow this week when a measure intended to guarantee meet and confer rights with the state died in the House Appropriations Committee. The bill is dead, but the issue is not, said Tim Welch, a spokesman for the Washington Federation of State Employees, the largest state employees union. Last year the union formed a foster care division to try to win collective bargaining rights for foster parents. The union says foster parents have a variety of requests of the state, including reduced workloads for caseworkers and more money for training.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Democrats Steer the War in Iraq in Fits and Starts
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  Over the next few weeks, the new Democratic Congressional majority will try to translate public discontent with the war in Iraq into actual policy, with a series of votes on the withdrawal of combat troops from Iraq  the partys most consequential votes yet.

title: Users of the Javits Center Criticize Its Expansion Plan
description: Many of the companies that use the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center are openly criticizing the long-awaited plan to expand it, saying the current scheme would provide less new exhibition and meeting space than expected, would increase the cost of running trade shows and could discourage visitors from going there.

title: Yankees See Their Offensive Future in 18-Year-Old Prospect
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 9  Torre Tyson spent last season as the hitting coach for the Yankees Class A team in Charleston, S.C. It is the lowest full-season affiliate in the organization, but Tyson could look at a teenager and see a star in the making.

title: Government-Rebel Fighting Forces Sri Lankans to Flee
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, March 10  Thousands of civilians fled into government-controlled territory today and on Friday as the military started a fresh offensive to capture rebel held areas in eastern Sri Lanka.

title: Iraq's Premier Pleads for Help to Curb Violence
description: BAGHDAD, March 10  Addressing representatives of 13 nations and 3 international groups, Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki opened a much-anticipated regional conference here with a plea to Iraqs neighbors to back his efforts to control the violence engulfing the country by refusing to finance attacks or allow people to cross borders to participate in them as suicide bombers or militia members.

title: Music in Review
description: CHARLIE LOUVIN

title: A Time for Wisdom, at Long Last (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Mets Tell Snchez Its Time to Shape Up
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 9  Manager Willie Randolph will be in his office at 8 a.m. sharp Saturday, and if Duaner Snchez knows whats good for him, he will be there 15 minutes early.

title: Russian Prosecutors Search Office of Yukoss Audit Firm
description: MOSCOW, March 9  Russian prosecutors and Interior Ministry officers searched the Moscow office of the auditing firm PricewaterhouseCoopers Friday in connection with its work with Yukos, the bankrupt oil company, and with PricewaterhouseCooperss own tax filings.

title: Kasparov, Building  Opposition to Putin
description: MOSCOW

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about Philippe Decoufl, at the Joyce Theater, omitted two performances. He has shows at 2 and 7:30 p.m. tomorrow, in addition to 8 tonight.

title: Politics Lite: No Sacrifice, No Substance, No Success
description: The accepted wisdom in British political circles is that Tony Blair won three elections by giving the British voters charisma and energy unfettered by dull or controversial policies. The Tories have now taken the lesson to heart. They are fighting back with feel-good, idea-light campaigns of their own, and it seems to be working. They are now significantly ahead in the polls.

title: Agustn Tamargo, 82, Journalist Who Despised Castros Regime, Dies
description: Agustn Tamargo, an outspoken Cuban journalist who strongly criticized the regime of Fidel Castro in print and on the radio in Miami, where he became a leading voice of the exile community, died Wednesday in Miami Beach. He was 82.

title: Worth the Wait, on a Hospital Sofa: A Mother Camps Out to Be Near Her Ailing Baby Boy
description: This is a small tale of the city, of a worried mother and of her new son, born ill. No one has done anything wrong in this story, not the doctors, not the nurses, not the hospital, not the insurance company.

title: Afghanistan: Blast Wounds Tribal Elder
description: A senior tribal elder, Mullah Naquibullah, a close ally of President Hamid Karzai, and five others were wounded in a remote-controlled mine explosion in southern Kandahar Province, police officials said. The attack came after two suicide bombers struck NATO military convoys on the edge of the city of Kandahar on Thursday, wounding five civilians but causing no military casualties. In northern Afghanistan on the same day, a German engineer was killed by gunmen.

title: Scoppetta Says Fire Hits Home and Heart
description: They were called the kids from Woodycrest, or the homeboys.

title: Amid Inquiries, Senator Plans to End Career
description: TRENTON, March 9  State Senator Wayne R. Bryant, the Camden County Democrat who is the subject of state and federal corruption investigations, announced on Friday that he would not seek re-election in November.

title: World View Podcast
description: CALVIN SIMS. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe.

title: Evangelical Environmentalism
description: For a couple of years, there have been encouraging signs that conservative Christians are starting to take environmental matters seriously  especially global warming. But in a recent letter, several of the most prominent leaders of the conservative Christian wing of the Republican Party, including James Dobson, Gary Bauer and Paul Weyrich, told the policy director of the National Association of Evangelicals, the Rev. Richard Cizik, to shut up already about global warming.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Arts on Tuesday about Marni Nixon, who has provided the singing voice for many actresses in movies and who is playing Prof. Henry Higginss mother in the concert performances of My Fair Lady at Lincoln Center this week, referred incompletely to her role in the Disney animated film Mulan. Although she provided the singing voice of Grandmother Fa, it was June Foray who provided the voice for the speaking parts.

title: Bush Adds to Ranks of Military Health Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 9 (Bloomberg News)  Two war veterans are among seven appointees chosen by President Bush on Friday to round out a commission that will review the militarys health care system.

title: Troubles Hit Real Estate at High End
description: Until now, deep-pocketed Wall Street tycoons and foreign investors benefiting from a weak dollar seemed to be holding up the luxury real estate market even as the low-end fractured. But there are signs that some high-end real estate developers are also being hit by the slowdown.

title: Orchestra to Sell Off Instruments It Prized
description: Four years ago the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra rested its musical and financial future on a collection of 30 precious string instruments. In an about-face, the orchestra now says its health depends on selling them.

title: Budget Money for Troops (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush and Chvez Spar at Distance Over Latin Visit
description: SO PAULO, Brazil, March 9  President Bush began the first full day of his weeklong trip to Latin America here on Friday promising job-creating aid but ended up competing for attention with President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela, who called the American visit an act of imperialism, adding, Gringo, go home!

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Weekend yesterday with a music review of the opera Wakondas Dream, at the Orpheum Theater in Omaha, reversed the identities of two performers. William Ferguson was lying down, and Eugene Perry was at left.

title: Natalie Bodanya, 98, Soprano at Metropolitan, Dies
description: Natalie Bodanya, an American soprano who sang at the Metropolitan Opera in the 1930s and early 40s and who later became a voice teacher, died on Sunday in Santa Barbara, Calif. She was 98.

title: Detective Who Fired 31 Shots Testifies in Killing by Police
description: A grand jury in Queens weighing evidence in the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell heard yesterday from the last of the five police officers involved in the case, a detective who fired 31 of the 50 shots at Mr. Bells car.

title: Working Backward and Seeking Reasons in the Ashes
description: They jumped out like daisies, two unexpected dashes of color half buried in a ghostly moonscape of ash and charcoal that had been one sprawling Bronx familys belongings before the fire.

title: Are You Ready to Listen? This Rocker Just Wants to Talk
description: I love tourists, Andrew W. K. said as he strolled by Times Square on Monday. Theyre excited about everything, and I love excitement.

title: Neighbors and Others Arrive in Iraq Seeking Peace
description: BAGHDAD, March 9  In a symbolic victory for Iraq, representatives of neighboring countries as well as world powers are gathering here to discuss how they could help stabilize the troubled country.

title: Suicide Car Bomber Kills 7 Soldiers in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, March 10  On one of the holiest days in the Shiite calendar, a suicide car bomber tried today to break through a military checkpoint on a bridge leading to Sadr City, a Shiite stronghold, apparently intending to ram into a crowd of people on the other side, the authorities said.

title: Managing Your Aces
description: WHATS the best way to manage the gifted people who are increasingly important in the knowledge economy?

title: New Election for Brooklyn Council Seat Is Set for April 24
description: A second special election for a City Council seat representing central Brooklyn will be held on April 24, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: A Celebrity Warship Gets a Hall of Fame to Call Its Own
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va.  As sacred relics go, it doesnt seem too inspiring. In appearance, Nathaniel Hawthorne said, it looked like a gigantic rat-trap. In life, it had little more than a single day of major achievement, and in that it was less than triumphant. In death, it was even less grand, sinking into the Atlantic during a storm, not even a year after it first lumbered onto the scene.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article in some copies yesterday about the Mountaineer, a rifle-toting mascot who entered Madison Square Garden for this weeks Big East basketball tournament without being searched or questioned, misstated the name of the mascots university. It is West Virginia University, not the University of West Virginia.

title: China to Open Fund to Invest Currency Reserves
description: BEIJING, March 9  China will create an agency to invest its immense reserves of foreign currency, now totaling more than $1 trillion, the countrys finance minister announced on Friday.

title: A Mothers Past Abuses in the Eyes of Her Family
description: Television executives were expected to be fearful this season (of declining ad revenues, of the Web), but instead theyve been resourceful, introducing strong new shows and online partnerships, and recently even displaying the kind of noblesse oblige that you usually find in flush, confident industries.

title: Was Danes Madness Just Method? Jury to Decide
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  With just days to go before the trial, the opposing counsels were already squaring off.

title: Jefferson Makes Return, but Cant Rescue Nets
description: HOUSTON, March 9  Richard Jefferson, the Nets small forward, returned to game action Friday night for the first time in more than six weeks. And it appears that his journey to a full recovery will be as long and as arduous as that of his team.

title: Explosives Are Missing From Mine in Arizona
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 9  Law enforcement officials are searching for hundreds of pounds of missing explosive material of the type used in the 1995 bombing of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City.

title: Text: Malikis Address to Regional Conference
description: Following is a transcript of the speech delivered today by Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq at a conference with representatives of Islamic and Western nations, as recorded and translated by The New York Times.

title: Neighborhood Now Wonders About Safety of Its Homes
description: It was built 106 years ago, the same year that New York State started requiring automobile owners to register their vehicles. But the row house at 1022 Woodycrest Avenue in the Bronx is hardly an endangered species in the city.

title: Buyout Firm and Partner Bid for British Drugstores
description: LONDON, March 9  The private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Company said Friday that it was teaming up with the Italian billionaire Stefano Pessina to make a takeover bid for Alliance Boots, Britains largest drugstore chain.

title: New Mexico: Cockfighting Ban Goes to Governor
description: A bill outlawing cockfighting received legislative approval when the State Senate concurred with a measure approved in the House. Gov. Bill Richardson, a Democrat, has indicated he will sign the measure into law. Animal protection advocates had tried for almost two decades to ban the sport, but their efforts were frustrated by rural legislators who argued that cockfighting was part of New Mexicos culture. The bill says that first and second violations of the ban would be misdemeanors, and that subsequent convictions would be felonies. If the bill becomes law, Louisiana will be the only state in which cockfighting remains legal.

title: Yanks Pavano Misses Start for Valid Reasons
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 9  Carl Pavano did not make his scheduled start Friday against Tampa Bay for personal reasons.

title: N.H.L. Suspends Islanders Simon
description: Islanders forward Chris Simon has always had a fierce, menacing appearance, reinforced by his 1,765 career penalty minutes during his 14 seasons as an enforcer in the N.H.L., and by his tough upbringing as an Ojibwa Indian who battled alcoholism as a teenager.

title: Woman Injured in Florida Workplace Shooting
description: MIAMI, March 9  A woman was critically injured on Friday when her former boyfriend walked into the company where she works and fired several shots at her as he chased her through cubicles, the authorities said.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday, about a study that calls into question the distinction between torture and cruel, degrading and inhumane treatment, misstated the surname of a spokesman for the Justice Department. He is Erik Ablin, not Amblin.

title: Some Sectors in Europe Face a Labor Shortage
description: FRANKFURT, March 9  Corinne Margot is reaching deep into her bag of tricks to find new employees.

title: Bowing to Sikhs Call, California Wants Textbook Change
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 9  The picture on Page 95 of An Age of Voyages: 1350-1600, a seventh-grade history book used in California schools since last fall, had been unremarkable to state education officials: a stiff 19th-century portrait of a man with a trimmed beard holding a few beads and wearing a crown.

title: For Winona, 52 in a Row and a Chance at History
description: WINONA, Minn., March 8  The Wisconsin baseball cap Jonte Flowers wore backward leaving basketball practice Thursday was a nod to his younger brother, Michael, a starting guard for the Badgers. Jonte already has something Michael wants  a national championship  and a share of something Michael can never touch.

title: Another Grim Week in Iraq
description: On Sunday in Basra, British troops stormed an Iraqi intelligence office and found about 30 prisoners, some of them tortured. Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki was outraged  not at the torture, but at the raid that halted it. Soon British troops will be leaving Basra, leaving Mr. Maliki and his security forces free to do as they please.

title: Sparkling Lights, Lingering Birdcalls and Lots of Lingerie
description: Before you see Tempo de Vero (Summertime), you hear it, as a rich layering of birdcalls fills the darkened stage at Dance Theater Workshop, from songbirds trilling announcements to the mournful cooing of doves. Its so thick as to be edible  a delightfully tangible counterpoint to the barely visible trio of bodies swaying underneath Beatriz Milhazess tantalizingly shimmering chandelier.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Thursday about women forced into sexual slavery by Japan during World War II misstated in some copies when a picture of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was taken. It was on Feb. 7, not on Wednesday.

title: A Proposed Tax Increase Has Lawmakers in Unfamiliar Territory
description: HARTFORD, March 8  When M. Jodi Rell, Connecticuts Republican governor, proposed raising income taxes by 10 percent to pay for an increase in spending for public education, there was bipartisan befuddlement all around the Capitol.

title: F.B.I. Head Admits Mistakes in Use of Security Act
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  Bipartisan outrage erupted on Friday on Capitol Hill as Robert S. Mueller III, the F.B.I. director, conceded that the bureau had improperly used the USA Patriot Act to obtain information about people and businesses.

title: Hoyas Muscle Into Final in Seesaw Battle
description: The reminders of Georgetowns storied basketball past lingered around the Hoyas bench last night at the Big East tournament.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Thursday about women forced into sexual slavery by Japan during World War II misstated in some copies when a picture of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe was taken. It was on Feb. 7, not on Wednesday. (Go to Article)

title: Marburys Talk Show May Need a Remake
description: Stephon Marburys new talk show, Stars on Stars, on Fox Sports Net gives the Knicks point guard a different image, but its doubtful he wants to be seen as a star-struck host. His guest on the first episode, which aired yesterday, was as polished as Marbury was raw. Kobe Bryants enthusiastic responses to a half hour of soft questions led the Lakers star to rave, The best show Ive ever done.

title: Atlanta Bus Crash Toll Is 7 After a 5th Ballplayer Dies
description: ATLANTA, March 9  A fifth college baseball player on Friday died of injuries suffered when his teams chartered tour bus plunged 30 feet off a highway overpass last week, bringing the death toll from the accident to seven.

title: Comedians as Activists, Challenging Prejudice
description: In the strange calculus of race, white people never seem to suffer as a group when their members are disproportionately involved in bad things, according to at least one Arab-American comedian. You know: corporate scandals, presidential assassinations, Nascar.

title: Europe Sets Ambitious Limits on Greenhouse Gases
description: BRUSSELS, March 9  The European Union approved a compromise agreement on Friday that would make Europe the worlds leader in the fight against climate change but would also allow some of Europes most polluting countries to limit their environmental goals.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on Sunday about three fatal accidents involving pedestrians struck by motorists in New York City carried incorrect information from the police about the timing of one victims death. The victim, Christopher Weber, underwent emergency surgery and died at 7:29 a.m. at Bellevue Hospital Center; he was not dead on arrival.

title: Spring Tests Promise and Patience
description: Port St. Lucie, Fla.

title: Asian and Jewish (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: How the Young Poor Measure Poverty in Britain: Drink, Drugs and Their Time in Jail
description: WYTHENSHAWE, England  Wandering the streets after dusk in this endless housing project, the five teenagers said they were not troubled by the turns their lives had taken so far. Not by the absent fathers, the mothers on welfare, the drugs, the arrests, the incarcerations, the wearying inevitability of it all.

title: Warren Alpert, 86, Entrepreneur, Is Dead
description: Warren Alpert, an entrepreneur who sold sheets and towels from his fathers truck at age 13 and who two months ago donated $100 million to Brown University, died on March 3 in Manhattan. He was 86 and lived in Manhattan.

title: That Great White Whale Through a Wellesian Lens
description: It takes a fool or perhaps a genius to adapt one of the greatest American novels for the stage  and Orson Welles was a bit of both. He chased Moby-Dick through much of the 1950s. After writing and starring in Moby Dick  Rehearsed in 1955, he made his own film version of that Melville classic for British television before starring in John Hustons. But Welles still wasnt finished, returning to the novel at the end of his life, filming scenes of himself reading it in one of his many unfinished works. (There are remarkable excerpts on YouTube.)

title: Too Many Secrets
description: It is a challenge to keep track of all the ways the Bush administration is eroding constitutional protections, but one that should get more attention is its abuse of the state secrets doctrine. A federal appeals court in Virginia this month accepted the administrations claim that the doctrine barred a lawsuit of a torture victim from going forward, and the government is using the defense in another torture case in New York. The Supreme Court needs to scale back the use of this dangerous legal defense.

title: Bulldogs Coach Is Loud and Clear About a Bid
description: ATLANTA, March 9  In the hallway outside his teams locker room, Rick Stansbury, the Mississippi State coach, accepted congratulations from university officials with a voice barely above a whisper after his teams 84-82 overtime victory against Kentucky. He had spent two and a half hours shouting to his team above the din in the Georgia Dome created by the throng of Kentucky fans, and his voice was nearly gone.

title: Hard-Line Parties Gain in Northern Ireland Vote
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 9  The Democratic Unionists, the hard-line Protestant party led by the Rev. Ian Paisley, emerged as one of the main winners on Friday in elections for a new assembly in Northern Ireland.

title: Seeking a Runner, the Giants Get Droughns
description: The Giants, needing to fill the hole left by the retirement of Tiki Barber, added running back Reuben Droughns yesterday by trading wide receiver Tim Carter to the Cleveland Browns. The deal is pending physicals.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about shootings at schools in Michigan and Texas misstated the title of a police official who provided details about the shooting in Midland, Mich. Robert Lane is the deputy chief of the Midland Police Department, not the chief deputy.

title: A Tempest-Tossed Woman, Lost in an Ocean of Regret
description: Keely Garfields latest work, performed Thursday evening at Danspace Project, begins on the tremulous deck of a sea-tossed ship. In Decked, a short dance set to a song by Citizen Cope, Ms. Garfield and three other dancers cross the stage diagonally, crawling on hands and knees. Dressed in layers of knits and averting their eyes, they inch forward, placing one hand in front of the other, their shoulders and knees swaying as methodically as metronomes.

title: Swiss Miss
description: Winterthur, Switzerland

title: Unemployment Rate Declined in February
description: Job growth slowed last month but still remained firm, the government reported today, in the latest sign that the job market is holding up despite other signs of economic weakness.

title: Revisiting Overstock.com and Utah
description: It was the last Monday in February, and another Utah legislative session was coming to a close. A group of lobbyists, legislators and state officials were meeting to hash out the merits of a controversial bill. Among those in the room was our old friend Patrick M. Byrne, the chief executive of Overstock.com, the struggling Internet retailer based in Salt Lake City.

title: On Wearing Our Salaries on Our Sleeves
description: IVE often wondered how it was that the characters in Jane Austens novels always seemed to know everyone elses income.

title: A Highlight-Reel Dunk Shows How Far Nets Nachbar Has Risen
description: HOUSTON, March 9  Nets forward Bostjan Nachbar slashed down the middle of the lane, launched himself toward the rim and, before anyone could react, his knees were dangling in the face of Philadelphia 76ers center Samuel Dalembert.

title: Olmert-Abbas Meeting to Go Ahead
description: With the Palestinian factions still in disagreement over filling important positions for a new coalition government, Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president, gave Ismail Haniya, the prime minister from Hamas, another two weeks to form the unity government. The delay will also ensure that Mr. Abbass meeting in Jerusalem with Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel, scheduled for tomorrow, can go ahead.

title: Park Tries to Balance Access and Nature as It Rebuilds
description: MOUNT RAINIER NATIONAL PARK, Wash., March 7  The big loud trucks rumble upstream, past where the Sunshine Point campground stood before the flood, beyond the historic park buildings that came so close to being swept away when the Nisqually River blew out its banks in November.

title: An Orchestra of Standouts in a Lively Musical Blend
description: IPalpiti means heartbeat in Italian, and it seems a fitting name for the vibrant string orchestra from which the conductor Eduard Schmieder elicited a lively pulse at Zankel Hall on Wednesday night.

title: Obamas Back Fund-Raising in New York, Not Quietly
description: Since opening his presidential fund-raising committee in January, Senator Barack Obama has made a series of stealthy trips to New York, quietly prospecting for contributions and supporters in the city of one of his chief rivals for the Democratic nomination.

title: Where Wilderness Meets Wildlife in Florida
description: As the throttle was shoved forward, the flats boat jumped and started skimming past Rabbit Key, a small mangrove hummock ringed by sand flats. In less than a minute, the island had slipped far astern and the horizon opened out to the Gulf of Mexico. With a cloudless blue sky, a light northeast breeze and the temperature in the mid-70s, it was one of those midwinter days in South Florida that make visitors and residents alike wonder why anyone would willingly endure the ravages of a northern winter.

title: Brad Delp, 55, Singer and Guitarist for Boston, Dies
description: Brad Delp, the lead singer for the multimillion-selling rock band Boston, was found dead on Friday in his home in Atkinson, New Hampshire. The Associated Press reported that a police spokesman said Mr. Delp apparently died alone and that there was no indication of foul play. The cause of death is under investigation and a report is to be released Monday, the Associated Press reported. Mr. Delp was 55.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about efforts to have a street corner in Manhattan named for the late actor Jerry Orbach misstated the middle initial of the lawyer who is advising Mr. Orbachs widow, Elaine. He is James B. Fishman, not James J.

title: Censoring Speech Wont Protect Kids (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Horrific Blaze Unites Cultures in Rituals of Grief
description: A father arrived by plane in the morning, returning to a new world: Five of his children were dead, his old life wiped away.

title: A Good Guess Yields a Title as the Spring Nationals Begin
description: ST. LOUIS, March 9  The first national championship decided at the American Contract Bridge Leagues Spring Nationals here was the Baldwin Flight A North American Pairs. Dave Abelow of Owings Mills, Md., and Dick Wegman of Bethesda, Md., won it on Thursday night.

title: Shutting Down Fake Prep Schools
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has taken much-needed action against fraudulent prep schools that inflate transcripts for high school athletes before passing them on to big-time college sports programs. It announced that it would no longer accept transcripts from four nontraditional high schools that had failed to pass muster under a new academic review program.

title: Volkswagen Predicts Increased Sales and Profit for This Year
description: Volkswagen said yesterday that profit and sales would rise this year as the Skoda Fabia and Audi A5 models attract more customers and a corporate overhaul reduces production costs.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: The Critics Choice column on Monday, about new CDs, misstated some lyrics sung by Jay Farrar on The Search, a new album by Son Volt. The first lyric quoted is: I cant stand any more indecision, not I cant stand any more decisions. The second one is: Well know when we get there if well find mercy, not Well know when we get there. Well find mercy.

title: Terrorists Down on the Farm
description: It seems odd somehow to complain that a play isnt grim enough. But that is the overall impression left by Defender of the Faith, a compact drama by Stuart Carolan receiving its American premiere at the Irish Repertory Theater.

title: Pastor Leaves Door Ajar for Other Black Women
description: When Suzan Johnson was 14 years old and already standing 5-foot-10, she went most afternoons to the basketball courts in Mullaly Park in the Bronx, an otherwise male preserve. She learned from those boys how to box out and post up. She listened attentively as they chatted about what they looked for in a girlfriend.

title: Paper Balanchine
description: CHARLES ASKEGARD and I crossed Lincoln Center plaza bundled in navy overcoats with tote bags slung over our shoulders like a couple of accountants on a lunch hour exercise break. It was a frigid mid-February afternoon. The winter wind cut through to my already aching middle-age bones. Even Charles, my ultra-fit 38-year-old buddy, a 6-foot-4, 185-pound principal dancer at the New York City Ballet, felt the pain.

title: German Bishops Remarks on West Bank Are Denounced
description: FRANKFURT, March 9  A pilgrimage to Israel by 27 Roman Catholic bishops from Germany last week was meant to be a historic symbol of reconciliation between Jews and German Catholics.

title: F.D.A. Warning Is Issued on Anemia Drugs Overuse
description: The Food and Drug Administration issued strict new warnings yesterday about overuse of widely prescribed anemia drugs after a flurry of recent studies suggested they might cause heart problems or hasten the death of cancer patients.

title: Investors Get a Break, but Some Lenders Absorb Blows
description: THE stock market took a breather after the wild ride a week ago, even in the face of plentiful economic data and more bad news on the subprime front. Radio stations agreed to a $12.5 million settlement with regulators, while a takeover battle brewed at Take-Two Interactive.

title: Girls Death Raises Toll in Bronx Fire to 10
description: The deadly fire in the Bronx that had killed eight children claimed another young victim late last night, when a girl who had been hospitalized since Wednesday died, a spokeswoman for the citys chief medical examiner said today. The girl died from complications of smoke inhalation.

title: Spring's  the Thing
description: Die-hard skiers know that parts of the west get the most snow in April - after the poseurs have returned to the links. That means wide-open slopes and varying warm-cold conditions for which there is lots of new gear. By PAUL HOCHMAN.

title: Personal Best
description: Set the bar high in classic 30s-inspired sportswear.  And let the games begin.

title: When in Doubt, Shoot
description: Sometimes it all comes down to a flick of the wrist.

title: History, Digitized (and Abridged)
description: SALINAS, Calif.

title: Analog Memories in a Digital World
description: WHEN I was a little girl in the 1960s, living in Rochester, my mother had her own ideas about music that children might like. In a nod to conventional parenting, she played the obligatory Burl Ives record or two. But most of the music heard in our house was what she enjoyed listening to, including Eartha Kitt's swarthy "Just an Old Fashioned Girl" and Miriam Makeba's scandalously irreverent "One More Dance."

title: In Geneva, the Sun Shines Through
description: GENEVA  The bright lights and unfettered optimism of the auto show here cannot chase away all of the clouds hanging over the industry. During press previews this week, Ford put on a happy face as it introduced a new Mondeo sedan for the European market, even while it undergoes the latest attempt to cut thousands of jobs and turn around a business that has been losing billions of dollars.

title: Celebrating the Car, Amid the Congestion
description: GENEVA - Each spring the international auto industry joyfully descends on this wealthy city in the Swiss Alps to celebrate the car.

title: Sweet Home Alabama
description: Readers in Alabama have been pouring scorn on me, along with splashes of vitriol, after a couple of references in my Obama column. In particular, I wrote: In a remark that seemed delightfully uncalculated (itll give Alabama voters heart attacks), Mr. Obama described the call to prayer as one of the prettiest sounds on Earth at sunset.

title: History 2.0
Your Comments on Win-a-Trip Column
description: I welcome your comments on my Sunday column about my Win-a-Trip contest and about the need for young people to see more of the world. I will probably travel with the student and teacher to Rwanda, Burundi and Congo, but Id particularly welcome suggestions for the kinds of stories we should cover. Also, dont miss the video, the page on myspace.com and the blog from last years winner Casey Parks.

title: Penns Stephen Danley Hijacks The Bracket
description: In a continued effort to get inside the N.C.A.A. tournament, we here at The Bracket are tickled that Penns starting forward and Rhodes Scholarship finalist Stephen Danley (9.0 ppg, 4.8 rpg) has agreed to contribute. Needless to say, the writing quality and IQ of The Bracket is about to take precipitous leap.By Stephen Danley

title: Hes Just Patrick
description: During the second half of Georgetowns 84-82 victory over Notre Dame Friday night in the Big East semifinal at Madison Square Garden, Coach John Thompson III of the Hoyas walked toward the middle of the court to Patrick Ewing Jr., his forward, who was approaching the bench for a timeout.

title: Down Memory Lane With Eric Young
description: Eric Young hugged so many players in the Angels clubhouse that he seemed like a player who had arrived late for camp and was catching up with everyone. Actually, Young, a 14-year major league veteran, retired and is working for ESPN. He put a media credential around his neck and started doing interviews. I moved over to the other side, Young said with a smile. I spoke to Young about his new career, his old career and, before long, the topic shifted to Rutgers. Young played baseball and football at Rutgers and graduated in 1989. I couldnt resist telling Young about my 20-year connection to him. When I began working at The New York Times in 1987, the first story that I wrote was an unbylined piece about Rutgers beating Boston College, 38-24. Young, who grew up in New Brunswick, N.J. was the star of the homecoming game with nine catches. I called him the hometown hero, the kind of originality that Im sure really impressed the editors. Youve got to get me a copy of that, Young said. I promised to e-mail it to Young. About an hour later, I saw Young in the press box so I dug into the archives and found the story. He leaned over my right shoulder to read about what he had accomplished that day. Man, that brings back some great memories for me, Young said. Me, too.

title: In Geneva, the Sun Shines Through
description: GENEVA  The bright lights and unfettered optimism of the auto show here cannot chase away all of the clouds hanging over the industry. During press previews this week, Ford put on a happy face as it introduced a new Mondeo sedan for the European market, even while it undergoes the latest attempt to cut thousands of jobs and turn around a business that has been losing billions of dollars.

title: The Return of Duaner
description: The beauty of spring training is that, unlike the regular season, games  or should I say the outcomes  fall behind issues and themes in the importance hierarchy. So I stayed back in Port St. Lucie this afternoon to write about the obvious story of the day, Duaner Sanchezs lengthy meeting with Willie Randolph and Omar Minaya this morning. The meeting was supposed to start at 8, but when I arrived a little after 7:30, I was told that it had already begun.

title: Seed Faith for Oral Roberts
description: Lurking near the media workroom today, Eddie Sutton is here to watch his son, Sean Sutton, the Oklahoma State coach, in the semifinals of the Big 12 tournament.

title: With a Rebel Yell
description: The Nevada-Las Vegas band is playing Viva Las Vegas  not your traditional fight song  and most of the red-clad fans at the Thomas & Mack Center are singing along. Alas, no Elvis impersonators. U.N.L.V. and Brigham Young are both headed to the N.C.A.A. Tournament no matter the outcome of the Mountain West conference championship (with seeds in the 4 to 6 range) but the game promises to be fun to watch  lots of pressure defense, lots of fast breaks and a bigger-than-usual share of 3-pointers. The crowd is split 80-20 in U.N.L.V.s favor. Fans in Las Vegas havent been this pumped up for the Running Rebels since Jerry Tarkanian left in 1992. Something else to think about when pondering the bracket  the Rebels havent won an N.C.A.A. Tournament game since Tarkanian left (0-2); Brigham Young hasnt won one since 1993 (0-4).

title: Rebels on the Road
description: Two other tidbits about the U.N.L.V.-Brigham Young game. First, despite being played on U.N.L.V.s home floor, the Rebels are the road team, wearing dark road jerseys. Thats because they are seeded second, and Brigham Young is seeded first. But the Runnin Rebels, who practiced this week at a local high school because they could not practice on their home court, got to use their usual locker room.

title: Durant Good Enough for Win
description: The Texas freshman phenom Kevin Durant turned a horrendous start Friday night into one of the Big 12 tournaments most memorable performances ever during the Longhorns 74-69 comeback victory over 11th-seeded Baylor.

title: Taking a Dam Tour
description: The Bracket had a few hours to spend before the basketball game today. There is not much to do in Las Vegas (ahem), so the Bracket, in a Griswoldesque move, drove to the Hoover Dam. It is, youll be relieved to know, still holding back Lake Mead.

title: In Need of Clarity
description: The Bracket went court side in search of some gurus after Georgetowns snoozer victory over Pittsburgh in the Big East title game. Theres much more intrigue in The Bracket than there was on the court at Madison Square Garden tonight. Expect some actual drama when the selections are revealed on Sunday.Jerry Palm took a break from his blog to tell me that his four No. 1 seeds of right now are Ohio State, North Carolina, U.C.L.A. and Florida. (If Florida loses to Arkansas on Sunday, Palm says that Kansas will be a No. 1 seed.) He said Georgetown probably deserves a look for No. 1, at least over Kansas, but probably wont get one.Palms last four in the tournament: Purdue, Syracuse, Missouri State and Illinois. His last four out: Air Force, Florida State, Kansas State and Texas Tech. Palm said that there would be a lot of intrigue at the bottom of the bracket. I could end missing a half-dozen, he said. Well, more like three. I had three wrong last year. Theres a lot of tough calls.Bubble teams will be cheering for North Carolina against North Carolina State and Florida against Arkansas. (Though the Razorbacks may have already earned their way in.)Si.coms resident bracket guru,  Stewart Mandel, checked in with similar feelings as Palm.Ive been doing this mock thing for years, Mandel said. I never remember it being so jumbled. This is the hardest time Ive had sorting out the No. 1 seeds. Ohio State is the only team thats 100 percent certain a No. 1 seed.

title: Outsiders Tug at Queens Newspapers
description: By Monday afternoon, Maureen E. Walthers, the publisher and editor of The Times Newsweekly in Ridgewood, Queens, had given up hoping for a double homicide and was willing to accept something more run-of-the-mill, like a pharmacy heist. What she had in the bag was a water main break  not exactly thrilling, though, to its credit, it had created a sinkhole.

title: Elvis Loved Him. Whats With the Hall of Fame?
description: Mays Landing

title: How to Appeal to Baseball Fans? Advice: Dont Try
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 10  With the wisdom of his 57 years, the greatest third baseman in baseball history can reflect on his career as a cautionary tale for the greatest third baseman of today.

title: For Venerable Lawmaker, Hot Tub Beckoned
description: TRENTON

title: Letters to the Editor
description: IN PRAISE OF THE ROCK BOAT

title: Alissa Shaw, Robert Zardkoohi
description: Alissa Lee Shaw and Robert Babak Zardkoohi were married on Friday in Puerto Vallarta, Mexico. Alfredo Casillas , a civil registrar judge, officiated at Dreams Puerto Vallarta Resort and Spa.

title: Jennifer Pollowitz, Evan Schiffman
description: Jennifer Diane Pollowitz, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. James A. Pollowitz of Ardsley, N.Y., was married last evening to Evan Peter Schiffman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Schiffman of West Caldwell, N.J. Rabbi William Dreskin officiated at the Roosevelt Hotel in New York.

title: Clinton Mugs, Without a Trek to Little Rock
description: Chappaqua

title: Contributors
description: Serge LeBlon

title: Dubai on a Budget? No, Its Not a Mirage
description: DUBAI on a budget sounds like an oxymoron. The most ostentatious of the seven city states of the United Arab Emirates, Dubai is where travelers go to find a self-proclaimed seven-star hotel, indoor skiing and artificial islands springing up from the seas in the shape of palm trees. A stay at that seven-star hotel, the sail-shaped Burj Al Arab, starts at more than $2,000 a night.

title: Selling Your Home? Dont Call an Agent; Broadband Access Is Not a Priority; Reducing Collisions Between Cars and Deer (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Home-Cooked Meals (Just Add the Asterisk)
description: Scarsdale

title: Childrens Books / Young Adult
description: Thanks to J. K. Rowling and Philip Pullman, being a fan of fantasy is no longer any cause for shame. Children are reading again and, so they say, adults are reading childrens books. Or at least reading those writers.

title: The Kings Is Dead! Long Live the Kings!
description: S WONDERFUL  well, mostly  with the five Loews wonder theaters, built in 1929 and 1930 to establish the chains primacy in the New York area. The Paradise, in the Bronx, has just come alive as a performance hall, the Loews Jersey has reopened in the same format, and two others became churches long ago.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Sunday in Play magazine about the Washington Wizards star Gilbert Arenas misidentified the device he installed in his home to improve his conditioning. It is a hypobaric chamber, which simulates high altitude conditions  not a hyperbaric chamber, which helps the body absorb oxygen. (Go to Article)

title: Childrens Books
description: In 1991, my wife and I wandered into Eeyores Books for Children on the Upper West Side, looking to freshen the nightly round of bedtime stories. The Houdini Box, by Brian Selznick, sat right by the cash register.

title: Palestinian Convoy Attacked
description: JERUSALEM, March 10  Unidentified gunmen fired at the convoy of a Palestinian cabinet minister from the Islamist movement Hamas in the West Bank on Saturday, wounding one of his escorts. Hamas condemned the attack and said its political rival Fatah was responsible, Palestinian news media reported.

title: That Way-Out Minivan Becomes More Hospitable to Earthlings
description: TESTED: 2007 Nissan Quest.

title: The Last Crane Letter
description: To the Editor:

title: Animal House
description: ONE of the first things you learn when you move out of the city is that the outdoors is bound to find its way in. My husband and I discovered this some 20 years ago after taking up residence in the house we had just bought. Our new roommate was a red squirrel, whose acquaintance we made within days. We had two cats, but they were urban transplants, too. Pete eyed the bewildered squirrel lazily from his comfortable perch on the sofa and blinked; Cosmo dashed under the bed and trembled. They were of no help with anything beyond the occasional cockroach.

title: To Have, Hold and Cherish, Until Bedtime
description: Not since the Victorian age of starched sheets and starchy manners, builders and architects say, have there been so many orders for separate bedrooms. Or separate sleeping nooks. Or his-and-her wings.

title: Run-Flat Tires: Are They Solving a Problem or Creating Several?
description: RUN-FLAT tires, which have been offered on some new cars for the last few years, are a soothing security blanket. They can be driven for miles after losing their air, allowing drivers to delay fixing a flat until there is a safe place to stop and avoiding a harrowing tire change along a busy highway.

title: Girl, 6, Dies, Bringing Bronx Fires Toll to 10
description: According to the customs of his homeland, Mamadou Soumare should not be allowed to receive such terrible news when he was alone.

title: Online Extracurriculars
description: I interview high-school seniors who apply to my alma mater. I routinely Google these students and discovered that one posted information on his blog that reflects poorly on him. May I ask him about the blog? May I mention it to the university? Should it affect the score I give him?  Keith Lublin, West Bloomfield, Mich.

title: Correction: Helping Children to Navigate 2 Worlds
description: Because of an editing error, the Parenting column last Sunday, about a black couple helping their children deal with issues of class and race, referred incorrectly to Caleb and Kyle Lewis of Toms River. Caleb and Kyle were given a tour of Kean University by members of the Haitian and black student unions. The Lewises were not members of those groups.

title: Pelosi Cautions Bush Not to Veto an Iraq Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  Nancy Pelosi, the House speaker, challenged President Bush on Saturday over his threat to reject an Iraq spending bill if it calls for a troop withdrawal, even as the administration sought to shift money to pay for additional forces in Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Ariane Finkel, Max Goldman
description: Ariane Joy Finkel, the daughter of Phyllis and Kenneth Finkel of New York, was married last evening in Negril, Jamaica, to Max Remy Goldman, a son of Lucy and James Goldman of Mercer Island, Wash. Rabbi Stephen Henriques officiated at the Rockhouse Hotel.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Department of Homeland Security announced its intent last month to exempt children from new rules that would require them to have passports when traveling between the United States and Canada. The first phase of these rules, known as the Western Hemisphere Travel Initiative, instituted earlier this year, requires that United States citizens  including children  use passports when flying to Mexico, Canada, Central and South America, the Caribbean and Bermuda. The second phase, which will go into effect as early as January of next year, will require the same for sea and ground travel to these destinations. If the restrictions are eased, children from both the United States and Canada  15 and younger  will be able to cross the land borders between the United States and Canada with certified copies of their birth certificates and parental supervision. Those 16 to 18 years old traveling with public or private school groups, religious groups, social or cultural organizations or sports teams will also be able to use certified birth certificates instead of passports, as long as they are supervised by adults. ... The Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art is scheduled to open at the Brooklyn Museum on March 23. At the heart of the center is an installation of Judy Chicagos The Dinner Party (1979), pictured above. Two other exhibitions, Global Feminisms, running through July 1, and Pharaohs, Queens and Goddesses: Feminisms Impact on Egyptology, running through Sept. 16, fill out the rest of the 8,300 square-foot space (www.brooklynmuseum.org). ... American Airlines recently introduced a new reservations and information tool on its Web site, www.aa.com. Online visitors click on Redeem AAdvantage Miles, then enter their destinations and travel dates. They have the option of searching for award seat availability on either fixed travel dates or within a four-week time period with a new Dates Flexible option. ... For the Jimmy Buffett concert on March 24 at Dune Preserve on Anguilla, the Anguilla Great House (www. anguillagreathouse.com), the Sirena Hotel (www.sirenaresort.com) the Paradise Cove Resort (www.paradise.ai) and the CuisinArt Resort & Spa (www.cuisinartresort.com) are all offering special packages. For more information, contact the hotels directly.
