title: Dreaming of a Life of Privilege, but First...
description: I FIRST saw him in the break room at the graphic design trade school I was attending in Phoenix. He was getting a Butterfinger from the candy machine, and all I could think was that he looked like Bart Simpson  same mischievous smile, same flat-top haircut. Nobody better lay a finger on my Butterfinger! I imagined him saying, my mind grasping at linguistic and cultural straws.

title: A Tailor-Made Apartment That Was Worth the Wait
description: THE job interviewer leaned close and asked in an ominous voice, How would you feel living in an apartment that is half the size of your fathers wash basin?

title: Correction: Its God vs. Satan. But What About the Nudity?
description: An article last Sunday about efforts to adapt Paradise Lost as a film, to be produced by Legendary Pictures, transposed the titles of two films the company has helped make. They are Batman Begins, not Batman Returns; and Superman Returns, not Superman Begins. (Legendary co-financed the Batman release, and co-financed and co-produced the Superman release.)

title: September Song
description: Writing to Hannah Arendt in December 1967, Mary McCarthy reported Susan Sontags arrest in an antiwar demonstration, and then abruptly asked: And what about her? When I last watched her with you at the Lowells, it was clear that she was going to seek to conquer you. Or that she had fallen in love with you  the same thing. Anyway, did she?

title: Strut!
description: In an era of big-brand sameness, a few men are ruffling their feathers. Recent window displays at Barneys New York featured mens jackets by Thom Browne made of ostrich feathers. During last months New York fashion shows, some men dressed to their own beat. Shown here, 21-century Beau Brummells.

title: Menu Splits Personality, From Old Dishes to New
description: SOME restaurants are worlds unto themselves, while others reflect their communities. The Cooperage Inn is a mirror of Baiting Hollow, a still-rural hamlet just north and west of Riverhead where large new homes have been popping up in former potato fields.

title: At The Agency, It Isnt Pretty
description: AT Wilhelmina Models, Becky Southwick was sizing up Chloe, the latest girl to make her way into the agencys Flatiron district offices. To the layman, Chloe, an attractive and statuesque strawberry blonde, has the fat-free torso and foal-like limbs of someone barely past puberty. Still, Ms. Southwick, an agent with a keen eye and a wicked tongue, is moved to pull out her ever present tape measure. Chloes hips have grown to a 36  from a 35. Not good.

title: A Primary, as in First (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Iran See Iraq Talks as Good First Step
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  Both American and Iranian diplomats today cautiously welcomed as an important first step the outcome of a regional meeting on the violence in Iraq, which brought a rare face-to-face encounter between the two sides.

title: From Out of the Cold, Artists Works Find a Warm Embrace
description: Montclair

title: The Real Riddle of Changing Weather: How Safe Is My Home?
description: BY now it is no longer news that people are jiggling the planets thermostat.

title: Calgary Exchanges Its Cowboy Duds for a Tuxedo
description: THERE was a time, not so many years ago, when the only reasons most tourists would bother venturing into Calgary was for the two-week rodeo festival in July or as a stop on the way to the Banff mountain resort, some 80 miles west. But this rugged city in central Alberta is undergoing an energetic revitalization brought on by an oil boom, and its population, according to the Calgary Civic Census, has increased nearly 30 percent in the last decade, to almost 992,000.

title: A Bank Oasis, in Rich Shades of Red
description: WHEN UBS, the Zurich-based financial institution, decided to create a new floor dedicated to its wealthiest private clients in New York, it wanted something that would set the space apart. Instead of traditional, the company went ultramodern  just like its approach to the kind of high-tech finance that this sector requires. Instead of the typical blues of banking, it created an environment around a rich shade of red that it hoped would bring all the right associations to mind  among them, the companys logo and television advertising campaign and, for some people, numerous works in UBSs collection of contemporary art.

title: A Bridge to Machu Picchu Runs Into Problems
description: To some people, the nearly completed Carilluchayoc Bridge project in Peru, which would connect the small village of Santa Teresa to Machu Picchu, the 15th century Inca citadel, is a bridge too far.

title: Can Your Dog Humanize the Office?
description: A MEMO was sent last month to the 125 employees of Archer Malmo, a marketing agency in Memphis. Titled Office Dog Etiquette, it said in part:

title: Composing for Shakespeare While Listening to Timberlake
description: IT has been said about the composer and lyricist Michael Friedman that he can do a little bit of everything. And judging by his current to-do list, its true.

title: Surf and Turf
description: Local color for the beach or the street.

title: Lombard Street, San Francisco, Begins to Shine
description: LOMBARD STREET in San Francisco has long been regarded as a clogged access road to the Golden Gate Bridge, a tacky strip of old motor inns, dingy storefronts and aging gas stations. But like the Tenderloin and other districts that have gone from cheap to almost chic, this faded mile in the Marina District is sitting on real estate too valuable to stay gritty.

title: Communitys Residents Are Abuzz Over the Millionaire in Their Midst
description: WOODBINE, N.J., March 10  Long before the lottery came to Woodbine, a Frenchman named Baron De Hirsch had his own dream of riches, buying 5,300 acres in 1891 for what he imagined would become a Jewish agricultural paradise.

title: Albanys Idea of Democracy; Selling Your Home? Dont Call an Agent (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: One Small Step for Man
description: Is the future as yellow as a newborn chick? Or does it come in space-age silver?

title: Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: Knowledge Is Power Only if You Know How to Use It
description: IF we can land a man on the moon, why cant we ...? has been a familiar, fill-in-your-pet-peeve lament about the state of the world since Neil Armstrongs historic giant leap in 1969. It is a question that continues to engage innovators and scholars.

title: In Romneys Bid, His Wallet Opens to the Right
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  In the months before announcing his bid for the Republican presidential nomination, former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts contributed tens of thousands of dollars of his personal fortune to several conservative groups in a position to influence his image on the right.

title: Which Is the Peoples Opera? Let the Fireworks Begin
description: THE announcement late last month could not have been more stunning.

title: Correction: The Risk Is All Yours in Office E-Mail
description: The Career Couch column last Sunday, about the risks of office e-mail messages, referred incorrectly to Jefferson Wells, a firm that employs Don Ulsch, a lawyer who said that all information on a companys work computers normally belongs to the company. It is a consulting firm, not a law firm.

title: Killer Asteroid? Bomb It. Or Paint It.
description: NASA said last week that it couldnt afford to hunt for all potentially Earth-threatening space objects, ensuring for now that the odds are that civilization wouldnt know about a lethal asteroid or comet until it hit.

title: A Woman With a Rich History, Making Art and Teaching Children
description: Goshen

title: Glen Cove Circuit-Board Maker Will Close
description: AFTER spending about $12 million in the past year to revive its flagging business, Photocircuits Corporation in Glen Cove has announced that it will close April 15. The company employs about 740 workers, who will be left without jobs.

title: Dismay Over New U.N. Human Rights Council
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 9  The United Nations Human Rights Council begins a three-week session in Geneva on Monday amid expressions of frustration from rights advocates at its early performance and alarm over proposals that might weaken it further.

title: Mistress of the Many Richard Strausses
description: WHOS the fairest of them all? In ancient Greece every schoolboy knew that it was Helen of Troy. Two thousand years later her fame was intact. In Christopher Marlowes immortal phrase from around 1590, hers was the face that launched a thousand ships.

title: French Taste Sways a Local Palate
description: Tasting successive vintages made by Eric Fry at the Lenz Winery in Peconic is like visiting an outstanding chef each year and sampling his signature dishes. The basic themes remain the same, but experimentation and personal development yield different nuances.

title: Letters
description: Why Forecast Recessions?

title: If Life Imitates Art, Hes in Big Trouble
description: Rye Brook

title: Lotto Makes Sense, Even for Losers
description: AT least poker tables have some atmosphere, a jingle of highball glasses, a hint of 1990s menthol smoke in the armchairs, the sweet musk of nearby cash. The same goes for playing the horses: there are characters, scandals, competition, not to mention real payoffs.

title: A New Battery Takes Off in a Race to Electric Cars
description: VROOOOM! Or, rather, much more softly: brmmm.

title: Part-Timer? Nascar Keeps Pulling Martin Back In
description: Mark Martin foolishly thought he had escaped all of the pressure and expectation that come with racing in the Nextel Cup series.

title: Aylin Tashman and Louis Kim
description: Aylin Zehra Tashman and Dr. Louis Joong Kim were married yesterday at the Arizona Biltmore Resort and Spa in Phoenix. The officiant was Judge Lawrence F. Winthrop of the Arizona Court of Appeals in Phoenix.

title: A Family Feud That Is Familiar
description: A little problem between a stepson and a stepmother. A fathers estrangement from his children.

title: Sunny or Cloudy, Moods Cast an Influence
description: Q. You are in a bad mood and cant seem to shake it. What effect could this have at work?

title: Why Libbys Pardon Is a Slam Dunk
description: EVEN by Washingtons standards, few debates have been more fatuous or wasted more energy than the frenzied speculation over whether President Bush will or will not pardon Scooter Libby. Of course he will.

title: Want to Get Some Work Done? Wait Till April
description: Warning to employers: this might not be the best time to assign a big, complicated project. Thats because March is the No. 1 month for distracted workers.

title: Up Front
description: This week Tony Judt reviews Sacred Causes, a book that offers a provocative reassessment of the Roman Catholic Church in the 20th century, particularly its role in combating fascism and Communism. Judt, a historian who was raised and educated in Britain but has been living in America for the past 20 years (he directs the Remarque Institute at New York University), is no stranger to controversy. Last October, he was in the news when a speech he was scheduled to give on the Israel lobby was abruptly canceled by the Polish Consulate in New York, reportedly under pressure from Jewish organizations incensed by Judts strong criticism of Israel. More than 100 scholars and journalists defended Judt in a letter published in The New York Review of Books, while others accused him of spreading the toxins of anti-Semitism. I remain saddened by the Polish Consulate affair, Judt (who is Jewish) wrote in a recent e-mail message; but, he added, the controversy helped foster a more open and public conversation about Israel, the Israel lobby, anti-Semitism (real and imagined) and Jewish stances vis--vis all these.

title: A Time and Place for Grousing
description: As a new correspondent in Moscow years ago, I was given the rule about complaints. You were allowed to complain only if three major things went wrong. When the water was only hot on one floor of the apartment building and only cold on the next floor (and the toilet in your flat had become a boiling cauldron), that amounted to one complaint. A headache, a flat tire, a long wait for bread  those were zilch, routine irritations in the Soviet scheme of things. It turned out to be an important lesson for a pampered American in an un-pampered world.

title: Crusader Is Needed to Make Albany Work; Selling Your Home? Dont Call an Agent; The Dobbs Ferry Party: Why We Formed It (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: From Rival N.C.A.A. Stars to Subdued N.B.A. Rookies
description: It is March and J. J. Redick sits on the Orlando Magic bench, trying, unsuccessfully, not to sulk. His team has been losing lately.

title: Danielle Schachter, Alexander Gillette
description: Danielle Marie Schachter was married last evening to Alexander Porter Gillette. Rabbi Arthur Baseman officiated at the Don CeSar Beach Resort in St. Pete Beach, Fla.

title: Crisis Looms in Market for Mortgages
description: On March 1, a Wall Street analyst at Bear Stearns wrote an upbeat report on a company that specializes in making mortgages to cash-poor homebuyers. The company, New Century Financial, had already disclosed that a growing number of borrowers were defaulting, and its stock, at around $15, had lost half its value in three weeks.

title: Going Where Mother Led
description: I COME from a family of very strong women. My mothers mother, Nana, was a strong individual and had lots of opinions and made them known. And my mother likewise. She brought in a lot of money for the family as a real estate broker, and she had an enormous personality.

title: Raging Thirst
description: Prohibition was one of the longest, dumbest chapters in the history of 20th-century American folly, and the impulses behind it are still alive today. The architects of this bizarre experiment were as varied as the country in which they lived: faith-based Christian zealots, idealistic social reformers, flat-out bigots, a few solemn feminists and more than a few cynical businessmen who simply wanted their blue-collar workers to show up sober and on time. The movement even included a genuine terrorist organization, the Ku Klux Klan. The generals in this culture war believed, in Michael A. Lerners words, that the prohibition of alcohol and the elimination of the saloon would morally uplift the people of the United States, ultimately creating a healthier citizenry, safer cities and workplaces, and a more efficient society.

title: Let 10,000 Young Artists Bloom
description: LONDON

title: When English Eyes Are Smiling
description: New Haven

title: Trying to Meet the Neighbors
description: Is there anybody out there? Give the question some thought before you answer, because its more perilous than it seems. Deny the possibility of a universe populated with intelligent extraterrestrials that can speak and mate and battle with humanity, and the science-fiction canon collapses; more than a centurys worth of novels, from The War of the Worlds to Old Mans War, would find their speculative foundations swept out from underneath them. But admit to a sincere belief in the remotest potential for alien life, and prepare to be fitted for a straitjacket; a recent survey conducted by Baylor University found that more Americans believe in ancient civilizations like the lost continent of Atlantis than in U.F.O.s.

title: Confidence Man
description: In your new film The Hoax (due out April 6), you play Clifford Irving, the notorious writer who forged an autobiography of Howard Hughes in 1971. Irving was remarkably convincing. Until Hughes came out of seclusion to reveal that the book was a fake, the publishing world completely embraced him.

title: Correction: Mission Improbable: Tom Cruise as Mogul
description: An article last Sunday about United Artists misidentified one of the investors in its parent company, Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. It is the Texas Pacific Group, not Thomas H. Lee Partners. The article also referred incorrectly to the title of UAs first film under its new managers in two references. It will be Lions for Lambs, not Lambs for Lions.

title: The Barometric Pressure Is Just the Beginning
description: OUTWARDLY Abrams & Bettes doesnt differ much from the typical morning or evening chat show. Huddled behind a curving silver desk, two affable, telegenic hosts whip through news headlines, cringe good-naturedly when the other tries a hand at a corny joke, and cut to field reporters who provide updates on leading stories. They even have their own logo and theme music.

title: Fighting Disease, and Then the Bills (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: From a Revered Tree, Plates and Platters
description: On the lathe in his Quaker Hill studio, James Stidfole has been turning goblets, bowls, plates and platters made from one hefty branch of an iconic copper beech that once stood at the Eugene ONeill Theater Center in Waterford.

title: Just for Laughs: Newer Than New Wave
description: FOR five decades the brilliant French filmmaker Eric Rohmer, now 86, has been writing and directing quiet, pensive, rigorously unemphatic comedies about the baffled relations between men and women. Because his pictures are (at least superficially) so similar, and because they tend to be pretty much action free, its not always easy to remember which is which.

title: Pink Clouds Over Richmond Hill
description: THE air in Smokey Oval Park took on the sweet smell of baby powder. Teenagers shrieked as they raced after one another, armed with plastic bottles filled with colored water and packets of what looked like psychedelic Kool-Aid mix.

title: A 19th-Century Turn
description: It perhaps strikes anyone who has read an ambitious historical novel  and certainly strikes anyone who has had the audacity to try to write one  that the enterprise represents the triumph of hope over experience, a suspension of hard-won, armoring caution, a Peter-Pannish faith in ... well, faith. How daunting it must be to get it right: facts and artifacts, syntax and slang, costumes and customs, fads and prices, conventional wisdoms and bright ideas. And if such a novel were to aspire to be a bulging monster, teeming with extravagantly vivid characters going about their coincidentally intersecting lives with amplified voices, wearing garish clothes, committing melodramatic vices, loving (and hating) with the fervor of characters from a comic opera, then such fiction would seem perfectly ill-suited to a writer and observer known heretofore as the wised-up, sardonic, founding co-editor of the late Spy magazine. As a columnist (for New York magazine) and a radio commentator, Kurt Andersen should react to the emotions described by gee whiz like a fox to a bunny wabbit.

title: Hatchback Slathered in Hot Sauce
description: WHEN they introduced the Mazda 3 sedan and four-door hatchback-cum-wagon in 2003, the Mazda people had a spiel that went something like this: The kids these days! They want everything! Theyre paying 16 grand but they want a mini-Mercedes, so thats what we have to give them. Even though, back in our day, entry-level cars had cardboard steering wheels, and if you wanted a sunroof you had to wait for a rust hole to form above your head  which usually took only a couple of weeks.

title: Correction: Town Shows Its Face, if Not Its Reputation
description: An article last Sunday about a book of photographs of Vidor, Tex., incorrectly referred to a killing as part of the towns legacy of racism. James Byrd Jr., who was dragged to his death near Jasper, Tex., in 1998, had not moved from Vidor the day before he died and was not a resident of Vidor. (Those were the circumstances of a different case involving Bill Simpson, one of four blacks trying to integrate a housing project there in 1993. He left Vidor after seven months, complaining of harassment. Hours after moving out, he was shot dead in Beaumont, Tex.) The article also referred incorrectly to the distance from Vidor to Fredericksburg, Tex., home to a painter who attended a gallery show of the photographs. Fredericksburg is about 300 miles away, not nearby.

title: Palestinian Officials Convoy Is Attacked in the West Bank
description: JERUSALEM, March 10  Unidentified gunmen fired at the convoy of a Palestinian cabinet minister from the Islamist movement Hamas in the West Bank today, wounding one of his escorts. Hamas condemned the attack and said its political rival Fatah was responsible, according to Palestinian news reports.

title: A Street Fair That Outgrew Its Street
description: PRIDEFEST, the annual gay-themed street fair in the West Village, has long stood as a honky-tonk counterpart to the citys gay pride parade, its hawkers selling pink T-shirts and rainbow-patterned tube socks from booths along nine narrow blocks of Washington Street.

title: The Week in Westchester
description: Would a Yonkers Curfew Keep Youths in Line?

title: Against Odds, Iraqi Refugees Reach U.S.
description: SAN DIEGO, March 5  Assads desperate flight from Iraq began on foot.

title: Survivor
description: Survival stories, in their elemental simplicity, can be deeply appealing to those seeking escape from complicated, densely scheduled lives. As Georgina Harding puts it in The Solitude of Thomas Cave, existence is very plain when it is reduced to one day at a time and to that one days routine of survival. Thats a good summation of both the attractions and the dangers of the genre.

title: Gas Dealers Want Self-Service Ban Lifted
description: IN the Town of Huntington, gas station attendants still pump gas for every customer and make change right at the car window.

title: Palestinian and Israeli Leaders Meet Again
description: JERUSALEM, March 11  Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian Authority president, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel held their second meeting in a month on Sunday night, but aides said afterward that there was little concrete progress to report.

title: He Asks You to Just Make More Room for Yourself
description: Brookville

title: The Vanishing Neoliberal
description: On July 25, 1981, Michael Kinsley published an essay in The New Republic called The Shame of the Democrats. The Democratic Party, the young Kinsley wrote, is viewed with growing indifference. It is run by lawyer-operators with no commitment to any particular political values. It is filled with politicians who will do or say anything for a word or a dollar of support. It represents a dwindling collection of special interest groups whose interests are less and less those of either the general populus or the tired and poor. In short, Kinsley wrote, the Democratic Party has collapsed not just politically but morally.

title: The Talk
description: slouch / (slouch) / v. / to sit or stand with an awkward stooping gesture: he slouches like Gilligans hat; [n.] a lazy or inefficient person, an old-fashioned slacker, e.g., Define inept  hes no slouch at boondoggling; in fashion parlance, one of the key looks for summer, with even razor-sharp labels like Versace embracing the big easy, e.g., Watch your posture in that slouch jacket or youll look like the third guy on the left of the evolution chart.

title: Race for the Cured
description: The meat slicer could be the first appliance to earn a place on the kitchen counter since the espresso machine. Thats because American artisans are no longer hiding the salumi  Italian for cured meats. The process by which cuts of meat, usually pork, are salted and aged in a place thats cool, dark and drafty, like a mountain cave (the traditional method) or a well-ventilated meat locker (the Food and Drug Administrations preference), is now being mastered on these shores.

title: The Brain on the Stand
description: I. Mr. Weinsteins Cyst When historians of the future try to identify the moment that neuroscience began to transform the American legal system, they may point to a little-noticed case from the early 1990s. The case involved Herbert Weinstein, a 65-year-old ad executive who was charged with strangling his wife, Barbara, to death and then, in an effort to make the murder look like a suicide, throwing her body out the window of their 12th-floor apartment on East 72nd Street in Manhattan. Before the trial began, Weinsteins lawyer suggested that his client should not be held responsible for his actions because of a mental defect  namely, an abnormal cyst nestled in his arachnoid membrane, which surrounds the brain like a spider web.

title: Men Smelling Badly
description: Osmanthe Yunnan, Herms (****)

title: Web Sites
description: New York City residents can find some useful information at a number of government Web sites.

title: The Flavors of Vietnam, Made Into Comfort Food
description: THE lighting at Mekong Vietnamese is dim; the chairs are nondescript, the dcor forgettable.

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: In the Computer Dating Game, Room for a Coach
description: NOT getting any online dates? Maybe its time for an online makeover.

title: Catharine Muscat, Justin Gary
description: Catharine Sharp Muscat was married last evening in Boynton Beach, Fla., to Justin William Gary. Rabbi Barry M. Silver officiated at Indian Spring Country Club.

title: Amy Scott and Alexander Heilner
description: AS a fine art photographer, Alexander Heilner is known by his friends for his overactive mind and social schedule, his 1,000-plus alphabetized collection of records and CDs, and the annual scavenger hunt he organizes each year in Manhattan.

title: Now Ticking | Big Ben for Men
description: Time for a new watch? Dent  the British clockmaker famous for creating the Big Ben tower in London as well as timepieces for luminaries like King Edward VI and Charles Darwin  has a new line of watches for the common man. Frank Spurrell, the founder of Watch Magazine, and Twysden Moore, a London nightclub entrepreneur and watch fetishist, acquired the label after assuring the original owner that they were not going to make tacky plastic alarm clocks. Expect instead a classic square-face ticker inspired by Big Ben and a round homage to an 1848 ship chronometer used by the Royal Navy in the world wars. Go to www.dentwatches.com.

title: The Price of Keeping the Lights On
description: This years electric bills have made Connecticut the victor in a contest no state wants to win: it now has the highest electrical rates in the continental United States.

title: Whats on Monday Night
description: 8 P.M. (Bravo) INSIDE THE ACTORS STUDIO Chris Rock will be James Liptons guest tonight. Expect Mr. Liptons usual attempts to get the nitty gritty details of his guests childhood and influences. The two should have plenty to chat about: Saturday Night Live, Mr. Rocks experience as the host of the Academy Awards, his sitcom Everybody Hates Chris and his work in films including New Jack City and his latest project, I Think I Love My Wife.

title: When Words Collide
description: Put aside Myanmar and Russia for the moment. The latest battleground over the suppression of civil liberties, over the consequences of speaking freely, is a lot closer to home. Its in what Anahad OConnor described in The Times last week as the affluent hamlet of Cross River, where three girls, juniors at John Jay High School, got in trouble for saying the word vagina at a school function after faculty members told them not to.

title: Childrens Books
description: In the course of any literary or journalistic career, all of us at one time or another write something thats utter poop. But few dare to make that word the title of a book, as this writer-illustrator team did in their last, much-praised outing together, Poop: A Natural History of the Unmentionable.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: New World Ordering
description: With Al Gores documentary An Inconvenient Truth playing in theaters around the world to an enthusiastic response, its surprising that more museums have not highlighted the ways in which artists have been attentive to environmental change, or even the ways that technology is complicating the idea of a natural world.

title: One Vote for Less Worry on Wall St.
description: AFTER two weeks of nervous trading on Wall Street over concerns about the state of the economy, evidence of strong, stable growth might come in handy. One analyst expects to find it in several pieces of data this week, confirming his rosy outlook for the economy and the stock market.

title: Speech Crimes
description: Get a few language types together, and before long someone will bring up the great divide between the preservers and the observers of English, the prescriptivists and the descriptivists  those whod rap your knuckles for using snuck versus those who might cite Anglo-Saxon cognates in its defense.

title: Lady Slings the Booze
description: The Samurai Sipper does not on principle parade her family around like sock puppets at preschool. But how else to salute Campari, the classic aperitivo, without mentioning the Samurai Spouse? Born on Riverside Drive, weaned in the San Fernando Valley, the Spouse spent his preteen years on Via Statilio Tauro on the outskirts of Rome. Home-schooled by his Canadian mother, the Spouse scavenged and sold scrap metal for a fistful of lire, ate horse meat without censure and lugged straw baskets home from the neighborhood osteria, where chianti flowed from spigots. His father, an American opera singer born in Shanghai to a Russian mother, was a basso, meaning he played tough guys, which for him was not a stretch. The Spouse, too, is tough, silent but fierce, an ber-Samurai. He handily wins the prize for the most cosmopolitan man in Manhattan.

title: England Rocks, and a Map Now Proves It
description: Everyone knows that Jim Morrisons grave is in Paris, but who knew that Dusty Springfields grave is in Henley-on-Thames or that the grave of the former Rolling Stone Brian Jones, above left, is in Cheltenham?

title: A Ban on Horse Slaughter (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lonely Female Seeks Companion. I Wont Bite.
description: PERSONAL ads can be compelling. Take the one for Jack, who is described as one gorgeous hunk. He loves a good bath, doesnt like to party and doesnt want to be fawned over. He will, however, make a wonderful, loyal companion. Then theres Charlie. Hes a nice, medium-size guy who enjoys jogging. And Alivia describes herself as athletic and playful, but needs someone who will let me snuggle.

title: For a City With Everything Else, Design Hotels
description: IN recent years, Shanghai has witnessed the appearance of all the accoutrements that befit a quickly growing, cosmopolitan city, with high-end restaurants like Jean Georges and flagship fashion boutiques such as Armani and Dolce & Gabbana popping up in the city's more affluent sections.

title: N.Y.U. Women Reach Final Four
description: The New York University womens basketball team advanced to the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. Division III tournament with a 76-64 victory against Kean University of Union, N.J., last night in Manhattan.

title: Holding the Line on New Development
description: Homestead, Fla.

title: Making a Pilgrimage to Cathedrals of Commerce
description: THE 19th-century shopping arcades of Paris, or passages couverts, are proof that anything modern, if spared the wrecking ball, can be stimulus for nostalgia. When these iron-columned, glass-covered structures shot up around the city in the 1820s and 30s, they were visionary pieces of industrial-age technology, as whoop-de-do in their day as the warped titanium of Frank Gehry is for ours.

title: Old World Charm, and Inventive Fare
description: WITHIN a mansion that looks like the home of a prosperous plantation owner, Crabtrees Kittle House in Chappaqua manages to maintain the flavor of a cozy inn.

title: Mazda and Volvo Try on New Genes
description: STEVE MATTIN has a problem with old Volvos: there are so many.

title: Facing Sorrow, a Neighborhood Closes Ranks
description: On hot summer days he felt like the Pied Piper of Woodycrest Avenue.

title: A Political Flavor (Waffles Included)
description: Stephen Colberts television persona opposes virtually everything that the founders of Ben & Jerrys ice cream stand for. Yet there he is on the label of his very own flavor, Stephen Colberts AmeriCone Dream (vanilla ice cream with fudge-covered waffle cone pieces and caramel). And there were the founders, Ben Cohen and Jerry Greenfield, appearing on The Colbert Report on Comedy Central last week.

title: Steakhouse-Size Portions, but Not Just Beef
description: SPECIALTY cuisines may come and go, but steakhouses are forever. The latest example is BlackStones Steakhouse, which opened eight months ago in Norwalk. In looks, this newcomer resembles some of the classic old steakhouses, with a dark interior and gaslight-style overhead fixtures. Dinner prices, too, are steakhouse standard, ranging from $30.95 to $34.95 for beef, veal and lamb entrees. Portions are monster-large; again, that seems par. And though potatoes and a vegetable accompany almost all lunch entrees, the only gratis items at dinner are the butter and commercial-tasting rolls. As at many similar venues, all vegetables and other dinner sides are extra, priced from $5.95 to $6.95 (but, it should be noted, big enough for at least two  a delicious bowl of creamed spinach actually served four of us, as did the sauted mushrooms).

title: Vogue Words
description: Three phrases, new and old, are being bruited about the world of English. If youre not using at least one, you are letting the language pass you by.

title: Of Decibels and Desperation
description: A LITTLE before 6:30 Wednesday evening, the intersection of 73rd Street and 37th Avenue in Jackson Heights, Queens, was in full swing. Cars from three directions were trying to head south on 73rd, a narrow, one-way residential thoroughfare that was glowing like daylight from a cluster of supermarkets and Indian restaurants at the corner. They were not doing it quietly.

title: To and From Split, With a Stop in Rome
description: My husband and I are planning a trip to Croatia in the summer. We would like to spend some time in Rome on the way. Our miles are on American. Can you suggest the best way to travel from New York to Rome, from Rome to Split and from Split to New York?  Sarah Gillespie, Westport, Conn.

title: Gilberto Gil Hears the Future, Some Rights Reserved
description: SALVADOR, Brazil

title: No Helmut Required
description: For the man who rides motorcycles  or just wants to look as if he does  Steve McQueen is It. He was so devoted to biking that, for the epic chase scene toward the end of The Great Escape, he actually played one of the Nazis racing after his character. He was also  no surprise  extremely concerned with looking the part. His label of choice? Belstaff. The company reinvented the biker jacket in 1924, when it pioneered the use of waterproof, breathable wax cotton. But Belstaff coats are more than just practical: they have an lan that gives ordinary guys King of Cool status. So it made sense for the companys owners, the Malenotti family, to buy McQueens Belstaff Trialmaster at auction last November for $32,000.

title: Mr. Wicked
description: Before seeing the Broadway musical Wicked for the 25th time, Gregory Maguire, who wrote the novel Wicked, was in the lobby of the Gershwin Theater last month persuading people not to read it. Granted, the people were 9, 10 and 13, and Maguire was telling their respective mothers that the book could be a destination read for freshman year in college. But when he saw the girls hangdog faces, he conceded that, if their mothers read it first and approved, they might try it at 16 instead.

title: Back to School
description: ST. GEORGE, Utah

title: The Country Barrister
description: Eye opener: I get up at 8 a.m. I have a bath and write until lunch. Before I begin writing, I have a glass of Champagne. It sets my brain racing, but I was on the radio once, and the interviewer asked me, Are you having counseling for that?

title: Standards for Bloggers (1 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A War of Words, All of Them Hyphenated
description: CROSS RIVER, N.Y.

title: Major Indexes Gain as Global Markets Rebound
description: Global stock markets bounced back last week, and on Wall Street the three major stock indexes posted healthy gains.

title: Scouting for Stuff. Finding Nostalgia.
description: NEW MILFORD

title: Karen Bello, Brian Wilkow
description: Karen Marcia Bello is to be married this afternoon to Brian Richard Wilkow. Rabbi Albert Lowenberg is to officiate, with Rabbi Valerie Lieber participating, at Westbury Manor, an events space in Westbury, N.Y.

title: Santiago De Compostela, Spain: O Dezaseis
description: SANTIAGO DE COMPOSTELA has been a tourist town for a millennium; it looks like one, too, with its massive central cathedral, huge central squares, and ancient hotel, now a parador. So finding the right restaurant there is about as challenging as it is in Disneyland. But just outside the old part of town is an important huge university and a part of the city geared not to tourists but to students and locals.

title: A System for Dealing With Sex Offenders (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Take Another Route
description: The more closely people examine the $1 surcharge on one-way Metro-North tickets that is scheduled to start next year, the shakier it looks.

title: Mancuso Still Has a Shot at Ski Racing Title, but Little Chance to Rest
description: The Olympic gold medalist Julia Mancuso of the United States remains in striking distance of ski racings most coveted trophy after finishing fifth in a World Cup giant slalom yesterday, eight days before the annual circuit comes to a close.

title: How Long Must a Co-op Deal Wait?
Bloodless Revolution
description: To the Editor:

title: The Goal Standard
description: Not long ago, Nike, having repeatedly failed to crack the rebellious skateboard market, had its ad agency hire a bunch of Ph.D. students in anthropology to produce ethnographic studies of skateboarders tastes. Eventually this led the company to hire the graffiti artist Futura, who designed a limited edition of the Dunk basketball sneaker that Nike made in the 1980s. The sneaker was sold through skateboard stores, and sneakerheads snapped it up. Like art museums, sports companies have found that the best way to tap into the coveted youth market is to bring outsider artists in.

title: Whats Wrong in the N.B.A.? Agent Spells It Out
description: The N.B.A. has been ruined by money, selfish players and opportunistic agents, and warped by an emphasis on entertainment over fundamentals. This diatribe can be heard on any bar stool, but it is coming from an N.B.A. agent.

title: A Wee Identity Crisis
description: Edinburgh

title: As Authentic as Authentic Gets
description: Before you order for the first time at the Taqueria Downtown, the owners would like you to note the list of their Ten Commandments posted there.

title: Tie Space Continuum
description: Since it is cautiously conceded that composers, poets and visual artists often function in the capacity of philosophers, we should feel reasonably confident in regarding lovers of music, poetry and painting as potential students of philosophy. So why not extend this exalted status to shoppers? Time to stock up on shirts? Think of yourself as a seeker of wearable truth.

title: Guitar Heroes, Make That Heroines, in Indie Rock
description: MARNIE STERN, 30, played her electric guitar in the basement performance space of Cake Shop on Ludlow Street last month. This would have been a familiar occurrence if she were knocking out punk rock bar chords, or plucking an airy folk melody. But both of Ms. Sterns hands moved swiftly along the fretboard like pale spiders, her fingertips hammering the strings to create a looping rush of notes, which combined with the recorded guitar and drum tracks from her iPod into a cyclone of vaguely heavy metal-ish rock. She wore Gap-style street clothes  a long-sleeve pink T-shirt and jeans  and mostly watched her hands as she played. But at one point, a pink pick clutched in her teeth, she tipped her small, ski-jump nose in the air, closed her eyes, and lets her blond hair fall behind her in a classic snapshot of guitar-god nirvana.

title: The Week on Long Island
description: Nassau Comptroller Warns County on Finances

title: Black Jacobins
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridget Lowell, Joseph Bonfiglio III
description: Bridget Dominique Lowell, the daughter of Clare Lowell and James Lowell, both of Huntington, N.Y., was married last evening to Joseph Bonfiglio III, the son of Barbara Bonfiglio of Durham, N.C. The Rev. Ray Gooch, a United Methodist minister, officiated at Bay 7, an event space in Durham, and Matthew Pierce, a friend of the couples and a seminary graduate, participated in the ceremony.

title: Prosecutors Ouster Shifts Political Order
description: SANTA FE, N.M., March 9  The snow-dusted mesas and million-dollar adobes look enchanting as ever, but the political landscape here has shifted sharply since the Justice Department ousted a onetime Republican darling as United States attorney in New Mexico after party loyalists complained that he was not tough enough on crooked Democrats.

title: Power to the People
description: College Park, Md.

title: Jennifer Peters, Michael Lewis
description: Jennifer Julia Peters, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Runals Peters of Cold Spring Harbor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Michael Jason Lewis, the son of Sandra B. Lewis of Hauppauge, N.Y., and Jules S. Lewis of Coram, N.Y. The Rev. Dariusz Koszyk performed the ceremony at St. Dominic Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, N.Y., with Rabbi Allen Block taking part.

title: Nets Lose Their Leaders, Then Lose Their Way Against the Spurs
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 10  The frustration of a disappointing season boiled over for the Nets on Saturday night when their captain, Jason Kidd, and coach, Lawrence Frank, were ejected from a game against the San Antonio Spurs for arguing with the referees.

title: Why Sellers May Be Disappointed
description: HOME sellers beware. Despite what real estate industry data might suggest, sales prices were down by 10 to 20 percent around the state last year  and prices are still flat in most locales, according to an East Brunswick analyst who keeps day-to-day tabs on New Jersey residential transactions.

title: In Uruguay, Bush Finds Friendly Ear and Taste of Home
description: ESTANCIA ANCHORENA, Uruguay, March 10  Of all of the Latin American nations President Bush is visiting this week, this one is the smallest, with a population that is roughly half that of New York City.

title: The Nights Young, So Find a Gray Bar
description: NEW YORK does not lack for hip bars that drip with beautiful people sipping $12 drinks, being assaulted by thumping music and feeling that they have found the center of the nightlife universe.

title: Muslim Inmates Demand Equality on Their Plates
description: Valhalla

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 25 in T: Womens Fashion magazine, about the director and artist David Lynch, rendered the title of a 1923 book by Robert Henri incorrectly. It is The Art Spirit, not The Spirit of Art.

title: Drowsy Driving Raises Legal Issues
description: UNLIKE drunken driving, drowsy driving leaves no obvious chemical markers. Drivers rarely self-report that they fell asleep, and few law enforcement agencies make a big effort to categorize accidents caused by tired drivers.

title: Land Trust Faces Deadline in $11 Million Deal
description: TWO years ago the Diocese of Trenton approached a conservation group based in Princeton Township with a land-use proposal that was both benevolent and self-serving. The diocese asked the D&R Greenway Land Trust if it could raise enough money to buy  and thus permanently preserve  337 acres in Hopewell Township graced with open fields, dense woods, busy streams and a hilltop vista worthy of a Frederic Church canvas.

title: And Im Not Your Girl, Gramps
description: THE vestibule of Sunnyside Community Services, in Queens, where 13 home health aides registered recently for a daylong workshop, resembles a welfare office with its banged-up furniture and worn-out faces.

title: To Karbala They Traveled, by Foot, Donkey, S.U.V. and Helicopter
description: KARBALA, Iraq, March 10  The Shiite pilgrims came here carrying bread and walking sticks and jugs of water. Adel Abdul Mahdi, the Shiite vice president of Iraq, carried three shrapnel wounds from a recent suicide bombing.

title: To Reach Me in Russia, Just Dial Brooklyn
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia

title: The Week in Connecticut
description: In the Daily Shuffle, Rail and Bus Ridership Rises

title: A Continent Away, Heartbreak Over Relatives Once Seen as Lucky
description: BAMAKO, Mali, March 10  Saturday was nearly unbearable for the women of the Soumare family. Each time Malian television replayed images from a fire thousands of miles away  of childrens bodies being carried from a charred house, of Malians wailing on the Bronx streets  the women here broke down too. In the living room of the familys compound, three women fainted and had to be revived.

title: Insuring Against Floods
description: MOST homeowners whose houses are within a flood zone designated by the Federal Emergency Management Agency know it, because they are required to buy flood insurance to get a mortgage. But a major storm could inundate outlying areas, too  either as a result of tidal surges or backups of sewage and drainage systems. Unfortunately, standard homeowner and co-op and condo policies exclude flood damage from storms.

title: 36 Hours in Charleston, S.C.
description: CHARLESTON became a new city in 2005. Once choked off from its northern suburbs by a pair of dangerously obsolete trussed spans, residents can now zip over the Cooper River along the new Arthur Ravenel Jr. Bridge  a 3.5-mile-long, eight-lane wonder. More than a traffic shortcut, the Ravenel Bridge has fundamentally altered Charleston's psychology. Nowhere is this more true than on the bridge's wide bike-and-pedestrian lane. Suburban moms from Mount Pleasant rub elbows with families from gritty downtown Charleston. And Lycra-wearing cyclists whiz past iPod-clutching joggers from the bustling Citadel and College of Charleston. It's a perfect symbol for Charleston, straddling the Old and New South.

title: What Rhymes With Queens?
description: THE last time Queens tried to pick a poet laureate, in 2004, there were 78 hopefuls to choose from. That year, the contest had gotten off to a slow start. The deadline for applicants had been extended twice, from December 2003 to January 2004 and then to April. By mid-March, only nine people had applied.

title: Theyll Do It Themselves, Thanks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.

title: Young Composer Finds His Fuel in Restlessness
description: THERE is no easy label to hang on Nico Muhly, a 25-year-old Juilliard-trained composer in New York. His music  typically small, elegant parcels filled with clear melodies, pulsating rhythms and the occasional alarming abrasion  has been performed at Carnegie Hall, Lincoln Center and prominent international halls. Vibrant, erudite and endlessly irreverent, Mr. Muhly sees no reason to ally himself with any particular stylistic camp. He doesnt need the company: he has more than 1,000 friends on his MySpace page.

title: Local Rule
description: THIS year, Schools Chancellor Joel Klein and Mayor Michael Bloomberg have proposed changes that would radically alter financing formulas for the city school system and revolutionize its existing bureaucratic management structure. City lawmakers and the State Board of Regents are nervous, but they shouldnt be. Despite what the critics say, the changes will work.

title: An Off Night for Francis Ends Right on Target
description: WASHINGTON, March 10  Steve Francis was a starter again Saturday night and, by the end of the evening, a star again.

title: Their Cups Runneth Over
description: IF you go out on the town with the Hold Steady, be sure to stock up on Advil to battle your hangover the next morning. This is the quintet that takes fierce pride in being dubbed a bar band, (from Brooklyn, no less) and whose refrain gonna walk around and drink some more from the song Party  is often taken as a direct order by the groups mostly male fan base.

title: Matthew Goode | Actor
description: Despite idolizing Dapper Dans like Richard Burton and David Niven while growing up, Matthew Goode considers himself a jeans-and-T-shirt type of bloke: I like minimum fuss  elegantly disheveled. He has played upper-class Britons in films like Woody Allens Match Point, but in his next movie, The Lookout, Goode appears as a psycho with a shaved head and a beard, a look he came to love. I dont really like my hair long; it makes me start to get a bit vain, he says. So, he prefers the monastic look? Yeah, but without the morals.

title: Marjabelle Y. Stewart, 82, White-Gloved Author, Dies
description: Marjabelle Young Stewart, who was widely known as the Queen of Couth for her vast, genteel empire of books and classes about etiquette, died March 3 in Kewanee, Ill. She was 82 and had lived in Kewanee for many years.

title: From Tiny Start to a Baking Empire
description: When Deanna Matthews mixed up a batch of fruit-nut cakes and brandied apricots back in 1978 in the kitchen of her 1812 farmhouse, she had no idea where her tiny project would lead.

title: The Failed Attorney General
description: During the hearing on his nomination as attorney general, Alberto Gonzales said he understood the difference between the job he held  President Bushs in-house lawyer  and the job he wanted, which was to represent all Americans as their chief law enforcement officer and a key defender of the Constitution. Two years later, it is obvious Mr. Gonzales does not have a clue about the difference.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 4 P.M. (HBO) WORLD CHAMPIONSHIP BOXING Its boxing day on HBO, starting with this 12-round heavyweight championship bout broadcast live from the S.A.P. Arena in Manheim, Germany. Wladimir Klitschko, whose 47-3 record includes an intimidating 42 knockouts, will defend his title against Ray Austin of Cleveland. Mr. Austins 24-3-4 record includes a relatively paltry 16 knockouts, but he has not lost a fight in five years. Following the Klitschko-Austin showdown, HBO will present Countdown to Barrera-Marquez, a half-hour teaser for next Saturdays super-featherweight title fight between Marco Antonio Barrera, the champion, and the challenger Juan Manuel Marquez. Expect profiles, career highlights, interviews, analysis and forecasts for the bout at the Mandalay Bay in Las Vegas.

title: Poetry in Slo-Mo
description: Like so many other Sunday-afternoon television viewers clutching bottles of beer, I was born to be a champion athlete, but somehow fate got in the way and instead I was mistakenly shunted into this career as a white-collar wage slave. Now, finding myself sitting at a computer in a room with a single window that gives out onto a courtyard when I should be warming up on a practice field in the morning sun, I have done what any self-respecting free agent would do when the game of life has passed him by: Ive become a fan.

title: Muscle Man
description: When the lights came on at the Dolce & Gabbana spring show, the scene resembled a cattle call in Sparta. The classical Greek aesthetic is a strong influence in mens fashion, Domenico Dolce says. We were definitely inspired by the spirit of the ancient Olympics, of a healthy mind and body  a mental and sensual freedom.

title: Directors Without Borders
description: Nearly seven years ago, the director Alfonso Cuarn called his friend Guillermo del Toro and told him to watch an incomplete movie he had just seen. The film, called Amores Perros, which translates, roughly, as love that is like a dog, was directed by a former D.J. named Alejandro Gonzlez Irritu. Like Cuarn, del Toro, a director of elegant, almost religious horror films, was dazzled by the movie. It was much too long, but its intertwined trio of stories, all tales of love and redemption, had ambition and weight: the film aimed to be no less than a fresco of Mexico City, with all its chaos and violence and beauty. I did not know Guillermo, Irritu recalled recently, still amused by the memory. When he showed up at my door, he said, I am in love with your movie. Ill sleep on your couch and we can fix Amores Perros in four or five days.

title: He Befriended a Serial Killer, and Opened the Door to God
description: COTTAGE GROVE, Wis.

title: Snchez, Arriving Early to Mets Camp, Apologizes for Tardiness
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 10  The sun rose here at 6:36 a.m. Saturday, by which time Duaner Snchez was driving to his scheduled 8 a.m. meeting with Manager Willie Randolph and General Manager Omar Minaya.

title: All Are Welcome at These Open Houses (Except for the Signs)
description: Consider it fallout from the citys still-buoyant real estate market.

title: Amy Schwartz, Scott Fink
description: Amy Jill Schwartz and Dr. Scott Andrew Fink are to be married this afternoon at Temple Beth Torah in Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Howard Stecker will perform the ceremony.

title: South Korea Reviews Its Dark Past, but the Pace Is Slow
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 9  In his final days, the Venerable Bogwang, a fisherman turned Buddhist monk, wrestled with his conscience. The scriptures he revered exhorted him to leave behind the entanglements of the material world.

title: Au Naturel Is the Fashion on Some Gay Cruises
description: Gay cruises are nothing new, but a gay cruise on a five-star luxury sailing ship, on which the staterooms are outfitted with fine linens, flat-screen televisions and iPods, and the guests are outfitted in, well, nothing, could be the latest trend to hit the seas.

title: In March, Being Methodical Is One Way to Drive Foes Mad
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10  Counting down the shot clock is a hallmark of every vocal student section, but nowhere is the practice more prevalent and more significant than at Washington State.

title: Why Were Fed Up With State Legislators; Wherever You Are, Youre a New Yorker; Denying Parole: The Safest Choice? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Out There
description: Three days after learning that he won the 2006 Nobel Prize in Physics, George Smoot was talking about the universe. Sitting across from him in his office at the University of California, Berkeley, was Saul Perlmutter, a fellow cosmologist and a probable future Nobelist in Physics himself. Bearded, booming, eyes pinwheeling from adrenaline and lack of sleep, Smoot leaned back in his chair. Perlmutter, onetime acolyte, longtime colleague, now heir apparent, leaned forward in his.

title: Officer Down
description: Whether Detective Superintendent Andy Dalziel survives DEATH COMES FOR THE FAT MAN (HarperCollins, $24.95) is almost beside the point. Reginald Hills crude and canny policeman (the Marcus Aurelius of mid-Yorkshire to those who love him) is nothing less than a force of nature in these idiosyncratic procedurals, and the act of terrorism that has his life hanging by a thread may pose an even graver threat to the natural order of his kind of genre novel.

title: Follow the Earrings, and Find the Mystery Woman
description: FOR years, every time I saw Max Ophlss romantic masterpiece of 1953, The Earrings of Madame de ..., the film left me with the nagging impression that it was based on some minor classic of late 19th-century or early 20th-century European literature that I had shamefully neglected to read. Surely it would be found on the shelf with Guy de Maupassant (Le Plaisir), Arthur Schnitzler (La Ronde) and Stefan Zweig (Letter From an Unknown Woman), the great and subtle ironists from whom Ophls drew some of his most enduring work.

title: Identity Crisis
description: Counting the Cost of a Chargeback

title: A Tiki Bar Fit for a Prince
description: LONDON

title: Where Everybody Knows Your Parking Space
description: AT magic hour in TriBeCa on a warmish February evening, the setting sun glints off the brick-and-gilt facade of the Western Union building, and black Labs appear on the sidewalk, tugging at owners swaddled in cashmere overcoats. As the cobbled streets empty, the lights flicker on across an entire floor of a sooty industrial gray building, a telltale sign of a luxury loft within.

title: Paradise Lost; Praise Dance; Ars Nova; The Police
description: PARADISE LOST

title: Bush Heads to Colombia as Scandal Taints Alliance
description: BOGOT, Colombia, March 10  The Bush administration has no closer ally in South America than Colombia, the recipient of more than $4 billion in American aid this decade to combat drug trafficking and guerrilla insurgencies. But a widening scandal tying paramilitary death squads and drug traffickers to close supporters of President lvaro Uribe is clouding President Bushs brief visit here on Sunday.

title: Reporting the News Even When a Competitor Gets There First
description: WHY were readers of The New York Times left without a word of news coverage of the Walter Reed Army Medical Center scandal for six days after it had been exposed by The Washington Post? That was the question posed to me in the wake of The Posts Feb. 18 scoop by readers thirsty for news of the poor care given those wounded in Iraq.

title: Bush Addresses Misuse of F.B.I. Subpoenas
description: ESTANCIA ANCHORENA, Uruguay, March 10  President Bush acknowledged on Saturday F.B.I. shortfallings in the disclosure that the bureau improperly used the USA Patriot Act to obtain thousands of business, financial and other records in the United States.

title: Welcoming Gardens, Whispering Photograph Me
description: The gasps you may hear throughout the rooms of the Hudson River Museum this month are the sounds of visitors welcoming an early spring. Contemporary Photography and the Garden, which brings together the works of 16 American and European artists, is all about flowers and greenery  cultivated, wild, mysterious and preserved.

title: A Housing Fair for the West Bank; Selling Your Home? Dont Call an Agent (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Iranian Seeks to Make Case for Nuclear Program
description: TEHRAN, March 11  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran wants to take part in a meeting of the United Nations Security Council to brief member states about Irans nuclear program, a government spokesman said on state-run television today.

title: For the Converted, and a Few Others
description: SOME vegetarians exhibit a missionary impulse, forever trying to convince their friends that eating meat is cruel, unhealthy or wasteful. When spoken words  or a copy of The Jungle  fail to persuade, these herbivores may start using disturbing visual aids: photographs of caged calves or documentaries on the short, brutish lives of confined chickens.

title: Reporters and Sources Slowed Their Dance to Show the Steps
description: WASHINGTON

title: Sara Kaufman and Eric Greenberg
description: Sara Miriam Kaufman and Eric J. Greenberg were married last night at the Forest Hills Jewish Center in Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik performed the ceremony.

title: The Last Boys of Summer
description: Who pitched the last game at Ebbets Field?

title: Bookshelf
description: THE POLICE CLOUD. By Christoph Niemann. Schwartz & Wade/Random House. $15.99. (Ages 3 to 7) There once was a cloud who lived in a big city. Ever since he had been a small puff, he had dreamed of being a police officer. This daffy premise is worked out with perfect dreamlike logic, as the cotton-ball cloud perches on a chair to ask the police chief for a job, and soon floats happily over a busy city street. Though the clouds career is brief, it takes an unexpected turn that works out for everyone. Niemanns work often appears on the cover of The New Yorker and in this publication, and this is his first book for children.

title: Fuel Lines
description: Theres a lot of stuff we consume while barely pausing to consider where it comes from; it is easy, these days, to be insulated from production. Inquisitive writers profitably explore the knowledge gap: recent work about the life stories of handguns, French fries and Panama hats comes to mind. Tracy Kidder chronicled the creation of a computer in The Soul of a New Machine, and last year Michael Pollan traced the sources of our dinners in The Omnivores Dilemma. This year comes something new about those obscure practicalities of how does it get here: Oil on the Brain, by Lisa Margonelli.

title: On the Road With Bush and Chvez
description: Caracas, Venezuela

title: Ye Olde High-End Condo
description: NEW condominiums on the East End are rare enough that any proposal grabs attention, but the interest is most intense when the proposal involves a well-known property.

title: A Widows Might
description: In 1915, the 18-year-old Frulein Klindworth married Siegfried Wagner, and thus became part of the most prominent  not to say scary  cultural dynasty in the Kaisers Reich. And yet she wasnt even German. Born Winifred Marjorie Williams, she became German by adoption after she was sent from a Sussex orphanage to Berlin to be looked after by elderly distant relations named Klindworth.

title: Still Swinging
description: For years, the British director Peter Whitehead has been a legend among a rarefied group of cinastes. Now the rest of us will be able to enjoy his work. A documentary about his life, In the Beginning Was the Image, by Paul Cronin, will be screened this spring at the Tribeca Film Festival. Whitehead is best known for his rare footage of the Rolling Stones and Pink Floyd in the 1960s, though it was his cinma vrit style that deftly captured the shifting tides of his era. In The Fall, a Godardian stew of art and politics in America, Whitehead documented the 1968 student protests at Columbia University; the kaleidoscopic Tonite Lets All Make Love in London (1967) immortalized the swinging London scene, including players like David Hockney, Julie Christie and Michael Caine. More handsome than most of his pop-star subjects, the Cambridge-educated Whitehead squired plenty of groovy glamazons: Nico, Nathalie Delon, Niki de Saint Phalle and Dido Goldsmith. By the end of the decade, however, he had dropped out of the scene to raise falcons and later went on to write esoteric novels. Now that his films are once again on the festival circuit, perhaps its time for a proper bow.

title: Aid Workers and Military (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Made for Walking
description: Even after a brief winter freeze, stepping outside in warmer weather brings a smile and stokes the appetite. Its a perfect time for a walk down the peaceful, romantic stretch of West Fourth Street from Eighth Avenue to Seventh Avenue South, with its historic brick town houses. This charming street is lined with small restaurants and cafes, including a few that have opened since last summer.

title: A Memento of Romantic Spain
description: THERE are few forgotten musical masters. A kind of universal quality control seems to be at work, gradually editing out the less-than-memorable and holding on to what we ought to keep in mind. Isaac Albniz may be an exception, although as more contemporary pianists come to grips with the physical difficulties of his Iberia, Albniz is edging into the public consciousness.

title: Another Warning on Warming
description: If President Bush requires any more proof that he sits on the wrong side of the global warming debate, he should listen to his own scientists. An internal draft of a report the administration will soon forward to the United Nations shows that his program of voluntary reductions has done little to stop the rise in greenhouse gases generated in this country.

title: Reflections on Life as a Shaker-Upper
description: SINCE the 1960s the playwright, director and designer Richard Foreman has been the emperor of New York experimental theater, with some constants in those experiments: nonlinear tableaus about the unconscious mind, deliriously decorated sets, actors dressed like commandos from Dr. Seusss special forces. Voices (often Mr. Foremans own) and, lately, projected films add to the sensory overload.

title: Guys Night Out
description: My father lives in the suburbs and doesnt get out much. When he does get out, he enjoys himself. The man is certainly capable of joy. Its just that his happiness makes my mother uncomfortable. Disco-dancing at weddings, eating dessert with too much gusto, drumming on the kitchen table to a radio jingle  they all rub her the wrong way. If my father even laughs too loudly, my mother tells him hes getting punchy. That usually quiets him down.

title: Man of the Hour
description: Since its unheralded arrival at a Greenwich Village theater in 1965, Man of La Mancha has become something of a warhorse, to put it mildly. So its easy to forget that back then it was the very antithesis of what people expected musicals to be. Its central character, Miguel de Cervantes, was in jail. And his central character, Don Quixote, was on his deathbed before long. Written by Dale Wasserman, the show was dark, it was spare, it had no jaunty production numbers. In fact, it had no chorus. You couldnt cheer up with a drink at intermission  it didnt have an intermission, either. And there was certainly no way to know that Mitch Leigh and Joe Darions sappiest song would become the shows most famous.

title: Song of My Former Self
description: Eleven years ago, at 19, I was a nice, Midwestern Korean girl living in a decrepit former frat house in St. Paul complete with lava lamps, a beyond-creepy laundry room and an array of Grateful Dead skull bongs. I happened to be a dead ringer for James Iha, the guitarist from the Smashing Pumpkins, except for the amateur eyeliner job and frosty mauve lipstick. I sported a beauty-school shag, courtesy of a friend of a friend, complete with razored ends and a platinum skunk stripe. I got by as a fashion-design student with a little familial support and a meager part-time job in a vintage boutique called Heartbreaker. I remember wearing a pastel polyester vintage chevron cardigan  which looked like a very happy and tacky Easter basket  and white platforms with knee socks in the abysmal Minnesota sleet. I was actually more Tokyo-pop-meets-Vegas than I-know-the-band grunge, which would have been to my utter dismay, had I bothered to study myself more closely.

title: Hannah Swacker, Jesse Kurnit
description: Hannah Bess Swacker, a daughter of Sharon H. Swacker of Brooklyn and Robert B. Swacker of Manhattan, was married last evening to Jesse Max Kurnit, the son of Susan and Paul D. Kurnit of Cortlandt Manor, N.Y. Rabbi Stacy Bergman officiated at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Gentlemen of the Road
description: Chapter 7: On the Seizing of a Low Moment

title: Karin Levine, Scott Alswang
description: Karin Tammy Levine and Scott Bruce Alswang were married last evening by Rabbi William Kraus at the Pleasantdale Chateau, a party space in West Orange, N.J.

title: Suburbias Northward Crawl
description: HYDE PARK

title: Unchecked Hitting Returns to the N.H.L.
description: Since its return from the 2004-5 lockout, the N.H.L. had been almost completely free of ugly and dangerous play. Referees have called games closely, by the book, removing much of the obstruction that clogged the game over the preceding 10 years and establishing an atmosphere largely free of gratuitous mayhem.

title: Purim, Just Another Reason to Party
description: Last Saturday, at the start of the Jewish holiday of Purim, Rabbi Shmuel Lein read from a ceremonial scroll at the Chabad of North Brooklyn, a center of Hasidic Jewish culture on Bedford Avenue and North Fifth Street in Williamsburg.

title: Selig Echoes Owner and Urges Matthews to Clear the Air
description: TEMPE, Ariz., March 10  The Los Angeles Angels closed their clubhouse at 10 a.m. on Saturday so the players could watch a videotape that was produced by Major League Baseball and is required viewing for each team. The subject of the 15-minute tape was baseballs drug program.

title: A FlAW HE CANT OVERlOOK
description: Two summers ago, a computer consultant and cartoonist named William Levin was strolling down Seventh Avenue in Park Slope when the window of Jackrabbit Sports caught his eye. Above a display of shoes was a sign advertising marathon and triathlon training programs. An individual with an untrained eye might not have given the sign a second glance. But to Mr. Levin, the chubby capital letters contained a serious flaw.

title: Correction
description: A review on Feb. 11 about Maravich, by Wayne Federman and Marshall Terrill, and Pistol: The Life of Pete Maravich, by Mark Kriegel, referred incorrectly to the heart defect that led to Maravichs death in 1988. It was congenital; there is no indication that it was genetic.

title: Linda Shulsky and Philip Pomper
description: Linda Rosenfeld Shulsky and Philip Pomper are to be married today by Rabbi Ruth Gais at the brides home in New York.

title: Thousands Flee as Sri Lankan Forces Strike at Rebels
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, March 10  Thousands of civilians fled into government-controlled territory on Friday and Saturday as the military started a fresh offensive to capture rebel-held areas in eastern Sri Lanka.

title: A Son and a Protg Gets His Moment
description: Later this week, Howie Dickenman will place his fathers bow tie in his jacket pocket, a reminder that he is the lifer son of a lifer coach.

title: Thinking Green, Not Pumping It
description: LOS ANGELES

title: The Death of a Family Man
description: THE last time Xia Gui Ping spoke to her husband, Zhang Hongqi, it was Feb. 18, the first day of the Lunar New Year. The phone rang at 7 that morning in her house in Luoyang City, in eastern China. On the line was Mr. Zhang, making the call he had made every day for five years.

title: Harlems Newest Beacon
description: GENTRIFICATION in Harlem has taken many forms, as the neighborhood has revived and celebrated its past, and last week it reached a new milestone: its first Upper East Side-style high-rise condominium tower, to rise 30 stories above the low-rise brownstones for which the nearby Mount Morris Park Historic District is known.

title: Of Private Equity, Politics and Income Taxes
description: UNCLE SAM may be coming after the buyout kings.

title: Iraqis Flee City as Militants Burn Homes
description: BAGHDAD, March 11  Sunni militants burned homes in a mixed city northeast of Baghdad on Saturday and Sunday, forcing dozens of families to flee and raising the specter of a new intimidation tactic in Iraqs evolving civil war, Iraqi officials and witnesses said.

title: On Holy Day, Iraqi Soldiers Stop Bomber; 7 of Them Die
description: BAGHDAD, March 10  On one of the holiest days in the Shiite calendar, a suicide car bomber on Saturday tried to circumvent a military checkpoint on a bridge leading to Sadr City, a vast Shiite neighborhood, apparently intending to plow into a crowd of people nearby, Iraqi and American authorities said.

title: Jody Litwin, Brian Paul
description: Jody Leigh Litwin and Brian Jeremy Paul are to be married this evening by Rabbi Michael Rothbaum at Waters Edge, a restaurant in Long Island City, Queens.

title: Ominous Rap, Bedroom Pop and Long-Buried Jazz
description: Dlek

title: Melissa Kishel, Brian Forman
description: Melissa Alison Kishel, a daughter of Susan and Paul Kishel of Dix Hills, N.Y., was married yesterday to Brian Robert Forman, the son of Marsha and Gary Forman of New City, N.Y. Rabbi David H. Chanofsky officiated at Capitale, an events space in New York.

title: Welcome Sight on the West Side
description: Best Cellars, specializing in inexpensive wine at 1291 Lexington Avenue (87th Street) since 1996, has opened a boutique at 2246 Broadway (80th Street), opposite Zabars.

title: Hitlers Beneficiaries
description: To the Editor:

title: Between Black and Immigrant Muslims, an Uneasy Alliance
description: Under the glistening dome of a mosque on Long Island, hundreds of men sat cross-legged on the floor. Many were doctors and engineers born in Pakistan and India. Dressed in khakis, polo shirts and the odd silk tunic, they fidgeted and whispered.

title: Whats on Sunday Night
description: 8 P.M. (Showtime) AN INCONVENIENT TRUTH (2006). This newly anointed Academy Award winner for best documentary, directed by Davis Guggenheim, follows former Vice President Al Gore as he lectures on the dangers of global warming and calls for immediate action to curb what he calls a dire situation  one that can no longer been seen merely as a political issue. Says Mr. Gore, It is now clear that we face a deepening global climate crisis that requires us to act boldly, quickly and wisely.

title: Win a Trip, and See a Different World
description: Cast your eyes above and meet Hidaya Abatemam, whom I met last month in a remote area of southern Ethiopia. She is 6 years old and weighs 17 pounds.

title: Laminated Windows Keep Out the Din
description: GOOD windows keep out rain and snow, and better windows keep out cold, wind and heat. But most windows arent very good at stopping noise.

title: Human / Nature
description: Why devote oneself to that aggressively minor genre, poetry, when novels and screenplays and tell-all memoirs get more notice and make more money? Brad Leithauser answers that question in Curves and Angles, or at least he lets Jorge Luis Borges answer it for him: the second of this new books three sections consists of translations (Leithauser cautiously calls them adaptations) of some of the Argentinian writers work, one of which, Poem Written in a Copy of Beowulf,  begins by wondering why you would struggle to learn a difficult new language  English, in Borgess case  when youre only going to forget it anyway.

title: Never Mind the Bordeaux
description: Ive had only one real job in my life. I know what youre thinking, but managing the Sex Pistols wasnt a job; it was a lifestyle that consisted of creating an environment that you could run wild in. The boring job was in London in 1962, when I was 16. I hadnt done well on my exams  in fact, I hadnt bothered to take most of them. University was not in the cards.

title: Where Tugboats Chug and Ikeas Coming
description: RED HOOK, a nub of a Brooklyn peninsula jutting into the Buttermilk Channel opposite Governors Island, is perhaps not everyones ideal place to live. A high-crime area not very long ago, it is at times eerily silent, at others mournfully full of the noise of industry. Broken glass and cracked sidewalks can still be found; amenities, while on the increase, are still relatively few. Large chunks of formerly solid rows of houses have been torn out. And by the way, theres no subway stop.

title: Annals of Poetry
description: The history of American poetry, like the history of America itself, is a story of ingenuity, sacrifice, hard work and sticking it to people when they least expect it. Whether its Ezra Pound dismissing his benefactor Amy Lowell as a hippopoetess or Yvor Winters accusing his friend Hart Crane of possessing flaws akin to a public catastrophe, you can count on the occasional bushwhacking in the land of what Horace called the touchy tribe.

title: The Local Buzz
description: Cornwall, N.Y.

title: A Renaissance in Full Bloom for Aging Theaters
description: Torrington

title: Unsivilized
description: Mr. Mark Twain went a little easy on Pap Finn, it appears, in The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, but that aint no matter. Here comes Mr. Jon Clinch, 123 years later, to finally help us probe beneath Paps surface charm  his alcohol-soaked destitution; his petty thievery; his hatred of Negroes; his coercive, violent, money-leeching treatment of his son, Huck  and discover, lets face it, that the man had issues.

title: In March, Being Methodical Is One Way to Drive Foes Mad
description: LOS ANGELES, March 10  Counting down the shot clock is a hallmark of every vocal student section, but nowhere is the practice more prevalent and more significant than at Washington State.

title: Palestinian Christians Look Back on a Year of Troubles
description: TAYBEH, West Bank  Jack Massis, 51, a grocer here in this last entirely Christian village in the West Bank, speaks matter-of-factly about how two of his teenage sons were beaten with clubs last month.

title: Catfish Sandwich to Go. Hold the Candlelight.
description: MICHAEL SCALISI, a 40-year-old screenwriter, lives just down the block from Jezebel, a Hells Kitchen restaurant famous for its soulful food and celebrity-heavy clientele. But the other evening, Mr. Scalisi could be found hovering right inside the restaurants kitchen door, there to collect what he described as home cooking but without the home  in this case, an order of barbecued salmon.

title: Will Vivis Law Be Vivis Legacy?
description: More than a year after the slim white whippet with brown markings escaped from the tarmac of Kennedy Airport, the calls are still coming in from throughout the city, even from the Bronx.

title: One Bullet Away From What?
description: WASHINGTON

title: Medicaid Costs Can Be in Eye of the Crusader
description: In the escalating public battle over his budget cuts, Gov. Eliot Spitzer has offered several critiques of the states vast health care system, some unquestionably true, and some subtle and complex.

title: Iraqs Leader Asks for Aid in Curbing Strife
description: BAGHDAD, March 10  Addressing representatives of 13 nations and three international groups, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki opened a much-anticipated regional conference here with a plea to Iraqs neighbors to back his efforts to control the violence engulfing the country by refusing to finance attacks or allow foreign fighters to cross their borders.

title: Admire the Footwork, but Mind the Hands
description: LONDON

title: Elizabeth Galbreath, Ambrose Carr III
description: Elizabeth Ford Galbreath, a daughter of Eugenie and Michael Galbreath of Greenwich, Conn., was married last evening to Ambrose Aloysius Carr III, the son of Mr. Carr Jr. of Quogue, N.Y., and the late Nancy Carr. The Rev. Michael R. Moynihan officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Vincent Ferrer in New York.

title: Halliburton to Move Headquarters to Dubai
description: HOUSTON, March 11  Halliburton, the big energy services company, said today that it would open a corporate headquarters in the United Arab Emirates city of Dubai and move its chairman and chief executive, David J. Lesar, there.

title: Mr. 76759 Designs His Dream House
description: MINOR improvements still occur to him, but Herman Wallace has more or less finished his dream house. Its got a yellow kitchen, a hobby shop and custom-made pecan cabinets. It should be noted that no actual house exists, but this is understandable. Mr. Wallace has been in solitary confinement at the Louisiana State Penitentiary in Angola for the last 34 years.

title: Like Father, Like Son: Creating a Spark at the Garden
