description: During the second half of Georgetowns 84-82 victory against Notre Dame on Friday night in the Big East semifinal at Madison Square Garden, Hoyas Coach John Thompson III walked toward the middle of the court to forward Patrick Ewing Jr., who was approaching the bench during a timeout.

title: The Week in New Jersey
description: A New Owner for a Hot Political Site

title: A Jury Pool Untainted, Barbeque and All
description: Denis Collins, Juror No. 9, said he never expected to be picked to hear the case against I. Lewis Libby Jr., the former aide to Vice President Dick Cheney who was ensnared in the leaking of a C.I.A. operatives name to reporters.

title: Voters Accept Divorced Candidates, but They Have Limits
description: ALREADY in this pre-presidential year, the question is out and about: How judgmental will the public be of candidates, how demanding of idealized personal lives and vintage family values?

title: Rebecca Elin, Mark Cahan
description: Rebecca Tansman Elin, the daughter of Susan T. Elin and Joel A. Elin of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married last evening to Mark Stewart Cahan, a son of Andrea J. Cahan and Dr. Frederick M. Cahan of Highland Park, Ill. Rabbi Avraham Weiss officiated at the Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers in Manhattan.

title: Beyond the Pleasure Principle
description: It is a point of pride among baby boomers that after our kids leave home, we enjoy a continuing closeness with them that our parents rarely had with us. We certainly do keep in touch: 80 percent of 18- to 25-year-olds had talked to their parents in the past day, according to A Portrait of Generation Next, a recent study conducted by the Pew Research Center in tandem with MacNeil/Lehrer Productions. Yet if the survey is any guide, Gen Nexters arent getting the credit they deserve for being  as many of them told pollsters they felt they were unique and distinct. It is not easy carving out your niche in the shadow of parents who still cant get over what an exceptional generation they belong to.

title: Finally, She Hears a Yes
description: IT was the job hunt, not the apartment hunt, that Ali Schmitz thought would be tough.

title: Upgrading New Yorks Courts
description: The United States Supreme Court has added to its docket for next term an appeal of recent lower court decisions invalidating New Yorks clubhouse-controlled judicial election system. As a result, the legal pressure to come up with a replacement for the discredited election process by the end of the current legislative session has been lifted, greatly diminishing the chances that Albany will act. The silver lining, if there is one, is that Gov. Eliot Spitzer and state lawmakers can now devote more attention to other court reform issues:

title: The Pirates of Pendants
description: Devon Turnbull, a young designer who is part of a Manhattan fashion collective called Nom de Guerre, is not what youd call a mamas boy  but he does like wearing her pearls. A few years ago, when she gave them to him, he had all 109 restrung onto a gold-link chain that hangs below his waist, like something between a prayer shawl and an overextended rosary. He took up pearl wearing for complex spiritual reasons having to do with Transcendental Meditation and a system of Vedic astrology called Jyotish. But I also just always liked pearls, Turnbull says.

title: The Education of a Publisher
description: LAST Monday, Jared Kushner, the boy publisher of The New York Observer, was nestled in a wingback chair in the book-strewn office of the newspapers longtime editor, Peter Kaplan. They were talking about Mr. Kushners latest acquisition, the Web site politicsnj.com. The more stuff he buys, Mr. Kaplan, said, leaning back, the happier I am.

title: Daydreams for Runner Whos Not Quitting His Day Job
description: In track and field, some professionals train and compete full time and others, not quite as good as the stars, have to work full time as well.

title: Louisville, Ky.: 21c Hotel Museum
description: THE BASICS

title: Facing Things That Destroy Your Life
description: ADDICTION, whether to drugs or alcohol, doesnt lack for TV exposure. The likes of Entertainment Tonight and Access Hollywood seem to exist these days to chronicle various stars spins in and out of rehabilitation facilities.

title: A Small Colt Gets by With a Big Heart
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 10  Circular Quay is a slight colt like his father, Thunder Gulch, and Saturday here in the 94th running of the Louisiana Derby he demonstrated that he inherited an attribute far more important than his diminutive stature. He has his fathers big heart.

title: Digging for the Roots of American Theater
description: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.

title: A Return Engagement: Get Shorty
description: There was a time when schoolboys could hardly wait to trade in their little jackets and knee pants for a real suit with trousers, just like Dads. But if designers have their way, grown men could be revisiting their preteens. Thom Brownes shrunken tailoring probably sparked the revival; last year he even showed gray flannel shorts suits for ice-skating. Now others have zeroed in, albeit in more relaxed ways: Michael Kors, Ralph Lauren, Louis Vuitton and Dsquared are teaming shorts with casual jackets and sandals or loafers. It was British soldiers in 19th-century India who first bared their legs by cutting off their pants; soon after, shorts were standard issue for British uniforms in tropical climates. Wealthy Americans in Bermuda became familiar with the look, and by the mid-1930s, stylish men of means wore navy sports jackets with white tennis shorts off court and double-breasted blazers with gray flannel shorts for sailing or drinks at the yacht club.After World War II, things became more democratic. Casual summer shorts popped up on campuses (often worn with jackets), and returning veterans embraced them as the perfect uniform for mowing the lawn. A few brave retailers even tried to sell businessmans special three-piece shorts suits, but, thanks in part to air-conditioning, the idea mercifully never caught on. By the 60s, stodgy shorts had given way to hip cutoff jeans. In our own era of stylistic appropriation, anyof these versions just might work, handled properly. For creative types, tailored Bermudas and an unlined jacket in summer seem the height of style. One conceit wed rather not endorse: the preppy custom of exchanging vows at a garden wedding, in jacket, bow tie, shorts and knee socks. A marriage that begins like that is bound to end badly.

title: The Little Puritans
description: Not long ago, after a nice outdoor dinner on Jamaica, my brother and I ordered drinks and lighted cigarettes. My delightful nephew, who is 12, became miserable. You really have to put those out, he told us. You could die.

title: Maeve Hebert, Michael Ward
description: Maeve Cathleen Hebert, a daughter of Grace and Bernard Hebert of Paducah, Ky., was married last evening to Michael Joseph Ward, the son of Anita and Robert Ward of Northford, Conn. Joyce Palmer, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated at the City Club of Washington.

title: William Carroll and Leo Cardini
description: William Lee Carroll and Leo Cardini were joined in a civil union on Thursday in the ceremony room in the offices of the Lyndhurst Health Department in Lyndhurst, N.J. Mayor Richard J. DiLascio of Lyndhurst officiated.

title: Weird and Weirder Numbers on Pay Reports
description: PORING over executive pay filings  packed as they are with all the new details that the Securities and Exchange Commission requires  is turning out to be, no surprise, an exercise in exhaustion. Asking for additional data in the filings, the regulators said, would make them more illuminating.

title: Chicer by the Dozen
description: The Starbury

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article last Sunday in Play magazine about the Washington Wizards star Gilbert Arenas misidentified the device he installed in his home to improve his conditioning. It is a hypobaric chamber, which simulates high altitude conditions  not a hyperbaric chamber, which helps the body absorb oxygen.

title: Correction: Francesca von Habsburg
description: A credit with an article on Feb. 25 about Francesca von Habsburg, the Austrian society and art figure, omitted the name of one of the designers of the clothes she was wearing. While the boots were indeed by Rick Owens, the dress was by Jean Paul Gaultier.

title: Defender of the Faith
description: This is a depressing and unpleasant book. To be sure, any story that starts with the rise of fascism and ends with Al Qaeda is unlikely to be uplifting. And Michael Burleighs catalog of delusion and violence, much of it in the name of higher causes and transcendent faiths, casts the 20th century in a distinctly unflattering light. But what makes his latest book a truly grim read is the relentlessly mean-spirited tone, together with some of the more troubling interpretations and asides.

title: Love Hurts
description: Michael Parkers shiftless characters arent the type youd introduce to your sister  not if you liked her. They steal from their dead grandmothers to buy a few cans of malt liquor, rummage between the couch cushions in other peoples houses for stray quarters or loiter outside their exes homes until the police tell them to stop. Theyve made messes of their lives and are in the process of making them worse.

title: A Culinary Odyssey, on a Path Blazed by Orwell
description: GEORGE ORWELL, who memorably sketched the stark existence of living on bread and thin soup in Paris in the 1930s, hardly seems like an obvious guide to exotic food in the tropics. Yet, in his classic novel Burmese Days, Orwell creates a vibrant scene of his hero and heroine wandering through market stalls filled with ripe pomelos the size of green moons, red bananas, dried fish, crimson chilies, ducks cured like hams, larvae of the rhinoceros beetle, heart-shaped betel leaves, and baskets of heliotrope-colored prawns the size of lobsters.

title: The Way We Deal With Day Laborers
description: FARMINGDALE

title: This Time, the Turbulence May Last Awhile
description: AFTER starting the year on a positive note, the markets began to backtrack on fears of economic troubles ahead. At the same time, a fresh round of geopolitical concerns pushed oil prices above $60 a barrel. And market volatility returned with a vengeance, raising fears that a full-blown market correction could be imminent.

title: A Documentary Series With a Personal Touch
description: SOMETIMES, Robert Richter says, feedback is gratifying, as when a World War II veteran thanked him for his documentary The Last Atomic Bomb, which focuses on a woman who survived the bombing of Nagasaki, Japan, and now travels the globe to promote nuclear disarmament.

title: It Takes Green to Be Green
description: Government can give, but it can also take away. Nobody knows that better than Charles and Susan Rouse of New Jersey.

title: Books Strew the Path to the Altar
description: TO be sure she is hitched without a glitch, Sarah Cartwright has spent $150 for books on advice, planning and etiquette for her wedding on June 7. These include Wedding Etiquette Hell: The Brides Bible to Avoiding Everlasting Damnation by Jeanne Hamilton and Bridal Bargains: Secrets to Throwing a Fantastic Wedding on a Realistic Budget by Denise and Alan Fields.

title: Fed Up
description: Barry Glassner has made it his business to set credulous consumers of mass media straight. His best-known book, The Culture of Fear, took apart several stories poised somewhere between urban myth and the lead item on the evening news, arguing that according to statistics, teenage moms arent really tearing up the fabric of society, road rage is less of a problem than lightning strikes, and gun control, not building more prisons, might be the best way of stopping violent crime.

title: A Blast From the Past or a Bust in the Future?
description: Projecting how a baseball player will perform is no magic science.

title: New York Tinderbox
description: FIRST came chaos, a neighbor said, then death.

title: Detail Orientation
description: After shopping in vain for himself, Phillip Lim, the designer behind the womens label 3.1 Phillip Lim, gave up and decided, If you cant find it, why not make it? The resulting mens line, which makes its debut at Barneys New York and Jake in Chicago this spring, reflects Lims minimal color palette and attention to minutiae: a shrunken white military jacket with intricately woven black trim; a slightly askew bow tie sewn to the chest of a simple cardigan; a humble V-neck T-shirt adorned with an outsize pocket. Im a classicist, Lim says, with occasional thoughts of madness.

title: Georgetown Goes Old School and Captures Big East Title
description: The main theme running through Georgetowns weeklong run in the Big East tournament has been reviving past glories.

title: Manhattans Littlest Soldiers
description: Park Avenue between 66th and 67th Streets is not the first block you might try if you were looking to find boys and girls with guns. And none of Manhattan, for that matter, presents good odds for turning up children engaged in paramilitary maneuvers.

title: Nixon and Mao
description: To the Editor:

title: Suddenly, Those Treasury Bonds Dont Look So Bland
description: INVESTORS lulled into thinking that they didnt need boring Treasury bonds in their portfolios may have just had a rude awakening.

title: Catching a Wave of High-Tech Exports
description: IT would be easy to conclude that American exports rose 12.7 percent in 2006 because of the cheaper dollar, which made commodities like corn and wheat much more affordable to international buyers.

title: Correction: In Search of Flannery OConnor
description: An article on Feb. 4 about Flannery OConnors hometown, Milledgeville, Ga., misspelled the name of a restaurant. It is Chick-fil-A, not Chik-fil-A. (A reader pointed out the error in an e-mail message on Feb. 27.)

title: Amid Police Concerns, No Movie Scenes in City for Rapper
description: A movie production company began filming in Manhattan yesterday without one of its actors, the rapper Busta Rhymes, after the Police Department raised public safety concerns about him.

title: The Endless Journey Home
description: MIRA NAIRS next film will be the biggest she has ever tackled, with Johnny Depp as the lead and a budget of about $100 million. The film, Shantaram, which she has just agreed to direct for Warner Brothers, is based on Gregory David Robertss autobiographical novel about an Australian robber and drug addict who escapes from prison and reinvents himself by starting a medical clinic in the slums of Bombay.

title: The Spy Who Loved Her
description: SOMEDAY, in a decade, maybe two, a moment will come when World War II slips silently from living memory. That will be occasion for another book to pile on the teetering Everest of volumes about that war; so many books that you would think our very lives depended on our understanding of it. As they did, as they do. The millennium has turned, a new war is upon us. But we are far from done with the old war yet.

title: Buffalo Soldier
description: Its a testament to the stylist Ray Petris genius that more than 15 years after his death, his influence is everywhere. At the spring shows, his spirit turned up in collections as diverse as D&G (tribal power), Alexander McQueen (Harlem dandies) and Junya Watanabe (sports gear as high fashion). Even his personal uniform of dark jeans, bomber jacket and porkpie hat has recently been sighted in Lower Manhattan, Omotesando and Hoxton Square.

title: Rave Rage
description: Remember glow sticks, whistles and reaching for the lasers? If not, get used to them: rave culture is wafting through fashion and music like so much dry ice. Guests at Raf Simonss show were treated to a rare viewing of Mark Leckeys 1999 party film, Fiorucci Made Me Hardcore, which served as a backdrop for metallic-striped tank tops and baggy shorts. Versace went for acid orange and green prints; Prada had clashing chromatic combinations; even Comme des Garons presented gold duds that wouldnt have been out of place at an illegal open-air fest in Half Moon Bay. And Walter Van Beirendonck, whose Wild & Lethal Trash label had a huge following among clubbers a decade ago, has been enjoying a comeback. But its in London, where the scene arguably originated, that rave is being most ecstatically embraced. The new musical standard-bearers for the next generation of clubbers include Hadouken!, Enter Shikari and the Klaxons, a trio that has been known to step out in Carri Mundanes new Cassette Playa line of track suits covered in cartoon characters and outfits inspired by retro video games. Add to that roaming parties like Young Turks, D.J.s like Simian Mobile Disco and clubs like White Heat, and youve got a scene hotter than an all-night dance floor. Now make . . . some . . . NOISE!

title: After Disciplinary Hearing, Simon Issues Apology
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 8  Islanders forward Chris Simon, noting that he had sustained a concussion, said Saturday night that he had little recollection of his retaliatory strike against Ryan Hollweg, which drew a suspension and may end his season.

title: Hey, Why Not Stop and Smell the Tires?
description: AS automotive gimmicks go, few can stir the senses like Kumhos new scented tires. Kumho, a South Korean manufacturer that has been selling tires in the United States since 1966, said it hoped to build better brand recognition here by selling tires made with lavender-scented oil.

title: Big Trucks, Small Roads: Will New Rules Help?
description: LAWRENCE

title: Keeping Tired Drivers Alert, With No Snooze Button
description: AFTER a tough week at the office, the highway stretches ahead of you. The car is warm and the engine hums. Your eyelids slowly close.

title: Still Pumping Iron
description: FIVE or six mornings a week, Ben Sann leaves the Esplanade, the residence for the elderly on West End Avenue and 74th Street where he lives, and walks three blocks to the Jewish Community Center in Manhattan, on Amsterdam Avenue and 76th Street. He takes the careful, shuffling steps of someone learning how to ice skate. In front of him he pushes a walker, a precaution against losing his balance rather than a strict necessity. He can, as a joke, walk alongside it, pretending it is a companion.

title: Paying a Price to Conserve Energy
description: MARGARET DEEGAN SLYWKA knows painfully well what happened 33 years ago, the last time the clocks changed to daylight saving time in the winter. Then a 14-year-old sophomore living in Seymour, Conn., she was hit by a car while walking to high school on Jan. 7, 1974  the day after President Nixon ordered that clocks be moved ahead an hour  and she ended up in a coma for two weeks and a body cast for months.

title: Sharp Suiter
description: At London Fashion Week, Todd Lynns razor-thin striped suits, double-breasted satin tuxedo jackets and skinny pleated trousers stood out like Boy George in Parliament. The Canadian newcomers presentation generated such buzz that Giorgio Armani himself, along with bands like Dirty Pretty Things, turned up in his front row. The natty clothes, available at Barneys New York, toe the line between serious tailoring and a just-stayed-up-all-night-with-Kate decadence (albeit in $1,800 pants). Though hes been outfitting rock legends like Bono and a Rolling Stone or two for years, Lynn still harbors a rock n roll fantasy: to dress the Berlin-era David Bowie, when his look was effortless, eccentric and real. No matter how much you dress yourself up, Lynn says, there always has to be a sense of realness.

title: Utahs Epic Ride
description: UP high in the sunny Wasatch mountain range, above the tree line at 10,000 feet, the Highway to Heaven is just 500 yards long.

title: Letters
description: The Luminist

title: A Real-Life Rocky, Still Stirring the Crowd
description: UNION

title: The Human Touch
description: To the Editor:

title: Where Are the Grown-Ups When You Need Them?
description: AS I write this, I am just back from the lovely town of Clinton, S.C., where I spoke at a school called Presbyterian College. I was speaking on a subject of great interest, at least to me: the image of the adolescent in mass culture. I used to teach about this area  the political and social content of the culture  before many of you readers were born, and I am still compelled by it.

title: Correction: The Family Vacation (Climate-Change Lessons Included)
No Bake-Off Winner, but a Winning Recipe
description: MY mother spent the summer of 1971 testing every variation on Bohemians, pastrylike cookies that she made with walnuts or pecans or no nuts at all. My twin brother, Bill, and I were the lucky tasters. We decided which batches were the lightest, chewiest, best. It was as if we had formed a small, secret club that met from June to September whenever my father was at work. Ma was trying to win the grand prize ($25,000 at the time) in the Pillsbury Bake-Off. And we believed she would.

title: How Solid a Line Against Development?
description: Homestead, Fla.

title: Edison the Inventor, Edison the Showman
description: This article was adapted from The Wizard of Menlo Park: How Thomas Alva Edison Invented the Modern World, by Randall Stross, a contributor to The New York Times. The book, to be published on Tuesday by Crown Publishers, examines the reality and the myths surrounding the Edison legacy.

title: 11 Years Later, Questions of What If
description: WALHALLA, S.C. After coming tantalizingly close to pulling the biggest upset in the history of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, the homespun head coach and his hot-shot assistant locked in a long embrace.

title: The Flow Isnt Always in Their Plays
description: FORGET basketball. Michael Jordan gave the world of style so much, from the $175 sneaker to the concept that shorts need no longer be short. And nowhere has the legacy of his image lingered more stubbornly than in the shaven-head look he helped make ubiquitous in the National Basketball Association  and beyond.

title: Off-Duty Officer Kills Man at Brooklyn Club
description: An off-duty police officer shot a man to death at a raucous Brooklyn dance hall early yesterday, the police said, after the man fired at least once at another off-duty officer.

title: Anand, a Master of Rapid Play, Helped Put India in the Game
description: Over the years, many grandmasters have become celebrities, even heroes, in their homelands. But probably just one has inspired enough of his countrymen to take up the game that the country became a world chess power. That is Viswanathan Anand of India.

title: Hungary Coalition Stays the Austerity Course
description: BUDAPEST, March 9  The steel barriers around Parliament here say much about the state of Hungarys democracy nearly three years after the country joined the European Union and 17 years after the Soviet Army ended decades of occupation.

title: In a Matchup Between Big Men, Hibbert Stands Taller
description: After Georgetown walloped Pittsburgh, 65-42, last night to win the Big East tournament at Madison Square Garden, the end of the two handshake lines featured the two big centers, the 7-foot-2 Roy Hibbert of Georgetown and the 7-foot Aaron Gray of Pittsburgh.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Theater

title: Florida Focuses on Conference and Title Game vs. Arkansas
description: ATLANTA, March 10  Like it or not, the Florida Gators have reached a point in their season in which they are being sized up for another run at a national championship. They would rather focus on Arkansas, the team they will meet Sunday in the Southeastern Conference tournament championship game.

title: For Seven Yale Students, a Shop to Call Their Own
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Dont Cripple Eminent Domain
description: New Jersey is so built up that long-term economic growth will depend on the revitalization of its cities with new industry, housing and stores. But significant redevelopment is unlikely to occur if the current campaign to demonize eminent domain and restrict its uses is allowed to succeed.

title: City Slicker
description: The once-rebellious  and, until recently, largely extinct  pompadour of the 1950s is being revived in a sleekly streamlined way. Were not talking about the rockabilly relic modeled by Brando and Presley; the present-tense pompadour stresses clean-cut sophistication, not Wild One insurrection. Its a modern adaptation of a classic hairstyle, tailored to the feeling of the clothes of the season, says Terry Saxon, the Paris-based stylist who created this look. The perfect pompadour takes two-step styling. First, comb through a mousse or gel and create the shape (deep side parting, hair swept back from the sides, flat on top). Then rub pomade through to perfect the look. The mousse or gel sets it, and the pomade gives it shine, Saxon says. No hats allowed.

title: In Uruguay, Bush Finds a Leftist He Can Embrace (and Name)
description: ESTANCIA ANCHORENA, Uruguay, March 10  Of all of the Latin American nations President Bush is visiting this week, this one is the smallest, with a population that is half that of New York City.

title: Reducing the Risk of Default
description: BECAUSE of new policies from Freddie Mac, some, if not many, of the millions of borrowers with poor credit could be shut out of home mortgages. But Freddie Mac also says that it is planning new mortgage products in an attempt to reduce the risk of default.

title: Abandoned in the Snow
description: Abandoned in the Snow

title: In a World of Cubicles, a Search for Lifes Meaning
description: In a fortuitous collision of talent and casting, a young actor named Michael Nathanson is igniting explosive comic charges onstage at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch. Playing Jim, a Seattle office temp, in Dan Dietzs surreal new comedy tempOdyssey, Mr. Nathanson pulls out every stop for a brilliant tour de force.

title: Ariel and the Silver Car
description: THE keys were in the car door. That much Ariel Guadalupe remembers telling the police on the September day in 2004 when she was nabbed for stealing a 1999 silver Ford Crown Victoria in Queens. She was 14.

title: Suite Dreams
description: Somewhere between a power nap and a disco nap lies Yelo. The new sleep spot on West 57th Street is getting New Yorkers to take a load off  in the purely holistic sense. Drop into the futuristic space with or without an appointment (a monitor in the window alerts passers-by to the next available opening, also visible at www.heloyelo.com) and settle into a YeloCab, a patented, high-tech honeycomb where everything from the chair to the temperature (and the Nepalese cashmere blanket) is calibrated to lull you to sleep for 20 to 40 minutes  all you need to boost your productivity and alertness, according to Nicolas Ronco, Yelos founder. Ronco, a 39-year-old former business-development executive, admired during trips to Asia how his Eastern colleagues handled stress by taking quick naps during the day. Experiencing reflexology and sleep therapy in Japan and volunteering on an ashram in India taught him the power of calm in the midst of a metropolis. But theres nothing New Age about the space, which is gender-neutral right down to the hard-to-find products it sells. We have guys who are embarrassed to come in here, Ronco says, but then they buy memberships and stop in before meetings or dinners. Its better than going home. An annual membership costs $100 to $500.

title: Calendar of Events
description: FILM

title: Inside the List
description: SONTAG, LATE AND EARLY: Susan Sontag, whose posthumous collection of essays and speeches, At the Same Time, is reviewed in this issue by Pankaj Mishra, placed exactly one book on the Times best-seller list during her long career: The Volcano Lover, a historical novel, appeared here for eight weeks in 1992.

title: Unintended Consequences
description: First: forget about the jacket copy. Its not going to give you much help. It mentions a few of the characters in this novel, sure, and says a little about what they do and who they are; it tells you that in July of 1969, two astronauts set foot on the moon; far below, in ravaged Mozambique, a young revolutionary is murdered by a package bomb. Think these events have nothing to do with each other? Wrong. They are connected by numbers, presumably by their weight. By the end of the book, you read on its front, some of your most cherished beliefs will be altered; Im sorry to tell you my beliefs are still intact. Now, at this point you may be thinking I hated this book. I didnt. It was just that as I read, and read again, I wanted to shake it and shout, Tell me a story, for crying out loud!

title: Tales From Tehran
description: Q: New Yorks Museum of Modern Art is screening 32 of your films this month and touting your accomplishments as one of the great film directors of our time. I imagine you are less celebrated back home in Tehran. No one criticizes me; no one encourages me. Nobody has anything to do with me. Those who need to know who I am know who I am.

title: No Textbooks, No Resources, Parents Complain
description: SHOREHAM

title: In Minnesota, as in Oakland, Some Credit Is Due
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.

title: Fiasco in Brooklyn
description: The state of politics in the 40th District in Brooklyn is, frankly, a mess. Mathieu Eugene, an unlicensed physician, appeared the winner in a special election last month to fill the City Council seat vacated this year by Yvette Clarke, who had moved on to the House of Representatives. Ms. Clarke and her mother, Una Clarke, who previously held the council seat, enthusiastically backed his campaign.

title: Rejecting the Levy Way
description: The Suffolk County Legislature would do its constituents a great service by decisively rejecting an anti-loitering bill now before it. The bill forbids people to obstruct vehicle or foot traffic on county roads. Its sponsors, Jack Eddington and Joseph Caracappa, portray it as an innocuous safety measure, but in fact it is a badly disguised effort to intimidate and harass Latino immigrants, specifically the day laborers whose presence in Farmingville has been a source of tension for years.

title: Islanders Forward Simon Suspended for Season
description: Islanders forward Chris Simon was suspended for the final 15 games of the regular season and for the playoffs by the N.H.L. on Sunday, a ban that will last at least 25 games and could extend into next season, for slamming Rangers forward Ryan Hollweg in the face with his stick in last Thursday night's game at Nassau Coliseum. The N.H.L. vice president Colin Campbell announced the suspension a day after a disciplinary hearing was held in New York on Saturday. "The National Hockey League will not accept the use of a stick in the manner and fashion in which Mr. Simon used his Thursday night," Campbell said in a statement. "As a consequence of his actions, Mr. Simon has forfeited the privilege of playing in an N.H.L. game again this season, regardless of how many games the Islanders ultimately play." Simon issued a statement Saturday expressing regret over the incident and apologizing to Hollweg. The Islanders said Simon was recovering from a concussion suffered in Thursday's game and would not be available for further comment. The Islanders, currently holding the seventh playoff spot in the Eastern Conference, will play without one of their stalwarts. Simon, 35, is a 14-year veteran with abundant playoff experience  he won a Stanley Cup with Colorado in 1996 and has reached the finals with two other teams  and is regarded as one of the league's toughest players. "Chris Simon has played a major role in our success this season and we will miss his presence in our lineup," the Islanders' general manager, Garth Snow, said in a statement. "His regret is clearly evident in the statement he released last night. Our entire organization supports Chris every step of the way." Simon's punishment takes him out of any playoff games this season, and if the Islanders play less than 10 games in the playoffs, the suspension will stretch into next season and last for at least 25 total games. The hit happened Thursday night, late in the third period of a tie game against the Rangers. Hollweg checked Simon hard into the boards and after Simon got up, he charged after Hollweg and, with two hands on his stick, slammed it into Hollweg's chin. The hit narrowly missed Hollweg's neck, which could have been a much more serious injury, and Hollweg suffered only a gash on his chin. He returned to the game and played in the Rangers' game on Saturday as well. The Rangers will play the Islanders two more times this season. "Whether it's appropriate or not isn't for me to judge," Rangers Coach Tom Renney said of the punishment. "The two things for me that are most important is that Ryan is O.K., he's able to play. And Chris, for me anyway, is a good man. He's had to pay the price and that's appropriate. It needs to be a message that's loud and clear, of course. We all have to move forward and learn what we can from it." Simon's suspension is two games longer than the one given to Marty McSorley in 2000 when he smashed his stick over the head of Donald Brashear in a game in Vancouver. McSorley was also subsequently charged with assault by the Vancouver police and was convicted, although he served no jail time. The Nassau County district attorney's office said Friday that an assault charge was being considered against Simon. A decision is expected later this week.

title: On the Cover
description: The actor Richard Gere in a Calvin Klein Underwear gray crew-neck T-shirt, $30 for pack of two. At Bloomingdale's. Macy's. Gere's own necklace.

title: Passages Couverts, the Arcades of Paris
Editors Choice
description: THE CURTAIN: An Essay in Seven Parts, by Milan Kundera. Translated by Linda Asher. (Harper- Collins, $22.95.) The latest of Kunderas meditations on the nature and meaning of the novel.

title: Paperback Row
description: A FAMILY DAUGHTER, by Maile Meloy. (Scribner, $14. ) Meloys first novel, Liars and Saints, concerned four generations of a California family named the Santerres, whose Roman Catholic matriarch, Yvette, schemed to raise her teenage daughters child as her own. A Family Daughter continues the intricately plotted family saga, but with a twist: it treats Liars and Saints as a semiautobiographical novel written by Yvettes granddaughter, Abby. Meloy follows Abby from the age of 7, in 1969, to her success as a young novelist, recasting the details of this intensely complicated family. Our reviewer, Jeff Giles, called Meloys many subplots rich, moving and full of human comedy.

title: A Generation Lost
description: The current generation of young Palestinians, many say, is the most radical, the most accepting of violence and the most despairing.

title: Oil on the Brain
description: GAS STATION: Chasing The Hidden Penny

title: When You Catch an Adjective, Kill It
description: Kicking things off with adjectives is a little like starting a kids' birthday party with the broccoli course. Because as far as not getting respect goes, adjectives leave Rodney Dangerfield in the dust. They rank right up there with Osama bin Laden, Geraldo Rivera, and the customer-service policies of cable TV companies. That it is good to avoid them is one of the few points on which the sages of writing agree. Thus Voltaire: "The adjective is the enemy of the noun." Thus William Zinsser: "Most adjectives are ... unnecessary. Like adverbs, they are sprinkled into sentences by writers who don't stop to think that the concept is already in the noun."

title: Lately
description: A Winter's Tale

title: The Gospel of Food
description: The word "enjoy" appears in the official dietary guidelines issued by the governments of Britain, South Korea, Thailand, and Australia. Norway comes right out and declares, "food and joy = health." The United States' dietary guidelines, faithful to our Puritan roots, say nothing about enjoyment.

title: Finn
description: Under a low sun, pursued by fish and mounted by crows and veiled in a loud languid swarm of bluebottle flies, the body comes down the river like a deadfall stripped clean.

title: The Solitude of Thomas Cave
description: I SHALL NOT FORGET the sight of him as we left, that picture stays strong with me: his figure still and straight on the wide shore, the land huge and bare about him, the snowy dip of the valley at his back, the mountains on either side, twin peaks they were of seeming identical height, rising steep and smooth and streaked with grey as if in some strange reversal the rock were ashes that had been poured down on to the snow from heaven; the sea a darkened pewter and having that sluggishness to its movement that comes when it is heavy with the beginnings of ice. In all God's Earth, from the tip of Africa to the Indies or the wide Pacific, a man might never see a sight so lonely.

title: Flora Segunda
description: AS COMMANDING GENERAL of the Army of Califa, Mamma is in charge of just about everything, so she is not much home-she's always off on an inspection, or maneuvers, or at a grand council somewhere, or just working late. Thus, Crackpot's crumbling is no particular bother to her. Idden, too, is nicely out of it, even if her current post, Fort Jones, is the back end of Nowhere. At least she can count on having someone else do her laundry and cook her supper.

title: Predicting the Path to Atlanta
description: Midwest | West | East | South

title: Why We Travel
description: "I think it was interesting, because we stayed in a Japanese-style garden, talked about it in Chinese, and we were in United States. The different countries elements were assembled at that moment."

title: Clinton Vows Middle Class Will Not Be Invisible to Her
description: NASHUA, N.H., March 10  Echoing her husbands 1992 presidential campaign message about the forgotten middle class, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton accused the Bush administration on Saturday night of turning the middle class and working families into invisible Americans whose needs have gone ignored for the last six years.

title: The Week Ahead: March 11 - 17
description: THEATER

title: Fred Thompson Considers Running
description: Former Senator Fred Thompson, who now plays a district attorney on Law & Order, told Fox News today that hell make a decision in the coming months about whether to jump into the field of Republican candidates vying for the 2008 presidential nomination.

title: Welcoming the Hindu Spring
description: In Queens, the Indo-Caribbean community celebrated spring with the Phagwah festival.

title: Briefly Talking Baseball, Only Baseball, With Gary Matthews Jr.
description: Gary Matthews Jr. of the Los Angeles Angels is not talking about why reports have linked him to a nationwide drug distribution ring. He has dodged questions for almost two weeks, which has infuriated Arte Moreno, the club owner.Still, as Matthews prepared for a game on Saturday, I wanted at least to attempt to interview him. Im big on studying body language so, when Matthews looked about as approachable as he was going to get, I introduced myself and asked him if he could answer some baseball questions.Baseball questions only? Matthews said.I repeated my request. I figured that Matthews might relax if he talked about baseball issues and might reveal a little about how he is feeling during an obviously tense time. Matthews told me he would speak after he took batting practice.About 20 minutes later, Matthews returned to his locker, but, his stance had changed. Matthews said he did not have time for an interview and said wed have to do it another time. I asked him if he could do it later in the day, but he declined. Sensing that this pursuit of an interview was almost lost, I asked him to simply answer a couple of baseball questions. He agreed.Matthews on why he wanted to sign with the Angels (aside from the five-year, $50 million contract): First and foremost, it was to win. This is a team I was really familiar with the last few years. It was a team that really gave us some problems in Texas. It was a team you had respect for because they always found a way to win. Everybody talks about this team needs to score runs. We scored all the runs in the world in Texas and still ended up in the same place in October. It was the opportunity to win, their young pitching and their fan base. Those were all really attractive to me.Matthews on how he can make the Angels even better: Just doing what I do. They felt that they needed some defense up the middle. Obviously, for me to come in and play center field the way Im capable of playing, was something that I was looking fwd to doing, something that I bring to the table. And just bring a balanced game.Then Matthews, who had a career year with a .313 average, 19 homers and 79 runs batted in with the Texas Rangers last season, showed a cocky side.Obviously, I standout defensively, but I still pride myself on being able to do everything well, Matthews said. There are going to be guys faster than me. There are going to be guys who have more power, but there are not a whole lot of guys who do everything. Thats what I try and do.I told Matthews that Buck Showalter, his former manager with the Rangers, thought Matthews should have won a Gold Glove Award last season. Matthews said he learned a lot about himself while playing in Texas. With this brief interview getting close to being over, I asked Matthews what I felt was a semi-baseball question. Was he able to fully concentrate on baseball this spring?That is not a baseball question, Matthews said.That, we both agreed, was the end of the interview.

title: Rickey Being Rickey
description: Rickey Henderson blew into camp this morning for his annual spring tour. This years focus, as it was last year, is teaching the Mets to run like him. Over 25 seasons, Henderson stole 1,406 bases, including a mind-boggling 130 in 1982. To me, that record is as untouchable as Dimaggios 56-game hitting streak or Ripkens 2,632 consecutive games, although Henderson said that Jose Reyes would be the only player he could envision challenging his marks.

title: Love and Basketball
description: Prior to the Texas-Oklahoma State game in the semifinals of the Big 12 tournament on Saturday, a fan, Paul Thompson, participated in the Phillips $66,000 Free Throw Giveaway.

title: The Rebels yell: Viva Las Vegas
description: U.N.L.V. won the Mountain West Conference tournament, feeding off a frenzied crowd and a Brigham Young team that ran out of gas. The bleachers emptied at the end of the 78-70 victory, as fans acted like they hadnt been here before. But for a program that has been to the N.C.A.A. tournament twice since 1991, and has been through nine coaches since Jerry Tarkanian left in 1992, there was some pent-up celebration in the Rebels Nation. They stuck around for the awards ceremony, in which Rebels guard Kevin Kruger won the M.V.P.

title: The Midwest Bracket
description: 1. Florida16. Jackson State

title: West Region Matchups
description: 1. Kansas16. Florida A&M or Niagara

title: East Region Matchups
description: 1. North Carolina16. Eastern Kentucky

title: South Region Matchups
description: 1. Ohio State16. Central Connecticut

title: N.C.A.A. Selection Show 30 Minutes Away
description: Who will be No. 1? Or rather, who will be the Nos. 1? In less than half an hour, the N.C.A.A. tournament selection committee will decide which of college basketballs elite teams will sit atop each quarter of the mens bracket.

title: And Your No. 1 Seeds Are
description: And here they are America, your four No. 1 seeds for the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Rodriguezs Quest for a Ring
description: When I spoke with Mike Schmidt at the Phillies camp last Sunday, he mentioned something Ill probably never forget.

title: Upsets Are Inevitable
description: Now that the N.C.A.A. tournament field has been announced, the debate can shift from who will get in (and at what position) to who will be the first team out. One of the things that makes this tournament so exciting is the one-and-done format that has a tradition of yielding a number of dramatic upsets.

title: Is the Establishment Clause Unconstitutional?
description: The question in my title sounds odd, even silly, because as everyone knows, the establishment clause is a part of the Constitution. It is the first clause of the First Amendment: Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion. At this point I am tempted to begin a sentence with that is and follow it with a gloss on the clause. But just what these apparently simple words mean has been debated by the courts with increasing vociferousness and little resolution since Everson v. Board of Education, often referred to as the first modern establishment clause case, was decided in February of 1947.The issue in Everson was whether the use of public funds to transport students to and from parochial schools was an establishment of religion because religions interests would be advanced by the expenditure of state monies. Now, 60 years later on March 6th, the Supreme Court of California has considered and ruled on the issue of whether a municipal agency (the California Statewide Communities Development Authority), may provide tax-exempt bonds to avowedly sectarian schools for the purpose of constructing cafeterias, athletic facilities and other campus buildings. The facts are different  in 2007 it is buildings rather than buses that pose the problem  but the basic question is the same: When can it be said that a government action amounts to an establishing of religion?

title: Searching for the Dark Side
description: It is possible to write the history of our increasing knowledge about the universe and our place in it as a series of blows to human pride. We discovered that the Earth and then the Sun are not the center of the universe, that we do not reside at the center of the galaxy and that there is nothing particularly special about our own Milky Way system. The latest such shock is that the kind of matter we  and everything we can see directly  are made of accounts for only a sixth of the total mass in the universe. In the absence of knowledge, we label the rest as dark matter and look to detect it via its effects on what we can see.

title: Squeezed Orange
description: Needless to say, the biggest talk around the office here at the Old Gray Lady tonight was about the omission of Syracuse from the 65-team field. This is because many of The Brackets co-workers are fellow Orange alums. While The Bracket was pounding away at the keyboard getting his picks in for the paper, he heard one die hard even mention a viewing boycott. Gotta love March. (For good blogging on Syracuses case, look to Kim Baxter and Mike Waters.)

title: Dragons Without Consolation
description: One team that deserved to get in even more than Syracuse is Drexel, who went on the road and won in the Carrier Dome earlier this year. The Dragons also won at Villanova and Creighton, two other teams that reached the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Mayo Cited
description: UPDATE: Citation dismissed.

title: Music 24/7
description: The human animal is eminently musical, a creature that consciously builds its own instruments and organizes and projects repeatable sound structures in time, heard in selected spaces on occasions of special purpose. Human music is a vehicle for personal and collective enjoyment and expression, and a means to transcend time and place. Its widespread presence and diversity suggests an underlining socio-physiological necessity. Apparently there are no people on this planet during the last 30,000 years who did not and do not make their own music. So it is no surprise to wake up in the year 2007 and find music everywhere all the time.

title: Arbaeen in Karbala
description: Millions of Shiites made a pilgrimage to Karbala, Iraq, despite the threat of snipers and suicide bombers.

title: Stock Offerings This Week
description: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

title: When the Personal Becomes Presidential
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Mouth That Roars, With the Soul That Crumbles
description: Liev Schreiber doesnt merely fill a stage, as great actors are said to do. In the gut-grabbing revival of Eric Bogosians Talk Radio, which opened last night at the Longacre Theater, Mr. Schreibers presence seems to fill the air as inescapably as weather. You get the feeling that even if you shut your eyes and plugged your ears, he would still be gnawing at your senses and manipulating your mood.

title: East Side Doorman Fatally Stabbed; Suspect Is Charged
description: A doorman was stabbed to death on the Upper East Side on Saturday night by a college student after an argument that may have been about a woman, the police said.

title: Irans President Wants to Tell Security Council of Nuclear Aims
description: TEHRAN, March 11  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran wants to take part in a meeting of the United Nations Security Council to brief member states about Irans nuclear program, a government spokesman said Sunday on state-run television.

title: Facing Fraud Trial, Conrad Black Flouts the Rules
description: TORONTO, March 6  When Conrad M. Black pleaded not guilty to criminal fraud charges in December 2005, a federal court in Chicago granted his request that he be defended by Edward L. Greenspan, one of the most famous criminal defense lawyers in Canada, where he is known by the nickname Fast Eddie.

title: A Sea of Mourners, Sharing Two Families Loss
description: Just after noon yesterday, eight gleaming Cadillac hearses threaded their way thorough the heart of High Bridge in the Bronx, past Fanta Express Hair Braiding and Dia-Bugi 99 Cent and Mohamed Alfa Bah Discount. They turned left onto 166th Street and stopped. Before them was a sea of people.

title: Israeli Officials Praise Saudi Peace Initiative
description: JERUSALEM, March 12  Israeli officials, pressed by Washington, are suddenly finding much to praise in a Saudi peace proposal that was dismissed when it was offered in 2002, at the height of a series of Palestinian suicide bombings.

title: Overblown Personnel Matters
description: Nobody is surprised to learn that the Justice Department was lying when it claimed that recently fired federal prosecutors were dismissed for poor performance. Nor is anyone surprised to learn that White House political operatives were pulling the strings.

title: A Bill Democrats Should Like
description: The Bush administrations new farm bill, one of the more sensible pieces of legislation to emerge from this administration in quite a while, faces its first big Congressional test this week. The House Budget Committee will vote on a budget resolution that, while non-binding, establishes spending priorities and sends a powerful signal to the authorizing committees about where the House leadership thinks the money ought to go.

title: At European Art Fair, Newcomers Muscle In
description: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands, March 11  A pair of uninvited guests arrived at this years European Fine Art Fair. For the first time in the fairs 20-year history, the auction giants Sothebys and Christies have muscled their way into what has traditionally been a premier showcase for international dealers.

title: For a Roster Spot, a Met Is Prepared to Get Dirty
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 11  In passing up a chance to play football in the Southeastern Conference, Mets outfielder Ben Johnson traded one helmet for another. The decision was not difficult: Either way, he would wear a helmet.

title: In New Tactic, Militants Burn Houses in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, March 11  Sunni militants burned homes in a mixed city northeast of Baghdad on Saturday and Sunday, forcing dozens of families to flee and raising the specter of a new intimidation tactic in Iraqs evolving civil war, Iraqi officials and witnesses said.

title: Tsai-Fan Yu, 95, Physician, Dies; Helped Alleviate Gout
description: Dr. Tsai-Fan Yu, a physician and researcher at Mount Sinai Medical Center who helped explain a principal cause of gout and evaluated early drugs to treat the disease that are still in use, died on March 2 in Manhattan. She was 95.

title: In a Funeral Parlor in East Harlem, Nine Coffins Point Toward Mecca
description: Franciscos Funeraria in East Harlem is not a large operation; when someone calls about a body in the middle of the night, the phone rings at the home of Elefterios Filipoussis, the funeral director.

title: Human Bones Found at a House in the Bronx
description: For years, neighbors knew little about the frail, older woman who lived at 3280 Perry Avenue, a weathered two-story house in Norwood, in the Bronx. She lived alone, neighbors said, and seemed to value her independence.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Feb. 27 about a Discovery Channel documentary that said a crypt in Jerusalem contained the bones of Jesus of Nazareth referred imprecisely to the Aramaic language. While Aramaic and Hebrew are closely related and Hebrew is written using the Aramaic script, they are distinct languages; Aramaic is not an ancient dialect of Hebrew.

title: Mets Single-Game Tickets Now on Sale
description: Mets single-game tickets for the 2007 season went on sale yesterday. The defending National League East champion Mets open their 81-date home schedule April 9 against the divisional rival Philadelphia Phillies.

title: New Defense Chief Eases Relations Rumsfeld Bruised
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates has set in motion a review of the Pentagons dealings with the nations spy agencies to improve cooperation and heal working relationships bruised by his predecessor, Donald H. Rumsfeld, just one way Mr. Gates has forcefully if quietly pushed back on Mr. Rumsfelds initiatives.

title: For This Family of Pros, the Con Is Everything
description: So much research is devoted to studying whether violence on television desensitizes children. Yet nobody seems to worry that adults are becoming inured to excellence.

title: Last Hurrah for a Gay Playground
description: At five minutes before 10 on Saturday night, the Roxys manager, Jason McCarthy, lined up the folks who staff the discothques massive front bar. O.K., everybody, remember what I told you, he said. Smile a lot. Hug people a lot. Tell them how important the gay community has been to this place. O.K.?

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about fund-raising efforts in New York by Senator Barack Obama misspelled the surname of one of President John F. Kennedys closest advisers, who introduced Mr. Obama at a fund-raiser. He is Theodore C. Sorensen, not Sorenson. The error also appeared in an article in The Arts on Feb. 22 about books written by candidates, including Profiles in Courage, which then-Senator Kennedy wrote with guidance from Mr. Sorensen. (The Times has misspelled Mr. Sorensens surname more than 135 times in headlines and articles during the 50-plus years he has been a Democratic adviser and well-known author.)

title: Surprise! Spartans Assault Box Office
description: LOS ANGELES, March 11  Even a film business that expects big numbers is likely to be double-checking the box-office receipts for Warner Brothers 300 on Monday and asking, What just happened?

title: Israeli and Palestinian Leaders Meet, Producing Scant Results but a Pledge to Talk Again
description: JERUSALEM, March 11  Mahmoud Abbas, the Palestinian president, and Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel held their second meeting in a month on Sunday night, but aides said afterward that there was little concrete progress to report.

title: Another Kind of Appeal From Death Row: Kill Me
description: Robert Comer says that his death sentence is just and that the state of Arizona should go ahead and kill him.

title: Voice Lesson: An Outsider in Charge
description: Early in 2006, before The Village Voice went into the ditch  before one of its writers was found to have fabricated an article, before its interim editor was fired by a notice that was scrawled on a napkin, before another new editor was hired but then did not take the job, before another one was hired and then fired in six months  I was sitting at the Odeon restaurant in downtown Manhattan with Michael Lacey, one of the partners of New Times, a chain of weekly newspapers that merged with the Voice newspapers in 2005.

title: Cancer Research Funds (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Years of Strife and Lost Hope Scar Young Palestinians
description: NABLUS, West Bank  Their worried parents call them the lost generation of Palestine: its most radical, most accepting of violence and most despairing.

title: The Next Big Health Care Battle
description: At a time when the nation is pondering how to provide medical coverage to some 47 million uninsured Americans, it is logical and right to start with the countrys nine million uninsured children. The Bush administration, unfortunately, is going in exactly the opposite direction.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the troubled state of many of Britains youth reversed the rankings for Britain and the United States in a Unicef study that measured childrens well-being in 21 industrialized countries. It was Britain that scored the lowest; the United States was the second-lowest. (Go to Article)

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article on Saturday about violence in Iraq misstated the sequence of events surrounding a military operation south of Baghdad on Friday involving soldiers from the First Battalion, 23rd Infantry Regiment. The soldiers were shown detaining Iraqi men at the start of the military action. It was not until later that the soldiers took fire from the area.

title: Weak Lead-In Programming Takes a Toll on the News Ratings
description: Last year, around the time that CBS agreed to pay an estimated $15 million a year to lure Katie Couric away from NBC, it spent several million dollars more in licensing fees to coax another nationally known television personality from the NBC station in New York to the one owned by CBS: Judge Judy.

title: Is This Supporting the Troops? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Can Colas Be Healthy? (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A Political Memo article on Thursday about the challenges Rudolph W. Giuliani faces in running for president as a former New York City mayor referred incorrectly to the presidency of Theodore Roosevelt, also a New York City mayor. He served more than 100 years ago, from 1901 to 1909; his presidency was not almost 100 years ago. And although he was indeed the last president born in New York City, he was not the last born-and-bred New Yorker to make it to the White House. His distant relative, President Franklin D. Roosevelt, was born and raised in Hyde Park, N.Y.

title: Tracking of Killer Asteroids Runs Low on Money and Short on Time
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  NASA can find and track most of the nearby asteroids that could hit and damage the Earth, but there is not enough money in its budget to finish the project within a 15-year deadline mandated by Congress, according to an agency report released Friday.

title: Apollo, the Beach Boys and a Soupon of Agitprop
description: A generation or two of New York dancegoers grew up with the Joffrey Ballet at City Center, the companys home until it decamped for Chicago in 1995. The vivid, distinctive presences of Joffrey dancers of the 1960s and 70s worked indelible magic, as did the pertness for which the company was known and occasionally dismissed, despite the technical skills of many of those bouncy charmers. New York briefly saw the Joffrey in 2004 in the Lincoln Center Festivals celebration of Frederick Ashton and his ballets, and its perfect, madcap production of Ashtons Wedding Bouquet is still being talked about.

title: Bush Visits Colombia Amid Security and Protests
description: BOGOT, Colombia, March 11 The risky nature of President Bushs trip to this violent country was spelled out on a television monitor aboard Air Force One en route from Uruguay: Colombia presents the most significant threat environment of this five country trip!

title: Social Issues Clown Their Way to Center Stage in Libya
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Jamal Dawob reflects what Libya has been for the last 37 years, a place singularly defined by an eccentric ruler, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. He is our spiritual leader, our godfather, Mr. Dawob said with a shining smile as he explained why he concentrated on painting portraits of Colonel Qaddafi. I do it out of love.

title: On Screens Soon, Abused Earth Gets Its Revenge
description: LOS ANGELES, March 11  Tired of abuse by mankind, the earth is angry. Worse, the planet is out to even the score.

title: Isiah Thomas Earns New Deal as Knicks Coach
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 12  Isiah Thomas survived his one-season ultimatum, with a month to spare. Thomas, the New York Knicks president and coach, has been given a multiyear contract extension and will continue to serve in both roles, the Knicks announced today.

title: Brooklyn: Pedestrian Killed in Hit and Run
description: A 47-year-old man was struck and killed by a black Lincoln Town Car that fled the scene shortly before 2 a.m. yesterday in Coney Island, the police said. The victim, whose name was not released, was crossing Surf Avenue when he was struck by the sedan, which was heading west, the police said. The driver then drove north on West 31st Street, the police said. The victim was taken to Lutheran Medical Center and pronounced dead a short time later. There were no suspects and no arrests yesterday.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: A Dreamgirl Is the Top Entertainer

title: With Redesign of Time, Sentences Run Forward
description: Having just turned 84, Time magazine is coming out with a new look and editorial approach on Friday.

title: A Wrangle After Democrats Shun Fox as Debate Platform
description: A full year and a half ahead of the presidential election, the Fox News Channel has suddenly become an issue in the campaign, even as the network tries to cover that campaign.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,183 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans last week:

title: Ford Is Close to a Deal to Shed Aston Martin Sports Cars
description: DEARBORN, Mich., March 11  The Ford Motor Company is expected to sell Aston Martin, maker of the upscale British sports cars favored by James Bond, to a group of investors that includes the racing mogul David Richards and a pair of Kuwaiti companies, people with direct knowledge of the deal said Sunday.

title: For 35 Years, Waiting for News of a Missing Son
description: Every time she answers her phone, Gloria Chait hopes no one replies.

title: Treasury Bill Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Queens: Woman Found Dead Was Strangled
description: The medical examiner concluded yesterday that a woman who was found dead in her home on Saturday night had been strangled. Police officers responded to a report of an unconscious woman at 125-60 Sutphin Boulevard, near Rockaway Boulevard, about 6:35 p.m. on Saturday and found the woman, Raychelle Shelby, 48, who was pronounced dead by emergency medical workers, the authorities said. Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the city medical examiner, said yesterday that an autopsy showed Ms. Shelby had died of ligature strangulation.

title: Halliburton Moving C.E.O. From Houston to Dubai
description: HOUSTON, March 11  Halliburton, the big energy services company, said on Sunday that it would open a corporate headquarters in the United Arab Emirates city of Dubai and move its chairman and chief executive, David J. Lesar, there.

title: Midmajors Are Pushed Aside by Power Conferences
description: After the 2006 N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, which featured a stunning surge to the Final Four by George Mason of the Colonial Athletic Association and a run to the Round of 16 by two Missouri Valley Conference teams, the selection committee last night appeared to shy away from teams from smaller conferences.

title: In Crowded G.O.P. Field, a Lesser-Known Hopes to Capitalize on the Issues
description: ORANGE CITY, Iowa, March 10  When the dapper man in the starched shirt, lavender tie and navy blue suit interrupted Donna Van Peursem, 61, and her friends at the Pizza Ranch here on Saturday, she failed to recognize him but sensed she somehow should.

title: Zimbabwe Police Accused of Beating Opponents
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 12  Members of Zimbabwes political opposition and largest civic group said today that their leaders were beaten and hospitalized after the police arrested them and scores of others during the violent breakup of a weekend anti-government rally.

title: The New New Republic? Fatter, for Starters
description: First, what hasnt changed about the venerable 92-year-old magazine, The New Republic, which is making its debut today as a biweekly with a new design and a new owner:

title: A Universal Tax Credit (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: This Time, Tragic Butterfly Lives in a Low-Frills Zone
description: Madama Butterfly is a lot of opera for 25 bucks. At the Salzburg Festival $25 would probably get you half the overture, at the Metropolitan Opera a little more. The New York City Operas Opera-for-All series offered five of these all-for-one-low-price attractions last fall and came back with Puccinis weepy, ever-winning study in Japanese-American relations on Friday.

title: New Twist for Idol: Time Out for Charity
description: In terms of cash flow, nobody in the television business comes close to Simon Cowell, the star attraction of televisions biggest attraction, American Idol. So it only made sense that he be in the middle of that shows first charity extravaganza: raising cash for the poor of Africa and the United States.

title: Gonzales Should Quit, Senator Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  A leading Senate Democrat demanded on Sunday that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales step down, saying he had politicized his office at the expense of the nations laws.

title: Frances Effort to Export the News Is Catching On
description: PARIS, March 11  With presidential elections looming, even the top executives of the television station France 24, a 24-hour international news channel that is subsidized by the government, cannot predict its future.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the troubled state of many of Britains youth reversed the rankings for Britain and the United States in a Unicef study that measured childrens well-being in 21 industrialized countries. It was Britain that scored the lowest; the United States was the second-lowest.

title: General Steps Down in Walter Reed Furor
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  The Army announced today that its top medical officer is retiring effective immediately, as the fallout continued from revelations of shoddy conditions at the Walter Reed Medical Center.

title: Manhattan: Vote on Ban of Nonwood Bats
description: A City Council committee was expected to approve a bill today that would ban the use of nonwood bats in high school baseball games, according to Council officials. The measure, introduced by Councilmen James S. Oddo, Republican of Staten Island, and Lewis A. Fidler, Democrat of Brooklyn, is to be voted on by the full Council on Wednesday. The sponsors cited cases in which metal bats have been linked to serious injuries and, as evidence, research by the Nicholas Institute of Sports Medicine and Athletic Trauma. But at an Oct. 23 hearing, the citys Department of Education opposed the proposal and the director of the National Center for Catastrophic Sports Injury Research said there was no evidence that batted-ball injuries are a greater problem from aluminum bats as compared to wooden bats. A second hearing was scheduled for this morning, before the committee vote.

title: Indentured Servants in America
description: A must-read for anyone who favors an expansion of guest worker programs in the U.S. is a stunning new report from the Southern Poverty Law Center that details the widespread abuse of highly vulnerable, poverty-stricken workers in programs that already exist.

title: After 40 Years in French Politics, Chirac to Retire
description: PARIS, March 11  After more than four decades as a politician and a dozen years as president, Jacques Chirac announced his retirement from politics on Sunday, but he did not endorse Nicolas Sarkozy, the presidential candidate and leader of the party Mr. Chirac founded.

title: Local Immigration Law Faces Court Challenge
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 12  A federal trial opened here today weighing legal challenges to local ordinances adopted by the city of Hazleton, Penn., to crack down on illegal immigrants, the first time that this type of local law will get a hearing by a federal judge in a full-scale trial.

title: Transit Guard Is Fatally Shot in Brooklyn
description: A security guard for New York City Transit was shot and killed on a street near Paerdegat Basin in Brooklyn early yesterday, shortly after ending his late shift at the Linden Yards maintenance center in Canarsie, officials said.

title: Familiar Names Add New Title in St. Louis, the Silodor Pairs
description: ST. LOUIS, March 11  The second major event at the Spring North American Bridge Championships of the American Contract Bridge League here was the two-day Silodor Open Pairs, which ended Saturday night in a victory for Giorgio Duboin from Italy and Roy Welland of New York. It was the first North American national pair title for either player, though both have won several national team championships, and Duboin has four world team titles.

title: Lacking Papers, Citizens Are Cut From Medicaid
description: WASHINGTON, March 11  A new federal rule intended to keep illegal immigrants from receiving Medicaid has instead shut out tens of thousands of United States citizens who have had difficulty complying with requirements to show birth certificates and other documents proving their citizenship, state officials say.

title: Francis, Like Knicks, Is Full of Surprises
description: The moment the Knicks burst into the playoff picture was captured in a single image late Saturday night: Steve Francis, standing atop the scorers table in Washington, his arms folded triumphantly.

title: DePauw Cuts Ties With Controversial Sorority
description: DePauw University severed its ties today with a national sorority that evicted two-thirds of the universitys members last year in what the sorority called an effort to improve its image for recruitment, but which the evicted women described as a purge of the unattractive or the uncool.

title: For Wars Gravely Injured, Challenge to Find Care
description: When Staff Sgt. Jarod Behee was asked to select a paint color for the customized wheelchair that was going to be his future, his young wife seethed. The government, Marissa Behee believed, was giving up on her husband just five months after he took a snipers bullet to the head during his second tour of duty in Iraq.

title: Manhattan: City Warns Debt Collectors
description: The citys Department of Consumer Affairs yesterday warned debt collectors that they must be licensed if they wish to collect from New York City residents. In the past two months, the department has secured agreements and fines totaling more than $65,000 from six unlicensed collection agencies, while it continues to investigate several others. Jonathan B. Mintz, the commissioner of consumer affairs, said that abusive collection tactics can significantly harm a consumers credit history and impact the financial resources of those who need it most.

title: At War With Ghosts and History
description: Guns are brandished like toys, and the talk crackles with chatter about drive-by shootings. A burial and a killing take place onstage, and the Grim Reaper has at last claimed mighty Aunt Ester. All too soon: She was just 366 years old. Even so the mystery of life, not death, is the true subject of August Wilsons King Hedley II, which opened last night at the Signature Theater Company in a forceful production that concludes its season, dedicated to Mr. Wilsons work, on a stirring note.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about the first solar observatory in the Americas misstated the title of Ivan Ghezzi, a doctoral student at Yale University who helped investigate the site, in Peru. Mr. Ghezzi is the archaeological director  not the overall director  of the National Institute of Culture, in Peru. (Cecilia Bkula Budge is the director.)

title: Is That Just Some Game? No, Its a Cultural Artifact
description: When Henry Lowood, curator of the History of Science and Technology Collections at Stanford University, started preserving video games and video-game artifacts in 1998 he thought it was closer to professional oblivion than a bold new move into the future.

title: A Shaky Performance Doesnt Rattle Hughes
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 11  The first hitter Phil Hughes faced Sunday was Travis Hafner, one of baseballs most dangerous sluggers. Hughes fired two fastballs, and Hafner looked at both for strikes. Then a curveball just missed.

title: The Swimsuits Were Skimpy, but the Magazine Was Invisible
description: Sports Illustrateds annual swimsuit issue  devoted to the athletic rigors of wearing a wet bikini  is often criticized for its soft-core content. But this year, another controversy erupted over the magazines self-censorship.

title: After False Claim, Wikipedia to Check Degrees
description: After an influential contributor and administrator at the online encyclopedia Wikipedia was found last week to have invented a history of academic credentials, Jimmy Wales, Wikipedias co-founder and globetrotting advocate, called for a voluntary system for accrediting contributors who say they have advanced degrees, like a Ph.D or M.D.

title: Log In Your Measurements, and the Clothes May Fit
description: CUSTOMERS bought $9.6 billion worth of apparel online in the United States last year, according to Forrester Research, the Internet consulting firm. But not one of those customers tried anything on first.

title: Immigration on Bushs Agenda in Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA CITY, March 12  President Bush arrived here late Sunday for the Central American leg of his tour through Latin America, where his agenda will increasingly be dominated by south-of-the-border demands for the decriminalization of immigrant workers in the United States.

title: The Battle Over How to Teach Reading (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Police Quash Meeting Held by Opposition in Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 11  Hundreds of Zimbabwes riot police officers violently crushed an attempt by protesters to hold what they called a prayer meeting on Sunday in one of the capitals largest slums to express opposition to President Robert G. Mugabes rule.

title: Sunshine on History
description: In November 2001, while the world was focused on terrorism, President Bush issued an executive order making it significantly harder for historians and the public to gain access to a former presidents official papers. The House has a chance tomorrow to reverse this damaging decree.

title: A Courageous Act (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions on Friday about a report by the Justice Departments inspector general critical of the F.B.I.s use of administrative subpoenas misspelled the surname of the Justice Departments spokesman, who defended the removal of eight United States attorneys, another problem for the department. He is Brian Roehrkasse, not Roehrkass.

title: Presidential Papers Belong to the People (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bill to Ban Aluminum Bats Advances
description: New York City would become the first jurisdiction in the United States to prohibit the use of metal bats in high school baseball games under a bill approved today by a City Council committee.

title: New CDs
description: 8BALL & MJG Ridin High  (Bad Boy/Atlantic)

title: As Mobile Phones Grow More Complex, Carriers Insist on Fewer Operating Systems
description: MILAN, March 11  Two operating systems run more than 95 percent of the worlds computers, but dozens of systems are behind the 2.5 billion mobile phones in circulation, a situation that has hampered the growth of new services, industry executives and independent specialists say.

title: 20 Students Who Work Hard and Dream Big Win Times Scholarships
description: To Feruz Erizku, the grimness of the Andrew Jackson Houses in the South Bronx has been a source of both despair and drive. In the morning, as she makes her way to school, Ms. Erizku stares at the cigarette butts on the elevator floor, smells the marijuana that wafts from some apartment doors, strolls past young men who seem void of purpose. She wonders: Is this the end of the road?

title: Bush to Press Free Trade in a Place Where Young Children Still Cut the Cane
description: CHIMALTENANGO, Guatemala, March 11  Work starts early for the people of the Guatemalan countryside, sometimes as early as 5 or 6. Not the time, the age.

title: Isles Simon Suspended Through Playoffs
description: The National Hockey League suspended Islanders left wing Chris Simon yesterday for the final 15 games of the regular season and for the duration of the playoffs, if the Islanders qualify. The ban will be for at least 25 games, a league record, and could extend into next season.

title: Manhattan: Shortage of High School Seats
description: The New York City Department of Education hopes to improve the high school graduation rate, but has not planned for enough seats to meet that goal, according to a report released yesterday by the citys public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum. The report said the department has set a goal of having 70 percent of high school students graduate in four years, but its five-year, $13.1 billion school construction plan, which calls for the creation of 26,000 high school seats, assumes a graduation rate of only 46 percent. Andrew Jacob, a Department of Education spokesman, rejected the reports findings. The report is absurd, he said in a statement. Our construction plan is adjusted annually to reflect projected changes in the graduation rate and demographic trends. We will create seats for all our high school students in whatever numbers they are graduating  the more the better.

title: Legislature Acts to Restore Spitzers Cuts in Health Care
