description: The New York State Assembly and Senate introduced budget bills and resolutions on Friday and over the weekend that would restore several hundred million dollars in health care spending cut by Gov. Eliot Spitzer in his executive budget.

title: The Perfect Lawn, Mowed and Muted
description: A court battle over the right to demonstrate on Central Parks Great Lawn has underscored an astounding fact. In the heart of the nations largest and arguably most opinionated city, there is no place to hold a large rally. Central Park has long been the site of such gatherings, but the Bloomberg administration insists that its grass is too fragile to permit them now. Its an inadequate and distressing rationale, and we hope that the lawsuit will remind the city of the importance of making space for large gatherings where New Yorkers can exercise their right of free speech.

title: Texans Want to Strike Rule on Projecting Retiree Care
description: The nations 50 states and the largest cities will soon be required to disclose the value of the health care they have promised their retired workers. The prospect of that disclosure, under a new accounting rule, is not a happy one for governments.

title: Hagel Holds Off on 2008 Presidential Race
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, said today that he is not jumping into the 2008 presidential race  for now, at least  so he can concentrate on domestic and global concerns, particularly helping to bring an end to the Iraq war.

title: Cheney Assails Those Favoring Iraq Drawdown
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Vice President Dick Cheney offered an aggressive defense of the Bush administrations Iraq strategy today, asserting that those in Congress who pursue a gradual drawdown of American forces are undermining the troops and that a withdrawal would represent a full validation of the Al Qaeda strategy.

title: 4th Shareholder of Nikko in Japan Rejects a Citigroup Offer as Low
description: Citigroups $10.8 billion takeover offer for the Nikko Cordial Corporation, a Japanese brokerage firm, has been rejected by a fourth shareholder.

title: $1 Billion Expansion Is Planned for the Hard Rock in Las Vegas
description: Morgans Hotel Group and DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, which recently acquired the Hard Rock Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas, are planning a nearly $1 billion expansion of the boutique resort just off the Strip, according to people briefed on the discussions.

title: U.N. Faults Sudan Government for Darfur Crisis
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 12  A high-level United Nations mission to Darfur said today that the Sudanese government had organized and taken part in human rights crimes against its own population and that international action to stop the killings and rapes had been inadequate.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A sports article in some copies on Friday, about the hockey game in which Chris Simon of the Islanders struck the Rangers Ryan Hollweg in the chin with his stick, rendered incorrectly a postgame quotation from Simon. He said, Ive always been known as a team guy, and I feel real bad about letting the team down. He did not say, Ive always been known as a clean guy, nor did he say, I just feel bad for letting my team down. A version of the quotation printed in larger type above the article and pictures repeated the errors.

title: A Players Eruption Draws Appropriate Fire
description: Hockey players are mostly tough yet sensible law-abiding gentlemen, but among them are a few skating volcanoes. You never know when one of those volcanoes will erupt, as left wing Chris Simon of the Islanders did Thursday night when he slammed the shaft of his stick across the face of Rangers forward Ryan Hollweg.

title: Is It Live ... or Yamaha? Channeling Glenn Gould
description: Was that relief I felt as the piano was playing? A feeling that some worry had been alleviated or a fear quieted? Why then was it also mixed with disappointment, as if some deep yearning had been thwarted? Not yet, not yet, not yet: relief and frustration intertwined.

title: Where Tobacco Ruled, Smoking Ban Gains Ground
description: ADAMS, Tenn., March 8  A century ago, a battle called the Black Patch War raged across Robertson County, where Rick Gregorys ancestors grew tobacco. In the vicious fight over prices, nightriders with rifles raided farms and dynamited equipment. Tobacco barns burned in the night, and salted beds lay fallow.

title: A Message to Health Insurers: Ask Before Raising Rates
description: ALBANY  Eric R. Dinallo, the governors acting insurance superintendent, wants to reclaim state control over health insurance rates.

title: Who Owns the Live Music of Days Gone By?
description: When it began in 1973, the King Biscuit Flower Hour was very much of its time. Bob Meyrowitz, who ran the show during its heyday, had the idea to start a weekly rock concert radio program as an alternative to chaotic festival shows after a fan was killed at the Rolling Stones performance at Altamont.

title: Best Buy Asks Four Agencies to Take Part in a Review
description: Best Buy in Minneapolis has asked four agencies to take part in a review for advertising assignments with spending estimated at $200 million. The assignments include brand advertising, television commercials and media planning.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on March 4 about the reflections of Mets left fielder Moises Alou on the shooting deaths of two relatives in Brooklyn in 1995 omitted a credit. Michael S. Schmidt interviewed Brooklyn authorities and neighbors for the article, which was written from Port St. Lucie, Fla., site of the Mets spring training.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about a court ruling terminating a lease on the site of the planned Atlantic Yards project near Downtown Brooklyn misstated the composition of a group that filed another case challenging the states right to condemn their properties under eminent domain law. The 13 plaintiffs in that suit include owners and tenants, not just owners. The article also misstated the reaction of Forest City Ratner, the developer of Atlantic Yards, to the ruling on the lease. Forest City said in a statement that it did not believe the ruling would have an impact on the project; it did not decline to comment.

title: Aint It Strange?
description: ON a cold morning in 1955, walking to Sunday school, I was drawn to the voice of Little Richard wailing Tutti Frutti from the interior of a local boys makeshift clubhouse. So powerful was the connection that I let go of my mothers hand.

title: Early Primary Rush Upends 08 Campaign Plans
description: WASHINGTON, March 9  The trickle of states moving their 2008 presidential primaries to Feb. 5 has turned into an avalanche, forcing all the presidential campaigns to reconsider every aspect of their nominating strategy  where to compete, how to spend money, when to start television advertising  as they gird for the prospect of a 20-state national primary day.

title: Slobodan Milosevics Last Waltz
description: Washington

title: Patriots Fatten the Deals to Acquire Free Agents
description: The New England Patriots of the Bill Belichick era have been celebrated for their fiscal responsibility, exercising a restraint in player acquisition that stands in sharp contrast to the annual splashes into the free-agent pool performed by the Washington Redskins and others.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about a lawsuit filed in Massachusetts by advocates for inmates and the mentally ill misstated the number of prison suicides in 2005 in California, which has been ordered to spend $600 million to improve mental health services in prisons. There were 36, not 44.

title: Rangers 2, Hurricanes 1 (S.O.)
description: In a game with more bizarre turns than an amusement park ride, the Rangers game against Carolina yesterday ended like so many others, with Madison Square Garden howling for Jaromir Jagr to salvage things.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Cheers and Jeers for Cond Nast
description: In its March/April issue, Good magazine offers a list of the 51 best magazines ever, which includes some eclectic choices, some praise and a couple of sharp jabs at the company that employs the bigshot editor who wrote the lists introduction.

title: Bush Seeks Iraq War Funds With No Strings
description: BOGOT, Colombia, March 11  President Bush on Sunday called for Congress to provide financing for the Iraq war with no strings attached. And he defended his decision, made formal this weekend, to send more than 8,000 more troops to Iraq and Afghanistan by saying they would be dedicated to training and support missions.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Top Seeds Can Often Mislead in N.C.A.A. Bracket
description: When it comes time to pick a champion in an N.C.A.A. bracket, people tend to cluster around a few of the favorites. Last year, more than half of the 3.1 million entries in ESPN.coms Tournament Challenge predicted that Connecticut or Duke would win it all. In 2005, more than half went with Illinois or North Carolina.

title: How Self-Control Lowers a Buyers Guard
description: If you use a lot of self-restraint to control one impulse, will you have too little to resist the next? A paper in The Journal of Consumer Research looks at the effects of self-restraint on subsequent impulse purchases.

title: After Campout, Mother Leaves Hospital With Son
description: A Long Island mother who camped out for nearly 118 hours in a hospital visitors lounge to be near her critically ill newborn went home Saturday night with her child, her husband said.

title: Gay Athletes Slowly Enter the Endorsement Arena
description: FOR years, the number of athletes who were openly gay and had endorsement deals could have been counted on the hand of the old-time baseball player Mordecai Brown, known after a farm accident by the nickname Three Finger.

title: Republicans See Divided Party and Trouble in 08
description: After years of political dominance, Republican voters now view their party as divided and say they are not satisfied with the choice of candidates seeking the Republican presidential nomination in 2008, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Sosa Tries to Prove Hes Still the Sammy of Old
description: SURPRISE, Ariz., March 11  Sammy Sosa is swinging a baseball bat again, trying to squeeze another season out of his 38-year-old body and trying to fashion a different ending to a career that has been compelling and perplexing. Sosa will always be known for hitting bushels of home runs, but there is also some doubt about whether all of them were legitimate.

title: An Efficient Way to Pick a Surprise Team
description: There are two ways of looking at how this years seedings for the N.C.A.A. tournament were determined by the selection committee.

title: Visceral Tales From Iraq, Where Life-Changing Days Are Just the Start of Pain
description: Bob Woodruff and Martha Raddatz, both of ABC News, have stories to tell about devastating carnage in Iraq. And both of them have already told these stories on television, giving them a visual impact that goes way beyond what is possible on the page. So together their new books raise the same questions: What purpose is served by a written account? Is it merely redundant? Why read about what weve already seen?

title: Bronx: Assisted-Living Worker Is Charged
description: A former worker at an assisted-living home was indicted on Friday on charges of stealing more than $300,000 from older and frail residents, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced yesterday. The worker, Frances Landrini, 36, of the Bronx, faces four counts of grand larceny and one count of scheming to defraud. She pleaded not guilty; her lawyer, Louis J. Reda, did not immediately respond to a request for comment last night. Ms. Landrini was a contract worker at the New Fordham Arms Home for Adults, a 35-bed home at 2915 Williamsbridge Road, where she helped residents pay their bills and conduct financial transactions. Over two years, Mr. Cuomo said, Ms. Landrini persuaded residents to sign blank checks, claiming that she would fill in the rest to pay the residents bills but instead cashed the checks or deposited them into her own bank account. Mr. Cuomo said Ms. Landrini fraudulently obtained and negotiated more than 150 checks from 12 residents.

title: Looking Ahead
description: DRUG WARS The battle for control of Caremark Rx, the prescription drug benefits manager, could be resolved Friday, when the companys shareholders are scheduled to vote on a takeover offer by CVS, the big pharmacy chain. Express Scripts, another leading pharmacy benefits manager, has tried to counter the CVS bid and may try once again to break up the deal. But CVS, which has raised its bid to $26 billion, seems to hold the advantage.

title: The Brackets First-Round Picks
description: MIDWEST

title: Play With Your Friends
description: The Bracket and The New York Times have hatched a way for you to experience all the excitement of the N.C.A.A. tournament online  the upsets, the buzzer beaters, the thrill of picking that sleeper Final Four team none of your friends picked.

title: To Have, Hold and Cherish, Until Bedtime
description: With many adults having trouble sleeping at night, orders for separate bedrooms, or even his-and-her wings, are gaining popularity.

title: Hillary Rodham Clinton: Seeking a Return to the White House
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has already spent far more time in the White House than the rest of the presidential field combined.

title: John McCain: A Candidate Tied to an Increasingly Unpopular War
description: Senator John McCain of Arizona has only been defeated in one race in his political life, in a heated contest against George W. Bush for the Republican presidential nomination in 2000. Now as he runs for president again, his candidacy has become closely tied to the increasingly unpopular war that his rival began.

title: Mitt Romney: Appealing to Conservatives, Hailing From Massachusetts
description: It is not unusual for prominent Massachusetts politicians to run for president. What is unusual is for one to run by appealing to the most conservative wing of the Republican party. But little of Mitt Romney's political career has followed a conventional path.

title: Bronx Fire Victims Are Mourned
John Edwards: Seeking the Top of the Ticket on 2nd Try
description: Been there, almost done that: One distinction John Edwards holds in the crowded presidential field is being the only candidate in either party to have been on a November presidential ballot, having served as Senator John Kerry's running mate in 2004.

title: Barack Obama: A Freshman Senators Hope-Fueled Campaign
description: Barack Obama, a freshman senator from Illinois, might be the first to admit that the excitement generated by his presidential bid has little to do with what he has already done, and much more to do with hopes about what he might do.

title: Rudolph W. Giuliani: Improvising With an Emphasis on 9/11
description: Most candidates for president have a carefully crafted stump speech, a talk they deliver over and over to emphasize the themes, proposals and even key words they think are at the heart of their appeal. Not Rudolph W. Giuliani.

title: Will Uncle Sam Come After Private Equity?
description: Get ready: The chill that private equity funds have been feeling in Europe may be about to cross the pond. Lawmakers in the United States are considering taxing the rich fees that private equity bigwigs earn as income, rather than the capital gains that they are currently considered to be. Such a move would take a big chunk out of the 20 percent performance fees that private equity firms charge and will no doubt be fought tooth and nail by the industry.

title: 4th Nikko Shareholder Rejects Citis Bid
description: And then there were four. Citigroups $10.8 billion takeover offer for Nikko Cordial, a Japanese brokerage firm, has been rejected by yet another shareholder, bringing the total number of those opposed to the much-ballyhooed deal to four.

title: Adaptive Planning Taps V.C. Funding
description: Adaptive Planning, a provider of collaborative business performance management (BPM) software, announced Friday that it had completed a $7.5 million round of financing. Cardinal Venture Capital led the round, which also included participation from previous investors ONSET Ventures and Monitor Ventures.

title: Hutchinson Shareholders OK Vodafone Deal
description: Shareholders of Hutchison Telecommunications International have approved the $11.1 billion sale of its Indian unit to Vodafone Group, a transaction that will finance a special dividend and expansion in Southeast Asia. Stockholders representing a majority of Hutchison Telecoms shares approved the sale at an extraordinary general meeting in Hong Kong, Tim Pennington, chief financial officer of Hutchison, said Friday. The plan got overwhelming support, he said.

title: Former Brocade Official Seeks a Separate Trial
description: Brocade Communications Systems former human resources director, accused of conspiring with the companys former chief executive to manipulate stock option grants, asked a judge for a separate trial. Stephanie Jensen, charged in August with conspiracy, fraud and false securities filing, seeks to sever her case from that of Brocades former C.E.O., Greg Reyes, so he can provide exculpatory testimony at her trial, according to a filing in San Francisco federal court Friday.

title: Weird and Weirder Numbers on Pay Reports
description: Amid the increasingly heated debate over executive pay, The New York Times Gretchen Morgenson takes a look at how illuminating the new details that the Securities and Exchange Commission requires in companies pay filings really are. Calling the filings an exercise in exhaustion, Ms. Morgenson suggests that the additional data now required by the S.E.C.  with a view to helping shareholders better understand the details of executive compensation  has produced opaque results.

title: Russian Prosecutors Search Office of Yukoss Audit Firm
description: Russian prosecutors and Interior Ministry officers searched the Moscow office of the auditing firm PricewaterhouseCoopers Friday in connection with its work with Yukos, the bankrupt oil company, and with PricewaterhouseCooperss own tax filings. Russian officials have compared the Yukos affair to the Enron scandal in the United States, with ominous implications for the firm.

title: Buyout Firm and Partner Bid for British Drugstores
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said Friday that it was teaming up with the Italian billionaire Stefano Pessina to make a takeover bid for Alliance Boots, Britains largest drugstore chain. The move comes amid a flurry of buyout interest in European retailers. K.K.R., based in New York, and Mr. Pessina, who is the deputy chairman of Alliance Boots and its largest shareholder, made a friendly approach worth 1,000 pence in cash for each Alliance share, or about 9.7 billion pounds ($19 billion).

title: 3/11 Memorial Opens in Madrid
description: On Sunday, Spain marked the third anniversary of the March 11, 2004 terrorist attacks in Madrid. At a ceremony outside the Atocha train station, King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia dedicated a memorial to the 191 train passengers who were killed there when Islamic extremists detonated 10 bombs during the morning rush hour.

title: China to Launch Mammoth Investment Fund
description: China will create an agency to invest its immense reserves of foreign currency, now totaling more than $1 trillion, the countrys finance minister announced on Friday. The minister, Jin Renqing, offered no specifics about how much of Chinas currency reserves would be under the agencys control. But whatever the precise figure, analysts say that the agency is certain to begin life as one of the worlds biggest investment funds.

title: Is Private Equity the Next Oracle of Omaha?
description: Warren E. Buffett, dubbed the Oracle of Omaha for his savvy investments in publicly-traded companies, may be facing some competition from buyout shops. BusinessWeek notes that private equity firms, with their coffers bulging with unprecedented amounts of cash, are taking minority stakes in public companies. And, the magazine says, their involvement is causing the halo effect usually reserved for the likes of Mr. Buffett, signaling that there may be a new player to mimic in the market.

title: Private Equity Said to Be Circling Strategic Hotels
description: Strategic Hotels & Resorts, a chain of luxury accommodations, may be the latest real estate investment trust to be the target of a buyout bid. Those who are reportedly mulling a move on the Chicago-based REIT include the Blackstone Group, the Carlyle Group and Walton Street Capital.

title: Asian-American Theaters Plan New Festival
description: In 2003, leaders from Asian-American, Latino-American and African-American theater companies held a round-table discussion during a Theater Communications Group conference at the White Oak retreat in Yulee, Fla., to examine the state of their art.

title: Canadian Lawyer Sued Over Hedge Fund Collapse
description: A 76-year-old Montreal lawyer with a penchant for preserving Scottish culture has emerged as an alleged culprit in the collapse of Canadian hedge-fund Portus Alternative Asset Management. KPMG, the court-appointed receiver overseeing Portus, has filed a lawsuit against the lawyer, Anthony Malcolm, alleging that he set up a series of offshore accounts that Portus co-founder Boaz Manor used to siphon off $17.6 million of client money.

title: Chuck Who? Poll Finds Few Opinions About Hagel
description: Most voters have no opinion of Senator Chuck Hagel, who is expected to announce today if he plans to seek the Republican nomination for President.

title: Private-Equity Backer Floats British Self-Storage Firm
description: Safestore, Britains largest self-storage operator, has raised more than 150 million pounds ($291 million) for its private-equity owners in an initial public offering that comes a year after debt refinancing gave shareholders a 100 million pounds payout. The company said on Friday that it raised 209 million pounds from floating almost half of the firm on the London market, putting a value on the business of 449 million pounds.

title: Goldman Sends Buyout Banker to London
description: Goldman Sachs is relocating investment banker John Waldron from New York to London, where he will be co-head of the group that advises private equity firms. Reuters said the move is another signal of the sectors growing significance in Europe.

title: Eliot Spitzers Good Baptist Wife
description: You would think that Gov. Eliot Spitzer, who is Jewish, would be exempt from reminders about attending church on Sunday, but that is what happened  indirectly  during a visit to Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem on Sunday morning.

title: Ford Closes in on Aston Martin Deal
description: Ford Motor is expected to sell Aston Martin, maker of the upscale British sports cars favored by James Bond, to a group of investors that includes the racing mogul David Richards and a pair of Kuwaiti companies in a deal that will be announced Monday, according to The New York Times. The Times said that Ford, which put Aston Martin up for sale last August, will retain a 15 percent stake in the marque.

title: CVC Capital Adds Partner in New York
description: CVC Capital, a European private equity firm with $24 billion in assets under management, said Monday that it hired Robert L. Berner III as a partner to help expand its business in the United States. Mr. Berner, formerly a managing director at Ripplewood Holdings, will be a partner in CVCs recently opened New York office, CVC said.

title: Report Urges Changes to Burnish U.S. Markets
description: Arguing that the competitiveness of the United States capital markets is under strain, a committee of the United States Chamber of Commerce on Monday proposed a series of steps to ease the regulatory burdens for U.S. companies. The report, which noted a substantial decrease in the number of initial public offerings in the U.S., called for the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 to be folded into the 1934 law that created the Securities and Exchange Commission and urged companies to stop giving quarterly earnings guidance.

title: Bronx Fire Victims Are Mourned
description: Hundreds of people packed into the Islamic Cultural Center to say goodbye to the 10 victims.

title: Smaller Exchange Avoids Big Problems
description: As the markets dropped sharply last week, sending volume soaring and backing up trades handled by the New York Stock Exchange, at least one stock market player was resting easy. Bats Trading, an upstart electronic trading system based in Kansas City, Mo., said it handled the volatility with none of the glitches that others did.

title: Arthur Anderson Settles With Enron Investors
description: A federal judge gave final approval Friday to a $72.5 million settlement between Arthur Andersen and investors who sued the accounting firm over its role in the 2001 collapse of Enron. U.S. District Judge Melinda Harmon signed the final order at a brief hearing held in Houston, effectively ending the now defunct accounting firms involvement in the $40 billion class-action lawsuit.

title: After Record Run, Goldman Profits to Slow, Analysts Say
description: Analysts are betting that Goldman Sachs, which has reported record earnings and revenue for the past three years, may see a slow-down in the first quarter. The investment bank, whose stock has surged 36 percent in the last 12 months, far outpacing its rivals, is expected to post solid, if not stellar results, when it announces its results this week.

title: Facing Fraud Trial, Conrad Black Flouts the Rules
description: The upcoming criminal fraud trial in Chicago of Conrad M. Black, the former head of Hollinger International who faces more than 90 years in jail if convicted, has all the makings of good theater. First there is Mr. Black himself, a larger-than-life figure whose baroque vocabulary and towering demeanor can seem straight out of Dickens. Unlike most defendants in corporate malfeasance trials facing the rest of their years behind bars, Mr. Black has gone very public  giving interviews and speeches, writing articles chastising his accusers and vowing not only exoneration but a comeback.

title: Greenbergs P.R. Firm Sues for $2 Million
description: A public relations company hired who says it was hired to buff up the sullied reputation of Maurice Hank Greenberg, the former chief executive of the American International Group, is suing Mr. Greenbergs company, C.V. Starr, for allegedly refusing to pay a $2 million bill.

title: Schering-Plough to Pay $14.5 Billion for Drugs Unit
description: Akzo Nobel said Monday it would sell its pharmaceuticals unit Organon BioSciences to Schering-Plough for 11 billion euros ($14.5 billion), dropping its previously announced plans to hold an initial public offering for the business. The deal bulks up United States-based Schering-Plough, whose chief executive has made no secret of his desire to find acquisitions.

title: Trump Resorts Hires Merrill as Adviser, Report Says
description: Donald Trumps Trump Entertainment Resorts has hired Merrill Lynch to help the company evaluate its options, which might include selling a single casino or even the entire company, according to The New Jersey Star-Ledger. Other possibilities for the Atlantic City casino operator include an equity offering to raise cash or even taking the company private, the report said.

title: Dollar General Agrees to $6.9 Billion Buyout
description: Dollar General, a discount retailer with more than 8,000 stores in the United States, said Monday it agreed to be acquired by private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts for $7.3 billion, including about $380 million in assumed debt. Kohlberg Kravis will pay $22 in cash for each Dollar General share, or about 31 percent more than the shares closing price on Friday, Dollar General said. The companys board has unanimously approved the transaction and is urging shareholders to vote in favor of it.

title: Royal Philips to Sell Taiwan Chipmaker Stake
description: Royal Philips Electronics, Europes largest consumer electronics maker, said Friday it plans to sell its 16.2 percent stake in Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing over the next few years. The stake is valued at around $8.5 billion. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing is the worlds biggest contract chip maker by revenue.

title: Police Restore Order in Hunan Province After Riots
description: BEIJING, Mar. 13  An estimated 20,000 people clashed with police in Hunan Province late last week, as a protest over rising transportation costs escalated into a riot, witnesses and overseas news reports said.

title: Gov Seeks Insurance Changes
description: In the Empire Zone column this morning, acting insurance superintendent Eric Dinallo says the Spitzer administration is seeking to reclaim prior approval before increases of health insurance rates. Right now, insurers can raise rates on their own, and the Insurance Department is limited in what it can do retroactively. Hence, double digit increases have become a common practice.

title: Obama and Fox
description: Theres still some interesting fallout from the dissolution between Nevada Democrats and Fox News, after senior party officials decided to cancel an August debate amid an uproar among liberal bloggers and activists over the choice of networks.

title: UnitedHealth to Buy Sierra Health for $2.6 Billion
description: UnitedHealth Group, the health-insurance giant, said on Monday it would acquire Sierra Health Services for $2.6 billion, or $43.50 in cash per share, to help it expand in the fast-growing Southwest. Sierra provides health benefits and services to 310,000 members in Nevada and 320,000 customers throughout the United States.

title: Ancient Mysteries of N.C.A.A. Rankings
Q & A: Shea Gallante
description: Like many Manhattan chefs, Shea Gallante has cycled through more than a few popular and celebrated restaurants. He put in time at Coco Pazzo Teatro, at Felidia and at Bouley, where he rose to the rank of chef de cuisine and lapped up knowledge and ideas from David Bouley. In 2004, he got a kitchen of his own, snagging the top job at Cru, in Greenwich Village, which opened that year. Reviews of his work at Cru have been hugely admiring. Mr. Gallante is 33.

title: Around the neighborhood
description: Links to real estate news:

title: 2008: Primary Permutations
description: With state after state moving toward an earlier primary schedule, as they covet the early-bird prominence of Iowa and New Hampshire (as well as South Carolina and Nevada), Adam Nagourney examines how a squished primary season would affect the presidential political cycle:

title: Congress: The War Comes Home
description: Both the House and Senate head toward clashes over Iraq policy this week though the main events loom in the future.

title: Architect of Desire
description: I have a confession to make: I always knew we needed an architect. (To our readers who suggested that this was the case, thanks. You were right.)

title: Ford to Sell Aston Martin in $925 Million Deal
description: There was nothing top secret about this deal: Confirming several previous reports, Ford Motor said Monday that it would sell its Aston Martin, known as the sports car of choice for James Bond, to a group including racing mogul David Richards and two Kuwaiti investment firms. The transaction values Aston Martin at $925 million, but Ford will keep a stake in the unit vauled at $77 million, the company said.

title: Legislature Adds to Spitzers Budget
description: Budget negotiations kick into high gear this week as the Senate and Assembly begin their joint public negotiations. The chambers introduced their budget bills on Friday and over the weekend.The Assemblys budget, which came in late Friday, would increase the governors $120.6 billion proposal to nearly $121.3 billion, in large measure because of restoring several hundred million dollars worth of health care cuts by the governor.

title: Express Scripts Says It Cant Raise Caremark Bid
description: Acknowledging its weakened position, Express Scripts said Monday that it woud not raise its offer for rival Caremark Rx without the chance to conduct due diligence, which Caremark has refused to allow. The announcement appears to put CVS in a position to win the bitter takeover feud for Caremark, a bitter fight that has played out in public and in the courts since December. In a press release, Express Scripts criticized Caremarks merger process as flawed and continued to urge Caremarks shareholders to vote against the merger with CVS, the nations largest drugstore chain.

title: Bushs Consigliere
description: Like the editorial page of The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal editorial page thinks Alberto Gonzales has made a mess of things at the Department of Justice. The Journals reasoning, however, is a bit different: The incompetence at Justice is getting to be expensive for Presidential power. The lead editorial in The New York Times on Sunday chastised Gonzales for being consigliere to Mr. Bushs imperial presidency.

title: Hagel Postpones Decision on 2008
description: Senator Chuck Hagel officially announced today that he, too, will postpone making decisions on his political future until later this year, saying he wanted to focus full time on issues before the Senate, including the war in Iraq. But he didnt foreclose the possibility of deciding to join the crowded Republican field of possible presidential contenders, saying he would decide at a later date.

title: Statement by U.S. Senator Chuck Hagel on His Political Future
description: America stands at an historic crossroads in its history. It is against this backdrop that I find myself at my own crossroads on my political future. Burdened by two wars, faced with dangerous new threats and global uncertainty, beset by serious long-term domestic problems and divided by raw political partisanship-America now reaches for a national consensus of purpose. America's response to the challenges and opportunities that confront us today will define our future. Finding solutions to these challenges and capitalizing on these opportunities will not wait until the next election.

title: Avon
description: An ad for Avon.

title: Avon, Ad 2
description: An ad for Avon.

title: Well-Timed Insider Sales Draw Attention
description: They seem to have automated everything else, so why not insider trading? BusinessWeek reported Monday that the Securities and Exchange Commission, the nations top markets regulator, is planning to take a close look at automated trading plans, which are often set up for executives as a way to buy and sell stock of their own companies. The S.E.C. is said to be looking for evidence that these automated programs are being used (or abused) to facilitate stock sales based on inside information  which is just what they are supposed to prevent.

title: Editors Note
description: An essay in the Book Review on March 4, "Confessions of a Book Abuser," by Ben Schott, defended the ways people physically "mistreat" books. Readers have subsequently pointed out a number of resemblances between Schott's essay and "Never Do That to a Book," an essay on the same subject by Anne Fadiman that was part of her 1998 book "Ex Libris: Confessions of a Common Reader."

title: Morgan to Buy Stake in a Fifth Hedge Fund
description: Morgan Stanley shows no sign of a waning interest in hedge funds. The investment bank said Monday that it has bought a minority stake in Abax Global Capital, a startup cofounded by Citadel Investment Group veterans that will focus on Asian investments. Morgan Stanley did not disclose the size of the stake or the value of the deal.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Black Snake Moan'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews 'Black Snake Moan,' starring Christina Ricci and Samuel Jackson.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Black Snake Moan'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews 'Black Snake Moan,' starring Christina Ricci and Samuel Jackson.

title: Majority Back Health Care for All
description: Robin Toner reports on a New York Times/CBS News Poll showing support for guaranteeing health insurance for every American.

title: Blackberrys Magic
description: David Pogue takes another look at the Blackberry Pearl.

title: The Villages Inside Cairo
description: In Cairo, where citizens often fix water and electricity lines on their own, many people are resigned not to expect anything from politics or government.

title: Quadruple Your Money in Worthless Options
description: The latest enforcement action by the Securities and Exchange Commission relating to intruded brokerage accounts has a nice switch: In addition to having the defrauded investors buy shares of thinly traded companies you never heard of, this group, of three traders from India, also made good money trading in worthless options of a company almost everyone knows: Google.

title: A Seniors Game
description: The Bracket is delighted to have another entry from our favorite guest blogger and Rhodes Scholarship finalist, Penn forward Stephen Danley. His first post on The Bracket caused quite a stir over on the Penn campus, as evidenced by some of the comments left on the blog. Danley recognized the controversy as a good thing, which shows hes got good journalist instincts.

title: Bin Laden Turns 50, or Doesnt
description: Although no one seems certain that the date is correct, The Associated Press reported on Sunday that  people are marking it anyway:

title: The Language Of Baseball
description: When John Farrell, the pitching coach for the Boston Red Sox, said that he had learned about 20 to 25 Japanese phrases to better communicate with pitchers Daisuke Matsuzaka and Hideki Ojakima, he made me think: Shouldnt I at least know a few Japanese phrases?So I enlisted the help of Roger Kahlon, Hideki Matsuis interpreter, to teach me how to say, How does your arm feel? in Japanese. Kahlon gave me the translation and it took me about three tries before he approved my pronunciation. But, because of Kahlons assistance, I now had a question to ask  and probably shock  any Japanese pitcher.While waiting to interview Sammy Sosa of the Texas Rangers on Sunday, I spotted Akinori Otsuka, a Japanese reliever. Finally, I had the chance to test my Japanese. I dug through my notebook, found the translation, repeated it to myself and then approached Otsuka.As soon as Otsuka heard the words, he smiled and said in English, My arm feels good. He seemed pleased or amused or both that I had asked him a question in Japanese. I told Otsuka the background to my story and he nodded. We talked for a few more minutes and one thing was obvious: Otsukas English was much better than my Japanese.

title: Sim City
description: Very strange site here at Legends Field right now: the simulated game.

title: Taliban Threatens to Kill Kidnapped Italian Journalist
description: A senior Taliban commander told an Afghan news agency on Saturday that the Italian reporter Daniele Mastrogiacomo would be killed at the end of this week, unless Italy agreed to withdraw its 1,900 troops from the NATO force in Afghanistan before then. As Reuters reports:

title: Of Harvey Weinstein and Ultrasuede
description: Since leaving Miramax to cofound The Weinstein Company, Harvey Weinstein has invested in an assortment of niche media plays, some of which are firmly outside the movie industry in which he made his name. His firm, which describes itself as a multimedia company, bought cable arts channel Ovation and invested in aSmallWorld.net, an invitation-only social-networking Web site for adults. The movie moguls latest potential target  a fashion company  is even farther afield.

title: Profligate and Pandering
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer lit into Senate Republicans at a press conference this afternoon, calling their proposed budget profligate and their behavior pandering.

title: Reader Suggestions for Darfur
description: Six weeks ago I asked readers to send in their suggestions for ending the conflict in Darfur. There were about 300 responses, and heres a sampling. Please add your comments at the bottom to identify which you agree with or think are awful.

title: Revolving Door: Wachovia, GE, Arsenal Capital
description: Wachovia Securities, Wachovias investment banking arm, said Monday that it hired two managing directors to cover the media and communications industries. William Bundy, who had been at J.P. Morgan Chase, will work in Wachovias media and communications investment banking group, and John Schwarz, previously of Lazard, will be in the mergers and acquisitions group.

title: Metal Bat Ban, Moving Fast
description: This afternoon, a City Council committee approved a ban on the use of metal bats in high school baseball games, deeming them unsafe. If the ban passes the full Council by a large majority on Wednesday, as seems likely, the city could become the first jurisdiction in the United States to prohibit the use of the bats.

title: In Calpine Case, Adviser Puts Its Fee on the Line
description: Shareholders of Calpine, the bankrupt energy giant, are lining up some high-powered advisers as they try to influence the companys Chapter 11 case. Shareholders are typically relegated to the sidelines in bankruptcy, under the theory that there will be nothing left for them after creditors get paid. But members of Calpines official committee of equity holders think there will be something left in the till  and so, apparently, does their financial adviser, Perella Weinberg Partners.

title: Video Baggage
description: In the upcoming presidential campaign, there will be no more need for those cumbersome old spoken gotchas. The ones that never play very well at the debates:

title: Express Scripts Shares Rise on Possible End to Caremark Battle
description: The battle for Caremark Rx seemed all but over Monday after Express Scripts said that under current conditions it could not raise its $26.3 billion offer for the rival drug benefits manager. Many analysts concluded that CVSs $26 billion bid would win support of Caremarks shareholders, with Wachovia analyst Matt Perry declaring: If the two offers are within approximately 5 percent of each other, Caremark shareholders are likely to approve the CVS offer.

title: Michael Eisner Presents His Prom Queen
description: It is shaping up to be a busy month for Michael Eisner, the former head of Disney. Less than a week after announcing it would help take baseball-card maker Topps private, Mr. Eisners investment firm, Tornante, said it was launching Vuguru, an independent studio to produce and distribute original programming on the Web. Mr. Eisner has shown an interest in Web-based video with his previous investment in Veoh Networks, a video-sharing site that competes with the much more widely visited YouTube.

title: Giuliani and the Conservatives
description: As a video circulated around the Internet featuring a 1989 speech in which Rudolph W. Giuiani promoted public financing for abortions, the former New York Mayor was in Washington today touting his ties to some prominent conservatives.

title: First in War, First in Peace, Last in the National League
description: Up here on the Space Coast today, where I had a chance to chat for a few minutes this morning with Nationals Manager Manny Acta, the Mets former third-base coach. He asked why I didnt come to Viera when the Mets played here Saturday.Are you underestimating my Nationals? Acta asked. Dont go underestimating my Nationals.I told him I wasnt (although I dont know that I ever estimated them in the first place.)

title: Tears Cast a Shadow at a Sunny Tech Gathering
description: Much is being made of venture capitalist John Doerr breaking down into tears as he talked about global warming on Thursday during the TED conference in Monterey, Calif. But what may be more disturbing is what he actually said: Im scared. I dont think were going to make it.

title: Looking for the Chicago Connection in a Satellite Radio Deal
description: Should the proposed merger of satellite radio operators XM and Sirius come to pass, who should get the credit? According to the New Yorkers James Surowiecki, that would be Milton Friedman.

title: Alliance Boots Rejects Buyout Bid
description: British pharmacy chain Alliance Boots rejected a 9.7 billion pound ($18.8 billion) buyout offer from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and its own executive deputy chairman, saying the bid tabled only a few hours before was too low. Shares in Alliance Boots, formed last year from the merger of retailer Boots and drugs wholesaler Alliance Unichem, were up 7 percent at 997 pence.

title: A Health Crackdown
description: A city health inspector has shut down The Coffee Shop, the well-known Union Square bistro, for what the owner says are picayune violations. It appears to be part of a general crackdown after the recent unpleasantness at a KFC/Taco Bell in Greenwich Village.

title: Hedge Funds Share in Epics Bloody Spoils
description: The most famous surviving words from the ancient Greek Battle of Thermopylae have been molon labe, the defiant taunt by 300 Spartans to their numerically superior Persian adversaries. Translated, it means roughly Come and take them, referring to their weapons. This past weekend, it could also have referred to seats at movie theaters, as viewers swarmed cinemas to help Warner Brothers 300 shatter box-office records.

title: Clinton on Halliburton and Dubai
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton lashed out at Halliburton today for its announcement that it would open a corporate headquarters in Dubai and move its chief executive officer there. The action has raised a lot of questions, and Senator Clinton was quick to link the company to its multi-billion defense and war contracts as well as its ties to Vice President Dick Cheney.

title: Pro-War Caravan Heads for Washington
description: As the blog IraqSlogger has noted, a caravan of supporters of the war in Iraq set off from California on a cross-country trip last week intended to counter antiwar rallies planned for this weekend, ahead of the fourth anniversary of the American invasion of Iraq.

title: Zig Zagging
description: I was in Spokane yesterday to work on a story about the Gonzaga basketball team and I am convinced that the Bulldogs are going to win at least one game in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Were Number 5!
description: Last night, the French television channel France 2 broadcast President Jacques Chiracs address to his people  in which he announced, as expected, that he would not run for a third term as president. After the address, France 2 turned to Brice Hortefeux, a representative of Mr. Chiracs party, the Union for a Popular Movement, for his thoughts.

title: The Middle School Challenge
description: Middle school is a netherworld between elementary school and high school, and teachers can be the key.

title: New CNN Poll
description: CNN has just released a nationwide poll that shows Rudolph Giuliani leading Senator John McCain among registered Republicans.

title: Blogtalk
description: Republicans and Al Sharpton, in league against Eliot Spitzer, a libertarian site says. [Reasons Hit and Run]

title: New NYT/CBS Poll: G.O.P. Discontent
description: A new poll by The Times and CBS News finds that Republicans are disillusioned with their partys direction, dissatisfied with the current field of 2008 candidates and believe that contenders who oppose the Bush administrations Iraq war policies will have an advantage in the election.

title: Revvin up the rivalry
description: Here we are in Fort Myers for the spring revival of baseballs best rivalry, the Yankees and the Red Sox. The Yanks scored three in the first off Tim Wakefield, with Carl Pavano now taking the mound for the Yankees. (Really, he is.)

title: But Seriously: Why Is There a Gender Gap in Laughter?
description: In my column on laughter, I mention that female speakers are more likely to laugh than male speakers are. Thats one aspect of a large gender gap that Robert Provine, a neuroscientist at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County, discovered when he left the lab and went out into the wild  well, sidewalks and shopping malls  to observe laugh episodes.

title: Shoulder to Shoulder, in Grief
description: Thousands mourned 10 victims of a Bronx house fire, members of an extended family of immigrants from Mali.

title: Representing the Libertarian Wing
description: Representative Ron Paul, a nine-term Republican from Texas, formally announced his presidential candidacy today.

title: Political Vows
description: Its not quite a link-up between the Montagues and the Capulets, but in this super-heated political environment it comes close.

title: Your Comments on Darfur Column
description: My Tuesday column looks at what we can do about Darfur  and at your suggestions for the next steps we should take. Please offer your comments below, by hitting the comment tab.

title: Blog Poll
description: There are blogs out there for every political persuasion. The question is, whos reading them?

title: Home in San Francisco, Pelosi Gets the Crawford Treatment
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 12  San Francisco, meet Crawford, Tex.

title: Film Producer and Partners Buy Halston
description: The film producer Harvey Weinstein is casting himself in the role of fashion industry magnate.

title: For U.S. Troops at War, Liquor Is Spur to Crime
description: In May 2004, Specialist Justin J. Lillis got drunk on what he called hajji juice, a clear Iraqi moonshine smuggled onto an Army base in Balad, Iraq, by civilian contractors, and began taking potshots with his M-16 service rifle.

title: Strike at Big Shipyard Is Yet Another Effect of Katrina
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss., March 12  The long arm of Hurricane Katrina has pushed thousands off the job and on strike at one of the nations biggest shipyards here, workers and union officials say.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about plans by the oil services company Halliburton to transfer its chief executive to a corporate headquarters in the United Arab Emirates city of Dubai misstated the surname of an analyst with Energy Intelligence Group, who commented on the move. She is Barbara Shook, not Barbara Struck.

title: Another Supplement, Under the Microscope
description: Not so long ago, antioxidant vitamins were hailed as natures own weapons against chronic illness, powerful antidotes to horrid diets and failed exercise plans.

title: Bush Meets Anger Over Immigration Issue as He Promotes Free Trade in Guatemala
description: GUATEMALA CITY, March 12  President Bush came to this struggling Central American nation on Tuesday bearing a message that free trade with the United States would improve conditions for even the poorest Latin Americans.

title: White House Said to Prompt Firing of Prosecutors
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  The White House was deeply involved in the decision late last year to dismiss federal prosecutors, including some who had been criticized by Republican lawmakers, administration officials said Monday.

title: Journeys to the Distant Fields of Prime
description: LOS ANGELES Four hundred people packed into an auditorium at U.C.L.A. in January to listen to a public lecture on prime numbers, one of the rare occasions that the topic has drawn a standing-room-only audience.

title: City Hopes to Fix a Staten Island Railroad Bridge That Could, but Now Cant
description: A gap of less than a foot stands between the city and its goal of rejuvenating rail freight traffic between Staten Island and the rest of the country.

title: Chief Army Medical Officer Is Ousted
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  The Armys top medical officer was forced into retirement Monday, yet another aftereffect of the disclosure of shoddy conditions for outpatients at Walter Reed Army Medical Center.

title: Thoughtful Wanderings of a Man With a Can
description: Sometimes Doing Something Poetic Can Become Political, and Sometimes Doing Something Political Can Become Poetic is a very long title for an exhibition. But its perfect for Francis Alss show at David Zwirner, his first Manhattan gallery solo in a decade. And it captures in a nutshell the thinking behind some of the most interesting art today.

title: Study Says Computers Give Big Boosts to Productivity
description: Money spent on computing technology delivers gains in worker productivity that are three to five times those of other investments, according to a study being published today. But the study also concluded that the information technology industry itself was unlikely to be a big source of new jobs.

title: Ritzenhein Drops Out of Championship
description: The United States 8-kilometer running championship, to be held Saturday in Central Park, lost a star yesterday when Dathan Ritzenhein withdrew because of an injured left foot. His coach, Brad Hudson, said that Ritzenhein, the 24-year-old Olympian, sustained a minor injury while running last week on grass in Tallahassee, Fla. If Ritzenheins recovery stays on schedule, he will run in the Cardinal Invitational next month in Palo Alto, Calif., and probably the Healthy Kidney 10 kilometers in May in Central Park.

title: On the Scales: 	Suicide Found to Be Less Likely in Heavier People
description: That fat people are jolly is almost certainly a myth, but a study published yesterday has found a strong association between higher body mass index, or B.M.I., and lower risk of suicide.

title: Stardust Hotel-Casino in Las Vegas  Is Demolished
description: LAS VEGAS, March 13  With a deafening rumble and a cloud of debris that has become all but customary in this city of short-lived icons, the venerable Stardust Hotel-Casino was demolished early this morning.

title: Itinerant Performance Artist Muses About Life on the Road
description: In the sweetly nostalgic new monologue 1001 Beds, Tim Miller fondly remembers meeting his longtime partner, Alistair, and in a savvy romantic maneuver, quickly giving him a new part in a show. The role called for someone willing to pour a bucket of water over Mr. Millers nude body.

title: Passing Through but Leaving a Lasting Impression
description: Travel often turns my expectations upside down. In 1999, I visited Iran with a small group of Americans to watch a total eclipse of the sun. On the afternoon of the event, I found myself alone in Esfahans vast Khomeini Square: one American among 50,000 Iranians.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on March 2 about the slaying of Ken Gorman, a supplier of medical marijuana in Denver, included an erroneous estimate from Allen St. Pierre, the executive director of the National Organization for the Reform of Marijuana Laws, on the number of legal marijuana providers who have been killed nationally. Mr. St. Pierre says he can only verify six killings since 2003, not the 20 since 1997 that he earlier estimated.

title: A Regiment of Actors Falls in, Night After Night
description: Staging a war isnt absolutely necessary to put together a first-class theatrical ensemble, but it doesnt hurt. At least thats the view of the cast of Journeys End, the venerable British World War I drama currently playing at the Belasco Theater. R. C. Sherriff drew this 1928 story from his time in the trenches, and the revival, directed by David Grindley, features a cast who play together with admirable finesse, Ben Brantley wrote in his review in The New York Times.

title: After Barber Slips Off, Droughns Says Hes Ready for the Grind
description: Reuben Droughns met Brandon Jacobs for the first time yesterday. The two will compete to become the Giants starting running back.

title: Knicks Regain Mediocrity, and Thomas Gets the Glory
description: Greenburgh, N.Y.

title: Ford to Sell Aston Martin to Group Led by Ex-Racer
description: DEARBORN, Mich., March 12  The Ford Motor Company will raise $848 million toward its overhaul plan by selling Aston Martin, its British luxury sports car brand, the automaker said Monday.

title: After Evicting Members, Sorority Is Itself Evicted
description: DePauw University severed ties yesterday with a national sorority that evicted two-thirds of the universitys chapter members last year in what the sorority called an effort to improve its image for recruitment, but which the evicted women described as a purge of the unattractive or the uncool.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in the special Business of Green section on Wednesday about nontoxic and biodegradable products in restaurant kitchens misspelled the surname of a farmer who uses oil from a deep fryer to run his diesel truck, and it misstated part of the name of his farm. He is Michael Yezzi, not Yessi, and he owns Flying Pigs Farm, not Flying Pigs Farms.

title: CBS Cuts Redstones Salary and Bonus
description: Sumner Redstones paychecks are getting smaller  both of them.

title: L.S.U. Gets No. 3 Seed but Doesnt Feel Like Celebrating
description: BATON ROUGE, La., March 12  Four members of the Louisiana State University athletic department assembled in a sixth-floor meeting room of the Athletic Administration building Monday morning, same as they do every week.

title: Prosecutors Offer to a Witness Dominates Teachers Sex Trial
description: Under prodding from defense lawyers, a crucial witness in the statutory rape trial of an East Side private-school teacher testified last week that prosecutors had not promised him any help in return for his testimony.

title: Companion of Bomber in Casablanca Is Questioned
description: PARIS, March 12  Moroccan officials on Monday were questioning the companion of a suicide bomber who blew himself up in an Internet cafe in Casablanca on Sunday, according to news agencies and local press reports. At least three people were wounded in the blast.

title: Court Blocks Snowmaking at Indian Sites
description: LOS ANGELES, March 12  A federal appeals panel on Monday blocked a ski resorts plan to make artificial snow by spraying treated wastewater on mountains that Indian tribes consider sacred.

title: Bonds Ponders 2008 and Possible Successor
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., March 12  Barry Bonds lost two fly balls in the sun in the first inning, an embarrassing development for any player at any time. But Bonds made fun of himself by smiling and putting his glove over his eyes upon returning to the San Francisco Giants dugout.

title: Healing: A Caveat on Circumcision as AIDS Prevention
description: While circumcision may help protect a man from catching the AIDS virus, men who are already infected and are then circumcised should refrain from sex until they have fully healed, researchers said last week.

title: Play and Ritual in the Village, an Unseen Terror at the Gates
description: Sometimes it is better not to know much about a dance before you see it, or at least to have no explicit information about it. Advance word about Fagaala (Genocide in Wolof, a language spoken widely in Senegal), performed by Compagnie Jant-Bi on Saturday night at the Harvey Theater of the Brooklyn Academy of Music, was that it was a passionate response to genocide, specifically the one in Rwanda, and over all a monstrously topical theme today.

title: Turn to Tolstoy
description: Politicians have taken to publicizing reading lists. President Bush, we were told, last summer was to read a comic historical novel on the first Afghan war and Camuss The Stranger. The Tory members of the British Parliament were issued weighty books on Middle Eastern politics. But why is no one reading Tolstoys novel Hadji Murad?

title: Rain Forests, It Seems, Need the Dry Season
description: To the uninitiated, the Amazon rain forests are a vast ocean of trees that are unchanging throughout the year.

title: At Risk: A Potential Drawback to That Daily Aspirin
description: Men who take daily doses of aspirin, acetaminophen or nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs like ibuprofen may slightly increase their risk for high blood pressure, a new study reports.

title: Canada: Bidding for Mining Concern
description: Oxbow Carbon and Minerals Holdings raised its offer for the Great Lakes Carbon Income Fund to about 657 million Canadian dollars ($562 million), topping a higher bid from Rain Commodities and extending a bidding war for Great Lakes, a producer of carbon used to make aluminum. Oxbow raised its bid to 13.50 Canadian dollars a share for Great Lakes Carbon, which was above Rains bid of 13.25 Canadian dollars a share, Oxbow said. Oxbow, a unit of the privately held energy company Oxbow Group, bid 13 Canadian dollars a share on Wednesday. Oxbow is based in West Palm Beach, Fla., and Rain Commodities is based in India. Shares in Great Lakes Carbon trade on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Data Show How Electronics Mix With Medical Devices
description: If a halogen lamp causes static on a nearby radio, the problem is probably not serious. But what if the electronic antitheft device in the department store makes a heart pacemaker malfunction, or a cellphone used in a hospital interferes with a blood pressure monitor?

title: Bush Aides and Business Meet on Shift in Regulation
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Senior Bush administration officials began a series of high-level discussions on Monday with top executives from Wall Street, corporations and the major accounting firms. Many of the executives have urged the rollback of laws passed in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom scandals as well as limits to liability from government and shareholder lawsuits.

title: Let Everyone Use What Wall Street Knows
description: Doylestown, Pa.

title: Defying the Odds on a Project in Skid Row
description: LOS ANGELES  Its a short trip from the excesses of Beverly Hills to the despair of skid row. Few architects bother to make it.

title: A Sea of Mourners, Sharing Two Families Loss
description: Just before 1 p.m. yesterday, eight gleaming Cadillac hearses threaded their way through the Bronx, past Fanta Express Hair Braiding and Dia-Bugi 99 Cent and Mohamed Alfa Bah Discount. From Webster Avenue, they turned left onto East 166th Street and stopped. Before them was a sea of people.

title: Canada: Manslaughter Charge in Afghanistan Case
description: A soldier was charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of a fellow soldier in Afghanistan. Master Cpl. Jeffrey Walsh was killed Aug. 9 when a gun discharged during a patrol outside Kandahar in southern Afghanistan. Master Cpl. Robbie Fraser was charged with one count of manslaughter in the case and one count of negligent performance of duty. Master Corporal Fraser has returned to his base in Shilo, Manitoba. Both were in Afghanistan as members of the Princess Patricias Canadian Light Infantry.

title: Dolan Says Thomas Has Solved Knicks' Crisis
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 12  When he reluctantly became the Knicks coach last June, Isiah Thomas was given a specific ultimatum and a vague standard to reach.

title: Veterans Programs Overwhelmed, Panel Is Told
description: The Veterans Administration and its benefits programs are being overwhelmed by claims from injured soldiers, sailors and marines returning from the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq, and the programs need to be streamlined, a Congressional panel was told today.

title: Big Money Still Learning to Lobby
description: On a cold evening in late January, Senator Charles E. Schumer invited a whos who of hedge funds to dinner at Bottega del Vino on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. More than $100 billion worth of wealth sat around the table, including Paul Tudor Jones of Tudor Capital; Steven Cohen of SAC Capital; Stanley Druckenmiller of Duquesne Capital; and James Chanos of Kynikos Capital, according to a person who was briefed on the dinner.

title: Mission Is Forging a New Legacy, Not Defending a National Title
description: Gainesville, Fla.

title: Correction
description: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about a campaign by Patrick M. Byrne, the chief executive of Overstock.com, against a type of short selling, referred incorrectly to David Rocker, a short seller and former head of Rocker Partners. Mr. Rocker and his firm were not the subject of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into possible manipulation of Overstock.com shares. (Mr. Rocker did testify in the course of an S.E.C. investigation of similar accusations against Gradient Analytics, a research firm. The S.E.C. recently sent a letter to Gradient saying that it would not pursue any action against the firm.)

title: Boston Scientific Considers Spinning Off Division
description: There is more to Boston Scientific than the troubled heart stent and defibrillator businesses for which it is best known  enough, in fact, that the company predicts it could raise at least $1 billion by spinning off a portion of the rest to the public.

title: Letters
description: Decisions and the Terminally Ill

title: Shoulder to Shoulder, in Grief
description: Hamidou Gumaneh locked his store and turned around the sign on the glass door so it read Closed. It was a rare pause in the daily bustle of Koina, the Islamic bookstore and halal grocery that he owns at the corner of East 166th Street and Clay Avenue in the Bronx.

title: A Tribute to the Man Who Fed Broadways Soul
description: It appeared to be a typical New York moment in a city that loves its icons. Hundreds of people gathered behind metal barricades outside the Schoenfeld Theater on 45th Street. Neon flashed on marquees, the press had cameras and microphones ready, and police on horseback waited at the curb.

title: Defenses Find Way to Beat New Rules
description: BUFFALO, March 12  When it came to troubling on-ice behavior in the N.H.L. last week, nothing could top the stick-swinging of Islanders forward Chris Simon. But for fans of freewheeling hockey, three games in Buffalo were raising concern because they seemed to signal the return of the neutral-zone trap.

title: Barricades to Storm, Whether or Not Any Guards Were on Them
description: There was a superficial electricity ahead of last weekends double bill at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center: Cecil Taylors new trio and John Zorns Masada. It was conducted further by some critics and through the nervous conversations of the audience before the show. It had to do with the notion that a pugnacious jazz avant-garde was being invited inside the gates of a dull and powerful establishment.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Manhattan: Rulings on Convention Arrests
description: The city may use secret police intelligence in civil rights lawsuits to defend its policies during the 2004 Republican National Convention, but it will be penalized for failing to disclose the information earlier in the case, a federal judge ruled yesterday. The New York Civil Liberties Union, which is suing the city on behalf of seven people who claim they were wrongly arrested and detained during the convention, had argued that intelligence reports and testimony from David Cohen, the deputy police commissioner for intelligence, should be barred because the city missed deadlines for disclosing that Mr. Cohen and the documents would be part of its defense. Magistrate Judge James C. Francis IV agreed that city lawyers had offered no legitimate excuse for being late and said the city would have to pay legal fees and other costs as punishment.

title: Good Cop and Bad Cop on Security Programs Case
description: O.K., Steven Brill, weve got some questions, Joe Brancatelli and I: Bad cop, good cop. Take a seat. Which Mr. Brill did, though in the conference room of his own offices in Manhattan.

title: Rare White Deer Versus Ethanol: Conservationists at Odds in Seneca
description: ROMULUS, N.Y., March 9  Every year, when Robert and Barbara Smith drive from their home in Pennsylvania to the Finger Lakes for a family getaway, they almost always stop by a sprawling preserve here to glimpse the largest known herd of rare white deer.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted March 7 through March 11 with 1,362 adults throughout the United States.

title: Spreading Smallpox
description: Q. Would it really have been possible for Europeans to infect Native Americans with the smallpox virus by giving them blankets used by other victims? How long could the virus live on a blanket?

title: A Place to Turn When a Newborn Is Fated to Die
description: MINNEAPOLIS  The day after Alaina Kilibarda was born, her breathing started to falter, as her family knew it might. During the pregnancy, doctors had told James and Jill Kilibarda that their baby had a lethal genetic problem that would probably end her life within hours of birth.

title: U.S. Relieves Judge of Duties in Courtroom
description: An immigration judge in New York who has been repeatedly rebuked by federal appeals judges for his hostile questioning of asylum-seekers was relieved of courtroom duties yesterday and reassigned to a desk job, lawyers and a union official said.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,184 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: French Premier Throws Support for Presidency to Political Rival
description: PARIS, Mar. 12  Prime Minister Dominique de Villepin on Monday formally endorsed his political rival, the center-right candidate Nicolas Sarkozy, for president.

title: A Ramble Through the Mind of the Pogues Poet
description: BOSTON, March 10  He knew he was totally mediocre, he was a measly old poet, Wordsworth, and never made it at anything like Coleridge, Shane MacGowan said, adding, He had really bad teeth. Mr. MacGowan, the principal singer of the Celtic rock band the Pogues and a man fabled for his thirst, affinity for illicit substances and terrible dentition, has sympathy for Wordsworths friend Coleridge, who alienated Wordsworth with his opium use. Like Coleridge, Mr. MacGowan has his appetites and he too is known for his way with a verse.

title: Averting Disaster
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Lender Faces Credit Crisis With Banks
description: During a credit crisis nearly a decade ago, New Century Financial found a white knight in U.S. Bancorp, which was willing to save the company with a fresh infusion of capital.

title: From a Rapt Audience, a Call to Cool the Hype
description: Hollywood has a thing for Al Gore and his three-alarm film on global warming, An Inconvenient Truth, which won an Academy Award for best documentary. So do many environmentalists, who praise him as a visionary, and many scientists, who laud him for raising public awareness of climate change.

title: Pavanos Line for Yankees: Two Runs, Four Hits, No Injuries
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., March 12  Most of the Yankees took the team bus to City of Palms Park on Monday. The starting pitcher, Carl Pavano, made his own arrangements. It could have been an adventure.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a dispute between the Democratic Party and Fox News over a presidential debate in Nevada referred incorrectly to one Democratic candidate who dropped out of the debate shortly before it was canceled. Bill Richardson is the current governor of New Mexico, not a former one.

title: AT&T Megastore Aims to Make It Fun to Buy a Phone
description: With the opening yesterday of its first megastore, AT&T is trying to do the seemingly impossible: make buying cellular service an almost entertaining experience.

title: Halliburton Office Move Is Criticized
description: HOUSTON, March 12  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and other leading Congressional Democrats sharply criticized Halliburton on Monday for relocating its chief executive to Dubai, suggesting it was possibly part of an effort to dodge American taxes and investigations.

title: Freight Train Derails and Explodes in Central New York
description: A freight train carrying liquid propane derailed yesterday in a rural section of central New York State, and the accident was accompanied by a thunderous explosion and a fierce fire that forced the evacuation of homes, schools and a jail in the area, halted passenger train service and temporarily shut a section of the New York State Thruway, the authorities said.

title: Islanders Not Letting Suspension Alter Focus
description: SYOSSET, N.Y., March 12  With one big man absent, the Islanders practiced for an hour Monday morning, then stuffed their equipment into canvas bags and caught a flight to Montreal, where they begin four-game trip that would have been critical anyway.

title: Trenton: Proposal on Companies Dealing With Iran
description: An Assembly committee approved a measure yesterday that would bar the states pension funds from investing in any foreign company with ties to or doing work in Iran. Citing the Iranian regimes harsh denunciations of Israel, the bills sponsor, Assemblyman Neil M. Cohen, a Democrat of Union, said the measure would also require the divestment of securities in any such company to send a message that New Jersey had no support for the Holocaust-like genocide embodied in statements by Iranian leaders.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An obituary on Wednesday about Martin A. Trow, a sociologist of education, incorrectly described one of the three co-authors of Union Democracy: The Internal Politics of the International Typographical Union (1956). Seymour Martin Lipset was then a member of the Columbia faculty, not a fellow doctoral candidate of Mr. Trow and James S. Coleman, who worked with Mr. Lipset on the project and were listed as co-authors.

title: Judge Stops Sale of Monsantos Genetically Engineered Alfalfa
description: A federal judge revoked the governments approval of Monsantos genetically engineered alfalfa yesterday, ordering a halt to seed sales and banning any planting of the crop after March 30.

title: The Death of Geography?
description: A handshake can still trump a videoconference. The energy services giant Halliburton announced on Sunday that it will move its corporate headquarters and its chief executive, David Lesar, from the old boomtown of Houston (Texas) to the rising boomtown of Dubai (United Arab Emirates). The move sends the message that even in the new economy, some of the old rules still apply, including that location matters.

title: More Red Cells May Help Athletes. How About Dogs?
description: Elite athletes in many sports use the rest high, train low strategy to improve endurance. But can it help dogs?

title: Bristol-Myers Tightens Process for Setting C.E.O. Pay
description: Responding to a drumbeat for better corporate governance, Bristol-Myers Squibb said today that it had agreed to a new guideline for establishing pay for its chief executive.

title: Britain Proposes Law to Curb Greenhouse Gases
description: LONDON, March 13  As nations and politicians in many parts of Europe compete to burnish their green credentials, the British government today proposed laws requiring a 60 percent reduction in total carbon dioxide emissions by 2050.

title: Philistines, but Less and Less Philistine
description: Archaeologists have applied more polish to the long-tarnished reputation of the Philistines.

title: Search for Remains Will Close Parts of West Street
description: City officials plan to close parts of West Street for about a month as part of an expanded search for human remains from ground zero, according to a memorandum sent yesterday to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A music review on Thursday about the jazz trumpeter Ralph Alessi and his band, at the Center for Improvisational Music in Brooklyn, misidentified the organization in which his brother, Joseph, is a principal trombonist. It is the New York Philharmonic, not the Metropolitan Opera.

title: Whats on Tuesday Night
description: 8 P.M. (My Network TV) AMERICAN HEIRESS Though you cannot choose the people in your family, you can try to kill them. This new series stars Alicia Leigh Willis as Elizabeth Wakefield, a wealthy heiress whose plane crashes in the jungles of Guatemala. Not everyone in the family is broken up about her disappearance: her oldest brother, Damian (Race Owen), is vying for control of the Wakefield empire and it just might help his cause to sabotage every attempt to rescue his sister.

title: The Claim: Vitamin E Helps Remove Scars
description: THE FACTS

title: Manhattan: City Sued Over Hiring of Bridge Painters
description: The federal Justice Department filed a lawsuit yesterday against the city Transportation Department, claiming that city officials discriminated against women when hiring bridge painters. The city, which employs about 100 painters to maintain about 700 bridges, has never hired or offered to hire a woman for the job, despite applications from several women, the suit said. The city has hired 13 bridge painters in the past 10 years, and four of the 56 applicants were women, according to the lawsuit. Georgia Pestana, the chief of the Labor and Employment Division of the city Law Department, said in a statement, We are confident the court will determine that D.O.T.s hiring practices for bridge painters comply with civil service requirements and are gender neutral.

title: Assigning Ratings to Commercials Turns Out to Be a Tricky Task
description: TELEVISION networks and advertising agencies were arguing for months over how to count the number of people who actually watch commercials. And they seemed to have come up with a compromise last fall  a system of averaging commercial viewing over an entire program.

title: Gonzaga Pulls Together by Leaving One Behind
description: SPOKANE, Wash., March 12  The Gonzaga Bulldogs practice in a new campus arena filled with luxury suites, video screens and advertisements for Toyota and Pepsi.

title: Too Much of Nothing, a Japanese Affliction
description: The phenomenon of hikikomori casts a pall over Japans image, solidifying a certain view of the country as a place afflicted with especially peculiar varieties of social dysfunction. Those mired in hikikomori, mostly teenagers and young adults, retreat from the world, isolating themselves in their rooms for months or even years at a time, relying on the Internet, video games and comic books as their sole sources of external connection. Support groups for parents struggling with self-confining children have sprung up all over the country.

title: New DVDs
description: ANIMATED SOVIET PROPAGANDA

title: From James Brown to Dylan, Expansive Hip-Hop
description: The standard line on the Roots is that theyre the best live band in hip-hop, which is a bit like saying that Lost is the best show on television about an inscrutable tropical island.
