But if the Roots ever felt any ambivalence about their lot as a jam-happy stage act, they surely arent expressing it now. Their current tour involves four horns, a James Brown tribute and a surplus of rubbery interludes. Its a show, in the most straightforward sense, and it seems unlikely to alter the conditions of their acclaim.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Thursday about Chinese children who were adopted by Jews and are now going through the ritual of bat mitzvah referred imprecisely in one reference to the location in a synagogue where the Torah is read. It is a bimah, not an altar.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a picture in some copies on Saturday with a front-page article about how a fatal fire in the Bronx united cultures in grief, carried an erroneous credit. The photograph of passers-by in front of the burned house was by Librado Romero of The New York Times, not by the New York City Fire Department.

title: Senator From Nebraska Says No to Presidential Bid, for Now
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, said Monday that he would not enter the 2008 presidential race  for the time being, at least  so he could concentrate on domestic and global concerns, particularly helping secure an end to the Iraq war.

title: High Security as Iraqi Leader Visits Restive Anbar
description: RAMADI, Iraq, March 13  Minutes before Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki was due to arrive here by helicopter on Tuesday for his first official visit to Anbar Province, the epicenter of the Sunni Arab insurgency, his advance team of security guards had one last piece of business to take care of.

title: Wrong Turn on Sex Offenders
description: With little public discussion and no opposition to speak of, Gov. Eliot Spitzer has made New York the latest state to travel down a murky legal road, to a place where laws are made not in response to facts, but to wishfulness and fear. It is a place where prisoners who finish their sentences remain locked up for crimes they might commit, submitting to psychological treatment that nearly always fails and whose only sure outcome is the open-ended spending of tens of millions of dollars a year.

title: How Do You Solve a Crisis Like Darfur?
description: For anyone who thinks that genocide is absolutely the rock-bottom possibility, keep an eye on Darfur.

title: Goal No. 1: Good Science. Goal No. 1: Diversity.
description: BALTIMORE  Theres something striking about the laboratory of Michael F. Summers at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. Its not the giant nuclear magnetic resonance machine that he uses to visualize molecules; its the faces of the people who work there.

title: Joseph Metcalf III Dies at 79; Led Invasion of Grenada
description: Vice Adm. Joseph Metcalf III, who in October 1983 was given less than two days to plan and start the controversial invasion of the Caribbean island of Grenada after President Ronald Reagan issued orders to overturn a Marxist coup, died on March 2 at his home in Washington. He was 79.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: A Political Memo article on Thursday, about the challenges Rudolph W. Giuliani faces in running for president as a former New York City mayor, referred incorrectly to the timing of the two-term presidency of another New Yorker, Theodore Roosevelt. He began serving more than 100 years ago, in 1901; his presidency was not almost 100 years ago. A correction in this space yesterday referred incorrectly to Mr. Roosevelts time as a public official in New York City. He was a police commissioner, not a former mayor.

title: Dig This Campaign
description: You load 16 tons, and what do you get? How about a paycheck, vacations, a dental plan and a 401(k)?

title: Another Restaurant Is Shut for Health Code Violations
description: A once-hip dining place on Union Square that became a tourist destination after being featured on the HBO series Sex and the City has become one of the latest restaurants cited for health code violations after a rat-infested KFC/Taco Bell was closed two and a half weeks ago.

title: Council Moves Toward Ban on Metal High School Bats
description: New York City would become one of the first cities in the country to prohibit the use of metal bats in high school baseball games, under a bill that a City Council committee approved yesterday and that the full Council is considered all but certain to pass tomorrow.

title: Pope Says Catholic Politicians Must Back Churchs Doctrine
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, March 13  Pope Benedict XVI strongly reasserted Tuesday the churchs opposition to abortion, euthanasia and gay marriage, saying that Roman Catholic politicians were especially obligated to defend the churchs stance in their public duties.

title: Letter From California: In the Kingdom of the Garage Door Opener
description: I am sitting on the front porch of my fathers house in a small town in the heart of Californias almond country. It will be 80 today, the first day of daylight saving time. I have been watching the park across the street for hours.

title: At Bottom of Bracket, Niagara Relishes Chance
description: LEWISTON, N.Y., March 11  There were no balloons at an N.C.A.A. tournament selection party at Niagara Universitys Gallagher Center on Sunday night. Players and fans were deflated after the news that the Purple Eagles would face Florida A&M in a play-in game Tuesday in Dayton, Ohio.

title: Edith dAddario, 84, Joffrey School Director, Dies
description: Edith dAddario, for 43 years the director of the Joffrey Ballet School in Greenwich Village, died on March 4 in Brooklyn. She was 84.

title: General Tries to Clarify Remarks on Gay Troops
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  The nation's highest-ranking military officer said today that he should not have expressed his personal view that homosexual conduct was immoral, and that he instead should have focused recent remarks on his support for current Pentagon policy that prohibits openly gay people from serving in the armed forces.

title: U.S. Diplomat Optimistic About Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 12  The departing American ambassador to Afghanistan, Ronald E. Neumann, said Monday that he did not see the Taliban as the big threat it appeared to represent a year or two ago, and that he was leaving feeling reasonably optimistic about the state of the insurgency and the countrys progress.

title: The Law, Under Bush and Gonzales (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: 100 Years On, Auden Gets in the Subway
description: Wystan Hugh Auden had two Yorks in his life. The one in England is where he was born in 1907. This York, our York, is where he spent half his 66 years. I adore New York, Auden once wrote to a friend, as it is the only city in which I can live and work quietly. Presumably, he was not being ironic.

title: Whats So Funny? Well, Maybe Nothing
description: So there are these two muffins baking in an oven. One of them yells, Wow, its hot in here!

title: Correction
description: A March 7 editorial on the conviction of Lewis Libby said incorrectly that Joseph Wilson IV was sent by the State Department in 2002 to Niger to check out a report that Iraq had tried to buy uranium there. Mr. Wilson was sent by the C.I.A.

title: A Peek Into the Dream World of a Revered Polish Novelist
description: A curious scene greets the audience arriving for Republic of Dreams, a play about the Polish writer Bruno Schulz, by Double Edge Theater at La MaMa E.T.C. A man in a bowler hat sits at one end of a long table reading a journal, a meat grinder at his elbow. A woman in a shawl sits at the other end, a menorah with three candles before her. Downstage a man is painting a piece of cloth, a mannequin in a full-length slip nearby.

title: The Classic British Sports Car From China
description: LONGBRIDGE, England  MG, the legendary British brand that expired after a lengthy illness, will be revived this month as a Chinese sports car when the Nanjing Automobile Corporation begins to produce convertible sports cars under that name in China.

title: Zimbabwe Opposition Groups Say Leaders Beaten
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 12  Members of Zimbabwes political opposition and largest civic group said Monday that their leaders had been beaten and hospitalized after the police arrested them and scores of others during the violent breakup of a weekend antigovernment rally.

title: Opposition Undercuts Troops, Cheney Says of Spending Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Vice President Dick Cheney lashed out at Congressional opponents of the war in Iraq on Monday, saying that Democrats and others who would limit President Bushs authority to spend money on the war were undermining the troops and telling the enemy simply to watch the clock and wait us out.

title: Tales of Desperation in the Middle East (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: British Lords Defend Their Seats, Like Junkyard Bulldogs
description: LONDON, March 12  Faced with the unpleasant prospect of actually having to run for office, members of the House of Lords declared Monday that their chamber had functioned pretty well without elections for hundreds of years and that there was no need to rush into anything now.

title: Fast-Risers High Hopes and Sudden Fall
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  D. Kyle Sampson has never worked full time as a federal prosecutor. But for much of the Bush administration he played a considerable role in vetting who served in the Justice Department. And last year he used his post as chief of staff to the attorney general to make a bid for a job as a United States attorney in Utah.

title: I Didnt Promise, In Snoring and in Health! (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: B.Y.U. Makes the Most of a Mature Lineup
description: Beyond a simple test of talent, the N.C.A.A. tournament is a caldron of pressure. And Brigham Young, more than any team in the field, would seem to have the maturity to handle it.

title: Great Views of Miss Liberty, for Those Who Care to Look
description: THE Statue of Liberty was right outside the window, but David Afshar did not look up. He sat on the opposite side of the Staten Island ferry with his head buried in the business section of the newspaper.

title: Triumph of Willful Blindness to the Horror of History
description: Leni Riefenstahl liked to say that her art and life were devoted to the pursuit of Beauty. But her career, as Hitlers favorite and highly gifted filmmaker, stands as an enduring rebuke to Keatss assertion that Beauty is truth, truth beauty, and that is all ye need to know.

title: Kennedy, Eager for Republican Support, Shifts Tactics on an Immigration Measure
description: WASHINGTON, March 12  Facing a rebellion from some crucial Republicans, Senator Edward M. Kennedy has abandoned efforts to produce a new immigration bill and is proposing using legislation produced last March by the Senate Judiciary Committee, then controlled by Republicans, as the starting point for negotiations this year, lawmakers said Monday.

title: Ford Is Selling Aston Martin
description: DETROIT, March 12  The Ford Motor Company said today that it would sell Aston Martin, maker of the upscale British sports cars favored by James Bond, to a group of investors that includes the racing mogul David Richards and a pair of Kuwaiti companies.

title: Memo Pad
description: FLYERTALK.COM SOLD FlyerTalk.com, the Web site with scores of vibrant forums on frequent-flier programs, loyalty points and travel, has been sold to Internet Brands by Randy Petersen, who founded the site almost nine years ago. Mr. Petersen will continue as a consultant for four years. In e-mail messages to members and to site moderators, Mr. Petersen said he decided to sell only after plenty of sleepless nights. Other travel companies that had expressed interest, he said, included American Express, Expedia, Travelocity and Cond Nast Interactive. Internet Brands operates e-commerce sites for cars, real estate, mortgages and travel. Mr. Petersen said he chose Internet Brands, which was not the highest bidder, because they werent interested in making any changes to FlyerTalk.com.

title: Boston Scientific Considers a Spinoff to Raise $1 Billion
description: There is more to Boston Scientific than the troubled heart stent and defibrillator businesses for which it is best known  enough, in fact, that the company predicts it could raise at least $1 billion by spinning off a portion to the public.

title: Having a Baby: Whole Milk, in Moderation, May Aid Fertility
description: Eating whole-milk products instead of skim or low-fat ones may decrease the risk for a certain type of infertility, new research has found.

title: Growing Older, and Adjusting to the Dark
description: How well do you see at night? If youre over 50, probably not as well as you think, no matter how many carrots you eat. The typical 50-year-old driver needs twice as much light to see as well after dark as a 30-year-old. Yet few of us compensate adequately for the reduction in nighttime acuity that occurs in the aging eye.

title: Chinas Trade Surplus Nearly Ties Record
description: HONG KONG, March 12  Chinas already large export business has accelerated this year, with the customs agency announcing Monday that the February trade surplus nearly tied a record set in October.

title: Corrections
description: The Talking Business column in Business Day on Saturday, about a campaign by Patrick M. Byrne, the chief executive of Overstock.com, against a type of short selling, referred incorrectly to David Rocker, a short seller and former head of Rocker Partners. Mr. Rocker and his firm were not the subject of a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into possible manipulation of Overstock.com shares. (Mr. Rocker did testify in the course of an S.E.C. investigation of similar accusations against Gradient Analytics, a research firm. The S.E.C. recently sent a letter to Gradient saying that it would not pursue any action against the firm.) (Go to Article)

title: Whose Oil Is It, Anyway?
description: San Francisco

title: Betty Hutton, Film Star of 40s and 50s, Dies at 86
description: Betty Hutton, a singer and actress celebrated as a blond bombshell of Hollywood musicals and comedies in the 1940s and 50s, died Sunday night at her home in Palm Springs, Calif., her executor announced today. She was 86.

title: Epic of Human Migration Is Carved in Parasites DNA
description: A human body is not the individual organism its proud owner may suppose but rather a walking zoo of microbes and parasites, each exploiting a special ecological niche in its comfortable, temperature-controlled conveyance. Some of these fellow travelers live so intimately with their hosts, biologists are finding, that they accompany them not just in space but also in time, passing from generation to generation for thousands of years.

title: Buyout Firm Is Acquiring Dollar General Retail Chain
description: Even the superrich go thrift-store shopping every once in a while.

title: Manhattan: Mistrial in Arms Case
description: A Federal District Court judge has dismissed a jury and declared a mistrial in an international arms smuggling case that was scheduled to begin yesterday. The judge, Richard J. Holwell, acted after prosecutors said that their informant, Kelly Davis, had admitted himself to a psychiatric hospital for evaluation and had been on a suicide watch. In the case, Arthur Solomonyan, a 26-year-old Armenian who lived for a time in New York, and six others were charged in 2005 with arms smuggling and plotting to import military weapons for illegal sale. The prosecutors said they were ready to proceed without Mr. Davis, but defense lawyers said they wanted to question Mr. Davis about his role in the case. He certainly is a key witness in the story thats going to be told by either side, Judge Holwell said, and he set a new trial date of June 4.

title: Homeless Woman Is Charged in Fire
description: CHICAGO, March 12  A homeless woman was charged Monday with first-degree murder and aggravated arson for an apartment fire that killed four people on the North Side of the city early Saturday, the authorities said.

title: Swisscom Makes Offer for FastWeb
description: MILAN, March 12  The telephone company Swisscom offered 3.74 billion euros, or $4.93 billion, on Monday to acquire FastWeb, one of the largest fixed-line phone companies in Italy.

title: South Korea: 900 SAT Scores Canceled
description: The scores of all 900 students who took the SAT exam in South Korea in January will be canceled, the Educational Testing Service announced in South Korea on Friday. Tom Ewing, a spokesman for the testing service, which is responsible for security issues involving the College Boards college admissions exam, said an investigation had shown that an unknown number of students had seen at least a portion of the test before the exam was given on Jan. 27. Because the number could not be determined, he said, all the scores were being canceled. Students will be able to retake the test or accept a refund. In the early 1990s, thousands of Graduate Record Exam scores were canceled across most of India, Mr. Ewing said, and in 1992 about 10,000 scores on the TOEFL, a test measuring fluency in English, were canceled in China.

title: Petrosexuals, Start Your Engines (and Your Foul Mouths)
description: There is a lot to be said about the profound and intimate relationship between men and their cars. Dont expect Bullrun to say any of it.

title: No Favor Seen for Donation From Corzine
description: TRENTON, March 12  The dean of the Seton Hall University School of Law said on Monday that Gov. Jon S. Corzines $1 million donation to the university played no role in the schools decision to give a scholarship to Mr. Corzines former companion Carla Katz, who is also the leader of one of the states largest public employee unions.

title: UnitedHealth Buys Sierra, Adding Western Customers
description: The UnitedHealth Group, the largest health insurance company in the nation, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Sierra Health Services for $2.6 billion, adding customers in the Southwest and West.

title: Former Executives of Nortel Are Accused of Accounting Fraud
description: TORONTO, March 12  Stock market regulators in the United States and Canada filed civil charges on Monday against former executives of Nortel Networks, a large maker of telecommunications equipment. The former chief executive, Frank A. Dunn, and others were accused of committing accounting fraud to meet earnings forecasts and investor expectations.

title: Hip-Hop Is Rock n Roll, and Hall of Fame Likes It
description: Its official: Hip-hop is rock n roll.

title: Canada: Hotel Operator Posts a Profit
description: Four Seasons Hotels, the worlds largest operator of luxury hotels, reported a fourth-quarter profit on higher room revenue. Four Seasons, based in Toronto, said profit was $16.9 million, or 44 cents a share, in contrast to a loss of $37.8 million, or $1.03 a share, a year earlier. The company said it had higher costs in the year-earlier period related to retirement benefits and lower revenue after ending its lease for the Pierre in New York. Revenue rose 19 percent, to $69.8 million, from $58.5 million, because of an increase in hotel management and ownership fees. Revenue for each available room worldwide rose 14 percent, to $258.13; at properties in the United States, it was up 8.4 percent, to $297.83. Four Seasons agreed last month to be sold to a group of private investors.

title: Mayor Expects Calm After Grand Jury Decides Police Case
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today that he expected a muted community reaction to a Queens grand jury decision that could come as early as this week on whether to indict any police officers in the shooting of an unarmed black man killed last fall hours before his wedding.

title: Mexican President Presses Bush on Border Fence
description: MRIDA, Mexico, March 13  President Felipe Caldern of Mexico used a welcoming ceremony for President Bush here today to voice his opposition to the security fence the United States is building along their shared border.

title: In Mexico, Bush Seeks to Bolster Uneasy Alliance
description: MRIDA, Mexico, March 12  Just a few days before President Bush was scheduled to land here on Monday for bilateral talks, the Mexican Foreign Ministry sent an angry diplomatic note to the United States.

title: Prediction Proved: Light Speeds Up an Asteroid as it Spins
description: Although entirely without mass, particles of light have enough force to push an asteroid around, and possibly to spin it so fast that it breaks apart.

title: U.S. Sets Rules for Digital TV Payments
description: The government will offer households as much as $80 each to help convert televisions to receive digital broadcasts under a $1.5 billion program.

title: F.D.A. Offers Guidelines to Fresh-Food Industry
description: The Food and Drug Administration yesterday offered new, nonbinding guidelines to food processors to try to reduce the risk of food poisoning in fresh-cut produce like bagged spinach leaves, sliced tomatoes and imported melons, but acknowledged that it could not say with certainty what caused the recent outbreaks connected to E. coli and salmonella, or how to stop them.

title: A Lesson in Picking a Bracket: Being Wrong Makes You Right
description: As college basketball fans fill out their N.C.A.A. tournament brackets this week, they no doubt will wonder which team, if any, will be this years George Mason, the team that wrecked millions of brackets last season with its improbable run to the Final Four.

title: How Two Studies on Cancer Screening Led to Two Results
description: Of all the forms of cancer, lung cancer is by far the deadliest. So doctors have long hoped to come up with a screening test that would find it early, before it can grow and become untreatable.

title: Citys Immigration Restrictions Go on Trial
description: SCRANTON, Pa., March 12  In a test case about the power of cities to crack down on illegal immigration, a federal trial opened here Monday in which municipal restrictions in Hazleton, Pa., are being challenged as discriminatory and overreaching.

title: Manhattan: Arrests at Antiwar Protest
description: Twenty students were arrested yesterday at an antiwar protest in an Army and Navy recruiting station at 157 Chambers Street. The protest began at noon when members of the group, Students for a Democratic Society, marched from the campuses of Pace University and the New School and converged near the recruitment center. The 20 staged a sit-in while about 40 others stood outside chanting antiwar slogans, banging steel drums and waving posters. Organizers said that the students were demonstrating against military recruitment practices, and that the protest was intended to call attention to the fourth anniversary of the start of the Iraq war, which will be next week. The police said the 20 would be charged with criminal trespass.

title: 2002 Saudi Plan Revived as Spur to Arab-Israeli Talks
description: JERUSALEM, March 12  Israeli officials, pressed by Washington, are suddenly finding much to praise in a Saudi peace proposal that was dismissed when it was offered in 2002, at the height of a series of Palestinian suicide bombings.

title: As Fight Escalates, Senate Rejects Health Care Part of Spitzers Budget
description: ALBANY, March 12  Gov. Eliot Spitzers plan to cut health care spending is running into staunch resistance not so much from New York City Democrats but increasingly from the upstate and suburban Republicans who lead the State Senate.

title: Needing One Starter, Mets Measure Park Against Prospect
description: VIERA, Fla., March 12  Chan Ho Park thought he threw one bad pitch in Mondays game against the Washington Nationals. So did his catcher, Paul Lo Duca. The problem was, they were talking about different pitches, and that difference of opinion summed up Parks performance in the Mets 9-6 loss.

title: N.C.A.A. Committee Rewards a Season of Effort
description: To the N.C.A.A. womens basketball committee, it was not what you have done lately, but what you have done all season.

title: Zimbabwe Opposition Leader Appears in Court
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 13  Limping and missing part of his hair, apparently because of a head wound, the Zimbabwe political opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai appeared in a Harare court today after being jailed and beaten for his role in a banned anti-government meeting.

title: Police Widen Hunt for Attacker of 101-Year-Old Queens Woman
description: Every officer working yesterday in all 76 police precincts in New York City was shown the same thing: a grainy 45-second video of a 101-year-old woman being punched and robbed in the lobby of her Queens building on March 4.

title: Waiting-Room Camaraderie, an Interlude in the Struggle
description: A vibrant woman in a Harley-Davidson T-shirt jumps up from her seat. Oops! I better feed the meter or my bike will get ticketed! As she runs out of the waiting room, a woman Ive come to call the Kibitzer says reverently: You know shes had 14 surgeries? Shes some gutsy woman.

title: U.N. Mission Says Sudan Took Part in Rights Crimes
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 12  A United Nations Human Rights Council mission to Darfur said Monday that the Sudanese government had organized and taken part in human rights crimes against its own population, and that international action to stop the killings and rapes had been inadequate.

title: G.O.P. Voters Voice Anxieties on Partys Fate
description: After years of political dominance, Republican voters now view their party as divided and say they are not satisfied with the choice of candidates seeking the Republican presidential nomination in 2008, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: From Injuries to Agent Trouble, Pavanos Got It All
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.

title: Akzo Nobel Sells Drug Unit to Schering-Plough
description: LONDON, March 12  The Schering-Plough Corporation agreed on Monday to buy the Organon BioSciences unit of Akzo Nobel for $14.4 billion in cash in a surprise move that fueled further takeover speculation in the industry.

title: Drug Maker Subpoenaed About Marketing
description: Johnson & Johnson said yesterday it had received subpoenas from federal prosecutors in Philadelphia, Boston and San Francisco related to sales and marketing of three drugs.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Be Careful With That!

title: Bon Voyage as a Bonus
description: The all-expenses-paid vacation  the reward given by companies to sales representatives in fast-paced, commission-driven fields  is coming back after falling out of favor a few years ago. But this time, many employers have abandoned the cookie-cutter vacation package and are offering their best workers a menu of options.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A profile of Terence Tao, a world-renowned mathematician, in Science Times yesterday referred incorrectly to work he did with another mathematician on prime numbers. They proved that it is always possible to find, somewhere in the infinity of integers, a progression of any length of equally spaced prime numbers  not a progression of prime numbers of any spacing and any length.

title: Jonathan Lethem Offers Film Option to His Latest Novel
description: The author Jonathan Lethem announced yesterday on his Web site that he planned to give away a film option to his latest novel, "You Don't Love Me Yet," published by Doubleday. Mr. Lethem, the author of "Motherless Brooklyn" and "The Fortress of Solitude," said he would select a filmmaker who agreed to two conditions: that 2 percent of the budget be paid to him when the film gets a distribution deal, and that the filmmaker release ancillary rights to the film five years after it has its premiere, so that they may be entered into the public domain. Under the question "Why?" on his Web site (jonathanlethem.com), Mr. Lethem said he had lately "become fitful about some of the typical ways art is commodified." "You Don't Love Me Yet" goes on sale today.

title: Cliff Notes
description: Jotting on an elegant feat of hillside engineering.

title: Study Links Bear Stearns to Subprime Mess
description: Bear Stearns was among the Wall Street firms that helped fuel the meltdown in the subprime mortgage sector by failing to adequately monitor the quality of the loans they were buying, a credit-research firm, CreditSights, concluded in a study. An unidentified Bear Stearns executive told The New York Post that the research firm got it wrong, period.

title: Boston Scientific Considers $1 Billion Spinoff
description: There is more to Boston Scientific than the troubled heart stent and defibrillator businesses for which it is best known  enough that the company predicts it could raise at least $1 billion by spinning off a portion to the public. Boston Scientific, based in Natick, Mass., said yesterday that it was considering a public stock offering for 18 percent to 25 percent of those other businesses, which are grouped under its Endosurgery division.

title: Aquiline Raises $1.1 Billion Buyout Fund
description: Aquiline Capital Partners, a private equity firm founded by former executives of Marsh & McLennan, said it closed its first fund at $1.1 billion. Aquiline will use the fund to make in investments in financial-services companies.

title: 8 Out of 8 (and Not Yet 8)
Bristol-Myers Tightens Process for Setting C.E.O. Pay
description: Responding to a drumbeat for better corporate governance, Bristol-Myers Squibb said Monday that it had agreed to a new guideline for establishing pay for its chief executive. Under the guideline, chief executive compensation at the company will require approval by a three-quarters vote of the independent directors, rather than just a majority.

title: Apax Partners to Stop Venture Funding
description: In what will no doubt be unwelcome news for Silicon Valley entrepreneurs, Apax Partners Worldwide has announced that it will stop investing in start-up companies to focus solely on leveraged buyouts after it raised a record 10 billion euro ($13 billion) takeover fund. Our next fund will be 100 percent buyouts, Martin Halusa, chief executive of Apax, said last week after giving a presentation to the Washington State Investment Board in Olympia. Our venture results have been very volatile, and our focus is on the more stable end of the business.

title: Former Executives of Nortel Are Accused of Accounting Fraud
description: Stock market regulators in the United States and Canada filed civil charges on Monday against former executives of Nortel Networks, a large maker of telecommunications equipment. The former chief executive, Frank A. Dunn, and others were accused of committing accounting fraud to meet earnings forecasts and investor expectations.

title: Swisscom Dials Up Deal for Italys FastWeb
description: Swisscom bid 3.74 billion euros ($4.93 billion) on Monday to acquire FastWeb, one of the largest fixed-line phone companies in Italy, in what analysts suggested could signal the start of a consolidation wave in the telecommunications industry. The deal, worth $4.93 billion, would give Swisscom, a phone operator, the chance to counter slowing growth in its home market while giving FastWeb financing to continue its expansion in the underdeveloped broadband Internet market in Italy.

title: Weil Gotshal Said to Lose Bankruptcy Stars
description: You win some, you lose some; that may be what the law firm Weil, Gotshal & Manges is thinking right now. Just as the firm welcomes back legendary bankruptcy partner Harvey Miller, it is losing four other restructuring stars to a rival firm.

title: Timing Is Everything for Hyperion Insiders
description: Oracles $3.3 billion acquisition of Hyperion Solutions, announced March 1, is turning out to be a very sweet deal for some company insiders. The announcement that Oracle would pay $52 dollar a share for the Santa Clara-based maker of business intelligence software, a big premium over the $42.84 the stock had closed at the previous day, caused Hyperions stock to jump 20.4 percent to $51.57 by the close of the market.

title: Acer Seeks Prey to Surpass Lenovo
description: Acer is going to try to make a major purchase in the PC world this year and says it will pass Lenovo to become the third largest computer maker in the world. In an interview with The Wall Street Journal, Acers chief executive J.T. Wang said the Taiwan-based company wants to make a meaningful acquisition of another PC maker this year. We are looking at some candidates which we want to pick up, he said.

title: Microsoft in Deal to Buy Tellme, Report Says
description: Microsoft is close to acquiring Tellme Networks, a privately held maker of products that bridge the worlds of speech recognition and the Internet, in a deal that could come as early as this week, according to CNet News.com.

title: Private Equity Firm Picks Up Linde Unit
description: Linde, the worlds biggest producer of industrial gases, said Monday it sold part of its BOC Edwards subsidiary to private equity firm CCMP Capital for 685 million euros ($901.12 million). The deal to sell the unit of BOC Edwards, which was part of Britains BOC Group that Linde paid 12.4 billion euros for last year, is subject to regulatory approval.

title: Sale Gives Akzo Nobel Cash for Deals
description: Akzo Nobels $14.4 billion deal to sell its Organon BioSciences unit to Schering-Plough has stoked further takeover speculation in the industry.

title: Amid Hew and Cry, British Buyout Firms Stay on Message
description: British private equity leaders, determined to change the perception of themselves as vultures and locusts, stayed on point Monday. Speaking at the annual dinner of the British Private Equity and Venture Capital Association, Rod Selkirk, the associations chairman, said private equity takeovers were responsible for strong growth in British jobs and exports over the past five years. He said the industry had also benefited workers pension funds, because their investments in private equity funds had made double-digit gains.

title: Is this a good thing?
description: Intelligent Mirror

title: Anadarko Unloads K2 Stake
description: Anadarko Petroleum agreed to sell part of its stake in the K2 oil and natural gas field in the Gulf of Mexico to two undisclosed buyers for $1.2 billion. The sale, which is expected to close in the second quarter, would reduce Anadarkos stake in the project to 41.8 percent from 65 percent, the company said.

title: S.E.C. Charges Hackers With Stock Manipulation
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission charged three men Monday with hacking into online brokerage accounts based in the United States, primarily from Thailand and India, and manipulating stock prices to turn a profit for themselves. The civil charges, brought in a Nebraska federal court, claim the men allegedly used stolen identity information to pose as online buyers, inflate the value of the stock, and then sell their own shares at a higher price.

title: Procter & Gamble Disposes of European Tissue Business
description: Procter & Gamble said on Monday it had agreed to sell its European tissue operations to a Swedish hygiene and paper product maker SCA for 512 million euros ($672 million). SCA said the acquisition would give it a batch of new brands, including Tempo, the market leader in paper handkerchiefs in western Europe and Hong Kong.

title: Will Dollar General Draw a Rival Offer?
description: Kohlberg Kravis Robertss $6.9 billion offer for Dollar General had analysts split over whether a competing bidder might emerge. Many agreed, however, that the discount retailer was an ideal target for a leveraged buyout.

title: Merrill Lynch Tunes In to Australian TV Auction, Report Says
description: Merrill Lynch was looking at a possible bid for CanWest Globals stake in the Australian broadcaster Ten Network, Reuters reported. Canadas CanWest has a 56.4 percent stake in Ten and had initially hoped to get up to 2 billion Australian dollars ($1.6 billion) for the holding, but the sale has apparently made slow progress. Ten has a market value of about 3 billion Australian dollars, including the CanWest stake, based on the latest share price.

title: Merger Monday May Boost Banks League Rankings
description: More than $30 billion in just four deals announced Monday may represent a big payday for investment-banking advisers, potentially shaking up the industrys league tables as the industry enters the home stretch, MarketWatch notes. The Web site estimated that the total fees could ring in between $30 million and $100 million. Check out the breakdown after the jump.

title: Tough Market Ahead for This Weeks I.P.O.s
description: Initial public offerings from tech maker BigBand Networks, commodities risk management firm FCStone and medicine maker Tongjitang Chinese Medicines face a choppy new issues market this week. Roiled by the big sell-off two weeks ago, the I.P.O. market is attempting to find its footing after a couple of big stumbles by recent deals.

title: State Monitor Finds TXU Abused Texas Power Market
description: In yet another bump in the road for the proposed buyout of TXU, a report has found that the company manipulated the Texas electric market in 2005, costing consumers $70 million and giving the utility $20 million in extra profits. TXU, the largest power generator in Texas, sold power to the market at inflated prices and caused electricity prices to rise 15.5 percent during a four-month summer stretch, according to an outside expert whose report was released by state regulators on Monday.

title: Coping With Dementia
description: Former players who have dementia do not qualify for the N.F.L.'s disability insurance program, because neither the league nor the union consider their conditions football-related.

title: Bush Aides and Business Meet on Shift in Regulation
description: Senior Bush administration officials began a series of high-level discussions on Monday with top executives from Wall Street, corporations and the major accounting firms. Many of the executives have urged the rollback of laws passed in the wake of the Enron and WorldCom scandals as well as limits to liability from government and shareholder lawsuits.

title: Lender Faces Credit Crisis With Banks
description: The Wall Street banks and brokerage firms that just a few months ago welcomed New Century Financial with open arms and gave it credit lines worth billions of dollars have quickly shut off the spigot, forcing it ever closer to bankruptcy. New Century, one of the biggest mortgage lenders to borrowers with weak, or subprime, credit, said in a securities filing Monday that all its lenders had frozen their credit lines and were demanding that it buy back $8.4 billion in loans that it issued using the money it borrowed from the banks  money New Century says it does not have.

title: Film Producer and Partners Buy Halston
description: the film producer Harvey Weinstein is casting himself in the role of fashion industry magnate.

title: Britains TCI Makes Noise at J-Power
description: The Childrens Investment Fund is turning up the heat on Electric Power Development to triple its dividend, marking the first time the British activist hedge fund has targeted a Japanesey company. Known as TCI, the fund has urged the countrys largest electricity wholesaler, often called J-Power, to increase its year-end dividend to 100 yen from its current plans for 30 yen. With a 9.9 percent stake, TCI is J-Powers largest shareholder.

title: Chicago Merc Counsel Joins Skadden
description: Jerry Salzman, the longtime outside counsel for the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, joined Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom on Monday, as the law firm he cofounded is closing down after 40 years. Mr. Salzman is leaving Freeman, Freeman & Salzman months after the exchange agreed to acquire CBOT Holdings, the parent company of the Chicago Board of Trade, in an $8 billion deal that could create the worlds largest futures exchange. Skadden represented the Merc in that deal.

title: Qantas Shareholders Pose Obstacle to Deal
description: The 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.6 billion) takeover bid for Australias Qantas Airways hit a rough patch on Tuesday as some large shareholders remained cool on the deal. The Australian Financial Review reported that UBS and Balanced Equity Management, who together have enough clout to kill a deal, have pressed the airlines management to release a report explaining why the bid led by Macquarie Bank and the Texas Pacific Group does not undervalue the company.

title: Citi Raises Bid for Japanese Brokerage to $13.4 Billion
description: After Nikko Cordials four biggest shareholders dismissed its first bid as too low, Citigroup on Tuesday raised its offer for the Japanese brokerage by 26 percent to $13.4 billion. Citigroups new bid now values Nikko, one of Japans largest brokerage firms, at 1,700 yen ($14.48) a share, up from 1,350 yen.

title: Goldman Posts Record Quarterly Profits
description: Goldman Sachs reported a 29 percent increase in profit for its first quarter despite growing concern on Wall Street over falling stock prices and an imploding subprime mortgage market.

title:
Knowing What It Means
To Miss New Orleans
description: Ive spent a good amount of time in Louisiana since hurricanes Katrina and Rita blew through, reporting on how New Orleans is rebuilding itself through food. I didnt head down for Mardi Gras this year, and I was missing the place.

title: There Is No Joy in Syracuse
Open Channels
description: It is not exactly The Congressional Register, but YouTube is being employed by growing numbers of politicians to put video of floor speeches and other statements online. And the trend is likely to accelerate as C-Span makes more video of Congress available.

title: New Artistic Director for Bush Theater
description: The board of directors of the 35-year-old Bush Theater in London announced the appointment of Josie Rourke as artistic director.

title: Icahn, in Battle Mode, Offers to Buy Homebuilder
description: Carl C. Icahn is getting tough with WCI Communities. The billionaire financier said Tuesday he would offer to buy the residential homebuilder for $22 share and if the company were to resist, he made it clear that he would try to throw out the board and get the deal done regardless. WCI is just one of several companies that Mr. Icahn has been prodding in recent months in what has been an especially active period for the activist investor.

title: 2008: Conversions and Snubs
description: Senator John McCains name has been synonymous with campaign finance laws for a long time. And its well known that the bulk of conservatives dislike the McCain-Feingold law. (In fact, the audience at the Conservative Political Action Conference booed and hissed at mentions of the law just a little more than a week ago. And it clapped and cheered when Mitt Romney vowed to fight the law in his speech.)

title: Health Dept.: Its Not a Crackdown
description: Jessica Leighton, the citys deputy commissioner for environmental health, denies that the city has started a crackdown involving restaurant inspections, in the wake of the KFC/Taco Bell rat episode.In the old days, you got a slap on the wrist and they tell you to move the jar of olives onto the shelf, and that was it, said the owner, Charles Milite.

title: One for the eyes
description: Lavish exterior

title: Why Not Let Scooter Off the Hook?
description: Scooter Libby is unlikely to become the next Leonard Peltier or Mumia Abu-Jamal, but Michael Kinsley says its time to Free Scooter! Kinsley uses his column in Time to make a liberals case for pardoning Scooter Libby. He writes:

title: Top General Opposes Openly Gay Troops
description: Gen. Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told The Chicago Tribune yesterday that he opposes any change to the dont ask, dont tell policy, which bars service by openly gay soldiers. General Pace, a Marine officer, explained why he supported the current policy:

title: In Lobbying Dance, Hedge Funds Are Still Learning the Steps
description: While hedge funds confidently flex their muscles in the markets and in boardrooms, in Washington they are experiencing the awkward growing pains of a relatively new industry coming to grips with its own power. Some hedge funds like D. E. Shaw and Cerberus Capital Management have spent time and money in the capital, but most funds have been content to hope Washington will not rear its regulatory head.

title: Lehman Buys Stake in Large Hedge Fund
description: Moving deeper into the alternative-asset management business, Lehman Brothers said Tuesday it had bought a 20 percent stake in D.E. Shaw, one of the largest hedge funds in the United States. Terms of the deal were not disclosed, but it follows similar transactions at Lehman and other Wall Street firms that want to be able to offer their clients greater access to these private pools of capital. Morgan Stanley has been especially active: It announced Monday that it had bought a piece of Abax Global Capital, its fifth hedge-fund investment in the past few months.

title: $15 Million Homes
description: Tour three grand estates in Naples, Fla., Jackson, Wyo., and Malibu, Calif.

title: Barry Bonds Loves Japan
description: How would Barry Bondss massive personality and desire for preferential treatment have fit into the team-oriented world of Japanese baseball? While it seems far-fetched to envision Bonds taking his booming swing to Japan, he said it is a country where he believes he could have played.

title: Egyptian Blogger Remains in Jail
description: A 22-year-old Egyptian bloggers appeal was denied, and he will have to remain in jail, The Associated Press reports today.

title: The Midwest, Game-by-Game
description: The Midwest region, top left in your 64 team bracket, will be known as the region with the reigning national champion Florida Gators. Lets take a look at how Florida and the other 15 teams in the Midwest match up.

title: Proxy Firms Flip May Bury Express Scripts Bid
description: The diagnosis for Express Scripts $26.3 billion bid for Caremark Rx is getting even grimmer. On Tuesday, a proxy advisory firm came out in favor of the proposed merger of Caremark, a drug-benefits manager, with drugstore chain CVS, reversing its previous position that shareholders should reject the deal.

title: Zell, Tribune and a Tale of Two Baseball Teams
description: Though some reports have said that Samuel Zells bid for Tribune is a solid hit, it may be a fielders choice of sorts; but in any case, the ball is still in play. Mr. Zell, who completed the record-breaking sale of his Equity Office Properties Trust last month, has said that he intends on keeping the media conglomerate together, including its newspaper and television properties and the Chicago Cubs.

title: MUSIC IN REVIEW; Juan Diego Flrez
description: Carnegie Hall

title: City Council, Not So Green?
description: The New York League of Conservation voters has released a scorecard [link fixed] that rates the 51 City Council members on the leagues favored issues.A caveat: Despite the purported mathematical precision that typically accompanies these types of scorecards from various lobbying groups, the percentages and rankings are apples-to-oranges comparisons with no statistical validity. But they are a general guide to what a lobbying group thinks of the councils performance. In this case, it applauds the quick approval of a solid waste plan but is unhappy with slow movement on several other bills on global warming, energy efficiency, transportation alternatives, and watershed protection.

title: Peltz Takes a Bite Out of Cadbury Schweppes
description: Is Nelson Peltz trying to satisfy his sweet tooth? Responding to rumors Tuesday, Cadbury Schweppes said that Mr. Peltz has amassed a stake of nearly 3 percent in Cadbury, the worlds largest candy and soft drink maker. Shares in the company on the London Stock Exchange were up 10.6 percent, at 602.50 pence each, valuing the company at about 12.6 billion pounds ($24.3 billion).

title: Six Degrees of Rick Pitino
description: The University of Louisvilles Web site notes that 19 of Rick Pitinos former players and assistant coaches have gone on to head coaching jobs. Several  including Floridas Billy Donovan, Kentuckys Tubby Smith and Holy Crosss Ralph Willard  join him in this years N.C.A.A. tournament field. And several of those coaches former assistants have taken the link one generation further, including the likes of Virginia Commonwealths Anthony Grant, who worked for Donovan, and Xaviers Sean Miller, who worked for both Willard at Pittsburgh and for another Pitino disciple, Herb Sendek, at Miami of Ohio and N.C. State.

title: Private Equity Sets Record Pace in 2007
description: If you thought that private equity funds would slow down after last years rapid-fire dealmaking, think again.

title: Document: West Street Closing
description: As reported this morning, parts of West Street will be closed for about a month as part of an expanded search for human remains from ground zero. Here is the memorandum [pdf] from Deputy Mayor Edward Skyler to Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: When Beer Goes Over the Top
description: Its been way too long, I know. All I can say is I had a few tasks to do for the newspaper, as well as jury duty, and then there was the little matter of losing my car keys, at which point I had a bit of a snap attack. Oh, and the $65 parking ticket I got before I could find a spare key. Manhattan is not a place that takes kindly to lifes little adventures. Lets just say Ive been in a solitary, brooding mood.

title: What Is Clear Channels Plan B?
description: Clear Channel Communications has been quiet about its fallback options in the event that shareholders shoot down its $18.7 billion proposal to go private. But with investor opposition building, such a scenario seems increasingly likely. And Victor Miller, an analyst at Bear Stearns, sees plenty of possibilities for what the nations largest radio broadcaster could do next.

title: Macquarie to Buy Spirit Finance
description: Spirit Finance, a real estate investment trust based in Scottsdale, Ariz., said on Tuesday it would be acquired by a consortium led by Australias Macquarie Bank for about $1.6 billion. The group offered $14.50 per share in cash, a premium of about 11 percent over Spirit Finances closing price of $13.05 on Monday. The deal is expected to close by the end of the third quarter, Spirit Finance said, though a provision lets it solicit other bids through April 9.

title: For Many M.B.A.s, a Big Graduation Present Ahead
description: Its a really good time to be an M.B.A., Andy Chan, assistant dean and director of the M.B.A. Career Management Center at Stanford University, tells Bloomberg News. How good? Last year, graduates of Harvard Business School averaged a record $186,174 in starting pay, while new M.B.A.s from Stanfords business school earned an average of $183,000. Starting pay for graduates from the top business schools may rise further, thanks to intense competition for them among big Wall Street firms like Goldman Sachs and Citigroup.

title: Smaller Buyout Firms, Profiting Under the Radar
description: A new generation of private equity entrepreneurs is making its mark on the industry, according to a report in BusinessWeek. Some of these entrepreneurs firms, like New Mountain Capital, are run by relative unknowns. Others are run by private-equity veterans like Silver Lake Partners, headed by Glenn Hutchins, a co-founder of the Blackstone Group.

title: Bloomberg on the Bell Grand Jury
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will be meeting shortly with community leaders in southeast Queens, as speculation grows that a grand jury will wrap up its inquiry into the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell and release its findings as early as tomorrow.

title: Spitzer: Senate Outdoes Enron
description: Time for the Empire Zone to delve for a moment into the budget numbers game.

title: General Motors
description: An ad from General Motors.

title: Win a Trip  Send Before Midnight Tonight.
description: Well, okay, no need to enter immediately. But my win-a-trip contest is now officially open, and applications are being accepted. Ill choose one university student and one school teacher from the applications, and my plan is to travel together in the latter half of June to Rwanda, Burundi and eastern Congo.

title: Malcolm Smiths Defining Moment
description: Last night, an interesting piece of political theater played out on the Senate floor as the Republican majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, brought up the governors controversial health care budget plan for a vote  several weeks before the budget deadline.

title: Voices From the Poll
description: In the latest Times/CBS News poll, an oversampling of Republicans was gathered to help measure their views. The nationwide poll, conducted from March 7-11 with 1,362 adults, found Republicans who were dispirited and dissatisfied with the slate of their partys candidates as well with the overall direction of the party. (Full story by Adam Nagourney here.)

title: Bloomberg: The Most Proud American
description: The political prospects of Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg came up again today when he was in Washington to speak at a Treasury Department conference on keeping United States capital markets competitive.Mr. Bloomberg sat on a panel with some heavyweights: Alan Greenspan and Paul A. Volcker, former chairmen of the Federal Reserve; Arthur Levitt Jr., former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission; and Robert E. Rubin, former Treasury secretary. The current secretary, Henry M. Paulson Jr., and the current S.E.C. chairman, Christopher Cox, moderated the panel. Mr. Cox, a Republican former congressman from California, noted that Mr. Bloomberg had won re-election by a greater margin than any other Republican in New York City history.

title: Could Sourcefire Spark a Security I.P.O. Trend?
description: Sourcefires successful initial offering last week may have represented a turning point in the buyout trend among makers of security software. The 451 Group, which researches the enterprise technology sector, expects a steady flow of computer security companies to go public over the next few quarters. Among them: Postini, Barracuda Networks, AcrSight and Fortinet.

title: Odds & Ends From Yankees Camp
description: The Yankees play the first of three consecutive home night games at Legends Field tonight against the Cincinnati Reds. Good pitching matchup as Mike Mussina takes on Aaron Harang.

title: Poll Outtakes: Gore, Cheney and Clinton
description: A few more interesting tidbits out of the New York Times/CBS News poll that we wrote about in todays newspaper.

title: Havana Good Day
description: Quite an odd scene around 9:20 this morning inside Tradition Field: on the mound, Orlando Hernandez. Catching, Mike DiFelice. In the stands, yours truly and a few other reporters, and thats it.

title: Carbon Copies Reveal a Trend
description: After the rush of deadline stories on Sunday, The Bracket picked up his phone to chat about this years field with Friend of The Bracket and Orlando Sentinel scribe Dave Curtis. When DC asked The Brackets Final Four  Florida, U.C.L.A., Georgetown and Texas A&M  he responded, I have the exact same one. Weird, but not stunning.

title: Blogtalk
description: Voting in Brooklyns 40th Council District, again and again. [The Politicker]

title: Papal Exhortation May Cause Problems for Giuliani
description: In news that might make John Kerry feel more comfortable in his retirement from presidential politics, but could be disturbing to Rudolph W. Giuliani, The Associated Press reports today that:

title: Does Britain Need New Nuclear Weapons?
description: As The Guardian reports, a second junior member of Prime Minister Tony Blairs government resigned today over Mr. Blairs plans to commit Britain to restocking its nuclear arsenal in the future when the current Trident nuclear missile system warheads start to deteriorate.

title: Blogtalk: When a General Speaks
description: When the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff of the United States gives an interview in the middle of a controversial war, bloggers pay attention. When the chairman offers his opinions about the immorality of homosexuality, the bloggers respond from far and wide.

title: Clear Channel Delays Vote on Buyout
description: In an apparent effort to avoid defeat, Clear Channel Communications on Wednesday pushed back both the record date and the voting date for a proposed $18.7 billion management-led buyout. Now, the record date  which determines the shareholders eligible to vote on the deal  has been delayed to March 23, and the vote itself moved to April 19 from March 21.

title: Stir-Fried Squid
description: New York Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, prepares a stir-fried squid in no time flat.

title: Head South, Not North
description: Recently, Nick touted Ethiopia as a great destination for student travellers. He wrote that it was cheap and safe. Ten days later a group from the British embassy in Ethiopia was kidnapped. It was announced that today the non-Ethiopians in the group had been released.

title: Kristof on Colbert
description: Nick was on the Colbert Report Monday night to share the news about the Win a Trip contest. The best moment was when Colbert asked Nick:

title: Cracking Up
description: The most entertaining player in this years N.C.A.A. tournament is not Kevin Durant or Greg Oden. ItsTravon Free, a center at Long Beach State, who can be spotted performing at the Laugh Factory in Hollywood and the Ice House Comedy Club in Pasadena.

title: What If I Like Your Politics but Dont Like Your Art?
description: Directly across the street from my studio, where for most of the day I sit writing music, there is a makeshift shrine put together by the residents on my block to commemorate Larry, the homeless man who lived there for at least the past 11 years. Since my studio is just about 150 square feet I looked out my window often to see Larry in his living quarters, a pieced together structure of cardboard boxes and discarded blankets.

title: The Really Real Hillary
description: Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below.  The Editors

title: Mussinas Not Laughing Yet
description: Last spring in Lakeland, Fla., Mike Mussina pitched a game so bad it was funny. He gave up 10 runs on 12 hits in four innings. One of the four homers the Tigers hit was smashed so far, Mussina worried it would crack his windshield in the players parking lot.

title: Torre Makes Cuts; A-Rod Makes Comments
description: As that wise sage Homer Simpson said, when he took over as pee-wee football coach, Now its time for the easiest part of any coachs job: the cuts.

title: At a Harlem Reunion, a Rancher From Missouri Meets His DNA Cousins
description: As genetic testing for ethnicity and ancestry has become more available to the public, more Americans are seeking information on their lineage. And many are confronting surprises in family background, racial makeup and newfound relatives.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 10:30 P.M. (Comedy Central) HALFWAY HOME A suspicious smell and an in-house narc lead to the residents of Crenshaw House being forced to take a drug test in the premiere of Halfway Home, an improvised comedy in which five ex-cons live together in a residential rehab facility.

title: Start-Up Fervor Shifts to Energy in Silicon Valley
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13  Silicon Valleys dot-com era may be giving way to the watt-com era.

title: The Right to Ban Arms
description: A federal appeals court panel in Washington has marched blithely past a longstanding Supreme Court precedent, the language of the Constitution and the pressing needs of public safety to strike down Washingtons law barring residents from keeping handguns in their homes.

title: Clinton Sees Some Troops Staying in Iraq if She Is Elected
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton foresees a remaining military as well as political mission in Iraq, and says that if elected president, she would keep a reduced but significant military force there to fight Al Qaeda, deter Iranian aggression, protect the Kurds and possibly support the Iraqi military.

title: Microsoft to Open Its Online Gaming Service to Windows Users
description: Microsoft announced yesterday that it was extending the online gaming service for its Xbox consoles to the millions of people who use Windows PCs to play games over the Internet, a move that could bolster the popularity  and profits  of video gaming.

title: Ernie Ladd, Hall of Famer in Football and Pro Wrestling, Dies at 68
description: Ernie Ladd, a massive defensive tackle turned wrestler who was the only man elected to the American Football League Hall of Fame and the World Wrestling Entertainment Hall of Fame, died Saturday at his home in Franklin, La. He was 68.

title: What We Owe Wounded Veterans (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Letters
description: Butters Good for You

title: Latex, Vinyl, 0r Soap?
description: THE video was dark and grainy, the camera operator anonymous. But the clip, which appeared to show a customer at a popular downtown restaurant extracting a disposable glove from a plate of food, caused a small stir on Monday when a link to it was posted at eater.com, a blog that chronicles the New York dining scene.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: New Landmarks for New York on Park Place

title: F.D.A. Warns of Odd Effects of Sleep Pills
description: The most widely prescribed sleeping pills can cause strange behavior like driving and eating while asleep, the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday, announcing that strong new warnings will be placed on the labels of 13 drugs.

title: When Warriors Come Limping Home
description: Shameful details continue to emerge on the neglectful care extended to soldiers wounded in Iraq and Afghanistan. The Armys inspector general reports that more than nine out of 10 disabled veterans have been kept waiting for benefit evaluations beyond the 40-day limit set by the Pentagon. Some have waited up to a year and a half for benefits.

title: Niagara Earns a Victory and a Shot at Kansas
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 13  A season full of subplots and twists took a good turn at the right time Tuesday night for Niagara.

title: Rodriguez Tells Fans to Embrace Him, or Else
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 13  Alex Rodriguez tries to insist that he wants to remain in New York. But an option in his contract allows him to become a free agent after this season, and in a radio interview Tuesday, he threatened to invoke the option if the fans did not embrace him.

title: When You Need a Zoning Variance
description: Many second-home owners dream of increasing the size of their weekend or vacation getaway  putting up a second story, expanding the pool house, building a detached garage, adding a deck, installing an extra-long boat dock. Buyers of vacant land also often think big. The challenge, of course, lies in turning those dreams into reality.

title: Paying Up to See a Long, Long Way
description: Apartments with sweeping views of Central Park have always been a must-have for a certain swath of the rich and famous in Manhattan. Now the same impulse seems to have caught on with companies searching for offices, especially in the financial services industry.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sunday Business this week about coaching services for users of online dating sites misstated the Web address of one such service. It is EvanMarcKatz.com, not EvanMarkKatz.com.

title: Police Lieutenant Arrested in Federal Sting
description: NEW HAVEN, March 13  The head of the Police Departments narcotics division was arrested on Tuesday, accused of bribery and stealing tens of thousands of dollars. The arrest was the culmination of a federal sting operation that also led to the arrest of a detective and three bail bondsmen.

title: More Homeowners Are Unable to Make Payments
description: The percentage of home owners who were unable to make their mortgage payments increased noticeably in the fourth quarter and shot up significantly among people with weak, or subprime, credit, according to an industry report released today.

title: Icahn Makes Bid for Florida Home Builder
description: The investor Carl C. Icahn bid $955.9 million yesterday for WCI Communities, the Florida builder of condominiums and single-family homes, after saying he wanted to oust the board because the stock was undervalued.

title: Treasury Reportedly Set to Act to Free North Korean Money
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  The Treasury Department is expected to move formally this week to bar American banks from engaging in transactions with a bank in Macao linked to North Korea, clearing the way for North Korea to regain possession of money at the bank frozen since 2005, a Bush administration official said Tuesday.

title: Britain Drafts Laws to Slash Carbon Emissions
description: LONDON, March 13  As nations and politicians in many parts of Europe compete to burnish their green credentials, Britain on Tuesday became the first national government to propose binding laws enforcing a steep cut in carbon emissions, in this case a 60 percent decrease by 2050.

title: Study Ties Heart Attack Deaths to Weekend Care
description: A study of nearly all heart attack patients in New Jersey finds that those who arrived at a hospital on a weekend were less likely to get aggressive treatment and were slightly more likely to die than those who arrived during the week, researchers are reporting.

title: Senate Passes Bill on Steps Advised by Sept. 11 Panel
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  The Senate passed legislation on Tuesday that would enact more recommendations made by the Sept. 11 commission, but the bill faces the threat of a White House veto because it offers expanded union rights to airport screeners.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about a request by the winner of a Feb. 20 special election for a City Council seat that another election be held because of questions about his residency misstated the percentage of votes won by the candidate, Dr. Mathieu Eugene. It was 34 percent, not 43 percent. The error also occurred on Feb. 21 in an article about the election.

title: Familiar Fallback for Officials: Mistakes Were Made
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales fell back on a classic Washington linguistic construct on Tuesday when he acknowledged that mistakes were made in the dismissals of eight federal prosecutors last year.

title: Hampton Bays: Ex-Teacher Loses Suit Over Firing
description: A grammar school teacher who claimed she was fired after being branded as a witch by school officials had her federal $2 million lawsuit against the Hampton Bays School District rejected by a jury yesterday. The teacher, Lauren Berrios, 37, said in her lawsuit that Andrew Albano, the former principal at Hampton Bays Elementary School, had accused her of practicing and teaching witchcraft. The suit claimed that Mr. Albano was a born-again Christian bent on converting the school and that his anger over her refusal to be converted provoked him to fire her in 2001. This woman was denied tenure and she came up with this witch claim, and the jury clearly found it far-fetched, said Steven C. Stern, a lawyer for the school district.

title: Canada: Agloma Steel and German Suitor Part Ways
description: Algoma Steel said it had failed to reach agreement on a takeover by Salzgitter of Germany and had scheduled preliminary discussions with other potential buyers. Algoma said in mid-February that it might be acquired by Salzgitter at a price lower than where the companys shares were trading at the time. Algoma negotiated with potential buyers in 2005 and renewed negotiations in February 2006 without reaching an agreement.

title: The Sound of a Wood Bat (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Approves Glaxo Cancer Drug
description: GlaxoSmithKline won permission yesterday from the Food and Drug Administration to sell a tumor-growth inhibitor called Tykerb to treat breast cancer.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about child labor in Guatemala, one of the five countries President Bush visited on a trip to Latin America, misstated the minimum wage there. It is about $1 an hour, not $1 a day.

title: City Closing Restaurants Since Video
description: The owners of the Coffee Shop, a popular cafe on Union Square, say they had never failed a city health inspection in 17 years of business. So when inspectors came last week and shut them down  citing a number of violations that the owners say would have earned them a slap on the wrist in the past  they could think of only one thing: the KFC/Taco Bell rat video.

title: New York City Council Approves Ban on Metal Bats
description: The New York City Council passed a bill today banning the use of metal bats in high school baseball games, securing enough votes to override a potential veto by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and setting up a possible legal challenge from the metal bat industry.

title: Setting Sail on a Bumpy Cruise With the Shadowy Shostakovich
description: A documentary grab bag of film clips, diary readings and desultory narration, A Journey of Dmitry Shostakovich peeks at the politics of this controversial composer. Yet absent any kind of narrative discipline, the movie is ultimately as ambiguous and impenetrable as its subject.

title: Rangers Let Another Lead Slip Away
description: Rangers forward Michael Nylander sat for several minutes in front of his locker last night, his skates still tied, his head resting in his hands. As the Rangers player most often criticized for not shooting enough, Nylander had taken seven shots and scored twice but still ended up explaining how the Rangers had squandered a lead and lost, 3-2, to Ottawa.

title: Princeton Returns Grant
description: Princeton University has given back $782,375 to a foundation that is seeking the return of hundreds of millions more in grants it gave to universities. Princeton is returning the money, which was used for a now-defunct program aimed at supporting graduate students in economics, politics and sociology. The payment is the latest move in a battle to control the Robertson Foundation, which began as a $35 million gift to Princeton in 1961 by heirs to the A.&P. supermarket fortune, and has increased to more than $800 million. The Robertson family said that the gift was to be used to train foreign affairs specialists but that Princeton used some of it for other purposes. Princeton said in a statement it had not used the money improperly, although it did not adequately disclose the programs nature to the foundation board.

title: Critics to Marketers: Suicide Is No Joke
description: THE backlash against a spate of advertising with suicide themes has claimed a third commercial. Washington Mutual has stopped running a spot that showed actors playing bankers poised atop a building as if about to jump.

title: Retail Sales Barely Rise; Cold Weather Gets Blame
description: Retail sales rose less than forecast in February as cold weather kept shoppers home.

title: Case Dropped in H.P. Spying
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14  A California judge today dismissed charges against Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, in a corporate spying case that grabbed national headlines and prompted Congressional hearings on protection of personal phone records.

title: Its Not Up to the Killer (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Really Real Hillary
description: Poor Hillary Clinton. Not only does she have to overcome the electability thing, the likability thing and  with some voters at least  the Bill thing. Now shes got to live up to the whole woman thing  the promise that, as Ellen Malcolm, president and founder of the fund-raising group Emilys List, recently proclaimed on behalf of all women nationwide, she will be a president of the United States who is like us.

title: Ecuador: Lawmakers and Police Clash in Congress
description: A group of fired legislators clashed with the police after forcing their way into Congress as President Rafael Correas plan to rewrite the Constitution continued to generate protests. Dozens of protesters supporting Mr. Correa also gathered in front of the building, screaming epithets to the group of about 20 legislators, who were dismissed last week by the Electoral Tribunal after trying to reverse a ruling that could have potentially eroded their power. Mr. Correa, who is seeking to diminish the easy ability of Congress to oust presidents in Ecuador, accused the fired legislators of abusing the misery of the people. Mr. Correa is Ecuadors eighth president in 10 years.

title: Alter the Power to Pardon (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Teachers Adventurous Life, Distilled Into an Unlikely Book
description: WAYNE, N.J.

title: For Citigroups C.E.O., It Was a Very Good Year
description: Citigroups total return to shareholders fell short of the returns of many of its peers in 2006, according to the compensation committee of the companys board, but the year was financially rewarding nonetheless for Charles O. Prince, the chairman and chief executive.

title: Asia and Europe Stocks Follow Wall Street
description: NEW DELHI, March 15  Asian and European stock markets tumbled today, following the sharp drop in U.S. stocks on Tuesday, as concerns spread about the consequences of loose lending practices in the United States housing market.

title: Brazilian Government Invests in Culture of Hip-Hop
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  In a classroom at a community center near a slum here, a street-smart teacher offers a dozen young students tips on how to improve their graffiti techniques. One floor below, in a small soundproof studio, another instructor is teaching a youthful group of would-be rappers how to operate digital recording and video equipment.

title: Whaling: A Japanese Obsession With American Roots
description: AYUKAWA, Japan  Why does Japan insist on whaling?

title: Answering Latin Left, Bush Pledges to Help Poor
description: MRIDA, Mexico, March 13  In the slums of Brazil, in the impoverished villages of Guatemala and finally here in Mexico, President Bush promised this week to deliver social justice to poor and struggling Latin Americans left behind by the global economy.

title: Pakistani Militants Hit Targets Close to Home
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Along the Afghan border, not far from this northwestern city, Islamic militants have used a firm foothold over the past year to train and dispatch suicide bombers against American and NATO forces in Afghanistan.

title: Veteran of the Nuremberg Trials Cant Forget Dialogue With Infamy
description: PORT WASHINGTON, N.Y.

title: Colorado Has Song in Its Heart, and Not Drugs on Its Mind
description: DENVER, March 13  The Colorado General Assembly wants to be quite clear on this point: When the singer-songwriter John Denver praised the joys of Colorado and sang about friends around the campfire, and everybodys high, in 1972, he was not referring to illicit drugs. Definitely not. Dont even think it. The high in question, lawmakers say, is really about nature and the great outdoors  the tingly feeling you get after a nice hike, perhaps.

title: Food Calendar
description: Kir and Variations

title: Indian Police Arrest 2 Suspects In Train Bombing
description: NEW DELHI, March 14  Two men have been arrested in connection with the deadly bomb explosion in February on a train between India and Pakistan, the Indian police said today. The arrests are the first in the ongoing investigation into the attack, in which 68 people were killed.

title: Simpson Book Rights Will Be Auctioned
description: The rights to the aborted O. J. Simpson book, If I Did It, will be publicly auctioned so the family of the murder victim Ronald L. Goldman will receive all future proceeds from their sale, a judge in Los Angeles ruled yesterday.

title: Iraqi Military Sees Drop in Violence in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, March 14  With the first full month of the Baghdad security plan completed, the Iraqi military announced Wednesday that the level of violence in the capital had decreased substantially. But the degree of improvement was unclear, partly because of the continued confusion over casualty counts here, and an American general cautioned against reading too much into optimistic reports, given that January and February were two of the worst months for car bombings since the invasion.

title: Bush Tries to Mend Relations With Mexico
description: MRIDA, Mexico, March 14  President Bush left Mexico today without reaching concrete agreements with the new Mexican president on a host of issues, from greater cooperation on attacking drug traffic to extending protections for Mexican farmers who grow corn and beans.

title: Manhattan: NBC in Deal With City on Jobs
description: NBC Universal extended its commitment to maintain a presence in New York City under an agreement approved yesterday by the citys Industrial Development Agency. NBC said it would move the operations of its MSNBC cable channel and 421 jobs to Rockefeller Center from Secaucus, N.J. It also agreed to keep at least 3,850 jobs in the city until 2023. In exchange, the agency gave NBC $1.5 million in real estate tax benefits. NBC had previously pledged to maintain 2,350 employees in the city until 2010.

title: Firefighters Group in Rift With Giuliani
description: John McCain will be there, as will Hillary Rodham Clinton, John Edwards and half a dozen other presidential candidates. But when firefighters hold a candidates forum today in Washington, Rudolph W. Giuliani, the contender most closely identified with their profession, will not attend.

title: Haiti: Gang Leader Caught
description: The police have arrested one of the countrys most feared gang leaders, known by his first name, Evans, the United Nations said. Known for organizing criminal activity in his corner of Cit Soleil, the seaside shantytown in Port-au-Prince, Evans led attacks against United Nations peacekeeping troops in recent months.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about the use of statistics to identify possible surprise winning teams in the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament misidentified the team that defeated Texas A&M in the Big 12 conference tournament quarterfinals. It was Oklahoma State, not Oklahoma.

title: Buffalos Pain: Giving Up Old Art to Gain New
description: BUFFALO, March 13  For a city that has lost so much unwillingly over the last several decades  industries, prestige, jobs and more than half its population  perhaps it was inevitable that a decision to allow anything of great value to leave here willingly would be met with howls of protest.

title: Canada: Bank Acquires New Jersey Money Manager
