description: The Royal Bank of Canada agreed to buy a money manager J. B. Hanauer & Company of New Jersey, in its sixth acquisition in the United States in the last year. Details of the purchase, which is expected to be completed in May, were not disclosed, Royal Bank said. J. B. Hanauer, created in 1931, specializes in fixed-income and wealth management services. The company, based in Parsippany, has five offices in three states, with about 300 employees including 147 financial consultants, and almost $10 billion in assets under administration.

title: Wives United by Husbands Post-N.F.L. Trauma
description: ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 9  The night that Sylvia Mackey and Eleanor Perfetto first met, back in October at a Baltimore Ravens reception for former National Football League players and their families, their connection was immediate. As she sat on a couch with her husband, Mrs. Mackey watched Dr. Perfetto cradle the hand of her husband as he blankly shuffled across the floor toward the Mackeys.

title: A U.S. Alliance to Update the Light Bulb
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  A coalition of industrialists, environmentalists and energy specialists is banding together to try to eliminate the incandescent light bulb in about 10 years.

title: Teenagers Science Project Wins $100,000 Scholarship
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  When 17-year-old Mary Masterman set out to build a spectrograph, she knew it would be no easy task. The device, an instrument used to identify characteristics of different kinds of molecules, can cost thousands of dollars, and Mary was building on a budget.

title: Decaf Being Joined by De-Heartburn
description: Much of the action in the coffee war of the last few years has been over the best-tasting brand. There, McDonalds and Dunkin Donuts are battling Starbucks, not to mention Caribou Coffee, Peets Coffee & Tea and numerous others. And Burger King offers a turbo-strength version.

title: Oneida: Clues to Train Explosion
description: Federal investigators examining what caused a freight train to derail and explode in central New York State said yesterday that they had discovered a flawed piece of track near the scene of the accident. The investigators, with the National Transportation Safety Board, said that they found the piece yesterday, during the initial stages of their investigation, one day after the train, which was carrying propane from Buffalo to Selkirk, exploded in Oneida. A spokesman for the agency, Keith Holloway, said investigators were examining the derailed cars for any signs of pre-existing flaws and would continue looking for other anomalies on the tracks. CSX Corporation, the train operator, said the company was working to pipe petroleum from some of the derailed cars into a pit where it would be burned.

title: The Value of Zero Is Increasing
description: SACRAMENTO, March 14  Aaron Brooks averaged more than 17 points a game for the Oregon Ducks this season, led the Pacific-10 conference in scoring and helped his team capture a No. 3 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Renewing a Call to Act Against Climate Change
description: MIDDLEBURY, Vt.  Some are born earnest, some achieve earnestness, and some have earnestness thrust upon them. Bill McKibben qualifies for inclusion in at least two of these wedges of humanity.

title: Discounts Stimulate Sales, Helping Kroger to 36% Increase in Profit for 4th Quarter
description: The Kroger Company, the nations biggest supermarket chain, said fourth-quarter profit rose more than analysts had anticipated as discounts spurred sales.

title: Feeling Push for a Bigger Javits Expansion
description: So what does Gov. Eliot Spitzer want in a revamped Jacob K. Javits Convention Center?

title: Russian Company Accused of Buying Press Coverage
description: MOSCOW, March 13  Telenor, the Norwegian cellphone company, said Tuesday that a Russian telecommunications company paid journalists in Ukraine to publish negative articles about Telenor in the midst of a business dispute.

title: Grand Jury Deliberating in Case of Groom Killed on Wedding Day
description: A grand jury in Queens that is weighing evidence in the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell ended it first day of deliberations today without voting on whether to hand up an indictment in the case, a law enforcement official and lawyers involved in the case said.

title: No Stumping for Culture in the French Presidential Election
description: PARIS, March 13  Is culture losing its political clout in France? That may seem a bit of a stretch, since the government still pours $3.8 billion into the arts every year  about 30 times as much as the budget of the National Endowment for the Arts in the United States.

title: Closing on a House, and a Lifes Story, Told in Art
description: BELLPORT, N.Y., March 7  The run-down little cottage on Country Club Road seemed like the perfect investment: a two-bedroom on a half-acre plot a couple of blocks from the bay and from the quaint village here on the South Shore of Long Island. The price, as is, was around $300,000.

title: Bruised Feelings and a Shaky Knee for F.C. Barcelona
description: BARCELONA, Spain, March 13  All Samuel Etoo wants is a little love. No, make that a lot of love.

title: Senate Democrats Offer Spending Plan, but No Way to Pay for It
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Senate Democrats have drafted a budget that would reject President Bushs spending cuts for health care and education, would keep taxes low and would eliminate the deficit by 2012.

title: At Long Beach State, Its Players, Not Games, That Get Away
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., March 13  Long Beach State forward Sterling Byrd called U.C.L.A. guard Arron Afflalo last weekend and said everything that a concerned high school teammate would:

title: More Openness in Government (Offices, That Is)
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Its a good time to be Thom Mayne. A founder of the Los Angeles-based firm Morphosis, he has evolved from brash outsider into one of the countrys most celebrated architects in less than a decade by infusing his industrial-machine aesthetic with a slyly idiosyncratic sensibility. And he pulled that off while taking on an improbable mix of clients, including public school administrators and government bureaucrats.

title: Ex-Leaders of Bronx Charity Avoid Prison in Fraud Case
description: Two former executives of a Bronx charity avoided prison sentences yesterday and instead will be fined for their roles in a fraud scheme in which they stole money intended for children and the elderly to make renovations to a beachfront apartment, to purchase cars, and to donate $875,000 to a financially struggling radio network.

title: Stark Images of Privation, and Diary as Confession
description: The images of starvation and death in Blockade, Sergei Loznitsas compilation of archival news clips recording the siege of Leningrad during World War II, are so stark that a conventional soundtrack could only distract you from the harsh pictures of this city, Russias second-largest, in the throes of catastrophe.

title: Pope Reaffirms View Opposing Gay Marriage and Abortion
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, March 13  Pope Benedict XVI strongly reasserted on Tuesday the churchs opposition to abortion, euthanasia and gay marriage, saying that Roman Catholic politicians were especially obligated to defend the churchs beliefs in their public duties.

title: Scrutiny Increases for a Group Advocating for Muslims in U.S.
description: With violence across the Middle East fixing Islam smack at the center of the American political debate, an organization partly financed by donors closely identified with wealthy Persian Gulf governments has emerged as the most vocal advocate for American Muslims  and an object of wide suspicion.

title: Kerik Is Said to Refuse a Plea That Calls for Prison Time
description: Federal investigators offered to end their criminal investigation of Bernard B. Kerik, the citys former police and correction commissioner, in exchange for his pleading guilty to charges that he engaged in federal tax fraud and wiretap conspiracy, but he refused, according to Mr. Keriks lawyer and a person briefed on the case.

title: 2 New York City Police Officers Seriously Injured
description: Two New York City police officers were seriously injured in separate incidents last night, one in Harlem and one in Brooklyn.

title: Google Should Be Green (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lee Will Be Out Longer for Knicks
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 13  After David Lee left a game Feb. 23 against Milwaukee with an injured right ankle and leg, he was told by the Knicks medical staff that it was a sprain and a strain. The expectation was that he would return to action relatively quickly.

title: Mistakes Made on Prosecutors, Gonzales Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Under criticism from lawmakers of both parties for the dismissals of federal prosecutors, Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales insisted Tuesday that he would not resign but said, I acknowledge that mistakes were made here.

title: Bad Loans Put Wall St. in a Swoon
description: Stocks fell broadly and sharply yesterday afternoon after a report on mortgage defaults indicated that the troubled housing market will weaken further before showing signs of improvement.

title: Newark: Court Clerk Charged in Bribery Case
description: A Newark municipal court clerk was charged yesterday with accepting bribes in exchange for altering a criminal record to allow someone to pass a federal background check, federal prosecutors said. The clerk, Louis March, 38, was charged in a criminal complaint by the F.B.I. with extortion under the color of official right, said Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney. Mr. Christie said Mr. March accepted $4,000 in cash from an undercover agent who was posing as the boyfriend of someone with a criminal record who needed to pass a background check to work at La Guardia Airport.

title: West Bank Sites on Private Land, Data Shows
description: JERUSALEM, March 13  An up-to-date Israeli government register shows that 32.4 percent of the property held by Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank is private, according to the advocacy group that sued the government to obtain the data.

title: Spanish Flavors Speak for Themselves
description: SO the Spanish restaurants in New York almost never serve food that tastes particularly Spanish. So what.

title: Loss by Sharapova Means Henin Will Become No. 1
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., March 13  After losing in the fourth round at the Pacific Life Open, Maria Sharapova simply shrugged, looking exhausted and uninterested after her mistake-filled match against Vera Zvonareva.

title: Evangelical Group Rebuffs Critics on Right
description: The board of the National Association of Evangelicals has rebuffed leaders of the Christian right who had called for the association to silence or dismiss its Washington policy director because of his involvement in the campaign against global warming.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,185 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the death of the following American yesterday:

title: From Mexico Also, the Message to Bush Is Immigration
description: MRIDA, Mexico, March 13  As President Bush tried to mend frayed relations with Mexico, the Mexican president gave him a cool reception on Tuesday, calling on Mr. Bush to live up to his longtime promise to make Mexico a priority and criticizing American plans to build a 700-mile fence along the border.

title: Gays in Nigeria (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Charge of Plagiarism, an Echo of a Fathers Case
description: Jacqueline R. Griffith seemed to be flourishing as a tenured assistant professor in economics and finance at Kean University in New Jersey  that is, until another member of her department accused her of having plagiarized sizable portions of her doctoral dissertation.

title: John Thow, 57, Composer, Dies
description: John Thow, a prolific composer of chamber, symphonic and stage works and a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, died on March 4. He was 57.

title: Lawyers Call 2 Detectives in Fatal Shooting Most Vulnerable
description: Lawyers for several of the five police officers involved in last years fatal shooting of Sean Bell in Queens said yesterday that the undercover detective who shot first  firing 11 times  and a detective who fired 31 shots, the most of any of the five, are the most vulnerable to criminal charges.

title: Bangladesh Military Government Holds 40 in Graft Sweep
description: DHAKA, Bangladesh, March 10  Peering into the heart of its democracy, Bangladesh has found a latemodel Hummer, three golden pheasants, several pet peacocks and piles of money.

title: Viacom Sues Google Over YouTube Video Clips
description: Viacom, the parent company of MTV and Comedy Central, sued Google and YouTube in federal court today, citing massive intentional copyright infringement.

title: Top General Explains Remarks on Gays
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  The nations highest-ranking military officer said Tuesday that he should not have expressed his personal view that homosexual conduct was immoral, and that he instead should have focused recent remarks on his support for current Pentagon policy that prohibits openly gay people from serving in the armed forces.

title: Loyalty to Bush and Gonzales Was Factor in Prosecutors Firings, E-Mail Shows
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Late in the afternoon on Dec. 4, a deputy to Harriet E. Miers, then the White House counsel and one of President Bushs most trusted aides, sent a two-line e-mail message to a top Justice Department aide. Were a go, it said, approving a long-brewing plan to remove seven federal prosecutors considered weak or not team players.

title: Transcript of Interview With Senator Clinton
description: Following is a transcript of an interview by Michael Gordon and Patrick Healy of The New York Times with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, conducted on Tuesday at her office on Capitol Hill. A few of the questions have been edited for brevity and clarity, and extraneous material omitted.

title: His Stage Was a Restaurant: Broadway Honors Sardi
description: A long line of people waited outside the Gerald Schoenfeld Theater yesterday afternoon for a matinee performance and, like on many other days, headed over for an early dinner at Sardis restaurant.

title: A Stars Supporting Cast Takes a Bitter Bow
description: There is no crueler way to lose a basketball season that was all about success than to have a desperation 3-point heave bank into the net, then find out that the clock started late and that there probably should not have been enough time to shoot it.

title: Nets Cap Trip by Squeaking Into 7th Place
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, March 13  The Nets squandered lead after lead, and with only 40 seconds remaining, their 7-point advantage was gone. An 11-day trip was grinding to an end, and who could blame them for lacking the energy to win? But win they did, scoring 6 of the last 8 points for a 112-108 victory against the New Orleans Hornets.

title: The Purse Isnt Congresss Only Weapon
description: THE debate that Congress needs to have about the Iraq war is being hijacked by sound-bite arguments. Defenders of President Bush concede that Congress has the power of the purse and insist it could use it to completely cut off the funds to the troops. But that, most of them say, is the only power Congress has to change the course of the war. They then insinuate that exercising this power would be an unspeakable act of disloyalty to our soldiers, leaving them without supplies, ammunition or pay. Congress is thus placed in a box: it has a single awesome power that it would never employ.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, the Bangkok Journal article on March 6 about Bangkoks successful effort to cut air pollution misidentified the gender of the public health faculty dean at Thammasat University there, who said a group of strong-willed environmental pioneers was largely responsible. The dean, Nuntavarn Vichit-Vadakan, is a woman.

title: Young Palestinians (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: At B.Y.U., Growing Pains and Gains
description: Beyond a simple test of talent, the N.C.A.A. tournament is a caldron of pressure. And Brigham Young, more than any team in the field, would seem to have the maturity to handle it.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some copies on Sunday about winners of a multistate Mega Millions lottery worth $390 million misspelled the surname of one winner. He is Ed Nabors, not Ed Neighbors.

title: Goldman Sachs Posts a 29 Percent Gain
description: Goldman Sachs reported a 29 percent increase in first-quarter profit, setting a record amid growing concern on Wall Street over falling stock prices and an imploding subprime mortgage market.

title: Meals by Elevator, With the Touch of a Chef
description: SPEND enough time in hotels and order enough room service and you get used to strangers stomping through the door, stepping over your suitcase and nudging aside your laptop to make way for the turkey club. You get to the point where you dont even notice them.

title: U.N. Inspector Reports on North Korea Visit
description: BEIJING, Mar. 14  North Korea will honor its commitment to shut down a reactor it has used to produce fuel for nuclear bombs, but it has demanded that the United States first remove financial penalties against the country, the chief of the United Nations nuclear watchdog said today.

title: A Prodigys Life Is Played Out in a Japanese Game of Skill
description: Wu Qingyuan, the subject of Tian Zhuangzhuangs stately and respectful biopic, was one of the 20th centurys top players of go, a Japanese game involving the placement of pebbles on a board and said to rival chess in complexity. The intricacies of the game do not figure much in The Go Master, which is more concerned with the rituals of play and with the intensity of the heros discipline and commitment.

title: Earnings at Goldman Were Up 29% in Quarter
description: Goldman Sachs reported a 29 percent increase in profit yesterday for its first quarter of 2007, setting a record amid growing concern on Wall Street over falling stock prices and an imploding subprime mortgage market.

title: Clinton and Obama Court Jewish Vote
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  As Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama compete for Jewish donors and voters, Mrs. Clinton is following a tried-and-true rule of hers from New York  support Israel to the last  while Mr. Obama is trying a more delicate strategy that hit some bumps this week.

title: Bush Defends Gonzales in Firing of Prosecutors
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  President Bush defended Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales today amid the furor over the firing of federal prosecutors, but he said he was troubled over the clumsy handling of the dismissals.

title: Answering Cheney About the Troops (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lebanon: 4 in Palestinian Group Held in Bombings
description: The authorities said they had arrested four men in Beirut whom they described as members of Fatah al-Islam, a radical Palestinian faction, in connection with the bombing of two minibuses in the city last month that killed three people and wounded 23. Two other members of the group were being sought in the attack, on the eve of the second anniversary of the assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri, a security official said. News reports said the men were detained after explosives were found in an apartment in the Christian neighborhood of Achrafieh.

title: 50 Protesters Hospitalized in Zimbabwe
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 13  The Zimbabwean opposition leader Morgan Tsvangirai and 49 other antigovernment protesters were sent to a Harare hospital for treatment on Tuesday, two days after the police arrested and beat them for their efforts to hold a protest meeting.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on March 3 about smoking bans at gambling sites misstated the title of Russell Sciandra. He is the director of the Center for a Tobacco Free New York, a coalition of groups of which the American Cancer Society is a member. He is not the president of the American Cancer Society.

title: Interior Dept. Energy Leases Prompt a Suit
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  A decision by the Interior Department to reactivate 20-year-old energy drilling leases in southern Utah areas that have since been set aside for protection and recreation will be challenged in court on Wednesday by three environmental groups.

title: Officer Shot in Gun Battle in Harlem
description: A plainclothes police officer was shot twice and seriously wounded last night in a gunfight in Harlem with a suspect who was killed, the authorities said. The officer was hospitalized and expected to survive.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article yesterday about the Knicks progress under the leadership of Isiah Thomas as coach and team president misstated their record with 19 games left in the regular season. It is 29-34, not 19-34.

title: A Crooner With the Power to Knock the Arena Senseless
description: The cultural symmetry was perfect. While the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame was having its annual induction ceremony at the Waldorf Astoria on Monday evening, Josh Groban, the 26-year-old pop superstar who has nothing to do with rock n roll, was serenading faithful Grobanites, as his fans are known, at Madison Square Garden. Call it the peaceful coexistence of two worlds.

title: Top Democrats Propose Expanding Health Insurance for Children
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Two of the most influential voices on health policy, Representative John D. Dingell and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, offered a bill Tuesday to expand the Childrens Health Insurance Program, as Democratic leaders in both houses said they would try to triple spending on the program over the next five years.

title: Stand Back, Pinkberry: Yolatos Here
description: Frozen yogurt is back, and Pinkberry, the Los Angeles company that put it in focus, has a new local competitor that serves a different type of treat. Yolato is where the creaminess of gelato meets frozen yogurts refreshing tang in flavors like pistachio, hazelnut and chocolate. Yolato, which has its headquarters in Edgewater, N.J., opened its first New York store in January in Greenwich Village at 120 Macdougal Street (Bleecker Street). On Sunday it opened a second location on the Upper West Side at 2286 Broadway (82nd Street).

title: Living in an Amsterdam Canal House
description: Even though he lives in an Amsterdam canal house built before 1593, Corey M. Reardon expects 21st-century, American-style service. And he has learned to go out of his way to get it.

title: Paulson, at Talks on Regulation, Suggests Pendulum Has Swung Too Far
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Responding to criticism from many corporate executives and business groups that rule changes in the wake of the Enron scandal had gone too far, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. suggested on Tuesday that the administration was considering a more business-friendly approach to regulation.

title: Queens: Conviction in Killing of City Worker
description: A Queens man has been convicted of the 2002 killing of a New York City Department of Environmental Protection worker, prosecutors said. The man, Taiquan Williams, 25, of Jamaica, was convicted of second-degree murder on Monday evening in State Supreme Court. The worker, Eugene McMahon, was fatally shot as he sat in his department vehicle on Aug. 9, 2002, said Richard A. Brown, left, the Queens district attorney. Mr. Brown said Mr. Williams shot Mr. McMahon in the head during a robbery, and Mr. Williams faces up to 25 years to life in prison.

title: Coach Farm Goats Have a New Cheesemaker
description: MILES and Lillian Cahn, who founded Coach Farm in Pine Plains, N.Y., 22 years ago to produce goat cheese and yogurt, have sold the cheesemaking and distribution components of their business. The Cahns will continue to operate the farm, now called Mill Hill farm.

title: China in Crackdown During Parliamentary Session, Report Says
description: BEIJING, March 14  China has mounted a violent crackdown on protests and arrested political activists in a bid to curb dissent during the annual session of its parliament, Human Rights Watch said in a report today.

title: New Jersey Suburb Stunned by 15 Arrests in Latest Drug Raid
description: EAST HANOVER, N.J., March 13  Students and other residents of this small Morris County suburb were struggling on Tuesday to make sense of the weekend arrests of a high school football player and his volunteer coach in the third high-profile drug roundup since last spring.

title: Politics, Pure and Cynical
description: We wish wed been surprised to learn that the White House was deeply involved in the politically motivated firing of eight United States attorneys, but the news had the unmistakable whiff of inevitability. This disaster is just part of the Bush administrations sordid history of waving the bloody bullhorn of 9/11 for the basest of motives: the perpetuation of power for powers sake.

title: Jeans, Yes, but Still Nicely Pressed
description: TO trace the changes in upscale restaurants over the last few decades, you can survey the losers: Lutce and white linens; servers in tuxedos and diners in ties. You can salute the winners: Nobu and filament bulbs; mix-and-match menus and polyglot cuisines.

title: Texas House Rejects Order by Governor on Vaccines
description: Six weeks after Gov. Rick Perry issued an executive order making Texas the first state to require that sixth-grade girls be vaccinated against a sexually transmitted virus that causes cervical cancer, the State House of Representatives voted 119 to 21 yesterday to approve a bill that would nullify the order.

title: Iraq Premier Meets Leaders in Area Torn by Insurgency
description: RAMADI, Iraq, March 13  Minutes before Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki arrived here by helicopter on Tuesday for his first official visit to Anbar Province, the epicenter of the Sunni Arab insurgency, his advance team of security guards had one last piece of business to take care of.

title: Cambodia: Prince Sentenced in Absentia
description: Prince Norodom Ranariddh, a former prime minister, was sentenced in absentia to 18 months in prison for selling the headquarters of the party he once led. He is accused of earning $3.6 million on the deal but denies the charge. Prince Ranariddh was ousted as party leader last year and is now abroad. He was ousted as co-prime minister in 1997 in a coup led by the other co-prime minister, Hun Sen, who now runs the country on his own. An aide said the prince, a son of the retired king, Norodom Sihanouk, might seek a pardon from the current king, Norodom Sihamoni, who is his brother.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening This Week

title: Late-Night Friends Taking on Prime Time
description: LOS ANGELES  The last time Conan OBrien worked with both Andy Richter and Jonathan Groff, it was May 26, 2000  Mr. Richters last night after seven years riding the couch as the loyal sidekick on Mr. OBriens Late Night on NBC.

title: German Official Adds to Mystery of Iranian Missing in Turkey
description: ISTANBUL, March 13  More than a month after a former top official in Irans Defense Ministry disappeared in Turkey, a German official on Tuesday stirred up the controversy over whether he had defected with the collusion of the West.

title: Mancuso Is Among 4 Skiers Racing for the Overall Title
description: LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland, March 13  When she was 12 years old, Julia Mancuso was already emerging as a once-in-a-generation talent from Squaw Valley, a challenging Californian ski resort near the Nevada border.

title: Growers Yearn to Be Free of Mandarin Seeds
description: Maricopa, Calif.

title: Pig Out
description: BOLINAS, Calif.

title: Folding a Spoof Inside a Parody of Something Like Life
description: Theres something a little depressing about the very idea of another show sending up reality television. It just feels lazy: this is the best you can do? An imitation of an imitation of life?

title: Matsui, Injured Much of 2006, Is Making Up for Lost Time
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 13  When Hideki Matsui arranged his annual dinner with the Yankees beat reporters, he first selected the same Tampa steakhouse as last year. Then he changed his mind. There was more than a meal to consider.

title: New York Mayor Warns Against Growing Inequality in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Flanked by national leaders in government and business, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg warned on Tuesday that widening financial inequality in the United States was not morally right and expressed concern about the surging economic growth of China.

title: At a Harlem Reunion, a Rancher From Missouri Meets His DNA Cousins
description: A rollicking gospel choir was shaking the floor of a Harlem brownstone when Vy Higginsen told the crowd around the soul food buffet to hush. The new cousin had arrived.

title: Houston, the Oil Town, Is Sharing in a Boom
description: HOUSTON  The good times are back.

title: Judges Say E.P.A. Ignored Order in Setting Emission Standards
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  A three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit rebuked the Environmental Protection Agency in a decision Tuesday, indicating that the regulators had flouted Congress and the courts in setting the standards governing hazardous air pollution emissions from plants making bricks and ceramics.

title: Immigrant Can Return to U.S. After Burying Family in Mali
description: An illegal immigrant who lost four children and his wife in last weeks fire in the Bronx learned yesterday that he would be allowed to travel to and from his West African homeland to bury his family, ending a period of uncertainty amid his grief.

title: Ballyhoo of Broadway Shuffles Off to ... China
description: If starry-eyed young actors dream of making it big one day on Broadway, what do starry-eyed Broadway producers dream of? China, baby.

title: Senate Begins Debate on Getting U.S. Out of Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  In the face of determined opposition from the Bush administration, the Senate began an impassioned debate today over an exit strategy from Iraq, heading toward a vote on a Democratic resolution aimed at a pullout of American combat troops in 2008.

title: What You Get for ... $15,000,000
description: Naples, Fla.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Two Brown Loyalists Remain on Knicks Bench
description: Larry Brown no longer strolls the hallways of Madison Square Garden. His name is rarely whispered within its walls. But he is not entirely gone, either.

title: Squid in a Snap
description: SQUID is all about speed: like scallops and shrimp, its almost impossible to undercook. Old-timers used to say, Cook it for two minutes or two hours, and thats about right.

title: Congress Gears Up for Debate on Getting U.S. Out of Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  The Senate will begin debate Wednesday on a Democratic resolution calling for the withdrawal of most American troops from Iraq in 2008, with Republicans saying they are eager to critique and ultimately defeat the Democratic approach to ending the war.

title: WhoseTube? Viacom Sues Google Over Video Clips
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 13  Since it bought YouTube last October, Google has been chasing deals that would give it the right to put mainstream video programming on the site. Just a few weeks ago, Googles chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, seemed confident that this courtship of old-line media companies would prove fruitful.

title: Living to See a Milestone (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: House Panel Ponders the Growth and Risk of Hedge Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 13  Lehman Brothers, the global investment bank, bought a 20 percent stake on Tuesday in the management companies of D. E. Shaw, a $29 billion hedge fund that is among the largest and oldest funds in the business.

title: 3 Bombings Raise Fears of New Effort by Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 13  Three bombs, two of them carried by suicide bombers, exploded in southern Afghanistan on Tuesday, killing four people and wounding at least 10, and raising fears that the Taliban was starting a new wave of violence, officials said.

title: Clear Channel Postpones Vote on Sale
description: Clear Channel Communications, the largest United States radio broadcaster, postponed a shareholder vote on its $19 billion sale by a month yesterday to improve the deals chances for approval.

title: U.N. Finds Evidence That Russian Gunships Aided in Missile Attacks on Villages in Georgia
description: MOSCOW, March 13  A United Nations observer mission in Georgia on Tuesday opened an investigation into missile attacks in three remote Georgian villages, and the initial evidence suggested that Russian helicopter gunships were involved.

title: Sniffing Out Fraud in the Bottle
description: A FEW months ago a wealthy wine collector held a dinner to taste some rare old Burgundies that he had purchased at a recent auction. He had invited several fellow Burgundy lovers, and the wines poured that night, ranging from 45 to 85 years old and worth tens of thousands of dollars, represented just a small cross-section of the purchase.

title: Aging Resort Demolished to Make Way for a Young One
description: LAS VEGAS, March 13  With a deafening rumble and a cloud of debris that has become all but customary in this city of short-lived icons, the Stardust Hotel-Casino was demolished early Tuesday morning.

title: Eat Drink Make Revolution: The Cuisine of Hunan Province
description: TODAY we have our choice of books that explore the regional cooking of France or Italy in rich, firmly grounded detail, but until recently, regional Chinese cooking was little-reconnoitered territory.

title: Ex-Siemens Executives on Trial for Bribery
description: DARMSTADT, Germany, March 13  Two former managers for the engineering conglomerate Siemens told a German court on Tuesday that they participated in paying bribes of roughly 6 million euros in Italy as part of the companys plan to anchor itself in the booming market for power generation equipment.

title: 50 Protesters Freed in Zimbabwe Court
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 14  Fifty Zimbabwean antigovernment protesters who were arrested and beaten by riot police in Harare three days ago were freed today after neither the police nor prosecutors showed up at a court hearing at which the activists were to be charged, defense lawyers said.

title: Betty Hutton, Film Star of 40s and 50s, Dies at 86
description: Betty Hutton, a singer and actress celebrated as a blond bombshell of Hollywood musicals and comedies in the 1940s and 50s, died Sunday night at her home in Palm Springs, Calif., her executor announced yesterday. She was 86.

title: Mutual Funds at Some Risk on Mortgages
description: Mutual funds held mortgage-related debt securities issued by the subprime lenders New Century Financial, NovaStar Financial and others at the end of last year, indicating that everyday investors are among those who will probably be hurt by the turmoil that is tearing through the residential mortgage market.

title: Mother and 2 Children Die in House Fire, but a 3rd Is Rescued
description: MANVILLE, N.J., March 13  A mother and two of her children were killed in a fast-moving fire late Monday, but a third child was saved by his father and godfather, who were alerted by a smoke detector and plunged into thick smoke to rescue him, officials said.

title: H.P. Restarts as Spy Case Lingers On
description: Mark V. Hurd, the chairman and chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, would prefer that the discussion at the annual meeting this afternoon focus on the companys future, not its past.

title: Not Irish, but Maybe Its for the Best
description: WHEN I was in college, I somehow acquired a recipe for what Ive always considered to be the ultimate Irish soda bread. Made with buttermilk, butter, eggs, raisins and sugar, its baked in a heavy iron skillet so that the top and bottom crusts become crunchy and browned while the center stays tender and pale, studded with treacly bits of raisins.

title: Philosopher Wins Templeton Prize for Spiritual Matters
description: A Canadian philosopher who believes that spirituality is an essential part of the study of philosophy and the social sciences has won the $1.5 million Templeton Prize for advancement and research of spiritual matters.

title: Two Mets Veterans Get Their Work in Out of the Spotlight
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 13  As the Mets team bus was chugging along two-lane Route 60 on Tuesday, still more than an hour from arriving at the Cleveland Indians complex in Winter Haven, the most important aspects of the Mets day were playing out here with few people watching.

title: Medical Data on Empire Blue Cross Members May Be Lost
description: WellPoint, one of the nations largest health insurers, has begun notifying 75,000 members of its Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield unit in New York that a compact disc holding their vital medical and other personal information had disappeared.

title: For a Man Who Refuses to Grow Up, Life Is One Long Teenage Prank
description: Adolescence can be a testing time, especially when it lasts for about 20 years. That, at any rate, is the experience recorded by Glasgow Phillips in The Royal Nonesuch, a darkly comic, self-attacking anti-memoir that in its better moments offers an acid critique of contemporary American culture and its twin obsessions: fame and riches.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about child labor in Guatemala, one of the five countries President Bush visited on a trip to Latin America, misstated the minimum wage there. It is about $1 an hour, not $1 a day. (Go to Article)

title: Gaza Strip: Abductors Known, Hamas Says
description: A spokesman for the Hamas-led government, Ghazi Hamad, said the group had definite information about who kidnapped the BBCs Gaza correspondent, Alan Johnston. He was abducted by gunmen on Monday. Palestinian security services in Gaza were making efforts to bring about his release. The kidnappers are believed to belong to a powerful Gaza clan that regularly engages in criminal activity.

title: Pants for Guys Who Do Yoga
description: Gear test with Michael Burgasser, yoga instructor.

title: Suffer the Little Children
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Russia Accused in Georgia Attacks
description: The U.N. found  evidence that Russian gunships aided in missile attacks on villages in Georgia.

title: A Wrap-Up of Fall Fashion
description: Cathy Horyn looks back at the fall runway season and discusses why there's reason to rejoice.

title: Stamp Commemorates Longfellows Birth
description: The Postal Service is commemorating the 200th anniversary of Henry Wadsworth Longfellows birth with a new 39-cent stamp, the latest in the annual Literary Arts series. Longfellow is best remembered for his epic poems, including Paul Reveres Ride and The Song of Hiawatha. The new stamp was designed by Kazuhiko Sano based on an 1870s photograph of Longfellow and shows scenes from Reveres ride in the background. It goes on sale at a ceremony at noon today that is free to the public, as part of a stamp show at Madison Square Garden through Sunday. The ceremony will include recitations by winners of the Poetry Out Loud National Recitation contest.

title: News From Verona
description: The Public Theater announced casting for the star-crossed lovers in this summer's first Shakespeare in the Park production, "Romeo and Juliet."

title: On the Horizon: Sarah Ruhl and Others
description: Playwrights Horizons' 2007-8 season will include a new play by Sarah Ruhl and the Off Broadway directing debut of the Tony Award-winning actress Blair Brown, the company has announced.

title: Google Changes Policy on Search Records
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14  Web search companies collect records of the searches people conduct, a fact that has long sparked fears among privacy advocates and some Internet users that this valuable personal data could be misused.

title: Khosla-Backed Firm Aims for Synthetic Petroleum
description: Another day, another round of funding for a clean tech start-up. LS9, a high-tech fuel company thats all about imitating nature, said it has received $5 million in funding, as the search for the next new thing in renewable energy continues. The company hopes to make what it calls renewable petroleum, a synthetic version of petroleum and other oil-based industrial products. (It has trademarked the name.)

title: Watt-Com Fever Heats Up Silicon Valley
description: It is no secret that venture capitalists have begun pouring billions into energy-related start-ups with names like SunPower, Nanosolar and Lilliputian Systems. But The New York Times notes that interest is now spilling over to many others in Silicon Valley  lawyers, accountants, recruiters and publicists, all developing energy-oriented practices to cater to the cause.

title: H.P. Restarts as Spy Case Lingers On
description: Mark V. Hurd, the chairman and chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, would prefer that the discussion at the annual meeting Wednesday afternoon not focus on the revelations of last fall that a dysfunctional board spied on its members and on journalists.

title: Paulson Tells Conference New Business Rules are Too Strict
description: Responding to criticism from many corporate executives and business groups that rule changes in the wake of the Enron scandal went too far, Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr. suggested on Tuesday that the administration was considering a more business-friendly approach to regulation.

title: At Trial, Ex-Siemens Executives Describe and Defend Bribes
description: Two former managers for the engineering conglomerate Siemens told a German court on Tuesday that they participated in paying bribes of roughly 6 million euros in Italy as part of the companys plan to anchor itself in the booming market for power generation equipment. But the two men, Horst Vigener and Andreas Kley, mounted a vigorous defense of the payments, arguing that Siemens benefited greatly from them.

title: Bear and UBS Subpoenaed Over Subprime Research
description: Massachusetts Secretary of State William F. Galvin said Tuesday he had ordered UBS Securities and Bear Stearns to turn over documents concerning their analysts recommendations on subprime lenders such as New Century Financial. Among the questions that Mr. Galvin is examining is whether these banks analysts published positive research on New Century, whose stock has plunged as problems in the home mortgage market have emerged, to bolster other financial relationships at the banks, The Boston Globe reported.

title: The Scenes in Harlem and Brooklyn
description: Two police officers were injured in separate assaults on the night of March 13.

title: House Panel Ponders Risk of Hedge Funds
description: In a strange coincidence, Lehman Brothers announcement that it had bought a 20 percent stake in D. E. Shaw, a $29 billion hedge fund that is among the largest and oldest funds in the business, came the same day that the House Financial Services Committee held a hearing on hedge funds.

title: An Update from Casey
description: Boarding the trip home from Africa, I was so glad to be going home. I hadnt bathed much in the past two weeks. I hadnt eaten much either. Wed been held up twice by bandits, and I was starting to get sick from exhaustion and changing weather.

title: For Citigroups C.E.O., It Was a Very Good Year
description: Citigroups total return to shareholders fell short of the returns of many of its peers in 2006, according to the compensation committee of the companys board, but the year was financially rewarding nonetheless for Charles O. Prince, the chairman and chief executive.

title: Citi Says It Wont Raise Nikko Offer Again
description: After raising its offer for the Japanese brokerage Nikko Cordial by 26 percent on Tuesday, Citigroup said Wednesday that its offer is final. The boards of the two companies agreed to raise the tender offer price to 1,700 yen ($14.40) a share, from last weeks initial bid of 1,350 yen ($11.44) a share after it was rejected by some of Nikkos largest shareholders.

title: Strange Bedfellows: Odd Turns in D.C. Madam Case
description: It might yet turn out to be what everyone seems to hope and expect: a tale of sex and power, secrecy and scandal, hypocrisy and comeuppance. So far, though, what we seem to have is a tale of murky motives, shifting legal strategies and chutzpah.

title: GMAC to Receive $1 Billion from G.M.
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, the former financing arm of the General Motors Corporation, said on Tuesday that it would receive $1 billion more from G.M. under the terms of its spinoff and warned that it would be affected by the weakening market for mortgages. GMAC said G.M. would transfer about $1 billion to the financing company in the form of stock by the end of the first quarter under the terms of its sale to a group led by Cerberus Capital Management.

title: Pricing of Chinese Retail I.P.O. Suggests Demand Is Alive and Well
description: Chinas Intime Department Store has priced its initial public offering at the top of the range for a total of 2.43 billion Hong Kong dollars ($311 million), suggesting the recent market correction and subsequent volatility has not had much impact on the Hong Kong I.P.O. market. Other parts of the capital markets are finding the going tough at the moment, but FinanceAsia notes that companies that have chosen to go ahead with their Hong Kong I.P.O.s have found that investor demand is still there.

title: Algoma Loses One Suitor, but Sees Others on the Horizon
description: d Salzgitter, a German steel company, has dropped out of talks to buy a Canadian rival, Algoma Steel, after word of the secret negotiations leaked, driving up the price of a takeover and piquing the interest of other potential suitors. While Salzgitter has walked away four weeks after starting talks, there are other interested parties that surfaced after news of the Salzgitter discussions became public last month, Algoma said Tuesday, adding that it plans to enter into negotiations with them in hopes of salvaging a sale.

title: Medical Product Firm Buys Back $2 Billion of Its Shares
description: The medical products maker Baxter International said Wednesday its board had authorized the repurchase of an additional $2 billion of its common stock. The company, based in Deerfield, Ill., said the repurchase would be executed upon completion of its existing share repurchase program. Baxter said it has about $800 million of remaining authorization under the $1.7 billion program the board approved in February 2006.

title: Cerberus Adds Adviser for Possible Chrysler Bid
description: Magna International, Cerberus Capital Management and a team led by the Blackstone Group and Centerbridge Partners are among the frontrunners to buy DaimlerChryslers Chrysler unit, Bloomberg News reported.

title: Juniper Executives Resign Days After Delayed Results Filed
description: Juniper Networks, the computer network equipment maker, said Tuesday that the chief financial officer, Robert Dykes, and an executive vice president, Robert Sturgeon, have resigned, just days after the company filed previously delayed financial statements with federal securities regulators.

title: Cantor Bets on Carbon Market
description: the financial services firm Cantor Fitzgerald has merged its previously separate United States pollutant brokerage with its carbon brokering business to try and cash in on expected expansion in carbon markets. Cantor wants to put its environmental brokerage, which until now has focused on markets in pollutants like sulfur and nitrous dioxide, to work in emerging carbon markets. A power shift in the Congress last autumn has raised hopes for a national carbon market, leading to a surge of interest among investors.

title: Viacom Sues Google for $1 Billion
description: Ever since Google coughed up that $1.65 billion for YouTube, critics of the online video site have been predicting a landslide of copyright lawsuits. While that landslide has yet to occur, the first boulder has fallen. Viacom, the parent company of MTV, Nickelodeon and Comedy Central, filed a wide-ranging lawsuit against Google on Tuesday, accusing it of massive copyright infringement. Viacom said it was seeking more than $1 billion in damages and an injunction prohibiting Google and YouTube from committing further infringement.

title: Travelport Plans I.P.O. for Orbitz Unit
description: Travelport, a travel-services company owned by private equity firms, said Wednesday it plans to sell part of its Orbitz Worldwide unit in an initial public offering, which it expects to complete in the third quarter. The size of the stake to be sold and the price are still undetermined, Travelport said.

title: Lehman Profit Rose in First Quarter
description: Lehman Brothers on Wednesday reported a $1.15 billion profit in its fiscal first quarter, up nearly 6 percent from the comparable quarter a year ago. Net revenue rose 13 percent, to $5 billion, Lehman said. Separately, Lehmans stock posted its biggest decline in about five years on Tuesday amid concerns about rising mortgage defaults.

title: J.P. Morgan Wants to Be Hollywoods Rainmaker
description: J.P. Morgan Chase is going Hollywood  all the way. Already one of the major players in structuring and financing entertainment deals, the investment bank is planning a unit aimed at advising moviemakers on everything from financing arrangements to merchandising deals, according to The Wall Street Journal. The Journal noted that the plan is part of J.P. Morgans effort to grow its business without relying on acquisitions.

title: Examining Edwards
The Number Youve Reached Is No Longer in Service
description: Alfonso Soriano, the $136 million man for the Chicago Cubs, is not pining for the Yankees as he had done in previous seasons. When Soriano was asked if he kept in touch with any of his former teammates, he said that he did not.

title: Shagging Fly Balls With the Mariners
description: Richie Sexson was in left field yesterday shagging fly balls with some of his Seattle Mariners teammates. But Sexson was not merely catching the balls. He also used them for target practice. After Sexson snagged a ball, he would fling it about 120 feet into a storage room that housed the groundskeepers. Sexson had nifty aim, nailing his target about 10 times.

title: 2008: Firefight
description: Most of the Democratic and Republican 2008 possible contenders are appearing today before the International Firefighters Assocations forum, with one conspicuous absence.

title: The Rockefeller Apartments
description: It's a club whose membership is determined by eye, not by bank account.

title: Getting Back to New Orleans
description: If youre really longing for some good New Orleans food, you might consider heading for a visit soon to taste food from two women who embody New Orleans kitchen tradition.

title: Will He Stay or Will He Go?
description: Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, facing calls for his resignation mainly from Democratic senators and candidates over the firings of several United States attorneys, told CNNs Miles OBrien in an interview this morning that his fate rested with President Bush.

title: Wouldnt It Be Cool if
description: Yes, it is absolutely true that I (reluctantly) conceded we needed an architect.

title: To Firefighters: Edwards Walks Picket Lines
description: Former Senator John Edwards put down a marker this morning for the 10 other presidential candidates and politicians who will follow him in addressing the International Association of Fire Fighters in Washington today.

title: Bids for Lad Magazine Publisher Are Due, Paper Says
description: The magazine empire that spawned a host of imitators filled with hometown hotties and college humor is up for sale, with bids due Wednesday for Dennis Publishing, the New York Post reported. Allen & Company is running a full-fledged auction for the company, which is looking to sell its flagship Maxim, as well as a sister publication, Stuff and Blender, a music magazine.

title: Proxy Firm Still Opposes Caremark-CVS Deal
description: Chalk one up for Express Scripts.

title: In Vermont, Come Spring and High Water
description: Theyre watching the sky, the thermometer and the river in Montpelier, Vt., today, hoping it wont turn out to be 1992 all over again.

title: Alberto Gonzales, Master of Understatement
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Mar. 12 column, Overblown Personnel Matter.

title: Ganging Up on Gonzales
description: The calls for Alberto Gonzales to resign as attorney general have created a told you so moment for the nations editorial pages. The New York Times editorial page says Gonzales has shown why he was such an awful choice for this job in the first place. The Washington Post says Gonzaless tenure in office has served only to deepen our conviction that he should never have been confirmed. The Los Angeles Times editorial page implies that we might even want to pity the poor man: [D]ont blame him for the lack of principled leadership at the Justice Department. Blame his boss. President Bush appointed a man clearly unqualified for the job.

title: A New Wave of Old Liberals Takes Over
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 11 column, The Vanishing Neoliberal.

title: Until sleep do us part?
description: Research shows that separate bedrooms have become the latest craze among American couples (as The New York Times reports).

title: Currents
description: Punk rock anarchy meets the bourgeois notion of decorating, Swedish modernism, sleek, sculptural furniture and more.

title: Awaiting the Bell Grand Jury
description: A grand jury could decide as early as today whether to indict any of the five police officers involved in the fatal shooting of Sean Bell in Queens. In an article this morning, William K. Rashbaum and Cara Buckley handicap the case, based on interviews with lawyers for several of the officers. The consensus: the officers most vulnerable to criminal charges are the detective who shot first  firing 11 times  and a detective who fired the most shots, 31.The grand jury  a group of 23 ordinary citizens working in secret on behalf of the government  do not determine guilt or innocence. Their job is to determine whether there is sufficient evidence of a crime to warrant a criminal proeeding. Their decision does not have to be unanimous  a minimum of 12 of 23 votes is required for action. (This site has more about how grand juries operate, including a discussion by a deputy prosecutor from Brooklyn.)

title: Personal Shopper
description: Forward-looking goods from companies that go way, way back.

title: Home Depot Chief: No Plans to Go Private
description: Home Depots chief executive, Frank Blake, offered a reality check Wednesday to those who are hoping his company will soon become the biggest buyout target in history. Were not thinking about going private, Mr. Blake said at a Metro Atlanta Chamber of Commerce conference. Were very pleased with the capital structure we have. There has been speculation that Home Depots stalled stock price and its valuable real-estate assets could make the home-improvement retailer an attractive acquisition candidate for private equity firms. With a market capitalization of about $76 billion, though, Home Depot would be quite a tall order for even a posse of firms flush with cash.

title: Senate Agrees to Begin Iraq Debate
description: For the first time this session, Senate Democrats cleared the procedural hurdle of 60 votes to move forward and debate a resolution on the war in Iraq. Twice before the Republicans had voted against debating a single resolution embraced by Democrats (and some leading Republicans). This time, the Senate passed, 89-9, a procedural motion that will set the stage for formal debate.

title: UBS Investment Banking Co-Head to Resign
description: Jeffrey McDermott, one of UBSs three global co-heads of investment banking, will step down on June 30 to pursue outside entrepreneurial opportunities, Bloomberg News reported Wednesday, citing an internal memo. A UBS spokeswoman confirmed the memos contents, but declined to comment further.

title: Chart: Restaurant Closings
description: In the wake of the infamous  rats-at-Taco-Bell video, the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygienes inspectors have been closing down restaurants at a furious pace. Between Feb. 26, the Monday after the rat video made its debut, and last Saturday, the department closed 94 restaurants and take-out outlets following inspections, records show.

title: The Scene in Greenwich Village
And the Play-In Game Goes to  Affirmative Action?
description: Back in the booming dot-com heyday of the early oughts, some enterprising young Web company  and they were all enterprising back then  came up with a clever idea to promote its N.C.A.A. Tournament Bracket game. It announced that it would reward one billion dollars for anyone who could pick every game correctly. This overexuberance was typical of the time  the Web just printed money back then, after all  but was nevertheless tantalizing. The N.C.A.A. tournament bracket is intimidating and enormous, yet somehow approachable. Every tournament game? Heck: I could do that.

title: Trouble with the Senecas
description: The Empire Zone read with interest the story in the Buffalo News this morning about the protest rally held by the Seneca Nation at which Gov. Eliot Spitzer was branded an agent of satan and compared to Adolph Hitler. All this because the governor wants the Indian nation to start collecting taxes on cigarette sales to non-Indians, an issue that has been a point of contention for many years and led to violent protests in the past.

title: Obama: Washington Has Its Own Fires
description: Senator Barack Obama used quite a few firefighting metaphors in criticizing the nations capital this morning, telling the International Association of Fire Fighters that Washington is the sort of place where people create other kinds of fires  whether its messing with funding for first-responders or saying he is too green to run for president.

title: Wall Street Makes Its Presidential Bets
description: The road to the White House clearly involves more than a few trips to Wall Street. The latest evidence comes from The New York Observer, which reports on the array of presidential contenders who touch down in New York on at least a weekly basis to raise cash from the citys rich and powerful, including many investment bankers, hedge fund managers and private equity honchos.

title: Clinton Invokes 9/11 With Firefighters
description: Firefighters did not endorse Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in her United States Senate race in 2000, but they applauded steadily this morning as she said that, as president, she would be there with you when you need me.

title: Too Many Phone Numbers?
description: GrandCentral.com will give you one universal phone number.

title: Kerik, Again
description: Two articles in The Times this morning have a bearing on the presidential quest of Rudolph W. Giuliani: one about Bernard B. Kerik, the other about the former mayors rift with a national firefighters union.The first is particularly interesting: It seems that federal prosecutors are not quite done with Mr. Kerik, Mr. Giulianis former police and corrections commissioner, who came close to being the nations homeland security chief.

title: Bloomberg: A Country of Laws
description: At a news conference this morning in Brooklyn, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg appealed for calm as a Queens grand jury seemed close to a decision on the Sean Bell shooting:

title: Bloomberg Surges Past Giuliani
description: Among New York City voters, that is.

title: McCain Warns of Nightmare Scenario in Iraq
description: In case anyone wondered what Senator John McCain thinks about the current Democratic resolutions and proposals on Iraq in the Senate, he just put it pretty clearly to the International Association of Fire Fighters.

title: Important Times Reader Service Information
description: Dear Times Reader Beta Testers,

title: A-Rods Future: Should He Stay or Should He Go?
description: A couple of hours before Alex Rodriguez turned all chatty on Mike & the Mad Dog yesterday, I found a subject he wouldnt touch.

title: Charges Dropped Against Hewlett Packards Dunn
description: A judge dropped the charges Wednesday against Hewlett-Packards former chairwoman, Patricia Dunn, who had been accused of orchestrating the boardroom spying scandal at the Silicon Valley computer company.

title: Yet More Musings on a Microsoft-Yahoo Deal
description: For months, pundits have been kicking around the (wildly speculative) idea of Microsoft buying Yahoo to take on Google, the giant of the Web search world. John Battelle, the editor of SearchBlog, a blog on search technology, was among them. But now Mr. Battelle, who also founded the online ad network Federated Media Publishing, thinks he has a better idea, though one he admits might sound crazy: a joint venture between the two companies to create a search monetization business.

title: Haiti: Walt Bogdanich's Notebook
description: Walt Bogdanich discusses the elections situation in Haiti. Video courtesy Discovery Times channel/CBC. Producers: Peter Bull, Walt Bogdanich, Jenny Nordberg. Editor: Pascal Akesson.

title: Haiti: Soccer Slayings
description: Soccer fans were executed by corrupt policemen in 2005. Video courtesy Discovery Times Channel/CBC. Producers: Peter Bull, Walt Bogdanich, Jenny Nordberg. Editor: Pascal Akesson.

title: Haiti: Democracy Undone
description: A preview of the Discovery Times documentary 'Haiti: Democracy Undone.'Video courtesy Discovery Times Channel/CBC. Producers: Peter Bull, Walt Bogdanich, Pascal Akesson.

title: Bolivia's Shift to the Left
description: Evo Morales's presidency heralds a dramatic shift to the political left for Bolivia, South America and perhaps beyond. (Producer: Brent McDonald)

title: Bolivia Shifts the Drug War Debate
description: Bolivia's new president, Evo Morales, is promising a dramatic shift in coca policy that could jeopardize the U.S. war on drugs.  Juan Forero reports. Producer: Brent McDonald.

title: Microsoft to Buy Speech Technology Company
description: Confirming reports that it was close a deal, Microsoft said Wednesday that it would buy Tellme Networks, an speech-recognition technology company. In a statement, Microsoft said that it plans to integrate Tellmes products into its mobile offerings, with a long-term goal of integrating the technology into the rest of its lineup.

title: Fast Times for Wall Streets Debt Whizzes
description: Troubles in the mortgage market have put a spotlight on the arcane world of structured finance and the alphabet soup that includes CDOs and CMBSs. These woes may also be creating additional opportunities for Wall Street workers who know about such complex things, according to MarketWatchs David Weidner, who reports that bankers and traders who have experience structuring collateralized debt obligations, or CDOs, are in high demand to feed departments handling securities backed by mortgages, assets, corporate debt and other loans.

title: Of Omelets and On-Time Arrivals
description: Im not really a breakfast person  never have been. While I love breakfast foods, Im almost never in the mood for a big meal at the start of the day.

title: A Right to Life-Saving Marijuana? A Federal Court Says No
description: Another legal door was slammed today in the ever-contentious question of medical marijuana, when a federal appeals court  ruled once again that Angel Raich of Oakland, Calif., could be prosecuted for smoking cannabis even though her doctor says it is the only drug keeping her alive.

title: Darn that Colbert!
description: I took a tumble last Saturday while on my regularly daily run, but I didnt think much of it. My chest hurt, but I figured it would go away.

title: The Search for Good Searching: Partly Over!
description: Beet.tv is not the final resting place for the Montessori-educated online funnyman Ze Franks show. Thats blip.tv, which is totally totally different but I get them mixed up in my head.

title: The Muffin Joke? Stop, Youre Killing Me
description: Id hoped to start parsing your theories on the gender gap in laughter today, but first we must deal with an emergency. In a shocking and unexpected development, readers reported laughing out loud at the muffin joke.

title: Red Foxes on the Prowl in N.I.T.
description: Maybe Marist did deserve an at-large bid to the N.C.A.A. tournament after all.

title: Blogtalk: Gonzales Under Fire
description: The blogosphere turned a little faster this week fueled by the furor over the firings of multiple United States attorneys. When President Bush spoke on the issue for the first time today, the keyboarding pace quickened even more.

title: Jim Gaffigan
description: A skit from Jim Gaffigan's DVD, "Beyond the Pale."

title: Looking Inside the South Region
description: The South Region, bottom right in your bracket, has Ohio State as the top seed, with the powerful Greg Oden in the middle. Memphis, the second seed, hasnt lost since Dec. 20 and Texas A&M, the third seed, has Acie Law. Heres a game-by-game look at the first round.

title: Spring Fever
description: You probably thought I was working on my bracket, but Ive been trying to catch up on reading, Beauty Services (the endeavor seems to require caps), the light-bulb shortage in the house, the rest. The blog absolutely continuesuntil they roll up the carpet, I suppose. I dont think weve even begun to scratch the surface. (Autre, I hope youre rested.) Theres a lot to report and talk about. Tomorrows paper will have a story about the fall runway trends; impossible to summarize, I think, and Julie Gilhart of Barneys is right when she says its not about trends, its about designers. Three or four years ago one might have complained that the runways had become little more than slick marketing opportunities, and Im not referring to Tom Ford. Ford saw the big-picture view of fashion, at the right time (and maybe thats why Id like to see him do something different, more daring and entrepreneurial, than returning to fashion). But I think the industry now has an incredible group of leaders, individual minds who are really committed to doing good work: Raf Simons, Isabel Toledo, Alber Elbaz, Miuccia Prada, Olivier Theyskens, Narciso Rodriguez, Marc Jacobs. Im sure Ive left somebody out.

title: Clinton Ducks Answer on Whether Homosexualty Is Immoral
description: Asked if she believed homosexuality was immoral, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton declined to answer the question in a television interview this morning and said it was for others to conclude.

title: Bell Grand Jury Went Home
description: There will be no announcement today.

title: Thursdays Best (Cough, Cough)
description: Admit it. Were less than 24 hours from the start of the N.C.A.A. tournament and youre starting to wish that you had taken Thursday and Friday off. Youre asking your friends on IM right now: Should I get food poisoning or the flu? Should I make up another distant relatives funeral to attend?

title: Bush Questioned on Prosecutors
description: President Bush was peppered with questions about the dismissal of several federal prosecutors while on a trip to Mexico.

title: Knight vs. Media, Again
description: Bob Knight has never been known for a charming reticence in his approach to the media. The Texas Tech basketball coach brought his trademark bluster to a news conference on Wednesday at Lawrence Joel Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Winston-Salem, N.C., as the No. 10 seed Red Raiders prepared to face No. 7 Boston College Thursday in the first round of the East Regional.

title: Council Bans Metal Bats in High School, With Veto-Proof Vote
description: The New York City Council passed a bill on Wednesday banning the use of metal bats in high school baseball games, setting up a possible legal challenge from the metal bat industry.

title: Blogtalk: Another Day
description: Todays Spitzerism: colossally misdirected, a reference to the Senate budget. [Capitol Confidential]

title: Everybodys Sleeper, Trouble at the Top, and One Dolla Beal
description: The practice session in Sacramento is more than half over and a few key storylines have emerged:

title: Hughes Heads Out
description: The call came at 5:35 p.m. today, when Phil Hughes walked into Manager Joe Torres office for the demotion he knew was coming. For two minutes or so, he met with Torre and pitching coach Ron Guidry. They emerged with Guidry and Hughes talking some more.

title: Giuliani Praises (One) Journalist
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani has not always been a fan of the press, and in particular, as mayor he clashed with The New York Times. But tonight, at the biggest fund-raiser of his campaign, in front of about 1,000 supporters, he singled out for praise the Times columnist Nicholas Kristof. And to tell the truth, Mr. Giuliani sounded as surprised about it as anyone else.

title: Giuliani Focuses on Energy
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani said tonight that weaning the United States off foreign oil must become a national purpose, that doing it within 10 to 15 years would be a centerpiece of a Giuliani presidency, and that he will have much more to say on the subject as the campaign wears on.

title: David Pattens Year at the Beach
description: David Patten keeps the student ID card from Santa Ana College tucked in a shelf back home.

title: The Sun as Youve Never Seen It Before
description: On the Internet right now, just one click away, you can find a wonderful movie made by NASA of a recent transit of the Moon past the Sun, but it is something very special. This version is viewed not from the Earth but from one of NASAs twin Solar Terrestrial Relations Observatories, satellites that recently were launched to study the Sun from space.

title: Pelfrey Pleads His Case
description: John Maine pitched very well this afternoon against Detroit, allowing only a leadoff homer to Curtis Granderson in four innings, and hes no dummy, either. After watching a little bit of Mike Pelfreys performance, Maine sat on a stool in front of his locker and asked a few reporters, The storys Pelfrey, right?Someone nodded, and Maine said, Thats what I like to be: under the radar and forgotten.To be fair, Maine isnt exactly under the radar, and he certainly isnt forgotten; he is, although Willie Randolph will not announce as much for a few weeks, penciled in as the teams No. 3 starter. But on this day, Maine was right: All Mike Pelfrey, all the time, and with good reason.

title: Joe Boyd Remembers the Sixties
description: The legendary producer of artists like Pink Floyd, R.E.M. and Fairport Convention talks about his new memoir, 'White Bicycles,' about the scene in late 60's London.

title: Penns Danley Preparing for Texas A&M
description: LEXINGTON, KY.  Here in the bowels of Rupp Arena, I just ran into Stephen Danley, the Rhodes Scholarship finalist, Pennsylvania forward and The Brackets most unique blogger. You remember him, the senior forward from Penn, whose lively prose here has kicked off a heated debate about pretension, as well as some witty byplay and multi-syllabic trash talking between the grads of our Ivy League schools.

title: Clinton, Obama and Gays
description: After Hillary Clinton came under fire for not directly addressing the question of whether she thought homsexuality was immoral, her campaign last night released a statement from the Senator. In her statement, Mrs. Clinton addressed the remarks of General Peter Pace, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who said he should not have publicly expressed his view that homosexual conduct was immoral and akin to adultery.

title: Comment Zone: Metal Bats
description: Nytimes.com is inviting readers to share their thoughts about the City Councilsban on metal bats in high schools, approved yesterday.

title: Chinese Trailblazer Is Used to Going Her Own Way
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., March 14  Li Na, who advanced to the semifinals of the Pacific Life Open on Wednesday, remembers the first time she defied her coach in China.

title: When to Violate the Top Two Commandments of Antigovernment Crusaders
description: When asked to identify the two most important items from their list of 10 public policy commandments, most antigovernment crusaders pick (1) public spending shall be kept to an absolute minimum and (2) the state shall not transfer income from rich to poor.

title: Hedge Funds, the Usual Suspects, Blamed for Volatility in Asia
description: The recent volatility and pullback in Asian markets have prompted some investors to sound a familiar refrain: Its all the fault of the hedge funds.

title: Death Rate Higher in Heart Attack Patients Hospitalized on Weekends, Study Finds
description: An extensive study of heart attack patients in New Jersey finds that those who arrived at hospitals on weekends were less likely to receive aggressive treatment and were slightly more likely to die than those who arrived on weekdays, researchers are reporting today.

title: Senate Panel Seeks to Question Justice Officials
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  The Senate Judiciary Committee voted today to authorize subpoenas to bring five top Justice Department officials before the panel as it investigates the dismissal of eight federal prosecutors in recent months.

title: Sunni Who Gave Comfort in Dark Night of War Pays the Price
description: BAGHDAD, March 14  From the day that Mudhafer al-Ubaidi, 47, took the job as the head of the Adhamiya District Council in Baghdad, he was a marked man. His predecessor had been killed by insurgents in the predominantly Sunni neighborhood four months ago.

title: Yanks Mientkiewicz Is Most Proud of Making Twins a Winner
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 14  Torii Hunter thinks about a former teammate whenever he tucks his 11-year-old son, Torii Jr., into bed.

title: The Danger Zone
description: The national unemployment rate came in at 4.5 percent last week and was generally characterized as pretty good. But whatever universe those numbers came from, it was not the universe that black men live in.

title: Folk-Rock Memories, Psychedelic but Clear
description: The 1960s had a single, precise climax, Joe Boyd says, and he was there.

title: Guidelines for Using a Cellphone Abroad
description: As a T-Mobile subscriber, Ken Grunski, a businessman in San Diego, knew that his cellphone would work during a trip to Tanzania. What he did not expect was the bill: $800 for 10 days use.

title: Open the Primaries (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Google Adds a Safeguard on Privacy for Searchers
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14  Web search companies collect records of the searches that people conduct, a fact that has long generated fears among privacy advocates and some Internet users that valuable personal data could be misused.

title: A Camera That Can Take Pictures When the Light Starts to Fade
description: One of the biggest stars of last weekends Photo Marketing Association show in Las Vegas was Canons new megacam, the $4,000 EOS-1D Mark III. It doesnt capture more pixels than other cameras, just better ones, the company says. Canon says its 10-megapixel CMOS sensor (for complementary metal-oxide semiconductor) has bigger microlenses over each picture element, so more light from the subject is recorded.

title: Bigger Than Any Breadbox, a Hole Has the City Puzzled
description: When it comes to the birth of a sinkhole, a big bang there is not.

title: U.S. Troops to Open 100 Garrisons Across Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, March 15  American forces here plan to operate out of 100 neighborhood garrisons across the capital in the next month as part of the new offensive to secure the city, the American commander in charge of Baghdad said today.

title: Dissident Priest in El Salvador Is Rebuked by the Vatican
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, March 14  The Vatican on Wednesday rebuked a Jesuit priest who is a leading proponent of liberation theology, saying that some of his writings, well known in Latin America, were either erroneous or dangerous.

title: Texas A&M Scraps Against Penn
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 15  For the first 20 minutes against Pennsylvania, Texas A&M looked as good as advertised. The Aggies played smothering team defense. Their senior star, Acie Law IV, was in command, whether threading nifty passes into the paint or launching effortless jumpers from the perimeter.

title: Newly Released
description: The subjects of this months new books range from the collective consciousness of a Chicago advertising agency to the imagined life of a young woman living in an impoverished Latin American country. There is also a posthumously published novel that has at its heart an enormous catfish: She was the nightmare fish of small boys, and she came from the depths of sweaty dreams to suck them and their feeble cane poles from the bank or the boat dock to a soggy grave.

title: Barbara Gittings, 74, Prominent Gay Rights Activist Since 50s, Dies
description: Barbara Gittings, a prominent gay rights activist who a decade before the Stonewall rebellion of 1969 was agitating for the rights of lesbians and gay men, died on Feb. 18 at her home in Kennett Square, Pa. She was 74.

title: 50 Protesters in Zimbabwe Are Set Free Without Charges
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 14  Fifty Zimbabwean antigovernment protesters who were arrested and beaten by riot police officers in Harare three days ago were freed Wednesday after neither the police nor prosecutors showed up at a hearing at which the protesters were to be charged, defense lawyers said.

title: Southampton: Officer Charged With Misconduct
description: A Southampton police officer pleaded not guilty in Suffolk County Court yesterday to charges that he helped two women evade arrest in exchange for sexual intercourse, the district attorneys office said. The officer, Guy Giammatteo, 32, pleaded not guilty to coercion, receiving bribes and official misconduct, prosecutors said. One of the women was a fugitive with an outstanding warrant and the other was involved with narcotics, prosecutors said. Officer Giammatteo is also accused of exposing himself to a woman. He was suspended in January, according to the Southampton Police Department. William Keahon, Officer Giammatteos lawyer, said the accusations were false.

title: Hoyas End Belmonts Big Day
