description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., March 15  Busloads of fans had come east from Nashville to the Lawrence Joel Veterans Memorial Coliseum to watch their underdog Belmont Bruins play in the N.C.A.A. tournament. And for a moment, there was even a glimmer of hope that No. 15 seed Belmont might make its first-round game against heavily favored No. 2 Georgetown at least interesting.

title: New Jersey Groups Line Up to Plead for Slice of $33.3 Billion
description: UNION, N.J., March 14  Even by the participants accounts, the opening steps of the states budget dance, often a drawn-out and contentious exercise, were part of a rather choreographed affair.

title: Florida: Settlement in Boot Camp Death
description: The states Department of Juvenile Justice reached a $5 million settlement with the parents of a 14-year-old boy who died in January 2006 after being beaten at a boot camp in Panama City. The agreement, orchestrated by Gov. Charlie Crist, would require approval by the Legislature. A lawyer for the boys parents, Ben Crump, said the family would seek another $5 million settlement from Bay County, which ran the boot camp. A criminal case is pending against the seven guards charged with beating the boy, Martin Lee Anderson, and against a nurse who watched.

title: Britain: Lords Reject Elected Chamber
description: After a two-day debate, the House of Lords rebuffed demands to make it an elected body, setting the stage for a fight over the future of the upper chamber. Peers, as members of the Lords are known, voted by 361 to 121 in favor of having all members appointed. Last week, the House of Commons voted by a majority of 113 for a wholly elected Lords and to remove those members who inherit their seats. The gulf between the two houses raises the prospect of months of wrangling as the government searches for a compromise. Pressure to reform the Lords has gathered momentum as the police investigate allegations that the Labor Party offered seats in return for loans and donations.

title: Pelfrey Has to Struggle, Making the Mets Happy
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 14  Mike Pelfrey lost his fastball Wednesday somewhere among the orange groves and cattle farms that line the roads between here and Port St. Lucie. That would not have mattered to him six months ago. He would have thrown it anyway, defiant that his best pitch, even on a bad day, would be good enough.

title: Unstarched Collars
description: LIKE many men working in a creative field, Michael Famighetti is not a traditional tie guy. I find most of them too wide, or too silk, he said. Basically, too stuffy. Which is not to say that Mr. Famighetti, 28, a photo editor at the Aperture Foundation, does not like wearing ties. He just prefers them loosened up a bit, a little offbeat, somewhere between a Ferragamo and a fish tie.

title: Gray Skies in China (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: With Voices in His Head, a Detective Gets to Work
description: The hard-boiled detective is an American archetype, to urban mythology what the cowboy is to the Wild West. At the moment, however, American television seems to prefer its detectives soft-boiled. Monk is about a prissy private eye with obsessive compulsive disorder. The Closer showcases a Southern detective with a secret addiction to sweets. That kind of fancy is a natural swing of the pendulum away from the long hegemony of facts and forensics on Law & Order and CSI. So is outright fantasy. The heroines of Medium and Ghost Whisperer resolve conflicts by talking to the dead.

title: Suspected Leader of 9/11 Attacks Is Said to Confess
description: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, long said to be the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks, confessed to them at a military hearing held in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, on Saturday, according to a transcript released by the Pentagon yesterday. He also acknowledged full or partial responsibility for more than 30 other terror attacks or plots.

title: Nash and the Suns Return to Dallas and Outduel Nowitzki
description: DALLAS, March 14  Just a regular-season game, the top two teams in the N.B.A. had said with a shrug but a perceptible glint in their eyes before the thrilling night began.

title: S.E.C. Seeking Stock Options Data From L-3
description: L-3 Communications Holdings Inc., a maker of battlefield communications systems, was asked yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission for information on past stock option practices.

title: Charming Stories and Ugly Truths
description: Lexington, Ky.

title: Calendar
description: Garden Programs

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: Amerifit Brands, Bloomfield, Conn., chose KSL Media, New York, to handle its media planning and buying account, which had been at MediaCom, New York, part of the GroupM unit of the WPP Group. Spending was estimated at more than $11 million. Amerifits brands include Azo, which treats urinary tract infections, and Estroven, an herbal supplement for menopause.

title: Alberto Gonzales and the Mistakes (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: I Dont Like to Kill Children
description: Following are excerpts from the testimony of Khalid Shaikh Mohammed on March 10 in a Combatant Status Review Tribunal hearing provided by the United States government. Parts were edited out. Mr. Mohammeds statements, parts in English and parts in Arabic through a translator, came in response to instructions that he could say whatever youd like to say so long as its relevant:

title: Democrats Measure for Iraq Pullout in 2008 Nears Senate Vote; White House Threatens Veto
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  In the face of determined opposition from the Bush administration, the Senate on Wednesday began an impassioned debate over an exit strategy from Iraq, headed toward a vote on a Democratic resolution aimed at a pullout of American combat troops in 2008.

title: For Connecticut Officer Charged With Theft, a Career of Ups and Downs
description: NEW HAVEN, March 14  In nearly four decades on the force in this city, Lt. William White has collected a string of accolades, cultivating an expansive network of informants and conducting dozens of arrests to take down street gangs and drug dealers.

title: Loan Unit Drags Down H&R Block
description: Just a few years ago, the tax-preparation giant H&R Block was making as much money from offering home loans to individuals with risky credit as it was preparing tax returns for millions of Americans.

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: An Aloe, Gazing East and South

title: Bank of America Pays Settlement in Improper Trading Case
description: Bank of America has agreed to pay $26 million to settle charges that its securities unit published fraudulent research reports on companies and failed to prevent leaks of reports that were used for improper trading, federal regulators said yesterday.

title: Inmate Enters Guilty Plea in 89 Killing
description: WHITE PLAINS, March 14  A convicted killer serving a lengthy sentence pleaded guilty on Wednesday to another murder, for which one of the victims high school classmates was wrongfully imprisoned for 16 years.

title: The Loss of a Newborn (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Considers New Iran Sanctions Resolution
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 15  The Security Council received today a draft of a new resolution to impose sanctions on Iran for its defiance of demands that it suspend its nuclear enrichment activities and return to negotiations over its nuclear program.

title: The Stylist Who Would Be Star
description: Los Angeles

title: China: Industrial Output Surges Again
description: Chinas industrial output rose 18.5 percent in January and February, the National Bureau of Statistics said, after gaining 14.7 percent in December. That beat the 15 percent median estimate of 20 economists surveyed by Bloomberg News. In February, Chinas exports jumped the most they had in 12 years, and domestic sales accelerated.

title: Bush Leaves Mexico With Optimism, but No Agreements
description: MRIDA, Mexico, March 14  President Bush left Mexico on Wednesday without reaching concrete agreements with the new Mexican president on a host of issues, from greater cooperation on attacking drug traffic to extending protections for Mexican farmers who grow corn and beans.

title: An Electronic Translator With a Human Voice
description: Just larger than a deck of cards, Franklins top-of-the-line Speaking Global Translator can order sushi for you, in 12 languages.

title: Countering the Big-Bank Trend
description: A small bank is the vein that carries blood to the heart, said Edward Carpenter, chairman of Carpenter & Company, an investment bank that in 33 years has organized the founding of 708 banks in California and across the United States.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Friday about Nils Y. Wessell, a former president of Tufts University, referred incorrectly to the role of one of its schools when he became president in 1953. It had a school of law and diplomacy that introduced students to international law; it did not confer law degrees.

title: U.S. to Review Anemia Drugs for Safety
description: Use of the anemia drugs Aranesp and Epogen, made by Amgen, and Procrit, from Johnson & Johnson, will be reviewed by federal health insurance programs because of concerns that side effects may be harming patients.

title: New Jersey Assembly Considers Legislation on Autism, Seen as Prevalent in the State
description: NEWARK, March 14  After a recent federal study showing New Jersey had the nations highest per-capita prevalence of autism, the State Assembly is expected to approve a package of bills Thursday intended to improve early detection of the disorder, plan for better services for adults who have it, and finance the Governors Council on Autism, created in 1999 to research causes of and treatments for autism-related disabilities.

title: Report on Anti-Semitic Incidents
description: The Anti-Defamation League reported yesterday that anti-Semitic occurrences were down last year in New York and New Jersey, states with the highest number of cases of vandalism and harassment against Jews, but that such events increased in Connecticut, which ranks seventh nationally. In 2006 there were 284 such cases in New York, down 25 percent from the previous year, the league said. There were 244 cases in New Jersey, down 8 percent, and 77 in Connecticut, up 35 percent from 2005. While the decreasing numbers in New Jersey reflect a national trend, they also show a continuing need to erase the persistent scourge of anti-Semitism, especially among our youth, said Etzion Neuer, the leagues regional director, based in New Jersey.

title: Microsoft Agrees to Buy Maker of Voice-Recognition Software
description: Microsoft said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Tellme Networks to add voice-recognition software that lets users obtain a phone listing, order a pizza and search the Internet.

title: Worlds Collide: Louisville Finds a Kentucky Home
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 14  When Rick Pitino walked onto the floor of Rupp Arena on Wednesday, something unusual occurred: nothing. There was no thunderous applause greeting him the way it had during his eight years as coach of the University of Kentucky. He was not booed, heckled or berated the way he was on the three occasions over the past six years when he came here as coach of the University of Louisville.

title: For the Record
description: A picture credit was omitted on the front page of Business Day on Friday with an article about the investment career of Nathaniel Rothschild, of the dynastic Rothschild family. The photograph of Mr. Rothschild was by Jack Guez/Agence France-Presse  Getty Images. Also, the article carried incorrect information in a quotation from Charles G. Phillips, who likened Mr. Rothschild to Prince Hal in the Shakespearean play Henry IV. Prince Hal became Henry V  not Henry IV, as Mr. Phillips said.

title: A Wireless Way to See Whos Calling
description: Combining the magic of Bluetooth with the wonders of Caller ID, a new wireless headset lets you see who is calling right on the earpiece. The BlueAnt V12 Bluetooth headset has a backlit L.C.D. screen that displays the phone number of the caller alongside other information like battery and volume levels.

title: Grand Jury in Bell Case Hears From New Witness
description: A grand jury in Queens that is weighing evidence in the police shooting of Sean Bell interrupted its deliberations today to hear from a new witness, a law enforcement official said.

title: Grand Jury in Fatal Police Shooting Case Ends First Day of Deliberation Without a Vote
description: A grand jury in Queens that is weighing evidence in the police shooting of Sean Bell ended its first day of deliberations yesterday without voting on whether to hand up indictments in the case.

title: A Museum Takes Steps to Collect Houses
description: LOS ANGELES, March 14  Shortly after moving here last year to take over as director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Michael Govan started looking at houses  not as a place for him to live but as potential museum pieces.

title: In Statement, Matthews Says He Never Used H.G.H.
description: TEMPE, Ariz., March 14  Gary Matthews Jr., the Los Angeles Angels center fielder, said Wednesday that he had never used human growth hormone, offering his first comments about his reported connection to a nationwide drug distribution ring.

title: Mayors Housing Program Reaches the One-Third Mark
description: Olateju Ogunremi has won two lotteries: the visa lottery that enabled him to emigrate from Nigeria in 1999 and the housing lottery that is allowing him, his wife and their three children to move into a new two-family house in East New York, Brooklyn.

title: Both Options Fail in Seattle Road Vote
description: SEATTLE, March 14  Six years after an earthquake damaged the elevated waterfront freeway that runs through downtown Seattle, prompting a prolonged and bitter debate over how to replace it, residents appear to have rejected both choices put before them in a citywide advisory vote.

title: Have Guitar, Will Recycle
description: THE typical high E string on an electric guitar is a stainless steel filament 32 inches long and one-hundredth of an inch thick. It weighs perhaps as much as a few paper clips  not a lot of raw material, but enough for the Barenaked Ladies to concern themselves with on their recent North American tour, which concluded last month.

title: Minnesota: Archbishop Forbids Mass at Conference on Homosexuality
description: The Roman Catholic archbishop of St. Paul and Minneapolis has forbidden the participants in a symposium on Catholicism and homosexuality to celebrate a Mass at their conference in Minneapolis this weekend. The archbishop, Harry J. Flynn, sent a letter to the organizers, New Ways Ministry, warning that the symposium may well cause significant confusion to members of the faithful, because some of the speakers have publicly questioned church teaching on homosexuality. About 500 participants have registered to attend the symposium, about half of them priests and nuns, and many others parish lay leaders.

title: Immigration Misery
description: A screaming baby girl has been forcibly weaned from breast milk and taken, dehydrated, to an emergency room, so that the nations borders will be secure. Her mother and more than 300 other workers in a leather-goods factory in New Bedford, Mass., have been terrorized  subdued by guns and dogs, their children stranded at school  so that the country will notice that the Bush administration is serious about enforcing immigration laws. Meanwhile, tens of thousands of poor Americans, lacking the right citizenship papers, have been denied a doctors care so that not a penny of Medicaid will go to a sick illegal immigrant.

title: Co-Head of Global Investment Banking Will Leave UBS
description: Jeffrey A. McDermott, one of three global heads of investment banking at UBS, will leave June 30 after six years at the bank, according to a company memo.

title: Clark Howell, 81, Leader in Study of Human Origins, Dies
description: F. Clark Howell, credited with transforming the study of human origins from just stones and bones to a broader discipline drawing on biology, ecology, geology and primatology, died on Saturday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 81.

title: China Moves to Give Private Property Legal Protections
description: BEIJING, March 15  After more than a quarter-century of market-oriented economic policies and record-setting growth, China is expected Friday to approve its first law to protect private property explicitly.

title: Senators Longer View of the U.S. Role in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  Following are excerpts from the interview on Tuesday with Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton about Iraq:

title: After Profit, G.M. Faces Rough Road
description: DETROIT, March 14  For General Motors, there was some positive news to report Wednesday: the automaker said that it earned a profit in the fourth quarter, that cost cuts had progressed faster than planned and that its losses plummeted in 2006.

title: Chinas Sort of Congress
description: The annual session of Chinas National Peoples Congress, now concluding, is not quite the ritual of absolute fealty it used to be. Reporters get to chase delegates in the hallways, and insiders say there have been some lively debates in the closed sessions. Still, the two-week gathering of 2,980 carefully vetted delegates remained largely a choreographed show to put the stamp of legality on decisions already made. And just so democracy didnt get out of hand, authorities warned some dissidents to steer clear of foreign journalists while the congress was meeting and put others under house arrest.

title: For the Record
description: A headline in Business Day on Tuesday about the acquisition of the Organon BioSciences unit of Akzo Nobel misstated the purchaser. It is Schering-Plough, not Schering A.G., an unrelated German company. Also, the article referred imprecisely to an earlier deal in the drug industry. Bayer, the German drug maker, last year acquired Schering, not Schering-Plough.

title: Mass and a Rich Oratorio, Joined at the Concert Hall
description: Igor Stravinsky, a Russian firebrand and scion of a noted opera singer, adopted and discarded numerous styles over the course of a lengthy career. Arthur Honegger, the French-born son of a Swiss coffee trader, sought to reconcile Impressionism with the contrapuntal rigor of Bach. What they had in common was Paris, where Stravinsky arrived in 1910 and Honegger the following year, and Switzerland, where both took refuge during World War I. These composers knew each other and shared important associates, notably the Swiss conductor Ernest Ansermet.

title: Antitrust Case Against Glassmakers
description: European Union regulators accused the Nippon Sheet Glass Company, the Asahi Glass Company and two competitors of fixing the price of glass used in construction. Asahis Glaverbel unit in Belgium, Nippon Sheet Glasss Pilkington in Britain, the Guardian Industries Corporation in the United States and Saint-Gobain in France said that they were notified of the accusations and would respond. The companies have two months to reply.

title: Push to Fix Ozone Layer and Slow Global Warming
description: HONG KONG, March 14  An unusual coalition of industrial and developing countries began pushing Wednesday for stringent limits on the worlds most popular refrigerant for air-conditioners, as evidence mounts that the refrigerant harms the earths ozone layer and contributes to global warming.

title: Installing Adobe Reader
description: Installing

title: Hamas and Fatah Agree on Unity Government
description: JERUSALEM, March 15  After many months of negotiations, broken by periods of fierce fighting, the rival Hamas and Fatah movements announced today they had agreed on a national unity government, which is expected to be ratified on Saturday.

title: F.D.A. Issues Warning on Sleeping Pills
description: Prescription sleeping pills can cause unusual behavior like driving and eating while asleep, the Food and Drug Administration warned today.

title: One Number That Will Ring All Your Phones
description: If you have only one telephone with one phone number, this column wont be of any interest to you. Skip to another article, you eccentric you.

title: On Bushs Trip, a Name Unspoken and a Surprising Phrase
description: MRIDA, Mexico, March 14  Try as they might to make President Bush utter the name of his chief Latin American nemesis, President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela, reporters who covered Mr. Bushs five-nation trip through South and Central America could not succeed.

title: Blair Wins Vote to Renew Atom Arsenal
description: LONDON, March 14  Struggling with a restive Labor Party in his final months of power, Prime Minister Tony Blair faced down a significant mutiny in Parliament on Wednesday, winning a vote to renew Britains nuclear deterrent only with the support of opposition lawmakers.

title: Retailers Board Pledges to Speak
description: Home Depot, the home-improvement retailer criticized last year when its directors did not attend the annual shareholders meeting, said yesterday that the full board would be at this years event.

title: CD Holding Medical Data of 75,000 Is Retrieved
description: A missing compact disc containing confidential medical and personal information on 75,000 Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield members was recovered yesterday, according to Magellan Behavioral Services, a managed care company that monitors payments for mental health and substance abuse cases of insurers.

title: The Sounds of an Orchestras Singular Personality
description: The Russian National Orchestra, founded by the pianist and conductor Mikhail Pletnev in 1990, began life as a post-Soviet assertion of private enterprise. It proclaimed itself independent of government sponsorship, and it stresses to this day that it runs entirely on private financing.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,187 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: 4 Editors, an Art Director and a Shot at the Magazine Title
description: Sixty years ago, The Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists of Chicago created its so-called Doomsday Clock to alert the world to the perils of the post-Hiroshima age.

title: Manhattan: Mayor Criticizes Parade Organizers
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday criticized a decision by the organizers of the St. Patricks Day Parade to move the citys firefighters to the middle of the procession from their traditional position near the front. I think they should all be up front, and thats always been the tradition, the mayor said. The New York Post and The Daily News reported last week that parade organizers were upset with the firefighters for holding up the parade last year to allow firefighters from New Orleans to join them. The mayor also criticized the organizers longstanding refusal to allow gay groups to march. I think all parades in this city should be open to everybody, no matter what your orientation or ethnicity or anything else is, Mr. Bloomberg said.

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption with the London Journal article on Tuesday, about a plan to make the House of Lords into an all-elected legislative body, referred incorrectly to the British shorthand term for Parliament. It is Westminster  not Whitehall, which is shorthand for Britains executive branch of government.

title: Israel: Bomb Song Cleared
description: Israels entry for the annual Eurovision Song Contest, Push the Button, has been approved by the competitions organizers, despite earlier suggestions that its lyrics were inappropriate. The song, by a band called the Teapacks, has been interpreted as a protest against Irans president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad.

title: Manhattan: Burglar Loses Lawsuit Against City
description: A federal judge has dismissed a lawsuit filed against the New York Police Department by a man who claimed that officers beat him during a 2004 burglary arrest in Brooklyn. The judge, Shira Scheindlin of Federal District Court, issued a directed verdict on Tuesday, meaning that no reasonable jury could have found for the plaintiff, the City Law Department said. The plaintiff, Michael Julia, was arrested in Borough Park on Jan. 15, 2004, city officials said. He and an accomplice, his girlfriend, later pleaded guilty to second-degree burglary in connection with several break-ins, the department said. Connie Pankratz, a Law Department spokeswoman, said the city had a witness who would have testified that Mr. Julia fell and hit his head before the police arrived.

title: A Cuckold With a Bird, in Search of a Big Payday
description: The men and women who populate contemporary relationship dramas tend to belong to a specific demographic, and when they quarrel, do so on pale sofas and sea grass rugs. Their minds may be cluttered  with unruly dissatisfaction, with upper-middle-class regret  but their rooms have the air of 100 oxygen tanks.

title: General Pace, Gays and Morality (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: With a Couch Potatos Style, Private Eye Works the Mall
description: Conan OBriens loyalty to Andy Richter is impressive. Its moving. Mr. Richter played sidekick to Mr. OBrien on NBCs Late Night from 1993 to 2000, beginning when Mr. OBrien was nothing but a cub. But the awkward fact is that Mr. Richter didnt stay for the duration, Ed McMahon-style, Tonto-style. In his sweet and beta way, Andy Richter deserted.

title: Division-Leading Raptors Give Knicks Glimpse of What Could Be
description: TORONTO, March 14  A formerly hopeless team, rebuilt around a youthful core and anchored by an All-Star big man, gave a brilliant showing Wednesday night. It had the unmistakable look of a rising power in the Eastern Conference. Some might even classify the Toronto Raptors rapid development as evident and significant progress.

title: Woodss Event Criticized for Limits
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 14  On a snowy morning last week in Washington, Tiger Woods gathered with several power brokers from the PGA Tour to announce the birth of a tournament.

title: North Korea Is Said to Tie Nuclear Accord to Freeing of Funds
description: BEIJING, March 14  The chief of the International Atomic Energy Agency said here on Wednesday that North Korea had pledged to honor its commitment to dismantle its nuclear arms program only after sanctions had been lifted on its funds frozen in a bank in Macao since 2005, which could introduce a snag in carrying out the accord negotiated with the United States last month.

title: Things Heat Up in Albany, and Not Just the Weather
description: ALBANY, March 14  Now the budget fight is getting personal.

title: For the Record
description: The Sports of The Times column on Sunday, about Coach Howie Dickenman of Central Connecticut State and his place in the collegiate basketball coaching fraternity, gave an incomplete list in some copies of former assistants to Jim Calhoun at the University of Connecticut who, like Dickenman, have led teams to this years N.C.A.A. tournament. Karl Hobbs of George Washington became the fourth former assistant  joining Dickenman, Dave Leitao of Virginia and Glen Miller of Pennsylvania  after his team won the Atlantic 10 tournament championship on Saturday.

title: F.D.A. Warns of Sleeping Pills Strange Effects
description: The most widely prescribed sleeping pills can cause strange behavior like driving and eating while asleep, the Food and Drug Administration said yesterday, announcing that strong new warnings will be placed on the labels of 13 drugs.

title: Homeowners at Risk
description: So far, the housing bust has been mainly about subprime lenders going broke, bankers and investors trying to avoid the fallout, and regulators rousing  too late, apparently  from hibernation. The story yet to unfold involves the millions of American families who are in danger of losing their homes.

title: Playing Hunches at Harvard
description: In mid-January, Mohamed El-Erian, head of the $30 billion Harvard Endowment, made a $1.6 billion bet that markets around the world were overvalued, and he sold off stocks representing 5 percent of Harvards total portfolio.

title: Clinton Says Some G.I.s in Iraq Would Remain
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton foresees a remaining military as well as political mission in Iraq, and says that if elected president, she would keep a reduced military force there to fight Al Qaeda, deter Iranian aggression, protect the Kurds and possibly support the Iraqi military.

title: When the Cravings Wont Quit, Turn On the Camera
description: This just in from pseudoscience: Addiction documentaries contain an element that excites dopamine receptors, shuts down the frontal lobe and causes intense cravings.

title: The Winners of the Rockwell Mixed Pairs
description: At the Spring North American Bridge Championships in St. Louis, the winners of the Rockwell Mixed Pairs on Wednesday night were Mildred Breed of Austin, Tex., and Richard Zeckhauser of Cambridge, Mass. Before the last round they were trailing Jane and Bob Teel of Birmingham, Ala., by one board. But the winners scored 76 percent in that round to the Teels' 23 percent, leaving Breed and Zeckhauser ahead by 2.09 match points. Third were Janet Robertson of Timonium, Md., and Ken Cohen of Philadelphia.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on Monday about the comedian Richard Jeni misstated his age. He was 49, not 45.

title: General Pace and Gay Soldiers
description: Theres a good reason that military officers avoid commenting on politics, society and public policy. The results are usually bad.

title: Small-Town Brothers Have a Sibling Relationship With Butler
description: BUFFALO, March 14  When your big brother is also your basketball coach, it can be hard to escape criticism.

title: The Right Fit Can Be Elusive
description: FINDING multifocal lenses that fit and correct distant, intermediate and near vision can require time and the willingness to persevere until your ophthalmologist or optometrist gets it right.

title: For the Record
description: The On Baseball column on Sunday, which began with a report about Terry Ryans ability as general manager of the Minnesota Twins to build a consistent winner with a relatively small payroll, omitted the writers credit in some copies. It was reported and written by Murray Chass from Fort Myers, Fla.

title: The Dark Side of a Good Friend to the Soil
description: IVE always thought of worms as my friends, until I started talking to ecologists who have been studying their voracious appetite for leaves.

title: Tremors May Forecast Quakes
description: Small tremors emanating from Earths tectonic faults may help scientists forecast the likelihood of a major earthquake, according to a study. The tremors may precede the most destructive types of earthquakes, which occur in areas where two tectonic plates meet. The slow grinding of the plates causes low-frequency earthquakes. The study, to be published in the March 15 issue of Nature, linked low-frequency earthquakes and the tremors for the first time, according to scientists from Stanford and the University of Tokyo.

title: Suspected Maoist Rebels Kill Many Indian Police
description: NEW DELHI, March 15  Suspected Maoist rebels stormed a police post in the heavily forested center of India early Thursday morning, killing nearly 50 police in what was apparently the biggest attack on state law enforcement in the last several years of leftist insurgency.

title: The Value of Zero Is Increasing
description: SACRAMENTO, March 14  Aaron Brooks averaged more than 17 points a game for the Oregon Ducks this season, led the Pacific-10 conference in scoring and helped his team capture a No. 3 seed in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Wal-Mart Is Said to Have Big Banking Plans
description: An Ohio representative is planning to release information today that suggests Wal-Marts ambitions into consumer banking may extend beyond what the retail giant had previously disclosed.

title: A Short Season Begins With a Bundle of Big Ideas
description: Jacqulyn Buglisi and her dances were the heart of Buglisi Foreman Dance, now Buglisi Dance Theater. In her years with the Martha Graham Dance Company, which she joined in 1977, Ms. Buglisi performed with a vivid extra spark that has also informed her choreography. Neither she nor Donlin Foreman, a Graham dancer who was a founder of the original company, has been afraid of larger-than-life Graham-style passion and handsome production values. And Ms. Buglisi has always been full of intriguing ideas about dance themes.

title: Better Vision Without Looking Your Age
description: MANY baby boomers who grew up wearing contact lenses thought they were liberated from glasses forever. But sometime between the 40th and 50th birthdays a cruel reality sets in. Suddenly the type in the newspaper is smaller. The controls on the car dashboard are blurry. Menus and price tags become illegible.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary on March 6 about Henri Troyat, the popular Russian-born French writer, referred incompletely to his survivors. Besides his son, Jean-Daniel, they include his stepdaughter, Michle Troyat McKeown; three grandchildren; and six great-grandchildren.

title: A Slow Death
description: WHILE New York State does not subscribe to the death penalty for the moment, the federal government does. Over the last few years there has been a surge in death penalty prosecutions authorized by the United States attorney general, both nationwide and in federal cases in New York. But these have resulted in disproportionately few death penalty verdicts, at enormous costs and burdens to the judicial system. A more prudent and realistic approach in the way the government seeks the death penalty is warranted.

title: Phone Venture to Start April 1
description: Nokia and Siemens said they planned to begin operating a joint venture phone network on April 1, with both companies having agreed to increase net asset contributions. Siemens will contribute 2.4 billion euros ($3.2 billion), while Nokia will add 1.7 billion euros to the venture, Siemens said. Nokia, based in Finland, and Siemens, based in Germany, agreed in June to merge their phone network units to close the gap with the market leaders, Ericsson and Alcatel-Lucent.

title: Avon Comes Calling With a New Campaign
description: REMEMBER the perky commercials that began with the ringing of a doorbell followed by the words Avon calling? Now, years later, Avon wants to ring billions of doorbells at the same time with the largest campaign in its 121-year history.

title: Clinton Seesaws on Question of Gay Morality
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  Asked if she believed homosexuality was immoral, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, initially said Wednesday that it was for others to conclude, but later issued a statement saying she did not think being gay was immoral.

title: A Week Showing the Risks of Routine Police Work
description: The slayings of two auxiliary police officers last night came in a week that has underscored the dangers of routine police work in New York City.

title: Charges Dismissed in Hewlett-Packard Spying Case
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14  A California judge on Wednesday dismissed charges against Patricia C. Dunn, the former chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, in a corporate spying case that gained national attention and prompted Congressional hearings on the protection of personal telephone records.

title: Voting on Unions (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. How high should my sofa be, relative to the other seating in the room?

title: Terror Suspect Said to Confess to Other Acts
description: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who took responsibility for the Sept. 11 attacks, said he decapitated the American journalist Daniel Pearl, according to a revised transcript released today of his remarks at a military hearing held in Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, on Saturday.

title: Oversight Is Set for Beleaguered U.S. Reading Program
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  Under attack for improprieties uncovered in its showcase literacy program for low-income children, the Department of Education will convene an outside advisory committee to oversee the program, known as Reading First, Education Secretary Margaret Spellings said Wednesday.

title: G.M. Posts Fourth-Quarter Profit on Cost Cuts
description: DETROIT, March 14  General Motors said today that it earned $950 million in the fourth quarter of 2006, its largest quarterly profit in more than two years, as its restructuring plan drastically reduced expenses. But in a consequence of heightened expectations about the success of G.M.s turnaround, Wall Street analysts expressed disappointment with the performance, which was hurt by heavy losses from subprime mortgages at its finance arm.

title: The Long Exit
description: Senator Carl Levin has always been one of the most serious participants in the Iraq debate. Hes one of those politicians who could actually pass a test of Middle East cultural literacy  who could tell you what the Mahdi Army is or whether Al Qaeda is a Sunni or Shiite organization. Hes one of the Democrats who generally hasnt formed his Iraq position with an eye to Iowa primary voters or the partys donor base.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a project by the Internal Revenue Service to ask tax lawyers and accountants to write some of its new rules misstated the time at which John D. Graham, who was appointed by President Bush to streamline the federal rule-making process, became dean of the graduate school at the nonprofit research organization RAND. It was in October 2005, not last week.

title: No Raise, but No Tears, for Warren Buffett
description: While many companies are starting tie the pay of chief executives to stock performance, dont expect Berkshire Hathaway to jump on the bandwagon anytime soon.

title: Google Is Reviving Hopes for Ex-Furniture Makers
description: LENOIR, N.C.  Almost 40 years ago, when Irene Marsh was a young woman, she took a few months of computer science courses. But when Ms. Marsh realized that would not help her find a job in this Appalachian furniture region, she dropped out and went to work in a factory making tabletops.

title: Bowie Kuhn, Ex-Commissioner of Baseball, Dies
description: Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball during a tumultuous 15-year period when the game experienced dramatic growth accompanied by unprecedented labor strife, died today at a hospital in Jacksonville, Fla. Kuhn, who lived in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was 80.

title: Dying Woman Loses Appeal on Marijuana as Medication
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 14  Federal appellate judges here ruled Wednesday that a terminally ill woman using marijuana was not immune to federal prosecution simply because of her condition, and in a separate case a federal judge dismissed most of the charges against a prominent advocate for the medicinal use of the drug.

title: Canadian Is Awarded Spirituality Prize
description: A Canadian philosopher who believes spirituality is an essential part of the study of philosophy and the social sciences has won the $1.5 million Templeton Prize for advancement and research of spiritual matters.

title: Stop the Presses, Boys! Women Claim Space on Op-Ed Pages
description: Whatever other reasons may explain the lack of womens voices on the nations op-ed pages, the lack of women asking to be there is clearly part of the problem. Many opinion page editors at major newspapers across the country say that 65 or 75 percent of unsolicited manuscripts, or more, come from men.

title: With New York Talent, Little-Noticed New England Team Won It All
description: What goes around, comes around, sometimes 60 years later. Holy Cross will attest to that.

title: In the Village, Festivity Tinged With Violence
description: Greenwich Village has long been the cheery, boozy living room of Manhattan, where the word shoot is most often a reference to a game of barroom pool, not street violence. Last nights shootings  in which two auxiliary police officers, a bartender and their attacker were killed  jarred police helicopters, officers on horseback and the swirling lights of squad cars against laughter, tipsy college students and tourists with cellphone cameras.

title: New Style for Studios: Peddling Films Softly
description: LAS VEGAS, March 14  As one of this summers most anticipated and heavily marketed movies, Spider-Man 3, the latest in the Sony Pictures blockbuster superhero series, will be hard to miss. But this week at ShoWest, the movie industrys annual convention for thousands of theater owners, filling four days and two Las Vegas hotels, a giant poster in the convention area is pretty much all the promotion it is getting.

title: China: Petroleum Seller Acquired
description: The China Petroleum and Chemical Corporation, Asias largest oil refiner, will buy the Hong Kong petroleum products distribution unit of China Resources Enterprise for 4 billion Hong Kong dollars ($511 million). The two companies signed a framework agreement, and the final purchase price remains subject to review, according to China Resources. A formal agreement will be signed in mid-April, the company said. The Beijing-based China Petroleum and Chemical, which is known as Sinopec, is expanding its refining and fuel distribution system to keep pace with the rapidly growing Chinese economy.

title: Now, a Radio Station for (Your Name Here)
description: Web sites like Pandora.com personalize the music you stream to your desk, while satellite radio offers portable listening but little personalized track choice. Slacker, a music service unveiled this week, hopes to merge the two concepts into something new: personal portable radio for the computer, car and coat pocket.

title: St. Patricks Day Parade (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Malling of Moscow: Imperial in Size and a View of the Kremlin
description: In architectural terms, few cities have endured more abuse than Moscow has during the last decade or so, from the ruthless demolition of major historic landmarks to the boom in garish faux-historical reproductions. So I suppose the news that Norman Foster, one of the worlds most talented architects, has designed a glorified mall in Moscow shouldnt seem tragic.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an effort by Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield to notify 75,000 members that a compact disc holding their medical and other personal information had disappeared misstated the telephone number to call for information. It is 1-800-293-3443  not 3433.

title: In a Test of Capturing Carbon Dioxide, Perhaps a Way to Temper Global Warming
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  American Electric Power, a major electric utility, is planning the largest demonstration yet of capturing carbon dioxide from a coal-fired power plant and pumping it deep underground.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: News From Verona

title: Safety of Sleeping Pills Depends on Using as Directed
description: The word from many sleep experts yesterday was that, despite the federal warning, prescription sleeping pills are relatively safe drugs if taken as directed. But that is a big if.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about competition for Jewish support between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama incorrectly described Mr. Obamas views about the culpability for stalled peace talks between the Palestinians and Israelis. Mr. Obama blames Hamas, which controls much of the Palestinian government, for the stalled peace talks; he does not blame Israel. (Go to Article)

title: Bush Criticizes Handling of Prosecutors Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  President Bush said Wednesday that he had confidence in Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, but that he was frankly not happy about the way Mr. Gonzales had handled the dismissal of federal prosecutors, a move that has led to a Congressional investigation into whether the White House allowed politics to interfere with law enforcement.

title: Indian Police Kill 11 at Protest Over Economic Zone
description: NEW DELHI, March 14  The police fired on protesters in eastern India early Wednesday, killing at least 11 people at a demonstration against one of the new Chinese-style economic zones.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Feb. 28 about a deal to overhaul the New York State workers compensation system misstated the average weekly pay in the state, as calculated by the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. It is around $1,000, not around $1,200.

title: Jury Advises Death Penalty in Girls Murder
description: MIAMI, March 14  The sex offender who was convicted last week of the rape and murder of Jessica Lunsford, 9, in 2005 should be executed, a jury recommended on Wednesday.

title: The Biased Broadcasting Corporation
description: Jerusalem

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Miss New York Pageant Moves From North Country to the North Shore
description: The Miss America organization said yesterday that it had moved the Miss New York competition from Watertown, near the Canadian border, where it had been held since 1982, to Huntington, on Long Island, more than 300 miles south, so that the pageant could be more convenient for women from New York City.

title: Leader of Far Right in France Joins (and Jolts) Race for Presidency
description: PARIS, March 14  Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the far-right National Front, officially registered as a candidate for president on Wednesday, adding new uncertainty to an already volatile campaign.

title: A Dead Swindler Holds Sway Over South Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 14  Brett Kebble was by all accounts a larger-than-life figure  gold-mining tycoon, concert-quality pianist, raconteur, gourmand, flamboyant benefactor of politics and the arts and, not least, master swindler. So it is fitting that the scandal he left behind after his death 18 months ago should be oversize, too.

title: But Coach, I Practiced in the Living Room
description: TO hear her tell it, Diana Neary is a terrible, terrible bowler.

title: Council Bans Metal Bats in High School
description: The New York City Council passed a bill yesterday to ban the use of metal bats in high school baseball games, securing enough votes to override a potential veto by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg. The vote set up a possible legal challenge from the metal-bat industry.

title: Georgia: Evidence of Copter Attack Cited
description: Three days after mysterious military strikes against Georgian villages in the remote Kodori Gorge, the authorities displayed photographs in a closed meeting for diplomats in Tbilisi, the Georgian capital, showing the remains of military ordnance being collected by a United Nations team. The debris, apparently of guided missiles fired from attack helicopters and unguided BM-21 rockets fired from the ground, further suggested a coordinated military operation. Georgia said Russian attack gunships conducted the sorties. Russia denied it. No one was injured, but several buildings were damaged. The United Nations is expected to release findings as soon as next week.

title: Gonzaless Critics See Lasting, Improper Ties to White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  As he pressed his case to be confirmed as attorney general, Alberto R. Gonzales made a promise to the Senate Judiciary Committee  and to the nation at large.

title: Class Aims to Put Students Under the Hood, and Into Stable Jobs
description: On a frigid Monday night late last month, long after the daytime students had departed, Jose A. Castro, a vice principal at Automotive High School in Brooklyn, stood before two rows of desks parked next to several cars in a second-floor classroom. Before him sat a diverse and unlikely group of adult recruits that he hopes will help replenish the shrinking ranks of qualified mechanics in New York City.

title: Writer Goes Home, Lands in a Soap Opera
description: It is arguably the case that someday in a future not too far away, writers will match lawyers, civil servants, meter maids, and usurious executives of credit-card companies as the countrys most detested professionals. Due for this particular ignominy are not the journalists and gossip columnists who have long been under the cultures reproving mallet but the writer writers  the purveyors of fiction, the memoirists who copy them, the haute novelists who smugly decline invitations from Oprah.

title: A Dashboard Buddy With Maps and Music
description: The Harman Kardon Guide + Play GPS-500 wont just get you from Point A to Point B  it will also entertain you along the way.

title: Maha Ghosananda, Called Cambodias Gandhi, Dies
description: The Venerable Maha Ghosananda, a Buddhist monk who led the rebuilding of his religion in Cambodia, calling for peace and reconciliation after the overthrow of the Khmer Rouge in 1979, died Monday in Northampton, Mass. He was in his late 70s and lived in Providence, R.I., and Leverett, Mass.

title: Potential Jurors Know Little About Ex-Media Tycoon
description: CHICAGO, March 14  If the first day of jury selection for the former press tycoon Conrad M. Black is any indication, then many in the potential jury pool have not forgotten the corporate scandals of a few years ago.

title: Hugo Chvez Is Tied to Giuliani Firm
description: Rudolph W. Giulianis law firm has lobbied for years on behalf of an oil company controlled by the Venezuelan president, Hugo Chvez, a strident critic of President Bush and American-style capitalism.

title: A Top Player Captures an Elusive Championship
description: ST. LOUIS, March 14  At the Spring North American Championships here, run by the American Contract Bridge League, the winners of the Leventritt Silver Ribbon Pairs on Monday night were Allan Siebert of Little Rock, Ark., and Alan Stout of Jacksonville, Fla. In the event, for players 55 years and older, they finished one and a half boards ahead of Martin Morris of Wheeling, Ill., and Charles Nemes of Hinsdale, Ill., with Richard Gabriel and Joseph Machotka of Chicago third.

title: Penn Finds a Leader in Ivy Player of the Year
description: Mark Zoller, a gregarious forward on the University of Pennsylvania basketball team, shared a dorm room three years ago with a skinny, soft-spoken freshman reserve guard who seemed particularly determined not to fade away.

title: Whats on Thursday Night
description: 7 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) PRIVATE SCREENINGS: BETTY HUTTON A look back at the brassy star of 1940s and 50s Hollywood, who died Sunday at 86. This follows a mini-festival of Ms. Huttons (Left) films: at noon, M.G.M. Parade Show No. 27 (1955); at 12:30 p.m., The Stork Club (1945); at 2:15 p.m., The Perils of Pauline (1947); and at 7 p.m., Cecil B. DeMilles Greatest Show on Earth (1952).

title: Israeli Panel on Lebanon War Lays Onus With Top Officials
description: JERUSALEM, March 14  A government-appointed committee examining Israels failures during the war in Lebanon last summer says it will publish an interim report in mid- to late April apportioning responsibility to top officials, heightening uncertainty about the future of the beleaguered prime minister, Ehud Olmert, and his government.

title: Coast Guard Cancels Contract for Vessel
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  The Coast Guard said Wednesday that it was canceling a contract with two military contractors to develop a vessel for a wide range of missions in the post-9/11 world and would instead have the Coast Guards own acquisition branch handle the project.

title: Suspension of Jurist Unleashes Furor Against Musharraf
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 14  A political and legal maelstrom has erupted after Pakistans president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, unceremoniously suspended the countrys chief justice last week, in a step that lawyers and rights activists have called an assault on the independence of the judiciary.

title: Coleridge Was Wordsworths Albatross
description: One summer day in 1797, after walking 40 miles, young Samuel Taylor Coleridge bustled down a Dorset hillside and burst through a cornfield into the garden where William Wordsworth and his sister, Dorothy, were at work. The two- or three-day visit became three weeks of tramping the countryside, nightlong talk about a new world and the poetry that was to shape it, and long sessions of feverish writing at a common table. Lines and images were swapped back and forth, often literally, as one poet used the others notes or supplied a missing stanza.

title: Ill Never Pay $34 for a Caesar Salad Again
description: THERE is nothing more terrifying than watching a child read a hotel dining room menu on the third morning of a vacation.

title: Teachers Sex Trial Focuses on Etiquette Questions
description: Should teachers offer advice on what color underwear is the right color for their students? Should students give roses to their teachers on Valentines Day?

title: Save a Face, Save the World
description: HOW I had forgotten the 90s: that optimistic decade when I walked around with my sticky mat and precious new cellphone, as obsessively yogic and introspective as Madonna. I attended Ashtanga classes and imagined peace while in pigeon pose, thinking it was an effective way to contribute to global reform.

title: To Be Possessive and Proud of It in Arkansas
description: LITTLE ROCK, Ark., March 14  Bowing to a native sons passion for proper punctuation and etymological exactitude, the General Assembly has put the English-speaking world on notice: the possessive case of Arkansas requires an  s.

title: An Explosion and a Bomb Kill at Least 11 in Afghanistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 14  A huge explosion on Wednesday in a hunting supplies store here killed at least six people and wounded nine, and a few hours later a suicide bomber detonated explosives strapped to his chest in a bazaar in the eastern province of Khost, killing five people and wounding 38, officials said.

title: Musical. Broadway. Bad Things Happen. A New Writer. The Show Goes On.
description: Rupert Holmes was at the piano one recent afternoon, recording some music at M&I, a small throwback of a recording studio on the 14th floor of the Film Center Building on Ninth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Curry Stars, but Maryland Holds Off Davidson
description: BUFFALO, March 15  The Maryland Terrapins won their opening-round game, but Stephen Curry won their respect.

title: South Africa: Health Minister Has Liver Transplant
description: Dr. Manto Tshabalala-Msimang, the controversial health minister, underwent a successful liver transplant in Johannesburg, officials said, a response to a long-term autoimmune disease. The health of Dr. Tshabalala-Msimang, 66, became an issue last month after she appeared at government meetings in an apparent state of confusion.

title: Baghdad Violence Declines in Security Push, Iraq Says
description: BAGHDAD, March 14  With the first full month of the Baghdad security plan completed, the Iraqi military announced Wednesday that the level of violence in the capital had decreased substantially. But the degree of improvement was unclear, partly because of the continued confusion over casualty counts here, and an American general cautioned against reading too much into optimistic reports, given that January and February were two of the worst months for car bombings since the invasion.

title: Virginia: Court Bars Families From Moussaoui Evidence
description: Families of victims of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks cannot view hundreds of thousands of nonpublic documents used in the trial of Zacarias Moussaoui, an appeals court said, overturning a lower courts order. The United States Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, said the families were not entitled to view documents that were given to Mr. Moussaouis lawyers to aid his defense but were not made public. Mr. Moussaoui, 38, is the only person charged in the United States in connection with the attacks.

title: Wearing the Corset to Work
description: THE Madonna zip-front tracksuits sold at H&M last year may have disappointed some fans, for in all their polyester shininess, they didnt look like something She would wear. A cheerleading squad at a Florida retirement home, maybe, but not Her.

title: Lesotho: Soros Pledges $3 Million to Fight Lethal TB
description: The financier George Soros offered $3 million to finance a pilot project in Lesotho for fighting extensively drug-resistant tuberculosis, known as XDR-TB. Mr. Soros, in association with Partners in Health, a medical charity, hopes to cut the death rate to about 50 percent. XDR-TB was first reported in South Africa, which surrounds Lesotho.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Oct. 3 about an expedition to survey the debris field of the U.S.S. Macon, a Navy dirigible that crashed over the Pacific Ocean in 1935, referred imprecisely to the end of the Navys lighter-than-air program. While the crash of the Macon put an end to the use of rigid airships, the Navy continued to use blimps and semirigid airships; the last flight in the lighter-than-air program was in 1962. This correction was delayed because a readers e-mail message was not forwarded to the appropriate editors.

title: Senate Rejects Measure for Iraq Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  In a largely party-line vote, the Senate today rejected a Democratic resolution aimed at withdrawing most American combat troops from Iraq in 2008. But Democratic leaders vowed to keep raising the measure to escalate pressure on the Bush Administration and the Republican Party for an exit strategy from Iraq.

title: Taking Responsibility for Attacks
description: In a statement to a military tribunal, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed took responsibility for 31 terror attacks or attempts, including the following:

title: Sweden: Time Warner Ends Offer
description: Time Warner Inc., the media company, withdrew its $900 million offer for TradeDoubler, an Internet advertising company, after failing to win the support of shareholders. The companys AOL unit scrapped its 215-kronor-a-share bid after the deadline expired today, Time Warner said.

title: Greenwich Village Gunfight Leaves Four Dead
description: Police are investigating why a former marine opened fire on a pizzeria Wednesday night, fatally shooting a bartender, and then killing two unarmed auxiliary police officers who chased him through a busy stretch of bars and restaurants in the heart of Greenwich Village.

title: Iraqis Progress Lags Behind Pace Set by Bush Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 14  The Bush administration, which six months ago issued a series of political goals for the Iraqi government to meet by this month, is now tacitly acknowledging that the goals will take significantly longer to achieve.

title: Uniformed Eyes and Ears on the Front Lines
description: They form a kind of shadow police force, uniformed but unarmed and unpaid. Part community-minded volunteers and part would-be officers, they go on neighborhood patrols, help with crowd control at places like Yankee Stadium and serve as an official-looking eyes and ears.

title: Goldman Sachs Is Fined $2 Million in a Pattern of Illegal Trading
description: The Goldman Sachs Group was fined $2 million by market regulators yesterday for allowing clients to make illegal short sales before stock offerings.

title: Wall Street Rebounds After Asian Stocks Plunge
description: Wall Street started pulling itself back up from yesterdays sharp fall, with stocks closing slightly higher today.

title: Looking Inside the West Region
description: The West Region has plenty of offense, featuring high-scoring guards (Aaron Afflalo of U.C.L.A., Scottie Reynolds of Villanova, Zabian Dowdel of Virginia Tech). It has defense (Southern Illinois, Pitt and Villanova). It has favorites (Kansas, U.C.L.A.), possible Cinderellas (Virginia Commonwealth) and a mid-major that isnt (Gonzaga).

title: Americans in Amsterdam
description: Tour the elegant apartment of Corey M. Reardon and Hudson Young in the City of Bridges.

title: Looking Inside the East Region
description: Georgetown could be the hottest team. Kevin Durant could be the hottest player. Oral Roberts could be the hottest pick. Heres a look at the best games and best matchups in the region.

title: Live at St. Ann's
description: Photographs of recent productions at St. Ann's Warehouse in Brooklyn.

title: Meet Central Connecticut State
description: Most of us undoubtedly have only 24 hours to get to know Central Connecticut State, so we might as well make the most of it. They play Ohio State Thursday evening.

title: Prime Time
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: First Round Action
description: Highlights from the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament on Thursday.

title: Renaissance, Baroque and Rococo
description: Images from Faith and Fortune: Five Centuries of European Masterworks at the Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art.

title: Where has all the old teak gone?
description: Gone to U.S. houses, every one.

title: Homes on the Isle of Palms
description: See a handful on quintessential homes built along this   island's seven miles of stunning beachfront.

title: Basic Books Plans New Series of Biographies
description: Basic Books plans to introduce a new series of slim biographies of subjects encompassing Andy Warhols soup cans, the Alfred Hitchcock classic Psycho, and Wagners Ring cycle. Basic Books, an imprint of the Perseus Books Group, plans to announce today that the new series, Basic Ideas, is to begin this fall. David Steinberger, the president and chief executive of Perseus, said he has signed 10 authors so far, including William F. Buckley Jr. (to write about Barry Goldwaters Conscience of a Conservative), Stephanie Coontz (Betty Friedans Feminine Mystique) and Jeff Sharlet (Pete Seegers If I Had a Hammer). Mr. Steinberger said the series would include brief, powerful books by writers with extraordinary insight about significant works.

title: An Entrepeneur Counters the Big-Bank Trend
description: At a time when mergers have reduced the number of banks in the nation, community banking start-ups are gaining favor among entrepreneurs. The New York Times notes that the number of banks in the United States has fallen to 7,402 at the end of last year from 14,411 banks in 1977.

title: Silicon Valley Makes Clean-Tech Pitch to Washington
description: Seeing green in more ways than one, some big names from Silicon Valley on Wednesday urged Washington to double its funding of energy research, The San Jose Mercury New reported. The chief executives and venture investors used a day of meetings organized by TechNet, an organization set up by technology executives, to try and convince members of the Bush administration and Congress, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi, that they need a sustained federal commitment to research, and changes in tax policy to spur the development of clean technology.

title: Bank of America Pays Settlement in Improper Trading Case
description: Bank of America has agreed to pay $26 million to settle charges that its securities unit published fraudulent research reports on companies and failed to prevent leaks of reports that were used for improper trading, federal regulators said Wednesday. With the settlement, Bank of America becomes the last bank to settle an industrywide inquiry into possible conflicts of interest between analysts and bankers and ends a six-year investigation into the companys misuse of its own analysts research.

title: Religion With Guns
description: The Danish writer and director Anders Thomas Jensen's 2005 feature, "Adam's Apples"  about a neo-Nazi sentenced to community service at a rural church run by a sunshine-and-lollipops vicar  is one of the latest examples of the post-"Pulp Fiction" bloody comedy. It's also one of the weirdest, mixing glib humor with dead-serious spiritual inquiry.

title: Goldman Sachs Is Fined $2 Million in a Pattern of Illegal Trading
description: Goldman Sachs was fined $2 million by market regulators Wednesday for allowing clients to make illegal short sales before stock offerings. Goldman did not follow procedures that might have uncovered a pattern of illegal trades from 2000 to 2002, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the New York Stock Exchange said in statements.

title: Hedge Funds Are Blamed for Volatility in Asia
description: The recent volatility and pullback in Asian markets have prompted some investors to sound a familiar refrain: Its all the fault of the hedge funds.

title: Copper Merger Gets Thumbs Up from Shareholders
description: Freeport-McMoRan Copper and Golds $25.9 billion cash-and-stock acquisition of a rival, Phelps Dodge, was approved Wednesday by shareholders of both companies. The deal would create the worlds largest publicly traded copper company. In separate votes by shareholders of Freeport, which is based in New Orleans, and Phelps Dodge, based in Phoenix, the buyout was approved by about 98 percent of the votes cast, the companies said in a joint statement.

title: Berlusconis Mediaset Eyes Endemol Bid
description: Mediaset, the broadcaster controlled by former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, is prepping a bid for Dutch reality TV producer Endemol, the creator of the genre classic Big Brother. Mediasets chief executive, Giuliano Adreani, told journalists that the company is planning a bid with Endemols founder, John De Mol, who sold the company to Spains Telefnica and now wants to get it back.

title: Orphans Searching for Hope
description: "My Brother" is billed as the tale of two poor, orphaned siblings, the aspiring standup comic Isaiah (Nashawn Kearse) and the developmentally disabled James (Christopher Scott). It wants to be much more than that. At times it seems to want to counter 15 years' worth of Mayhem-N-the-Hood stereotypes all by itself, folding in commentary on the theological conundrums involved in accepting Down syndrome as God's will; the bond of Otherness shared by African-Americans and nonwhite Third World citizens; the perils of interracial romance; and the proper social function of standup comedy.

title: Cardboard Maker Raises $1.7 Billion
description: The Smurfit Kappa Group, the worlds largest maker of cardboard boxes, raised 1.3 billion euros ($1.7 billion) Wednesday in Irelands biggest initial public offering in almost eight years. The shares were priced at 16.5 euros apiece, valuing the company at about 3.4 billion euros.

title: Gotta have it!
description: Supersized Superyacht

title: Sale of H&R Block Loan Division May Experience Turbulence
description: Turmoil in the subprime mortgage market may throw a wrench into H&R Blocks plans to sell its subprime mortgage group. While its tax business is showing signs of improvement, H&R Block cannot get rid of its subprime mortgage group, Option One, fast enough. H&R Block disclosed yesterday that its loss widened to $60.3 million in the third quarter as a result of continued problems at Option One, which the company put on the block last year.

title: Merrill May Switch Camps in Alliance Boots Fight, Report Says
description: Merrill Lynch is considering providing debt financing for a private equity group hoping to mount a 9.7 billion pound ($18.8 billion) bid for Alliance Boots, the British drugstore chain, The Guardian reported. Merrills interest in backing a new bid emerged just a day after it quit as Alliance Boots joint broker and two days after Alliance rejected an initial bid of 10 pounds a share from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the deputy chairman of Boots, Stefano Pessina.

title: Macquarie Buys British Car Park Unit from 3i
description: An investment fund of Australias Macquarie Bank has agreed to buy the car-parking facilities of Britains National Car Parks for 790 million pounds ($1.52 billion) from a private equity firm, the 3i Group. 3i will retain NCPs car-clamping and towing services unit following the demerger of the group. NCP operates about 850 car parks with about 50,000 spaces, accounting for more than half Britains off-street parking market, and is the largest provider of spaces at airports and railway stations.

title: S.E.C. Seeking Stock Options Data From L-3
description: L-3 Communications Holdings, a maker of battlefield communications systems, was asked Wednesday by the Securities and Exchange Commission for information on past stock option practices. The company plans to provide the requested material to the agencys enforcement division and will continue to cooperate fully, according to a report it filed with the S.E.C.

title: F.C.C. to Reinstate Pay-TV Ownership Cap
description: After struggling with the issue for more than six years, the Federal Communications Commission is finally making a serious stab at reinstating limits on the audience reach of cable operators and other subscription television providers. Such a move would limit the ability of certain providers to make any large acquisitions in the near future.

title: Potential Jurors in Black Trial Leery of Salaries in the Millions
description: If the first day of jury selection for the former press tycoon Conrad M. Black is any indication, then many in the potential jury pool have not forgotten the corporate scandals of a few years ago. Judge Amy J. St. Eve began the process on Wednesday of winnowing down a pool of more than 100 potential jurors in the criminal fraud trial of Mr. Black and three former associates in United States District Court by asking them about their attitudes toward money, titles and tax loopholes.

title: Rival Bidder Jumps Into Chicago Exchange Deal
description: The IntercontinentalExchange said Thursday that it offered to merge with the Chicago Board of Trade, seeking to derail that exchanges agreement to combine with its hometown rival, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The surprise bid, valued at about $9.9 billion in stock, came just a few weeks before shareholders of CBOT, the parent of the Chicago Board of Trade, were scheduled to vote on its merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Not Effete and Not Abiding
description: The testy relationship between Gov. Eliot Spitzer and Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, veered into nastiness during an argument in the governors office yesterday, just minutes after the two had appeared together at a solemn bill-signing ceremony.It was a spirited discussion between two guys who arent effete, said Darren Dopp, the governors communications director. He said Senator Bruno, the states top Republican, used some vulgarities to describe the relationship between Malcolm A. Smith, a Democrat and the Senate minority leader, and the governors posterior.

title: Why Californias Hewlett-Packard Case Fell Apart
description: As the California attorney generals office dropped charges against Hewlett-Packards former chairwoman, Patricia C. Dunn, and accepted guilty pleas from three other defendants over a spying scandal, pundits are speculating over the reasons why. The most common refrain: The laws at the time did not warrant Ms. Dunns conviction.

title: A Wrap-Up of Fall: Reasons to Rejoice
description: WHEN the fall runway season ended, a week ago Sunday, there seemed more to consider than to sweep aside. Rare was the first-tier show that clanged like an empty pot  and you wouldn't have said that six months ago, when designers conjured up a cross between a Star Trek groupie and an Elvis impersonator. (See Steven Meisel's spread in February Italian Vogue for details.)

title: Maker of Gitanes Cigarettes Receives $15 Billion Offer
description: The tobacco company Altadis said Thursday that it had received an unsolicited approach from the Imperial Tobacco Group of Britain that values the company, which makes Fortuna, Gitanes and Ducados cigarette brands, at 11.52 billion euros ($ 15.21 billion).

title: Bear Stearns Profit Rises 8 Percent
description: Bear Stearns, Wall Streets leading underwriter of mortgage-backed securities, said Thursday that earnings in its fiscal first quarter rose 8 percent from a year ago, but problems in the risky subprime loan sector hurt mortgage-related revenue. The investment bank said net income in the quarter increased to $554 million from $514 million in the year-earlier period.

title: Peltz Cracks Cadbury, Creating Two Potential Targets
description: Nelson Peltz may have broken the record for the time it took for an activist investor to elicit change from a company. Just days after Cadbury Schweppes disclosed that Mr. Peltz had acquired nearly 3 percent of its equity, the company announced Thursday that it would split into two businesses: one focused on drinks, the other on confections.

title: The Difference Between Reno and Gonzales
description: The Washington Post, in an editorial titled The Reno Precedent, rebuts The Wall Street Journals contention that Janet Renos firing of all 93 United States attorneys at the start of Bill Clintons first term is analogous to Alberto Gonzaless firing of eight United States attorneys in the middle of President Bushs second term:

title: Police Shooting in Greenwich Village
description: Pictures from a surveillance video released by the New York Police Department show a gunman attacking two auxiliary police officers.

title: The Moderns
description: A FEW years ago, Douglas McGrath, the screenwriter and director of "Emma" and "Infamous," was having lunch at Michael's with his friend Paul Blake, a producer of contemporary musicals like "Roman Holiday" and "White Christmas." The two were at one of the tables nestled in that restaurant's brightest corner, in the garden of the Rockefeller Apartments, the swankily modernist, bifurcated building whose two undulating facades erupt north onto 55th Street and south onto 54th Street, right across from the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture garden.

title: G.E., Blackstone Strike Deal to Acquire PHH
description: General Electric and the Blackstone Group said Thursday that they would buy PHH, a financial-services and mortgage provider, for $31.50 a share, or $1.8 billion. The price represents a 13 percent premium to PHHs closing stock price of $27.81 on Wednesday. According to the terms of the deal, G.E. Capital will acquire PHH, holding onto the PHH Arval fleet management services unit while selling PHH Mortgage, a residential mortgage servicer, to Blackstone after the transaction closes.

title: Enchanting TED
description: Last week, I attended my second TED conference, which stands for Technology, Entertainment, and Design. During the four-day conference, you hear 50 speakers, who are given 18 minutes each.

title: Cisco to Hook up with Network Software Maker WebEx
description: Cisco Systems said Wednesday that it would buy WebEx, a collaboration-software maker, for $3.2 billion, or $57 a share. The deal is the latest in a string of unusual acquisitions for Cisco, the router giant, which has sought to bulk up on services it can provide over its network hardware.

title: 2008: On the War
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton offered a more layered approach to a military presence in Iraq, in the first in a series of interviews with the 2008 candidates by The Times. Michael Gordon and Patrick Healy parse her positions this way:

title: Who Will Lose Most, Google or Viacom?
description: Viacoms $1 billion lawsuit over YouTube is only the latest indication that Google has no chance of winning a long-term battle against the entertainment industry over copyright law, suggests Dallas Mavericks owner and online video entrepreneur Mark Cuban on his personal blog. Even if Google wins the suit, Hollywood will lobby Congress to change the Digital Millennium Copyright Act, Cuban argues. He writes:

title: Where Chairman Mao Still Sows Revolution
description: It can be easy for the West, its attention necessarily focused on violent extremism of an Islamist nature, to forget that there are other kinds abroad in the world. So when news breaks like the deadly attack on a police station in central India this morning, the identity of the suspected culprits can sometimes bring one up short: Maoists? There are still Maoists?

title: Hot Commodity: CBOT Stock Jumps 15%
description: Has the IntercontinentalExchange sparked a bidding war? Investors seem to hope so. Shares of CBOT Holdings, the parent of the Chicago Board of Trade, rose 15 percent, to $191 in early trading Thursday after Intercontinental, an electronic marketplace for energy trades, announced its offer to merge with the exchange in a $9.9 billion stock swap. The surge put shares of CBOT, which is in the final stages of a merger with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, above the value of Intercontinentals bid, based on an exchange ratio of 1.42 Intercontinental shares for each CBOT share. (That comes out to $186.38 based on Incontinentals recent price of $131.25.)

title: Bloomberg: A Horrible Night
description: NYPD

title: Giuliani on Darfur
description: Several Democratic presidential candidates  particularly John Edwards and Barack Obama  have been outspoken on Darfur. On the Republican side, theres been less interest, aside from Sam Brownback. But Rudy Giuliani weighed in last night in a major speech, and Im hoping hes going to keep up the drumbeat. Obviously pressure from Republicans counts for much more in this White House than calls from Democrats or from hand-wringing op-ed columnists. Heres what Giuliani said:

title: Test Your Math Skills
description: Ive periodically said that the U.S. needs to improve its quantitative skills, because our students are so far behind those abroad in this area. The NY Times published a nice math quiz in which you can see how you measure up. The quiz consists of eight questions that were given Terence Tao, now one of the worlds top mathematicians, shortly before he turned eight years old. One of the questions, for example, was: What angle does the hour hand of a clock describe in 20 minutes?

title: The Rules of the Track
description: The Spitzer administration has sent letters to the six would-be contenders for New Yorks horseracing franchise, outling how the bidding process will work now that the administration has decided to ignore the findings of the Pataki-era Ad Hoc Committee on the Future of Racing, which recommended that Excelsior Racing Associates get the franchise.Proposals are due on March 31, and the contenders will be asked to make public presentations on April 10 and April 11.

title:
Old-Growth
Finds the
New World
description: THE house that Robin Howe and her husband, Andy Grossman, share in Bridgehampton, N.Y., is only a year old, but their living room floor dates back a century. Made of wide-plank teak, the floorboards have "a lived-in feel that is attractive and old and gentle on the feet," said Ms. Howe, a fashion designer.

title: In Queens, Grand Jurors Return
