description: A short while ago, the jurors returned to continue their deliberations about the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell, according to the police bureau of The Times. The grand jury is weighing whether to indict any officers in the fatal shooting of Mr. Bell.

title: F1 drivers all ready for racing
description: Yes, it has finally started, and the Thursday afternoon press conference and a few photos from the track attest to it: the drivers are itching to get on the track, and ready to race. Even the Kimi Raikkonen of Ferrari is looking just like the Kimi Raikkonen of McLaren, as this photo shows. Kimi is an inveterate yawner but never while he is on the track racing, where he frequently makes us all leap out of our chairs rather than tend toward sleep.

title: McCains Back on the Bus
description: DES MOINES  The Straight Talk Express is back on the road today.

title: Enchanting TED
description: Last week, I attended my second TED conference, which stands for Technology, Entertainment, and Design. During the four-day conference, you hear 50 speakers, who are given 18 minutes each.

title: Long Loves Spitzer
description: Michael R. Long, quoting Shakespeares The Tempest, expresses his disapproval this morning with Senate Republicans budget proposal and conditional approval of Gov. Eliot Spitzers own proposal. Mr. Long is the chairman of the states Conservative Party  which, as he reminds us all in his press release, was founded in the 1960s by conservative New Yorkers who felt that the Republican Party had lost its way.Its interesting in the context of the ongoing budget negotiations, in which Mr. Spitzer and the Senate Republicans dont even agree on what their respective proposals actually do: Senate Republicans, through Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader, insist that they are actually cutting money from Mr. Spitzers budget, rather than adding it. Mr. Longs press release backs the governor, suggesting that the Senate Republicans are even more profligate than he thinks the Democrats usually are.

title: Another Departure in Store at UBS?
description: Update: Kenneth D. Moelis will resign from UBS, DealBook reported Monday. Go here for the latest item.

title: Could There Be a Crime in the Firing of Prosecutors?
description: The general assumption in news coverage about the Justice Department/White House firing of federal prosecutors has been that it may have been sleazy, inappropriate and the subject of a cover-up, but that there was nothing illegal about it. Thats probably the case with most of the individuals who were fired.

title: Coach Pitinos Brackets
description: Louisvilles Rick Pitino knows a thing or two about this tournament, winning it with Kentucky in 1996 and reaching the Final Four on four other occasions. His Cardinals are a No. 6 seed, which hardly bothers him: he believes that this is a year when a team seeded fifth or lower can easily capture the tournament.

title: Chicago Merc Says Deal Is Still On
description: Responding to the IntercontinentalExchanges surprise bid for its would-be merger partner, CME Holdings, the parent of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, sounded unruffled Thursday. In a news release, the company said that its $8 billion deal to combine with CBOT Holdings, which runs the Chicago Board of Trade, would proceed as planned, despite Intercontinentals bombshell $9.9 billion offer for CBOT. In a brief statement, the CME said simply this:

title: Will a Palestinian Unity Government Disunite the West?
description: More than a month after promising in their Mecca accord to do so, Hamas and Fatah, the two main Palestinian factions, have reached agreement on a slate of cabinet ministers in a joint unity government for the Palestinian territories. It is to be put to a formal vote of confidence in the Palestinian parliament on Saturday.

title: Harmony Before the Squabble
description: Mr. Spitzer and Joseph Bruno, the Republican majority leader, had their blow-up after the bill-signing and news conference. (Gothamist has the metacoverage.) This morning, Danny Hakim of The Times reported, Some lawmakers also said that Mr. Bruno was angry about which lawmakers were permitted to stand at the lectern and speak during the news conference.

title: Location, Location, Location
description: Of the many obscure, untested and unproved theories that The Bracket will subject you to about the N.C.A.A. tournament, none is better than the Outpost Upset Theory.

title: Espeed: Robert Chapman Is Calling. And Calling.
description: If Robert Chapman is an investor in your company, and he calls you to talk business, he expects a call back.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about competition for Jewish support between Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama incorrectly described Mr. Obamas views about the culpability for stalled peace talks between the Palestinians and Israelis. Mr. Obama blames Hamas, which controls much of the Palestinian government, for the stalled peace talks; he does not blame Israel.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "Talk Radio," "The Attic" and "Moby Dick  Rehearsed."

title: Did a Cat Cancel Lunch?
description: On a day with much breaking and anticipated news, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg had a light schedule to begin with: a speech at the Queens Chamber of Commerces annual St. Patricks Day Luncheon at Terrace on the Park, and no plans to take more questions from reporters.

title: Judith Nathans Appeal
description: Hillary Rodham Clinton has used her spouse as a weapon on the campaign trail. And so has Mitt Romney. A big question hanging over the Giuliani campaign has been whether he would do the same, given the circumstances of his third marriage to Judith Nathan, which followed his headline-grabbing divorce from Donna Hanover.

title: Objections to a Last-Minute Witness
description: State Senator Malcolm A. Smiths district includes the Queens neighborhood where Sean Bell was killed by undercover police officers last year. Senator Smith is also the chambers minority leader, and today he decided to hold a press conference warning of the consequences should a grand jury currently deliberating in the case decide not to hand down any indictments of officers.Mr. Smith stressed that he had no hard information on what the grand jury would do, but said he had been prompted to act by the news that investigators had offered up a last-minute witness who said he saw a man fire a gun at the police.

title: When a DNA Test Shows a Lethal Fate
description: Katharine Moser, who was at risk for Huntington's disease, decided to be tested for the gene that causes it. She now knows she will develop the disorder.

title: Luxury Real Estate in Sarasota
description: Hear from lifestyle designer Adrienne Vittadini and other homeowners in Sarasota on the booming luxury second-home market on Florida's west coast.

title: Turn Out the Lights
description: Im sitting here courtside at the Louisville-Stanford game and thinking about Bruiser Flint, Jim Boeheim and Don Meredith. Flint and Boeheim, the Drexel and Syracuse coaches, each had better teams than Stanford and were shut out of the tournament.

title: CVS Shareholders (But Not Calpers) Approve CVS Deal
description: It may end up being largely symbolic, but Calpers, the countrys biggest pension fund and a major force on corporate governance issues, said it voted its shares against drugstore chain CVSs $23.5 billion acquisition of drug-benefits manager Caremark Rx. Objecting from both sides of the deal, Calpers said it opposed the transaction with its 3.1 million CVS shares and 2.1 million Caremark shares. Nevertheless, CVS shareholders approved the deal Thursday, leaving Fridays vote by Caremark shareholders as the final hurdle.

title: The Other Half of Team Giuliani
description: Over at The Caucus, Gerry Mullany notes that a big question hanging over the Giuliani campaign has been the role of his third wife, Judith Nathan, in the campaign. A video of Ms. Nathan seems to have answered that question.

title: House War Bill: Eat Your Spinach
description: There was no lunch break during the House Appropriations Committee hearing today, but there was plenty of time to talk about spinach.

title: New Yorkers and the Bell Case
description: The Quinnipiac University Poll that showed Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg ahead of Rudolph W. Giuliani in the race for president  at least on their home turf of New York  also had some interesting numbers about New Yorkers view of the Sean Bell case (this was highlighted by Capitol Confidential last night.)The poll found that 57 percent of New York City voters support criminal charges against the officers who killed the unarmed Mr. Bell. (A grand jury in Queens is in its second day of deliberations on the matter, after hearing much evidence not available to people who answer polls.)

title: The Milwaukee Brewers: Turning Off Van Halen
description: Does Ned Yost, the manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, prefer David Lee Roth over Sammy Hagar as the lead singer for Van Halen? As Hagars vocals to When Its Love played over the sound system at Maryvale Baseball Park on Thursday, Yost waved up at the press box and ran a finger across his neck to indicate that he wanted the music turned off.

title: Erin Go Boo
description: City Councilman Miguel Martinez is threatening to deploy a novel weapon in the increasingly testy battle between organizers of the St. Patricks Day Parade and the firefighters they are pushing to the middle of the procession: the boo coalition.According to news reports, John Dunleavy, the chairman of the planning committee, said that he moved the firefighters to the middle because they held up the parade last year allowing firefighters from New Orleans to unfurl a banner thanking New York for its help after Hurricane Katrina and because they show up to the celebration drunk.

title: Its Official: California Sets Feb. 5 Primary Date
description: Californians like a good backdrop, and so perhaps it is no surprise that Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger today chose The Stanford Mansion in Sacramento  the site of the first presidential visit to California in 1880  to sign the bill that officially moves Californias primary from June to Feb. 5.

title: Shootout: What the Bloggers Saw
description: A Brooklyn Life has this account of the Greenwich Village shootout from the vantage point of a Chinese restaurant on Bleecker near Sullivan Street:

title: Clinton Clarifies Remarks on Gays
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton just released this statement on whether homosexuality is immoral, after being pressed by gay rights organizations to clarify her initial remarks.

title: Life and Times of Seth Greenberg
description: Virginia Tech Coach Seth Greenberg cant turn around without seeing a familiar face or a familiar color here at the subregional in Columbus.

title: List: Failing Middle Schools
description: The state education commissioner has added nine New York City schools to a list of those in danger of being closed for academic failure. Eight of the nine are middle schools, a clear sign of the deepening crisis in the quality of education in middle grades in the city.Commissioner Richard Mills announced the moves today, saying that various changes to the list would put the total number of schools under registration review at 65 statewide, 35 of them in New York City. Three schools each were added to the list in Buffalo, Syracuse and Rochester, and one each in Wyandanch and Yonkers. (Eight schools were removed: six in New York City, one in Hempstead, and one in Yonkers.)

title: Performance: Peter Mattei
description: Mr. Mattei performs an aria from "The Barber of Seville."

title: Document: Joining the Auxiliary
description: Auxiliary police officers, like the two men killed in last nights shootout, are volunteers who do not carry guns. They wear uniforms identifical to paid officers, wear badge-like stars and carry nightsticks.

title: Scholarships for Need or Merit? At Hamilton, Need Wins
description: Hamilton College, a smallish but well-regarded liberal arts institution in upstate New York, announced today that it would stop awarding scholarships to students based on merit  that is, academic achievements and qualifications  next year.

title: Meaner Than . . . You Know
description: Around the Winthrop basketball team, it is a compliment to be known as a JunkYard Dog, such an honor that Coach Gregg Marshall presents a doll of a professional wrestler by that name after Eagles victories to the player who is judged to have played the toughest.

title: A Narcissistic Approach to Iraq
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 15 column, The Long Exit.

title: A Long History of Unemployment
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Mar. 15 column, The Danger Zone.

title: ACIE LAW IV/Steve Danley
description: I know we had a story in the paper today about the re-emergence of the number 0 on college jerseys, but for my money Im watching the best name Ive seen in a long time on the back of a jersey. Its sported by Texas A&M point guard Acie Law IV.

title: Ciscos WebEx Deal: Sizzle, Steak or Both?
description: Ciscos acquisition strategy has been a bit of a puzzle lately. The company, best known for making routers that direct network traffic, got Silicon Valley talking earlier this month when it bought the technology assets of Tribe.net, a mostly forgotten social networking site. On Thursday, Cisco announced another offbeat (and much bigger) deal: the $3.2 billion purchase of WebEx, a Web-based video conferencing service.

title: Obama Echoes Clinton on Morality and Gays
description: The campaigns of Barack Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton are in sync not only on the geopolitical importance of Selma, Ala., but also on the issue of whether homosexuality is moral or not. This afternoon, the Obama campaign released the following statement:

title: Update: Back to Deliberations
description: The new last-minute witness in the Sean Bell case testified this afternoon for less than an hour before the grand jury, according to a law enforcement official who spoke on the condition of anonymity.The 23 Queens residents on the grand jury have returned to their deliberations, the official said.

title: J.P. Morgan Adds Energy Banker
description: J.P. Morgan Chase has hired Ian Connor as a managing director in its energy investment banking group, according to an internal memo. Mr. Connor, who was previously at Goldman Sachs, will focus on the power companies when he joins the firm in June. Prior to Goldman Sachs, Mr. Connor was a power and utilities banker at Lazard.

title: Clinton: Homosexualty Not Immoral
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton has issued a statement clarifying her earlier response to a question about the morality of homosexuality, and Barack Obama has also put out a statement, The Caucus reports.

title: Spitzer Protest in Midtown
description: The Intelligencer estimated that thousands of demonstrators were in midtown this afternoon, stepping up the oppoition by unions and others to Gov. Eliot Spitzers health care cuts:

title: Sweets on the Side
description: Until a recent pleasure trip to Chicago, I didnt think it possible to encounter a menu with a category Id never seen before. I didnt think menus could get any more segmented and complicated than they already had.

title: Theres a Baseball Game Tonight?
description: Youd never know it in the Mets clubhouse, where the televisions are tuned to the N.C.A.A. tournament games and players are (jokingly) plotting how to watch the next wave of games if theyre supposed to be in the dugout.

title: Tuberculosis Risk at Bronx Hospital
description: The city Health Department is investigating a case of drug-sensitive tuberculosis in a health care worker who works at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx. Mothers, babies, patients, and staff who were in the maternity, neonatal, or psychiatric units at St. Barnabas from Nov. 1, 2006 to Jan. 24, 2007, may have been exposed and should be screened immediately.

title: Nick the Quick (Talker)
description: The Creighton junior guard Nick Bahe is majoring in journalism and someday dreams of breaking down N.C.A.A. tournament games like Clark Kellogg and Jay Bilas. (For now hell settle for coming off the bench to help the Bluejays advance in the N.C.A.A. tournament against Nevada on Friday.)

title: C.J.s Excellent Adventure, Part 2
description: With spring training more than halfway over now, I thought wed check in again with C.J. Nitkowski, the longtime big league reliever whos embarking on a new career in Japan with the Softbank Hawks. C.J. has agreed to answer some questions here and there throughout the season.

title: Pataki Releases His Iowa Volunteers
description: Iowapolitics.com is reporting: Former New York Gov. George Pataki has told supporters he cannot guarantee he is going to run for president this cycle and has given his blessing for them to join other presidential campaigns. A couple of big names have apparently made the jump to Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts.

title: In Defense of the Faceless Dolts Who Chose the Teams
description: Its worth noting that, without fail, the poor souls charged with the thankless job of choosing the field for the N.C.A.A. tournament are called dolts by just about everybody. Teams that make the tournament feel they should have been granted a better seed, and teams that were seeded No. 1 feel they have the toughest route to the Final Four. But the truly aggrieved, those charged with the fiercest righteous indignation, are those who were left out of the tournament altogether. Last year the anger mobs were from Cincinnati, Michigan, Maryland and Missouri State. (You are forgiven if you didnt remember who the snubs were last year; its possible not even the snubbed teams remember anymore.)

title: Blogtalk: Feuds and Infestations
description: Dunleavys shillelagh. [Gotham Gazette]

title: A Tale of Two Mascots in Columbus
description: Feathers could have been flying here at this N.C.A.A. tournament subregional in Columbus, Ohio. Chief Illiniwek, the college student dressed up to look like an American Indian for Illinois athletic events, and Virginia Techs Hokie, which resembles a turkey, could have been trading barbs in the first-round game.

title: Inside Fatah al Islam
description: An interview with the fugitive Palestinian leader Shakir al-Abssi.

title: Three Envelopes at Home Depot
description: Frank Blake, the new chief executive of Home Depot, is doing his best to come off as the un-Nardelli. The latest episode is his apology to angry customers on MSN Money:

title: Blogtalk: Clintons War Views
description: Theres no question that the views of Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on the Iraq war and how to move forward  to borrow a phrase  light up the keyboards across the blogosphere. Especially on the left, which is still incensed because she wont apologize for her 2002 vote authorizing the use of force in Iraq. No matter how many times she says if she knew then what she knows now, its not good enough (for the anti-war contingent).

title: Life in South Beach
description: The South Beach area of Miami, Fla., is vibrant, sometimes chaotic and always fun.

title: Who Are You Calling a Favorite?
description: Notre Dame is seeded sixth, which should make it the favorite to defeat No. 11 Winthrop in the first round of the East Region on Friday in Spokane. But the Eagles have more recent N.C.A.A. tournament experience than the Fighting Irish, who last qualified in 2003.

title: Butler Sharpshooter Keeps On Shooting
description: In a noisy Butler locker room following Thursdays victory over Old Dominion, forward Pete Campbell looked around the room with a smile, letting it all sink in.

title: A Dying Language
description: Eighteen residents of an isolated village in northeastern China, all over 80 years of age, are the last speakers of Manchu.

title: The Lessons of a Challenging Season
description: There was no bottom for months.

title: Hannah Takes the Stairs
description: A trailer for "Hannah Takes the Stairs," a film by Joe Swanberg.

title: Lights, Camera, Action!
description: Todd Wright is the strength coach for the Texas Longhorns and one of his strengths could one day win him an Oscar nomination. Wright supervises the making of motivational videos for Coach Rick Barnes to show to his players.

title: California's Hidden Buttes
description: A rare glimpse into Sutter Buttes, California. What has always been privately owned land may become the state's newest park.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Barley'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A.O. Scott reviews "The Wind That Shakes the Barley," a film about the Irish uprising of the early 1920s.

title: A Diamond for Davidson
description: When the Davidson freshman shooting guard Stephen Curry fouled out Thursday with 20.9 seconds remaining in his teams 82-70 loss to fourth-seeded Maryland, he received a standing ovation from the crowd of 18,646 at HSBC Arena in Buffalo, N.Y.

title: Bush at G.O.P. Fundraiser
description: President Bush told Republicans tonight that the party can retain the White House and regain control of Congress in 2008, if they hold true to their values.

title: Kellogg: These Tigers Are Slick
description: The Memphis assistant coach Derek Kellogg still looks fit enough to run the point for Coach Cal, just as he did with those great UMass teams from the early 1990s. (Where have you gone, Lou Roe?)

title: McCains Fashion Sense
description: MASON CITY, Iowa  O.K., we have the answer to the question everyone has been asking:

title: Quiet Knight
description: Bob Knight was back in his element once again, making his return to the N.C.A.A. tournament this week after Texas Tech missed the field last season. But he didnt seem very Knight-like courtside at Lawrence Joel Veterans Memorial Coliseum in Winston-Salem, N.C., on Thursday.

title: The 2007-2008 Season for the 21st Century Philharmonic
description: If New York had a full-time symphony orchestra that only played music from the 20th and 21st centuries it might be called the 21st Century Philharmonic and its first season might look something like this:

title: The 2007-2008 Season for the 21st Century Philharmonic
description: If New York had a full-time symphony orchestra that only played music from the 20th and 21st centuries it might be called the 21st Century Philharmonic and its first season might look something like this:

title: Buckeyes Dominate (the TV)
description: The Ohio State fans have left the building and we finally have competitive basketball on the TV: Duke vs. V.C.U.

title: Obamas Boldface Donors
description: Senator Barack Obama was wearing a wide smile tonight as he bounded out of the Senate chamber and rushed to catch a downward elevator. He had little time to spare; a fundraiser for his presidential campaign was soon to begin in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: They Might Have to Name a Candy Bar After Him
description: You knew that New Mexico States Reggie Theus was a different type of college coach when you heard the way his players spoke about him Thursday as they prepared to face Texas on Friday in the opening round of the East Region in Spokane.

title: Its A Small World
description: The Bracket checked in with the N.C.A.A. tournaments most famous almost hero, the former Western Carolina coach Phil Hopkins. Back in 1996, Hopkins 16th-seeded Western Carolina team had two shots at the buzzer  one to win and another to tie  that missed against No. 1 Purdue. A No. 16 seed has never beaten a No. 1, and Hopkins team may have come closest of any of the 90 teams that have tried.

title: Smart Like a Fox
description: Nevada Coach Mark Fox was bummed out that his best friend and former boss, Trent Johnson, got thumped by Louisville in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament on Thursday. Fox said that hed been so wrapped up in his own team that he didnt even realize that Stanford was playing that day. Fox hadnt even looked at a full bracket until this morning.

title: An Old Kentucky Home
description: When people ask how a columnist chooses among the eight sub-regionals in the tournament, I could give a stuffy answer about potential upsets or strength of matchups. The fact is, I whined and begged to come to Kentucky because, in a way, its home. More than three decades ago I was a young news reporter covering this area, and it got a hold on me.

title: Davidson Fills West Wing With Pride
description: The White House press secretary and Davidson alum Tony Snow didnt get to watch all of the 13th-seeded Wildcats 82-70 loss to No. 4 seed Maryland on Thursday, but he saw the games most entertaining action.

title: Rock Ambassadors
description: Foreign bands are gaining an American foothold, as seen at the South by Southwest music festival in Austin., Tex.

title: Hating Duke In North Carolina
description: You could feel the hatred of Duke filling Lawrence Joel Veterans Memorial Coliseum on Thursday night in Winston-Salem, N.C., even though the Blue Devils were hundreds of miles north and playing in Buffalo.

title: The Voice of Experience, but a Frisky Approach
description: When the jazz legend Annie Ross barks out I Got Rhythm, she turns this great Gershwin standard into a hipsters credo. If youve got as much rhythm in your body and music in your head as Ms. Ross does at 76, who indeed could ask for anything more?

title: Igawa Struggles to Find His Trademark Control
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 15  Kei Igawa walked the first two Atlanta Braves he faced on Thursday, so Jorge Posada and Ron Guidry met him on the mound at Legends Field. Igawa speaks little English, and Posada and Guidry speak no Japanese.

title: Grand Jury in Sean Bell Case Stops to Hear From a New Witness
description: The Queens grand jury weighing evidence in the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell interrupted its deliberations yesterday to hear from a new witness, a law enforcement official said.

title: Attack on Sadr City Mayor Hinders Antimilitia Effort
description: BAGHDAD, March 15  Gunmen ambushed a convoy on Thursday that was carrying the mayor of the sprawling Shiite area known as Sadr City, seriously wounding him and complicating American efforts to rein in a powerful Shiite militia there. The attack killed Lt. Col. Muhammad Motashar, the director of the Sadr City police station.

title: In Portland, Ore., Where Trees and Imagination Are Evergreen
description: PORTLAND is one of those friendly, funky cities you move to after college to be within easy striking distance of water, mountains, coffeehouses, brew pubs and like-minded people your age  but it's just as friendly (if slightly less funky) when you have kids of your own in tow.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,189 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: California Joins Move to Earlier Primaries
description: LOS ANGELES, March 15  With a swipe of his pen, some flowery remarks and a good backdrop, Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger moved Californias presidential primary on Thursday to February of next year from June, placing the nations most populous state at the increasingly congested front end of the primary calendar.

title: Earmark Lives, but Dares Not Speak Its Name
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Members of Congress used to know an earmark when they saw one. They used the term to describe any of the favored, parochial expenditures that lawmakers might tuck into a complicated spending bill  $35 million for a Mississippi space center, for example, $25 million for spinach growers or $74 million for peanut farms.

title: The Line on the Revolution, From Those Who Drew It
description: From Revolution to Republic in Prints and Drawings, an excellent and voluminous two-part exhibition at the New York Public Library, explores how journalistic images help shape a nations history in the way they portray military battles and political leaders.

title: AtlanticA
description: WHAT Oceanfront resort and residential development.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: U.N.L.V. Runs Into the Second Round
description: CHICAGO  Georgia Tech averaged more than 79 points a game during the regular season. Nevada-Las Vegas averaged 75. And when the teams looked at one another before their first-round matchup, they saw a lot of themselves. It was enough to expect a fast-paced, made-for-television game.

title: In Tribunal Statement, Confessed 9/11 Plotter Burnishes His Image as a Soldier
description: WASHINGTON, March 15 Above all else, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed considers himself a soldier.

title: Relighting Snuffed Candles
description: The Bush administrations mania for secrecy has been dealt an overdue blow by the House. Significant numbers of Republicans voted with Democrats to reverse the erosion of the publics right to know how its government operates. A package of strong open-government measures would repair some of the damage inflicted in the past six years on laws governing taxpayers access to federal records and presidential archives, while bolstering the standing of whistle-blowers to report abuses in agencies without fear of retaliation.

title: The Battle Over Iraq, in America (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Hospital Worker With TB May Have Exposed 500 Patients
description: An employee at a Bronx hospital has tuberculosis and may have exposed hundreds of patients and co-workers, including more than 200 newborn babies, officials said yesterday. They appealed to people who could have been infected to arrange for testing and treatment.

title: After the Shooting Is Over
description: Jodi Picoults latest topical novel, Nineteen Minutes, takes its title from the duration of a high-school shooting rampage perpetrated by Peter Houghton, a much-bullied New Hampshire teenager. Everyone would remember Peter for 19 minutes of his life, but what about the other nine million? asks Peters mother. Answer: The other nine million will be recapitulated by Ms. Picoult in compassionate, everyday detail  and in what seems like real time.

title: New Pipeline Will Bypass the Bosporus but Involve Russia
description: MOSCOW, March 15  Russia, Greece and Bulgaria signed an agreement on Thursday to build an oil pipeline bypassing the crowded Bosporus in Turkey, a long-debated project that will increase oil supplies to Europe but give Russia control over an important piece of the Continents energy infrastructure.

title: U.N. Council Gets New Draft Decree on Iran Nuclear Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 15  The Security Council received on Thursday a draft of a new resolution to impose sanctions on Iran for its defiance of demands that it suspend its nuclear enrichment activities and return to negotiations over its nuclear program.

title: Real Men in Blue, Who Really Bleed Red
description: City Councilman Charles Barron got one thing right after the unarmed Sean Bell was killed four months ago in a police fusillade. Were not the only ones that can bleed, the ever-helpful Mr. Barron said.

title: New Suitor for Exchange in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, March 15  The Intercontinental Exchange surprised financial markets Thursday by making an unsolicited $10 billion bid to wrest the Chicago Board of Trade away from its planned merger partner, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: Bears Johnson Gets 4-Month Prison Sentence
description: Tank Johnson, the Chicago Bears defensive tackle who needed special permission from a judge to travel to Miami for the Super Bowl after a December police raid on his home, was sentenced yesterday to four months in prison. He was taken into custody immediately, and he also must pay a $2,500 fine.

title: Gunmen in Gaza Fire at Car of U.N. Official
description: JERUSALEM, March 16  In an apparent kidnapping attempt, Palestinian gunmen on Friday fired 14 bullets into the armored car of the Gaza director of the United Nations refugee agency.

title: Wisconsin Survives Scare From 15th Seed
description: CHICAGO, March 16  Wisconsins star forward, Alando Tucker, was asked Thursdayhow to avoid becoming the fifth second-seeded team in history to lose to a No. 15 team in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: In Heart of Village, 4 Lives Intersect in a Chain of Violence
description: The killer who strode into the pizzeria was wearing a black hooded sweatshirt, a Yankees cap and a gray beard that was so obviously phony you could see the glue holding it in place. His black bag concealed a .380-caliber semiautomatic handgun and six magazines holding 90 rounds of ammunition, and in his waistband were a 9-millimeter handgun and clips with more bullets.

title: Bending Toward Elegance With a Virtuosic Efficiency
description: Liszts piano music is something between a mirror and a lie detector. Think flashy and self-serving as you play it, and so it responds. Think better thoughts, and the music transforms itself.

title: Nets Fate May Rest With Jeffersons Play
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 15  As the Nets enter the stretch run, their fate could rest with one of their returning stars, Richard Jefferson, both for his play and his swagger.

title: Bid for Qantas Losing Favor
description: A bid by a private equity consortium to take over Qantas Airways appears to be in trouble after improvements in the airlines earning prospects have left the offer looking inadequate. The Airline Partners Australia consortium, which includes the Texas Pacific Group, Macquarie Bank and Allco Equity Partners, made the takeover bid last year, valuing Qantas at 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.75 billion). At the time, many were surprised that the bidders believed the airline was worth so much, but with recently growing passenger loads and stable fuel prices, that view has changed. The underlying conditions in the airline market have improved and have made the original bid look a bit skinny, said Matthew Crowe, the transportation analyst at JPMorgan in Sydney.

title: They Digress: Books Mentioned in the Article
description: Here is information about the books mentioned in this article.

title: No. 16 Seed Cant Slay Ohio State Goliath
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 15  Before the Central Connecticut State basketball team departed from campus on an admittedly bleak mission, the university president, John Miller, gave some stones to the players. It was supposed to conjure David and Goliath and how the small can fell the mighty.

title: Truth Is Revealed in Bets Rose Didnt Make
description: Pete Rose still cant get it right. He said in a radio interview Wednesday that when he managed the Cincinnati Reds in the 1980s, I bet on my team every night.

title: Between the Precise Layers, a Cultural Narrative
description: IN Philip Taaffes book nothing is ever used up. Any motif, whether man-made or taken directly from nature, can have a new and vital life, with proper placement and adjustments in scale and color, of course. Ditto any technique. This point is driven home by the suavely eye-popping new paintings in Mr. Taaffes latest show at the uptown Gagosian Gallery. They partake of everything from Northwest Coast Indian masks to Islamic ornamental patterns to marbleizing and gilding, and the word recycling doesnt begin to do them justice.

title: Auxiliary Officers Know the Limitations, and the Dangers, When They Volunteer
description: They carry nightsticks but not guns. They wear uniforms but not bulletproof vests underneath, unless they buy the extra protection on their own. They have police radios that buzz with reports of crimes in progress.

title: 2 Democrats Clarify Beliefs About Gays
description: Under pressure from gay rights groups, two rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination, Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama, issued statements yesterday saying they believed homosexuality was not immoral.

title: Manhattan: U.S. Sues State Prison System
description: The Justice Department filed a civil rights lawsuit yesterday against the State Department of Correctional Services, which runs the states prisons. The lawsuit, filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan, claims that the department discriminates by failing or refusing to reasonably accommodate Muslim employees who cannot comply with the departments uniform or grooming rules because of their religion. Last year, a Muslim guard, Abdus Samad N. Haqq, at a work release institution on West 110th Street, filed a lawsuit seeking an order permitting him to wear his kufi, a cap Muslims wear to signal devotion. His case is pending. A spokesman for the state attorney generals office did not respond to a request for comment.

title: President Turns to an Insider to Negotiate on Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  It was hardly a social call when Fred F. Fielding, the new White House counsel, turned up Wednesday afternoon on Capitol Hill.

title: Call for Speed Limit Has German Blood at 178 M.P.H. Boil
description: PFAFFENHAUSEN, Germany, March 14  Ask Marc Bongers about the wisdom of introducing a speed limit on the German autobahn, and he answers by impatiently revving the 435-horsepower engine of a specially modified Porsche. Slowpokes, he said, already spoil half the fun.

title: That Actor Has a Pretty Good Voice
description: Typically, when Rossinis Figaro, the title character of Il Barbiere di Siviglia, first appears and sings his famous aria the Largo al factotum, he is alone. Addressing the audience, he introduces himself. No mere barber, Figaro asserts that he is essential to the functioning of his town. Need a confidential note passed on? A scheme initiated? An eligible husband if you are a debutante; a new husband if you are a widow? Then Im your man, Figaro says. Everyone needs him; everyone calls him.

title: Corruption Charges Keep Opposition Figure Off Nigeria Ballot
description: FREETOWN, Sierra Leone, March 15  A leading opposition candidate in Nigerias presidential election has been omitted from the official list of candidates, which was released Thursday by the Independent National Electoral Commission.

title: A Chance to Hike Californias Hidden Buttes (Maybe)
description: TO motorists traveling on Interstate 5 through the Sacramento Valley of Northern California, the distant Sutter Buttes resemble mountains one might see in a Disney animated movie  a compact cluster of twisted peaks and rounded knobs that rise abruptly above the pancake-flat valley floor.

title: Knicks Struggle to Get the Ball to Curry
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 15  Although it has been the Knicks key to winning all season, Coach Isaiah Thomas found himself screaming at his players Thursday to get Eddy Curry the ball in the post.

title: Green Energy Enthusiasts Are Also Betting on Fossil Fuels
description: Silicon Valleys technology investors have taken to the ramparts, threatening to tear down the oil and gas industries dominance with innovations that use ethanol, solar and wind.

title: Germany Says Hedge Funds Should Devise Conduct Code
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  The finance minister of Germany said Thursday that he favored the development of an internationally accepted code of conduct for the $1.4 trillion hedge fund industry but that it would take the worlds leading economies at least a year to decide how to establish a set of standards.

title: English Lit: Answers to the Questions
description: Based on questions, linked here, from So You Think You Know Jane Austen?

title: Japan Stands by Declaration on Comfort Women
description: TOKYO, March 16  The government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe repeated today that there was no evidence that the Japanese military had forcibly recruited women into sex slavery during World War II.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: World Jewish Congress Dismisses Leader
description: The World Jewish Congress, the small nonprofit group that compelled European banks to pay billions of dollars in Holocaust restitution, has dismissed its longtime leader, Israel Singer, after three years of controversy.

title: Tears for the Loss of Her Alfre, the One Who Had Todo. Todo.
description: Alfredo Romero called Martha Pioquinto on his cellphone about 7 p.m. on Wednesday. It was a routine call between sweethearts: They met years ago when they bumped into each other on a street in Mexico City, and now, sharing a small apartment in Sunnyside, Queens, they doted on one another. Though not married, they called each other husband and wife.

title: Marching With a Mouse
description: There arent a lot of environmental groups with their own investment bank consultants, so when you hear that Environmental Defense has just hired the boutique Wall Street firm Perella Weinberg Partners, you know that were in a new world. Every college activist should study this story, because it is the future. In the old days, when activists wanted something done, they held a sit-in or organized a protest march. Now they hire an investment bank.

title: Art Listings
description: ART

title: Lenders Pay Universities to Influence Loan Choice
description: Dozens of colleges and universities across the country have accepted a variety of financial incentives from student loan companies to steer student business their way, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo of New York announced yesterday.

title: Louisville Routs Stanford
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 15  Louisvilles Derrick Caracter is perhaps one of the most talented freshmen in the country. He may also be one of the most troubled, as the 16 games he missed this season because of suspensions attest.

title: V.C.U. Ousts Duke in First Round
description: BUFFALO, March 15  Eric Maynor made the shot that lifted Virginia Commonwealth and ended Dukes season.

title: Take a Rat to Dinner
description: ITS difficult not to react viscerally to the images  repeatedly shown on television, in newspapers and on YouTube  of rats scurrying about the KFC/Taco Bell restaurant in New York Citys Greenwich Village at night, like villains in a twisted childrens book. Throughout history, after all, rats have been associated with plague and pestilence. From works of literature like Dostoyevskys Notes From Underground to psychoanalytic texts like Freuds case study The Rat Man, the symbolism of rats is uniformly negative. In metaphor, to smell a rat is to sense that something is amiss, and a snitch is called simply a rat. Rats have few fans.

title: French Lick Returns to Its Sin City Roots
description: WE glided on ancient steel rails alongside a clear, slow-moving river, past golden fields and red barns, a canopy of green overhead. The view from the Pullman cars windows looked very much like it did 90 years ago, when Parke Flick used to ride the train with his father, who was on his way to work at the West Baden Springs Resort near French Lick, Ind.

title: Stryker C.E.O. Earns a Grade of 98
description: Stephen P. MacMillan came within a whisker of meeting all of the boards goals for him in his second year as chief executive of the Stryker Corporation, the maker of medical and surgical products, according to the companys annual meeting proxy statement filed today.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Meet Jim Gaffigan. No, Seriously. Stay After the Show and Meet Him.
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 12  When Jim Gaffigan ended his 75-minute stand-up set here Sunday night at a sold-out 2,000-seat theater, the real show was, arguably, only beginning.

title: New Jersey Assembly Approves a Bill to Hold Presidential Primary Earlier
description: TRENTON, March 15  The Assembly voted on Thursday to move New Jerseys presidential primary up to Feb. 5 in an effort to have more say in who runs for president, although some political experts say so many states have joined the stampede that it might be better to hold it later.

title: 3 Detectives to Be Indicted by Grand Jury in Bell Case
description: A Queens grand jury voted today to indict three city police detectives  two black men and a white man  in the killing of Sean Bell, an unarmed 23-year-old black man who died in a hail of 50 bullets in November, a defense lawyer in the case said.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about Shane MacGowan of the Pogues misspelled the title of a song by the band. It is Sally MacLennane, not Sally MacLennan.

title: Living With Autism: The Teenage View
description: Autism, an enigmatic disorder of the central nervous system, excites an unusual kind of curiosity. The curiosity, it should be said, includes no small part of outright identification. After all, the disorders signature behaviors  shrieking, retreating, acting obsessively or withdrawn  are familiar to many of us in extremis, or at least in adolescence.

title: A Concept, a Host, an Island and People Who Eat People?
description: Dont fool yourself. Any brilliant idea you might have for a reality television series has probably already been imagined and pitched by go-getters like Dave Roberts and Gil S. Ripley, the hotshot comedy-writing team observed peddling their dubious wares in the documentary American Cannibal. As the movie observes them tossing around outlandish concepts, then trying to interest jaded cable network executives in their trashy ideas, you are tempted to wonder if the documentary, directed by Perry Grebin and Michael Nigro, is a put-on.

title: As Asian Art Becomes a Citywide Attraction
description: Despite the increasing number of dealers in Asian art at the European Fine Art Fair in the Netherlands  there were 17 dealers this year compared with 11 a decade ago  no fair can compete with the International Asian Art Fair in New York, which opens next Friday and runs through March 28. Begun in 1996, the fair has spawned two weeks of events: Another fair, the Arts of Pacific Asia Show, Asian art sales at Sothebys and Christies, smaller auctions at Doyle and Bonhams, and gallery exhibitions all over town.

title: Winthrop Drops Irish in First Round
description: SPOKANE, Wash. -- Notre Dame came to the N.C.A.A. tournament early, played early and left early as the Winthrop Eagles upset the Fighting Irish, 74-64, in a first-round game filled with drastic shifts of momentum at Spokane Arena.

title: Penn Conjures the Spirit of Past Ivy League Teams
description: Lexington, Ky.

title: The New, Old Leopard
description: Again and again, we are reminded that there are new species to be found in this world, in numbers we can barely begin to guess. Sometimes they are discovered thanks to painstaking investigation of biological hot spots, like the Eastern Arc Mountains of Tanzania or the equatorial rain forest in the Heart of Borneo. And sometimes new species are discovered through a closer look at creatures whose existence is already well known. That is what has happened with the clouded leopard of Borneo. Evolutionary common sense would suggest that this leopard  an island inhabitant, after all  might well be a species all its own, distinct from its mainland relatives. Genetic tests at the federal National Cancer Institute have confirmed that fact.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a white Missouri man and a black Harlem woman who found out through genetic testing that they were related referred imprecisely to the given name of a performer who entertained during a New York family reunion. She goes by Cissy Houston, not Emily. (She was born Emily Drinkard.)

title: Lives Intersect Violently on a Busy City Street
description: They werent cops cops. They werent sons of police officers, born with blue in their blood, like many in the New York City Police Department. They didnt even tell some people about their jobs. Bookish, even nave young men, each brought an eccentric back story to his role as an auxiliary police officer, and to their partnership on the street.

title: Vanderbilt Rains 12 3-Pointers Over George Washington
description: SACRAMENTO, March 15  N.C.A.A. tournament games, and specifically first-round games between No. 6 and No. 11 seeds, are known for being close and competitive.

title: Mine Unions Report on the Sago Disaster Contradicts Earlier Findings
description: CHARLESTON, W.Va., March 15  Sparks generated inside the Sago Mine by friction between falling rocks, or between the rocks and metal roof supports, were the likely cause of the methane gas explosion early last year that killed one miner and led to the asphyxiation of 11 others whom the blast trapped, a report by the United Mine Workers of America maintains.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article yesterday about antiwar legislation in Congress misidentified the Senate majority leader in some copies. He is Harry Reid of Nevada, second-from-left, not Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, left. (They were among four Democratic senators shown preparing remarks.) (Go to Article)

title: Subject of C.I.A. Leak Testifies on Capitol Hill
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Valerie Plame Wilson testified today that the career she loved as an undercover C.I.A. agent was over in an instant when her role was disclosed in the summer of 2003.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Tuesday about strategies used by successful players in last years ESPN.com Tournament Challenge basketball contest referred incorrectly to the number of brackets submitted in the game. It was more than 3 million, not 750,000.

title: Boobies and Their Buddies: Real Stars of Darwins Turf
description: The males bite each others necks and draw blood, the narrator says, but thick layers of fat mostly prevent serious injury.

title: History of Hernia Patch Raises Questions on Implant Recalls
description: How do makers of implanted medical devices react when one of their products starts breaking?

title: Imperial Tobacco Makes $15 Billion Bid for Spanish Rival
description: MADRID, March 15  Imperial Tobacco, a British cigarette maker, confirmed Thursday that it had made a 11.5 billion euro ($15.2 billion) takeover bid for Altadis, its Madrid-based rival.

title: Manhattan: City Contractor Charged
description: A building contractor working for the City Sanitation Department was accused yesterday of filing false records with the city certifying that he had hired a local subcontractor, the Department of Investigation said. The contractor, Chaudhry Ali, 43, president of Shawn Construction, was charged with criminal possession of a forged instrument, said Rose Gill Hearn, the commissioner of investigation. He had not yet appeared in court yesterday afternoon, prosecutors said. Ms. Gill Hearn said Mr. Ali was required to subcontract a certain portion of a roofing contract to a local company, and falsely certified that a Brooklyn company had done the work. She said the Brooklyn company was unaware that it had been identified as the subcontractor and did not perform the work.

title: A Happy Housewife Does the Time Warp, and Madness Ensues
description: Blind faith that all will be revealed can keep you glued to a movie long after the arrival of that sinking feeling that none of what youre seeing can possibly add up. As you watch Premonition, a psychological thriller that scrambles time in the life of a desperate housewife, you imagine that the director, Mennan Yapo, and the screenwriter, Bill Kelly, must have some notion of where theyre heading, so you suspend your doubts, invest your emotions and go along for the ride. After all, arent these Hollywood professionals who know something about storytelling? And didnt a major star (Sandra Bullock) sign on to the project?

title: Curators Husband Guilty in Thefts From the Hermitage
Wholesale Inflation Surged in February
description: The governments measure of inflation at the producer level rose sharply in February, reflecting a broad increase in prices on everything from gasoline to cigarettes.

title: Redressing F.B.I. Abuses (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: For Snowboarders, Style Still Trumps Spins
description: STRATTON, Vt., March 15  The 1260 is the next revolution in snowboarding  literally  after a 1080-degree spin (three full rotations), which was a money trick at the Winter Olympics last year.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A museum review on Saturday about the U.S.S. Monitor Center in Newport News, Va., misidentified the site where the Monitor was built. It was the Continental Iron Works in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, not the Brooklyn Navy Yard. (The ship was outfitted and commissioned at the yard.)

title: A Lawyer Like a Hurricane
description: PASCAGOULA, Miss.  Richard F. Scruggs, one of the countrys most successful trial lawyers, made his first fortune in a case that hit close to home. He sued asbestos makers on behalf of workers at the shipyard in his hometown, Pascagoula, who had developed lung diseases. He made his second fortune with lawsuits against the tobacco industry, coming up with a winning legal strategy in Mississippi that he then applied nationwide.

title: Zimbabwe: Go Hang, Mugabe Tells Critics
description: President Robert G. Mugabe dismissed international condemnations of his governments violent assaults on opposition members, saying of his Western critics, They can go hang. Speaking after a meeting with Tanzanias president, Jakaya Mrisho Kikwete, Mr. Mugabe, left, said Western governments ignored violent acts by the opposition Movement for Democratic Change in favor of criticizing his regime when it tries to prevent violence. The police beat at least 50 protesters when they tried to hold a meeting on Sunday; many, including the leader Morgan Tsvangirai, were hospitalized.

title: Rat-Filled Beats Historic, So City Offices Move Out
description: OPA-LOCKA, Fla., March 12  The desert-yellow walls of the old City Hall rise rippled and pockmarked to pink domes and narrow minarets. Decorative peaks like tiny staircases top the barrier walls. A pointed pink-and-white archway frames the view down to Ali-Baba Avenue, the main road through a city once called the Baghdad of the South.

title: Britain: Luxury Home Prices Rise
description: Luxury home prices in London rose at an annual rate of 31 percent in February, the fastest pace in 28 years. The average price of Londons most expensive houses and apartments gained 2.6 percent on a monthly basis, according to data compiled by Knight Frank, a real estate broker based in London. Prices in central London have for the past two years been growing at three times the rate of the rest of Britain, said Liam Bailey, the partner in charge of residential research at Knight Frank.

title: After Slow Start, Bruins Flex Their Muscle
description: U.C.L.A. Coach Ben Howland is famously organized and meticulously prepared, creating his practice schedule months in advance and generally resisting any temptation to change it.

title: Ex-Internet Tycoon in Japan Guilty of Fraud
description: TOKYO, Friday, March 16  Takafumi Horie, the 34-year-old Internet tycoon once heralded as a symbol of new capitalism in Japan, was found guilty Friday morning by the Tokyo District Court of violating securities laws at his company, Livedoor. He was sentenced to two years and six months.

title: Sharp Rise in Producer Prices Shows Inflation Still Hangs Over Economy
description: Prices rose broadly and sharply for businesses in February as an array of goods, from childrens toys to tobacco, became more expensive.

title: A Solemn Journey to Mali Gets Under Way
description: Five victims of last weeks deadly fire in the Bronx were carried out of an East Harlem funeral home this morning in four plain wooden boxes and escorted to Kennedy International Airport in black hearses, the first leg of their journey back to Africa.

title: New Face of Jihad Vows Attacks
description: TRIPOLI, Lebanon  Deep in a violent and lawless slum just north of this coastal city, 12 men whose faces were shrouded by scarves drilled with Kalashnikovs.

title: Cadbury to Separate Drinks and Candy Businesses
description: LONDON, March 15  Cadbury Schweppes, the British maker of Dr Pepper soft drinks and Dairy Milk chocolate, said Thursday that it planned to split off its American beverage unit from its candy businesses, following pressure from shareholders, including the billionaire Nelson Peltz.

title: A Huge Hole in Airport Security
description: While enormous effort is focused on screening airline passengers for explosives or weapons before they can board a commercial flight, it remains shockingly easy for airport employees to sneak into secure areas and carry dangerous materials onto a plane without detection. That frightening truth was underscored by a flagrant breach of security at the Orlando Airport in Florida last week that was detected only because of an anonymous tip.

title: Near Charleston, Two Spots Where Life Is Quiet and Quieter
description: WHEN Julian H. Baumann and his wife, Karen, set off on their quest to buy a vacation home two years ago, they started in Myrtle Beach, S.C., then drove south toward Savannah, Ga., sizing up beach communities along the way. When they came upon Isle of Palms, a barrier island 15 miles east of Charleston, S.C., they stopped looking.

title: Confession at Guantnamo by 9/11 Mastermind May Aid Other Qaeda Defendants
description: The admissions made by the mastermind of the Sept. 11 attacks illuminated and transformed the cases against him and the 13 other Qaeda leaders transferred last year from C.I.A. prisons to the Navy base at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba.

title: Inflation Rose in February
description: A rebound in energy prices pushed inflation higher in February, suggesting that a weakening economy has not yet taken much pressure off rising prices, as the Federal Reserve has long hoped.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the winners of the Intel Science Talent Search referred incorrectly to the 40 finalists. There were 20 women and 20 men; they were not almost equally divided by sex  as were the top 10, which included six women. Because of an editing error, the article also misstated the night the winners were announced. It was Tuesday, not Monday.

title: Massachusetts: Aide to Governors Wife Resigns
description: A woman whom Gov. Deval L. Patrick hired as chief of staff for his wife, Diane, has resigned less than a week after it was disclosed that Mrs. Patrick was being treated for depression and exhaustion. The woman, Amy Gorin, who with her husband led fund-raising for Mr. Patricks campaign for governor, was appointed to the $72,000-a-year position last month. Mr. Patrick also announced that he was hiring a senior aide to the State Senate president, Robert E. Travaglini.

title: A Weak Hitter, but With the Muscle to Ban Metal Bats
description: IT seems a perverse coincidence that James S. Oddo, the crusading New York City councilman and self-identified boy-of-summer behind the Councils decision on Wednesday to ban metal bats from high school baseball in the city, was stymied in his own sporting past by a pathological fear of curve balls. As a kid on Staten Island, he couldnt hit them. No way would he end up on the Mets.

title: Japan: Airlines Office Raided in U.S.
description: The All Nippon Airways Company had its offices in Los Angeles searched for nine hours yesterday by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, according to a statement from the carrier. The FBI declined to say why the office was searched. We dont know why they raided the office, but we confirmed with our staff there that it wasnt anything to do with the operation of the aircraft or terrorism, a spokesman at All Nippon, Rob Henderson, said. The customer service center in Los Angeles is the headquarters of the airlines North American operations and is responsible for passenger and cargo sales for the western and southern United States.

title: White Plains: Student Sentenced for Forgery
description: A former Pace University student was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to five years of probation and 100 hours of community service after he admitted making fake drivers licenses, prosecutors said. The student, William Gerhard, 20, of Yorktown, pleaded guilty to second-degree forgery in November, said Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. Ms. DiFiore said Mr. Gerhard made and sold New Jersey drivers licenses out of his dorm room. She said the licenses were sold to students, who mainly used them to buy alcohol.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: The Greenness of Al Gore (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gunman Was Aspiring Filmmaker With Pent-Up Hostility and a Rsum of Failures
description: David R. Garvins first brush with New York City came at a time when his life was already drenched in personal and professional failure. It ended in May 2005 with a collapsed career in the production department of The Wall Street Journal.

title: Far From Inevitable, McCain Retunes 2008 Engine
description: MASON CITY, Iowa, March 15  Senator John McCain of Arizona worked hard for years to make himself the all-but-inevitable 2008 Republican presidential nominee, assembling a formidable machine of advisers and contributors, repairing his relationship with the Bush White House and reaching out to conservatives long wary of his views.

title: Antonio Ortiz Mena, 99, Mexican Finance Minister in 1960s, Dies
description: MEXICO CITY, March 15  Antonio Ortiz Mena, who as Mexicos finance minister in the 1960s was the architect of a period of remarkable growth known as the Mexican miracle, died on Monday. He was 99.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on March 6 about Thomas DiBiagio, who said that he was forced out as the federal prosecutor in Maryland in 2005 because of political pressure stemming from investigations involving associates of then Gov. Robert Ehrlich Jr., referred incorrectly to the office Mr. Ehrlich held in 2001, when he recommended Mr. DiBiagio for appointment. He was a Republican member of Congress. He was not Marylands sole statewide Republican officeholder.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: SECOND HOMES ON DISPUTED LAND

title: People
description: People

title: Voyages to the Islands, Both Real and Imaginary
description: Steven Blier and Michael Barrett have created a cottage industry out of the art song repertory  with occasional forays into popular song  by presenting thematic programs closer in spirit to old-fashioned salon evenings than to modern recitals.

title: The Price Is Right, So Skiers Are Rediscovering Some Old Slopes
description: AT a management meeting early this month, Glenn Godsey was presented with the immediate business forecast for his recently purchased property, Tuxedo Ridge, a once-defunct ski area about 40 miles northwest of New York City.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article yesterday about antiwar legislation in Congress misidentified the Senate majority leader in come copies. He is Harry Reid of Nevada, second-from-left, not Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, left. (They were among four Democratic senators shown preparing remarks.)

title: Romney Candidacy Puts Massachusetts Economy in Spotlight
description: BOSTON, March 14  When Mitt Romney became governor of Massachusetts in 2003, the state had a budget gap of almost $3 billion and was losing thousands of jobs a month.

title: One Proposal for Tribune Said to Lose Momentum
description: As a March 31 deadline nears for deciding the fate of the Tribune Company, the proposal from Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate billionaire, is falling from favor, according to people close to the situation.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Korean Publisher Withdraws Anti-Semitic Comic

title: Long Live Punk and Patti (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Young Actress Is Taken In, and Then the Tables Turn
description: The casting couch is as old as the theater, and the movies only expanded the ways for producers, directors, writers or even stage managers and key grips to lure star-struck young actresses or actors onto it. It still claims its victims, and The Director, a new play by Barbara Cassidy at the Flea Theater, is the story of one. Well, several, to be exact.

title: A Dream of Sleep (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about the shooting of a New York City police officer in a gunfight with a suspect misspelled the officers surname in some copies. He is Officer Robert Tejada, not Tejeda.

title: China Backs Property Law, Buoying Middle Class
description: BEIJING, Friday, March 16  After more than a quarter-century of market-oriented economic policies and record-setting growth, China on Friday enacted its first law to protect private property explicitly.

title: Feathered Neighbors
description: WHO Ted Lee Eubanks, 56, owner of a nature tourism company, from Austin, Tex. WHAT 3-bedroom house WHERE Galveston, Tex.

title: White House Now Unsure if Firings Were Mierss Idea
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  The White House backed away today from its earlier assertions that the former White House counsel, Harriet E. Miers, was alone in hatching the idea to fire United States attorneys early in 2005.

title: True to Their School, but Lately Just Left of the 72nd Hole
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 15  Seven days apart in Florida, two graduates of Milton High Schools class of 1992 stood on the 18th green at a PGA Tour event plotting a path to victory.

title: Truth, Confessions and Torture (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ablaze in Swirls of Amber Grain
description: While van Gogh was a patient at an asylum in Saint-Rmy, France, a year before his suicide in 1890, he produced a colorful landscape, The Wheat Field Behind St. Pauls Hospital. That painting is said to be the first van Gogh to enter a museum.

title: Just Like Life, With Quiet Journeys and Cosmic Whirls
description: One of Paul Taylors great gifts is his ability to create a world in which movement and mood mirror the truths of life: its absurdity, its beauty and austerity, and even its ugliness. On Wednesday night at City Center Mr. Taylors expansive vision was particularly entrancing in a program that opened with Airs, a masterwork from 1978 that takes seven dancers on a tranquil, free-flowing journey.

title: Defense Helps Butler Advance Past Old Dominion
description: BUFFALO, March 15  Turning a close game at halftime into a convincing victory, Butler defeated Old Dominion, 57-46, Thursday afternoon in a Midwest Region first-round game at HSBC Arena. Butler (28-6), seeded No. 5, will face No. 4-seed Maryland in a second-round game Saturday afternoon.

title: Washington State Savors Opening Victory
description: SACRAMENTO, March 15  The typical No. 3 seed contends for its conference championship every season, advances to the N.C.A.A. tournament almost every year and views first-round games as minor irritants, to be endured rather than enjoyed.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Wal-Mart Drops Bid to Operate Its Own Bank
description: Wal-Mart said today that it has abandoned plans to open its own bank, a reversal prompted by what the retailer said was manufactured controversy surrounding the proposal.

title: Big Deficit Seen in New Jersey Pension Fund
description: A prominent member of the council that oversees investments by New Jerseys pension funds said yesterday that the state has been vastly underestimating how much money it should have to pay for retirement benefits that have been promised to employees.

title: The Dandy Who Helped Mr. Arnold Turn His Coat Inside Out
description: Plenty of playwrights try to draw parallels between Americas past and present. So it can take a minute watching Andr, a play about the Revolutionary United States that opened on March 10 at the Metropolitan Playhouse, to remember that this is not a stilted look back at history through the lens of hindsight. Andr is the story of the British officer who helped Benedict Arnold to turn his coat. It was written in 1798, when the events it dealt with were still fresh, and the question of how the Republic should behave in wartime was crucial to the still-forming identity of a new nation. Plus a change. ...

title: Do You Know Where Your Slogan Is?
description: MADISON AVENUES ability to contribute phrases to the vernacular has always been prized as a way to amplify the voice of an advertising campaign.

title: India Maoists Kill 49 in Raid on Police Post
description: NEW DELHI, March 15  Suspected Maoist rebels stormed a police post in the heavily forested center of India early Thursday morning, killing nearly 50 officers and their recruits from a village militia. The attack was one of the biggest since the resurrection of armed leftist rebellion in the last several years.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports headline in some copies yesterday about the Phoenix Suns 129-127 victory in double overtime against the Dallas Mavericks misstated the games outcome. Steve Nash and the Suns outdueled Dirk Nowitzki and the Mavericks, not the other way around.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about the close ties between Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and President Bush misidentified President John F. Kennedys brother, the attorney general from 1961 to 1964 and one of President Kennedys closest advisers. It was Robert F. Kennedy, not his son Robert F. Kennedy Jr.

title: Phony Fraud Charges
description: In its fumbling attempts to explain the purge of United States attorneys, the Bush administration has argued that the fired prosecutors were not aggressive enough about addressing voter fraud. It is a phony argument; there is no evidence that any of them ignored real instances of voter fraud. But more than that, it is a window on what may be a major reason for some of the firings.

title: A Day of Slaloms and Slices
description: THE notion of skiing in the morning and golfing the same afternoon usually reflects wishful thinking  or the convenience of a private jet. For a brief window in mid to late spring, however, weather conditions can converge in mountain spots to allow this elusive combination, and some resorts take advantage of it by holding annual ski-and-golf tournaments. The entrants vary in skill level and competitive drive, but all are in search of the ultimate day of recreation.

title: Faculty Members Queried About State Senators Work Record
description: The 440 faculty members at the Camden campus of Rutgers University received e-mail messages this week from an associate provost asking questions about the activities of State Senator Wayne R. Bryant, the embattled legislator who collected up to $35,000 a year for four years to lecture at the law school there but who records say hardly did so.

title: Memphis Avoids Upset by North Texas
description: NEW ORLEANS  The 15th-seeded North Texas basketball team had all the warm-and-fuzzy trappings of an N.C.A.A. tournament upstart heading into their game with No. 2 Memphis on Friday.

title: Coroner Rules Death of British Soldier in Iraq Unlawful
description: LONDON, March 16  A British soldier who died four years ago after an American pilot opened fire on his convoy in Iraq was killed unlawfully, a coroner ruled today.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: To Guide a Student (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Latin Rock Reconvenes, and It Means Business
description: Its hard to believe that Man, the enormously popular Mexican rock band, has been together since 1986, give or take a few lineup changes. Its show at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday  one of two, both sold out  seemed more like the work of a band recently convened by supermanagers in order to be attached to advertising. The four handsome core members didnt evince much chemistry, no inside jokes; they hardly interacted. The show was tight as a drum, stripped of longeurs and entertaining, in a businesslike way.

title: Big Changes at Big Sur
description: DRIVERS passing through Big Sur on Highway 1 between Los Angeles and San Francisco are inevitably awed by the duel of sea and sky played out against the rugged Santa Lucia Mountains. Indeed, the pristine slopes facing Highway 1, a designated American National Scenic Byway, are some of the most rigidly protected in the country, guarded by a phalanx of agencies that range from the Monterey County Resource Management Agency to the California Coastal Commission.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 15, 2007

title: OPEC Says It Wont Increase Output
description: VIENNA, March 15  Ignoring concerns over slowing economic growth, slightly volatile stock markets and a softening housing market in the United States, OPEC ministers said on Thursday that they would keep oil production at current levels.

title: Judge Bars a Buyout Vote at Netsmart
description: WILMINGTON, Del., March 15 (Dow Jones/AP)  A Delaware judge has barred Netsmart Technologies from polling shareholders on a $115 million offer to sell out to private equity firms until it tells investors more about how the software company was shopped.

title: Bowie Kuhn, 80, Former Baseball Commissioner, Dies
description: Bowie Kuhn, the commissioner of baseball during a tumultuous 15-year period when the game experienced dramatic growth accompanied by unprecedented labor strife, died yesterday at a hospital in Jacksonville, Fla. Kuhn, who lived in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla., was 80.

title: Sorting Through a Trove of European Treasures
description: HARTFORD  In 1917 the Wadsworth Atheneum here made a haul that set it on the road to greatness: 1,325 European objects from the collection of the financier J. P. Morgan, a Hartford native and one of the countrys most spectacular acquisitors of money and art. The gift, made by Morgans son and heir, Jack, meant a giant step forward for the Wadsworth in the field of European old master art.

title: Off the Mean Streets, Into the Gym
description: CHICAGO, March 15  Sherron Collins was only a fourth-grader, which was not so long ago for someone who is 19. People in the neighborhood would come here, to the cramped gym at a Boys & Girls Club to watch him play. And little Sherron would dazzle them. The cheering from the three-row metal bleachers would silence the gunshots and the sirens and the trouble outside.

title: Iraqi Inmates Escape From British Military Prison
description: BAGHDAD, March 17  Ten inmates at a British military internment facility in Basra used an audacious plan to escape over the past several days by switching places with visitors who had come to visit the facility.

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: For Officers in the Aftermath, a Time for Vigilance, Reflection and Sorrow
description: Ricardo Mantilla, a transit police officer, walked his beat on a subway platform as usual yesterday, keeping his ears and eyes open. But something had changed.

title: Hamas-Fatah Coalition Misses Wests Goals
description: JERUSALEM, March 15  The Hamas-led Palestinian government, boycotted by the West since its election more than a year ago because of Hamass support of terrorism, announced Thursday a unity coalition with the more moderate Fatah movement in hopes of ending the boycott.

title: Rove Is Linked to Early Query Over Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  Karl Rove, the senior presidential adviser, inquired about firing United States attorneys in January 2005, e-mail messages released Thursday show. The request prompted a Justice Department aide to respond that Alberto R. Gonzales, soon to be confirmed as attorney general, favored replacing a group of underperforming prosecutors.

title: A Game With New Tricks for an Old System
description: When I was growing up, my friends and I lamented that no matter where we went, it seemed that the best stuff wouldnt happen until we were about to leave. You spend a couple of weeks at summer camp and only in the final days do you realize that the counselors leave a certain very important door unlocked. And you think, Wow, this is awesome; but why couldnt it have been this way the whole time?

title: A Band Takes a Bigger Stage to Show How Far Its Come
description: All right, said James Mercer of the Shins on Wednesday night, sounding slightly awed. Madison Square Garden. Even my parents have heard of this place.

title: G.M. Says It Has Found Serious Flaws in Accounting
description: DETROIT, March 15  General Motors, a company once known as the model of corporate accounting, warned investors on Thursday that its performance was threatened by ineffective controls over financial reporting, including inadequately trained personnel and failure to obtain managements approval for some transactions.

title: Heat Shows Nets How to Survive a Season of Injuries
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 15  The injury woes that have plagued the Nets this season seem all but irrelevant compared with what the Miami Heat has been through.

title: Virginias Unrelenting Defense Upends Albany
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio  There was not a safe spot on the floor for Albanys Jamar Wilson. His first shot was a wild fling at the hoop on a reverse layup after three Virginia players ran at him. His next shot had no chance, nor did his third shot, a 6-footer through a maze of hands in his face.

title: 2 Financial Institutions Find Common Cause in New York
description: As they sat down for breakfast six months ago, there would have seemed to be plenty of differences between E. Stanley ONeal and Deborah C. Wright. He heads Merrill Lynch, one of Wall Streets largest firms, while she leads Carver Federal Savings Bank, the countrys largest black financial institution, but a fraction of Merrills size.

title: The Sky Is Falling. Really.
description: Tiburon, Calif.

title: Youve Read the Novels (Now Read the Footnotes)
description: Furze is a plant found all over England. It covers Egdon Heath, the forbidding wasteland in Thomas Hardys Return of the Native, and when I first read the novel, many years ago, I conjured up a vivid and completely inaccurate picture of what it looked like. I envisioned furze as a tangle of bare, black and gnarled stalks  a bonsai version of the leafless evil trees in Walt Disneys Snow White. In fact furze is the same plant as gorse, the yellow-flowered shrub that Winnie-the-Pooh falls into. My reading was factually false but imaginatively true to the spirit of Hardys bleak, oppressive landscape.

title: Neighbor Leaves Singapore Short of Sand
description: SINGAPORE  Some countries have strategic oil reserves; others stockpile rice or wheat. The island nation of Singapore has emergency reserves of imported sand.

title: Senate Rejects Democrats Call to Pull Troops
description: WASHINGTON, March 15  The Senate on Thursday rejected a Democratic resolution to withdraw most American combat troops from Iraq in 2008, but a similar measure advanced in the House, and Democratic leaders vowed to keep challenging President Bush to change course in Iraq.

title: Small White Wonders and Other Delicacies
description: Sometimes all it takes to rivet the eye is a large assembly of small, tenderly made, exquisitely expressive objects.
