The latest proof is Incisive Images: Ivory and Boxwood Carvings, 1450-1800, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, an intimate display of nearly 100 carved figures, crucifixes, reliefs, containers, hand-held weaponry and the occasional piece of furniture. Made of ivory or boxwood, all come from the museums collections, and last Friday night they were stopping traffic even before the show was officially open.

title: Future of UBS Executive Part of Wall Street Chatter
description: Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBSs investment bank in New York, is threatening to leave the firm, according to people briefed on the matter.

title: Groups in Brazil Aim to Call Military Torturers to Account
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  Frustrated by their own governments timidity but encouraged by recent court rulings in Argentina and Chile, Brazilian human rights groups are seeking to overturn an amnesty for human rights abuses that went into effect in 1979, when a right-wing military dictatorship ruled this nation.

title: Serving His Country, Then Serving His Team
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 15  At Marine boot camp in Parris Island, S.C., Rich Young could handle 4:30 a.m. wake-ups, three-mile runs and 10-mile hikes lugging a 75-pound pack on his back.

title: B.C.s Front Court Leaves Knight a Dollar Short
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., March 15  Of all the upset possibilities in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, No. 7 Boston College figured to be an easy mark. The Eagles came into the tournament having lost five of seven games and were without their starting center, who was dismissed from the squad in January for breaking team rules.

title: Report Says Public Schools in California Are Broken
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 15  A scathing 18-month evaluation of Californias public schools has concluded that the states educational system is broken, crippled by a complex bureaucracy, flawed teacher policies and misspent school money, leaving it in need of sweeping reforms that could cost billions of dollars.

title: English Wit: Questions From So You Think You Know Jane Austen?
description: It takes a close read of Pride and Prejudice to answer these questions from So You Think You Know Jane Austen? (Answers, linked here, can be covered at the quiz takers discretion.)

title: Japan: Nissan Plans Production Cuts
description: Nissan Motor plans to cut production at two plants in Japan from April 2 until the end of June because of weaker demand. Nissan will cut a shift on a production line in Kanagawa and in Tochigi Prefectures, a spokesman, Yuichi Nakagawa, said. Each plant has two lines. The plant in Kanagawa makes subcompacts like the March, and the Tochigi plant builds Skyline sedans and other vehicles. Nissans domestic vehicle sales, excluding minicars, fell for a 17th straight month in February.

title: Canada: Blackout on Early Vote Results Upheld
description: Longstanding restrictions that bar the reporting of federal election results from eastern districts while polls are still open in western time zones are constitutional, the Supreme Court ruled in a 5-to-4 decision. Rejecting an argument that the prohibition violated free speech, the court said the temporary nature of the ban made it permissible. It upheld the conviction of Paul Bryan, a software developer in British Columbia, who posted vote tallies from Atlantic Canada in the 2000 election on a Web site while polls in his far western province were still open. He was fined $1,000 by a lower court. The rules were introduced in 1938 to cover radio broadcasts in the belief that voters in western time zones (there are six time zones across Canada) might be influenced or even discouraged from voting by results from the eastern zones.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on Tuesday about Michael F. Summers, a biochemist who promotes training programs to increase diversity in science, misstated his age. He is 49, not 59. The article also misstated the given name of an analytical chemist whom Dr. Summers named as one of his mentors. He is Isiah Warner, not Isaiah Warner.

title: Eight City Middle Schools Join Those at Risk of Closing
description: In a sign of deep troubles in New York Citys middle schools, state officials yesterday identified nine additional city schools in danger of being shut down for academic failure  eight of them serving the middle grades.

title: Risky Business Still Attracts Eager Lenders
description: As the subprime mortgage market implodes, it is worth noting just how that is affecting all the other credit markets where risky loans were deemed perfectly rational.

title: Russia: Human Trafficking Ring Broken
description: The Federal Security Services, working with the police in Russia and other countries, said it had broken up a ring accused of trafficking people from Southeast Asia and former Soviet states through Russia and to Western Europe. It said the operation had been directed by an unidentified Russian government official.

title: Chinese Leader Strikes Defensive Tone
description: BEIJING, March 16  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said today that his country is still struggling to overcome major obstacles to its internal development and will not seek to disrupt the world order dominated by the United States.

title: Countdown Starts Toward the Final Four
description: In last years N.C.A.A. basketball tournament, 11th-seeded George Mason made it all the way to the Final Four.

title: McDonalds to the Rescue
description: Although sixth-seeded Duke was upset, 79-77, by No. 11 seed Virginia Commonwealth, the Blue Devils will be just fine.

title: Eastern Kentucky Shows Grit, But Not Enough
description: The first and only time Eastern Kentucky and North Carolina met on a basketball court, the year was 1950, Harry Truman was president and the Tar Heels were apparently no match for the Colonels.

title: Breaking Down Butler vs. Maryland
description: No. 4 Seed Maryland (25-8) vs. No. 5 Seed Butler (28-6)

title: Hoosiers Go Over Bulldogs Instead of Through Them
description: SACRAMENTO, March 15  The Indiana Hoosiers came to California and seemed to lose all of their core Midwestern values.

title: Regarding Replicas
description: Even with a fiberglass body, it's hard to tell the difference between a classic and a replica.

title: Whats on Friday Night
description: 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) DON'T DRINK THE WATER (1969). Woody Allen does it all night long in three back-to-back comedies, starting with this one, co-written by Mr. Allen (based on his own play) and directed by Howard Morris, about an American family accused of spying behind the Iron Curtain when their plane lands in Bulgaria and they disembark to take pictures. Jackie Gleason and Estelle Parsons play the guileless tourists under the protection of the absentee ambassador's son (Ted Bessell), who seems a little short of ammunition in the brains department. Mr. Allen outdid himself by writing, directing and starring in the next two films: "Take the Money and Run" (1969), a mockumentary about a dim-witted bank robber and his "gub," at 9:45, and "Bananas" (1971), in which a consumer-products tester becomes president of a tropical third-world nation to win the love of a political activist (Louise Lasser), at 11:15.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article last Friday about a lawsuit seeking to prevent Massachusetts from placing mentally ill inmates in solitary confinement misidentified the plaintiff, who was discussing the case at a news conference. He is Stanley J. Eichner, executive director of the Disability Law Center  not Robert Fleischner of the Center for Public Representation, who is a co-counsel in the case.

title: Crossed Paths in the Village
description: The Web site of David R. Garvin, the gunman who killed a pizzeria worker and two auxiliary police officers in the West Village before he was shot dead Wednesday night, reveals a frustrated writer of screenplays with a dark and bizarre sensibility.

title: On The Market
Eating Out in Addis Ababa
description: It may not be your first thought when planning a culinary journey, but Addis Ababa, the capital city of Ethiopia, has a vibrant food culture worth exploring.

title: What You Can Get for $1 Million in...
Friday's First Round Action
description: Highlights from the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Hook, Lead Line, and Thinker
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Boots Powered by Gasoline
description: Gas-powered boots, first conceived by a Russian student in 1974, have been held up as a symbol of Russia's inability to convert rich scientific traditions into useful merchandise.

title: A Political Path
description: Cory Booker, the mayor of Newark, talks about his road from the suburbs to Oxford to public housing.

title: Top Seed Is Out in Bridge Tournament
description: ST. LOUIS, March 16  In the Spring North American Bridge Championships here, there was one major upset in the quarterfinals of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams, which ended on Thursday night: the No. 1 seed, Nick Nickell, Dick Freeman, Bob Hamman, Jeff Meckstroth, Eric Rodwell and Paul Soloway, lost to the No. 25 seed. Down by 31 international match points at halftime, Piotr Tuszynski and Apolinary Kowalski from Poland, and four Californians, Farid Assemi, Nick Bykov, Srikanth Kodayam and Ed Wojewoda, came back to win, 146 imps to 134.

title: Pulse
description: Winters sharp edge is finally easing, and shoppers are seeking lighter coverage. This years crop of spring coats breaks out of the boring trenches.

title: Switch at the Roundabout
description: The Roundabout Theater Company's current season will end with the New York premiere of "Beyond Glory," a solo performance by Stephen Lang in which he will portray eight veterans from World War II, the Korean War and Vietnam, as they look back on courageous moments in their lives. Mr. Lang adapted it from Larry Smith's 2003 book of the same title, which contains interviews with winners of the Congressional Medal of Honor.

title: All in the Family
description: Living with six children in 800 square feet.

title: Nissan Chief Gives Up North American Duties
description: DETROIT, March 16  Nissan chief executive Carlos Ghosn is to give up his responsibility for Nissans North American operations, and focus on leading Nissan and Renault of France, which he also runs, Nissan said today.

title: Can the Merc Top ICEs Offer? Some Doubt It.
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange may find it difficult to top Intercontinenental Exchanges $10 billion bid for the Chicago Board of Trade, analysts said yesterday. Under terms of ICEs proposal, the Board of Trades shareholders would own about 51.5 percent of the combined company, which would be based in Chicago and have its headquarters at the Board of Trades storied building in the financial district.

title: G.M. Says It Has Found Serious Flaws in Accounting
description: General Motors, a company once known as the model of corporate accounting, warned investors on Thursday that its performance was threatened by ineffective controls over financial reporting, including inadequately trained personnel and failure to obtain managements approval for some transactions. The disclosure, made in G.M.s annual report filed with federal regulators after a six-week delay, was the latest indication that the automaker is on shakier footing than first thought.

title: 2 Financial Institutions Find Common Cause in New York
description: There would seem to be plenty of differences between E. Stanley ONeal and Deborah C. Wright. He heads Merrill Lynch, one of Wall Streets largest firms, while she leads Carver Federal Savings Bank, the countrys largest black financial institution, but a fraction of Merrills size.

title: V.C.s Hedge Cleantech Bets with Fossil Fuels
description: Silicon Valleys technology investors have taken to the ramparts, threatening to tear down the oil and gas industries dominance with its green-tech innovations that use ethanol, solar and wind. The cry has been raised by some of the Valley most stored venture capital firms such as Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Its principals, John Doerr in particular, have passionately (and tearfully) advocated development of alternative energies as a way to create energy independence and clean up the carbon-saturated atmosphere.

title: One Proposal for Tribune Said to Lose Momentum
description: As a March 31 deadline nears for deciding the fate of Tribune, the proposal from Samuel Zell, the Chicago real estate billionaire, is falling from favor, according to The New York Times. The company, which has been on the auction block for more than five months, has all but dismissed three earlier bids. With Mr. Zells bid losing steam, The Times said, management is forced to reconsider how the company might restructure.

title: Germany Says Hedge Funds Should Devise Conduct Code
description: The finance minister of Germany said Thursday that he favored the development of an internationally accepted code of conduct for the $1.4 trillion hedge fund industry but that it would take the worlds leading economies at least a year to decide how to establish a set of standards.

title: Burkle and Case Get Together on Brazilian Venture, Report Says
description: AOL founder Steven Case, supermarket magnate Ronald Burkle and venture capitalist Vinod Khosla are teaming up to invest in a company that could produce up to 1 billion gallons of ethanol a year in Brazil, according to The Wall Street Journal. Brazilian Renewable Energy Company, known as Benco, closed an initial $200 million round of funding this week, The Journal said. The deal is expected to be officially announced Thursday, according to the newspaper.

title: Ex-Internet Tycoon in Japan Guilty of Fraud
description: Takafumi Horie, the 34-year-old Internet tycoon once heralded as a symbol of new capitalism in Japan, was found guilty Friday morning by the Tokyo District Court of violating securities laws at his company, Livedoor. He was sentenced to two years and six months. Mr. Horie, who had pleaded not guilty and argued that the trial was politically motivated, is expected to appeal. Prosecutors, who depicted Mr. Horie as a greedy and lawless figure who had manipulated the books to inflate his companys stock price, had sought a four-year term.

title: No Raise, but No Tears, for Warren Buffett
description: While many companies are starting tie the pay of chief executives to stock performance, dont expect Berkshire Hathaway to jump on the bandwagon anytime soon. For Warren Buffett, Berkshires chief executive, such an arrangement would be a gold mine. His companys stock is valued at more than $106,000 a share. And last year, it rose 24 percent in value. But in a regulatory filing Thursday, the company said that neither the profitability of Berkshire Hathaway nor the market value of its stock are to be considered in the compensation of any executive officer.

title: Banker Accused in Insider Trading Scheme Had a Birds-Eye View
description: Mitchel S. Guttenberg, the UBS banker who has been charged with conspiracy and securities fraud Thursday for allegedly masterminding an insider tarding scheme, apparently got his inside dope from his perch on an elite committee at UBS that signed off on all upgrades and downgrades, Businessweek says, taking another look at the banking scandal.

title: Delaware Court Faults Sale to Buyout Firms
description: In a ruling that could have broader effects on the booming buyout business, a Delaware judge faulted Netsmart Technologies for excluding strategic buyers from its sale process and ordered the company to delay a vote on its proposal to be acquired by two private equity firms. In a memo to clients, law firm Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz called the decision, issued late Wednesday by Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. of Chancery Court, a major opinion on a deal that, although small, had many of the same elements as large private-equity transaction.

title: A Pizza That Could Take a Slice Out of Banking Bonuses
description: For Wall Street investment bankers who have been looking for inventive ways to spend last years record bonuses, theres something new on the menu: the $1,000 pizza. Manhattan restauranteur Nino Selimaj has added the pricey pie  apparently the most expensive in the world  to the menu at Ninos Bellisima on Second Ave., one of his six restaurants in the city. The uncooked pizza is topped with creme fraiche, chives, eight ounces of four different kinds of Petrossian caviar, four ounces of thinly sliced Maine lobster tail, salmon roe, and a little bit of spice with wasabi, according to CBS station WCBS-TV.

title: Network Appliance Shareholders File Suit Over Options Backdating
description: Another company is being accused of options backdating, but this time its the shareholders pointing the finger.

title: A Passion for Color
description: Images from the exhibition "Helio Oiticica: The Body of Color," at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston.

title: Valley Veteran to Run Yahoos Brickhouse
description: Yahoo hasnt officially announced its Brickhouse program dedicated to launching innovative new products, but CNet News notes that word has leaked that it has hired a startup veteran to head up the program. Serial entrepreneur Salim Ismail, chairman of Confabb.com, a directory of conferences, and co-founder of PubSub, confirms on his blog on Thursday that hes joining Yahoo.

title: Texas Lawmakers May Rein in TXU Buyout
description: Texas state Senate approved legislation Thursday that would strip TXU of some of its power plants and increase state authority over TXU operations  including the right to approve the utilitys proposed $45 billion sale to a group led by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Texas Pacific Group.

title: Subprime Investment Weighs on Chicago Bank
description: Chicago bank holding company Corus Bankshares said its sizeable investment in the stock of troubled subprime lender Fremont General has caused Coruss position in Fremont to become materially impaired, which will spark a hefty pretax charge that could be $14.3 million or even higher. While Corus emphasized that it has the intent and the ability to retain its Fremont investment, the Chicago company believes that Fremonts recent travails require the company to record a charge in the first quarter of 2007, to reflect the decline in the value of its Fremont investment.

title: R.I.M.s Options Backdating May Be Intentional, Expert Says
description: The stock options expert whose research triggered a wide investigation into backdating says the pattern of option grants at Research In Motion does not appear to be the result of an accidental misunderstanding of accounting rules, as the companys chief executive officer has suggested.

title: Chinese Biofuel Producer Sees Heavy Demand in I.P.O.
description: China Agri-Industries, a producer of biofuel, has raised $410 million after pricing its initial public offering at the top of the range following hefty demand from both institutional and retail investors. The strong interest came despite the Hang Seng Index shedding more than a thousand points last week. The retail tranche was 607 times oversubscribed, making it the second most popular I.P.O. with the Hong Kong public this year after China Huiyuan Juice, which drew $27.7 billion worth of retail demand.

title: C.B.O.T. Bid May Boost Montreal Exchange I.P.O.
description: The Intercontinental Exchanges surprise $10 billion bid for the Chicago Board of Trade is expected to provide an added lift to Montreal Exchanges initial public offering, and could help boost the value of the upstart derivatives market to more than C$1.2 billion ($1 billion) when its shares begin trading later this month, The Globe and Mail said.

title: AOL Fails in Bid for Ad Broker
description: AOL said Thursday it has withdrawn its cash offer for Swedish online marketing specialist TradeDoubler because it had not acquired enough shares by the bid deadline. AOL, a unit of Time Warner, offered in January to buy TradeDoubler in a cash deal that valued the company at around $900 million.

title: Vivendi Offers to Unload Titles to Win Music Deal, Report Says
description: Vivendis Universal Music has offered to sell key catalogues, including the songbooks of Britney Spears and the Spice Girls, to win the European Unions go-ahead for its 1.63 billion euro ($2.17 billion) takeover of BMG Music Publishing, The Guardian reported.

title: TXU, EchoStar Deals May Have Role in UBS Turmoil
description: As reports surface that Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBSs investment bank in New York, is threatening to leave the firm, speculation on the whys and wherefores of the situation is increasing.

title: Study Questions Hedge Funds Stock-Picking Prowess
description: Evidence is weak that hedge funds are better stock pickers than mutual funds, a recent academic study suggests. The study was based on quarterly reports of funds long positions filed with regulators, rather than on published hedge fund indexes, which some say paint a skewed picture of hedge funds returns.

title: Duke Loses, and Everyone Cheers
description: Virginia Commonwealth University is a public college based in Richmond. It is most famous for its medical school  it has Americas oldest organ transplant center  and its arts school branch, which, bizarrely, is located in Education City, Qatar. (It also offers a degree in Homeland Security and Emergency Preparedness, so this is where the next Jack Bauer is coming from, for better or worse.) The trash metal costume band GWAR was formed there. Its a modest university of 30,000 students, and most of the time, its nestled comfortably outside the public consciousness.

title: Giuliani and His Ex-Police Commish
description: LOS ANGELES William J. Bratton, the police chief here and one of Rudy Giulianis former police commissioners, has shed some light on their private, eyebrow-raising meeting last week.

title: Financial Analyst Is Formally Charged
description: The research analyst who is a key player in the fight between Fairfax Holdings and short-selling hedge funds was indicted Thursday on wire fraud charges unrelated to the case. Spyro Contogouris was formally charged in relation to a case related to a prior real-estate job; he was arrested for that matter last November. Mr. Contogouris, whose criticism of Fairfax drove several hedge funds to sell short the company, is part of a $5 billion lawsuit filed by the Canadian insurer alleging a conspiracy to drive its stock price down.

title: Judge Is Not Amused by Conrad Blacks Lawyer
description: An article in The New York Times chronicling the pageantry of the upcoming fraud trial of Conrad Black, the former head of the Hollinger media empire, put Mr. Blacks Canadian lawyer in a sticky situation Wednesday. The Guardian notes that Mr. Blacks attorney, Edward Greenspan was hauled over the coals for making tongue-in-cheek remarks about his treatment as a foreigner in Americas legal system.

title: Weighing Nacchios Chances in Qwest Trial
description: Though many will be rooting for his conviction, Joseph Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, may escape from his trial on 42 insider-trading charges unscathed, according to lawyers watching the case. The trial, which begins March 19, will determine whether Mr. Nacchio is guilty of selling $101 million shares of Qwest from January to May of 2001 after getting internal warnings that the countrys fourth-largest phone company would fall short of revenue expectations.

title: Congress Gets a No-Look Pass
description: The Wall Street Journal editorial page condemns a different sort of March Madness:

title: Dark Skies Over Tampa
description: Convinced we had found the architects who would be perfect for us, we headed down to Tampa to meet with Don Cooper of Cooper Johnson Smith. But the first impressions were far from favorable.

title: McCain Retunes '08 Engine
description: The Straight Talk Express, a vehicle that in the 2000 campaign became a potent symbol of Mr. McCain's message and appeal, is back.

title: Permira and Centaurus Are Said to Be in Talks with Atos
description: Two British firms  Permira, the buyout group, and Centaurus, an activist hedge fund  have proposed a 4 billion euro ($5.3 billion) deal for Atos Origin, a French information technology services group, the Financial Times reported Friday, citing unnamed sources. Atos confirmed Thursday that it had received an informal bid, but did not disclose the bidders. Shares in the company surged 25.2 percent to 49.50 euros a share on Thursday.

title: Can a Co-op Board Limit Rent Charged in a Sublet?
description: Q I own a co-op in New York, and I want to sublet my apartment. I understand that the board has the right to approve the sublet, to limit the number of people in the unit to two and to ask for or forgo a sublet fee.

title: Ousted L.A. Paper Publisher Joins Burkles Firm
description: Jeffrey M. Johnson, the former Los Angeles Times publisher whose stand against Tribune led to his ouster, has taken a position with Ronald Burkles Yucaipa Companies, the private investment firm that is trying to acquire his former employer. The Times, which is owned by Tribune, said that Mr. Johnson will be a principal in the company, overseeing its media interests, including parts of Al Gores Current TV channel.

title: If a Rent-Controlled Tenant Is Evicted, What Then?
description: Q My neighbor's apartment was under rent control until he was evicted last month. Is the apartment now deregulated, and can the rent legally go to any price? I am interested because my own apartment is rent-controlled, and I'm worried that the landlord will do everything in his power to evict me.

title: A Snowshocked JetBlue Hits the Cancel Button
description: Sure, the weather is kind of crummy in the Northeast this morning. New York area commuters woke up to find a little wet snow on lawns and car windows, a little slush on streets and sidewalks, some sleety flakes in the air and more expected later today. Not much fun but not a great big deal, at least not yet.

title: Talk of a Dow Partnership Stirs up Buyout Talk
description: As rumors of a buyout dance around Dow Chemicals, the chemical giant is in talks with Indias Reliance Industries to create a joint venture that would reduce its exposure to the volatile commodity chemicals market. The Financial Times said that reports have suggested that a deal might lead to a takeover of Dow by Reliance, Indias largest public company, sending shares up 5 percent. But unnamed sources told the F.T. that such speculation was untrue.

title: Have Republicans Become Their Own Enemy?
description: Before the Congressional elections of 2006, a common meme among political writers was to assert that the Republicans had turned into 1980s Democrats: a corrupt, sleazy Congressional majority that had forgotten the principles that brought it to power. In the cover story for the redesigned Time magazine, Karen Tumulty suggests that a few months as the minority party havent changed things. (Tumultys critique also owes a debt to Slate editor Jacob Weisbergs notion of interest-group conservatism). Conservatives are handcuffed to a political party that looks unsettlingly like the Democrats did in the 1980s, one that is more a collection of interest groups than ideas, recognizable more by its campaign tactics than its philosophy, she writes. She continues:

title: 2008: From Iowa to New Hampshire
description: In Iowa, Senator John McCain jumpstarts the Straight Talk Express, as he tours around the state, talking to voters and reporters about the war, his age and immigration (among other things).

title: Caremark Says Shareholders Approve CVS Merger
description: The three-month war over Caremark Rx is over, and the pharmacy chain from Woonsocket, R.I. has won. Caremark said Friday morning that its shareholders approved a $26.5 billion offer by CVS, the nations largest drugstore chain, creating a new company with tremendous clout over drug prices.

title: Blackstone Said to Prepare for I.P.O.
description: Blackstone Group, one of the worlds largest private equity firms, is preparing for an initial public offering, though the decision to go public has not yet been made, a person briefed on the plans told DealBook. CNBCs David Faber, who originally reported the I.P.O. preparations Friday morning, said Blackstone has been working with investment bank Goldman Sachs on an offering, adding that preliminary prospectus could be filed with regulators in two weeks. An I.P.O. would be just the latest audacious move for Blackstone chairman Stephen Schwarzman, who recently led his firm in a $39 billion purchase of Equity Office Properties Trust, the largest leveraged buyout ever completed. It would also represent a remarkable turn for Mr. Schwarzman, who, in his role as buyout king, has extolled the virtues of leaving public shareholders behind.

title: Find a Ride on the Web
description: Yesterday, in my e-mail column, I described the TED 2007 conference, which was held last week in Monterey, California. And I promised to share with you some of my notes from the conference in a few blog entries.

title: A Friday Viewers Guide
description: Hopefully you have somehow managed to take a half day today or to skip work all together. If you do go to work, heckling any Duke fans in the office would probably make it worth while. The relative lack of upsets on Thursday, just like last year, means that high seeds are likely to begin dropping in droves today. If youre headed to an early Happy Hour or stuck hitting refresh on the browser, here is The Brackets guide to the best games today by time slot.

title: In with the new
description: New age interior

title: They finally got the formula right
description: As a longtime skeptic about the ability of the International Automobile Federation and the teams to return a Formula One weekend to the simplicity and glory of its greatest years, I am absolutely stunned to see that after finally creating a great qualifying session last year, the FIA has come up with a fantastic formula for Friday practice. (Which it had killed several years ago through various efforts at rewriting the rules.)

title: On YouTube, Redstone Contains Multitudes
description: Viacom, controlled by Sumner Redstone, is suing Google for $1 billion for copyright violations on its YouTube video service. But CBS, also controlled by Sumner Redstone, is making licensing deals with Google for YouTube to use some of its content. What gives?

title: Parade Politics
description: It wouldnt be the St. Patricks Day Parade in New York without a healthy dose of politics.

title: The Laugh Gap Explained
description: Here are three explanations that readers came up for the Laugh Gap between the sexes:

title: A Curious Sight on Capitol Hill
description: Valerie Plame Wilson, the former C.I.A. operative whose cover was blown by White House officials and others, is testifying this morning before the House Government Oversight Committee on the chain of events that led to her name turning up in Robert Novaks syndicated column and to I. Lewis Libby, the vice presidential aide known as Scooter, being convicted of obstruction of justice and other charges.

title: Bloomberg: Stop Illegal Gun Traffic
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg spoke passionately about the need to get illegal guns off the streets on his weekly radio interview this morning in the aftermath of the Greenwich Village shootout that left four people dead, including two auxiliary police officers.

title: Tickets, Tickets, Everywhere Tickets
description: Desperate fans held fistfuls of tickets to the sub-region here in Columbus. Face value: $61. Asking price? Whatever.

title: Obama Disputes Bill Clintons Take on War Views
description: Senator Barack Obama is pushing back against former President Bill Clinton this morning over Mr. Clintons apparent statement that Mr. Obama was initially ambivalent about the Iraq war.

title: No Mixed Emotions; All Heartbreak
description: Pete Gillen, the former coach of Virginia, was assigned the Columbus sub-regional pod three weeks ago as an analyst for Westwood One radio. He did not know at the time the Cavaliers would be put in the draw.

title: John Edwards on Poverty
description: More than any of the presidential candidates, John Edwards has come up with a specific and plausible plan that provides for health care coverage for all Americans. And he followed that up yesterday with an excellent speech on poverty at home and abroad, with some good and specific ideas.

title: Windy City Anticipation
description: Chicago has a championship favorite (Kansas), it has a close-to-home favorite (Wisconsin) and highly intriguing games to start the day (Nevada-Las Vegas vs. Georgia Tech) and end it (Kentucky vs. Villanova).

title: 'I Think I Love My Wife'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "I Think I Love My Wife," Chris Rock's new film.

title: Whose Home Court Is It Anyway?
description: Rupp Arena is the hallowed home of the Kentucky Wildcats, but youd never know it this weekend. Instead of Big Blue from the rafters to the food court, it has been a sea of red and well, darker, blue.

title: Ex-Hollinger C.O.O. to Pay $29 Million in S.E.C. Settlement
description: As the former media executive Conrad Black prepares for his trial, he may have a bigger worry than a lawyer with an ill-advised sense of humor. David Radler, the deputy chairman and chief operating officer at Hollinger International, has settled civil fraud charges for $29 million, the Securities and Exchange Commission announced Friday.

title: Memphis Wakes Up Before Halftime
description: For the first 16 minutes, it looked like Memphis spent too much time out on Bourbon Street last night. The Tigers were sluggish, their offense impotent and North Texas was improbably controlling the game. The Mean Green played harder, crashed the boards and played with the verve of a team poised to pull an upset.

title: By Bidding for Altadis, Is Imperial Tobacco Now in Play?
description: By launch a bid for Altadis, Britains Imperial Tobacco has stirred up speculation that it may be a potential deal target as well. The potential acquiror? Altria. According to Reuters, because of antitrust regulations Altrias only plausible deal partner is Imperial, and should the British tobacconist reach a deal with French-Spanish Altadis, that window will close.

title: Landrys Bids Again for Smith & Wollensky
description: Still trying to make a surf-and-turf special, seafood restaurant operator Landrys Restaurants on Friday increased its offer for the Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group to about $84 million, topping a bid by the Patina Restaurant Group.

title: Inside, A Different Story
description: Fifteen minutes before the Virginia-Albany tip-off here at Nationwide Arena in Columbus, there were empty seats galore.

title: Gary Williams a Duke Fan?
description: Heres something that might surprise Maryland basketball fans. Gary Williams, your long-time basketball coach, was rooting for A.C.C. rival Duke when the Blue Devils lost to Virginia Commonwealth in Buffalo on Thursday night.

title: Technology Begets Transparency
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans Mar. 16 column, Marching With a Mouse.

title: Bell Grand Jury Is Done
description: The Queens grand jury investigating the fatal police shooting of Sean Bell has finished its work.

title: Valuing a Public Blackstone
description: As reports emerge that buyout behemoth  Blackstone Group is considering an initial public offering, here is the multibillion-dollar question: What would a publicly traded Blackstone be worth? It is difficult to guess, because most of the private equity firms financial figures are, well, private. But a comparison with Fortress Investment Group, which recently opened its kimono as part of its highly successful I.P.O., gives some extremely rough guideposts.

title: Why Dis Them?
description: As noted here earlier, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg used his weekly radio appearance today to talk about the ongoing flap between John Dunleavy, the head of the St. Patricks Day Parade, and the city Fire Department. He said he would spend most of the parade tomorrow marching with firefighters to stand up for them.

title: 3 Indictments in Bell Case, Under Seal
description: [Updated, 4:30 p.m.]

title: Valerie Wilson in the Floodlights
description: No matter where opinion might land on the CIA leak case and the fate of I. Lewis Scooter Libby, the spectacle of Valerie Wilson testifying this morning at a Congressional hearing offered new insights into the disclosure of her identity 3-1/2 years ago and the ramifications of a newly empowered Democratic majority on Capitol Hill.

title: Court Battle: Private Equity vs. Hedge Funds
description: In one way, at least, there is a winner in the competition between private equity and hedge funds: Private equity, by a score of 30-17. This battle was fought not on Wall Street, or even in the leafy environs of Greenwich, Conn., but on a basketball court, in a 20-minute charity game on Thursday night. Reuters writer Michael Flaherty has some post-game color:

title: Music Video: El-P
description: An exclusive video of "Smithereens" by El-P.

title: 11 Companies Get Calpers Seal of Disapproval
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System has released its annual Focus List of companies it considered corporate underachievers. Calpers  at $230 billion,the nations biggest and most influential pension fund  rates companies according to their earnings and their corporate government policies. Those that made the list are the poster children for bad performance and bad corporate governance, said Calpers President Rob Feckner.

title: Its Texas A&M-Corpus Christi
description: Before the game, CBS broadcaster Jim Nantz wasnt sure how to shorten the schools name for ease. Just Corpus Christi, right? he asked someone.

title: McCain Apologizes for Tar-Baby Moment
description: CEDAR FALLS  Senator John S. McCain offered an apology in Cedar Falls today after he used the word tar-baby in response to a rather arcane question from an Iowa voter about federal intervention in divorce and custody cases. The phrase is considered by some to be a racial epithet.

title: McCain Stumbles on H.I.V. Prevention
description: SOMEWHERE in NORTHERN IOWA  The unthinkable has happened. Senator John McCain met a question, while sitting with reporters on his bus as it rumbled through Iowa today, that he couldnt  or perhaps wouldnt  answer.

title: Dont Raise Your Hands to Me
description: People you love and admire can have thriving, full-dress shows you dont even know about. They can have their own CHANNELS you dont know about. Thats the fact in the world of online video.

title: The End of a Friendship?
description: Thad Matta left Xavier for Ohio State three years ago, but Musketeer fans have long and bitter memories. Last night, when Matta found a seat along press row to scout Xavier and BYU in Lexington, he was lustily booed. Now, Xavier has a chance for revenge.

title: Born To Run
description: Memphis Coach John Caliparis hip might be replaced and his waistline might be slightly larger, but he sure can talk like he did in his UMass heyday.

title: Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, Omar Sheikh and Angelina Jolie
description: As Adam Liptak reported today in The Times, Khalid Shaikh Mohammeds claim that he murdered Daniel Pearl, the Wall Street Journal journalist who was abducted and killed in 2002, might help another jihadi, Omar Sheikh, get off death row in Pakistan. Mr. Sheikh is the British-born Muslim who was found guilty in July 2002 of kidnapping and conspiring to kill Mr. Pearl and is appealing his death sentence.

title: Vows: David and Rona
description: David Kraut and Rona Shalev met online, and he proposed with a video spoof of their favorite television show, "24."

title: Where Jordan Rules
description: Michigan State Coach Tom Izzo didnt need to be reminded where he was playing when the Spartans faced Marquette on Thursday in the first round of the N.C.A.A. Tournament East Regional in Winston-Salem, N.C. All he had to do was listen to the cheers from the North Carolina fans in the stands as the scoreboard monitor showed a Tar Heel highlight reel during breaks of his game.

title: Blogtalk: Park Slope Revolts
description: The Park Slope community leaders revoltedagainst the citys one-way traffic plan. [Streetsblog]

title: Natural Wines Redux
description: With the 2005 Burgundies and Bordeaux on my mind I was about to offer a post on the tyranny of great vintages, but Ive been distracted by the absorbing and sometimes heated discussion that is continuing in the comments section of my recent post on technology and winemaking. So many good and interesting points have been made that I feel compelled to respond to at least a few of them.

title: Hagel and McCain: Vietnam to Iraq
description: Despite their shared past fighting in Vietnam, Senators Chuck Hagel and John McCain disagree profoundly about Iraq. Janny Scott reports.

title: Still Waiting for a Bracket-Busting Upset
description: Its not easy anymore to find a school that has never made the N.C.A.A. tournament. The proliferation of conferences  major, mid-major and infinitesimal  have made the once-daunted task of sneaking in the N.C.A.A. tournament every decade or so decidedly simpler. With only 10 Division I-A teams unaffiliated with any conference (four of which will join a league next year; gone are the days of Notre Dame and DePaul scheduling at their whim), earning a bid, for most schools, is merely a matter of coming together for one key week in early March. With so many schools lacking a storied basketball tradition, in many smaller conferences theyre simply rotating N.C.A.A. bids every few years.

title: A Great Day for the Irish  But Who Are They?
description: Those readers who take any notice of bylines will not, perhaps, be surprised to learn that your blogger is of Irish extraction. Im hardly unique that way  some 34 million Americans claimed Irish ancestry in the 2000 census, nearly 12 percent of the population.

title: A.C.C. vs. Big East
description: Boston College didnt need to fret about unfamiliarity as it prepared to face No. 2 Georgetown on Saturday in the second round of the East Region in Winston-Salem, N.C. The two teams are old foes. Boston College, the No. 7 seed, and Georgetown were original members of the Big East Conference before the Eagles defected to the Atlantic Coast Conference in 2005.

title: Bo Knows The Jerk, and Ronnie Arrow Shoots Straight
description: Wisconsin Coach Bo Ryan is one of the most entertaining coaches to sit behind a microphone. After Wisconsins come-from-behind victory against Texas A&M-Corpus Christi, he was trying to explain how out of sync his team was. He pretended to bounce a ball and move his head, out of rhythm, and said it was like Mervin Johnson.

title: Trailer: Black
description: A trailer for "Black," a film by Sanjay Leela Bhansali.

title: Working Overtime
description: The Brackets bracket may be pretty well shot at this point, but theres one prediction that we can brag on. We said on Selection Sunday that the game between Nevada and Creighton would be the best game of the first round. So far, we can feel good about saying that were right. (Its been the only overtime game of the tournament entering the night sessions on Friday.)

title: A-Low-Ha from Sacramento
description: Washington State guard Derrick Low showed up to his teams practice session at Arco Arena on Friday wearing a maroon T-shirt that read: ALowHa Cougs! In the middle was a flower.

title: The Games, They Are A Changin
description: At home, games in the first two days of the tournament seem to just keep coming, and you can see bits and pieces of all of them, even if you dont want to.

title: Pass the Potatoes
description: The weather in the east is erratic as designers. A few days of spring, and today the view out my window is winter world. I dont think the dinner guest will make it through the snow and ice; he informs me that hes stuck under a boiler, and boilers come before roast chicken and potatoes. The potatoes are the French ones, and I boil them and coat them with sea salt and serve them like that. Bernard Alloux was very concerned, before I left Paris, that I had the right sea salt, and, I suppose, by that he meant the coarse kind you get in Brittany, where he has a little cottage with fruit trees. We talk a lot about food when were driving around Paris, and I keep saying I want to drive by the butcher on the Ile St. Louis, where Alaia gets the most delicious steak. After I wrote an article for the Magazine about the meals that Alaia cooks in his kitchen, several years back, American travelers turned up at the butcher just to gaze at the meat. Why is this unsurprising? I bet some of them even thought about buying an electric plate and a frying pan, just to have that taste, that existence. Ill accept that as a definition for lifestyle.

title: Steve Reich Talking Music
description: Steve Reich  Part I(mp3)On his early musical education, 12-tone music and discovering The Rite of Spring.

title: An Intentional Foul, To Start The Game
description: The Kentucky-Villanova game was all of three seconds old before a whistle blew. Dwight Perry was called for a foul.

title: A Shot In the Dark
description: As the night sessions come to a close on the opening weekend of the N.C.A.A. tournament, theres been a distinct lack of buzzer beaters and the so-called Shining Moments. Sure, theres been some good, competitive games. But weve yet to see a defining play that will endure for years.

title: Hot Tots, and Moms Hot to Trot
description: Judith Warner has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below.  The Editors

title: In March, More Towns Seem to Love a Parade
description: HOBOKEN, N.J., March 15  Department stores start to haul out their Christmas tinsel around Halloween these days, and pumpkin picking starts soon after Labor Day. Now you can add St. Patricks Day, which, with its accompanying parades, is becoming a matter of Erin go on and on.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption on March 4 with an article about Leroy Nicholas Barnes  a former heroin dealer from Harlem who is the subject of Mr. Untouchable, a book and a documentary  carried incorrect information from the producer of the film about the photograph. Mr. Barnes and Marc Levin, the films director, were seated at a chessboard; they were not playing chess because the board was rotated 90 degrees from its proper orientation. (The producer, who supplied the picture, said the board was set up that way to get the best images of Mr. Barness hands on the chessboard.)

title: Delays for Casino License Appeals Could Cost Pennsylvania
description: PITTSBURGH, March 16  The legal battle over appeals filed by four companies that lost out in the recent round of bidding for casino licenses in Pennsylvania could cost the state hundreds of millions of dollars in gambling tax revenue and delay promised property tax relief.

title: Palestinians New Unity Can Be Just a Beginning
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  With the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, now politically cohabitating with the militant Islamic group Hamas in a national unity government, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rices attempts to stitch together a new Middle East peace plan just became even more complicated.

title: Abreu Remains Confident Hell Be Ready for Opener
description: KISSIMMEE, Fla., March 16  Bobby Abreu took another step Friday in his cautious recovery from a strained oblique muscle.

title: Parsing Hillary Clinton on Iraq (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: For the Record

title: A Slain Officers Mother Tells of Her Sad Intuition
description: Nicholas T. Pekearos mother knew.

title: Picking Stocks That Dont Sin
description: ALMOST seven years ago, when we moved to New York from London and were trying to figure out how to invest our paltry nest egg, I mentioned to a financial adviser that I was interested in putting our money into socially responsible investments.

title: Consumer Prices Rose 0.4% in February
description: A rebound in energy prices pushed inflation higher in February, suggesting that a weakening economy has not yet taken much pressure off rising prices, as the Federal Reserve has long hoped, according to government figures released yesterday.

title: Swelling Crowds Across Pakistan Denounce Musharrafs Suspension of Chief Justice
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 16  Protests over the suspension of the countrys top judge continued Friday in several cities, with riot police officers and protesters clashing for the first time in the capital and the political opposition joining forces with lawyers who have been rallying for days. About 200 protesters, including a former president, were arrested in Islamabad, Rawalpindi and Lahore.

title: Sorority Life (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Short, Intense Career Marked by Vibrant Color
description: HOUSTON  Maybe it is a new form of cultural colonialism or a sign of its demise, but the term American artist is becoming more inclusive, and museums in the southern and southwestern United States are helping. Six years ago the Museum of Fine Arts here established an International Center for Arts of the Americas to study 20th-century Latin American art. And it has made an enormous commitment to the short, intense career of the Brazilian artist Hlio Oiticica (1937-80).

title: Five Victims of Bronx Fire Fly Home to West Africa
description: The twins were the last to go. Harouma and Sisi, each 7 months old, were lifted in the plain wooden coffin they shared and carried into the back of a waiting hearse.

title: Muscular Approach Accented With a Ghostly Whisper
description: Alan Gilbert made a strong impression when he conducted the New York Philharmonic last month, and on Thursday evening he returned to Avery Fisher Hall to prove that it wasnt a fluke. This time his program was decidedly more rugged: Gyorgy Ligetis otherworldly Violin Concerto was the centerpiece, and the Schumann Third Symphony was there to test his mettle in the Romantic canon.

title: In Dodgertown, Theyve Seen This Show Before
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., March 16  The atmosphere was electric Friday afternoon for Daisuke Matsuzakas start against the Los Angeles Dodgers. More than 9,000 fans crammed into Holman Field to see Matsuzaka, the $103 million pitcher from Japan whose white-knuckle negotiations with the Boston Red Sox over the winter kept major league baseball riveted.

title: World View Podcast
description: CALVIN SIMS. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe.

title: Mortgage Shares Rise Again as a Subprime Lender Gets a Line of Credit
description: The Fremont General Corporation, a provider of subprime loans through brokers, said yesterday that Credit Suisse had increased a line of credit to the company to $1 billion, helping the shares of mortgage companies rise for a third consecutive day.

title: Pining for Irish Soil? You Can Buy It by the Bag
description: SPEONK, N.Y., March 14  Part of being Irish in America is a nostalgia for the old sod. The rich, dark dirt holds centuries of farming and famine and fighting. For millions of immigrants and generations of descendants, it is the essence of their heritage: the subject of great poets, the wealth of Irish kings.

title: How Close Is Too Close to Shane MacGowan and the Pogues?
description: The other evening I was doing a very grown-up thing, ironing an oxford cloth shirt for work, when my youth reared up and punched me in the mouth. On the television, a Cadillac commercial about a stylish familys morning rituals was accompanied by the jaunty melody to the song Sunnyside of the Street, by the Irish folk-punk band the Pogues.

title: 10 Detainees Pull Off Escape as Visitors Take Their Place
description: BAGHDAD, March 16  Ten Iraqis being held in a British military detention center in Basra carried out an audacious escape plan over the past several days: they switched places with visitors, British authorities said Friday.

title: Attacks Kill 2 Iraqis and Expose Hundreds to Chlorine Gas
description: BAGHDAD, March 17  Three suicide bombers driving trucks loaded with explosives and tanks of chlorine gas detonated their payloads in Anbar Province on Friday, killing at least two Iraqi police officers and wounding or sickening more than 350 people, the American military command said today.

title: Russia: Return Dacha, Court Tells Ex-Premier
description: A court in Moscow has for the second time ordered Mikhail M. Kasyanov, a former prime minister, to return a luxury home he bought from the state in 2004, ruling that he had acquired it illegally. Mr. Kasyanov, who served under President Vladimir V. Putin from 2000 to 2004, dismissed the decision as politically motivated and vowed to appeal, as he did when a court ordered the return a year ago. The purchase came under scrutiny after he declared his opposition to Mr. Putin and vowed to run for president next year.

title: What We See in Hugo Chvez
description: Buenos Aires

title: With Shifting Explanations, White House Adds to Storm
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  As White House aides combed through documents on Friday trying to figure out if Karl Rove, the senior strategist, should talk to Congress about the dismissal of federal prosecutors, President Bush set off for Camp David. But the rain grounded his helicopter, and he was forced to go by car.

title: Nevada Survives Thriller With Its Star on Bench
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 16  One of the timeless story lines in the N.C.A.A. tournament is a big-time player from a small conference program carrying his team.

title: Investigation Thrusts Former Counsel Back Into the World of Politics
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  By all accounts, Harriet E. Miers was delighted to be back in Dallas. It was Valentines Day. She had been unemployed for little more than two weeks, and when she met a friend, Jerry K. Clements, for lunch at an elegant Uptown neighborhood restaurant, Ms. Miers looked happier and more rested, Ms. Clements said, than she had in years.

title: International Support Is Sought at U.N. for Iraq Rebuilding Plan
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 16  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon appealed Friday for international support for Iraq at a ceremony here to introduce a five-year reconstruction plan for the country.

title: Court Says Health Coverage May Bar Birth-Control Pills
description: The Union Pacific Railroad Company did not discriminate against its female employees by excluding birth-control pills from its health insurance coverage, according to a federal appellate panel in St. Louis.

title: Jayhawks Provide Plenty of Highlights, if Not Drama
description: CHICAGO, March 16  If the Kansas Jayhawks should falter in the N.C.A.A. tournament, it will probably be because they occasionally struggle to reign in their talent.

title: Purely Political Motives in Outing, Ex-Agent Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Valerie Wilson finally spoke Friday, after almost four years at the silent center of a political scandal that touched Washingtons most rarefied circles of government and news media.

title: Killing of Briton by U.S. Pilot Was Criminal, Coroner Rules
description: LONDON, March 16  A British soldier who died four years ago after an American pilot opened fire on his convoy in Iraq was killed unlawfully, a coroner ruled Friday.

title: For Francis and the Knicks, Missed Opportunities
description: Steve Francis was lying face down on the Madison Square Garden court last night, reaching for his back after a collision in the lane. Just about everything that could go wrong had gone wrong on the play, including the result.

title: Manhattan: Immigrant Advocate Pleads Guilty to Fraud
description: A Bronx woman who was an advocate for Central American and Caribbean immigrants pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to defrauding immigrants of more than $1 million, prosecutors said. The woman, Maria Elena Maximo, charged immigrants $500 to $2,500 to apply for work permits and green cards for which they were not eligible, the prosecutors said. In some cases, they said, her faulty applications led to deportation proceedings. Ms. Maximo pleaded guilty to two counts of mail fraud and faces a maximum of 20 years in prison for each count.

title: These Boots Were Made for 22 M.P.H.
description: UFA, Russia  Being a star engineering student at the top-notch science university here wasnt enough to exempt Viktor K. Gordeyev from his physical education class.

title: Whats on Sunday Night
description: 8 P.M. (National Geographic) GALPAGOS Until a few centuries ago, this isolated archipelago  13 major volcanic islands, 6 smaller islands and 107 rocks and islets  off the coast of Ecuador remained a mystery to much of the world. Then a visit to the pristine islands, and their vast number of endemic species, in 1835 inspired Charles Darwin to come up with his theory of evolution by natural selection. Today the Galpagos rich environment has been increasingly decimated both by tourists and by local populations, who have introduced plants and animals that prey on native species and destroy their habitats. This new three-part special, made over 20 years, journeys from the rim of the Sierra Negra volcano on the island of Isabela to the active shores, retraces Darwins route and examines the efforts of conservationists to preserve this once-pristine oasis.

title: Make the Lords Stand for Election? First, Lets Sit and Think
description: When I visited Baghdad in 2003 and 2004, I found senior people in the Coalition Provisional Authority largely uninterested in events in the province where I was based. They focused on writing a draft constitution for Iraq. Paul Bremer III was excited about the document and thought it could be a source of national pride. But very few Iraqis had been consulted. They did not think it would bring a more effective government and felt it would be dangerously disruptive. I was reminded of this when I read about the vote this week to turn the House of Lords into a wholly elected chamber.

title: 3 Detectives Are Indicted in 50-Shot Killing in Queens
description: A grand jury voted yesterday to indict three city police detectives  two black men and a white man  in the killing of an unarmed 23-year-old black man who died in a burst of 50 police bullets outside a Queens strip club hours before he was to be wed last year, defense lawyers and police union leaders said last night.

title: Spiritual Realities in Service of Science and Vice Versa
description: When the Templeton Foundation gave its annual prize, now valued at $1.5 million, to the philosopher Charles Taylor, it probably did itself an even greater service than it did the honoree.

title: Japan Repeats Denial of Role in World War II Sex Slavery
description: TOKYO, March 16  The government of Prime Minister Shinzo Abe repeated Friday that there was no proof that the Japanese military forced women into sexual slavery during World War II.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the contents of e-mail messages sent by government officials concerning the dismissals of United States attorneys misspelled the surname of a former White House lawyer who received one of the e-mails. He is David Leitch, not Leatch.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about disputes between Singapore and its neighbors referred incorrectly to an article in the newspaper Business Times that proposed that the government create a charitable foundation to go with its investment activities in the region. The article was a bylined column by Vikram Khanna, associate editor; it was not an editorial representing the views of the newspaper.

title: Trade and the Home Front
description: In a speech just before his recent Asia trip, Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson Jr. cited a poll showing that only a third of Americans view free trade as an economic plus, while nearly half say it is bad for jobs and wages. Unless Mr. Paulson and the administration do a lot more to counter that public anxiety  and growing opposition on Capitol Hill  President Bush stands to lose his fast-track authority to negotiate trade deals, which will be up for renewal soon, and will find it increasingly hard to block protectionist laws.

title: A Neighborhood Reels in the Wake of 3 Killings in Its Midst
description: Anyone who strolled to the corner of West Houston and Macdougal Streets in Greenwich Village yesterday and peered through the windows of De Marcos Pizzeria saw a tableau that seemed frozen in time.

title: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Accuses His Own Party
description: President Robert G. Mugabe appeared to lash out at officials in his own party, warning the partys Youth League in a speech of an insidious dimension where ambitious leaders have been cutting deals with the British and Americans to unseat him. Some in the party, known as ZANU-PF, have sought to engineer the retirement of Mr. Mugabe, 83, fearful that the nations economic freefall will loosen their grip on power. Mr. Mugabe has defied them, hinting that he may seek another six-year term. Zimbabwe has been on alert for weeks in the face of increasingly defiant protests.

title: For Teachers, Middle School Is Test of Wills
description: When a student at Seth Low Intermediate School loudly pronounced Corinne Kaufman a fat lady during a fire drill one recent day, Mrs. Kaufman, a 45-year-old math teacher, calmly turned around.

title: Out to Make 6:31 A.M. Fashionable
description: Melissa Payner, the chief executive of Bluefly.com, a publicly traded company that calls itself the ultimate hook-up for the fashion obsessed, seems herself to be obsessed, or at least intent, on giving Bluefly an identity. With several racy advertisements under her designer belt, Ms. Payner vows to make her Web site for discount clothing the hippest, coolest place to shop.

title: Oregon Almost Gets an Unpleasant Surprise
description: SPOKANE, Wash., March 16  Oregon surprised some people last weekend by trouncing Southern California for the Pacific-10 tournament championship. The Ducks might have surprised others Friday with an unexpectedly narrow 58-56 victory against Miami of Ohio in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Release of List in Drug Inquiry Will Take a Week or More
description: It will take the Albany County district attorney at least a week, and possibly longer, to compile lists of Major League Baseball and National Football League players who may have received anabolic steroids and human growth hormone through a Florida pharmacy, a spokeswoman for the Albany office said yesterday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: White Finds the Motivation to Reach New Heights
description: STRATTON, Vt., March 16  He is a leader in his sport, someone who has raised the level of competition and earnings to new heights, so it is fitting that Shaun White should become the first snowboarder to experience space travel.

title: Man Wrongly Held in 02 Italy Terror Raid Wins Damages
description: ROME, March 16  Less than half a year after the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, the Italian police suddenly swooped up 15 immigrants in connection with a murky plot to attack the American Embassy in Rome with chemical agents. Two years later the case collapsed in court.

title: Where Victim Was at Home, Indictments Bring Relief
description: After a week of mounting tension in southeast Queens, the news that three officers would face criminal charges in the shooting of Sean Bell came as a relief to Bishop Erskine Williams. He heard it on television yesterday afternoon and could not stop smiling.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a convicted killer pleading guilty to a second murder for which another man had served 16 years in prison before being exonerated omitted the given name of a spokesman for Janet DiFiore, the Westchester County district attorney. He is Lucian Chalfen.

title: Nets Lose Their Way, and Few Take Notice
description: Question: Why is Isiah Thomas, the embattled Knicks coach, dragged through the coals in New York while Lawrence Frank, the coach of the meandering Nets, receives a pass?

title: Popularity Might Not Be Enough
description: LETS say you wanted to build an advertising-supported online media business that took in $50 million a year in revenue. How many users would you have to attract to get there?

title: Greenwich Village Gunman Saw Himself as Slow to Anger, E-Mail Says
description: David R. Garvin viewed himself as a peaceful man, one who could be pushed to the edge only by aggressive people he did not know.

title: Utah Sets Rigorous Rules for School Clubs, and Gay Ones May Be Target
description: SALT LAKE CITY, March 16  Most people would probably not consider the average high school chess club to be a hotbed of disorder or immorality. But a club is a club, and Utah has decided that student groups need some stern policing and regulation.

title: Lawmakers Aim to Curb Loan Abuses
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  Senior Democrats in Congress, worried that the rising number of homeowners who cannot repay their mortgages could cause broader economic problems, have begun drafting legislation to curtail predatory lending practices.

title: Eleventh-Seeded Winthrop Finally Has Its Day
description: SPOKANE, Wash., March 16  Notre Dame came to the N.C.A.A. tournament early, played early and left early. But the Irish did not leave without a fight.

title: More Rights in Egypt, Not Fewer
description: Last month, a 22-year-old Egyptian blogger was sentenced to four years in prison for what he had posted online; hed been charged with criticizing President Hosni Mubarak and insulting Islam. This week, the police violently broke up a peaceful protest against pending constitutional amendments and detained a number of people. None of these things bode well for human rights or democracy in Egypt.

title: Virginia Tech Rallies as Illinois Turns Cold
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 16  Virginia Tech is a football school in a basketball-first league. What it needs are signature victories in the N.C.A.A. tournament to make itself more accepted with the round ball, and it got one here Friday night.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in the Circuits pages of Business Day on Thursday about using cellphones overseas misstated the charge to T-Mobile USA customers for placing a call in Britain. It is 99 cents a minute, not $1.99. The article also referred incorrectly to the status of CDMA cellphone technology in Australia. While CDMA phones from American carriers do not operate there, other CDMA phones are in use; they are not basically nonexistent. And the article also referred incompletely to a source of low rates for calls from Britain. The rates  26 cents a minute for local calls and 9 to 14 cents a minute for calls to the United States  are available with use of a SIM card sold by Telestial.

title: Hamilton: Corzine Proposes New Rules for Chemical Plants
description: Promising that he would be relentless in upholding his solemn responsibility to deter terrorist attacks at New Jerseys industrial facilities, Gov. Jon S. Corzine announced a proposal yesterday to enact tighter security measures at more than 50 plants that use the kind of deadly chemical gases that could pose a threat to thousands of people in the surrounding communities. Since 2005, 42 of the states most vulnerable plants have been forced to evaluate ways to reduce risks, and several have changed chemicals or processes. Mr. Corzines proposal would require more stringent regulations to be adopted at 52 additional facilities, including water treatment plants and food processing factories, which use deadly chlorine gas. If adopted by the Legislature, the regulations would be among the tightest in the nation. Rick Hind, legislative director for the Greenpeace toxics campaign, urged Congress not to enact a Bush administration proposal, supported by the chemical industry, that would allow looser federal guidelines to supersede New Jerseys regulations.

title: A Dirge and an Outburst, Served Up With Caution
description: Singing and writing new songs are mainstays of American popular culture. But the sense of the new doesnt always translate to the classical art-song recital, which can smack of the dutiful  for performers, and for the audience  even when it includes brand-new work.

title: Despite Buildup, China Insists Its Goals Are Domestic
description: BEIJING, March 16  Prime Minister Wen Jiabao of China said Friday that his country is still trying to overcome major obstacles to its internal development and suggested that it will not seek to disrupt the world order dominated by the United States.

title: G.O.P. Savors Edge on Iraq Vote, but Uneasy Lies the Crown
Eustace Lycett, 91, Designer of Special Effects for Disney Movies, Dies
description: Eustace Lycett, whose work helping to create special effects for major Disney productions  including characters in Mary Poppins who walk on smoke, and seemingly empty suits of medieval armor engaged in combat in Bedknobs and Broomsticks  earned him a share in two Academy Awards, died on Nov. 16 at his home in Fullerton, Calif. He was 91.

title: Thoroughly Modern, With More Than a Hint of Classicism
description: The Steve Kuhn Trio, which wraps up a four-night run tonight at Birdland, makes music rich with harmonic possibility and bright, ebullient swing. Its an effortlessly modern enterprise, with roots stretching through a tangle of post-bop traditions. For any admirer of jazz piano, or articulate small-group jazz in general, its something that shouldnt be missed.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 10 P.M. (SNY) BOXING: EVANDER HOLYFIELD VS. VINNY MADDALONE Mr. Holyfields third fight since coming out of retirement in a quest to win a fifth world heavyweight championship.

title: Fusing Arab and Western Couture as Brother Leader Watches
description: TRIPOLI, Libya

title: In Success, Sampson Gains Fans in Indiana
description: SACRAMENTO, March 16  Players had gone to the locker room, fans had bolted for the concourse and band members had started packing up their trombones.

title: Fickle Investors Bobbing in Sea of Subprime Loans
description: INVESTORS this week showed that while they are still ready to sell at a moments notice, they remain unpredictable.

title: The Immigrants: 2 Sides of the Story (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Yes, Even Bach Had to Pass an Audition
description: Its strange to imagine a musical deity like Bach humbly applying for a job and being judged by inferior mortals. Its even odder to think that he initially wasnt the preferred candidate for the dual position of cantor of St. Thomas Church and music director of Leipzig.

title: That Face of Beauty, the Chaos It Creates
description: If a concert pianist wants to champion an overlooked work, all he needs to do is to program it on a recital tour. But if a leading soprano wants to perform a challenging role in a little-known opera, she needs an entire opera company to mount the work, with all the money, time and risk such a commitment entails.

title: Awaiting a Compromise on YouTube
description: Viacom is so ticked off at YouTube, my son Nick informed me not long ago. Its just so obvious.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on Thursday, about the cost of death penalty cases, misstated the number of state death row inmates who have been exonerated. Since 1973, 123 have been exonerated, according to the Death Penalty Information Center, not 197.

title: Disney Inquiry on Pixar Grants Finds No Misconduct by Jobs
description: The Walt Disney Company, concluding an internal investigation, cleared Steven P. Jobs yesterday of any misconduct in issuing backdated stock options at Pixar, the computer animation studio that Disney bought last year.

title: Pace Neednt Apologize (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Real Estate Broker in Southampton Faces Federal and State Child Pornography Charges
description: Federal prosecutors yesterday charged a prominent Southampton real estate broker with possession of child pornography that they said included images of infants being sexually molested.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article last Saturday about the shared grief of Muslim Malian immigrants in New York following a fire that killed members of two families misspelled the surname of the owner of Makbarat As-Salaam, a cemetery in Millstone, N.J., where some of the victims were eventually buried. He is Anthony Suleiman Sparno, not Spano. (Mr. Sparno, known as Tony, also uses Suleiman as a surname.)

title: Manchu Language Lives Mostly in Archives
description: The decline of the Manchu language has become a serious obstacle for historians studying the Qing Dynasty archives. Only a fraction of the extensive Manchu-language records held in Beijing and other regional centers have been translated and there are fewer than 40 translators working in these archives.

title: Irans President Vows to Keep Nuclear Project
description: TEHRAN, March 16  President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad vowed Friday that Iran would never dismantle its nuclear program, even in the face of toughened sanctions from the United Nations Security Council.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,195 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Southern Group Protests a Depiction of the Confederate Flag
description: TALLAHASSEE, Fla., March 16  A Tallahassee museum on Friday rejected a request by the local chapter of the Sons of Confederate Veterans to remove an exhibit the group considers disrespectful of the Confederate flag.

title: Gaza Gunmen Fire on U.N. Car in Possible Kidnapping Try
description: JERUSALEM, March 16  In what was apparently a kidnapping attempt, Palestinian gunmen on Friday fired 14 bullets into the armored car of the Gaza director of the United Nations refugee agency.

title: Defending His Title, Without His Twin
description: Jorge Torres will defend his title this morning in the United States mens 8-kilometer championship run in Central Park. Or, at least one can only assume that is Torres wearing bib No. 1.

title: Blacks Ex-Partner Pays $29 Million to Settle Civil Case
description: The longtime former business partner of Conrad M. Black settled a civil case with federal regulators yesterday by agreeing to pay $29 million on the eve of Mr. Blacks criminal trial.

title: Durant Puts on a Dazzling Show in Prime-Time
description: SPOKANE, Wash., March 16  CBS and the N.C.A.A. provided a prime-time showcase Friday night for the freshman Kevin Durant for viewers on the East Coast. Durant responded by scoring 27 points to lead the fourth-seeded Texas Longhorns to a 79-67 victory against 13th-seeded New Mexico State in the first round of the East Region.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A review yesterday of Annie Ross, who is singing at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evenings, misstated the clubs telephone number. It is (212) 206-0440.

title: Art as Art, Not Cash (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Men Will Be Men, but How Is the Question
description: On the surface, Tea and Sympathy, Robert Andersons 1953 play set inside a psychologically stifling boys boarding school, is an indictment of the dangerously limited ways Americans have codified masculinity. And from where we are perched now  the era of Project Runway, the Hedi Slimane suit, the $100 exfoliating creams just for men  the play would seem as applicable to our habits as a dial on a digital television.

title: Florida Girls Lift Weights, and Gold Medals
description: NEW PORT RICHEY, Fla.  She was an Atlas of the exurbs, hoisting a 210-pound barbell over her ponytailed head and holding it there, arms just barely aquiver, while the high school gymnasium exploded in cheers.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: On a Wing and a Prayer

title: White House Delays Action in Inquiry on Attorneys
description: WASHINGTON, March 16  The White House has delayed until next week a decision on whether to release additional documents and to permit top aides to President Bush, including Karl Rove, the chief political adviser, to testify in a Congressional inquiry into the dismissal of federal prosecutors.

title: For V.C.U. and Its Coach, Trust Is Contagious
description: BUFFALO, March 16  A simple gold chain, purchased at a hardware store by Coach Anthony Grant, has become a symbol of Virginia Commonwealths season.

title: Marc Torsilieri, 48, Provider of Annual Christmas Tree, Is Dead
description: Marc Torsilieri, who looked like a ginger-bearded lumberjack and played the part in splendid fashion by annually felling the Christmas tree for Rockefeller Center, died on March 12 in Somerville, N.J. He was 48, a little over half the age of most of the Norway spruces he helped find, transport, decorate and remove.

title: Whats on Monday Night
description: 7 P.M. (TLC) MY LIFE AS A CHILD In Different From You, the fourth installment of this series of life stories made by and about young people, four children describe what its like not to fit in and tell how they deal with teasing. This episode features an 11-year-old girl who just wants to play football, a 9-year-old boy who is ostracized for his unorthodox style, an 11-year-old American Indian girl and a 10-year-old boy whose older brother is autistic.

title: Kentucky Wins Battle of Former Champions
description: CHICAGO, March 16  The uniforms and the names of the universities were familiar, but their place in the world of college basketball seemed distant. Kentucky and Villanova, former champions of the N.C.A.A. tournament searching for a bright cap to disappointing seasons, found themselves meeting as middling participants of the opening round.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A review on Tuesday of Cecil Taylors trio and John Zorns Masada, at the Rose Theater, misstated the year that Lincoln Center began regularly presenting jazz concerts. It was 1987, not 1988.

title: Star-Spangled Schlemiel
description: Berkeley, Calif.

title: Rejuvenated Hantuchova Is Finding Her Way Back
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., March 16  At high noon Friday, the spectators here slathered on sunscreen, huddled under umbrellas and furiously fanned themselves during the first womens semifinal at the Pacific Life Open.

title: Inhabiting the Fringes, and Not Willing to Conform
description: Pity the curator with grand ambitions to present modern dance from faraway lands. More often than not, its a thankless task, thorny visa issues aside. What may seem experimental to foreign choreographers turns out to be, on a New York stage, rather pass.
