In Stories of Us, presented at Dance Theater Workshop on Thursday night, the Vietnamese choreographer Le Vu Long and his company, Together Higher, offer a production clearly inspired by Western dance forms with some lofty if indistinct aims of its own.

title: The Bad Boys of Investing Grow Up
description: EMERGING markets have a reputation for being the bad boys of investment. They can be volatile and self-destructive, yet there is something seductive about their rough, unfinished quality and growth potential that keeps investors coming back.

title: An Upset in the Vanderbilts and a Title in the Mixed Pairs
description: ST. LOUIS, March 16  At the Spring North American Championships here, the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams semifinals were played on Friday. The No. 4 seed (Lou Ann ORourke, Eric Greco, Geoff Hampson, Marc Jacobus, Norberto Bocchi and Giorgio Duboin) faced No. 25 (Piotr Tuszynski, Apolinary Kowalski, Farid Assemi, Nick Bykov, Srikanth Kodayam and Ed Wojewoda). The No. 7 seed (Christal Henner-

title: An R&B Star Who Doesnt Look Like One
description: How much would I have to change for you to love me? Robin Thicke was asking, and judging from the response on Thursday night at Irving Plaza, the answer was, Not one whit. (Or, to spell it phonetically, Woooo!)

title: Charisma and a Search for Self in Obamas Hawaii Childhood
description: HONOLULU, March 12  To his high school classmates, Barack Obama was a pleasant if undistinguished student, the guy who seemed happiest on the basketball court, the first to dive into the pumpkin carving at Halloween, the one whose oratorical prowess was largely limited to out-debating classmates over the relative qualities of point guards.

title: Mediate Seeks Redemption and Reunion With Palmer
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 16  The first time Rocco Mediate played golf with Arnold Palmer, he took $20 off him and the scorecard, too.

title: Richard S. Prather, Author of Naked Mysteries, Dies at 85
description: Richard S. Prather, a hugely popular mystery writer of the 1950s and 60s whose novels were known for their swift violence, loopy humor and astonishing number of characters with no clothes on, died on Feb. 14 at his home in Sedona, Ariz. He was 85.

title: Hot Tots, and Moms Hot to Trot
description: Bling-Bling Barbies and pouty-lipped Bratz. Thongs for tweens, and makeover parties for 5-year-olds. The past couple of shopping seasons have brought a constant stream of media stories  and books and school lectures and anguished mom conversations  all decrying the increasingly tarted-up world of young girls and preteens. Now the American Psychological Association has weighed in as well, with a 67-page report on the dangers of the sexualization of girls.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in some copies on Tuesday about the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremony misspelled the given name of a musician who paid tribute to the punk-rock-pioneer Patti Smith. He is Zack de la Rocha of Rage Against the Machine  not Zach.

title: For No. 1 Buckeyes, Late Shot Prevents Early Exit
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 17  For 39 minutes 51 seconds, Justin Cage had played flawlessly and had Xavier on the precipice of an unlikely upset against top-seeded Ohio State in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament Saturday. He had scored 23 points and battled the Buckeyes star center, Greg Oden, all afternoon. And now, out of frustration, Oden shoved Cage to collect his fifth foul.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption in some copies with a sports article last Saturday, about Georgetowns 84-82 victory over Notre Dame in a Big East mens basketball tournament game, misidentified the Notre Dame player in the No. 2 jersey. He is Tory Jackson, not his teammate Russell Carter. (As the caption correctly noted, Carter scored 21 points and missed a late shot for the lead. Jackson scored 20 points.) Also, the article referred imprecisely in some copies to the father of Georgetowns current coach, John Thompson III. His father, the longtime coach at Georgetown, is John Thompson Jr.  not Sr.

title: Oh, Mirror, Mirror, on the Wall, Whos the Naughtiest of Them All?
description: Its hard to know whether Ann Liv Young immediately sheds her performing self after her shows or goes home to Google herself incessantly, searching for (hopefully outrageous) mention of her anti-erotic spectacles.

title: Delays and Dangers as Messy Storm Hits Region
description: A harsh winter storm marked by a mixture of snow, sleet and freezing rain descended on the Northeast early yesterday, burying parts of the region in damp snow, halting air traffic at many airports and stranding thousands of travelers.

title: Wal-Mart Abandons Bank Plans
description: Few efforts illustrate the breadth of Wal-Marts ambitions  and the fears that they at times generate  as much as a nearly decade-long drive to establish its own bank.

title: Auditioning for the World Stage at an Austin Festival
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 16  As a recent favorite among music bloggers, the earnest indie-rock band Cold War Kids drew a teeming throng of hundreds to its performance on Thursday night at South by Southwest, the music industrys annual convention and music festival here. Offering a clutch of hooky riffs and anxious vocals, the band stood a chance to win new fans. But few are likely to match the influence of Naoki Shimizu, the Japanese music executive who watched silently from the back of the room, standing with arms crossed and bouncing on his toes.

title: Russia: Chechen Blames Moscow for Torture
description: Ramzan Kadyrov, the new president of the restive southern region of Chechnya, condemned what he acknowledged was systemic torture but sought to shift the blame to federal security officers, not local Chechen ones. His remarks came three days after the Council of Europe reported finding significant evidence of illegal detentions and torture of suspects in Chechnya, and accused Russian officials of ignoring the problem. The report noted that many of the accusations of abuse are leveled at Chechen forces loyal to Mr. Kadyrov. His remarks also underscored the tensions between Chechen and Russian officials, despite President Vladimir V. Putins open support of Mr. Kadyrov.

title: Iowa: Tar Baby Prompts an Apology
description: Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, offered an apology in Cedar Falls after using the term tar baby in answering a voters question about federal intervention in divorce and custody cases. In response to the question, Mr. McCain said he was not going to take a position that it was proper to declare divorces invalid because of someone who feels they werent treated fairly in court. He said, We are getting into a tar-baby of enormous proportions, and I dont know how you get out of that. When told afterward that some people considered the term a racial epithet, Mr. McCain responded, I hope that its not viewed that way. A moment later, he apologized, saying, I dont think I should have used that word, and I was wrong to do it. One of Mr. McCains rivals for the 2008 Republican presidential nomination, for Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts, apologized last year for using the term in referring to the troubled Big Dig highway project in Boston.

title: Colorado: Suit Filed Over Ejection From Speech
description: Two people who were removed from a presidential event in 2005 filed a lawsuit on Thursday against three White House staff members on the grounds that their rights to free speech had been violated. The two, Leslie Weise and Alex Young, were ejected from a speech given in Denver by President Bush because they arrived in a car with an antiwar bumper sticker, despite having done nothing disruptive, according to the A.C.L.U. of Colorado, which is representing them. The lawsuit names Steven A. Atkiss, James A. OKeefe and Greg Jenkins, all of whom worked for the Office of Presidential Advance at the time, as being responsible for the removal. Ms. Weise and Mr. Young filed an initial lawsuit in 2005 against two other individuals working at the speech.

title: Mortgage Trouble Clouds Homeownership Dream
description: Perhaps the American dream of homeownership is not for everyone.

title: In Looking at a Police Shooting, Jurors Views Lead to Compromise
description: To legal experts, yesterdays decision reached by a grand jury in the Sean Bell case appeared to be a compromise between those who think the police are too quick to shoot at unarmed black men and those who saw the hail of bullets as the officers justified efforts to protect their own lives.

title: Maybe a House Is Now Out of Reach, but Theres Always Furniture
description: AS the American housing market boomed in recent years, Americans took billions of dollars out of their homes and used the money to buy other things. When the housing market faltered, an important issue became whether that would drive down other spending, further slowing the economy.

title: Starting Slow, Florida Cruises
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 16  For 20 minutes against No. 16 Jackson State on Friday, top-seeded Florida looked vulnerable. It hit only 1 of 13 3-point shots, looked sluggish defensively and let the Tigers stay in the game.

title: Slowed Down, Rebels Still Move On
description: CHICAGO, March 16  Georgia Tech averaged more than 79 points a game during the regular season. Nevada-Las Vegas averaged 75. And when the teams looked at each other before their first-round matchup, they saw a lot of themselves. It was enough to expect a fast-paced, made-for-television game.

title: Strauss Speaks in a Softer Voice, Dense but Delicately Clear
description: The item of interest at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night was Richard Strausss String Sextet for the opera Capriccio, with the Orchestra of St. Lukes, conducted by Hans Graf, fattening the musics original dimensions to those of a chamber orchestra piece. In Strausss words-versus-music debate, the Sextet serves not only as an overture but also indirectly as a character. Flamand is Strausss onstage composer, who argues for the supremacy of operatic music over operatic texts; from the pit an example of his work is offered.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column yesterday about a decision by the Supreme Court of Canada upholding restrictions that bar the reporting of federal election results from eastern time zones while polls are still open in western time zones misstated the number of time zones in Canada. It is six, not five.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A headline on Tuesday with the obituary of Edgar Baitzel, an executive of the Los Angeles Opera, misstated his title. As noted in the article, he was chief operating officer, not chief executive.

title: New Jersey Men Die in Dive to Explore Ship Off Keys
description: MIAMI, March 16  Three New Jersey men died Friday while exploring a sunken Navy ship off the Florida Keys. A fourth man, who did not enter the ship, survived.

title: Taming Fossil Fuels
description: Each day seems to bring news of another prominent convert to the cause of requiring mandatory reductions in carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases. Each day also seems to bring news of technological advances that would make it possible to achieve those reductions without serious economic damage. Put all these glad tidings together, and Congress has all the reasons it needs to move quickly to regulate global warming emissions here at home, thus setting an example for the world.

title: Some More Numbers to Juggle in Figuring Out Retirement
description: WHEN a group of economists argued recently that Americans might be saving too much for retirement, Fidelity Investments could not have disagreed more.

title: New Jersey Men Die in Dive to Explore Ship Off Keys
description: MIAMI, March 17  Three New Jersey men died Friday while exploring a sunken Navy ship off the Florida Keys. A fourth man, who did not enter the ship, survived.

title: A Titan of Private Equity May Go Public
description: Private equity may soon be going very public.

title: Nissan Chief to Step Away From North America Unit
description: DETROIT, March 16  The chief executive of Nissan Motor, Carlos Ghosn, seemed like the rare executive who could be in three places at once  Japan, where he runs Nissan; France, where he is in charge of Renault; and the United States, where he oversees Nissans operations in North America.

title: Even if Perceptions Change, Beauty Finds a Way to Remain
description: Paul Taylor has spoken pithily about the ways a dances components can shift the viewers perception, even without any planning by the choreographer. In his Polaris Mr. Taylor explored how different a piece can look when repeated with different dancers, music and lighting. An interesting aesthetic exercise, but what matters most about this 1976 work, to a score by Donald York, is that it is one of Mr. Taylors most beautiful.

title: Mr. Shaw Goes to Harlem (and Meets Snoop Dogg)
description: What would George Bernard Shaw think about urban renewal or the United States current policy toward the poor? Or hip-hop music? Do you care?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a coalition of industrialists, environmentalists and energy specialists who are trying to eliminate the incandescent light bulb misstated the name of a business-environmental group that cooperates on global warming issues. It is the United States Climate Action Partnership, not the United States Carbon Action Program.

title: Iran Is Playing a Growing Role in Iraq Economy
description: NAJAF, Iraq  While the Bush administration works to stop Iran from meddling in Iraq, Iranian air-conditioners fill Iraqi appliance stores, Iranian tomatoes ripen on the windowsills of kitchens here and legions of white Iranian-made Peugeots sit in Iraqi driveways.

title: Airport Insecurity
description: HERES something depressing to think about the next time you stand in an endless security line at the airport during a business trip: the job application to become a Transportation Security Administration screener stresses how arduous the job is; for instance, being able to lift a 70-pound bag is a requirement. But the application takes just two minutes to fill out, and one part of the physical fitness test for a screener who was hired was conducted over the phone.

title: Afghans and U.S. Trade Charges in Death of 5 Police Officers
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 16  The government said Friday that soldiers of the American-led coalition had mistakenly killed five Afghan police officers on Thursday in the volatile Helmand Province. But the government later backed away from the accusation after the coalition strongly denied that its soldiers were involved.

title: Its No. 4 vs. No. 7 in Bridge Championship Today
description: St. Louis, March 17 - The 64-board final of the Vanderbilt Knockout Teams at the Spring North American Championships here will be between the No. 4 and the No. 7 seeds.

title: Action in Kazakhstan
description: Apparently a whopping correction is in order. John Ford was widely reported to have died in 1973, but it turns out he is alive and well and still making movies  in Kazakhstan.

title: Salukis Stopper
description: The most valuable player for Southern Illinois in its 61-51 victory over Holy Cross on Friday night scored 4 points.

title: A Killer Kind of Comedy
description: After the success of Wes Craven's "Scream" franchise  not to mention the unstoppable "Scary Movie" spawnings  it takes nerve to attempt yet another serial-killer parody. But nerve is exactly what Scott Glosserman's mockumentary, "Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon," has in spades, along with rapier-sharp observations and a firmer grasp of tone than many more generously financed projects. If Christopher Guest ever turned his attention to psycho killers instead of folk singers and dog breeders, this is exactly the sort of movie he would make.

title: Barcelona Striker Samuel Eto'o
description: Samuel Etoo turned 26 years old on Saturday, March 10, the same day 10-man Barcelona earned a rousing 3-3 draw against archrival Real Madrid at the Camp Nou Stadium in Barcelona.

title: Putting the We in Team
description: The first round of the 2007 NCAA Tournament is completed, and its safe to say, as much fun as it was, its unlikely that any snapshots from the past two days will be included in one of those misty highlights packages CBS trots out to advertisers. The closest we came to a buzzer-beater was Virginia Commonwealth guard Eric Maynors jump shot with 1.8 seconds left to beat Duke, and the first round lacked the signature upset that has become the hallmark of sports most democratic event.

title: Your Comments on my Middle East Column
description: My Sunday column is about U.S. policy toward Israel and the Palestinian territories, and the lack of a more open debate about it in U.S. political circles. Im leaving Saturday on a reporting trip to Afghanistan and Pakistan (though next Tuesdays column will be one Ive written in advance about Cheney), but please post your comments below on the Middle East column. And dont just comment on my column  comment on each others posts, or if you have expertise and someone raises a question, please answer it.

title: The Barefoot Contessas Recipe for Cheddar Corn Chowder
description: CHEDDAR CORN CHOWDER Serves 10-12

title: My Lunch With Ina
description: EAST HAMPTON, N.Y.  After I arranged an interview with Ina Garten for late last month, I asked if she could cook something so it could be photographed for my article. She immediately offered to make lunch. (O.K., as a food lover, I admit I hoped she would.)

title: F1s first qualifying has everything, including a surprise
description: Pole position for Kimi Raikkonen at Ferrari, Fernando Alonso second fastest, Nick Heidfeld third fastest and Lewis Hamilton crowning a great weekend with a fourth position. And Felipe Massa, the favorite of the winter testing finishing16th after his car broke down with a gearbox problem. Thats the surprise but should it be?

title: 2008: Top O the Day
description: Heres a rundown of some of the 2008 campaign coverage in several of the nations newspapers.

title: The Points Are Coming in Bunches
description: Vanderbilt never trailed against George Washington Thursday and won by 33 points. North Carolina never trailed against Eastern Kentucky later that night and won by 21. Xavier trailed by 9 with a little more than 16 minutes to play and rallied to beat B.Y.U. by 2. Texas A&M trailed by 2 with 13 minutes left and came back to beat Penn by 16.

title: Murder by Dummy
description: "Dead Silence" begins with a young couple opening a mysterious parcel containing a ventriloquist's dummy. Moments later, the husband, Jamie (Ryan Kwanten), goes for takeout, and the doll kills and mutilates his wife. Jamie, now a murder suspect shadowed by a smart-aleck detective (Donnie Wahlberg), drives to the couple's old hometown, buries his beloved and tries to learn if her demise had to do with an old local ghost story about a vengeful ventriloquist named Mary Shaw (Judith Roberts). Um, yeah.

title: The Quakers, Upon Further Review
description: Louisville Coach Rick Pitino had a good point the other day (not exactly the first time). He was talking about the scrutiny on all coaches, particularly in the northeast, and then he noted: It was a lot easier to get into coaching 15 years ago when there was no Internet or talk radio. Back then, the premise was that the fans knew that you knew more than them.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Huntington's
description: The Times's Amy Harmon was drawn to a dilemma of DNA testing: Is it better to know you will develop a disease, even if there is nothing that can be done?

title: Bluegrass Controversy
description: Eighth-seeded Kentuckys victory over No. 9 seed Villanova on Friday night pushed its streak of advancing to the N.C.A.A. tournaments second round to 16 straight years. But it hardly diminishes the pressure on Coach Tubby Smith.

title: What If They Switched Jerseys?
description: The battle of Ohio is under way  Ohio State vs. Xavier  and the first half has been spirited, both on the floor and in the stands. Both teams fans traveled well and have perhaps a third of the arena. The Xavier faithful may still bear hard feelings for Buckeyes Coach Thad Matta for the way he left the Musketeers three years ago after indicating he had no intention of leaving Cincinnati.

title: Pinch Us: The Bracket Loves a Parade
description: Thousands of pieces of bright-green clothing, stashed in closets and drawers for 364 days, found their way to downtown Chicago on Saturday morning. The people wearing the festive wear watched the Chicago River turn green. Dying the river is a tradition dating to 1961. The tradition of wearing garish green T-shirts requesting a kiss and plastic leprechaun-style hats is unknown.

title: Buyer Beware: Stolen Tickets in Columbus
description: The ticket brokers who will try to sell tickets outside Nationwide Arena in Columbus, Ohio, for Sundays second-round games are going to be watched very closely by the police. There are 550 stolen tickets on the loose.

title: Oh, No! Oh, Yes! O-H-I-O!
description: St. Patricks Day in Columbus, and everybody in OShaughnessys, the pub around the corner from Nationwide Arena, is wearing green. It is tough to pick out the Buckeyes fans because they are not wearing the usual scarlet and gray.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu: March 18
description: Given the week of storms that weve had, bookended by congressional hearings into the firings of United States attorneys, calls for Attorney General Alberto Gonzales to resign (and a presidential scolding from Mexico to boot), the Senate Democrats defeated (again) on an anti-war resolution, the House moving forward on its own and, no small matter, the appearance and voice  after long, long silence  of former C.I.A. officer Valerie Wilson testifying on the Hill, the Sunday news show lineup of guests reflects the gamut of politicians circling a White House under fire.

title: A Cut Above
description: One of The Brackets favorite recent N.C.A.A. tournament underdogs emerged in 2004, when a Nevada point guard named Todd Okeson led the No. 10 seed Wolf Pack to upsets of Michigan State and Gonzaga in the first weekend of the tournament. Okeson had the straight-from-central-casting story: he was from Weskan, Kan., a town of about 300 people, and he had received no other Division I scholarship offers.

title: Dont Blame Lofton on Tubby
description: Every time Tennessees Chris Lofton scores 20 points in a game, Kentucky Coach Tubby Smith gets beat up for not signing Lofton, who was Mr. Basketball in Kentucky in 2004.

title: The Awakening Of A Sleeping Giant?
description: Michigans firing of Coach Tommy Amaker on Saturday reverberated loudly throughout the Big Ten.

title: Butler Is Already Famous
description: While Butler is perhaps the team with the lowest profile in the Round of 16 thus far, the private, liberal arts university in Indianapolis boasts an eclectic list of former students and faculty.

title: Letters
description: Darwin's God

title: Palestinian Lawmakers Ratify Unity Government
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, March 17  The Palestinian legislature, with a third of its members in Israeli jails, met here and in Gaza by video conference and ratified a new national unity government today by a show of hands.

title: Checking His Temper, if Not the Oil
description: CAR trouble came naturally to our family. If we didnt quite invite it, we always made a place for it, expecting it and welcoming it. This is probably because my father never thought cars were anything you could much count on. You could depend on friends and family, possibly, and if material accessories were something you considered turning to, you might look to books or a decent fishing rod. But cars, no. He never did much to keep up the faux-woodie Country Squire, so when it got a flat, ran out of oil or started wheezing, it was just another sign of the innate frailty of the mechanical world. Whether he pulled over and called AAA or just kept puttering along, it was always with the same resigned acceptance.

title: Paradise, in Contract
description: One afternoon in December, Roy Patrao peered through a sturdy iron gate and scanned the gnarled roots of a tree embracing the ruin of an old stone house. Only a shell of the house survived, with thick columns holding up a portico. A window shutter made of seashells and slatted wood was visible amid the overgrown bush. On this plot of land, Patrao saw his dream.

title: In the Billiard Room, With a Candlestick
description: YOURE not supposed to judge a book by its cover. Can you say the same of dcor?

title: Easley Takes a Roundabout Route to the Mets
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 15  Damion Easley considers himself a New Yorker, but he can safely say that leaving is one of the best things that has happened to him.

title: From Among the Ruins, a Bustling Centerpiece
description: WHEN Ciro Scalera first visited the old building at 27 Halsey Street, seven years ago, it was in ruins  an all-too-apt metaphor for the state of downtown Newark in those days.

title: New Digs for Queen of the Fish
description: BATTAMBANG II, a grocery near Fordham University in the Bronx, could easily be considered a video and magazine store that also sells groceries. A wall is dedicated to contemporary Cambodian movies and karaoke videos, and the shelves are laden with Cambodian fashion magazines and Khmer-language newspapers. The small back room bulges with thousands of VHS tapes of serialized Cambodian soap operas and folk tales.

title: Sara Luft, Joshua Wechter
description: Sara Elena Luft and Joshua Zimmerman Wechter were married last evening at Temple Emanuel in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. Cantor Mark Biddelman performed the ceremony.

title: Rangers Find Offensive Touch and Pour It On
description: For a few minutes during the first period last night against the Boston Bruins, with forward Martin Straka lying face down on the ice at Madison Square Garden, it seemed as if the Rangers luck could not get any worse. Plagued by injuries, enduring a string of games decided by a single bounce in a close playoff race, the Rangers have made a habit of flirting with disaster.

title: Livonia, Michigan
description: Im part of a group of friends whove known each other since fourth grade, says Zeke Arzooyan, climbing his backyard ice wall, with his wife, Louise (left), and their daughter, Jewell. Every year we go ice climbing, and I set up the wall to practice here at home. I happen to have two huge trees that are eight feet apart. I put eight-inch lag bolts through eight-foot-long, four-by-four posts, spaced out every 32 inches. Then I drape fencing over both sides and cover it in cloth. Then comes the water. It runs continuously for two weeks straight. Its about 12,000 gallons of frozen water. All told, about $60 worth of water. Climbers come from all around the state to practice. Its free, but they have to sign a waiver. When were up there, the neighbors come out every now and then to take a peek. I know theyre thinking, What the hecks he up to now?

title: The Center Stayed Put, and Winthrop Plays On
description: SPOKANE, Wash., March 17  Craig Bradshaw made such a good impression while playing center for New Zealand in the 2004 Olympics that some coaches tried to persuade him to transfer from Winthrop to a university with a higher profile.

title: Nickels and Farms
description: Residents of the Hudson Valley should be paying close attention to a simmering debate in Albany over legislation that environmentalists call the bigger, better bottle bill and that water-carriers for the beverage industry call an onerous new tax.

title: Whose Life Is It?
description: Poor Nigel Hamilton; hes having a bad run of luck with big biographical projects. After publishing a respected three-volume biography of the British field marshal Bernard Montgomery, he embarked on the first book of a projected three-volume work on John F. Kennedy. JFK: Reckless Youth (1992) was a salacious but well-researched and insightful book about Kennedys early years. The experience of writing it, however, was so harrowing for Hamilton (he felt hazed by the toadies of the Kennedy family, he said, and had been thwarted by the fascistic spirit of the family loyalists at the John F. Kennedy library in Boston) that he gave up after just one volume. After Bill Clinton: American Journey, the first of a projected two-volume biography, took a critical pounding in 2003 (Michiko Kakutani, writing in The Times, called it a sleazy new low in the chronicling of presidential lives) it was an open question whether Hamilton would again feel moved to give up after one book.

title: Evolution of a Feminist Daughter
description: REBECCA WALKER  the daughter of Alice Walker, the author of The Color Purple, and Mel Leventhal, a civil rights lawyer  was a nascent feminist when she laid bare the details of her freewheeling, lonely adolescence in her 2001 book, Black, White and Jewish: Autobiography of a Shifting Self.

title: New Inflation Fears Cap a Rocky Week
description: It was another rough week on Wall Street and it ended with a thud, after a report on inflation on Friday alarmed many investors in advance of this weeks Federal Reserve meeting on interest rates.

title: Rollicking Ride Leaves Taylor in Lead
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 17  Arnold Palmer beat Mickey Mouse to this town by a few years, and an argument can be made as to who has left more stomachs in knots.

title: Why Wage Insurance Is Dividing Democrats
description: WASHINGTON

title: A Slow Emancipation
description: Once, when I was a child in Kumasi, Ghana, I asked my father, in a room full of people, if one of the women there was really my aunt. She lived in one of the family houses, and Id always called her auntie. In memory, I see her lowering her eyes as my father brushed the question aside, angrily. Later, when we were alone, he told me that one must never inquire after peoples ancestry in public. There are many Ashanti proverbs about this. One says simply, Too much revealing of origins spoils a town. And heres why my father changed the subject: my auntie was, as everyone else in the room would have known, the descendant of a family slave.

title: It Didnt Start With the Potato Famine
description: CHARLES F. CUMMINGS, the renowned city historian of Newark, loved to shed light on forgotten chapters of New Jerseys past. Several years ago, he decided his next project would be an exhibition commemorating the Irish-American experience in his home city and throughout the state.

title: Another Small Step Forward for Pavano
description: CLEARWATER, Fla., March 17  The sight was odd, to say the least. As the Philadelphia Phillies tapped fists in the infield after an apparent 3-2 victory against the Yankees on Saturday, Jorge Posada jogged onto the field in his catching gear, and the home plate umpire, Scott Barry, signaled the ball boy to bring him two more baseballs.

title: 36 Hours in Nairobi, Kenya
description: NAIROBI has always been a place in between. It started out as a pit stop on the Kampala-Mombasa railway, and today many tourists look at it the same way: a place to stop for the night, resupply and then leave at first light for a safari or jaunt to the beach. But the city, Kenyas capital, is emerging as a destination in itself. It has great restaurants, endless shopping, classy colonial-era hotels and plenty of wildlife within the city limits. You can play with baby elephants and hang out with giraffes and then dine on all the ostrich and crocodile you can eat. Its a thoroughly African city with a whiff of the old English era. True, Nairobi gets a bad rap for crime, but if you avoid cruising around late at night and keep a careful eye on your stuff, you shouldnt have any problems. Many first-time visitors say they are surprised by how comfortable they feel in the city.

title: Flip Taxes: A Pox on Sellers Profits
description: NEXT to a proposal to redecorate the lobby, the surest way to get a co-op or condo building buzzing is for the board to propose a flip tax.

title: Ever Wonder Who Makes Those Sparkling Skating Outfits?
description: Milford

title: Jesika McKenzie, Stephen Peterson
description: Jesika Leigh McKenzie and Stephen Christopher Peterson were married yesterday afternoon in front of the Hillsboro Inlet Lighthouse in Hillsboro Beach, Fla. The Rev. Larry Bergstrom, a United Methodist minister, officiated.

title: Tennessee Is Shedding Football-Only Reputation
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 17  When the allotment of tickets for Tennessees N.C.A.A. tournament appearance ran out, Volunteers fans left without tickets would not be shut out. Several joined the Long Beach State Athletic Association so they could get priority and buy some of the tickets allotted to Long Beach for the games here in the first two rounds of the tournament.

title: A Room for the Night (Not 40 to Life)
description: BOSTON

title: A Time to Mourn, a Time to Leap
description: ON Wednesday night, one week after the fire that claimed 10 lives in the Highbridge section of the Bronx, and less than a mile east of the house on Woodycrest Avenue that had burned, nearly two dozen people gathered in a community garden at dusk to light a more healing flame.

title: Pink Slip Blues
description: It is a brave author who embeds the rationale for writing his novel into the novel itself. But 70 pages into Joshua Ferriss first novel, set in a white-collar office, we meet Hank Neary, an advertising copywriter writing his first novel, set in a white-collar office. Ferris has the good sense to make Nearys earnest project seem slightly ridiculous. Neary describes his book as small and angry. His co-workers tactfully suggest more appealing topics. He rejects them. The fact that we spend most of our lives at work, that interests me, he says. A small, angry book about work, his colleagues think. There was a fun read on the beach.

title: Beyond the Bubble, With Small-Cap Stocks
description: SMALL-CAP stocks are significantly overvalued. In fact, they are even pricier, on average, than they were in March 2000, just before the Internet bubble burst. In contrast, the average large-cap stock is moderately undervalued.

title: Georgetown Outmuscles Its Former Big East Foe
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., March 17  A soaring slam, bruising blocks, rising tempers and dueling technicals. Who knew an old-fashioned Big East bash would break out in the middle of the N.C.A.A. tournament?

title: Little Films on Little Screens (but Both Seem Set to Grow)
description: IN the award-winning 2005 movie Black, the Bollywood actor Amitabh Bachchan plays an eccentric, disillusioned teacher who helps a blind, deaf and mute girl learn to speak and rejoin her family. But the Miracle Worker roles are reversed years later, when the girl discovers that her teacher is suffering from Alzheimers disease.

title: Tree Work by Con Ed Draws Criticism
description: Greenburgh

title: White Up to Old Tricks in Halfpipe Win
description: STRATTON, Vt., March 17  With a dominating victory in the final event of the competitive snowboard season, Shaun White made the case that he has returned to the form he showed last season, when he was undefeated in all disciplines and won a gold medal in the halfpipe at the Winter Olympics in Turin, Italy.

title: Always a Solid Citizen, Foyle Is Now an American One
description: Adonal Foyle used the word we last week to talk about the United States and, for the first time, he could be accurate as well as proud.

title: Passengers Recourse When Flights Are Delayed or Canceled
description: I am a Thai and travel frequently. Members of the Star Alliance are my favorite airlines. Could you give details on how airlines in Europe and the United States are obliged to compensate passengers when flights are delayed?  Pichai Kanivichaporn, Bangkok

title: Hansbrough Takes Charge as Tar Heels Quell a Threat
description: WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., March 17  Tyler Hansbrough took off his mask, revealing his face and unveiling the game that has made him an icon at North Carolina in only two seasons.

title: Waste Not
description: Pete Seeger has one. So do Abby Rockefeller, the Bronx Zoo and Glacier National Park. As of last year, so do I. Mine is a Sun-Mar nonelectric composting toilet.

title: At Any Age, Poetry Works Its Magic
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: A Team Gains Strength From Its Weakened Coach
description: RALEIGH, N.C., March 17  Already, it was going to be an arduous week for Kay Yow, the Hall of Fame womens basketball coach at North Carolina State: Blood work for a tumor cell count on Monday. Chemotherapy for Stage 4 breast cancer on Wednesday. An opening-round game in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Sunday.

title: Same Land, Different Buildings
description: PLAINVIEW

title: Why He Gets the Laughs
description: CALL it sheer coincidence. But when it comes to historical reputation, the nations 13th president may also be its unluckiest.

title: City of Refuge
description: AT 10 on a blustery night a few weeks ago, a slightly built 44-year-old Orthodox Jew named Isaac Schonfeld trudged to the top floor of the Millinery Center Synagogue.

title: In March, Protesters Recall War Anniversaries
description: WASHINGTON, March 17  Thousands of demonstrators marched to the Pentagon on Saturday to mark both the fourth anniversary of the American invasion of Iraq and the 40th anniversary of the march along the same route to protest the Vietnam War.

title: Schumann Retouched, Mendelssohn Revisited
description: SCHUMANN: SYMPHONIES NOS. 2, 4

title: Russ Whitney Wants You to Be Rich
description: Among the promises made after midnight to people who want to believe them, amid ads for the cream that will make you look young again and the motionless exercise system that will melt away your fat comes the voice from the television that asks, Are you among the thousands living paycheck to paycheck, just getting by, making payments on debts and credit cards?

title: Correction: Calendar of Events
description: A picture caption in the Calendar last week about a benefit concert today at the College of New Jersey in Ewing Township misdentified the performer shown. The photograph was of Sara Hickman, one of the scheduled performers  not Lisa Bouchelle, who is opening the benefit event.

title: Same Dance, New Partners
description: Suddenly, everything seemed oddly familiar in Albany, with the governor praising one house of the legislature while accusing the other of stalling. When there are three sources of power, as there are in New York States lawmaking apparatus, it often comes down to two against one. And the only difference between this dynamic and any ordinary sandlot tussle is that the odd man out  in this case, the Republican leader of the State Senate, Joseph Bruno  is capable of making lots of mischief.

title: G.O.P. Anger in Swing State Eased Attorneys Exit
description: ALBUQUERQUE, March 17  The first whiff of something suspicious came when a 15-year-old boy received a voter registration card in the mail. Soon a second one arrived. Then his 13-year-old neighbor got one, too.

title: Prostitutions Brutality (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Southern Illinois Ousts Virginia Tech
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 18  While other teams might count points as a sign of value to their team, Southern Illinois counts stitches. Three Saluki players had stitches taken out just before the start of the N.C.A.A. tournament, a sign of how nasty they practice against each other and what other teams are up against.

title: Max Hoffman Made Imports Less Foreign to Americans
description: THE cars of Honda and Toyota, which Americans first came to know as underpowered imports from across the Pacific, are today so Americanized it is easy to forget that their names are derived from their companies founders.

title: U.S. and Israel Differ on Palestinian Contacts
description: JERUSALEM, March 18  The first fractures surfaced Sunday in the Israeli and American approaches to the new Palestinian unity government, with Israels cabinet voting overwhelmingly to boycott it, while the United States Consulate here refused to rule out contacts with some moderate Palestinians who are now serving as ministers.

title: If the Mirror Could Talk (It Can)
description: TRACY NOAH is a self-described shopaholic who stops by Bloomingdales in Manhattan every day during lunch hour. But last Thursday she came upon something new: a prototype for an interactive mirror stationed among the embroidered cotton dresses and duster pants in the Nanette Lepore department. Displayed in a vintage-looking white wooden frame, the full-length mirror doubled as a three-part high-resolution digital screen.

title: A Texas-Size Hunger for Gulf Coast Condos
description: GALVESTON, Tex.

title: Permanent Vacation
description: 1. Paisley flower-patterned cotton printed rug from Urban Outfitters: $28 at www.urbanoutfitters.com.

title: Suicide Bombers Using Chlorine Gas Kill 2 and Sicken Hundreds in Western Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, Sunday, March 18  Three suicide bombers driving trucks loaded with explosives and tanks of chlorine gas detonated their payloads in Anbar Province on Friday, killing at least two Iraqi police officers and wounding or sickening more than 350 people, the American military command said Saturday.

title: Correction: Coast Lines
description: The Style article on March 4, about up-and-coming mens-wear designers, misstated the stores where some of the Nicholas K clothing is available. The pants on Nicole Kunz, the lines designer, are available at Hampden Clothing, Charleston, S.C. The jacket worn by her brother, Christopher, is available at Hollywood Trading Company at Fred Segal, Santa Monica, Calif.; his shirts are at Klasse LA, Santa Monica, Calif. None of those items are available at Odin, 199 Lafayette Street, New York.

title: Bracket Cant Come Between Coaching Buddies
description: Lexington, Ky.

title: Seeking a Solution to Darfur Genocide (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Indie Rapper Reseizes the Brooklyn Moment
description: WRITERS and musicians often fixate on certain landscapes at certain times. For Thoreau in the 1840s it was Walden Pond. For Madonna in the 1980s it was her body. For the rapper-producer El-P (birth name Jaime Meline) in the 00s its post-9/11 New York.

title: Ice Men
description: Writing fiction isnt an activity for the faint-hearted, and anyone who has managed, as Dan Simmons has, to generate two dozen books (in an impressive variety of genres) in just 22 years clearly deserves credit for discipline, diligence, resolve and, most of all, confidence. His will to persevere  to see every story, short or dauntingly long, through to the bitter end  has been regularly fortified by the recognition of his peers: his rsum includes a Hugo award (from the World Science Fiction Society), four Bram Stoker awards (from the Horror Writers Association) and a couple of World Fantasy awards. His latest opus, however, raises the disturbing possibility that this energetic writers hard-earned self-assurance may be tipping over into something more like hubris. The Terror is a 769-page novel about men stuck in the ice.

title: Fisher Gives Series Two Women at Wheel
description: Two women are expected to drive in the first race of the IndyCar Series season Saturday night in Homestead, Fla. It would be hard to find anyone who has not heard of Danica Patrick. The other woman actually preceded Patrick.

title: St. Patricks Day, and All Its Traditions
description: The cardinal seemed to strike an unusually solemn note for a St. Patricks Day.

title: Storm Over an Ill-Starred Chapel
description: On the Upper West Side, where churchgoers are few and real estate is dear as gold, West-Park Presbyterian Church has a familiar problem. Its roof leaks, and its 117-year-old walls are shedding chunks of brownish-red sandstone.

title: Albany Divided on Calculation of School Aid
description: ALBANY, March 17  For years, school aid in New York has been calculated with dozens of formulas that make the Human Genome Project look downright intelligible by comparison. But year after year, no matter which districts gained or lost students, or what data was plugged into the formulas, New York City always received close to 39 percent of new spending and Long Island received between 12 and 13 percent.

title: Myslivecek; Joan Didion
description: MYSLIVECEK A Composer Overshadowed

title: For Neighbors, Happiness Is a Two-Way Street
description: THE news that the citys Department of Transportation was considering a plan to reroute two main streets through Park Slope leaked out slowly at first, but spread quickly.

title: Down the Middle
description: For the past few years weve been flooded with national housing-market statistics  chronicling a boom, predicting a bust. But as any homeowner knows, national numbers dont tell you much about whats happening in the local housing market. For that you have to go deeper. Whats striking if you look closer is that different patterns emerge, says Jonathan J. Miller, chief executive of the New York-based real estate appraisal and consulting firm Miller Samuel Inc. In New York, for instance, were finding bidding wars in some markets and prices dropping in others.

title: Rona Shalev and David Kraut
description: Rona Shalev, a daughter of Diane Shalev and Isaac Shalev of New York, is to be married this afternoon to David Todd Kraut, the son of Deborah Schneider Kraut and Dr. Jeffrey A. Kraut of Santa Monica, Calif. Rabbi Marvin Tokayer is to perform the ceremony at Temple Emanu-el in Closter, N.J.

title: Two Veterans of Bad Old Days in Brooklyn
description: LITTLE BUDDY, a k a Jack Solomita, age 3, stood on a dining room chair and swung a blue and green key chain decorated with a logo for the still-a-dream Brooklyn Nets basketball team. His father, Pete Solomita, a chef who bakes cookies at home for his Little Buddy Biscuit Company, winced.

title: Foot-in-the-Door Plan Offered to Slim Schools
description: THE vision was sweeping: demolish the latticework of bureaucracy within the states school districts. Eliminate pricey superintendents. Merge tiny districts into larger ones. Ax support staff, chop out boards of education and save local taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars in the process.

title: Increased Pay for Judges; Giving Jobs to Illegal Aliens; School Textbooks Arent Necessary; A Dog Park in Huntington (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Panoply of Personality in One Coaching Matchup
description: CHICAGO, March 17  No one, including Bo Ryan himself, is quite sure what words will spill from his mouth next.

title: Facing Life With a Lethal Gene
description: The test, the counselor said, had come back positive.

title: Preservation, vs. Live and Let Build
description: COMING upon Park Hill, a stately 19th-century neighborhood of mansions and bungalows on a 300-foot-high wooded plateau overlooking the Hudson River, is like discovering a never-never land.

title: Pakistan and Islamists (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Butler Silences Maryland, and Some of Its Skeptics
description: BUFFALO, March 17  Butler was ranked among the nations top 20 teams for most of the season, a position that was accepted by some, but questioned by others.

title: After an Apartment Is Deregulated ...
description: Q If the renewal rent on a rent-stabilized apartment goes from below $2,000 to above $2,000, my income for the last two years was over $175,000 each year and my landlord takes all of the appropriate steps to destabilize the apartment, will I be allowed to live out the term of my new lease?

title: The Commuting Conundrum
description: IN many ways, commuter railroads are a victim of their own success.

title: Shannan Carter, Michael Hollingsworth
description: Shannan Elizabeth Carter and Michael Rinehart Hollingsworth were married yesterday. Msgr. Robert B. OConnor performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Blessed Sacrament in New York.

title: Tuition Trick
description: My ex-husband and I each agreed to pay for half of our son's education. Because he is enrolling in a university where his dad teaches, our son receives a tuition remission, but my ex insists that I must still write him a check for half the tuition because that tuition waiver is his benefit, not mine. Am I ethically obligated to pay?  H.H., New Jersey

title: Calendar of Events
description: COMEDY

title: Where the Dinner Table Is an Altar of Thanks
description: ETHIOPIA is not a country people go to for food. But despite its lack of culinary fanfare, Addis Ababa, the capital city, has a rich and unexpected food culture. And more than just great meals, this is food that comes with a story.

title: Wanted: Room to Pli
description: On a hectic afternoon last week at the Dance Studio of Park Slope, a row of parents and restless siblings lined one wall of a practice room, sitting on a long bench across from a wide mirror. Arrayed before them was a group of 5-year-old girls in leotards, the occasional fluffy pink tutu and, in one case, a black and pink T-shirt bearing the words Dancers Rock.

title: How to Cut the High Cost of Flying to Africa
description: FOR American travelers, one of the biggest expenses of any trip to Africa, whether a South African safari or a beach holiday in the Seychelles, is simply getting there. During high season most flights cost $2,000 or more round trip  in coach  and require stopping or changing planes. And while a few airlines, like Delta and South African Airways, have been adding more convenient routes, fares have continued to rise.

title: Bonnie Kerker, Peter Ephross
description: Bonnie Diane Kerker, an epidemiologist, was married in New York last evening to Peter Joseph Ephross. Rabbi Andrew Bachman officiated at the Central Park Boathouse.

title: Hope Springs Maternal
description: One of the pills most pernicious side effects is bloat in the publishing industry. For most of history, having a baby  or heck, a dozen  has simply been womens natural lot, not something they had time or inclination to examine at any length. Now the journey to motherhood, as it is often called, is something to be feared, postponed, mulled and eventually exalted in endless memoirs, or mom-oirs (though plenty of dads are writing them too). The majority of these are extremely tedious. Its difficult to think of another subject so miraculous in its fundamentals, yet so banal in its particulars.

title: Nanny, $44,880; Redskins Owner, 0
description: A nanny who said that Daniel M. Snyder, owner of the Washington Redskins, had underpaid her won $44,880 last week when a Montgomery County Circuit Court in Maryland agreed that she had not been compensated for overtime hours she had worked.

title: Sudanese in Israel Hope They Have Found a Home
description: MOSHAV HEREV LAET, Israel  It is a simple tin shed on the edge of a carrot field, but the young man from Darfur is relieved to call it home.

title: American Players Are on a Roll, Especially One 15-Year-Old
description: American players have had a very successful stretch over the last few months.

title: Free Lunch Returns (And Why Its Not Free)
description: At the Trash Bar on Grand Street in Williamsburg, the smell of fried potatoes hangs heavy in the air. At a booth fashioned out of car seats from junkyard vans, three 20-somethings fish potato nuggets out of a cardboard container, then dunk them in ketchup before gobbling them down. And the best part about them? Theyre free  with the price of a drink.

title: The Week in New Jersey
description: Custody Dispute Derails McGreevey Settlement

title: Its All Geek to Me
description: Seattle

title: Baseball Stole His Eyes, but Not His Passion
description: JERSEY CITY

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Illustrations of William Wordsworth and Samuel Taylor Coleridge on Page 18 of the Book Review today with a review of The Friendship: Wordsworth and Coleridge, by Adam Sisman, are reversed, and the credit for the engraving of Wordsworth is rendered incorrectly. Wordsworth, who is shown on the right, should be on the left and the credit should read: Mansell/Time Life Pictures  Getty Images. (Go to Article)

title: Dial Tone
description: Prepaid Phone Cards

title: The Dog Just Wants to Help. So Does He.
description: Babylon

title: Look Whos Talking
description: SUE PIKE, a slender 45-year-old who lives in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, does not consider herself a cat whisperer. She is, however, in the business of psychically healing these most touchy of mans animal companions.

title: Manny Being Manny Is Hurting the Red Sox
description: The 86-year Curse of the Bambino ended when the Boston Red Sox won the 2004 World Series. But as long as the American Leagues best right-handed hitter plays left field in Fenway Park, the teams fans will continue to moan about Manny being Manny.

title: Cape Town, South Africa:  Extreme Hotel Cape Town
description: THE BASICS

title: In Vast City, Tragedy Fades if Not Kept Vivid
description: Ten Malians in the Bronx are laid into the earth, and three innocents lie dead in Greenwich Village. Soon enough these tragedies could begin the slow fade from municipal memory.

title: Make Way for Copyright Chaos
description: Berlin

title: Your Manager Is a Bully (but You Arent Helpless)
description: Q. Your boss regularly berates you in department meetings, and the behavior is starting to become offensive to you. What should you do?

title: New LIPA Chairman Stressing Conservation
description: KEVIN LAW, Gov. Eliot Spitzers choice as the new chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, is making no pledges that Long Island electric rates, now among the nations highest, will drop more than modestly anytime soon.

title: Struggling Maier May Be Nearing End of His Run
description: LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland, March 17  Hermann Maier said Saturday that he would wait until this summer to decide whether to continue racing now that he has completed the least successful season of his extraordinary career.

title: St. Anns Mother Hen and Her Crowded Nest
description: IF Susan Feldman could explain why The Princess and the Pea is her favorite fairy tale, believe her, she would. She isnt one for holding back. Not her ideas about music, theater and performance art. Not her commitment to tough, raw, emotion-provoking material. Not  as her friend Rosanne Cashs dad might have put it  her penchant for walking the creative line where the sharpest edges are cut.

title: Documentary Maker Starts by Focusing on a Person
description: ON a recent Saturday, Nick Doob was limping around his house in Hastings-on-Hudson. He had injured his leg in a minor biking accident during one of his daily 32-mile round trips between his home and his office on the Upper West Side. In addition to being an avid cyclist, Mr. Doob is a documentary filmmaker who has balanced freelance camerawork with producing, directing and editing his own films over the past four decades.

title: Look at Me, World! Self-Portraits Morph Into Internet Movies
description: NOAH KALINA flew to Switzerland last month to attend the opening of Were All Photographers Now, an exhibition at the Muse de lElyse in Lausanne. The show is a survey of trends in digital photography, particularly portraiture, and Mr. Kalina produced its foremost example of how technology is changing the genre. His globally popular video everyday is composed of 2,356 daily self-portraits shot from Jan. 11, 2000, to July 31, 2006.

title: Texans Find Their Own Hamptons Equivalent
description: GALVESTON, Tex.

title: Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: My Parents Couldnt Outlive, or Outrun, Each Other
description: TODAY such a marriage would not raise eyebrows. But for my parents generation and class, they truly married on the cusp. At 40, my father seemed destined for lifelong bachelorhood; at 29, my mother was on the brink of becoming an old maid.

title: Laos Sees Possibility of Tourism in Caves Used During the Secret War
description: A network of caves promises to further illuminate the secret war the United States waged in Laos against the North Vietnamese, but may also help open a region in need of tourism revenue.

title: Storm Brings New Woes to Travelers at Kennedy
description: Fourteen hours after boarding an airliner to fly to North Africa for an endurance run across the Sahara, Jeremy Colgan walked through the cabin door and back onto the jetway today. In the ice storm that pelted the New York area overnight, the plane never left Kennedy International Airport.

title: In Handbag Gallery, Neighbors See a Nuisance
description: EAST HAMPTON

title: Correction: Follow the Earrings, and Find the Mystery Woman
description: An article last Sunday about The Earrings of Madame de ..., a film based on a novel by Louise de Vilmorin, referred incorrectly to the writers father. He was a botanist who helped run the French horticultural house Vilmorin-Andrieux; he was not a furniture manufacturer. Also, the article referred incorrectly to the career of Danielle Darrieux, one of the stars of the film. She appeared in a few films during World War II; she did not sit out the Occupation.

title: Theres More Than Meets the Eye
description: THERE are three basic ways to drive a Mini Cooper, each pleasurable.

title: Truly Human
description: Thirty years ago, I was a housewife, a renegade housewife who left her clothes at the Laundromat in San Francisco and ran off to Mexico to live with the Indians. I wanted magic, poetry and genuine human warmth. Not that I knew where I was going; I just headed south beyond the freeways and the shopping malls, past volcanoes and pyramids, toward the highlands of Chiapas, where the contemporary Maya live. I ended up among the true people in a place called the Belly Button of the World.

title: Airlines Learn to Fly on a Wing and an Apology
description: DALLAS  Airlines are getting serious about saying theyre sorry.

title: The Early Bird Catches the Condo
description: THE more information, the better. That was Dr. Moitri Chowdhury Savards motto when it came to hunting for an apartment for her family.

title: With 3,200 Flights a Day, a Few Problems
description: Even when skies are clear and the nations air traffic control system is running perfectly, airlines have to contend with problems that cause delays. The 482 Boeing 737s that Southwest Airlines operates make about 3,200 flights a day. As at other airlines, something is always going wrong.

title: Nowadays, a Candidate Can Seem Too Experienced
description: RUNNING a credible campaign for president has always required an elusive mixture of star power and experience. But Barack Obamas strong challenge to Hillary Clinton and Rudolph W. Giulianis recent surge past Senator John McCain in the polls raise an interesting question: How much does experience matter now in presidential politics?

title: Volunteers Sweat Out Final Shot
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 18  The Tennessee bench screamed, Foul him! In Nationwide Arena, where the Ohio State Buckeyes play some of their games, the Volunteers feared an Ohio State moment was coming.

title: Putting Fears of Counterfeit Wines in Perspective
description: UNLESS their preferred vintage is a 1961 Chateau Latour, or something equally pricey, wine-lovers chilled by the recent news of a federal investigation into the sale of counterfeit wines can relax when they open a bottle, experts say, because nobody is interested in counterfeiting bargain wines.

title: At Home in Their Niches. And Breaking Out.
description: Cupid

title: Show Me the Moneyless
description: How does traveling the world asking poor people why they think theyre poor differ from traveling the world asking people in pain why theyre in pain or thirsty people why they thirst? Is this a serious, legitimate inquiry, or does it betray a certain faux-autism that might be better suited to performance art? These are two of my questions for William T. Vollmann, the prolific, award-winning novelist and journalist whose new book, Poor People, centers on just such a Pyrrhic, postmodern project: asking the unfathomable of the unfortunate and using their numbed, predictable responses as proof of their plights intractable mystery.

title: Seeds of Doubt
description: What if you woke up one morning and lost faith in the power of words to describe your world? What if your own most heartfelt admissions sounded, to you, like cheap self-deceptions, illusions, slogans anyone could use? What if you were a poet of supreme concision  having learned much from Emily Dickinson  and you wanted to make vivid, bitter poems from that anxious and baffling predicament?

title: Cleaning Up the 20th Century
description: BEIJING

title: Female Coach Leads Boys Team Into Final
description: Ruth Lovelace is a rarity. She is the coach of a boys high school basketball team. Today, she will become an even bigger rarity: the first woman to coach a boys team in a New York City Public Schools Athletic League final at Madison Square Garden.

title: Please Dont Tell Her Shes Funny for a Girl
description: ON a rare winter weekend when Saturday Night Live was in reruns and Amy Poehler had not been called upon to play Hillary Clinton, Paula Abdul, Nancy Grace or any of the dozens of women she gleefully cuts down to size, she could have spent her Sunday evening any way she wanted  say, at home, with the phone disconnected, catching up on much-needed sleep. Instead she was standing on the subterranean stage of the Upright Citizens Brigade Theater in Chelsea, navigating through another marathon night of performing, this time without the benefit of cue cards or a script.

title: All Creatures Great, Small ... and Endangered
description: AFTER completing the nature documentary The Blue Planet  a $10 million, eight-part BBC series that took 20 camera teams five years to shoot, spawned an international concert tour based on its Emmy-winning score and eventually was shown in more than 50 countries  its producer, Alastair Fothergill, could have taken a well-deserved break.

title: For No. 1 Buckeyes, Late Shot Prevents Early Exit
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 17  For 39 minutes 51 seconds, Justin Cage had played flawlessly and had Xavier on the precipice of an unlikely upset against top-seeded Ohio State in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament Saturday. He had scored 23 points and battled the Buckeyes star center, Greg Oden, all afternoon. And now, out of frustration, Oden shoved Cage to collect his fifth foul.

title: The Ides of March 2003
description: TOMORROW night is the fourth anniversary of President Bushs prime-time address declaring the start of Operation Iraqi Freedom. In the broad sweep of history, four years is a nanosecond, but in America, where memories are congenitally short, its an eternity. Thats why a revisionist history of the White Houses rush to war, much of it written by its initial cheerleaders, has already taken hold. In this exonerating fictionalization of the story, nearly every politician and pundit in Washington was duped by the same bad intelligence before the war, and few imagined that the administration would so botch the invasions aftermath or that the occupation would go on so long. If only I had known then what I know now ... has been the persistent refrain of the war supporters who subsequently disowned the fiasco. But the embarrassing reality is that much of the damning truth about the administrations case for war and its hubristic expectations for a cakewalk were publicly available before the war, hiding in plain sight, to be seen by anyone who wanted to look.

title: Abu Dhabi Explores Energy Alternatives
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates, March 14  On the outskirts of this Persian Gulf boomtown, past an oil refinery and a water desalination plant, the foundations are being poured for an ambitious project that will house a research facility and perhaps even a power plant, all intended to take this oil-producing giant into the next energy wave.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: BOULDER DINING

title: Officers Charged in Shooting Face Problems Beyond Court
description: It is up to the courts now to decide the fate of the three city detectives who were indicted in the death of an unarmed black man in Queens.

title: Melanie Young and David Ransom
description: Melanie Anne Young and David Linsley Ransom were married last evening in New Orleans. Judge Charles A. Imbornone of Orleans Parish First City Court performed the ceremony at Commanders Palace, a restaurant.

title: Talking About Israel
description: Democrats are railing at just about everything President Bush does, with one prominent exception: Mr. Bushs crushing embrace of Israel.

title: Feeling the Pressure
description: 1. Symptoms

title: Calendar of Events
description: Music and Dance

title: Up Front
description: James Poniewozik, Time magazines television critic, reviews Joshua Ferriss first novel  a book about office culture  on this weeks cover. Ive worked my own share of marginal office jobs, Poniewozik admitted in an e-mail message. The people and the milieu were much like those Ferris describes, just lower-pressure and lower-paid. I knew quickly he got the milieu right.

title: Most of Ethiopa Is Safe to Visit, Tour Firms Say
description: Despite the recent kidnapping of five Europeans and eight local people in the Afar region of Ethiopia near the disputed border with Eritrea, adventure tour operators say travelers should not be dissuaded from visiting Ethiopia.

title: Marlins Linescore: 3 Betrayals of Fans in 10 Years
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.

A picture on March 4 with an article about a screenplay of Paradise Lost was printed upside down. The rebel angels should have appeared in the lower half of the illustration by Gustave Dor, which was inverted by Art Resource.

title: North Haven, Big-Box Central, Shifts Gears
description: NORTH HAVEN is home to some 23,000 people, four interstate exits and big-box stores like Home Depot, Target, B. J.s, T. J. Maxx and OfficeMax. Rarely is the town accused of smart growth.

title: Subsidized Houses for Rich People
description: Next time you sit down to write your monthly mortgage or rent check, consider this: In Santa Barbara, about 90 miles northwest of Los Angeles, a public-private partnership is planning to build a subsidized-housing development for some families earning as much as $177,000.

title: TV Land
description: What makes a house a home is a topic suitable for poetry. But a house or a home is always something else. It is property. Does this fact contain poetry? Probably not. But it does contain entertainment. Its a form of television entertainment Id never paid the slightest bit of attention to until I got involved in buying property myself, which happened right around the time that the long housing boom was unraveling last year. Previously invisible to me, these entertainments were, for months, the only things I wanted to watch. Buying, selling, updating, restoring and flipping for quick profits  it all ran together, but I watched even when I couldnt remember if the title of a certain show was Flip This House or Flip That House.

title: The Basics
description: Popular routes from New York to Nairobi are through London on British Airways (www.ba.com) or through Amsterdam on Northwest/KLM (www.klm.com), each less than $1,600 round trip for tickets purchased a month in advance. You can arrange airport pick-up through your hotel, but its easy, safe and cheaper to grab a cab at the airport. The fare downtown runs around 1,000 Kenyan shillings (about $14, at 71 shillings to the dollar).

title: Britain Wonders if More Elections Equal More Democracy
description: LONDON

title: New Yorks Unarmed Bravest
description: New York relies heavily on its full-time police officers to keep the lid on crime rates that have fallen so far they rival those in much smaller towns. But many of the officers who help keep New Yorks streets safe are in fact volunteers  unarmed, unpaid and, we learned this week, in some cases tragically and unnecessarily vulnerable.

title: A Gallerist Turned Developer
description: ON the southeast corner of Hester and Baxter Streets in Lower Manhattan, a new building called 123 Baxter is marketing 21st-century amenities: refrigerators with Internet connections and an automated underground garage.

title: Works That Speak Volumes in a 19th-Century Poets Voice
description: The title of Wave Hills generally buoyant but sometimes dark and very uneven spring show by 10 contemporary artists is Emily Dickinson Rendered. It suggests a channeling of the brooding poet and recluse, who spent almost all her life in the familys houses in Amherst, Mass. When she died in 1886, her sisters discovered 40 hand-bound volumes of more than 1,700 of her poems. Few had ever been published.

title: Why Do My Pipes Keep Clogging Even When I Clean Them Repeatedly?
description: GROSSWENDT: The first thing you should do is hire a plumber who can snake a camera down the pipes to see what is going on. You may have tree roots that have grown into your sewer lines, which is a typical problem, believe it or not. In a kitchen, the likely culprit is grease that has built up to the point where normal cleaning won't fix it.

title: German Grapes From Two Eras
description: Elbling, an ancient white Mosel grape grown on limestone, and Dornfelder, a red grape bred in 1956, provide Germany with savory minor wines.

title: For a Press Baron, a Showdown in a City He Barely Knew
description: Chicago

title: Prince of Darkness
description: Joe Hill is the first guy to admit that its probably a good thing he took up writing instead of acting. He was just 9 years old when the zombie auteur George Romero cast him in Creepshow, a 1982 fright flick written by Hills dad, who also played a dimwit farmer. There were all these cool rubber monster parts lying around, Hill told me over dinner in December. For a little kid, it was a blast. There was my dad, there was some one-on-one time with my dad. But I was terrible. Oh, was I bad. The bit about his father he sort of tucked into the conversation as if it were an aside. His dad is a topic he discusses with great reluctance, not because he doesnt love the guy but because when you are as much your fathers son as Joe Hill is Stephen Kings, once you start talking about your dad, you might never get a chance to talk about anything else.

title: They Break for Summer
description: JAMES GISANTE peered out the window of the Island Cafe on City Island Avenue during lunchtime on Tuesday, taking in all the clangorous machinery outside. Dump trucks rumbled over holes in the ground, backhoes kicked up thick clouds of dust and giant excavators stood ready for action.

title: A Twisting Ride to the Web
description: MY life is like a quilt rather than a blanket. I need to collect experiences.

title: Balancing Party Loyalty and a Duty to Justice
description: An uninitiated visitor to the federal courtroom in Newark where the former New Jersey Senate president John A. Lynch Jr. pleaded guilty last September to charges of official misconduct and tax evasion would have found it hard not to wonder about the identity of another character in the room.

title: Can I Get an Amen?
description: In 1950, as the gospel singer and guitarist Sister Rosetta Tharpe was preparing for a guest performance on Perry Comos television show, The Chesterfield Supper Club, she was instructed to climb into a horse-drawn wagon and sing White Christmas while simulating a country hayride. The Rosettes, her backing group, were told to wear bandannas. Tharpe objected to this latter indignity  not an easy thing to do for a veteran singer hungering for a large audience  and the Rosettes eventually performed without the demeaning bandannas. As Gayle F. Wald demonstrates in Shout, Sister, Shout!, a short, absorbing biography, this was just one of many instances in which the expectations of the entertainment industry and the aspirations of this genre-defying artist were painfully out of sync.

title: Nonprofit Show, but Moneys Riding On It
description: EVERYONE is doing it these days.

title: Chinese Village Struggles to Save Dying Language
description: SANJIAZI, China  Seated cross-legged in her farmhouse on the kang, a brick sleeping platform warmed by a fire below, Meng Shujing lifted her chin and sang a lullaby in Manchu, softly but clearly.

title: The Inexplicable Lightness of Obesity
description: In the land of the 16-ounce steak, the supersize cola and the grande cappuccino, bigger always seems more desirable than smaller. Except, of course, when whats bigger is the person actually having the steak, the cola or the cappuccino.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture caption with an article last Sunday in T: Mens Fashion magazine, about the actor Richard Gere, carried an incorrect identification from Everett Collection, a photography archive, for the actress shown with Mr. Gere in a scene from the film The Hoax. She is Julie Delpy  not Hope Davis, another cast member.

title: Is It the Real Thing? Or Can You Actually Drive It?
description: For enthusiasts who want to own the car made notorious by the actor James Dean, theres a choice:

title: The Week in Connecticut
description: After Teenagers Death, Change in Road Promised

title: Letters: The Partial Digitization of World History
description: To the Editor:

title: Sweeping Him Off His Street
description: After 13 years of avoiding what he calls the Giuliani sweeps  when the streets were emptied of homeless by the police during freezing weather  and searching for safe places to spend the night on the street, Cadillac Man is finally coming in from the cold.

title: Vaughn and Rutgers Still Have Work to Do
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., March 14  After a Nike camp for basketball prospects four years ago, one analyst on oldgoldfreepress.com, a Purdue athletics Web site, called Kia Vaughn a power post player who will bump and grind when others will try to pivot around.

title: Little Consistency in Bus Safety Standards
description: DR. ALAN ROSS did not develop a passion for school bus safety until 10 years ago, when his son asked why there were no safety belts on the bus he rode to school in Litchfield County, Conn.

title: U.N.L.V. Runs Wisconsin Out of the Tournament
description: CHICAGO, March 18  After his team lost to Wisconsin in the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, Texas A&M-Corpus Christi coach Ronnie Arrow did not hesitate to predict Wisconsins demise. He said that Nevada-Las Vegas matched up well with the Badgers and would beat them.

title: Caring for the Bottom Line
description: Think of all the hospital ads you have seen recently, and you will quickly realize how much importance these institutions attach to the bottom line. But the zeal of one hospital to protect its finances violated any sense of medical ethics.

title: A Young Life Full of Drive, Humor and Purpose
description: Max Marshalik remembered the older brother who protected him, taking the blame once for a Chicken McNugget stain he had left on an expensive sofa. Jacob Feygin recalled the childhood friend who helped him learn to ride a bicycle and overcome his fear of roller-coasters. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly talked about the auxiliary police officer who, in his final training exam, received the highest grade in his class.

title: Personal Sound Effects
description: THE director Mira Nair could be forgiven for hewing to one subject on a recent Friday night. Her new film, The Namesake, was having its premiere in two New York theaters: uptown at the Paris Theater and downtown at the Angelika Film Center.

title: Daring to Bet That Americans Would Take a Shine to Imports
description: FOR more than a year, my father has been driving around Boulder, Colo., in a Toyota Prius. This might seem like an odd development for a man whose career as a foreign car dealer was defined in many ways by a bitter lawsuit with Toyota in the 1960s, but it spotlights some of the reasons Toyota is poised to pass General Motors as the worlds largest carmaker.

title: Playing SimCity for Real
description: For much of the past century, the hills and valleys around Los Angeles have been a kind of developers paradise, a patchwork of expansive ranches, many dating to the 1840s and 1850s, that supplied builders with a seemingly endless stock of raw acreage. As the region boomed, subdivisions and office parks spread steadily over these former ranch lands, until Los Angeles County encompassed not only Los Angeles but also nearly a hundred other smaller cities. How much bigger the area can get may be a matter of geography. West and south is the Pacific Ocean. East is desert. And the Angeles National Forest and San Gabriel Mountains bound the northeast. It may not be the case that the Southern California dream has run its course here. But the dream may be running out of room.

title: In an Easter Dress, a Social Set Revealed
description: St. Louis

title: Nadal Makes Short Work of Roddick
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., March 17  In a blink, the semifinal match between Rafael Nadal and Andy Roddick was over Saturday.

title: A Little More Sunlight
description: A tree trunk shattering in the wind can sound very much like a lightning strike. I braced for the worst when I heard that sound a few months ago while lying in bed at home in Brooklyn. My first thought was that the gargantuan locust tree belonging to my next door neighbor was about to come crashing down, pounding my cherished garden into rubble and perhaps even caving in the rear wall of my 19th-century brownstone.

title: When Regulators Knock Twice
description: EVEN dead cats bounce, as the idiom goes, and the stocks of subprime lenders did just that last week. Fremont General, a financial company with a big subprime unit that it is trying to sell, is up 51 percent since it disclosed that it had received a cease-and-desist order from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation after the markets closed on March 2. The stock closed on Friday at $8.90.

title: Correction: History, Digitized (and Abridged)
description: An article last Sunday about the digitization of historical documents referred incorrectly to a 1968 letter from Jacqueline Kennedy to Leonard Bernstein, part of a Bernstein collection that was donated to the Library of Congress. The letter, which thanked Bernstein for conducting a Gustav Mahler work at the funeral of Robert F. Kennedy, was referring to the Adagietto movement from Mahlers Fifth Symphony; Mrs. Kennedy did not thank him in the letter for conducting Mahlers Requiem. (Mahler never composed a requiem.)

title: Welcome to the Club
description: DO not be fooled. The Poona Club is just a state of mind.

title: Is Paying Off a Loan a Good Idea?
description: AS many homeowners dip into their home equity, a small but growing number are doing the opposite  paying off their mortgages quicker than lenders require.

title: How to Soften the Edges of Technology
description: ITS a given these days that computers come sheathed in plastic or metal, as do the keyboards, mice and monitors that accompany them.
