description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Bush Pleads for Patience in Iraq on Wars Anniversary
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  President Bush marked the fourth anniversary of the start of the Iraq war today by prodding Congress to pass an emergency war-spending bill and by warning the American people that hard days lie ahead.

title: Detainee Alleges He Was Beaten in U.S. Custody
description: LONDON, March 19  David Hicks, the first detainee to be formally charged under the new military tribunal rules at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, has alleged in a court document filed here that during nearly five years in American custody he was beaten several times during interrogations and witnessed the abuse of other prisoners.

title: Behind the Veil at Blackstone? Probably Another Veil
description: WALL STREET is eager to get its hands on the Blackstone Groups prospectus to get a peek inside the private equity powerhouse, which is notorious for its secrecy. But investors may be disappointed at what few details they discover if the firm decides to go ahead with the initial public offering it is said to be considering.

title: Win Leaves Nadal at Loss for Words
description: INDIAN WELLS, Calif., March 18  After winning his first title since the French Open last June, Rafael Nadal still could not relax.

title: In Dueling Financial Studies, Fuel for New York-London Rivalry
description: Engaging in their own form of March madness, New York City and London are each proclaiming to have come out on top when matched up against a group of world capitals.

title: Researchers Track Down a Plague of Fake Web Pages
description: Tens of thousands of junk Web pages, created only to lure search-engine users to advertisements, are proliferating like billboards strung along freeways. Now Microsoft researchers say they have traced the companies and techniques behind them.

title: Manhattan: Antiwar March in Midtown
description: Thousands of war protesters, including union members, veterans and church groups, marched through Midtown yesterday afternoon, starting at Bryant Park and moving along 42nd Street, up Third Avenue to 57th Street and down Second Avenue to 47th Street. The demonstration was one of several nationwide, including one on Saturday in Washington, in advance of the fourth anniversary of the invasion of Iraq, which is tomorrow. The police lined the sidewalks along the route, which passed the offices of Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer. No violence was reported during the march, and no arrests were made, the police said.

title: Proposals for Mental Health Parity Pit a Fathers Pragmatism Against a Sons Passion
description: WASHINGTON, March 18  Its Kennedy versus Kennedy as two members of Congress from the same family face off over competing versions of legislation that would require many health insurance companies and employers to provide more generous benefits to people with mental illness.

title: Memphis Turns Its Weakness Into a Winning Ingredient
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 18  By ending its victory against Nevada in the second round of the N.C.A.A. tournament by scoring the games final 14 points, the Memphis basketball team showed that two of its perceived weaknesses were strengths.

title: Wolfpack Wins One for Yow, and Dreams of Winning More
description: RALEIGH, N.C., March 18  Mornings are the worst time for Kay Yow in her battle against Stage 4 breast cancer. The cumulative effects of chemotherapy have drained her energy. Her toes have grown numb, and she must concentrate when she takes a step.

title: Jay Kennedy, 50, an Editor and Scholar of Comic Strips, Is Dead
description: Jay Kennedy, who as editor in chief of King Features Syndicate revived Prince Valiant and introduced the popular newspaper comic strips Curtis, Mutts and Zits, died on Thursday in Costa Rica. He was 50 and lived in New York City and Orient Point, N.Y.

title: A Promotion to Sell Cars by Losing the Keys
description: HOW does a carmaker unlock the door to reaching distracted, elusive customers in an increasingly competitive category? Nissan North America is hoping the answer may lie with, um, keys.

title: In Shriner Spending, a Blurry Line of Giving
description: ABILENE, Tex.  John C. Goline is living proof of the good work done by the Shriners. Struck by polio as a child, he can walk today only because of his six years in and out of the Shriners hospital in Shreveport, La., where, like all patients, he received free treatment.

title: Atlantic City Aiming Higher as Casinos Slip
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 14  Making money used to be so easy in this doleful seaside resort, at least if you were in the casino business: Efficiently shuttle a steady parade of day-tripping grandparents clutching rolls of quarters through midmarket gambling halls, and success was all but assured.

title: Gunfire and Fights Erupt in Midtown After School Basketball Game
description: Gunfire broke out last night as thousands of teenagers left Madison Square Garden after a high school championship basketball game, the police said. Witnesses said they heard three to six shots, but the police said no one was injured.

title: When Kuhn Intruded on a Rivalry
description: For better or for worse, Bowie Kuhn had a major effect on much of baseball history as commissioner from 1969 to 1984. He put the World Series in prime time and the designated hitter in the American League. Instead of attending the game in which Hank Aaron broke Babe Ruths career home run record, he sent an emissary. He rejected Curt Floods plea to overturn his trade from the Cardinals to the Phillies. He suspended George Steinbrenner, Ted Turner and Denny McLain. He barred Mickey Mantle and Willie Mays for promoting casino gambling.

title: Singing and Doing the Hustle in Austin
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 18  Marnie Stern was onstage alone with her guitar in one among more than a thousand showcase concerts at the annual South by Southwest Music festival. She wasnt exactly a typical singer-songwriter. Her guitar was electric; her backup band was an iPod clipped to a belt loop, and it blasted crashing, galloping drums and her own recorded guitars as she layered on frenetically repeating runs and slashing chords. Connected, connections, connected, connections, she sang.

title: Opposition Official Beaten as Zimbabwe Crackdown Grows
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 18  Zimbabwes crackdown on the nations political opposition expanded on Saturday and Sunday to block foreign travel by leading government critics, and one official of the main opposition party was severely beaten while en route to Harares airport for a flight to Brussels.

description: SPOKANE, Wash., March 18  In the first half of Oregons 75-61 victory against Winthrop on Sunday, a 5-foot-6 freshman Duck, guard Tajuan Porter from Detroit, was covering a 6-10 senior Eagle, center Craig Bradshaw from New Zealand.

The paper has been in a tense standoff with its current and former reporters, who overwhelmingly voted to unionize last fall.

title: In New Hampshire, Towns Put Climate on the Agenda

title: Manhattan: New Job for Former M.T.A. Chief
description: Katherine N. Lapp, the executive director of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority from 2002 through 2006, has been appointed executive vice president for business operations at the University of California. Ms. Lapp, 50, will be paid $400,000 a year to oversee administrative operations for the university system, managing real estate, human resources, information technology and procurement. A lawyer, Ms. Lapp worked on criminal justice issues in New York in the administrations of Mayor David N. Dinkins, a Democrat, from 1990 to 1993; Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, from 1994 to 1997; and Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, from 1997 to 2001.

Maybe there are deep, even sinister connections that bind Thomas Weelkess gentle counterpoint to Sam Amidon yelling hillbilly music at the top of his voice.

description: BEIJING, Monday, March 19  The United States and North Korea have resolved a standoff over North Korean funds frozen in a Macao bank, clearing the way for talks to focus on putting in place a nuclear disarmament accord, American and Chinese officials said Sunday.

title: When Rendering Decisions, Judges Are Finding Law Reviews Irrelevant
description: I havent opened up a law review in years, said Chief Judge Dennis G. Jacobs of the federal appeals court in New York. No one speaks of them. No one relies on them.

title: Corrections: For the Record

It was St. John the Apostle, sometimes known as St. John the Beloved Disciple, grasping the robe of the Virgin  not John the Baptist. The review also misstated the source of the items in the exhibition. Five of the nearly 100 pieces were borrowed from private collections; not all came from the Mets collection.

title: Odd World as G.O.P. Seeks More Spending

When the Republican-led State Senate called last week for spending more in next years budget than did the Democratic governor, Eliot Spitzer, or the Democratic-led State Assembly, newspapers around the state marveled at what one called a political Freaky Friday and another termed Bizarro world, a nod to the alternate, topsy-turvy universe of Superman and Seinfeld fame.

title: Physical Salukis Make Sure Hokies Have a Rough Day

title: Senator Insists Bush Aides Testify Publicly

title: Connecticut Shows Its Superiority

Perhaps still smarting from a loss to Rutgers 12 days earlier in the championship game of the Big East tournament, the top-seeded Huskies trounced No. 16 Maryland-Baltimore County, 82-33, in a relentless display of superiority in the Fresno Region.

description: Exaggerated fears that illegal immigrants are fraudulently receiving Medicaid health benefits have led to a crackdown that is preventing tens of thousands of American citizens from obtaining legitimate coverage. Congress, whose mindless actions led to this travesty, needs to fix this injustice.

title: U.S. and Israel Disagree on Palestinian Contacts

title: Pure Movement Bubbling Forth From Its Deep Source
description: Tina Croll describes her Ancient Springs as a journey of the spirit. Well, such journeys are a dime a dozen on the citys dance stages. But Ancient Springs, performed on Saturday night at the Danspace Project at St. Marks Church, is an imaginative, beautifully performed pleasure because it can be looked at simply as dancing.

title: Colombia May Extradite Chiquita Officials
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 18  Colombian officials said over the weekend that they would consider seeking the extradition of senior executives of Chiquita Brands International after the company pleaded guilty in United States federal court to making payments to paramilitary death squads.

title: My Fellow Boomers, Time to Transition
description: If Christopher Buckley played fair, he would wait for things to happen before making fun of them. But he prefers to position himself just ahead of the curve, somewhere in the scantly distant future, the place where fanciful extrapolations of reality are born. By now just about every species of Washington huckster has been treated to Mr. Buckleys style of prescient ridicule, yet political life ceaselessly tosses him bait. In Boomsday that bait is the notion that an indignant young blogger armed with a copy of The Fountainhead might balk at being forced to pay the baby boom generations Social Security bill.

title: Official Alerted F.B.I. to Rules Abuse 2 Years Ago, Lawyer Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 18  Almost two years before the Federal Bureau of Investigation publicly admitted this month that it had ignored its own rules when demanding telephone and financial records about private citizens, a top official in that program warned the bureau about widespread lapses, his lawyer said on Sunday.

title: Barclays Bank Makes Inquiry on Takeover of ABN Amro
description: LONDON, March 19  Barclays, one of Britains largest banks, has made an informal takeover approach for ABN Amro Holding, the largest bank in the Netherlands, which is under pressure from hedge funds to consider a merger or asset sales to bolster its lagging share price.

description: A business partner of Conrad M. Black and three companies will pay $63.4 million to settle claims and debt with the Sun-Times Media Group, the company said yesterday.

description: SO PAULO, Brazil  In their heyday, Estevam and Snia Hernandes were the Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker of Brazil, on television preaching a gospel of material success and living a life to match.

title: Even Superfluous Options Can Satisfy
description: To satisfy customers, purchases should be like airplane novels: lengthy but undemanding, full of meaningless, engrossing twists and turns.

title: Free Throws Help Nets Buy Playoff Insurance
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 18  The playoffs are anything but a lock for the Nets and the Los Angeles Clippers. So they must treat the few regular-season games that remain with an intensity fit for the postseason.

title: Two Firefighters Charged With Assault
description: Two firefighters were arrested and charged with assault in separate incidents on Saturday, the police said. The first firefighter, Harry Pfeiffer, 27, and his friend Nicola Ciaramella, 27, are charged with attacking a third man, Ronald Buonagura, 31, with a shovel at Mr. Buonaguras home in Howard Beach, Queens, about 7 p.m., the police said. Mr. Buonagura in turn stabbed Mr. Pfeiffer and Mr. Ciaramella with a knife, the police said; none of the men were seriously injured. All three were charged with weapons possession and assault, the police said. They said the fight appeared to be over a woman. The second firefighter, Douglas Barry, was arrested shortly before 11 p.m. at Broadway and Warren Street in Manhattan and charged with third-degree assault, the police said. He is accused of punching a woman in a dispute over a cab.

title: History Lessens

title: Different Morning Newscast for Public Radio Listeners
description: The New York public radio station WNYC is teaming up with the distributor Public Radio International to produce a national morning radio program that will compete with National Public Radios long-running and popular Morning Edition.

title:
Russia Gives Iran Ultimatum
on Enrichment
description: PARIS, Mar. 18  Russia has informed Iran that it will withhold nuclear fuel for Irans nearly completed Bushehr power plant unless Iran suspends its uranium enrichment as demanded by the United Nations Security Council, European, American and Iranian officials said.

title: Bomb Attacks in Baghdad and Kirkuk
description: A suicide bomber struck a Shiite mosque in Baghdad during prayers today, killing at least six worshippers and wounding 32, police said, according to news service reports.

title: U.S. Embassy Convoy in Afghanistan Is Attacked
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 19  A suicide car bomber attacked a convoy of vehicles carrying United States embassy officials on a busy road in Kabul today, seriously injuring an American security guard who was traveling in one of the vehicles. A 14-year-old Afghan boy was killed; witnesses said there were other civilian injuries as well.

title: A Gun in My Home: Is It My Right? (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Brooklyn: Carbon Monoxide Forces Evacuations
description: About 300 people were evacuated from more than 50 homes in Sunset Park for several hours yesterday because of a carbon monoxide gas leak resulting from a manhole fire, the Fire Department said. Seven people, including two unconscious women and two paramedics, were taken to area hospitals after the evacuations, which took place shortly after noon on 55th Street near Seventh Avenue; none suffered serious injuries, the department said. Others were treated at the scene, above. A resident, Danny Lee, 26, said he called 911 after his carbon monoxide detector went off and he smelled smoke coming from his basement. It worked, he said of the detector. Thats why Im standing here talking to you.

title: The Strange Career of a Boy With an Edge, or Several
description: Nighttime, of the inkiest blue variety. A dowdily dressed old woman slowly hobbles by, leaning on her cane. Thunder sounds, but, coatless, she pauses to stare up at the gleaming words slashed across that sky: There once was a boy named Edward Scissorhands. ... And a magical realm beckons in which almost everything interesting happens on dark and stormy nights.

title: Peers Say a Union Leader Compromises Contract Talks
description: TRENTON, March 18  The presidents of five unions that represent New Jersey state workers charged on Sunday that their contract negotiations were being undermined by the personal relationship between Gov. Jon S. Corzine and Carla Katz, a labor leader who accepted hundreds of thousands of dollars in gifts from Mr. Corzine after they ended their romance in 2004.

title: Lincoln Defends Its Title in P.S.A.L. AA Division
description: Late in the third quarter last night, Lincoln High Schools plan for winning the Public Schools Athletic Leagues AA division city championship became abundantly clear, if it was not already. Lance Stephenson demanded the ball, dribbled to his right and buried a 3-point shot.

title: For 5 Lost in Bronx Fire, Rest in Malis Red Earth
description: BAMAKO, Mali, March 18  The men were the first to gather around the unfilled graves on Sunday, using rope to lower Fatoumata Soumare and her four childrens wooden coffins into the red Malian earth.

title: It Wasnt Just a Bad Idea. It May Have Been Against the Law.
description: The Bush administration has done a terrible job of explaining its decision to fire eight United States attorneys. Story after story has proved to be untrue: that the prosecutors who were fired were poor performers; that the White House was not involved in the purge. But the administration has been strangely successful in pushing its message that the scandal is at worst a political misdeed, not a criminal matter.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about plans by the Internet search giant Google to build two facilities in Lenoir, N.C., misstated the month it announced the decision. It was January, not February.

title: A Division of NBC Buys Out One of Its Harshest Online Critics
description: In a review of Top Design, the reality show on Bravo Networks, a staff writer for the Web site Televisionwithoutpity.com mused that in the future, the show would be just another filthy memory whose outcome Ive long since forgotten.

title: Mexico Questions Police Officials About Ambush
description: MEXICO CITY, March 18  Three high-ranking state police commanders and a former police chief were being held for questioning on Sunday in the attempted killing of the Tabasco State secretary of public security, after hundreds of soldiers and federal agents raided the police headquarters there the day before.

title: After an Upset, Marist Finds Itself in the Second Round and on the Map
description: One day after Marist stunned Ohio State in the first round of the womens N.C.A.A. tournament, Alisa Kresge and her teammates were still buzzing yesterday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An architecture review on Tuesday of housing complexes in the skid row area of Los Angeles misidentified the location of the planned New Carver Apartments. They are slated for a site along the 10 Freeway, not the 110 Freeway. Also, a picture caption with the review carried an incorrect credit. The image, of a model of the Carver Apartments, was by Michael Maltzan Architecture  not Will Carson/Michael Maltzan Architecture.

title: Still Not Fixing the Army Corps
description: Readers will recall that the Democrats promised to upend the status quo as soon as they won majority control. But some things, it appears, are untouchable, among them the Army Corps of Engineers. Presented with another opportunity to reform the Corps  its weaknesses exposed by the levee failures in New Orleans and other misjudgments predating Hurricane Katrina  Democrats on the House transportation committee took a dive.

description: New-media companies and record labels are feuding again. But this time, it is the digital companies that warn they may be driven out of business.

title: Injury Scare for Mets Hernndez Is a Very Short-Lived One
description: JUPITER, Fla., March 18  The Mets had an injury scare Sunday with their planned No. 2 starter, Orlando Hernndez, but it appeared inconsequential as Hernndez took a significant step toward solidifying the Mets rotation.

title: Death of a Marine
description: Jeffrey Lucey was 18 when he signed up for the Marine Reserves in December 1999. His parents, Kevin and Joyce Lucey of Belchertown, Mass., were not happy. They had hoped their son would go to college.

title: A Less-Than-Perfect Florida Survives a Scare
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 18  With the score tied and less than eight minutes remaining in top-seeded Floridas second-round N.C.A.A. tournament game, the Purdue band struck up a familiar song.

title: Uproar Over Memphis Power Brokers Unpaid Bills
description: MEMPHIS, March 16  Everybody has to pay the light bill, an unpleasant maxim lately made even more so here, knowing the powerful do not always observe it.

title: Lycos, Early Search Engine, in a U.S. Remake as Jubii
description: Through a quirk of dot-com history, Lycos Europe cannot sell itself in the United States using its own once-famous name. Instead, the Internet service, partly owned by Bertelsmann of Germany and Telefnica of Spain, is remaking itself for the American market using the brand and services of Jubii, its Danish search and community business.

title: Ridge: Off-Duty Officer Catches Suspect
description: A day after graduating from the Suffolk County Police Academy, an off-duty officer arrested a driver on Saturday who was running from the scene of a crash on Route 25, the Suffolk County police said yesterday. The officer, Anthony Napolitano, who had seen the crash from inside his car, arrested the driver, Steven Kowalski, after a brief pursuit in a wooded area, the police said. Mr. Kowalski, 31, of Farmingville, was charged with driving while intoxicated and leaving the scene of an accident with injury, the police said. The two occupants of the other vehicle involved in the crash, which occurred about 5:30 p.m., suffered injuries that were not life-threatening, the police said; their names were not released. Officer Napolitano is to officially begin work today at the Fourth Precinct in Hauppauge.

title: The Week Ahead
description: FED MEETING The Federal Reserve Open Market Committee will conduct a two-day meeting, to conclude Wednesday. It is expected to keep the benchmark interest rate steady at 5.25 percent, as it has since June, but analysts will be looking closely at its statement for clues to where interest rates are heading.

title: A Young Life, Full of Drive and Humor, Lost in Duty
description: Max Marshalik remembered the older brother who protected him, taking the blame once for a Chicken McNugget stain he had left on an expensive sofa. Jacob Feygin recalled the childhood friend who helped him learn to ride a bicycle and overcome his fear of roller-coasters. Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly talked about the auxiliary police officer who, in his final training exam, received the highest grade in his class.

title: Brutality, Thy Name Is Love (and Thy Flavor Farce)
description: As an undergraduate Brian Harris studied creative writing at Princeton. He went on to get a M.B.A. at the University of Chicago and work as a stock analyst. Some time ago he abandoned all that to heed his earlier calling, and his new play, Tall Grass, suggests he made a decision wiser than it might seem.

title: Real ID Madness (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article by Reuters on Saturday about the creation of a joint military command for Ivory Coast, a step toward unifying government and rebel forces, incorrectly described the current military situation. The government controls the south, while the rebels control the north, not the other way around.

title: Manhattan: Officials Support Union Effort
description: City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. and Representatives Jerrold Nadler and Anthony D. Weiner put their weight behind an effort to unionize 362 Verizon telephone workers yesterday, confirming that a majority of the workers had signed cards saying they wanted to join the Communications Workers of America. The three political leaders confirmed that 219 of the 362 workers had signed pro-union cards as union officials called on Verizon to grant union recognition because of this majority showing. But Verizon is invoking its right under federal law to ask for a secret-ballot election overseen by the National Labor Relations Board to determine whether a majority wants a union. The 362 employees, who install telephone equipment for businesses, work for a unit called Verizon Business. They worked for MCI before Verizon acquired MCI last year. The group was not unionized under MCI.

title: Detainee Said to Confess Role in Cole Bombing
description: A top Al Qaeda operative acknowledged his role in the bombings of two American embassies in Africa in 1998 and in the attack on the U.S.S. Cole in Yemen in 2000, according to a transcript released by the Pentagon today.

title: Grabbing Momentum, Jayhawks Outdo the Wildcats
description: CHICAGO, March 18  A quick burst of action early in the second half of Kansas 88-76 victory against Kentucky on Sunday served as a microcosm of the difficulty of beating the Jayhawks, the top seed in the N.C.A.A. tournaments West Region.

title: Explosion in Coal Mine Kills 61 in Siberia
description: MOSCOW, March 19  A methane gas explosion this morning killed at least 61 people in a Siberian coal mine, located in a region notorious for mine accidents. Some 64 more were alive but trapped underground by early evening, emergency officials said.

title: Mussina Can Smile After Fourth Start of Spring
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 18  Five days turned grouchiness into sunshine. Mike Mussina stood in the Yankees clubhouse at Legends Field on Sunday afternoon with ice wrapped around his right shoulder and with a grin on his face, eager to discuss his first effective outing of the spring  one, he felt, that had been too long in coming.

title: Dont Cry for Reagan
description: As the Bush administration sinks deeper into its multiple quagmires, the personality cult the G.O.P. once built around President Bush has given way to nostalgia for the good old days. The current cover of Time magazine shows a weeping Ronald Reagan, and declares that Republicans need to reclaim the Reagan legacy.

title: A Review for I Love New York Will Proceed Without Incumbent
description: A review to find an agency for the tourism campaign for Empire State Development, known by its theme, I Love New York, will proceed without the incumbent since 2003, Eric Mower & Associates.

title: Ripples of Sensuality, and an Insatiable Vampire
description: The composer David Del Tredici turned 70 on Friday, and the New Music Collective of the Brooklyn Conservatory of Music observed the occasion with an evening of his recent music on Saturday. Mr. Del Tredici fundamentally reshaped contemporary American composition in the 1980s by rejecting modernism in favor of tonality. Yet for all the lasting effects of that move, this concert felt like a private salon: audience members appeared to know one another, and some were heard mentioning other well-wishers who had failed to get tickets for the sold-out performance.

title: Officers Charged With Manslaughter in Bell Case
description: Two New York City police detectives pleaded not guilty today to charges of manslaughter in the death of Sean Bell, the unarmed 23-year-old black man who died in a burst of 50 police bullets.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the account by Dmitri V. Kovtun, a Russian business consultant, of his dealings with Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer who died of radioactive poisoning in November, omitted part of a credit. Alan Cowell not only contributed from his home base in London, but he also reported from Moscow with Steven Lee Myers.

title: Pet Food Is Recalled After Link to Animal Deaths
description: More than 60 million cans and pouches of dog and cat food sold under dozens of brand names were recalled on Saturday after being linked to the deaths of 10 animals.

title: All the Worlds a Story
description: Journalism has always been a product of networks. A reporter receives an assignment, begins calling sources  people he or she knows or can find. More calls follow and, with luck and a deadline looming, the reporter will gain enough mastery of the topic to sit down at a keyboard and tell the world a story.

title: Viacoms Full-Court Press for Online Ads
description: Justin Timberlake did not attend Nickelodeons annual advertising presentation this month, but one of Viacoms own ad sales executives, Jim Tricarico, took the stage to perform a rendition of the singers SexyBack.

title: City Vows to Improve Aid to Homeless Families
description: With the number of homeless families at a record high halfway into Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs five-year plan to reduce the homeless population by two-thirds, city officials are acknowledging missteps in their approach and are looking to revamp a controversial rent subsidy program geared toward poor families.

title: Winner in Central Park Has the Route Down Cold
description: Anthony Famiglietti lives on the Upper East Side, less than a mile from Central Park. He runs in the park every day, fast enough to have become a 2004 Olympian in the steeplechase.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the account by Dmitri V. Kovtun, a Russian business consultant, of his dealings with Alexander V. Litvinenko, the former K.G.B. officer who died of radioactive poisoning in November, omitted part of a credit. Alan Cowell not only contributed from his home base in London, but he also reported from Moscow with Steven Lee Myers. (Go to Article)

title: Robbery Suspect Says the D.E.A. Made Him Do It
Tracking Asteroids (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Sorrow for Afghanistan: AIDS Joins List
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 13  Sitting and eating quietly on his fathers lap, the 18-month-old was oblivious to the infection in his veins.

title: Mancuso Finishes Third; Climate Is Story of Season
description: LENZERHEIDE, Switzerland, March 18  Julia Mancuso, a 23-year-old from Squaw Valley, Calif., finished third in the overall standings of the 2006-7 World Cup circuit, the best finish for an American woman since 1984.

title: After Lean Times, Prizes and Not One Apology
description: LONDON, March 18  Lionel Shrivers novel We Need to Talk About Kevin was an incendiary device of a book about family dysfunction at its most acute. It won the 2005 Orange Prize for fiction, got fantastic reviews and huge sales, and seriously inflamed its readers. Many found it mesmerizing, if painful; some wanted to hurl it out the window.

title: Stuart Rosenberg, Director of TV and Films, Dies at 79
description: Stuart Rosenberg, a hard-working director of series television and theatrical films who captured the simmering anti-authoritarianism of the late 1960s in the widely popular Paul Newman prison drama Cool Hand Luke, died on Thursday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 79.

title: Love? Obey? These Vows Are to Nag or to Shoot
description: Havent womens magazines and Dr. Phil gone a long way toward saving us from truly bad marriages? Dont couples compromise more than they complain? Arent they home right now drawing up rosters so that the person who takes out the garbage on Wednesday and Friday doesnt have to do the dishes on Tuesday and Saturday? And arent these people always talking, talking, talking; keeping their love alive, the passion burning, the flame high?

title: Does Free Speech Exist in School?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Fred F. Fielding, the new White House counsel, referred incorrectly to the Democratic congressman from California to whose Capitol Hill office Mr. Fielding paid a courtesy call as one of his first acts in his new job. He is Representative Henry A. Waxman; he is not a "Jr."

title: The Beginnings of Morality?
description: Dr. Frans de Waal argues that human morality would be impossible without certain emotional building blocks that are clearly at work in chimp and monkey societies.

title: A Slice of Life
description: Photographs from Matthew Bourne's production of "Edward Scissorhands."

title: Encore for Encores!
description: Encores!, the popular and highly praised series of concert performances of musicals at City Center, is spinning off a summertime series.

title: Theater Briefs
description: The Signature Theater Company has extended the run of August Wilsons King Hedley II for a week, through April 22, at its Peter Norton Space, 555 West 42nd Street.

title: Rival Hospital Chain Said to Prepare Triad Offer
description: Community Health Systems, a hospital operator, was near a deal over the weekend to buy Triad Hospitals, which has already agreed to be acquired by a group of private equity funds, The Wall Street Journal reported. Community Health, which runs acute-care hospitals, has been seen by some analysts as a potential buyout target itself.

title: Barclays Bank Makes Inquiry on Takeover of ABN Amro
description: Barclays, one of Britains largest banks, has made an informal takeover approach for ABN Amro Holding, the largest bank in the Netherlands, which is under pressure from hedge funds to consider a merger or asset sales to bolster its lagging share price.

title: Rejected, British Tobacco Giant Still Wants to Buy French-Spanish Rival
description: Imperial Tobacco of Britain said on Sunday that it would continue friendly efforts to buy a Franco-Spanish rival, Altadis, which rejected its initial attempt at 45 euros a share. Imperial, which makes Lambert & Butler and Embassy cigarettes, offered 11.5 billion euros ($15.3 billion) for Altadis on Thursday, beginning a possible bidding war in the consolidating tobacco industry.

title: UBS to Lose President of Investment Bank
description: After an avalanche of reports surfaced that Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBSs investment bank, was considering ditching the firm following a series of run-ins with the Swiss banks management over private equity deals, The New York Times reports that Mr. Moelis, who helped turn the Swiss bank into a mergers and acquisitions giant, is indeed leaving.

title: Quanta Services Sets $1.26 Billion Deal
description: Quanta Services, a provider of engineering support to power companies, said Monday it had agreed to buy InfraSource Services, a Pennsylvania company that also provides services to utilities, for $1.26 billion in stock.

title: A Division of NBC Buys Out One of Its Harshest Online Critics
description: In a review of Top Design, the reality show on Bravo Networks, a staff writer for the Web site Televisionwithoutpity.com mused that in the future, the show would be just another filthy memory whose outcome Ive long since forgotten.

title: Former Sun-Times Executive to Pay $72 Million Settlement
description: A business partner of Conrad M. Black and three companies will pay $63.4 million to settle claims and debt with the Sun-Times Media Group, the company said Sunday. Mr. Blacks partner, F. David Radler, 64, was president and chief operating officer of the Sun-Times Group when it was known as Hollinger International. The payment means that Mr. Radler and firms he controls have paid a total of $72 million to settle claims and debt owed to the publisher, the Sun-Times Group, based in Chicago, said Sunday in a statement.

title: As YouTube Faces Pricey Lawsuit, Some Wonder: Wheres the Business Model?
description: Viacoms $1 billion copyright-infringement lawsuit has turned fears that Googles purchase of YouTube would end up being a legal quagmire into a reality. Now, attention is turning to whether other predicted pitfalls of the $1.65 billion deal  namely that the site will end up being a financial black hole  will also come true.

title: I.P.O. Market Offers Deals for Those With Derring-Do
description: When the markets get choppy, risky investing categories like initial public offerings tend to suffer. But, says BusinessWeek, the recent market turmoil that started with the sell-off in China has not overwhelmed the I.P.O. scene, and it may create opportunities. Stock in companies like BigBand Networks, which helps cable companies deliver high-definition video, have risen as much as 30 percent above their opening prices.

title: A Public Blackstone Might Keep Its Secrets
description: Wall Street is eager to get its hands on the Blackstone Groups prospectus to get a peek inside the private equity powerhouse, which, in keeping with its description as private guards its secrecy. But The New York Times suggests that investors may be disappointed at what few details they discover if the firm decides to go ahead with the initial public offering it is said to be considering.

title: Faso on the Budget Plans
description: These are strange days in the capital.

title: Motorola Chiefs Non-Bonus Came to $1.27 Million
description: It was widely reported earlier this month that Motorolas chief executive, Edward Zander, received no annual bonus last year, after Motorolas cell phone business derailed during the fourth quarter, hammering the companys profits.

title: V.C.s Sweeten Hyperactive Technologies
description: Hyperactive Technologies, the maker of Hyperactive Bob, a product that helps fast-food restaurants manage their kitchens, has received $8.4 million in a second round of venture funding, VentureWire reported. Hyperactive Bob, a robotic camera system, pans walk-ins and the drive-through line to organize cooking. The company was spun out of Carnegie Mellon University, CNEt News.com notes, adding that the firm has the best company name ever.

title: In Friendlys Fight, a Brotherly Feud
description: Behind the scenes of the battle for control of Friendly Ice Cream is a tale of two brothers who founded the company during the Great Depression only to become estranged after disagreements over its future.

title: Shell Scores Victory in Takeover of Canadian Unit
description: Royal Dutch Shell is on the verge of taking over Shell Canada, announcing early Saturday that it had scored a significant victory in its bid of 8.7 billion Canadian dollars ($7.4 billion) for the firm. Royal Dutch, one of the largest public oil companies in the world, already owns about 78 percent of Shell Canada and is trying to buy the rest.

title: Google Buys Adscape to Expand in Video Game Advertising
description: Google purchased a video game advertising firm, Adscape, to expand into in-game advertising, Google said on Friday. Financial details were not disclosed, but Red Herring last month reported the value of the expected deal at about $23 million.

title: Merrill Chief Could Get $251 Million in Exit
description: Merrill Lynchs chief executive, E. Stanley ONeal, could receive $251.4 million if he were to resign from the company under certain circumstances, the company disclosed Friday. The estimated payout would be triggered if Mr. ONeal was terminated without cause or resigned for good reason, Merrills annual proxy statement said.

title: Analyst Sees AOL Deal on the Horizon
description: Will Time Warner log out of AOL?

title: Buyout Firms Said to Consider Rival TXU Bid
description: The Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group are leading a consortium that is considering making a rival bid for TXU, The Financial Times and Reuters reported Monday, citing undisclosed sources. Such a move could spark a bidding war for the Texas energy giant, which recently agreed to be acquired by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group for $45 billion.

title: Good Reasons to Play (or Coach) College Basketball
description: In 2006, the hottest story in college basketball was the battle for the N.C.A.A. scoring title between Gonzagas Adam Morrison and Dukes J.J. Redick. In a college basketball landscape that had been decimated by players leaving early for the N.B.A., the two players were purported to be all that was right with the sport. Not only did they devote themselves to the college game  though Morrison did leave after his junior year  they were best pals; they even played the video game Halo online against each other all hours of the night. What college student cant relate to all-night video game sessions? These guys were what college was supposed to be all about.

title: Disney Clears Jobs of Options Misconduct at Pixar
description: Walt Disney, concluding an internal investigation, cleared Steven P. Jobs on Friday of any misconduct in issuing backdated stock options at Pixar, the computer animation studio that Disney bought last year. A brief statement by John E. Pepper Jr., Disneys chairman, did not mention Mr. Jobs by name. But the statement said that while options were backdated at Pixar prior to the acquisition, no one currently associated with Disney was involved in any intentional or deliberate acts of misconduct.

title: Lays Desk Goes Up for Auction
description: Once the center of power, the desk of Enrons former chairman, Kenneth L. Lay, is up for sale on eBay. The desk is being sold by a charity, Saving Animals Across Borders, which is also auctioning the desks that Jeffrey Skilling and Richard Kinder used when they were presidents of the now-defunct energy company. Mr. Lay and Mr. Skilling, who also served as chief executive, were convicted in May 2006 for their role in the accounting fraud that led to the collapse of Enron in 2001.

title: ServiceMaster Agrees to $4.7 Billion Buyout
description: ServiceMaster, which provides home services such as house cleaning and pest control, said Monday it had agreed to be acquired by a group led by the private equity firm Clayton, Dubilier & Rice for about $4.7 billion. ServiceMaster said in November it had hired Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs to explore strategic alternatives for the company, including a possible sale.

title: Carlyle to Cut Stake in Chinas Xugong, Report Says
description: The Carlyle Group has agreed to take a reduced stake in Xugong Group Construction Machinery of China in a bid to help speed approval of the deal, which has been awaiting government approval for more than a year, according to The Wall Street Journal. Carlyle has signed an agreement to take a 45 percent stake in Xugong, The Journal said.

title: FCStone I.P.O. Shines in Turbulent Market
description: The FCStone Group, a commodities risk management firm, rocked the market for initial public offerings on Friday, rising 30 percent after pricing at the high end of its estimated range. FCStone offered 5.1 million shares at $24 a share, at the top end of its $21-$24 range, raising $122 million. The stock opened at $27.50 and rose to end its first trading day at $31.13.

title: BofA Says Law Firm Used Privileged Info in Biovail Suit
description: Lawyers for Banc of America Securities presented e-mail evidence in a New York federal court Friday that they say shows that the law firm Kasowitz, Benson, Torres & Friedman knowingly used privileged documents in order to bring a case against several hedge funds on behalf of Biovail Pharmaceuticals, a drugmaker.

title: Benchmark Reaps Rewards of Microsofts Tellme Deal
description: Microsofts move to buy Tellme for about $800 million represents a boon for Benchmark Capital, as well as Kleiner Perkins Caufield and Byers, but no home run on the order of Google, says The Red Herring.

title: Hedge Funds Take Hollywood, but For How Long?
description: In an article on the ubiquity of hedge funds in Hollywood these days, The Economist says that the survival rate of the new wannabe studios backed by investment pools may not be high. Noting that three-quarters of the newly financed outfits may be gone within five years, it also notes that the film industrys real problem is not so much a shortage of films as a shortage of eyeballs.

title: Hardest Working Band at SXSW
description: Meet the Black Lips, the hardest working band at the South by Southwest festival in Austin, Tex.

title: Tilting Hollywoods Balance of Power to Talent Agency Clients
description: At a time when Hollywood is crawling with hedge funds, private equity and other aspiring film financiers, Media Rights Capital, a company spun off from a talent agency, Endeavor, best known as the players behind the HBO industry satire Entourage, is helping to shift the balance of power in movie-making by giving filmmakers and stars more earning power and ownership of their projects, notes The New York Times.

title: Congress: On Prosecutors and the War
description: Democrats learned a few things from Republicans over the years, and one of them was how to name legislation in a way that makes opponents seem like they are attacking apple pie.

title: What S.A.T. Scores? Into the Sorting Hat With You!
description: If Barry Schwarz had his way, getting into the college of your choice really would be like winning the lottery. Elite universities ought to take a page from Hogwarts and draw the names of all qualified students out of giant Sorting Hat, suggests Schwarz, the author of The Paradox of Choice, on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. He writes:

title: Bumptop Desktop
description: Some more of my notes from this years TED conference, which I described the other day.

title: Good idea or bad idea?
description: Flatpack housesSure, everyones heard of flatpack furniture but now you can own a flatpack house to go around it. Indeed the Swedish furniture chain Ikea has just launched its own range of houses in England and Scotland. Priced at less than 100,000, flatpack houses are being seen as a solution to Britains lack of affordable housing. But heres the best news: the timber-framed homes come already built.

title: Under Pressure, Take-Two Says It Will Consider a Sale
description: Staring down the barrel of a proxy fight, Take-Two Interactive Software has blinked.

title: Your own Fantasy Island
description: For a mere $40,000 a day, you can get away in style at a luxury villa in the Bahamas that comes with a 48-foot yacht, 24-seat movie theater, full staff, and two Hummers. Check out the other places you can go for a truly high-end vacation at http://www.homeaway.com/index.cfm/tgt/top-10-luxury-vacation-rentals/index.html

title: Hercules to Acquire Rival Todco for $2.3 Billion
description: Hercules Offshore, an oil and gas drilling company, said Monday that it would acquire a larger rival, Todco, for about $2.3 billion in cash and stock, gaining a larger footprint in the global oil rig market. Under the terms of the deal, Todco shareholders will receive .979 Hercules shares and $16 in cash for each of their shares, for a total of $42.01 per Todco share. The deal represents a 28 percent premium to Todcos closing price Friday.

title: 2008: Online Campaigns
description: The Wall Street Journals Amy Schatz writes that differing online strategies of the various campaigns are starting to emerge  and diverge somewhat.

title: Obama, Master of Persuasion
Iraq War Quadrennial
description: Iraq is hardly the kind of story that needs an anniversary to suddenly thrust it back onto front pages. Every day, multiple strands compete for our attention, from Washington and the campaign trail to Baghdad and Basra. Still, it must be said.

title: Today in the Sean Bell Case
description: Before the sun rose this morning, three detectives left their homes and arrived at central booking in Queens shortly after 7 a.m. There they went through the familiar routine of criminal defendants: getting fingerprinted and photographed, turning over their possessions and filling paperwork.

title: Moelis Is Leaving UBS: The Memo
description: Its official: Kenneth D. Moelis, the president of UBS investment bank, is leaving. DealBook obtained a copy of an internal memo by Huw Jenkins, the chairman and chief executive of UBS investment bank, and Peter A. Wuffli, the president of the firms Group Executive Board, announcing the veteran investment bankers departure.

title: It Wasnt Supposed to Be Like This
description: Its a 75-minute drive from Tampa to Anna Maria Island. After our incredibly disappointing meeting with the architect Don Cooper, it seemed as if the ride took four times as long.

title: Final Titles Awarded as Bridge Nationals Wrap Up
description: ST. LOUIS, March 19  Two major national titles were decided on Sunday, the concluding day of the American Contract Bridge Leagues Spring North American Championships here.

title: Takeover Talk Lifts ABN Shares to Record High
description: Reports that the British bank Barclays might bid for ABN Amro, the Dutch financial group, sent ABM Amros shares surging to a record Monday. The stock gained as much as 10 percent, despite skepticism from some analysts who questioned whether such a merger would actually happen. With the increase, ABNs market capitalization swelled to about $76 billion.

title: The Supersized Airliner Arrives in America
description: The home of the quadruple cheeseburger and the worlds tallest thermometer is playing host to the next giant of the skies. The Airbus A380 has landed in New York.

title: Fortress Affiliate Sees Deals in Subprime Mortgages
description: While the troubled subprime mortgage market has weighed down Wall Street  Bear Stearns and Lehman Brothers both reported that their 1st-quarter revenues were hurt by the sector  others see a buying opportunity. Buyers like Goldman Sachs have said that they see a chance to acquire beaten down assets cheaply, anticipating a rebound, rather than a continued implosion.

title: Document: Queens D.A. on Bell Case
description: The office of the Queens district attorney, Richard A. Brown, has posted his statement [pdf] outlining the grand jury indictments of three detectives in the Sean Bell case.

title: Bad Weather, Bad Behavior
description: How are you doing? asked a hostess as I entered a downtown restaurant on Friday night, and she uttered the question in a pitying, sympathetic tone of voice, the kind of tone you might use when addressing someone going through a divorce or an I.R.S. audit.

title: The Iraq War in Polls Over 4 Years
description: In the four years since the start of the war in Iraq, the American public has grown more and more critical, and now they describe the war as going badly and believe the United States should have stayed out of Iraq in the first place.

title: A Gadflys Proposal for Goldman: No More Options
description: Evelyn Y. Davis, a shareholder gadfly with a long history of haranguing corporate executives, wants the board at Goldman Sachs to stop handing out stock options. And she wants them to quit cold turkey.

title: 2006 Lobbying Tab: $151 Million
description: Lobbyists spent a new record  $151 million  in 2006, trying to influence policy in Albany, according to the latest report from the states Temporary Comission on Lobbying.

title: Diagnosing the Next Big Drug Deal
description: Bristol-Myers Squibb has inspired all kinds of takeover speculation recently. There has been less talk about Wyeth, an even larger pharmaceuticals giant that Catherine Arnold, an analyst at Credit Suisse, thinks could be an acquisition target as well. In a report Monday on possible mergers and acquisitions activity in the drug industry, Ms. Arnold also identified two drugmakers that appear to be natural acquirers: GlaxoSmithKline and Novartis.

title: Are First-Year Lawyers Overpaid?
description: These days, a first-year lawyer at a top firm can earn more than an associate justice of the Supreme Court. This is just one of the points made by Susan Hackett, general counsel of the Association of Corporate Counsel, as she argues that there is no good reason for the recent rise in legal associates pay. Her organization represents the in-house legal departments that pay for outside lawyers.

title: Parking Site Hits a Nerve
description: The new site Uncivilservants.org seems to be stirring up some city employees who use  some say abuse  their parking privileges. Commenters claiming to be police officers say the site is putting them at risk. And theres a suggestion that the Internal Affairs bureau is monitoring the site.

title: The Guantanamo Confessions: U.S.S. Cole Edition
description: The Pentagons Combatant Status Review Tribunal released its latest transcript today from a senior Al Qaeda operative. Todays special guest is Walid BaAttash.

title: Audio: Eye on Politics
description: The Timess Adam Nagourney talked about the influence the war in Iraq is having on the 2008 campaign for president today on WCBS radios Eye on Politics segment.Adam Nagourney (mp3)

title: Big Ben Versus the Big Apple: Another Take
description: Its easy to write off the warnings about Wall Street losing its position as the center of the financial universe as merely the cries of prideful opportunists. After all, even if foreign exchanges are taking bigger shares of the worlds stock offerings lately, its not as if Wall Street is hurting much. One look at last years record bonuses will tell you that.

title: Document: Indictment in Bell Case
description: Here is a copy of the indictment [pdf] filed today in the death of Sean Bell, against Detectives Michael Oliver, Gescard Isnora and Marc Cooper of the New York Police Department.

title: In the News: Zimbabwe
description: . The country was in horrible straits then and sadly things have only worsened.

title: Not Your Grandmother's Pancake
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, prepares (and deconstructs) a savory Korean pancake called pa jun.

title: Finding Trustworthy Translators
description: The question from Mark Schroeder, a Times reader in New York, was a good one. How can someone who does not speak the language of the people involved quote them and determine an accurate set of facts for an article? he asked in a Feb. 23 e-mail.

title: Appreciating Anchovies
description: Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, prepares pasta with anchovies for people who hate anchovies.

title: The Pink Coffee Table in Baghdad
description: The first video news I watched on a cellphone was a smoke signal. I saw it in the back of a cab. The Pope had died, and CNN had its cameras trained on the chimney over St. Peters Square. Viewers were told to expect white smoke when the cardinals had elected his replacement.

title: The Spanish French Toast
description: The New York Times food columnist Mark Bittman, a k a TheMinimalist, takes French toast south of the Pyrenees.

title: Chickpeas in Love
description: Mark Bittman, a k a The Minimalist, explains the ins and outs of making falafel at home.

title: Noah on Bush
description: Theres a strong argument that the Florida center Joakim Noah is the most relevant and charismatic figure in college basketball since Bill Walton was roaming the paint in Westwood in the early 1970s.

title: An Upset Is All in the Numbers
description: After four days and 48 games, The Bracket takes a breath and spends some down time examining its bracket, and the brackets of the 27,000-plus participants in The New York Timess online Bracket Tournament. Get ready for some mild-to-moderate number crunching

title: The Clinton Spin
description: No politicians raise money quite like the Clintons, whether its their success or ferocity or creativity (remember those White House teas, those Lincoln bedroom sleepovers?). Well, Bill Clinton is about to go where no other former president has gone before, arguably, in service to enriching his wifes presidential campaign warchest.

title: A Cerebral Sport
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 18 column, Your Brain on Baseball.

title: A Tragedy that Goes Beyond the Battlefield
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Mar. 19 column, Death of a Marine.

title: New York Women Smoking Less
description: Thats the latest finding from the city Health Department. The Bloomberg administration has been aggressive in fighting smoking, whether through tax policy, smoking bans or publishing disturbing pictures of smokers teeth in press releases (check out the link):

title: Apollo Contests $1.7 Billion EGL Buyout
description: Though shipping company EGL has agreed to a $1.7 billion, $38-a-share management-led buyout, its board may have to contend with another persistent suitor. DealBook has obtained a letter that the buyout firm Apollo Management sent Monday to EGLs board, in which it said it has made an even higher offer of $40 per share.

title: Blogtalk: Look at Me, Eliot
description: 1199s Remember Me ad: Governor Spitzer, I want you to look at me. [The Politicker]

title: Vice, Vacation and Video Games
description: The list of ways video games have damaged our world has gotten slightly longer: They are now alleged to encourage risky driving.

title: Drafting (Fred) Thompson
description: Some conservatives despairing of the Republican field are hoping that former Senator Fred Thompson goes beyond his musings about entering the presidential race. Now, two Tennessee congressmen are creating a Draft Fred Thompson 2008 committee.

title: Big Sister Clinton (2.0)
description: Wondering what this presidential campaign might look like in the world of Web 2.0 social networking sites?

title: Clinton-Obama War Feud Spills Into Forum
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Senior advisers to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and Senator Barack Obama clashed intensely tonight at a forum for campaign managers here over the positions of the two candidates on the war in Iraq and the tactics being used by both campaigns.

title: Before I Got Wired
description: ROME  My first professional gig was during World War II, accompanying my father, who played in the trombone section of the Providence, R.I., Local 198 Union big band. On Sundays we would go to the Majestic, a shabby vaudeville theater in Pawtucket, where the show was jugglers, hypnotists, magicians, saw players, and spoons players followed by filmed war news and a feature film. My job, sitting 5-year-old-proud in this amazing brass army, was to hand my father his mutes and new sheets of music and fantasize myself sliding the slide and emptying the spit valve just like him.

title: Hamas Militants Take Credit for Sniper Attack
description: JERUSALEM, March 19  An Israeli worker for an electric utility company was wounded by a sniper near the border with the Gaza Strip today, and the armed wing of Hamas claimed responsibility.

title: Letters
description: Al Gore and the Climate Debate

title: Lax Oversight Cited in Refinery Blast
description: HOUSTON, March 20  Company deficiencies at all levels were responsible for an explosion and fire that killed 15 workers and injured 180 others at the giant BP oil refinery in Texas City two years ago, a federal safety panel reported today.

title: In Testing for Allergies, a Single Shot May Suffice
description: At the age of 5, Sarah Marcus had her first skin test for allergies. She had 18 needle pricks and screamed from the first to the last. At 8, when she needed to be retested, she was terrified.

title: Nowadays, Angola Is Oils Topic A
description: VIENNA, March 16  Angola, which shared the stage with the worlds most powerful oil-producing nations at its first OPEC meeting here Thursday, is an unlikely candidate to be the darling of the global oil industry.

title: The Disastrous Mr. Mugabe
description: Zimbabwes president, Robert Mugabe, has spent much of his 26-plus years in power suppressing all opposition, persecuting defenseless minorities and destroying a once-promising economy. He has shamelessly tried to deflect all blame for the disastrous consequences  including a man-made famine and a catastrophically mishandled H.I.V./AIDS epidemic  onto international scapegoats, chiefly Britain and the United States.

title: Freight Coordinator to Be Acquired for $1.7 Billion
description: EGL Inc., the parent of Eagle Global Logistics, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by its chairman and chief executive, James R. Crane, along with two private equity firms in a deal valued at about $1.7 billion.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10:30 P.M. (Oxygen) TORI AND DEAN: INN LOVE It has been quite a year for Tori Spelling, left, who lost her father, feuded with her mother and as of last Tuesday plunged into parenting herself, when she gave birth to a baby boy, Liam Aaron McDermott. Now she and her husband, Dean McDermott, above, are about to embark on another adventure  that of innkeepers. This reality series follows them as they leave their Hollywood lives behind to invest Ms. Spellings $800,000 inheritance in a bed-and-breakfast in Southern California.

title: Shopping Mall Paradise (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Three Detectives Plead Not Guilty in 50-Shot Killing
description: The three detectives left their homes in the predawn darkness yesterday. They walked in the back entrance of the courthouse in Queens to Central Booking, where they went through a routine that must have seemed familiar: fingerprints, waiting, mug shots, more waiting, paperwork, more waiting.

title: Sniper Wounds a Utility Worker in Israel
description: JERUSALEM, March 19  An Israeli worker for an electric utility company was wounded Monday by a sniper near the border with the Gaza Strip, and the armed wing of Hamas claimed responsibility.

title: Letterman Is Ill, So Guest Takes Over Late Show
description: David Letterman has gone home sick this afternoon, forcing his CBS program to call in reinforcements from its guest list.

title: Yes, Lets Be Candid About the Mideast (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Lebanese Army Tightens Security at Camp to Press Militant Group
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 19  The Lebanese Army maintained a heavy presence on Monday in a Palestinian refugee camp in northern Lebanon where an Islamic militant group blamed for deadly bus bombings in February is based, army officials and camp residents said.

title: New York Teenagers Substance Abuse Drops
description: Teenage use of alcohol and drugs dropped significantly in New York City in 2005 compared with past years, and is lower than the national rate, but it remains disturbingly high, city officials said today, citing the results of a recently released survey.

title: Influential Director Resigns at Minneapolis Art Center
description: Kathy Halbreich, who greatly expanded the role of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis as a risk-taking multidisciplinary institution that is a model for contemporary art museums around the world, said yesterday that she was retiring after 16 years as director.

title: The Ex-Elite Flier Club
description: Elizabeth Davidson knew she would need to cut back on her business travel when she learned she was expecting her first child.

title: An Olympic Push to Ease Border Rules
description: BLAINE, Wash., March 16  Worried about trade, tourism and the success of the 2010 Winter Olympics in Vancouver, British Columbia, several states and Canadian provinces are pressing the Department of Homeland Security to ease some restrictions planned for the increasingly tight border between the United States and Canada.

title: Students Right to Free Speech
description: The Supreme Court heard arguments yesterday in a case that has attracted attention mainly because of its eccentric story line: An Alaska student was suspended from high school in 2002 after he unfurled a banner reading Bong Hits 4 Jesus while the Olympic torch passed by. But the case raises important issues of freedom of expression and student censorship that go far beyond the words on that banner. The court should affirm the appeals courts well-reasoned decision that when the school punished the student it violated his First Amendment rights.

title: Russia Objects to U.N. Plan for Kosovo as One-Sided
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 19  Russia on Monday signaled its opposition to the United Nations proposal to settle the status of Kosovo, Serbias breakaway province, and said a new negotiator should be appointed and fresh talks started.

title: Fortunes Diverge at Novastar
description: Last Friday, Novastar Financial Inc., a mortgage lender specializing in loans to risky borrowers, said it would lay off 350 people, or 17 percent of its workforce. It took action, the company said, to align its organization with changing conditions in the mortgage market.

title: Confident, Elegant, Chatty Even
description: Heres to us. Whos like us? Damn few.

title: Tracing the Cigarettes Path From Sexy to Deadly
description: For many Americans, the tobacco industrys disingenuousness became a matter of public record during a Congressional hearing on April 14, 1994. There, under the withering glare of Representative Henry A. Waxman, Democrat of California, appeared the chief executives of the seven largest American tobacco companies.

title: Louisianas Governor Wont Seek Re-election
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 20  Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco of Louisiana, politically battered by a shaky post-Hurricane Katrina performance, announced today that she would not seek re-election to a second term.

title: Editor's Note
description: An Op-Ed article on March 3, about Moroccos proposal for an autonomous Western Sahara, should have more fully disclosed the background of the author, Frederick Vreeland. Mr. Vreeland, a former American ambassador to Morocco, is also the chairman of a solar-energy company that has had contracts with the Moroccan government.

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption yesterday with a front-page article about the spending of money raised by Shriners misstated the state in which a leader at the Decatur Shrine Club raised concerns about proceeds from bingo. It was Alabama, not Georgia.

title: What the Left Hand Can Do, Hands in the Audience Applaud
description: Most pianists who had lost an arm would probably give up performing. But Paul Wittgenstein, the Austrian pianist who lost his right arm while serving on the Russian front during World War I, commissioned a number of works for left hand only.

title: 250 Words a Minute, Each of Them Crucial
description: IN the highly nuanced and little-known world of court reporters, interrupting a trial is usually a last resort. But in a profession in which accuracy is supreme, sometimes there is no choice.

title: Dont Pack Up, Bush Says After 4 Years of War
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  President Bush marked the fourth anniversary of the invasion of Iraq on Monday with a plea for patience and a stark warning against the temptation "to pack up and go home."

title: Rise of a Deadly TB Reveals a Global System in Crisis
description: LOS ANGELES  The spread of a particularly virulent form of tuberculosis in South Africa illustrates a breakdown in the global program that is supposed to keep the disease, one of the worlds deadliest, under control.

title: Scoring Isnt So Easy on the Ice
description: N.H.L. shootouts are played in front of crowds that stand for every shot, in arenas abuzz with expectation and, with the season waning, in situations that often have vital playoff implications. But the shootout decides not just which team gets a crucial point in the standings; it also forms a dividing line between shooters who are ready for the magnitude of that moment and those who are not.

title: Irans Operative in the White House
description: If an 18-year-old American soldier were caught slipping obscure military paperwork to Iranian spies, he would be arrested, pilloried in the news media and tossed into prison for years.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a headline and film review on Wednesday about The Go Master referred imprecisely to the game Go. Although the game flourished in Japan and is an important part of Japanese culture, it is believed to have originated in China. It is not a Japanese game.

title: Diallo Verdict May Have Made Prosecutors Cautious
description: By pursuing first-degree manslaughter charges against two detectives in the death of Sean Bell, prosecutors in Queens were probably influenced by what happened in the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo, criminal law experts said yesterday.

title: Top U.S. Official at Unesco Resigns Before Audits Release
description: PARIS, March 19  The highest-ranking American official at the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization has resigned, just days before an official audit made public on Monday reported that he had violated Unescos rules by granting seven contracts to an American consulting firm without an open bidding procedure.

title: Fire at Russian Nursing Home Kills 62
description: MOSCOW, March 20  A fire that swept through a home for the elderly and disabled in southern Russia killed at least 62 people early today, a toll that officials attributed to safety violations and a night watchmans negligence. Many of the dead were confined to their beds and unable to flee the smoke and flames, the officials said.

title: The Tilted Earth at Its Equal Night of Spring
description: Our clocks may have already sprung forward in a dubious attempt at energy conservation, but please, lets not lose track of the far weightier astronomical event that ushers in spring proper  even when the event has trouble keeping track of itself.

title: A Packed Test Flight Lands in Time for News at Noon
description: ON board the new Airbus A380 superjumbo jet yesterday as it made its first overseas flight with a full load of passengers, I made careful note of the hour and minute.

title: Cleveland Elections Board Told to Resign
description: CINCINNATI, March 19  Responding to a series of scandals, Ohios new secretary of state said Monday that she had demanded the resignation of the entire four-member Elections Board of Cuyahoga County, which includes Cleveland.

title: A Memorial Is Planned for Richard Gilman
description: A memorial tribute to the drama and literary critic Richard Gilman will take place on Monday at 1 p.m. at Symphony Space, 2537 Broadway at 95th Street, in Manhattan. Mr. Gilman died on Oct. 28 at age 83.

title: Point-Blank Perspective
description: Saunderstown, R.I.

title: John W. Backus, 82, Fortran Developer, Dies
description: John W. Backus, who assembled and led the I.B.M. team that created Fortran, the first widely used programming language, which helped open the door to modern computing, died on Saturday at his home in Ashland, Ore. He was 82.

title: Changes Sought in Naming of Prosecutors
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  The Senate moved Monday to revoke authority it granted the Bush administration last year to name federal prosecutors, with Democrats accusing the administration of abusing the appointment power at the center of an escalating clash over the ouster of eight United States attorneys.

title: Raymond D. Nasher, 85, Dallas Art Collector Who Built a Museum, Dies
description: Raymond D. Nasher, a real-estate developer and banker who, along with his wife, Patsy, amassed one of the worlds best collections of Modern and contemporary sculpture and built a lavish public home for it in downtown Dallas, died on Friday in Dallas. He was 85.

title: Simon Wont Be Charged, With an Assist to Hollweg
description: Islanders forward Chris Simon will not face criminal charges for his two-handed slash of Rangers forward Ryan Hollweg earlier this month, the Nassau County district attorney announced yesterday.

title: A Garden Stored Inside
description: With a few brave snowdrops hinting at winters end, the New York Botanical Garden has been preparing for its spring invasion of gawking, cooing, sighing human visitors. More and more people have been coming to the famed 250-acre garden in the Bronx, with numbers now reaching more than 800,000 people a year, almost twice as many as a decade ago.

title: Albany: Clash Over State Budget
description: Prospects for an on-time budget seemed unlikely yesterday as Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders could not even agree on how much money was available to spend. The governor said he would prefer a late budget to a bad one, underscoring his intent to overhaul the way the state spends money on Medicaid and education. I will in no way regret having a late budget if it is the only way we contain the rapid spending that has been too often the story line here up in Albany, Mr. Spitzer said. If we need to tolerate week after week after week without a budget, we will do so. Joseph L. Bruno, above, the Senate majority leader and the states top Republican, has proposed restoring many of the governors health care cuts and reshaping his education proposal. Mr. Spitzer and the Democratic-led Assembly urged Senate Republicans to scale back their spending proposals so serious negotiations could begin. The budget deadline is April 1.

title: New Stables Clear Way for Hudson River Park Expansion
description: A new stables for the police departments mounted unit was dedicated today, clearing the way for expansion of the Hudson River Park that runs along the citys west side.

title: The Claim: Stress Can Cause Acne
description: THE FACTS Chronically bad skin or the occasional nasty breakout can be a major source of stress. That much is known. But what about the reverse? Although scientists have suspected for some time that emotional stress can cause or worsen acne, the evidence for the claim has mostly been weak, stemming largely from anecdotal reports and a few small studies.

title: Husseins Former Vice President Is Hanged
description: BAGHDAD, March 20  The former vice president of Iraq, Taha Yassin Ramadan, was hanged shortly before dawn today, the prime ministers office said.

title: Britain Confronts Legacy of Slave Trade
description: LONDON  The way history has long been taught here, Britains abolition of the slave trade on March 25, 1807, allowed it to claim the moral high ground in the struggle to end slavery in the New World. Two centuries later, if a series of exhibitions planned for this year leave their mark, perceptions may be about to change.

title: U.S. Says Bombers Used 2 Iraqi Children as Decoys
description: BAGHDAD, March 20 Insurgents detonated a bomb in a car carrying two children after using the children as decoys to get through a military checkpoint in Baghdad, an American general said Tuesday.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the dismissal of Israel Singer, a leader of the World Jewish Conference, referred incorrectly to the health of the organizations president, Edgar M. Bronfman, who has said he wants his son Matthew to succeed him. Dr. Adam Rosenbluth, Mr. Bronfmans doctor, said Mr. Bronfman is in very good health. He has no chronic debilitating illness nor does he have any illness that would have impact on his longevity and his ability to lead the congress. He is not in poor health. (Go to Article)

title: Bombing of U.S. Embassy Convoy Kills Afghan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan, March 19  A convoy from the United States Embassy was hit by a suicide car bomb on a busy road here on Monday, killing a 14-year-old Afghan bystander and seriously wounding an American security guard in the convoy, officials said.

title: Toll Rises to 104 in Siberia Mine Blast
description: MOSCOW, March 20  The death toll following a methane gas explosion on Monday in a Siberian coal mine rose to 104 today as rescue workers continued to search for survivors, according to Russian government officials and the official regional press service.

title: Explosion Kills at Least 78 in Siberia Mine
description: MOSCOW, March 19  A methane gas explosion on Monday in a Siberian coal mine, in a region notorious for mine accidents, killed at least 78 people, and dozens were still trapped underground by late evening, emergency officials said.

title: Family of Slain Pizza Worker Is to Return Body to Mexico
description: The wake yesterday for a pizzeria employee murdered last week in Greenwich Village signified the end of many things for his companion and two brothers. They were to return his body to Mexico today and have abandoned their quest to establish a new life in the United States.

title: Piecing Together the Clues of an Old Collision, Iceball by Iceball
description: Sometime, probably several billion years ago, a rocky iceball almost as large as Pluto crashed into another almost Pluto-size iceball.

title: Beyond the News, Reminders of the War
description: The hosts of Today and Good Morning America began yesterday on their feet, standing like evening news anchors alongside maps and images of Iraq  marking the fourth anniversary of the war by looking back at its disappointments. Images of roadside bombings and sectarian carnage flashed across the screen along with a clip of Vice President Dick Cheney in 2003 saying that American troops would be greeted as liberators.

title: Sentence for an Ex-Trader
description: The former head of Citibanks worldwide commodities trading desk was sentenced to 15 months in prison yesterday after pleading guilty to conspiracy last year in connection with a plan to inflate trading profits by as much as $20 million.

title: Wins Validate Florida Stars' Decisions to Stay
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 19  The Florida junior Al Horford remembers the free and easy days of his freshman year. Before playing time was a given and celebrity a nuisance, Horford, Taurean Green, Joakim Noah and Corey Brewer would go to Floridas practice gym at night and play knock-down, drag-out games of one-on-one.

title: Pakistan: 6 Judges Resign to Protest Chief Justices Removal
description: Intensifying a continuing legal crisis, six judges from Sindh and Punjab Provinces resigned to protest the suspension of the chief justice of the Supreme Court, Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry, by President Pervez Musharraf on March 9 for alleged abuse of office. Incensed lawyers and opposition activists who accuse General Musharraf of trying to subdue the judiciary clashed with the police in Islamabad, the capital, and Lahore last week, and lawyers have staged protests in other cities. In an interview with a private television news channel, General Musharraf defended the action and sought to dispel speculation that emergency measures would be imposed in the country or that army troops would be called on to quell the unrest on the streets.

title: Toyota Pickup Scores Below-Perfect on Safety
description: DETROIT, March 19  Detroits automakers are getting some help from the federal government, at least in terms of their efforts to find flaws in the new pickup built by their Japanese rival Toyota Motor.

title: Utility and Sierra Club Deal Aims to Cut Carbon Dioxide
