description: WASHINGTON, March 19  A Midwest electric company and the Sierra Club announced a deal on Monday under which the environmental group will drop its complaints against a coal plant, and the utility, Kansas City Power and Light, will take steps to cut carbon dioxide output by the amount that a new plant will produce.

title: Jagrs Misfire Is Right on the Mark for the Rangers
description: The goal will not find its way onto Jaromir Jagrs personal highlight reel. The play began as a pass, born of desperation, from behind Pittsburghs net in the waning seconds. Jagr intended for center Michael Nylander to put the puck in the net, but Penguins defenseman Rob Scuderis stick did the trick instead.

title: Theater Association Supports Dismantling of Scalping Laws
description: ALBANY, March 19  A trade association representing Broadway theaters and producers is doing an about-face and now wants state officials to dismantle the laws that limit the resale of tickets to musicals, plays, concerts and other events.

title: Melee Sours Garden Officials on Basketball Title Game
description: For decades, the final game of the Public Schools Athletic Leagues AA division basketball tournament has been one of the citys most prestigious high school sporting events. But, as was demonstrated on Sunday night, it can also produce a combustible mix of school rivalries, taut emotions and adolescent excess.

title: Manhattan: Meeting on National Parks
description: In anticipation of the 100-year anniversary of the national parks system, the National Park Service has scheduled a public meeting today at Federal Hall National Memorial to listen to comments on the future of the parks, officials said. The session, from 6 p.m. to 8 p.m. at 26 Wall Street, is one of a series scheduled around the country. Although the centennial is 10 years away, officials said they were seeking input now to allow a 10-year lead time for projects to commemorate the anniversary. We are asking the public what they would like us to do with their parks, said Darren Boch, a spokesman for the service.

title: MySpace Restrictions Upset Some Users
description: Some users of MySpace feel as if their space is being invaded.

title: Mini-Clinic and Pharmacy Right There in Terminal C
description: A start-up company has come up with a way to meld the time spent waiting in a crowded doctors office or at a pharmacy counter into the time people already spend cooling their heels in airports.

title: Private Rocket Lost Shortly After Launch
description: A privately developed rocket that carried the hopes of cheap access to space was lost minutes after launch from the Marshall Islands on Tuesday  but the millionaire behind the launch called it a success.

title: Newark: Doctor Admits to Racketeering
description: A doctor from Livingston pleaded guilty yesterday in State Superior Court to writing thousands of phony prescriptions for a drug gang that illegally sold prescription painkillers like OxyContin, prosecutors said yesterday. The doctor, Mario Comesanas, 51, pleaded guilty to first-degree racketeering, Attorney General Stuart Rabner said. Dr. Comesanas, who faces 15 years in prison and must forfeit his medical license, admitted writing fraudulent prescriptions at the home of another man charged in the case, Mr. Rabner said. He said 17 other people, including a pharmacist, had also been charged in the case. The ring sold 20,000 to 30,000 OxyContin and Percocet pills a week, with most of the drugs going to another group in the Bronx, Mr. Rabner said.

title: The Kids Are All Right. You Can Hear It in Their Cellos.
description: These days a snowstorm, like the one that hit New York on Friday, is usually enough to decimate even an audience of hard-core concertgoers.

title: No Rush to Get Civil Unions in New Jersey
description: New Jersey health department officials released the number of applications for civil unions today, showing that 229 gay and lesbian couples have applied for civil union licenses since Feb. 19, when the unions became legal in the state.

title: The Polluters (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Secure Manning Through 2009
description: While the Giants had hoped for stronger, more consistent play from quarterback Eli Manning in his first three seasons, they have no intention of trying to improve without him.

title: An Operation That Made Everything Clear
description: With some trepidation, my husband, Richard, who is 73 and otherwise healthy, finally decided it was time to have the cataract removed from his left eye, which had a visual acuity rating of worse than 20/200 (being able to read 20/20 on the eye chart is normal).

title: The Young and the Restless: Some Eclectic New Composers
description: John Adamss four years as the holder of the Composers Chair at Carnegie Hall come to an end next month, and he isnt going quietly. Over the weekend he presented In Your Ear Redux, a mini-festival at Zankel Hall. Its finale, on Sunday afternoon, was a three-hour concert by the vibrant young new-music ensemble Alarm Will Sound, devoted largely to music composed or arranged by its players. The exception  not surprisingly, given the occasion  was Mr. Adamss Scratchband (1996), a vigorous, bright-hued, pop-tinged work that in both spirit and substance perfectly suits this band.

title: India Wins in a Record Rout
description: India recorded the biggest-ever World Cup winning margin, 257 runs, against Bermuda yesterday in Trinidad. India, which lost to Bangladesh in its opening contest, surpassed the score of 398-5 that Sri Lanka made against Kenya in 1996. In the days other match, Zimbabwe made 202-5 against West Indies.

title: Falling Ice Injures Four Women in Three Incidents
description: Falling ice around the metropolitan area injured at least four people yesterday, prompting the authorities to temporarily shut down roads and streets to remove potential hazards, police and fire officials said.

title: Bush and Democrats Clash Over Testimony
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  President Bush and Senate Democrats clashed angrily this afternoon, as the president said he would not allow his key aides to testify under oath about the dismissal of United States attorneys, while the Democrats insisted they would settle for no less.

title: For G.O.P., First Stop on 08 Trail Is Hotbed of Immigration Politics
description: DES MOINES, March 17  Immigration, an issue that has divided Republicans in Washington, is reverberating across the partys presidential campaign field, causing particular complications for Senator John McCain of Arizona.

title: Canada: Move to Drop Oil Sands Tax Break
description: A budget released by the minority Conservative government on Monday would phase out special tax concessions for investors in oil sands projects by 2015. The current system dates back to 1972 and allows oil companies to depreciate capital investments in oil sands operations at a highly accelerated rate. Intended as a method of promoting oil sands developments, it effectively postpones all taxation on income from the projects until their billions of dollars in investment costs are fully written down. The left-leaning New Democrat Party has said that the current rush to develop the oil sands makes special tax concessions unnecessary.

title: New E-Mail Gives Details on Attorney Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales was extremely upset that his deputy told Congress last month that a federal prosecutor had been fired for no reason, according to e-mail released Monday by the Justice Department.

title: Federal Agency to Inspect CSX Rail Tracks
description: The Federal Railroad Administration said yesterday that it was speeding up inspection of 1,300 miles of track in New York operated by CSX Transportation after several derailments upstate in recent months.

title: In Prosecuting Police, History Says Aim Low
description: New Yorks worst-kept secret was officially revealed yesterday with the unsealing of indictments against three police detectives in the Sean Bell case.

title: Parents Disrupt Panel to Attack School Changes
description: Shouting respect the parents and put the public back in public education, about 100 demonstrators disrupted a meeting of the Panel for Educational Policy last evening and denounced the Bloomberg administrations plans for further restructuring of the school system.

title: Treasury Bill Auction Results
Kuhns Achievements Are Not All That They Seem
description: This may be perceived as an unpleasant job, but somebody has to do it: the deconstruction or demythologizing of the former commissioner Bowie Kuhn.

title: Two Members of Home Depot Board Will Not Stand for Re-Election
description: Perhaps the seat was a little too hot.

title: Celebrity Offender, Model Begins Sanitation Duties
description: John Montgomery noticed the television crews and reporters, corralled along the fence outside a Sanitation Department garage in Lower Manhattan. He noticed the way they snapped to attention when a black sport utility vehicle pulled up. He noticed the way they focused on the tallish, Garboesque woman who stepped out.

title: Tests by Pet Food Maker Killed 7 Animals Before Recall
description: Of the 10 cats and dogs whose deaths have been linked to pet food that was recalled over the weekend, seven died in a test that the manufacturer began administering last month, the Food and Drug Administration said Monday.

title: Wal-Mart Fights Back Over Firings
description: Wal-Mart asserted yesterday in a court filing that two of its former top marketing officials had engaged in a sexual relationship during the process of selecting new advertising agencies and had sought jobs with one of the agencies they ultimately recommended.

title: China: Mobile Phone Bids Sought
description: China Mobile Communications invited bids for contracts worth as much as 24 billion yuan ($3.1 billion) to build the countrys first high-speed phone network. The company asked equipment makers to submit bids for the network, based on a homegrown standard, said Chen Haofei, the secretary general of an industry group backing the standard. China Mobile, based in Beijing, will spend 4 billion yuan on subsidies for third-generation handsets, and the network will cover eight cities in China, including Beijing and Shanghai.

title: Making the Batting Cage as Appealing as the Bracket
description: A short and admittedly simplistic answer to an important question posed last week by C. C. Sabathia was televised nationally over and over beginning last Thursday and on through the weekend.

title: I.R.S. Agents Feel Pressed to End Cases
description: The head of the Internal Revenue Service faces questions in Congress today about auditors complaints that they are being forced to close corporate cases prematurely, allowing billions in tax dollars to go unpaid.

title: Army Brigade Finds Itself Stretched Thin
description: FORT POLK, La., March 14  For decades, the Army has kept a brigade of the 82nd Airborne Division on round-the-clock alert, poised to respond to a crisis anywhere in 18 to 72 hours.

title: Film Has Two Versions; Only One Is Julie Taymors
description: LOS ANGELES, March 19  In Hollywood creative differences among moviemakers often make for more interesting results on the screen. But rarely do those battles escalate so much that a studio takes a movie away from an award-winning director.

title: Court Rejects Suit Against Enron Banks
description: A federal appeals panel ruled yesterday that a class-action lawsuit against investment banks over their role as advisers to Enron cannot go ahead, dealing a blow to shareholders who lost billions of dollars after the company collapsed in 2001.

title: Skilled Ear for Music May Help Language
description: Anyone who has tried to learn Chinese can attest to how hard it is to master the tones required to speak and understand it. And anyone who has tried to learn to play the violin or other instruments can report similar challenges.

title: Court Hears Whether a Drug Statement Is Protected Free Speech for Students
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  Kenneth W. Starr had a strategy for convincing the Supreme Court that an Alaska high school principal and school board did not violate a students free-speech rights by punishing him for displaying the words Bong Hits 4 Jesus on a 14-foot-long banner across the street from school as the 2002 Olympic torch parade went by.

title: Russia Gives Iran Ultimatum on Enrichment
description: PARIS, March 19  Russia has informed Iran that it will withhold nuclear fuel for Irans nearly completed Bushehr power plant unless Iran suspends its uranium enrichment as demanded by the United Nations Security Council, European, American and Iranian officials say.

title: Suit Prompts New Jersey to Reinvent Voting System
description: TRENTON, March 19  With the reliability of the states electronic voting machines on trial in Superior Court and under the gaze of the State Commission of Investigation, the New Jersey attorney generals office said on Monday that over the next few months it would set up procedures to certify that voting machines reliably log votes and produce a paper trail.

title: Free-Agent Salaries Are Soaring in N.F.L.
description: When Marv Levy was the coach of the Buffalo Bills in the 1980s and 90s, he never knew how much money his players made. He did not have an agent, and his own salary negotiations consisted of the Bills owner, Ralph Wilson, telling him what he would be paid.

title: Lower Seed at Home? Womens Sites a Puzzle
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., March 19  Rutgers is seeded fourth in the Greensboro Region of the N.C.A.A. womens basketball tournament. Michigan State is seeded fifth. But when the teams meet in the second round Tuesday night, Michigan State, not Rutgers, will be playing at home.

title: Doctors, and a Medical Procedure, on Trial in Kazakhstan
description: SHYMKENT, Kazakhstan  For weeks now, Kanat Alseidov has been sitting only a few feet from the doctor on trial for prescribing a blood transfusion for Mr. Alseidovs 2-year-old son, who had pneumonia.

title: One Mans Musings About Assorted Influential Lives
description: In an earlier era, commonplace books were what blogs and My Space pages are today. They were collections of quotations, observations, clippings, proverbs, poems, personal asides and anything else that someone found worthy of saving for future reference or sharing with friends. They served, W. H. Auden wrote in the introduction to his own wonderful commonplace book, A Certain World, as a sort of autobiography, a map of the collectors personal planet.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,206 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Lottery  Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Growing to Appreciate the N.B.A.s Age Limit
description: The National Basketball Association, in concert with its players union, passed a rule two years ago that required players to be 19 and at least one full year removed from high school in order to be eligible for the N.B.A. draft.

title: New DVDs
description: W. C. FIELDS COMEDY

title: Material Shows Weakening of Climate Reports
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  A House committee released documents Monday that showed hundreds of instances in which a White House official who was previously an oil industry lobbyist edited government climate reports to play up uncertainty of a human role in global warming or play down evidence of such a role.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about efforts by Microsoft researchers to trace the origins of fake Web pages that lure search-engine users to advertisements misspelled the surname of a cybersecurity investigator for the company. He is Ming Ma, not Ming Wa.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about Iraqi Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Malikis first official visit to Anbar Province, center of the Sunni insurgency, included an incorrect geographic comparison. At 52,282 square miles, Anbar occupies about the same amount of area as North Carolina  not Utah, which is almost 85,000 square miles.

title: Losing His Sight, but Not His Dream of Making Olympics
description: OTTAWA  When Brian McKeever made his debut with the Canadian team at this years world Nordic skiing championships in Sapporo, Japan, he was no stranger to high-level competition.

title: Janet Brown, Fashion Retailer, Dies at 59
description: Janet Brown, an influential fashion retailer who brought important designers to the wealthy clientele of her small store on Long Island, often before the designs were famous or even sold in Manhattan, died in a car accident on Friday near her home in Oyster Bay, N.Y. She was 59.

title: Delta Says Top Executive Wont Receive Stock Package
description: Delta Air Lines said yesterday that its chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, who has shepherded the carrier through reorganization, would not receive any stock, incentive payments or severance when the company exits bankruptcy protection this spring.

title: Booker Tries to Unseat Legislators, Dividing Party
description: NEWARK, March 19  The broom was an effective prop during Cory A. Bookers electoral juggernaut last spring, when he won the mayors office by a landslide and swept his slate of candidates into the nine-seat Municipal Council. On election night, he and his allies pumped corn husk brooms over their heads to drive home the point that they were clearing away the old guard that had governed this city for decades.

title: Ernst Haefliger, Swiss Tenor, Dies at 87
description: Ernst Haefliger, a Swiss tenor who was most renowned as an interpreter of German art song and oratorio roles, died on Saturday in Davos, Switzerland, where he maintained a second home. He was 87 and lived in Vienna.

title: When Less Is Best
description: Why are we in Afghanistan? Vice President Cheney talks terror, Britain focuses on narcotics. The European Union talks state-building, others gender. On a different day, the positions seem interchangeable. Five years ago, we had a clear goal. Now we seem to be pursuing a bundle of objectives, from counterinsurgency to democratization and development, which are presented as uniform but which are in fact logically distinct and sometimes contradictory.

title: Seeds of Compassion, Buried but Not Gone
description: Michael was 16 years old when his life changed. How much worse could it become? Mental retardation had allowed him only one great pleasure  his bicycle  and even that was taken away when he was hit by a truck while riding.

title: Money Looms in Episcopalian Rift With Anglicans
description: As leaders of the Anglican Communion hold meeting after meeting to debate severing ties with the Episcopal Church in the United States for consecrating an openly gay bishop, one of the unspoken complications is just who has been paying the bills.

title: Sorority Exclusions (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pushed Aside, Frye Fights Back to Knicks Forefront
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 19  Channing Frye did not fade out of the Knicks offense. He was shoved out. This was a matter of necessity, not malice, but it still produced a nasty bit of whiplash.

title: A South Jersey Town Emerges as a Hub of E-Commerce
description: LUMBERTON, N.J.  With its red-brick exterior and a wood-paneled lobby that is decorated with artwork from students at the nearby elementary school, the post office in this unassuming town 20 miles east of Philadelphia hardly looks like a center of Internet commerce.

title: Take-Two Examines Possible Sale of Company
description: Take-Two Interactive Software, the video game publisher whose marketplace impact has been overshadowed by its corporate upheaval, said yesterday that it was weighing options including a possible sale of the company, prompting a surge in its stock price.

title: The Fats in Nuts
description: Q. Is it true that the good oil in nuts turns to a trans fat when the nuts are roasted?

title: For the Record
description: A chart with a front-page news analysis article on March 11 about a looming crisis in the mortgage market mislabeled the size of the market that trades mortgage-backed securities. It trades in hundreds of billions of dollars a day, not hundreds of millions.

title: On 4th Anniversary of War, a Day of Vigils and Protests
description: CHICAGO, March 19  Opponents of the war in Iraq and people paying tribute to Americans and Iraqis who have died in the conflict gathered Monday across the country in cities large and small on the fourth anniversary of the start of the war.

title: Barclays Confirms Talks to Buy Big Dutch Rival
description: LONDON, March 19  Barclays, the British bank, confirmed on Monday that it was in exclusive talks with ABN Amro Holding about a possible takeover that could be the biggest in the financial services industry.

title: Airbus Superjumbo Takes a Lap Around America
description: For all its troubles, the double-decker superjumbo Airbus A380 is enjoying a star turn in the aviation world spotlight.

title: Detainee Says He Was Abused While in U.S. Custody
description: LONDON, March 19  David Hicks, the first detainee to be formally charged under the new military tribunal rules at Guantnamo Bay, has alleged in a court document filed here that during more than five years in American custody he was beaten several times during interrogations and witnessed the abuse of other prisoners.

title: Trial Opens for a Former Brooklyn Judge Accused of Accepting Bribes to Fix Cases
description: In the four years since Justice Gerald P. Garson was charged with taking payoffs from a lawyer in his Brooklyn chambers, a turbulent chapter of legal and political history has unfolded, with more characters than a Robert Altman movie.

title: The Scientific Promise of Perfect Symmetry
description: It is one of the most symmetrical mathematical structures in the universe. It may underlie the Theory of Everything that physicists seek to describe the universe.

title: More Mobile Technology
description: Work harder, and watch your spending on the road. Thats the message from financial executives at midsize companies surveyed by American Express and CFO Research Services. More than 40 percent of 300 executives said they expected to increase spending on mobile technology designed to increase business travelers productivity like cellphones, personal digital assistants and laptops, said American Express, which offers business travel management services, including corporate credit cards. Nearly three-quarters said they planned to improve procedures for making sure employees complied with travel spending policies to spot and halt maverick spending by employees, said Tom Tierney, the senior vice president for sales at the American Express U.S. Commercial Card division.

title: G.O.P. Criticizes Schumers Dual Roles in Investigation
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, has long been seen as one of the best political performers in Washington, a master of spotting hot issues and wringing the most out of them.

title: Fans, Start Your Engines for Extreme Marriage
description: Readers of spy novels sometimes used to imagine that they could be of service to their governments, since they knew cold the ways of the K.G.B. and understood various tricks of transportation in the Urals.

title: Money: Financial Troubles Can Affect the Heart
description: Patients who have trouble paying their medical bills do significantly worse in the year after heart attacks than patients under less financial pressure, a new study finds.

title: Statements and Restatements
description: The Bush administration  with the vocal support of business interests  is arguing that the time is right to loosen some of the requirements of the Sarbanes-Oxley corporate reform law, passed after the scandals at Enron and WorldCom. But if anyone doubts that these reforms, designed to increase accuracy and accountability, are necessary, consider this: According to the research firm Glass Lewis, nearly 10 percent of companies listed on exchanges in the United States refiled their financial statements last year after finding mistakes.

title: State Farm Skirts Judge in New Hurricane Plan
description: After more than eight weeks of stalemate over a federal court agreement to reopen thousands of insurance claims from Hurricane Katrina in Mississippi, State Farm said yesterday that it would work instead through state regulators. The new plan would speed the flow of money to storm victims but they would lose the courts oversight.

title: Communist Party USA Gives Its History to N.Y.U.
description: The songwriter, labor organizer and folk hero Joe Hill has been the subject of poems, songs, an opera, books and movies. His will, written in verse the night before a Utah firing squad executed him in 1915 and later put to music, became part of the labor movements soundtrack. Now the original copy of that penciled will is among the unexpected historical gems unearthed from a vast collection of papers and photographs never before seen publicly that the Communist Party USA has donated to New York University.

title: On the 4th Anniversary of the War (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Honorees Include 2 Who Help Tenants in Arrears
description: Filled with wrangling lawyers, exasperated judges and seemingly intractable landlord-tenant disputes, the housing court in Brooklyn is often an unhappy place. That is particularly true for tenants facing eviction because they cannot pay their rent.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: For You, Too, Fame May Be Waiting at YouTube

title: Lightning and Climate Change
description: Nitrogen oxides, the reactive gases that contribute to smog near the ground and help regulate ozone far above it, are not made by cars and industry alone. A lot of NOx, as the various gases are collectively known, is made by lightning.

title: Zimbabwes Crackdown Widens to Reach Opposition Grass Roots
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 19  There were indications on Monday that the Zimbabwean governments violent crackdown on its political critics was spreading from widely reported assaults on opposition leaders to less public attacks and threats against local activists and their supporters.

title: Packing 100 Pairs of Shoes
description: If I told you that Im a shoe salesman who makes an occasional business trip, you would probably think, Now theres a safe job.

title: Qaeda Operative Confesses Role in Cole Bombing
description: A top operative of Al Qaeda has acknowledged his role in the bombings of two American embassies in Africa in 1998 and in the attack on the destroyer Cole off Yemen in 2000, according to a hearing transcript released yesterday by the Pentagon.

title: Be It Padua or Illyria, Boys Will Be Boisterous
description: Even advanced urban pack rats will be impressed by what the Propeller Company can cram into a single closet. Walk-in wardrobes on wheels are the scenic stars of this all-male London-based troupes boisterous and inventive productions of Shakespeares Taming of the Shrew and Twelfth Night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Snowflakes as Big as Frisbees?
description: Since at least the 19th century, people have periodically claimed to see giant snowflakes falling from the sky  big ones the size of saucers and plates or even larger, their edges turned up, their heaviness making them descend faster than small flakes.

title: Inquiry Into Deaths of Three Divers
description: Three New Jersey men who died after becoming trapped in a sunken ship while scuba-diving off the coast of Key Largo, Fla., were carrying spools of line to find their way out but apparently did not use them, investigators said yesterday. The men  Kevin Coughlin, 51, of Chatham Borough; Jonathan Walsweer, 38, of Westfield; and Scott Stanley also of Westfield but whose age was not released  died on Friday while attempting to enter the interior of the sunken vessel. Detective Mark Coleman, of the Monroe County Sheriffs Office, said rescue divers found large amounts of silt inside the ship, which would have made it difficult for the men to find their way out.

title: Bohemia: Woman Is Injured in House Fire
description: The Suffolk County police are investigating a fire that injured a woman late Sunday in Bohemia, the police said yesterday. The fire, at 883 Wall Street, started about 11:40 p.m. in the living room of a ranch house. Three teenagers escaped and alerted a neighbor. After the police were called, a neighbor, Joseph Imperato, 53, a New York City firefighter, entered the house to search for the woman, but was driven back by the fire. The woman, Donna Blieka, 46, was rescued by firefighters and taken to the Nassau University Medical Center. She was in critical condition yesterday, the police said. The fire was not considered suspicious, the authorities said.

title: For Mets Pitchers, Location Is the Word
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 19  Every spring when the Mets begin playing exhibition games, the pitching coach Rick Peterson puts together a forum for his pitchers near their warm-up area at Tradition Field.

title: Two Directors of Home Depot Will Not Seek Re-election
description: Perhaps the seat was a little too hot.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the dismissal of Israel Singer, a leader of the World Jewish Conference, referred incorrectly to the health of the organizations president, Edgar M. Bronfman, who has said he wants his son Matthew to succeed him. Dr. Adam Rosenbluth, Mr. Bronfmans doctor, said Mr. Bronfman is in very good health. He has no chronic debilitating illness nor does he have any illness that would have impact on his longevity and his ability to lead the congress. He is not in poor health.

title: Disparities: Secondhand Smoke Effects May Vary in Children
description: African-American children tend to have more tobacco-related illnesses than other children do, and a new study suggests that part of the problem may be that they react to secondhand smoke more strongly.

title: Scientist Finds the Beginnings of Morality in Primate Behavior
description: Some animals are surprisingly sensitive to the plight of others. Chimpanzees, who cannot swim, have drowned in zoo moats trying to save others. Given the chance to get food by pulling a chain that would also deliver an electric shock to a companion, rhesus monkeys will starve themselves for several days.

title: Manhattan: Former Police Officer Pleads Guilty
description: A former city police officer pleaded guilty yesterday in Federal District Court to drug trafficking charges, federal prosecutors said. The former officer, Jose Torrado, admitted helping his brother distribute large quantities of cocaine and marijuana in the New York area from 2002 to 2005, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Mr. Torrado, 31, of the Bronx, joined the Police Department in 2001 and resigned in 2006 as a result of the investigation, Mr. Garcia said. He added that while Mr. Torrado served as a police officer, he worked with a group that smuggled drugs from Mexico to New York in trucks.

title: Brooklyn: Janitor Is Accused of Rape
description: A janitor was arrested yesterday on and charged with raping an 8-year-old girl in the basement of Public School 91 on Albany Avenue near East New York Avenue, the police said. The janitor, Francis Evelyn, 58, of Brooklyn, was charged with first-degree rape, sex abuse and endangering the welfare of a child. Melody Meyer, a spokeswoman for the Department of Education, said that Mr. Evelyn had been removed from the schools pending disposition of the case. According to the police, the child told her mother about the sexual attacks, which they said took place between Feb. 1 and March 9.

title: Yankees Coach Looks in the Mirror and Sees Posada
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 19  With the ease of one friend meeting another in a coffee shop, the Yankees coach Tony Pea pulled up a chair at Jorge Posadas locker in the clubhouse. Pea placed his paper coffee cup on the floor, picked up a baseball and began an impromptu catch-and-throw lesson.

title: Exercise: Working Out the Memory as Well as the Muscles
description: Exercise, researchers have found over the years, appears to help people fight the natural memory loss that comes with aging.

title: In Favor of Something Big, Loud and Often Ignored
description: Its like sitting on a mine of buried treasure, said Paul Jacobs, the 30-year-old chairman of the organ department at the Juilliard School. I want to draw attention to an instrument that is sorely misunderstood and neglected by the mainstream of classical music.

title: Talk of Exchange Deal
description: CHICAGO, March 19 (Reuters)  CBOT Holdings Inc. and IntercontinentalExchange, the energy derivatives market, are moving quickly after a proposal on Thursday by ICE to buy the Chicago exchange for $9.9 billion.

title: Cue the 4:53 Silver Bullet to Happy Hour
description: YOU know the old drinkers saying that it is always 5 oclock somewhere? Coors is turning back the clock seven minutes in an effort to turn the clock forward when it comes to reaching consumers through new media.

title: Keep on Truckin
description: For years, truck makers have tried to build carlike features into their products. Now, a leading truck maker is peddling its wares with a carlike campaign.

title: Costs Expand for Digging of New Subway
description: Rising real estate prices will force the Metropolitan Transportation Authority to pay about $54 million more than it had anticipated to buy five Upper East Side buildings and portions of 24 others to make way for construction of the Second Avenue subway, according to a new estimate provided to the authority.

title: Medicare Still Pays Doctors Who Owe Back Taxes
description: WASHINGTON, March 19  Thousands of doctors and other health professionals who participate in Medicare are delinquent in paying federal income and payroll taxes, owing more than $1.3 billion, but they continue to receive Medicare payments because the government does little to check their background, federal investigators said Monday.

title: Start of Conrad Black Trial Put Off to Today
description: CHICAGO, March 19  The criminal trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black and three associates ran into some delays on Monday after lawyers for Mr. Black raised concerns about the timing of two large settlements by a chief witness in the case.

title: Am I Really a Neo-Cossack?
description: Greetings from Afghanistan, where Im sitting in the New York Times bureau at the moment, going through my email. My Sunday column on Israel generated plenty of both blasts and praise. At one end of the spectrum, The New York Sun published an extraordinary editorial, The New Blood Libel, which began:

title: Your Comments on my Cheney Column
description: I welcome your comments on my Tuesday column about whether Dick Cheney is an Iranian mole. If you have other suggestions for who should be investigated as a possible mole, list them here as well. Also, here are links to a column about Cheney from last month (and the reader comments) and and a related blog post.

title: Beyond the News, Reminders of the War
description: Four years after the U.S. invasion of Iraq, most Americans still have no direct sense of the war beyond the television set, Alessandra Stanley writes in todays Arts section. And news programs are not the only place where viewers are exposed to the conflict; it has surfaced as a subplot or subliminal theme on reality shows and sitcoms.

title: Smoke and Mirrors
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Gorgeous greens
description: Pezula view

title: Why Blackstone Might Go Public
description: Blackstone Groups reasons for considering a initial public offering probably include a desire for a way for insiders to cash out more easily, as well as a bit of hubris, according to MarketWatchs David Weidner. Having the biggest market capitalization and making the first splash could be worth more than the purely financial reward to someone who already has all the money he could ever want, Mr. Weidner writes.

title: President Bushs Comments on the Dismissal of U.S. Attorneys
description: Following is the text of President Bush's remarks on the dismissal of United States attorneys, delivered on March 20, as provided by the White House.

title: Court Rejects Suit Against Enron Banks
description: A federal appeals panel ruled Monday that a class-action lawsuit against investment banks over their role as advisers to Enron cannot go ahead, dealing a blow to shareholders who lost billions of dollars after the company collapsed in 2001.

title: Triad Dumps Private Equity for Higher Bid from Rival
description: Triad Hospitals ditched its deal to sell itself to a private equity consortium after it received a better offer from a rival, Community Health Systems. Triad said Monday that it had accepted Community Healths $5.1 billion offer to create the biggest publicly traded hospital chain in the nation.

title: Settlements Delay Start of Conrad Blacks Trial
description: The criminal trial of the former media baron Conrad M. Black and three associates ran into some delays on Monday after lawyers for Mr. Black raised concerns about the timing of two large settlements by a chief witness in the case.

title: Delta Says Top Executive Wont Receive Stock Package
description: Delta Air Lines said Monday that its chief executive, Gerald Grinstein, who has shepherded the carrier through reorganization, would not receive any stock, incentive payments or severance when the company exits bankruptcy protection this spring.

title: Banks Confirm Talks on $80 Billion Merger in Europe
description: Confirming myriad reports, Barclays, the British bank, said Monday that it was in talks with ABN Amro Holding about a possible takeover. Analysts esimated the price of a deal at 60 billion euros ($80 billion), which could make it the biggest ever in the financial services industry.

title: CBOT Green Lights Talks With ICE
description: CBOT Holdings, the parent of the Chicago Bord of Trade, and IntercontinentalExchange, the energy derivatives market, are moving quickly after a proposal on Thursday by ICE to buy the Chicago exchange for $9.9 billion. The parent of the Chicago exchange said Monday that its board had authorized talks with ICE, adding it had not changed a recommendation that shareholders vote next month in favor of a merger struck with CME Holdings, parent of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

title: War at Home: A Back Step Toward an Exit
description: As Democratic House leaders move toward a critical vote this week on Iraq spending legislation, one of their most difficult challenges has been gauging the restlessness on the partys left.

title: At Bank of America, $23 Million for Chief
description: The chairman and chief executive of Bank of America, Kenneth D. Lewis, received compensation valued at nearly $23 million in 2006, according to a regulatory filing Monday. Mr. Lewis, 59, received $1.5 million in salary, $6.5 million in nonequity incentive plan compensation, and stock and option awards that were valued by the company at $14.6 million on the dates they were issued.

title: Sentence for a Former Citibank Trader
description: The former head of Citibanks worldwide commodities trading desk was sentenced to 15 months in prison Monday after pleading guilty to conspiracy last year in connection with a plan to inflate trading profits by as much as $20 million. At a hearing in Manhattan, Judge Alvin K. Hellerstein of United States District Court also ordered the former trader, David Becker, to pay $200,000 in restitution and a $25,000 fine. The prison term will be followed by two years of supervised release.

title: Two Directors of Home Depot Will Not Seek Re-election
description: Perhaps the seat was a little too hot.

title: A.M.A. Opposes UnitedHealth Deal for Sierra
description: The American Medical Association asked the Justice Department on Monday to block the UnitedHealth Groups proposed $2.6 billion purchase of Sierra Health Services, saying the deal would be anticompetitive. The A.M.A. estimated that if the merger were completed, UnitedHealth would control 78 percent of the market for health maintenance organizations in Nevada and 95 percent of the market in the Las Vegas-Paradise area.

title: SAC Takes Stake in Florida Homebuilder
description: SAC Capital, the hedge fund, continues to show its activist side. SAC disclosed on Tuesday a 9.5 percent stake in WCI Communities, a Florida homebuilder that the billionaire financier Carl Icahn recently offered to acquire, and said it might enter into discussions with the companys management.

title: Prospective Jurors Questioned in Case Against Former Qwest Chief
description: Jury selection began on Monday in the $101 million insider trading trial of the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, Joseph P. Nacchio, who watched prospective jurors and actively consulted with lawyers.

title: Quanta Services to Buy InfraSource
description: Quanta Services, a builder of energy and telecommunications networks based in Houston, said Monday that it would buy InfraSource Services for $1.26 billion to expand its services and increase its national presence. The all-stock deal calls for the exchange of 1.223 shares of Quantas common stock for each outstanding common share of InfraSource. That is about $30.13 a share, a 17.4 percent premium over the closing price of InfraSource stock last Friday, according to the companies.

title: Big Investors Take Their Climate Concerns To Congress
description: Joining a growing chorus from American businesses, more than 50 major investors, who together manage $4 trillion, asked Congress on Monday to enact tough federal legislation to curb carbon emissions and to overhaul energy policies nationwide. It marks the first time that a group of major money managers, including Merrill Lynch and the California Public Employees Retirement System, have requested that Congress take such extensive action on global warming.

title: Rosneft Gets $22 Billion from Banks to Bid on Yukos Assets
description: Rosneft, Russias state-run oil company, will borrow $22 billion to buy assets, including those of bankrupt Yukos Oil, helping President Vladimir Putin seal control of the nations energy industry. Rosnefts board on March 15 approved borrowing $13 billion and $9 billion in credits arranged by banks including Goldman Sachs and BNP Paribas, the company said in a statement Tuesday.

title: Bear Stearns Starts Up $500 Million China Fund
description: Bear Stearns and Chinas richest man, Huang Guangyu, set up a $500 million fund to invest in retailers in China. Mr. Guangyu, chairman of Gome Electrical Appliances Holdings, will use his closely held Eagle Investment Group to invest $250 million for buying non-appliance retailers, with the New York-based investment bank contributing the remainder, the companies said in a joint statement Tuesday.

title: Intarcia Taps V.C.s for $50 Million
description: Investors were flush with love for Intarcia Therapeutics, despite a failed initial public offering in 2005 and abandonment of its lead-drug program a year ago. The 10-year-old drug developer returned to the well to raise $50 million in a venture capital round led by new investor New Leaf Venture Partners to advance drug delivery programs for hepatitis and diabetes.

title: BlackRock Joins Growing Opposition to Laureate Buyout
description: BlackRock has added its name to the list of those opposing the $60.50 per share, $3.1 billion buyout of Laureate Education. But the go-shop window has closed without a better offer. BlackRock sent a letter Monday to the Laureate independent board members stating that without an increase it would not support the management buyout backed by a consortium including Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Citigroup Private Equity and SAC Capital Management.

title: Nu Image Said to Be in Deal for First Look
description: The production company Nu Image/ Millennium Films is reportedly in talks to buy the hedge-fund backed First Look Pictures, whose chief executive and largest shareholder, Henry Winterstern, recently resigned. The move is an about face since Mr. Wintersten was himself planning to make a run at Nu Image before he fell afoul of a backer Prentice Capital Management, reportedly for his lavish spending habits and inability to pick a winner.

title: NimbleGen, a Biotech Firm, Considers Initial Offering
description: A biotech firm, NimbleGen Systems, filed an initial public offering with the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell up to $75 million in common stock. The company, based in Madison, Wis., makes microarrays, or biological assays, and related products for the life sciences research market.

title: Chinese Regulators Move to Cool Market
description: Chinas securities regulator barred companies from using proceeds from share sales to invest in stocks in an attempt to damp overheating financial markets. Companies are also banned from buying derivatives and convertible bonds with share sale proceeds, the China Securities Regulatory Commission said Tuesday.

title: Landrys Blasts Wollensky C.E.O.s Role in Patina Deal
description: Landrys Restaurant Group, which is battling Patina Restaurant Group for control for Smith & Wollensky Restaurant Group, is claiming that Wollenskys chief executive, Alan Stillman, is pushing the Patina deal because he stands to personally gain if the Los Angeles group walks away the winner.

title: Heap of History: Communist Archive
description: The Communist Party USA has donated a vast archive of documents to New York University, Patricia Cohen reports today. The cache contains decades of party history including founding documents, secret code words, stacks of personal letters, smuggled directives from Moscow, Lenin buttons, photographs and stern commands about how good party members should behave, and the hand-written last will of the labor activist Joe Hill, which was later set to song. Liberal and conservative historians were enthusiastic about the addition of so many original documents to the historical record, though it could take years to catalog them all.

title: Correction: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about tragic events in New York City that often mark a neighborhood for decades, while others fade from memory, misspelled the given name of a black teenager whose fatal shooting in a white neighborhood in Brooklyn in 1989 set off racial unrest. He was Yusuf Hawkins, not Yusef.

title: Who Wants Control of Take-Twos Joystick?
description: After Take-Two Interactive Software, the video game publisher announced Monday that it was mulling a sale, analysts appeared divided on whether the company could pull off a deal, and if so, with whom. Take-Two said that it was weighing options including a possible sale of the company, days after a group of private equity and mutual funds that control 46 percent of the outstanding shares said it would seek to oust the board and possibly the top management.

title: Dubai Aerospace to Buy 2 Carlyle Companies, Report Says
description: Dubai Aerospace Enterprise is nearing a deal to buy a series of aviation businesses from the Carlyle Group for more than $1.5 billion, Reuters reported Monday, citing an unnamed source. As part of the agreement, DAE, an investment firm, would buy Landmark Aviation, an aircraft maintenance provider, and Standard Aero, which provides repair and overhaul services at airport terminals for small-jet aviation and some military transports, according to Reuters source.

title: Palm May Reach Deal by Thursday, Report Says
description: Palm, the iconic but struggling maker of smartphones and handheld devices, could reach a deal to sell itself by this Thursday for at least $20 a share, the Web site Unstrung reported citing unnamed sources. Among the four leading bidders is Nokia, the worlds largest cellphone maker, according to the site. But Unstrung reported that Palm management would prefer a private equity bidder, naming the Texas Pacific Group and, tentatively, Silver Lake Partners as in the running.

title: Affiliated Computer Gets Buyout Offer
description: Affiliated Computer Servicess chairman, Darwin Deason, and Cerberus Capital Management said Tuesday they had offered to take the technology outsourcing company private for $59.25 a share in cash, or about $8.2 billion including assumed debt. The offer represents a 15.5 percent premium to Affiliated Computers closing share price Monday.

title: Naomi Campbells Sanitation Vacation
description: For Naomi Campbell, preparing to pay her debt to society  five days of community service for hitting her maid with a cellphone  did not simply require the summoning of enough humility to leave the fashion world for the blue-collar one. It also required a thorough examination of her fashion options.

title: The News in Quotes: Parents, Police, Communists and a Supermodel
description: Second Avenue Subway: We are praying that they run out of money.  Sally Ardrey, whose East 72nd Street home would be torn down.

title: Cockfighting and Freedom
description: Last week, New Mexico Gov. Bill Richardson, a candidate for the 2008 Democratic presidential nomination, signed a law banning cockfighting, making Louisiana the last state in the union to permit the practice. Weekly Standard senior editor Christopher Caldwell doesnt appear to like cockfighting, but he thinks the eagerness of comedians and columnists alike to lampoon Richardson for opining there are strong arguments on both sides illustrates how something fundamental in American politics has changed. It used to be, under the U.S. system, that one could do anything that was not expressly forbidden, Caldwell writes in The Financial Times. Now one is forbidden to do anything one cannot make an explicit case for. The burden of proof has shifted.

title: A Rodent as a Holiday Treat
description: Before Easter, eating the meat of capybara, reputed to be the worlds largest rodent, has a status in Venezuela similar to that of turkey during Thanksgiving.

title: Jim Cramers Guide to Market Manipulation
description: Mad Money host Jim Cramer has gained a huge following, and more than a few critics as well, with his explosive stock-picking patter. But in a revealing video interview with TheStreet.com, the financial Web site he cofounded, Mr. Cramer drops some bombshells that go well beyond his usual chair-throwing, Booyah-shouting routine. In the clip, which has drawn lots of commentary on YouTube, Mr. Cramer brags about his ability as a former hedge-fund manager to game the stock market and offers what amounts to a how-to to aspiring stock manipulators, The New York Post reported Tuesday.

title: Hot Stuff
description: In one of the three-minute interstitial talks at the recent TED conference, presenter Steve Beshara demonstrated a high-end oven that cooks food up to 15 times as fast as a traditional oven. As the Mission: Impossible theme played, he attempted to bake a rack full of souffls in 90 seconds. (Needless to say, he succeeded.)

title: 9/11 Mastermind Confesses, and the World Shrugs
description: The muted international response to Khalid Shaikh Mohammeds confession that he plotted the attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, is evidence that the Bush administrations policies on the detention and treatment of enemy combatants have harmed the interests of the United States, says Washington Post columnist Anne Applebaum. She writes:

title: Blockbuster Chief to Resign This Year
description: After 10 years, Blockbuster is running the closing credits on chief executive John Antioco. The video-rental chain, which has struggled to compete with changing movie-viewing habits and upstart services such as Netflix, said Tuesday that Mr. Antioco, who has led the company since 1997, would step down by the end of the year. The agreement drew praise from activist investor Carl Icahn, who sits on Blockbusters board. In previous years, Mr. Icahn has sparred with Mr. Antioco about how to run the company and how much Mr. Antioco gets paid.

title: Pakistans Cricket Meltdown
description: With dozens dead in clashes in the northwest and continuing fallout over President Pervez Musharrafs suspension of the chief justice of the countrys Supreme Court, Pakistan hardly needed to hit the bad-news trifecta.

title: 2008: Migrating Immigration Stances
description: The Timess Adam Nagourney has a major policy piece on immigration today that spells out the liabilities for Republican candidates on the issue, especially Senator John McCain. The Arizona senator has been his partys most vocal proponent of comprehensive immigration legislation, which would include a path to citizenship for those currently in the country illegally. But in response to questions from Iowans recently, Mr. McCain said he would be open to supporting a different bill that would force illegal immigrants to return home before applying for citizenship.

title: Bush Backs Gonzales in Phone Call
description: While everyones still sorting through last nights e-mail dump from the Justice Department on the fired United States attorneys (some 3,000 pages of documents released a few hours before midnight), President Bush called Attorney General Alberto Gonzales this morning to express his support.

title: $500,000 Homes
description: Tour an island home off the North Carolina coast, a log-style house in Beulah, Colo., and a contemporary condo in Seattle.

title: Not All Things to All People
description: As I thumbed through the 10-page menu at the eighth restaurant I was trying in my new neighborhood, my dinner companion had choice words for my efforts.

title: Bohemian Living
description: Tour the vacation home of Barbara Benish, an artist, and Petr Kalny, an architect, in the mountains of southern Bohemia in the Czech Republic.

title: Apollo to Buy Claires Stores for $3 Billion, Report Says
description: After a nearly four-month auction that sparked little excitement, Claires Stores may have finally found a bidder. The New York Post reported Tuesday that Apollo Management, the buyout firm run by Leon Black, is close to signing a $3 billion deal for the company, which sells jewelry and accessories to preteens. Citing unnamed sources, the paper said that Apollo would pay between $32 and $34.50 a share. Shares in the chain were up 1.33 percent at $31.17 in mid-morning trading Tuesday.

title: Benchmark Signals Gaming Plays With New Hire
description: Mitch Lasky, who as chief executive of Jamdat led the company to the top of the cellphone-games market, is leaving his post as head of Electronic Artss mobile-games unit to join Benchmark Capital as a general partner. The move suggests that Benchmark, a Silicon Valley venture firm that just celebrated the sale of portfolio company Tellme Networks to Microsoft, will be considering more investments in gaming startups.

title: Cricket World Cup
description: The competition, held in the West Indies, has seen the death of Pakistan Coach Bob Woolmer, the benching of the England captain and a good run of form for New Zealand and South Africa.

title: Five Against One: Joe Bruno
description: In recent years, when Albanys leaders have forsaken their customary three-men-in-a-room meetings to discuss the budget in public, they almost always avoided debate on substantive issues  like what to do about health care and education  and focused on procedural issues  like, whether they were all free the next week to continue the talks.

title: Milken Seeks Investors for Education Firm
description: The philanthropist, former junk-bond mogul and ex-convict Michael Milken is in deal-making mode. Bloomberg News reports that he is looking to sell $1 billion worth of equity in Knowledge Universe, his privately held group of education companies, and has hired Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse to help him find buyers.

title: France in the Chips
description: Surprising news item on the Decanter magazine website. Apparently sales of wood chips to Bordeaux wine producers have soared in the last few months. It was surprising to me, at least, because I thought that in 2006 the French had banned the use of wood chips in response to the European Unions decision in 2005 to allow their use. It turns out that though the Institut National des Appellations dOrigine, which regulates French A.O.C. wines, had last November banned the use of wood chips, the ban hasnt yet been signed into law. Ah, bureaucracy.

title: A Form 13D, Complete with a Four-Letter Word
description: Some harsh words, including the F-bomb, livened up the usually bland world of regulatory filings last week. The colorful exchange, noted by Paul Kedrosky on his blog Infectious Greed, was directed at Robert Chapman, the chief of Chapman Capital, whose grandiloquently harsh criticism of the companies he invests in regularly raises executive ire. (DealBook readers may recall that Mr. Chapman recently complained about not receiving a return phone call from the chief executive of eSpeed, another company he has pressured for change.)

title: A Glass Bridge Over the Grand Canyon
description: Grand Canyon National Park encompasses most of the wonder of the world it is named for, but there are slices of the canyons rim that have endured for years outside the parks control.

title: A Potential Barclays-ABN Amro Deal Takes Shape
description: It seems that the official talks between Barclays of Britain and ABN Amro of the Netherlands have been fruitful: The two have already hashed out agreements over location and management structure. In a statement, the two banks said that they have agreed to keep their headquarters in Amsterdam, and will maintain a primary listing on the London Stock Exchange and a secondary listing in Amsterdam.

title: In Affiliated Computer Deal, Room for a Rival Bid?
description: With a Darwin Deason as an ally, Cerberus Capital Management might seem to have the buyout of Affiliated Computer Services all wrapped up. After all, Mr. Deason is Affiliated Computers founder and chairman, and he has a voting stake of nearly 42 percent in the company, a provider of technology outsourcing services. But after Mr. Deason and Cerberus announced their plan Tuesday to take the company private in a deal valued at $8.2 billion, including debt, Bryan Keane, an analyst at Prudential Equity Group, speculated that Mr. Deason might be open to teaming up with someone else.

title: Halcyon Hires Real Estate Investor
description: Halcyon Asset Management, a hedge fund that manages $10 billion in assets, said Tuesday it hired Kyle Ransford as a managing principal to expand its real-estate investment activities. Mr. Ransford is a co-founder of Cardinal Real Estate Investments, a firm whose holdings include commercial and residential properties in New York and Los Angeles and islands in Fiji, according to its Web site. Mr. Ransford will remain a general partner at Cardinal, Halcyon said.

title: The Upsets That Didnt Happen
description: U.N.L.V. is the lowest seed still alive in the Round of 16. But as a No. 7, the Runnin Rebels are still in the top half of the bracket, if just barely.

title: Syrup Smell Alert  in Texas
description: New Yorkers, you are not alone when it comes to being perplexed by mystery odors. Recall the sweet smell that wafted over the city at least twice, perhaps three times, in 2005, and the gassy odor that swept through earlier this year, causing evacuations and transit disruptions.

title: A Time-Out for Grannis
description: Assemblyman Alexander B. Grannis, who is Gov. Eliot Spitzers nominee to head the states Department of Environmental Conservation, got his day in the Senate today  but it wont be his last.

title: A Bank Merger for the Record Books
description: Sanford I. Weills reign as the banking industrys top deal-maker may be coming to an end. If Barclays and ABN Amro succeed in their merger talks  they announced further progress Tuesday, including agreements on location and management structure  the deal would likely carry a price of more than $80 billion, which would surpass the value of Travelers landmark merger with Citicorp in 1998. That transaction is widely seen as the defining moment of Mr. Weills career and, up until now, no bank deal has topped its $72.6 billion price tag.

title: Video: Ray Kelly Interview
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly sat down last Tuesday for an interview with Lx.Tv, a lifestyle channel on the Web. Most of the questions are softballs but he does address the Sean Bell case about six minutes in: The central question to this incident: is this an aberration or is it an indication of a systemic problem? And thats what we want to find out.

title: Apollo Signs $3.1 Billion Deal to Buy Claires
description: Its official: Claires Stores, purveyor of costume jewelry and accessories to preteens, said Tuesday afternoon that it will be acquired by Apollo Management for about $3.1 billion in cash. Under the terms of the deal, Apollo will pay $33 a share for the company, a premium over Mondays closing price of $30.76.

title: The House Inches Toward a War Vote
description: A meeting of the House Democratic caucus broke up shortly after lunchtime. Before the doors swung open, a booming round of applause could be heard inside the room in the basement of the Capitol.

title: Document: Brasserie LCB Inspection
description: The New York Post reported this morning that the city has shut down Brasserie LCB on West 54th Street (the new, less expensive incarnation of La Cte Basque). According to Page Six, the owner, Jean-Jacque Rachou, got into a profanity-laced spat with the inspectors after they stayed for hours.

title: Go in Style
description: I went up to the Met last night for the Saks dinner for Olivier Theyskens. There were about 150 people there, and I wondered why the party was at the museum and not in a restaurant. The invitation said black tie but half the women wore short dresses or pantsuits, as if they werent in favor of the black-tie idea, and at the last minute I decided my flat, dark brown boots looked fine with my sleeveless navy wool dress. Sometimes, when youre willing to be very practical about your clothes, you have a better time.

title: Clinton on Big Sister Video
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is looking on the bright side about a dark video about her thats been making the rounds on YouTube.

title: Harry Potter, Friend of the Forests
description: When Scholastic announced that it would be printing 12 million copies of the final Harry Potter book, the number inspired more awe than practical concerns. Chiefly, where is all that paper going to come from?

title: Palm Buzz Spreads to Motorola
description: Faster than a thumb-typing Treo addict, rumors about a Palm takeover were flying Tuesday. The chatter, which began earlier in the day with a report on the Web site Unstrung.com, grew louder after blogs and news reports started seeing a potential connection between the purported Palm auction and the decision by Motorola chief executive Edward Zander to cancel a speech at a major industry conference next week. A Motorola spokesman told the Chicago Tribune the cancellation was because of an unforeseen scheduling conflict, but there was speculation that Mr. Zander might be too busy negotiating a bid for Palm.

title: Sierra Released; Sanchez On the Mend
description: Omar Minaya said Ruben Sierra, reassigned to minor-league camp last Thursday, has been granted his release and is trying to hook up with another team. Also, Duaner Sanchez is expected to begin throwing from a mound by the end of the week. He will need to throw a few bullpen sessions and some live batting practice before he will be ready to pitch in a game. Minaya seemed skeptical that would happen before the Mets leave Port St. Lucie after next Fridays game.

title: Big Night for Pelfrey
description: In the time since Mike Pelfrey last pitched  Wednesday, when his fastball was nonexistent  he has done more to get ahead in the fifth-starters derby than he did on that blustery afternoon in Lakeland. Check out his competition:

title: Fighting Malaria with GM Mosquitoes
description: Scientists have built a better mosquito: one that doesnt spread malaria. Researchers at Johns Hopkins University report  in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences that these genetically modified mosquitoes, which are resistant to the malaria parasite in mice, gradually replaced other mosquitoes when they both fed on infected mice.

title: Blogtalk
description: Mayor Bloomberg qualifies his months-old comments about excessive force in the Sean Bell shooting. [The Politicker]

title: The CW Network
description: A commercial pod from the CW Network.

title: Buyout Rumors Lift A.D.M. Stock, but Analysts Doubt a Deal
description: In a week of deals, the specter of yet another buyout sent the stock of one company spiking. Trading volume for shares of Archers Daniel Midland, the food-processing giant, spiked on Tuesday as the market responded to rumors of a takeover. But analysts remained skeptical of such a deal.

title: Blogtalk: Testimony in Attorneys Saga
description: The White House, in the latest chapter of the ever-evolving U.S. attorney saga, said that Karl Rove and Harriet Miers would be available to Congress to be interviewed, but only under strict conditions and not under oath. The left-leaning blogs did not seem surprised at the move.

title: Bush Stands by His Man
description: It was very clear from President Bushs brief statement and short news conference just ended that he does not intend to back down from his support of Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, nor will he allow his top White House staff  adviser Karl Rove and former White House counsel Harriet Miers and their deputies  to be subjected to open public testimony on Capitol Hill.

title: Calling Out Film Critics
description: That the movie 300 was able to weather an unusually fierce barrage of bad reviews on its way to becoming the No. 1 movie in America is prompting a simple question. Should critics just  stop?

title: Haircut in Kabul
description: For Nicholas D. Kristof, getting a trim from a street barber is a great gauge of how things are going in Afghanistan.

title: View From the Basement
description: The Bracket has touched ground in San Antonio and is perched in his hotel room overlooking the Alamodome . (I cant think of The Alamo itself and not think of Pee-wees Big Adventure, when Pee-wee reaches the Alamo and is crestfallen that theres no basement. A fortune teller had told him his bicycle was there.)

title: Basketball as Refuge
description: A few weeks ago, The New Yorker published a story about 24 co-creator Joel Surnow, who, as it turns out, is a self-described right-wing nutjob and personal friends with Rush Limbaugh, and who produces a show that inspired Dick Cheneys wife to proclaim she is an extreme 24 fan. I live in Brooklyn, so it goes without saying that the majority of my friends are liberals, at least those willing to speak about their political beliefs in the boroughs (somewhat) open air. Also, the majority of my friends are 24 fans. And they suddenly found themselves confused.

title: President Bush on Attorney Firings
description: A defiant President Bush warned Democrats to accept his offer to have top aides speak about the firings of federal prosecutors privately and not under oath.

title: But I Didnt Do It!
description: Stanley Fish has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below.  The Editors

title: Composer House Arrest
description: Many people think that all composers are dead men with puffy white hair. Its not true. There are plenty of us that are showing signs of life, were just sequestered at home trying to find time to apply for grants, answer e-mail, chase down payments, send out scores, and maybe even write music. We can only fulfill the romantic image of a tortured composer at work after weve tackled mounds of administration and paperwork. I value every moment that I spend writing music, and recognize the fact that it takes a lot more than inspiration to get there.

title: Composer House Arrest
description: Many people think that all composers are dead men with puffy white hair. It's not true. There are plenty of us that are showing signs of life, we're just sequestered at home trying to find time to apply for grants, answer e-mail, chase down payments, send out scores, and maybe even write music. We can only fulfill the romantic image of a tortured composer at work after we've tackled mounds of administration and paperwork. I value every moment that I spend writing music, and recognize the fact that it takes a lot more than inspiration to get there.

title: Why Is Blackstone Going Public?
description: Less than three weeks after he said public markets are overrated and really not worth it to rainmakers like himself, Stephen Schwarzman, chief executive of the private equity powerhouse Blackstone Group, is reportedly working on a plan to sell a chunk of the firm to the public. The rarefied preserve of private equity  in which moguls use private money to buy shareholder-owned companies, take them private and sell them later  would be parceled out, share by humble share, to everyday investors.

title: What You Get for ... $500,000
description: North Topsail Beach, N.C.

title: Why I Was Fired
description: Albuquerque

title: An Elite ZIP Code Becomes Harder to Crack
description: The Postal Service, which mapped out social class four decades ago by separating people into ZIP codes, is about to give a new dimension to the adage there goes the neighborhood. This summer, ZIP code 10021 on the Upper East Side will become even more exclusive.

title: Flemington: Charges Dismissed for War Protester
description: Charges were dismissed yesterday against a man arrested in Flemington in the summer of 2005 after the police said he organized an antiwar protest in the borough without receiving a permit. The man, Bob Flisser, was fined $100 after the police charged he organized a protest of 24 people in front of the courthouse in Flemington, said his lawyer, Fernando M. Pinguelo. The American Civil Liberties Union argued that the towns ordinance was overly broad and helped Mr. Flisser appeal. Yesterday, Flemington officials asked a State Superior Court judge to dismiss the charges. The boroughs lawyer, Barry Goodman, said that borough officials did not want to spend the money to fight the appeal.

title: For the Record
description: The East Village Journal article on Feb. 18, about a dispute between a theater and an anarchist bookstore that have shared space in the same building for six years but are now going their separate ways, gave an erroneous location in some copies for the Anarchist Switchboard, another countercultural bookstore that used to be in the neighborhood. It was on East Ninth Street, not St. Marks Place. The article also rendered incorrectly the name of another former bookstore in some copies. It was the Peace Eye Bookstore, not Peace Eye Books. A reader pointed out the error shortly after the article was published, and this correction was delayed for research.

title: Star in New Role, Gore Revisits Old Stage
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  The last time Al Gore appeared publicly inside the United States Capitol, he was certifying the Electoral College victory of George W. Bush. He returns on Wednesday, a heartbreak loser turned Oscar boasting Nobel hopeful globe trotting multimillionaire pop culture eminence.

title: Hey, You Look an Awful Lot Like ...
description: Celebrity spotting is a favorite New York sport. So heads turned and horns honked at the line on 57th Street between 10th and 11th Avenues yesterday morning, outside the AMV Unitel Studios. Waiting in the line were Madonna, President George W. Bush, Roseanne Barr, David Letterman, Paris Hilton, Whitney Houston and many more. Robert De Niro kissed Roseanne hello, and the president and Madonna posed for a photograph.

title: Bloomberg Asks Agencies to Propose Budget Cuts
description: The Bloomberg administration warned its agencies this week that they might have to cut 1.5 percent from their budgets for this fiscal year and 4 percent next year because of a slowdown in the national economy, volatility in the stock market and a tentative labor agreement with city firefighters.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the recent proliferation of St. Patricks Day parades in the New York region misstated the given name in some copies of the president of the Chamber of Commerce in Rockville Centre, N.Y., which began its parade in 1997. He is Michael Shenker, not Eric. The article also misstated the population of Hoboken, N.J., which held its parade on March 3 this year. It is 39,900, according to a 2005 census estimate  not 70,000.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Toll From Tainted Pet Food Is 14; F.D.A. Is Focusing on New Gluten
description: The Food and Drug Administration said Tuesday that five family pets had died as a result of eating contaminated food that is the subject of a widespread recall.

title: A Short War Lives Long in the Minds of Soldiers
description: Big war, little war. For the soldiers dispatched to the front lines to fight, war is war. A harrowing 20-minute sequence of nighttime combat in Blessed by Fire, a bitter remembrance of the Falklands War in 1982, captures battlefield chaos and confusion with a visceral force you wont forget. As panic-stricken soldiers scramble in the mud amid flaring rockets and exploding shells, a wounded man screams for his mommy.

title: South Korea: Another Attempt at Trade Deal
description: The United States will make a final attempt at clearing barriers to trade in automobiles, medicines and rice as part of a free-trade agreement with South Korea by sending a trade official to Seoul next week. Deputy Trade Representative Karan Bhatia, who will make the trip, said it is the last chance to get a pact. American and Korean negotiators must reach an accord this month to get it to their legislatures before President George Bushs fast-track trade negotiating authority ends July 1. An agreement would be the largest American trade deal since the North American Free Trade Agreement in 1994.

title: An American Version of Virgin Atlantic Is Tentatively Approved for Service
description: Virgin America, a proposed start-up airline backed by Richard Branson, won tentative approval to operate from the Transportation Department after agreeing to jettison its chief executive and revamp its financing to reduce the influence of Mr. Branson and other non-United States citizens.

title: A Journey That Will Come Full Circle and End With a Ring
description: MOSCOW, March 20  The bells of Lowell House at Harvard  so much a part of the universitys tradition that they have their own society of bell ringers  will soon return to the Russian monastery from which they were sold more than 70 years ago.

title: But I Didnt Do It!
description: Delray Beach, Fla.

title: At the James Beard Awards, Food May Come in Second
description: WHEN the James Beard Foundation awards are announced on May 7, winners will not go to a temporary stage at the Marriott Marquis hotel as they have for more than a decade. They will take their bows at Avery Fisher Hall in Lincoln Center.

title: Edwards and Wife Plan News Conference
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat making a second bid for the presidency, announced late Wednesday night that he would hold a news conference Thursday, a day after he and his wife, Elizabeth, visited Mrs. Edwards doctor to assess her health following her recovery from breast cancer.

title: Blockbuster Chief to Step Down
description: John F. Antioco, the chief executive of Blockbuster, who has been locked in a dispute with the companys board over the amount of his bonus, agreed today to step down before the end of the year.

title: Manhattan: Late Show Without David Letterman
description: David Letterman went home sick yesterday afternoon, forcing his CBS program to quickly call in reinforcements from its guest list. Adam Sandler, who had been scheduled to be the lead guest on Late Show with David Letterman last night, was hurriedly enlisted to step in as host. Mr. Letterman has been forced to call in guest hosts on two previous occasions because of illness. This time, Mr. Letterman contracted the stomach virus that has been raging in the New York area and was too ill to perform, a spokesman for the show said. Mr. Sandler called in Don Cheadle to be the lead guest on last nights show. Mr. Cheadle is the co-star in the movie Mr. Sandler intended to promote last night, Reign Over Me.

title: Italy Swapped 5 Jailed Taliban for a Hostage
description: ROME, March 21 An Italian journalist who was held hostage for 15 days by the Taliban in lawless southern Afghanistan was ransomed for five Taliban prisoners, the Italian government and Afghan officials confirmed Wednesday.

title: Sensing Shift in Bush Policy, Another Hawk Leaves
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  Among the hawks in the Bush administration, Robert Joseph long occupied a special perch.

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about problems in the subprime lending market referred incorrectly to a statement by the investment manager, the Pacific Investment Management Company. While Pimco did indeed say in a report to clients that losses on subprime mortgages would affect other aggressively underwritten loans, it was referring to the market in general  not specifically to investments under Pimcos control.

title: It Boils Down to This: Cheap Wine Works Fine
description: IN the beginning, there was cooking wine.

title: Britain Proposes Allowing Schools to Forbid Full-Face Muslim Veils
description: LONDON, March 20  British authorities proposed new rules on Tuesday to allow schools to forbid Muslim students to wear full-face veils in class, reflecting a wider debate over Britains relationship with its Muslim minority.

title: For the Record
description: A dance entry in the Listings pages of Weekend on Friday, about Adrienne Truscotts genesis, no! at Performance Space 122, misstated the time of the matinees on Saturday and Sunday. They will be at 5 p.m., not 4 p.m.

title: F.B.I. Is Warned Over Its Misuse of Data Collection
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  House Republicans joined Democrats on Tuesday in warning the F.B.I. that it could lose the power to demand that companies turn over customers telephone, e-mail and financial records if it did not swiftly correct abuses in the use of national security letters, the investigative tool that allows the bureau to make such demands without a judges approval.

title: Crowds in Somalia Mutilate Bodies of Soldiers
description: KIWAYU, Kenya, March 21  The chaos in Somalia took an ugly turn on Wednesday when full-scale fighting broke out in Mogadishu and furious crowds mutilated the bodies of government soldiers, chanting, We will burn you alive!

title: Earmarked for Success?
