description: WASHINGTON, March 20  Kirsten Gillibrand arrived in Congress two months ago, ready to tackle national problems like health care, immigration and the war in Iraq. But few issues are as challenging as the one she has been confronting for the past few weeks: picking pet projects for her district.

title: World Bank Revises Loan Strategy
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  After months of internal wrangling, the World Bank committed itself Tuesday to a new strategy to combat corruption in its $20 billion annual loan program but not to cut off financing to poorly or dishonestly governed countries without consulting the banks board.

title: Wolfpack Works Extra for Yow and Advances
description: RALEIGH, N.C., March 20  All moments have become magnified for North Carolina State in the N.C.A.A. womens tournament. Each success sustains the possibility of a national championship, while a loss would end a poignant season and, perhaps, an ailing coachs career.

title: China: Restrictions Placed on Investments
description: Chinas securities regulator barred companies from using proceeds from share sales to invest in stocks in an attempt to damp speculative buying. Companies are also banned from buying derivatives and convertible bonds with share sale proceeds, the Securities Regulatory Commission said. Regulators are concerned that proceeds are fueling the stock market frenzy, said Gabriel Gondard, a money manager at Fortune SGAM Fund Management, a venture of Socit Gnrale in Shanghai.

title: Fed Weighs Words About Its Next Move
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  The Federal Reserve, implicitly acknowledging hints of trouble in the economy, edged away today from previous signals that its next move on interest rates would be up.

title: When Workers Lose Their Jobs (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Young Composers With a Healthy Respect for Traditions
description: Young Concert Artists is known mainly for the young ensembles and soloists who, having won the organizations annual auditions, play concerts under its auspices until they are picked up by larger management companies. But since 1994 it has also had a program in which composers in the early stages of their careers are commissioned to write works for the winners of the performance auditions.

title: Jim Cronin, Foe of Illegal Trade in Primates, Dies at 55
description: Jim Cronin, a self-trained zoologist who built a wildlife park on a deserted pig farm in southern England, then roamed the world with his wife to rescue illegally captured chimpanzees, orangutans and other primates, died Saturday in Manhattan. Mr. Cronin, who lived at the wildlife park, Monkey World, in Dorset, England, was 55.

title: Japanese Officials Issue Warning on Flu Drug
description: The Japanese health authorities warned this morning that the anti-influenza drug Tamiflu should not be given to teenagers, after reports that some children who took the drug exhibited bizarre behavior, according to Japanese news reports.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a pet food recall included an erroneous phone number in some copies for a manufacturer hotline. It is (866) 895-2708.

title: Episcopals Rebuff Demands on Stance on Gays
description: Responding to an ultimatum from the leaders of the worldwide Anglican Communion, bishops of the Episcopal Church have rejected a key demand to create a parallel leadership structure to serve the conservative minority of Episcopalians who oppose their churchs liberal stand on homosexuality.

title: House Panel Authorizes Subpoenas for Top Bush Aides
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  A House Judiciary subcommittee today authorized subpoenas for Karl Rove, President Bushs political adviser, and other senior White House officials in the investigation into the firing of eight United States attorneys.

title: Gore Warns Congress of Planetary Emergency
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  It was part science class, part policy wonk heaven, part politics and all theater as former Vice President Al Gore came to Congress today to insist that global warming constitutes a planetary emergency requiring an aggressive federal response.

title: A Rush of Excitement, From Filling in Empty Spaces to Completing a Large Loop
description: The elegance of a logic puzzle is determined by the ratio of two things: the simplicity of its rules versus the variety and depth of logic needed to solve it.

title: Correction: Serving You Tonight Will Be Our Lawyer
description: An article on March 7 about libel lawsuits that have been filed against restaurant critics misidentified a newspaper whose restaurant reviewer lost such a case. As noted elsewhere in the article, it was The Irish News, of Belfast, Northern Ireland, not The Irish Times, of Dublin.

title: To Ingenuity Add a Shovel: Meet the Wovel
description: NEW CANAAN, Conn.

title: 100 Dead in Militant Clashes in Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, March 21  More than 100 people have been killed in fierce fighting in the past three days between foreign militants and local tribesmen in northern Pakistan, security officials said today.

title: Aid to Palestinians Rose Despite an Embargo
description: JERUSALEM, March 20  Despite the international embargo on aid to the Palestinian Authority since Hamas came to power a year ago, significantly more aid was delivered to the Palestinians in 2006 than in 2005, according to official figures from the United Nations, United States, European Union and International Monetary Fund.

title: Study Finds Brain Injury Changes Moral Judgment
description: Damage to an area of the brain behind the forehead, inches behind the eyes, transforms the way people make moral judgments in life-or-death situations, scientists are reporting today. In a new study, people with this rare injury expressed increased willingness to kill or harm another person if doing so would save others' lives.

title: U.S. Cautions Foreign Companies on Iran Deals
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  For all its efforts to apply economic and political pressure on Iran over its nuclear program, the United States has never used a potentially potent tool in its arsenal  penalties on foreign companies that assist Iran in producing oil and natural gas.

title: Drug Rule Seeks a Limit to Role of Paid Advisers
description: WASHINGTON  Expert advisers who receive money from a drug or device maker would be barred for the first time from voting on whether to approve that companys products under new rules announced today for the F.D.A.s powerful advisory committees.

title: Spain: Delphi to Close a Plant
description: The Delphi Corporation, the auto parts maker, said it had filed for bankruptcy protection for a Spanish unit as part of a plan to close a money-losing plant in Cadiz, Spain. The parts maker will spend about $70 million this quarter for severance costs for the 1,570 workers at the plant, which makes steering mechanisms. Delphi, based in Troy, Mich., disclosed the measure in a report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company has not yet reached a severance agreement with the Spanish union. The Cadiz plant is the primary asset of Delphi Automotive Systems Espaa, Delphi said.

title: In Two Concerts, a Russian Is a Russian Is a Russian
description: On Sunday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall the Russian National Orchestra played music by Russian Romantics, including a superbeloved Rachmaninoff piece for piano and orchestra. On Monday night at Avery Fisher Hall the National Philharmonic of Russia played music by Russian Romantics, including a superbeloved Rachmaninoff piece for piano and orchestra. I went to both concerts, but one or the other would have done.

title: A New Home With a Loft (for Hay) and All the Amenities
description: For the 15 police horses assigned to Mounted Troop B in Midtown Manhattan, life just got sweeter. There is a heated, 6,500-square-foot training ring. There are ample stalls, a hay loft and a horse shower, all in a spanking-new stable with a glorious Hudson River view.

title: Spivs, Teddy Boys and Other Less Than Proper Britons
description: In 1946 George Orwell sensed a change in the British style of crime. The classic domestic murder of the prewar years had given way to random, conscienceless acts of violence influenced by the anonymous life of the dance-halls and the false values of the American film.

title: Recipe: Risotto al Barolo
description: Adapted from "Molto Italiano" by Mario Batali (Ecco, 2005)

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about President Bushs remarks on the fourth anniversary of the invasion of Iraq misstated the amount the administration has requested from Congress to finance continuing military operations in the current fiscal year. It is $100 billion  not million. (Go to Article)

title: Manhattan: Details of Killers Marine Discharge
description: David R. Garvin, the man fatally shot by the police after he killed a bartender and two auxiliary police officers in Greenwich Village last week, was discharged from the Marine Corps in the fall of 1988 for failing to show up for required training that was part of his military commitment as a reservist, a spokesman for the Marines said yesterday. The spokesman, First Lt. Brian P. Donnelly, said that Mr. Garvin, a private, was discharged on Oct. 24, 1988, and that the discharge was classified as general under other than honorable conditions. Mr. Garvin began his service on March 4, 1986, and his specialty was field radio operator.

title: Louisiana Governor Wont Seek 2nd Term
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 20  Gov. Kathleen Babineaux Blanco, politically battered by a shaky post-Hurricane Katrina performance, announced Tuesday that she would not seek election to a second term this fall.

title: Russia, Iran and the Bottom Line
description: Lets hear it for the profit motive. Russia has apparently decided that it can do even better financially if it starts pressuring its longtime client Iran to curtail its nuclear appetites.

title: Albany Formula of 3 Men in a Room Expands to 6, With One at Odds With the Rest
description: ALBANY, March 20  Joseph L. Bruno, the State Senate majority leader, can probably now relate to Richard Grasso, Maurice Greenberg and other corporate executives who have tangled with Eliot Spitzer.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Thatcher Drama-Documentary Planned

title: For the Record
description: The Lumberton Journal article yesterday, about the New Jersey towns ranking as the most active community, per capita, of eBay buyers and sellers in the United States, misstated the amount the company donated to a local animal shelter. It was $10,000, not $100,000.

title: Pfizer Painkillers Patent Upheld
description: Pfizer, the drug maker, won a court ruling yesterday blocking a rival company, Teva Pharmaceutical Industries, from marketing a generic version of the painkiller Celebrex, the worlds top-selling arthritis drug, until 2015.

title: Couples Not Rushing to Civil Unions in New Jersey
description: NEWARK, March 20  Preliminary figures released on Tuesday show that 229 same-sex couples applied for civil union licenses in New Jersey in the first month since they became available, far fewer than the 1,700 who registered as domestic partners in the state within that options first month in 2004.

title: New Accusation in Running of Smithsonian
description: The former inspector general of the Smithsonian Institution says Lawrence M. Small, the institutions top official, tried to head off an audit of the organizations business ventures division.

title: Air Force Says Boeing Will Keep Contract
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 (AP)  The Air Force will not reopen the $15 billion contract awarded to Boeing to build rescue helicopters. but will continue to talk to two rival companies that contested the contract.

title: U.S. to Offer Care to Infants of Illegal Immigrants
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  In a reversal, the Bush administration said Tuesday that babies born in the United States to illegal immigrants with low incomes could automatically qualify for one year of Medicaid coverage, just as babies born to United States citizens did.

title: Watching Son Fight Cancer, Karl Feels Pride and Pain
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 20  George Karl leaned against the wall outside the visitors locker room for support, refusing to let emotion leak from his eyes.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 9 P.M. (13, 49) THROUGH DEAF EYES Alexander Graham Bell advocated purely oral teaching for deaf students. Leaders of deaf organizations had to struggle to prevent the suppression of sign language in the education of students like those above, at St. Ritas School for the Deaf in 1918. Six deaf filmmakers and interviews with educators and historians explore these and other developments for the deaf in America over 200 years.

title: 3 Stars Weigh Points Against Playoffs
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 20  Allen Iverson broke into a trash-talking falsetto to needle his buddy Carmelo Anthony when the two exchanged 3-pointers around the arc at the Denver Nuggets morning shoot-around.

title: Correction: Trans Fat Fight Claims Butter as a Victim
description: An article on March 7 about a debate over natural and manufactured trans fat misspelled the surname of a professor of epidemiology and nutrition at the Harvard School of Public Health, who commented on the chemical makeup of trans fat. He is Walter Willett, not Willet.

title: A Second Home, for the Love of the Land
description: Richard Radcliffe is putting his second home to work. Three years ago, Mr. Radcliffe, 48, who lives in San Francisco, bought a six-acre vineyard in Occidental, Calif., in Sonoma County. He now sells his annual harvest of pinot noir grapes (last year he generated 17 tons) to two local Sonoma County winemakers who use them for wines that retail for $45 to $55 a bottle.

title: Navarre Toasts a Wider World
description: FOR 25 years one of the great wine stories has been the rapid transformation of sluggish, antiquated local production networks into dynamic winemakers to the world.

title: Fresh From the Dim Sum Cart
description: IT was Sunday morning at Pacificana  a lavish new Cantonese palace in a second-story space above a bank in Chinatown in Brooklyn. The place was mobbed.

title: Attorneys Case Will Be Subject of Political Ad
description: WASHINGTON, March 20 Illustrating the potential political fallout from removing eight federal prosecutors, the House Democratic campaign committee plans to begin broadcasting a radio advertisement on Wednesday that seeks to link a Republican member of Congress to the controversy.

title: Inside Japans Puzzle Palace
description: TOKYO, March 20  Will there be another puzzle craze after sudoku?

title: Suffolk Lawmakers Vote No on Bill to Curb Day Laborers
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., March 20  The Suffolk County Legislature defeated a bill Tuesday that would have prevented day laborers looking for work from congregating near public roads. It was a measure that the county executive, Steve Levy, supported in part as a way to deal with illegal immigrants who, he said, threaten the quality of life on Long Island.

title: Overlooked Area to Join the White Plains Boom
description: WHITE PLAINS  With buildings like the Trump Tower at City Center and the two towers that are now rising as part of the Ritz-Carlton complex on Main Street, this citys downtown no longer has a shortage of luxury residences and big-name developers. But a significant area near the center of the city has escaped the building boom, even though it sits only a few blocks from Main Street.

title: Those New Directors Keep on Emerging...
description: Misery loves company, and no one in turn loves misery more than newbie filmmakers. That, at least, is one of the conscience-thwacking lessons of the 36th edition of New Directors/New Films, the annual joint venture of the department of film at the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center that opens tonight. Dedicated to the work of what the festival terms new or emerging filmmakers, New Directors/New Films has served as an early stopping point for former up-and-comers from Chantal Akerman to Spike Lee and Wong Kar-wai and many more filmmakers who faded from view or never finished emerging.

title: And Now, a Commercial Break That Doesnt Seem Like One
description: ABC is considering changes in the decades-old way it interrupts programs for commercial breaks. The goal is to encourage viewers to stick around rather than reaching for the remote or racing to the refrigerator.

title: In the Arms of Scandal, and Ready to Cha-Cha
description: The British use America the way we use rehab.

title: Rutgers Clears Latest Hurdle, Only to Find Duke
description: EAST LANSING, Mich., March 20  Rutgerss path in the N.C.A.A. womens tournament has so far involved some pretty tall obstacles, including bad weather, an unfriendly crowd and a 6-foot-9 center.

title: Texas: Shots Fired at Border Agents
description: Two Border Patrol agents examining packages of marijuana that had floated ashore along the Rio Grande were fired upon by unseen assailants on the Mexican side of the river, the authorities said. The agents, who returned fire, were not injured, and there was no sign that their bullets had struck anyone, said Oscar Saldana, a Border Patrol spokesman. It was the second such episode this year along a narrow part of the Rio Grande near Donna, about 13 miles northeast of McAllen. Mr. Saldana said the shooting was most likely a response by drug smugglers to the Border Patrols more intensive searches of the area.

title: Blockbuster Chief Agrees to Exit Deal
description: John F. Antioco, the chief executive of Blockbuster who has been locked in a dispute with company directors over the size of his bonus, has agreed to leave his job at the end of the year.

title: Rape Suspect Is Charged With Murder After Accuser Is Fatally Slashed on the Street
description: Natasha Ramen did nearly everything she could to stop the man who she said had hurt her from hurting her more.

title: The Allure of Baked Goods Brings Him Back
description: Seth Greenberg grew up baking with his father, William Greenberg Jr., whose sleek chocolate cakes, sticky buns, buttery cookies and distinctively decorated celebration cakes had a deservedly loyal following for decades. The Greenbergs sold their bakeries about a decade ago and Mr. Greenberg retired. But now Seth, who confesses to having missed the allure of butter, sugar and chocolate, has gone back into baking and is offering a limited array of temptations that can be ordered for delivery in Manhattan.

title: Its Not the Mets Record, Its How Theyre Playing
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 20  Finally, after a long and tiring spring, the Mets will play an important game next weekend.

title: Spanish for Pain Perdu
description: THERE is French toast, and then there are torrijas, the Spanish version. The origins of both are undoubtedly the same: yet another way to make good use of bread thats no longer fresh. Though torrijas, like French toast, can be served at breakfast, they can also be a knockout dessert.

title: Tortillas Like Mams, but This Is No Bodega
description: AURORA, Colo.

title: French President Backs Rival in Election
description: President Jacques Chirac today endorsed the center-right candidate Nicolas Sarkozy for president. The endorsement is an important milestone in a tense relationship between the two men that has been marked by years of bitter political rivalry and gives a significant boost to Mr. Sarkozy in Frances presidential elections that are now less than five weeks away.

title: Tom DeLay Looks Back
description: Since his forced retreat from power in a corruption scandal, Tom DeLay, the former House Republican majority leader, must have been watching re-runs of Cool Hand Luke. That films cynical rationalization of lifes conflicts as merely a failure to communicate is Mr. DeLays approach to explaining the Republicans loss of Congress last year.

title: Google Tests an Ad Idea: Pay Only for Results
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 20  Google is experimenting with a new proposition for advertisers: if you dont get results, you dont pay.

title: Ex-Captive in Guantnamo Makes Run for Office in Australia
description: AUBURN, Australia  Mamdouh Habib cannot drink cold water. He vomits when he tries to, he said. He knows he must drink water, so he engages in vigorous exercise in order to force some lukewarm water down.

title: Against Top-Tier Opponent, Nets Come Up Short Again
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 20  Even though the Nets are in the hunt for a playoff spot  partly because of the futility of other teams  they are missing a foundation upon which they can build some postseason swagger. They have little to boast about, like lengthy winning streaks or victories against top-tier competition.

title: No Paradise for Criminals Deported to Jamaica
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica  One persons dream of being plucked from life in the United States and plopped down in the middle of winter on a beach in Jamaica is another persons nightmare. Just ask Noel J. Bryan, who had a grimace on his face recently as he cursed his fate in the sunshine.

title: What People Really Need
description: In nasty and bumbling comments made at the White House yesterday, President Bush declared that people just need to hear the truth about the firing of eight United States attorneys. Thats right. Unfortunately, the deal Mr. Bush offered Congress to make White House officials available for interviews did not come close to meeting that standard.

title: Make New Friends Online, and You Wont Start College Friendless
description: Monique Yin is months from starting her freshman year at New York University, but she has already chatted online with hundreds of classmates and met many of them, too.

title: Bush Tours 2 Auto Plants and Talks of Energy Policy
description: CLAYCOMO, Mo., March 20  President Bush on Tuesday toured plants of Ford and General Motors, two troubled automakers, and then gave a pep talk to hundreds of workers, saying that their work would help national security by reducing the nations dependence on foreign oil.

title: In Case of Emergency, Extract Sausage From Freezer, and Enjoy
description: ASK cooks about their culinary emergency funds  for use in case of a rainy day, citywide blackout, severe illness or case of laziness  and youll get answers like boxes of pasta and jars of tomato sauce, cans of black beans or a stack of well-worn takeout menus.

title: Company Deficiencies Blamed in 2005 Texas Explosion
description: HOUSTON, March 20  An explosion and a fire that killed 15 contractors and injured 180 other workers at the giant BP oil refinery in Texas City two years ago was caused by company deficiencies at all levels, a federal safety panel reported on Tuesday.

title: Russians Report Huge Loan to Buy More Assets of Yukos
description: MOSCOW, March 20  The Russian state oil company Rosneft has lined up $22 billion in financing from a consortium of Western banks to buy assets from a bankrupt rival, Yukos, Rosneft said in a statement on Tuesday.

title: New Season, Fresh Looks
description: The 36th New Directors/New Films series runs through April 1 at the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, and at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, plaza level, Lincoln Center. This years event also includes a sidebar presentation of documentary classics from past festivals and a panel discussion with previously featured filmmakers, including Ryan Fleck and Anna Boden (Half Nelson, 2006). Ticket information is available at filmlinc.com or (212) 496-3809. The schedule through Tuesday:

title: Igawa Controls His Destiny in Yankees Rotation
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 20  After a double-play grounder ended the fifth inning Tuesday night, the left-hander Kei Igawa walked so slowly off the field that center fielder Johnny Damon beat him to the dugout steps. Damon stopped to tap gloves with the stoic Igawa, while multiple Yankees waited in the dugout with hands raised for high-fives.

title: Letters
description: Caveat Emptor

title: After Concussion, Shanahan Is Back for Rangers Playoff Chase
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 20  For more than a month, Brendan Shanahan watched the Rangers struggle to climb into the playoff race while waging his own battle with something he could not measure in goals or points.

title: Guatemala: 4 Held in Killings of Salvadoran Politicians
description: Four suspected drug traffickers were arrested on charges that they helped orchestrate the killings of three Salvadoran politicians and their driver in Guatemala last month. Interior Minister Carlos Vielman said the suspects, three men and a woman, had ordered corrupt police officers to kidnap the lawmakers to recover money and drugs from their car. None were found. Four police officers arrested in the case were later killed in jail. A fifth officer remains in custody and one is at large, officials said.

title: N.C.A.A. Wants Athletes to Avoid Online Pools
description: The popularity of an N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament contest through a social networking Web site has forced college administrators and athletes to deal with concerns that participation in the free online competition violates N.C.A.A. gambling rules.

title: 58 Militants and Tribespeople Die in Fighting in Northern Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, March 20  Fierce fighting between foreign militants and local tribesmen in northern Pakistan in the past few days has left at least 58 people dead, government and security officials said Tuesday.

title: Deadly Fire in Russia Highlights Negligence
description: MOSCOW, March 20  A fire that swept through a home for the elderly and disabled in southern Russia killed at least 62 people early Tuesday, a toll that officials attributed to safety violations and a night watchmans negligence. Many of the dead were confined to their beds and unable to flee the smoke and flames, the officials said.

title: A Home in the Czech Mountains
description: Nearly a century ago, a handsome, well-to-do miller in a rural Czechoslovak village proposed to a young woman. Unexpectedly, she turned him down to marry a musician from a neighboring town.

title: Back From the Footnotes, Taking Her Bows Behind the Footlights
description: Of all the unhappy nights in the American theater  the openings that became closings, the depressing effluvia of genius in decline, the advent of Mamma Mia!  the saddest was certainly April 14, 1865, when Lincoln was assassinated as he watched a performance at Fords Theater in Washington. The event was of course a national calamity, but for members of the theatrical world, insult swiftly followed injury, as news spread that the assassin was an actor named John Wilkes Booth.

title: Recipe: Port-Braised Duck Legs With Black Pepper and Dried Cherries
description: Adapted from All About Braising, by Molly Stevens (W.W. Norton, 2004)

title: After Bell, Critics Want Mayor to Broaden Focus on Police
description: In the months since the police shooting that left Sean Bell dead and his friends wounded outside a nightclub in Queens, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has kept up the measured, inclusionary tone that he struck from the beginning.

title: Janet Brown, 59, Retailer of Fashions for the Wealthy, Dies
description: Janet Brown, an influential fashion retailer who brought important designers to the wealthy clientele of her small store on Long Island, often before the designs were famous or even sold in Manhattan, died in a car accident on Friday near her home in Oyster Bay, N.Y. She was 59.

title: Changing Exclusion to Inclusion
description: THE PROBLEM The 15 second graders in Catlin Prestons class in Hoboken, N.J., last year seemed unusually cohesive, right from the start, Mr. Preston said. So he was surprised when he learned of the Mortal Enemy Club, formed by six children to spy on another child and exclude him from the club. Several parents had found out about it and complained. Mr. Preston agreed that such clubs could lead to no good.

title: Manhattan: First Contract for New Subway Line
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced yesterday that it had signed the first contract for construction of the new Second Avenue Subway. The contract, awarded to a joint venture of construction companies called S3 Tunnel Constructors, is worth $337,025,000, the authority officials said. The contract allows construction to begin on the first phase of the project, which will run from 96th Street to 63rd Street before connecting to existing train service, officials said. When the project is finished, plans call for the subway line to stretch from 125th Street to Hanover Square in Lower Manhattan.

title: Recipe: Sauternes Custard
description: Adapted from "How to Eat," by Nigella Lawson (Wiley, 2002)

title: In U.S. Camp at Last, DeMerit Hopes to Show He Belongs
description: Few people would reproach Jay DeMerit for looking forward to taking a break from the rigors of the English Premier League.

title: A Glimpse of a More Vertical Los Angeles
description: LOS ANGELES  Long before the new urbanism became a tired phrase, Playa Vista, the last remaining large tract of undeveloped land on this citys traffic-choked West Side, was envisioned as a place where people could live, work, shop and play without leaving their neighborhood.

title: Doctors Ties to Drug Makers Are Put on Close View
description: Dr. Allan Collins may be the most influential kidney specialist in the country. He is president of the National Kidney Foundation and director of a government-financed research center on kidney disease.

title: A Radio Host Tries His Voice on Television
description: Few approaches to telling stories would seem less suited to modern television than that of the radio show This American Life: Tales unfold at a pace set by the normal speaking voice, the driving ethos is one of empathy, and when the epiphanies come, they seem to arrive of their own accord. It isnt exactly Flavor of Love.

title: France: Business Leaders Suggest Economic Measures
description: The main French business federation said that the French economy would be unable to grow at its full capacity under programs put forth by the existing candidates for president and announced an economic program of its own. The federation, Medef, called for looser labor rules, lower taxes and incentives to bolster investment and innovation. Laurence Parisot, left, president of Medef, said there was little hope of achieving what she called an ambitious but realistic goal with the platforms of the three leading presidential candidates: Nicolas Sarkozy, Sgolne Royal and Franois Bayrou. If you look at the three principal programs, none of them is proposing what we believe is right, she said at a news conference. The first round of voting in the election is scheduled for April 22 with a runoff set for May 6.

title: Charter Group Will Enroll More Pupils in Houston
description: The Knowledge Is Power Program, a charter school network widely praised for its results with low-income students in its 52 schools nationwide, yesterday announced a $100 million plan, financed by private donations, to expand its Houston operations over the next decade to serve about 10 percent of the citys public school population.

title: Marylands Bid for Second Straight Title Ends
description: HARTFORD, March 20  Marylands bid to win a second straight national championship ended Tuesday night, done in by a relentless defensive effort from a team intent not only on advancing in the N.C.A.A. womens tournament but, perhaps, looking for good old-fashioned revenge.

title: Fighting Over When Public Should Pay Private Tuition for Disabled
description: Paying for private school is no hardship for Tom Freston, the former chief executive of Viacom, the company that runs MTV and Comedy Central. He left with a golden parachute worth $85 million.

title: The White House and Congress Seem Headed Toward a Familiar Collision
description: Once executive privilege is asserted, Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote for the majority in a 2004 Supreme Court decision, coequal branches of the government are set on a collision course.

title: Milken Wants to Sell Stake in His Education Company
description: Michael R. Milken, the former junk bond chief from Drexel Burnham Lambert who served prison time for securities fraud, plans to sell a $1 billion stake in his group of educational companies called Knowledge Universe. Goldman Sachs and Credit Suisse are helping find investors for the private sale, according to regulatory filings.

title: The Waters of a Scottish Loch Poured Through an Italian Filter
description: When youre embarking on an opera based on a classic work of literature, it helps to read the work first. That is, if you can.

title: Magazine Will Begin Consulting With Experts
description: Consumer Reports, widely respected for its independent assessments of consumer products, has long steered clear of consulting with industry and manufacturers. As a further shield from being compromised, it accepts no advertising.

title: A Rustic European Treat of Prunes Poached in Wine
description: OFTEN on a dessert table in a bistro or trattoria in Europe there will be a big bowl of plump prunes poached in wine. Its a dessert I love, but one that is rarely offered in the United States. Except at my house.

title: Iraq Bombers Blow Up 2 Children Used as Decoys
description: BAGHDAD, March 20  Insurgents detonated a bomb in a car with two children in it after using the children as decoys to get through a military checkpoint in Baghdad, an American general said Tuesday.

title: Raising Animals for Food (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pakistan: Government Lawyer Quits Over Judicial Crisis
description: Protests against the suspension of Chief Justice Iftikhar Muhammad Chaudhry by President Pervez Musharraf continued as Deputy Attorney General Nasir Saeed Sheikh and another senior judge from Sindh Province resigned. Mr. Sheikh said it was difficult to work in the current judicial crisis. Judges, lawyers and opposition activists have been holding demonstrations across the country to condemn chief the justices suspension this month as an attempt by General Musharraf to muzzle the judiciary.

title: Birth Control Coverage (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Line-of-Duty Death Benefits for Officers Work After 9/11
description: The New York City Police Pension Fund has approved line-of-duty death benefits for the family of Cesar A. Borja, the police officer whose death in January became a symbol of the plight of those who worked in Lower Manhattan after 9/11.

title: Family Hearth Moves to the Backyard
description: BATH, Ohio, March 15  Doug Weintraub loves showing off his new $60,000 fireplace. It is in his backyard, with a chimney, built by a stonemason from Ukraine, that stands 16 feet tall.

title: Brooklyn: Reward Offered in Hunt for Killer
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Agency and the union representing transit workers have joined with the Police Department in offering a $22,000 reward for information leading to the killer of a transit worker, James Plucica, agency officials said yesterday. Mr. Plucica, a guard for the transit system, was fatally shot on his way home early on March 11. The police said he was shot in the chest on Ralph Avenue about 1 a.m. as he waited for a bus.

title: Manhattan: Three More Gun Dealers Settle Suit
description: Three more gun dealers have agreed to settle a federal lawsuit filed by the city by allowing a special master appointed by the court to monitor their operations, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The settlements bring the number of dealers who have agreed to the monitoring arrangement to 12, the mayor said. The special master will have the right to monitor their records and inventory and videotape their operations to ensure compliance with federal laws, Mr. Bloomberg said. The city filed two lawsuits in Federal District Court in Brooklyn last year against 27 out-of-state gun dealers, claiming their operations had created a public nuisance, said Eric Proshansky, a lawyer for the city.

title: Judges Coaching of a Lawyer Broke the Rules, Jurors Are Told
description: The videotape shows two lawyers, a veteran and a younger man, discussing strategy in a divorce case.

title: Manhattan: German Firm Buys Port Cargo Company
description: A division of Deutsche Bank, Germanys largest bank, has agreed to buy Maher Terminals, which runs terminals at the Port of Elizabeth in New Jersey and the Port of Prince Rupert in British Columbia. The deal, which must be approved by the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and the Committee on Foreign Investments in Washington, comes a year after Dubai Ports World tried to buy a terminal in Newark run by a British company. A division of the American insurance giant AIG closed a deal last week for that terminal. RREEF Infrastructure, the Deutsche Bank subsidiary, will retain Maher to continue running its terminals. Terms of the deal were not announced.

title: Bushs Call for Patience on the War (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: In Venezuela, Rodents Can Be a Delicacy
description: SAN FERNANDO DE APURE, Venezuela, March 17  As dusk fell on the tropical wetland crawling with iguanas and small crocodilian caimans, Jos Ismael Jimnez pointed his harpoon at a rodent about the size of a Labrador retriever. With aim that comes from years of practice, he landed his spear on the back of its head.

title: Bush Clashes With Congress on Prosecutors
description: WASHINGTON, March 20  President Bush and Congress clashed Tuesday over an inquiry into the firing of federal prosecutors and appeared headed toward a constitutional showdown over demands from Capitol Hill for internal White House documents and testimony from top advisers to the president.

title: Gonzales Bowed to Politics, a Former U.S. Attorney Says
description: SEATTLE, March 20  John McKay, the former United States attorney for western Washington and one of the prosecutors whose abrupt dismissal has brought intense criticism to the Justice Department, said Tuesday that Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales had allowed the department to succumb to political pressure and that he should be held responsible.

title: My 8th-Grade Teachers Excellent Adventure (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Off the Menu
description: Looking Ahead

title: Food Calendar
description: Spring Dishes, at Least

title: Collective Creation, in Philadelphia and Beyond
High School Star O.J. Mayo Boosts U.S.C. Before He Arrives
description: LOS ANGELES, March 20  It sounds like a fairy tale.

title: Favorite Author Not on Tour? See the Movie
description: Can video save the literary star?

title: Dallas Leaves Knicks Battered and Bruised
description: The whirlwind known as the Dallas Mavericks whizzed through Madison Square Garden last evening, leaving the predictable carnage in its wake. The Knicks looked much worse for the experience.

title: Hedge Fund Is Charged Over Trades
description: Beacon Rock Capital has been charged with defrauding mutual funds of $2.4 million, the first hedge fund to be criminally accused of deceptive market timing, the United States attorney in Philadelphia said.

title: Once Again, Debt Is Miscast as the Villain
description: Later this year, the National Film Preservation Foundation is going to re-release a silent movie from 1912 called The Usurers Grip. Its a cautionary tale about borrowed money that revolves around the Jenkses, a fictional middle-class family who need a $25 loan so their young daughter can be treated for consumption. After a loan shark tricks Mr. Jenks into borrowing at an interest rate of 180 percent, the family is brought to the brink of ruin.

title: Prevalence of Alzheimers Rises 10% in 5 Years
description: More than five million Americans have Alzheimers disease, a 10 percent increase from the last official tally five years ago, and a number expected to more than triple by 2050, absent a cure, as the 85-and-over population soars and the baby boomers move into their late 60s and 70s.

title: ... But in Emerging, How Far Do They Go?
description: Richard Gazowsky, the subject of Michael Jacobss documentary, Audience of One, is a Pentecostal minister in San Francisco. Round-faced, energetic and irrepressibly cheerful, he is also an aspiring filmmaker, and as such perhaps an emblematic figure for the New Directors/New Films program, in which Mr. Jacobss film is one of the few documentaries.

title: Trial Begins for Ex-Chief of Hollinger
description: CHICAGO, March 20  Two wildly different portraits of Conrad M. Black were presented to the jury in opening arguments Tuesday at the criminal trial against the former newspaper baron and three colleagues.

title: Survey of High School Students Finds Significant Drop in Drug and Alcohol Use
description: Teenage use of alcohol and drugs dropped significantly in New York City in 2005 compared with past years, and is lower than the national rate, but it remains disturbingly high, city officials said yesterday, citing the results of a recently released survey.

title: If Theres No Church Nearby, Confess Your Sins at the Hospital
description: Apart from the confessional, there are few places more conducive to confronting uncomfortable truths and hidden family secrets than a hospital waiting room. And few families have a bigger skeleton in the closet than the kith and kin of the Innes clan in Samm-Art Williamss amusing new play, The Waiting Room, now being performed by the Negro Ensemble Company at the 45th Street Theater.

title: Massachusetts Sets Benefits in Universal Health Care Plan
description: BOSTON, March 20  Massachusetts took a major step toward enacting its near-universal health care overhaul, with the board that oversees the plan voting on Tuesday to require insurers to provide certain minimum benefits, including coverage of prescription drugs.

title: Despite Foes, Buffalo Museum Makes $18 Million in Auction
description: The first in a series of sales of antiquities from the collection of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo made more than $18 million yesterday at Sothebys, providing a substantial boost to the museums endowment but saddening a group of patrons who have protested the decision to sell.

title: Chip Makers Settle Patent Dispute
description: Toshiba and Hynix Semiconductor agreed to end patent disputes over flash memory chips used to store data in electronic devices like digital cameras and MP3 players. Financial terms were not disclosed. Each company will get a license to the others semiconductor technology and signed product supply agreements. The accord settles all patent-related litigation in Japan and the United States, including three disputes before the International Trade Commission in Washington. The legal battles between the companies began in November 2004 when Toshiba, which is based in Tokyo, sued Hynix, based in Ichon, South Korea, after the companies failed to extend a licensing agreement.

title: Ernst Haefliger, 87, Swiss Tenor Famous for Lieder and Oratorios, Dies
description: Ernst Haefliger, a Swiss tenor who was most renowned as an interpreter of German art song and oratorio roles, died on Saturday in Davos, Switzerland, where he maintained a second home. He was 87 and lived in Vienna.

title: Taking Wine Seriously Is a Prerequisite
description: IS Varietal an important restaurant, worthy of your rapt attention and utmost respect? Cant you tell?

title: At the Garden, There Are Messages in the Money
description: One N.B.A. big spender is the son of an automobile upholsterer. He sold garbage bags as a boy to raise money for a pair of Puma sneakers and financed his college years by teaching dance lessons to any clunky, corn-fed Midwesterner with a spare dollar.

title: Ousted California Prosecutor Previously Had Disputes on Strategy
description: LOS ANGELES, March 20  Among the cases of the eight federal prosecutors dismissed by the Department of Justice last year, none brought more accusations of egregious political retaliation than that of Carol C. Lam.

title: Driving the Drama, Musically, Along Utopias Leaps and Bounds
description: Mark Bennett, the composer of the incidental music and soundscapes for Tom Stoppards sprawling trilogy, The Coast of Utopia, was introduced to Jack OBrien, the director of the production, about a year before Voyage, the first of the three plays, opened at the Vivian Beaumont Theater. At that initial meeting, Mr. OBrien, emphasizing the important function music would have in connecting scenes and conveying mood, laid out a challenge to Mr. Bennett.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,214 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Oracle Says Profit Rose 35% to Exceed Expectations
description: Lawrence J. Ellisons three-year buying spree as chief executive of Oracle appears to be paying off.

title: The Troika and the Surge
description: President Bushs Iraq surge policy is about a month old now, and there is only one thing you can say about it for certain: no matter what anyone in Congress, the military or the public has to say, its going ahead. The president has the authority to do it and the veto power to prevent anyone from stopping him. Therefore, theres only one position to have on the surge anymore: hope that it works.

title: For Orange Zest, Substitute Kool-Aid
description: POKE around at allrecipes.com, as several million curious home cooks do each month, and you might stumble upon a recipe for Sesame Seared Tuna. It calls for high-quality tuna to be coated in sesame seeds, then cooked, fast and hot, and served quite rare. Visitors to this Web site have given the recipe five stars (the top rating), and 61 of them have posted comments about it, including the following: This was really good and well liked by all. I did use chicken tenders, (2/person) in place of tuna.

title: Nassau Comptrollers Audit Chides the County Clerk
description: MINEOLA, N.Y., March 20  The Nassau County comptroller issued a stinging audit on Tuesday of the county clerks office, charging that while the agency routinely receives and disburses more than $300 million a year in public money, it is administered like a mom-and-pop enterprise.

title: Al Gores Future
description: Al Gore has said many times, if never quite definitively, that he has no plans to run for president in 2008, but that has not stopped his fans from speculating, or hoping.

title: Correction
description: An article yesterday about President Bush's remarks on the fourth anniversary of the invasion of Iraq misstated the amount the administration has requested from Congress to finance continuing military operations in the current fiscal year. It is $100 billion  not million.

title: Video: Haircut in Kabul
description: One of the highlights Tuesday was Nick getting a trim near the Kabul market. The sight of a western journalist getting his haircut on the street didnt draw as large of a crowd as Nicks visit to the barber in the refugee camp in Sudan. This isnt the first time hes done this in Afghanistan (or even the second.) Was the third time the charm? Watch the video and then make your comments about Nicks hair.

title: Under the Influence
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Currents
description: A way to live the country life in the manner of a master, fanciful frames for a budding collection and more.

title: Coming Attractions
description: Art exhibitions flourish across the country. Here is a selection of the latest offerings.

title: Not your parents fireplace
description: Fireplace plus

title: The British Are Coming!
description: 59E59 Theaters will announce today the full lineup for its fourth annual festival of new theater from across the pond, "Brits Off Broadway," running from May 3 through July 1.

title: Will Bid for Affiliated Computer Go Higher?
description: Affiliated Computer Services should hold out for a higher price from Darwin Deason and Cerberus Capital Management, according to Breakingviews and the Financial Timess Lex column. Mr. Deason, who is Affiliated Computers chairman, and Cerberus offered Tuesday to buy the company for $59.25 per share, but a Prudential analyst thinks Mr. Deason might be open to other bidding partners.

title: The worlds most expensive rental?
description: Finally, some affordable housing in London. The Sunday Times reports that the most expensive rental in London is a six-bedroom house at 10 Park Street in the posh Mayfair neighborhood, just a short stroll from Hyde Park. Developer Paul Davies wants 40,000  or nearly $80,000  a week for a short-term rental or 30,000 a week for six months or more. The property comes with a mews house for the staff and a 38-foot swimming pool in the basement. Real estate experts I contacted agreed that the price is a bit steep, arguing that Davies is more likely to get 20,000 or 25,000 a week. Yeah, now thats more reasonable.

title: Trial Begins for Ex-Chief of Hollinger
description: Two wildly different portraits of Conrad M. Black were presented to the jury in opening arguments Tuesday at the criminal trial of the former newspaper baron and three colleagues. In the version put forward by a prosecutor, Lord Black is a thief who is different from a bank robber only in that his methods involve artfully worded memoranda and he wears suits and ties.

title: Insider Trading Is Disputed at Trial of Ex-Chief of Qwest
description: The former chief executive of Qwest Communications, Joseph P. Nacchio, deceived investors and the public when he secretly sold $101 million in stock before its share price fell sharply, a federal prosecutor declared during opening statements Tuesday in Mr. Nacchios insider trading trial.

title: Beacon Rock Hit With Criminal Charges Over Trades
description: Beacon Rock Capital, a hedge fund, was charged with defrauding mutual funds of $2.4 million through market-timing trades, the United States attorney in Philadelphia said.

title: Hedge Fund Lends a Hand to Accredited Home
description: A hedge fund, Farallon Capital Management, rode to the rescue of a suffering subprime mortgage lender, Accredited Home Lenders Holding, extending a five-year $200 million loan after the companys financial backers cut it off.

title: In Gay-Bias Suit, the Lack of Evidence Is the Issue
description: Examining the escalating battle between the white-shoe firm Sullivan & Cromwell and a former associate, Aaron B. Charney, who claims he was harassed because he is gay, The New York Observer concludes that this is a case of lawyers behaving badly.

title: Take-Two Seen as Vulnerable in Proxy Fight
description: Take-Two Interactive Software, which is locked in a proxy battle with several hedge funds, has a gaping hole in its antitakeover defense, a director at Institutional Shareholder Services tells The Deal. Under certain conditions, the companys charter allows shareholders to replace Take-Twos board of directors without the need for a formal vote.

title: Gateway Says It Is Not In talks With Acer
description: Talk of a deal between the computer maker Gateway and strong>Acer of Taiwan has been rampant ever since Acers chief executive, JT Wang was quoted earlier this month as saying he planned to make an acquisition in the PC industry this year.

title: Aegerion Pharmaceuticals Plans I.P.O.
description: Aegerion Pharmaceuticals, a biotechnology company whose backers include a private equity firm, Advent International, filed with regulators to raise as much as $86 million in an initial public offering.

title: Is York Advising on Chrysler Bid?
description: Jerome B. York, former chief financial officer at Chrysler and Kirk Kerkorians right-hand man, may be advising possible bidders on a Chrysler buyout, David Welch wrote in BusinessWeeks Auto Beat blog.

title: News Corp. and Hearst Form Chinese Media Venture
description: The News Corporation and Hearst have teamed up with Patrick McGovern, the billionaire tech publisher, to back a new venture in China that plans to make movies, DVDs and computer and virtual-reality games for the Chinese market, The New York Post reported. The venture, known as the China New Media Fund, has a total of $50 million in funding from the three media giants, The Post said.

title: Wheelmaker to Roll Out Share Offering
description: An automobile wheelmaker, Hayes Lemmerz International looks like it might finally be on a roll despite difficult times in the American auto-parts sector. Shares of the Northville, Mich., company have risen sharply since Hayes Lemmerz announced Friday that it plans a rights offering of up to $180 million worth of common stock, taking advantage of receptive capital markets to lower its debt.

title: Deal-Hungry Bertelsmann Starts up Joint Buyout Fund
description: Bertelsmann, Europes largest media company, is joining forces with private equity groups to establish a novel 1 billion euro ($1.33 billion) investment partnership that could herald a shopping spree for the company, which owns RTL and Random House, according to The Financial Times.

title: TXU Investors Take Their Case to Texas
description: Top executives from Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and tje Texas Pacific Group on Tuesday urged Texas legislators not to create new regulatory hurdles to their $45 billion purchase of the electric utility TXU. According to the Associated Press, Henry Kravis of Kohlberg Kravis suggested the private equity firms might walk away from the deal, which would be the largest leveraged buyout ever, if such measures were passed. But the Dallas Morning News said the investors stopped short of suggesting new regulations could kill the deal.

title: Icahn Gets His Way on Blockbuster Chiefs Exit Package
description: John F. Antioco, the chief executive of Blockbuster, who has been locked in a dispute with company directors over the size of his bonus, has agreed to leave his job at the end of the year, but he will exit with far less than he initially wanted. Among those most satisfied by the outcome: board member Carl C. Icahn, who started the fight over Mr. Antiocos pay.

title: Bank Analyst Leaves Prudential for Deutsche
description: Michael Mayo, the outspoken analyst who runs the financial-services research team for the Prudential Equity Group, is leaving to join Deutsche Bank. Mr. Mayo, who has been at Prudential since 2001, will bring his five-person team to Deutsche, where they will continue to cover financial stocks.

title: To Fight Identity Theft, a Call for Banks to Disclose All Incidents
description: Is the identity theft scourge getting better or growing worse?

title: The New Asian Art in New York
description: Museums around the city are coming to grips with the outpouring of work from China that is shaking up the art world.

title: An American Version of Virgin Atlantic Is Tentatively Approved for Service
description: Virgin America, a proposed start-up airline backed by Richard Branson, won tentative approval from the Transportation Department to operate after agreeing to jettison its chief executive and revamp its financing to reduce the influence of Mr. Branson and other non-citizens of the United States.

title: Personal Shopper
description: The ancient practice of lining the cave with animal hides gets a crisp new edge.

title: Study Tracks Reach of Venture Economy
description: A new report published by the National Venture Capital Association says that companies backed by venture capital providers over the past three decades employed nearly a 10th of private-sector workers and generally outperformed their non-venture-funded counterparts in 2005. The study, conducted by Global Insight, said that American companies that received venture capital funding from 1970 to 2005 accounted for 10 million jobs in 2005, or 9 percent of private-sector positions, $2.1 trillion in revenues, and 16.6 percent of total gross domestic production.

title: The Truth Is, Reagan Never Left Us
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Mar. 19 column, Dont Cry for Reagan.

title: Senator, Youre No Fidel Castro
Suspicious Twist to Death of Cricket Coach
description: The story of Pakistans cricket team that lost to Ireland in the World Cup on Saturday took another surprising turn last night as the death of their coach was labeled suspicious by Jamaican police.

title: C.B.O.T. Delays Shareholder Vote on Merc Offer
description: The Chicago Board of Trade postponed a shareholder vote on its proposed merger with its crosstown rival, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on Tuesday night in a delay the exchange said would allows its investors to review the Intercontinental Exchanges higher bid. Yet the C.B.O.T. also said that the Merc merger remains in effect.

title: and the clocks were striking thirteen.
description: It was a bright, cold day in April and the clocks were striking thirteen.

title: Debate on the Gonzales Eight
description: Michael Kinsley, now a Time magazine columnist, is squatting at the Time staff blog Swampland this week, where he announces that hes skeptical of the significance of the scandal over the Gonzales Eight. Citing Adam Cohens Editorial Observer column in The New York Times, Kinsley writes, Im not sure that I buy it. He explains:

title: 2008: March Money Madness
description: Last night in Washington, over 1,000 donors paid, at minimum, $1,000 to eat finger foods and see that dynamic duo, former President Bill and Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, give stump speeches in a hotel ballroom. The evening netted $2.7 million for her presidential campaign.

title: Seeing a Top, or Not, in Fortresss I.P.O.
description: When the Fortress Investment Group went public in February, it marked the first time that regular investors could own a piece of a United States hedge-fund and private-equity fund manager. Matthew Lynn of Bloomberg News suggests it also marked something else: a new period of restrained growth for so-called alternative investments, an asset class that has ballooned in recent years. As the private equity giant Blackstone Group also considers holding an initial public offering, Mr. Lynn urges investors to be wary of buying at the top of the market.

title: Morgan Stanley Says Profit Jumped 70 Percent
description: Morgan Stanley said Wednesday that its net income surged 70 percent from a year ago to $2.67 billion in its fiscal first quarter. Morgan Stanleys chief executive, John Mack, said the results reflected effective, disciplined risk-taking at the firms institutional securities arm.

title: Document: The Mayors Chopping Block
description: The mayors budget director, Mark Page, sent a letter  [pdf] on Monday to the heads of city agencies warning that they might have to cut 1.5 percent from their budgets this year and 4 percent in the next fiscal year. The agencies have been asked to submit proposed cuts by the end of the month. Only the schools have been spared from the exercise.

title: The Next Sudoku? - The New York Times
Ill Cry if I Want to
description: In Mondays installment, Paul claimed that his comments about the architects high fees made me cry.

title: Satellite Radio Firms Try New Menu to Sell Merger
description: As private equity bigwigs were trying to keep the Texas legislature from messing with their TXU deal, the chiefs of Sirius Satellite Radio and XM Satellite Radio were working to sell their proposed merger to regulators and lawmakers. The two companies said Wednesday that if they combine, the enlarged company will offer tiers of service, including a cut-rate package of radio programming consisting of fewer channels.

title: Lens: Crossroads
description: Photographer Librado Romeros photographs of Times Square, then and now.

title: More Doubts on A.D.M. Buyout Chatter
description: On Tuesday, Reuters reported unusual trading activity related to agribusiness giant Archer Daniels Midland, which some traders chalked up to rumors of a possible takeover, either by another company or by a private equity firm. The speculation drew out some skeptics, including a Merrill Lynch analyst who called a leveraged buyout of the company unlikely and an unnamed options trader who dismissed the chatter to Reuters as the latest of a long series of recent rumors in all kinds of stocks.

title: Horseracing Bidders, Pony Up
description: The governors office recently contacted bidders for the states thoroughbred franchise to let them know how administration plans to conduct background checks on them.

title: A Year of Billion-Dollar Hedge Fund Blowups
description: Amaranth Advisors, which managed $9 billion in assets before imploding after its energy-market trades went bad, is the best-known hedge fund casualty of 2006. But there were lots of others: At least 83 of these private investment pools gave up the ghost, according to a survey by the industry publication Absolute Return. Many of these were small funds, but nine (including Amaranth) had assets of at least $1 billion before calling it quits. That is a sharp contrast from 2005, when no billion-plus funds folded.

title: Justices Ties to Credit Suisse Get Attention
description: In December, the U.S. Supreme Court agreed to hear an antitrust case involving Credit Suisse. This week, Justice Anthony Kennedy abruptly recused himself, most likely because his son Gregory is a managing director at the investment bank.

title: CNBC Says Motorola-Palm Deal May Come Soon
description: CNBC was reporting Wednesday afternoon that a major Palm shareholder expects cellphone giant Motorola to announce a deal to acquire the company for about $2 billion. The announcement could come as soon as Thursday, the unidentified shareholder said. Rumors about such a deal made the rounds Tuesday after the Web site Unstrung.com reported that four parties  Motorola, cellphone company Nokia and private equity firms Silver Lake Partners and Texas Pacific Group  were considering a bid for Palm. None of those firms, nor Motorola, have commented on the deal speculation.

title: Gore on the Hill: Warmth from Congress, Heat from Critics
description: Al Gore had barely sat down in the hearing room and accepted warm greetings from legislators before critics on the Internet began calling him a showman and charlatan.

title: The Point Guard
description: An overview of the point guard position at the college level from the perspective of coaches and players.

title: Gores Visit on the Hill
description: Al Gore apparently had a few free minutes in his schedule as he made his way across Capitol Hill in between committee hearings today, so he dropped by the House chamber for a brief visit.

title: Obamas 2nd-Quarter Foray in New York
description: While all the presidential candidates are driving hard toward the March 31 fundraising deadline, in hopes of posting impressive numbers for the first quarter of 2007, the campaigns are already planning for their second-quarter goals, too. (The plan being, of course, to outdo their own performances in the first quarter.)

title: Triple Threat
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans March 21 column, The Troika and the Surge.

title: Round 2 for Jerry Orbach Corner
description: Will the audience be more receptive on the other side of the avenue?

title: About Comment Moderation
description: Here are answers to frequently asked questions from readers about The Empire Zones comment moderation.

title: Bruce Wassersteins Firm May Sell Legal Publisher
description: Bruce Wasserstein, the veteran deal maker and head of investment bank Lazard, could be getting out of the legal publishing business. Mr. Wassersteins investment firm, Wasserstein & Company, said Wednesday that it hired Credit Suisse to consider strategic options for portfolio company ALM, including a possible sale. ALM publishes 34 magazines and newspapers, including American Lawyer and the National Law Journal. The decision to seek out potential buyers came about 10 years after Mr. Wassersteins firm acquired ALM through its U.S. Equity Partners fund.

title: How Lame Is Your Bracket?
description: The Round of 16 tips off tomorrow and this is when The Bracket Tournament points start to add up. Each game picked correctly is worth 4 points in the online standings, with each upset giving you another 3 points. But having a partly dead bracket is, well, deadly, and some of us simply cant win.

title: New York Moving to Feb. 5 Primary
description: New York State is jumping on the bandwagon and joining the mega-primary.

title: My Blue Heaven
description: If there is a better place to watch a spring training game than here at Dodgertown, in Vero Beach, I have yet to find it. For those unlucky enough never to have made it here, my condolences because time is running out: the Dodgers will train here only one more season before moving across the country to Arizona.

title: New York Moving to Feb. 5 Primary
description: New York State is jumping on the bandwagon and joining the mega-primary. A bill moving the states presidential primary to Feb. 5 from March 4 passed both houses of the New York State Legislature today, and with Gov. Eliot Spitzer pledging support for the idea, the bill seemed almost certain to be signed into law. More details at The Caucus.

title: Citadel Takes Stake in Subprime Mortgage Lender
description: Two weeks after acquiring ResMae Mortgage, Citadel Investment Group on Wednesday took a further step into the subprime mortgage market with a 4.5 percent stake in Accredited Home Lenders Holding. The stake of 1.13 million shares is worth about $13.5 million based on Accrediteds closing stock price of $11.96, a rise of about 11 percent.

title: Rooters Guide to the Sweet 16
description: If youre a fan or alum of any of the 16 teams remaining in the N.C.A.A. tournament, you are willingly blinded by your loyalty. Your five are impenetrable heroes who are battling faceless men in opposite jerseys; they are nothing but Opponent. They stand in the way of your success, and their stories, during the game, are irrelevant.

title: Bloomberg for Senate?
description: The speculation about Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs interest in the presidency just doesnt seem to die down. A Wall Street Journal editorial [registration required] yesterday, The Bloomberg Calendar, suggests that the rush of states to move their primaries earlier in the calendar could create an opening for an independent like Mr. Bloomberg.The Journal mused:

title: Bush vs. Congress
description: From the White House press briefing today, so much back-and-forth about why the Bush administration wont allow recorded transcripts of any interviews between Congress and top aides on the firings of federal prosecutors.

title: The Pet Food Premium
description: Now that most pet owners have had enough time to triple-check the ridiculously long lists of recalled brands of dog and cat food, its time to think about what comes next.

title: Blogtalk: Unmasked
description: The creator of the Big Sister ad against Hillary Rodham Clinton has been unmasked. [The Caucus]

title: A-Rods Options
description: The Yankees believe Alex Rodriguez when he says he wants to stay in New York. But they also believe he will not let this off-season pass without trying to get a contract extension.

title: Bull Wrestling in India
description: Jallikattu, a 2000-year-old form of bull wrestling, takes place in villages in southern India during New Year's celebrations.

title: Three Tortoises and a Hare
description: At Wednesdays practice session in San Jose, U.C.L.A. talked defense. Pittsburgh talked defense. Southern Illinois talked defense.

title: Pressure Point
description: A point guard has just one assignment: Control everything.

title: In 2000, Butler Didnt Do It
description: With Florida preparing to play Butler in the Round of 16 of the N.C.A.A. Tournament on Friday, Ohio State Coach Thad Matta recalled the last time the two teams met in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: At Madison and 44th
description: Thom Browne, the mens designer who has an agreement with Brooks Brothers to produce a special line of mens and womens clothes, squeezed in some tweeds and top coats yesterday before everyone had put the fall season to bed. My own feelings about the collection were mixed, though they did not include disappointment. I think Browne fulfilled his mission to give Brooks something different without completely overturning the traditions of the 189-year-old company. Admittedly, the fit and proportion of the clothes (more Browne than Brooks), the solemn stiffness of the tweeds, the muscular legs in knee socks and the odd bespectacled model induced, at times, a thought of Austin Powers. Still, the overcoats and blazers were eye-catching and different, and I can imagine a woman having a good old time with the mens capes and tweed plus fours, pinching the elements that would look sexy and fun for her. A woman with a very subjective sense of style (and a slim, hipless figure) will know what to do with a small-fitting wool pantsuit, its trousers cropped, embroidered with the Brooks fleece logo. The collection seems evenly divided between mens and womens looks.

title: Going to the Chapel?
description: The Texas A&M Coach Billy Gillispie is the only bachelor coach remaining in the N.C.A.A. tournament. Hes also the only coach in the tournament who doesnt have any children. His single status has earned him the nickname College Stations Most Eligible Bachelor. Gillispie said in an interview on Monday at Reed Arena that he wasnt sure if he would ever get married again.

title: Twos Company
description: The Ohio State freshman point guard Mike Conley Jr. and the freshman center Greg Oden live together in student housing, but their lifestyles are as different as their personalities.

title: Clinton Ad Creator Unmasked
description: A political mystery was solved on Wednesday with the unmasking of the maker of a much-discussed Internet advertisement that portrayed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as Big Brother. The creator, it turned out, worked for consultants to Senator Barack Obama, a rival for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: A Corner for Orbach Looks Likely
description: Elaine Orbachs campaign to have a Midtown intersection named for her late husband, the actor Jerry Orbach, received unanimous approval tonight from members of Community Board 4. A neighboring panel, Community Board 5, had failed to endorse the idea.Fortunately for Mrs. Orbach, the intersection she had her eye on  53rd Street and Eighth Avenue  straddles the two districts. Based on tonights meeting, Community Board 4 will be more receptive to the ceremonial name  Jerry Orbach Corner  when the full board votes on April 4. Then the matter goes to the City Council.

title: Edwards Curtails Campaign Trip to Be With Wife
description: Democratic presidential contender John Edwards, who curtailed his Iowa trip on Tuesday to be with his wife, Elizabeth, for her post-cancer medical appointments this week, announced tonight that they would be holding a news conference tomorrow at noon in Chapel Hill.

title: Dr. Stella Chess, Child Development Specialist, Dies at 93
description: Dr. Stella Chess, a child psychiatrist who helped develop and popularize the influential theory that children are born with distinct temperaments that can powerfully affect their outlook and relationship with their parents, died March 14 in Manhattan. She was 93.

title: Fighting Between Tribes and Outside Militants Grows in Largely Lawless Region of Pakistan
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan, March 21  Fighting between Central Asian militants and local tribespeople in northern Pakistan intensified Wednesday, raising the toll to 110 people killed since Monday, government and security officials said.

title: Ann DeChiara Malamud, Helpmate to Writer, 89, Dies
description: Ann DeChiara Malamud, whose marriage to Bernard Malamud helped him determine his course as a writer, died on Tuesday in Cambridge, Mass. She was 89.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q. Our dining table doubles as a home-office desk. How can we keep clutter in check?

title: Staten Island: Boy Found Handcuffed to Tree
description: A 13-year-old boy wearing just his underwear was discovered handcuffed to a tree yesterday. The boy, whom the authorities did not identify, told investigators that he was walking to a bus stop when a man with a knife forced him into the woods near Narrows Road South, in Grasmere, officials said. Two passers-by heard the boy yelling about 9 a.m., the police said, and flagged down a car carrying two agents of the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals. The two, John Delatorre and Jennifer Sarasky, helped the boy and called the police, said Joseph Pentangelo, the societys assistant director. The boy was taken to Staten Island University Hospital North. Law enforcement officials said he did not claim to have been sexually abused.

title: A Split in Fashiondom: Can This Label Be Saved?
description: NEWPORT BEACH, Calif.

title: Where the Wrong Gift Can Mean Loves Labors Lost
description: SEOUL, South Korea  When two young television stars called it quits only 12 days after their wedding recently, their very public and acrimonious divorce shined a rare spotlight on the underside of marriage in South Korea.

title: When the Boss Is Last in Line for a Paycheck
description: Its been a long time since Michelle Madhok has received a weekly paycheck. In 2004, when she started SheFinds.com, an online shopping publication, she thought she could pay herself a regular salary. But she quickly realized that was not how it worked when you become an entrepreneur.

title: A Smoke-Filled War Room
description: Washington

title: Welcome to My World, O My Beloved. Dont Bring Your Stuff.
description: WITH age I widen, and not just bodily. Recently, despite the fact that Ive never lived with a romantic partner before, a surge of affection  affection underscored by 44 years of on-and-off loneliness  led me to invite my boyfriend, Greg, to move into my 800-square-foot Greenwich Village apartment.

title: New York Acts to Ease Process in Foster Care
description: The Bloomberg administration unveiled an ambitious plan yesterday to move children through foster care more swiftly, with fewer moves within the system and more limited use of institutional care.

title: New York Poised to Join Move to Earlier Primary
description: ALBANY, March 21  New York State is jumping on the bandwagon and joining what is shaping up as the presidential mega-primary next Feb. 5.

title: Germany Cites Koran in Rejecting Divorce
description: FRANKFURT, March 22  A German judge has stirred a storm of protest here by citing the Koran in turning down a German Muslim womans request for a fast-track divorce on the ground that her husband beat her.

title: France: Education Official Fired for Opposing Muslim School
description: France replaced a regional school board president, Alain Morvan, for vigorously opposing a new Muslim high school in a Lyon suburb and for publicly complaining about pressure from the government to stop obstructing its opening. The school began admitting students this month after an eight-month struggle with Mr. Morvan, who said the schools founders were fundamentalists. It is the third Islamic school in France.

title: Corrections
description: For the Record

title: Fed Weighs Words About Its Next Move
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  The Federal Reserve, implicitly acknowledging hints of trouble in the economy, edged away Wednesday from previous signals that its next move on interest rates would be up.

title: Woods and Federer Find Common Ground at the Top of Their Games
description: MIAMI, March 21  Tiger Woods and Roger Federer compete in sports with distinct athletic movements, and they have forged a friendship based on respect and appreciation. They have spoken of the unique feeling of invincibility that has accompanied their triumphs, and they have gone out of their way to observe each other in motion.

title: Lately, Guards Are Just Unable to Get the Point
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 21  Great guard play wins games in March, or so the clich goes. Teams like Texas A&M, Nevada-Las Vegas, Ohio State and North Carolina have reached the Round of 16 at the N.C.A.A. tournament on the backs of their stellar point guards.

title: University in Moscow to Investigate Student Claims
description: MOSCOW, March 19  Moscow State University, one of Russias most prestigious, has opened an investigation into accusations by students that teaching standards and living conditions in one of its academic departments have been severely eroded, students and university officials said in recent days.

title: Budget Wrangling Persists, Centered in the State Senate
description: ALBANY, March 21  Pressure grew on Senate Republicans on Wednesday to strike a budget deal with Gov. Eliot Spitzer as the State Conservative Party stepped up criticism and the governor tried to divide hospital groups that have opposed his spending plan.

title: Bushs Big-Picture Battle: Presidential Prerogatives
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Ever since Republicans lost control of Congress, President Bush has known a fight like this could come.

title: Nepal: 26 Dead as Maoists Clash With Ethnic Group
description: At least 26 people were killed and 45 others injured when Maoists and militants from the Madhesi ethnic groups clashed in the southern town of Gaur. The United Nations, which is investigating the clashes, said the violence erupted as the groups held simultaneous rallies in the area.

title: A Proper Distinction
description: Thousands of crimes are committed every year, and, given the constraints of time and money, its up to prosecutors to decide which ones to pursue.

title: Editor of Russian Edition of Forbes Guilty of Defamation
description: MOSCOW, March 21  The editor in chief of the Russian edition of Forbes magazine was found guilty of defamation Wednesday in a dispute over an article about a business run by the wife of the mayor of Moscow.

title: Blog Exposes Creator of Ad Portraying Clinton as Big Brother
description: A political mystery was solved yesterday with the unmasking of the maker of a much-discussed Internet advertisement that portrayed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as Big Brother. The creator, it turned out, worked for consultants to Senator Barack Obama, a rival for the Democratic presidential nomination.

title: Manhattan: City Contractors Accused
description: Nine contractors who do business with the citys Department of Parks and Recreation have been charged with paying thousands of dollars in bribes to undercover agents in an effort to skirt wage laws, city officials said yesterday. The Department of Investigation said the contractors, who had a total of more than $7 million in construction contracts, paid bribes of $1,000 to $5,000 during a sting operation that lasted from 2005 to 2006. The department said the contractors paid the money to lift stop-payment orders issued by the city for underpaying at least 25 employees.
