The defendants, eight construction company owners and one foreman, have been charged with bribery, officials said.

title: I Dreamt That I Dreamt on a Bed Without Wrinkles
description: AS perhaps the last remaining homeowner who thinks its normal to use cotton swabs to clean baseboards, I pride myself on my old-fashioned housekeeping skills (if not always on the actual follow-through). But even I long ago abandoned the dream of creating a true hotel bed experience at home.

title: Calvert DeForest, 85, Larry (Bud) Melman on Letterman, Dies
description: Calvert G. DeForest, the dweebish man who gained cult status on David Lettermans late-night shows as the comic figure Larry (Bud) Melman precisely because he was not funny, died Monday in Babylon, Long Island. He was 85.

title: Motorola Cuts Revenue Forecast by $1 Billion
description: The business prospects of Motorola, the 80-year-old technology company, suddenly look as thin as the Razr, its iconic mobile phone.

title: Guardian Angels Seek Out More Mean Streets
description: It began in 1979 at a McDonalds in the Bronx where they all worked, 13 men living on little more than unsold hamburgers. It was a citizens watch group with a paramilitary look, part nosy misfit and part kung-fu: the Guardian Angels.

title: Morgan Stanley Net Jumps; Appeal on Lawsuit Is Won
description: It was a good day for John J. Mack.

title: Episcopal Church Rejects Demand for a 2nd Leadership
description: Responding to an ultimatum from leaders of the worldwide Anglican Communion, bishops of the Episcopal Church have rejected a key demand to create a parallel leadership structure to serve the conservative minority of Episcopalians who oppose their churchs liberal stand on homosexuality.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about Carol C. Lam, one of eight federal prosecutors dismissed last year, misstated the name of a health care company she prosecuted. It is Tenet Healthcare Corporation, not Tenant Health Care Corporation.

title: Senate Panel Backs Subpoenas of Bush Aides
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  The Senate Judiciary Committee today authorized the issuing of subpoenas that would summon Karl Rove and several other top Bush administration officials to Capitol Hill to testify under oath about the dismissals of eight federal prosecutors.

title: Amid Inquiry on Pupils Sex Abuse Charge, New Questions
description: When an 8-year-old girl came forward this week with allegations that she had been raped and sodomized by a custodian at her Brooklyn elementary school, it seemed like a straightforward case. The custodian was arrested on Monday and charged with rape.

title: Creating a New Reality, and a String of Hit Songs
description: The crowd at Irving Plaza quieted to a hush on Monday night as Chris Daughtry spoke between songs, asking his fans to sing along on his next number. I assume you guys have the record, he said, and a collective, largely female shriek answered in the affirmative.

title: Play Games Without Clutter or Tiresome Pop-Up Ads
description: For casual game players who are tired of the pop-up ads and other browser clutter on many free game sites, here is a new way to play. Designed for Windows-based computers, Hasbros Net Jet combines a $25 game controller with collection of $15 game keys, sold in stores or online at www.netjetinfo.com. (Some of the games freeze when used with Windows Vista. Hasbro says a fix is in the works.)

title: Conrad Blacks Co-Defendants Start Stating Their Cases
description: Two co-defendants of Conrad M. Black, accused of helping him steal $60 million from Hollinger International, did nothing illegal or were in the dark about any wrongdoing at the company, their lawyers said yesterday.

title: Wasserstein May Sell Stake in Publishing Company
description: Bruce Wasserstein, the chairman of Lazard, is considering selling his stake in ALM, publisher of American Lawyer Magazine and other legal publications.

title: Record Drug Bust
description: Coast Guard cutters off Panama intercepted a ship on Sunday carrying 42,845 pounds of cocaine, a record for a maritime drug bust, officials said. The ship, carrying about $300 million worth of cocaine bound for Mexico, was spotted by a Coast Guard patrol aircraft, which had received a tip about it. Fourteen Panamanian and Mexican crew members were arrested and were being transferred to the United States and Panama for prosecution.

title: The Fashion Shows, Junior Grade
description: HER outsize shades and off-center topknot gave her a slightly alien aspect, as if she had touched down from planet Hollywood. In fact, this very young woman (right) was strolling last week not on Melrose Place but on the streets of the Marais in Paris. Like most of her peers  school-age flaneurs, some scarcely in their teens  she seemed to have borrowed her artfully disheveled look from the pages of US Weekly or In Style.

title: N.F.L. Plans to Toughen Conduct Policy
description: The National Football League will announce a tougher personal conduct policy next week, one that could hand down harsh penalties, including yearlong suspensions, for players who repeatedly run into legal trouble.

title: An MP3 Player With Bluetooth: Look, Ma, Stereo but No Wires
description: Tiny MP3 players are a dime a dozen nowadays  but how many have Bluetooth? The Insignia 4-Gigabyte Player can transmit stereo MP3 music and video soundtracks to a pair of headphones over a wireless Bluetooth connection.

title: In Utah, an Opponent of the Culture of Obedience
description: SALT LAKE CITY  Rocky Anderson may not be the most liberal mayor in America. But here in the most conservative state, he might as well be.

title: Mets Still Seek Answers for Unformed Bullpen
description: VERO BEACH, Fla., March 21  Of the right-handed relievers the Mets are counting on this season, one has tendinitis, ones sleeping habits hindered his being ready for opening day and another is suspended until late May. In other words, the Mets would not mind if Ambiorix Burgos or Jorge Sosa, the hard throwers acquired over the winter, emerged as immediate options.

title: Panel Approves Five Subpoenas on Prosecutors
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  A House panel authorized subpoenas Wednesday requiring Karl Rove and four other senior Bush administration officials to testify under oath in the inquiry into the dismissals of eight federal prosecutors.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Big Stake Is Bought in Struggling Studio
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21  The independent film producer Nu Image has acquired a controlling interest in the troubled First Look Studios, an independent film distributor, the company announced on Wednesday.

title: France Rules in Favor of Paper That Published Muhammad Cartoon
description: PARIS, March 22  A French court ruled today in favor of a satirical weekly newspaper that republished cartoons featuring the Prophet Muhammad, which caused an international uproar when they first appeared in a Danish newspaper.

title: Coachs Unhealthy Obsession Has Led to Success at Texas A&M
description: COLLEGE STATION, Tex., March 19  Texas A&M Coach Billy Gillispie drinks Dr Pepper for breakfast, does not know his sisters last name and is so tough on his players that his mother swears that she would never play for him.

title: Abolishing the Middlemen Wont Make Health Care a Free Lunch
description: Proponents of single-payer national health insurance note that private health insurance has overhead costs of 10 to 25 percent of expenditures. Medicare, by contrast, has overhead costs of about 2 to 3 percent, and socialized European health care systems generally have low overhead costs as well. That is why single-payer supporters claim that we can save money by substituting government for private insurance. But this would shift overhead costs, not reduce them.

title: Case Study: A Students Free Speech (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Defibrillator Maker Props Up Stress Test Company
description: St. Jude Medical is stepping in to prop up a start-up company that it hopes can help revive the stagnating $6 billion market for implantable heart defibrillators.

title: Campaign Season, Again, in Brooklyn Council District
description: A month after a special election to fill a vacant City Council seat, the streets of central Brooklyn are once again the scene of intense signature collection and campaigning as another election approaches  for the very same position. And many residents seem bewildered that they are being approached again by candidates eager for their votes.

title: Inefficiencies Curb U.S. Aid to the Hungry, Report Finds
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  The United States provides more than half the food aid that feeds hungry people around the world, but its programs are plagued by inefficiencies that have sharply reduced the amount of food being provided and have slowed deliveries, the Government Accountability Office reported to Congress on Wednesday.

title: Agency Says Rebuilding Failures in Iraq Show Need for Changes
description: The failures of the American-financed reconstruction program in Iraq threaten to be repeated elsewhere unless the gulf between the military and civilian efforts in wartime is bridged by structural changes in the United States government, a federal oversight agency says in a report to be released today.

title: Ex-Chief of Collins & Aikman Is Said to Be Facing Indictment
description: DETROIT, March 21  David A. Stockman, a former congressman who served as President Ronald Reagans first budget director, is expected to be indicted on charges of accounting fraud related to his role as chairman of an auto parts supplier, people with knowledge of the matter said Wednesday.

title: A Designer With Altitude
description: WHEN the National Basketball Association announced an off-the-court dress code in 2005, it was hardly surprising to anyone familiar with the style of, say, Dennis Rodman, that players resisted the call to wear sports jackets and shirts with sleeves. Well, anyone but David A. Levin, the chief executive of Casual Male Retail Group, which caters to the altitudinous end of the human populace with stores like Casual Male XL and the more upscale Rochester Big & Tall.

title: A Pivotal Deal on the Way to a Very Tight Finish
description: Last Sunday, the final day of the Spring North American Bridge Championships in St. Louis, three teams could have won the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams.

title: Hang on to the Beat With Earbuds That Stay Put
description: Earbuds  small earphones that plug into your ear canals  are popular for listening to music on the go. But some listeners complain that earbuds fall out when they walk, or that they make their ears feel stuffed.

title: Correction: Have Guitar, Will Recycle
description: A picture caption last Thursday with an article about environmentally-conscious rock musicians misidentified a member of the rock group Guster. He is Ryan Miller  not Adam Gardner, who helped established Reverb, an organization that consults with performers on greener rock tours.

title: Italy Swapped 5 Jailed Taliban for a Hostage
description: ROME, March 21 An Italian journalist who was held hostage for 15 days by the Taliban in lawless southern Afghanistan was ransomed for five Taliban prisoners, the Italian government and Afghan officials confirmed Wednesday.

title: Gore Warns Congress of Planetary Emergency
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  It was part science class, part policy wonk paradise, part politics and all theater as former Vice President Al Gore came to Congress on Wednesday to insist that global warming constitutes a planetary emergency requiring an aggressive federal response.

title: Japan: Trade Surplus Widens
description: Japans trade surplus unexpectedly widened in February after a decline in oil prices caused import growth to slow. Export growth slowed. The surplus rose 7.7 percent, to 979.6 billion yen ($8.3 billion), compared with February a year earlier, the government reported. The entire Lunar New Year holiday fell in February, cutting short the time companies could ship goods to markets that observe the holiday, and the economist Noriaki Haseyama said it was too early to determine if exports are stalling.

title: Charges Dismissed Against Ex-Banker
description: A former Bear Stearns municipal bond banker yesterday won dismissal of federal criminal charges that he was involved in a kickback scheme tied to the construction of a hospital in the Chicago area.

title: Democrats Seek Votes for Bill on Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  House Democrats were scrambling today to find the 218 votes needed to pass a war spending bill that would set a timetable to bring American troops home from Iraq, as the Bush administration and Congressional Republicans worked aggressively to foil their effort.

title: Pets Owners Angered by Delays in Response
description: Bob Norkus has spent much of the past month grieving for his cat, Sophie, who died of kidney failure Feb. 17. Now, his sorrow is turning to anger toward the companies that manufactured and sold the food he believes killed her.

title: Parity for Mental Health (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: As Catskill Casino Takes Shape, It Is Beyond One Backers Grasp
description: Stanley S. Tollman was for many years one of Manhattans most engaging multimillionaires, a bon vivant with a bright smile, a deep South African accent and an ever-present cigar.

title: Did You Know Androids Could Eat Mail?
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Trustworthy public servant, loyal friend, computer whiz and especially handy to have around when the starship is damaged during a mission  thats R2-D2, the endearing android of Star Wars fame. Now R2-D2 has been enlisted for another task: collecting mail for the Postal Service.

title: B. Franklin Kahn, 82, Developer Credited With the REIT Strategy, Dies
description: B. Franklin Kahn, one of the first developers to recognize that real estate investments could trade much like mutual funds, died March 8 at his home in Chevy Chase, Md. He was 82.

title: More Rings Than Fingers for a Coach at Columbia
description: The contents of his sock drawer are the envy of college fencing coaches. But it is not his socks anyone cares about. It is the small wicker basket tucked among them where he keeps his 21 Ivy League championship rings.

title: Wary of Hamas, U.S. Is to Trim Aid to Palestinian Forces
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  The Bush administration will reduce by about 40 percent the aid it is seeking from Congress for the security forces of the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, and set new conditions for monitoring the money because of concerns that some of it could end up with Hamas, the militant Islamist organization, administration officials said Wednesday.

title: South Korea: Growth Revised Upward
description: South Koreas economy expanded 0.9 percent in the fourth quarter, more than first estimated, as exports declined less than initially anticipated, the Bank of Korea said. The figure was revised from an initial estimate of 0.8 percent and was down from a revised 1.2 percent rate in the third quarter. Goods exports fell 0.5 percent, less than the initial estimate of a 1 percent decline, the report showed. It was the first quarterly drop in exports since the three months ended Sept. 30, 2004. Business investment rose 0.1 percent in the fourth quarter from the previous three months and construction climbed 0.6 percent in the quarter. Private spending advanced 1 percent in the quarter, compared with an earlier estimate of a 0.8 percent increase, the report showed.

title: Ringing in the New Year by Wrestling Bulls
description: IT was a blistering hot day in January and the dirt streets of Avaniapuram, a tiny village in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu, were turned into a gladiator arena. Villagers dressed in plaid dhotis cleared out the rusty mopeds and pushcarts. They barricaded the storefronts with bamboo scaffolding. And along the sidewalk, they put up wooden fences to form a makeshift ring.

title: Jefferson Is Helping Nets, Even When Hes Hurting
description: Richard Jefferson realizes that he will not feel healthy until the season is over, but his return from arthroscopic ankle surgery has boosted the Nets playoff chances.

title: Japan Society Celebrates Its Centennial While Mending Its Fences
description: Youve lost your president, gallery director, executive vice president and education director along with several other pivotal staff members. Your exhibition schedule looms empty. Disaffected donors have stopped giving. What better time to celebrate your 100th anniversary?

title: McCartney Signs With Starbucks for His Next Album
description: Paul McCartney has decided to come together with Starbucks.

title: High Hopes for a Rothko Painting at Auction
description: Better known as a prolific donor  especially to his cherished Museum of Modern Art  David Rockefeller has decided to throw his hat into the auction arena, selling a seminal painting by Mark Rothko for what the auction house hopes will be more than $40 million.

title: Stepping on the Dream
description: One of the weirder things at work these days is the fact that were making it more difficult for American youngsters to afford college at a time when a college education is a virtual prerequisite for establishing and maintaining a middle-class standard of living.

title: Debate Over a Web Site About Parking
description: When a Web site called Uncivil Servants went live last week, the sites operator didnt know there was a bklyncop1 out there, the screen name of someone who identifies himself as a police officer and who questions the sites methods as a danger to the police.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,216 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Democrats See a Document Gap in Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  The dismissal of eight United States attorneys has elicited a long and ever-growing list of theories by Democrats on Capitol Hill about ulterior motives and suspicious coincidences. Now there is a new one: the document gap.

title: Ann Currys Ambition: To Witness the Suffering
description: On Sunday night Ann Curry briefly appeared on the NBC newsmagazine Dateline to introduce a segment titled To Catch a Con Man, an attempt to do for Internet scammers what the programs To Catch a Predator series has done for pedophiles. But as her recorded introduction was being broadcast, Ms. Curry was a world away: She had just arrived in Khartoum, the capital of Sudan, after traveling nearly 24 hours. Her final destination was Darfur, her third visit in 12 months to this region riven by ethnic warfare.

title: After Sopranos, a Need for a Hit
description: With a last burst of episodes starting April 8, The Sopranos, will exit the television arena for the final time, leaving millions of fans without their all-time favorite series, and a network, HBO, without its Hall of Fame performer.

title: Manhattan: Comptroller Criticizes Education Department
description: The citys Department of Education misspent as much as $784,943 in funds intended to provide prekindergarten services in Staten Island and parts of Brooklyn, the city comptroller, William C. Thompson, Jr. said yesterday. Mr. Thompson, left, said that an analysis of spending on nonpublic schools in Regions 6 and 7 during the 2004 and 2005 fiscal years found more than $400,000 in questionable bank transactions, including a cash withdrawal to repay an undocumented loan to the owner of a school building. The analysis also found that money intended for school services was used to pay for items like karate uniforms and an air-conditioner delivered to a nonschool location. Lindsey Harr, an Education Department spokeswoman, said that the city would take steps to ensure that any money owed was returned, but that the audit greatly exaggerates the amount of money that may have been improperly spent.

title: Focus on the Future in Louisiana
description: Sometimes the best thing a leader can do is step aside. By deciding not to run for re-election as governor of Louisiana, Kathleen Blanco has done that for a state desperately in need of new ideas.

title: A Habeas Corpus Appeal Veers to Capital Issues
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  A Missouri prosecutors final words to the jury strayed far over the boundary of proper argument, or so a federal appeals court ruled in overturning the death sentence of a man convicted of the execution-style murder-for-hire of a federal drug witness.

title: Marketers Have Eyes on the Third Screen
description: OLD media lagged behind in the race to go online, in part because the prospects for advertising  traditionally the major revenue source for newspapers, magazines and television  seemed unclear on the Internet. Then, online advertising took off, and the old media are still playing catch-up.

title: A Pair of Early Upsets Bring a Bit of Hoosiers Into Marists Season
description: POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., March 21  Alisa Kresge, co-captain of the Marist College womens basketball team, was walking with some of her teammates this week near the teams hotel in California. The players were giddy in the wake of their first-round upset of powerful Ohio State in the N.C.A.A. tournament on Saturday, Marists first victory ever in the womens tournament.

title: Clinton Camp Challenges Obama on Iraq
description: Over the last week, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton's presidential campaign has opened a new offensive against Senator Barack Obama: Former President Bill Clinton has asserted that Mr. Obama was initially ambivalent about the Iraq war, and Mrs. Clinton's strategist has highlighted his votes to finance a war he says he opposes.

title: Calendar
Corrections: For the Record
description: An article by Reuters on Tuesday about the sentencing of Raymond L. Girouard, an American soldier convicted of killing three Iraqi detainees, misstated his rank. He is a staff sergeant, not a sergeant. (After his court martial documents are processed in a few months, he will be reduced in rank to private.)

title: Going Head to Head Over the Prosecutors (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Edwards to Continue 08 Bid Despite Wifes Cancer
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 22  John Edwards, the Democratic candidate for president, said today that his wife Elizabeth Edwards was once again suffering from breast cancer, this time in an incurable form.

title: Old Programs on a New System
description: Q. Im going to be buying a computer soon. Will my old Windows programs run on the new Vista operating system?

title: The Myth of the Omniscient Narrator, and Other Stories
description: When This American Life, the public radio show that comes to Showtime tonight, began in 1995, it was founded on the belief that everyone has a story to tell. That idea seemed supremely hopeful in those days. It flattered the national pride in diversity while seeming to liberate various tense ideological discussions from identity politics. Stories, after all, arent static box-checking matters of race and ethnicity. Theyre dynamic and individualistic potentially bankable creations, furthermore, in the form of screenplays, or Oprah books.

title: Kazakhstan: Ethnic Fighting Subdued
description: The police restored calm to southeastern villages after two weeks of sporadic street fighting between Kazakhs and ethnic Chechens. A brawl at a bar in Kazatkom, a village near Almaty, with a large Chechen population, set off the violence, which spread to other villages and included fistfights, shootouts, arson and mass demonstrations. Dozens of people were injured. Local news outlets reported that two Kazakhs and a Chechen were killed.

title: Canada: Air India Defendant Sues Government
description: Ripudaman Singh Malik, an Indian-born Canadian Sikh acquitted in 2005 of involvement in the bombing 20 years earlier of an Air India plane traveling from Toronto to New Delhi that killed 329 people, has filed a lawsuit against the governments of Canada and British Columbia, where he was tried, claiming unspecified damages for wrongful imprisonment and malicious prosecution. Mr. Malik, once a millionaire businessman, claims the charges caused him to lose his savings and his reputation.

title: Celebrity Chef Announces Strict Animal-Welfare Policy
description: Wolfgang Puck, the Los Angeles chef whose culinary empire ranges from celebrity dinners at Spago to a line of canned soups, said yesterday that he would use eggs and meat only from animals raised under strict humane standards.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Britney Spears Leaves Rehab

title: China Scrambles for Stability as Its Workers Age
description: SHANGHAI, March 19  When she reached 50, the retirement age for many women here, Chen Rui, a career accountant, immediately did what millions of people of her generation have begun doing: she scrambled to find a new job.

title: The Year Without Toilet Paper
description: DINNER was the usual affair on Thursday night in Apartment 9F in an elegant prewar on Lower Fifth Avenue. There was shredded cabbage with fruit-scrap vinegar; mashed parsnips and yellow carrots with local butter and fresh thyme; a terrific frittata; then homemade yogurt with honey and thyme tea, eaten under the greenish flickering light cast by two beeswax candles and a fluorescent bulb.

title: Brain Injury Said to Affect Moral Choices
description: Damage to an area of the brain behind the forehead, inches behind the eyes, transforms the way people make moral judgments in life-or-death situations, scientists reported yesterday. In a new study, people with this rare injury expressed increased willingness to kill or harm another person if doing so would save others lives.

title: Congresss Challenge on Iraq
description: The House of Representatives now has a chance to lead the nation toward a wiser, more responsible Iraq policy. It is scheduled to vote this week on whether to impose benchmarks for much-needed political progress on the Iraqi government  and link them to the continued presence of American combat forces. The bill also seeks to lessen the intolerable strains on American forces, requiring President Bush to certify that units are fit for battle before sending any troops to Iraq. Both of these requirements are long overdue. The House should vote yes, by an overwhelming, bipartisan margin.

title: Chemical Plant Safety
description: The federal government has done almost nothing since Sept. 11, 2001, to secure chemical plants, perhaps the nations greatest terrorist vulnerability. But now it may be about to do something that will actually make things worse: wipe out safety rules at the state level. If Congress will not protect Americans, it should at least ensure that states can do it.

title: A Hopeful Passage to Safety Turns Into a Deadly Ordeal
description: Daunting are the challenges posed by Lifeboat.

title: Oversize Mudrooms Tame the Clutter at the Door
description: IN planning the renovation of her Sherman Oaks, Calif., kitchen, Lynne Lainer knew above all what she didnt want: her two sons backpacks and soccer shin guards cluttering her kitchen counters, and the familys cell phones and personal organizers plugged into all the outlets so that there wasnt even room for a toaster. Her architect responded by offering an increasingly common solution: an extension that, when the renovation is completed this summer, will accommodate cubbies, a built-in storage bench and charging stations and will provide a proper transition between the garage and the rest of the house. On the floor plan, the 9-by-12-foot space is called a mudroom, but Ms. Lainer doesnt really think of it like that.

title: Britain Arrests 3 Suspects in 2005 Bombings
description: LONDON, March 22  The British counterterrorism police seized three men today for offenses related to the London bombings  the first arrests since four suicide bombers killed themselves and 52 travelers on the London transit system on July 7, 2005.

title: Baby Steps to a Label-Obsessed Life
description: I DONT have children of my own. But as an uncle and the former editor of a childrens fashion magazine, I would like to think I have an honorary high-chairs view of the world of kiddie couture. Ive witnessed child models, encouraged by stage moms who would scare even Dakota Fanning, walk me through their portfolios. And companies have tried to sell me on the most unconscionable designs, including itsy-bitsy pumps that made little girls look like pole dancers in training heels.

title: 15 Die When Somalis Try to Disarm Rebels
description: KIWAYU, Kenya, March 21  The chaos in Somalia took an ugly turn on Wednesday when full-scale fighting broke out in Mogadishu and furious crowds mutilated the bodies of government soldiers, chanting, We will burn you alive!

title: Lawyers Say U.S. Acted in Bad Faith After Immigrant Raid in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, March 21  Lawyers for some of about 350 immigrants arrested this month in a raid on a leather factory in New Bedford, Mass., appeared before a federal judge Wednesday, charging that the government had acted in bad faith, moving the immigrants to detention centers in Texas too quickly and denying them adequate access to lawyers.

title: How Exercise and Bed Rest in Pregnancy Can Co-Exist
description: JEAN IRION was 37 when she found out, 12 years ago, that she was carrying triplets. She and her husband already had two children, then 7 and 9. They had carefully spaced this third pregnancy so that, Dr. Irion said ruefully, We wouldnt have three children in college at one time.

title: Gehrys New York Debut: Subdued Tower of Light
description: In the year since the concrete frame of Frank Gehrys first New York building began to rise along the West Side Highway in Chelsea, architecture fans have been quarrelling over its design. Are the curvaceous glass forms of the IAC headquarters building, evoking the crisp pleats of a skirt, a bold departure from Manhattans hard-edged corporate towers? Or are they proof that Mr. Gehrys radical days are behind him?

title: Teachers at California State Vote to Authorize a Walkout
description: LOS ANGELES, March 21  Faculty members at California State University, the nations largest four-year university system, overwhelmingly authorized a strike Wednesday after nearly two years in which they and the administration failed to negotiate a contract succeeding one that expired in July 2005.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: Schnauzer Begone

title: After Sell-Off, Chinese Stocks Back at a Record
description: SHANGHAI, March 21  After a huge sell-off here just a few weeks ago that helped set off a drop in global financial markets, Chinas stock market has rebounded and rose to a record Wednesday.

title: Georgia Murder Cases Cost Saps Public Defense System
description: ATLANTA, March 21  A high-profile multiple-murder case has drained the budget of Georgias public defender system and brought all but a handful of its 72 capital cases to a standstill.

title: The Astronauts Columbia Left Behind
description: While the world grieved for the Columbia crew lost on Feb. 1, 2003, three lonely men in space had a somewhat more complicated reaction. They were the members of Expedition Six, two Americans and a Russian installed at the International Space Station. They had been there since the previous November, and they were getting ready to come home. But the disaster suspended space travel, so no new crew would arrive to relieve them in the foreseeable future. Suddenly they were stuck in a sci-fi limbo.

title: Dirty Air Becomes Divisive Issue in Hong Kong Vote
description: HONG KONG, March 21  Worsening air pollution has become one of the most contentious issues in the vote on Sunday for Hong Kongs next chief executive, with the incumbent blaming emissions drifting across the border from mainland China for the problem while his challenger contends that Hong Kong is not doing enough to address the issue.

title: Ex-Qwest Official Says Chief Was Misleading on Growth
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications who is on trial for insider trading, knowingly repeated unreliable growth forecasts in 2000 and 2001, a former company official testified yesterday.

title: For Hackers, Brackets Present a Challenge of a Different Kind
description: The N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament has evolved into a popular online experience in the United States, a ritual of 63 games played over two and a half weeks with millions of fans logging on to their computers  often at work  to check scores and the status of their brackets and to watch streaming video of the games.

title: Tweaking the Zoom
description: MANY digital photographers are taking the plunge and upgrading to a single-lens reflex camera, in part because the lenses on such cameras are interchangeable. But one trip to a well-stocked camera store might convince some novices that this feature is not so attractive after all.

title: Off to War (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Jerry Orbach Is a Step Closer to a Corner Bearing His Name
description: There may be a sunnier side of the street for Jerry Orbach and his widow, Elaine.

title: A Mies Masterwork, Deteriorating and in Dispute
description: BRNO, Czech Republic

title: House Democrats Weigh Plan for Iraq Withdrawal
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Representative Dan Boren is a Democrat, but after visiting Iraq last week he announced a decision that puts him at odds with his partys leaders: he intends to vote against their plan to set a deadline for troops to leave Iraq.

title: Motorola Cuts Its Estimate of Earnings
description: The business prospects of Motorola, the 78-year-old technology company, suddenly look as thin as the Razr, its popular mobile phone.

title: Revealing Garments, Spirited Away in Concealing Bags
description: JERSEY CITY, March 21  Theres the holdup, and then theres the push-up. Now this: Three people made off with nearly $12,000 worth of bras and panties at a Victorias Secret at the Newport Center Mall here as customers milled about on Tuesday night.

title: A Rangers Welcome Back: 5 Goals, 1 KO
description: When Philadelphia forward Todd Fedoruk lay on the ice last night, Rangers forward Brendan Shanahan felt like he was replaying a nightmare. This was Shanahans first game back since he had to be carried off the Madison Square Garden ice on a stretcher after a ferocious collision with the Flyers Mike Knuble, and now the stretcher was being summoned for Fedoruk after he was knocked cold in a fight by the Rangers Colton Orr.

title: Illegal Worker, Troubled Citizen and Stolen Name
description: MARSHALLTOWN, Iowa  The two women named Violeta Blanco have never met. But for a long time they shared not only a name, but the same birth date and the same Social Security number.

title: Edwards Plans Announcement With His Wife
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat making a second bid for the presidency, called a news conference for Thursday to discuss the future of his campaign, a day after he and his wife, Elizabeth, visited Mrs. Edwardss doctor to assess her recovery from a bout of breast cancer.

title: Never Miss Oprah Again
description: Has this happened to you? Youre getting ready to be shot out of a cannon under the Big Top but you forgot to set your Series 2 or Series 3 TiVo to record Greys Anatomy. What is a human projectile to do? Why, whip out your Verizon cellphone, of course.

title: The Much-Needed Return of Pay-Go
description: While the House debates the course of the Iraq war today, the Senate has a chance to restore discipline to the federal budget, a first step in remedying years of damage from profligate tax cuts in the face of immense spending.

title: For Some Subprime Borrowers, Few Good Choices
description: Myriam Philemond says she knew almost from the start that she and her husband could not afford the nearly $500,000 house they bought in South Boston more than a year ago.

title: Bloomberg Seeks U.S. Aid for Treatment of 9/11 Illnesses
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Testifying at a Senate hearing on Wednesday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg pleaded for at least $150 million in annual federal aid to monitor and treat thousands of people who became ill after being exposed to dust and debris at ground zero.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A calendar of events in the Dining section yesterday misstated the day for a tasting of Burgundy wines by the New York Wine Guild. It will be on Wednesday, not Tuesday.

title: I Have Taken on My Daughters Hair and Won
description: OFTEN, the women let out a little gasp. I look up, a hair twisty dangling from my mouth, a clump of my 5-year-old daughters hair clenched in one fist, a comb in the other, ready for attack. She squirms on the bench in the family locker room at the local Y, freshly showered after a swim class and bracing for her hair appointment with me, her father, hellbent on taming those tresses.

title: Knicks Crowd Into the Trauma Ward
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 21  A day after losing to the Dallas Mavericks, the Knicks walking wounded were out in force at the teams practice facility.

title: Book on Bill Clinton Emerges From Years of Tapes
description: The conversations between President Bill Clinton and the historian Taylor Branch were long and late, sometimes stretching until 2 a.m., and always in secret. For eight years, at Mr. Clintons urging, they met in a second-floor office in the family quarters of the White House, Mr. Branch scribbling notes and a tape recorder running.

title: Officials Say Gunrunners Used Cellphone Pictures to Advertise
description: Cellphone cameras have become such a routine part of daily life that criminals are now using them to advertise guns imported from other states, prosecutors charged yesterday.

title: Whats on Thursday Night
description: 9 P.M. (22) BARENBOIM ON BEETHOVEN The Argentine-born pianist and conductor Daniel Barenboim, left, began learning the Beethoven sonatas as a young boy; by 17 he could play the entire cycle. No matter that my fingers have been playing the same notes since I was 8 years old, he said. The fingers know it, the brain knows it, and yet I find something new in it. In this Great Performances special, taped on June 25, 2005, at the Berlin Staatsoper, Mr. Barenboim performed five of Beethovens 32 piano sonatas  Nos. 5, 11, 19, 20 and 23, the Appassionata  as part of an eight-concert series. The special also presents excerpts from Mr. Barenboims master classes with the pianists Lang Lang, Jonathan Biss and Shai Wosner.

title: The Size of a Paperback and Most of the Functions of a Real PC
description: Hoping to put a PC in every purse, Samsung has upgraded its Q1 line of tiny 1.7-pound portable computers.

title: Bishop G. E. Patterson, 67, Who Led Church of God in Christ, Dies
description: Bishop G. E. Patterson, the presiding bishop of the Church of God in Christ, the nations largest African-American Pentecostal denomination, died Tuesday in Memphis. He was 67 and lived in Memphis, where the church has its headquarters.

title: Illinois: Hiring Settlement
description: A federal judge approved a preliminary settlement between the City of Chicago and lawyers who alleged that the city had violated a federal decree prohibiting the awarding of jobs and promotions to politically connected applicants. The ban, in effect since 1983, applies to about 37,000 city jobs. Among other provisions, the settlement calls for a $12 million fund to pay claims of $100,000 or less to individuals who say they were discriminated against Accusations of corruption in hiring have dogged the administration of Mayor Richard M. Daley. In 2005, a federal monitor was appointed to keep watch on the citys hiring practices.

title: The Mandate Is Maintained. Just the Details Are Different.
description: When the composers Lisa Bielawa and Eleanor Sandresky started the Music at the Anthology series of contemporary-music concerts under the guidance of Philip Glass in 1997, the name referred to its original home at the Anthology Film Archives in the East Village. The festival subsequently moved to a number of alternate Manhattan spaces; the name was contracted to MATA, but the mandate of providing exposure to emerging composers has continued.

title: Israel: Agreement Ends General Strike
description: Tens of thousands of public sector workers went on strike over unpaid wages for some municipal workers, causing the cancellation of flights in and out of the country and closing down many government offices. But it was short-lived, as state representatives and the head of the labor federation Histadrut came to an agreement, ending the strike by late afternoon.

title: Gentle Textures in an Outpost of Color and Quiet Ecstasy
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has some wonderful, carefully orchestrated chill-out spots  permanent little oases where you can sit, rest and muse without breaking the spell of art. The museum might consider adding another: Pink and Tan, Noah Sheldons solo exhibition at the DAmelio Terras Gallery in Chelsea.

title: Pooh Character Leads to Suit on Dress Code
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 21  Strict dress codes are common at many public schools in California, but Toni Kay Scott, 14, says her school crossed a constitutional line when it punished her for wearing knee socks with the Winnie-the-Pooh character Tigger.

title: The New Political Fixer: The Skin Doctor
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Stakes for Our Kids (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds of Brazil and Beyond, All in One Mans Voice and Guitar
description: Alone onstage at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday night, Gilberto Gil had a phantom band in his voice and his fingers. He sang percussion flourishes, cello lines, saxophone solos, bird cries; the chords he plucked on his guitar became chimes, undulations of sound, the other party in a wordless dialogue, a rock band or a samba-school strut. Every so often, he whistled too.

title: Gaza Strip: One Dead in Hamas-Fatah Clash
description: Inter-factional violence flared again in the Gaza Strip, days after the formation of a national unity government. A militant belonging to Fatah, identified as Rami Sroor, was killed in a clash with Hamas militants in northern Gaza.

title: Alaska to Pay Pilots in Plan to Kill Wolves
description: Alaska will pay pilots licensed to shoot wolves from the air $150 for each wolf they kill under a new plan intended to protect their prey, including moose and caribou, state wildlife officials said yesterday.

title: Connecticut: Indictment in Terrorism Case
description: A former sailor was indicted on charges of material support of terrorism and disclosing previously classified information relating to the national defense. The sailor, Hassan Abujihaad, formerly known as Paul R. Hall, was arrested in Phoenix on March 7 and is being prosecuted in Connecticut. He is accused of providing information about his battle groups movements while stationed in the Middle East to a suspected terrorist organization, Azzam Publications, which had his Navy e-mail address in its files. He faces up to 25 years in prison.

title: On Hit Lists, Anger Finds an Outlet
description: CHICAGO

title: Dirty Air Becomes Divisive Issue in Hong Kong Vote
description: HONG KONG, March 21  Worsening air pollution has become one of the most contentious issues in the vote on Sunday for Hong Kongs next chief executive, with the incumbent blaming emissions drifting across the border from mainland China for the problem while his challenger contends that Hong Kong is not doing enough to address the issue.

title: Anemia Drugs Under Review by Congress
description: A Congressional committee has begun an inquiry into the marketing and regulation of widely used anemia drugs that have recently raised safety concerns.

title: Whats in Lylas Hoard of Hair Essentials
description: Here are the products and accessories in my daughters hair basket:

title: Creole Folklore and Beats, and Drip Drip Drip of Nature
description: Tamango, the French Guianese tap dancer, begins his new show with dry ice swirling onto the stage; two figures, one crumpled on the floor, the other, twisting and crouching, appear in semi-darkness. In the background, water drips, a hint at the title, Bay Mo Dilo, which means Give Me Water in Creole.

title: Long Island Officials Weigh Two Sides of Consolidation
description: It is a Sisyphean task that politicians on Long Island have struggled with for decades: how to eliminate some of the hundreds of often overlapping municipalities and special districts that have resulted in a maze of regulations and driven up taxes.

title: Chirac, at Last, Backs Sarkozy in French Presidential Election
description: PARIS, March 21  Setting aside his personal feelings for the sake of his party, Jacques Chirac on Wednesday endorsed his longtime younger rival, Nicolas Sarkozy, as the person best suited to succeed him as president of France.

title: Thousands of Iraqis Who Flee to Kurdish Region to Escape War Face Harsh Living Conditions
description: BAGHDAD, March 21  About 160,000 Iraqis from outside the mountainous Kurdish north have moved there to flee a growing civil war, according to a draft of a report by an international group that tracks refugees and displaced people.

title: Apple TV Has Landed
Envoy Calls for Independence for Kosovo Ahead of a U.N. Debate
description: LJUBLJANA, Slovenia, March 21  The United Nations envoy to talks on the future of Kosovo, going beyond past statements, has recommended that the region be granted independence from Serbia.

title: Text of the Feds Statement
description: Following is the text of a statement released by the Federal Reserve yesterday after the Feds monetary policy panel, the Federal Open Market Committee, decided to leave interest rates unchanged.

title: Bracket Time: Anyone Have Bangladesh or Ireland?
description: All over the United States, basketball fans are celebrating March Madness, wondering if an outsider can crash the Final Four, the way George Mason did last year.

title: Lights! Camera! But Wheres the Action at U.C.L.A.?
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 21  The entrance to the Bruin Theater in Los Angeles was flanked by U.C.L.A. cheerleaders Monday night. John Wooden slid into a row reserved for his family. Bill Walton snagged an aisle seat to stretch his legs.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about the bribery trial of Gerald P. Garson, a former state judge in Brooklyn, referred incorrectly to the location of the courtroom where he once presided. Mr. Garson, a matrimonial judge, heard cases in the municipal building on Joralemon Street  not in the courthouse on Jay Street, the venue for his trial.

title: F.D.A. Limits Role of Advisers Tied to Industry
description: WASHINGTON, March 21  Expert advisers to the government who receive money from a drug or device maker would be barred for the first time from voting on whether to approve that companys products under new rules announced Wednesday for the F.D.A.s powerful advisory committees.

title: Census Reports Arizona County Still Has Biggest Growth
description: Maricopa County, which includes Phoenix and sprawls across 9,200 square miles, swelled by 100,000 people in the year ended last July 1, according to newly released census figures, retaining its title as the county with the biggest population increase in the country.

title: Louisiana Opening Offers Chance to Recast a Shaky Relationship With Washington
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 21  Since Hurricane Katrina, Louisiana has been a needy ward of Washington, though rarely a cooperative or cheerful one.

title: After Young Womans Death, Questions About Missed Chances
description: The killing of a 20-year-old Queens woman, and the arrest of a man who was under court order to stay away from her, has raised troubling questions for law enforcement and the young womans family about apparent miscues that preceded the attack.

title: Bank Freeze Stalls North Korea Talks
description: BEIJING, March 22  Talks aimed at dismantling North Koreas nuclear weapons program stalled here today over the failure to release up to $25 million frozen in a Macau bank that Pyongyang has demanded be returned before it continues disarmament negotiations.

title: Bronx: More Officers to Patrol Commuter Lines
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority is increasing police patrols on commuter trains and in stations to guard against terrorist attacks, the agencys executive director, Elliot G. Sander, said yesterday at the Spuyten Duyvil Metro-North station in the Bronx. As part of the effort to bolster security, the federal Transportation Security Administration will assign air marshals, who normally ride on commercial airliners, to take part in some train patrols. Mr. Sander said riders on the Long Island Rail Road and Metro-North Railroad would see more officers from the authoritys police force walking through trains, checking bags and patrolling platforms, stations and parking lots.

title: Bomb Explodes Near U.N. Chief in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD, March 22  Like most of the bombs that insurgents launch into the heavily fortified Green Zone, the mortar shell that exploded in the crook of a tree on the compounds eastern edge at 3:40 p.m. local time today caused some structural damage and no casualties. But this one carried a particularly resonant message about the continuing violence that plagues the capital.

title: Yankees Want Rodriguez to Stay, but Wont Sweeten His Deal
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 21  Alex Rodriguez has often said he is proud of his contract, and it is easy to see why. It is not only the richest deal in baseball history, but it provides him a chance to make still more money for even more years.

title: Manasquan: Woman Is Charged With Killing Son
description: A 46-year-old woman was charged yesterday with fatally stabbing her 9-year-old son, officials in Monmouth County said. The police found the woman, Kathlene M. DeMichele, in her apartment about 10:30 p.m. on Tuesday, bleeding profusely from self-inflicted wounds, said the Monmouth County prosecutor, Luis A. Valentin. Ms. DeMicheles son, Charles, was found with several stab wounds in a van parked outside the building, Mr. Valentin said. Ms. DeMichele was hospitalized in critical condition.

title: Correction
description: An Op-Ed article on March 3, about Moroccos proposal for an autonomous Western Sahara, should have more fully disclosed the background of the author, Frederick Vreeland. Mr. Vreeland, a former American ambassador to Morocco, is also the chairman of a solar-energy company that has had contracts with the Moroccan government.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about a rise in the prevalence of Alzheimers disease misstated the amount the federal government spends yearly for the average Medicare beneficiary who does not have the disease. It is $4,454, not $2,454.

title: Federal Judge Blocks Online Pornography Law
description: A federal judge in Philadelphia struck down a 1998 law today that made it a crime for Web sites to allow children to access material deemed harmful.

title: Historian Plans Book From Chats With Clinton
description: The conversations between President Bill Clinton and the historian Taylor Branch were long and late, sometimes stretching until 2 a.m. For eight years, at Mr. Clintons urging, they met in a second-floor office in the family quarters of the White House, Mr. Branch scribbling notes and a tape recorder running.

title: Baseball Lays Off Cable Operators Pitch
description: Major League Baseball spurned a revised offer by leading cable operators yesterday to retain the Extra Innings package of out-of-market games, which may now become the exclusive satellite domain of DirecTV.

title: Recycling Proposal Has Fizz, Leaving Proponents Hopeful
description: ALBANY, March 21  Like hardy perennials, or creatures of the undead, proposals to broaden New Yorks bottle-recycling laws rise up each spring in the Capitol. And just as regularly, those proposals are defeated.

title: Despite Recall, Pet Food Maker Is Still a Large Supplier
description: OTTAWA, March 21  Like many retail chains, PetSmart quickly removed several varieties of wet dog and cat foods made by Menu Foods, a Canadian manufacturer, that were recalled and have since been linked by the United States Food and Drug Administration to the deaths of 14 animals.

title: The Year Without Toilet Paper
description: The Conlin-Beavan family is four months into a yearlong lifestyle experiment in environmentalism that they call No Impact. Its rules are evolving but to date include eating only food (organically) grown within a 250-mile radius of Manhattan; (mostly) no shopping for anything except said food; producing no trash (except compost); using no paper; and, most intriguingly, using no carbon-fueled transportation.

title: Al Gore Appears on Capitol Hill
description: The scene as the former Vice President faced former colleagues, including James Inhofe of Oklahoma, one of Al Gore's most persistent critics.

title: Living on the Grid
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Elizabeth Edwards, Co-Campaigner
description: Elizabeth Edwards's cancer has returned, but her husband will continue his presidential campaign.

title: Snapshots of Time
description: Images from "The Event" at the Jeu de Paume in Paris.

title: Thinking of buying in Spain?
description: Europeans love sunshine. And thats why its no surprise that Spain has long been the top choice for people seeking a place to retire or to have a second home. But recently the countrys image has suffered as the result of press reports of corrupt developers and dodgy construction. We talked with Mark Stucklin, a Barcelona-based monthly columnist for the Sunday Times of London who also runs the Spanish Property Insight consultancy www.spanishpropertyinsight.com, to find out if Spain is still a good investment.

title: Box to the Future
description: Invoking Lewis Carroll, "E.T." and Tibetan Buddhism, "The Last Mimzy" is an overstuffed yet warmhearted sci-fi drama about a dying planet, resourceful kids and a science teacher firmly in touch with his spiritual side.

title: Deadly Reminiscence
description: In "Memory" Billy Zane plays Dr. Taylor Briggs, a researcher specializing in memory loss who becomes infected by a powdery substance while examining a patient in Brazil. Before you can say, "What's that again?," Taylor is having dream-infused seizures, during which he sees running children, flapping vegetation and a masked man in a black duster. The more he investigates the source of his visions, the more we are treated to shots of him staring at a computer while furrowing his brow. Audiences will leave the theater wearing a similar expression.

title: Turtle Power of the CGI Variety
description: As Hollywood falls over itself to produce greener movies with ecologically correct themes, only the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles remain willing to suggest that there is an upside to toxic waste. Spawned by sludge and grandiosely named after Renaissance artists, these crime-fighting reptiles have been rechristened "TMNT" and redrawn by an army of computer-generated-imagery specialists. Nevertheless, the now-23-year-old gang  perhaps to connect better with its target audience  is still living at home.

title: The Hustle and Bustle of Love
description: Based on the novel by Matthew Rettenmund, "Boy Culture" is a slick and absorbing drama about an attractive gay hustler named X (Derek Magyar), with an extensive investment portfolio and a restricted clientele of 12 wealthy men. When not servicing his "disciples," X conducts a volatile relationship with his two roommates (Darryl Stephens and Jonathon Trent) and criticizes the gay lifestyle in cynical voice-over. Only when he takes on a reclusive and much older client (elegantly played by Patrick Bauchau) is he forced to pay attention to a story other than his own.

title: Surviving in the Aftermath of Vietnam
description: Dying is easy, comedy is hard, and melodrama is almost impossible. The writer-director Ham Tran achieves the impossible in "Journey From the Fall," a sprawling tearjerker about a war-splintered South Vietnamese family trying to survive the aftermath of the American withdrawal and then seek a new life in the United States.

title: Making Waves in a Tough Community
description: "Pride," about a swim coach (Terrence Howard) leading an urban recreational center's swim team to a championship, about 1971, illustrates the adaptability and limitations of the sports movie.

title: Ready to Figuratively Rock and Pretend Roll
description: "You can't hold a gun if you're holding an air guitar."

title: Slopeside in Mont Tremblant
description: Take a tour of this stunning ski resort in the Laurentian Mountains of Quebec.

title: School Funding in New Jersey
Cleveland Hit Hard by Foreclosures
description: Cuyahoga County, including Cleveland and 58 suburbs, has one of the countrys highest foreclosure rates and officials say the worst is yet to come.

title: Nymex Stockholders Sell $956 Million of Shares
description: NYMEX Holdings, the parent company of the New York Mercantile Exchange, sold shares valued at $956 million in a secondary offering of shares held by NYMEX stockholders. The offering is expected to close on March 27.

title: A Bittersweet Return
description: As families begin to return to the Baghdad neighborhoods they fled, the threat of sectarian violence remains very real.

title: The Window Box Gets Some Tough Competition
description: Cities from Los Angeles to Chicago are offering incentives for builders who use environmentally friendly green roofs.

title: Defibrillator Maker Props Up Stress Test Company
description: St. Jude Medical is stepping in to prop up a start-up company that it hopes can help revive the stagnating $6 billion market for implantable heart defibrillators. The start-up, Cambridge Heart, based in Bedford, Mass., said Wednesday that St. Jude Medical would take over efforts to sell its product: stress test equipment that doctors use to assess patients as candidates for defibrillators.

title: Ex-Qwest Official Says Chief Was Misleading on Growth
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications who is on trial for insider trading, knowingly repeated unreliable growth forecasts in 2000 and 2001, a former company official testified Wednesday.

title: Charges Dismissed Against Ex-Banker
description: A former Bear Stearns municipal bond banker on Wednesday won dismissal of federal criminal charges that he was involved in a kickback scheme tied to the construction of a hospital in the Chicago area. The banker, P. Nicholas Hurtgen, was indicted in 2005 on charges of wire fraud, mail fraud and extortion. He was accused of helping a member of the Illinois Health Facilities Planning Board force the hiring of a politically connected construction company to work on medical buildings.

title: Stephen Schwarzmans Pay Paradox
description: Blackstone Group chairman Stephen Schwarzman may want to pay himself as little as possible if his private equity firm decides to go public, according to Breakingviews. That is because each dollar he foregoes is likely to boost his firms earnings and make his stake balloon in value.

title: Fremont Selling $4 Billion of Its Subprime Loans
description: Fremont General, which is seeking a buyer for its subprime mortgage unit, said Wednesday that it would sell $4 billion of subprime mortgages, reducing its exposure to the risky loans. The sale will result in a $140 million pretax loss, less than investors expected, and its disclosure helped push up shares of the company by 16 percent, to $10.19.

title: Ampd Mobile Rings Up Another $107 Million
description: Ampd Mobile apparently knows how to push the right buttons with venture investors. The two-year-old startup, which offers prepaid cellphone service along with downloadable videos, songs and games, has raised $107 million in a Series E round of funding from a list of big-name firms, according to several reports.

title: Nikko Shareholder Snubs Citigroups Sweetened Offer
description: Citigroup seems to be having a tough time trying to convince Nikko Cordials largest shareholder, Harris Associates, to turn over its shares in the Japanese brokerage.

title: Potential Bank Merger Puts Focus on ING
description: ING Group reiterated that it would participate in consolidation within the banking industry, as merger talks progressed between British bank Barclays and ABN Amro. On Thursday, a Dutch newspaper reported that ING had hired Goldman Sachs and J.P. Morgan to help it find options to expand in Europe.

title: Ex-Chief of Collins & Aikman Is Said to Be Facing Indictment
description: David A. Stockman, a former congressman who served as President Ronald Reagans first budget director, is expected to be indicted on charges of accounting fraud related to his role as chairman of auto parts supplier Collins & Aikman, The New York Times reported.

title: The Sound of Unsold Music
description: Elton John decided on Wednesday to release his catalog to iTunes, just in time for the latest sign of the seismic shift in the way consumers acquire music.

title: Conrad Blacks Co-Defendants Start Stating Their Cases
description: Two co-defendants of Conrad M. Black, accused of helping him steal $60 million from Hollinger International, did nothing illegal or were in the dark about any wrongdoing at the company, their lawyers said Wednesday.

title: China Railway Prepares for I.P.O.
description: Citigroup, Macquarie Bank and Citic Securities are poised to reap the benefits of $2 billion initial public offering of China Railway Construction. Bloomberg News reports that China Railway has hired the three banks to prepare it for the I.P.O., which could take place as soon as the end of this year.

title: Morgan Stanley Wins Appeal on Perelman Suit
description: On the back of record earnings, Morgan Stanley had more to celebrate Wednesday: The firm also won an appeal of a $1.57 billion jury verdict against it, stemming from a lawsuit brought by Ronald O. Perelman. The surprising decision by the state District Court of Appeal in Florida removes a legal and reputational pall that hung heavily over the firm during the bitter leadership battle that led to the return of John J. Mack, the investment banks chief executive.

title: Coles to Hold Three-Part Auction, Report Says
description: If bidders want all of Coles Myer, the Australian retailer, then they will have to pay in three different installments. The Australian Financial review reported that the board of directors of Australias second-largest retailer is meeting Friday to formally approve a three-part, A$20 billion ($16.1 billion) auction.

title: NBC, News Corp. Plan Their Own YouTube
description: Several media giants are teaming up to fight YouTube on its own turf. News Corp. and NBC Universal plan to announce as soon as Thursday that they are creating an online video site stocked with TV shows and movies, plus clips that users can modify and share with friends, according to The Los Angeles Times.

title: Jim Cramer on Jim Cramer (and That Video)
description: Critics of colorful Mad Money host Jim Cramer have been having a field day lately with comments he made in an video interview with TheStreet.com, during which he talked about his ability as a former hedge-fund manager to game the stock market. His description of certain legal and illlegal  but all somewhat dubious  practices reignited the long-running debate on whether he is a market genius or a hack.

title: Bertelsmann Said to Consider Thomson Learning Bid
description: Moving quickly, Bertelsmann, the media group, is considering a bid for Thomson Learning, a textbook publisher, just one day after announcing that it had formed an unusual partnership with two several private equity funds to target media companies, The Financial Times reported.

title: EU Clears Berkshire Deal for TTI
description: Warren E. Buffetts Berkshire Hathaway won approval from European regulators Thursday to buy U.S. company TTI, which distributes electronic components that other companies use to make a range of products. The European Commission cleared the deal automatically after identifying no antitrust problem and receiving no complaints from rivals within a deadline of 25 working days.

title: Whats Next for Motorola?
description: Motorola, the subject of rampant deal rumors on Wall Street this week, on Wednesday sliced about $1 billion off of its revenue projections for the quarter and announced a management shake-up. The beleaguered cellphone giant also said it was expanding a stock-buyback program, addressing a demand of the billionaire investor Carl C. Icahn, who has become a major Motorola shareholder.

title: Nu Image Takes Control of First Look Studios
description: The independent film producer Nu Image has acquired a controlling interest in troubled First Look Studios, an independent film distributor with hedge-fund backing, the company announced on Wednesday.

title: Police Comment on Uncivil Servants
description: The new site Uncivil Servants, which publishes pictures intended to document abuse of city-issued parking placards, has stirred the ire of some police officers, as we noted here the other day.

title: Paul Allens Firm to Seek Banking Investments
description: Vulcan Capital, the venture-capital vehicle of Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen, is creating a joint venture with Bankers Capital Group to look for investments in the banking sector in the southeast United States. Bankers Capital was launched last year by a group of executives that cleaned up troubled bank Flag Financial and sold it to RBC Centura, the Financial News reports.

title: Glu Mobile Goes Public in $84 Million Offering
description: Glu Mobile, a publisher of games for mobile phones, raised $84 million in an initial public offering that priced late Wednesday. The offering, which values the entire company at $327 million, comes amid what the GigaOm blog calls a slow resurgence of technology I.P.O.s.

title: Obama Said to Pull Support for Chicago Exchange Deal
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange insists that its $8.97 billion bid for its crosstown rival, the Chicago Board of Trade, will prevail in the end. But as the InterContinental Exchange touts its $9.9 billion higher bid, the Merc may have lost one of its highest-profile supporters: a certain Illinois senator running for president.

title: Japanese Land Prices Rise for First Time in 16 Years
description: TOKYO, March 22 (Reuters) - Japanese land prices rose for the first time in 16 years in 2006, offering further evidence that the nation is emerging from deflation with support from a steady economic recovery, a government survey showed on Thursday.

title: Tribune Circles Back to Zell Plan, Report Says
description: It seems the seesaw that is the Tribune drama has tipped back toward Samuel Zell. The Chicago billionaires bid to take the media conglomerate private may have fallen out of favor last week, but the Chicago Tribune reported Thursday that the companys directors are taking another look at his plan.

title: Peregrine Smackdown: Stay Away From My Dorothy!
description: For some reason the Lab has turned into Animal House lately. As an encore to the laughing rats and the malaria-busting mosquitoes, we now present, for your viewing enjoyment, the fighting falcons.

title: Dance Fever
description: A substratum of dedicated  even fanatical  amateur ballet dancers do exist.

title: Blame It on Obama?
description: Now that The Huffington Post has identified the creator of the Macintosh-inspired, anti-Hillary YouTube ad for Barack Obamas presidential campaign as an employee (now former employee) of a political-consulting firm that does business with Obama, will there be lasting effect from the discovery?

title: Bridging the Computer-to-TV Divide
description: Today in The Times, I reviewed the Apple TV box--and, for context, a couple of its rivals from Microsoft and Netgear.

title: Apple TV
description: David Pogue reviews Apple's TV box, which can connect your computer to your TV without wires.

title: A Better Reason for Banning Steroids
Men in the News Roundup
description: What man wouldnt welcome comparisons to Jay Gatsby, the filthy rich, soiree-throwing subject of Fitzgeralds Great American Novel? Conrad Black, thats who. In a response to a column in The London Times, Mr. Black, the former press tycoon now on trial for fraud, wrote:

title: A Brief Scare for Sanchez
description: Pitching from the mound for the first time since undergoing shoulder surgery last August, Duaner Sanchez threw 11 pitches before feeling what he called a pop by his shoulder. He stopped immediately, and a consultation with a doctor revealed that the sensation was nothing more than scar tissue breaking apart.

title: 2008: The Edwards Couple to Talk at Noon
description: The Edwards campaign is exceptionally tight-lipped this morning about what John and Elizabeth Edwards will say about her health at their noon press conference in Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: The Global Deterioration Scale for Assessment of Primary Degenerative Dementia
description: Stage 1: No cognitive impairment Unimpaired individuals experience no memory problems and none are evident to a health care professional during a medical interview. Stage 2: Very mild cognitive decline Individuals at this stage feel as if they have memory lapses, especially in forgetting familiar words or names or the location of keys, eyeglasses or other everyday objects. But these problems are not evident during a medical examination or apparent to friends, family or co-workers. Stage 3: Mild cognitive decline Friends, family or co-workers begin to notice deficiencies. Problems with memory or concentration may be measurable in clinical testing or discernible during a detailed medical interview. Common difficulties include:  Word- or name-finding problems noticeable to family or close associates  Decreased ability to remember names when introduced to new people  Performance issues in social or work settings noticeable to family, friends or co-workers  Reading a passage and retaining little material  Losing or misplacing a valuable object  Decline in ability to plan or organize Stage 4: Moderate cognitive decline At this stage, a careful medical interview detects clear-cut deficiencies in the following areas:  Decreased knowledge of recent occasions or current events  Impaired ability to perform challenging mental arithmetic-for example, to count backward from 100 by 7s  Decreased capacity to perform complex tasks, such as marketing, planning dinner for guests or paying bills and managing finances  Reduced memory of personal history  The affected individual may seem subdued and withdrawn, especially in socially or mentally challenging situations Stage 5: Moderately severe cognitive decline Major gaps in memory and deficits in cognitive function emerge. Some assistance with day-to-day activities becomes essential. At this stage, individuals may:  Be unable during a medical interview to recall such important details as their current address, their telephone number or the name of the college or high school from which they graduated  Become confused about where they are or about the date, day of the week, or season  Have trouble with less challenging mental arithmetic; for example, counting backward from 40 by 4s or from 20 by 2s  Need help choosing proper clothing for the season or the occasion  Usually retain substantial knowledge about themselves and know their own name and the names of their spouse or children  Usually require no assistance with eating or using the toilet Stage 6: Severe cognitive decline Memory difficulties continue to worsen, significant personality changes may emerge and affected individuals need extensive help with customary daily activities. At this stage, individuals may:  Lose most awareness of recent experiences and events as well as of their surroundings  Recollect their personal history imperfectly, although they generally recall their own name  Occasionally forget the name of their spouse or primary caregiver but generally can distinguish familiar from unfamiliar faces  Need help getting dressed properly; without supervision, may make such errors as putting pajamas over daytime clothes or shoes on wrong feet  Experience disruption of their normal sleep/waking cycle  Need help with handling details of toileting (flushing toilet, wiping and disposing of tissue properly)  Have increasing episodes of urinary or fecal incontinence  Experience significant personality changes and behavioral symptoms, including suspiciousness and delusions (for example, believing that their caregiver is an impostor); hallucinations (seeing or hearing things that are not really there); or compulsive, repetitive behaviors such as hand-wringing or tissue shredding  Tend to wander and become lost Stage 7: Very severe cognitive decline This is the final stage of the disease when individuals lose the ability to respond to their environment, the ability to speak and, ultimately, the ability to control movement.  Frequently individuals lose their capacity for recognizable speech, although words or phrases may occasionally be uttered  Individuals need help with eating and toileting and there is general incontinence of urine  Individuals lose the ability to walk without assistance, then the ability to sit without support, the ability to smile, and the ability to hold their head up. Reflexes become abnormal and muscles grow rigid. Swallowing is impaired.

title: McLeodUSA Hopes Third Times the Charm
description: McLeodUSA, the twice-bankrupt telephone provider once backed by Theodore Forstmann, is hearing the call of the public markets again. The company on Thursday filed with regulators to raise as much as $172.5 million in an initial public offering. We use the term initial loosely: McLeodUSAs predecessor company went public in 1996, and the company has since been through two Chapter 11 reorganizations.

title: Bridging the Computer-to-TV Divide
description: Today in The Times, I reviewed the Apple TV boxand, for context, a couple of its rivals from Microsoft and Netgear.

title: Al Gore Appears on Capitol Hill
description: The scene as the former Vice President faced former colleagues, including James Inhofe of Oklahoma, one of Al Gore's most persistent critics.

title: Finding Lost Objects in Germany
description: In Europe, where they take their arts very seriously, nothing happens without a meeting, even if it means a transcontinental flight. In early 2000, when Julia Wolfe, David Lang and I were commissioned to create a new work that eventually became the music for our staged oratorio, Lost Objects, the director of the Dresden Festival at the time, Torsten Mosgraber, flew to New York with Werner Ehrhardt, the concertmaster of Concerto Kln.

title: Coming to Harvard Law School: Wasserstein Hall
description: Bruce Wassersteins name disappeared from investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort last year. But it will be resurfacing somewhere else. Harvard Law School said Thursday that it received a $25 million gift from Mr. Wasserstein and would name a new building after the Lazard chairman.

title: Murder and Romance
description: Photographs from the new Broadway musical "Curtains."

title: The Strobers on YouTube
description: Gerald S. Strober and Deborah H. Strober, authors of Giuliani: Flawed or Flawless? The Oral Biography, have taken to YouTube to promote their book, a collection of interviews with 40 of Mr. Giulianis longtime associates, teachers, friends, opponents, critics and other astute political observers.

title: Edwards: The Campaign Goes On Despite Wifes Cancer Recurrence
description: Democratic presidential contender John Edwards and his wife Elizabeth announced today that Mrs. Edwardss cancer had returned, this time in a rib on her right side.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: The This Land column on Sunday, about plaques honoring World War II veterans at the Taylor County courthouse in Butler, Ga., that are segregated by race, misstated the name of the organization headed by John Cole Vodicka, who is pushing to have the plaques removed. It is the Prison and Jail Project, not the Jail and Prison Project.

title: Trading Journalists for Taliban
description: A reader asks:

title: Project Sunlight Gets the Green Light; Member Items Get the Sunlight
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has struck a deal with the leaders of the Legislature to require most recipients of member items to disclose any connections they have to the lawmakers who give them.

title: Ann Curry in Darfur
description: My Times colleague Jacques Steinberg has a very nice piece today about Ann Currys latest journey to Sudan, including her interview with President Bashir, the butcher of Darfur. Ann is doing superb work, and I just hope the other TV networks follow her trail to the killing fields.

title: St. Louis, a Gracious Host
description: Reporting the Midwest regional in the shadow of the Gateway Arch puts me in a good frame of mind and it is not just because of the positive memories of how well this Mississippi River city hosted the Final Four in 2005.

title: Life, Liberty and Wikipedia
description: In the wake of the Essjay controversy and a history departments ban, Wikipedias founder has sought to restore credibility in the Web site in a well-established fashion. He set new policies and granted confidence-building interviews in national magazines.

title: Greetings from Sarasota
description: The Yankees have a pretty full roster here in Sarasota to play the Reds. The only regulars left behind were Johnny Damon, Doug Mientkiewicz and Hideki Matsui.

title: Its All Politics
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 22 column, A Proper Distinction.

title: Paying for the Privilege
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Mar. 22 column, Stepping on the Dream.

title: Merrill Says Research Is Being Napster-ized
description: Rock stars and media giants are not the only ones worried about their creations being given away for free on the Web. Merrill Lynch, the giant securities firm, is taking new steps to protect its stock research, which it described in a note to clients as being Napster-ized  a reference to the Web site that used to be a hotbed of wanton song-swapping before it went bankrupt and relaunched as a subscription-based service. In Thursdays letter, Candace Browning, Merrills chief of global securities research and economics, began with an anecdote about how Merrills research had recently been duplicated with plagiaristic precision on a Web site based in New Jersey. Now, she wrote, the firm is taking stronger measures to safeguard its analysis.

title: 2008: Polling on Age
description: Whats the best age for a president of the United States? It depends who you ask, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.
