title: Airbus in America
description: In a media spectacle, the A380 touched down in New York this week. But the world's largest passenger plane has not yet sold to any American carriers.

title: Football Fever in Texas
description: Randomly placed among a mountain of media fact books about Texas A&Ms basketball team on a table in the press room of the Alamodome was a 2003-04 Football Writers Association of America Directory, a subtle reminder that football is still king here in Texas.

title: Blackstone Files for $4 Billion I.P.O.
description: Its in.

title: Slice Is Torn
description: Few people will watch the game between U.C.L.A. and Pittsburgh with more mixed emotions tonight than the the Manhattan College coach Barry Rohrssen. Rohrssen, who is nicknamed Slice, just finished his first season at Manhattan after a seven-year stint at Pittsburgh as an assistant coach and associate head coach under both Ben Howland and Jamie Dixon. Howland and Dixon are the best of friends  their relationship stretching back to when Howland recruited Dixon as a high school player.

title: Back to Balthazar
description: Arguably the hottest restaurant opening of early 2007 is Morandi, if you bear in mind that Gordon Ramsay at the London opened in late 2006, as did the Waverly Inn, which officially never opened  at least according to the coyly articulated position of the Graydon Carter Fabulosity Institute. It may never open, instead remaining content and profitable in some hyper-exclusive limbo where phones are never answered and hoi polloi are reduced to quivering, pointless supplication.

title: Politico: The Scoop That Wasnt
description: Within the drama of Elizabeth and John Edwards announcement that her cancer had returned dwelled a separate drama, about the hazards of a news cycle grown so heated that exclusives are measured in minutes  if not seconds  and the deadline is always past.

title: Is That a `Yes or a `No?
description: When the Florida Gators practiced today in preparation for Fridays regional semi-final against Butler, the reporters around courtside wanted to ask Coach Billy Donovan if he would be interested in moving to Kentucky to replace Tubby Smith, who is leaving the Wildcats to coach Minnesota.

title: A New Coach for Kentucky?
description: With the surprising news today that the Kentucky Coach Tubby Smith was headed to Minnesota, expect one of the big storylines for tonights game between Texas A&M and Memphis to be whether the A&M coach Billy Gillispie would jump to Lexington.

title: Giuliani on U.S. Attorneys Firings
description: In his first public comments on the matter, Rudolph W. Giuliani today took a wait-and-see view of the firings of several United States attorneys, saying he did not know enough yet to judge whether anyone in the White House or the Justice Department had acted improperly.

title: D.C. Vote Bill Derailed
description: This is a happy day, House Speaker Nancy Pelosi said earlier today. It is an historic day. It is a day when the people of the District of Columbia will finally have their voices heard and represented.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Offside'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews 'Offside,' an Iranian film about a group of young women who sneak into a soccer stadium.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Reign Over Me'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews 'Reign Over Me,' starring Don Cheadle and Adam Sandler.

title: Blogtalk: Overcast, Chance of Ooze
description: Should anyone be worried about oil oozing from the ground in Williamsburg? No, says the city. Smells O.K. [Gowanus Lounge]

title: And It Wasnt Even a B Game
description: Lots of humor at the old ballgame today. Jerry Springer had a seat behind home plate. The foul poles had the words Terrys Plumbing written vertically from top to bottom. As Peter Abraham shows us in his blog, there was a clown statue (designed by Springer  seriously) outside the Yankees clubhouse.

title: Blogtalk: The Edwardses
description: The announcement today that Elizabeth Edwards, wife of John, is facing a recurrence of cancer, gave the blogs a brief respite from acrimony, finger-pointing and, to a large part, politics itself. While some posts did consider the political ramifications for Mr. Edwards and the inaccuracy of early reports that he would quit or suspend his campaign, most simply offered their condolences.

title: Your TV, Scattered All Over the Web
description: Want to get some attention on the Web? Wave your virtual arms inside a packed chat room and yell YouTube killer!!!

title: Cancer Returns to Elizabeth Edwards
description: Presidential candidate John Edwards says he will continue with his '08 campaign despite news that his wife Elizabeth's breast cancer has returned.

title: Aggies Feeling Blue
description: Well, its about time that people stop underestimating Memphis. The No. 2 Tigers just completed a scintillating victory against No. 3 Texas A&M in the most hostile of environments. Amid a sea of Texas A&M maroon, the Tigers stayed calm down the stretch and again overcame their supposed nemesis  free throw shooting.

title: Ouch! G.O.P. Slams Pelosi
description: As the House wrangles over the emergency war spending bill, the National Republican Congressional Committee  responsible for getting people elected and re-elected to the House, put out this tonight:

title: Chief Says F.C.C. Is Against Cellphone Use on Airliners
description: The Federal Aviation Administration had been laying the groundwork to allow in-flight cellphone use. But the Federal Communications Commission will give up on the idea of allowing cellphone use on airplanes, the chairman said, because it is not clear whether the network on the ground can handle the calls.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the National Briefing column on Wednesday, about a measure passed by the Georgia House to ban the sale of candy made to taste like marijuana, misidentified the substance that marketers say is used to flavor the candy. It is hemp essential oil, not hempseed oil.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A news analysis article on Wednesday about the history and scope of executive privilege misstated the academic position held by Mark J. Rozell, who said that President Bush has invoked the privilege relatively sparingly. He is a professor at the School of Public Policy at George Mason University, not a law professor at George Mason.

title: Prosecutors in a Past Life, Sleuths of the Senate Now
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  When Senate Judiciary Committee aides huddled in a conference room on Monday night to work their way through Chinese takeout and thousands of newly disclosed administration e-mail messages about fired federal prosecutors, they got help from a surprising source: Senator Sheldon Whitehouse.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,218 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Hempstead: School Monitor Arrested
description: A hall monitor at Roslyn High School was arrested yesterday after two bags of cocaine fell out of her pocket in a hallway, the Nassau County police said. A teacher and a student at the school told the police that they saw the cocaine drop from the monitors pocket while she was on duty, the authorities said. The monitor, Evelyn J. Garza, 46, of Roslyn Heights, was expected to be arraigned on drug possession charges last night, the police said. The monitors identity was confirmed by a hallway security camera, according to the Roslyn School District. Ms. Garza was suspended without pay after her arrest, the district said.

title: Wide Range of Spending in N.J. Schools, Data Show
description: With an average class size of nine, the tiny Sea Isle City school district on the Jersey Shore is spending $33,805 for each of its 90 students this school year, or nearly three times the statewide average of $12,098 a student, according to figures released this morning by the New Jersey Department of Education.

title: A Cleaner Food and Drug Agency
description: In our highly medicated, high-technology society, it is essential that the Food and Drug Administration regulates drugs, medical devices and other products with complete objectivity  free from the taint of industry influence. So it is encouraging that the agency has proposed new rules to exclude experts who have significant financial ties to regulated industries from serving on committees that recommend whether a product should be approved.

title: Punch Lands Rangers Orr on YouTube
description: With one punch, Rangers forward Colton Orr vaulted himself into a nights worth of video highlights when he knocked the Flyers Todd Fedoruk unconscious Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: The Subprime Loan Machine
description: Edward N. Jones, a former NASA engineer for the Apollo and Skylab missions, looked at low-income home buyers nearly a decade ago and saw an unexplored frontier.

title: In the Yucatn Jungle, an Eco-Hideaway Sells Another Side of Mexico
description: I n the dense tropical forest west of the Mayan ruins of Tulum, a Texas-based developer is creating a jungle community, hoping to attract buyers more interested in exotic birds and wild orchids than ocean views.

title: Chief Says F.C.C. Is Against Cellphone Use on Airliners
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  The Federal Communications Commission will give up on the idea of allowing cellphone use on airplanes, the chairman said on Thursday, because it is not clear whether the network on the ground can handle the calls.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: A Road Trip Back to the Future
description: ONE of the high points of my childhood on Long Island  where most buildings were as ordinary as Monopoly houses  was driving past Endo Labs, a pharmaceutical company headquarters in Garden City made of undulating surfaces of corduroy-textured concrete. Endo was part medieval castle, part flying saucer and unlike any building I had ever seen.

title: France Begins Formal Inquiry on Oil Executive
description: PARIS, March 22  Problems increased for the French oil company Total on Thursday when Christophe de Margerie, the chief executive, was put under formal investigation by French authorities, who are looking into allegations that the company paid kickbacks to win a gas contract in Iran during the late 1990s.

title: Iran Detains British Sailors in Waters Off Iraq
description: LONDON, March 23  Fifteen British sailors carrying out a routine inspection in the Persian Gulf were captured at gunpoint and taken into custody by Iranian forces on Friday morning, the British Ministry of Defense said.

title: U.S. and South Korea Remain Apart on Trade Negotiations
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 22  Trade negotiations between the United States and South Korea have failed to narrow gaps on issues like agriculture, automobiles and textiles, leaving them for next week, negotiators said Thursday.

title: Intel, Already With Operations in China, Appears Ready to Build a Chip Plant There
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 22  Intel appears set to build a chip fabrication plant in northern China, a move that would mark a major milestone in the countries trade relations and could improve Intels competitiveness as it moves operations closer to its biggest customers.

title: You Can Call It the Little Easy
description: WHEN thousands of athletes from around the world pull on their running shoes in Mobile, Ala., tomorrow and set out through the streets in the 10-kilometer Azalea Trail Run, they will race past antebellum mansions, ornate old commercial buildings, majestic churches and storefronts topped by lacy cast-iron balconies and grillwork. The run, now in its 30th year, is timed for late March to coincide with the bloom of azaleas and dogwood, one of the prettiest seasons in Mobile, an easygoing port town spread along the banks of the Mobile River and bell-shaped Mobile Bay. The race attracts runners from as far away as Kenya and New Zealand, happy to test themselves amid the scent of wisteria. But they are far from the first outsiders to be attracted to Mobile.

title: Japan: Holder Rejects Higher Nikko Bid
description: Harris Associates rejected Citigroups $13.4 billion bid for Nikko Cordial, the Japanese brokerage firm, saying the price was still too low. Harris, which is Nikkos largest shareholder, with a stake of about 7.5 percent, has no plan at this stage to accept Citigroups bid of 1,700 yen ($14.47) a share, David G. Herro, Harriss chief investment officer, said. Citigroup raised its offer to 1,700 yen a share from 1,350 after Harris and other funds opposed the bid.

title: While Clinton Runs, She Minds the Store
description: IT is hardly a shocker that Karen Persichilli Keoghs rimless eyeglasses are askew and that she has misbuckled the belt holding up the bottom half of her pinstripe pantsuit. Self-focus is not her forte. Nor is it in her job description. Nor is it, considering the multitudinous goings-on in her career biosphere, even possible.

title: U.S. Attorney in Michigan Disputes Reason for Removal
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  The ousted United States attorney in western Michigan said Thursday that she was told last November that she was being forced out to make way for another lawyer the Bush administration wanted to groom, not because of management problems.

title: Seeking Office, in Fiction and in Fact
description: New Yorks most recognizable district attorney says he is thinking about running for president.

title: When the Snow Begins to Fall, He May Not See It Stop
description: A pointed little thriller with metaphysical pretensions, First Snow is shrewd enough to approach basic philosophical questions in sneaky, offhand ways. Are our individual fates sealed, or can we alter them by changing our behavior? In trying to shape our destinies, are we just bringing them on? Is knowing the future a blessing because it allows us to plan ahead and make amends, or a curse that cant be shaken?

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Stagestruck Sleuth, Crazy for Clues and Cues
description: As befits a musical about a musical, Curtains  the talent-packed, thrill-starved production that opened last night at the Al Hirschfeld Theater  features an assortment of upbeat anthems to this business we call show. But the number that best captures the essence of the latest (and, sad to say, one of the last) of the collaborations from the songwriting team of John Kander and Fred Ebb is a low-key ballad called Coffee Shop Nights.

title: Knicks Squander Opportunity
description: David Lee was back in uniform last night, but it was everything else that the Knicks were missing that doomed them to another crushing defeat.

title: With Game on Line, Two Free Throws Are the Difference
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 22  A 64.4 percent free-throw shooter this season, Memphis guard Antonio Anderson stepped to the line Thursday night with 3.1 seconds left for the most important foul shots of his college career.

title: Taken Off Its Game, Kansas Regroups in Time
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 22  The specter hanging over HP Pavilion on Thursday night was wearing Bradley red and Bucknell orange.

title: House Narrowly Backs Iraq Timetable
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The House of Representatives voted today, by an extremely narrow margin and after an unusually emotional debate, to set a timetable for bringing American troops home from Iraq.

title: If You Want the Yankees to Win, the Key Plays Are at Home
description: BEFORE he retired from broadcasting in 1996, Phil Rizzuto made it a point never to change subjects during a Yankees rally. He could be discussing bunions; it didnt matter. As long as the Yanks were hitting, the Scooter stayed on topic.

title: In 4th Case in 2 Weeks, a Bank Robber Says He Has Explosives
description: Police helicopters whirred overhead yesterday in Carroll Gardens, Brooklyn, and the police were out in force searching for a man who had made threats with an explosive device.

title: Italy: No Regrets Over Taliban Deal
description: Foreign Minister Massimo DAlema said he did not discuss with American officials the deal in which five Taliban prisoners were traded this week for the freedom of a kidnapped Italian reporter in Afghanistan. Despite strong criticism from officials in the United States and Europe, Mr. DAlema told reporters in Rome, I am not the slightest bit repentant for having saved the reporter, Daniele Mastrogiacomo, adding that it is preferable to have a controversy over having saved him, rather than for having had him killed.

title: Gambling in My Backyard (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Surging Real Estate Values Put Giant French Retailer in Play
description: PARIS, March 22  Carrefour, Europes answer to Wal-Mart and the worlds second-largest retailer, is in play.

title: Ex-Deputy of Interior Dept. Pleads Guilty
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  J. Steven Griles, the second-highest official at the Interior Department during President Bushs first term, pleaded guilty today to lying to a Senate committee about his ties to Jack Abramoff, the disgraced lobbyist who obtained help from the Interior Department for his Indian tribal clients.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Renzo Piano

title: NBC and News Corp. to Create YouTube Rival
description: Two big media companies, the News Corporation and NBC Universal, finally announced today their joint venture to sell video clips and entire shows and movies via a new Web site and throughout the Internet on an advertising-supported basis.

title: Does Soprano Get Whacked? Does He Get a Banana Split?
description: BLOOMFIELD, N.J., March 22  They gathered here  an old man in a black fedora and leather jacket, a woman in a tracksuit, a young mother pushing a stroller  for a final glimpse at Tony and Carmela and A. J. and Meadow.

title: Art in Review
description: NAN GOLDINMatthew Marks 523 West 24th Street, Chelsea Through April 14

title: As 08 Candidate, Giuliani Strikes a New Tone on Guns
description: As mayor of New York City, Rudolph W. Giuliani became the favorite Republican of gun control advocates.

title: Modern Dutch Master, but Citizen of the World
description: At the Neue Galerie you generally know what youre in for: work by early-20th-century German and Austrian artists, and in the cafe, fine apple strudel.

title: Congress Asks Purdue for Fusion Claim Findings
description: A Congressional committee has asked Purdue University for copies of its findings in an investigation of a Purdue scientist who claims to have generated nuclear fusion in a desktop experiment.

title: German Judge Cites Koran, Stirring Up Cultural Storm
description: FRANKFURT, March 22  A German judge has stirred a storm of protest by citing the Koran in turning down a German Muslim womans request for a speedy divorce on the ground that her husband beat her.

title: Motorola Cuts Its Estimate of Earnings
description: The business prospects of Motorola, the 78-year-old technology company, suddenly look as thin as the Razr, its popular mobile phone.

title: Brooklyn: Library Director Appointed
description: The Brooklyn Public Library has a new executive director, Dionne Mack-Harvin, who is the first black woman to run a major public library system in the state, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday. Ms. Mack-Harvin, 34, has been interim executive director since June. She began her career with the Brooklyn system in 1996 as a librarian at the Crown Heights Library and has been a branch manager, regional librarian and chief administrator of the Central Library.

title: Israeli Soldiers Stand Firm, but Duty Wears on the Soul
description: JERUSALEM, March 22  Some of Jerusalems nicest people gathered the other night to listen to a talk by an Israeli soldier troubled by how he and some of his colleagues had behaved in the occupied West Bank.

title: Vanderbilt and Player Each Find New Life
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 22  The day when Davis Nwankwos life ended, then started again, seems to be stuck in everyones memory but his.

title: A 5-Foot-6 Freshman Stands Tall for Oregon
description: ST. LOUIS, March 22  The athletic director of Detroits Renaissance High School, Michael Hunt, recalled when the Michigan coach first saw Tajuan Porter play basketball.

title: Enter Stage Left, With a Ticket
description: IT doesnt always take talent to be on a Broadway stage. Sometimes all you need is $31.50.

title: News Corp. and NBC in Web Deal
description: In a long-anticipated challenge to YouTube and other online video sites, two big media companies yesterday announced a new venture to showcase their own programming across the Internets biggest Web sites, as well as a new jointly owned Web destination.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about violence in Iraq misspelled the surname of an American general who described a car bombing in which he said insurgents had used two children as decoys to deceive soldiers at a Baghdad checkpoint. He is Michael D. Barbero, not Barbaro.

title: Down by 20 Points, Buckeyes Again Fight Back to Win
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 22 - With yet another improbable, scintillating and heart-stopping comeback, the Ohio State Buckeyes are evolving into the Comeback Kids of this N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Grant Holders Must Disclose Financial Ties
description: ALBANY, March 22  All recipients of the state grants known as member items will now be required to disclose any financial connections they have to the lawmakers who arranged them, Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Thursday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about violence in Iraq misspelled the surname of an American general who described a car bombing in which he said insurgents had used two children as decoys to deceive soldiers at a Baghdad checkpoint. He is Michael D. Barbero, not Barbaro. (Go to Article)

title: No Sex, Please, Were French
description: Paris

title: Smith Leaves Kentucky to Rebuild Minnesota
description: Tubby Smith led the University of Kentucky to the N.C.A.A. tournament for 10 consecutive seasons, but the toll of one of college basketballs most demanding jobs appears to have caught up with him.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Onstage Seating
description: For Spring Awakening at the Eugene ONeill Theater, 230 West 49th Street, Manhattan, tickets for 26 onstage seats are sold for each performance, for $31.50, through Telecharge: (212) 239-6200 or telecharge.com.

title: Nascar Finds New Car in a Tunnel
description: As an up-and-coming crew chief in the 1970s, Gary Nelson knew he would have an edge over his Nascar competitors if he could make racecars glide more efficiently through the air. But that was long before stock-car racing became a sport of engineers, and Nelson struggled to come up with a design that would reduce drag. He simply could not see the air.

title: State Takes Control of Troubled Public Schools in St. Louis
description: ST. LOUIS, March 22  The Missouri State Board of Education voted on Thursday to take control of the troubled St. Louis public schools.

title: Former Gonzales Assistant to Testify Thursday
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  D. Kyle Sampson, the former top assistant to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales, has agreed to testify next Thursday before a Senate panel investigating the controversial firings of eight United States attorneys.

title: French Court Rules for Newspaper That Printed Muhammad Cartoons
description: PARIS, March 22  A French court ruled Thursday in favor of a satirical weekly newspaper that faced charges brought by two Muslim groups after it published cartoons featuring the Prophet Muhammad that had caused an international uproar when a Danish newspaper published most of them.

title: Trade Talks Stall Between U.S. and South Korea
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 22  Trade negotiations between the United States and South Korea have failed to narrow gaps on crucial issues like beef imports, leaving them for make-or-break talks next week, officials here said today.

title: Tutus Optional: Related Venues and Schedules
description: Here is a brief rundown of adult ballet classes in New York and their cost. Most schools offer lessons in a range of levels and other forms of movement. It is wise to call and double-check the times and levels available. No reservations are needed. Discounts for multiple lessons generally apply.

title: Defiance in the Pharaohs Valley
description: GURNA, Egypt  The Egyptian authorities have evicted hundreds of peasants from this village in southern Egypt because their mud brick houses, which have sat atop some of the worlds most treasured and ancient tombs for centuries, were leaking sewage onto priceless antiquities.

title: New York to Take Legal Action Over Steering of Students to Lender
description: Andrew M. Cuomo, New Yorks attorney general, announced yesterday that he planned to bring a civil lawsuit against a student lending company for deceptive business practices, accusing it of paying colleges and universities to steer borrowers toward its loans.

title: To Increase Floridas Influence, Lawmakers May Set a January Date for Presidential Primary
description: MIAMI, March 22  Florida could move its presidential primary to as early as Jan. 29  a week before the Super-Duper Tuesday date of Feb. 5 that California set this month and that New York, Texas and a flurry of other states are eying  after the State House of Representatives approved the change this week. Gov. Charlie Crist said Thursday that the State Senate should follow suit.

title: A Relaxed Approach to Life, Up for Sale
description: Im editing, said David Easton, the New York interior designer, with typical understatement. I sold my house a year ago and put everything in a warehouse. Then I thought, Why should all those things sit in a warehouse?  On Wednesday Doyle New York will auction nearly 600 lots of furniture, decorations and paintings from Mr. Eastons former weekend house in Suffern, N.Y.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about possible financial consequences for the Anglican Communion if it severs ties with the Episcopal Church in the United States for consecrating an openly gay bishop misspelled the surname of a priest who said the American church is not a pariah to everybody. She is the Rev. Lisa Fischbeck, not Fishbeck.

title: DNA Match Leads to Arrest in 25-Year-Old Murder Case
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., March 22  On Jan. 31, 1982, her mother found the body of 19-year-old Michele Mika facedown in bed with an eight-inch carving knife stuck in her back. After she was killed, the police had said, Ms. Mika was sexually assaulted for several hours.

title: In a Judges Corruption Trial, Tapes Reveal Tips to a Lawyer
description: Judging from the audiotape, Paul Siminovskys first day as a government informer was fairly productive.

title: Dwight Chamberlain, 68, Expert on Bird Talk, Dies
description: Dwight R. Chamberlain, a naturalist who studied the language of crows and ravens and helped to explain the intricate vocal cues they use in fighting, feeding and social interactions, died on March 10 at his home in Leota, Ind. He was 68.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: Politics, Honor and the Prosecutors (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: L.A. Times Opinion Editor Resigns
description: Andres Martinez, the editorial page editor of The Los Angeles Times, resigned today, saying that he had been undermined by his publisher over what Mr. Martinez described as a perception of a conflict of interest.

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: People
description: People

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: NASA Delays Decision About Next Launch
description: NASA officials have decided to put off until April a final decision about whether to fly the space shuttle with a fuel tank damaged by a hailstorm last month, or to wait for a new tank to be completed and shipped from the manufacturing plant in New Orleans.

title: Borders to Close Many Stores and Start a Retail Web Site
description: The Borders Group, one of the nations largest book retailers, announced a new strategic plan yesterday to close nearly half of its Waldenbooks stores, sell off or franchise most of its 73 overseas superstores, sever its relationship with Amazon.com and start its own online retail site.

title: Los Angeles Times Editorial Page Chief Quits
description: Andrs Martinez, the editorial page editor of The Los Angeles Times, resigned yesterday, saying he had been undermined by his publisher over what Mr. Martinez described as a perception of a conflict of interest.

title: Blackstone Says It Plans to Go Public
description: After a firestorm of speculation, the Blackstone Group, the largest private equity firm in the nation, said yesterday that it would seek an initial public offering that would value the firm at as much as $40 billion and that would offer a first glimpse inside its closely guarded money machine.

title: Els Works at How to Win, Not at How to Come Close
description: MIAMI, March 22  In the three years since Ernie Els last won a PGA Tour event, the foundation of his swing has been twisted and stretched.

title: Iraqi Roused From Sleep Wakes Up to a Nightmare
description: Four years, thousands of dead, dozens of documentaries  that, at least, is one way to tabulate the war in Iraq. It is a war that can seem without answer or end and that, as we enter the fifth year this week, may become among the most documented in history. There are soldier stories, lyrical meditations and wonky exegeses, propagandistic screeds, gonzo entertainments and stirring testimonials. The Prisoner or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair belongs squarely in the first-person subgenre, though its heat-seeking title suggests its makers yearn for something bigger and grander.

title: Doubts Arise on Immigration Bills Chances
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  House lawmakers stood before the television cameras on Thursday and hailed the introduction of a new measure to secure the border and move millions of illegal immigrants toward citizenship.

title: Oracle Says Rival Stole Its Software
description: Oracle sued its rival SAP yesterday, accusing the big German software maker of intruding into its computer systems to carry out corporate theft on a grand scale.

title: After Struggle, Democrats Unite Around Iraq Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The Democrats rode to power last November on the publics discontent with the war in Iraq, but have struggled -- long and hard and often to little effect -- to move beyond opposition to President Bushs policies. Now, by a vote of 218 to 212, they have coalesced around a plan of their own.

title: Maximum Sentence Imposed in Killing of Dancer
description: A man who worked as an actor and yoga teacher convicted of killing a young dancer from Ohio was sentenced today to 25 years to life in prison.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Who Else but an Old Buddy Can Tell How Lost You Are?
description: In Reign Over Me, Don Cheadle plays Alan Johnson, a Manhattan dentist in possession of the usual trappings (at least in movies) of comfort and success: a silver Volvo, a big apartment, a lovely wife (Jada Pinkett Smith), two children and a vague but acute feeling of malaise. Like the investment banker being played by Chris Rock on a nearby screen at the multiplex (in I Think I Love My Wife), Alan is not so much unhappy as bored by his own contentment.

title: Camden: Police Officer Indicted
description: A Camden police officer was indicted yesterday on charges that he conspired to rob a drug dealer, provided a gun for the robbery and agreed to launder the proceeds, state prosecutors said. The officer, Cpl. Michael Anthony Hearne, 42, of Woodbury, was charged with giving a .38-caliber pistol to another man, who he believed was going to commit the robbery, said Attorney General Stuart Rabner. Corporal Hearne was arrested at the Super 8 Motel in Bellmawr on Nov. 10, 2006, as he went to meet with the second man, the state police said, and was suspended. Corporal Hearnes lawyer did not return a telephone call yesterday afternoon.

title: Jersey City: Arrests in Bodega Killing
description: Two men have been arrested and charged with killing a bodega owner during a robbery five months ago, Hudson County officials said. Fidelina A. Claros, 47, the owner of the G & P deli and grocery, was shot twice in the head and once in the back during the robbery, on Oct. 30, prosecutors said. The men, Richard Salcedo, 25 and Antwan Shannon, 41, both of Jersey City, were charged with murder, said Hudson County Prosecutor Edward J. De Fazio.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Lands You Cant See in a Guidebook
description: Can a South American Indian landscape painter find inspiration in Brooklyn? In a word, yes. Carlos Jacanamijoy (of the Inga people of Colombia) has no trouble making a connection between the urban jungle where he lives now and the Putumayo rain forest on whose edge he grew up. Here, the roar of the subway or the incessant traffic of cars and pedestrians on the Brooklyn Bridge, projected by the sun, is right in front of me, through my window, he writes. In the same way I remember listening, among lights and shadows, to the cacophony of animals during an overwhelming night in the middle of the jungle.

title: Wildhorse Meadows and Meriwether Ranch
description: Wildhorse Meadows

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Advertising Council, New York, promoted an executive and hired another. George Perlov, senior vice president for planning, research and foundation relations, becomes executive vice president for research and innovation. Also, Alberto G. Rojas joined as corporate communications director, leading efforts to reach out to Spanish-speaking consumers for the national public-service campaigns from the council. Mr. Rojas had been client services director at the New York office of the Jeffrey Group.

title: Senate Questioning on Mortgages Puts Regulators on the Defensive
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  Democratic and Republican senators criticized banking regulators on Thursday for failing to respond more quickly to curb the growth in risky home loans to people with weak credit.

title: A Nanny Who Can Be Murder at the Piano
description: The pretty young blonde in the taut French film The Page Turner wears a ponytail that hangs down her back like a dagger. Shes a quiet one, this girl, with a small, enigmatic smile and no evident inner life. When we first meet her shes about 10 and playing an upright piano in her familys living room. Her hands attack the keys with force, as if she were stabbing rather than tickling the keys. In case we missed the point of this violence, and, really, there is only one point to be had in this film, the director Denis Dercourt keeps cutting between the girl and a man rapidly hacking away at a large slab of beef with a knife.

title: Class-Action Status Is Denied to Katrina Suits in Mississippi
description: A federal district judge in Mississippi refused yesterday to give class-action status to lawsuits filed by homeowners suing State Farm Insurance for denying claims along the Gulf of Mexico after Hurricane Katrina.

title: After Scare, a Sigh of Relief for Snchez
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 22  Within a 90-minute span, the emotions surrounding Duaner Snchezs return to the mound ranged from celebration to anxiety to relief. The pop that Snchez said he felt in his surgically repaired right shoulder during his first mound session in nearly eight months Thursday morning was merely caused by scar tissue that had broken free.

title: Letter From California: A Hidden Populace in a Vacant Lot
description: I have been wondering about a restaurant here. Do locals call it Donut & Burger or the Donut & Burger? Maybe its simply D. & B. to the morning rush-hour drivers idling in the drive-through lane or the kids crowding the walk-up window in the last few minutes before school starts. The rest of the day Donut & Burger is a lonely place, a squat, stand-alone cube of a building with a tattered awning. Not all the food it serves is circular. You can get fries. You can get fries with your cinnamon roll if you want. Most people, I suppose, order either the doughnut or the burger. But I felt I had to order the doughnut and the burger. It was the eponymous thing to do, and I knew I would be doing it only once.

title: Gaza Strip: Palestinian Killed in Internal Clash
description: A Palestinian was killed in Gaza City when members of his family, associated with Fatah, clashed with Hamass Executive Force. Earlier, gunmen forced out the driver of a United Nations refugee agency car and made off with the vehicle. The driver, a local employee, was unharmed. A United Nations spokesman said agency cars would temporarily stay off Gazas roads.

title: The Player Who Played as Kubrick
description: Even if it doesnt add up to more than a fitfully amusing collection of comic sketches, Color Me Kubrick  a fictional portrait of Alan Conway, a real-life British con man who hustled his way across England by impersonating the reclusive, seldom-photographed filmmaker Stanley Kubrick  is a platform for John Malkovich to burst into lurid purple flame.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the Sothebys auction of antiquities from the collection of the Albright-Knox Art Gallery in Buffalo misstated Sothebys commission on objects sold. It is 20 percent of the hammer price for the first $500,000 and 12 percent of the rest  not 20 percent of the first $200,000 and 12 percent of the rest. (The commission was raised in January.)

title: In Secret, Polygamy Follows Africans to N.Y.
description: She worked at the Red Lobster in Times Square and lived with her husband near Yankee Stadium. Yet one night, returning home from her job, Odine D. discovered that African custom, not American law, held sway over her marriage.

title: Colombia: A Challenge to Banana Tariff
description: Colombia, the worlds third-biggest banana shipper, filed a new complaint with the World Trade Organization against European rules that it said discriminated against banana exports. The trade organization first ruled against Europe in September 1997, backing claims brought by Ecuador, the United States, Guatemala, Honduras and Mexico almost two years earlier. The new request starts a fresh challenge to a tariff of 176 euros ($234) per metric ton.

title: U.N. Chief Undeterred by Attack in Iraq
description: CAIRO, March 23  United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said here today that a mortar round that struck close by him in Baghdad on Thursday surprised and scared him, but would not deter him from expanding the United Nations presence in Iraq.

title: Diagnosis as Art, Not Rocket Science
description: Every patient knows the feeling, that lurching sense of dread after the doctor has finished poking and prodding, or scanning the latest test results, and momentarily sinks into thought. Its a taut, suspenseful moment. What exactly is going on in that highly trained medical brain?

title: Wyoming: A Comeback Worthy of a Grizzly Bear
description: Yellowstone Park grizzly bears have rebounded so successfully that they have been removed from the endangered species list, the federal Fish and Wildlife Service said. From the bears perspective, the move means little, said Chris Servheen, a wildlife biologist with the service. Mr. Servheen said the population of bears, which had been listed as threatened, would be monitored under a conservation agreement involving Wyoming, Montana, Idaho and a group of federal wildlife and natural resource agencies. The service said there were only about 300 or fewer bears in the park when they were listed as threatened in 1975; today, they number at least 500.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about a vote authorizing a strike by the faculty of California State University gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the surname of a university spokeswoman who said she does not foresee a shutdown of the university. She is Clara Potes-Fellow, not Portes-Fellow.

title: Europe Approves Trans-Atlantic Air Pact
description: BRUSSELS, March 22  European Union transportation ministers approved a deal with the United States on Thursday to open the $18 billion trans-Atlantic aviation market to greater competition, hoping to encourage growth and lower air fares.

title: U.C.L.A. Proves Too Much for Pitt
description: SAN JOSE, March 23  As if the N.C.A.A. selection committee did not yank enough heartstrings putting U.C.L.A. in the same region as Pittsburgh, tournament organizers assigned the teams to locker rooms right across the hall from each other.

title: Jamaican Police Say Pakistan Cricket Coach Was Strangled
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 22  The Jamaican police said Thursday that the coach of Pakistans cricket team, who was found dead in his hotel room on Sunday after his team lost a critical match in the sports World Cup here, had been strangled.

title: Army Revises Upward Number of Desertions in 06
description: A total of 3,196 active-duty soldiers deserted the Army last year, or 853 more than previously reported, according to revised figures from the Army.

title: California: The Land of Milk and Megadairies
description: The Tulare County Board of Supervisors approved a plan Tuesday for two 160-acre megadairies to be built across from Colonel Allensworth State Historic Park, a site dedicated to the history of Californias first and only black planned community. The county approved the proposal by a local rancher to establish two dairies with some 16,000 cows near the park, in a remote corner of the Central Valley. Citizens, including some from the original Allensworth Colony, and environmentalists have protested the plan.

title: An Earlier Marriage for Giulianis Wife
description: Judith Nathan had been married twice, and not once as generally believed, before she wed Rudolph W. Giuliani in 2003, aides on the Giuliani presidential campaign said last night.

title: Court Rejects Law Limiting Online Pornography
description: A federal judge in Philadelphia yesterday struck down a 1998 law that made it a crime for Web sites to allow children to gain access to material deemed harmful.

title: See You at the Barre
description: PAIN flashed through my thigh when the teacher told us to lift a leg onto the barre and bend over it. Franois, my neighbor, suggested I align my chest straight over the leg, rather than torquing my body into a pretzel.

title: Foiled by the Gun Lobby
description: In a sleazy political stroke, Republicans played the gun lobbys card yesterday as the House was on the verge of redressing one of the longest-running injustices of American democracy: the denial of a Congressional vote to the taxpayers of the District of Columbia. The historic proposal for full representation in the House was derailed by a G.O.P. motion to attach a ban on Washingtons legitimate attempts to outlaw firearms in the city limits. Democratic leaders had to retract the bill and promise to prevail later without such a poison pill.

title: Japan: Minister Critical of Blond Envoys
description: Foreign Minister Taro Aso said yellow-faced Japanese could play a more constructive role in Middle East diplomacy than Americans. Japan is doing what Americans cant do, he said, according to the newspaper Nikkei. Japanese are trusted. If you have blue eyes and blond hair, its probably no good. Mr. Aso is often mentioned as a successor to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe.

title: Times Company Will Increase Dividend on Its Stock by 31%
description: The New York Times Company, under pressure from investors because of its stagnant stock performance, announced yesterday that it would raise its quarterly dividend by 31 percent.

title: Iraqi Official Wounded in Suicide Attack
description: Deputy Prime Minister Salam al-Zubai was wounded today when a suicide bomber blew himself up inside a hall behind Mr. Zubais house, where the deputy prime minister was attending Friday prayers.

title: Where Heart of Darkness Begets Head of Nuttiness
description: Werner Herzogs great subject, or rather his dominant preoccupation  what paranoia was to Alfred Hitchcock or violence to Sam Peckinpah  is mania. The characters in his most memorable films are men who live in a permanent, irrational state of war with themselves, with the rest of humanity, with the wild inscrutability of the natural world. They are loners, conquerors, obsessives. In his recent documentaries, notably Grizzly Man and The White Diamond, Mr. Herzog observes them with rueful philosophical detachment. There was a time, though, when the grandeur and ferocity of his cinematic ambition marked him as a kindred spirit.

title: When Cricket Turns to Murder in Sunny Jamaica
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 23  Cricket, especially that rambunctious form of the sport practiced in the Caribbean, has always been about far more than the ball and the sticks and the men dressed in white standing out in the sun.

title: Corzine Should Detail Gifts To Labor Chief, a Lawyer Says
description: Nearly three weeks after Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey acknowledged that he had given more gifts to a former companion  and prominent state labor leader  than previously disclosed, a public-interest lawyer demanded yesterday that he provide details of those gifts.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A sports article on Monday about Connecticuts victory over Maryland-Baltimore County in the opening round of the N.C.A.A. womens basketball tournament misstated the year UConn last won the national championship. It was 2004, not 2003.

title: Load Up. Remove Clothes. Then Try Not to Lose Head.
description: Muscles bulge and heads explode in Shooter, a thoroughly reprehensible, satisfyingly violent entertainment about men and guns and things that go boom (heads, mostly). Did I mention the exploding heads? It is an admittedly primitive pleasure, but I do love watching stuff blow up in movies (heads, not so much). There is something unaccountably gratifying, at times reassuring about watching the screen  the bigger the better  become engulfed by surging waves of liquid orange, in the image of a car exploding into the air like a rocket, in a room, a building, a boat, a truck, you name it, shattering into confetti.

title: Illinois: Hiring Inquiry Brings New Indictment
description: The former head of Chicagos largest municipal department, who was also a top official with a powerful citywide political campaign organization, was indicted on nine counts of mail fraud. The charges, announced by Patrick J. Fitzgerald, the local United States attorney, are the latest in a continuing federal investigation of fraudulent Chicago hiring and promotion practices that has resulted in 44 convictions since early 2004. The indictment alleges that the official, Alfred Sanchez, commissioner of the Streets and Sanitation Department until 2005 and a leader with the Hispanic Democratic Organization, engaged in a scheme from 1994 to 2005 to provide city jobs, promotions and other employment benefits to induce and reward political campaign work. Mr. Sanchez, 59, is the 47th person to be charged in the investigation.

title: U.S. General Strengthens Military Ties in Beijing
description: BEIJING, Mar. 23  Chinas recent test of an anti-satellite weapon sent a confusing message to the world about its military intentions, but the United States and China are slowly building stronger military-to-military ties anyway, the top-ranking United States military officer said today.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: MIDNIGHT (HBO) RUSSELL SIMMONS PRESENTS DEF POETRY  The sixth season of rhymes from the Supper Club in New York wraps up with performances by Black Ice, Georgia Me, Suheir Hammad and Nelly Furtado. Mos Def, left, is the host.

title: Theyre Looking for a Few Good Coal Miners
description: YOU load 16 tons, and what do you get? How about a paycheck, vacations, a dental plan and a 401(k)?

title: Elvish Impersonators
description: DESPITE the growth in the ranks of J .R .R. Tolkien enthusiasts since the Lord of the Rings films put his fantasy world of Middle-earth on screen, Tolkiens most avid admirers still risk being labeled geeks. But wearing elf ears or not, they are a force to be reckoned with.

title: China Ends North Korea Talks Amid Delay in Return of Funds
description: BEIJING, March 22  Talks here aimed at dismantling North Koreas nuclear weapons program were halted by China late Thursday after they stalled over the failure to release from a Macao bank up to $25 million that North Korea had demanded be returned before it continued negotiations.

title: As U.N. Chief Meets Premier of Iraq, the Zone Is Shelled
description: BAGHDAD, Friday, March 23  A mortar shell fired into the heavily fortified Green Zone landed about 80 yards from the home of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki on Thursday while he and the United Nations secretary general, Ban Ki-moon, were holding a news conference to mark Mr. Bans first visit to Baghdad.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: A Wasteful Society (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: No Second Term for Trade Negotiator
description: Peter Mandelson, the European Unions top trade negotiator, said he would not seek a second term after his current tenure ends in 2009. As European trade chief, Mr. Mandelson has been coordinating the blocs strategy in World Trade Organization talks and defending Airbus in a dispute with the United States government and the Boeing Company. He has held the post since November 2004 and said he would not leave before his term expires in November 2009.

title: France: Government Opens U.F.O. Files
description: The National Center for Space Research opened its files on U.F.O.s, putting them on a Web site that was quickly jammed by heavy traffic. The archive, at www.cnes-geipan.fr/geipan/, spans 50 years.

title: New to Job, Gates Argued for Closing Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  In his first weeks as defense secretary, Robert M. Gates repeatedly argued that the detention facility at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, had become so tainted abroad that legal proceedings at Guantnamo would be viewed as illegitimate, according to senior administration officials. He told President Bush and others that it should be shut down as quickly as possible.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Foreclosures Force Suburbs to Fight Blight
description: SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio  In a sign of the spreading economic fallout of mortgage foreclosures, several suburbs of Cleveland, one of the nations hardest-hit cities, are spending millions of dollars to maintain vacant houses as they try to contain blight and real-estate panic.

title: I Dont Expect My Life to Be Significantly Different, She Says
description: Elizabeth Edwards received the news this week that every woman who has had breast cancer fears, that the disease has come back after treatment and begun to spread.

title: A Different Kind of Gay Marriage Debate
description: EDISON, N.J., March 21  At first blush, the wedding show at the New Jersey Convention and Expo Center seemed pretty straight. Exhibitors as mainstream as Macys, Fortunoffs and Hilton presented place settings and room rates. Chocolate-covered strawberries were free for the taking. A video about a nice couple named Michelle and Dan played near nuptial portraits of happy heterosexuals.

title: Boy Recalls Frightening Details of a Shooting at a Queens Deli
description: In the instant before the gunman started shooting, the boy thought he was just another customer barreling through the delis front door. But then the boy saw the mans eyes, wild behind a black ski mask. And he saw the gun in the mans hand.

title: California: Marijuana Card Ruling
description: An appeals court ruled that Californias medical marijuana law does not automatically shield patients from searches by law enforcement. The unanimous ruling by a three-judge panel of the State Court of Appeal said a Napa County sheriffs deputy had probable cause to search the vehicle of Gabriel Strasburg, who claimed to have a medical marijuana card, in October 2005. The law limits patient possession to eight ounces. The deputy claimed Mr. Strasburg had about 23 ounces and a scale and was smoking in a parked car. Mr. Strasburg pleaded no contest to misdemeanor possession but appealed, claiming an unlawful search. In the decision, Justice James Marchiano said the amount of marijuana found in the search left a strong suggestion that Mr. Strasburg was using the act as a faade to conceal illegal activity.

title: A Test for Congress on the War (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Communists in America (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Window Box Gets Some Tough Competition
description: CARMEL VALLEY, Calif.  It is the green season, when the rains give way to a landscape of renewal, and gardeners clutching copies of Sunset magazines Western Garden Book emerge exultantly from their winter dens.

title: Rat Poison Found in Tainted Pet Food
description: A toxic chemical used in some countries as a rat poison has been found in tainted pet food that has been linked to the deaths of at least 14 pets, the New York State Departmention Agriculture announced today.

title: In Surge in Manhattan Toddlers, Rich White Families Lead Way
description: Manhattan, which once epitomized the glamorous and largely childless locale for Sex and the City, has begun to look more like the set for a decidedly upscale and even more vanilla version of 1960s suburbia in The Wonder Years.

title: Ski Resort Chic in the Mountains of Quebec
description: TUCKED into the Laurentian Mountains less than 80 miles north of Montreal, Mont Tremblant is a stunning Quebec ski town perched at the southern tip of Lake Tremblant. It somehow manages to blend the kitsch of a Disney-like ski resort, the elegance of a small cosmopolitan city and the serenity of fir-and-pine-covered mountains.

title: Welcome Inside the Factory Where TV Is Made and Sold
description: VH1s Acceptable TV allows viewers to play television executive, and if that sounds boring and overthought  well, thats the gag. Television people have been busting their old-fashioned Hollywood-trained brains over how to induce Internet-obsessed viewers to text in, vote on content and make videos of their own.

title: Indias Banks Are Seen as Antiquated and Unproductive
description: NEW DELHI, March 21  Hundreds of bank branches can be found in Indias capital nestled behind metal grates in concrete buildings and tucked down alleyways off busy thoroughfares. Many of the offices are jockeying for attention with battered signs and offers of high rates for deposits and low-rate loans.

title: New Coin of the Realm
description: President Hugo Chvez of Venezuela had an especially good time baiting President Bush during their recent competing tours of Latin America. But demagoguery and showmanship will do nothing to solve Venezuelas 20 percent inflation rate  now the highest in Latin America  and growing food shortages that are punishing the poor whose interests Mr. Chvez so loudly declaims.

title: ConAgra Reports a Profit
description: ConAgra, the maker of Slim Jim meat snacks and Chef Boyardee pasta, reported a third-quarter profit yesterday as earnings from trading commodities overcame the cost to recall its Peter Pan peanut butter last month.

title: Our Cricket Problem
description: LAST week, the greatest sporting event of the year in terms of audience began in Jamaica, when the West Indies beat Pakistan in the inaugural match of the 2007 Cricket World Cup. A six-week extravaganza follows  51 matches that are being monitored with nail-biting excitement around the world. The final, on Saturday, April 28, will take place in Barbados, but friends of mine in New York are already planning a World Cup party at the home of an expatriate with a satellite dish. The party will be attended by a raucous group of Indians and Pakistanis, Bangladeshis and Brits, Australians and Zimbabweans. But of course there will be no Americans.

title: Culture of Intoxication and a Victim
description: Cliffside Park, N.J.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about appeals filed by companies that lost out in bidding for casino licenses in Pennsylvania misstated the number of slots-only casinos that are operating in the state. It is four, not three. (In addition to those in Wilkes-Barre, Bensalem and Chester, one is operating in Erie.)

title: Abdullahs Chance
description: Is Saudi Arabia becoming the new Egypt?

title: Democrats Shore Up Support for Iraq Votes
description: WASHINGTON, March 22  For days, Democratic leaders have scrambled to shore up enough support to pass their Iraq legislation. They delayed the final vote by a day, fearful that a few undecided lawmakers  on the left and right  could jeopardize their plan to set a timeline to bring troops home from Iraq by Sept. 1, 2008.

title: Fuzzy Madness: Mascots Gone Wild
description: During the first round of the N.C.A.A. tournament last weekend, John Goodman  a freshman who wears a steer costume to cheer for the Texas Longhorns  did what comes naturally to mascots: He patted a referee on the back.

title: When a Bird Sings an Aria, Youd Be Wise to Duck
description: Philip Glass writes so many operas for so many companies that it sometimes takes years for his works to find their way to New York. The Juniper Tree didnt have far to travel: Its premiere was at the American Repertory Theater, in Cambridge, Mass. But that was in 1985, and it took until Tuesday evening for this chamber opera to have a New York performance: an unstaged concert version at Alice Tully Hall by the Collegiate Chorale, with help from the Orchestra of St. Lukes and Michael Riesman, Mr. Glasss house conductor.

title: Times Company Plans to Increase Its Dividend
description: The New York Times Company, under pressure from investors because of its stagnant stock performance, announced today that it would raise its quarterly dividend by 31 percent.

title: Tanya Reinhart, 63, Pundit on Israeli-Palestinian Conflict, Dies
description: Tanya Reinhart, an Israeli linguist best known to the public as an ardent critic of her countrys policies toward the Palestinians, died on Saturday while vacationing in Montauk, N.Y. She was 63.

title: Asia Week Axiom: The Only Constant Is Change
description: All things must change, the Tao tells us. New York Citys Asia Week is not exempt. When this early spring week of sales and shows was officially begun a dozen years ago, a brand-new International Asian Art Fair was its centerpiece. Installed at the Seventh Regiment Armory, it was a charismatic event.

title: Reclaiming Homes, Iraqis Find Peril
description: BAGHDAD, March 22  When Hazim Said and his family returned to their house in southwestern Baghdad on March 1, two months after fleeing a murder and intimidation campaign by Sunni Arab insurgents, Mr. Saids wife and two sons collapsed to the floor in tears of joy and kissed the walls.

title: Harold I. Lief, Advocate of Sex Education, Dies at 89
description: Dr. Harold I. Lief, a leading sex therapist who was an early advocate of having medical schools put greater emphasis on sex education in training doctors, died on March 15 at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa. He was 89.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture with a report in the Arts, Briefly column on Wednesday about the winners of the 2007 Martin E. Segal awards, which recognize outstanding achievement by young artists, carried an erroneous credit, and a credit was omitted from another picture with the report. The photograph of the Daedalus Quartet was by Steve J. Sherman  not by Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times. Mr. Ito took the picture of the mezzo-soprano Kate Lindsey.

title: An Immigrant Segment by Radios Jersey Guys Draws Fire
description: NEWARK, March 22  Craig Carton and Ray Rossi think mental illness is hilarious and Asian-Americans are best mocked with sing-song Chinese accents. The men, hosts of an afternoon radio show called The Jersey Guys that is heard here on WKXW (101.5 FM), favor adjectives for politicians that have to be bleeped out.

title: Marco Polo Manuscript Featured at New Exhibition
description: The first image visitors will see in Venice and the Islamic World, 828-1797, which opens Tuesday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is an illuminated manuscript in French that charts Marco Polos departure for Asia. Dressed in pale pink merchant garb, he is shown leading a group of dignitaries toward the docks along the Riva degli Schiavoni in Venice. The manuscript also depicts a birds-eye view of the city, including many landmarks: the Piazza San Marco with St. Marks Basilica and its four bronze horses and the Doges Palace.

title: For AT&Ts Chief, a 94% Increase in Pay
description: AT&T had a good year in 2006. Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the longtime telecommunications executive who shepherded the company through the 2005 merger with SBC Communications, had an outstanding one.

title: In Some States, Maker Oversees Use of Its Drug
description: Many states, looking to rein in the cost of expensive antipsychotic drugs like Zyprexa, have turned to an unusual ally for help  the very company that sells the drug.

title: Numbers Only Tell Part of the Story for Pavano
description: SARASOTA, Fla., March 22  The catcher sees the whole field, which was useful for Jorge Posada in the bottom of the fifth inning Thursday at Ed Smith Stadium. Posada, the Yankees catcher, looked to the mound and thought he saw a cluster of bubbles. Only bubbles do not buzz.

title: As Cellphone Industry Shifts, Motorola Needs a Quick Fix and a Long-Term Plan
description: Edward J. Zander, the chairman and chief executive of Motorola, generally has little in common with Hollywoods studio chiefs. But like them, his future may depend, at least in the short term, on whether he can produce another hit.

title: Edwards Says Wifes Cancer Has Returned
description: CHAPEL HILL, N.C., March 22  John Edwards, the North Carolina Democrat, said Thursday that his wifes cancer had returned in incurable form. He proclaimed that he would continue his bid for the presidency, saying, The campaign goes on strongly.

title: Braves Cast a Wide Net in Finding a Franchise Voice
description: ATLANTA, March 22  This was different than pointing two Yamaha speakers out the window of a small press box to announce a pee-wee football game.

title: A Pianist Displays the Form of a Winner
description: Zankel Hall was packed on Wednesday night with concertgoers curious to hear the New York recital debut of the $300,000 pianist. That is, Ingrid Fliter, who last year became the fifth winner of the prestigious Gilmore Artist Award. She is also the first woman to win.

title: Walking Out to Sea
description: WHO Angela Williams, 41, a real estate broker in Atlanta

title: As Big Company Sells Resorts, Hopes Rise for a Northeast Revival
description: THE Northeastern ski season is on the wane, and so is the American Skiing Companys grip on the regions ski industry. After a decade of dominance in the Northeast through its ownership of several large ski resorts, the company has recently announced a series of sales that will shed at least five properties  including Killington, one of the regions best known.

title: The Logic and the Timing of Taking Blackstone Public
description: WALL STREET knows how to keep score. Its called money.

title: Alec Wyton, 85, Organist Who Updated Church Music, Is Dead
description: Alec Wyton, an English-born organist, composer and teacher who brought contemporary influence to American church music over decades, two of them as organist and choirmaster at the Cathedral Church of St. John the Divine in Manhattan, died on Sunday in Danbury, Conn. He was 85.

title: Manhattan: Contractor Barred From City Work
description: A contracting company that worked for the citys Department of Housing Preservation and Development has been barred from performing work for the city and state for five years after city investigators found it had not paid required wages, the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., said yesterday. Mr. Thompson said a city administrative law judge determined that the company, Integrity Construction and Consulting Services, of Queens, had underpaid four carpenters, two laborers and a bricklayer who worked on a renovation of 536-38 West 163rd Street, by a total of $189,633.22.

title: Bishops Denounce Writings of a Catholic Theologian
description: In a rare step, Roman Catholic bishops in the United States have declared as false teaching two pamphlets by a Catholic theologian who argues that abortion, contraception and same-sex marriage are morally permissible under Catholic doctrine.

title: New Jersey Man Who Fled Somalia Ends Up in an Ethiopian Jail
description: LONDON, March 22  A 24-year old American who told the F.B.I. that he went to Somalia last December to help build an Islamic state there is now being held in an Ethiopian prison, where he was sent after being detained in Kenya.

title: They Are Artists Who Are Women; Hear Them Roar
description: The combination of the Global Feminisms exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum and its Elizabeth A. Sackler Center for Feminist Art, whose inauguration this show celebrates, is like a false idea wrapped in confusion.

title: British Police Arrest 3 in 2005 Bombings
description: LONDON, March 22  The British counterterrorism police seized three men on Thursday for offenses related to the bombings in the London transit system on July 7, 2005, in which four suicide bombers killed themselves and 52 passengers.

title: Bill Clinton Raises $70,000 Without Breaking a Sweat
description: The primping before political fund-raisers can go something like this: a trip to the hairstylist, perhaps a new dress or pumps, certainly a pressed suit, some well-applied makeup, a snack to absorb the white wine and a hired car or cab at the appointed hour.

title: Prosecutors Failed to Warn Judge of Threats to Victim
description: Prosecutors in Brooklyn failed to warn a judge about threats against a 20-year-old woman in a rape case who was later killed, the Brooklyn district attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said yesterday. He characterized the omission as an honest mistake.

title: Related Events and Venues
description: Here is information about the fairs and shows in this article:

title: The Hudson on Moscow
description: The citys tourism agency opened an office in Moscow yesterday, officials said. The office of the agency, NYC & Company, is among 11 recently opened overseas by New York City. The agency said New York is a top destination for Russian visitors to the United States and that about 46,000 Russians visited the city last year, an increase of 24.3 percent over the previous year.

title: Building Blocks
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Bracket Havoc
description: One of the distinct pleasures of covering the N.C.A.A. Tournament is being able to watch your bracket crumble right before your eyes. Thats pretty much what happened in San Antonio tonight, as two one-point games put a distinct stench in the The Brackets bracket. Id picked both Tennessee and Texas A&M to reach the Regional Final here in the South. Both were logical picks that seemed quite realistic, even in the waning minutes.

title: Taking It on the Chin
description: After his teams miraculous 85-84 comeback victory over fifth-seeded Tennessee on Thursday night, the Ohio State freshman center Greg Oden received several stitches in his chin.

title: Macao's Gambling Tycoons
description: Stanley Hos casino empire in Macao is under assault from a group of ambitious Las Vegas tycoons.

title: A Dwindling Breed
description: A Paul Rudolph architectural road trip to Tracey Towers, in the Bronx, as well as buildings in Middletown, N.Y., New Haven, Conn., and South Dartmouth, Mass.

title: On the Market
A Look Back
description: Images from "Facing Fascism: New York and the Spanish Civil War."

title: Under Pressure, Times Co. to Increase Dividend
description: The New York Times Company, under pressure from investors because of its stagnant stock performance, announced Thursday that it would raise its quarterly dividend by 31 percent. The new dividend  23 cents a share a quarter, up from 17.5 cents  is payable on June 13 to shareholders of record on June 1.

title: Indias Banks Are Seen as Antiquated and Unproductive
description: Indias drive to become a global economic powerhouse faces a huge roadblock in its inefficient, largely state-controlled financial system, The New York Times reports. Two-thirds of Indias banking business is conducted through less than 5 percent of its branches, and its growing corporate sector has headed overseas for financial advice and loans.

title: Surging Real Estate Values Put Giant French Retailer in Play
description: The New York Times takes a look at how Carrefour, the worlds second-largest retailer, was put into play. Last month, the American real estate investment firm Colony Capital and the richest man in France, Bernard Arnault, announced that they had acquired nearly 10 percent of Carrefours shares and hoped to translate that value into a fat capital gain.

title: Simply stunning
description: Chalet interior Alpine chimney

title: Oracle Says SAP Stole Its Software
description: The ferocious and long-running battle between Oracle and its German rival, SAP, for pole position in the business software industry took a turn for the courthouse Thursday. Oracle sued SAP accusing the worlds No.1 business software maker of intruding into its computer systems to carry out corporate theft on a grand scale.

title: Qwest Gave Chief a Raise Despite Cloud, Witness Says
description: A former director of Qwest Communications testified Thursday that the board had agreed to give Joseph P. Nacchio, then its chief executive, a raise and 7.25 million shares in stock options about a month after the phone company acknowledged for the first time that it had used one-time transactions to help meet financial targets.

title: Government Witness Testifies in Black Case
description: Jurors at Conrad M. Blacks trial were told on Thursday that a major investor in Mr. Blacks giant media company blew the whistle on fees and perks that he and his lieutenants were collecting and that Mr. Black was out of a job not long after that.

title: Acquisition Price for Insurer Rises
description: The insurance broker Hub International said Thursday that its recently announced agreement to be acquired has been amended to increase the purchase price for each share to $41.50, from $40. In February, Hub said it would be acquired by the private equity firm Apax Partners, together with Morgan Stanley Principal Investments, for about $1.7 billion. The increase in consideration followed competing proposals, the company said in a statement.

title: Carlyle Said to Raise $15 Billion Buyout Fund
description: Carlyle Group, the Washington-based private equity giant, is putting together a $15 billion fund for buyouts in the United States, which would be nearly twice the size of its previous fund, Reuters reported, citing undisclosed sources.

title: Palm Sinks as No Bid Emerges
description: Palm shares took a beating Thursday when a much-anticipated bid from Motorola failed to materialize. Palm shares lost nearly 9 percent after traders interpreted Motorolas silence on the subject as evidence that it wont be acquiring Palm.

title: Vertrue Agrees to $800 Million Buyout
description: Internet marketer Vertrue, which runs the online matchmaking service LavaLife, agreed to be acquired by a trio of investment firms and its senior managers for $48.50 a share in cash, or about $800 million including debt. J.P. Morgans private equity arm One Equity Partners, venture capital firm Oak Investment Partners, and Rho Ventures, a venture investor, along with managers led by Vertrue chief executive and co-founder Gary Johnson, will invest an undisclosed amount of equity in the deal, which is slated to close by Sept. 30.

title: Oodle Gets New Round
description: Classified advertising web site Oodle, founded by three former Excite.com employees, said Wednesday it raised $11 million in venture funding. The company collects classified ads from different sources and lets users search them on its site. Jafco Ventures, a new investor, led the round. Greylock Partners and Redpoint Ventures, both of which gave money in the companys previous funding round, also contributed to the new round.

title: Take-Two Activists Get Proxy-Firm Support
description: With a shareholder showdown looming at Take-Two Interactive Software, two proxy advisories are placing good odds on an investor groups move to take control of the beleaguered video game publisher.

title: Eisai Buys Morphotek to Build Drug Pipeline
description: Japanese pharmaceutical titan Eisai said Thursday it will bulk up its cancer drug pipeline with a deal to buy Morphotek for $325 million. The move will expand Eisais presence in the United States. It will also bring the traditional pharmaceutical company deeper into the biologic therapeutics field, where products are generally made using living cells. Venture-capital backed Morphotek develops monoclonal antibodies for the treatment of cancer, inflammation, and infectious diseases.

title: Please Keep Writing. We Need Help.
description: It always makes us happy to know that you are reading along as we stumble forward in our quest to build our dream home.

title: Key Qantas Shareholder Rejects Buyout Bid
description: One of Qantas Airways largest shareholders has rejected a Macquarie Bank-led A$11.1 billion ($9 billion) buyout of the Australian carrier, threatening the worlds biggest airline takeover.

title: Living in Lake Geneva
description: This picturesque Wisconsin vacation enclave is known as the Hamptons of the Midwest.

title: Limelight Networks Plans $200 Million I.P.O.
description: Limelight Networks, a digital-content delivery provider backed by Goldman Sachss private equity arm, filed to raise as much as $201 million in an initial public offering of stock. In July, Goldman Sachs Capital Partners led a $130 million funding round for Limelight, whose network helps media companies to distribute video, music, games and downloads over the Internet.

title: Citigroup to Hang Commercial Shingle in London
description: Citigroup is setting up a global commercial banking operation in London that will push into medium-sized corporate lending in Britain and Germany. The move is part of a broader restructuring of Citigroups corporate bank that reflects the efforts of the banks chief executive, Charles O. Prince III, to boost organic growth while streamlining the organization.

title: G.E. Wins Over Sanyo Electric Credit
description: After several rounds of negotiations, General Electric said Friday that it will buy Sanyo Electric Credit, the financing affiliate of struggling electronics maker Sanyo, in a transaction that could top out at 135 billion yen ($1.14 billion). In a statement Friday, Tokyo-listed Sanyo Electric Credit said the company had agreed to a tender offer from General Electric under which the U.S. conglomerate will pay 3,250 yen ($27.51) per share, a premium of nearly 62 percent from the closing price of 2,010 yen ($17.02) on Friday.

title: Enel and Acciona in Talks on Endesa Bid
description: Enel, the Italian utility, and Acciona, the Spanish construction and energy group, confirmed on Friday that they were in talks about launching a joint bid for Endesa, the Spanish electricity group, that is currently the subject of an offer from Eon of Germany.

title: The News in Quotes: Complications Ensue
description: An Endless Election: Im not sure why this has been so complicated.  Dr. Mathieu Eugene, who is running again in a special election in the 40th Council District (the second of four elections this year in the district).

title: Will Citi Crash the ABN Amro-Barclays Party?
description: Though Barclays negotiations with Dutch rival ABN Amro are exclusive right now, another bidder may want to bust in. Executives within Citigroup are pushing for the American banking giant to make its own bid for ABN Amro, the Wall Street Journal reported on Friday. Citigroup, itself the product of a series of mergers, is studying the possibility of an unsolicited bid, the paper said citing unnamed sources.

title: Morgan Stanley Revamps Sales and Trading
description: One day after announcing record earnings, Morgan Stanley on Thursday a reorganization of its securities sales and trading businesses that would eliminate the traditional equities and fixed income divisions. The move will also give more autonomy to the European and Asian regions, both of which are generating increasing portions of the firms profits.

title: Clear Channel Shareholder Plans to Reject Buyout Offer
description: In a blow for the Mays family, one of Clear Channel Communications largest shareholders said Thursday that it planned on voting against a proposed $18.7 billion management buyout. Highfields Capital Management, which owns roughly 5 percent of the radio giant, said the $37.60-a-share offer was too low.

title: A Stars Emotional Range
description: Greg Oden, who went through puberty as an embryo, will be one of the top two players selected in the N.B.A. draft. At 19, he is already his own conglomerate, which is impressive considering he plays for free. He was actually invited to play on the United States national team last year with LeBron James, Carmelo Anthony and Amare Stoudemire even though hed never played a game at a competitive level above high school. (This put him at the same level, at the time, as me.) His legend is such already that professional basketball franchises major corporations with hundreds of thousands of fans, personal seat licenses and a dozen tall men they pay millions for running up and down a floor  appear to be losing games on purpose to maximize the opportunity that he might play for them  and their fans are perfectly O.K. with this.

title: Pearson Shares Rise Amid Buyout Chatter
description: Pearson shares rose the most in 14 months amid speculation that the company, which owns Penguin Books and the Financial Times newspaper, may receive an offer from a buyout firm or be split up, Bloomberg News reported. The stock was up as much as 4.2 percent Friday. A Pearson spokeswoman did not confirm or deny the rumors.

title: Icahn Raises Stake in Motorola
description: Shortly after Motorola disappointed shareholders and analysts by cutting its revenue forecasts and failing to make a bid for rival Palm, its biggest gadfly has increased his stake in the company.
