Carl C. Icahn, the billionaire activist investor, increased his stake in the beleaguered cellphone maker to 2.7 percent from 2.48 percent, according to a regulatory filing made on Friday.

title: Trans-Atlantic Travel Pact May Herald Airline Mergers
description: By lifting restrictions on air traffic between the United States and Europe, the so-called open skies agreement that European Union officials approved on Thursday may herald a renewed push for airline consolidation. Under the accord, European and American airlines will be allowed to fly any route between any European city and one in the United States. The change, which will take effect in March 2008, is expected to markedly increase competition in many European countries.

title: Scenes of Saugatuck
description: Offering world-class natural beauty and a low-key lifestyle, Saugatuck, Mich., appeals to many families seeking a retreat from city life.

title: A Look Inside Blackstones Money Machine
description: Blackstone Group, confirming a firestorm of speculation, said Thursday it would seek an initial public offering that would value the firm at as much as $40 billion. The preliminary prospectus offered a first glimpse inside Blackstones closely guarded money machine, which churned out $2.3 billion in profit in 2006. The offering is being structured to allow Blackstone to retain many advantages of a private business  a setup that Breakingviews compares with Berkshire Hathaway under Warren Buffett.

title: The Reluctant F.B.I. Informer
description: An anonymous  because he (I think its a he) is required by law to remain that way  president of a small Internet access and consulting business writes in a Washington Post op-ed about his experience as the recipient of a national security letter from the F.B.I. Three years ago, I received a national security letter (NSL) in my capacity as the president of a small Internet access and consulting business, the author writes. The letter ordered me to provide sensitive information about one of my clients. There was no indication that a judge had reviewed or approved the letter, and it turned out that none had. The letter came with a gag provision that prohibited me from telling anyone, including my client, that the F.B.I. was seeking this information.

title: Democrats Rally for House War Bill
description: Speaker Nancy Pelosi called a mandatory 8:30 a.m. meeting for all House Democrats. The topic, of course, was Iraq. The reason? To make one final check to see if her Democrats did not change their minds overnight on the partys signature Iraq legislation to be voted on in a few hours.

title: Exploring Northern Michigan
description: Tour a handful of vacation communities on the shores of northern Michigans pristine lakes.

title: The Manhattan Baby Boom
description: Since 2000, according to census figures released last year, the number of children under age 5 living in Manhattan mushroomed by more than 32 percent. And though their ranks have been growing for several years, a new analysis for The New York Times makes clear for the first time who has been driving that growth: wealthy white families.At least half of the growth was generated by children who are white and non-Hispanic. Their ranks expanded by more than 40 percent from 2000 to 2005. For the first time since at least the 1960s, white children now outnumber either black or Hispanic youngsters in that age group in Manhattan.

title: The Right to Be Meaningless and Funny
description: Sorry, Jesus, no bong hits for you: Jonathan Zimmerman, director of the history of education program at New York University, says both sides are wrong in the Supreme Court case over whether a high school student can display a banner that says Bong Hits 4 Jesus. Zimmerman writes in The Christian Science Monitor: The banner was a foolish vulgarity, unworthy of court-affirmed protection for politically meaningful speech. Under the schools theory, meanwhile, educators could censor any speech that contradicted their goals or ideas.

title: So, We Meet Again
description: Vanderbilt and Georgetown, a pair of small, private schools in different conferences, have played in each of the past two seasons. Vanderbilt won in December 2005, and Georgetown won last November, 86-70.

title: Next Generation Georgetown
description: John Thompson III, the Georgetown coach, sat under the bright lights, between a microphone and the N.C.A.A. backdrop, answering questions.

title: Reyshawn Terry In Doubt for Tar Heels
description: The first question for North Carolina Coach Roy Williams at his press conference Thursday was about the whole atmosphere. Since it was in the bowels of Continental Airlines Arena, The Bracket would have answered stuffy. And in the tiny locker rooms of the teams  seriously, the size of a spare bedroom  it was smelly.

title: 2008: Uniting for the Workers
description: For the Democratic field, appealing to Nevadas union workers will be the focus of the weekend. Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton, Barack Obama and Christopher J. Dodd, as well as Gov. Bill Richardson are scheduled to speak at a culinary workers rally in Las Vegas to kick off contract negotiations. On Saturday, that set will be joined in Sin City by several others, including John Edwards, for a health care forum sponsored by the Service Employees International Union and the Center for American Progress, a liberal think tank.

title: Tattoo You
description: Southern California freshman point guard Daniel Hackett has the most eclectic set of tattoos. He grew up in Italy (moving to the United States about four years ago), where his father was a player and a coach. On Hacketts left arm is one that reads Italian Stallion. He said the high-school cheering section at St. John Bosco in Southern California called him that.

title: Royal Bank of Scotland Names Former Citigroup Executive to Run American Unit
description: LONDON, March 23 (Reuters) - Royal Bank of Scotland named the former Citigroup executive Ellen Alemany as chief executive of its RBS America unit on Friday as part of a management revamp to bring its United States businesses closer together.

title: Rooters Guide to the Sweet 16, Friday Edition
description: Yesterday, I tried to help out fans without any specific team loyalty decide whom to root for during last nights games, the official Out Of Bounds Right-Thinking, Good-Hearted, Pure-of-Spirit Human Beings Guide To Whom To Root For In The Sweet 16. (O.O.B.R.T.G.H.P.O.S.H.B.G.T.W.T.R.F.I.T.S.S.) Howd my advice go? The teams I recommended cheering for went 0-4; I hope I caused you no heartache. Lets see if I can bring you more joy with a look at whom you should pledge your allegiances to tonight.FRIDAY

title: And Baby Makes Three
description: Anyone interested in sending Carlos Delgado a baby gift better get to work soon. His blue maserati is gone, and according to Mets PR man Jay Horwitz, Delgado left an hour ago to fly back to Puerto Rico for the birth of his first child, Carlos Antonio.

title: Inheritance Rights Under Rent Control
description: Q When my mother died, I became the tenant of record in her rent-controlled apartment. If I marry, would my wife be able to succeed me upon my death? What about a "significant other" who has lived with me for more than a year?

title: The Blame Game
description: The real effect of the subprime mortgage debacle is not yet clear, but todays Times has no fewer than three articles assigning blame.

title: Did Jim Cramer Cross the Line?
description: As money-manager-cum-TV-personality James Cramer was apologizing Thursday for parts of his recent treatise on how to manipulate stock prices, his nemesis, stock-analyst-cum-writer Henry Blodget, was tapping out a column for Slate suggesting that Mr. Cramer may have destroyed his own career.

title: Welcome to the Business of Green Blog!
description: Welcome. Youve landed on a new blog, The Business of Green, which goes live on Monday, March 26, 2007. With green power rising on the political and social agenda like never before, IHT correspondents James Kanter and Elisabeth Rosenthal sound off on the major environmental stories of the day  and invite you to have your say, too. Well be exchanging ideas that focus particularly on how both companies and consumers are reacting to global warming. Let us know whether you think businesses, politicians and individuals are taking climate change seriously. Give your views on the clean technologies andproducts that can make a difference. And tell us when you see greenwash from big business, rather than responsible stewardship of the planet. Remember, if youd like your comments reviewed forpublication in the newspaper, please include your full name and the country youre writing from. We look forward to the most global conversation about the Business of Green on the Web.

title: Wired in Rio
description: Gregory Dicum tours the city's coffee bars. With its traditional botequins and sleek espresso bars, it's easy to catch a buzz in Rio.

title: Former Morgan Stanley Chief Talks Private Equity
description: Are private equity deals getting too expensive? A reader of the Financial Timess Web site posed that timely question to Philip Purcell, the former chief executive of Morgan Stanley. His answer was a definite maybe. Mr. Purcell, who is now the president of Continental Investors, replied that prices are high enough that some buyout firms might see lower returns on current deals than they saw over the past 15 years. History would say that some buyers are overpaying, he said during an online Q&A.

title: Bloomberg, Scalpers and the Free Market
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg defended ticket scalpers this morning in his weekly interview on WABC radio.

title: J.P. Morgan Hires Head Semiconductor Banker
description: Mark Edelstone, a research analyst from Morgan Stanley, will join J.P. Morgan Chase as the firms global head of semiconductor investment banking, J.P. Morgan said Friday in an internal memo.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about G. E. Patterson, the presiding bishop of the Church of God in Christ, misstated the relationship of some of his survivors. Mary Hawkins and Lee Ella Smith, both of Memphis, and Barbara Davis of Detroit are his sisters, not his daughters. The obituary also gave an incorrect spelling in some copies for the name of the magazine of which he was editor and publisher. It is Bountiful Blessings Magazine, not Bountiful Blessing Magazine.

title: Browne Betty
description: One evening many months ago I was having a drink with a guy from Wall Street at the Four Seasons when, distracted by an animated group of well-dressed men at the end of the bar, he said, Theyve just finished closing a deal. I hadnt the faintest idea how he knew that, but it struck me, suddenly, that he was right. Of course! He had observed scenes like this hundreds of times. He knew there was a reason for their intimate laughter because his eyes told him so.

title: House Democrats Narrowly Pass War Bill
description: House Democrats squeaked through passage of their emergency war spending bill just now, getting just the required 218 votes needed.

title: Vilsack to Endorse Clinton
description: Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa, who quickly dropped in and out of the Democratic field for the 2008 race, will endorse Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton on Monday when shes visiting the state, were told.

title: Medical Misstep in Cricket Inquiry
description: In quick succession, natural death turned to a suspicious one, and now Jamaican police say Bob Woolmer was murdered in the hours after he coached Pakistan to a humiliating defeat to Ireland.

title: Its Always Sunny in Bradenton
description: Were here in Bradenton for the Yankees second visit of the spring. Shawn Chacon just threw the first pitch for the Pirates. Hes not doing that toe-tapping thing he did in his delivery when he pitched for the Yankees.

title: Snow to Undergo Surgery
description: Tony Snow, the White House press secretary, announced today that he would undergo surgery next week after tests found a small growth in his lower abdomen.

title: So Near and Yet
description: Certainly it would be an upset if Butler, the fifth seed, were to defeat No. 1 seed Florida, the defending N.C.A.A. champion, when they meet tonight in the Midwest regional semifinal in the Edward Jones dome.

title: A Look at the Canadians Who Seek Chrysler
description: Though the names most often mentioned as potential buyers of Chrysler have been private equity firms like the Blackstone Group and Cerberus Capital Management, several reports highlight a lesser-known firm with roots in the car business. That would be the Canadian auto-parts supplier Magna International.

title: Saudi Arabia Steps Up to the Plate
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans March 23 column, Abdullahs Chance.

title: Bush Vows Veto
description: If legislation in any form resembling what House Democrats passed today were to reach the White House, President Bush forcefully said he would veto the measure.

title: Frugal Traveler: Mountain High, Budget Low
description: The high Alpine resorts of Switzerland often come with a high price tag. What budget-conscious resorts in the Alps do you recommend?

title: Reading the Bloomberg-Spitzer Tea Leaves
description: Item 1:

title: Could Private Equity Come Calling for Sprint?
description: Time for more elephant hunting.

title: Only in New York: An Elite ZIP Code
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: Faroe Islands
description: On these mystical islands, nestled between Iceland and Norway, locals round up wild lamb for an annual slaughter.

title: The Hospital Buyout That Almost Flatlined
description: Though it briefly reigned last year as the largest leveraged buyout ever, the $33 billion deal to take HCA private almost ended with a drink and a shrug. So say Alan Hartman and Jim Forbes, the Merrill Lynch investment bankers who advised the hosital chain, in an interview with Dealmaker magazine. The proposed buyers - Merrill Lynch, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, Bain Capital and the hospital giants management  spent a final week of tough negotiations with advisers to HCAs special committee, haggling over a price.

title: Blogtalk: Weekender
description: On blowing the horn in a traffic jam and other acts of futility. [Metroblogging]

title: Our Nightly Bread
description: A couple of years ago, when diners in this city, like diners around the country, seemed to be as firmly and slavishly in the grip of carbo-phobia as possible, I feared for the fate of bread in restaurants.

title: Vows: Hilary and Andrew
description: After splitting up after college, Hilary Poris and Andrew Macklin realized they were meant to be together.

title: Wangs Hamstring Is Hurting; Henns Stock Is Rising
description: While the Yankees were losing here in Bradenton, 3-2 to the Pirates, Chien-Ming Wang felt some discomfort in his right hamstring while running at the Yankees complex in Tampa. The Yankees shut him down for the rest of the workout and say theyll have no more details until tomorrow.

title: Morgan Unveils Plans for Discover I.P.O.
description: Morgan Stanley announced Friday its long-expected plans to spin off its Discover credit card operations in an initial public offering. It was not immediately known how much the nations second-largest investment house expected to raise from the I.P.O., which Chairman and Chief Executive Officer John Mack had promised would be undertaken after he took the leadership at Morgan Stanley in June 2005.

title: T-minus to Tip-Off
description: It was a late-arriving crowd at Continental Airlines Arena in East Rutherford, N.J., where tip-off was a few minutes away and half of the mauve-colored seats were still empty. The game had not started, but the bands were in a fierce competition, playing at the same time, creating a cacophony of chaos. (Georgetown sounded like it was playing some version of Go Tell It On the Mountain, while Vanderbilt was playing something familiar but not quite recognizable.) It is hard to tell which side most of this crowd will take  there is a spunky contingent of Vanderbilt fans behind Jim Nantz and the CBS crew, but the Georgetown fans seem to have spread themselves out a bit more. I imagine well see, and hear, a lot from the North Carolina fans during the second game.

title: A Bit Cricket Crazed
description: George Vecsey had a column Thursday about his foray to find one of the few places in Manhattan to watch . If he were here hed have to go to great lengths to avoid cricket.

title: Giuliani on His Wifes Early Marriage: No Big Deal
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  News that his wife has been married three times, not twice, as has been widely reported for years, would have no effect on his run for president, Rudolph W. Giuliani said today.

title: China's Talent Shines at Juilliard
description: Educators at the Juilliard School feel China could herald a new era for classical music.

title: Advocacy and Teaching
description: Stanley Fish has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below.  The Editors

title: A Star Shines for Winthrop
description: Winthrops victory in this years N.C.A.A. tournament, the teams first tournament win ever, has the universitys most famous former student hoping for an encore next season.

title: Steve Reich Talking Music: The Orchestra Is a Museum
description: Steve Reich  Part III(mp3)On the orchestra, Bachs practical problems and changes at Carnegie Hall.

title: After Congo Elections
description: Six months after a historic democratic election, will Congo find stability? Jeffrey Gettleman reports from Goma.

title: Restaurants Try Smaller Portions
description: T.G.I. Friday's is trying to figure out how it can offer customers the option of less food and still make money doing it.

title: Breaking Down the West and the South Regional Finals
description: WEST REGIONAL FINAL

title: Russia: Detentions Reported Ahead of Anti-Kremlin March
description: In advance of an anti-Kremlin protest march set for today in Nizhny Novgorod, Russias third-largest city after Moscow and St. Petersburg, the police detained several planners and confiscated 60,000 copies of an opposition newspaper, organizers of the protest, called the Dissenters March, said. One protest planner, Oksana Chlysheva of the local Foundation to Support Tolerance, said that the police and other security officers had begun to mass in the city and that unidentified people have visited schools, universities and stores warning people not to attend.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about questions raised by Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign about the consistency of Senator Barack Obamas opposition to the Iraq war incorrectly rendered a statement by Bill Burton, a spokesman for Mr. Obama. Mr. Burton said that it was Mr. Obama who would not comment on a hypothetical question about how he might have voted on the resolution authorizing the war had he been in the Senate in 2002. Mr. Burton did not say that he, as a spokesman, would not comment on that hypothetical question.

title: Suspicions Turn to Crickets Dark Side
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 23  Cricket, especially that rambunctious form of the sport practiced in the Caribbean, has always been about far more than the ball, the wickets and the smartly dressed men standing out in the sun.

title: S.I. Man Charged in Attacks on Boys
description: A Staten Island man was charged yesterday with sexually abusing a 13-year-old boy after ordering him to strip at knifepoint this week and handcuffing him to a tree, the police said.

title: Forget the Eyes. The Teeth and Tongues Are Worse.
description: Wes Cravens 1977 film, The Hills Have Eyes, in which suburbanites battled mutant cannibals, was a pulpy parable of the thin line separating civilization from savagery. Last years remake was basically the same movie with glossier production values and a less satirical, more bludgeoning approach to violence. This follow-up  in which National Guard trainees are trapped on a former atomic test site and are stalked by flesh-eating freaks headquartered in a warrenlike mountain hideout  is essentially a catalog of transgressive images, lighted and edited like a heavy-metal video.

title: Government to Take a Hard Look at Horror
description: LOS ANGELES, March 23  To drive almost anywhere here this week is to run a gantlet of advertising for movies about killing.

title: Herman Stein, 91, Composer of Moody Horror and Science-Fiction Scores, Dies
description: Herman Stein, a little-known craftsman who, unseen but very much heard, helped terrify the audiences of a spate of classic horror and science-fiction films, died on March 15 at his home in Los Angeles. Mr. Stein, a former staff composer at the Universal studio in Hollywood, was 91.

title: Election Winner With a History of Struggle
description: MALVERNE, N.Y., March 23  They were calling it an upset, Patricia Ann McDonalds victory on Tuesday over the incumbent mayor of this village of 9,000 people in western Nassau County. But somehow, amid the leftover Champagne, drooping balloons and wilting bouquets in Mrs. McDonalds living room on Friday afternoon, her victory seemed almost scripted.

title: Plane Is Hit in Somali Capital as Threat to Government Builds
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 23  Insurgents shot down a cargo plane over Mogadishu on Friday, witnesses and Somali officials said, possibly killing the 11 people on board and raising fears that Somalias transitional government faces an increasingly organized and lethal threat.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Extra Time soccer roundup on Wednesday, about United States national team preparations for friendly matches, misidentified one team members professional affiliation. Jonathan Spector plays for West Ham United in the English Premier League  not for Charlton. (He played for that English Premier League team last season.)

title: Report on E. Coli Outbreak Cant Solve Mystery
description: The authorities said yesterday that they had been unable to determine the precise source of the E. coli bacteria found in bagged fresh spinach last year that killed three people and sickened more than 200 others.

title: Britain Questions 2005 Bombing Suspects
description: LONDON, March 23  The British police began interrogating three men on Friday who were apprehended under counterterrorism laws on Thursday for alleged offenses related to the London suicide bombings of July 7, 2005.

title: Saudi Arabia Bars Israeli Journalist Traveling With U.N. Chief
description: CAIRO, March 24  Saudi Arabia has barred entry to a Washington-based Israeli journalist traveling with Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on his current Middle East tour, the United Nations said today.

title: His Sons Cases Pending, Reid Returns to the Eagles
description: PHILADELPHIA, March 23  Andy Reid returned to work Friday and acknowledged that the legal and personal troubles of his eldest sons prompted him to at least briefly ponder giving up his job as the Eagles head coach.

title: Mix Broadway and Jazz, Then Stir With 50s Flair
description: Marching-around-the-breakfast- table songs. Thats Marilyn Mayes amusing and accurate description of some of the almost-hit singles she recorded in the 1960s for RCA Records: numbers like Step to the Rear, a peppy parade song from the all-but-forgotten 1967 show How Now, Dow Jones?

title: Our Echoes Come From You
description: Afghanistan is now both more and less than a nation. Dialects of its official language are spoken from Iran to India. Its greetings and rituals are recognizable in Chechnya. Kabuli woodwork incorporates motifs from Syria, the Mughal Empire and pre-Islamic Uzbekistan. On Tuesday, I heard a song from a mystical order, founded in Afghanistan, which was played by musicians from the borders of Nepal.

title: Iraq Reconstruction Teams to Receive Needed Support
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Ten veteran diplomats and four representatives of the Agency for International Development will depart for Iraq in coming days as the civilian core of 10 new provincial reconstruction teams, the first step in what the Bush administration has promised will be a significant increase in efforts to accelerate local economic and political development.

title: Life Coaching for the Soul
description: When Renee Marble, a marketing consultant in Jackson, Miss., needed guidance to improve her profit margins, she searched the Internet and got direction from a business coach. But when she hit a crossroads en route to trying to become an ordained Episcopal deacon, she scanned the Internet for a coach of a different kind: a spiritual coach.

title: The Labor of Raising Fresh Produce
description: The clocks have sprung forward, and the change of seasons is under way. But from trees budding in January because of unseasonable temperatures in the Northeast to frozen citrus crops in the West, this winter will be remembered for delivering some unusual weather.

title: 9 Die as Assassins Blasts Wound Sunni Deputy Premier
description: BAGHDAD, March 23  An assassination attempt on one of Iraqs deputy prime ministers, a Sunni in the Shiite-dominated government, left nine people dead Friday and was another in the mounting number of cases of Sunni-on-Sunni violence.

title: Heavy Bag (and You Know Who You Are), Meet This Fist
description: THE timer clock signaled the start of the final round, and I came at Doug DeWitt bobbing and weaving as if I were toying with some glass-jawed pug from the neighborhood. A solitary ray of sunshine sliced through the window of the suburban garage that was our makeshift gym, casting pugilistic shadows across the cold concrete floor.

title: Head of Joint Chiefs Calls Chinas Military Aims Unclear
description: BEIJING, March 23  Chinas recent test of an antisatellite weapon sent a confusing message to the world about its military intentions, but the United States and China are slowly building stronger military-to-military ties, the top-ranking United States military officer said Friday.

title: Another Group May Bid for Spanish Utility
description: MADRID, March 23  The Italian utility Enel and the Spanish construction conglomerate Acciona said Friday that they were working on a bid for the Spanish utility Endesa.

title: Data Show Wide Differences in New Jersey School Spending
description: With an average class size of nine, the tiny Sea Isle City school district on the Jersey Shore is spending $33,805 on each of its 90 students this school year, or nearly three times the statewide average of $12,098 per student, according to data released yesterday by the New Jersey Department of Education.

title: Knight of the Living Dead
description: London

title: Key Shareholder Rejects Bid for Qantas
description: SYDNEY, Australia, March 23  Private equity firms bidding for Qantas Airways scrambled to keep their proposal on track today, extending the closing deadline by two weeks as a key shareholder rejected the terms of their offer of 11.1 billion Australian dollars ($8.9 billion).

title: Tillman Inquiry Finds Errors, Official Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  A Pentagon investigation into the death by friendly fire of Cpl. Pat Tillman in Afghanistan will make recommendations that nine officers, including four generals, be held responsible for mistakes in the way the incident was handled and disclosed, a defense official said.

title: Rat Poison Found in Pet Food Linked to 14 Deaths
description: Rat poison has been found in pet food blamed for the deaths of 14 animals, federal and New York State officials said yesterday, but they said they were unsure how it had gotten there.

title: F.A.A. Calls for a Runway Mapping System
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The Federal Aviation Administration said on Friday that it had asked the industry to design a device for the cockpit of a plane that shows the planes position on an airport map to help pilots avoid becoming confused and using the wrong runway or taxiway.

title: Gonzales Met With Advisers on Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and senior advisers discussed the plan to remove seven United States attorneys at a meeting last Nov. 27, 10 days before the dismissals were carried out, according to a Justice Department calendar entry disclosed Friday.

title: Washington: Enhanced License Program
description: State residents will be able to use drivers licenses to cross the border from Canada as part of a pilot program to make identification requirements more flexible, the Homeland Security Department said. Residents can apply for a drivers license that is slightly more expensive than a standard license and requires proof of citizenship and residence similar to that needed for a passport, according to a department statement. Currently, residents can use a conventional drivers license or birth certificate, but starting as soon as January 2008, American citizens may be required to show a passport before re-entering the country via land or sea from Mexico, Canada, the Caribbean, Bermuda, Central America and South America.

title: Florida Proves Too Tall and Too Much for Butler
description: ST. LOUIS, March 23  With less than three minutes remaining Friday night at the Edward Jones Dome, the underdog Butler Bulldogs and the defending national champion Florida Gators were tied.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,223 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: U.S. Treasury Official to Help Free Up North Korean Funds
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The Bush administration said Friday that it had been more difficult than anticipated to fulfill an agreement to return $25 million in frozen bank funds to North Korea and that a top Treasury official would fly to China to help free the money.

title: University of Florida Senate Denies Degree to Jeb Bush
description: MIAMI, March 23  Pondering his options after eight years in office, former Gov. Jeb Bush can cross one off the list, honorary degree recipient at the University of Florida, the largest university in the state.

title: Union Chief Didnt Detail Corzine Gifts
description: Carla Katz, a former companion of Gov. Jon S. Corzine of New Jersey and the president of a major union in the state, has long contended that she has no obligation to reveal large sums of money that Mr. Corzine has given her, but the United States Department of Labor issued a formal request in 2005 that she disclose any gifts of value.

title: A Prison Sentence From the Other Side of the Bars
description: In 2002 Lisa Ling, who spent her young life as an international correspondent for the classroom news broadcast Channel One, put down her coffee cup and left her seat on The View, where, for three years, she had traded opinions with Barbara Walters. Ms. Ling felt the call to derring-do once more, so she joined National Geographic Television to cover the drug wars in South America, looting in Iraq, the horrors of the American prison system  stories that require bodyguards and durable shoes. Last year she sneaked into North Korea as a medical assistant.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about Tanya Reinhart, an Israeli linguist and critic of her countrys policies toward the Palestinians, misstated her birth year. It was 1943, not 1944. (As the obituary correctly noted, she was 63.)

title: Their Italian Hearts Are in the Scottish Highlands
description: American composers intent on pillaging literature for their operas should look at the early-19th-century Italians to see how it is really done. If settings of Tennessee Williams or F. Scott Fitzgerald falter out of excessive respect for the originals (among other reasons), operas like Rossinis Donna del Lago  which opened in a new production at New York City Opera on Thursday  appropriate distinguished literary names like Sir Walter Scotts and cheerfully reduce their writing to operas usual You Jane, me Tarzan dimensions.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 6 P.M. (Style) DRESS MY NEST Thom Filicia, the interior designer who helped style-deficient men make over their digs in Queer Eye, aids the opposite sex in this new design series in which a sharp-dressing young woman between 21 and 35 is asked to bring out her favorite outfit as inspiration for a room she wants refurbished. After he and Erika Martin, a stylist, determine what the outfit says about her personality, Mr. Filicia, above, creates a new room design and then hits the street to find furniture and accessories that he thinks will reflect the clients inner being  and keep the birdie happy at home.

title: Critic of Hussein Grapples With Horrors of Post-Invasion Iraq
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

title: Yankees Find New Face Vying for Bullpen Spot
description: BRADENTON, Fla., March 23  Sean Henn has never won a game in the major leagues, but he has experienced the glamour of New York baseball. His agent is Billy Martin Jr., and he has attended the baseball writers annual black-tie dinner in Manhattan, where the major award winners receive their trophies.

title: Texas, Addressing Sexual Abuse Scandal, May Free Thousands of Its Jailed Youths
description: HOUSTON, March 23  Battered by a sexual abuse scandal in its juvenile justice system, Texas may soon free most of the 4,000 jailed youths who have served their minimum sentences but who are still being held, in many cases for reasons that are undetermined.

title: Mozambique: Armory Deaths Rise to 93
description: At least 93 residents of the capital, Maputo, were dead a day after colossal explosions at a military armory on the citys edge spewed munitions for miles in every direction, and officials feared the toll would rise. More than 400 people were injured, and the central hospital ran out of blood. Many of the injured were kilometers away from the armory, said Paul Fauvet of the Mozambique news agency AIM. Its as if they were being fired on with rockets and mortars, he said. It looked like a mushroom cloud. The Defense Ministry said the explosions were probably touched off by the late-summer heat. President Armando Guebuza pledged to relocate the arsenal, while critics said the military had been slow to carry out promises to destroy the aging rockets and shells, dating from the nations long civil war, which ended in 1994.

title: The Shuttle May Go, but the Stories Will Linger
description: MERRITT ISLAND, Fla.  The old-timers still talk of manned rockets and raucous nights at the space cowboy roadhouses, the Moon Hut and the Mouse Trap, places where yesterdays gravity resisters could raise a beer to honor the Moon and missions thereabouts.

title: Egypt Rebuffs U.N. Chief on Darfur
description: CAIRO, March 24  President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt rebuffed a request today from Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to influence Sudans president to drop his objections to United Nations peacekeepers in Darfur.

title: Two Low-Key Young Architects With an Attitude, a Vision and Now a Prize
description: In an era that celebrates big-name architects and multimillion-dollar building projects, Gaston Nogues and Benjamin Ball offer a change of pace. One wears siren-red Converse sneakers, the other a beatnik fedora and goatee; their studio is a three-car garage in the Echo Park section of Los Angeles that is taken up mostly by building tools. Neither has yet turned 40.

title: Giving the Metalheads Plenty to Scream About
description: The Roseland Ballroom was packed on Thursday night with metalheads, drawn by the promise of a strong triple bill. The headliner was Lamb of God, a band of noisemakers from Richmond, Va. And toward the end of the night, D. Randall Blythe, the lead screamer for Lamb of God, found time to salute one of the opening acts. He shouted, Give it up for Trivium! And the crowd made a curious sound: a mixture of cheers, claps and  it was unmistakable  boos.

title: When to Press on to Game? It Often Depends on the Game
description: There is one particularly important difference between playing in a duplicate pair event and in a team-of-four tournament. In pair events, you try to go plus on every board; you do not push for thin games. Why? Suppose every other table but yours stops in three spades, and you push into four spades. Also, lets assume that every declarer in three spades makes his contract exactly. If you make your game, you get a top; but if you go down one, you get a zero.

title: Public Takes Up Pros and Cons of Edwards Bid
description: DENVER, March 23  Important policy debates about the course of the nation in the next presidential election are still out there and will no doubt return. But for one day, many people all over the country seemed able to pause and reflect on something deeper, to questions of mortality and the bonds of marriage, ambition and devotion, hope and denial.

title: After 5 Days of Mopping and Scrubbing, What Else Would a Model Wear?
description: First there was a cry, then a murmur, and finally a swoon. Naomi Campbell, the millionaire fashion model, emerged yesterday from a grimy Department of Sanitation garage in a floor-length evening gown, marking the end of her court-ordered community service.

title: U.S. Military Opens Inquiry Into Whether Marines Killed 10 Afghans After Attack on Convoy
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The United States military has opened a formal investigation into whether marines in eastern Afghanistan killed noncombatants after a suicide bomber detonated his explosive-laden car near their convoy on March 4, Marine officials said Friday.

title: World View Podcast
description: Calvin Sims and Sarah Lyall discuss British youth.

title: Multiple Perspectives on a Relationships End
description: Charlotte Vincents Broken Chords is about her bitter divorce and breakups in general. It has been described by critics as brave and beautiful. Nothing unfamiliar about the material or its reception.

title: Suit Tries to Stop Mailing of Ballots as Union Is Set for Contract Vote
description: TRENTON, March 23  Two Trenton-based locals of the Communications Workers of America that are opposed to New Jerseys proposed contract for state workers filed a lawsuit in federal court here on Friday to stop the ballots from being mailed to about 35,000 members.

title: Democrats Consider Deal for Passage of Trade Pacts
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Democrats in Congress are mulling a proposal to the Bush administration intended to resolve disagreements over labor, environmental and other issues blocking approval of pending trade deals, Congressional and administration officials said Friday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary on March 14 about Ernie Ladd, who was the only man elected to both the American Football League Hall of Fame and the World Wrestling Entertainment Hall of Fame, referred incorrectly to some of his football accomplishments. He did not play in the first Super Bowl in 1967, and he played in four  not three  A.F.L. championship games.

title: Landfill Has 9/11 Remains, Medical Examiner Wrote
description: Papers filed yesterday by family members of 9/11 victims who want the city to separate tons of debris on Staten Island to search for human remains include a letter in which the city medical examiner says he is almost certain some remains are present in the landfill, and an affidavit from a recycling supervisor who recalls watching debris being carted away to pave roads and fill potholes.

title: Former Interior Aide Pleads Guilty to Lying
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The second-highest official at the Interior Department during President Bushs first term, J. Steven Griles, pleaded guilty on Friday to lying before a Senate committee about his ties to Jack Abramoff, the disgraced lobbyist who is now in prison.

title: Tax Loans Are Losing Some Allure
description: Refund anticipation loans have been a profitable business for tax preparers like H&R Block and Jackson Hewitt.

title: Legal Convolutions for Gay Couples
description: One consequence of denying gay couples the right to marry is that it forces people to resort to legal convolutions to protect their familys financial interests. This problem is currently at the center of an intriguing lawsuit involving Olive Watson, a granddaughter of Thomas Watson Sr., the founder of I.B.M., and Patricia Ann Spado, her former lesbian partner of 14 years.

title: Nets Drop From 7th to 9th in Conference Standings
description: ORLANDO, Fla., March 23  As he suited up in the locker room before Friday nights game against the Magic, forward Mikki Moore mumbled what could be the Nets mantra as the regular season winds down.

title: Actor Receives 25 Years to Life in 05 Murder
description: An actor and yoga teacher who was convicted of killing a young dancer from Ohio was sentenced yesterday to 25 years to life in prison.

title: BP Plans to Bid for Yukos Assets in Auction
description: MOSCOW, March 23  BP said on Friday that it planned to bid against the state-owned oil giant Rosneft in a bankruptcy auction for assets of the Yukos oil company, a surprise announcement that signaled BPs deepening involvement in Russias turbulent energy sector.

title: Isnt That a Tennis Stadium Under All of That Water?
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, March 24  On the outside, it still looks like the place that stages the first Grand Slam tennis tournament of the year.

title: Not Very Cricket, Is It? (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report by The Associated Press yesterday in the National Briefing column, about a study of the Smithsonian Institutions eight art museums, misidentified one of two museums that the report said should be reorganized under one director. It is the National Portrait Gallery  not the National Gallery of Art  that would be joined with the American Art Museum.

title: Democrats Unite Around an Iraq Plan of Their Own
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The Democrats rode to power last November on the publics discontent with the war in Iraq, but they have struggled  long and hard, and often to little effect  to move beyond their opposition to President Bushs policies. Now, by a vote of 218 to 212, they have coalesced around a plan of their own.

title: Ohio to Sell Bonds to Avert Home Foreclosures
description: Ohio, which had the highest foreclosure rate in the nation at the end of last year, plans to issue $100 million in taxable municipal bonds next month to help homeowners refinance mortgages.

title: Bras Found, With Panties Still at Large
description: Some days it doesnt pay to stop for a bite at Chuck E. Cheeses, especially if youre traveling around with more than 100 stolen bras.

title: A Half-Century of Honky-Tonk With a Trove of Hits
description: Willie Nelson and Merle Haggard  that just would have been easy business. And, put in terms of copyright and back catalog, it would have been a follow-through on Pancho and Lefty, the hit record they made together almost 25 years ago. But to triangulate them with Ray Price, as the new record Last of the Breed does, is to structure a summit meeting on honky-tonk singing.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 23, 2007

title: Analyst Cites Bid to Buy Chrysler Group
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., March 23  DaimlerChrysler shareholders are so eager to jettison the unprofitable Chrysler Group that a whiff of a rumor about a bid in the works pushed the automakers stock to an eight-year high Friday.

title: Clinton Is Said to Have Gained a Major Endorsement in Iowa
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential bid has won an important endorsement from former Gov. Tom Vilsack of Iowa, a leading politician in the state with the first presidential caucus, according to two Democrats with first-hand knowledge of the endorsement.

title: Iran Protests Aggression in Case of Seized Britons
description: LONDON, March 24  One day after its forces seized 15 British naval personnel near disputed waters, Iran accused Britain today of blatant aggression, further ratcheting up diplomatic tensions. Britain demanded the immediate and safe return of its personnel.

title: Pediatricians Voice Anger Over Costs of Vaccines
description: The nations pediatricians, the foot soldiers in the campaign to vaccinate Americas children, are starting to revolt.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Thursday about the return of Nets small forward Richard Jefferson from injury, referred incorrectly in some copies to his medical treatment. He had arthroscopic ankle surgery, not knee surgery.

title: Hunt for Roots in Africa Ends in Prison
description: TINTON FALLS, N.J., March 23  Amir Mohamed Meshal may be no different from any other 24-year-old community college dropout struggling to figure out what to do with his life. First, he tried unsuccessfully to join the Army; then he headed overseas to connect with his ancestral roots and find a decent job.

title: A Menu of Youthful Energy Served Up With Experience
description: A prerogative of age for musicians is to distill a repertory built up over decades to the works that remain dearest to them. Colin Davis seems to have chosen that option as he approaches his 80th birthday (in September). But that still leaves considerable breadth, given that Mr. Daviss signature pieces are the big scores of Berlioz, the symphonies and tone poems of Sibelius, music by Mozart and Haydn and isolated works like Brittens Peter Grimes.

title: Congo: Army Battles Guards of Ex-Vice President
description: Soldiers of the two top politicians in Congo battled on in the streets of Kinshasa, the capital, for a second day, but by nightfall, troops loyal to President Joseph Kabila had gained the upper hand after hundreds of fighters commanded by Jean-Pierre Bemba, left, a former vice president and failed presidential candidate, fled across the Congo River. Witnesses said the fighting began when the presidential guard tried to disarm Mr. Bembas men, who responded with machine-gun fire. The government then wheeled in tanks and heavy artillery. By yesterday, more than two dozen people had been killed. Bodies were sprawled in the streets. Some of the fallen fighters wore grass headdresses and amulets thought to bestow magical powers. The authorities issued an arrest warrant for Mr. Bemba, accusing him of high treason. He and his wife holed up in the South African Embassy, one of the most heavily fortified buildings in Kinshasa.

title: Milton Wexler, Groundbreaker on Huntingtons, Dies at 98
description: Milton Wexler, a psychoanalyst who applied his talent for conducting group therapy to brainstorming sessions for scientists working on the hereditary disease that ravaged his wifes family, died on March 16 at his home in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 98.

title: Prosecutors Challenge Psychiatric Defense of Mother Charged in Girls Death
description: Prosecutors sought yesterday to challenge a psychiatric defense offered by the mother of Nixzmary Brown, a 7-year-old girl who was found beaten and starved to death in her familys Brooklyn apartment in January 2006.

title: Knicks Sign Center Who Was Undrafted but Not Unnoticed
description: CLEVELAND, March 23  The Knicks landed an intriguing young big man Friday.

title: Thoughts of Those Who Served, Turned Into Student Drama
description: Voices in Conflict, a play created by students in the advanced theater class at Wilton High School in Connecticut, is made up of monologues from soldiers and others involved in the Iraq war. The full script, and an earlier draft, is online, freewebs.com/voicesinconflict. Here are excerpts:

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about questions raised by Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign about the consistency of Senator Barack Obamas opposition to the Iraq war incorrectly rendered a statement by Bill Burton, a spokesman for Mr. Obama. Mr. Burton said that it was Mr. Obama who would not comment on a hypothetical question about how he might have voted on the resolution authorizing the war had he been in the Senate in 2002. Mr. Burton did not say that he, as a spokesman, would not comment on that hypothetical question. (Go to Article)

title: Iranian President Cancels U.N. Trip, Blaming U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 23  As the Security Council prepared to vote on a resolution imposing sanctions on Iran over its nuclear program, Irans president canceled his plans to address Council members before the expected vote on Saturday.

title: House, 218 to 212, Votes to Set Date for Iraq Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  A deeply divided House of Representatives voted Friday to bring most American combat troops home from Iraq next year, with Democrats employing their new Congressional majority to create the most forceful challenge yet to President Bushs war policy.

title: Life in the Mean Seats
description: Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Jets Sign Tuiasosopo to Vie for a Spot at Quarterback
description: The Jets signed quarterback Marques Tuiasosopo yesterday to compete with Kellen Clemens for a backup position.

title: Hoyas Past Is Becoming Present
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 23  The links between this Georgetown team and its championship-contending predecessors run far deeper than the blue and gray uniforms. The present Hoyas are trying to recapture their past as a way to finally escape it.

title: Unwary Investors
description: Mania is an established feature of stock markets. But in this weeks upswings, investors have seemed especially heedless of dangers lurking in the economy.

title: Forward Faces Big Task Against Ohio States Star
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 23  The matchup of Ohio State center Greg Oden and Memphis forward Joey Dorsey in Saturdays final of the South Regional is being billed as a battle for the ages.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the recurrence of cancer in Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of John Edwards, a Democratic presidential candidate, misstated Paul E. Tsongass political status when he ran for president in 1992 after having been treated for non-Hodgkins lymphoma. He was a former senator from Massachusetts, not a senator.

title: Corporate Dramas Steal the Show From the Fed
description: THE Federal Reserve Boards decision not to raise rates and to move away from its bias toward raising rates would have dominated headlines in most weeks. But big personalities and big corporate news stole the show this week.

title: Injury Tests Climbers Resolve High Above the Ground
description: Every athlete has competed while injured. But at what point does trying to play through pain become stupid rather than courageous? It is one thing to play with an injury in a championship game or at the Olympics, but I encountered this problem while facing my most difficult rock climb.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: A Museum Sale Sets a Record

title: Martnez: Snchez Needs Time
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 23  Pedro Martnez has been off to the side for much of the spring, working hard to recover from rotator-cuff surgery and occasionally talking to reporters about his physical status.

title: Longtime Lawyer to Politicians Is Cuomos Pick to Police Them
description: Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo has hired a veteran New York elections lawyer to be his special counsel on public integrity issues, his office said yesterday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about a lawsuit against the Napa Valley Unified School District and Redwood Middle School over a student dress code misstated the role of the American Civil Liberties Union of Northern California and of a San Francisco law firm in some copies. Lawyers for the A.C.L.U. and lawyers for the law firm are providing legal services for the plaintiffs; they are not the plaintiffs.

title: Rebel Poet Loses His Heart (and Head)
description: Not many singers today face the pressure that Ben Heppner must feel. His lean, burnished and powerful voice makes him the closest the opera world has right now to an ideal Wagnerian heldentenor. The Metropolitan Opera is not alone in counting on Mr. Heppner for Tristan und Isolde (which he will sing next season). And he is poised to portray the impossible-to-cast title role in Siegfried.

title: Europeans Are Kicking Off a Quiet Revolution in Worldwide Banking
description: LONDON, March 23  In the snow-covered mountains of Davos, Switzerland, top executives of Barclays, the British bank, and ABN Amro, a Dutch rival, ran into each other at the World Economic Forum in January.

title: California: Spinach Contamination Remains a Mystery
description: The authorities said they had been unable to determine the precise source of the E. coli bacteria found in bagged fresh spinach last year that killed three people and sickened more than 200. But in a report released by the federal Food and Drug Administration and the California Department of Health Services, officials said they were able to identify environmental risk factors that probably contributed to the outbreak. Contaminated irrigation water, uncomposted manure used as fertilizer, the presence of wildlife and livestock and the hygiene of the workers handling the crops all might have served to transport the E. coli 0157:H7 bacteria, they said. We do not know, ultimately, how that contamination happened, said Dr. Kevin Reilly of the California Department of Health Services.

title: Walter J. Turnbull, 62, Harlem Choir Founder, Dies
description: Walter J. Turnbull, who founded the Boys Choir of Harlem, died yesterday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. He was 62.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Wednesday about a recall of pet food misidentified the hometown of Elizabeth Krottinger, who said her dogs were hospitalized with kidney damage after eating the food. It is Addison, Tex.  not Anderson.

title: Fairness for Mental Health
description: After a decade of small-bore measures and frustrating stalemates, it looks as if Congress may be ready to require that insurance coverage for mental illness and substance abuse be provided on the same terms as coverage for physical ailments. So-called parity legislation would be a boon to the millions of Americans who suffer from mental illness or addiction and find it hard to afford treatment. It should also reduce the high productivity losses from depressed or stressed workers.

title: Play About Iraq War Divides a Connecticut School
description: WILTON, Conn., March 22  Student productions at Wilton High School range from splashy musicals like last years West Side Story, performed in the state-of-the-art, $10 million auditorium, to weightier works like Arthur Millers Crucible, on stage last fall in the schools smaller theater.

title: Northern Ireland Government Plans Hit Snag
description: LONDON, March 24  Northern Irelands biggest Protestant party, led by the Rev. Ian Paisley, balked today at joining a government with the provinces Roman Catholics only two days before a deadline to restore a power-sharing local government in Belfast.

title: In the Animal Kingdom, the Wild Bunch Rules
description: Nature often looks better at a distance. Planet Earth, an 11-part mother of all nature series to be shown on the Discovery Channel for five consecutive Sundays, beginning tomorrow night, understands this truth. The BBC, which produced the series with Discovery, used helicopters, long lenses and all manner of cutting-edge film techniques to bring us the photographic spoils of a five-year global odyssey.

title: Knicks Hit New Low and May Go Further
description: CLEVELAND, March 23  A look of disgust crossed Isiah Thomass face, although it was hard to pinpoint when it became permanent. The way things are going for the Knicks, the expression might not leave Thomass face until sometime in August.

title: Windfall Time: When Angels Battle Demons
description: MATTHEW BUSHLOW, a publicist in Burlington, Vt., is expecting a $2,000 tax refund this year. Like many people who anticipate a windfall  whether from a bonus, book advance, birthday money or Uncle Sam  Mr. Bushlow is on the verge of spending the money even before the check lands in his account.

title: Ex-Senator Is Set to Run for Governor of Louisiana
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 23  John B. Breaux, a former Democratic senator from Louisiana, said Friday that he would be a candidate in the race for governor this fall if the state attorney general cleared up questions surrounding his residency.

title: A Bigger Army? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Flood of Pleas to F.C.C.: No Phones on Planes, Please
description: In response to the news that the Federal Communications Commission opposes the proposal to allow cellphone use on airliners, mostly for technical reasons, The New York Times asked readers of its Web site to post comments about the issue.

title: Not So Free Trade (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Fraud Inquiry Looks at Lawyers in Diet-Drug Case
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., March 22  W. L. Carter knew there was something fishy going on when he went to his lawyers office a few years ago to pick up his settlement check for the heart damage he had sustained from taking the diet drug combination fen-phen.

title: American Theater, Lost and Found
description: When the lights went down at the TriBeCa Performing Arts Center for a series of readings earlier this week, characters like Pocahontas took the stage in new short plays with vintage twists. The works had drawn from the hugely neglected legacy of American popular drama from the American Revolution to World War I, which gave birth to many of the themes and characters that still linger in popular culture.

title: Familiar Profile Looms in Teams Resurgence
description: East Rutherford, N.J.

title: U.S. News & World Report Editor Resigns
description: Brian Duffy, 52, the editor of U.S. News & World Report, has left the magazine to write a book and his job responsibilities have been given to his No. 2, Brian Kelly, 52, according to a statement yesterday from the magazines owner, Mortimer Zuckerman.

title: The Spanish Civil War: Black and White in a Murky, Ambiguous World
description: If there are any doubts about the deep longing we have to believe in heroes, to discover those with superior courage, vision and commitment, and then to celebrate their accomplishments, the new exhibition at the Museum of the City of New York should put those doubts to rest. Facing Fascism: New York and the Spanish Civil War, which opened yesterday, is in full celebration mode.

title: Discreet Swiss Banks Now Offering Sophisticated Investment Vehicles
description: GENEVA  The new headquarters of Pictet & Cie. is a modern glass-and-steel high rise on this citys edge, wedged between a Shell gas station and a cut-rate electronics outlet.

title: South Africa Lowers Voice on Human Rights
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 23  Modern South Africa came about, historians agree, in part because of the United Nations unrelenting stance against apartheid. The United Nations affirmed that South African racism was not merely an internal political problem, but a threat to southern Africa. It banned arms shipments to South Africa. It demanded fair treatment of black dissidents.

title: 775 Nissan Workers Agree to Buyouts
description: The Nissan Motor Company, the Japanese automaker, said yesterday that 12.5 percent of the 6,200 workers at its two Tennessee plants accepted early retirement and buyout offers.

title: Five Injured by Smoke in Bronx Fire
description: Five people were hospitalized yesterday morning after a kitchen fire filled their Bronx apartment with smoke, and three remained in critical condition last night, fire officials said.

title: Woods Has the Club for Putting or Tossing
description: MIAMI, March 23  Tiger Woodss putter has survived two swing changes, one marriage and years of rattling around in his golf bag.

title: F.B.I. Agents Investigate 2 Lawmakers in the Bronx
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating allegations of corruption against two Bronx lawmakers  State Senator Rubn Daz Sr. and his son, Assemblyman Rubn Daz Jr., according to an official familiar with the investigation who spoke on the condition of anonymity.

title: As Mother Looks On, Bruins Guard Sprints Toward Final Four
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 23  June Collison expects the shaking, the blurred vision and the temporary hearing loss to start all over again.

title: Test Results Due Out Soon Are Crucial to Stents Future
description: Physicians and Wall Street analysts are eagerly awaiting news next week about heart stents that could have big implications for patients and stent makers alike.

title: Debt and the College Graduate (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: At Zimmer, a Raise Based Largely on a Bonus and Incentives
description: J. Raymond Elliott, who announced in November that he will be stepping down as chairman and chief executive of Zimmer Holdings by June 30, earned just under $12 million in 2006, according to a proxy statement filed Friday. Zimmer makes orthopedic products.

title: Bush Spokesman Schedules Surgery
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Tony Snow, the White House press secretary, said Friday that he would have surgery on Monday to remove a growth in his abdomen.

title: Vonage Told to Stop Using Verizon Technology
description: A federal judge said yesterday that he would order Vonage Holdings, the Internet-based telephone service, to stop using technologies patented by Verizon Communications.

title: Facing Terrible News, and Going On (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Wounded in Shooting in the Bronx
description: Two people were wounded last night in a shooting outside a Bronx deli that drew a second gunman, who then fired at officers and fled, the police said.

title: Mr. Spitzers Budget Deals
description: Gov. Eliot Spitzer has fearlessly taken on two of the most thankless jobs in New York State government: reining in health care spending and fixing the education financing formula. Anybody who has watched television recently knows why politicians are reluctant to try to make health care spending more rational. The health care workers union has spent millions of dollars on commercials accusing Mr. Spitzer of being heartless and unwise. Meanwhile in Albany, Republican state senators have declared war over Mr. Spitzers proposals on how education dollars get spent.

title: When Home Is Too Much of an Advantage
description: When the pairings for the womens N.C.A.A. Division I basketball tournament were announced last week, C. Vivian Stringer, the longtime head coach at Rutgers, needed all the restraint in her power to contain herself.

title: Explosive Tar Heels Rally to Win
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 23  North Carolina did not play a perfect 40 minutes, but it was not necessary. The young, gifted Tar Heels are capable of exploding at any moment, and that was what they did Friday night at the Meadowlands. Piecing together about 12 minutes of brilliant basketball, they roared back from a 16-point second-half deficit that flattened Southern California, 74-64.

title: Porter Supplies Early Edge, Then Helps Ducks Escape
description: ST. LOUIS, March 23  Tajuan Porter of Oregon is barely big enough to be called a Duck. At 5 feet 6 inches, Porter is kind of a duckling, but not the ugly kind.

title: Mets Hernndez Looks Close to Being Ready
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 23  Before Orlando Hernndez, the Mets 41-year-old right-hander, pitched six strong innings against St. Louis on Friday, he spent about 45 minutes going through a variety of exercises, hardly the normal routine for most pitchers about to head to the mound.

title: Apple Cult Becoming a Religion
description: APPLE will not release the iPhone until June, but Leander Kahney, the writer of The Cult of Mac blog, posited this week on Wired News that the new phone is already partly responsible for a major change in how the company is perceived (wired.com). After nearly three decades, Apple is finally being taken seriously not just by the true believers, but by just about everybody.

title: Iran Seizes 15 Britons on Patrol in Persian Gulf
description: LONDON, March 23  Fifteen British naval troops carrying out an inspection in the Persian Gulf were seized by Iranian forces on Friday, the British government said.

title: Politics in the Digital Age (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Advocacy and Teaching
description: Delray Beach, Fla.

title: A Career Path Built From the Debris of War
description: War coverage has often elevated the careers of journalists who were willing to take on the risks of being close to deadly action.

title: Senate Democrats Pass a Budget That President Opposes
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  The Senate passed a Democratic spending outline on Friday that proponents said would balance the federal budget by 2012, provide more money for programs like childrens health care and extend some of President Bushs tax cuts beyond 2010.

title: Have Surgery. Go Sightseeing.
description: WOULD you be willing to have nonurgent medical procedures done overseas, if you could recover in a fine hotel and your employer not only picked up all the costs, but actually paid you for having the work done outside the United States?

title: U.N. Chief Isnt Discouraged by His Close Call in Iraq
description: CAIRO, March 23  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon said Friday that a mortar shell that landed near him on Thursday in Baghdad had surprised and scared him but would not deter him from expanding the United Nations presence in Iraq.

title: Foreigners Get Benefit of Tax Cut
A Museum-Quality Car for a Subway Yet Unbuilt
description: Expectations are high for construction of the Second Avenue subway, and the futuristic new subway cars that will run on it. Made from gleaming stainless steel, the cars have a range of modern innovations: round porthole windows that would look at home on a rocket ship; high-tech air purification systems that use ultraviolet lamps to kill germs; illuminated route maps on the wall; and  incredible as it seems  public address systems that make clear, intelligible announcements.

title: Multitaskers of Manhattan
description: On bicycle, on foot and often behind the wheel, users of digital devices present potentially dangerous scenes every day.

title: No More Teen-Pop Fluff: Aguilera Tries Being a Serious Singer
description: No doubt the ushers and bouncers were thrilled. On Friday night, Madison Square Garden was packed with well-behaved fans. They didn't make a scene by screaming too loud. Many of them declined to dance in their seats, let alone in the aisles. And for the most part, they saved their applause for after each song, instead of rudely cheering all the way through.

title: Replays and Lying Eyes
description: My late grandfather, a military man with a crewcut you could balance a sheet of carbon paper on, loved nothing more than umpiring Little League games in Moweaqua, Ill. He was a modest, kind man, but he savored the power of being an umpire, the sense of order and justice it provided him. The world was chaotic, but inside the diamond, it was not, and only he had the ability to answer the unanswerable. In small-town Illinois youth baseball, games had only one umpire, and I dont think he would have wanted it any other way. There can be only one voice of truth.

title: New Poli-Book Best-Seller List
description: This months political best seller list, an exclusive to The Caucus, continues to carry some of the months-long hot books, but there are newcomers moving up that offer historical perspectives with parallels to the present, as well as current perspectives and examinations of events here-and-now.

title: Wang to Start Season on Disabled List
description: The Yankees received the results of Chien-Ming Wangs M.R.I. this morning, and the news was not good. Wang, who was lined up to pitch on opening day, will start the season on the disabled list and not return to the Yankees until the end of April, at the earliest.

title: Split Decision
description: The Mets play their final split-squad games of the spring today, meaning no more bus rides for guys like Mike Carp, Ben Johnson and Lastings Milledge. The regulars, as usual, are staying back in Port St. Lucie for a game against Baltimore, but a few members of the coaching staff are down in Jupiter for a game against the Marlins.

title: Vintage Toyotas
description: Fifty years after the company's first cars came to America, collectors are finding interest in Toyota.

title: Goliath vs. David
description: The Memphis junior forward Joey Dorsey made headlines here in San Antonio on Friday with his trash talk about the Ohio State freshman center Greg Oden.

title: Track Work at Spa-Francorchamps Progresses
description: I just received some cool photos from Luc Willems, the Spa circuit press officer. Spa in the snow is one thing, but Spa as it undergoes its partial redesign, is quite another. Here are a couple of the shots. I might do an image gallery later. Both shots below are taken from the Source hairpin. The first shows the garage side  with the garages on the left  while the second shows the old garage side, leading down to Eau Rouge. You can see the first layer of repaving on the track, too, incidentally. Im looking forward to seeing this revamped Spa in mid-September at the Belgian Grand Prixwhen, I suspect, it will also be snowing.

title: The General vs. the Housewife
description: How has a self-described timid mother put the leader of Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, on the ropes? Nicholas Kristof reports from Islamabad.

title: National Championship Motivation
description: The 3 a.m. text messages that Ohio State Coach Thad Matta receives dont surprise him anymore.

title: Sloopy on the Water
description: The boisterous Ohio State band was cruising the riverwalk in a boat here in San Antonio more than three hours before todays game between the top-seeded Buckeyes and the No. 2-seeded Memphis Tigers in the N.C.A.A. tournaments South Regional final.

title: Anderson Injured
description: The Memphis sophomore guard Antonio Anderson, the hero of the Tigers victory against Texas A&M on Thursday night, went down with what appeared to be a gruesome injury with 3:25 remaining in the first half Saturday.Anderson was inadvertently elbowed in the face by his teammate Robert Dozier, who came down after leaping for a rebound and inadvertently connected with the right side of Andersons face. Anderson lay on the court for about two minutes as two Memphis trainers tended to the bleeding on Andersons face, then escorted him off the court.Anderson, who made the decisive free throws with 3.1 seconds remaining to beat Texas A&M, is one of the Tigers key players, a starter who averages 7.9 points a game. A Memphis team official said he had a small cut above his right eye. He was receiving stitches and was expected to return.

title: Carl Pavano on Opening Day. Seriously.
description: Some stuff you couldnt make up if you tried. This is now a statement of fact: Carl Pavano is lined up to be the Yankees opening-day starter.

title: Those Were the Days
description: Chances are decent, it would seem, that if you are reading this blog, you are not old enough to remember the 1982 national championship game between North Carolina and Georgetown.

title: Traveling Man?
description: Georgetown forward Jeff Green, along with his teammates and coach, met with the media on Saturday. It took 21 questions  good thing it was not a game of 20 Questions  before someone asked Green if he had seen a replay of his winning basket against Vanderbilt on Friday night, and whether he thought he had traveled before taking the shot.

title: Will Hells Kitchen Ever Truly Feel Like Home for Gays?
description: A gay migration has traveled up the West Side to Hells Kitchen. This new gay presence, however, is very different from what went before. In the West Village and Chelsea, gay culture was in many respects the prevailing culture. But in Hells Kitchen, the gay community is just one of many subcultures that share and sometimes compete for a common turf. As gays migrate to Hells Kitchen, some say that harassment against them is a greater issue than in the more heavily gay neighborhoods of Greenwich Village and Chelsea.

title: And in the Womens Bracket
description: Arizona State made it to the Round of 8 for the first time in team history with a 67-49 victory Saturday against Bowling Green in the regional semifinals at Greensboro, N.C. When Rutgers followed by upsetting Duke, 53-52, in the other semifinal, it set up what is likely to be an emotional game between the Sun Devils and the Scarlet Knights on Monday in the regional final.

title: Clear as Mud
description: Now that Coach Tubby Smith has left Kentucky for a new job at Minnesota, people at the Midwest Regional in St. Louis keep asking Billy Donovan of Florida if he is interested in taking over the Wildcats.

title: Texas Eyeing Goestenkors?
description: The Duke womens basketball coach, Gail Goestenkors, has been named in several reports as the No. 1 candidate on Texas wish list as the Longhorns look to fill the opening created by Jody Conradts resignation. Goeskenkors declined to address the speculation on Saturday after her top-seeded Blue Devils, the N.C.A.A.tournament favorite, were knocked out by No. 4 Rutgers, 53-52, in Greensboro, N.C.

title: Begging for Fans
description: The womens game might be growing, but drawing fans is still a concern for N.C.A.A. tournament officials. Thats why No. 1 Duke was sent just 50 miles west of Durham, N.C., to play in the Greensboro Regional this weekend. The Blue Devils have a strong following and drew 6,392 to Greensboro Coliseum for their game against No. 4 Rutgers on Saturday.

title: Sundays Breakfast Menu: March 25
description: The lineup for the Sunday news shows seems split between two of the main topics of the week just ended: first, the firings of United States attorneys and the constitutional battle that is thundering between the White House and Congress; second, the vote on the Iraq war spending that face a certain veto by President Bush. A third topic, the continuing presidential campaign of former North Carolina Senator John Edwards, despite the news that his wifes cancer has now spread, is bound to weave its way through some of the interviews and chatter around the roundtables.

title: Wheres Greg?
description: Its hard to miss Greg Oden. The center for Ohio State, Oden is arguably the most recognizable player in this N.C.A.A. tournament, a 7-foot reminder of the impact of the N.B.A.s new early entry rules.

title: A Long Trip
description: In the spring of 2004, when Greg Oden and Mike Conley Jr. were sophomores in high school, I took a trip to Indianapolis to write about Oden. An assistant college coach in Indiana had told me that Oden was the best center prospect hed ever seen, the sure-fire No. 1 pick in the 2006 N.B.A. draft.

title: Calipari Says He Will Remain at Memphis
description: During Ohio States 92-76 victory against Memphis on Saturday, a woman sat near mid-court with a white sign that read, Calling Coach C, UK Line 1.

title: Intentional Memory Loss?
description: The funniest moment of Thad Mattas postgame press conference came when a reporter from Ohio decided to point out the pink elephant in the room.

title: Welcome. Now Buckle It.
description: That Wild Ride Under the El

title: The Week in Long Island
description: Brookhaven Lab Avoids Cuts in Budget

title: Rangers Score, Then Let Lundqvist Take Over
description: BOSTON, March 24  At the end of overtime on Saturday, having just faced a flurry of shots that required him to sprawl all over the crease, Rangers goalie Henrik Lundqvist leaned back on the net and labored to catch his breath. He had just bailed out the Rangers while they were short-handed in overtime, after he had bailed them out for most of regulation.

title: Before Bulldozers, the Sound of Purring
description: IT was a little after 6 on an icy Saturday night, and the makeshift trap, a three-foot-square box made of wood and netting, had been propped up on a stick next to an empty lot in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, for 20 minutes. A 40-foot purple string ran from the stick, along the sidewalk, into the window of a red Mazda, where Laura Brahm was holding the other end.

title: Waiting for Freedom, Messing It Up
description: Princeton, N.J.

title: Russias Deadly Mines (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction: Presidential Rsums
description: An article last Sunday about the political experience of presidential candidates misstated the number of years that Barack Obama, a Democratic candidate for president, served in the Illinois State Senate. He served eight years, not nine. The article also omitted part of the name for the medal that John F. Kennedy won for his heroism in World War II. He won the Navy and Marine Corps Medal, not the Navy Medal.

title: Dont Mind That Misnomer: Its Got Yield
description: OVER the last month, yields of Treasury bonds have fallen. And yields on junk bonds  often known euphemistically as high-yield bonds  have been at historically low levels for years.

title: Stepping Onto Center Stage
description: NEW students at Purchase College are often surprised that Joe Ferry, chairman of the studio production department in the Conservatory of Music, knows someone as cool as the singer-songwriter Regina Spektor. But the photograph in his office proves it. There they are  Dr. Ferry and the pop star, whom he mentored when she attended the conservatory, in a pose from her student days. Theyre stopped cold when they realize she graduated from here, Dr. Ferry said. When I show them the couch she napped on, its like George Washington slept here.

title: Local Radio Is Cutting the Static and Going Digital, Finally
description: AS drivers pick their way down the West Side Highway of Manhattan, the noise is often more annoying than the traffic  and its not just the honking.

title: When the Judge Has Gone Fishin
description: IF you have to get arrested, dont do it on the weekend. Courts tend to run on skeleton crews, meaning youll most likely spend more time locked up, waiting to be seen by a judge. Not fun.

title: But Whos Against the Next War?
description: To hear the Democrats vying for the 2008 presidential nomination tell it, their foreign-policy views represent a sharp, even radical break with the course the Bush administration has pursued since 9/11. Senator Hillary Clinton has contrasted President Bushs unilateralism with what she has called her own internationalism. Senator Barack Obama vowed to provide the kind of leadership we need to re-establish our standing in the world and renew our allies respect. Former Senator John Edwards has emphasized his differences with the administrations domestic policy, but he has also promised to abandon a foreign policy based on ideology and to return America to its place of moral leadership.

title: Curl Up and Transcend
