description: Pod hotels  a new wave of budget accommodations offering a pint-size, though not unstylish, place to rest ones head  are landing everywhere. How did it happen? Here, one plausible theory.

title: Correction
description: An article Saturday about the discovery that rat poison had been found in pet food blamed for the deaths of 14 animals misstated the status of a recall by Menu Foods. It did not expand its recall to all wet food products on Friday.

title: Early Conditioning to Get the Job Done
description: I WAS one of six children. I grew up working in my parents drugstore with my brothers and sisters. Even in first grade, Id finish the school day and go to the store. It gave me an appreciation of work.

title: Correction: Truly Indie Fans
description: A picture credit on Jan. 28 with an article about black fans of indie rock misspelled the photographers surname. The photograph of the rock group Earl Greyhound was by Darren Ankenman, not Ankerman. The error was pointed out by Mr. Ankenman in an e-mail message on Tuesday.

title: Closing a Case Will Not Mean Closure at Duke
description: DURHAM, N.C.

title: The Split-Screen State of the Union
description: ONE of my many obsessions is to listen to the speeches of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. over and over again. Almost every line is a jewel, but two in particular come to mind as I survey the state of the union.

title: How to Improve It? Ask Those Who Use It
description: DR. NATHANIEL SIMS, an anesthesiologist at Massachusetts General Hospital, has figured out a few ways to help save patients lives.

title: The Week in Westchester
description: Neuberger to Use Gift to Further Art Education

title: Infidel
description: To the Editor:

title: Braves Do Repairs and Try to Restore What Was Theirs
description: Throughout the Atlanta Braves unparalleled run of 14 consecutive division championships, nary a player was heard to boast of the teams superior standing, certainly not before a season began.

title: Mazurkas, Moody Soundscapes and Miniature Suites
description: ROB SCHWIMMER:

title: For Exquisite Morsels, a Day to Have Reservations About
description: I DONT typically recommend pop-music lyrics as words to dine by, but when it comes to identifying  and avoiding  the worst time to visit a premier restaurant, I have to defer to the title and chorus of a hit song by the Boomtown Rats.

title: Author Says Yankees Are Missing Something
description: Who could possibly question Derek Jeters place in Yankee history?

title: A Hostage Taken, a Ransom Paid (Again)
description: ROME

title: The Papers Chase
description: When writers die, their work lives on  and their papers go to Texas. Or Yale, Harvard, Emory, the New York Public Library, the British Library and other scholarly institutions that collect authors manuscripts and correspondence. How such papers change hands  and find monetary value  is the result of a peculiar alchemy between market forces and literary reputations.

title: A Splash of Contrast in Oregon and Florida
description: ST. LOUIS, March 24  Consider the contrasts between the Florida and Oregon mens basketball teams, which will meet on Sunday in the Edward Jones Dome for the right to advance to the N.C.A.A. tournaments Final Four.

title: Iran Cites Aggression in Case of Captured British Personnel
description: LONDON, March 24  One day after its forces seized 15 British naval personnel near disputed waters, Iran accused Britain on Saturday of blatant aggression, while Britain demanded the immediate and safe return of its personnel.

title: Like the Edwardses, Some Use Work When They Must Fight Serious Illness
description: When John and Elizabeth Edwards learned on Wednesday that Mrs. Edwardss breast cancer had returned, the presidential campaign, which often seems removed from daily life, suddenly mirrored reality for thousands of American families facing deadly illnesses. Mr. Edwardss choice  whether to scale back a demanding career to be with his wife  is one faced throughout the nation.

title: Omahas Culture Club
description: When I tell people Im originally from Omaha, they often confuse it with Oklahoma or Iowa. Omaha, a Manhattan photographer I met the other day said. Thats near Nebraska, isnt it? Omaha is one of those ultimate flyover places, an urban Podunk so vaguely situated in coastal Americans mental maps that the mere mention of it can actually halt conversation.

title: City Police Spied Broadly Before G.O.P. Convention
description: For at least a year before the 2004 Republican National Convention, teams of undercover New York City police officers traveled to cities across the country, Canada and Europe to conduct covert observations of people who planned to protest at the convention, according to police records and interviews.

title: A Promise Yet to Be Realized
description: THE soup was beautiful to see: fat white shrimp touched with coral, juicy tan mushrooms, green bell peppers and kaffir lime leaves, all in a clear broth. And it was beautiful to eat: suffused with shrimp essence and lime, and spiced to leave a tingle in the throat.

title: Correction: A Culinary Odyssey, on a Path Blazed by Orwell
description: The Explorer column on March 11 about dining in Myanmar misstated the value of the kyat, the Myanmar currency, and the price in kyats of meals there. A meal at Napi, also known as Fatty Ladys Place, in Ohnoma cost about 1,250 kyats, not 7  the equivalent of $1 a person. Meals at several roadside joints in the countryside rarely cost more than 1,800 kyats, not 10. (Although the official exchange rate is seven kyats to the dollar, almost all private transactions use rates of 1,000 to 1,250 or more kyats to the dollar.)

title: Justices to Hear Case on Wages of Home Aides
description: Evelyn Coke sat in her wood-frame home in Corona, Queens, a hobbled figure, not realizing that this is supposed to be her moment in the spotlight.

title: Pushing the Fight Against Racial Segregation
description: SYOSSET

title: Lost and Found
description: The stylized images of ancient Assyrian kings, with their braided beards and Art Deco muscles, riding out in chariots to hunt lions or men, are now familiar, but until the 19th century nothing was known of them. All evidence had been buried for more than two millenniums under the soil of what is today Iraq. How we came to uncover that world, and how that world reached out toward our own, is part of the story David Damrosch tells in The Buried Book: The Loss and Rediscovery of the Great Epic of Gilgamesh.

title: Artificial Intelligence, With Help From the Humans
description: COMPUTERS still do some things very poorly. Even when they pool their memory and processors in powerful networks, they remain unevenly intelligent. Things that humans do with little conscious thought, such as recognizing patterns or meanings in images, language or concepts, only baffle the machines.

title: Congress Expands Scope of Inquiries Into Justice Department Practices and Politics
description: WASHINGTON, March 24  Justice Department officials went before Congress this week to acknowledge that mistakes were made. Lawmakers remained skeptical of the accounts and demanded better answers. Members of Congress hinted at potential abuse of power and threatened to rein in the department.

title: Second Helpings at Hotels
description: When the Ritz-Carlton, Grand Cayman went shopping for a chef three years ago, it didnt go after a brand-name toque with an overcooked empire. It scored the critical darling Eric Ripert, who had yet to open a restaurant outside New York. Since then, hoteliers from Vegas to Boca are not out to get the old war horses  Alain Ducasse or Wolfgang Puck  but one of the hot new gastropreneurs.

title: Park Loses a Battle and Faces Another
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 24  Chan Ho Park pitched so well Saturday that the Mets are sending him out again Monday. It is not typical fare for a starting pitcher, but then again, as far as the Mets are concerned, Park is no longer a starter.

title: A Place to Play a Piano, Forte
description: IN all the places Ronen Segev has lived in Manhattan, only one neighbor ever complained that his piano-playing made too much noise.

title: Free Throws Bounce Out, and So Does No. 1 Duke
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 24  For 39 minutes 59.9 seconds, Rutgers and Duke had parried and countered through a gritty, intense N.C.A.A. womens tournament regional semifinal game that had a frenzied final minute of momentum shifts and gasping, clutch plays.

title: Fedoruk Learns Downside of Being Flyers Enforcer
description: VOORHEES, N.J., March 24  A day after the Rangers Colton Orr knocked him cold in a fight, sending him to a hospital, Philadelphia Flyers forward Todd Fedoruk decided Thursday that it would not be such a good idea to watch television when he got home.

title: A Mexican Newcomer, Like Its Sister, Is a Star
description: WHEN Besito opened in Huntington a year ago, it changed the way Long Islanders viewed Mexican restaurants. This was no spare storefront with an earnest but limited kitchen. Nor was it one of the chains serving Tex-Mex favorites and combination plates, where everything tastes the same. Besito was an upscale, elegant spot with exciting food. It immediately flew to the head of the class as the Islands best Mexican restaurant.

title: Sept. 11 Tribute Faces Legal Challenge
description: JERSEY CITY

title: How They Lived and Loved
description: The Yale University Art Gallerys exquisite new American folk art exhibition opened the day before Valentines Day with over-the-top pink walls and the title Made for Love: Selections From the Jane Katcher Collection of Americana. But it is much more than hearts and flowers.

title: Dallas Does Dallas
description: There is a statue in the Nasher Sculpture Center in downtown Dallas that seems particularly fitting for this particular city. Called The Age of Bronze, it is by Rodin and happens to be the oldest piece in the collection, a life-size, perfectly formed male nude in a pose that is both pensive and slightly pained. It is supposed to depict, according to the director of the museum, Steven A. Nash, the dawning of a new age of self-awareness, or self-consciousness. Distinguishing between the two has long been a psychic struggle here, though the unqualified success of the Nasher itself  a gift to Dallas from the shopping-mall magnate and local philanthropist Raymond D. Nasher, housed in a flawless, quietly self-confident building by Renzo Piano  suggests that Dallas might finally be getting there. The city seems willing to throw off its long-held infatuation with glitz and glamour, while remaining obsessed with maintaining a reputation for impeccable, indisputable good taste.

title: Cassady a Special, Special Instructor for Yanks
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 21  He is still on a depth chart every day, listed as No. 40, the way he was in his glory days more than a half-century ago. Howard Cassady, the running back known as Hopalong who won the Heisman Trophy for Ohio State in 1955, has been in baseball longer than he was in football.

title: City in Florida Fires Official Who Planned to Change Sex
description: LARGO, Fla., March 24  The longtime city manager here was fired early Saturday, one month after he disclosed his plans to seek a sex change.

title: New Identities Spring From Former Retail Stores
description: THE small-city department store has had a tough few decades.

title: Pakistan Cricket Team, Coach Killed, to Go Home
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 24  Pakistans national cricket team departed Jamaica on Saturday and left behind both a humiliating early elimination in the Cricket World Cup and the body of their slain coach, Bob Woolmer.

title: Pattern of Migration
description: I grew upon one of the last orange-and-avocado ranches in Orange County, Calif., now a housing tract where cookie-cutter ranch homes have million-dollar price tags. My parents emigrated from Northern Ireland  Mom from Belfast and Dad from a village in County Derry  and for the first decade or so of my life, my parents still called Ireland home.

title: Jeers Go On in Local Enron Scandal
description: INSIDE the lemon-yellow building that houses the Gloria Wise Community Center in Co-op City, a dozen kindergartners in an after-school program rehearsed a hip-hop song about math, while sixth graders cut flower shapes from construction paper for a springtime art project.

title: Preservation and Ecology Clash in Windmill Repair
description: BRIDGEHAMPTON

title: Security Council Votes to Tighten Iran Sanctions
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 24  The United Nations Security Council unanimously agreed Saturday to impose new, more stringent sanctions to press Iran to suspend uranium enrichment and rejoin negotiations over its nuclear program.

title: Florida Ends Oregons Run
description: ST. LOUIS, March 25  It is traditional for winning teams to cut down the nets after capturing a regional round of the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament. But they do not often start as early as Florida did today when the Gators beat Oregon, 85-77, to qualify for the Final Four.

title: New-Generation Collectors Give Toyota Some Respect
description: ONE of the few automotive niches where Toyota does not yet have a strong presence is the collector car market. Fifty years after its first troubled attempts to bring cars to American roads, there are signs that this may be changing: quietly, and outside the usual collector car circles, a groundswell of interest in vintage Toyotas has been building.

title: Go Figure
description: The Language Mavenhood is becoming less pluralistically ignorant.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: O.K. Everywhere

title: How to Show That Youre No Gordon Gekko
description: BURIED in the Blackstone Groups 221-page-thick prospectus is an unusual paragraph: The firm says it plans to start a charitable foundation.

title: 2 Newark Men Charged With Beating Informant
description: Two New Jersey men said to be members of the Grape Street Crips gang in Newark were indicted on charges of severely beating an informant who was cooperating with the F.B.I. in a drug investigation of the gang.

title: You Want Your HD? Here Are Three Options
description: HD RADIO offers better reception  zero static  than conventional AM and FM broadcasts. The digital signal is transmitted in the same frequency as conventional analog stations, so you dont need a new antenna for your car and theres no subscription fee to listen to HD stations.

title: Carters 40, Plus Pizazz, Let Nets Steal a Victory
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., March 24  In a battle to make the playoffs, the Nets have become a bottom-line team, one with a premium on victories and little regard for aesthetics.

title: Diamonds Move From Blood to Sweat and Tears
description: KOIDU, Sierra Leone  The tiny stone settled into the calloused grooves of Tambaki Kamandas palm, its dull yellow glint almost indiscernible even in the noontime glare.

title: Writing in Verse Helps Redick Cope
description: When J. J. Redick, a guard for the Orlando Magic, was in eighth grade, he used an outlet that he learned from his favorite teacher, Terri Steffen, to cope with the death of his maternal grandfather. That outlet was poetry.

title: For Europe, a Moment to Ponder
description: SEVILLE, Spain

title: Economic Reformer Will Lead Shanghai
description: HONG KONG, March 24  The ruling Communist Party appointed Xi Jinping as the top leader of Shanghai, the east coast urban center whose previous leadership was purged in one of the most sweeping corruption crackdowns in the countrys recent history.

title: Call Me, Ishmael
description: It could all have been so different. Just think: every thorny literary problem solved by modern technology. Who hasnt read Wuthering Heights and gnashed her teeth at poor Cathys fate, yoked to dreary Edgar Linton when we all know she yearns to swoon into hunky Heathcliffs arms? But alas, unaware that her beloved is listening, she appears to refuse him in no uncertain terms: It would degrade me to marry Heathcliff now. And so Heathcliff lopes away into the storm-wracked night without hearing the rest of her speech (he shall never know how I love him), and readers are denied the swoony bliss of true romance. So admit: Youve thought it. Ive thought it. Weve all thought it. If only theyd had their phones!

title: Ripples From the Subprime Storm
description: SOME homeowners may have skipped recent articles about the subprime mortgage meltdown, thinking its of interest only to investors. But mortgage industry professionals say that the subprime collapse has significant implications for all homeowners  even those with good credit.

title: Miami Beach:  The Fontainebleau Suites
description: THE BASICS

title: Last Call?
description: STATEN ISLANDS oldest bar, Liedys Shore Inn, is the kind of place where the 73-year-old telephone sounds like an old-fashioned alarm clock when it rings.

title: Blair Says Iran Was Unjustified in Seizing 15
description: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain said today that the seizure of 15 British naval personnel by Iranian forces last week was unjustified and wrong and took place in Iraqi waters.

title: Vintage Sounds From the Sahara and Points South
description: Group Doueh

title: The Arts Here. Wheres the Crowd?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Northeast Los Angeles: Set for a Close-Up
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Team Managers Expect Anything, and Thats Not an Exaggeration
description: As the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament enters its final week, teams are scrambling to prepare.

title: Campaign Finance Capers
description: By day, lawmakers feud over the state budget with new-found intensity. But at dusk, Albanys legislative routines revert to normal. Sundown is fund-raising hour in the state capital, the time when every restaurant or club or hotel has a room or two with an open bar and a few tough canaps and a lawmaker shaking hands in exchange for campaign checks.

title: Eating and Drinking in Spains Capital
description: EATING ON THE RUN

title: The Secretary We Had
description: After the 1988 presidential election, Donald Rumsfeld sent George H. W. Bush a congratulatory letter. In it, Rumsfeld, who had antagonized Bush during the Ford administration, wrote that he would like to be your ambassador to Japan. It was quite a comedown for Rumsfeld, who had harbored presidential ambitions of his own. But a person on the Bush transition team responsible for handling such requests noticed that Rumsfelds letter had already been reviewed, and that scrawled across it in capital letters was a fatal verdict: No! This will never happen!! G. B.

title: Election of Gay Candidate Would Be a First on S.I.
description: In a special election this week, voters on Staten Island could make history by electing the first openly gay official in the borough, the citys most conservative.

title: Warming Up on Capitol Hill
description: Al Gore held his first hearing on global warming about 25 years ago, when he was a member of the House of Representatives, and a quarter century later Congress seems to be listening to him. Apart from the usual dinosaurs  James Inhofe, who took great glee in pointing out that Mr. Gore had a big house that used lots of energy, and Trent Lott, who dismissed the former vice presidents ideas as garbage  Mr. Gore received a strong welcome from the two Congressional committees that will frame any legislation to deal with the warming threat.

title: The General and the Housewife
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan

title: Sasha Evans, Josh Orth
description: Sasha Evans and Josh Orth were married last evening at the Maritime Hotel in New York. Jay S. Dankberg, a retired New York City housing court judge, officiated.

title: In New Jersey, Old Slave Quarters vs. New Homes
description: SOUTH BRUNSWICK, N.J.  By the New Jersey Turnpike, where the states rural past runs into mammoth warehouses, a tug of war is taking place over the fate of a farmhouse built in 1713 with its cramped slave quarters over the kitchen still intact and a where a Revolutionary-era spinning wheel and a bill of sale for a young black girl were unearthed in the basement.

title: A Director Comfortable With Catastrophe
description: THERES something about the way the Danish director Susanne Bier says the word comfortable that tells you a lot. Shes trying to explain why, even though she likes working with actors she knows, she always casts unfamiliar ones too. Ive got this fear of becoming comfortable, she says, carefully pronouncing all four syllables and letting her face, her tone and her body language convey complete distaste.

title: James Cramer as Emily Litella
description: James J. Cramer, CNBCs televangelist of trading with his manic  Mad Money  show, now says that those sins he was confessing were not his own.

title: Freshmen Lead Buckeyes Right Where They Expected to Go
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 24  Back when Mike Conley Jr. and Greg Oden were precocious high school teammates dominating the A.A.U. circuit, they were advertised as the ultimate package deal.

title: Sight Specific in Venice
description: Since theyre the only thing about him remotely clichd, its impossible not to grant the 33-year-old Spanish design hotshot Jaime Hayon his signature spectacles. In the tradition of luminaries like Philip Johnson and Daniel Libeskind, Hayons rubber azure frames have come to define his image  an appropriately hipper, quirkier one than his dark-rimmed elders.

title: Training a More Skeptical Eye on Grant Requests
description: FOR years, members of the Suffolk County Legislature have doled out grants, ranging from several hundred to many thousands of dollars, to local groups and nonprofit agencies in the county.

title: An Eccentric Cinema Landscape
description: HOW is this for a day at the movies? And not just any day  today:

title: G.O.P. Senators Are Critical of Gonzales
description: WASHINGTON, March 25  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales faced a weakening of Congressional support over the weekend, as Republican lawmakers joined Democrats in questioning his credibility, pointing to new evidence that conflicts with his statements that he played little role in the deliberations on the dismissal of eight United States attorneys.

title: Susan Bernard, Joel Grae
description: Susan Pitt Bernard and Joel Belloch Grae were married last evening at Sharz Caf and Wine Bar in Manhattan. Robert D. Lippmann, a retired Supreme Court judge in Manhattan, officiated.

title: Calendar of Events
description: FILM

title: Gentlemen of the Road
description: Chapter 9: On anxieties arising from the impermissibility, however unreasonable, of an elephant's rounding out a prayer quorum.

title: Moving the Air Throughout a Home
description: FOR many homeowners, the term whole-house ventilation produces an image of a large louvered fan that creates indoor breezes as it sucks outside air through open windows, down hallways, around corners, up stairs and then into and out of the attic.

title: Galit Student, Seth Myers
description: Galit Student, a daughter of Nechama and Isaac Student of Teaneck, N.J., is to be married today in New York to Seth Meigs Myers, a son of Sue-Ellen and Douglas M. Myers of Cambridge, Mass. Rabbi Lester B. Bronstein is to officiate at the Central Park Boathouse.

title: Rules of the Game
description: Q: As a former presidential candidate and three-term Democratic senator from New Jersey, you are surprisingly hard on Democrats in your forthcoming book, The New American Story, in which you criticize the party for constantly awaiting rescue by a fairy-tale prince. One of their curses is the search for the charismatic candidate, which is really a search for how you felt during J.F.K.s time and after the assassination.

title: Acknowledging Our History (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Famous Frames
description: Sometimes an exhibition does not need a big theme or a purpose; it can just be a collection of beautiful, powerful pictures. So it is with The Best of Photography and Film From the George Eastman House Collection, now at the Long Island Museum in Stony Brook.

title: Not So Smart About Smart Growth; There Are Hidden Costs for Hospital Expansion (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Is This the Answer to Drug Use?
description: Hackettstown, N.J.

title: Take a Train, Help Save the Planet (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Comfort and Style
description: The snow hadnt disappeared from the streets of New York and already the first trend of spring could be seen up and down Madison Avenue: the revival of flat ballet-style shoes. In the 1950s, they were a popular alternative to spindly high heels; designers of calf-length full skirts showed their fashions with ballet slippers made by Capezio. At the time, such shoes were not commercially available. But today many manufacturers produce variations of the ballet flat. Not to be outdone, a carriage horse in Central Park showed off its own spring shoes: hooves painted with purple glitter.

title: Touch of Evil
description: A Mo Hayder novel makes a nice palate cleanser when youve binged on too many mellifluent literary mysteries and dont feel like shooting it out with yet another wise-racking private eye. Starting with her debut thriller, Birdman, with its lurid depictions of the modus operandi of a surgically trained serial killer, Hayder has always exercised her considerable storytelling skills by going straight for the gut. After giving pedophilia a whirl in The Treatment, she mothballed the conventionally driven London cop who served as her series detective and in The Devil of Nanking wrote a grotesque but thoughtful account of the 1937 Nanking massacre, filtered through the perceptions of a troubled modern-day Englishwoman with disturbing issues of her own.

title: New Data, New Worry on Housing
description: FOR the first time in months, the Federal Reserve has signaled that the economy has cooled to the point that the central bank is as likely to lower interest rates as it is to raise them. One analyst anticipates further signs of economic weakness this week.

title: You Want to Do What? And You Want to Do It When?
description: The next time someone tells you, Theres no time like the present, ask them what day they had in mind.

title: Feet on Mexican Soil, Eyes on the Stars
description: FROM the start the painter Rufino Tamayo has gotten a fair amount of flak. While the muralists Diego Rivera, David Alfaro Siqueiros and Jos Clemente Orozco were celebrated for creating a politically engaged art form native to Mexico, Tamayo was criticized for borrowing too much from European masters like Picasso and Matisse. Even his nickname seems vaguely insulting: In Mexico hes called the fourth great one.

title: Money, a Source and New Questions About a Story
description: CONTROVERSY is again swirling around The Timess 2005 article about 18-year-old Justin Berry and the Web world of child pornography, where the reporter Kurt Eichenwald discovered him and younger boys under the sway of predatory adults.

title: Before Leaping
description: WHEN you are considering buying in a new building, brokers agree that finding out as much as you can about the developer can help you gauge how much of a risk you might be taking.

title: Theyve Got Mail, but Look Who Delivered It
description: The mail arrives around 11 a.m. at Harbour Pointe at Shorehaven, a new gated development of pastel attached houses on a spit of central Bronx waterfront circled by gulls. A cluster of mailboxes is fixed to a pole at each blocks foot.

title: Jordana Kirsh, Jason Berger
description: Jordana Erin Kirsh, the daughter of Marcia and Michael A. Kirsh of Cresskill, N.J., was married last evening to Jason Henry Berger, the son of Heidi and Joseph H. Berger of Montreal. Rabbi Justin Schwartz officiated at the Rockleigh Country Club in New Jersey.

title: Something Old, Borrowed and Nothing Blue About It
description: Romance/Romance, a theatrical bonbon with book and lyrics by Barry Harman and music by Keith Herrmann, shifts mercurially between sweet and tart in its current stylish production at the Paper Mill Playhouse.

title: Up Front
description: Over the years, the critic, television host and cultural gadfly Clive James seems to have met  and interviewed  just about everyone worth knowing. His growing archive of video conversations with artists and writers, taped in his London library and gathered at his Web site (clivejames.com), constitutes a virtual Whos Who of British cultural life. With Cultural Amnesia, his 25th book, just published, James throws a kind of ideal cocktail party of the mind, bringing together idiosyncratic portraits of 100-odd cultural and political figures ranging from the celebrated (Anna Akhmatova, Charles de Gaulle, Dick Cavett) to the semi-obscure (Karl Tschuppik? Virginio Rognoni?). On this weeks cover, he takes the measure of the filmmaker and Nazi darling Leni Riefenstahl, the subject of two new biographies. Riefenstahls defenders have tried to present her as a feminist pioneer and auteurist standard bearer. But James will have none of it. Riefenstahl is the classic instance of the 20th-century artist hiding from reality behind her art, he said via e-mail. She was unique in her capacity to take a commanding place in a mans world, but she was anything but unique in her capacity for deception. You have to be sentimental, however, to call it self-deception. She wasnt a dreamer; she was a liar.

title: In the Hospital, Mrs. Edwards Set Campaigns Fate
description: LAS VEGAS, March 24  As the nurse fumbled to find the vein in her arm last Wednesday and Elizabeth Edwards was bracing for the worst possible news, her decision about her husbands presidential campaign was sealed.

title: Egypt to Vote on Expanding Powers of the Presidency
description: CAIRO, March 24  Egyptian officials are hoping to add powers to the Constitution that would allow the president to more easily dissolve Parliament and give him free rein to suspend civil liberties and imprison anyone deemed a terrorist threat.

title: Tip-Off | Beyond Baedekers
description: For decades it seems as if travel guides have stuck to the same old formula. But some new arrivals are out to reinvent the genre. In Taschens Hotels and More series ($25; www.taschen.com), Angelika Taschen presents her edited version of top city sites (for Paris and London, with Berlin on the way), organized around favorite hotels and lushly illustrated with photography. Taking word of mouth to its logical conclusion is the photographer Ami Sioux. For her new Degree Books series, from Scintilla (about $33; www.scintillalimited.com), she asked locals to draw maps to their favorite places, and then paired each with a photo she took once there. So far shes covered Reykjavik, Iceland (right); Berlin, London, Paris and New York are promised soon. And Moleskine has entered the postmodern era, where the emphasis is on you: part journal, part guidebook, its new City Notebooks ($16.95; www.moleskine.com) let you write your own itinerary, aided by maps, pull-off tabs and room to scribble. Editions for 12 European cities are out, with eight for North America due in spring and fall.

title: Inside the List
description: QUOTES I: A lots been written already  most of it deservedly positive  about the new Yale Book of Quotations, edited by Fred R. Shapiro. Its an attractive book: clean, tart, concise. And Shapiros got a nice eye for recent bits of pop flotsam, quoting snatches of lyrics from people like Snoop Dogg, Gwen Stefani and Lisa Left Eye Lopes. Still, its hard to flip through Shapiros anthology without puzzling over this question: What happened to the literary fiction (and nonfiction) of the last 25 years? Shapiro is not totally blind to this stuff  there are quotations from Alice Sebold, Kazuo Ishiguro, Roddy Doyle and some others. But its pretty slim pickings. Really, no David Foster Wallace, Jonathan Franzen or Nicholson Baker? No Lorrie Moore, Jhumpa Lahiri or Zadie Smith? No Mary Gaitskill, Allegra Goodman, Jeffrey Eugenides, Rick Moody or David Gates? And how about nonfiction writers like Malcolm Gladwell, Elizabeth Gilbert, Eric Schlosser, James Wood, David Sedaris and William Langewiesche? Or poets like Kay Ryan and Tony Hoagland? Uh-uh. Nope. Nada. Nyet.

title: The Week in New Jersey
description: Farewell to Irritating Emissions Testing Systems

title: Baby Imminent? Plan Ahead
description: BY definition, theres no good time to die. But whats the best time to be born? Though variables are involved, heres one answer: avoid weekends.

title: Her Ride to Nowhere
description: IN my native Iowa, it was easy to be seduced by the pristine geometry of vacant blacktops, where a car can travel at least mile a minute, stair-stepping from field to unclothed field and not meet a patrol car.

title: Correction: The Shape of Cinema, Transformed at the Click of a Mouse
description: An article last Sunday about movie download services referred incorrectly to the availability of the film Black, starring the Bollywood star Amitabh Bachchan. It was indeed released theatrically in the United States, in 2005, and is out on DVD; it was not unreleased here in theaters or on DVD.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the multiethnic character of the Highbridge neighborhood in the Bronx misidentified the location of the Shady Moon Deli and Grocery, which is three blocks from the site of a fire on March 7 that killed 10 people. It is on Nelson Avenue, not Nelson Street.

title: Egypt Refuses U.N. Request to Help Sway Sudan Leader
description: CAIRO, March 24  President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt rebuffed a request on Saturday from Secretary General Ban Ki-moon to influence Sudans president to drop his objections to United Nations peacekeepers in Darfur.

title: Cruise Lines Face More Policing of Waste Disposal
description: THIS summer, a new kind of passenger might make an appearance on cruise ships in Alaska: rangers whose job is to make sure the vessels are not polluting the states waters. The Alaskan state program, which includes plans to have as many as 60 monitors inspect ships waste disposal methods, is one of the latest examples of state and federal efforts to keep billions of gallons of cruise ship waste from affecting coastal waters.

title: In Baseball, Searching for Balance in the Scheduling Vortex
description: As anyone holding his riddled N.C.A.A. tournament bracket will groan, records of college basketball teams  29-5 here, 18-10 there  are often not what they seem. The collective strength of a teams opponents over a season plays a crucial role in a teams tournament future, by most estimates ranking only behind school colors and Menacing Mascot Index.

title: U.S. Envoy Says He Talked With Iraq Rebels
description: BAGHDAD, March 25  The senior American envoy in Iraq, Ambassador Zalmay Khalilzad, held talks last year with men he believed represented major insurgent groups in a drive to bring militant Sunni Arabs into politics.

title: Drone From Stevens Lab Will Patrol in the Hudson
description: HOBOKEN

title: A Listeners Take
description: IS it worth the time, trouble and cost to upgrade a cars sound system? If you appreciate better sound, it is.

title: Kristen Boswell, James Hayes III
description: Kristen Anna Boswell, the daughter of Karen Boswell and Stephen T. Boswell of Wyckoff, N.J., was married yesterday to James F. Hayes III, the son of Andrea W. Hayes and Mr. Hayes Jr. of Hawthorne, N.J. The Rev. Dr. David E. Wiley III officiated at Grace United Methodist Church in Wyckoff.

title: A Republican Up-and-Comer Vows to Revive His Party
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Amid the sea of square jaws and swept-back gray hair in Congress, Representative Adam H. Putnam, a tousled redhead whose cherubic appearance still causes Capitol police to stop him occasionally, appears a bit out of place.

title: When Walter Mitty Met Conway Twitty
description: IM standing inside a darkened eight-by-eight-foot recording booth in Nashville, staring into a microphone. A window looks into a small studio where the musicians Ive hired are exchanging ideas in shorthand. I can hear them through my headphones (Bob, come in one bar later on the vocal), but I cant see much. I feel vulnerable and excited. I wonder if this is what plastic surgery is like. After all, these specialists are nipping and tucking one of my most intimate parts: my song.

title: For a Charmer From Iraq, an Angel From Queens
description: ON Monday evening, a 2 -year-old Iraqi girl named Noor Sabah sat in a hospital room at St. Marys childrens hospital in Bayside, Queens, and struggled to remove the packaging surrounding a Disney Tinker Bell doll. Noors mother, Eman Jassim Mohammed, who has been sharing a bed with her sick daughter since the pair checked into the hospital earlier this month, used a pair of surgical scissors to free the golden-haired doll of its complicated rigging, much to the delight of the little girl.

title: The Homeless Maze
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg set a very ambitious goal when he said he would reduce the number of homeless by one third in five years. Halfway through the program, though, the ranks of the homeless have gone up considerably, with the number of families reaching a new high.

title: Pod Hotels
description: A new wave of budget accommodations are landing everywhere. How did it happen? Here, one plausible story.

title: The Urban Landscape of So Paulo
description: A culture of creativity is fashioning a new capital of cool.

title: Boston Street Smarts
description: For the trio behind Bodega, the city is far from buttoned up.

title: Yemen's Galapagos
description: An island off of the Arabian Peninsula shelters 700 unique species.

title: The Iconic City of Texas
description: Dallas learns to love itself.

title: The European Economy Since 1945
description: In the second half of the twentieth century, the lives of Europeans were transformed almost beyond recognition. In 1950, many of the continent's residents heated their homes with coal, cooled their food with ice, and lacked even rudimentary forms of indoor plumbing. Today, their lives are eased and enriched by natural-gas furnaces, electric refrigerators, and an array of electronic gadgets that boggles the mind. Gross domestic product per capita, what the income of a typical resident of Europe will buy, tripled in the second half of the twentieth century. The quality of life improved even more than suggested by this simple measure. Hours worked declined by one-third, providing an enormous increase in leisure time. Life expectancy lengthened as a result of improved nutrition and advances in medical science. To be sure, not all was sweetness and light. Unemployment rose. Tax burdens soared. Environmental degradation, political repression, and limits on consumer sovereignty were pervasive under the authoritarian regimes that dominated Eastern Europe for four decades after World War II. But by any objective standard, the last half century has left Europeans today enormously better off than their grandparents were fifty years ago.

title: Off the Record
description: Tupac Shakur is chain-smoking, sitting in a chair, when I arrive for our interview one December afternoon in 1995. Glancing out the window of his hotel room off the Sunset Strip in Los Angeles, he bears little likeness to the hotheaded, fire-breathing hellion that he often becomes in his videos, in the courtroom, or on the local news. With the television blaring in the background, the twenty-four-year-old rapper's eyes dart around the room as the phone rings, his pager vibrates, and room service arrives in unison.

title: Leni Riefenstahl
description: When King Wilhelm I of Prussia was proclaimed German kaiser in 1871, Berlin became a center of political power. With its three million inhabitants, the metropolis on the Spree became an economic, civic, and, in particular, social and cultural hub. At the turn of the century, Berlin possessed an expressly international flair, even if restrictive Wilhelmian policies repeatedly checked modern developments and avant-garde movements. But this had little effect on the fascination that the city held. Visitors, both German and foreign, strolled along the elegant Unter den Linden, past spectacularly ostentatious architecture and tributes in stone to the Hohenzollern rulers. They visited the well-stocked department stores, the opulent opera houses, the magnificent revue palaces, and Max Reinhardt's celebrated theaters, sampling the various worlds that Berlin nurtured in the Grnderjahre, the years of expansion in the early 1870s when it basked in the light of its newfound importance.

title: Tales From the Torrid Zone
description: Some years ago I returned to my birthplace and found it had become a luxury holiday resort. Described in the brochures as "Iririki, Island of Elegance" and lying snugly in Port Vila's blue harbour, its forty-four acres were crowned with flowering trees and contoured like a tall polychromic hat; you could walk the shadowy path around its brim in twenty minutes. It was a comfortable spot; when the mainland sweltered, Iririki usually got sea breezes and cooling showers. Once it had contained just two houses: our mission bungalow and-set in parklike grounds with a flagpole flying a bedspread-sized Union Jack-the palatial residence of the British Resident Commissioner. Now seventy-two air-conditioned accommodation units were strung across its northern end.

title: Virgin
description: By any material reckoning, virginity does not exist. It can't be weighed on a scale, sniffed out like a truffle or a smuggled bundle of cocaine, retrieved from the lost-and-found, or photographed for posterity. Like justice or mercy, we can only determine that it exists at all because of the presence of its effects-or its side effects. Unlike many of our habits and practices, virginity reflects no known biological imperative and grants no demonstrable evolutionary advantage, nor has being able to recognize it in others been shown to increase anyone's chances of reproduction or survival. Perhaps this is why even our nearest animal relatives, whose sexual behavior and social structures are often startlingly similar to our own in other respects, show no signs at all of knowing what virginity is.

title: Rumsfeld
description: Just after 9:37 A.M. on the morning of September 11, 2001, Officer Aubrey Davis of the Pentagon police was standing outside Donald Rumsfeld's office on the third floor of the Pentagon's E Ring. Inside, Rumsfeld, though aware that the World Trade Center towers in New York had already been hit, was proceeding with his regularly scheduled CIA briefing. Davis, on the other hand, had concluded from watching the TV news that the country was under attack and the Pentagon might be a target. Assigned to the defense secretary's personal bodyguard, he had come on his own initiative, ready to move Rumsfeld to a better-protected location.

title: Lost City Radio
description: They took Norma off the air that Tuesday morning because a boy was dropped off at the station. He was quiet and thin and had a note. The receptionists let him through. A meeting was called.

title: The Week Ahead: March 25 - 31
description: FILM

title: Pulse
description: Pedal and shop until you drop, expanding to welcome a baby line to the family and more.

title: Editors Choice
description: THEN WE CAME TO THE END, by Joshua Ferris. (Little, Brown, $23.99.) Layoff notices fly in Ferriss acidly funny first novel, set in a whitecollar office in the wake of the dot-com debacle.

title: Paperback Row
description: BLACK SWAN GREEN, by David Mitchell. (Random House, $13.95.) The wonders of adolescence collide with the trials of real life in this lyrical novel, set in a provincial English village. Mitchell, author of the Man Booker Prize finalist Cloud Atlas, tells the story of 13-yearold Jason Taylor in 13 chapters, one for every month of 1982, plus January 1983. Jason is drawn to the exotic and otherworldly; he submits poems to the parish newsletter under the pseudonym Eliot Bolivar and retreats to the woods beside Black Swan Green, where Gypsies camp in the quarry and an old woman lives in an isolated, fairy-tale house. At the same time he has to contend with his severe stammer, schoolyard bullies and the simmering tension between his parents. In Jason, Mitchell creates an evocative yet authentically adolescent voice, Nell Freudenberger wrote here.

title: Women and Art
description: Images from "Global Feminism" at the Brooklyn Museum.

title: So Paulos Concrete Jungle
description: Rio may have samba and Speedos, but these days it's So Paulo that is swinging like the hips of the girl from Ipanema. Brazil's largest city  11 million and counting  has transformed itself from a dull and featureless capital of finance into the epicenter of Brazilian culture, where art, architecture, design and fashion are flourishing.

title: Oh, Baby
description: This spring, food things come in teeny-weeny packages. So if you've got it, milk it.

title: Ambassador Bids Farewell to Iraq
description: Zalmay Khalilzad, President Bushs nominee for ambassador to the United Nations, leaves Iraq this week.

title: Big Game in the Little Dance
description: For all the excitement of the N.C.A.A. Tournament, the most thrilling, ludicrous ending of any college basketball game this March  and probably all season, maybe all decade  was early Saturday afternoon, in the Division II championship game. (These schools are so small that they dont have players names on the backs of their jerseys, because they cant afford not to recycle uniforms from year to year.) The favorites were Winona State University of tiny Winona, Minn.; the Warriors had won 57 consecutive games and were the defending champions. Their opponents? Barton College, a miniscule private Christian college in Wilson, N.C. With 45 seconds left, Winona State held a seven-point lead and appeared well on its way to a second consecutive championship.

title: How the College Game Went Pro
description: After Ohio State beat Memphis in the South Regional final, the CBS analyst Bill Raftery interviewed coach Thad Matta and players (and high school friends) Greg Oden and Mike Conley Jr. The following exchange between Raftery and Matta took place:

title: Have Clothes, Will Travel
description: Gear for urban walkers, rain makers and stylish weekend warriors.

title: Why We Travel
description: "The paraglider becomes an extension of yourself. You envision where you want to go: up, down, left, right, to that mountain, to that river. And you go. To me, its an addiction."

title: In the Details
description: Portland's original and vintage-mod Ace Hotel is all about the small touches.

title: The Chimerical Beauty of the Faroe Islands
description: An isolated area where the march of time has not eroded ancient ways.

title: Close Reading: Rufino Tamayo
The Rural Bastion of Le Perche
description: This rural region of France is as beautiful as it is unknown.

title: Tales From the Torrid Zone: Travels in the Deep Tropics
description: A Place Called Pandemonium

title: The Bees Are Back in Town
description: Its getting dangerous to be on the field in spring training. Three days after a swarm of bees forced a few Yankees to flee the field in Sarasota during a game, another angry gang invaded the field here in Lakeland during batting practice. Everyone scurried for cover as the bees spread to left field.

title: Maybe They Can Activate Ron Guidry
description: Breaking news from Yankees camp, and its not good: Jeff Karstens is hurt, too.

title: Sunday Sampler Platter
description: The battle between the White House and Congress over the firings of eight U.S. attorneys, continued to dominate the Sunday news shows, with several prominent Republicans questioning Attorney General Alberto Gonzaless credibility.

title: Random Musings From Port St. Lucie
description: The worst-kept secret around these parts is the Mets rotation, which will comprise Tom Glavine, Orlando Hernandez, John Maine, Oliver Perez and, when they need him in two weeks, Mike Pelfrey. The Mets have announced that Keith Hernandez will throw the ceremonial first pitch at the home opener April 9 but are not ready to announce that Glavine will start opening day (even though hes been on schedule to do so since exhibition games began).

title: The Secret Is Out
description: Wouldnt you know, a few minutes after todays game ended, Willie Randolph called Mike Pelfrey into his office. In came the pitching coach Rick Peterson, too. The door closed, and less than a minute later, Pelfrey walked out wearing a poker face.You hear things, Pelfrey said. I was prepared for the worst, but I guess it turned out good.

title: The Official Cup of the N.C.A.A.
description: Near the beginning of a news conference with North Carolina Coach Roy Williams and his players on Saturday, someone with a video camera poked through a blue curtain, discreetly aiming the camera at the stage where the coach and players sat. The N.C.A.A.-appointed moderator quickly told the person to leave, because the only cameras allowed were the two at the back of the room.

title: Behind a Mascot, a Familys Pain
description: The saddest sidebar to the N.C.A.A. tournament involves a 21-year-old North Carolina student named Jason Ray (or Jayson, as there seems to be some uncertainty over the spelling of his first name) who lies in a coma, on life support, in a New Jersey hospital.

title: Mascot Brotherhood
description: With North Carolinas mascot Jayson K. Ray in a New Jersey hospital after being hit by a car on Friday, his counterparts in St. Louis at the Midwest regional were thinking about him and taking sympathetic action an hour before the game between Oregon and Florida.

title: Sean MacPherson | Restaurateur
description: Sean MacPherson and his restaurant Swingers defined early-90s Los Angeles. A decade later, his Park restaurant and Maritime Hotel turned Manhattans West Chelsea into a tailgate party for groovy young things. Now, after his glamification of the Waverly Inn (with Graydon Carter and others) in the West Village, his new Bowery Hotel is giving devotees a reason to head east. Why the Bowery? I love the streets history and its location, even its sound. And the neighborhood is shifting. Besides us, the New Museum and a Whole Foods are coming. The look? Everything is handpicked, all antiques and old rugs, like our version of the Algonquin. Do you ever take a break? I just went snowboarding in Colorado, and I go surfing in Mexico  Im a Mexican citizen.

title: Open Skies, Cloudy Skies?
description: Suddenly the Atlantic is looking like an even easier hop. Open skies on routes between Europe and the United States would boost travel between many more cities. But environmentalists are crying foul, saying the likely boost in sales would wipe out European initiatives to cut aviation emissions. Airlines are vowing to clean up their act. Richard Branson of Virgin says he will plow billions of dollars into research into cleaner fuels. British Airways emphasizes the need for more efficient engines. Many carriers encourage their passengers to offset their emissions by funding green projects. But will any of these efforts help to cancel out the effects of new flights serving the 25 million extra air passengers who are expected to take advantage of open skies over the next five years?

title: Give Me An A
description: Three guys wearing blue sweatshirts, each with a large letter on the front, stood behind the Georgetown bench. H-O-Y they read. Minutes later, another guy appeared. He wore an S. An empty seat was between the Y and the S. The A must have been stuck in the concessions line.

title: Sun Devils On A Mission
description: After stunning No. 1 seed Duke in the Greensboro Regional semifinal on Saturday, No. 4 Rutgers is considered by many to be the heavy favorite going into its Round of 8 game against No. 3 Arizona State. The teams play on Monday in Greensboro, N.C., with the winner advancing to the Final Four in Cleveland.

title: Comment on The General and the Housewife
description: Nicks Sunday column, The General vs. The Housewife is about a mother of three who is partly responsible for the street protests in Pakistan against the countrys president, Gen. Pervez Musharraf. Youre invited to read the column or watch the video and then add your comments on this post.

title: Is Life Elsewhere?
description: Of all the questions facing mankind, perhaps the most fascinating is concerned with life beyond the Earth. Does it exist  if so, where?  and what will it be like? So far we do not have the answers, and some people still maintain that we are alone in the universe. Since there are around a hundred thousand million stars in our galaxy, many of which are attended by planets, this seems unlikely, but we cannot be sure because we have no positive proof of life anywhere except on Earth. However, I have the feeling that at least one of these fundamental points may soon be cleared up.

title: For Four Teams, a Season to Remember
description: The great philosopher Charlie Brown once, while trying to inspire his charges during a conference at the pitching mound, said that no one remembers who finished in second place. (Linus, ever the plucky contrarian, began rattling off World Series losers throughout history.) The founding, organizing tenet of sports states that the only goal is to win a championship; anything less than that was a waste of time. You might as well have finished last.

title: Phew, Anyone TiVo That Game?
description: Whether the North Carolina-Georgetown game is labeled, oxymoronically, as an instant classic probably depends on which side you cheered for. But it would seem that a true classic game required both teams to play well  not just for about 35 minutes, but all the way until the end.

title: The Museum of Modern Music Philharmonic
description: Most modern artists dont have a problem with museums. I dont either. I love MOMA.

title: The Museum of Modern Music Philharmonic
description: Most modern artists don't have a problem with museums. I don't either. I love MOMA.

title: You Want to Do What? And You Want to Do It When?
description: Whats the worst time to buy a car? Eat at a fine restaurant? Get arrested? Times writers shared their thoughts on Sunday in Week in Review.

title: European Union, at 50, Seeks Footing as the World Shifts
description: BERLIN, March 25  Fifty years after its foundation was set in Rome as a trading bloc for six countries, the European Union marked a midlife milestone here on Sunday with all-night parties, a laid-back street festival and a fervent plea for renewal by the German chancellor, Angela Merkel.

title: Rice Aims for Delicate Balance in Mideast Shuttle
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank, March 25  American, Israeli and Arab officials continued their crawl toward Middle East peace negotiations on Sunday. Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice prodded the Israeli and Palestinian leaders to agree, at least, to negotiating objectives, while Egyptian officials said that they were waiting for Israel to make the next move.

title: Edwardss Cancer Has Spread Into One of Her Hips
description: Elizabeth Edwards, the wife of the presidential candidate John Edwards, elaborated on her cancer diagnosis in an interview broadcast last night, saying that the disease had spread to one of her hips.

title: Of Senate Snails and Scriveners
description: Campaign finance reform has progressed in Washington thanks, in part, to fast public posting of candidates megamillions on the Internet. House members must file electronically and so must party committees and lobbyist-donors. But not that ultimate redoubt of Capitol clubbiness, the Senate.

title: Campaign Candor
description: John and Elizabeth Edwards managed to keep smiling last week as their lives once again took a terrible turn. The former senator talked about the importance of staying tough. Mrs. Edwards, whose breast cancer has metastasized, said, Were going to always look for the silver lining.

title: India Attracts Universities From the U.S.
description: CHENNAI, India  It was an unusual university entrance interview.

title: Yankees Add Elbow to Injury Report
description: LAKELAND, Fla., March 25  The ballpark here is called Joker Marchant Stadium, and the name was appropriate for the Yankees on Sunday. Considering their luck with pitchers lately, they must have felt like the victims of another cruel joke.

title: In Alabama, Execution Without Representation
description: Nobody much likes the fact that Alabama does not provide indigent death row inmates with lawyers.

title: Study Says Drugs Work as Well as Stents
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 26  Many heart patients routinely implanted with stents to open arteries gain no lasting benefit compared to those treated with drugs alone, researchers are reporting today.

title: And to the Winners Go the Dinosaur Skull and the Mummified Hand
description: The dinosaur skull was advertised as perfect for a New York City apartment, though with a starting bid of $100,000, it was clear that the apartment in question was not, say, a studio in a walk-up.

title: G.O.P. Senators Lug Weight of War Toward 08
description: NORTH CONWAY, N.H., March 24  Senator John E. Sununu knows that his political future could hinge on the war in Iraq, try as he might to change the subject.

title: With a New Owner, a Book Publisher Gets a New Name
description: Warner Books, which has been inexorably linked with mass-market commercial fiction by authors like James Patterson and Nicholas Sparks, is taking on a new name and a new logo that it hopes will reflect its evolution as a publishing house, the company plans to announce today.

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about broad spying by the New York City police on people expected to protest in the city during the 2004 Republican National Convention referred incorrectly in some copies to the disposition of the property of one protester, Joshua Kinberg, who devised a bicycle equipped with cellphone, laptop and tubes that could spray the ground with messages in chalk. The spraying apparatus  not the bicycle  was held for more than a year before being returned; Mr. Kinberg says the authorities have still not returned his bicycle.

title: Texts That Run Rings Around Everyday Linear Logic
description: The feeling is familiar. You are listening to a piece of music, and nothing links one moment with the next. Sounds seem to emerge without purpose from some unmapped realm, neither connecting to what came before nor anticipating anything after. The same thing can happen while reading. Passages accumulate like tedious entries in an exercise book. Chaos, disorder, clumsiness, disarray: these must be the marks of poor construction or, perhaps, of deliberate provocation.

title: Hot Spectrum Draws Cash, and Ideals
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 25  It is referred to as the last beachfront property in the wireless world  a prized swath of spectrum that is about to be sold at federal auction. And it has touched off an intense lobbying effort pitting cellular companies against a variety of new players interested in the potential of a next-generation mobile Internet.

title: Brooklyn: Indictment in Scooter Crash
description: A Brooklyn teenager arrested last summer after a fatal water scooter accident in Mill Basin inlet has been indicted on charges of manslaughter and criminally negligent homicide, according to prosecutors. The teenager, Aristotle Plagianakos, 17, of Mill Basin, was charged in connection with a June 30 crash involving his water scooter and one driven by Paul Zaccaria, District Attorney Charles J. Hynes announced on Friday. Mr. Zaccaria, 17, also of Mill Basin, was killed; his body was not recovered until 37 days after the collision, prosecutors said.

title: I Still Dont Want Rats (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: City Asks Court Not to Unseal Police Spy Files
description: Lawyers for the city, responding to a request to unseal records of police surveillance leading up to the 2004 Republican convention in New York, say that the documents should remain secret because the news media will fixate upon and sensationalize them, hurting the citys ability to defend itself in lawsuits over mass arrests.

title: A Superhero for Tights (Er, Times) Like These
description: Captain America, who was killed this month in a comic book but is rumored to be returning to life in time for a movie, first came on the scene in 1941, back when a nervous nation was looking for a patriotic symbol of American power. But times have changed, and so have superheroes. In films like Batman Begins and television shows like Heroes, they are now more flawed, moody and ambivalent about power than ever.

title: Treasury Bills Scheduled for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes todays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills tomorrow.

title: Sopranos Colorful Voice Undimmed, Despite a Cold
description: Some things are more memorable for their imperfections: the fly in the amber, the lopsidedness in a friends smile. Add to this list Diana Damraus cold at her recital on Wednesday night at Weill Hall.

title: Even After Victory, Busch Is Not Sold on New Racecar
description: BRISTOL, Tenn., March 25  In the debut of Nascars Car of Tomorrow, 21-year-old Kyle Busch crossed the finish line first in the Food City 500 on Sunday. To celebrate, he spun out his car in front of the crowd, leaving dark circles of rubber on the light-colored concrete. When he drove into victory lane, he could not stop smiling.

title: A Rail System (and Patience) Are Stretched Thin in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, March 25  The century-old elevated train system here is as much a city fixture as the towering skyline and the piercing blue waters of Lake Michigan.

title: Mr. Pucks Good Idea
description: From time to time, consumers are reminded of the power they have, and the power of the choices they make. There is no better example than the rising popularity of organic food  a matter of conscience and of taste. More and more people are buying local, organic produce and trying to find meat and eggs and dairy products from farms that are not part of the horror of factory farming.

title: Failing Schools See a Solution in Longer Day
description: FALL RIVER, Mass.  States and school districts nationwide are moving to lengthen the day at struggling schools, spurred by grim test results suggesting that more than 10,000 schools are likely to be declared failing under federal law next year.

title: In Fight Over Spitzer Tax Plan, Its Loophole vs. Incentive
description: Executives of big companies doing business in New York knew they were in trouble as soon as Gov. Eliot Spitzers budget director invoked the l-word.

title: As Ridership Rises, Long Island Bus System Faces $4 Million Deficit
description: The riders in Jamaica waiting for the bus to Nassau County were a hardy lot. Some had spent an hour on the subway just to get to the bus stop, which was no more than a pole on a narrow sidewalk where the snow had not been shoveled. It was 7 a.m., and a freezing wind was whipping down Hillside Avenue.

title: Remember the Teletubbies? The Brand Owner Hopes So
description: IF nostalgia isnt what it used to be, a major reason may be efforts by marketers to encourage consumers to look back sooner rather than later.

title: Georgetown Heads to Final Four
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 25  The revived Georgetown fans roared with every basket, sensing a return to the past in the most unexpected of ways. And a generation after his father last led the Hoyas to the Final Four, Coach John Thompson III grabbed the public-address microphone at games end and led a cheer.

title: Manhattan: Tax Credit for Renters
description: A pair of bills introduced in the State Senate and Assembly would provide an estimated 1.1 million New York City households with an annual $300 rent credit on their city personal income taxes. The city would absorb the cost, $261 million a year. The City Council speaker, Christine C. Quinn, proposed the credit on Feb. 15, but it requires the approval of state lawmakers. Flanked by tenant advocates and politicians at a City Hall news conference yesterday, Ms. Quinn said that two-thirds of city residents were renters and that they deserved relief similar to the $400 rebate on property taxes that city homeowners have received each year since 2004. Individual renters with incomes of less than $43,000 and families with incomes of up to $75,000 would be eligible for the credit. Where roommates split the rent, the credit would be evenly divided among them unless they agreed on a different arrangement. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has not said whether he supports the proposal.

title: Justice Official Wont Testify on Prosecutor Firings
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  A lawyer for a Justice Department official involved in the controversial firings of eight United States attorneys said today that his client would not testify on Capitol Hill because she is convinced she would not be treated fairly.

title: Confident U.N.C. Watches Its Composure Simply Crumble
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 25  Even while Georgetown was chipping away at North Carolinas once-imposing lead, no one wearing Tar Heels blue seemed too concerned. The Tar Heels are talented, deep, confident and well-coached, and there is a certain mystique that surrounds this program. Imploding is not something that they do.

title: Bang on a Board: Sophisticated Music for Primitive Instruments
description: Watching the ensemble So Percussion brilliantly perform Steve Reichs Music for Pieces of Wood was like watching whirling dervishes enter an intensely focused, disciplined trance. But with the dervishes you are merely a voyeur. The audience at Miller Theater on Friday could share the state of ecstasy drummed up by the percussion group, which opened the Composer Portraits concert dedicated to Mr. Reich.

title: A Vocalist Who Relishes the Poetry
description: Gerald Finley, who sang at Zankel Hall on Friday night, has a bass-baritone of easy luxury. Mr. Finley must work hard to manage the top of his voice, but manage it he does. Elsewhere in his range there is a welcoming quality. Music is invited in, rather than pursued, and made at home.

title: For a Chief and His Son, a Chance at a Final Four Reunion
description: SAN JOSE, Calif., March 25  The U.C.L.A. Bruins are getting ready to play in the Final Four for the 17th time in their history.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an item in the Suits column in Sunday Business yesterday on a video clip in which James J. Cramer, a CNBC television personality, recommended ways to move stock prices, misidentified the organization that requested that the video clip be removed from YouTube.com. The request was made by TheStreet.com, which taped the original interview, not by CNBC. (Go to Article)

title: Anna Nicole Smiths Death Called Accidental
description: Anna Nicole Smith died from an accidental overdose of drugs, officials in Broward County said today. They said no criminal activity was involved and they did not expect to file charges against anyone.

title: Hey, Boss, Permission for a Follow-Up Question?
description: The Internet age was supposed to mean that concentration of the media in just a few hands is yesterdays news because the barriers to entry in the online world are so low.

title: Manhattan: Revising Mortgage Rules
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer, a Democrat of New York, said yesterday that he favored an overhaul of federal mortgage regulations, citing widespread concern about the surge in defaults and foreclosures involving subprime mortgages, risky home loans made to people with weak credit. Citing data from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Census Bureau, Mr. Schumer said that about 91,000 households in New York State, including 53,000 in the New York City metropolitan area, were at risk of foreclosure by the end of 2008, as interest rates on adjustable-rate mortgages are reset. At a hearing on Thursday, members of the Senate Banking Committee criticized the Federal Reserve for failing to curb mortgage lending abuses. The chairman, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, said that new legislation might not be needed and that excesses could be addressed under existing regulations.

title: The Circular Firing Squad in California
description: Reporting on the contretemps at The Los Angeles Times last week brings to mind a scene in which you come upon a sinking vessel and see people scrambling everywhere. And then you realize they are not looking for buckets, but guns.

title: A Disputed Fee
description: A dispute has been raging between elderly Holocaust victims and Burt Neuborne, a lawyer who helped win a $1.25 billion settlement from Swiss banks, over the size of the fees Mr. Neuborne has requested. A federal magistrate judge has wisely recommended significantly reducing the fees. If the Federal District Court accepts the recommendation, it will put an end to an unfortunate aspect of an important lawsuit.

title: Pakistan Detains Opposition Members
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 25  The Pakistani police detained hundreds of political opposition members in an attempt to thwart nationwide protests planned for Monday to denounce Gen. Pervez Musharrafs suspension of the chief justice, opposition leaders said Sunday. The government acknowledged some arrests but said the oppositions claims were exaggerated.

title: Iraq Moves to Ease Restraints on Baath Party Members
description: BAGHDAD, March 26  The American ambassador to Iraq, Zalmay Khalilzad, offered a sober assessment of the outlook for the country in the near future at his final news conference on Monday.

title: Indonesia Defiant on Refusal to Share Bird Flu Samples
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 26  Indonesian health officials remained defiant today at the start of a three-day meeting with the World Health Organization, saying Indonesia refused to share its H5N1 bird flu samples with the organizations researchers unless their country is guaranteed affordable access to vaccines.

title: Long Way Home: A Rough South Lion Honored in His Old Lair
description: OXFORD, Miss., March 24  The minimarts in this town are not allowed to sell cold beer, and anyone familiar with Larry Brown or his fiction might reasonably think that he is the reason. Mr. Brown, who grew up in this area, wrote stories with many a compulsive drinker, many a winding road and nary a designated driver.

title: Bogota: Complaint to Be Refiled
description: The State Ethics Commission says it does not have the authority to review an ethics complaint against Gov. Jon S. Corzine, the mayor of Bogota said yesterday, but he plans to refile his complaint today with another agency. The mayor, Steven Lonegan, a Republican, said that he would submit the complaint to the Advisory Ethics Panel, a two-member state board that makes determinations on the governors conduct. The complaint contends that Mr. Corzines gifts to Carla Katz, his former companion and a state labor leader, including a $470,000 loan that he eventually forgave, create an appearance of a conflict of interest. Mr. Corzine and Ms. Katz, president of Communications Workers of America Local 1034, which represents state workers, dated from 2002 until the summer of 2004. At the time, Mr. Corzine was a United States senator.

title: Theismann Dropped From Monday Night Crew
description: After one season as the lead analyst for Monday Night Football on ESPN, Joe Theismann will be dismissed and replaced by Ron Jaworski, the network is scheduled to announce today. Theismann is expected to be offered another job at the network.

title: A High Price for Freedom
description: Washington

title: Middle East Television (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Costly, Flawed Justice (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Shared Goal: A Decent Home (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: New Crop of Books on the Evils of Wall Street Misses Old Standards
description: In his 1958 novel From the Terrace, John OHara told the story of how Alfred Eaton deployed a suave manner and ruthless ambition to scale Wall Streets peaks, only to find himself out of a job at the age of 52.

title: Gators Get Defensive and Move Closer to Repeat
description: ST. LOUIS, March 25  It is traditional for winning teams to cut down the nets after capturing a regional round of the N.C.A.A. tournament, but they do not often start as early as Florida did Sunday when it defeated Oregon, 85-77, to advance to the Final Four.

title: Rangers Fortunate to Have Hot Goalie as Playoffs Near
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.

title: Its Not Your Mother-in-Law in a Tutu, but She Dances
description: There are no mothers-in-law in ballet, George Balanchine once proclaimed. But Francis Patrelle bit the bullet in What Do We Do About Mother? For this new work, performed by Dances Patrelle on Saturday night at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, he created not only an ailing mother-in-law (and mother) but also a grown son and daughter, a daughter-in-law and the daughters lover.

title: Fuzzy Critters With High Prices Offer Lesson in New Concepts
description: IF the face of e-commerce 1.0 was the Pets.com sock puppet, will the new face of e-commerce be a Webkinz?

title: Hoboken: Accident Stalls Path Train
description: A PATH train bound for the 33rd Street station in Manhattan derailed at 2:55 p.m. yesterday after leaving Hoboken, stranding about 300 passengers for roughly two hours, the authorities said. Pasquale DiFulco, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which manages the PATH system, said there were no injuries. After another PATH train was dispatched alongside the derailed train, he said, the passengers were transferred and taken to Hoboken, where they arrived at 4:15 p.m. He said one set of wheels on one of the trains middle cars had left the tracks, for reasons that remained unclear. Direct service from Hoboken to Manhattan had not resumed late yesterday, and Mr. DiFulco said it was unclear whether it would be restored for commuters this morning. But he said PATH riders could travel from Hoboken to the Pavonia station in Jersey City and then to 33rd Street in Manhattan.

title: Knicks Problems Are Clear, but the Solutions Are Not
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 25  Battered by injuries and now illness, the Knicks prepared for the most important stretch of their crumbling season Sunday without two more regulars.

title: Drop in Ad Revenue Raises Tough Question for Newspapers
description: For newspapers, February was the cruelest month. So far.

title: As Egypt Votes on Laws, Cynicism Rules the Street
description: CAIRO, March 25  There was no time on Sunday for politics in Qalaat el-Kabash, a poor neighborhood in a poor city, a neighborhood that burned to the ground five days ago.

title: The Hamas Conundrum
description: As Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice moves into the final days of her Middle East trip, she still needs to come up with a way to translate the current lull in the violence between Israel and the Palestinians into an opening for genuine peace negotiations.

title: Passing Test at End, Tiger Woods Again Excels
description: MIAMI, March 25  The wind was pressing palm trees sideways, whipping up waves and sending tiny leaves tumbling, but Tiger Woods walked from station to station with a firm back and a straight face.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about a fund-raiser for Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons presidential campaign held at SoulCycle, a spinning studio in Manhattan, misidentified the studios neighborhood in some copies. It is on the Upper West Side, not the Upper East Side.

title: A Fresh Face Vows to Revive the G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  Amid the sea of square jaws and swept-back gray hair in Congress, Representative Adam H. Putnam, a tousled redhead whose cherubic appearance still causes Capitol police to stop him occasionally, appears a bit out of place.

title: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about deliberations over the dismissal of eight United States attorneys misquoted President Bush in some editions. Speaking in his weekly radio address about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzaless role in removing the attorneys, Mr. Bush said I strongly support the attorney general in this decision, not in his decision.

title: Head of Smithsonian Resigns After Audit
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  The governing board of the Smithsonian Institution announced today that it had accepted the resignation of its top official, Lawrence M. Small, following an internal audit showing that the museum complex had paid for his routine use of such lavish perks as chauffeured cars, private jets, top-rated hotels and catered meals.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,227 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: John T. Gilbride, 90, Former Chairman of Military and Commercial Shipbuilder, Dies
description: John T. Gilbride, a former chairman and chief executive of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, once the largest independent shipbuilding company in the country, died on March 17 at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 90.

title: Rangers Stay Cool in Another Pressure-Filled Win
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 25  During a timeout in overtime, just after Jaromir Jagr earned the Rangers a power play on a rush to the net, the Rangers skated over to the bench and looked on calmly as Coach Tom Renney discussed strategy.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Four Turtles Trump 300 at the Weekend Box Office

title: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
description: WASHINGTON, March 25  Three Republican senators voiced fresh concerns on Sunday about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzaless handling of the dismissals of eight United States attorneys amid questions about whether the firings were politically motivated.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Friday about new calculations by the Army that show a higher number of desertions than it previously reported misspelled the given name of an Army spokesman who said data errors were caused by confusion among employees who tally them. He is Lt. Col. Bryan C. Hilferty, not Brian.

title: Jamaican Police Face Obstacles in Inquiry of Cricket Coachs Death
description: KINGSTON, Jamaica, March 25  The Jamaican police said Sunday that their investigation into the death of Bob Woolmer, the coach of Pakistans cricket team killed a week ago after his team lost a critical World Cup match, was complicated by the fact that many potential witnesses had already left Jamaica.

title: Colombia Rejects Paramilitary Report
