description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 25  Colombias government disputed a published report on Sunday of leaked C.I.A. intelligence linking the chief of the army to paramilitary death squads, saying any accusations against him should be made formally through the judicial system.

title: Cathy Seipp, 49, Noted Columnist and Blogger, Dies
description: Cathy Seipp, a columnist and blogger who became widely known for poking fun at the liberal leanings popularly associated with her hometown, Los Angeles, died there on Wednesday. She was 49 and lived in the Silver Lake area of Los Angeles.

title: Dirrty Girl, Sometimes Its Hard to Be a Woman
description: No doubt the ushers and bouncers were thrilled. On Friday night Madison Square Garden was packed with well-behaved fans. They didnt make a scene by screaming too loud. Many of them declined to dance in their seats, let alone in the aisles. And for the most part they saved their applause for after each song, instead of rudely cheering all the way through.

title: Buyer of Distressed Properties Sees Opportunity in Newspapers
description: Samuel Zells first foray into publishing came when he was in high school in the 1950s. He would visit the magazine vendors under the El tracks in Chicago and buy up copies of Playboy for 50 cents. Then he would go home to the suburbs and sell the magazines to his pals for three or four times what he paid.

title: Sunni Baghdad Becomes Land of Silent Ruins
description: BAGHDAD, March 25  The cityscape of Iraqs capital tells a stark story of the toll the past four years have taken on Iraqs once powerful Sunni Arabs.

title: Distributor of Medical Test to Buy a Rival
description: Beckman Coulter, a maker and distributor of biomedical testing and laboratory products, agreed yesterday to acquire Biosite, a smaller maker of diagnostic blood tests, for about $1.55 billion in cash.

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about an opening ceremony for a stable on Pier 76 in Manhattan misidentified the treat that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg was feeding to a horse. It was a carrot, not sugar.

title: Manhattan: Mortgage Oversight
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said yesterday that he favored an overhaul of federal mortgage regulations, citing widespread concern about the surge in defaults and foreclosures involving subprime mortgages, risky home loans made to people with weak credit. Citing data from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and the Census Bureau, Mr. Schumer said that about 91,000 households in New York State, including 53,000 in the New York City metropolitan area, were at risk of foreclosure by the end of 2008, as interest rates on adjustable-rate mortgages are reset. At a hearing on Thursday, members of the Senate Banking Committee criticized the Federal Reserve for failing to curb mortgage lending abuses. The chairman, Senator Christopher J. Dodd, a Connecticut Democrat, said that new legislation might not be needed and that excesses could be addressed under existing regulations.

title: Meager Efforts to Protest Meet Subterfuge and Nightsticks
description: NIZHNY NOVGOROD, Russia, March 24  Here in Russias third-largest city on Saturday, barely was a banner unfurled or an anti-Kremlin slogan chanted before a wave of heavily armored police officers engulfed a small group of demonstrators and journalists gathered for a protest against President Vladimir V. Putins government.

title: Despite Choices on TV, the Favorites Reign
description: The number of television channels received by the average household in the United States has more than doubled in the last decade, reaching 104.2 in 2006, from only 41.1 in 1995, according to a report released recently by Nielsen Media Research. But the number of channels actually watched has not kept pace.

title: For the Record
description: An article in some copies yesterday about Congressional criticism of the Justice Department inaccurately summarized a March 15 report in the National Journal about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales and the National Security Agencys program to eavesdrop domestically without court warrants. The National Journal report asserted that Mr. Gonzales continued to advise President Bush on a proposed internal Justice Department review of the N.S.A. program after learning that his own conduct would be scrutinized. The National Journal report did not explicitly allege that Mr. Gonzales tried to block the investigation.

title: The Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC DATA The Commerce Department will release revised figures for fourth-quarter gross domestic product (Thursday), which are expected to confirm a 2.2 percent annualized growth rate for the quarter. The department will also release data on durable goods orders for February (Wednesday). Economists forecast a 3.5 percent increase in orders for durable goods for the month, after an 8.7 percent decline in January. The Labor Department will release its latest weekly reading of unemployment claims (Thursday).

title: The Twists of the Sean Bell Case (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Gay Media Outlets Seek Place at the Table at Awards for the Representation of Gays
description: On the eve of one of the highest honors awarded by the gay community, the organization that recognizes positive portrayals of gays and lesbians in the mainstream media is facing growing pressure to honor its own.

title: On a Modest Little Deal, a Championship Was Lost
description: When there is a photo finish among three teams for first place, it is likely that one big deal decided the event. But the small last-round deal in the diagram cost a team the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams at the Spring North American Championships in St. Louis this month.

title: Ronaldinho Becoming the Face of Soccer
description: CASTELLDEFELS, Spain  Ronaldinho ambled into the room and apologized for being late.

title: Lights, Camera, Tirade! Hollywoods Elite Seen Online
description: In the YouTube age, Hollywood celebrities might want to rethink whether to have temper tantrums  or, at least, have them far from the cameras on movie sets.

title: Waiting to Show Model Behavior
description: The line of beauty, contrary to the 18th-century aesthetic theory of William Hogarth, does not undulate in nature along a serpentine curve, not when it is held up to the strict measurements of Americas Next Top Model.

title: Trying Tricycle and Talk in Dialogue With Viewers
description: There are days when nothing seems profitable and nothing suits, from the rejected outfits littering your bedroom furniture to the aborted improvement projects littering your brain. Surveying the props scattered across the pristine floor of the sanctuary at St. Marks Church, the Brazilian choreographer Cristina Moura wore the look, both bewildered and dissatisfied, of a woman who has tried on many ideas, each one more ill-fitting than the last.

title: Studies Cast Doubt on Some Drugs for Heart Disease
description: An experimental heart drug abandoned by Pfizer because of safety problems failed to reduce the plaque that clogs arteries even though it raised so-called good cholesterol, new studies released today showed.

title: A Nearly Unbeatable Team and the Man Behind It
description: Clinched by a victory over the Kansas Jayhawks on Saturday night, the U.C.L.A. Bruins will compete in the Final Four next weekend for the second year in a row. While that might seem like a nifty triumph, The U.C.L.A. Dynasty, a new documentary tonight on HBO about the universitys basketball program 40-odd years ago, makes you realize just what a tepid distinction it actually is.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: Lottery Numbers

title: Iran to Limit Cooperation With Nuclear Inspectors
description: The government of Iran yesterday denounced as illegal a sanctions package approved unanimously over the weekend by the United Nations Security Council, and in retaliation announced that it would limit cooperation with the United Nations nuclear oversight agency.

title: Citigroup Plans to Shed Thousands of Jobs
description: NEW DELHI, March 26  Under pressure from shareholders, Citigroup is planning to shed thousands of jobs and sharpen its focus on its operations outside North America.

title: Freddie Francis, Cinematographer, Dies at 89
description: Freddie Francis, a versatile British cinematographer whose talent for creating atmosphere won him two Oscars, died on March 17 in London. He was 89.

title: Agencies Quit SABMiller Unit Over Creative Differences
description: The Miller Brewing Company unit of SABMiller and two agencies have separated.

title: Sri Lankan Rebels Bomb Air Base
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, March 26 --- The deepening ethnic conflict in Sri Lanka took a perilous turn early today when rebel forces launched their first air strike on the outskirts of the capital, killing three members of the Sri Lankan air force and wounding 17.

title: European Carmakers Act Pre-emptively to Keep Control
description: DETROIT, March 25  Porsches decision this weekend to raise its stake in Volkswagen, along with DaimlerChryslers recent decision to find suitors for Chrysler, reflect European automakers desire to control their own fates, rather than see them decided by less friendly acquirers.

title: Japan Again Denies Role in Sex Slavery
description: TOKYO, March 26  Facing increasing criticism for denying that Japan coerced women into sex slavery during World War II, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe repeatedly refused today to acknowledge state responsibility in recruiting the so-called comfort women, but offered them an apology.

title: Praise and Lampoons for the Crimsons Ombudsman
description: After one of the nations most venerable college newspapers announced last week that it had hired an ombudsman, reactions ranged from praise for the papers diligence to disappointment with the scope of the writers first column. And then there was the online satire.

title: For Many Palestinians, Return Is Not a Goal
description: AMMAN, Jordan, March 22  For nearly 60 years Nimr Abu Ghneim has waited, angrily but patiently, for the day he would return to the home he left in 1948.

title: Emerging Republican Minority
description: Remember how the 2004 election was supposed to have demonstrated, once and for all, that conservatism was the future of American politics? I do: early in 2005, some colleagues in the news media urged me, in effect, to give up. The election settled some things, I was told.

title: Rutgers Saved Season in the Midnight Hour
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 25  Rutgers Coach C. Vivian Stringer has been around basketball long enough to know what an N.C.A.A. tournament contender looks like. But she did not see it in her Scarlet Knights earlier this season. They were too young. They were out of shape. They did not play defense.

title: The Album, a Commodity in Disfavor
description: LOS ANGELES, March 25  Now that the three young women in Candy Hill, a glossy rap and R&B trio, have signed a record contract, they are hoping for stardom. On the schedule: shooting a music video and visiting radio stations to talk up their music.

title: Detainees Lawyers Seek Removal of Prosecutor
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, March 25  As American officials prepare for the reopening on Monday of the military commissions that will try some of the detainees here, a dispute over the proper role of military defense lawyers in the planned war crimes trials is intensifying.

title: Manhattan: Restaurant Inspections
description: City health officials should change their method for evaluating restaurants and issue a letter grade from A to F, State Senator Jeffrey D. Klein said yesterday. Mr. Klein, a Bronx Democrat, said he would introduce legislation requiring restaurants to prominently post the letter grade. No restaurant is going to want an F in their doorway, he said yesterday. Andrew Tucker, a spokesman for the Department of Health and Mental Hygiene, said that the agency would review the senators proposal, but that the current scoring system allowed the agency to provide more detail about violations than a lettered grading system would.

title: For the Record
description: The Books of The Times review on Thursday, about Too Far From Home: A Story of Life and Death in Space, by Chris Jones, misidentified the space shuttle that broke apart on Feb. 1, 2003, in one of two references in the opening paragraph. It was the Columbia, not the Challenger. (The Challenger exploded in January 1986.)

title: Brooklyn Man Fleeing Police Dies in Fall
description: A man sought for questioning on a complaint of domestic violence fell to his death from the 19th-floor terrace of a Brooklyn apartment late Saturday, apparently in an attempt to evade officers who were about to enter the front door, the authorities said yesterday.

title: In China, Fight Over Development Creates a Star
description: CHONGQING, China, March 23  For weeks a dispute had drawn attention from people all across China as a simple homeowner stared down the forces of large-scale redevelopment that are sweeping this country, blocking the preparation of a gigantic construction site by an act of sheer will.

title: Aged, Frail and Denied Care by Their Insurers
description: CONRAD, Mont.  Mary Rose Derks was a 65-year-old widow in 1990, when she began preparing for the day she could no longer care for herself. Every month, out of her grocery fund, she scrimped together about $100 for an insurance policy that promised to pay eventually for a room in an assisted living home.

title: Inside a Busload of Devotion, Fully Aware of Iraqs Dangers
description: A ghoulishness underlies the opening minutes of Pilgrimage to Karbala, an installment of the PBS series Wide Angle tonight that follows a busload of Iranians as they travel to the Shiite shrines in that Iraqi city. You briefly get the sense that the filmmaker, Kevin Sim, wouldnt mind if the bus were blown up; that his goal is simply to catch news as it happens. Soon, though, this misimpression  the film is actually very thoughtful  gives way to an even more uncomfortable reality: The people hoping to have this bus blown up are the pilgrims on it.

title: So You Picked the Final Four? Join the Club
description: Whats a Final Four without a George Mason or another plucky party crasher? Whats an N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament without a little-known team that is all guile and grit and topples an elite team to capture Americas heart?

title: Complaints Flood Texas Youth Hot Line
description: AUSTIN, Tex., March 22  Investigations hot line, said Brian Yasko, answering the phone at the Texas Youth Commission in a windowless command post that officers are calling the belly of the beast.

title: Changing of Guard as 11 Step Down in New Jersey
description: TRENTON, March 23  None of them are getting any younger. Some of them have one eye on the future and the other on the aggressive United States attorney. And for others, several long looks at their younger challengers have helped them make up their minds.

title: Maker of Mobile Games Brings Line to BlackBerry
description: Is that BlackBerry owner tapping out a crucial e-mail message, or playing just one more round of Asphalt: Urban GT 2?

title: Unfancied Connecticut Is One Step From the Final Four
description: FRESNO, Calif., March 25  This is not considered one of Connecticuts great teams. It has no seniors, not a single player who has been to the Final Four. The bench is not deep. The outside shooting can be spotty. Frankly, Coach Geno Auriemma said the other day, his team is not quite ready yet to win a national championship.

title: U.N. Says Saudis Will Admit Israeli Journalist
description: JERUSALEM, March 26  The United Nations said today that a Washington-based Israeli journalist traveling with Secretary General Ban Ki-moon who had been unable to obtain to obtain a visa to accompany him to Saudi Arabia on Tuesday would now be admitted to the country.

title: The Toll of War (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: No Happy Ending to Marists Fairy Tale
description: DAYTON, Ohio, March 25  Marist did its best not to appear star-struck at the start of its Dayton Regional semifinal on Sunday. But everywhere the Red Foxes looked, greatness was on display.

title: Poor Behavior Is Linked to Time in Day Care
description: A much-anticipated report from the largest and longest-running study of American child care has found that keeping a preschooler in a day care center for a year or more increased the likelihood that the child would become disruptive in class  and that the effect persisted through the sixth grade.

title: For Budget-Makers, the Clock Ticks Loudly
description: ALBANY  Budget negotiations continued to stall over the weekend, raising the specter of the first late budget in three years. But while Gov. Eliot Spitzer was at a stalemate with state Republicans, he appeared to have resolved the biggest point of contention with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, according to a person with knowledge of the discussions.

title: U.S. Envoy Says He Had Meetings With Iraq Rebels
description: BAGHDAD, March 25  The senior American envoy in Iraq, Ambassador Zalmay Khalilzad, held talks last year with men he believed represented major insurgent groups in a drive to bring militant Sunni Arabs into politics.

title: Vying to Run States Tracks, Racing Interests Woo Politicians
description: There are more than a few cookie jars lying around Albany in any given year, from the development money dished out by public authorities around the state, to the pork-barrel spending divvied up by the governor and legislative leaders during budget negotiations.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Thursday about a Web site that posts pictures showing vehicles with government-issued parking permits that appear to be parked illegally in New York City included a quotation in which a police spokesman misidentified the police precinct that covers Chinatown, where 12 such vehicles were towed recently. It is the Fifth Precinct, not the First.

title: Inquiry Calls Tillmans Shooting Death Accident
description: A Pentagon investigation into the combat death of Cpl. Pat Tillman in Afghanistan has concluded that he was shot accidentally by fellow soldiers but that investigations into the circumstances of his shooting were initially mishandled.

title: Dear Diary
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: A Flute Sparkles in Mozarts Spirited, Rent-Paying Quartet
description: Chamber music ensembles can sometimes seem like poorly arranged marriages, with a dynamic that doesnt quite work. But the members of the Nash Ensemble from London, who performed at the 92nd Street Y on Wednesday, were collegial and dynamic, attuned to one another (and in tune) throughout a wide variety of repertory.

title: Study Supports Safety of Heart Drug, but Not Its Effectiveness
description: A new study presented at a cardiology conference yesterday might allay some fears about the safety of Johnson & Johnsons controversial heart drug, Natrecor, but the results also showed the drug did not work in the population studied.

title: Beautiful People, Wretched Childhood
description: A friend of Robert Goolricks parents once wrote this about them: When I first knew these people, I thought they were brilliant and beautiful and their house a magical place. Then I began to see them as ordinary and, finally, pathetic. That same downhill trajectory shapes Mr. Goolricks blistering family memoir. As a child he found his parents and their friends elegant, glamorous, sophisticated and only a wee bit peculiar. They frequently gave the kinds of parties at which someone could scream Whooo! Whooo! and people laughed until they wept, even after the 20th or 50th time.

title: Glare of Publicity Finds an Inspector General
description: WASHINGTON, March 23  After Glenn A. Fine gave up a chance to play for the San Antonio Spurs of the National Basketball Association to accept a Rhodes scholarship in 1979, he stayed in shape as a member of Oxford Universitys basketball team. But the 5-foot-9 Mr. Fine, always eager for a challenge, also decided to try out boxing.

title: For One Met, Spring Training Is Just Beginning
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 25  Guillermo Mota is expected to take part in his first workout with the Mets on Monday, showing up right as his teammates are preparing to leave. For about six weeks, he will remain here in a curious limbo, beginning a spring training program that the rest of the teams pitchers started in mid-February. He does not have much choice.

title: British Arrests Refocus Glare on Muslim Area
description: LEEDS, England, March 25  At their formal best, West Yorkshire police officers in tall dark helmets adorned with a silver badge and wearing neon yellow vests stood outside five run-down terrace houses on Sunday. Behind closed doors, plainclothes detectives searched the property of three Muslim men and their relatives.

title: Father-Son Hug Is Love and History in a Moment
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.

title: A Quirky Voice Now Grounded in R&B
description: MACY GRAY

title: Transfer Goes Home to Ohio State to Find N.C.A.A. Success
description: SAN ANTONIO, March 25  After two years at Bowling Green, Ron Lewis was tired of losing.

title: Pakistan Police Detain Opposition Members Ahead of Protests
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 25  The police detained hundreds of political opposition members in an attempt to thwart nationwide protests planned for Monday to denounce Gen. Pervez Musharrafs suspension of the chief justice, opposition leaders said Sunday.

title: Northern Ireland Rivals Reach Deal
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 26  After years of mutual hostility and recrimination, the leaders of Northern Irelands dominant rival groups, Sinn Feins Gerry Adams and the Protestant leader, the Rev. Ian Paisley, met today for their first face-to-face talks and agreed to form a joint administration for the province on May 8.

title: At Swimming Championships, a Restocked Talent Pool
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Monday, March 26  Swimming has its problems: lingering concerns about doping and the early retirement of Ian Thorpe.

title: For the Record
description: A theater review last Monday about Di Yam Gazlonim!, a Yiddish version of The Pirates of Penzance that has returned to the JCC in Manhattan, misstated the year in which the operetta is set. While the libretto does not specify a time, elements of the plot point to either 1873 or 1877  not to 1897. (The error first appeared in a Nov. 8 review of the opening of the production at the JCC. The review last Monday was a shorter version of the original review.)

title: The Lonely Patient - Prologue
description: My brother-in-law Richard was a sculptor. For almost a year, he had been having vague symptoms, bloody noses and spots of numbness on the roof of his mouth, which he blamed on mold in his studio, the vagaries of New England weather, and a lifetime of exposure to epoxy-laden materials. In late March, we shared our weekly midday meal at Johnnie's Luncheonette. We each ordered the usual. For Richard, it was onion rings, which left his lips shiny, and a chocolate shake. I had a turkey sandwich, mashed potatoes, and water with a slice of lemon. As we skidded home in the snow, Richard told me that he had a rare form of sinus cancer. He looked no different than he had the week before: wild-haired and thick-nosed at fifty, an expressive face with deep lines slanting from his nostrils to the corners of his mouth. His hands, gripping the steering wheel, were large and knotty. His size had intimidated me as a boy; now as then, his dramatic voice was overshadowed by his yet bigger ideas about almost everything. I had always thought of Richard as invincible, so at first I didn't believe he'd understood correctly what he'd been told.

title: Retirement paradise in Uruguay?
Bank Poses Obstacle in North Korea Nuclear Talks
description: HONG KONG, March 26  A largely foreign-owned North Korean bank has emerged as a major obstacle to a deal that would allow six-party negotiations over North Koreas nuclear program to move forward.

title: Good for Goodness Sake?
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Are They Drivers or Magic Wands
description: Ben Weir, a former PGA Tour professional, tests new drivers with heads designed to resist twisting.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an item in the Suits column in Sunday Business yesterday on a video clip in which James J. Cramer, a CNBC television personality, recommended ways to move stock prices, misidentified the organization that requested that the video clip be removed from YouTube.com. The request was made by TheStreet.com, which taped the original interview, not by CNBC.

title: Correction: 36 Hours in Prague
description: The 36 Hours column last Sunday about Prague referred incorrectly to service on Czech Airlines from New York airports to Prague. The airline flies nonstop from Kennedy Airport only. It does not fly from Newark.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about the limits of multitasking misspelled the surname of a cognitive scientist at the University of Michigan, who said that "'Multitasking is going to slow you down, increasing the chances of mistakes." It is David E. Meyer, not Mayer.

title: Elton John Celebrates 60 Lavishly, in His Garden
description: Elton John never seemed like the kind of guy to shrug off a big occasion. So it was natural, perhaps even inevitable, that he would celebrate his 60th birthday at Madison Square Garden. His sprawling concert on Sunday night featured no onstage candles  not even "Candle in the Wind"  but felt ceremonial enough without them. There were dedications, recollections and a shower of confetti. A banner was unfurled from the rafters, bearing a giant number 60 under Mr. John's name.

title: Thousands of Settlers Return to Vacated West Bank Town
description: A group of right-wing activists is temporarily reoccupying a destroyed Jewish settlement in the West Bank in the hopes of signaling an official return.

title: Zell Bid for Tribune Gains Traction, Again
description: The Tribune Company, it seems, is again warming up to the offer tabled by real estate mogul Samuel Zell. After reports surfaced last week that the Tribune Co. had cooled to the Mr. Zells proposal, The New York Times says that the mercury is rising.

title: A Bull Market in Books About Wall Street
description: A new crop of books, both fiction and nonfiction, are coming out that aim to capture, if not update, Wall Streets rich mix of greed, striving, intrigue and vanity.

title: European Carmakers Act to Keep Control
description: Porsches decision this weekend to raise its stake in Volkswagen, along with DaimlerChryslers recent decision to find suitors for Chrysler, reflect European automakers desire to control their own fates, rather than see them decided by less friendly acquirers, The New York Times says.

title: Hey, Boss, Permission for a Follow-Up Question?
description: The Internet age was supposed to mean that concentration of the media in just a few hands is yesterdays news because the barriers to entry in the online world are so low. But judging from the banter on a conference call for reporters last week by the News Corporation and NBC Universal, corporate control of the news media is still going strong. The companies were announcing a new joint venture for Internet video.

title: Clear Channel Bidders Bash Analyst Critic
description: Bain Capital and Thomas H. Lee Partners, the buyout shops behind the Mays familys bid to take Clear Channel Communications private, have been trash talking a Bears Stearns analyst who has pegged their $18.7 billion bid as too low, The New York Post reported.

title: Distributor of Medical Test to Buy a Rival
description: Beckman Coulter, a maker and distributor of biomedical testing and laboratory products, agreed Sunday to acquire Biosite, a smaller maker of diagnostic blood tests, for about $1.55 billion in cash. The combination would bolster Beckman Coulters offerings for blood tests, including those for heart failure, certain diseases and the presence of drugs.

title: Under XM-Sirius Merger Plan, Potty Mouth Is Optional
description: The shock jock Howard Stern has been very important to the success of Sirius Satellite Radio. Subscriptions surged after he agreed to bring his raucous show to the service.

title: How a Hedge Fund May Have Kicked Off a Bank Sale
description: In the merger talks between Barclays, the British bank, and ABN Amro, a Dutch rival, hedge fund The Childrens Investment Fund is the proverbial the grease for the wheel. Its activism in several deals, including the scuppered merger between the Deutsche Borse and the London Stock Exchange, has garnered the fund a lot of attention recently.

title: Discretion, Sophistication Still Define Small Swiss Banks
description: Switzerland is known for its banks, some of them now global giants like UBS and Credit Suisse. But it is the smaller, more discreet banks that are changing the most these days, says The New York Times.

title: BP Plans to Bid for Yukos Assets in Auction
description: BP said on Friday that it planned to bid against the state-owned oil giant Rosneft in a bankruptcy auction for assets of the Yukos oil company, a surprise announcement that signaled BPs deepening involvement in Russias turbulent energy sector.

title: Revamping Private Equitys Image (and Maybe Its Name)
description: Blackstone Groups recent decision to form a charitable foundation is an important step  though maybe just a baby step  toward burnishing the image of an industry that has come under attack in Europe, and increasingly in the United States, as being overpaid and out of touch, DealBook wrote in Sundays New York Times.

title: Livedoor Given Japans Largest Corporate Fine
description: The Internet start-up Livedoor was ordered to pay a $2.4 million fine Friday  the largest in Japanese corporate history  for violating securities laws. The fine is the latest blow in a scandal that has led to convictions of seven former executives and accountants. The Tokyo District Court ordered Livedoor to pay the fine  280 million yen  and its subsidiary Livedoor Marketing to pay $338,000, a court official said on the customary condition of anonymity.

title: Former Citigroup Executive to Head RBS America
description: Royal Bank of Scotland named the former Citigroup executive Ellen Alemany as chief executive of its RBS America unit on Friday as part of a management revamp to bring its United States businesses closer together.

title: Hellman & Friedman Does Deal for Kronos
description: Buyout firm Hellman & Friedman has agreed to buy labor management software company Kronos  for $1.8 billion, Kronos said Friday. The Deal.com notes that Kronos was the fifth company to agree to be taken private by a buyout shop last week, adding that the five deals were worth a combined $12.9 billion.

title: For Doerr, Google Makes Another Kind of Green
description: Much of the attention that venture capitalist John Doerr has drawn in recent months has focused on his environmental advocacy and investment in green technologies. But, says The San Jose Mercury News, thanks to his investment in search engine powerhouse Google, Mr. Doerr in recent months has been quietly amassing the kind of green that Silicon Valley traditionally favors.

title: Does a Palm Takeover Make Sense?
description: As takeover rumors swirl around Palm, the maker of the Treo smartphone, technology analysis firm The 451 Group assesses the fit  or lack thereof  for a half-dozen potential acquirers, including Dell and Hewlett-Packard. The report calls a deal with Research in Motion, which makes the Blackberry handheld device, a very intriguing possibility. Such a combination could allow Research in Motion to build a line of Windows devices that are still true BlackBerrys with relatively little effort, The 451 Group writes.

title: Wall Street Fills Out Its Presidential Brackets
description: In the most wide-open presidential election season since 1928, a mating ritual is under way that will determine which candidate raises enough money to get his or her partys nominationand which Wall Street backers have the most influence on policies affecting the economy, regulation, and global markets, BusinessWeek says.

title: Xstrata Bids for Another Canadian Miner
description: Swiss-based Xstrata appears to have succeeded in gobbling up another piece of Canadas mining industry with a friendly bid worth C$4.6 billion ($4.0 billion) for LionOre Mining International. The all-cash offer of C$18.50 per share was unanimously approved by LionOres board of directors, both companies announced Monday.

title: Canadian Consortium Inks Deal for New Zealand Yellow Pages
description: The investment arm of the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan of Canada has bought Telecom New Zealands yellow pages directories business for about C$1.85 billion ($1.59 billion), the telecom provider said Monday. Private equity consortium of CCMP Capital and Teachers Private Capital, the investment arm of the O.T.P.P., has bought the yellow and white pages directories, both print and online.

title: British Housebuilders to Merge
description: George Wimpey and Taylor Woodrow are merging to create Britains largest housebuilder, a move that will lead to up to 700 job losses. The deal, announced this morning, will create a new company called Taylor Wimpey. It will have annual revenues of 6.7 billion pounds ($13.1 billion), and an estimated market capitalization of 5 billion pounds ($9.8 billion).

title: I.P.O. Case Goes to Supreme Court
description: The Supreme Court will hear a case Tuesday that could affect the way banks cooperate with rivals and create syndicates to share the risks and rewards of initial public offerings. Eight of the nine justices will hear the oral argument in Glen Billing v. Credit Suisse First Boston, a class action that asks what role, if any, antitrust law should play in the regulation of the securities industry, and specifically in policing I.P.O.s.

title: Private Equity Teams Up Ahead of Foodservice Auction
description: Although final bids are not due until April, the auction for Royal Aholds U.S. Foodservice, a business worth an estimated $5.5 billion, is heating up. According to The Deal.com, buyout shops are jockeying for position, and food service heavyweight Sysco could team up with one to buy the target.

title: Is Morgan Stanley Changing Course With New Century Sale?
description: In a reversal, Morgan Stanley is in the process of holding an auction for $2.48 billion in mortgages from subprime lender New Century, The New York Post reported Monday. The loans represent the collateral given to Morgan for a $2.5 billion credit line the firm extended to New Century, which currently finds itself in a precarious financial and legal situation.

title: New Director Is Named to Edinburgh Fringe
description: The Edinburgh Festival Fringe has a new director. He is Jon Morgan, currently the executive producer at the Contact Theater in Manchester, England, Theatre.com reported.

title: European Investors Can Join Vivendi Suit, U.S. Court Rules
description: A federal judge in New York has ruled that French, British, and Dutch citizens who bought Vivendi shares before the French media and telecom group neared bankruptcy in 2002 are allowed to join a U.S. class action against the company that was initiated by Vivendi shareholders.

title: Grease Finds Its Wheels
description: America has voted, or at least a few Americans have voted, and the new production of "Grease" has its leads.

title: The Senate Takes On the War, Prosecutors
description: It will be Senate Democrats (and a few Republicans) versus the Bush administration on two fronts this week.

title: Hot Spectrum Draws Cash, and Ideals
description: The auction for a prized swath of spectrum that could reshape the debate over who controls access to the networks that deliver digital content to consumers is about to go into high gear. Among those maneuvering ahead of the auction for the spectrum, which could be used for voice services for cellular carriers, new frequencies for emergency responders, or a commercial high-speed broadband multimedia network, are the nations four largest cellular providers, rural and regional wireless carriers, cable and satellite television companies and a range of technology companies  including Google and Yahoo.

title: Enel and Acciona Will Challenge E.Ons Bid for Endesa
description: Enel, Italys biggest utility, and Acciona said they will offer at least 41 euros ($54.37) a share for the stock they dont already own of Spanish power company Endesa, trumping a rival bid by E.On. The offer depends on E.On receiving less than 50 percent of Endesa in its tender, Acciona said in a statement Monday. The bid by Enel and Acciona, which together control 46 percent of Endesa, values all of Spains largest power utility at a minimum of 43.4 billion euros.

title: Citigroup to Shed Thousands of Jobs
description: Citigroup, under pressure from its shareholders, is planning to shed thousands of jobs and sharpen its focus on its operations outside North America. Citigroup will announce a broad restructuring plan that could involve the elimination or relocation of as many as 15,000 high-cost jobs from areas including New York, London and Hong Kong, The New York Times reported, citing several executives briefed on the matter.

title: Texas Pacific Said to Consider Iberia Bid
description: Texas Pacific Group is considering making an offer to buy Iberia Airlines, Reuters reported Monday, citing people familiar with the matter. British Airways is also said to be interested the Spanish carrier, according to The Independent.

title: Bush in Isolation
Another Suitor May Bid for Alliance Boots
description: Guy Hands, a longtime British dealmaker, may wade into the battle for Alliance Boots, the Telegraph reported Monday citing unnamed sources. But he may have a tough time going up against a rival offer from the pharmacy chains deputy chairman and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts.

title: Teletubbies
description: A clip from the Teletubbies.

title: Gov, Mayor Work Things Out
description: Budget talks might be stalled, but Gov. Eliot Spitzer appears to have worked out his biggest difference with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: 2008: Campaign Cash
description: This week marks the final days for campaign fundraising toward the presidential contenders first round of quarterly reports. While some top-tier candidates have exceeded expectations, others are acknowleding their fundraising got off to a slower start. Still others are playing that low expectations game. The tallies are due for release April 15.

title: Obama May Face the Ghosts of Liberals Past
description: Is Barack Obama the new Eugene McCarthy? Or the new Gary Hart? Or the new Paul Tsongas? Or the new Bill Bradley? Or the new Howard Dean? Maybe, to all of those questions, says Ronald Brownstein from his new perch as a columnist on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times. Obamas early support is following a pattern familiar from the campaigns of other brainy liberals with cool, detached personas and messages of political reform, from Eugene McCarthy in 1968 to Gary Hart in 1984 to Bill Bradley in 2000, Brownstein writes. Like those predecessors, Obama is running strong with well-educated voters but demonstrating much less support among those without college degrees. He continues:

title: Carlyle to Acquire Goodyears Engineered Products Unit
description: Goodyear Tire & Rubber has agreed to sell almost all of its Engineered Products business, which makes hoses and conveyor belts, to a unit of the Carlyle Group for $1.475 billion, the tire maker said. Carlyle will make the acquisition through a portfolio company, EPD.

title: All Right, Already, Lets Drink
description: Its been a fascinating conversation on issues of winemaking, short cuts, technology and such, but I for one want to lighten up a little and talk briefly about the real reason were having this discussion: wine itself and what Ive recently enjoyed. It all comes back to that, doesnt it? The bottom line is, we love the wines that move us.

title: Revolving Door: J.P. Morgan, Lehman, Aquiline
description: J.P. Morgan Chases asset-management group named Jonathan Ingram to lead the European higher alpha team. Mr. Ingram, who has worked at the securities firm since 2000, was previously a client portfolio manager in the asset-management divisions currency group, Reuters reported.

title: Siena Poll: Spitzer Takes a Hit
description: Not surprisingly, the advertising barrage against Gov. Eliot Spitzers health care cuts has produced a cut in Mr. Spitzers favorability ratings. According to the new Siena poll, 62 percent of voters have a favorable view of the governor, down from 74 percent in February. Thats a big change, but it still leaves him pretty popular. Time will tell what this investment of political capital returns.

title: Scouting Atlanta
description: The consensus from reading a few newspapers at the airport this morning is that this is going to be a powerhouse Final Four. A few folks, like Drew Sharp of the Detroit Free Press, are disappointed by the lack of upsets. Others, like ESPN.coms Pat Forde, are looking forward to some heavyweights clashing in Atlanta.

title: Could Wal-Mart Bid for J Sainsbury?
description: File this as intriguing but highly tenuous: Wal-Marts British division, Asda, is trying to determine whether a bid for J Sainsbury would violate antitrust rules, Reuters reported citing unnamed sources. So far, Asda has not yet asked Britains Competition Authority about its available options, ranging from a bid for the whole company to picking up pieces that a private equity buyer would spin off.

title: More Talk of a Time Warner Revamp
description: Carl Icahn must be smiling.

title: Heat Invades Cool Heights Over Arizona Desert
description: The so-called sky islands of southern Arizona, formerly green havens above the desert, have experienced near collapse.

title: Set Off
description: Today Maria Aspan has the boffo back story of the Lily Tomlin/David O. Russell brushfires on the set of I Heart Huckabees, which were filmed for our instruction and entertainment.

title: A Conversation With Ronaldinho
description: Ronaldo de Assis Moreira, known to the soccer world simply as Ronaldinho, is one of the most recognizable players in the world. The Brazil star has led his club, F.C. Barcelona in Spain, to two straight La Liga titles and last season's European Champions League crown.

title: HealthSouth to Sell Surgery Unit to Texas Pacific
description: Rehabilitation chain HealthSouth said Monday it has agreed to sell its surgery division to the Texas Pacific Group for about $920 million in cash plus a stake in the surgery business. The sale marks the second divestiture for HealthSouth this year as it restructures following a major financial scandal.

title: Council Complains It Cant Get Respect  With Respect to Con Ed
description: The Bloomberg administration hired an Albany law firm to prepare a 247-page report about the Queens blackout last July, along with 35 pages of comments, but failed to supply the City Council or members of the public with a copy until this morning, outraged City Council members said this morning.

title: London Traders Top New Yorkers in Pay
description: Even with their record bonuses last year, Wall Streeters may have reasons to envy their counterparts in the Old Country. Bloomberg News reports that traders in London are making as much as 50 percent more in compensation than traders in New York, according to a study by Napier Scott Executive Search (a firm which just happens to be based in London). The report comes as New York is engaged some deep soul-searching about whether it is losing its edge to London as a venue for initial public offerings, hedge funds and other badges of status in the financial-services industry.

title: D.I.Y. Foreign Aid
description: Readers are always asking Nicholas D. Kristof how they can help. He found an inventive way via the Web.

title: The Real Cost of Takeout
description: New York runs on takeout and delivery, but the working conditions of the guys who actually show up with the food is something many New Yorkers prefer not to think about.

title: Taking Stock of a Citi Bid for Dutch Bank
description: For a stock analyst, writing a thoughtful, complete research note can be difficult when news changes by the minute. For instance, on Monday Merrill Lynchs Guy Moszkowski released a note examining the possibility that Citigroup might step into the negotiations between Barclays and ABN Amro.

title: Hes Making A List
description: Appearing at todays family-planning confab in Albany, Gov. Eliot Spitzer took a light jab at Senator Craig Johnson, the newly elected Long Island Democrat.

title: Well, Its My Birthday Too
description: Today is my birthday, which Ive always been proud to share with Phillies broadcaster Harry Kalas. The Yanks are playing the Phils today, but I didnt see Harry. Maybe he gets his birthday off. Its also the birthday of Jean Afterman, the Yankees assistant general manager. Every year we wish each other happy birthday, and every year shes 29.

title: Silver Says No To A Shutdown
description: Thanks to the seeming impasse between Gov. Eliot Spitzer the legislative leaders over Mr. Spitzers proposed budget cuts, theres talk of a government shutdown in the air. We caught up with the Speaker of the Assembly, Sheldon H. Silver, in the halls of the Capitol this morning, and he commented briefly on the idea.

title: Horror Movie
description: The U.C.L.A. Bruins have no choice. They are going to have to watch the game tape that many of them never wanted to see.

title: Back to the Drawing Board
description: How hard could it be to find an architect? True, our first choice hadnt worked out  and had left me in tears in the process  but, as my mother never said, There are plenty of fish in the sea.

title: The Highs and Lows of a Biotech Deal
description: News about a merger in the world of immunoassays  that is, blood tests  has sent shares in one biotech company soaring and stock in another plummeting. Beckman Coulter said Sunday that it will buy Biosite, a maker of several blood tests, for $1.55 billion in cash, or $85 a share.

title: Mota Is Back
description: All sorts of fun stuff going on in Mets camp today, including:

title: Conservative Mojo Gone Missing
description: Paul Krugman responds to readers comments on his Mar. 26 column, Emerging Republican Minority.

title: Honest Edwards
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Mar. 26 column, Campaign Candor.

title: The D.N.C.: Let the Cameras Roll
description: YouTube, step aside.

title: Blogtalk: Under Surveillance
description: This report from Jim Dwyer over the weekend has stirred up the blogosphere:

title: Sanchez Done for at Least 4 Months
description: Duaner Sanchez will require surgery to fix a hairline fracture of the coracoid, a small bone in the front of his right shoulder. Omar Minaya said he anticipates Sanchez will be out until at least August.

title: D.I.Y. Foreign Aid
description: Readers are always asking Nicholas D. Kristof how they can help. He found an inventive way via the Web.

title: Audio: Eye on Politics
description: Adam Nagourney(mp3)

title: Ask Bill Clinton: Hes a Pardoning Expert
description: With a subcommittee of the House Judiciary panel set to hold a hearing on Thursday on the presidential authority to grant pardons, the ranking Republican on the committee appears to want to upstage the Democrat-controlled panel.

title: That free press in Pakistan
description: Pakistan often boasts of its free press, and its true that President Musharraf has allowed a reasonably vigorous press and even tolerated criticisms of him. But at the same time he has disappeared occasional journalists, and I just heard today that a Pakistani who was finally released from Guantanamo wrote a book in Pashto about his experience  and as it was about to be translated into English, Pakistan disappeared him again, a few months ago.

title: President Bush and General Musharraf
description: The Bush administration has made a strategic mistake, I believe, in identifying itself so closely with Pervez Musharraf and in being so reluctant to criticize his dictatorial moves. I happened to run into an old friend, Asma Jahangir, who is a prominent Pakistani lawyer and a U.N. Rapporteur on human rights.

title: Your Comments on Do-It-Yourself Foreign Aid
description: In Tuesdays column I write about how ordinary people can use www.kiva.org to make loans to people in poor countries. Theres also a video featuring Abdul Sattar and Storai Sadat. I welcome your comments below on that column  or on other effective ways to donate to fight poverty.

title: Hey, They Shrunk The Note
description: For the last few years the Washington establishment has started its day with a daily dose of CW  or conventional wisdom  and counter-CW, by reading the The Note, the ABC News online, political news letter.

title: The Vilsack-Clinton Connection
description: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton wont know until the night of the Iowa caucuses whether the backing of Tom and Christie Vilsack, the states former governor and first lady, who formally announced today that they were endorsing her, will pay off. But Mr. Vilsack could reap benefits sooner.

title: Extrasolar Planets in the Goldilocks Zone
description: Patrick has done his usual excellent job of outlining the importance of the discovery of life on Mars (or elsewhere in the solar system  Jupiters moon Europa looks like an interesting outside bet), but it wont be long before were able to look far beyond our own neighborhood. A month or two ago, the Spitzer Space Telescope obtained the first spectra of the atmospheres of extrasolar planets. These results were for large planets close to their parent stars, and relied on the planets happening to pass behind the star, but nonetheless a start has been made.

title: Fred Thompsons Record
description: With former Senator Fred Thompson pondering a bid for the Republican presidential nomination, the hunt is on to see if he has his conservative credentials in order or whether there might be some moderation lurking in his voting past.

title: A New Home in the Bowery
description: Time lapse video of construction taking place between August 2006 and February 2007. Video courtesy of Inet Onsite.

title: Great Day for the Yankees
description: Thats what GM Brian Cashman called it, in so many words, and for the Yankees, it was about time. They beat the Phillies, 5-1, got that mammoth homer from A-Rod, a two-run double from Doug Mientkiewicz (hes finally getting some hits), five solid innings from Kei Igawa, a clean M.R.I. from Jeff Karstens and a strong bullpen outing from Andy Pettitte.

title: Couric Criticized for Edwards Interview
description: CBS News has been slammed today over Katie Courics interview with John and Elizabeth Edwards on 60 Minutes, the criticisms whipping around the blogosphere and permeating all quarters, including Mr. Edwardss discussion about global warming in California today and at his wifes appearance at the City Club forum in Cleveland.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A listing with a film review in Weekend on Friday about The Prisoner or: How I Planned to Kill Tony Blair misstated its opening dates for five cities. It opens in Austin, Tex.; Cambridge, Mass.; Chicago; and San Francisco this coming Friday, and in Los Angeles on April 6. It did in fact open in New York and Washington last Friday, but not in the other five cities.

title: Suicide Attack on Sri Lankan Army Base Kills 7
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, March 27  A day after guerrillas bombed a military air base on the edge of the capital here, seven people were killed today when a pair of suspected rebel suicide bombers tried to drive a tractor loaded with explosives into an army camp in the countrys east.

title: Republicans to Rely on President Bushs Veto to Block Troop Withdrawal Plan
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  As the Senate opened debate Monday on a $122 billion Iraq spending bill, Republicans vowed not to allow Congress to impose a withdrawal date for American troops, but said they would rely on President Bushs veto pen rather than procedural maneuvers to block it.

title: Juxtapositions of Movement, Sound and Silence
description: Works & Process at the Guggenheim, a popular series devoted to shedding light on the creative process through performance and discussion, presented three ballets by the Italian choreographer Luca Veggetti at the museums Peter B. Lewis Theater on Sunday night. They included a world premiere and a rare visit by members of the Cincinnati Ballet.

title: From Ashes of Yukos, New Russian Oil Giant Emerges
description: MOSCOW, March 26  Only a few visible traces of Yukos Oil remain in Nefteyugansk, a remote Siberian town so inseparable from Russias energy wealth that it has neft, or oil, in its name. Here and there, workers barracks, trucks and some aging equipment are still painted yellow and green, the color of Yukoss logo.

title: For the Record: Progress Is Seen Against Hepatitis
description: Thanks in large part to effective vaccines, rates of hepatitis A and hepatitis B infection have declined to their lowest levels in 40 years, according to data published recently by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Incidence of hepatitis C, for which there is no vaccine, has also declined substantially.

title: In the Marmoset Family, Things Really Do Appear to Be All Relative
description: Well, Ill be a monkeys uncle has now taken on a new meaning. Scientists studying marmosets have discovered that over half the males carry their brothers sperm.

title: Rice Works to Bring Israels Olmert and Arab Leaders Closer on What Issues Can Be Broached
description: JERUSALEM, March 26  Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice pressed Prime Minister Ehud Olmert of Israel on Monday to agree to peace talks that would include three issues that have bedeviled Middle East negotiations since 1979.

title: When Student-Adviser Tensions Erupt, the Results Can Be Fatal
description: Being a graduate student is the most grueling and intense part of becoming a scientist, but it rarely leads to murder. Here are some rare instances.

title: Judge Says Police Files Remain Secret
description: A federal judge refused yesterday to reissue his order preventing disclosure of police documents about surveillance leading up to the 2004 Republican convention in New York City, saying the existing ruling to keep them secret still stands.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the World Briefing column on Thursday about order being restored in parts of Kazakhstan after fighting between ethnic groups misidentified the countrys capital. It is Astana  not Almaty, which was the capital until 1997.

title: Struggles Make It Sweeter as Rutgers Reaches Final Four
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., March 26  Rutgers Coach C. Vivian Stringer kissed the net that had just been cut down at Greensboro Coliseum after her Scarlet Knights dominated Arizona State, 64-45, in their regional final Monday night to advance to the N.C.A.A. womens Final Four.

title: Foregone Conclusion Appears to Keep Egyptian Voters Home
description: CAIRO, March 26  There were two views of reality in Egypt on Monday: one on the state-run Nile News that showed voters streaming to the polls for a constitutional amendment, another on the streets where polling places were largely empty, according to independent monitoring groups and random checks.

title: Justices Agree to Revisit Child Pornography Laws
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  The Supreme Court agreed Monday to undertake its latest effort to define the permissible boundary between free speech and the governments prohibition of child pornography.

title: Life Magazine, Its Pages Dwindling, Will Cease Publication
description: Life is dead, again.

title: A Mystery at Hong Kong Horse Racing Track
description: HONG KONG, March 26  It was a device worthy of Rube Goldberg, or perhaps Wile E. Coyote. A remote-controlled mechanism with a dozen launching tubes was found buried in the turf at Hong Kongs most famous horse racing track last week; it was rigged with compressed air to fire tiny, liquid-filled darts into the bellies of horses at the starting gate.

title: L.S.U. Is Back in the Final Four Even Without Its Coach
description: FRESNO, Calif., March 26  Louisiana State advanced to the womens Final Four for a fourth consecutive season on Monday night, maintaining a stubborn presence in the N.C.A.A. tournament despite the absence of its former coach amid charges of inappropriate conduct.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Busta Rhymes Faces Jail

title: Swimming Worlds Are a Multitasker's Paradise
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, March 27  Natalie Coughlin had just won a bronze medal in the 100-meter butterfly, but savoring the moment was out of the question.

title: Reagan Budget Chief Is Charged With Fraud
description: David A. Stockman, the former budget director for President Reagan, was indicted today on charges that he covered up the dire financial state of his company as it was headed into bankruptcy.

title: Ex-Software Chief Is Guilty
description: The former chief executive of Aspen Technology, a maker of software for oil and chemical companies, pleaded guilty yesterday to federal charges that he lied to investors.

title: YouTube Awards the Top of Its Heap
description: Et tu, YouTube? The mellow Silicon Valley video-sharing site, once styled as nothing more than a converted loft space for oddball videos, is looking more Hollywood by the minute. Back in the day, say, six months ago, YouTube was still meant to be pure NoCal: no judgments, no hierarchies, big bandwidth and lots of freedom. YouTube videographers werent supposed to get stars on their doors from the powers that be.

title: Rising Tennis Player Uses the Power of Negative Thinking
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 26  To prepare for one of the biggest tennis matches of his career, Amer Delic visualized hitting forehands into the seats and volleys into the net. He pictured himself being blown off this island by Nikolay Davydenko, the No. 4 seed in the Sony Ericsson Open.

title: In Trial, Drugs Equal Benefits of Artery Stents
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 26  Many heart patients routinely implanted with stents to open arteries gain no lasting benefit compared with those treated just with drugs, researchers reported Monday.

title: Ex-Law Clerk Tells of Brooklyn Judges Meetings and Gifts
description: The judge sat at the defense table. The law clerk sat on the witness stand. The law clerk looked across the courtroom and pointed at the judge.

title: Political Theater: A Banned Play on the War (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain: Call for First-In-Humans Drug Trial Reforms
description: In response to a clinical trial at a London hospital last year in which six men nearly died, the European Medicines Agency proposed new guidelines for European Union researchers to take for high-risk medicines being tested for the first time in humans. The men signed up to receive TGN1412, an immune stimulant from a small German concern, and rapidly suffered multiple organ failure, requiring weeks in intensive care. The reaction had not been predicted from animal experiments. Under the guidelines, new high-risk drugs should be given to one volunteer at a time, allowing intervals to check for reactions. They also suggest that monitoring extend long after the initial experiment. In addition, British researchers have questioned conventional animal models, especially for immune molecules or long-acting medicines.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Friday about a plan by The New York Times Company to increase its dividend misstated the year that the company started its current dual-class share structure. It was 1957  not 1969, the year the company went public. The article also misstated the procedure for changing the dual-class structure. A change can occur only with the approval of the Ochs-Sulzberger family trust, which controls the Times Company; it cannot be made by the company.

title: Problems Cited Between V.A. and Pentagon
description: WASHINGTON, Mar, 27  The Department of Veterans Affairs and the Department of Defense continue to have problems collecting and sharing medical data, hampering treatment for wounded soldiers, lawmakers said at a Congressional hearing today.

title: 8 Decades of Gay Men, at the Altar With History
description: You wanna get married? says the school librarian, breathing heavily, to the handsome Korean War veteran at what is clearly the beginning of a beautiful relationship. This is not quite a Barbara Cartland moment, given its context in Some Men, the surface-skimming, hit-and-miss new comedy by Terrence McNally that opened last night at the Second Stage Theater.

title: Robert Petersen, Publisher of Auto Buff Magazines, Dies at 80
description: Robert E. Petersen, who channeled his enduring California-boy fervor for fast cars with tailfins and chrome-plated engines into a string of successful magazines, including Hot Rod and Motor Trend, died Friday in Santa Monica, Calif. Mr. Petersen, who lived in Beverly Hills, Calif., was 80.

title: Carmakers Push More Use of Alternative Fuels
description: The chief executives of United States automakers urged President Bush yesterday to back incentives to bring ethanol and biodiesel to more pumps as the companies bolster output of so-called flex-fuel vehicles.

title: Boomers: Whimpers or Bangs?
description: On Jan. 1, 2046, the hardiest members of that noisy, 78-million member club known as the Baby Boomers will be celebrating their 100th birthdays.

title: Outcomes: Fertility Treatment and the Next Generation
description: Although the study was small and the results open to interpretation, Danish researchers have found that men born to mothers who had fertility treatments had lower sperm concentrations than other men.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Tuesday about efforts by Cory A. Booker, the mayor of Newark, to unseat state legislators who he says are blocking his agenda misstated the given name and title in some copies for a New Jersey Senate candidate he is backing, and incorrectly attributed a potential distinction to her. She is Teresa Ruiz, not Theresa, and she is deputy chief of staff to the Essex County executive, not chief of staff. If elected, she would be the first Hispanic woman in the New Jersey Senate  not the first Hispanic. (The first was Robert Menendez, now a United States senator.) The article also referred imprecisely to the 29th Legislative District. It includes all of Hillside Township, not just a slice of it.

title: From the Ashes of the Cocteau Repertory, a New Company Is Born
description: The Exchange repertory company announced two new shows yesterday: Realism by Anthony Neilson and Jump! by Lisa McGee, to start performances at the Kirk Theater on Theater Row in April. Never heard of the Exchange?

title: Manhattan: Detective Held on Rape Charge
description: A detective was arrested yesterday and charged with raping his companion, the police said. Detective Michael Seward of the Police Departments Brooklyn warrants squad was arrested in Manhattan shortly after 9 a.m., according to the police. They said that Detective Seward was accused of rape by his companion after the couple had a dispute.

title: Stock Bonuses at American Anger Pilots
description: It may look like chicken feed in this era of mammoth executive pay packages, but a combined $21 million in stock payouts to five top executives at American Airlines is looming large in labor talks with pilots still angry about pay concessions made four years ago.

title: Scientists Hope Vigilance Stymies Avian Flu Mutations
description: Just exactly what is the bird flu virus doing?

title: Stockman Is Charged With Fraud
description: About a month before his company filed for bankruptcy protection, the chief executive of Collins & Aikman, a maker of vehicle instrument panels and floor mats, made a last-ditch attempt for a loan.

title: Trafficker or Healer? And Whos the Victim?
description: ALEXANDRIA, Va., March 26  The case of the United States v. William Eliot Hurwitz, which began in federal court here on Monday, is about much more than one physician. Its a battle over who sets the rules for treating patients who are in pain: narcotics agents and prosecutors, or doctors and scientists.

title: For Smaller Fighters of H.I.V., Weapons Dwindle
description: If it can be sold, traded or swiped, you can find it at the intersection of Mother Gaston Boulevard and Belmont Avenue in Brownsville. In this crazy corner of Brooklyn, bleary-eyed men and women with faces worn from hustling a buck  or more  stand outside all-night delis, their eyes shifting about as quickly as their feet.

title: Memo Pad
description: TRAVEL COST MORE IN 2006 Average one-way domestic air fares paid by corporations, which dropped to a six-year low in 2005, rose last year to $231, the American Express Business Travel Monitor reported. Average one-way international fares continued a four-year climb, to $1,707, and average international daily hotel rates rose for the fifth consecutive year, to $230. Average daily car rental rates crept up again, to $69. Corporate pressure on business travelers to comply with booking policies held down the rate of increases, said Mike Streit, vice president of American Express Business Travel Advisory Services. The average air fare rates were calculated from hundreds of domestic and international routes negotiated for corporate clients by American Express, from discount coach to first class. The average rate for car rentals includes fuel, taxes and other charges. Among domestic hotels, average nightly rates rose most sharply in the cheapest niche, the budget category, to $179 in the fourth quarter of 2006 from $150 in the comparable 2005 quarter.

title: Gunmen in Iraq Kill Tribal Opponent of Al Qaeda
description: BAGHDAD, March 27  Attackers killed a prominent member of an Iraqi tribe that had taken a stand against Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia, and in other violence today more than 53 people were killed in gunfire and bomb attacks.

title: The Claim: You Can Disinfect a Kitchen Sponge in the Microwave
description: THE FACTS  For years, it has been said that people looking for an easy way to disinfect their soiled sponges, which can become remarkable germ magnets, can pop them in the microwave. The practice has become common. But is it effective?

title: Scientists Explore Ways to Lure Viruses to Their Death
description: There are only a few basic ways to fight viruses. A vaccine can prime the immune system to attack them as soon as they invade the body. If a virus manages to establish itself, a doctor may be able to prescribe a drug to slow down its spread. And if all else fails, a doctor may quarantine a patient to head off an epidemic.

title: A Smoother Re-entry
description: With corrections costs going through the roof, states and localities are beginning to figure out the long-term costs of just shoving inmates out the door when their sentences are finished. To prevent people from ending up right back inside, states will need to embrace re-entry programs that provide ex-offenders with training, jobs, places to live and a range of social services that dont exist in most places.

title: 9 Officers Faulted for Aftermath of Tillman Death
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  Army officers violated regulations and misled members of Cpl. Pat Tillmans family by failing to disclose promptly in 2004 that he had been accidentally killed by other American soldiers, a Pentagon investigation concluded Monday.

title: Flood of Sewage in Gaza Kills at Least 4
description: At least 4 people were killed today in the northern Gaza Strip and more than 30 injured when a sewage system collapsed, flooding a village with waste water, according to the United Nations agency for Palestinian refugees.

title: Seized Group of Britons Is Healthy, Iranians Say
description: LONDON, March 26  The stalemate over the 15 British naval personnel seized by Iranian forces north of the Persian Gulf last week continued Monday, with Britain repeating its demands for their immediate release and Iran refusing to say where exactly they were being held or what would happen to them.

title: Pakistan: Nationwide Protests
description: Thousands of political opposition members rallied peacefully across Pakistan to denounce President Pervez Musharrafs suspension of Chief Justice Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry. Around 2,000 protested in Lahore and 3,000 in Karachi. Leaders termed the turnout a success after the arrests of hundreds of opposition members over the weekend.

title: The Dinner Was Potluck, but Then, So Was the Art
description: They came bearing sticky rice with sweet Cambodian sausage, peanut soba noodles and carrot-ginger soup. The spinach salad with almonds and capers was quickly devoured. And whoever made the pistachio-mango tart was judged to be a god.

title: Intel to Build Advanced Chip-Making Plant in China
description: SHANGHAI, March 26  Intel has already labeled it Fab 68, the $2.5 billion chip-manufacturing plant that is set to become the companys first major production site in Asia.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the election in Hong Kong gave the incorrect number of votes in some copies won by the incumbent chief executive, Donald Tsang. He received 649 votes from electors, not 645. The article also referred incorrectly to the vote in some copies. It was the first contested election for chief executive since the territorys return to China in 1997; it was not the first contested election ever held in Hong Kong.

title: A Life Filled to the Brim, With Still More to Add
description: When she learned that the fellow she was talking to had once spent time in Romania, Peggy Stone slipped into Romanian from English as effortlessly as a Formula 1 driver shifting gears. Too bad the guy didnt know two words of the language. He was curious, though, how she had picked it up.

title: Aide to Gonzales Wont Testify About Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  An aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales on Monday invoked her constitutional right to refuse to testify before a Senate panel investigating last years removal of eight United States attorneys, her lawyer told the committee.

title: U.S. Long Worried That Iran Supplied Arms in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  More than 20 months ago, the United States secretly sent Iran a diplomatic protest charging that Tehran was supplying lethal roadside explosive devices to Shiite extremists in Iraq, according to American officials familiar with the message.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Sunday about the election in Hong Kong gave the incorrect number of votes in some copies won by the incumbent chief executive, Donald Tsang. He received 649 votes from electors, not 645. The article also referred incorrectly to the vote in some copies. It was the first contested election for chief executive since the territorys return to China in 1997; it was not the first contested election ever held in Hong Kong. (Go to Article)

title: U.N. Report Urges Independence for Kosovo
description: UNITED NATIONS, March 26  Martti Ahtisaari, the United Nations secretary generals envoy for Kosovo, on Monday officially recommended its independence, saying it was the only way the strife-worn Serbian province could become economically viable and politically stable.

title: In the City, Its Super: The Power to Suggest
description: The Palm was on its best behavior on Sunday night. Waiters in white coats swarmed the room like a crime-scene team, topping off wine glasses, delivering salads and assiduously dismantling any Alaskan King Crab Leg that had managed to remain intact on someones dinner plate.

title: One Solid Herbicide
description: Gardeners and farmers the world around know about Roundup, the popular herbicide that kills weeds (and just about any other plant).

title: At Risk: For Firefighters, the Danger May Be Within
description: The most common cause of death among firefighters at work is not burns or smoke inhalation, but heart attacks, and a new study reports that those attacks are 10 to 100 times as likely to occur when firefighters are suppressing a fire as when performing nonemergency duties. Cardiovascular events account for 45 percent of deaths of firefighters on duty.

title: Snchez Faces Surgery for Shoulder Fracture
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 26  The pop in his shoulder that Duaner Snchez felt while pitching Thursday, the one that caused him to hunch over in discomfort and grab at the front of his shoulder, was not the loosening of scar tissue. It was a more serious injury, a hairline fracture of his coracoid, a small bone in the front of his right shoulder that could cause big complications for the Mets bullpen.

title: Heat Invades Cool Heights Over Arizona Desert
description: SUMMERHAVEN, Ariz.  High above the desert floor, this little alpine town has long served as a natural air-conditioned retreat for people in Tucson, one of the so-called sky islands of southern Arizona. When it is 105 degrees in the city, it is at least 20 degrees cooler up here near the 9,157-foot summit of Mount Lemmon.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A picture in some copies with an art review in Weekend on Friday about Van Gogh and Expressionism, at the Neue Galerie, was published in error. It showed The Rice Portrait of Jane Austen, which accompanied the Inside Art column.

title: Senators Aide Held on Gun Charge
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  A close aide to Senator Jim Webb, Democrat of Virginia, was arrested on Monday and jailed after trying to take a loaded handgun into a Senate office building, officials said.

title: Mideast Leaders Agree to Meet Biweekly
description: JERUSALEM, March 27  After three days of shuttle diplomacy between Israeli and Arab cities and a late night of haggling, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said today that she had persuaded Israeli and Palestinian leaders to hold talks twice a month.

title: King Cole Gets a Cleaning; Pipe and Bowl Are Next
description: And now: the lighter, brighter merry old soul.

title: Prosecution Complex
description: Washington

title: An Elusive Diagnosis, and One That Comes With a Risk of Cancer
description: When Rene Parcover found out there was a name for the disease that left her so weak she needed a wheelchair to get to doctors appointments, she was so relieved she started sobbing.

title: City Report Defends Con Ed for Key Choice in Blackout
description: Lawyers for the Bloomberg administration are defending Consolidated Edisons decision not to shut down the electrical network that failed in western Queens last July, causing a nine-day blackout.

title: N.C.A.A.s 1957 Classic Is Only a Memory for Now
description: To make it worse, to make defeat snatched from the jaws of victory sting even more, Lennie Rosenbluth was going back to North Carolina this weekend, home to Chapel Hill.

title: J. Kirk Osborn, a Lawyer in the Duke Lacrosse Case, Dies at 64
description: J. Kirk Osborn, a lawyer who gained national prominence defending one of three Duke University lacrosse players against a dancers accusations of sexual assault last year, died Sunday in Chapel Hill, N.C. He was 64.

title: Japan Leader Who Denied State Role in Wartime Sex Slavery Still Apologizes
description: TOKYO, March 26  Facing increasing criticism for denying that Japan coerced women into sex slavery during World War II, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe repeatedly refused Monday to acknowledge state responsibility in recruiting the comfort women, but offered them an apology.

title: Inventory Details Mrs. Astors $131 Million Estate
description: Her 12-room duplex apartment on Park Avenue is worth about $24 million  $2 million per room. Her 65-acre estate in Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., is valued at $17 million  nearly $20.5 million if you include the personal property inside. She holds an estimated $23.5 million in stocks, and the jewelry she keeps in New York City has been appraised at around $1.3 million.

title: You Are Also What You Drink
description: What worries you most? Decaying teeth, thinning bones, heart disease, stroke, diabetes, dementia, cancer, obesity? Whatever tops your list, you may be surprised to know that all of these health problems are linked to the beverages you drink  or dont drink.

title: My Brother, My Self: Love in the Time of Drought
description: Daniel Masons first novel, The Piano Tuner, published in 2002, when the author was a 26-year-old medical student, was a dazzling debut. Part bildungsroman, part Conradian quest, part Odyssey-like saga, that novel recounted the quixotic tale of a British piano tuner named Edgar Drake, who was sent in 1886 by Her Majestys government to a remote village in Burma to repair a piano belonging to Surgeon Maj. Anthony Carroll, an eccentric officer in charge of a vital military post. As harrowingly rendered by Mr. Mason, the stories of Drake and Carroll became both an examination of the brutalities and the compromises of Britains imperial adventure, and an elliptical meditation on the storytelling process itself.

title: The Story of a Creative Duo, Told Through Their Songs
description: Life would be a snap if you followed some basic musical comedy advice. Make someone else happy, and you will be happy too. Remember that every day comes once in a lifetime, so make the most of every day; and so on and so forth.

title: Making Every Day a Sun Day
description: In perhaps the most famous letter ever written to the editor of a newspaper, an 8-year-old girl named Virginia OHanlon said she turned to The New York Sun to find out if there was a Santa Claus because her father told her, If you see it in The Sun, its so.

title: Yahoo to Offer a Network for Web Ads on Cellphones
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 26  Yahoo is moving to secure a position on the next Internet battleground: Web search and advertising on cellphones.

title: Study Links Aspirin and Longer Life
description: Women who take aspirin in low or moderate doses reduce their risk of dying from any cause, particularly heart disease, a study published yesterday concluded.

title: House Iraq Vote: Political Theater? (6 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Letting Go of an Ancient Quarrel
description: It took a few centuries, but Irelands biggest chasm was bridged yesterday. There was the Rev. Ian Paisley, the hardest of hard-line Protestant Unionists, sitting with Gerry Adams, the very incarnation of militant Irish Catholic republicanism. It was their first public meeting.
