And out of it came an agreement to form a joint administration of Northern Ireland that will take office on May 8, reviving the long dormant home rule legislature and staving off an extended period of direct British rule.

title: Mine Company Makes Bid for Nickel Producer
description: OTTAWA, March 26  Xstrata, the Swiss mining company, moved to extend its presence in the nickel market Monday with a friendly takeover of LionOre Mining International valued at 4.6 billion Canadian dollars ($3.96 billion).

title: Tough Days to Be a French Oilman
description: PARIS, March 26  Christophe de Margerie, the new chief executive of Total, Frances largest corporation and one of the worlds big energy companies, was formally placed under investigation last week on suspicion of paying bribes to win a huge gas project in Iran.

title: Barclays Chief Places Third in Pay
description: LONDON, March 26  Barclays, the British bank that is in merger talks with ABN Amro, said Monday that it paid its president and head of investment banking almost five times the compensation of its chief executive last year.

title: Council Considers Trial Period for Neighborhood Taxi Stands
description: In the television sitcom Taxi, the dispatcher used a radio to tell the cabdrivers where to pick up their next fares. That system started to change in 1982, when yellow-cab companies were permitted to transfer two-way radios to their nonyellow cars, to free up yellow cabs for street hails. And the system disappeared entirely in 1987, when radio-dispatched cabs were phased out.

title: The Police and the Spy Unit
description: Mayor Michael Bloombergs city attorneys are fighting the release of police surveillance records related to the 2004 Republican National Convention in New York City by arguing that the public might misinterpret them or the news media will fixate upon and sensationalize them. Those are the risks we take in a democracy.

title: 2 Injured in Upper West Side Fire
description: A firefighter and a 31-year-old woman were seriously injured today in a fire that broke out at 8 a.m. in the basement of a five-story apartment building less than a block east of Lincoln Center on Manhattans Upper West Side.

title: Homeowner Stares Down Wreckers, at Least for a While
description: CHONGQING, China, March 23  For weeks the confrontation drew attention from people all across China, as a simple homeowner stared down the forces of large-scale redevelopment that are sweeping this country, blocking the preparation of a gigantic construction site by an act of sheer will.

title: Pakistan: Tribesmen Promise to Shun Militants
description: Some 800 tribal elders in northwest Bajaur pledged not to give shelter to anyone suspected of terrorist activity. The promise is a bid to bring peace to the tribal region near the Afghan border, where a strike by an American Predator drone in January 2006 came close to killing Al Qaedas second in command, Ayman al-Zawahri, and did kill 18 others. Last October, an airstrike by Pakistani forces on a religious school in the district reportedly killed 83 people. Similar promises made by tribal leaders in North and South Waziristan have been criticized because, in exchange, the government agreed to pull out troops. The Bajaur pledge comes with no such agreement by the government.

title: What We Can Do
description: We must acknowledge the limits of our power and knowledge in Iraq, Afghanistan and elsewhere and concentrate on what is achievable. The question is not What ought we to do? but What can we do?

title: Documentary on Islam (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Ulster Factions Agree to a Plan for Joint Rule
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, March 26  After years of hostility and recriminations, the leaders of Northern Irelands dominant rival groups, Gerry Adams of Sinn Fein and the Protestant leader, the Rev. Ian Paisley, held their first face-to-face talks on Monday and agreed to form a joint administration for the province on May 8.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,229 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: Disfiguring Treatment? No, It Was Healing
description: My daughter and I were talking about outing oneself  the act of disclosing ones inner identity. The discussion was not purely academic.

title: Needle Biopsy Risks
description: Q. Is it true that needle biopsies leak lung cancer cells into the bloodstream, spreading cancer throughout the body?

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An obituary last Tuesday about Raymond D. Nasher, a collector of Modern and contemporary sculpture who founded a Dallas museum to exhibit it, omitted his survivors. They include his daughters, Andrea Nasher, Joanie Nasher and Nancy Nasher Haemisegger, and three grandchildren.

title: A Tale of Power and Intrigue in the Lab, Based on Real Life
description: On Nov. 1, 1991, outraged that his doctoral thesis had been passed over for an academic prize, a young physicist at the University of Iowa named Gang Lu opened fire at a physics department meeting. He killed five people and paralyzed another before taking his own life.

title: Ex-Qwest Official Says Nacchio Ignored Advice
description: DENVER, March 26 (Bloomberg News)  Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications, insisted on telling analysts the company could meet revenue targets that were later revised, an ex-finance chief testified on Monday.

title: Bush Spokesmans Cancer Returns and Spreads
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  Tony Snow, the White House press secretary who has spoken frequently of his battle with colon cancer, has suffered a recurrence of the cancer and the disease has spread to his liver, White House officials said today.

title: Newark: Air Passengers Checked for Sickness
description: A Continental Airlines flight from Hong Kong was held on the tarmac at Newark Liberty International Airport for nearly three hours yesterday while representatives of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention interviewed passengers with flulike symptoms. Karen Hunter, a spokeswoman for the agency, said seven passengers showed signs of fever and reported vomiting before Flight 98 took off. During the 14-hour flight, several more passengers, members of a Canada-based travel group, showed signs of illness. After the flight landed, an expert in contagious diseases determined that the passengers probably had a routine virus and were not infected with the avian flu, Ms. Hunter said. All of the 272 passengers on board were allowed to debark and continue their travels.

title: Hopes for a Plaque-Fighting Drug Dim
description: An experimental heart drug abandoned by Pfizer because of safety problems failed to reduce the plaque that clogs arteries even though it raised so-called good cholesterol, new studies released yesterday show.

title: Goodell Says Hell Punish N.F.L.s Problem Players
description: PHOENIX, March 26  N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell said Monday that he expected to begin disciplining players who were tainting the league with their misbehavior under a new personal conduct policy that will start within a month. He is threatening to punish repeat offenders with one-year suspensions and teams with fines and the loss of draft picks.

title: Indonesia to Resume Sending Flu Virus Samples to W.H.O.
description: Indonesia said Tuesday that it would resume sending samples of avian flu virus to the World Health Organization for research purposes, on the understanding that they will not be shared with commercial vaccine makers.

title: Senate Keeps Pullout Date in Iraq War Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  The Senate defeated an attempt to erase an American troop withdrawal date from an Iraq spending bill this afternoon after an emotional debate about the powers of the presidency and Congress and the well-being of front-line soldiers.

title: Ex-President of CBS Radio Is Returning to Lead Unit
description: CBS said yesterday that it would bring back the former president of its radio division, Dan Mason, to succeed Joel Hollander as head of the 144-station group.

title: M.T.A. Seeks Designs for Cameras to Be Installed Inside Subway Cars
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has asked two subway car manufacturers to come up with designs for digital security cameras that could be installed inside the cars, officials said yesterday.

title: The Old and the New, Becoming the Compelling
description: Anyone who has come across Thomas Ads as a performer knows what an unusually good pianist he is. Louis Lortie played two pieces by Mr. Ads, a British composer, as part of his Carnegie Hall recital on Saturday. Liszt and Chopin occupied the rest of the evening.

title: AT&T Has Done the Deals. Now It Needs Results.
description: Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the chairman and chief executive of AT&T, is captivating several hundred employees in an Atlanta auditorium with a pep talk about the rosy future of the worlds largest telephone company. His demeanor is commanding, cut with a practiced avuncular charm.

title: Thousands of Settlers Return to West Bank Town
description: HOMESH, West Bank, March 26  Ariel Hazani stretched out on a sleeping bag next to a silver pup tent on the same patch of grass where his home once stood in this former Jewish settlement. Around him on Monday, about 2,000 other right-wing activists were also setting up camp for the night.

title: Intel to Build Advanced Chip-Making Plant in China
description: SHANGHAI, March 26  The Intel Corporation has already labeled it Fab 68, the $2.5 billion chip-manufacturing facility that is set to become the companys first major production site in Asia.

title: Between-Cars Crackdown Adds to Arrests on Subways
description: Four times since December, women have told the police about a frightening crime at the No. 7 subway lines Fifth Avenue station: a man riding between cars grabbed their purses as the train pulled away, sometimes yanking the victims to the ground.

title: Citigroup to Cut at Least 10,000 in an Overhaul
description: Citigroup, the global banking giant, is stepping up its first major overhaul since it was forged by a merger nearly a decade ago.

title: Egypt Voters Approve Constitutional Change, Government Says
description: CAIRO, March 27  Voters in Egypt have overwhelmingly approved amendments to the countrys constitution, the government said today, despite opposition organizations calling for a boycott.

title: Protester Disrupts Service With Blair and Queen
description: LONDON, March 27  A protester ran to the front of Westminster Abbey during a service on Tuesday commemorating the 200th anniversary of the abolition of the slave trade, shouting, You should be ashamed! and This is an insult to us! at Prime Minister Tony Blair and Queen Elizabeth, who were only a few yards away.

title: Both Laughs and Demons, Hidden in Lost Memories
description: Found wandering the streets of Chicago, her feet bruised and bloody, a homeless woman whom the doctors call Mary Smith suffers from dissociative amnesia, also called fugue amnesia. She has lost her memory and sense of identity. A supervising psychiatrist (Liam Craig) asks a younger doctor (Rick Stear), who has his own demons, to work with Mary (Deirdre OConnell) to retrieve her memory.

title: Auxiliary Officers in N.Y. to Get Protective Vests
description: New York City will begin providing bullet-resistant vests to its 4,500 auxiliary police officers, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced today at a news conference in Greenwich Village, where two auxiliary officers were fatally shot by a gunman on the night of March 14.

title: E.On Bid for Endesa Wins Support From the Board and a Large Shareholder
description: MADRID, March 26  The German energy company E.Ons chances of winning its protracted takeover bid for a Spanish utility, Endesa, took a step forward Monday.

title: Turkey: Prosecutors Open Investigation Into Prime Minister
description: Prosecutors in Ankara are investigating whether Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan once referred to Abdullah Ocalan, the imprisoned Kurdish rebel leader, by the honorific Sayin, or esteemed, the Anatolian News Agency reported. Praising a criminal or criminal organization in Turkey is itself a crime. According to reports, Mr. Erdogan referred to Mr. Ocalan by the honorific in an Australian radio interview in 2000.

title: Optional Caesareans Carry Higher Risks, Study Finds
description: Caesarean sections performed without a medical reason result in longer hospital stays, higher costs and more than twice as many rehospitalizations as vaginal deliveries, a new study reports.

title: Aid to Darfur Is Imperiled, Officials Say
description: DERIBAT, Sudan, March 25  It was supposed to be a top United Nations officials first visit to a camp for Darfur residents chased from their homes by the grim conflict here, but it did not begin or end well.

title: Reader Response: Commuting
description: Selected responses to a previous question on commuting in the region.

title: Involuntary Call-Up Set for Marines
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  As many as 1,200 Marine reservists are being involuntarily called up for duty in Iraq next year for jobs the service has been unable to find enough volunteers to fill, the Marine Corps said Monday.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 26, 2007

title: You, Too, Can Be a Banker to the Poor
description: KABUL, Afghanistan

title: Knicks Let Magic Slip Away and Playoff Hopes Dim
description: The battle at the bottom of the Eastern Conference playoff field might have been decided last night by one large palm, two momentous swats and one very large non-call.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An architecture review on Thursday about Frank Gehrys IAC headquarters building along the West Side Highway in Chelsea misspelled the name of the German city that is the site of his Vitra Design Museum, which the IAC building was said to bring to mind. It is Weil am Rhein, not Weil am Reim.

title: Disposable Friendships and a Fight to the Finish
description: Jennifer Aniston and Courteney Cox are best friends who played best friends on Friends, so it should be fun to see them reunited as enemies on tonights season finale of Dirt on FX.

title: Whats on Tonight
description: 10 P.M. (A&E) DRIVING FORCE The family that races together stays together. Thats according to John Force, who brought his three daughters  Ashley, now 24; Brittany, 20; and Courtney, 18  into the family drag-racing business, having missed out on much of their childhoods. Tonight the Forces prepare to burn rubber in a second season of this reality series. It will follow Ashley as she moves into the funny car division, in which she is expected to finish in the Top 10  a first for a woman  and could end up competing against her father; and John as he pursues a 15th National Hot Rod Association championship.

title: Spitzer Willing to Give Ground in Budget Talks, Up to a Point
description: ALBANY, March 26  Gov. Eliot Spitzer struck a more conciliatory tone on Monday about the budget, suggesting that he was willing to make compromises in order to get a budget passed by the State Legislature before the fiscal year begins next week.

title: Blair Sends Iran Tough Warning on Seized Britons
description: LONDON, March 27  Tensions escalated between Iran and the West on Tuesday over 15 Britons held by the Iranians, with Prime Minster Tony Blair warning that Britains campaign to free them would move into a different phase if they were not released.

title: Ulsters Dr. No Says Yes, and His Flock Follows
description: BALLYMENA, Northern Ireland, March 27  It is known as the heart of Paisley Protestant country, the town that launched the long political career of hard line Northern Ireland Protestant leader Ian Paisley, once nicknamed Dr. No.

title: Manhattan: Suit Filed by Subway Rescuer
description: Wesley Autrey Sr., the construction worker who leapt to the subway tracks at West 137th Street in January to save the life of a stranger, has filed a lawsuit charging that a lawyer and a man who represented himself as an entertainment executive tricked him into signing an unconscionable contract allowing them to exploit his name and personality. In papers filed last week in State Supreme Court in Manhattan, his current lawyer, Barbara S. Mehlsack, charges that Diane L. Kleiman, a lawyer, and Mark Anthony, also known as Mark Anthony Esposito, injured Mr. Autreys reputation by, among other things, pressuring a school to pay him a speakers fee and demanding expenses from a magazine reporter as a condition for access to Mr. Autrey. The lawsuit seeks damages and the voiding of the contract. Ms. Kleiman did not return a message left on her telephone answering machine yesterday, and a phone number for Mr. Anthony could not be found.

title: Bank Blocks Plan to Release Frozen Funds to North Korea
description: HONG KONG, March 26  A largely foreign-owned North Korean bank has emerged as a major obstacle to a deal that would allow six-party negotiations over North Koreas nuclear program to move forward.

title: France: Carrefour Speculation Ends
description: Speculation that Carrefour, the French retailer, was headed for a takeover were dashed late Friday, setting off a sharp decline in the companys share price yesterday. Takeover speculation ended when Bernard Arnault, a French investor, and Colony Capital, an American investment firm, said they would not acquire more than 20 percent of Carrefour until June 30, 2008, unless Carrefours largest shareholder, the Halley family, decided to sell its 13 percent stake or a new shareholder bought more than 5 percent of the company. Speculation that a takeover was imminent had swirled around the company since last month when Colony Capital and Mr. Arnault, together with a hedge fund, bought a 9.8 percent stake. Stock in Carrefour, which is based in Paris, fell 1.19 euros, or 2 percent, to 54.22 euros a share.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Friday about Elizabeth Edwards and her cancer diagnosis gave an incorrect description in some copies for the cancer that afflicted Tony Snow, the White House spokesman, who expressed support for Mrs. Edwards. He had colon cancer, not prostate cancer.

title: Iraqis Announce New Steps Aimed at Reconciling Sunnis and Shiites
description: BAGHDAD, March 26  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki and President Jalal Talabani announced Monday that they plan to introduce a proposal that would allow thousands more former members of Saddam Husseins Baath Party to serve in the government.

title: Three Outs Will Be All the Yankees Need From Rivera
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 26  The most harrowing nightmare for the Yankees is not losing a starting pitcher to a spring injury, which has happened three times in the last eight days. It is losing Mariano Rivera.

title: To Visit a Museum, Perchance to Dream
description: SEEING your first tiger can be surprising, worrying, fascinating and ultimately tiring. Especially if you are a toddler on your first visit to the animal dioramas at the American Museum of Natural History.

title: Dropping Detachment and Reconnecting to Patients
description: At some point during training, medical students often unconsciously begin to think of their patients as alien beings, members of a weak, unlucky species of unrelated biped. It is a predictable, if regrettable, psychic defense mechanism in those first difficult years of immersion in human disability and death.

title: Records Tumble at Swimming Championships
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, March 27  On a night in which four world records fell, Michael Phelps of the United States grabbed the spotlight tonight by smashing Ian Thorpes world record in the 200-meter freestyle at the world swimming championships here.

title: Bertelsmann Reaches Deal With EMI Over Napster
description: Bertelsmann, the German media giant that provided financial backing to Napster when it was an unauthorized file-sharing service, has agreed to settle with the last of the major record companies that had sued it for copyright infringement.

title: Plea of Guilty From Detainee in Guantnamo
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, March 26  In the first conviction of a Guantnamo detainee before a military commission, an Australian who was trained by Al Qaeda pleaded guilty here Monday to providing material support to a terrorist organization.

title: When Torture Is Normalized (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Perahia, Poet of the Keyboard, Comes Back With Thunder
description: The pianist Murray Perahia has been sidelined by hand injuries a couple of times in recent years, but lately he has been telling interviewers that he has overcome his latest bout and is back at full strength. His recital at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday afternoon was confirmation: his playing sounds bigger and more powerful than it once did. He has, it seems, abandoned his old image as a sensitive keyboard poet in favor of one that moves him into the Horowitz school of outsize Romantic thundering.

title: Letters
description: The Origin of Morality

title: Time for Answers
description: The news that Monica Goodling, counsel to the attorney general and liaison to the White House, is invoking her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination takes the United States attorney scandal to a new level. Ms. Goodlings decision comes just days after the Justice Department released documents strongly suggesting that Attorney General Alberto Gonzales has not been honest about his own role in the firing of eight federal prosecutors. Mr. Gonzales is scheduled to testify before the Senate in three weeks, but that is too long to wait. He should speak now, and explain why he continues to insist that his department did nothing wrong.

title: Justices Hear Arguments About Pacts on Pricing
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  A 96-year-old rule that treats as an automatic antitrust violation any agreement between a manufacturer and its retailers to adhere to a minimum resale price is considered archaic and out of touch by the Bush administration and economists of the Chicago school.

title: In the Lab: Robots That Slink and Squirm
description: MEDFORD, Mass.  The robot lies dissected on the black slab of a lab table, its silicone rubber exterior spread and flattened like a trophy snakeskin. Hair-thin wires run in a zigzag line along the inner length of its pale artificial flesh.

title: It Can Hold 853 Passengers, but Why Should You Share?
description: IM not sure that we need any more, but here are two new examples that define over the top in air travel: The superjumbo A380, all 10,000 square feet of it, as a personal or business jet. And a private airport terminal just for first-class and top elite-status passengers.

title: Pakistans Silent Majority Is Not to Be Feared
description: London

title: Jerry Girard, WPIX Sports Broadcaster, Dies at 74
description: Jerry Girard, a sports broadcaster for WPIX-TV in New York from 1974 to 1995, died Sunday in Hawthorne, N.Y. He was 74.

title: Refrigerator Art Maybe, but Buyers See Local Resonance
description: LIVINGSTON MANOR, N.Y., March 26  The little girl stood on the tips of her toes, pointing at the large blue figure floating on the canvas. The figure had the shape of a teardrop and was hollow, save for three specks aligned like a capsized triangle on its fat upper edge.

title: New DVDs
description: MURIEL

title: When the U.F.O.s Land, Its Time for a Long Nap
description: Business travel is a lot like space travel. I should know. I used to direct the fatigue countermeasures program at NASA, where we studied the effects of space travel on astronauts. And as an independent scientist, I am constantly traveling on business, so I see how frequent fliers handle exhaustion.

title: Corrections
description: An editorial on March 19 stated incorrectly that the House version of the 2007 Water Resources and Development bill would cost $40 billion. The anticipated cost is $14 billion to $15 billion.

title: High Praise and Gratitude for a Noted Theater Critic
description: What kind of write-up would the drama and literary critic Richard Gilman have given to his own memorial service at Symphony Space in Manhattan yesterday?

title: Mets Welcome Back Mota as One of Their Own
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 26  Guillermo Mota moseyed into the Mets clubhouse a few minutes after 2 p.m. Monday and could not walk two steps without being intercepted by a teammate, a coach or a clubhouse attendant.

title: For Some Black Pastors, Accepting Gay Members Means Losing Others
description: ATLANTA  When the Rev. Dennis Meredith of Tabernacle Baptist Church here began preaching acceptance of gay men and lesbians a few years ago, he attracted some gay people who were on the brink of suicide and some who had left the Baptist faith of their childhoods but wanted badly to return.

title: 14 Accused of Corruption in a New Jersey City
description: NEWARK, March 26  One bribe was made in exchange for dismissing the complaints of a distressed tenant against a landlord. A second was to ensure a timely lead paint inspection. Another was submitted for the most basic of needs: to keep water service from being shut off.

title: Dental Health: Treating Gum Disease May Ease Other Ailments
description: Intensive treatment of gum disease may lead to improved blood flow and significantly reduced inflammation in the body, a new study reports.

title: Centennial Salute to Grieg, Far Beyond Peer Gynt
description: Edvard Grieg was not a master of big forms, but rather of expression. This is a fans way of saying that his work is elegant and accessible rather than complex or thorny. Eminently approachable and graceful in his writing, he was extremely popular in his lifetime and remains a staple of pops concerts today  at least for Peer Gynt, which represents the more film-music side of an altogether accessible oeuvre.

title: Elton John Celebrates 60, Lavishly, in His Garden
description: Elton John has never seemed like the kind of guy to shrug off a big occasion. So it was natural, perhaps even inevitable, that he would celebrate his 60th birthday at Madison Square Garden. His sprawling concert on Sunday night featured no onstage candles  not even Candle in the Wind  but felt ceremonial enough without them. There were dedications, recollections and a shower of confetti. A banner was unfurled from the rafters, bearing a giant number 60 under his name.

title: New Zealand: Investors Buy Yellow Pages
description: CCMP Capital Asia and a unit of the Ontario Teachers Pension Plan agreed to buy the Yellow Pages unit of the Telecom Corporation of New Zealand for 2.24 billion New Zealand dollars ($1.6 billion). CCMP Asia, a buyout firm spun off from JPMorgan Chase, and Teachers Private Capital will pay 2.17 billion New Zealand dollars in cash for the print and online directories, Telecom New Zealand said. Telecom New Zealand also expects to get 75 million New Zealand dollars from the units debtors, and plans to use income from the sale to return capital to shareholders, it said.

title: Mindful of Past, Clinton Cultivates the Military
description: Of all the early problems Bill Clinton faced as president, few stand out to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton as more frustrating and avoidable than his rocky relationship with the military, her advisers say.

title: Embattled Smithsonian Official Resigns
description: WASHINGTON, March 26  The governing board of the Smithsonian Institution announced Monday that it had accepted the resignation of its top official, Lawrence M. Small, after an internal audit showing that the museum complex had paid for his routine use of lavish perks like chauffeured cars, private jets, top-rated hotels and catered meals.

title: Runs, Hits and Calories
description: Scripted schedules, living out of a suitcase and pressure for peak performance. It is the life of the business traveler and of the professional baseball player.

title: Anna Nicole Smiths Death Is Ruled an Accidental Drug Overdose
description: MIAMI, March 26  An accidental prescription drug overdose killed Anna Nicole Smith last month, the medical examiner who performed her autopsy said Monday.

title: An Ancient Greek Lesson About the Abuse of Power
description: Even for the Greek gods, what goes around comes around. If Zeus has the upper hand in Aeschylus Prometheus Bound, it is a sure bet that Prometheus, the Olympian rebel who defied authority and saved the human race, will have the last laugh.

title: Bronx: Drug Informant Convicted
description: A 24-year-old man who worked as an undercover operative for the Drug Enforcement Administration was convicted of armed robbery by a State Supreme Court jury last week, even though he claimed to have been on duty for the federal agency at the time of his arrest. The man, Juan Medina, who had helped the drug agency recover a discarded gun used in a crime and had led agents to a heroin operation, had been working for the agency for about two months when he and several others participated in a home invasion robbery in the Bronx in November 2004. Mr. Medina, who faces a 25-year prison sentence, told the police that he had infiltrated a drug gang and had tried to stop the robbery. He said he had informed a federal agent about the robbery before it occurred. But at Mr. Medinas trial, the agent testified that Mr. Medina had not spoken to him about the crime.

title: Nondescript Flurries of Motion, a Tepee and Tea in the Nude
description: Adrienne Truscotts genesis, no! unintentionally disproves the once-popular notion that non sequiturs and weak irony are innately hilarious and make interesting art. The cast of downtown dance notables  Ms. Truscott, David Neumann, Carmine Covelli, Natalie Agee, Neal Medlyn and Io Straithern-Perl  wholeheartedly went along for the ride. But the choreographer, who has performed with LAVA and the Wau Wau Sisters, must have a small, subversive voice inside telling her to trust her true comic gifts.

title: From Rabbi, the Eclectic Shul Aid Matzo Test
description: SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., March 26  Call it a bus mitzvah. Or maybe bus matzo.

title: No Need to Disclose Gifts, Corzine Ex-Companion Said
description: TRENTON, March 26  Carla Katz, a former companion of Gov. Jon S. Corzines and the president of a major state employees union, responded to a 2005 demand from the federal government that she disclose gifts that Mr. Corzine had made to her with a four-page letter arguing that the gifts were not subject to disclosure requirements.

title: Quebec Liberals Are Re-elected, Avoiding Another Secession Vote
description: QUEBEC, March 26  The federalist Liberal Party was re-elected as a slim minority government in provincial elections here Monday. The outcome means Quebec will avoid another divisive referendum on whether the French-speaking province should separate from the rest of Canada.

title: Thailand: Thaksins Wife Charged With Tax Evasion
description: Prosecutors charged Pojaman Shinawatra, the wife of the deposed billionaire prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, and her brother and secretary with tax evasion. It is the first prosecution of a member of Mr. Thaksins family since the Sept. 19 coup. Analysts said the military government was trying to paint a picture of a family enmeshed in corruption, a justification for the coup. Mrs. Pojaman was arraigned in a Bangkok court. Her trial is to begin May 14.

title: In London, a Trial Over an Anonymous Blog
description: LONDON

title: Conservative Jewish Seminary Will Accept Gay Students
description: The Jewish Theological Seminary, the intellectual and spiritual center of Conservative Judaism, said yesterday that it would begin accepting openly gay and lesbian candidates into its rabbinical and cantorial schools.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on March 18 about flight delays at John F. Kennedy International Airport caused by a winter storm gave an erroneous name in some copies for an airline whose flight to Zurich was delayed. (The Practical Traveler column in the Travel section on March 18, about ways to cut the cost of flying to Africa, gave another rendering of the name.) It is Swiss International Air Lines, known as Swiss; it is not SwissAir or Swiss Air. (Swissair, the former national airline of Switzerland, went bankrupt in 2001.)

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article yesterday about deterioration in Chicagos elevated train system misstated the timing of expansion work on the Brown Line. The work on the $529.9 million expansion began in 2004; it is not set to begin next month. (Some track closures and other construction are planned for next month.)

title: Newark: Construction Worker Killed
description: A 25-year-old construction worker was electrocuted while working at McKinley Elementary School at 1 Colonnade Place shortly before 10 p.m. last night, the Newark Fire Department said. The worker was on a lift, putting in new windows at the school, when he somehow came into contact with current from a power line, said John Brown, a spokesman for the Fire Department. The man, who was not identified, was taken to University Hospital, where he was pronounced dead, the authorities said.

title: 'Sewage Tsunami' in Gaza
description: At least 4 people were killed today in the northern Gaza Strip and more than 30 injured when a sewage system collapsed.

title: Housing Struggles
description: In Newark, heavy mortgage debt has led many first-time homebuyers to the edge of financial ruin.

title: What Is Your Favorite Quote From a Recent Book?
description: The editor of the new Yale Book of Quotations has a nice eye for recent bits of pop flotsam, Dwight Garner writes in Sundays Book Review. But what happened to the literary fiction (and nonfiction) of the last 25 years?

title: Opening Salvos at the Hurwitz Trial
description: The retrial of William Hurwitz (the subject of my Findings column) began Monday looking like a rerun of the first trial as the prosecutor spouted familiar horror stories and waved the same red flags. But this is already looking like a tougher case for the prosecution.

title: Straight Talk on Tough Issues
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Carnegie Biography Wins History Prize
description: David Nasaw has been named the winner of the $50,000 New-York Historical Society American Book Prize for his biography, "Andrew Carnegie" (The Penguin Press). Mr. Nasaw is the Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr. Professor of History at the City University of New York Graduate Center. His book tells the rags-toriches story of Carnegie, who became a steel baron and the richest man in the world before deciding to give away his fortune. In announcing the prize with Louise Mirrer, president and chief executive of the Historical Society, Roger Hertog, the board chairman, called the biography "magisterial" and said of Carnegie: "He set himself the ultimate goal of donating all his wealth to society, and at the same time he became a devoted advocate of world peace. The example set by this extraordinary life is remarkably relevant to us today." Professor Nasaw will accept his prize and be named the society's American history laureate in ceremonies on April 27.

title: Aruba I.P.O. Prices Above Expected Range
description: The weak performance of the initial public offering of the wireless carrier Clearwire has many in the telecom industry wondering how another wireless start-up, Aruba Networks, will fare in its market debut.

title: Former Collins & Aikman Chief Is Charged With Fraud
description: David A. Stockman, a former congressman who served as President Ronald Reagans first budget director, was indicted Monday on charges that include bank fraud, conspiracy and obstruction of justice for his role as chief executive of the auto-parts supplier Collins & Aikman.

title: Stock Bonuses at American Anger Pilots
description: It may look like chicken feed in this era of mammoth executive pay packages, but a combined $21 million in stock payouts to five top executives at American Airlines is looming large in labor talks with pilots still angry about pay concessions made four years ago.

title: AT&T Has Done the Deals. Now It Needs Results.
description: In December, AT&T closed on an $86 billion acquisition of BellSouth, capping a string of multibillion-dollar takeover deals, and leaving the company ready and needing to compete through execution, not acquisition, The New York Times reported Tuesday.

title: Forbes Needs Women? Investor Said to Push for Growth
description: Less than a year after buying a $300 million stake in Forbes, Elevation Partners may be itching to see some results. Elevation, a private equity firm co-founded by U2 frontman Bono, which took a minority stake in Forbes in August, is pushing the media company to find new ways to increase revenue, according to The New York Post.

title: Correction:  For the Record
description: A picture caption on Friday with an article about Rudolph W. Giuliani's positions on gun control included an erroneous reference in some copies for Charles E. Schumer, with whom Mr. Giuliani was shown at a news conference in 1995. At the time, Mr. Schumer was a United States representative from New York, not a senator.

title: Bertelsmann Reaches Deal With EMI Over Napster
description: Bertelsmann, the German media company that provided financial backing to Napster when it was an unauthorized file-sharing service, has agreed to settle with the last of the major record companies that sued it for copyright infringement.

title: E.On Bid for Endesa Wins Support
description: The chances that E.On, the German energy company, could win its protracted takeover bid for the Spanish utility Endesa took a step forward Monday. Endesas board recommended E.Ons bid of 42.4 billion euros ($56.3 billion) to its shareholders and a bank agreed to give E.On control of nearly 10 percent of the shares.

title: Executive Tells of Odd Payouts to Hollinger
description: A media executive told federal jurors on Monday how the sale of a half-billion dollars in assets by the Hollinger International newspaper conglomerate was structured to funnel money to a Canadian holding company controlled by the media baron Conrad M. Black. Michael Reed, a former chief executive of Community Newspapers Holdings, which bought several community newspapers from Hollinger in 1999 and 2000, said Hollinger executives insisted on including money for the Canadian company.

title: S.E.C. Censures Ernst & Young
description: Federal regulators censured the accounting firm Ernst & Young on Monday and ordered it to pay $1.6 million to settle charges that it compromised its independence and contributed to faulty accounting by a client in 2001.

title: Ex-Qwest Official Says Nacchio Ignored Advice
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief executive of Qwest Communications, insisted on telling analysts the company could meet revenue targets that were later revised, an ex-finance chief testified on Monday.

title: Ex-Chief of Aspen Technology Pleads Guilty
description: The former chief executive of Aspen Technology, a maker of software for oil and chemical companies, pleaded guilty Monday to federal charges that he lied to investors. The former chief, David L. McQuillin, 49, said that as chief operating officer of the company in 2001 and 2002, he entered into a secret side agreement with the Yukos Oil Company to help Aspen meet its revenue target.

title: Former Financial Officer of Engineered Support Accused of Fraud
description: Federal prosecutors on Monday accused the former chief financial officer of the military contractor Engineered Support Systems of backdating stock options without disclosing his actions and then making a false statement to investigators.

title: Northwest Restructuring Makes Headway
description: Northwest Airlines can begin seeking creditor approval of a plan to exit bankruptcy that values the company at an estimated $7 billion, a judge ruled Monday. Judge Allan L. Gropper of Federal Bankruptcy Court said that when Northwest revises its disclosure statement to include agreements reached on Monday, the statement could be released to creditors along with a restructuring plan.

title: Big Medias Web Video Play May Help Start-Ups
description: The news that the News Corporation and NBC Universal are teaming up to start an online video distribution network that may well rival Googles YouTube is a tale of big-name media giants trying to outmaneuver one another as they struggle to win control of content distribution on the Internet.

title: Executive Coach With a Groovy Approach
description: In the growing field of executive coaching, Marshall Goldsmith is among the cream of the crop  and seems to be feeling very Zen about it. Mr. Goldsmith, who apparently has coached bigwigs at companies including Boeing, Motorola and Goldman Sachs, promotes a Buddhist-inspired path to enlightened leadership, according to a profile of the coach in The Chicago Tribune.

title: Burkle and Broad May Raise Tribune Bid, Report Says
description: The auction for Tribune may indeed be set for another round. With less than a week to go before Tribune is scheduled to conclude its six-month strategic review, the Los Angeles billionaires Ronald Burkle and Eli Broad are considering raising their bid for the media company, The Chicago Tribune reported.

title: Citigroup Overhaul to Test Chiefs Mettle
description: With his career and his companys prospects on the line, Citigroup chairman Charles O. Prince III is preparing the most sweeping restructuring of the financial giant since it was forged from a merger a decade ago.

title: Sanofi Executives Said to Clash on Bristol-Myers Bid
description: A deal between Sanofi-Aventis, Frances largest drug company, and Bristol-Myers Squibb of the United States could still be in the offing. The Times of London reports that if a battle of egos between Sanofis chairman and its younger chief executive is resolved, the French company may dust off its $54 billion merger plans with Bristol-Myers.

title: Goldman Sells Wind Energy Firm for $2.5 Billion
description: EDP-Energias de Portugal agreed to buy Horizon Wind Energy of Texas from Goldman Sachs for $2.15 billion in cash. Adding Horizon, which is based in Houston and has assets in 15 states, more than doubles EDPs worldwide wind-power production capacity and raises its ranking to fourth from sixth among the worlds largest producers of power from wind turbines.

title: Credit Suisse Put $13 Million in Its Chairmans Pocket
description: Credit Suisse Group said it paid its chairman, Walter Kielholz, 16 million Swiss francs ($13.2 million) last year, one-third more than a year earlier, after profit at the bank, the second-largest in Switzerland, rose to a record. Mr. Kielholz, who earned 12 million francs in 2005, received 9 million francs in cash and 7 million francs in share-based compensation, the bank said in its 2006 annual report, published Monday. Marcel Ospel, chairman of larger Swiss rival UBS AG, received 26.6 million francs.

title: Citigroup Trader Accused of Lying in Australian Suit
description: A Citigroup employee who traded Patrick Corporation stock on the banks account lied about his reasons for selling the shares, Australias federal court was told Monday. It is a misleading and dishonest answer you give today, Bret Walker, a lawyer for the Australian Securities & Investments Commission, told Andrew Manchee, a proprietary trader for Citigroup. I disagree, Mr. Manchee replied on the second day of a trial in Sydney.

title: HSBC Buys Swiss Life Ventures
description: HSBC Holdings will buy Swiss Life Holdings stake in two ventures for 228.8 million euros ($305 million), as it seeks to bolster profit from insurance in France. The bank, based in London, will buy the remaining 50.01 percent stake it does not already own in a French life insurer, Erisa, and the property and casualty insurer Erisa IARD, HSBC said Monday in a news release.

title: Barclays Diamond Feels Confident About ABN Amro deal
description: Robert E. Diamond Jr., head of investment banking at Barclays, seems to be feeling pretty good these days. Mr. Diamond said on Tuesday the British bank was in a strong position in its talks on an $80 billion take over of its Dutch rival, ABN Amro. His comments also come after Barclays revealed that Mr. Diamond out-earned his boss five-fold.

title: Carrefour Declines as Takeover Talk Wanes
description: Speculation that Carrefour, the French retailer, was headed for a takeover were dashed late Friday, setting off a sharp decline in the companys share price Monday. Takeover speculation ended when Bernard Arnault, a French investor, and Colony Capital, an American investment firm, said they would not acquire more than 20 percent of Carrefour until June 30, 2008, unless Carrefours largest shareholder, the Halley family, decided to sell its 13 percent stake or a new shareholder bought more than 5 percent of the company.

title: Buyout Rumors Stir Shares in British Retailer
description: Shares in Next, a British clothing retailer, reached an all-time high Tuesday after rumors of private equity interest in the company emerged. One market trader told The Times of London that shares in Next, which was up 78 pence at 23.06 pounds, had jumped on rumors of a leveraged buyout by the retailers management or an approach by private equity firms.

title: Hedge Funds Hit $1.89 Trillion, Report Says
description: The estimated net assets of the global hedge fund industry rose by 6 percent in the final quarter of 2006 and by 24 percent over the year as a whole to reach $1.89 trillion, according to Hedge Fund Asset Flows & Trends Report 2006-2007, released by Institutional Investor News and HedgeFund.net.

title: Many in Newark Unable to Afford Their Homes
Rollin, rollin, rollin
description: Aerial view of Bell Ranch

title: Blackstones $50 Million Workers
description: Are Blackstone Groups employees really worth an average of $50 million apiece? That value, based on reports that the private equity firm could be worth $40 billion in an initial public offering, could well be the highest bounty ever placed on the heads of office workers, Breakingviews writes.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on March 19 stated incorrectly that the House version of the 2007 Water Resources and Development bill would cost $40 billion. The anticipated cost is $14 billion to $15 billion.

title: Housing Struggles
description: In Newark and elsewhere, heavy mortgage debt has led many first-time homebuyers to the edge of financial ruin.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Sunday about global warming gave the wrong number of votes needed to override a presidential veto in the Senate. That requires two-thirds of senators present and voting, not 60 senators.

title: A Curious Case of Taking the Fifth
description: Monica Goodling, a Justice Department official who is counsel to the attorney general and liaison to the White House, is taking the Fifth rather than testify before the Senate Judiciary Committee about the firing of the Gonzales Eight. George Washington law professor Orin Kerr, writing at the group legal blog The Volokh Conspiracy, says he doesnt follow the rationale nor see a legally valid reason for Goodling to invoke her Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination. The Fifth Amendment privilege is available if the witness has reasonable ground to believe that her testimony will be used against her to prove an element of a crime, Kerr writes. He continues:

title: 36 Hours in Orlando
description: A weekend itinerary in the "other" Orlando, Fla., which offers a variety of cultural activities that have nothing to do with theme park attractions.

title: 2008: The War and Money
description: Senator John McCain cut short his campaign and fundraising events in Florida, returning to Capitol Hill because his vote may be needed by Republicans on the war spending bill. According to the Washington Post, Mr. McCain told a conservative radio station that he needed to beat back this recipe for defeat that the Democrats are foisting off on the American people.

title: A Generation of Economists Misguided?
description: Is there too much Freak- in the new economics? Writing in The New Republic, Noam Scheiber worries that economists have begun valuing ingenuity above usefulness. [$] He writes of his experiences interacting with graduate students in the Harvard economics department:

title: Documents: Con Ed and the Blackout
description: The fracas in the City Council yesterday over the handling of a new city report on the the Queens blackout obscured, to a degree, the main findings and recommendations of the report [pdf]:

title: Housing Hopes
description: Investors are confused by the various housing market indicators. First we heard that existing home sales were stronger than expected, and that that was good news. Then we heard that new home sales plunged, and that was bad news. Today we get the S.&P. Case-Shiller index for January, which looks bad.

title: $7 Million Homes
description: Tour a six-bedroom house in Greenwich, Conn., and waterfront estates on Lakes Michigan and Tahoe.

title: Vests for the Auxiliary Police
description: Shortly before noon, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is expected to announce that the city will begin providing bullet-resistant vests to its 4,800 auxiliary police officers. The news conference is scheduled to take place in the Greenwich Village police precinct where two volunteer auxiliary officers were fatally shot by a gunman on March 14.

title: Snows Cancer Returns
description: The White House is reporting this morning that doctors who performed surgery on Tony Snow, the administrations press secretary, found evidence that his cancer has resurfaced.

title: What I.P.O. Drought?
description: Startup companies and their investors may be worried about the dry market for initial public offerings, but happy hour has quietly returned for money-losing startups that are seeking public capital, The Street.coms Kevin Kelleher writes.

title: Election Day Again  on Staten Island
description: In a special election today on the north shore of the island, voters will choose the successor to the late Assemblyman John W. Lavelle, who was also the chairman of the boroughs Democratic organization. Mr. Lavelle, who was 57, died of a stroke in January.

title: A Predictable Final Four
description: If you picked the Final Four correctly, you should be proud of your accomplishment. But as Chief Bracket Correspondent Pete Thamel pointed out yesterday: With top-seeded Florida and Ohio State meeting second-seeded U.C.L.A. and Georgetown next weekend in Atlanta, this will be the first Final Four since 1993 with no team seeded lower than No. 2.

title: Flipping Back Through History
description: One of the definitive signs of March is when you walk into a press room and see copies of the official N.C.A.A. Final Four Records book spread out on tables.

title: Neglect and Scandal Reign in Congo
description: Six months after a historic election, the fledging government is struggling to put Congo back together.

title: The Multi-Touch Screen
description: Today, a few more notes from my visit two weeks ago to the TED conference

title: Mapping Silicon Valleys Political Lines
description: Which would-be president are Silicon Valleys moguls and tastemakers lining up to support? That is the question the ValleyWag blog set out to answer, drawing up a list based on press clippings, attendance lists at fundraisers, and our own guesses. Illinois senator Barack Obama and New York senator Hillary Clinton each get several names in their columns.

title: Didnt Improve His Opinion of Kelly
description: In this video interview with The Politicker, City Councilman Charles Barron, one of three council members mentioned in secret New York police intelligence reports, promises an investigation: This is absurd. They talk about some democracy? This is a hypocrisy.

title: As Amaranth Investors Wait, Ex-Trader Serves Solengo
description: As former Amaranth Advisors energy trader Brian Hunter prepares to launch his new hedge-fund firm  it is reportedly called Solengo Capital Advisors  investors in his old firm, Amaranth, are still waiting to get whats left of their money back. Financial News reports that a group of investors in Amaranth, which collapsed after its bets on the energy market went bad, have offered to drop their legal claims against the firm in hopes of collecting their remaining capital more quickly.

title: TA Associates Invests in Fund of Hedge Funds
description: Private equity firm TA Associates said Tuesday it acquired a minority stake in K2 Advisors, which runs a fund of hedge funds. Financial terms were not disclosed, but K2 said that $100 million of the deal proceeds would go toward its existing fund strategies and to seed new ones. TA Associates, which invests in financial services companies, recently participated in a management buyout of Jupiter, Commerzbanks asset-management arm in the United Kingdom. K2 said it oversees about $5.5 billion from institutions and private investors.

title: Best Buy Snaps up Broadband Provider
description: The consumer-electronics retailer Best Buy said Tuesday it would acquire Speakeasy, an Internet service provider that serves small businesses, for $97 million. The Seattle Times describes how Speakeasy began life as an Internet caf in 1994 (which was quite early for Internet cafs) and grew into a national broadband provider. It stayed independent even as small Internet providers were being gobbled up by larger ones and by big telecom companies.

title: Position Battles Late in Camp
description: Were sweating it out here in muggy Fort Myers as the Yankees take on the Twins. Carl Pavano, the probable opening day starter, just gave up his fourth single in a row and its tied, 2-2.

title: Times Reader Beta Has Ended
description: On March 27, 2007, Times Reader launched as a subscription service for $14.95 a month or $165 a year. Access to TimesSelect and Premium Crosswords are included in the price. If you are currently a TimesSelect or Premium Crossword subscriber you will receive a pro rated refund on those products when you purchase Times Reader.

title: Ultimate Fightings Big Matchup
description: A relatively small deal announced Tuesday packs a wallop in the world of mixed martial arts, an increasingly popular but sometimes controversial sport.

title: Onward. Upward?
description: Alexander B. Grannis, the Assemblyman who Gov. Eliot Spitzer has nominated to head the Department of Environmental Conservatiom, has cleared his first hurdle. The Senate Environmental Committee voted to approve his nomination after todays round of questioning, which included not only some senators who had spoken before, but a couple of Assembly members who were along for the ride, too.

title: Webb Defends Gun-Toting Posse
description: Facing a crush of reporters today just outside the Senate chamber, Senator James Webb declined to comment on specifics of the case in which a close aide was arrested Monday trying to carry a loaded handgun into a Senate office building.

title: Document: Get In, and Stay In
description: Heres a little something interesting, apropos of todays special elections.

title: The Feasts of Mike Bloomberg
description: A Daily News reporter asked Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to comment today on neighbors complaints about the Feast of San Gennaro. The mayors response:

title: Taxi Talk: Bloomberg Weighs In
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg weighed in today on the debate over placing more yellow taxi stands outside Manhattan:

title: The Yankees on YouTube
description: You wont be seeing much of Chien-Ming Wang in the first couple of weeks of the season, but heres a clip of his commerical for Taiwan.

title: A Colloquy on the Sean Bell Case
description: At a news conference today announcing the purchase of bullet-resistant vests for auxiliary police officers, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly were asked about a report that was the wood of The Daily News this morning, in which a man claimed he had been shot by Sean Bell, who was killed in the November police shooting in Queens. Following are their answers, as transcribed by The Times.[Reporter asks if the commissioner saw the article.]

title: Two Words You Never Thought Youd Hear
description: This is what Carl Pavano said after completing six strong innings today against the Minnesota Twins: Im ready.

title: War at Home: All Eyes on Hagel
description: The Senate is preparing for a critical vote  slated for 5 p.m.  on Iraq legislation.

title: A Few Words, but Not the Final Ones
description: The other day a reader, responding to my recent post about Balthazar, submitted the following comments, and I saved them until now because they raised some topics and asked some questions that I wanted to address.

title: All Eyes on the Coach
description: Billy Donovan, from any standard measure or perception, is a man at the top of his profession. In four days, he will attempt to become the first coach in 15 years to lead his team to consecutive national championships. He has revolutionized the grimy game of recruiting, adjusting to a world where your best players have little desire to hang around too long. He has followed in the footsteps of his mentor Rick Pitino in that the man knows how to wear a suit. (Ive always considered Pitino and Donovan modern-day college basketball Gordon Gekkos; winning, for lack of a better word, is  good.) Most impressive, he has retained his dignity and respect despite being a grown man with the name Billy.

title: Comment Zone: Separate Medallions?
description: A Zone reader, Matt, is getting a lot of positive feedback for his proposal to solve the yellow cab shortage in Queens, Brooklyn, and the Bronx:

title: Senate Democrats Prevail in Iraq Vote
description: Senate Democrats considering an Iraq spending bill mustered enough votes late this afternoon  (barely) at 50-48  to defeat a Republican amendment that would have stripped out language setting a timetable for withdrawal of troops from Iraq.

title: Marist Poll: Spitzer Under Fire
description: Todays WNBC/Marist Poll provides more grist for those of us wondering how the millions of dollars worth of anti-Eliot-Spitzer ads over the last few weeks have affected his popularity.

title: Gauging Obamas YouTube Numbers
description: Back in the old days (2004), political observers gauged a candidates relative popularity based on his polling numbers, his cash totals and his endorsements.

title: The Lastings Decision
description: Playing off Tylers post, there arent many roster decisions to be made (officially), but Lastings Milledges hand injury may wind up putting a crimp in the Mets plans. Milledge reinvented himself over the winter, showing up to camp six weeks ago with an improved attitude and, he said, 13 pounds of muscle. Until Matt Alberss fastball drilled him on the right hand Sunday, Milledge was batting .352 and his 28 total bases ranked second behind Jose Reyes.

title: Blogtalk: Hawaiian Shirt Day, Ruined
description: The State Ethics Commission staff is too busy to join the Temporary State Commission on Lobbying for pizza on its monthly Hawaiian Shirt/Dressdown day. Also: Bad day for the budget talks. [Capitol Confidential]

title: Blogtalk: Guns and Senators
description: While waiting for the Senate to vote on an Iraq spending bill that includes a timetable for withdrawing troops, blogs passed the time with tales of senators and handguns.

title: Can Market Forces Clean Up Dirty Water?
description: Ever since the Stern Report was released in the U.K. in December, it seems like politicians and green groups are thinking about how market forces can be harnessed to clean up the planet. Last week the World Conservation Union (ICUN), based in Gland, Switzerland, suggested that carefully developed water markets or water payment schemes can help prevent further degradation of the worlds precious clean water sources.

title: Shooting Victim Denies Blaming Bell
description: A Queens man hasdenied reports that he told the police that Sean Bell shot him in a drug-related dispute last year.The tale of the shooting appeared on the front page of The Daily News and was later repeated by Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly at a news conference. He said the information had been passed along to the Queens district attorney, who is prosecuting three officers in the fatal shooting of Mr. Bell.

title: Going Nova
description: Hypernova, a young hip Iranian rock band, performs for the first time in New York City.

title: Albany Nears a Budget Deal
description: In a major step toward passing a state budget by the April 1 deadline, Gov. Eliot Spitzer and state legislative leaders agreed Tuesday night to add at least $850 million to his proposed budget and appeared to have resolved the main issues that divided them, Danny Hakim and Nicholas Confessore report this evening. The tentative deal involved several key concessions by the governor to Senate Republicans. Mr. Spitzer agreed to restore $350 million of the $1.3 billion worth of health care cuts he had proposed. He also said he would add $500 million in new education aid. He also agreed to distribute property tax rebate checks.

title: Staten Island: Titone and Tobacco Prevail
description: Staten Islanders have elected the boroughs first openly gay elected official by selecting Matthew Titone to an Assembly seat on the islands North Shore, according to unofficial returns from todays special election.

title: Burger King Shifts Policy on Animals
description: In what animal welfare advocates are describing as a historic advance, Burger King has announced that it will begin buying eggs and pork from suppliers that do not confine their animals in cages and crates.

title: Oh Brass on the Grass Alas
description: This article was written with Susan Levenstein.

title: Oh Brass on the Grass Alas
description: This article was written with Susan Levenstein.

title: Midshipmen Accused of Misconduct on Cruise
description: The United States Naval Academy said yesterday that it was investigating accusations of lewd behavior and excessive drinking by midshipmen on a Caribbean cruise this month.

title: Rangers Winning Ways End Abruptly in Second Period
description: MONTREAL, March 27  The Rangers had a sneaking suspicion they would hit a bump or two in the last couple of weeks of the season. As hard as they have worked to climb into sixth place in the Eastern Conference, as many games as they have pulled out by the slimmest of margins, they could not expect perfection.

title: Tajik President Outlaws Slavic Endings on Names
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, March 27  Amid a series of idiosyncratic decrees aimed at removing traces of Soviet influence, the president of Tajikistan announced Tuesday that he had dropped the Slavic ov from the end of his surname and that, henceforth, the same must be done for all babies born to Tajik parents.

title: Orin Atkins, 82, Executive Who Built Up Ashland Oil, Dies
description: Orin E. Atkins, who helped transform Ashland Oil from a regional oil refiner into a multinational energy conglomerate but whose 16-year tenure as chief executive was marred by improper business dealings, died on Friday in Dallas. He was 82.

title: Typical French Town Is Split Over Election
description: AUXERRE, France  With its timbered houses, twisted streets and Gothic cathedral, this picture-perfect town in Burgundy looks much as it did 500 years ago.

title: Problems Still Hampering Veterans Care, Senators Say
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  The Department of Veterans Affairs and the Department of Defense continue to have problems collecting and sharing medical data, hampering treatment for wounded soldiers, lawmakers said Tuesday at a Congressional hearing.

title: White House Spokesmans Cancer Recurs
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  Tony Snow, the press secretary to President Bush, has suffered a recurrence of the colon cancer he battled two years ago, and the disease has spread, reaching the liver, White House officials said Tuesday.

title: West Virginia Ends Rally With Exclamation Points
description: West Virginia was denied one of college basketballs most coveted honors  a berth in the N.C.A.A. tournament  but it does not want to let the consolation prize slip away.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,233 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans yesterday:

title: The Entourage Is Gone. The Jet Is Gone. But for the Ex-Speaker, the Work Goes On.
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  Former Speaker J. Dennis Hastert usually trundles through the Capitols hallways alone these days, his head down, chin buried in his chest, without the coterie of aides who trailed him just a few months ago when he was second in line to the presidency.

title: Recipe: Sauted Chicken Livers With Mushrooms and Sage
description: Adapted from Quatorze Bis

title: The Prosecutors, and the Big Picture (4 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Personal Conduct a Topic That Wont Go Away
description: PHOENIX, March 27  Tennessee Coach Jeff Fisher rubbed his weary eyes when he was asked about Adam Jones, better known by his nickname, Pacman.

title: Stolen Artworks and the Lawyers Who Reclaim Them
description: BARELY a week seems to go by without news of another case involving the restitution of looted antiquities or of art appropriated during the Nazi era. In part this is because of a climate newly sensitive to such claims. But these cases also owe a debt to the lawyers who helped pioneer cultural property law.

title: The Big Show Is Coming, Now Brace for the Throngs
description: Philadelphia

title: Episcopalians in Colorado Plan to Leave Denomination
description: One of the largest Episcopal parishes in Colorado has decided to leave the Episcopal Church, prompting the diocesan bishop to dissolve the leadership of the congregation and heightening tensions between theological traditionalists and liberals in the denomination.

title: Giants Off-Season Has Been Work With No Progress
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 27  If the Giants are going to be better next season than they were last year, they have shown few signs of improvement.

title: Mayor Defends Spying by Police Before G.O.P. Convention
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg yesterday defended police spying on potential protesters in advance of the 2004 Republican National Convention, saying that it was necessary for security during an uneasy time.

title: Mets Need Heilman in Bullpen More Than Ever
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 27  Aaron Heilman jogs out of the bullpen to London Calling by the Clash. It is an urgent song for a low-key reliever, and one that fans at Shea Stadium can expect to hear even more than the 74 times they did last season.

title: Woman in Cardiac Arrest Is Rescued From West Side Fire
description: By the time Lt. Ken Voisin smashed through a locked window security gate and made his way inside Apartment 3C of an Upper West Side building yesterday, he could see nothing through the thick smoke. Only keen instincts and modern technology  a thermal-imaging camera  saved the two people huddled inside, one of them already in cardiac arrest.

title: Thai Coup Leader Calls for Emergency Powers
description: BANGKOK, Thailand, March 28  The general who led a coup last September asked his appointed prime minister today to impose a state of emergency in Bangkok as public opposition to the government grew.

title: For the Record
description: A sports article in some copies on March 19, about Lincoln High Schools victory against Boys and Girls High to win the Public Schools Athletic Leagues AA division city boys basketball championship, referred incorrectly to an accomplishment by Coach Ruth Lovelace of Boys and Girls High. With that game, she became the first woman to coach a boys team in the P.S.A.L.s highest division championship game at Madison Square Garden  not the first woman to coach a boys team in any championship game. (Noreen Begley was the first in 1992 when she coached the Murry Bergtraum boys to the finals in what was known as the B division.)

title: Recipe: Scallops With Seaweed Butter
description: Adapted from LAtelier de Jol Robuchon

title: A Contract Buyout Closes the Ruland Era at Iona
description: Iona College yesterday officially bought out the last two years of Coach Jeff Rulands contract.

title: How Many Scientists?
description: Sometimes you read something about this administration that is just so shameful it takes your breath away. For me, that was the March 20 article in this paper detailing how a House committee had just released documents showing hundreds of instances in which a White House official who was previously an oil industry lobbyist edited government climate reports to play up uncertainty of a human role in global warming or play down evidence of such a role.

title: A Section of an East Harlem Building Under Renovation Collapses
description: A large portion of a five-story apartment building under renovation in East Harlem collapsed in a dusty roar yesterday, disrupting subway and Metro-North service in Upper Manhattan and forcing the evacuation of nearby buildings.

title: Charges of Vote Rigging as Egypt Approves Constitution Changes
description: CAIRO, March 27  Egyptian officials said Tuesday that the public overwhelmingly approved changes to the Constitution in a vote on Monday, while opposition groups and human rights organizations dismissed the results as the product of widespread vote rigging.

title: Police Chief of a Fire Island Village Is Accused of Assaulting a Tourist
description: RIVERHEAD, N.Y., March 27  Ocean Beach has a well-earned reputation for strict policing  whether directed against people eating ice cream cones in the wrong place or boisterous patrons in the bars that encircle its business district.

title: Plea Deal May Spare Man Jail Time in Wifes Suicide
description: The husband of a woman who drove her minivan off a cliff at Bear Mountain State Park last year, killing herself and injuring the couples two children, pleaded guilty today to endangering the welfare of a child in a deal with prosecutors that could spare the man jail time.

title: The (Art) World According to Edward Goldman
description: Los Angeles

title: A Wealth of Programs to Pique Visitors Interest
description: VISITORS to a museum learn by looking, reading and, perhaps, tuning into an audio program. What they put into a visit is what they get out of it.

title: Live, From Station KFYI in ...Well, Thats Complicated
description: LOS ANGELES, March 27  When people hear the radio host Joe Crummey on Phoenixs popular KFYI murmur sarcastically, We dont have enough human rights activists in this town, they know he means Phoenix.

title: ITT Guilty of Revealing Classified Military Data
description: The ITT Corporation, a major manufacturer of night-vision goggles used by the American military, pleaded guilty yesterday to illegally sending classified military information to other nations, including China, and agreed to pay a $100 million penalty.

title: Seeking a Lift From the Contemporary
description: MAXWELL L. ANDERSON, the new director of the Indianapolis Museum of Art, had been in the city only seven months, but his sports loyalty had taken root.

title: Recipe: Spinach Pancakes
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Russia: Putin Chum Picked as Elections Chief
description: The central election committee, dominated by supporters of President Vladimir V. Putin, elected as its chairman a former colleague of Mr. Putins from St. Petersburg, Vladimir V. Churov. Mr. Churov, a member of the lower house of Parliament since 2003, worked with Mr. Putin in the St. Petersburg governors office in the 1990s. He replaces Aleksandr A. Veshnyakov, whom Mr. Putin ousted this month after he criticized new election laws. Russia is approaching elections for Parliament and president.

title: IPods and Cellphones Join the Audio Tour
description: IN science fiction, museums of the future are often pristine repositories of the art and artifacts of times past. Chatty robots and humanoid holograms help visitors navigate the collections.

title: Satellite TV Creates Sports Bar in the Sky
description: Dave Adams of Brooklyn had his eyes glued to the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament game between Ohio State and Memphis on Saturday. He threw a celebratory fist in the air as Ohio State center Greg Oden, his favorite player on the court, made his way to the basket. A cold beer sat to Adamss side, and he held a bag of chips in one hand.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a new strategic proposal by Borders Group, one of the nations largest book retailers, misstated the companys plans for its international segment. It is exploring various alternatives that could eventually lead to the sale or franchising of the majority of its 73 superstores abroad, including those in Britain, Ireland, Australia and New Zealand; it is not closing the stores. (Go to Article)

title: Closing Up for the Summer
description: When homeowners close up a beach house after Labor Day, they have a checklist of things to do to prepare the home for the harshness of winter. Similarly, second-home owners with winter retreats  from ski cabins that dont get much use after the slopes shutter, to desert houses that are silent well before triple-digit-temperature time  must do everything necessary to prepare for the elements of summer.

title: Master of the Science of Packing and Crating
description: Los Angeles

title: Murder, I Read
description: Youre at the mystery section of an airport bookstore and the loudspeaker has just announced that your flight is in the late stages of boarding. You have maybe three or four minutes to make a choice. (That is your assignment, if you choose to accept it.) How do you go about deciding?

title: 2 Cities and 4 Bridges Where Commerce Flows
description: JUREZ, Mexico  Much like Oakland and San Francisco, El Paso and Jurez are neighboring cities that coexist in a larger regional economy. Jurez and El Paso, however, are separated by more than a body of water, the Rio Grande; they are also divided by the United States-Mexico border. And that border, connected by four bridges, has become one of the busiest crossings in the world.

title: Burger King Shifts Policy on Animals
description: In what animal welfare advocates are describing as a historic advance, Burger King, the worlds second-largest hamburger chain, said yesterday that it would begin buying eggs and pork from suppliers that did not confine their animals in cages and crates.

title: F.C.C. Approves $12 Billion Sale of Univision Communications
description: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the $12.3 billion buyout of Univision Communications after the company agreed to pay a record $24 million fine and improve the quality of its childrens programming.

title: Blair Pushes Iran for Release of Captives
description: LONDON, March 27  Tensions escalated between Iran and the West on Tuesday over 15 Britons held by the Iranians, with Prime Minister Tony Blair warning that Britains campaign to free them would move into a different phase if they were not released.

title: On U.S. Team, Players Come and Go but Bradley Remains
description: As the United States mens national soccer team prepares for tonights friendly match against Guatemala, it is fair to ask, What about Bob?

title: Family Criticizes Query Into Tillmans Death
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 27  The family of Cpl. Pat Tillman has issued a scathing retort to a Pentagon investigation of their sons death, calling the report shamefully unacceptable and asking for Congressional intervention.

title: Grand Plans and Huge Spending
description: THE cultural building boom shows few signs of slowing. Nationwide, art institutions are renovating, adding wings or starting from the ground up. Projects include relatively modest undertakings like the Cooper-Hewitt National Design Museums $25 million plan to increase its gallery space by moving the museums library and administrative offices out of the building, and ambitious ones like the new $208 million home for the Miami Art Museum on Biscayne Bay, designed by the Swiss architects Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron.

title: Lebanon: U.N. Gives Hariri Inquiry Another Year
description: The Security Council extended its investigation into the 2005 assassination of former Prime Minister Rafik Hariri for another year, until June 2008.

title: Marketers, Gingerly, Bite at Parody Bait
description: AT a recent photo shoot in the garment district, Joshua Neuman was dressed all in white, except for a black bowler hat and black combat boots. He wore fake eyelashes on his right eyelid, and held a cane in one hand, a glass of milk in the other.

title: Sweeps in Iraq Cram Two Jails With Detainees
description: BAGHDAD, Wednesday, March 28  Hundreds of Iraqis detained in the Baghdad security crackdown have been crammed into two detention centers run by the Defense Ministry that were designed to hold only dozens of people, a government monitoring group said Tuesday.

title: Boston Got What It Wanted, or So It Seems
description: Maybe the move will wind up serving as the catalyst that vaults the Boston Red Sox to their first American League East title since 1995, but when they began their pursuit of Daisuke Matsuzaka last fall, one of their main motivations was to keep him from the Yankees.

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Monday, with an article about the shift by consumers to digital music from CDs, misstated the name of the band that had signed a deal to record two songs rather than a full album. It is Candy Hill, not Cherry Hill.

title: Thomas Quick With Calming Words as a Rift Starts to Show
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 27  Isiah Thomas has taken a gentler approach to his point guards this season, a stark contrast from Larry Browns caustic public comments last year.

title: English or Spanish, Two Voices on Labels
description: FROM a distance, it looks like a red zipper running along the front of the museum. Closer, you can see that its classic Jenny Holzer  truisms and other sayings from the artist shooting up an L.E.D. display on the facade of a new building at the Museum of Contemporary Art in San Diego. You can catch familiar gems like abuse of power comes as no surprise and ambivalence can ruin your life.

title: Recipe: Italian-Style Vegetable Pancakes
description: Time: At least 30 minutes

title: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Monday about the decline of newspaper advertising revenues in February misstated the period in which print revenue declined 3.7 percent, to $13.2 billion. It was for the fourth quarter of 2006 compared with the same period in 2005  not for the full year.

title: For the Record
