description: Because of an editing error, the byline on an essay in Science Times yesterday about hormonal treatment for prostate cancer referred incorrectly to the writer, Richard Wassersug. He is not an M.D.

title: British Architect Wins 2007 Pritzker Prize
description: Three decades after his Pompidou Center in Paris turned the architecture world upside down and brought him global fame, the British architect Richard Rogers has been named the 2007 winner of the Pritzker Prize, the professions highest honor.

title: On the Road to Self-Discovery, Korean Jail Was a Pothole
description: As a child on suburban Long Island, Cullen Thomas devoured Tintin comic books and the tales of Richard Francis Burton, the Victorian explorer. He thirsted for high adventure in foreign parts. At age 23, he got it: a sentence of three and a half years in South Korean prisons for mailing himself a kilogram of hashish.

title: Food Calendar
description: The Burgundies of 2004

title: Coffins, Hearses and Other End-Time Curios
description: Springfield, Ill.

title: Wal-Mart Chief Writes Off New York
description: Wal-Mart to New York: fuhgeddaboudit.

title: Quiet, Please? Not for This Art
description: Detroit

title: Senator Calls Gun Incident Inadvertent
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  Senator Jim Webb, facing a barrage of questions about the arrest of an aide who tried to take a loaded handgun into a Senate office building, said on Tuesday that the move was inadvertent.

title: Brooklyn: Police Lieutenants Trial Begins
description: Prosecutors opened their case in State Supreme Court yesterday against an off-duty police lieutenant accused of killing a tenant during a fight over the rent in May 2005. The lieutenant, Shamik Walton, a 19-year veteran of the Police Department, has been charged with second-degree manslaughter for the shooting of Byron Hearst, 27, a construction worker. Lieutenant Walton is free on $30,000 bail and has been working on modified duty. Kenneth M. Taub, the prosecutor, said Lieutenant Walton and Mr. Hearst had argued and shoved each other in a minor confrontation before the lieutenant shot Mr. Hearst three times. A defense lawyer, Anthony L. Ricco, portrayed Mr. Hearst as the aggressor, saying, Shamik Walton was forced to use his service revolver on that day.

title: Baseball Balks at InDemand Proposal
description: Major League Baseball refused yesterday to commit to a deal proposed by InDemand that cable operators carry the Extra Innings package of games at the same financial terms as DirecTV.

title: Recipe: Shrimp in Brik Dough With Basil Pesto
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: Where to See the Yarns the New Filmmakers Are Spinning
description: The 36th New Directors/New Films series runs through Sunday at the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, and at the Walter Reade Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center. Ticket information: filmlinc.com or (212) 496-3809. The schedule through Sunday:

title: Manhattan: M.T.A. Wont Pay Boards Insurance
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would stop paying for health insurance for members of its board. The agency made the move in response to a legal opinion by Attorney General Andrew M. Cuomo that determined the practice was improper. The authority said that 4 of its 21 board members were receiving benefits through the New York State Health Insurance Plan. The combined insurance payments for the four would have cost the authority about $40,000 this year, said Jeremy Soffin, a spokesman for the authority. The four board members had been paying what would normally be considered employees shares of the premiums, Mr. Soffin said.

title: A Neighborhood Is a Gallery, Its Brick Walls Canvases
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Who Killed Fido? We All Did
description: Madison, Wis.

title: Pancakes of the World, Dressed for Dinner
description: THERE is a world of pancakes beyond breakfast. Some are familiar to experienced cooks: potato pancakes and their Swiss cousins, rsti; corncakes and their South American relatives, arepas; and the earthy buckwheat crepes of Brittany. Others are a little more advanced, like the ones we cook here.

title: Teenager Casts Light on a Shadowy Game
description: GERONIMO, Tex.  Levi Draher, 16, walked to the front of the Navarro High School gym in early March and picked up the microphone before a hushed audience of fellow teenagers.

title: Youngsters Defiance Is a Lesson in Acceptance
description: A soccer team of Canadian girls recently applied sandbox mores when they decided that the report-card virtue of plays well with others was meant to include everyone  including those in Muslim headscarves.

title: On College Campuses, a Crop of Galleries
description: THESE days its hard to find a public museum that does not have a major expansion or building project under way. This trend has even infiltrated colleges and universities.

title: Indonesia to Send Bird Flu Samples, With Restrictions
description: Indonesia said yesterday that it would resume sending samples of avian flu virus to the World Health Organization for research purposes, on the understanding that they would not be shared with commercial vaccine makers.

title: On the Bowery, a New Home for New Art
description: NAMING rights for a museums grand spaces are part of the deal for valued donors these days. But when the New Museum of Contemporary Art began its capital campaign for a $50 million building on the Lower East Side of Manhattan, the bathrooms were the first places to be christened.

title: Gift Horses? Bring Them On
description: IN years past, art museum directors could be pretty sure that when a patron called to discuss an in kind gift, it was to talk about donating a work of art.

title: Australian Detainees Life of Wandering Ends With Plea Deal
description: LONDON, March 27  David Hickss journey through the post-Sept. 11 military legal labyrinth has sometimes seemed as uncertain and tortuous as his lifes journey, from high school dropout and kangaroo skinner to a young man in search of a war and a cause.

title: Iranian Rock Band Has a New York Moment
description: Performing Monday night at Fat Baby bar on the Lower East Side, the four members of Hypernova almost made it through their set before distinguishing themselves from the many other hip and hungry young talents who come to New York seeking musical recognition.

title: One Picture, 1,000 Tags
description: WHAT do you see when you see a work of art?

title: Manhattan: Council Budget Reform
description: The City Council will begin reviewing money it allocates annually through programs known as Council initiatives, the speaker, Christine C. Quinn, said yesterday. There are 168 initiatives this fiscal year that award money to 900 community organizations. About 300 of those groups, which are set to receive $32.5 million, will be required to begin submitting quarterly performance reports with the Council this year. Another 300 groups will be required to do so in 2008, and the final 300 in 2009. Ms. Quinn said the new requirement would make the citys $55 billion budget more transparent.

title: Those Arias, That Tragedy, in Xhosa
description: No one can know whether Bizet, whose Gypsy opera, Carmen, is set in Spain and sung in French, would have approved of the movie musical U-Carmen e-Khayelitsha. But you suspect that he would have admired the filmmakers gall.

title: Still Trying to House Katrinas Victims
description: The Bush administrations mishandling of the Hurricane Katrina housing crisis has often looked like an attempt to discourage survivors from applying for help. The House has taken an important step toward reversing this policy with a bill that would require the Department of Housing and Urban Development to issue tens of thousands of new housing vouchers under the Section 8 program, which allows low-income families to seek homes in the private real estate market.

title: Lender Said to Be Weighing a Bankruptcy Filing Soon
description: New Century Financial, the troubled subprime mortgage company, could file for bankruptcy protection as early as the end of this week, people briefed on the companys plans said yesterday.

title: Confronting Fears With Grace and Pratfalls
description: Wearing a suit of armor and pointy red shoes, Sol Pic took tentative steps along a strip of light. Holding a small, worn shopping bag labeled snack pack, she approached the audience, did a quick head count and came to the uneasy realization that she probably didnt have enough to go around.

title: Recipe: King Crab Salad
description: Time: 10 minutes

title: A Troves Long Road to the Smithsonian
description: THE Smithsonian Institution likes to call itself the nations museum, but it was never a must for lovers of African art until now.

title: James Taking the Game Into His Hands
description: LeBron James raced home from a Cavaliers practice last weekend to complete two urgent tasks.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 27, 2007

title: When the Police Spied on Protesters (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: ...Offers a Festival of New Surprises
description: One of the chief pleasures of New Directors/New Films  perhaps the main reason to return to this well-respected, sometimes uneven program  is surprise. A mini-festival presented by the Museum of Modern Art and the Film Society of Lincoln Center, New Directors promises a yearly respite from the same old stuff, and perhaps also from the predictable forms of novelty for its own sake.

title: The Smithsonian Challenge
description: From the very beginning of his stewardship of the Smithsonian Institution, Lawrence Small proved that he was inept at the delicate art of raising private money for a public institution. Mr. Small, who resigned last weekend, was hired to operate the Smithsonian in a businesslike manner, in keeping with his nonscientific background as an executive at Citibank and Fannie Mae. He goes out under the cloud of an internal audit that showed he was paid for inappropriate and excessive expenses. His own apparent misbehavior has led the Senate to freeze a badly needed increase in financing.

title: Whats on Wednesday Night
description: 8 P.M. (22), (26) THE STATE OF THE OCEANS ANIMALS Case studies from every corner of the globe illustrate the effects of global warming and illegal fishing on sea animals in this episode of Journey to Planet Earth. Matt Damon is host and narrator.

title: Regulator Favors Standards Against Predatory Lending
description: WASHINGTON, March 27 (Bloomberg News)  The chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, Sheila C. Bair, said Tuesday that Congress should set standards to protect borrowers against predatory lenders, becoming the first top regulator to urge a legislative solution for the subprime problem.

title: Bush Vows Not to Negotiate on Iraq Timetable
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  A defiant President Bush vowed today not to negotiate with Congress about setting a date for withdrawing American troops from Iraq, and he said the American people would blame lawmakers if there is any delay in approving money for the war effort.

title: Maryland: Expressing Regret for Slavery
description: The State House of Delegates passed a resolution on Monday expressing profound regret for the role the state played in slavery. The resolution, passed earlier by the State Senate, had failed to pass the legislature last year. It mirrors similar legislation under consideration this year in Missouri. On Feb. 28, the Virginia General Assembly passed a resolution expressing profound regret for the role slavery played in that state. Slavery in Maryland dates to the states founding as a colony in 1634. It was officially ended in 1864 under a new state Constitution.

title: Backdating Case Is Settled
description: The former general counsel at Monster Worldwide Inc., Myron F. Olesnyckyj, was permanently banned yesterday from working as a director or officer of a public company, settling a Securities and Exchange Commission lawsuit for backdating stock options.

title: Immortality, or a Museum of Ones Own
description: IN a new French film, Avenue Montaigne, an aging mogul explains to his son that he is going to auction his entire art collection so that people will see how brilliant he was in accumulating it.

title: Javits Center Gives Baseball a Price Break for FanFest
description: The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center board broke with a longstanding policy last week when it voted to effectively give Major League Baseball a subsidy. The convention center on the Far West Side of Manhattan will provide a $200,000 discount on the rent at its exhibition hall during baseballs FanFest next year, which will be a prelude to the 2008 All-Star Game at Yankee Stadium.

title: Senate Supports a Pullout Date in Iraq War Bill
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  The Senate went on record for the first time on Tuesday in favor of a withdrawal date from Iraq, with Democrats marshaling the votes they needed to deliver a forceful rebuke to President Bushs war policy.

title: Bounty From New Film Directors ...
description: Perhaps they were just saving the best for last. This Saturday and Sunday, the programmers for New Directors/New Films are presenting a selection worthy of the festivals storied history and the too-often-unmet promise inherent in its name: Reprise, one of the most passionately and intellectually uninhibited works from a young director Ive seen in ages. Directed by Joachim Trier, who wrote the tender, funny, narratively ambitious screenplay with his fellow Norwegian Eskil Vogt, this galvanizing first feature traces the parallel adventures of two best friends whose twinned literary aspirations and everyday lives take the shape of a punk-rock bildungsroman.

title: In Wake of Two Deaths, Auxiliary Police Will Get Safety Vests
description: New York City will supply bullet-resistant vests to all of its 4,500 auxiliary police officers, city officials announced yesterday, less than two weeks after two of the officers  who are unarmed volunteers  were gunned down in Greenwich Village.

title: Albany: New Trial Ordered in Fatal Stabbing
description: The states highest court ordered a new trial yesterday for a man convicted of fatally stabbing a livery-cab driver in 1991, saying that an expert on eyewitness identifications should have been allowed to testify on the defendants behalf. Nico LeGrand was convicted in 2001 of murdering the driver, Joaquin Liriano, on Morningside Drive in Manhattan after several eyewitnesses testified against him. Mr. LeGrands defense team wanted to present an expert about the reliability of eyewitness testimony, but the trial judge did not allow it. Yesterday, the State Court of Appeals ruled 7 to 0 that the expert should have been allowed to testify because conventional wisdom as to the fallibility of eyewitnesses had changed considerably over the years.

title: Paul C. Lauterbur, 77, Dies; Won Nobel Prize for M.R.I.
description: Paul C. Lauterbur, who shared the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 2003 for developing magnetic resonance imaging into a way to look inside living organisms, died yesterday at his home in Urbana, Ill. He was 77.

title: Shoulder-to-Shoulder Swooning
description: WE humans take our art very seriously. How else to explain the throngs who will brave the foulest weather just to stand three or more deep to glimpse the latest blockbuster exhibition?

title: A Director Weighs in With a Curatorial Touch
description: LOS ANGELES

title: Auto Union Head Vows Hard Line Against Concessions
description: DETROIT, March 27  The head of the United Automobile Workers union, who has been criticized by some members for not taking a firm enough stance against wage and benefit cuts, made clear Tuesday that workers are done making sacrifices.

title: New Works From China Command Attention
description: ENTERING the Metropolitan Museum of Arts renowned Chinese painting galleries, visitors expecting black-and-white brush paintings and subdued classical scrolls may be shocked to encounter an enormous color photograph of a Chinese farmer riding a bicycle straight at them.

title: For the Record
description: A picture credit in Weekend on Friday with the Books of The Times review, about How Doctors Think, by Jerome Groopman, misspelled the photographers surname. The picture of Dr. Groopman was by David Carmack, not Carmac.

title: Do Student Beliefs Have a Place in the Classroom? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: For Investors, a Less Insular Island
description: The Long Island commercial real estate market was once surprisingly insular, dominated by local players. But new faces are now on the scene, as investors coming from outside the area are increasingly buying up Long Island office buildings. Often, these new faces are institutional investors flush with capital.

title: Staten Island Elects Its First Openly Gay Public Official
description: In a special election yesterday, Staten Islanders elected the boroughs first openly gay official by selecting Matthew Titone to a State Assembly seat on the islands north shore.

title: An Actress Who Wears Her Uterus on Her Sleeve
description: Jackie Hoffman just wants to be Jackie Hoffman.

title: A Challenge for Curators: An Iguana in the House
description: THE American Museum of Natural History has one of the most extensive collections in the world. Yet for all its stuffed grizzlies and elephants, its 94-foot faux whale and its towering T. rexes, the museum has learned what other natural history and science museums around the country know: if you really want to wow your visitors, get the real living thing.

title: Study Re-evaluates Evolution of Mammals
description: The mass extinction that wiped out dinosaurs and other life 65 million years ago apparently did not, contrary to conventional wisdom, immediately clear the way for the rise of todays mammals.

title: Leaving Room for the Troublemakers
description: LAST May, a 30-something American curator named Chris Gilbert stormed off his job at the Berkeley Art Museum in California. He left in a dispute over a word.

title: Headaches Leave DiPietros Status Uncertain
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 27  When the Islanders took the ice against the Devils on Tuesday night, they were without goalie Rick DiPietro, who missed the game because of headaches that began after Sundays overtime loss to the Rangers.

title: Home Base for Laughs? Comedy Central Thinks So
description: Nobody in broadcast television has been laughing much lately at the state of comedy. This season exactly one situation comedy, Two and a Half Men on CBS, is among the 20 most-watched shows on television.

title: 2 European Bank Chiefs Got Big Raises in 2006
description: LONDON, March 27  Deutsche Bank and the Credit Suisse Group, two of Europes biggest banks, rewarded their top executives with bigger paychecks last year, but their compensation still trailed that of their American counterparts.

title: Behind Foreclosures, Ruined Credit and Hopes
description: NEWARK  After Franklin Abazie fell behind on his mortgage last year, he tucked one of his foreclosure notices, still in its ripped envelope, into the visor of his car  a looming reminder of why he had to take a second job.

title: Canada: T-Shirt Maker Shifts Production
description: Gildan Activewear, one of the largest makers of T-shirts in North America, said it would close five plants in Canada, the United States and Mexico and eliminate 1,830 jobs to move production to lower-cost operations in Central America. The company will shut two textile plants in Montreal, two sewing plants in Mexico and a cutting factory in Bombay, N.Y., it said. Gildan will record a restructuring charge of $21.5 million, or 35 cents a share, in fiscal 2007, which ends in September. Gildan, based in Montreal, is shifting production from older plants in North America to newer factories in Central America. It expects to save $45 million a year starting in fiscal 2008 from lower expenses for production, shipping and duties.

title: Officer Is Shot in Leg on Brooklyn Street; One Suspect Is Held
description: A 27-year-old police officer was shot in the leg while trying to arrest a man who was smoking marijuana on a Brooklyn street last night, according to the authorities.

title: Correction: It Boils Down to This: Cheap Wine Works Fine
description: An article last Wednesday about cooking with wine gave an incorrect neighborhood for Astor Wines & Spirits, 399 Lafayette (4th Street). It is in NoHo, not SoHo.

title: A Death Embellished
description: The Pentagons investigation of the friendly fire death of Pat Tillman, the Army Ranger who became an administration icon for its war on terror, has left the corporals family doubtful that the truth has really come out. Even as the Army reaffirmed its belief that Corporal Tillman deserved a Silver Star for valor, the family denounced the award as part of a cynical design to conceal the real events from the family and the public, while exploiting the death of our beloved Pat as a recruitment poster.

title: Many Paisley Supporters Back Joint Ulster Government
description: BALLYMENA, Northern Ireland, March 27  It is known as the heart of Paisley Protestant country, the town that started the long political career of the Rev. Ian Paisley, the hard-line Northern Ireland Protestant leader once nicknamed Dr. No.

title: Staten Island: Beetle Infestation Found
description: A silver maple tree infested with the Asian longhorned beetle has been found on Staten Island, the first evidence ever of the tree-damaging insect in the borough, the citys Parks and Recreation Department said yesterday. Beetle eggs in the tree, in a privately owned woodland in Bloomfield, were discovered on Thursday by United States Department of Agriculture workers. When the maple was last inspected, in May 2006, it showed no signs of infestation, the parks department said.

title: Williams Shows Australian Open Was No Fluke
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 27  It was less a match than a memorandum of what Serena Williams is capable of when she puts her mind behind her might. Covering the court like a tarp, Williams suffocated top-seeded Maria Sharapova in 58 bloodless minutes Tuesday in the fourth round of the Sony Ericsson Open.

title: Upgraded Version of Xbox 360 to Be Introduced by Microsoft
description: Raising the ante in the video game wars, Microsoft is bringing out a new version of the Xbox 360 game machine that has a bigger hard drive, better high-definition video support and a stylish black finish, not an insignificant feature in a world where looking cool ranks high.

title: What You Get for ... $7 Million
description: Greenwich, Conn.

title: New Effort to Tap Technology to Aid the Service Economy
description: A group of large technology companies, universities and professional associations are creating a new organization to support and promote research into ways that technology can increase productivity and innovation in the economys service sector.

title: Trying to Disarm the Dangerous World That Students Live In
description: MIAMI GARDENS, Fla.

title: Senators Cite F.B.I. Failures as Chief Promises Change
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  Director Robert S. Mueller III of the F.B.I. told a Senate committee Tuesday that he was moving swiftly to fix the problems exposed in the latest report on the bureaus failures, most prominently the mishandling of demands for records under the USA Patriot Act.

title: Reprisal Attacks Against Sunnis Kill Scores in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, March 28  One of the bloodiest chapters in Iraqs sectarian strife unfolded over the last two days in the northern city of Tal Afar where gunmen, some of them apparently police officers, participated in revenge killings of scores of Sunni Arabs in the aftermath of a huge double suicide bombing in a Shiite neighborhood.

title: A Pit Bull Who Provided Lessons in Loyalty and Unfailing Love
description: HOBOKEN, N.J.

title: Result of Military Trial Is Familiar to Civilians
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, March 27  In the first session of the new military commission system set up by Congress, the first detainee to face a judge sounded for a time as though he was ready for a trial.

title: Altered Spaces: The Good, the Bad and the Dizzying
description: IN a letter to The Denver Post last fall, a Colorado artist said that Daniel Libeskinds addition to the Denver Art Museum made him physically sick. I feel devastated, wrote the artist, Candis Cebula. After less than two minutes on the fourth floor of the new Hamilton wing, I had to leave. Art is visual, and the visual disorientation of the walls made me so nauseated and dizzy I could not enjoy the fabulous art, no matter how hard I tried.

title: France: Court Voids Conviction of Railway for Jewish Deportations
description: An administrative appeals court in Bordeaux overturned the 2006 conviction of the national railway SNCF for taking part in the deportation of two members of a French Jewish family in World War II. The conviction last June, ordering compensation, set off 1,800 more claims. The appeals court said the case did not fall within its jurisdiction  lawsuits brought against the state  because SNCF is an independent entity. It did not rule on the case itself, brought by two members of the Lipietz family who were put on a train to the transit camp at Drancy near Paris in May 1944. They remained there until the camp was liberated a few months later, and brought the suit in 2001. Thousands of French Jews were transported from Drancy to Nazi death camps. A lawyer for the family said it would appeal.

title: Rosneft Wins Yukos Stake in 4-Minute Sale
description: MOSCOW, March 27  After bidding that lasted just four minutes, the Russian state oil company Rosneft won an auction Tuesday for assets of the bankrupt company Yukos, further tightening the Kremlins control of energy industries in Russia.

title: Phelps Smashes Another World Record, His Own
description: MELBOURNE, March 28 - Michael Phelps of the United States smashed another record Wednesday night, and this time it was his own.

title: Sri Lanka: Suicide Attack at Army Base Kills 7
description: A pair of suicide bombers thought to be Tamil Tiger rebels tried to drive a tractor loaded with explosives into an army camp in the eastern district of Batticaloa and blew themselves up when they were intercepted by troops. Besides the bombers, seven people were killed. The bombing came a day after the guerrillas carried out an airstrike on a military base north of Colombo, the capital, their first since fighting began more than two decades ago.

title: Portugal Utility Deal for U.S. Wind Farm
description: EDP-Energias de Portugal, an electric utility, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Horizon Wind Energy of Texas from the Goldman Sachs Group for $2.15 billion to more than double its wind-power production.

title: Columbia Disciplines 8 for Disrupting Speakers
description: Columbia University has warned or censured eight students who were involved in disrupting speakers from the Minuteman Project last October in a melee that cut short the program, a university spokesman said yesterday.

title: Pennsylvania: Charge in Suicide Case
description: Perjury and other charges were filed against a state senator in the wake of the suicide of a 14-year-old neighbor. The boy, Louis Farrell, shot himself in July with a handgun owned by the lawmaker, Bob Regola. Mr. Regola was charged with three counts of perjury, one count of allowing possession of a firearm by a minor, one count of recklessly endangering another person and three counts of false swearing. The perjury and false swearing counts relate to testimony he made last month that his teenage son did not have access to the gun. That was contradicted by state troopers, who said Mr. Regola told them the gun was kept in his sons room at one time.

title: San Francisco Board Votes to Ban Some Plastic Bags
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 27  Paper or paper?

title: Break Seen in Logjam Over Trade
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  Prospects for Congressional approval of several pending trade pacts received a surprising lift on Tuesday when Democrats in the House proposed a series of revisions that won guarded praise from both organized labor and the Bush administration.

title: Dispute Over Britons Held by Iran Escalates
description: LONDON, March 28  The dispute with Iran over Britains captured sailors and marines escalated sharply on Wednesday when Britain froze all bilateral business with Iran and the Iranians displayed some British prisoners on state television  an act condemned by the Foreign Office here as completely unacceptable.

title: Earths Climate Needs the Help of Incentives
description: Washington

title: A Butcher With Tables Behind the Counter
description: LAS Americas, a carnicera in Sunnyside, Queens, has been serving the meat needs of the Colombian, and greater Latino, communities for nearly 30 years.

title: Big Waves Sighted on the Waterfront
description: Boston

title: Proposed Changes Would Shift Duties in Protecting Species
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  The Fish and Wildlife Service is considering limiting the ability of federal wildlife protection agencies to intervene on behalf of endangered species that may be harmed by federal actions.

title: U.S. Opens Naval Exercise in Persian Gulf
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  In a calculated show of force, the United States Navy began a major exercise in the Persian Gulf on Tuesday, a move that Bush administration officials said was part of a broader strategy to contain Iranian power in the region.

title: Absorbing the Holocaust, With Help From Survivors
description: FOR 50 years she didnt utter a word about the Holocaust to her family. She had a number, 52643, branded on her forearm, but Bronia Brandmans family never discussed it. Then, 10 years ago, when she began volunteering as a gallery educator at New Yorks Museum of Jewish Heritage, another volunteer insisted she tell her story.

title: For a Sweeter Passover, Old and New Sephardic Delights
description: ON the 500th anniversary of Spains expulsion of Jews, King Juan Carlos went to a synagogue in Madrid and said, in essence, mistakes were made, welcome back.

title: A House in Downtown Seville
description: Spending half your life traveling from airports to hotels to planes and the other half tackling the heat and dust of Houston can make you yearn for something different. Just ask Heidi Heinz, an American who was on one of her frequent business trips as a consultant for the global management company Accenture when she had an epiphany.

title: Entrepreneur Gets 9 Years in Tax Case
description: Walter C. Anderson, an American telecommunications entrepreneur who once tried to turn the Russian Mir space station into an orbiting hotel for the wealthy, was sentenced to nine years in prison yesterday for failing to report $365 million in income.

title: Up Close Under the Sea
description: WAILUKU, Hawaii

title: Apart From Wanting It All, What Makes Boomers So Special?
description: Is the cute concept of baby boomers useful to historians?

title: Letters
description: Democracy at the Stove

title: Ex-Lawyer Recalls Dealings With Judge in Bribery Case
description: Here was the star witness: slumped forward in his chair, sad-eyed, rocking slightly side to side, chastising himself in quiet fits of white-collar shame.

title: Spirits Are Angry. Bad Time to Bomb Their Volcano.
description: SIDOARJO, Indonesia  How to tame a mud volcano: try dropping hundreds of giant concrete balls into it.

title: War at Home: Ancient Tale of Revenge and Regret
description: In her recent work about the Trojan War, the puppeteer and storyteller Theodora Skipitares draws equivalents to current events. A program note for her new piece, The Exiles, asks us to think of Helen, whose kidnapping ignited the war, as probably the first weapon of mass destruction. But the play is less about her than about what happens when war comes home.

title: Hollinger Trial Witness Tells of Payment Note
description: CHICAGO, March 27 (Bloomberg)  A witness at the trial of Conrad M. Black testified he saw a lawyer for Hollinger International write a note directing payment of $9.5 million to Mr. Black and three other men from the sale of several small newspapers.

title: Uranium Ignites Gold Rush in the West
description: LA SAL, Utah  Given its connotations, Pandora is an oddly inappropriate name for an uranium mine.

title: Recipe: Korean-Style Crisp Vegetable Pancake (Pa jun)
description: Time: 30 minutes

title: An Expanding Museum Capitalizes on Photography
description: LAST year, with one eye on the community, another on the academy and its third eye meditating squarely on posterity, the High Museum of Art in Atlanta made a big splash after the opening of two new buildings, both designed by the Italian architect Renzo Piano. The new wings more than doubled the museums exhibition space, created a visitor-friendly public campus, bringing a good deal of positive national attention to a notable regional museum and, with that rising tide, giving its photography department a visible and intentional lift.

title: The Health of a Child (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Park Officer Is Indicted in Shooting
description: A Bergen County grand jury indicted a New Jersey State Park Police officer yesterday on a charge of reckless manslaughter in the fatal shooting of a member of the Ramapough Mountain Indians last April that caused outrage among the tribe.

title: Israel Fires Into Gaza, Responding to Rocket Attack
description: JERUSALEM, March 28  The Israeli Army fired into the northern Gaza Strip today, targeting a Palestinian militant cell about to launch a rocket attack, an army spokeswoman said.

title: Morehouse Searches for a Leader and a Way to Keep Making Gains
description: ATLANTA, March 27  At an unspeakably early hour for college students on a Sunday, several dozen young men recently boarded buses here, dressed so elegantly they appeared to be engaged in silent sartorial combat. One even wore an ascot.

title: Opening Day: Excitement. Renewal. Pavano?
description: FORT MYERS, Fla., March 27  His last two years have been so miserable, it is easy to forget who Carl Pavano used to be. In 2004, the year before he signed with the Yankees, Pavano was an All-Star who won 18 games for the Florida Marlins.

title: Veterans Director in Arizona Steps Down After Violations
description: PHOENIX, March 27  The director of the Arizona Department of Veterans Services resigned Tuesday, days after the public disclosure of health and safety violations at a nursing home for veterans.

title: In New Jersey, 3 More Subpoenas Tied to Special Grants
description: TRENTON, March 27  Stepping up their investigation of possible corruption in the New Jersey State House, federal authorities have issued subpoenas to three lawmakers demanding that they explain their ties to organizations that have received $3.4 million in special grants.

title: From Michigan, a Clean-Running Museum
description: PETER M. WEGE, a leading philanthropist in western Michigan, is not an art collector.

title: Three Fish Walk Into a Bar...
description: FOR almost two hours on a recent afternoon, Jol Robuchon cooled his heels in the lounge by the entrance to LAtelier de Jol Robuchon at the Four Seasons Hotel in Midtown Manhattan. He ordered a coca light, which made the hostess hesitate for a few seconds until she realized he wanted a Diet Coke. He was waiting to give a lesson on cooking with shellfish (March, April  these are the best months for seafood, he said), but lunch customers were still lingering in the dining room. Worse, they were still sitting on the tall, comfortable stools at the restaurants heart  the horseshoe-shaped counter that surrounds the open kitchen.

title: Siemens Executive Arrested
description: FRANKFURT, March 27  German prosecutors arrested one of the top-ranking executives at Siemens on Tuesday in an investigation into suspected bribery, dealing the troubled company another blow in what has become a steady drumbeat of corruption accusations.

title: A Museum Grows in Brooklyn
description: Six years ago, when Laurie Cumbo founded Mocada, a museum that showcases the works of black artists across the diaspora, it was housed on the fourth floor of a church-owned brownstone in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Space was scarce  800 square feet  and resources more so. It was literally mom and pop, Ms. Cumbo, 31, recalled. My family stuffing envelopes, picking up art, hanging things up. And the building was a walk-up, which meant lots of huffing and puffing, she added.

title: Afghanistan: 4 Policemen Killed in Southern Suicide Attack
description: A suicide bomber dressed as an Afghan soldier detonated the explosives strapped to his body at the entrance of the police headquarters in Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, and killed four policemen.

title: Pickles and Cheese, Not Wine and Cheese, at the New Whole Foods
description: The latest Whole Foods Market, all 72,000 square feet of it, opens tomorrow at 95 East Houston Street (Bowery). Given its location, it pays homage to the Lower East Side with a stand for local pickle makers in a corner of its elaborate cheese department.

title: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts yesterday about The Boomer Century: 1946-2046, a documentary on most PBS stations tonight, misstated the year Tony Snow, the White House press secretary, who appears on the program, was born. It was 1955, not 1957.

title: Choice Shows: Europe
description: Surreal Things: Surrealism and Design

title: Worlds Cruelty and Pain, Seen in an Unblinking Lens
description: If this were a perfect world, everybody would see the photographer James Nachtweys astonishing shows at the United Nations and at 401 Projects in the West Village.

title: Lagging Technology Effort Is Called Danger to Airliners
description: WASHINGTON, March 27  Airliners are vulnerable to catastrophic collisions on the ground because the government is moving too slowly to install warning technology, the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board said Tuesday.

title: An Anniversary With a Forward Look
description: In an ideal musical culture there would be no need for the American Composers Orchestra. Classical music programs in the United States would not be dominated, as they mostly are, by the works of dead European males.

title: Axel Rosin, 99, Longtime Head of the Book-of-the-Month Club, Dies
description: Axel G. Rosin, a former president of the Book-of-the-Month Club and later the head of the Scherman Foundation, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 99.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening Next Week

title: Blood-Stain Reds and Skeptical Grays
description: GRAY might not sound like a particularly exciting shade to choose as the central theme for a big, ambitious museum exhibition. But if the artist mixing the grays is Jasper Johns, the color suddenly takes on a new brilliance.

title: Dinner as a Carefully Staged Ceremony
description: THE greeting you get from Jungjin Park, the owner of the strange and sometimes wonderful new Japanese restaurant Rosanjin, starts out uneventfully enough.

title: Correction: Tortillas Like Mams, but This Is No Bodega
description: An article last Wednesday about Hispanic groceries misspelled the surname of a senior director of neighborhood marketing for one supermarket chain. He is Jim Carrado, not Corrado. The article also misidentified Mr. Carrados employer. He works for Winn-Dixie, not Publix.

title: Call to Increase M.R.I. Use for Breast Exam
description: Two reports being published today call for greatly expanded use of M.R.I. scans in women who have breast cancer or are at high risk for it.

title: Albany Leaders Near Deal on a Budget
description: ALBANY, March 27  In a major step toward passing a state budget by the April 1 deadline, Gov. Eliot Spitzer and state legislative leaders agreed Tuesday night to add at least $850 million to his proposed budget and appeared to have resolved the main issues that divided them.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: The Empire Strikes; Snoop and Diddy Strike Back

title: The Industry of Art Goes Global
description: PARIS

title: In Defense of Day Laborers
description: In cities and suburbs across America, the confluence of homes, big-box stores and striving immigrant men has created an informal, often unruly job marketplace that has survived every effort to ban it or harass it out of existence.

title: With Local Figures on the Ballot, Others May Shun an Early Primary
description: ALBANY, March 27  When the State Legislature voted last week to move New Yorks presidential primary to Feb. 5 from March, lawmakers said they wanted to ensure that more candidates would actively campaign in the state.

title: The Man Who Would Move the Barnes
description: MERION, Pa.

title: In a Trance Where Strobes Flash and the Techno Beat Pulses
description: If youre looking for a documentary about the electronic music scene filled with historical lectures, performance clips and talking heads, Headspace ... The Sound of Life ... isnt for you and doesnt try to be.

title: Manhattan: Partial Deadlock in Teacher Case
description: The jurors in the trial of Lina Sinha, left, a schoolteacher accused of having had a sexual relationship with two male students from 1996 to 2002, beginning when they were junior high school students, indicated yesterday to Justice Carol Berkman of State Supreme Court that they had reached agreement on 10 of the 19 counts in a revised indictment and that they were at an impasse on the rest. The jury did not disclose which counts they had agreed on. Eleven of the 19 counts are nonsexual charges against Ms. Sinha, such as making false calls to 911, witness tampering and bribing a witness. Justice Berkman instructed the jurors, who have deliberated for three and a half days, to continue to try to reach a verdict on all counts, and deliberations are to continue today.

title: Portugal: Utility Buys Texas Wind Farm
description: EDP-Energias de Portugal, an electric utility, said that it had agreed to buy Horizon Wind Energy of Texas from the Goldman Sachs Group for $2.15 billion to more than double its wind-power production. EDP, which is based in Lisbon, said it would borrow the money to pay for Horizon, which is based in Houston and has assets in 15 states. EDP has branched into Spain and the United States because it faces growing competition in Portugal. The market in the United States has gained appeal because the federal government has extended incentives for wind energy.

title: When Serious Collectors Band Together
description: WHILE established museums are struggling with a drop in the philanthropy that has long helped to build their collections, a recent bequest to the Dallas Museum of Art stands out as a model of generosity.

title: Child to End Publication, but Web Site Will Continue
description: As goes Life, so goes Child.

title: Ground Zero Arts Center Loses Theater Company
description: In a new twist to the juggling act at ground zero, the city said yesterday that the Signature Theater Company would not be included in a performing arts center to be designed there by Frank Gehry, leaving the Joyce Theater, which presents dance, as the buildings sole resident.

title: Mideast Leaders to Hold Talks Twice a Month
description: JERUSALEM, March 27  After three days of shuttle diplomacy between Israeli and Arab cities and a late night of haggling, Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice said Tuesday that she had persuaded Israeli and Palestinian leaders to hold talks twice a month.

title: France: Qatar Affirms Airbus Order
description: Airbus rescued a $16 billion order from Qatar Airways for 80 A350 XWB long-range planes after designing a wider body and wings to beat out Boeings rival 787 Dreamliner. We have got what we want from them, said Akbar al-Baker, chief executive of the state-owned Persian Gulf airline. He said he expected to sign a preliminary order in a few weeks and a firm order at the Paris Air Show in June. Mr. Baker threatened to buy Boeings rival 787 Dreamliner last month unless Airbus came up with a detailed redesign of the A350 by June..

title: For the Record
description: A picture caption in some copies on Monday with a sports article about Tiger Woodss victory at the CA Championship misstated his winning streak at Doral Golf Resort and Spa. It was his third victory in a row there, not his sixth.

title: In Night of World Records, Phelps Leaves Biggest Ripple in the Pool
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Wednesday, March 28  Michael Phelps does not agree, but perhaps Ian Thorpe retired at just the right time after all when he hung up his goggles in November.

title: Saudi King Condemns U.S. Occupation of Iraq
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia told Arab leaders on Wednesday that the American occupation of Iraq is illegal, and he warned that unless Arab governments settle their differences, foreign powers like the United States would continue to dictate the regions politics.

title: Man Denies He Told Police That Sean Bell Shot Him
description: Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly said yesterday that a Queens man had told the police that he was shot last year by Sean Bell, the groom-to-be who was killed by police gunfire in Jamaica in November. But in an interview, the man, Anthony Jeffers, denied accusing Mr. Bell.

title: Overcoming a Frat Party Reputation
description: BROOKLINE, Mass.

title: First, a New Artery Stent Study; Now, Questions About What It All Means
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 27  Is today the first in a new era for angioplasty and stenting, the artery-clearing technology that enchanted doctors while giving birth to a multibillion-dollar industry?

title: The Hunger and the Hostility Vanish in One Bite
description: DINING out is one of the greatest pleasures of living in New York City. The variety! The quality!

title: After Congo Vote, Neglect and Scandal Still Reign
description: KINDU, Congo  The highway out of town is a single dirt motorcycle track. The colonial-era railroad has finally broken down. The last of the mighty river barges lies rotting on shore with weeds shooting up through its ribs.

title: Queens: Man Dies After Being Hit by Bus
description: A city bus struck and killed a 23-year-old motorcyclist yesterday in Queens, the police said. The victim, Kristopher Thompson of Cambria Heights, was taken to Mary Immaculate Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. The accident happened at about 6:45 p.m. when a bus traveling west on Hillside Avenue hit Mr. Thompsons motorcycle, which was going east on Hillside, near the intersection with 173rd Street. The bus driver was not issued a summons.

title: Utah: Venue Change Pondered for Sect Leader
description: A judge denied three motions by defense lawyers for the fundamentalist Mormon polygamist leader Warren Jeffs, but left possible a change of venue to Salt Lake County. The judge, James L. Shumate, said if he determined during the jury selection process that an impartial panel could not be seated in Washington County, he would move the case. Mr. Jeffs, 51, is charged with two felony counts of rape as an accomplice in connection with his performance of an April 2001 spiritual marriage of a 14-year-old girl to her 19-year-old cousin. If convicted, he could face life in prison.

title: Children Held in Manila Bus Siege Are Released
description: MANILA, March 28  The owner of a daycare center gave himself up after taking a busload of his students hostage here today. He had driven them to Manila City Hall, where he railed against corruption in Philippine politics through a loudspeaker and criticized the government for failing to provide education for the poor.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, a sports article on Monday about Yankees pitcher Jeff Karstens, who struggled in a spring-training game against the Detroit Tigers, misstated his statistics in some copies. He had a 3-1 record and a 2.70 earned run average before facing the Tigers on Sunday, not after giving up six runs in two innings in that game.

title: Mr. Rogerss Neighborhoods
description: A look at the work of Richard Rogers, the architect who is the 2007 recipient of the Pritzker Prize.

title: Getting to the Bottom of Gitmo
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Expansion, Coast to Coast
Ballet Discoveries
description: Images from productions of Romeo and Juliet past and present.

title: Israelis Dismantle Settlement
description: Police removed more than 450 right-wingers from the ruins of Homesh, a former Jewish settlement in the northern West Bank.

title: Joan Nathan
description: Joan Nathan is an authority on Jewish-American food. Her most recent cookbook, "The New American Cooking," published by Random House in 2005, won the James Beard Award in the Food of the Americas category and the International Association of Culinary Professionals (IACP) Award for Cookbook of the Year. Ms. Nathan answered readers' questions about cooking and entertaining during Passover.

title: The Future of Hydrogen Cars
description: Over on my blog (nytimes.com/pogue), I'm wrapping up my notes on the 2007 TED conference (Technology, Entertainment, Design), a reality-altering, four-day series of 50 speakers, most of whom are absolutely brilliant.

title: Law of Unintended Consequences?
description: When the State Legislature voted last week to move New Yorks presidential primary to Feb. 5 from March, lawmakers said they wanted to ensure that more candidates would actively campaign in the state. But if the bill is signed into law, it may have exactly the opposite effect.

title: Law Firms Ties to Hedge Funds Lead to Dismissal
description: The law firm Pillsbury Winthrop Shaw Pittman may lose $4 million in fees after a United States Bankruptcy Court judge on Tuesday dismissed it from a case, citing a conflict of interest. Pillsbury represented SonicBlue, an electronics maker that declared bankruptcy in 2003. In 2002, the law firm promised three hedge funds that invested in a $75 billion bond issue that theyd be paid in full in the event of a bankruptcy.

title: Lender Said to Be Weighing a Bankruptcy Filing Soon
description: New Century Financial, the troubled subprime mortgage company, could file for bankruptcy protection as early as the end of this week, people briefed on the companys plans said Tuesday. The company stopped making loans this month after federal prosecutors and regulators began investigating it and is trying to tie up financing that would allow it to reorganize or sell itself through a prepackaged bankruptcy, rather than be forced to liquidate itself.

title: Who Benefits in Secondary Buyouts?
description: As Goldman Sachs raises $3 billion for a secondary buyout fund, Breakingviews reports on a study suggesting that buyers in secondary deals may often be paying top dollar for mediocre assets. While secondaries are useful because they give private equity investors a chance to cash out early, the buyers in these transaction should beware, Breakingviews suggests.

title: Rosneft Wins Yukos Stake in 4-Minute Sale
description: After an auction that lasted just four minutes, the Russian state oil company Rosneft won the bidding Tuesday for assets of the bankrupt company Yukos, further tightening the Kremlins control of energy industries in Russia. In the auction, Rosneft bid against a joint venture of BP and Russian partners, called TNK-BP, for 9.44 percent of Rosnefts own stock, which Yukos had acquired in a swap before its bankruptcy.

title: Siemens Executive Arrested
description: German prosecutors arrested one of the top-ranking executives at Siemens on Tuesday in an investigation into suspected bribery, dealing the troubled company another blow in what has become a steady barrage of corruption accusations. The executive, Johannes Feldmayer, was detained as prosecutors searched company offices in Munich, where Siemens is based, and two other German cities, a spokeswoman for Siemens said.

title: F.C.C. Approves $12 Billion Sale of Univision Communications
description: The Federal Communications Commission has approved the $12.3 billion buyout of Univision Communications after the company agreed to pay a record $24 million fine and improve the quality of its childrens programming.

title: DoubleClick Said to Consider Sale
description: DoubleClick, an online advertising company controlled by a private equity firm, Hellman & Friedman, is exploring a sale and is in talks with potential suitors including Microsoft, the Wall Street Journal reported. DoubleClick was publicly traded in 2005 when it agreed to be acquired by Hellman & Friedman for about $1.1 billion. The firm is hoping to get at least $2 billion in a DoubleClick sale, a source told the Journal.

title: Supreme Court Hears I.P.O. Arguments
description: Arguments were laid out before the Supreme Court on Tuesday regarding whether the securities industry can be sued for allegations of antitrust violations in creating syndicates for initial public offerings. The court justices challenged the three lawyers who appeared before them by drilling down on the question of whether the Securities and Exchange Commission adequately polices the securities industry.

title: Aruba Raises $88 Million in I.P.O.
description: Wireless local-area-network technology developer Aruba Networks generated about $88 million in its first day of trading on Nasdaq Tuesday. The company, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., is one of a crop of venture capital-backed compaines to have done well in March I.P.O.s. Others include Glu Mobile and Sourcefire even though none of them has shown a profit. Still, Aruba is growing. Its revenue rose to $72.5 million last year from $12 million in 2005.

title: Vitamin Maker NBTY Said to Seek a Buyer
description: A nutritional supplement company, NBTY, is up for sale, The Deal reported, citing unnamed sources. The companys market capitalization is $3.3 billion based on Tuesdays trading. Bear Stearns and Bank of America are advising NBTY and first-round bids are expected in the next few weeks.

title: Bidders Roll the Dice Again on Riviera Holdings
description: Riviera Holdings, the owner of the Riviera Hotel and Casino in Las Vegas and the Riviera Black Hawk Casino in Black Hawk, Colo., is once again fielding a buyout offer from Riv Acquisition Holdings. The bidding group, which includes Starwood Capitals chief executive, Barry Sternlicht, said Monday it had offered $27 a share in cash for Riviera. A deal could be valued at $551.5 million. Shareholders in Riviera, which is based in Las Vegas, turned down a previous offer in 2006.

title: Bloomberg Defends Police Spying
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg defended police spying on potential protesters in advance of the 2004 Republican National Convention, saying yesterday that it was necessary for security during an uneasy time:

title: V.C.s Welcome in San Jose, Study Finds
description: Venture funding in San Jose, Calif., during 2006 totaled about $616.4 million, up 27.4 percent from the previous year, according to a report released Monday. The report, from VentureDeal and the Business Performance Management Forum, said San Joses venture financing growth was more than double the national average.

title: Hot China
description: http://www.breitbart.com/article.php?id=070328041237.iwdgl7e0&show_article=1

title: City National to Buy Lydian Wealth
description: City National, a financial management company based in Los Angeles, said it had agreed to buy Lydian Wealth Management, an asset manager, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

title: G.M. Will Not Bid for Chrysler, Report Says
description: General Motors will not make a bid for DaimlerChryslers Chrysler unit, the Times of London reported, citing unnamed sources close to the talks. The report came after an analyst at Bear Stearns, quoted in the The Detroit Free Press, suggested that a merger between General Motors and Chrysler would be challenged to pass antitrust scrutiny. Earlier in the week, the Detroit Free Press said that while General Motors held talks with DaimlerChrysler about a transaction in Janaury, it is not actively pursuing a purchase.

title: Vocus Stock Sale Could Bring in $67 Million
description: A Web-based software provider, Vocus, has announced a secondary public offering of up to 3.3 million shares that could generate a total of more than $67 million. By selling about 1.2 million shares of common stock at just over $20 a share, Vocus expects to generate $23.2 million directly, after deducting underwriting fees. Certain selling stockholders are selling an additional 1.6 million shares.

title: Xstrata Under Pressure to Increase LionOre Bid
description: The Swiss metal company Xstrata is facing pressure to increase its all-cash $4.6-billion bid for LionOre Mining International, a nickel mining company, following recommendations from analysts who said the offer undervalues LionOre. Xstrata proposed the deal on Monday, bidding $18.50 a share, but the offer was met with derision by institutional shareholders looking for more cash.

title: Aerovance Secures $32 Million V.C. Round
description: Aerovance, a drug maker, said Tuesday that Clarus Ventures had agreed to provide $32 million of financing that will allow it to independently pursue a clinical trial of its asthma drug Aerovant later this year. Aerovance is continuing to seek partnerships with pharmaceutical companies in support of trials that would give the partner licensing rights to Aerovant. The new funding will give Aerovance more freedom to select a partner for the drugs marketing and sales.

title: ATS Calls Off I.P.O.
description: ATS Automation Tooling Systems said Tuesday it had cancalled an initial public offering of 250 million Canadian dollars ($216 million) for its solar cell unit, Photowatt Technologies. The offering was in the works for more than a year and was postponed two weeks ago. ATS said Tuesday that two Photowatt orders, valued at more than $6.2 million, had been delayed by customers.

title: HSBC Lures Credit Suisses Simons
description: HSBC has hired a Credit Suisse banker, David Simons, as head of leveraged and acquisition finance in the Asia-Pacific region. Simons previously headed leveraged finance for non-Japan Asia at Credit Suisse. Mr. Simons will take up his new functions in May and will lead the banks efforts to build its strengths in event-driven investment grade and non-investment grade financing in Asia.

title: In Tribune Horse Race, Zell Is Said to Keep the Lead
description: In the ongoing saga of the Tribune auction, real estate magnate Samuel Zell appears closer than ever to winning the day. Tribune is expected to name a victorious bidder at the end of this week and Mr. Zells $8 billion takeover offer is emerging as the most likely candidate, Bloomberg News said citing unnamed sources.

title: Sanyo Chief Expected to Resign, Report Says
description: The president of the Japanese electronics giant Sanyo, Toshimasa Iue, is expected to resign early next week following a series of management failures and an accountancy scandal that has badly damaged the companys image, the Times of London reported, citing sources it did not identify.

title: ABN May Consider Other Deals if Barclays Talks Stall
description: The Dutch banking giant ABN Amro said Wednesday that it would look for other possible deals should talks with Barclays fall through. ABN also urged shareholders to reject a motion to break up the company. While ABN said it was excited about a potential deal with Barclays, it is unclear whether talks will lead to a merger.

title: Tracking the Next Private Equity Targets
description: With the floodgates of private equity cash securely open, investors are eyeing the full corporate landscape for buyout candidates. Based on a report from Goldman Sachs, BusinessWeek today wonders just who the next targets will be.

title: BA Considers Bidding for a Rival
description: British Airways is considering a 1 billion pound ($1.96 billion) bid for a rival British carrier, bmi, according to The Times of London. The paper said that bmis chairman, Michael Bishop, who is also a 50 percent shareholder, has received approaches from a number of airlines interested in buying a stake.

title: Bear Stearns C.E.O. Earned $40 Million in 2006
description: Bear Stearns said Tuesday it paid its chief executive, James Cayne, $40 million in cash, stock and other compensation last year, which was 32 percent more than in 2005. The Financial Times reported that Mr. Caynes compensation was on a par with the $40.5 million paid to Lehman Brothers chief executive Richard Fuld, but less than what the chiefs of Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch and Goldman Sachs earned last year. Financial News said Mr. Cayne received 24 percent of the money Bear Stearns set aside for the bonuses of its top five executives.

title: Can Gadgets and Humor Mix?
description: David Pogue tests the SoundKase Sonic iBoom Backpack.

title: Goldman Aims for $20 Billion Buyout Fund
description: Even as analysts speculate whether the Blackstone Group is trying to challenge Wall Streets investment banks with its initial public offering, the biggest bank of them all is aggressively targeting private equity firms turf. Goldman Sachs chief executive, Lloyd C. Blankfein, said Tuesday that his firms next buyout fund could reach $20 billion, which would be the largest such fund ever raised  by either a bank or a private equity firm. The remarks, which Mr. Blankfein made at his firms annual shareholder meeting, came as Blackstone is out raising a fund of its own that could end up a similar size.

title: Desperately Seeking Architect
description: Our search for the right architect continued without success. I began to think that we were the problem. We wanted too much: an architect who designs gorgeous homes that are not too fancy  someone with a fine aesthetic sensibility who is practical and whose rates are affordable.

title: ABN AMRO Urges Shareholders to Reject Breakup
description: AMSTERDAM, March 28 (Reuters) - The Dutch bank ABN AMRO (NYSE:ABN) on Wednesday urged shareholders to reject plans by a hedge fund to break-up or sell the company, as it pursues a merger with Britain's Barclays to create a bank worth over $175 billion.

title: MoveOn to Hold Virtual Chats With Candidates
description: MoveOn.org, the liberal activist group, is inviting its broad membership to take part in virtual question-and-answer sessions with some of the 2008 presidential contenders beginning next month  each one focusing on a particular topic.

title: Currents
description: Items that can work at home or go to work, discontinued pieces and samples have their day at the Conran shop and more.

title: Choosing the Next Republican Loser
description: Former Tennessee senator and current Law and Order district attorney Fred Thompson finished third among the potential Republican presidential candidates in a weekend poll conducted by USA Today and Gallup. Ross Douthat, an associate editor at The Atlantic, writing at The American Scene, sees a problem with this, beyond the fact that a Fred Thompson candidacy would mean there would be two separate Thompson 08 campaigns in the Republican primaries (though former Wisconsin governor Tommy Thompson seems to have prepared for this by using the rubric Tommy 08).

title: What to See, Region by Region
description: Art exhibitions flourish across the country. Here is a selection of the latest offerings:

title: Porsche Completes Purchase of More Volkswagen Shares
description: BERLIN, March 28 (AP) -- German sports car maker Porsche AG said Wednesday it had completed its acquisition of more shares in Volkswagen AG, boosting its stake in Europe's biggest automaker to 30.94 percent and triggering a formal takeover offer to VW's shareholders. Porsche doesn't expect many VW shareholders will accept its below-market-price offer, however.

title: CBS News Poll on Edwards
description: Americans agree with John Edwardss decision to continue his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination after his wife Elizabeth was diagnosed with a recurrence of cancer, according to a nationwide CBS News poll released this morning. Voters who say they expect to vote in the Democratic primaries next year are even more supportive of his decision.

title: Murder, I Read
description: Stanley Fish has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below.  The Editors

title: Wizard apartments!
description: Hot off the presses! Hogwarts is being turned into luxury apartments!

title: Forbes Backing Giuliani
description: Steve Forbes, who ran for president twice on a flat-tax platform, endorsed Rudolph W. Giuliani today, saying the former mayor would symplify the tax code if elected president.

title: 2008: Hearts, Minds and Pocketbooks
description: As March money madness reaches its peak, the presidential candidates arent the only ones dashing for cash. The Wall Street Journal reports that major donors to presidential candidates are also holding fundraisers for congressional contenders.

title: The Anthropology of Cellphones
description: Still more notes from the TED conference:

title: In Circuit City Restructuring, Canadian Stores May Go
description: The consumer electronics retailer Circuit City Stores said on Wednesday it will explore a possible sale of its Canadian unit InterTan and replace 3,400 employees with lower-paid workers in a cost-cutting move, sending its shares up 2.5 percent.

title: Is Citis Long Slump Finally Over?
description: Citigroup has been down so long, it looks like up to John McDonald, an analyst at Banc of America Securities. Mr. McDonald on Wednesday raised his rating on Citigroups stock to buy from neutral, writing that years of disappointing fundamental and stock price performance have set the bar low for Citi shares. The upgrade follows reports that Citi is preparing for its first major overhaul since being formed from the merger of Travelers and Citicorp a decade ago. In his research note, Mr. McDonald said that even modest improvement in management execution and financial results could be positive catalysts for the stock.

title: Driving While Democratic
description: What about the 85 U.S. attorneys who werent fired? Andrew Sullivan cites a month-old statistical study that seems to me to be worth wider examination, indicating that the Justice Department under President Bush may have engaged in political profiling by targeting local Democratic politicians for prosecution. Sullivan writes:

title: Tick, Tick, Tick
description: Its just after 11 a.m. Do you know where your confererence committees are?

title: Reward Offered in Horse Racing Investigation
description: The Hong Kong police offered a reward of $128,000 yesterday for information that would help them find whoever sneaked onto the turf of a horse racing track last week and concealed a device that could fire liquid-filled darts into the stomachs of horses waiting at the starting gate. The device was discovered before it was used.

title: Document: Free Lunch at Park Boathouse?
description: Following an audit released today, City Comptroller William C. Thompson, Jr. is calling on the operators of the Central Park Boathouse to pay a $381,000 tab to the city after failing to report $2.4 million in gross receipts, including nearly $255,302 in free meals to employees and guests.The citys lost share of those meals alone is $40,798 for the two year period ending in December 2005, the audit found. The boathouse operators say some free meals are part of its effort to promote and conduct business. Mr. Thompson responds that the boathouse failed to provide any supporting documentation of that claim and notes that some of the free meals ranged from $800 to $2,600 each.

title: Children Released in Manila Bus Siege
description: The owner of a daycare center gave himself up after taking a busload of his students hostage.

title: San Francisco Murals
description: Images from the urban artscape that adorns the avenues of the city's Mission District.

title: One Method of Economic Development
description: Charles Gargano, a major fundraiser for George E. Pataki who also served as chairman of the states Empire State Development Corporation, billed the agency for a $3,579 trip to Rome during his last months on the job last year and for some $16,000 worth of meals at expensive restaurants, Tom Robbins reports in The Village Voice.

title: China and Darfur
description: Mia Farrow and her son, Ronan Farrow, have an important piece in the Wall Street Journal today about Chinas shameful role in underwriting the genocide in Darfur. China is one of the few countries with real leverage over Sudan (most Sudanese oil exports go to China, and most Sudanese arms come from China). And so it is incredibly important to put pressure on China  and one of its vulnerabilities is its hosting of the Olympics next year.

title: Ritchie Capital Said to Be Near Fund Sale
description: Ritchie Capital Management, the hedge-fund firm founded by a former college football star, A.R. Thane Ritchie, is close to a deal to sell about half of the assets in its main multistrategy fund to Reservoir Capital Group, according to news reports.

title: The [Your Name Here] Hexagon of Saturn
description: Heres your chance to name something much bigger than a street after yourself.

title: Son Provides Doc Some Relief
description: With all this talk about Hoyas and family, theres another famous son in the Georgetown program aside from John Thomson III and Patrick Ewing Jr. The freshman guard Jeremiah Rivers is the son of the Boston Celtics Coach Doc Rivers.

title: Answering Your Questions on Micro-Finance
description: Wow  I was blown away by the response on the Tuesday colum about Kiva (so were the people at Kiva!). Thanks to all who became newly-minted financiers, and let me try to address some of your questions.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about a new strategic proposal by Borders Group, one of the nations largest book retailers, misstated the companys plans for its international segment. It is exploring various alternatives that could eventually lead to the sale or franchising of the majority of its 73 superstores abroad, including those in Britain, Ireland, Australia and New Zealand; it is not closing the stores.

title: TXU Investors Round Up Lobbying Team
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and the Texas Pacific Group have brought in a Texas-size posse of lobbyists in what seems to be an attempt to keep Washington from upsetting their proposed buyout of the energy giant TXU. The Washington-based publication The Hill reports that nearly a dozen lobbyists registered last week to represent the two private equity firms.

title: 2008: The Gallup Poll
description: A common theme among pollsters so far in the 2008 presidential race has been the Republicans lack of enthusiasm about their partys candidate. A recent Gallup/USA Today poll suggests that one prospective candidate might stir things up a bit in the Republican race should he decide to run  former Tennessee Senator Fred Thompson.

title: Chatty Biden Leaves Obama Near-Speechless
description: Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat from Delaware and a candidate for president, is well known in Washington for liking to talk, about many subjects, with much detail and repetition, and at considerable length. One of his rivals for the Democratic presidential nomination  Senator Barack Obama of Illinois  may have paid the price for Mr. Bidens loquaciousness (Note: if you want some fun, trying Googling Biden and loquacious) at a forum for Democratic presidential candidates before a labor audience in Washington this morning.

title: Union Uses Web to Keep Tabs on Blackstone
description: Given Wall Streets fascination with the proposed initial public offering of Blackstone Group, it was probably just a matter of time before someone set up a blog solely dedicated to the (potential) event. But the creator of Inside the Blackstone I.P.O. is not some hardcore private equity wonk  it is the Service Employees International Union, one of the biggest labor organizations in the United States. The anonymous blogs connection with the union was disclosed Wednesday in an S.E.I.U. press release, in which Stephen Lerner, assistant to the president of the Service Employees International Union, questioned the benefits to society of a publicly traded Blackstone:

title: Cadburys Chocolate Craving Returns
description: Cadbury Schweppes has candy on the brain. Prodded by activist investor Nelson Peltz, the British company said earlier this month it would split off its beverage unit to focus on becoming a giant in the confections business. The announcement had many analysts speculating that both pieces of the company could be attractive takeover targets. But Cadbury Schweppes chief executive Todd Stitzer hinted at a different outcome this week, suggesting it would make sense for Cadbury to buy United States-based Hershey, something it unsuccessfully tried to do in 2002.

title: One Last Run
description: The Bracket is delighted to get one final post from our favorite contributor, the former Penn basketball star and Rhodes Scholarship finalist Stephen Danley. Loyal bracket readers will remember Danleys posts before the N.C.A.A. tournament, when he described life as an Ivy League player and the magic of being a senior on Selection Sunday. Below are his thoughts on the end of his playing career and his postcollege options.

title: Science Doesnt Lie, but Politicians Sometimes Do
description: Readers respond to Thomas L. Friedmans March 28 column, How Many Scientists?

title: T Style Design | Op Culture
description: The 1970s are back in original designs and new pieces that graphically evoke the era.

title: Team Clintons Web-Chat, Woman to Woman
description: Note to voters: Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is so family friendly, she is very conscious of not calling during bedtime hours when her senior staff is home putting their kids to bed, according to Mrs. Clintons campaign manager.

title: Bush Quotes Iraqi Bloggers
description: President Bush has discovered bloggers. Iraqi bloggers.

title: An Innocent Misunderstanding
description: Like me, you may not get much fun out of learning that all your life youve misunderstood something important. I think you can have some fun with this. Wanna play?

title: Life Is Evolution
description: Some of you out there who know me better as a rock guitarist (of Queen, et al.) may also know that I have elected to go back to Imperial College London, after an absence of 30 years or so (I was busy!), as a post-graduate student, re-registering for the Ph.D. in astrophysics that I began around 1970. Laying my cards on the table, I am very aware of my essentially amateur status, but eager to catch up on the last 30 years of astronomical research. I get to go to some pretty high-powered seminars, plus enjoy the privilege of being around scientists who are in touch with the most distant surface of the bubble of knowledge that we are pushing out into the observable universe. And this gives me wonderful opportunities for insight.

title: CBS Poll on Iraq and Gonzales
description: Iraq As debate rages among Democrats and Republicans over whether to impose a timetable for withdrawing troops from Iraq, a poll conducted earlier this week by CBS News found that 59 percent of Americans agree with the House bill for a withdrawal date of September 2008.

title: Carbon Offsets: Are They for Real?
description: Dear readers, Im Liz Alderman, the IHTs Business Editor, and I invite you to check out the debut of a new column this week on the Business of Green. In Thursdays paper, Elisabeth Rosenthal writes about how everyone seems to be flying everywhere  a function of busier lives, better air connections and the proliferation of really cheap tickets. The problem, she writes, is that while air travel is the  dirtiest choice of transport  in terms of the emissions that cause global warming, no one has figured out how to square the dramatic rise in air travel with the need to curb carbon dioxide emissions. So wed like to ask: Have any of you purchased carbon offsets to cover your air travel? How did you choose an offset company and how did you research its green projects? If you would like your comments to be considered for publication in the IHT, please remember to include your full name and country. And thank you for coming to our new blog!

title: Budget: Headed North of $121 Billion
description: The New York State budget, weighing in at a hefty $121 billion-plus at last count, is rumbling ahead as the clock ticks down to the weekend deadline before the start of the fiscal year on April 1.

title: How to Avoid Those E-Rod Headlines
description: Everybody seems to have an opinion on Alex Rodriguez, because there are so many issues that complicate the picture: his regular-season success, his postseason failures, his personality, his contract, on and on and on. But say this for the guy: he really does work at his game. I cant think of any player in camp who does as much extra work before practice as Rodriguez.

title: Its Not You, Its Your Apartment
description: Homes can be romantic deal breakers. Some disappointed lovers shared their apartment horror stories with Joyce Wadler in the House & Home section. Share yours.

title: Do the Mets Have Room for Burgos?
description: There is no pitcher more intriguing in Mets camp than Ambiorix Burgos. You can substitute the words electrifying, unpredictable, inconsistent and filthy if you please, too. In the Mets 8-3 loss to Atlanta this afternoon, Burgos may have pitched his way onto the team. He threw two scoreless innings and struck out three. His ERA is still north of 7 but Burgos fills the mid-to-late inning power reliever role left vacant since Duaner Sanchezs shoulder injury turned more serious and Guillermo Mota got suspended for the seasons first 50 games.

title: Wanted: One Successor, Must Be Family Member in Good Standing
description: The reality is that George Steinbrenner will run the Yankees as long as he lives. His health may be failing, but if it is, Steinbrenner might never say so.

title: Bush and Rove Let It Loose, for a Bit
description: President Bush set aside his combative tone over the Iraq emergency war spending bill, to crack jokes before the Radio and Television Correspondents 63rd annual dinner tonight.

title: Prosecutors Assail Gonzales During Meeting
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales endured blunt criticism Tuesday from federal prosecutors who questioned the firings of eight United States attorneys, complained that the dismissals had undermined morale and expressed broader grievances about his leadership, according to people briefed on the discussion.

title: Boat Carrying 100 Haitians Beaches in Florida
