description: MIAMI, March 28  More than 100 Haitian refugees landed on a South Florida beach early Wednesday after their overcrowded sailboat ran aground. One refugee died while trying to get to shore, the authorities said.

title: Children in Group Homes (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Manhattan: Housing Benefits Expanded
description: The City Council passed two bills yesterday that expand tax benefits for Mitchell-Lama developments, which provide housing to families with low and moderate income. The first measure would eliminate the $40,000 cap on the assessed value of a unit qualifying for tax benefits for repairs and improvements. The second bill allows Mitchell-Lama co-op or condo developments to receive tax benefits for repairs and improvements and to finance them through government-subsidized loans. Council Speaker Christine C. Quinn said the bills were intended to stop a loss of middle-income housing.

title: A Garden Miracle: Roses Made Easier
description: I GREW up with roses that were sprayed so heavily with pesticides that I probably risked my life sniffing them.

title: Former Key Aide Testifies Today on Gonzaless Statements
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  D. Kyle Sampson, point man for the removal of eight United States attorneys, has spent almost seven years at the right hand of Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales.

title: For Athletes, the Next Fountain of Youth?
description: The latest curative leap to heal professional athletes and weekend warriors alike may sound like science fiction, but it could transform sports medicine. Some doctors and researchers say that in a few years the use of primitive stem cells from infants umbilical cord blood could grow new knee ligaments or elbow tendons creating a therapy that becomes the vanguard of sports injury repair.

title: Ecuador: Court Renews Power Struggle
description: Congress was in turmoil after Jorge Cevallos, its elected leader, moved to void an effort to expel 57 opposition legislators for trying to block President Rafael Correas plan to rewrite the Constitution to make it harder for Congress to topple presidents. The decision by Mr. Cevallos to accept a ruling by a provincial judge in the dispute over the fired lawmakers throws Mr. Correas plan into doubt. After his surprising announcement, Mr. Cevallos, who swore in the fired lawmakers substitutes just last week, sought refuge in his office, where he was protected by an elite police unit. The struggle to control Congress comes ahead of a referendum next month in which voters will decide whether to convene a constitutional assembly.

title: Exploring a Range of Motions
description: FIRST time for fear, second time for fun is the unofficial motto of this trapeze and acrobatics academy. The brightly colored studio may be short on amenities (no locker room or towels), but its a beacon for rookies who want to overcome their addiction to gravity in small group classes.

title: U.S. Iraq Role Is Called Illegal by Saudi King
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 28  King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia told Arab leaders on Wednesday that the American occupation of Iraq was illegal and warned that unless Arab governments settled their differences, foreign powers like the United States would continue to dictate the regions politics.

title: Manhattan: Groundbreaking for Subway Line
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that it would hold a ceremonial groundbreaking for the Second Avenue subway line on April 12. It will take place at Second Avenue and 99th Street, the southern end of a six-block segment of tunnel that was dug in the 1970s for the long-promised subway line. Plans were first formed in the 1920s and have been periodically revived and abandoned. The transportation authority now plans to spend $3.8 billion on the first phase of the subway, which includes stations on Second Avenue at 96th Street, 86th Street and 72nd Street. Preliminary construction work should begin next month. The line is scheduled to open in 2013.

title: Not a Communist (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Franchise Way to Play the Population Trend
description: Three years ago, Curt M. Maier retired before he turned 50 from his job as a general manager with Air Products and Chemicals, and began looking for entrepreneurial opportunities.

title: Bringing the Double Chin to Heel
description: AFRAID of surgery? Want lift without the lipo? How about a bra  for your face?

title: Smaller Songs, Large in Spirit
description: The Austrian composer Hugo Wolf was advised by Wagner, his idol, to focus on writing large-scale works. But Wolfs talent was for composing intense, theatrical song miniatures, which sometimes fuse striking Wagnerian harmonies with Schumannesque scene painting.

title: The French Way (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Northern Ireland Course Rated No. 1 Outside U.S.
description: Royal County Down in Northern Ireland ousted the Old Course at St. Andrews to top Golf Digest magazines list of the 100 best golf courses outside the United States.

title: Bare-Knuckle Enforcement for Wal-Marts Rules
description: The investigator flew to Guatemala in April 2002 with a delicate mission: trail a Wal-Mart manager around the country to prove he was sleeping with a lower-level employee, a violation of company policy.

title: Hip-Hop Reverberates in a Silent World
description: Things are done differently at the Lexington School for the Deaf in Queens.

title: For Some G.I.s, Less Time at Home, More in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  Army combat troops are likely to have to go back to Iraq with less than a year at home if the Bush administration decides to maintain higher force levels through early next year, the general responsible for preparing forces for overseas deployment said Wednesday.

title: Swindal Divorce Shakes Up Yankee Hierarchy
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 28  George Steinbrenner ate dinner in the cafeteria at Legends Field on Wednesday with his daughter Jessica beside him and her husband, Felix Lopez, next to her. Lopez merrily took out a cellphone and snapped a picture of his wife and his father-in-law. It was one big, happy family.

title: Iran Takes Harder Line in Dispute Over Britons
description: LONDON, March 29  Iran leveled new accusations against Britain on Thursday in the crisis over 15 captured British sailors and marines and withdrew a promise to free a woman sailor, insisting that Britain admit fault before any captives are released.

title: Trenton: Groups Seek to Block Highlands Development
description: A coalition of environmental groups called on Gov. Jon S. Corzine yesterday to declare a moratorium on major development in the environmentally sensitive Highlands area until a state council completes a master plan for development there. Last week, the state commission, established to create the development plan, extended the comment period by five weeks, to May 10. It is the fourth extension on a plan for the 400,000-acre area.

title: Claim Denied: A Horror Story (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Burgos Makes Case for Spot in the Mets Bullpen
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 28  The Atlas Van Lines truck parked outside the Mets clubhouse will depart for Shea Stadium on Friday morning. For an additional cost, the movers may be able to box up all the losses the Mets accumulated this spring and dump them somewhere in South Carolina.

title: In Dark on Bargaining, and Experienced in the Frustrations of Budgeting
description: ALBANY, March 28  Were a little over 80 hours away, said Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, as he convened budget negotiations in hopes of beating the deadline that looms on Sunday.

title: Transcript of Seized Sailors Statement
description: Following is a transcript of a statement by Faye Turney, a captured British sailor, that was broadcast on Iranian state television:

title: Residential Sales
description: Manhattan

title: Sometimes Even Glances Help You Embrace Shape and Space
description: Showcases have long been a fact of life in New York dance. The effect tends to be a somewhat haphazard cramming together of artists chosen by audition. But the 21-year-old Performance Mix Festival has always been a showcase of a different sort, reflecting the personal taste of a director, Karen Bernard, who is herself a practicing performance artist.

title: With a Charity for Soldiers, Youths Make Recycling Pay
description: NORWELL, Mass., March 27  Their bedrooms are strewn with the everyday flotsam of a teenagers life: heaps of unfolded laundry and a bottle of passion red nail polish, muddy soccer cleats and the box for Madden N.F.L. 2002, a video game.

title: Mammals Took Their Sweet Time to Flourish, Study Shows
description: The mass extinction that wiped out dinosaurs and other life 65 million years ago apparently did not, contrary to conventional wisdom, immediately clear the way for the rise of todays mammals.

title: Iran Shows Video of Britons as Dispute Heats Up
description: LONDON, March 28  The dispute with Iran over Britains captured sailors escalated sharply on Wednesday when Britain froze all bilateral business with Iran, and the Iranians displayed some British prisoners on state television  an act condemned by the Foreign Office here as completely unacceptable.

title: A New Cable to Connect
description: Q. What is HDMI?

title: Top Prize for Rogers, Iconoclastic Architect
description: Three decades after his Pompidou Center in Paris turned the architecture world upside down and brought him global fame, the British architect Richard Rogers has been named the 2007 winner of the Pritzker Prize, the professions highest honor.

title: 70 Killed in Wave of Revenge in Northern Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, March 28  One of the bloodiest chapters in Iraqs sectarian strife unfolded over the past two days in the northern city of Tal Afar where gunmen, some of them apparently police officers, participated in the revenge killings of scores of Sunnis in the aftermath of a huge double suicide bombing in a Shiite area.

title: For the Record
description: An obituary yesterday about Paul C. Lauterbur, who won a Nobel prize for developing M.R.I. technology into a way to look inside living things, misspelled the surname of a professor of physics at the University of Illinois who commented on his work. He is Charles Slichter, not Schlichter.

title: W.H.O. Urges Circumcision to Reduce Spread of AIDS
description: The World Health Organization officially recommended circumcision as a way to prevent heterosexual transmission of the AIDS virus yesterday, setting the stage for donor agencies to begin paying for the operation.

title: For the Record
description: A report in the Vital Signs column in Science Times on March 20, about exercise and memory, misstated part of the name of a brain region associated with memory loss. It is the dentate gyrus, not dentate gyrate.

title: Garden Q.&A.
description: The New Vine on the Block

title: Brooklyn: Court Papers Detail Mob Killing
description: A captain in the Genovese crime family and his son participated in the 2005 slaying of a mob soldier whose body was found in a car trunk in New Jersey during his federal extortion trial, according to court papers released yesterday as part of an indictment. The captain, Michael Coppola; his wife, Linda Coppola; and the son, Louis Rizzo Jr., were charged with conspiracy to use false identity papers. Mr. Coppola was apprehended this month after being a fugitive for more than a decade, prosecutors said. A letter submitted by prosecutors details other crimes the two men are accused of, and describes a recorded conversation between them about the gun that was used to murder the soldier, Lawrence Ricci. John Buretta, an assistant United States attorney, said he expected additional charges to be filed.

title: More Than 100 Killed in Wave of Attacks in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD, March 29  More than 100 people were killed in a series of attacks around Iraq on Thursday, including two suicide bombings that struck crowded markets during the weeks busiest shopping hours, the authorities said.

title: The Sermon on the Tapes
description: Dearly beloved, let us bow our heads and mourn the passing of so many beloved media storage formats: Home-movie film reels (1932-1975). Floppy disks (1969-2002). Eight-track tapes (3:15 p.m. on Aug. 3, 1965, to around dinnertime on Nov. 5, 1988).

title: The City Is Pushing Recycling Again, and With New Bins
description: Looking to boost sagging recycling rates, the city has begun a test program to provide waste bins for paper, cans and bottles in public spaces, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: Class Is in Session
description: STRETCHING, like flossing, is something many of us feel guilty about not doing often enough. When we do stretch, were likely to hold positions for as long as we can take it  like masochists.

title: Amelia S. Haygood, 87, Who Founded Classical Record Label, Dies
description: Amelia S. Haygood, a former clinical psychologist who more than three decades ago parlayed her love of classical music into the independent record label Delos, died on March 19 at her home in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 87.

title: An External Drive With Speed and Style, in Black and Flashes of Electric Blue
description: As with most of the current crop of external drives, the Toshiba U.S.B. 2.0 Portable External Hard Drive is as much about style as it is about substance.

title: Illinois Questions Ratings Agencies Gave to Utilities
description: Moodys Investors Service and Standard & Poors, the big credit ratings agencies, appear to be manipulating their reports to help the largest electric utilities in Illinois charge higher prices for power, the states attorney general asserted in papers filed yesterday.

title: Income Gap Is Widening, Data Shows
description: Income inequality grew significantly in 2005, with the top 1 percent of Americans  those with incomes that year of more than $348,000  receiving their largest share of national income since 1928, analysis of newly released tax data shows.

title: Flourishes of Hamburg, With Muscle and Finesse
description: The tradition of solid, efficient and often finely polished radio orchestras that still thrives in Europe never quite took off in the United States, despite Toscaninis efforts in that direction with the NBC Symphony. That may explain why there were so many empty seats at Carnegie Hall when one of the better German radio ensembles, the NDR Symphony Orchestra, of Hamburg, played high-energy concerts on Monday and Tuesday evenings, with Christoph von Dohnanyi on the podium.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Saturday about the subway cars purchased by New York City in 1949 in anticipation of construction of a Second Avenue line referred imprecisely to the outcome of those plans. Although no tunnels were dug with the $500 million earmarked in the 1950s for subway construction, some tunnel segments were indeed dug in the 1970s, after the plans were revived.

title: Chief Warns Automakers That U.A.W. Wont Budge on Health Care or Jobs Bank
description: DETROIT, March 28  Months before contract talks with Detroits automakers are set to begin, the United Automobile Workers union has seemingly declared two crucial issues off-limits for bargaining.

title: Room to Improve
description: Q.How can I strip an old metal office chair?

title: Zimbabwean Leaders Accused of Abducting Opponents
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 28  Hundreds of Zimbabwean political and civic advocates have been abducted and severely beaten in recent days by unidentified assailants, government critics said Wednesday, in dead-of-night assaults that appear to be part of a new government campaign to smother rising unrest.

title: Sports Briefing
description: BASKETBALL

title: Compassion, Indifference and Several Other Things Too
description: Robyn Hitchcocks longtime fans cherish his whimsical free-associating banter between songs nearly as much as the catchy, surreal songs themselves. But on Tuesday night at the Knitting Factory, in an unusual burst of straightforwardness, he explained the artistic strategy he has been using since he arrived in 1977 as the leader of the Soft Boys, a neo-psychedelic band in the punk-rock era.

title: Waiting Wears on a Defenseman
description: Parked next to the door to the Devils practice rink in West Orange, N.J., Monday afternoon was a bus, its hatches open so players could toss in their luggage for the trip to Long Island. Richard Matvichuk would stay behind. He would shower, dress and head home.

title: No Bonuses for Top G.M. Executives
description: DETROIT, March 28  General Motors, which significantly improved its financial performance in 2006 yet did not earn a profit, said on Wednesday that for a second consecutive year, it would not pay cash bonuses to top executives.

title: Violence Kills at Least 30 in Somalias Capital
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 29  Any hope for a quick peace in Mogadishu, Somalias turbulent capital, was snuffed out today when Ethiopian troops stormed into the center of the city, setting off clashes that killed more than 30 people.

title: 'Steamroller' in Albany Learns How to Concede
description: ALBANY, March 28  Gov. Eliot Spitzer brought a hard-charging style to Albany, taking on adversaries personally and directly, even lambasting lawmakers in their home districts. But the State Legislature knows how to play hardball too, and the rookie governor is having to meet them halfway on his first budget.

title: Colleges Hiring Lenders to Field Queries on Aid
description: The telephone number looks like any other university extension. And when students call with questions about financial aid, the recorded voice at the other end says, Thank you for calling Texas Tech Universitys Student Financial Center.

title: Morton Kornreich, 82, U.J.A. Leader, Dies
description: Morton A. Kornreich, a former national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal and chairman of the UJA-Federation of New York, died Tuesday in Boca Raton, Fla. He was 82 and lived in White Plains.

title: Manhattan: Decision on Subway Chief Nears
description: The leading candidate for the presidency of New York City Transit, which runs the citys subway and bus systems, is a former transit executive who has worked in New York and in Philadelphia, according to officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The candidate, Howard H. Roberts Jr., 67, ran New Yorks bus system in the mid-1980s and became the second-ranking executive of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority. Mr. Roberts said yesterday that he had not been offered the job, but that he was very interested. The previous president, Lawrence G. Reuter, resigned in February. A decision is expected in the next few days.

title: Gone Parkin
description: Los Angeles

title: Leaving Pakistan, a Seasoned Ambassador Prepares for Yet Another Turbulent Job: Iraq
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  Ryan C. Crocker said farewell to the American Embassy in Pakistan on Wednesday and flew to Baghdad for his swearing-in Thursday as the new ambassador to Iraq. He faces a political and diplomatic battlefield in which sectarian and terrorist killing dominates daily concerns of an Iraqi government that has only tenuous control.

title: Fed Chairman Says Uncertainties Have Grown
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  The chairman of the Federal Reserve acknowledged today that uncertainties about the economic outlook have increased somewhat in recent weeks and that turmoil in the market for subprime home mortgages has created severe financial problems for many individuals and families.

title: Some Dead Sopranos Come Back to Tell Tales
description: Just as sure as the sun rises and taxes are levied, one can be guaranteed that on The Sopranos, HBOs hit mobster series, someone will be killed.

title: What a Precocious Girl Needs
description: IM not the most winsome of women. There are no muslin bags of potpourri perfuming my drawers. Ive never strewn my bath water with petals, and the sole scented candle I have ever owned was lighted once: a vain attempt to veil my bulldogs flatulence with French vanilla. I even hate Audrey Hepburn. Give me a world-weary femme fatale over a doe-eyed ingnue any day. In short, Im not the target customer for Leontine, the latest outpost in Kyung Lees quirkily girlish mini-empire.

title: Pakistani Base Is Attacked by Suicide Bomber
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 29  A suicide bomber blew himself up in an attack today on a military training area in Punjab province, killing one soldier and wounding seven others, military officials said.

title: New Justice System Is a Work in Progress
description: In the last few weeks, the two most famous prisoners at the Guantnamo Bay naval base responded to proceedings against them by admitting their guilt.

title: Plea Deal for Man Whose Wife Drove Off Cliff
description: A man whose wife drove the family minivan off a cliff at Bear Mountain State Park last year, killing herself and injuring their two children, who were strapped into their seats, pleaded guilty yesterday to endangering the welfare of a child in a plea agreement that could keep him from serving time in jail, prosecutors said.

title: Revealing the Younger Haydn in a Twin Bill of Brothers
description: If sibling rivalry existed between Joseph Haydn and his younger brother Michael, there was from the start little doubt about the better man. In the last years of the 18th century Joseph was the most famous musician in Europe. Michaels reputation within the Salzburg-Vienna axis was distinguished yet close to home. His attachment to Salzburgs religious and political establishment  from which young Mozart fled to make his way in the world  lasted a lifetime. Mozarts father called Michael lazy and a drunk, but this was after he had beaten out his son for an important organist post.

title: Bloomberg Details Citys Antipoverty Experiment
description: Seeking new solutions to New Yorks vexingly high poverty rates, the city is moving ahead with a bold antipoverty experiment that will pay poor families up to $5,000 a year to meet targets like exemplary school attendance, going for medical checkups or holding down a full-time job, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said today.

title: Gentrification Blues: Requiem for a Cozy, Unassuming Rock Club
description: On the second-to-last Saturday night of its existence, the Lower East Side rock club Sin- looked just like any other Lower East Side rock club. A knot of smokers gathered around the door. Inside, past the hand-stamp girl and the sound booth, the line at the bar was three deep as men and women scrambled for $5 Yuenglings. Onstage Nous Non Plus, who sing in the style of a 60s French pop group, were performing. A few people danced, badly.

title: Raw but Welcoming, a Space for Lofty Ideas
description: San Francisco

title: A Radio Station Just for You
description: FOR all the talk about satellite radio, the most vibrant frontier in radio may be the Web. Many traditional AM and FM stations have begun streaming on the Internet, along with hundreds of smaller online-only operators. Even subscription download services like Napster, Rhapsody and Urge from MTV have preprogrammed radio for users who are not in the mood to hunt for tracks.

title: Zimbabwe Police Release Opposition Leader
description: JOHANNESBURG, March 29  The police in Zimbabwe today released Morgan Tsvangirai, one of the countrys most prominent opposition leaders, after detaining him and about 20 other members of his political party, the Movement for Democratic Change, on Wednesday.

title: Libel Lawsuit by WPP Chief Is Settled for $235,000
description: LONDON, March 28  Martin Sorrell, chief executive of the WPP Group, the advertising and marketing company based in London, accepted 120,000 ($235,415), on Wednesday to settle a lawsuit over libel complaints that included an e-mail message calling him a mad dwarf and an Internet blog linking him to money laundering.

title: Progress Energy Lowers Its Incentive Targets
description: Close readers of executive pay filings in recent years have noticed a tendency among companies to reward managers based on performance that is said to have exceeded their peers. But with so many companies contending that their executives performance beat their rivals  most often falling in the 75th percentile  corporate America began to resemble Lake Wobegon, where all the children are above average in intelligence.

title: Whats on Thursday Night
description: 8 P.M. (Turner Classic Movies) PRIVATE SCREENINGS: JANE FONDA  Ms. Fonda, who has been alternately revered and reviled, discusses her life and career with Robert Osborne. From growing up in one of Hollywoods royal families and taking home two Oscars to making her infamous trip to Hanoi during the Vietnam War, Ms. Fonda has been a sometimes divisive but always compelling figure. The film Barefoot in the Park (1967) follows at 9 p.m. The romantic comedy about newlyweds in New York, based on the play by Neil Simon, also stars Robert Redford (above with Ms. Fonda).

title: Merck Cancels Work on a New Insomnia Medication
description: Two weeks after the Food and Drug Administration issued safety warnings about widely used sleeping pills, the drug maker Merck canceled a venture into the shifting market for insomnia medications.

title: Equipment Problems Delay Plan for Cameras on Buses
description: A $5.2 million program to equip city buses with security cameras has been delayed because tests of the digital camera system have turned up gaps in the recorded images, transit officials said yesterday.

title: Report Says Interior Official Overrode Work of Scientists
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  A top-ranking official overseeing the Fish and Wildlife Service at the Interior Department rode roughshod over agency scientists, and decisions made on her watch may not survive court challenges, investigators within the Interior Department have found.

title: French Swimmer Stars in Middle Distances
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, March 29  Laure Manaudou was 14 and she had just won a silver medal in the 100-meter backstroke at the 2002 French championships behind Roxana Maracineanu, the world champion backstroker.

title: Under Ominous Cloud Formations, Ominous Anomie
description: If you are not interested in human behavior, why write plays?

title: South Korea Is Looking Nervously Over Both Shoulders
description: SEOUL, South Korea, March 28  As South Korean and American negotiators huddle in Seoul for trade talks this week, corporate South Korea is grappling with a troubling question: How can the country avoid being crushed by competition from low-cost China and high-tech Japan?

title: Text of 2nd Letter Attributed to Seized Sailor
description: Following is the text of a letter that Iranian authorities said Faye Turney, a captured British sailor, wrote to members of the British Parliament. This is the second letter attributed to Ms. Turney in two days; the Press Association news agency of Britain distributed this text:

title: Arabs and U.N. Chief Press Sudans Leader to End Darfur Crisis
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Thursday, March 29  The president of Sudan, Omar Hassan al-Bashir, came under pressure Thursday from Arab leaders to end the crisis in Darfur.

title: Young Sikh Men Get Haircuts, Annoying Their Elders
description: AMRITSAR, India  The day Jugraj Singh, at age 14, abandoned his turban and had a lifetimes growth of hair cut off, he collected the tresses from the barbershop floor and packed them into a plastic bag. Then he threw the bag into a river flowing out of Amritsar, the spiritual home of the Sikhs.

title: Owners Wont Shift Overtime Kickoff
description: PHOENIX, March 28  National Football League owners on Wednesday postponed discussion of a proposal to move the overtime kickoff to the 35-yard line from the 30, a change that the competition committee said would alleviate the advantage a team received by winning the overtime coin toss.

title: Cunning and Idealism (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Protests Prompt Thai Coup Leader to Request State of Emergency
description: BANGKOK, March 28  The general who led the coup in Thailand last September on Wednesday asked his appointed prime minister to impose a state of emergency in Bangkok as public opposition to the government grew louder.

title: Making Lyrics a Monologue and Melodies High Drama
description: With all due respect to James Taylor, you havent heard anyone dig as insistently into the marrow of his song Fire and Rain until youve heard Betty Buckley perform it in her new show, Singin for My Supper. With her longtime musical director, the jazz pianist Kenny Werner, Ms. Buckley has refined a sprawling stylistic fusion of jazz and theater singing that resists categories. Iconoclastic and spellbinding, it is what it is.

title: E-Mail Shows Roves Role in Fate of Prosecutors
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  Almost every Wednesday afternoon, advisers to President Bush gather to strategize about putting his stamp on the federal courts and the United States attorneys offices.

title: Deadly Tornados in Colorado and Oklahoma
description: Four people died in Texas, Colorado and Oklahoma after tornados swept through their areas last night as part of a storm system that also brought violent weather to at least three other states, officials said today. More damage from the storms could be uncovered throughout today as officials assess the extent of destruction left by the 65 tornados that rolled through six states on Wednesday.

title: A Dermatologist Shortage (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Sometimes, Its Better Not to Clean the Image Sensor on Your Camera
description: Devices for removing dust from the image sensor of a digital single-lens reflex camera are usually promoted by emphasizing the need for regular cleaning. Delkin, however, suggests that its SensorScope is mainly intended to limit cleaning.

title: Keeping Up With Tiger Woods by Swinging a Remote
description: I need some liniment for my sore muscles, a masseuse to work on my stiff shoulder and a golf pro to straighten out my swing, but that doesnt mean Ive been on the golf course. Instead, Ive been playing Tiger Woods PGA Tour 07, a game from EA Redwood Shores for the Nintendo Wii.

title: Located in Hospital, DNA Clears Buffalo Man Convicted in 80s Rapes
description: BUFFALO, March 28  The evidence, genetic material from two rapes stored on microscopic slides, had languished in a hospital drawer for more than 20 years, as the man convicted of the crimes languished behind bars. Numerous times, including four in the last two months, the authorities issued subpoenas for the material, only to be told that it was not in the hospital.

title: Ousted Judge in Pakistan Urges Musharraf to Respect Judiciary
description: RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, March 28  In his first public appearance since he was suspended as chief justice nearly three weeks ago, Iftikhar Mohammad Chaudhry insisted Wednesday that the government respect and observe the independence of judiciary.

title: For the Record
description: The Cheering Section article in sports on Sunday, about an authors contention that the Yankees have had 14 or 15 captains in their history instead of 11, misstated the publication date of a newspaper article about the team, and misspelled the surnames of two players mentioned in that article. The article from The Evening Star in Washington was published on April 20, 1903  not 1902. The players were Dave Fultz, not Fults, and Jesse Tannehill, not Tannebill.

title: Ransom A. Myers, 54, Dies; Expert on Loss of Fish Stocks
description: Ransom A. Myers, a fisheries biologist whose work brought wide attention to collapsing fish stocks around the world, died on Tuesday in Halifax, Nova Scotia. He was 54.

title: Lebanon Revokes Visa of Israeli Journalist
description: BEIRUT, March 29  Lebanon has revoked the visa it granted a Washington-based Israeli journalist traveling with Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on his current Middle East tour, and she was unable to accompany the United Nations party to Beirut on Thursday night.

title: A More Precise Version of Your Chariot Awaits
description: For close to a century, schoolchildren have been paraded by the Monteleone chariot, one of the Metropolitan Museums most prized objects. Teachers explained to them how in 1902 a farmer in a remote Italian village accidentally unearthed the remains of a tomb, which held the pieces of this 2,600-year-old Etruscan chariot.

title: Brooklyn: Court Papers Detail Mob Killing
description: A captain in the Genovese crime family and his son participated in the 2005 slaying of a mob soldier whose body was found in a car trunk in New Jersey during his federal extortion trial, according to court papers released yesterday as part of an indictment. The captain, Michael Coppola; his wife, Linda Coppola; and the son, Louis Rizzo Jr., were charged with conspiracy to use false identity papers. Mr. Coppola was apprehended this month after being a fugitive for more than a decade, prosecutors said. A letter submitted by prosecutors details other crimes the two men are accused of, and describes a recorded conversation between them about the gun that was used to murder the soldier, Lawrence Ricci. John Buretta, an assistant United States attorney, said he expected additional charges to be filed.

title: Connecticut Governor Proposes Limit on Annual Increases in Property Taxes
description: HARTFORD, March 28  Gov. M. Jodi Rell is proposing to limit municipalities in Connecticut to a 3 percent annual increase in property taxes. The governors plan comes nearly two months after her initial budget proposal, which included a 10 percent income tax increase and large increases in education spending.

title: Service Benefits Kids (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx: Six Officers Injured in Collision
description: Six police officers were treated for minor injuries yesterday after their three police vehicles collided on the Bronx River Parkway just south of the Pelham Bay exit, the authorities said. The collision occurred about 9 a.m. as the officers responded to a call for help from officers chasing a driver, Harold Boyce of Third Avenue in the Bronx, who had run a stop sign at East 236th Street and Bronx Boulevard and refused to stop for a police car, the police said. They said he then attempted to drive south on the Bronx River Parkway, where his car struck the police car. No injuries resulted from that collision, and Mr. Boyce, who tried to run, was chased down and arrested. The injured officers were treated at Jacobi Medical Center, the police said, and Mr. Boyce was charged with resisting arrest, driving with an expired license and reckless driving.

title: Witness Intimidation Is Charged in Sean Bell Case
description: The Port Authority police yesterday accused a Brooklyn man of intimidating a witness who emerged at the 11th hour to testify before the Sean Bell grand jury.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a vote by the Senate to support a date for withdrawing troops from Iraq misstated the withdrawal provision in the Senate legislation. Beginning a pullout of American troops within 120 days of the measures enactment is a requirement, not a goal. Completing the pullout by March 31, 2008, is a nonbinding goal of the legislation. (Go to Article)

title: Child Wants Cellphone; Reception Is Mixed
description: TO her parents amusement, Hannah Stacks, a third grader in Rye, N.Y., started asking for her own cellphone at age 6. To their consternation, she never stopped. Last fall, after a psychologist suggested tracking her behavior, Hannah, at the sprightly age of 8, got her phone as a reward for not being mean to her little sister for 30 days.

title: In Triumph and Humiliation, Harricks Still a Bruin at Heart
description: ANAHEIM, Calif., March 27  In the long and storied history of U.C.L.A. basketball, only two head coaches have won a national championship.

title: Communication in the Face of Terror
description: One of the glaring shortfalls during the 9/11 attacks  the fumbling attempt by federal agencies to communicate with one another in a crisis  remains stuck at ground zero. Five years after the governments law enforcement and disaster agencies vowed to develop a unified wireless network to put the 81,000 federal agents in sync, a scathing inspector generals report finds the plan fractured, disjointed and facing high risk of failure.

title: Mergers and Acquisitions No Longer Shock Japanese
description: TOKYO, March 24  One of the hottest new shows on Japanese television is called Vulture, though it is hardly a nature program. It is about a fictional New York investment fund that buys ailing Japanese companies and imposes harsh American-style management changes.

title: Street Violence by Paris Youths Intrudes Again Into French Politics
description: PARIS, March 28  Frances top presidential candidates seized on a new campaign issue on Wednesday after the police fought gangs of youths for seven hours at a railroad station here. Stores were destroyed, the pall of tear gas filled the station, Gare du Nord, and 13 people were arrested.

title: Senate Passes War Spending Bill With Iraq Deadline
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  Issuing a stinging challenge to President Bush, the Senate approved a spending measure today that provided more than $97.5 billion for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan but ordered troop withdrawals from Iraq to begin within 120 days and set a goal of removing most armed forces within a year.

title: Intel Plans Faster Chips That Also Save Power
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 28  Intel said Wednesday that it was on track or even ahead of schedule in developing a new generation of chips that would achieve a significant increase in performance without consuming more power.

title: Officers Trial in Killing Feeds Case Against City
description: In the courtroom where Lt. Shamik Walton is on trial, the charge is manslaughter, the stakes are 15 years in prison and the trouble is his alone.

title: Garca Mrquezs Shiner Ends Its 31 Years of Quietude
description: The feud between the Colombian writer Gabriel Garca Mrquez and the Peruvian writer Mario Vargas Llosa, onetime best of friends, had all the elements of a literary classic: accusations of betrayal, jealousy and adultery, and a brutal encounter 31 years ago when things turned bloody.

title: Scientists Say Sharks Death Could Be Tied to Feeding Tube
description: ATLANTA, March 28  A young whale shark that sank to the bottom of its tank at the Georgia Aquarium this year and died had been forcibly fed for months, a practice that may have punctured its stomach and caused an infection that led to its death, scientists said Wednesday.

title: Israel Fires on Gaza Palestinians, Saying Rocket Attack Was Near
description: JERUSALEM, March 28  The Israeli Army fired into the northern Gaza Strip on Wednesday, aiming at a Palestinian militant cell about to launch a rocket attack, an army spokeswoman said, the first time that Israel has responded to rocket attacks since a shaky cease-fire took effect in November.

title: Bush Withdraws a Nominee Dogged by a 2004 Donation
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  The Bush administration withdrew its nomination of a Missouri businessman as ambassador to Belgium on Wednesday after it became clear that Democratic senators were lining up against him because he had helped finance attacks on Senator John Kerrys war record during the 2004 presidential race.

title: Porsche Makes a Bid for the Rest of Volkswagen
description: Porsche made a bid for Volkswagen that values the carmaker at 35.8 billion euros ($47.7 billion), a low offer aimed at leaving Porsche with a controlling stake rather than full ownership.

title: A Garden of Many Delights for Three Alt-Rock Bands
description: Like were really gonna not play the one song you know. A request had come from somewhere in the crowd, and Brian Aubert, leader of the Silversun Pickups, was responding to it with a scoff. That one song is Lazy Eye, and it is probably the reason the band got this gig, opening for Snow Patrol and OK Go at Madison Square Garden.*

title: Why We Banned the Play About Iraq (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Strat-O-Matic Owner Makes a Move Toward an Investor
description: For 45 years, Hal Richman and his family have controlled Strat-O-Matic, which began with the baseball board game he invented as a teenager and grew into a small empire of sports board, video and Internet games. Now the Richmans are seeking an investor to buy a significant part of the company.

title: Up in the Attic, New Millennium Style
description: WHEN Elizabeth and Mordechai Kubany bought their house in Maplewood, N.J., eight years ago, its attic was dark and forbidding. It was just a storage space, Ms. Kubany said, but it had the ceiling of a cathedral. You could sense that the potential was enormous.

title: The Vanishing Arts at Ground Zero
description: For all the practical noises being made downtown, all the talk of cost overruns and tight schedules and difficult footprints, it comes down to this: only one arts institution still plans to settle at ground zero. The city has announced that the Signature Theater Company will not be part of the planned performing arts center. The center will have only one permanent occupant, the Joyce Theater, which presents dance. Certainly there are important practical issues here  escalating construction estimates and complicated structural problems. But this, like so much else that has gone on at ground zero, is the result of a failure of political will in a former governor and a state administration that has now been scattered to the winds.

title: Medical School in New Jersey Selects Leader
description: Dr. William F. Owen Jr., chancellor of the University of Tennessee Health Science Center, was approved yesterday as the new president of New Jerseys financially troubled state medical school.

title: Who Needs a Narrative? Just Look Good and Bang on Stuff
description: Be, the latest low-budget spectacle trying to tap into the seemingly inexhaustible tourist market for banging on trash cans in unison, seems like a collection of loose parts stitched together to create an indestructible global blockbuster. Produced by the Israeli company Mayumana, it starts with elements of Stomp (like drumming on ones chest), throws in some from Blue Man Group (giant tubes) and then adds sex appeal. It will probably run forever. (I just hope Im not quoted on the front of the theater.)

title: Rutgers Assistant Has Experience and History of Success
description: PISCATAWAY, N.J., March 28  Marianne Stanley has not received much credit for Rutgers surprising run into the Final Four, which is fine with her. She understands that the role of an assistant coach is not about visibility or accolades, even when the assistant has a rsum that few people in the sport can match.

title: City Wants Statue of Liberty Ferry Service to Expand Harbor Routes
description: In an effort to expand ferry service beyond the major tourist attractions to other parts of New York Harbor, city officials made an attempt yesterday to insert themselves into the federal governments process of choosing a Statue of Liberty ferry operator.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about a vote by the Senate to support a date for withdrawing troops from Iraq misstated the withdrawal provision in the Senate legislation. Beginning a pullout of American troops within 120 days of the measures enactment is a requirement, not a goal. Completing the pullout by March 31, 2008, is a nonbinding goal of the legislation.

title: Ex-Aide Says Gonzales Was Involved in Firings
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  The former chief of staff to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales testified today that contrary to Mr. Gonzaless earlier assertions, the attorney general was involved in discussions to fire United States attorneys.

title: A Video Camera That Wont Be a Burden to Carry to the Reunion
description: The checklist of things to pack when shooting video of the family reunion usually includes extra batteries and extra tapes. Sonys new Handycam models will help push those tapes closer to obsolescence. Like many new camcorders they record straight to a hard drive, providing up to 60 gigabytes of room.

title: Manhattan: Hospital Settles Federal Claim
description: Cabrini Medical Center agreed yesterday to pay $3.4 million to settle a federal claim that it improperly billed the New York State Medicaid program for operation of its detoxification unit, federal prosecutors said. The payment related to the operation of the unit from 1995 through 1999, said Michael J. Garcia, the United States attorney in Manhattan. Cabrini did not admit wrongdoing, and the hospitals lawyer, Howard Rogatnick, declined to comment yesterday.

title: National Organization for Women Endorses Clinton
description: The National Organization for Women endorsed Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York, for president and pledged to raise money for her from its 500,000 members. The groups effort on Mrs. Clintons behalf, called Making History with Hillary, is intended to build on the campaigns effort to appeal to women and ultimately draw the greatest shares of votes and donations by women for any presidential candidate in 2008.

title: Depletion of Sharks Hurts Ecosystem, Study Says
description: For years, conservationists have warned about over fishing of large sharks in the northwestern Atlantic, as the demand for meat and fins, coupled with slow growth and reproduction rates of many species, has caused sharp declines in populations of hammerheads, duskies and other sharks.

title: Troop Rise Aids Iraqis, Bush Says, Citing Bloggers
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  President Bush has discovered bloggers. Iraqi bloggers.

title: The Look of Very Old Money
description: BACK in the 1960s, Bulgari, the Italian fine jewelry company, revived a millenniums-old Roman tradition of incorporating coins into jewelry as a signature look in its own heavy gold necklaces, bracelets and rings. It is a charming bit of aesthetic currency that the company continues to revisit in its designs today.

title: Davis Cup Next Week, Roddick Plays It Safe
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 28  A knifing forehand volley by Andy Murray sent a sharp pain through the Sony Ericsson Open on Wednesday.

title: Its an April Fools Paradise
description: MY husband came out to the front porch where I was reading one day last week, shot a covert look over his shoulder and whispered, May I speak to you inside?

title: Killings in First Quarter Drop to One a Day, Lowest Rate in Decades
description: The recent fatal shootings of two auxiliary police officers and a restaurant worker in Greenwich Village hark back to a time when New York Citys streets were far more deadly. But the citys year-to-date homicide rate is at its lowest point since before the Police Department started tracking crime using current record-keeping techniques in 1962.

title: Audit Shows Underpaying by Operators of Boathouse
description: The backdrop for countless wedding photographs and film scenes, the Central Park Boathouse and the parks adjacent lake evoke romance and tranquillity, down to the elegant dishes served at the restaurant and the singing gondoliers who ply the waters.

title: Immigrants Becoming U.S. Citizens at High Rate
description: Legal immigrants in the United States have opted to become American citizens in historically high numbers in the last decade, according to a study published yesterday by the Pew Hispanic Center.

title: Brooklyn: Hospitalized Prisoner Is Shot After Assault, Police Say
description: A hospitalized prisoner at Kings County Hospital Center was shot by a police officer last night after he assaulted the officer with a bed rail, the police said. The prisoner, whose identity was not released, was arrested on March 26 in connection with an assault. Last night, shortly before 11, the prisoner broke off the plastic bed rail and hit the on-duty officer in the head, the police said, and the officer then shot the patient, who was taken to the operating room. The officer was treated for lacerations.

title: Afghanistan: Kabul Suicide Attack Kills 4
description: A suicide bomber on foot detonated his explosives close to the car of a high-ranking Afghan intelligence official and near a crowded bazaar in Kabul. The official was not hurt, but four civilians were killed.

title: Study Says Junk Food Still Dominates Youth TV
description: CAN television ads aimed at children finally go on a healthy diet?

title: New Legislation Protects Delivery Workers Who Use Bikes
description: Businesses that use bicycle delivery workers will have to give them helmets, require that they wear them and ensure that the bikes are safe, under legislation signed into law yesterday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Manhattan: Decision on Subway Chief Nears
description: The leading candidate for the presidency of New York City Transit, which runs the citys subway and bus systems, is a former transit executive who has worked in New York and in Philadelphia, according to officials at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority. The candidate, Howard H. Roberts Jr., 67, ran New Yorks bus system in the mid-1980s and became the second-ranking executive of the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority. He said yesterday that he had not had a job offer, but that he was very interested. The previous president, Lawrence G. Reuter, resigned in February.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: A New Book Club Pick by Oprah

title: Another Phone With Video and a Vowel-Conserving Name
description: First there was the smash-hit Razr. Then Motorola came up with the less popular and even more weirdly named Slvr, Pebl and Krzr.

title: Mountaintop Rescue
description: Mountaintop mining is a cheap and ruthlessly efficient way to mine coal: soil and rock are scraped away by enormous machines to expose the buried coal seam, then dumped down the mountainside into the valleys and streams below.

title: ... Having a Great Detox
description: IN the weeks before Tara Conner handed over her crown as Miss USA, she talked to television reporters about her stay at a treatment center for drug addiction and alcoholism. At the insistence of Donald Trump, an owner of the beauty competition, Ms. Conner had sought treatment at the Caron center in Wernersville, Pa., a former resort hotel set on a pastoral 110 acres.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 28, 2007

title: Manageable Threats Seen by Fed Chief
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  Ben S. Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, said Wednesday that he did not expect the escalating problems in the mortgage lending business to spread to the rest of the economy, but noted that the Fed had given itself the flexibility to adjust interest rates should the outlook change for better or for worse.

title: Its Not You, Its Your Apartment
description: DATING is fraught with disappointments, so you can imagine how delighted a single woman might be to find someone like Albert Podell  particularly after she Googles him and learns how rich he is. Last year, Mr. Podell, a 70-year-old lawyer, gave N.Y.U. Law School $2.9 million. He goes out four nights a week, to the opera, symphony or theater. He is well read. He says he has traveled to 162 countries.

title: For the Record
description: A picture with a report in the National Briefing column on Saturday about a revelation by Fife Symington, the former governor of Arizona, that he saw a U.F.O. in 1997 was published in error in some copies. The photograph showed Gov. Ernie Fletcher of Kentucky, not Mr. Symington.

title: Pacman Joness Bio Needs Some Changes
description: He is pro footballs most notorious player. Not the best, not the most popular and not the most famous, but definitely the most infamous.

title: For the Record
description: An essay in Science Times on Tuesday about the role eunuchs have played in history  a reflection prompted by the authors prostate cancer treatment, which resulted in chemical castration  referred imprecisely to one person who was a eunuch. He was St. Ignatius of Constantinople. (Other SS. Ignatius were not known to be eunuchs.)

title: Google, Online Ad Giant, Looks at Radio and TV
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 28  If there were any doubts about the scope of Googles ambitions in the advertising world, one of its recent job postings should dispel them: It seeks a head of national TV sales to help build a world-class national TV advertising sales team.

title: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  With both houses of Congress now firmly on record in favor of withdrawing from Iraq, President Bush vowed Wednesday not to negotiate a timetable with Democrats, and a confrontation appeared inevitable as each side prepared to blame the other for delays in providing money for the war.

title: Democrats Are Building on Unity Over Iraq Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  No one has seemed more surprised by the Democrats success in pushing an exit strategy for Iraq than the Democrats.

title: Nets Find Right Formula to Help in Playoff Push
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., March 28  If the Nets are to make the playoffs, and do anything noteworthy once they get there, they showed Wednesday night exactly what it would take: staunch defense and an offense committed to attacking the basket.

title: As Forbes Endorses Giuliani, Giuliani Endorses a Flat Tax
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani accepted the endorsement of Steve Forbes yesterday and embraced Mr. Forbess signature issue, saying he liked the idea of a flat tax  something Mr. Giuliani denounced when Mr. Forbes was running for president.

title: Jazz Listings
description: JAZZ

title: Two Innocents Abroad, With TV Cameras in Tow
description: Travel may be broadening, but the process isnt instantaneous. 1,000 Places to See Before You Die, a series that makes its debut in back-to-back episodes on the Travel Channel tonight, offers up a young Colorado couple as a sacrifice to the sad truth that, set against the great sights of the globe, ordinary tourists are pretty dull.

title: Walk Right in, Sit Right Down
description: THIS season there are enough colorful new dining chairs to enhance any dining room. But chairs are not just decorative objects; good ones will be comfortable enough to encourage guests to linger, a sure sign that the party was a success. What makes a chair comfortable is very subjective, though; what is good for one persons back may be bad for someone elses. So make sure to test chairs before buying them, taking frequent visitors or family members along if possible. When shopping online or by phone, ask about the companys return policy.

title: Thailand Promises Elections This Year
description: BANGKOK, March 29  Thailands prime minister, Surayud Chulanont, today rejected the advice of the general who put him in power, declining to declare a state of emergency in Bangkok to clamp down on anti-government protesters and instead promising to hold elections before the end of this year.

title: People and Accounts of Note
description: The Advertising Educational Foundation, New York, selected the awardees for its seventh annual Honors Night. Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, part of the WPP Group, will receive the agency award. The Gannett Company will receive the media award. The Kellogg Company will receive the advertiser award. And Keith Reinhard, chairman emeritus at DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, will receive the lifetime achievement award. The awards are to be presented on June 12 at the University Club.

title: For the Record
description: A music review on Tuesday about Elton John, at Madison Square Garden, misstated the title of a song he performed. It is All the Girls Love Alice  not All the Young Girls Love Alice, which is a phrase in the lyrics.

title: No U-Turns
description: There is an argument floating around Republican circles that in order to win again, the G.O.P. has to reconnect with the truths of its Goldwater-Reagan glory days. It has to once again be the minimal-government party, the maximal-freedom party, the party of rugged individualism and states rights.

title: A Soundtrack for Flamenco, With Clicking Castanets and Pounding Canes
description: Carlota Santana presides over the sort of friendly, modern flamenco in which dancers dont exactly lose all semblance of control. In a dance form like flamenco  in which the elusive goal, in a manner of speaking, is to turn oneself inside out  that is not necessarily a good thing. On Tuesday night Flamenco Vivo Carlota Santana, a New York company that originated in 1983, returned to the Joyce Theater with a program nearly as tame as it was long.

title: Ex-Auditor Says He Was Told to Be Lax on Oil Fees
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  A former top auditor at the Interior Department accused senior officials on Wednesday of prohibiting him and other investigators from recovering hundreds of millions of dollars in underpayments from oil and gas companies that drill on federal land and in federal waters.

title: The D.C. Tea Party
description: Washington

title: Living With Alzheimers Before a Window Closes
description: Mary Blake Carver gazes from the cover of a neurology magazine this month, under the headline Im Still Here! She often feels like shouting the message to her friends, her children, her husband.

title: Legislating Leadership on Iraq
description: This week it was the Senates turn. Like the House last week and the voters last November, the Senate made clear Tuesday that Americans expect to see the disaster in Iraq brought to an early and responsible end.

title: Got Crows-Feet? Call the Downward Dog
description: FOR a Friday evening, the small, intimate workout room at the New York Health & Racquet Club on East 57th Street was comfortably full. A dozen people sat, their chins pointed toward the ceiling, their lips puckered as if preparing for a kiss.

title: Marshall Rogers, 57, Artist Who Drew Batman Comics, Dies
description: Marshall Rogers, a comic-book artist who made his name illustrating Batman at a significant period in 1977 and 78, was found dead by a family member on Saturday at his home in Fremont, Calif. He was 57.

title: N.J. Lawmaker Indicted in Medical School inquiry
description: State Senator Wayne R. Bryant , of Camden County in New Jersey, was indicted on 20 counts today on charges of using his influence to steer grants to the states University of Medicine and Dentistry in return for no-show jobs.

title: A Rare Streak Is Still Waiting to Be Extended
description: Mike Moss of New York has won at least one national title in each of the five previous decades, joining a select few. He is trying to establish a record by capturing one in a sixth decade. And he came so close in the Jacoby Open Swiss Teams in St. Louis this month. He and his teammates, Brian Glubok of New York, Peter Fredin of Sweden and Agustin Madala of Argentina, finished 1.5 victory points behind the winners, David Maidman and Marin Marinov of New York and Kalin Karaivanov and Roumen Trendafilov from Bulgaria.

title: Almonte Chooses Frontier League Over College
description: Danny Almonte planned to graduate high school last year, then attend junior college in New Mexico. He had been bypassed in the major league draft in June and did not have the grades to play Division I college baseball.

title: After Years in Middle East Politics, One Palestinian Still Finds Hope
description: For some Israelis, Sari Nusseibeh, a Palestinian intellectual and public figure, has always been a nightmare.

title: Mozambique: Unexploded Munitions Recovered
description: The army said it had recovered at least 70 percent of the still-unexploded munitions that were hurled into suburbs of the capital, Maputo, after a military arsenal crammed with decades-old arms exploded last week. Separately, the health minister, Ivo Garrido, told Radio Mozambique that the death toll from the blast had risen to 117. Teams of de-miners and army engineers have been combing residential neighborhoods for the remaining munitions. Many of the wounded were children, some of whom have been sent to South Africa for treatment. Children near the explosion site are still fearful of returning to school, reports said. Some classes were as little as half full this week.

title: Britain: Finally, Some Cheese Action
description: Its a big day for fans of the Internet site cheddarvision.tv, where visitors have been watching a 44-pound round of cheddar mature 24 hours a day since Jan. 1. Today something will actually happen. As of last night, the site had counted more than 500,000 hits. About 55,000 fans are expected today, the BBC reported, when the camera, set up in a farmhouse by the West Country Farmhouse Cheesemakers, Somerset farmers who produces handmade cheddar, is given its first quality check. To ensure that the cheese is maturing properly (it is fully expected to take a year), an expert cheese maker will pull out a core and sniff and taste it, the BBC said. The sampling is at 10 a.m. local time, or 5 a.m. New York time.

title: Irresponsible Mortgages Have Opened Doors to Many of the Excluded
description: We are sitting on a time bomb, the mortgage analyst said  a huge increase in unconventional home loans like balloon mortgages taken out by consumers who cannot qualify for regular mortgages. The high payments, he continued, are just beginning to come due and a lot of people who were betting interest rates would come down by now risk losing their homes because they cant pay the debt.

title: Knicks Fight to Stay in Race Comes With a Cost
description: Fortune bounced the Knicks way at long last Wednesday night. It bounced several times, actually.

title: Giuliani Says Wife Would Attend Cabinet Meetings
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani said this week that if he were president, his wife could attend Cabinet meetings and advise him on federal policy, an unusually overt role in government decision-making for a first lady.

title: Calendar
description: Home Gardens and Beyond

title: Class Is in Session
description: THE Bosu Ballast Ball  a stability ball filled with sand-like grains  might remind you of a day at the beach. But hoisting one is no picnic. Seven pounds may not sound like a lot to shake over your temple like a maraca, or to lie down and clutch between your thighs, but youll think differently after the 100th rep.

title: Blackstone Sells Property
description: The Blackstone Group, the buyout firm that bought Equity Office Properties Trust, the real estate investment trust, agreed to sell 10 buildings in Austin, Tex., to Thomas Properties Group for $1.15 billion.

title: Authorities Break Up Illegal Sports Gambling Operations in New York and New Jersey
description: NEWARK, March 28  The authorities in New York and New Jersey said on Wednesday that they had broken up two separate illegal Internet gambling operations, arresting more than 60 people, including two former New York City police officers.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a plan by a conservative Colorado parish to leave the Episcopal Church in part because of the churchs policy on same-sex unions misstated that policy. Although the church allows dioceses and parishes to perform rites for same-sex couples, the denomination itself does not sanction such rites.

title: Text of Letter Attributed to Seized Sailor
description: Following is the text of a letter that Iranian authorities said was written by Faye Turney, a captured British sailor, to her family, including her husband Adam and daughter Molly. The Press Association news agency of Britain distributed this text of the letter:

title: Intel Plans Faster Chips That Also Save Power
description: SAN FRANCISCO, March 28  Intel said Wednesday that it was on track or even ahead of schedule in developing a new generation of chips that would achieve a significant increase in performance without consuming more power.

title: For the Record
description: The Ink column on Tuesday, about naptime in the Milstein Hall of Ocean Life at the American Museum of Natural History, misstated the location of the museums tigers. They are in the endangered-species exhibit near the Hall of Ocean Life and also in the Hall of Asian Mammals; they are not in the Akeley Hall of African Mammals. (Tigers are not native to Africa.)

title: Trenton: More Pressure on Corzine
description: Two public interest lawyers said yesterday that they planned to ask the United States attorneys for New Jersey and Washington to open a criminal investigation into whether Gov. Jon S. Corzine falsified disclosure statements he filed when he was a United States senator by not including a $470,000 loan to his companion. The lawyers, Carl J. Mayer and Bruce Afran, said they intended to ask the prosecutors to determine if Mr. Corzine, left, violated the False Statements Accountability Act of 1996 by not listing the loan to Carla Katz, a prominent state labor leader, in his Senate disclosure reports over three years. Last October, Mr. Corzine, facing scrutiny from the Senate Ethics Committee, amended those documents to reflect the loan, which he eventually forgave. Ms. Katz, president of Local 1034 of the Communications Workers of America, and Mr. Corzine dated from 2002 to 2004.

title: Indian College Quota Law Suspended
description: NEW DELHI, March 29  An incendiary law to expand caste-based college admissions quotas, which had generated weeks of protest last year, was temporarily suspended today by the countrys highest court.

title: Somehow It Feels Old Hat
description: THERE are reasons to raise a skeptical brow when a group as disparate as Miuccia Prada, Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan, Marc Jacobs and Madonna attempt to bring turbans of the Old Hollywood variety back into fashion.

title: Manhattan: Agreement to Buy Helmsley Building
description: Goldman Sachs Group and Monday Properties have agreed to buy the Helmsley Building on Park Avenue for $1.15 billion from Istithmar and Island Capital Group, Islands founder, Andrew Farkas, said yesterday. The sellers paid $705 million for the 1.35-million-square-foot building 16 months ago, he said. The sale was reported yesterday in The New York Post.

title: 2 Suitors for Tribune Co. Renew Their Interest
description: In the battle of billionaires looking to buy the Tribune Company, Eli Broad and Ronald Burkle may still make a comeback.

title: Please Feed the Peripherals (With Your Favorite TV Shows)
description: With the Miglia TVMax+, a Mac can quietly record television shows and share them with an iPod and Apple TV, creating a symbiotic ecosystem where electronics are the fauna and episodes of 24 are the tasty flora.

title: 7 Ex-Chiefs of U.S. Parks Have Target: Snowmobiles
description: HELENA, Mont., March 28  Seven former directors of the National Park Service have called on the secretary of the interior not to approve plans that would continue allowing as many as 720 snowmobiles a day at Yellowstone National Park.

title: Phelps Locks Up Spot; Is Villone Next?
description: Josh Phelps will make the Yankees roster this season, though Manager Joe Torre cant announce it yet. Andy Phillips is still here in spring training, and after striking out four times on Tuesday, he didnt play tonight. Hes hitting .190. Phelps went 0 for 1 and is now batting .424.

title: Recent Openings
description: New shows in New York include "The Year of Magical Thinking" and "Exits and Entrances."

title: For Public Display
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Picky Picky
description: From flashlights to egg cups, it's all in the edit at Turpan.

title: The New Collectibles
description: The real thing for spring.

title: Displacement and Destruction
description: The final hours of Suaada Saadouns life reveal the fierce pressure Sunnis face from Shiite militias in Baghdad.

title: The Tabasco Family
description: The McIlhenny Company, which owns Tabasco and is now in its fifth generation as a family-run business, has been working to overcome flooding caused by Hurricane Rita in 2005.

title: Mortgage Lenders Tighten the Rules
description: A growing number of New Yorkers, often with six-figure salaries and reasonably good credit, have begun to find that mortgages are harder to get as lenders try to stem losses from loans to the weakest, or subprime, borrowers.

title: Winfrey Picks Cormac McCarthys The Road
description: Oprah Winfrey has named "The Road," by Cormac McCarthy, as her latest book club selection, The Associated Press reported. The novel, published in September by Alfred A. Knopf, is a despairing account of a boy and his father lurching across the cold, wretched, wet, corpse-strewn, ashen landscape of a post-apocalyptic world. In her review in The New York Times, Janet Maslin wrote, " 'The Road' would be pure misery if not for its stunning, savage beauty.' " Ms. Winfrey said yesterday: "It is so extraordinary. I promise you, you'll be thinking about it long after you finish the final page." According to Nielsen BookScan, which tracks about 70 percent of industry sales, "The Road" has sold 138,000 copies. A paperback edition of the novel, a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle prize and regarded as a contender for a Pulitzer Prize, was not planned until September, but Vintage Books is publishing one now.

title: Historians Lose Da Vinci Code Appeal
description: The British publisher of the Dan Brown best seller "The Da Vinci Code" has prevailed again over the two historians who contended that Mr. Brown plagiarized themes from their book "The Holy Blood and the Holy Grail" (1982).The Court of Appeal in London rejected their appeal yesterday of a High Court ruling in April that Random House, the British publisher, had not infringed on the copyright of their book, the BBC reported. Both books are based on the theory that Jesus and Mary Magdalene married and had a child, and that the bloodline continues to this day. In a statement the authors, Michael Baigent and Richard Leigh, said, "We believed, and still do, that nonfiction authors would suffer and be discouraged from extensive research if it was found that any author could take another's ideas, 'morph' and repackage them, then sell them on." Random House was awarded the costs of the appeal, estimated at $589,000, and Mr. Baigent and Mr. Leigh face a legal bill of $5.89 million.

title: Simpson Book to Be Auctioned
description: Rights to the O. J. Simpson book "If I Did It" are to be auctioned on April 17 pursuant to a ruling by Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Gerald Rosenberg that proceeds from the sale and any subsequent book profits be turned over to the family of Ronald L. Goldman, The Associated Press reported. In the book Mr. Simpson explains how he might have carried out the slayings of his exwife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Mr. Goldman. Public outrage led to cancellation of the book and a companion television interview. Mr. Simpson was acquitted of the slayings in a criminal trial, but the Goldman family won a wrongful-death lawsuit against him in 1997 and has been trying ever since to collect a $33.5 million civil judgment.

title: Lukas Award Winners Announced
description: "The Looming Tower: Al Qaeda and the Road to 9/11" (Alfred A. Knopf), Lawrence Wright's history of events leading to the destruction of the World Trade Center, has won the $10,000 J. Anthony Lukas Book Prize, the Columbia Graduate School of Journalism and the Nieman Foundation announced. The other winners of this year's J. Anthony Lukas Prize Projects Awards were James T. Campbell, recipient of the $10,000 Mark Lynton History Prize, for "Middle Passages: African American Journeys to Africa, 1787-2005" (Penguin Press), and Robert Whitaker, recipient of the $30,000 J. Anthony Lukas Work-in-Progress Award for "Twelve Condemned to Die: Scipio Africanus Jones and the Struggle for Justice That Remade a Nation," to be published by Crown. Mr. Lukas, a journalist and author who won two Pulitzer Prizes, died in 1997. The prizes will be presented by Garrison Keillor on May 8 at Columbia's Graduate School of Journalism.

title: Creature Features
description: Images from the renovated Audubon Gallery in the American Museum of Natural History.

title: I Double Dare You: A Look at The Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey's Wheel of Steel Circus Stunt
M&A Takes Hold of Japanese TV
description: The popularity of a new scripted TV show in Japan highlights the recent shift in attitudes toward corporate raiding, says the New York Times. Indeed, one of the hottest new shows on Japanese television is called Vulture and focuses on a fictional New York investment fund that buys ailing Japanese companies and imposes harsh American-style management changes.

title: 2 Suitors for Tribune Renew Their Interest
description: In the battle of billionaires looking to buy Tribune, Eli Broad and Ronald Burkle may still make a comeback. The company has responded to a request for additional financial information from the two Los Angeles billionaires, whose bid for the company appeared to have been dismissed, people close to the companys auction said Wednesday.

title: No Bonuses for G.M. Executives
description: General Motors, which significantly improved its financial performance in 2006 but failed to earn a profit, said on Wednesday that for a second consecutive year, it would not pay cash bonuses to top executives. Such bonuses would undoubtedly have rankled members of the United Automobile Workers union ahead of this summers contract talks, although a G.M. spokeswoman, Renee Rashid-Merem, declined to say whether the pending negotiations were a factor.

title: Top Credit Suisse Executive Joins Ripplewood Firm
description: Credit Suisses head of Europe, the Middle East and Africa, Leonhard Fischer, has resigned to become co-chief executive at a holding company controlled by the private equity firm Ripplewood Holdings. His departure comes six weeks after one of Mr. Fischers colleagues was chosen as the Swiss banks next chief executive.

title: Porsche Makes a Bid for the Rest of Volkswagen
description: Porsche made a bid for Volkswagen that values the carmaker at 35.8 billion euros ($47.7 billion), a low offer intended to leave Porsche with a controlling stake rather than full ownership.

title: Prosecutors Say Ex-Qwest Chief Tried to Hide Assets
description: Joseph P. Nacchio, the former chief of Qwest Communications, who is on trial for insider trading, tried to hide $90 million in assets by transferring stock into accounts held solely by his wife, according to information that the prosecution is attempting to submit as evidence.

title: Blackstone Sells Austin Buildings for $1.15 Billion
description: The Blackstone Group, the buyout firm that bought Equity Office Properties Trust, the real estate investment trust, agreed to sell 10 buildings in Austin, Tex., to the Thomas Properties Group for $1.15 billion. The transaction includes five downtown office buildings with 2.5 million square feet and five properties in northwest Austin with almost 1 million square feet, Thomas Properties said Thursday.

title: Cerberus Picks up Tower Automotive
description: The private equity firm Cerberus Capital Management has agreed to buy the bankrupt auto parts maker Tower Automotive in a deal valued at about $1 billion, the company said Wednesday. Tower, which filed for bankruptcy protection in February 2005, said the sale required court approval and was subject to an auction if other investors submit qualified bids.

title: Pennsylvania Merger Creates Giant Health Insurer
description: Pennsylvanias two largest health insurers agreed on Wednesday to merge in a deal that had been in the works for years and gives the two nonprofits control over most of the states health insurance market. The boards of Independence Blue Cross of Philadelphia and Highmark of Pittsburgh separately approved a merger that would create the nations third-largest health insurer behind the UnitedHealth Group and Wellpoint.

title: Cerberus Said to Offer Job to Home Depot Ex-Chief
description: Home Depots recently ousted chief executive, Robert Nardelli, has received a job offer from Cerberus Capital Management, CNBC reported, citing undisclosed sources. But the home-improvement retailer may try to prevent him from joining Cerberus, a private equity firm whose investments include tje General Motors Acceptance Corporation and the parent of Air Canada, by invoking his noncompete contract, CNBC said.

title: Reconstructing a Chariot
description: The Metropolitan Museum of Art has reassembled a 2,600-year-old Etruscan chariot.

title: Harland, M & F Merger Approved
description: Shareholders of John H. Harland, a software maker, have approved the companys $1.7 billion acquisition by M&F Worldwide. M&F, which is based in New York, will pay $52.75 a share for Harland, which is based in Atlanta. Harland provides software and printed products to the financial and educational markets and will become a wholly owned subsidiary of M&F Worldwide.

title: Drug Makers Rake in $136 Million V.C. Haul
description: Venture capital is thriving in the Bay Area, it seems: In the past two weeks, three private drug development companies raised a combined $136 million in venture funding.

title: Blackstones Tragus Gobbles Up Restaurant Chain
description: Tragus, a portfolio company of the Blackstone Group, has made a board-recommended 96 million pound ($180 million) bid for the La Tasca Group, a chain of Spanish-food restaurants. Tragus intends to bolster its European presence with the addition of 58 La Tasca restaurants in Britain and four in the United States, adding to 175 restaurants it already operates in France and Italy. La Tasca is based in Lancashire, Britain.

title: Leonard Green Raises $5.3 Billion for Buyouts
description: Leonard Green & Partners said Wednesday it had closed its latest private equity fund, Green Equity Investors V LP, at $5.3 billion, nearly three times the size of its previous buyout fund, which closed four years ago.

title: Aurora to Acquire Mitchell for $500 Million
description: the Aurora Capital Group said Wednesday that it was close to finalizing its acquisition of a software developer, Mitchell International of San Diego, for more than $500 million. It was announced last month that Hellman & Friedman of San Francisco would sell Mitchell, but no price had been disclosed. General Electric Pension Trust is a co-investor in the purchase. Mitchells management is also investing in the deal and will have a stake of about 15 percent.

title: Warburg Pincus Invests $175 Million in Titan
description: Warburg Pincus will invest $175 million in the Titan Petrochemicals Group, an oil logistics company listed in Hong Kong. The investment was announced on Wednesday and will be made in two parts.
