First is a $75 million purchase of equity and convertible preferred shares in Titan Petrochemicals, which will give Warburg Pincus a 9.9 percent stake in the business along with one board seat.

title: Citic 1616s I.P.O. Raises $270 Million
description: In its initial public offering, Citic 1616 Holdings has raised $270 million, the maximum it sought on Hong Kongs Hang Seng Index. The company, which provides connectivity between voice and data service providers in Hong Kong and China and telecom operators in about 50 other countries, benefited from a well-timed roadshow that coincided with a rebound in the Hong Kong market.

title: Chinas Country Garden Readies Massive I.P.O.
description: Country Garden of China, a property development company, has set the price range for what will become the largest initial public offering by a mainland property company in Hong Kong. At the bottom of the range, the deal will total $1.3 billion, which would beat Shui On Propertys $877 million 2006 offering by 48 percent.

title: Regulators Seek $210 Million Penalty From TXU
description: Texas state regulators are demanding $210 million in fines from the energy company TXU for allegedly manipulating the wholesale power market in 2005. It would mark the largest penalty ever proposed by the Texas Public Utility Commissions staff. TXU, which is currently the subject of a $45 billion buyout proposal, called the accusations flatly wrong and said it planned to contest the findings.

title: Gol to Resurrect Varig
description: Gol will buy Brazils former flagship carrier, Varig, in a cash and stock deal valued at about $275 million, Gol said Wednesday. Gol will also assume about $45 million of Varigs debt. Varig, which had been Brazils top airline for decades, fell victim to crushing debt last year and was bought in bankruptcy proceedings by investors that included Brazilians and the United States investment fund Matlin Patterson.

title: Barclays Hires Citigroup in ABN Amro Talks
description: Barclayshas hired Citigroup as an adviser on its takeover negotiations with ABN Amro, Reuters reported Wednesday. The move would effectively block the United States group from making a counterbid for the Dutch bank.

title: Circling BCE, K.K.R. Plans Biggest-Ever Canadian L.B.O.
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts is looking to make a friendly takeover bid for BCE, the owner of Bell Canada. A successful purchase would be the largest acquisition in Canadian corporate history, according to The Globe and Mail, and one of the worlds largest leveraged buyouts.

title: Blackstone May Play the Spoiler in Alliance Boots Bid
description: The past week has not been kind to Stefano Pessina, the deputy chairman of Alliance Boots of Britani. While he and a partner, Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, are expected to raise the 9.7 billion pound ($18.8 billion) bid that his company rejected last month, rival suitors came into the picture. Then he was reportedly banned from the health and beauty stores central office.

title: Brazils AmBev Will Invest $2.4 Billion at Home
description: Upon announcing the $150 million acquisition of the local beer company Cintra on Wednesday, Brazils leading brewer, AmBev, said it would invest about $2.4 billion in Brazil over the next five years. AmBev already has close to 70 percent of the countrys beer market and said it required the record level of investment to expand its production capacity and take advantage of the growing beverage market.

title: European Commission Takes Spain to Court over Endesa
description: The European Commission took Spain to the highest European Union court on Wednesday for interfering in the $56.5 billion bid by the German utility E.On for Endesa. The move marks the latest legal hurdle in the takeover battle for Endesa, Spains biggest utility, amid accusations of economic nationalism and fears that the deal could spend years in litigation.

title: Live from New Orleans M&A Lawyer Confab
description: DealBook comes to you this morning from New Orleans, where Tulane University Law Schools 19th Annual Corporate Law Institute is just getting under way. Many of the nations most prominent deal lawyers, including Casey Cogut of Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and Richard Katcher of Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz, are here to talk tactics and drink mint juleps. Vice Chancellor Leo E. Strine Jr. of Delawares Court of Chancery is here as well, and he is already talking about two of his favorite subjects: go shops and staple financing. We wont dwell on the legal jargon, but we will bring you updates throughout the day and in tomorrows e-mail report.

title: For 3i Investors, a $1.57 Billion Payday
description: The private equity group 3i said Thursday it would pay out 800 million pounds ($1.57 billion) to shareholders later this year, bringing its total payouts to investors over the last two years to 2 billion pounds. Buoyant financial markets have driven up its returns from asset sales in the financial year ending this month, the firm said.

title: Crumpled Manhood Revisited
description: At this point in his career, the actor Paul Giamatti is pretty much the go-to guy for crumpled manhood, for characters whose disappointment with life is stamped on their spines and sagging jowls. In films like "American Splendor" and "Sideways," he turned dejection into a seduction technique and self-pity into a reason for living. Now imagine an entire film infected with this hangdog sensibility, unrelieved by humor or narrative interest, and you have "The Hawk Is Dying."

title: U.S. Steel to Acquire Lone Star for $2.1 Billion
description: United States Steel Corporation said it plans to buy Lone Star Technologies, a maker of welded pipe used in oil fields, in a $2.1 billion cash deal that will make it North Americas largest producer of tubular steel.

title: Hedge Fund Assets Are Up, but Returns Are Not
description: The worlds hedge funds managed more than $2 trillion at the end of 2006, 30 percent more than a year earlier, even as returns trailed, according to a survey. More than 350 hedge fund managers look after more than $1 billion each, according to HedgeFund Intelligences first global review of the industry. Europe is the worlds fastest-growing hedge fund market, while most assets in the category are managed out of the United States, the London-based researcher said.

title: From Immigration to Anarchy
description: This feature filmmaking debut by Peter Miller (a PBS veteran and longtime collaborator of Ken Burns) hews to standard television documentary format: archival photographs and talking heads. But the movie's meat-and-potatoes style seems less a failure of imagination than a means of putting in the foreground its subject matter: the tale of Nicola Sacco and Bartolomeo Vanzetti, Italian immigrants and outspoken anarchists charged with the 1920 robbery of a Massachusetts shoe factory and the murder of two of its employees.

title: Carmax Posts 15 Percent Rise in Earnings
description: NEW YORK (Reuters) - CarMax Inc., the largest retailer of used cars in the United States, said on Thursday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 15 percent, helped by strong sales and Internet traffic.

title: The Mind of Alberto Gonzales
Pork in the War Bill
description: President Bush and the Republican leadership in both the House and the Senate have complained about many of the additions to the emergency war bill that would provide billions of dollars for domestic projects.

title: The Future of Hydrogen Cars
description: Im wrapping up my notes on the 2007 TED conference (Technology, Entertainment, Design), a reality-altering, four-day series of 50 speakers, most of whom are absolutely brilliant.

title: Fired Prosecutors Arent the Only Sign of Politics in the Justice Department
description: Writing on the op-ed page of The Los Angeles Times, Joseph D. Rich, chief of the voting section in the Justice Departments civil rights division from 1999 to 2005, alleges that there has been a destructive pattern of partisan political actions at the Justice Department under President Bush, long before the Gonzales Eight. Over the last six years, this Justice Department has ignored the advice of its staff and skewed aspects of law enforcement in ways that clearly were intended to influence the outcome of elections, Rich writes. He adds:

title: No French Grand Prix in 2008?
description: Following races in Belgium, Germany and Italy, the French Grand Prix may take a sabbatical next year, according to a statement today from the Federation Franaise de Sport Automobile, and as I pointed out last week after reading an interview with Bernie Ecclestone in AutoHebdo.

title: Veronis Suhler to Buy Advanstar
description: Advanstar, a business-to-business marketer, will be acquired by a consortium led by a media-focused private equity firm, Veronis Suhler Stevenson, for $1.14 billion in cash. Veronis and its partners, Citigroup Private Equity and New York Life Capital Partners, will buy the company from its current sponsor, Credit Suisses DLJ Merchant Banking Partners, which has already approved the deal.

title: 2008: Insert Law & Order Candidate Joke Here
description: The media are ramping up their coverage of a possible Fred Thompson candidacy, and the former senator/current Law & Order star has done little to discourage the rampant speculation. The Washington Posts Michael D. Shear takes a look at Mr. Thompsons strengths and weaknesses relative to the existing G.O.P. field. Polls are already showing, at least, strong name recognition, and he has a fairly consistent conservative voting record (his support of the McCain-Feingold campaign finance legislation a major exception). Of course, hed have to catch up on fundraising.

title: Evolution of a Captain
description: From rookie of the year to captain of the Yankees, a look back at Derek Jeter's career.

title: Around the neighborhood
description: A roundup of real estate news:

title: As Pitch Leaks to Web, a Hedge Fund Wants Quiet
description: If hedge fund managers want to dispel their air of secrecy, this is probably not the way to do it. The folks at Solengo Capital, the firm being opened by former traders of the collapsed hedge fund Amaranth Advisors, have apparently told at least two blogs to remove Solengos marketing materials from their Web site, claiming they are not authorized to disseminate them. One of the blogs, Greg Newtons Naked Shorts, agreed to take down the brochure, telling Reuters that although he did not think he was legally required to do so, something like this can very quickly be a big legal bill.

title: Behind Closed Doors
description: Were back to five men in a room. (Is that better than three men in a room?)

title: Haute New Zealand
description: Poronui Station, an exclusive high-country property on New Zealands North Island, was listed among the worlds top 20 properties for sale in 2005 by Forbes magazine.

title: Food loves French's
description: An ad campaign, with a budget estimated at more than $12 million, introduces the theme "Food loves French's," with a heart made out of yellow mustard in place of the word "loves."

title: Daddy Delgado
description: Carlos Delgado rejoined the team this morning after spending the last six days with his wife after she gave birth to the couples first son, Carlos Antonio, last Friday in Puerto Rico.

title: Codes and Ciphers
description: At a panel discussion  last night about women in politics, the tireless Azi Paybarah of The Politicker was apparently one of the few men in attendance. He said that June ONeill, the state Democratic Party chair, had this advice as she introduced the panelists: Shake hands. Its a code.

title: Should Companies Sell While the Selling Is Good?
description: There are increasing complaints among shareholders that companies are selling out to private equity at bargain prices  leaving the buyout shops to enjoy the upside when the business gets sold or taken public again. But Robert Kindler, Morgan Stanleys vice chairman of investment banking, says these critics are generally off-base. In his opening speech Thursday to deal lawyers at Tulane Law Schools Corporate Law Institute, Mr. Kindler suggested that, in this torrid buyout market, most companies are getting top dollar when they agree to go private.

title: Ah, the Open Budget Process
description: So the big thing officials here in Albany point to when questioned about the lack of transparency in budget negotiations is the conference committee system, where the Senate and the Assembly are supposed to hash out the nitty-gritty details of the budget in public.

title: Mixed Signals on BCE Buyout Rumor
description: Thursdays report that BCE, the owner of Bell Canada, might be acquired by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in Canadas largest buyout drew this carefully worded statement from the company: There are no ongoing discussions being held with any private equity investor with respect to any privatization of the company or any similar transaction.

title: Hedi Slimane Exits Dior
description: Sidney Toledano, the chief executive of Dior, confirmed this morning that Hedi Slimane will no longer design Dior Homme, ending months of negotiations that were often at an impasse between the runway star and executives of Dior and LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton. Slimane has been replaced by Kris Van Assche, who signed his contract with Dior just a few hours ago in Paris.

title: Russian Steelmaker Mechel Buys Power Plant
description: Mechel, a Russian metals and mining company traded on the New York Stock Exchange, said Thursday it would acquire Southern Kuzbass Power Plant for about $265 million. The deal follows an auction for the power station, which was split off from Kuzbassenergo, a Russian utility, as part of a 2006 restructuring. Mechel said that the acquisition was part of a strategy to reduce costs by generating some of its own power.

title: Nostalgia for Reagan Is Unwarranted
description: Readers respond to David Brookss Mar. 29 column, No U-Turns.

title: No Taxation Without Representation, Take Two
description: Readers respond to Bob Herberts Mar. 29 column, The D.C. Tea Party.

title: Investment Banks Brave, New, Conflicted World
description: The big investment banks are everywhere these days, underwriting public offerings, advising buyers and providing deal financing  often on behalf of the same company. This ubiquity has created some concern when a bank needs to be found to handle a go shop provision in a takeover agreement, which essentially creates a window during which the target tries to drum up better offers. The dilemma: Does the desire for a completely independent bank trump the desire for a bank with sufficient resources and relevant experience?

title: theonion.com
description: Please tell me Brandon Armstrong is a classically trained anchorman.

title: McCains State Chairman: Ed Cox
description: Edward F. Cox, a lawyer and a son-in-law of President Richard M. Nixon who briefly ran against Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for Senate in 2005, will be the New York State chairman of Senator John McCains presidential campaign.

title: A No Good, Very Bad Day for I.P.O.s
description: For those who complain that initial public offerings are having a tough time, Wednesday will have provided no solace. Three I.P.O.s that opened that day raised about 21 percent less than they sought, potentially casting a shadow over three offerings set to debut this week. Bloomberg News notes that Super Micro Computer and SenoRx cut their prices to complete their deals, while GSI Technology lowered the number of shares offered. (The reasons why the companies offerings were less successful than expected isnt clear. Bloomberg offers a slowing economy and declining stock prices as possible culprits.)

title: The Giulianis: Inseparable, Even in Cabinet Meetings
description: Former New York Mayor Rudy Giuliani would have no problem letting his wife Judith sit in on cabinet meetings, were he elected president. And she doesnt have any problem with becoming an adviser in the West Wing either, especially on issues of health care.

title: C.E.O. to the Poor
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced today in Brooklyn that the city was moving ahead with a bold anti-poverty experiment that will use private donations to pay 2,500 families $25 to $300 for meeting various targets  better school attendance, higher test scores  up to a total of $5,000 a year.

title: A Clinton Crossover
description: The first Bill-to-Hill crossover of the presidential season involved the career shift of Jay Carson, a respected political operative who has worked as Mr. Clintons communications director since June 2005.

title: Fox Sets 2 Debates With Congressional Black Caucus
description: Fox News Channel is announcing today that it has cut a deal with the Congressional Black Caucus Institute to sponsor two debates, one with Democrats and another with Republicans in the 2008 presidential race.

title: McClatchy Chief Has a Private Vision
description: Going private is a long-term option for McClatchy, according to Gary Pruitt, the newspaper chains chief executive. But first, he told a crowd at Syracuse Universitys Newhouse School, he must put the company, which is the United States third-largest newspaper publisher, in a position to have the flexibility to go private.

title: Some Reality Checks on Hedge Funds
description: Last years implosion at Amaranth Advisors was so huge it caused many people to conclude that the hedge-fund business was in meltdown mode. But a new study paints a different picture, finding that there were fewer hedge fund liquidations in 2006 than there were in 2005. (There were fewer fund launches as well.)

title: What, No Video?
description: The office of State Senator Tom Duane says his latest podcast is now up on iTunes and other podcast directories (and the the link should have it available soon as streaming audio).

title: More on the Middle East
description: Since I quoted the New York Sun editorial a couple of weeks ago denouncing me for spreading a new blood libel in my colum about Israel, I should also note that there are plenty of other commentaries that are much more measured. The Jewish Daily Forward had a very sensible essay that discussed my column and how to react to the broader debate about Israel. Heres an excerpt, but its difficult to summarize and I recommend reading the entire essay.

title: Our National Epic Has Yet to Be Written Yo
description: Oh, I had low, low hopes for Justin.tv when I saw it on Joe Buas first-rate nutter blog, I Am a TV Junkie. Yeah, its another Web keyhole: another promise that youll get to watch someones random life full-time, and eventually to influence it.

title: Honda Markets Safety
description: Honda, a company well known for the fuel efficiency of its cars, now wants safety to be part of its identity too.

title: Blogtalk: Rolling Out, or Getting Rolled
description: The public rollout of Mrs. Giuliani on ABC: An inseparable couple, even in cabinet meetings? [The Caucus]

title: The Final Four on the Small Screen, and in Person
description: The clever but blandly named blog Complete Sports pointed out yesterday that because Jim Nantz is once again CBSs broadcaster for the Final Four, we can all expect one of his jocular witticisms once the eventual champion is crowned. Nantz has made a habit of this, with three famous punny groaners:

title: Breeden Talks Tough, Then Walks the Walk
description: Around lunchtime in New Orleans, former Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Richard Breeden told the audience at the Corporate Law Institute that he had a message for directors who think they can sit out the rise in shareholder activism: Change will come. Its only a matter of who brings it.

title: Movie Minutes: 'Meet the Robinsons'
description: The New York Times Chief Movie Critic A. O. Scott reviews "Meet the Robinsons" which features celebrated new graphics technology and tired old movie cliches.

title: Raising the Bar
description: I wrote about drinking before I wrote about eating, and Ive probably logged more time on barstools than at restaurant tables. Thats one reason I cheer up when I eat at a bar, but there are others. Like lifeguards, babies and SUV drivers, I like sitting up high.

title: Keep It Secret. Keep It Safe.
description: As went Gandalfs advice to Frodo, so goes  apparently  the legislative philosophy of Albanys leaders.

title: When in RomeAn Experiment for Reducing Smog
description: Heavy traffic in central Rome. Charlotta Smeds, Bloomberg News

title: When Politics Is Performance
description: There is little difference between politics and performance, D. Kyle Sampson told a Senate panel today. But can a move thats largely political, though not necessarily partisan, pass the smell test? As the recently resigned chief of staff to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales both contradicted and defended his boss today, the nuance of his claim became apparent in the context of the ouster of Carol C. Lam, one of eight United States attorneys whose dismissals called into question the credibility of the Bush Justice Department.The distinction between political- and performance-related reasons for removing a U.S. attorney is, in my view, largely artificial, Mr. Sampson said in  his opening statement to the Senate Judiciary Committee. A U.S. attorney who is unsuccessful from a political perspective, either because he or she has alienated the leadership of the department in Washington or cannot work constructively with law enforcement or other governmental constituencies in the district, is unsuccessful.

title: The Needless Fear of Day Care
description: Ive got some good news to share. The latest word about day care from the nations largest, longest-running, highest-quality, mega-government-financed study is this: it doesnt really matter much at all.

title: My 25-Man Roster Projection
description: The Mets opening day roster gained some clarity today when they reassigned seven players, most notably outfielder Ben Johnson, to minor-league camp and confirmed that Aaron Sele and Joe Smith have made the team. By my count, that accounts for 23 players, leaving four players -Jon Adkins, Ambiorix Burgos, Chan Ho Park and Lastings Milledge  to compete for the final two. Im also operating under the assumption that the fifth starter Mike Pelfrey, who wont be needed until April 15, will begin the season in the minors to free up a roster spot.

title: The Yankees Projected 25-Man Roster
description: Tomorrow, Joe Torre said, will be a busy day. He plans to announce his 25-man roster and his rotation, which means hell have to tell all the players involved before he tells the media.

title: Musical Test Drive
description: The public gets a chance to play a million-dollar Stradivarius before it is auctioned.

title: Project Runway
description: Ten years ago, most American airports offered visitors little more than a trifecta of coffee shops, greasy fast food and newsstands. But in just the last few years, United States airports have greatly expanded their amenities and offerings, including spas, upscale shopping malls and first-rate cuisine to make the travel experience more enjoyable.

title: Saturns Hexagon: The Plot Thickens
description: Were still not quite finished testing your many theories for the hexagon above Saturns north pole, but I can give you a brief progress report.

title: Bringing in the Noise
description: Some call it noise, I call it inspiration.

title: Detainee Says He Was Told of Sept. 11 Attacks
description: A detainee at Guantnamo Bay who has been described as a financier of the Sept. 11 attacks said at a closed hearing that top operatives of Al Qaeda informed him of the impending attacks the night before they occurred, according to a transcript released yesterday.

title: A Loan a Governor Forgave, but the Public Wont Forget
description: TRENTON, March 29  Jon S. Corzine has made countless multimillion-dollar  and a few multibillion-dollar  decisions as a Wall Street bond trader, as a United States senator and now as governor of New Jersey, but it is the comparatively small sum of $470,000 that currently has his administration enmeshed in protracted legal and political disputes.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A Media Talk report in Business Day on Monday, about plans by The Harvard Crimson to hire an ombudsman, misstated the name of the independent student newspaper at Brandeis University that already has a similar position. It is The Justice, not The Brandeis Justice.

title: A Rookie Is Energizing the Nets at Power Forward
description: Josh Boones N.B.A. coming-out party has been light on scintillating spin moves and acrobatic dunks, and heavy on craft, quick thinking and positioning. It has been demure, much like his demeanor.

title: New Jersey Commerce Secretary, a 9/11 Widow, Is Picked for the Port Authority Board
description: TRENTON, March 29  New Jerseys commerce secretary and the widow of a 9/11 victim was appointed Thursday by Gov. Jon S. Corzine to a seat on the board of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the World Trade Center site.

title: 2 Billionaires Make Offer for Tribune
description: The drama for control of the Tribune Company intensified last night as two Los Angeles billionaires put in a last-minute bid, topping an offer from the Chicago real estate magnate, Sam Zell, by a dollar a share.

title: Movie Guide and Film Series
description: MOVIES

title: Jury Convicts Ex-Principal of Having Sex With Student
description: The former principal of a Manhattan private school was convicted yesterday of having sex with one of her students in a classroom when he was about 13 and she was about 30.

title: Gonzales Defends His Role in Firings
description: BOSTON, March 30  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales today defended his previous characterization of his role in the dismissal of United States attorneys, and said At the end of the day, I know what I did, and I know that the motivations for the decisions that I made were not based upon improper reasons.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A report in the Arts, Briefly column yesterday, about plans for a film inspired by an essay in The New York Times by Dana Canedy, a Times editor, misidentified the rights that were acquired by Escape Artists, a production house based at Columbia Pictures. They were the rights to the life stories of Ms. Canedy; her fianc, First Sgt. Charles Monroe King, who was killed in Iraq in October; and their son, Jordan. It did not buy the rights to the essay.

title: Theater Listings
description: THEATER

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings
description: CLASSICAL

title: Dell Reports It Has Found Misconduct
description: With its accounting under scrutiny by federal regulators and prosecutors, Dell said yesterday that evidence of misconduct had been uncovered in an internal investigation of its financial practices over several years.

title: Dior Replaces Its Mens Wear Designer
description: Christian Dior, the luxury fashion goods company, announced yesterday that it had replaced Hedi Slimane, its mens wear designer, whose razor-thin suits helped revitalize the image of the house and ushered in a new era of fashion-conscious male consumers.

title: People
description: People

title: In Atlanta, New Attractions and a Touch of History
description: ATLANTA has reinvented itself again.

title: Somalia Battle Leaves 30 Dead and Shreds Hopes for Peace
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 29  Any hope for a quick peace in Mogadishu faded Thursday when Ethiopian troops stormed into the center of the city, setting off clashes that killed more than 30 people.

title: Many Plans, No News
description: In the Middle East today, home of the invention of algebra, a new math seems to have taken over. It is subtraction by addition. It goes like this: Add more trips to the region by Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice  who doesnt seem to have any coherent strategy  to an emotionally stale, restated Saudi peace overture to Israel, and combine it with a cynical Hamas-Fatah cease-fire accord and an Israeli prime minister so unpopular his poll ratings are now lower than the margin of error, and youll find that were actually going backward  way back, back to the pre-Oslo era.

title: Tonight's TV Listings
description: 7 P.M. (Cartoon Network) BILLY & MANDYS BIG BOOGEY ADVENTURE (2007) Poor Grim Reaper. The Underworld has stripped him of his powers and his ability to frighten in the first movie-length version of this popular cartoon. So, with the help of Billy, Mandy and Irwin, Grim must beat his arch rival, the Boogey Man, to the one thing that can make him the scariest being alive: the Hand of Horror! Repeats at 8:45 p.m.

title: A Walk in the Woods
description: WHO Jon P. Dulude, 63, a retired kitchen and bath equipment sales representative from York, Me.

title: Mozart Piano Concertos in Two Takes
description: Computers, it is said, can do anything, provided they are asked the right questions. Symphony orchestras  the kind with the near-limitless talent of the New York Philharmonic  are pretty much the same. Conductors with the right questions can make the Philharmonic glitter, bang, coo or roar to their own specifications. Colin Davis, who conducted the orchestra at Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday, turned it into a collection of exemplary Mozarteans.

title: Juilliard Students Put Spins on Tharp and a Premiere
description: Because of the level of performing at the Spring Dances at Juilliard program on Wednesday night, it was easy to imagine these sophomore, junior and senior students stepping right into professional careers.

title: How to Tell a Billionaire From a Bomber
description: The Billionaires, with a capital B, were delighted to hear that there are more superrich New Yorkers than they had thought.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article last Friday about roofs covered by vegetation referred incorrectly to the roof planned for the new California Academy of Sciences building. It will be the largest continuous swath of native vegetation in San Francisco, according to Paul Kephart, who is the technical consultant for the roof; it will not be the largest continuous swath of vegetation of any kind in San Francisco.

title: Correction: French Lick Returns to Its Sin City Roots
description: An article on March 16 about the reopening of resorts at French Lick, Ind., misstated the name of a golf tournament that Walter Hagen won there in 1924. It was the PGA Championship, not the United States Open.

title: Two Calls Still Have the Fans Buzzing
description: ATLANTA, March 29  Baseball has Umpire Don Denkingers call that helped the Kansas City Royals win the 1985 World Series. Soccer has Diego Maradonas so-called Hand of God goal that helped Argentina win the 1986 World Cup. Hockey has Brett Hull scoring the goal that clinched the Stanley Cup in 1999 even though his skate was in the crease before the puck was. But the N.C.A.A. basketball tournament has somehow avoided those kinds of inglorious moments, when a referees mistake leaves a lasting scar on a championship.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: POP

title: Seekers of True Stories Unite
description: CYNTHIA WADE, who has been making documentaries for 20 years, was once part of a smaller crowd.

title: Presidential Candidates Focus on Fund-Raising
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  Forget campaigning. Last week, Rudolph W. Giuliani held a presidential fund-raiser every day of the week. Senator John McCain raised money at three events on Wednesday and another Thursday, racking up 27 this month alone. And Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton is racing through five fund-raisers on Friday and Saturday, culminating with a gala in Miami that ends three hours before midnight.

title: Iraqi Widow Saves Her Home, but Victory Is Brief
description: BAGHDAD, March 29  The two men showed up on Tuesday afternoon to evict Suaada Saadouns family. One was carrying a shiny black pistol.

title: Iran, the Vicious Victim
description: London

title: A Player Switches Sides in the Interest of Education
description: Not that Martine G. Guerrier, a self-possessed, child-obsessed education policy expert, is much of a blusher. But at first blush the arrangement recently struck between Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, the Department of Education and Ms. Guerrier, formerly a most outspoken appointee to the citys Panel for Educational Policy as well as its first Haitian-American soccer mom, sounds like an exercise in keeping friends close and enemies closer. For all three parties, finally, unanimity! Or maybe not.

title: House Budget Is Clear on Spending, Vague on Revenue
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  House Democrats passed a five-year spending plan Thursday that offers something to almost everybody but leaves many questions unanswered  much like the plan passed last week by the Senate.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on Wednesday about the success of the Comedy Central cable channel misstated the precedent for a video game based on South Park, a popular Comedy Central series. One was released in 1998; a cell-phone game based on South Park planned by Viacom, Comedy Centrals parent company, will not be the first.

title: Heads of Arab States Prod Israel to Embrace Peace Offer
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 29  The leaders of 21 Arab governments on Thursday called on Israel to embrace a peace initiative that would have it withdraw from the land it occupied in the 1967 war in exchange for full diplomatic relations with them, saying the window would not remain open for long.

title: Listening to Then and Now (They Sound a Lot Alike)
description: During an onstage interview at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening, John Schaefer asked Anna Maria Friman why so many new-music partisans feel an affinity for very early music as well. Ms. Friman was probably the ideal person to ask, since her group, the Trio Mediaeval, sings medieval and modern music, and nothing between. And as it happened, her Norwegian trio was sharing the bill  an installment of Mr. Schaefers New Sounds Live series  with the Crash Ensemble, an Irish new-music band that plays with the energy and spirit of a rock group.

title: Yankees Are a Mans Mans Mans World
description: Is there an eager heir to claim the South Bronx house that George Steinbrenner is building right next door to the Babes? Is there a progeny exhibiting enough big-league potential on the family thoroughbred farm?

title: Pressed, Kyrgyz President Names His Critic as Premier
description: ALMATY, Kazakhstan, March 29  Under heavy pressure from an increasingly energized political opposition, the president of Kyrgyzstan appointed one of his critics as prime minister on Thursday, providing a highly visible platform for an opposition figure in a region uniformly dominated by one-party politics.

title: A Budget Deal Is Announced, Minus Details
description: ALBANY, March 29  Gov. Eliot Spitzer and legislative leaders agreed behind closed doors to double the number of charter schools in the state to 200 and create a fund of more than a half-billion dollars for stem cell research, officials said late Thursday night.

title: Flowers, Not Fanfare, for Brooke Astors 105th
description: Five years ago, to celebrate the occasion of Brooke Astors 100th birthday, her longtime friend David Rockefeller offered her a lavish party at his familys estate in Pocantico Hills, N.Y., that was attended by nearly 100 guests from the top reaches of New Yorks social strata.

title: Manhattan: Slight Drop in City Unemployment
description: New York Citys unemployment rate dropped to 4.8 percent in February, from 4.9 percent in January, the State Labor Department reported yesterday. The citys jobless rate, adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, has held below 5 percent for seven consecutive months, the longest stretch since 1988. The states jobless rate rose to 4.4 percent, from 4.3 percent in January, but remained below the national rate of 4.5 percent. The number of private-sector jobs in the state increased only slightly last month, rising by 5,200, or 0.1 percent, to 7.18 million. In the last 12 months, the state has added 103,100 private-sector jobs, a gain of 1.2 percent.

title: Urban Human Hounds Tracking Down the Beers
description: A FEW minutes after the lead runners scattered in all directions to search for their next mark, Edward Coda stopped on the corner of West 13th Street and Eighth Avenue to inquire about where the chalk-drawn trail picked up next. Which way did they go? Mr. Coda asked. I have two virgins following me. And theyre pretty slow.

title: Study Finds Shark Overfishing May Lower Scallop Population
description: For years, conservationists have warned about overfishing of large sharks in the northwestern Atlantic, as the demand for meat and fins, coupled with slow growth and reproduction rates of many species, has caused sharp declines in populations of hammerheads, duskies and other sharks.

title: A Longer Day for Schoolchildren? (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Pork Goes to War
description: EMERGENCY spending bills are called Christmas trees, for the unrelated ornaments that are added by members of Congress. (They are exempt from budget rules and are almost never vetoed, making them magnets for pork.) The nickname is usually not literal, but the Senates version of the fiscal 2007 supplemental appropriations bill that passed yesterday includes, among scores of other nonessential items, money for Christmas-tree growers.

title: Correction: Ski Resort Chic in the Mountains of Quebec
description: The Havens column last Friday about the weekend home market around the Mont Tremblant ski area in Quebec misstated the village where an Irish pub is expected to open soon. It is in the village of Mont Tremblant, not in nearby St.-Jovite.

title: Defying Bush, Senate Passes Iraq Spending Measure
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  Issuing a stinging challenge to President Bush, the Senate on Thursday approved a spending measure that provided more than $97.5 billion for military operations in Iraq and Afghanistan but ordered troop withdrawals from Iraq to begin within 120 days and set a goal of removing most armed forces within a year.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the reoccupation of an evacuated Israeli settlement in the West Bank by about 2,000 right-wing activists referred incompletely to the name of the mainstream organization of Israeli settlers, which did not endorse the action. It is the Yesha Council, not Yesha. (Yesha is the Hebrew acronym used by many settlers for the West Bank and Gaza.) (Go to Article)

title: Disgruntled Shareholders Vote in New Board at Take Two Interactive
description: Take Two Interactive software, the video game maker mired in boardroom factions, grand jury subpoenas and bad fortunes, faced an insurrection from shareholders yesterday that claimed the chief executive and three directors who were at the center of a stock options backdating scandal.

title: Its Fantasy Office 2007
description: OFFICE Fever: Catch it! Baseball season starts April 1, as does the 3rd quarter of Fiscal Year 2007. Youve drafted a powerhouse fantasy-baseball team; here are our picks for the ultimate fantasy-office roster.

title: The Sound of One Heart Breaking
description: The substance is in the silences in The Year of Magical Thinking, the arresting yet ultimately frustrating new drama starring Vanessa Redgrave that opened last night at the Booth Theater.

title: Read Me: It Was a Dark and Stormy Night ... (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Higher Self-Esteem Through Robbery
description: Ritual. Pattern. Repetition.

title: The Republic of Beauty, Melding West and East
description: Told often enough that the West and Islam are natural enemies, we start to believe it, and assume it has always been so. But the Metropolitan Museum of Art argues otherwise in Venice and the Islamic World, 828-1797, a show that, with classic Met largesse, recreates the spectacle of two different cultures meeting in one fantastic city, where commerce and love of beauty, those great levelers, unite them in a fruitful bond.

title: Art in Review
description: KRISTIN BAKER   Surge and Shadow Deitch Projects, 18 Wooster Street, SoHo Through April 14

title: Deal Makers Are Setting a Torrid Pace for 2007
description: After breaking the record for mergers and acquisitions last year, deal makers have started 2007 at an even faster pace.

title: S.I. Man Is Sentenced to Die for Slaying 2 Detectives
description: Standing before the Great Seal of the United States of America, under the gaze of hundreds, Ronell Wilson was dispatched from the city of his childhood yesterday and ordered to die for the murder of two police detectives.

title: Giuliani Testified He Was Briefed on Kerik in 00
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani told a grand jury that his former chief investigator remembered having briefed him on some aspects of Bernard B. Keriks relationship with a company suspected of ties to organized crime before Mr. Keriks appointment as New York City police commissioner, according to court records.

title: Southern Furniture That Has Survived Fire, Hurricanes and Damn Yankees
description: CHARLESTON, S.C.  Of the 32 dealers exhibiting at the Charleston International Antiques Show in March only two were selling Colonial and Federal furniture made in Charleston, which is highly prized here.

title: Live From the Rink, Its Will Ferrell on Ice
description: Will Ferrell is a ferocious marshmallow. In his dumb but endearing sports comedies, the spirit may be willing, but the flesh is flabby. As he ricochets from triumph to humiliation and back, he suggests an armchair George Plimpton whose characters, driven by an outlandish grandiosity, are deeply reassuring. For the sake of his career, Mr. Ferrell should never join a gym; buffed up, he would cease being one of us.

title: Survey Swaps MetroCards for Meal Receipts
description: Workers with the New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene have begun approaching patrons outside some chain restaurants and offering them $2 MetroCards in exchange for their dining receipts.

title: U.S. to Set New Duties on Goods From China
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  The Bush administration, in a major escalation of trade pressure on China, said Friday that it would reverse more than 20 years of American policy and impose potentially steep tariffs on Chinese manufactured goods on the ground that China is illegally subsidizing some of its exports.

title: Hong Kongs Sort of Election
description: The re-election this week of Donald Tsang as Hong Kongs chief executive was not a surprise, given Beijings control over the vote. What has turned out to be surprising is how Mr. Tsang was officially challenged for his job by a pro-democracy candidate with no backing from the mainland. And that brave challenger managed to get 123 of 796 electors to vote for him. Such an orderly challenge  plus the lack of social upheaval caused by this quasi-election  should send an important signal to Mr. Tsang and to Beijing. Ten years after the British handed over the islands to the Chinese, it is time to bring universal suffrage to Hong Kong.

title: Disuse of System Is Cited in Gaps in Soldiers Care
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  Lapses in using a digital medical record system for tracking wounded soldiers have led to medical mistakes and delays in care, and have kept thousands of injured troops from getting benefits, according to former defense and military medical officials.

title: Heralding Holidays With Sweet Sounds of Musical Joy
description: A sampling of noteworthy musical presentations planned for the holiday season at churches and concert halls in New York City, from this Sunday (Palm Sunday) through April 8 (Easter Sunday), selected by Vivien Schweitzer. All are free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations. Unless noted, church choirs are featured in church concerts.)

title: Bush vs. Congress Over the War (7 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Austrian, 90, Dies; Developed Major Vaccine
description: Dr. Robert Austrian, who developed a pneumococcal vaccine that has saved the lives of hundreds of thousands of people, died Sunday in Philadelphia. He was 90.

title: Spare Times: For Children
description: FOR CHILDREN

title: Young Carries Mountaineers to N.I.T. Title
description: In March, there has been a sort of madness to Frank Youngs game, the kind that comes when a player has tremendous confidence and seems to have forgotten that this sport is not supposed to be this easy. Young, a West Virginia senior, did it again last night, scoring 24 points to lead the Mountaineers to a 78-73 victory over Clemson and their first title in the National Invitation Tournament since 1942.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Science Times on March 13 about efforts to increase the number of minority students studying science referred imprecisely to the Meyerhoff Scholarship Program at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. Although the program indeed emphasizes the need for more minority students, it is open to any undergraduate.

title: An Inside Look at Life in an Exclusive Boys Club
description: The obnoxious princes who roll through the A&E reality series Sons of Hollywood are evidently presented as case studies in social Darwinism. Its not so much that theyre the offspring of celebrities, and thus big hounds; its that theyre the sons  two of the three, anyway  of that particular American combination of shrewd, rags-to-riches dads and modelicious moms.

title: Project Runway
description: AS the masseuses hands prod my back and dig into the folds behind my neck, I can feel my strained muscles begin to recover. Soft choral music, like monks chanting, plays around my head, and a light scent of juniper berries wafts through the room. I close my eyes and slowly drift off to sleep in the plush chair.

title: Rare Chance to Try Out a Masterpiece
description: When Antonio Stradivari of Cremona, Italy, started making violins in the 1660s, Newton had not yet discovered the principles of modern physics and the first piano had not yet been manufactured.

title: With the Greatest of Ease
description: THE Wheel of Death. To performers and audiences alike, this is the classic  and only  name for the enormous apparatus that spins menacingly under the spotlights in the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus.

title: Lawrence Township: Student Injured in Possible Hazing
description: A Rider University freshman was in critical condition yesterday after what prosecutors termed a possible hazing episode at a fraternity house, the Mercer County prosecutors office said. The student, Gary Devercelly, 18, of Long Beach, Calif., was taken to the Fuld campus of Capital Health System in Trenton around 2 a.m. yesterday after the police came to the Phi Kappa Tau fraternity house at Rider University because of a report that a student was vomiting after he drank too much, Prosecutor Casey DeBlasio said in a statement. Another student who left the house earlier was treated at the hospital for alcohol poisoning and released. Prosecutors said the matter was under investigation as a possible case of hazing.

title: Jazz Listings
description: Full reviews of recent jazz concerts: nytimes.com/music.

title: Drug for Stomach Ills Is Pulled From the Market
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  The maker of Zelnorm, a medicine that treats irritable bowel syndrome, withdrew the drug from the market today after federal drug officials concluded that it could increase the risks of heart attacks and strokes.

title: A Union Takes Cautious Aim at Blackstones Public Offering Plan
description: Norma Rae, Wall Street insider?

title: No Cellphones in the Air (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Feels Sting of Winning Saudi Help With Other Arabs
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  American officials said Thursday that they were caught off guard by remarks by the Saudi king condemning the American intervention in Iraq as an illegal foreign occupation and were seeking clarification. But they sought to tamp down tensions over the comments.

title: Whereabouts in Watts? Where Poetry Meets Chaos
description: For three long decades, Charles Burnetts Killer of Sheep, a fictional portrait of a working-class black family living in a broken-down home in a bombed-out stretch of Los Angeles, has been largely hidden from view. Shot in Watts in the early 70s and completed in 1977, the film was Mr. Burnetts M.F.A. thesis project and never meant for a commercial release. He operated the 16-millimeter camera himself, edited the black-and-white images into a visual poem and added the ballads, the jazz and the moody blues that seep into your head like smoke. The result is an American masterpiece, independent to the bone.

title: Island Gardens and Silverline
description: Island Gardens

title: Tehran Levels New Charges About Seized Britons
description: LONDON, March 29  Iran leveled new accusations against Britain on Thursday in the crisis over 15 captured British sailors and marines, and withdrew a promise to free the only woman in the group, insisting that Britain admit fault before any captives were released.

title: Day of Decision Looms for Several Mets on the Bubble
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 29  Joe Smith and Aaron Sele have made the Mets roster, that much is sure. The remainder of the Mets decisions, and they have several to make for only two roster spots, will come Friday, when the events of their game against the Florida Marlins could determine who heads to St. Louis, Class AAA New Orleans or parts unknown.

title: Rats in His Sights, and in His Backpack, Too
description: Robert M. Corrigans favorite table at his favorite Starbucks, just across Park Row from City Hall Park in Lower Manhattan, looks out on an ancient alley where he said rats often scamper.

title: Panel Endorses New Anti-Tumor Treatment
description: The first therapy that would direct a cancer patients own immune system to attack tumors moved a step closer to approval yesterday when it was endorsed by a federal advisory committee.

title: An Endgame in Zimbabwe That Mugabe May Yet Win
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe, March 27  To those who ask how long President Robert G. Mugabe can remain in control of Zimbabwe, given its wildfire inflation, the growing desperation of average people and the oppositions increasingly open hatred of the government, a former member of that government has an answer: longer than one might think.

title: The Way the World Ends, Vividly Imagined
description: The Seventh Seal, Pale Rider and Armageddon might make an unlikely triple feature, but the movies titles share the same source: the Book of Revelation. Also known as the Apocalypse, the last book of the New Testament is etched in Western cultural consciousness.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: A front-page article yesterday about living with the early stages of Alzheimers disease misstated the number of couples New York University had planned to accommodate in counseling sessions for Alzheimers patients and their spouses, and included erroneous information from the university on how many signed up. The sessions were to include 100 couples, not 200, and 26 couples enrolled, not 16. Also, a picture caption with the article misstated the age of Peter Hebert, who advocates for patients in Northern California. As the article noted, he is 67, not 76.

title: Still Ailing, Knicks Richardson May Have Back Surgery
description: Quentin Richardsons season is over and his future is somewhat clouded because of a back injury that apparently will require surgery.

title: Fests and Finery
description: A sampling of holiday celebrations in New York City, including dance and readings. Admission is free unless noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: More Than 100 Are Killed in Iraq as a Wave of Sectarian Attacks Shows No Sign of Letting Up
description: BAGHDAD, March 29  More than 100 people were killed Thursday in a series of attacks around Iraq that included two suicide bombings that struck crowded markets during the weeks busiest shopping hours, the authorities said.

title: CarMaxs Income Rises
description: The used-car retailer CarMax reported yesterday that fiscal fourth-quarter net income rose 15 percent, driven by a 12 percent increase in used-vehicle sales and an income increase from its financing unit.

title: Bangladesh Deals Swift Justice for Islamist Militants
description: NEW DELHI, March 30  The military-backed government of Bangladesh has executed six Islamist militants in connection with the murder of two judges, in a case that has come to signify unusually swift justice. The men had said in court that they sought to replace the countrys secular penal code with Islamic Shariah law.

title: New York City to Reward Poor for Doing Right Thing
description: Seeking new solutions to New Yorks vexingly high poverty rates, the city is moving ahead with an ambitious experiment that will pay poor families up to $5,000 a year to meet goals like attending parent-teacher conferences, going for a medical checkup or holding down a full-time job, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about the pending retirements of 11 of New Jerseys 40 state senators referred incorrectly to a previous large turnover, when 24 senators were defeated or retired in reaction to the Watergate scandal, and misstated the year that Gov. Jim Florio pushed through an unpopular tax increase, which led to another turnover. The election defeats took place in 1973, not 1974, and the tax increase was enacted in 1990, not 1992. The article also misstated the home county of one of this years retiring senators, Robert J. Martin. He is from Morris County, not Bergen.

title: Georgetown Player's Ignominious Mark
description: WASHINGTON, March 28  For the first time since 1985, Georgetown University has reached the Final Four of the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament. Coach John Thompson III and his assistants have led a swift and stunning revival of the program in just three seasons, a timetable so short that even Thompson said it exceeded his expectations.

title: Honda Wants to Be Known for Safety
description: MARYSVILLE, Ohio  From the time it started selling cars in the United States 35 years ago, Honda has fostered a reputation for building fuel-efficient vehicles.

title: Shootings Add to Denvers Anxiety, and Its Unsolved Crimes
description: DENVER, March 29  A rash of seemingly random shootings last weekend has baffled the police here and added to the unease of a city that in recent months has experienced a series of unsolved violent crimes.

title: Hot Dog Menu Draws a $250 Foie Gras Fine
description: CHICAGO, March 29  The owner of a hot dog restaurant offering sausages named after celebrities is the first person to be punished under a city ordinance that is the first in the country to ban the sale of foie gras.

title: F.D.A. Tests Show Chemical in Pet Food
description: ATLANTA, Ga., March 30  Scientists with the Food and Drug Administration have linked a chemical to the illness and deaths of cats eating tainted food and raised for the first time the possibility that dry pet food may have been affected as well as wet food.

title: After Beating Federer, Caas Keeps Winning
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 29  The first time Guillermo Caas overthrew the king, he was so consumed with the spoils of victory that he was ousted in the next round.

title: A Quaint Town With Quiet Things to Do
description: A long row of tall, black gaslights, standing as ramrod straight as soldiers on a parade ground, stretches for several blocks down the middle of Main Street in Wellsboro, Pa. They cast a gauzy, cozy, stay-a-while glow.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 3,237 American service members who have died since the start of the Iraq war. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Discovery to Buy Out Cox, a Major Shareholder
description: Discovery Communications said yesterday that it planned to buy out one of its three shareholders, Cox Communications, in a deal that included transferring the Travel Channel and $1.275 billion in cash to Cox for its 25 percent stake in the company.

title: Guantnamo Tribunal Accepts Australians Plea
description: GUANTANAMO BAY, Cuba, March 30  David M. Hicks, the Australian high-school drop out whose detention here has become an issue internationally, acknowledged in a military commission hearing here today that prosecutors had the evidence to prove he was an Al Qaeda trainee armed with an AK-47 who was prepared to fight Americans in the 2001 Afghanistan conflict.

title: Howell Township: Cause of Plane Crash Is Unclear
description: A pilot who was killed Wednesday night when his small plane crashed into the woods in Howell Township radioed air traffic control moments before the crash and did not indicate that anything was wrong, officials said yesterday. The Federal Aviation Administration said the pilot, Eugene R. Pilot, 70, of Neptune, was returning to Allaire Airport in Farmingdale after an hourlong flight when his single-engine Piper PA-28 crashed just after 8 p.m. The cause of the crash is still under investigation, said Bob Gretz of the National Transportation Safety Board.

title: Stockholders Oust Chief at Take-Two
description: Take-Two Interactive Software, the video game maker mired in boardroom factions, grand jury subpoenas and bad fortunes, faced an insurrection from shareholders yesterday that claimed the chief executive and three directors who were at the center of a stock options backdating scandal.

title: Thai Premier Rejects State of Emergency as Way to Halt Protests
description: BANGKOK, March 29  Prime Minister Surayud Chulanont of Thailand on Thursday rejected the advice of the general who put him in power, declining to declare a state of emergency in Bangkok to clamp down on antigovernment protesters. Instead, he promised to hold elections before the end of the year.

title: Uncle Ben, Board Chairman
description: A racially charged advertising character, who for decades has been relegated to a minor role in the marketing of the products that still carry his name, is taking center stage in a campaign that gives him a makeover  Madison Avenue style  by promoting him to chairman of the company.

title: In His White House, Giuliani Says, His Wife Might Have a Very Visible Role as Adviser
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani says that if he were president, his wife would be permitted to attend cabinet meetings and advise him on federal policy, an unusually overt role in government decision-making for a first lady.

title: A Step for Voting Rights
description: The Maryland Legislature struck a blow for democracy when it voted to overturn a law that barred more than 50,000 ex-offenders from the polls in the last presidential election. By signing the measure into law, Gov. Martin OMalley would make Maryland part of a growing movement for electoral fairness. He also would simplify one of the most complicated and confusing voting bans in the nation.

title: Unusually Good Food at an Unusual Hill
description: FOR sheer awfulness, the food sweating beneath the heat lamps at North Americas ski-area cafeterias could give airline fare a run for its money. Resort operators have tried to breathe life into their menus in recent years  bread bowl o chowder, anyone?  but the only thing that continues to be raised is prices, not the bar.

title: Pompoms, Pyramids and Peril
description: For decades, they stood by safe and smiling, a fixture on Americas sporting sidelines. But todays young cheerleaders, who perform tricks once reserved for trapeze artists, may be in more peril than any female athletes in the country.

title: The Drawing Center Names a Director
description: After a years search the Drawing Center has appointed an executive director: Brett Littman, who has been deputy director of the P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center in Long Island City, Queens, for nearly four years.

title: Ex-Aide Rejects Gonzales Stand Over Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  The former chief of staff to Alberto R. Gonzales testified on Thursday that he had consulted regularly with the attorney general about dismissing United States attorneys, disputing Mr. Gonzaless public account of his role as very limited.

title: Shiite Cleric Calls for Mass Protest Against U.S.
description: BAGHDAD, March 30  Religious leaders commanded by the radical Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr delivered a searing speech at Friday prayers today condemning the American presence in Iraq, while militiamen loyal to Mr. Sadr engaged in street battles against Iraqi Army soldiers in southwestern Baghdad, suggesting a resurgence of the militia.

title: Lottery Numbers
Ollies Restaurant Workers Sue, Complaining of Underpayment
description: Ollies, one of Manhattans best-known Chinese restaurant chains, was sued yesterday by 43 waiters, deliverymen and other workers who accused it of violating minimum wage laws by paying some employees as little as $1.40 an hour.

title: Manhattan: New Latino Theater Festival Announced
description: The city will play host to a new theater festival this spring featuring works by artists from New York, Latin America, the Caribbean and Spain, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The festival, TeatroStageFest, will run from April 30 through May 13 at sites in the East Fourth Street Cultural District, the mayor said. The festival will feature seven theatrical productions, panel discussions and concerts, Mr. Bloomberg said.

title: Manhattan: New Latino Theater Festival Announced
description: The city will play host to a new theater festival this spring featuring works by artists from New York, Latin America, the Caribbean and Spain, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg announced yesterday. The festival, TeatroStageFest, will run from April 30 through May 13 at sites in the East Fourth Street Cultural District, the mayor said. The festival will feature seven theatrical productions, panel discussions and concerts, Mr. Bloomberg said.

title: Roadblock for Spreading of Human Ashes in Wilderness
description: MISSOULA, Mont.  Last wishes notwithstanding, federal officials are opposed to a Montana womans plan for a business that would spread the cremated remains of her clients over western Montanas publicly owned wild mountain peaks and flower-studded meadows.

title: Shifty Wedding Crashers: Secrets From the Past
description: In After the Wedding, a Danish drama about ideals and money, sanctimony and obligation, bodies ricochet off one another like pinballs. Shot in digital video with a skittish, at times urgent freehand, the movie opens in India, where slender adults and scrambling children often fill every inch of the frame amid whorls of color and noise. Later, when the story moves to Denmark, where the bodies are paler and more spatially separated, the chaos of the street will have been replaced by the din of selfish human desire.

title: Austria: Specialty Steel Maker Is Acquired
description: Voestalpine, the biggest steel maker in Austria, agreed to buy a specialty-steel producer, Boehler-Uddeholm, for 3.52 billion euros ($4.69 billion), foiling a bid by a private equity company, CVC Capital Partners. Voestalpine, based in Linz, said it had agreed to pay 69 euros a share for Boehler. The acquisition will give Voestalpine a steel maker with customers worldwide including the Boeing Company and Airbus. CVC Capital, which is based in London, said last week that it planned to bid for Boehler, but Boehler, based in Vienna, said it opposed the bid.

title: The Battle-Scarred Heros (Near) Legacy in Art
description: In the midst of the Dutch and Spanish dignitaries in the foreground of Diego Velzquezs war tableau The Surrender of Breda, there is a small open space beneath one soldiers horizontal weapon. It appears to depict the back of the soldier beside him. But it is the suggestion of Arturo Prez-Revertes latest installment in his grandly entertaining Captain Alatriste series that Alatriste, he of the cold gray-green eyes and dauntless courage, was once part of the picture  although his likeness has since been excised.

title: Texas Law Firm Will Close and Settle Tax Shelter Case
description: Jenkens & Gilchrist, once a highflying Texas law firm with a national reach, will shut its doors for good and pay the Internal Revenue Service a $76 million fine as part of a deal announced yesterday with the Justice Department over questionable tax shelters.

title: Gates Signals Willingness to Close Prison
description: WASHINGTON, March 29 (Bloomberg)  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates indicated Thursday a willingness to close the United States prison for terrorism suspects at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, as long as a way could be found to keep the most dangerous detainees behind bars.

title: Arts, Briefly
description: Foxy Brown Books Her Next Fight

title: Ethiopian Helicopter Shot Down in Somali Capital
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 30  Missile-toting Somali rebels shot an Ethiopian helicopter gunship out of the sky today, apparently killing the crew and sending a fireball of a signal that they are as determined  and dangerous  as ever.

title: 3 Companies in Telecom Win U.S. Deal Worth Billions
description: The federal government said yesterday that it had selected AT&T, Verizon and Qwest Communications to bid on portions of the governments biggest telecommunications contract ever, leaving one longtime partner, Sprint Nextel, out in the cold.

title: Tensions Over French Identity Shape Voter Drives
description: PARIS, March 29  Frances presidential campaign has been seized by a subject long monopolized by the extreme right: how best to be French.

title: Voices Raised
description: A sampling of choral works for the Easter season in New York City. Admission is free unless otherwise noted. (Churches accept donations.)

title: Spare Times
description: AROUND TOWN

title: Communing With Nature on a Grand Scale
description: Although he was one of the greats of 19th-century American landscape painting and a founder of the Hudson River School, in the market madness of the current art world Asher B. Durand only recently became a boldface name. In May 2005 the New York Public Library allowed its star painting, Durands 1849 Kindred Spirits, to be spirited away for about $35 million by the Wal-Mart heiress Alice L. Walton, who is building the Crystal Bridges Museum of American Art in Bentonville, Ark.

title: Olmert Rejects Palestinian Right of Return
description: TEL AVIV, March 30  Israeli Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said in interviews published today that Israel would not allow a single Palestinian refugee to return to what is now Israel and that Israel bore no responsibility for the refugees, whose plight resulted from an attack by Arab nations on the fledgling state.

title: Spring Valley: Bus-Baked Matzo Not Done Yet
description: A Spring Valley building inspector said yesterday that the village would allow a rabbi to continue making matzo out of a large oven inside a school bus in his backyard. Rabbi Aaron Winternitz, who is also a schoolteacher, installed the oven in the bus, which sits behind his house, three years ago and has used it to make matzo for his congregation every Passover. But last week, after a neighbor complained of heavy smoke, village officials inspected the bus and ordered Rabbi Winternitz to shut it down. He was ordered to disconnect gas lines , move the bus further away from the house, and provide the village with engineering documents indicating that the oven was safe, said Manny Carmona, the deputy building inspector. Yesterday, however, Mr. Carmona said Rabbi Winternitz had been given a temporary reprieve because Passover, which begins Monday at sundown, is almost here.

title: Iran Broadcasts New Video of Seized Britons
description: LONDON, March 30  Iranian televisions Arabic-language channel broadcast footage on Friday of a captured British Royal Marine seeming to apologize deeply for entering Iranian waters without permission. Iran also released what it said was a third letter from Faye Turney, the only woman among the captives, in which she purportedly complained of being sacrificed to British and American policies.

title: Toyota Deepens Discounts on Its New Pickup
description: DETROIT, March 29  Toyota Motor continues to increase discounts on its new full-size pickup, the Tundra, another sign that it is not cutting into the profitable truck market as much as rival automakers had feared.

title: Younger and Cheaper Make Yankees Roster
description: DUNEDIN, Fla., March 30  Sean Henn had no idea where the Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre Yankees open the season. Now he won't have to make the gloomy two-day journey to Pennsylvania to find out.

title: Theater Listings
description: FIRST LIGHT A monthlong series of plays devoted to scientific and technological topics might not sound like an exciting string of nights out, but the folks behind the Ensemble Studio Theater/Alfred P. Sloan Foundation Science & Technology Project hope to persuade audiences otherwise.

title: Lawmaker in New Jersey Is Charged With Fraud
description: TRENTON, March 29  One of New Jerseys veteran legislators was indicted on fraud and corruption charges on Thursday. He is accused of using his considerable influence to gain a $37,000-a-year no-show job at the state medical school in exchange for bringing it millions of dollars in grants.

title: Fox News and Black Caucus Team Up on Debates
description: Fox News and the Congressional Black Caucus Political Education and Leadership Institute announced that they had agreed to sponsor two debates for presidential candidates this year. Negotiations between the network and the institute had been closely watched since Nevada Democrats backed out of a debate for Democratic candidates a few weeks ago that was sponsored by Fox News. The deal was canceled after liberal advocates and bloggers criticized the states Democratic leaders and Senator Harry Reid, the majority leader, for choosing the conservative-leaning network as a sponsor. The schedule for debates by Fox and the institute, includes a Sept. 23 event for Democratic candidates in Detroit. No date has been set for a Republican debate.

title: Story Time in the Senate
description: In his Senate testimony yesterday, Kyle Sampson, the former chief of staff to Attorney General Alberto Gonzales, tried to be a loyal Bushie, a term Mr. Sampson used in his infamous e-mail message to describe what he was looking for in United States attorneys. But if Mr. Sampson was trying to fall on his sword, he had horrible aim. In testimony that got so embarrassing for the White House that the Republicans tried to cut it off, Mr. Sampson simply ended up making it clearer than ever that the eight prosecutors were fired for political reasons.

title: South Africa: Town Gets Apartheid-Era Name Back
description: An appeals court rejected the governments renaming of the Limpopo town of Louis Trichardt to Makhado. Louis Trichardt was an Afrikaaner who led the trek to the area in the 1830s; Makhado was a local king there who resisted white invaders. The court said that officials did not sufficiently clear the change with the towns residents. The decision was a rare victory for advocates who have sought to block the scrapping of apartheid-era names for South African cities, streets and natural features in favor of African names. The countrys Arts and Culture Ministry said it accepted the decision, which was based on procedural issues, but did not say whether it would reopen the matter.

title: White House Proposal Would Move Illegal Immigrants Off the Citizenship Path
description: White House officials have issued a discussion document on immigration that calls for legislation that would grant legal status to illegal immigrants and guest workers, but would not put them on a path to citizenship. It would allow illegal immigrants to remain in the country indefinitely, under certain conditions, and would require guest workers to leave the country after six years. The document, drafted after several meetings with Republican senators, was designed to garner broad Republican support for key immigration principals. Democratic and Republican senators are negotiating in hope of coming to a consensus on an immigration bill.

title: Racy Letters From Hemingway to Dietrich to Be Unsealed
description: BOSTON, March 29  Ernest Hemingway, Nobel Prize-winning American novelist and hunter of lions, was not good at everything, it seems, including aquatic love. At least thats what he wrote to the actress Marlene Dietrich.

title: George Izenour, 94, Designer of Technologies for Theaters, Dies
description: George C. Izenour, a pioneer in theater design and technology who helped bring automation to stagecraft, died Saturday in Philadelphia. He was 94.

title: Bomber Kills Pakistani Soldier in Training Area
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, March 29  A suicide bomber blew himself up Thursday in a military training area in Punjab Province, killing a soldier and wounding seven others, military officials said.

title: Staten Island: Off-Duty Officer Rescues Child From Fire
description: An off-duty narcotics detective spotted a house fire in Castleton Corners yesterday morning and rescued a 4-year-old boy from the burning building, the police said. The detective, Vincent DiCrescento, was driving past 70 Windsor Road about 5 a.m. when he saw the three-story house burning, the police said. After phoning 911, Detective DiCrescento knocked on doors and alerted residents. Spotting a man calling for help from a third-floor window, Detective DiCrescento used an extension ladder to climb halfway up the building and grabbed the child when the man lowered him from the window. The man and his wife, who were not named by the police yesterday, were later led to safety by firefighters, the police said. The fire was brought under control just before 6 a.m., the Fire Department said.

title: Ruling Could Lead to Tariffs on Chinese Goods
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  In a ruling that could lead to new trade barriers on imports from China, a federal judge on Thursday dismissed a bid by China to block the Bush administration from imposing tariffs on Chinese goods produced by heavily subsidized government companies.

title: Another Ecuador Crisis Deepens as a Judge Is Fired Ahead of Voting
description: CARACAS, Venezuela, March 29  First, Ecuadors highest electoral court fired more than half of the countrys lawmakers this month. Then, the ousted lawmakers, who had been attacked by a mob of protesters, were issued an injunction from a provincial judge suspending their firing.

title: Charlotte Winters, 109, a Navy Enlistee in World War I, Dies
description: Charlotte Winters, the last surviving woman to have served in the American armed forces in World War I and one of the first to enlist in the Navy, died Tuesday at her home in Boonsboro, Md. She was 109.

title: Planned House Vote on Armenian Massacre Angers Turks
description: ISTANBUL, March 29  A planned vote in Congress that would classify the widespread killings of Armenians by the Ottoman Turkish government early in the 20th century as genocide is threatening to make bilateral relations unusually tense.

title: European Banker Joins March to Private Equity
description: LONDON, March 29  Leonhard Fischer resigned as the head of Credit Suisse Group in Europe on Thursday, a month after being passed over for chief executive, a job that went to Brady W. Dougan.

title: Power Atop the Yankees Looks to Remain a Steinbrenner Affair
description: Steve Swindal reported for work yesterday at Legends Field in what was certainly one of his final days as George Steinbrenners presumed successor at the Yankees.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings
description: ART

title: A Homespun Mendelssohn and a Liszt Knuckle-Buster
description: For all that the Canadian pianist Marc-Andr Hamelin has been typecast as a performer of near-superhuman technical prowess, his latest New York recital, at the 92nd Street Y on Wednesday night, opened with a tone of decided understatement. Mendelssohns Lied ohne Worte (Songs Without Words) are the antithesis of flashy: homespun and lyrical are more apt descriptions.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on March 12 about the last night at the Roxy, a discothque in Chelsea, misstated its history. It first became known in 1990 as a gay nightclub on Saturday nights, at the direction of two promoters, Lee Chappell and David Leigh  not in 1991, the year that John Blair, the promoter with whom the club became associated, arrived.

title: Rejected by Harvard? Your Valedictorian Probably Was, Too
description: Harvard College rejected 91 percent of applicants for the coming academic year, the highest rate in its history, after an expansion of financial aid encouraged more applications. A record 22,955 students applied to be part of the incoming freshman class at the college, the part of the university in Cambridge, Mass., focusing on undergraduate education. The college sent out 2,058 acceptance notices in December and yesterday, according to a statement on its Web site. Harvard increased financial aid for the school year starting in September to allow students from families earning less than $60,000 to attend free.

title: Call It Poison (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Justices Weigh Opening New Phase on Guantnamo
description: WASHINGTON, March 29  The start of military commission proceedings has opened one new chapter in the five-year saga of the detainees at Guantnamo Bay. The Supreme Court may soon open another.

title: Drivers Shrug as Gasoline Prices Soar
description: HOUSTON, March 29  Prices at the pump are rising again, much as they do every spring as oil traders bid up the price of crude ahead of possible summer shortages. Possibilities for more conflict in Iran and elsewhere in the Middle East are adding to the surge.

title: To Stent or Not to Stent (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Art Imitates Life, as Well as the Living, Fooling Many Along the Way
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y., March 29  Though he always looks a tad grumpy, people at a luxury office building here have grown fond of Artie, the security guard in the glass booth in the lobby corner.

title: No Pet Left Behind
description: ONE brisk afternoon this past winter, the lobby of the Ritz-Carlton, Bachelor Gulch in Beaver Creek, Colo., could have been mistaken for the Westminster Kennel Club dog show.

title: A Featherless Audubon Menagerie
description: I LEFT home at ten oclock of the morning, on Saturday the 11th of March, 1843, accompanied by my son Victor. I left all well, and I trust in God for the privilege and happiness of rejoining them all some time next autumn. So wrote John James Audubon, as he began his last major expedition up the Missouri River from St. Louis, 2,000 miles to Fort Union, in what is now North Dakota.

title: Comcast Chief Executive Receives $26 Million
