description: The Comcast Corporation, the nations largest cable company, paid its chief executive, Brian L. Roberts, a total of $26 million last year, according to its proxy statement released today.

title: Staten Island: Off-Duty Officer Rescues Child From Fire
description: An off-duty narcotics detective spotted a house fire in Castleton Corners yesterday morning and rescued a 4-year-old boy from the burning building, the police said. The detective, Vincent DiCrescento, was driving past 70 Windsor Road about 5 a.m. when he saw the three-story house burning, the police said. After phoning 911, Detective DiCrescento knocked on doors and alerted residents. Spotting a man calling for help from a third-floor window, Detective DiCrescento used an extension ladder to climb halfway up the building and grabbed the child when the man lowered him from the window. The man and his wife, who were not named by the police yesterday, were later led to safety by firefighters, the police said. The fire was brought under control just before 6 a.m., the Fire Department said.

title: Herbalife Rejects Offer
description: Herbalife, a seller of nutritional supplements, has rejected a takeover offer from the private equity firm Whitney & Company.

title: A 6-6 Center Blooms at Louisiana State
description: Louisiana States interim womens coach, Bob Starkey, said last Sunday that he would lose any comparison to his more accomplished rival, Geno Auriemma of Connecticut. Auriemma was a better coach, Starkey said, more handsome, funnier and a snappier dresser.

title: Leaving Others in His Wake, Phelps Sets Another Mark
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, March 30  In the underwater world of Michael Phelps, records and gold medals are acquired seemingly at will. In the underwater world of everyone else, the outcomes are much more in doubt.

title: Manhattan: Tentative Contract Deal for Metro-North Workers
description: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority has reached a verbal agreement on contracts with two coalitions of unions on the Metro-North Railroad, ending a labor dispute that has dragged on for four years and averting the possibility that some of the unions would strike this summer. But the deal did not include track workers, who are represented by the Teamsters union. Representatives of unions and the authority last night confirmed the agreement, which is expected to be formalized today so that it can be sent to the rank and file for ratification. Metro-North workers have been divided for several years between two rival union coalitions and, with the exception of the Teamsters, this deal brings both groups together under contracts that are virtually identical, according to Norman Brown, a machinists union official who is also a member of the transportation authoritys board. The contracts give workers wage increases over the next three years of 10.5 percent.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article on Tuesday about the reoccupation of an evacuated Israeli settlement in the West Bank by about 2,000 right-wing activists referred incompletely to the name of the mainstream organization of Israeli settlers, which did not endorse the action. It is the Yesha Council, not Yesha. (Yesha is the Hebrew acronym used by many settlers for the West Bank and Gaza.)

title: Carril Is Yoda to Notion of Perpetual Motion
description: PRINCETON, N.J., March 28  Pete Carril does not understand the fuss, but he is embarrassed by it. When he began coaching the Princeton basketball team in 1967, he used a play borrowed from the Boston Celtics. He added one from the Knicks. And when those did not work  no center at Princeton passed the ball like Bill Russell and no one shot the short bank shot like Sam Jones  he devised a few variations.

title: Workers Safety and the Gun Lobby
description: The aura of invincibility that has legislatures bowing before the gun lobby is running into a commendable challenge from corporate America. Two conservative powerhouses  gun fanciers and business leaders  are facing off in statehouses over the gun lobbys attempt to stop employers from exercising their property rights and barring workers from carrying firearms to work.

title: 65 Tornadoes Sweep Through Six States, Killing Four People
description: Four people were killed in Colorado, Oklahoma and Texas after 65 tornadoes swept through six states on Wednesday, officials said yesterday.

title: Dance Listings
description: DANCE

title: New Orleans Proposes to Invest in 17 Areas
description: NEW ORLEANS, March 29  New Orleans unveiled its latest redevelopment plan Thursday, choosing 17 zones where the city has decided to concentrate resources in order to stimulate investment and renewal.

title: The Modern Mating Game Through a Low-Key Lens
description: Summer in Berlin, Andreas Dresens microscopic examination of the humdrum lives of Katrin (Inka Friedrich) and Nike (Nadja Uhl), best friends who live in the same Berlin apartment building, is a pointedly unglamorous slice of life that could be set in any urban neighborhood where real estate prices havent gone through the roof.

title: Video Games Conquer Retirees
description: CHATAWA, Miss.  For 133 years the School Sisters of Notre Dame have lived here in a thick forest just up the hill from the Tangipahoa River. In a modest but stately compound called St. Mary of the Pines, 52 retired members of this Roman Catholic order spend much of their time as the orders members have since the 19th century. They read and garden, fish and sew. They pray five times a day.

title: Federal Agents Arrest 69 Immigrants in Baltimore in Raids
description: Immigration officers arrested 69 immigrants yesterday in raids at a temporary job agency and eight sites where the agency had placed workers in the Baltimore area, including several warehouses in the citys port.

title: Renaissance Romping With Henry and His Rat Pack
description: Thomas More obeyed his conscience. Anne Boleyn followed The Rules.

title: Corrections: For the Record
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about Yahoo's advertising network for Web sites used on mobile devices misstated the amount of financing that AdMob, a competitor in that field, recently received. It was $15 million, not $11 million.

title: Replacing Windows in a Condominium
description: Q Our condo has old windows that leak, making it difficult, expensive and wasteful to heat and air-condition. The windows cannot be repaired, and the board voted down the costly window replacement project that some owners had requested. Can the board deny us the ability to remedy the problem and force us to spend money on energy instead of replacement?

title: Finding Serenity
description: April Lane Benson chose her apartment 20 years ago for its proximity to Charivari, the West Sides first high-fashion store.

title: On The Market
Esther Mobley's College Essay
description: Esther Mobley wrote the following essay as part of her college application to Williams College:

title: Colby Kennedy's College Essay
description: Colby Kennedy wrote the following college application essay on a teacher, Albert Cho.

title: Table Manners
description: Dining furniture for every taste.

title: Art Smart
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: This Familys Hot Stuff
description: AVERY ISLAND, La.  In April, board members and shareholders of the McIlhenny Company plan to gather here for their annual meeting. Unlike well-publicized events at big public companies this year, where activist shareholders often hope to create a stir, a private gathering is planned, and the agenda will probably not be debated. The meeting promises to be what it always is: one part business and one part family reunion.

title: Dell Reports It Has Found Misconduct
description: With its accounting under scrutiny by federal regulators and prosecutors, Dell said Thursday that evidence of misconduct had been uncovered in an internal investigation of its financial practices over several years. Dell said its boards audit committee had identified a number of accounting errors, evidence of misconduct, and deficiencies in the financial control environment. The committee has been examining accounting and financial problems that the company previously said involved accruals, reserves and other balance-sheet items.

title: Shareholders Revolt at Take-Two
description: Take-Two Interactive Software, the video game maker mired in boardroom factions, grand jury subpoenas and bad fortunes, faced an insurrection from shareholders Thursday that claimed the chief executive and three directors who were at the center of a stock options backdating scandal.

title: Los Angeles Billionaires Make Offer for Tribune
description: The drama for control of Tribune intensified Thursday night as two Los Angeles billionaires put in a last-minute bid, topping an offer from the Chicago real estate magnate, Sam Zell, by a dollar a share. Ronald W. Burkle and Eli Broad, sent a letter Thursday night to Tribune management prior to the companys self-imposed deadline of Saturday, according to several reports Friday.

title: Deal Makers Are Setting a Torrid Pace for 2007
description: After breaking the record for mergers and acquisitions last year, deal makers have started 2007 at an even faster pace. With the first quarter drawing to a close, the value of corporate deals announced through Wednesday reached $1.08 trillion, according to Thomson Financial. That is 24 percent more than the value of deals in the first quarter of 2006.

title: European Banker Joins March to Private Equity
description: Thursdays announcement that Leonhard Fischer, the head of Credit Suisses European group, was leaving the bank to join a buyout firm is only the latest departure to showcase the growing power of private equity.

title: Discovery to Buy Out Cox, a Major Shareholder
description: Discovery Communications said Thursday that it planned to buy out one of its three shareholders, Cox Communications, in a deal that included transferring the Travel Channel and $1.275 billion in cash to Cox for its 25 percent stake in the company. The transaction, to which the companies have not assigned a total value, also includes trading to Cox a business called Antenna Audio that provides headset tours of museums around the world.

title: Enron Class-Action Suit Is Dismissed
description: A Manhattan federal judge has dismissed a class-action lawsuit accusing J.P. Morgan Chase of helping Enron hide fraud. The plaintiffs asserted that they bought J.P. Morgan stock based on the banks reputation for integrity and financial discipline, when in fact the company was helping Enron, a major client, hide billions of dollars of debt.

title: Austrian Steelmaker to Acquire Smaller Rival
description: Voestalpine, the biggest steel maker in Austria, agreed to buy a specialty-steel producer, Boehler-Uddeholm, for 3.52 billion euros ($4.69 billion), foiling a bid by a private equity company, CVC Capital Partners. Voestalpine, based in Linz, said it had agreed to pay 69 euros a share for Boehler. The acquisition will give Voestalpine a steel maker with customers worldwide including Boeing and Airbus.

title: Versace Chief Sees Potential I.P.O. Ahead
description: Talk of an I.P.O. for Gianni Versace is in fashion as the company posted net profits of $24.1 million for last year on Thursday. Speaking to Womens Wear Daily, chief executive Giancarlo DiRisio said that he is looking to get Versace on track for a possible stock market listing. But, he stressed its up to the owners to decide whether they want to take the company public. A decision will be made later this year.

title: Europeans Lash Out at Hedge Funds, Private Equity Investors
description: With the influence of hedge funds over publicly traded companies back in the spotlight thanks to developments at Dutch financial services giant ABN Amro Bank, both hedge funds and private equity investors came under fire on several European fronts Thursday. Political leaders urged talks at the European Union level and Socialists in the European Parliament released a critical report on secretive financial deals.

title: Dell Founder Says Aloha to Kona Village
description: Michael Dells MSD Capital and the Rockpoint Group have acquired the Kona Village Resort. The 82-acre Kona Village Resort in Hawaii has 125 bungalows on the beach next to 865-acre Hualalai Resort, a master-planned residential resort community that includes the Four Seasons Resort Hualalai which is owned by MSD Capital and Rockpoint Group as well. The resort dates back to 1965 and has been listed by Forbes magazine as one of the top 10 family luxury resorts in the country.

title: TXU Buyout Could Face Public Scrutiny
description: Texas state electricity regulators are considering a review of Texas Pacific Group and Kohlberg Kravis Roberts $45 billion buyout offer for TXU. While TXU officials have said the Public Utility Commission lacks the authority to review the deal, commissioners agreed Thursday to think about bending the rules to lay out how they could consider, and possibly nix, the deal.

title: Bids for Chrysler Are Due Soon
description: As the deadline for bids for the Chrysler Group draws near, interested parties are said to be shifting alliances. BusinessWeek reported that private equity group Cerberus Capital Management has decided to go it alone and that its former bidding partner, Magna International, is teaming up with Ripplewood Holdings.

title: BCE Rejected Buyout Approach, Report Says
description: BCE, the parent of Bell Canada, considered merging with rival Telus and has rejected approaches from private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, The Globe and Mail reported Friday. On Thursday, responding to a report of a possible buyout, BCE said there were no ongoing discussions with private equity funds.

title: Energy Startups File for I.P.O.s
description: Energy startups EnerNoc and Comverge have both filed preliminary papers for initial public offerings. While neither company has said when an I.P.O. may occur and although both are relatively small, they are seeing rapid growth. Comverges revenue at Comverge nearly doubled in the last two years from $17.9 million in 2004 to $33.9 million last year and EnerNoc has seen revenue rise from $800,000 in 2004 to $26.1 million in 2006.

title: Is Icahn Forcing Motorola to Mortgage its Future?
description: Carl Icahns demands on Motorola  of which the activist investor owns 2.7 percent  have put the company at an existential crossroads, Roben Farzad of BusinessWeek wrote. In his commentary, Mr. Farzad suggests that Mr. Icahns calls for huge share buybacks could force the cellphone company to mortgage future cash flows by taking on debt.

title: Sabre Shareholders Approve $4.5 Billion Buyout
description: Shareholders of Sabre Holdings, the parent of online travel-booking service Travelocity.com, on Thursday approved a $4.5 billion offer for the company from Silver Lake Partners and Texas Pacific Group. Affiliates of the two private equity groups will pay $32.75 per share in cash and assume about $550 million in Sabre debt. Sabre put itself on the block in September 2006.

title: Liberty Mutual Suit Will Go On
description: A New York state lawsuit accusing insurer Liberty Mutual of rigging bids and paying kickbacks to brokers will go forward despite the insurers attempt to dismiss it. A New York Supreme Court judge upheld the merits of the suit brought last year by then-New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer against the sixth-largest U.S. property-casualty insurer.

title: Four Seasons Deal Faces Opposition
description: As a vote on taking Four Seasons Hotels private looms, shareholder opposition is mounting. A major investor has said he will vote no which has in turn caused the stock to slump to $79.60, well below the bid price of $82 per share.

title: Battery Technologies Recharges with $6.2 Million
description: Battery Technologies, which makes an ultrathin carbon-zinc battery, has raised $6.2 million to expand production. SunBridge Partners led the Series A financing round, which also included Early Stage Partners, Key Capital and Orix Capital.

title: Goldman Names Korea Securities Head
description: Goldman Sachs has appointed Steve Park as a managing director and country head of its securities division in Korea. Mr. Park has been with Credit Suisse for nine years and is widely recognized as one of the most experienced bankers in the Korean market, said Finance Asia. He will be responsible for Goldmans securities business in Korea, except for businesses related to Goldman Sachs International Bank and will take up his new position in June.

title: KKR, Pessina Raise Alliance Boots Bid
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts and Stefano Pessina have increased their bid for health and beauty chain Alliance Boots to $19.7 billion. The bid comes a day after reports said that Mr. Pessina, who is Alliance Boots deputy chairman, was banned from the groups central office.

title: The worlds priciest home!
description: Updown

title: Texas Pacific Offers $4.5 Billion for Spanish Airline
description: Spanish airline Iberia said on Friday it had received a bid approach from private equity firm Texas Pacific Group which valued it at roughly 3.4 billion euros ($4.5 billion). The cash offer of 3.6 euros a share is below Iberias Thursday close and also below media reports which estimated its price tag at 4.4 euros per share.

title: Alinta Recommends Babcock Bid
description: Alinta, Australias largest energy infrastructure group, recommended a A$7.4 billion ($6 billion) bid by a consortium led by Australias Babcock & Brown on Friday and rejected a rival bid by Macquarie Bank.

title: A Union Takes Cautious Aim at Blackstones I.P.O. Plans
description: Norma Rae, Wall Street insider?

title: A New Twist in the Kerik Story
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giulianis history with Bernard B. Kerik looms as a likely issue in Mr. Giulianis campaign for president. His own aides have anticipated that questions are likely to arise about Mr. Giulianis judgment in, among other things, promoting Mr. Kerik for one of the countrys most important national security posts.

title: Man Group to Spin Off U.S. Brokerage Unit
description: Man Group, the British alternative asset manager, said on Friday it would demerge its U.S. brokerage unit and list it in New York. It also said group pretax profits were likely to be in line with consensus market expectations. The listing of a majority interest in the unit, Man Financial, will take place in the third quarter of 2007, subject to favorable market conditions, the firm said.

title: Man Group Plans I.P.O. For Its Brokerage Business
description: LONDON (AP) -- Man Group PLC, the world's largest publicly traded hedge fund company, said Friday it plans to split off its brokerage business, making it an independent company through an initial public offering on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Live from New Orleans: M&A Talk and a Fond Farewell
description: Change will come  its only a matter of who brings it.

title: San Diego Pension Fund Sues Amaranth
description: Amaranth Advisors was sued by the San Diego County retirement fund for securities fraud, a step the hedge fund said may delay refunds to clients hurt when it collapsed under $6.6 billion in losses in September. The fallen hedge fund lied about trading strategies and made excessively risky and volatile investments, according to a complaint filed yesterday by the San Diego County Employees Retirement Association. Amaranth said fighting the lawsuit, the first tied to the largest-ever hedge-fund failure, will drain remaining assets earmarked for investors.

title: Are They Going to Make My Wife Cry, Too?
description: I like my mother-in-law. Honest.

title: Patent Dispute Pits Tech Companies Against V.C.s
description: A rift has arisen among larger technology companies and smaller venture capital firms over whether dramatic changes to U.S. patent law are necessary, CNet News.com reported Thursday. The differences in opinion played out during a Thursday hearing in the House of Representatives Small Business Committee, which doesnt have the power to write patent laws but aimed to explore the small-business implications of Congress ongoing push for sweeping changes in the area.

title: Farmers to Plant Most Amount of Corn Since 44
description: WASHINGTON, March 30 (Reuters) - Inspired by the fuel ethanol boom, U.S. farmers intend to plant the largest amount of land to corn in 63 years -- 90.454 million acres -- the government said on Friday, potentially enough to produce a record 12.5 billion-bushel crop.

title: The Unanswered Question
description: As interesting as Kyle Sampsons testimony to the Senate Judiciary Committee was, it still didnt answer the single biggest question about the Gonzales Eight, notes Washington Monthly blogger Kevin Drum. Its this: so why did you choose those particular eight prosecutors to fire, anyway? Drum continues:

title: Global Capitalist, Heal Thyself
description: [T]he greatest obstacle to sustaining a healthy, globalised economy is no longer insufficient openness, writes Dani Rodrik, a Harvard professor of international political economy, in The Financial Times. Rodrik explains:

title: The Money Race
description: With the first quarter of the year ending this Saturday, presidential campaigns are preparing to release their fundraising tallies on April 15. A look at fundraising efforts by the leading candidates.

title: Torre Sets Roster and Rotation
description: Joe Torre had an early media briefing just now and settled most of the remaining questions about the makeup of the Yankees roster and rotation.

title: 2008: The Ghost of Bernie
description: The Timess William Rashbaum reports today that records show Rudolph W. Giuliani testified that he was briefed on Bernard B. Keriks ties to a company with suspected organized crime links before elevating him to New York City police commissioner in 2000  but he doesnt actually remember the meeting or any of the information. Mr. Giuliani also pushed for Mr. Keriks aborted nomination to be homeland security secretary in 2004. The campaign has denied that Mr. Kerik will pose a liability to the campaign.

title: Mayor Will Veto Pedicab Bill
description: Updated 11:10 a.m. and 11:25 a.m.Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said during his weekly WABC radio appearance this morning that he will veto a bill that caps the number of pedicabs in the city at 325 and imposes other regulations on the burgeoning industry.

title: Scrambling for Water
description: Some $2.5 billion in water projects are planned or under way in four states, the biggest expansion in the West's quest for water in years.

title: Government Shutdown?
description: With Congress and President Bush apparently heading toward a stalemate reminiscent of the 1995 government shutdown, I wonder who will top the Wall Street joke of that year, which reported that the government planned to issue three new types of bonds to fund itself:1: Clinton Bonds, which had no principal.2: Dole Bonds, which had no interest.3: Gingrich Bonds, which had no maturity.

title: Poverty Experiment: $8 Million to Go
description: Just for the record, we now have the complete roster of whos giving what for Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs two-year experiment in paying poor people for certain behavior. The $42 million raised thus far breaks down as follows:

title: Mighty Joe Smith
description: One of the best stories of the spring has been Joe Smiths rise from third-round draft pick to right-handed specialist in nine months. He learned the news yesterday morning, when equipment manager Charlie Samuels asked Smith join him for a second. I figured I was going to try something on, Smith said.

title: Stocking Up for a Storm
description: Just because people are putting on galoshes, that doesnt mean its going to rain.

title: Podcast: Baby Boom Revisited
description: Podcast: Only in New York (mp3)

title: Goldman and Citi Lead Dealmaker Rankings
description: They may be a few last-minute deals straggling in, but as the first quarter comes to a close, Goldman Sachs has a firm lead in the mergers-and-acquisitions league tables. Goldman had an advisory role in 104 announced deals with a total value of $311 billion so far this year, or about 29 percent of the $1.08 trillion of deals worldwide, according to Thomson Financial.

title: Disappointed on Charter Schools
description: This morning, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg half-heartedly praised an agreement reached in Albany last night that will create 50 new charter schools in the city.

title: 2008: New Time Poll
description: Although Rudy Giuliani remains the top choice of Republican voters for their partys presidential nomination, his lead over John McCain has softened somewhat, according to the latest Time magazine poll. And while John Edwards is still in third place behind Hillary Rodham Clinton and Barack Obama among the Democrats, his support has grown.

title: Jackson Slams Fox-C.B.C. Debate Deal
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson has been enlisted by a grassroots online group, Color of Change, to denounce the deal announced on Thursday between Fox News and the Congressional Black Caucus institute for two presidential debates later this year.

title: Transparency and Accountability
description: In the next 36 hours lawmakers in Albany will be asked to approve hundreds of pages of budget bills that they have not yet read, because they have not been printed. Key details of how some of the most important aspects of the budget work  the division of education aid and the way the property tax rebate will work  are still being worked out.

title: China on the Genocide Olympics
description: The other day I mentioned Mia Farrows call for branding the 2008 Beijing Olympics as the Genocide Olympics, as a way to pressure China to be more helpful in Darfur. A wire story today from Beijing shows that China is indeed feeling the pressure:

title: Your Turn To Write
description: My column on Israel a couple of weeks ago is still prompting lots of mail, much of it indignant. Yesterday I posted a Forward editorial that was sympathetic to me; heres an email I received today from a woman named Marion. As you can see, it castigates me  and the Times for good measure  and its fairly representative of the critical emails.

title: Decision Time for Villone
description: The Yankees still want Ron Villone. But for now, they want him to join their Class AAA team in Scanton. Villone, 37, said hed think it over for a few hours and decide later today or tomorrow.

title: After Take-Two Coup, a Long Road Ahead
description: Now what?

title: Kelly on Convention Arrests: It Wasnt a Wholesale Roundup
description: The Police Departments handling of the Republican National Convention in 2004  which included controversial surveillance of political groups and mass arrests  was perhaps the finest hour in the history of the department, Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly told Gabe Pressman of WNBC in an interview that will be broadcast at 6:30 a.m. Sunday. The Politicker has posted  an advance transcript and here is the exchange:

title: A Rewarding Year for Lazards Chief
description: Bruce Wasserstein recently gave a $25 million gift to Harvard Law School, but his bank account is quickly being replenished. As chairman of Lazard, Mr. Wasserstein earned $22 million in compensation last year, up 61 percent from 2005, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Liner Notes
description: Hes a manHes a treasure troveTell me what is your nameIm MC Rove

title: Pakistan and the Taliban
description: My Sunday column will be about Pakistan and Afghanistan, and will include excerpts from an interview with Hamid Karzai on Pakistani backing of the Taliban. Pakistani complicity in the resurgence of the Taliban is a complex issue, and its one that my Times colleague Carlotta Gall has done a superb job in reporting. One expert on the topic is Khawar Mehdi, a Pakistani journalist who knows the border areas well. Heres his take, from an email to me that he agreed to put on the record:

title: An Etiquette Lesson for Columbia
description: Flashback: Video of Columbia students rushing the stage during an appearance by Jim Gilchrist, founder of the anti-immigrant group, the Minuteman Project, in October.

title: Pavano: Who Wouldnt Be Excited?
description: Carl Pavano was all smiles today when we talked to him about making the start on opening day. I should be happy, shouldnt I? he said. Who wouldnt be excited at the opportunity?

title: Introducing Spitzerisms
description: In which your correspondents track the unusual verbiage of Gov. Eliot Spitzer, a highly precise public speaker who often uses words that rarely alight upon the ears in normal conversation.

title: Kentucky Speculation Dogs Donovan
description: The biggest off-court storyline at this Final Four is undoubtedly the possibility that Kentucky will pursue Florida Coach Billy Donovan for its open coaching vacancy.

title: The Budget Dance, Televised
description: Yes, this is a plug, but we thought readers of this blog might want to take a look at a few Empire Zone contributors on the TV. According to a promo for The New York Times Close Up, on NY 1, this weeks edition will feature Michael Cooper, the chief of the Albany bureau, reporting on the rhythms of the budget dance.

title: The Life of the Actual
description: Last night, my friend Bob Crowley, a set designer whose work appears in London and New York (The History Boys, The Coast of Utopia) invited me to join him for the Broadway opening of The Year of Magical Thinking, the Joan Didion play based on her book, for which Bob did the simple but effective sets. Its nice to visit other worlds if only to check your bearings. I liked the play, and I liked the book. If you grew up reading  or, is it devouring?  Didion, you cant help but be riveted by her observations. Vanessa Redgrave does as a wonderful job as Didion, and afterward I heard a number of people say how beautiful she looks. Redgrave is 70.

title: Document: Budget Estimates
description: For the curious, heres copy [pdf] of the official state budget estimates, as they stand now.

title: The Ally of My Ally is My Enemy
description: Why are two of America's friends jousting? Nicholas D. Kristof asks Afghanistan's president why he's so upset with Pakistan.

title: Blogtalk: Spokes and Tubes
description: Ah, its that time again: the monthly Critical Mass ride is tonight, with new police rules in place requiring permits for gatherings of 50 or more people. [Gothamist]

title: Much Ado About Hybrids
description: There was considerable buzzing a while back about the sales incentives and attractive financing deals that had become available on the once hot-selling Toyota Prius. The doomsday view was that interest in hybrid cars had peaked.

title: It Happened Here
description: The city is filled with so many basketball celebrities that some pass by almost unnoticed. One was at the airport yesterday: Bill Frieder, who was the focus of much attention in Atlanta 18 years ago when he was the head coach of the Michigan Wolverines.

title: Vows: Aislinn and Jeffery
description: A chance encounter during N.Y.'s Santacon Event helped to rekindle romance between Jeffery Franklin Klier & Aislinn Weidele.

title: Blogtalk: Rudy, Judi, Bernie and FDNY
description: The blogs had three major pieces about Rudolph W. Giuliani to mull over today. One involved a Times scoop revealing that the former New York mayor testified that hed been warned about Bernard B. Keriks possible ties to organized crime before he elevated him to police commissioner  although Mr.Giuliani said he did not recall the briefing taking place, much less the content. That news has already stirred up many readers at our sibblog, The Empire Zone.

title: A Reader Forum on Climate Change
description: The worlds richest countries, which have contributed by far the most to the atmospheric changes linked to global warming, are far ahead of the poorest ones in adapting to climate change. Next Friday, a new report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change will underline this growing climate divide, according to scientists involved in writing it, Andrew C. Revkin reports.

title: Times Reader and Crosswords
description: Several folks have written in to let us know that the crossword puzzle was not updating properly in the new reader. Weve posted a new build of the reader that fixes this issue. If this has been happening to you please download the new build here.

title: T Style | Shop
description: A tour of a new retail space that is more like a loft than showroom.

title: Fading Ink?
description: Tattoos have become so common in college basketball that it is almost surprising to see a star player without one.

title: The Next Hippie Bus?
description: The vehicle of the future may not be sleek and streamlined. Another recent view comes from Paul Saffo, one of the countrys most cited futurists, although he prefers the term forecaster.

title: Religion Without Truth
description: Stanley Fish has written an Op-Ed for The Times that appears in print and online today. Post a comment about it below.  The Editors

title: Taxi!
description: New Yorks 13,000 yellow cabs are easy to take for granted  until its raining and you cannot find one.

title: Former Adviser Breaks With Bush
description: Matthew Dowd, once a close political adviser to President Bush, became disappointed in the president's performance.

title: The Coalition Builder
description: Mayor Villaraigosa is known for his ability to help people transcend lines of race, class, ethnicity and geography.

title: Gang Capital of America
description: With the help of the FBI, Mayor Villaraigosa says he will break apart the city's most violent street gangs.

title: Black-Brown Divide?
description: As the demographics of Los Angeles shift, tensions are rising between blacks and Latinos, but the Mayor says such incidents are isolated.

title: Steve Reich Talking Music: Technology and Influence
description: In this final audio installment of Steve Reich's interview for The Score, the composer discusses the role that the rapid development of technology has played in his working life and music.

title: Steve Reich Talking Music: Technology and Influence
description: In this final audio installment of Steve Reichs interview for The Score, the composer discusses the role that the rapid development of technology has played in his working life and music.Central to that influence was the invention of the sampler in the 1970s, a device now in use by musicians of nearly every genre. When Mr. Reich began exploring the samplers possibilities some 30 years ago, he became interested in its potential to match any recorded sound to the intricacies of a live performance, a technique he ultimately used in the composition of Different Trains (1988), which takes natural rhythms and melodies of taped speech and weaves them with train whistles, sirens and music he wrote for the Kronos Quartet.

title: The New Ellis Island
description: The son of Mexican immigrants, the Mayor believes Los Angeles, more than any other city, is where dreams can be realized.

title: Auditions at the Metropolitan Opera
description: Disella Larusdottir hopes to make her native Iceland proud and perform well at the prestigious Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions.

title: Tony Scott, Jazz Clarinetist Who Mastered Bebop, Dies at 85
description: Tony Scott, a distinguished jazz clarinetist who in the 1950s helped steer his instrument out of the swing era and into the sax-infested waters of bebop, died on Wednesday at his home in Rome. He was 85 and had lived in Italy for many years.

title: The Fish Are Biting, but the Anglers Arent
description: In his short story Big Two-Hearted River, Ernest Hemingway delivered a paean to the trout that got away.

title: Early Music That Shows Its Age but Does So Robustly
description: The early-music movement is so entrenched that even in early classical music  Boccherini, Mozart  our ears expect the tight, taut, windy bounce of bow on gut, the light straight sound of music played without vibrato. So when this music is played richly, on modern instruments, with plenty of shake, its striking that it sounds old: a throwback to a time when contemporary mores and instruments, rather than scholarship on period style, set the musical tone.

title: Supporter of Putin Proposes, Once Again, to Extend Russian Leaders Term Beyond Next Year
description: MOSCOW, March 30  President Vladimir V. Putin has ruled it out, and the Kremlin was quick to do so again on Friday, but the idea never quite dies: amending Russias Constitution to allow Mr. Putin to extend his presidency beyond its legal end in 2008, now only a year away.

title: Studies Lead to Withdrawal of Drug for Bowel Ailment
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  The maker of Zelnorm, a medicine that treats constipation-related irritable bowel syndrome, stopped selling the drug Friday after federal drug officials concluded that it might cause heart attacks and strokes.

title: Merry-Go-Round on the Prosecutors (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Coaches Love Running the Free-Market Offense
description: Atlanta

title: Armys War Funds Can Last Through July, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  The nonpartisan Congressional Research Service has estimated that the Army has enough budget flexibility to pay for its military operations through July in the event that a standoff between the White House and Congress over Iraq holds up the money the administration says it needs for the war effort.

title: For Rutgers Women, Wisdom Is a Victory on a Path to Maturity
description: A little more than 150 loyal fans showed up at the Louis Brown Athletic Center on Thursday to see the Rutgers womens basketball team off to Cleveland and a date with Louisiana State in the Final Four.

title: In Big Shift, U.S. Imposes Tariffs on Chinese Paper
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  The Bush administration, in a major escalation of trade pressure on China, said Friday that it would reverse more than 20 years of American policy and impose potentially steep tariffs on Chinese manufactured goods on the ground that China is illegally subsidizing some of its exports.

title: 15 Plead Guilty in Scheme to Defraud Medicaid Plan
description: Fifteen people, including seven city employees, have pleaded guilty to federal charges in connection with a Medicaid scheme that prosecutors say cost the government millions of dollars over more than two years, the authorities said yesterday.

title: The Matzos of Togetherness
description: Why is this documentary different from all other documentaries?

title: Farmers to Plant Largest Amount of Corn Since 44
description: American farmers are planning to plant more corn this year than anytime since World War II, as farmers rush to cash in on high prices bolstered by the demand for ethanol.

title: Police Say Mother Admitted Smothering Baby at Shelter
description: A 21-year-old Queens woman was charged with murder yesterday after she admitted to smothering her 4-month-old son in a family shelter where the two of them lived, the police said.

title: Federal Judge Strikes Down Forest Management Rules
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  A federal judge in California on Friday overturned the Bush administrations revised rules for management of the countrys 155 national forests, saying that the federal Forest Service violated the basic laws ensuring that forest ecosystems have environmental safeguards.

title: At Florida Derby, Hoping That the First Time Is a Charm
description: The trainer Michael Matz knows better than perhaps anybody else how fickle the sport of horse racing can be. Matz experienced the best and the worst of the sport in 2006, when Barbaro emerged from being a little-known grass horse to the winner of the Kentucky Derby, a last hurrah before his eventually fatal injury in the Preakness.

title: A Night Custom-Made for Guys in Gowns
description: Jeffrey Wallach was running out of time. The big night was only three days away. So instead of sewing the rhinestones on the gold appliqu as he would have preferred, Mr. Wallach glued the rhinestones, one by one, onto the material.

title: Dubai Melds Tradition and Modernity in Worlds Richest Horse Race
description: DUBAI, United Arab Emirates, March 30  Sheik Mohammed bin Rashid al-Maktoum parted the throngs Thursday night, hand in hand with Princess Haya, as the worshipful clamored in their wake amid sculpted sand dunes. Some peered from the backs of camels, others through the fragrant smoke of hookahs.

title: A Bridge No Longer So Humble, at $600 Million
description: The Willis Avenue Bridge is hardly the most recognizable or the most graceful of the citys many bridges, but it will soon gain a distinction as one of the most expensive.

title: In Japan, a Historian Stands by Proof of Wartime Sex Slavery
description: TOKYO

title: Violence in Somalia Continues
description: NAIROBI, Kenya, March 30  Missile-toting Somali rebels plucked an Ethiopian helicopter gunship out of the sky on Friday, apparently killing the crew and sending a fireball of a signal that they are as determined  and dangerous  as ever.

title: An Escape From Sizzling Sidewalks
description: Who wants to go swimming? We do, too.

title: First Off-Track Betting Parlor Opens (in Style) in New Jersey
description: VINELAND, N.J., March 30  One thing is certain: Its not your traditional off-track betting parlor. Whether it will pay off is something else.

title: Howard Stern Tries to Kill American Idol With Kindness for a Weak Link
description: LOS ANGELES, March 30  For the last few years, three-quarters of the network television executives in Hollywood have tried to figure out how to derail American Idol, the Fox juggernaut that dominates the prime-time ratings.

title: Jury Acquits Police Lieutenant Who Killed Unarmed Tenant
description: An off-duty police lieutenant who shot and killed his unarmed tenant during an argument was found not guilty of criminal charges yesterday evening.

title: J. Paul Sticht, 89, Executive Who Expanded R. J. Reynolds, Dies
description: J. Paul Sticht, a former chairman of the tobacco company R. J. Reynolds Industries, now called Reynolds American, died Tuesday in Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: Bushs Global AIDS Effort Limited by Restrictions
description: President Bushs $15 billion plan to fight AIDS globally is seriously hampered by restrictions imposed by Congress and the administration, a panel of medical experts said yesterday.

title: B. R. Landau, 80, Biochemist Who Helped Explain Diabetes, Dies
description: Bernard R. Landau, a biochemist and physician whose innovative studies of how the liver processes glucose helped shed light on what goes wrong in diabetes, died on March 24 in Cleveland. He was 80 and lived in Shaker Heights, Ohio.

title: Mets Settle Their Roster, Sending Park to the Minors
description: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla., March 30  The intrigue started swirling shortly before 11 a.m. when the Mets pitching coach, Rick Peterson, tapped Chan Ho Park and told him that he, not Ambiorix Burgos, was starting against the Florida Marlins.

title: For the Record
description: A sports article on Thursday about Marianne Stanley, a successful assistant coach with the Rutgers womens basketball team, misstated the day the team will play in the Final Four this weekend and referred incorrectly to a statistic for one of the players. Rutgers faces Louisiana State tomorrow  not today  and center Kia Vaughn leads the team with 9.5 rebounds a game, not 6.3. (As the article noted, she averaged 6.3 points a game last season.)

title: Arts, Briefly
description: There She Was

title: The Poor Little Rich Girl in Leopard Skin Who Was Warhols Muse
description: Edie was a beauty, gee! said Andy Warhol.

title: Dispute Over Spy Files Cancels Police Officials Testimony
description: Lawyers for the city canceled testimony yesterday by a deputy police commissioner who directed a surveillance program on political activists before the 2004 Republican National Convention in New York.

title: Bloomberg Vetoes Bill Limiting Pedicabs
description: Saying the free market should dictate how many pedicabs roam the streets, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg vetoed a bill yesterday that would cap the number of pedicabs operating in the city at 325 and impose other regulations on the growing industry.

title: Back Surgery Sidelines Richardson for Rest of the Season
description: A Miami neurosurgeon cut into Quentin Richardsons back Thursday evening, perhaps saving his career. But at that moment, the Knicks also lost their last, best hope of a cavalry charge from the training room.

title: Travel Agents in Arizona Helped Smuggle Illegal Immigrants by Plane, Authorities Say
description: The latest package deal that smugglers have offered to illegal immigrants in sneaking across the Mexican border includes flights from Las Vegas to points around the country arranged by Arizona travel agents, law enforcement officials in Phoenix said yesterday.

title: Summers Here, at Least at the Gas Pump
description: IN anticipation of the summer driving season, consumers can expect more of the same: higher gasoline prices. But if they stop in at a Burger King along the way, they will know that at least some of the food they are eating comes from suppliers that treat their animals well.

title: Show Cats and Those Who Love Them
description: The Cornish rex is a sort of cat, and judging from its appearance it seems neither lovable nor cuddly. If you had a Cornish rex, you would not be inclined to name it Muffin or Lulu or Mayberry or Twizzle. It is a skinny, wiry animal with big ears and an august bearing.

title: Enterprise Rent-a-Car Buys Vanguard, a Rival
description: In the latest sign of consolidation within the car rental industry, Enterprise Rent-a-Car, the largest car rental company in North America, said yesterday that it had acquired a smaller rival, Vanguard Car Rental, which owns the National and Alamo brands.

title: For the Record
description: An article on Monday about efforts by American universities to expand to India and other countries misstated the name of an Indian educational institution that is in a partnership with Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh to offer students a Carnegie Mellon degree. It is the Sri Sivasubramaniya Nadar School of Advanced Software Engineering  not the Shri Shiv Shankar Nadar College of Engineering.

title: For the Record
description: The Personal Health column in Science Times on Tuesday about healthful beverages included incorrect information from the Beverage Guidance Panel about soy milk. It can indeed be legally fortified with vitamin D.

title: A Past Worth Preserving
description: Chaco Canyon, N.M.

title: Former Congressmans Wife Worked for Contract Winner
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  The wife of Gov. Jim Gibbons of Nevada was paid about $35,000 in consulting fees from a Nevada company the same year it was awarded a no-bid $2 million military contract that had been pushed by Mr. Gibbons when he was a member of Congress.

title: A New Rush to Go Public
description: ANOTHER frenzy so soon?

title: Negotiators Extend Deadline for South Korea Trade Pact
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  United States and South Korean negotiators on Friday extended a deadline to reach a free-trade agreement, as Washington struggled to complete a deal that could be used as a model for other Asian countries.

title: Shares Falter on Trade Tensions
description: Escalating trade tensions between the United States and China pushed the Standard & Poors 500-stock index slightly lower yesterday, the last trading day of March, limiting its third straight quarterly advance.

title: Awarding Legal Fees (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Nevadas Keystone Cops, Barely Serving or Protecting
description: Reno 911! fans dont fool around. Followers of the ubiquitous Cops parody  as well as the spinoff feature film and the whole Reno 911! state of mind  have become so serious about the long-running sitcom that the burlesque deserves a real hearing.

title: The Composer as Both Performer and Inspiration
description: The pianist Andrew Hill makes music of deep reflection and patient discovery. For most of his long career he has stayed faithful to a mode of abstraction steeped in his own preoccupations: enigmatic harmony, elasticized rhythm, a multilayered arrangement of texture and pulse. When he plays his own compositions  and he rarely plays anything else  he can create the impression of elusive and flickering beauty.

title: Divining the Future of the G.O.P. (5 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Burden of Debt (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Religion Without Truth
description: In 1992, at a conference of Republican governors, Kirk Fordice of Mississippi referred to America as a Christian nation. One of his colleagues rose to say that what Governor Fordice no doubt meant is that America is a Judeo-Christian nation. If I meant that, Fordice replied, I would have said it.

title: French Nun Says Church to Rule on Cure by John Paul II
description: PARIS, March 30  If the story Sister Marie Simon-Pierre told Friday is true, then Pope John Paul II exercised miraculous powers from beyond the grave. A proven physical miracle is an important qualification on the road to sainthood.

title: Toshio Sasaki, 60, a Sculptor of Major Projects in New York, Dies
description: Toshio Sasaki, a Japanese sculptor known for works in public spaces, particularly The First Symphony of the Sea, a 322-foot-long wall relief at the New York Aquarium at Coney Island, died on March 10 near his home in Nagakute in the Aichi Prefecture of Japan. He was 60 and also had a home in the Park Slope neighborhood of Brooklyn.

title: For the Record
description: A music review on Thursday about Robyn Hitchcock, at the Knitting Factory, referred imprecisely to two musicians in his band, the Venus 3. While the musicians, Bill Rieflin and Scott McCaughey, perform with the band R.E.M. on tour and in recording sessions, they are not formally members of that band.

title: Marbury Gets 43 Points, but the Knicks Needed 45
description: DALLAS, March 30  Knicks Coach Isiah Thomas said he had a simple message to his injury-stricken team before it faced the Dallas Mavericks on their intimidating home court Friday night.

title: Farmers Head to Fields to Plant Corn, Lots of It
description: With demand for ethanol pushing corn prices to $4 a bushel or higher, it was not a surprise that farmers intended to plant a lot more corn this season.

title: How to Do Many Things at Once (Badly) (3 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: The Name Game (Plus Typos)
description: THE practice of cybersquatting has evolved from the days when people bought a trademarked Internet domain name and hoped to squeeze the trademark owner for some cash. The law is pretty clear on that: you cant do it.

title: Three Arrested in Critical Mass Bike Ride
description: Three people were arrested and almost 50 people given summonses last night in the first Critical Mass bicycle ride since the city adopted new controversial rules that limit the size of un-permitted rides, the police said.

title: For the Record
description: A sports article on Thursday, about the impact of a pending divorce in the Steinbrenner family on the future of the Yankees ownership, misspelled the surname of a club executive who parted ways with the organization after his divorce. (The error was repeated in the Sports of The Times column yesterday.) He is Joseph Molloy, not Malloy.

title: Wondering What to Do in a Crazy, Mixed-Up World
description: Watching the installationlike dances of youngish New York choreographers often feels like peering into a rec room  a badly abused rec room, tossed by fits of temper, strewn with personal detritus and one match away from catastrophe.

title: Australian to Serve 9 Months in Terrorism Case
description: GUANTNAMO BAY, Cuba, March 30  David Hicks, the Australian high-school dropout whose detention became an international issue, will serve nine more months in custody, most of it in Australia, under the terms of a plea deal unsealed here Friday.

title: Despised by 29 Teams, Appreciated by the Rangers
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y., March 30  If there is a shoving or shouting match in a Rangers game, forward Sean Avery will most likely be the point man. He can be found at the bottom of nearly every pileup in front of a goalie. Just by hopping over the boards for a shift, Avery draws boos from opposing crowds and vitriol from opposing players.

title: Bangladesh Hangs 6 Islamist Militants in the Killings of 2 Judges
description: NEW DELHI, March 30  The military-backed government of Bangladesh on Friday executed six Islamist militants in connection with the murder of two judges, in a case that has come to signify unusually swift justice. The men had said in court that they sought to replace the countrys secular penal code with Shariah, the legal code of Islam based on the Koran.

title: German Retailer to Pay Restitution to Jewish Family for Berlin Property
description: FRANKFURT, March 30  Settling one of the last big property restitution cases arising from the Nazi era, Germanys largest retailer agreed on Friday to pay the heirs of a department store once owned by a Jewish family more than $100 million for the confiscation of what is now prime real estate in Berlin.

title: In the Bronx, an Early Lesson on Goodbye
description: There is an empty desk in a fifth-grade classroom at Public School 73 in the Bronx. Students pull out the gray hard-backed chair each morning for Bandiougou. We pull the chair out because when someone pushes it in, explained Renee Thompson, 10, we make a joke about it and say, Youre squishing Bandiougou.

title: As Cheerleaders Soar Higher, So Does the Danger
description: For decades, they stood by safe and smiling, a fixture on Americas sporting sidelines. But todays young cheerleaders, who perform tricks once reserved for trapeze artists, may be in more peril than any female athletes in the country.

title: Intel Can Recover Bonuses It Shouldnt Have Paid
description: More companies are instituting policies that appear to help them recover incentive pay if they have to restate their financial results and it turns out that executives did not deserve the extra pay. But compensation experts warn that not all of these provisions have teeth.

title: Corrections
description: The Movie Clock in Weekend yesterday was published in error. It showed theaters schedules for last weekend, not this weekend. Schedules for this weekend are at nytimes.com/movies.

title: Planned Visit to Syria by Pelosi Is Under Fire From White House
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  A planned visit to Syria next week by House Speaker Nancy Pelosi drew criticism on Friday from the White House, which accused the Democratic Congressional leader of failing to heed the administrations admonitions against travel to Damascus.

title: For the Record
description: An article in The Arts on March 15 about a plan by the director of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, Michael Govan, to collect pieces of significant residential architecture referred incorrectly to the ownership of an office designed by the architect John Lautner, which the museum intends to install both as an exhibit and for use by Mr. Govan. It is on long-term loan to the museum from the John Lautner Foundation, which owns the work; the museum did not acquire it for an undisclosed amount. The article also misstated the title of a book published by the museum in 1965. It is A Guide to Architecture in Southern California, not A Guide to Southern California Architecture.

title: Detainee Says Torture Led to Confessions
description: A prisoner held by the American military at Guantnamo Bay, Cuba, said he had confessed to several terrorist attacks and plots only because he had been tortured, according to a transcript of a hearing held on March 14 and released yesterday by the Pentagon.

title: Daddy May Write Laws, but Daughter Has Her Eye on a Book Deal
description: First there was chick lit. Then there was political-makeover lit. And now we have their spawn: D.C.-daughter lit. Or, as Mark Halperin, a political analyst for ABC News, prefers, A Book of Ones Own.

title: Investigation of Sharpe James Turns to Way Grant Was Given
description: TRENTON, March 30  Federal agents investigating the discounted sale of Newark city property to friends and political allies of former Mayor Sharpe James have subpoenaed documents to determine if Mr. James used his position as a state senator to help one close associate win a human services grant, according to legislators who have seen the subpoenas.

title: Tug of War Puts the Fans in the Middle
description: It was just amazing, marveled Stephen F. Ross, a sports law expert at Pennsylvania State University. You had a United States senator trying to broker a deal in public.

title: Avoiding Secret Testimony
description: The House Judiciary Committee has begun conducting closed-door interviews with some of the key officials involved in the Bush administrations purge of United States attorneys. The interviews may be harmless as long as they are merely a first step in the investigation. But they must not become a substitute for what this investigation really requires: sworn public testimony under oath by Karl Rove, the presidential adviser; Harriet Miers, the former White House counsel; and everyone else involved.

title: Does That Pack of Gum Need to Go on a Debit Card?
description: R. C. Welborn, a college student and part-time contractor in Pensacola, Fla., has learned a hard and costly lesson about debit cards. He said he got his first clue about potential pitfalls involving overdraft fees a year ago.

title: On the Other Hand, an Injury Helps Oden Thrive This Season
description: ATLANTA, March 30  Jeff Robinson is a 6-foot-9 sophomore forward at Lawrence North High School in Indianapolis who is working on his left hand.

title: Rail Unions Act to Avoid Health Care Charges
description: When city subway and bus workers went on strike 15 months ago, their leaders refused to accept changes to pension benefits for newly hired workers but ultimately agreed to have members pay a portion of health insurance premiums.

title: Standoff in Ukraine Prompts Some to Seek New Election
description: MOSCOW, March 30  Barely a year after parliamentary elections, Ukraine has lurched toward a new political crisis as President Viktor A. Yushchenkos support among lawmakers hemorrhages and he faces new calls to dissolve Parliament, now led by his rival, Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich.

title: Bush Visits the Wounded at Walter Reed Hospital
description: WASHINGTON, March 30

title: Was It a Hoax? Debate on a Secret Mark Gospel Resumes
description: Imagine the discovery of a previously unknown Gospel of Mark, a secret text suppressed by church authorities that pictured Jesus initiating his disciples with a hallucinatory, nocturnal and quite possibly homosexual rite. Imagine the headlines, the four-alarm book promotion and the cable network special.

title: Shiite Cleric Condemns U.S. as His Militia Takes to Streets
description: BAGHDAD, March 30  Religious leaders commanded by the Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr delivered a searing speech at Friday Prayer condemning the American presence in Iraq, while militiamen loyal to Mr. Sadr engaged in street battles against Iraqi Army soldiers in southwestern Baghdad, signaling a possible resurgence of the militia.

title: Whats on Saturday Night
description: 9 P.M. (A&E) FLIP THIS HOUSE The term dollhouse usually invokes preciousness. But in the third-season opener of this series, Welcome to the Doll House, it refers to a 650-square-foot, three-bedroom house in New Haven that must be renovated. The tiny size turns out to be the least of the worries of the flippers (above, from left, J. D. Esajian, Than Merrill, Jeremy Black, Lori Parks and Paul Esajian) when low temperatures result in frozen pipes, flooded basements and delays.

title: Plan for Wind Farm Off Massachusetts Clears State Hurdle
description: BOSTON, March 30  A proposal to build the countrys first offshore wind farm in the waters off Cape Cod won state environmental approval on Friday, bringing the project a major step closer to being built.

title: Gonzales Offers Defense on Prosecutors Dismissals
description: WASHINGTON, March 30  Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales on Friday defended his statements about the dismissals of eight United States attorneys as his aides prepared for his Congressional testimony that they regard as crucial to his survival.

title: Corzine, Who Claimed Obama as Protg in 04, Will Endorse Clinton, Democrats Say
description: TRENTON, March 30  Gov. Jon S. Corzine plans to endorse Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton for president on Monday, according to Democrats close to both.

title: Avant-Garde Music Loses a Lower Manhattan Home
description: The New York music scene can usually absorb the loss of one club or another without too much difficulty. If one shuts down, another will open pretty soon.

title: Talking Darfur to Death
description: The world has been discussing the genocide in Darfur for more than three years. But some 200,000 deaths later, it has yet to take effective action to force the Sudanese government to stop sponsoring the mass murder, rape, torture and forcible evictions being carried out on its orders in the region.

title: Hy Weiss, 84, Music Executive From Rock n Rolls Early Days, Dies
description: Hy Weiss, a music executive from the hardscrabble early days of rock n roll, died on March 20 in Englewood, N.J. He was 84 and lived in Rockleigh, N.J.

title: 30 Hurt in Crash in New Jersey
description: A New Jersey Transit commuter bus crashed through a highway divider shortly after exiting the Lincoln Tunnel last night, sending six people to hospitals and causing major traffic delays, according to officials with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: African Elephants in All Their Humanity
description: The PBS series Nature can always be counted on for wonderful images of animals as animals. But tomorrows installment, Unforgettable Elephants, comes amazingly close to giving us animals as people.

title: For the Record
description: A classical music entry in the Listings pages of Weekend yesterday about the pianist Vassily Primakov, at Arium for the Arts in the West Village tomorrow, included incorrect information from a publicist about the time of the performance. It is at 5 p.m., not 4 p.m.

title: Doping Test Reportedly Tied to Thorpe
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, March 31  Swimmings world governing body, FINA, confirmed Saturday in a statement that it had filed a legal appeal to a test conducted by the Australian Sports Anti-Doping Authority, but it did not confirm that the athlete tested was the recently retired Australian star Ian Thorpe.

title: New Yorks Flawed Primaries
description: So, remind us again why New York has to move next years presidential primaries from March to Feb. 5? The stampede in Albany to shift the date ever earlier was advertised as a way for New York voters to get more attention from the candidates. But the odds are that New York voters will not have a chance to play a major role in choosing their partys nominee even with this change. That is partly because of the field of candidates, and partly because of the states election rules.

title: Henin Leaves Past Behind and Plays Like Her Old Self
description: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla., March 30  For 20 minutes Friday morning, Justine Henin stood on the court hitting forehands by rote, pausing only to receive feedback from her long-time coach, Carlos Rodriguez.

title: Noahs Confident Strut Wins Few New Admirers
description: ATLANTA, March 30  During the N.C.A.A. championship game last year, Joakim Noah blew a kiss to the U.C.L.A. cheerleaders as his Gators were beating the Bruins.

title: Where Millions Entered U.S., a Debate on Letting in More
description: It was the perfect setting for a Congressional hearing on immigration, all the speakers agreed  the Great Hall on Ellis Island, where from 1892 to 1953 more than 12 million immigrants waited to be let in to America.

title: Pet Food Contained Chemical Found in Plastic, F.D.A. Says
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that it had not found rat poison in pet food that has been killing animals, but that it had found melamine, a chemical commonly used to make plastic cutlery that is also used in fertilizer.

title: U.N. Leader Calls for Lebanons Borders to Be Secured
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, March 30  Secretary General Ban Ki-moon called Friday for the fulfillment of the United Nations Security Council resolution in August ending the war between Hezbollah and Israel and proposing steps to rid Lebanon of illegal arms and secure its borders.

title: Freshmans Drinking Death Stuns a New Jersey University
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., March 30  An 18-year-old freshman at Rider University died on Friday, a day after he was admitted to a hospital after drinking an excessive amount of alcohol at a fraternity party.

title: For the Record
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on March 22 about changes at HBO after The Sopranos referred imprecisely to the lead characters in The Riches, a new series on a rival network, FX. They are an itinerant group of con artists most often referred to as Irish travelers  not Gypsies, the European ethnic group.

title: Pakistan: 14 Dead in Renewed Northern Fighting
description: At least 14 people were killed in renewed clashes between Uzbek militants and local tribesmen in the South Waziristan tribal region, officials said. The new fighting, over a hilltop, followed a four-day lull after more than 110 people were killed in a week. The tribesmen are trying to drive the outsiders, allies of the Taliban, out of Wana, South Waziristans main town. While the government has refused to say that it is helping the locals try to oust the foreigners, said to be more than 1,000-strong, sources say it is.

title: Missing in Pakistan (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rising British Pop Star Revives a Mercurial Style
description: Clowns handed out balloons and the sound system played perky Top 10 hits before Mika took the stage at the Gramercy Theater on Thursday night. Mika, whose song Grace Kelly was a No. 1 hit in Britain and is currently No. 75 on the Billboard Hot 100, was branding his music as pure pop fun, and he wasnt kidding. With a big smile on his face and in his voice, and with bright, bouncy, catchy tunes, Mika isnt flaunting any angst.

title: Bill to Legalize Abortion Set to Pass in Mexico City
description: MEXICO CITY, March 30  Dominated by liberals, Mexico Citys legislature is expected to legalize abortion in a few weeks. The bill would make this city one of the largest entities in Latin America to break with a long tradition of women resorting to illegal clinics and midwives to end unwanted pregnancies.

title: Horror Movies (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Joel Brodsky, 67, Photographer Who Specialized in Album Covers, Dies
description: Joel Brodsky, a photographer whose work appeared on the covers of hundreds of albums  most memorably The Best of the Doors, with its provocative Christlike image of Jim Morrison in black and white  died on March 1 in Stamford, Conn., where he had lived for five years. He was 67 and had previously lived in Manhattan.

title: In Paris, Language Sparks Culture War
description: PARIS, March 30  With French long engaged in a losing battle against English around the world, a new way of fighting back has been proposed by a multinational group of authors who write in French: uncouple the language from France and turn French literature into world literature written in French.

title: Speed May Do More Harm Than Good
description: IN the time it takes to read this sentence, you could be making big money in the markets. In theory.

title: Big Test for Workers as Owners
description: With the Tribune Company on the verge of deciding its future, perhaps no interested party remains more in the dark than its 20,000 employees, who could end up as majority shareholders under complicated financial arrangements proposed in competing plans.

title: Zimbabwe: Mugabe Wins Over Party for 2008 Vote
description: Zimbabwes ruling party, known as ZANU-PF, endorsed President Robert G. Mugabe as its candidate in the 2008 presidential election, handing the 83-year-old leader a victory in a guerrilla battle within the party to force him into retirement. The party had rebuffed Mr. Mugabes earlier effort to extend his current term to 2010, then found itself stymied when he reversed course and pledged to run in the already scheduled 2008 contest. Leaders from across southern Africa met with Mr. Mugabe in Tanzania this week, ostensibly to press him into retirement, but wound up publicly endorsing his rule of a nation with 1,700-percent-a-year inflation, 80 percent unemployment and one of the worlds lowest life expectancies.

title: Put the Hair to Good Use (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Olmert Rejects Right of Return for Palestinians
description: TEL AVIV, March 30  Prime Minister Ehud Olmert said in interviews published Friday that Israel would not allow a single Palestinian refugee to return to what is now Israel, and that the country bore no responsibility for the refugees because their plight resulted from an attack by Arab nations on Israel when it was a fledgling state.

title: From Afar, Hoyas Ex-Coach Quietly Cheers Recruits
description: ATLANTA, March 30  During John Thompson Jr.s tenure as Georgetown coach, Hoya Paranoia was always associated with the guarded nature of the program.

title: At a North American Event, the Rest of the World Weighs In
description: North American Bridge Championships is something of a misnomer these days. Stars from many other countries travel to these tournaments, held three times a year. In St. Louis earlier this month there were players from Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Bermuda, Brazil, Bulgaria, China, Egypt, England, France, German, Iceland, India, Israel, Italy, Japan, New Zealand, Pakistan, the Netherlands, Norway, Poland, Russia, Scotland, Spain, Sweden, Turkey and probably one or two more that I have overlooked.

title: Gliding and Bouncing, Powered by Caffeine, by Music and by Life
description: Student showcases are often a frightening obligation for family and friends. On Thursday night it was the usual crowd as the Second Avenue Dance Company, the resident group of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, offered its spring concert.

title: Tax Deal Provides Added Relief to Middle-Income Homeowners
description: ALBANY, March 30  Middle-class homeowners in Westchester County will get nearly $3,000. In Albany, they will receive $994, and in Erie County, $842.

title: For the Record
description: A report in the Sunday Shootout hockey column on Feb. 18, about the veteran defenseman Chris Chelios, referred incorrectly to his status as one of the oldest players to have competed in the National Hockey League. Earlier this season, Chelios became the third-oldest player to have competed in the N.H.L., not the second-oldest. (As the report noted, the oldest was Gordie Howe, who played at 52. Next was Moe Roberts, who played in a game two weeks short of his 46th birthday in 1951. Chelios turned 45 in late January.)

title: Nets Let a Late Lead Slip, and Fall in Playoff Race
description: AUBURN HILLS, Mich., March 30  The difference between the Detroit Pistons, among the elite of the Eastern Conference, and a marginal team like the Nets was made strikingly clear Friday night: the endgame.

title: For the Record
description: A front-page article on Tuesday about the effects that higher temperatures have had on the so-called sky islands of Southern Arizona misstated the year that fire destroyed 32,000 acres near Mount Lemmon, Ariz. It was 2002, not 2004.

title: Philip Morris Parent Pays Full $3.5 Billion to States in 98 Deal
description: Altria Group Inc., parent of the worlds largest tobacco company, made its full payment of $3.5 billion to states under a 1998 health care settlement, a move that may bolster the prices of municipal bonds backed by the payments.

title: Gulf Hits Snags in Rebuilding Public Works
description: MERAUX, La., March 30  Even before Hurricane Katrina ruined it, the St. Bernard Parish Fire Station No. 6 was not much to look at, just a cinderblock and sheet-metal cube whose contents included a fire truck, a kitchen and a paint-by-numbers rendering of the Last Supper.

title: Clinton Camp Turns to a Star in Money Race
description: Concerned about Senator Barack Obamas presidential fund-raising, Senator Hillary Rodham Clintons campaign has dispatched former President Bill Clinton to attend 16 fund-raisers in the last six weeks and to lead conference calls and Internet appeals to donors, in some cases assessing Mr. Obamas positions on Iraq.

title: Agency Rejects .xxx Suffixes for Sex-Related Sites on Internet
description: A longstanding proposal to create a specialized .xxx suffix for sex-related entertainment Web sites received a final rejection yesterday by the agency governing the Internet address system.

title: World View Podcast
description: CALVIN SIMS. Welcome to the New York Times World View podcast, a weekly conversation with Times foreign correspondents from across the globe.

title: Taking Stock: Where a Composing Prodigy Is Now, and How He Got There
description: That George Benjamin at 47 is one of the most formidable composers of his generation should come as no surprise. A British prodigy, he began playing the piano at 7 and was soon after composing. His first work for orchestra was given its premiere at a BBC Proms concert when Mr. Benjamin was 20.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: March 30, 2007

title: Spring Performances Help Younger Yankees Make Cut
description: TAMPA, Fla., March 30  It was quarter to nine in the morning of what might have been the last day of Todd Pratts long baseball life. Pratt, a 40-year-old catcher with 14 years in the major leagues, sat at his locker in the Yankees clubhouse at Legends Field, staring straight ahead, gnawing at his fingernails.

title: American Sets a Record, but, No, Its Not Phelps
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, March 31  The municipal authorities here have already put in place the long hose that will carry away the water in the Susie ONeill pool so it can be used for irrigation in the public gardens of a city that has been hit hard by drought.

title: Lets Put on an Automat! Cue Cops and Cheesecake
description: Diamonds may be forever, but a big bucket of rhinestones can spread a lot of glitter if you know what to do with em. The 1932 show Face the Music, with a sunny score by Irving Berlin and a gag- ridden circus of a book by Moss Hart, certainly isnt an enduring masterwork of the American musical theater. A full Broadway revival has never been attempted. But as the zippy Encores! concert staging of this forgotten bauble amply demonstrates, it must have shown audiences a fine time during the dark days of the Depression. And it is still quite capable of lifting the heart and setting the belly laughing with some regularity.

title: Man Group, the Large British Hedge Fund, Plans to Spin Off Its Brokerage Unit
description: LONDON, March 30  The Man Group, the worlds largest publicly traded hedge fund operator, said Friday that it would spin off its brokerage division to focus on its asset management unit.

title: Too Busy to Notice Youre Too Busy
description: RECENTLY Ive found myself annoyed by how busy my friends seem. Putting aside the possibility that they are avoiding me, some are so on the go that they barely have time to tell me they do not have time to talk. Every phone call, no matter how short, seems to be interrupted by several others. That is, of course, if I actually get a live person on the other end of the phone.

title: Iran Turns Up Volume in Face-Off Over Captured Britons
description: LONDON, March 30  As the confrontation over British military prisoners in Iran entered a second week, Iran stepped up its propaganda campaign, broadcasting new video on Friday of a captured British marine and releasing a third letter from the only woman in the group of captives.

title: After Senators Indictment, Republicans Ask Corzine for Special Session on Corruption
description: TRENTON, March 30  Less than 24 hours after one of New Jerseys most powerful Democratic state senators was indicted on federal charges of bribery, fraud and corruption, Republican legislators on Friday asked the governor to call a special legislative session to pass tougher laws on corruption.

title: Homeowners, Call Your Bankers Before They Call You
description: The day of reckoning is near for millions of homeowners who financed their dream house by taking out an adjustable-rate mortgage.

title: A Biomechanical Wonder, 100 Times a Game
description: THE long spring windup is over.

title: The Lexicon of Auto Shapes
The View From Newark
description: We are on the cusp of one of the most highly anticipated Final Fours in recent memory. And by recent memory, I mean since last year, because in 2006, everyone wanted to see how George Mason was going to fare under the big lights last year. (Answer: Not well.) The American sports scene has suffered from some seriously uninpsired championship battles in recent years: The last Super Bowl, World Series and Final Four were all mostly dull affairs, unless you happened to be a fan of the winning teams. With four powerhouses playing in Atlanta today, theres hope this will end the skid.

title: 25 Years Later
description: The British-controlled Falkland Islands in the South Atlantic are facing an influx of outsiders attracted by new prosperity.

title: Correction: Revealing All Before Anyone Else Can
description: An article last Sunday about the ways in which presidential candidates deal publicly with illness referred incorrectly to the death of former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts, who had lymphoma cancer. He died on Jan. 18, 1997, two days short of what would have been the end of his first term had he been elected president in 1992  not one day short. (The error first appeared on Oct. 3, 2004, in an article about the health of Senator John Kerry.)

title: The War at Home: Money for the Troops
description: President Bush and Congressional leaders continued to spar over the war spending bills, even though Congress is out on its spring recess.

title: 2008: Ultimate Family Roadtrip
description: John and Elizabeth Edwards have decided to pull their two young children out of school next fall and bring them along on the campaign trail, she announced Friday. She said they had been considering the option before learning that her breast cancer had recurred in an incurable form.

title: Around Washington: Bush Visits Walter Reed
